"url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=8232248", "date": "2021-03-06 15:28:21", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (41): SWEDEN (SKANE), NIGER (NIAMEY) POULTRY, HPAI H5N5, H5N1, OIE\n**********************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this posting:\n[1] Sweden (Skane): poultry, HPAI H5N5\n[2] Niger (Niamey): poultry, HPAI H5N1\n\n******\n[1] Sweden (Skane): poultry, HPAI H5N5\nDate: Fri 5 Mar 2021\nSource: OIE, Disease Alerts, 2021 [edited]\nhttps://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Animal_Health_in_the_World/docs/pdf/CUTOVER_OIE-WAHIS/SWEDEN_HPAI_149037_05032021.pdf\n\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza, Sweden\n-----------------------------------------\nInformation received on 5 Mar 2021 from Dr. Emeli Torsson, Senior Veterinary Advisor, Sweden\n\nSummary\nReport type: Immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 2 Mar 2021\nDate of confirmation of the event: 3 Mar 2021\nReason for notification: Recurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 19 Nov 2020\nManifestation of disease: Clinical disease\nCausal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N5\nNature of diagnosis: Laboratory (basic and advanced)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country.\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak location: Trelleborg [Skane County]\nDate of start of the outbreak: 2 Mar 2021\nOutbreak status: Continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: Farm\nTotal animals affected:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered\nBirds / 18 000 / 3000 / 3000 / 15 000 / 0\nAffected population: This is a farm with organic laying hens, housing around 18 000 animals. Clinical signs of increased mortality were seen 2 Mar 2021.\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Unknown or inconclusive\nEpidemiological comments: All animals were euthanized on 3 Mar 2021. Disinfection of the holding was completed on 4 Mar 2021. A protection zone (3 km [1.9 mi]) and a surveillance zone (10 km [6.2 mi]) have been put in place around the infected farm, and all other restrictions and necessary measures according to Directive 2005/94/EC are applied.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: Movement control inside the country; surveillance outside containment and/or protection zone; surveillance within containment and/or protection zone; zoning; stamping out; official destruction of animal products; official disposal of carcasses, by-products, and waste; disinfection\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nNational Veterinary Institute (national laboratory) / Birds / Real-time PCR / 3 Mar 2021 / Positive\nNational Veterinary Institute (national laboratory) / Birds / Virus sequencing / 3 Mar 2021 / Positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[HealthMap/ProMED map of Skane, Sweden: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/11081]\n\n******\n[2] Niger (Niamey): poultry, HPAI H5N1\nDate: Fri 5 Mar 2021\nSource: OIE, Disease Alerts, 2021 [edited]\nhttps://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Animal_Health_in_the_World/docs/pdf/CUTOVER_OIE-WAHIS/NIGER_HPAI_05032021.pdf\n\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza, Niger\n----------------------------------------\nInformation received on 5 Mar 2021 from Ali Seidou, OIE Focal Point for animal disease reporting, Niger\n\nSummary\nReport type: Immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 17 Feb 2021\nDate of confirmation of the event: 3 Mar 2021\nReason for notification: Recurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 20 Sep 2017\nManifestation of disease: Clinical disease\nCausal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: Clinical, laboratory (basic and advanced)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country.\n\nNew outbreaks (2)\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 2\nOutbreak location 1: Niamey Karadje [Niamey]\nDate of start of the outbreak: 17 Feb 2021\nOutbreak status: Continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: Backyard\nTotal animals affected:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered\nBirds / 40 / 21 / 20 / 0 / 0\nAffected population: Hens (Brahma breed) in a backyard\n\nOutbreak location 2: Niamey Saguia [Niamey]\nDate of start of the outbreak: 25 Feb 2021\nOutbreak status: Continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: Farm\nTotal animals affected:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered\nBirds / 28 000 / 257 / 200 / 0 / 0\nAffected population: Layers (Isa Brown breed)\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Airborne spread\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: Surveillance outside containment and/or protection zone; surveillance within containment and/or protection zone; traceability; zoning; official disposal of carcasses, by-products, and waste; disinfection\nMeasures to be applied: Stamping out; control of wildlife reservoirs\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nLABOCEL (national laboratory) / Birds / Reverse transcriptase-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) / 3 Mar 2021 / Positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[HealthMap/ProMED map of Niamey, Niger: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/15122\n\nThe following has been extracted from the OIE Technical factsheet 'Questions and Answers on Avian Influenza' (last updated 1 Mar 2021); subscribers are encouraged to visit the full text at https://www.oie.int/en/animal-health-in-the-world/update-on-avian-influenza/questions-and-answers-on-avian-influenza/.\n\n'What is the current situation of avian influenza?\n'Updated information on the current situation of AI is available here (https://www.oie.int/en/animal-health-in-the-world/update-on-avian-influenza/2016/), based on the data reported by countries through the OIE World Animal Health Information System (OIE-WAHIS).\n\n'Since August 2020, there has been a substantial increase in the number of AI outbreaks caused by various subtypes, notably the H5N8, reported by many countries in Europe, Asia and recently in Africa, which reflect a period of heightened risks. This 2020/21 epizootic is marked by the significant involvement and mortality of wild birds. As the risk of virus introductions via migratory wild birds remains high, countries should stay vigilant, and implement effective surveillance and monitoring measures for early detection and response.\n\n'What are the causes of the current wave of avian influenza cases and is it worse than in previous years?\n'Molecular characterization of the currently circulating AI virus subtypes shows genetic variability from previous years. This might be explained by multiple reassortments with low pathogenic viruses circulating in wild birds. The evolution of the viruses and these recent events need to be closely monitored and further studied in order to assess the risks.\n\n'It is most likely that migratory wild birds, followed by local farming practices, have contributed to the dissemination and introduction of the virus into new countries and farms. A similar situation of H5N8 epizootics in many countries associated with wild bird migration occurred in 2016/17.\n\n'The H5N8 virus has also reassorted with other wild bird influenza viruses to form new subtypes, which were also reported by countries.\n\n'What factors can facilitate the spread of avian influenza?\n'The dynamic of the spread of influenza viruses is extremely complex and difficult to predict. Several factors can influence it, such as the wild bird migration pattern, unregulated trade, farming systems, biosecurity and immunity status.\n\n'During the Northern Hemisphere winter, the wild bird movements may increase, and lower temperatures may facilitate the environmental survival of AI viruses, increasing exposure of infection in poultry. Additionally, the mixing of wild birds from different geographic origins during migration can increase the risk of virus spread and genetic reassortment resulting in changes in viral properties.\n\n'At [a] local level, as the AI viruses can survive for long periods in the environment, they can be easily transmitted from farm to farm by the movement of infected animals, as well as contaminated boots, vehicles and equipment if the adequate biosecurity measures are not implemented.\n\n'What is the risk of avian influenza for human health?\n'The epidemiology of AI viruses is complex: They can change and evolve by mutation and reassortment, with the emergence of new subtypes causing significant impacts on animal health and production. Some subtypes -- not all -- can be zoonotic and therefore pose a threat to human health.\n\n'Transmission of AI viruses to humans occurs when there is close contact with infected birds or heavily contaminated environments.\n\n'In February 2021, human cases of AI subtype H5N8 were reported by Russian authorities to the World Health Organization (WHO). The OIE/FAO network of experts on animal influenza (OFFLU) analyzed the preliminary information of the event and stated that, to date, there is no evidence to suggest that severe human infections or human-to-human transmission of this virus have occurred. This situation likely represents an isolated spillover event of the virus, as genetic evidence suggests that these viruses were derived from chickens with no adaptation to humans.\n\n'More information is available on the OFFLU statement (February 2021) at http://www.offlu.net/fileadmin/home/en/publications/pdf/OFFLU_Russia_H5N8_final.pdf.' - Mod.CRD]", "summary": "Recurrence of a listed 24 Jan 2021] have tested positive for H5N1 bird flu, the head of the parks authority told Reuters on [Fri 29 Jan 2021]. Rangers found the pelicans on [23 Jan 2021] in the Djoudj bird sanctuary, a remote pocket of wetland near the border with Mauritania and a resting place for birds that cross the Sahara Desert into West Africa each year. The birds were incinerated and the park is closed, said Bocar Thiam, Senegal's parks director.\n\nThe sanctuary is a transit place for about 350 species of birds but only pelicans were found dead.\n\nThis month [January 2021], Senegal reported an outbreak of H5N1 on a poultry farm in the Thies region about 120 mi [about 193 km] south, resulting in the culling of about 100 000 chickens. It is not clear if the 2 outbreaks are linked.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[HPAI viruses emerged in western Africa in 2006 and reemerged in 2015. No outbreaks of HPAI had been reported in Senegal until very recently (end of 2020; ProMED archive number 20210108.8085504), when an outbreak in a poultry farm due to H5N1 was documented 200 km (about 124 mi) south of Djoudj bird sanctuary. The temporal and spatial correlation between these 2 outbreaks strongly suggests they might be linked. - Mod.PMB\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map:\nSenegal: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/48]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED\n< Some 750 pelicans found dead in a UNESCO World Heritage site in northern Senegal last week [18 - 24 Jan 2021] have tested positive for H5N1 bird flu, the head of the parks authority told Reuters on [Fri 29 Jan 2021]. No outbreaks of HPAI had been reported in Senegal until very recently (end of 2020; ProMED archive number 20210108.8085504), when an outbreak in a poultry farm due to H5N1 was documented 200 km (about 124 mi) south of Djoudj bird sanctuary. 34(02) [edited]\nhttps://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=37605\n\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza, Cambodia\n-----------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 14 Jan 2021 from Mr. Phannara Tan, Director General, General Directorate of Animal Health and Production, Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries, Phnom Penh, Cambodia\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 5 Jan 2021\nDate of confirmation of the event: 11 Jan 2021\nReason for notification: recurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 26 Apr 2019\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory (basic and advanced)\nThis event pertains to the whole country.\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak location: Preak Tachraeng, Preak Norean, Aek Phnom, Battambang [Batdambang]\nDate of start of the outbreak: 5 Jan 2021\nOutbreak status: resolved (13 Jan 2021)\nEpidemiological unit: village\nTotal animals affected\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered\nBirds / 1990 / 1827 / 1827 / 163 / 0\nAffected population: Avian influenza affected poultry in backyard farms.\n\nOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, in percentages]\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBirds / 91.81 / 91.81 / 100 / 100\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\n\nEpidemiological comments: On [9 Jan 2021], a provincial veterinarian received information about sick-dead poultry from a farmer in the village. He then went there to check and collect samples from the affected poultry and sent them to the National Animal Health and Production Research Institute, which confirmed positive to H5N1 on 11 Jan [2021].\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: movement control inside the country, surveillance within containment and/or protection zone, stamping out, zoning, disinfection, vaccination prohibited, no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: surveillance outside containment and/or protection zone\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nNational Animal Health and Production Research Institute (NAHPRI) (national laboratory) / birds / real-time PCR / 11 Jan 2021 / positive\nInstitute Pasteur, Cambodia (regional reference laboratory) / birds / real-time PCR / 11 Jan 2021 / positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map at the source URL above.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Cambodia has been experiencing HPAI H5N1 since 2005. This is the 1st outbreak of HPAI associated with serotype H5N1 since 2018 (see https://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?fupser=&dothis=&reportid=27724). No cases in humans have been recorded in Cambodia since 2014. - Mod.CRD\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map:\nBattambang Province, Cambodia: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/12508]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail prohibited, no treatment of affected animals\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-01-11 00:00:00", "2005-03-24 00:00:00", "2021-01-09 00:00:00", "2021-01-13 12:03:27", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (26): MAURITANIA, SENEGAL, WILD BIRD, HPAI H5N1, OIE\n********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this posting:\n[1] Mauritania (Keur Massene): pelicans, HPAI H5N1, 1st report\n[2] Senegal (Saint-Louis): pelicans, HPAI H5N1\n\n******\n[1] Mauritania (Keur Massene): pelican, HPAI H5N1, 1st report\nDate: Tue 2 Feb 2021\nSource: OIE, WAHIS (World Animal Health Information System), weekly disease information 2021 [edited]\nhttps://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=38040\n\n\nHighly pathogenic influenza A viruses (infection with) (non-poultry including wild birds), Mauritania\n-------------------------------------------------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 2 Feb 2021 from Dr Baba Doumbia, directeur, services veterinaires, Ministere du Developpement Rural, Nouakchott, Mauritania\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 27 Jan 2021\nDate of confirmation of the event: 2 Feb 2021\nReason for notification: 1st occurrence of a listed disease in the country\nCausal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza A [AI] virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: suspicion, laboratory (advanced)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country.\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1: Commune of Ndiago, Bou Hajra, Keur-Macene, Keur Massene\nDate of start of the outbreak: 27 Jan 2021\nOutbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: natural park\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered\nGreat white pelican: _Pelecanus onocrotalus_ (Pelecanidae) / 16 000 / 500 / 495 / 495 / 0\nAffected population: The species is resident in the lower delta, and groups of a few hundred to a few thousand white pelicans are regularly observed in the water bodies of Diawling National Park.\n\nOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nGreat white pelican: _P. onocrotalus_ (Pelecanidae) / 3.13 / 3.09 / 99 / 6.19\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: surveillance outside containment and/or protection zone; surveillance within containment and/or protection zone; official disposal of carcasses, by-products, and waste; control of wildlife reservoirs; vaccination permitted (if a vaccine exists); no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[HealthMap/ProMED map of Keur Massene, Mauritania: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/30639]\n\n******\n[2] Senegal (Saint-Louis): pelican, HPAI H5N1\nDate: Mon 1 Feb 2021\nSource: OIE, WAHIS (World Animal Health Information System), weekly disease information 2021 [edited]\nhttps://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=38000\n\n\nHighly pathogenic influenza A viruses (infection with) (non-poultry including wild birds), Senegal\n-------------------------------------------------------------------\nInformation received on 1 Feb 2021 from Dr Mbargou Lo, directeur des services veterinaires, direction des services veterinaires, Ministere de l'Elevage et des Productions animales, Dakar, Senegal\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 14 Jan 2021\nDate of confirmation of the event: 28 Jan 2021\nReason for notification: 1st occurrence of a listed disease\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza [AI] virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: laboratory (advanced)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country.\n\nNew outbreaks: 1\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak location: Djoudj, Saint-Louis\nDate of start of the outbreak: 14 Jan 2021\nOutbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: natural park\nTotal animals affected:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered\nGreat white pelican: _Pelecanus onocrotalus_ (Pelecanidae) / 8887 / 822 / 822 / 0 / 0\nPink-backed pelican: _Pelecanus rufescens_ (Pelecanidae) / 35 / 0 / 0 / 0 / 0\nAffected population: The affected population is composed of great white (8887) and pink-backed (35) pelicans. The most affected animals are young. Djoudj National Bird Park host thousands of Palaearctic and Afrotropical migratory birds. It is a feeding, reproduction, and refuge site for many bird colonies. Each year, colonies of great white pelicans come to reproduce at a nesting box located not far from the wharf, along the Djoudj backwater.\n\nOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nGreat White pelican: _P. onocrotalus_ (Pelecanidae) / 9.25 / 9.25 / 100 / 9.25\nPink-backed pelican: _P. rufescens_ (Pelecanidae) / 0 / 0 / - / 0\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive.\nEpidemiological comments: Following a report of deaths in young white pelicans by the curator from the Djoudj National Bird Park on 14 Jan 2021, the commander/veterinarian and curator of the Gueumbeul Wildlife Reserve carried out an investigation onsite on 23 Jan 2021. Samples were sent, and the National Laboratory for Animal Husbandry and Veterinary Research of Dakar confirmed the disease (highly pathogenic avian influenza H5N1) on 28 Jan 2021. Out of a total of 8922 birds, 822 deaths and cases were recorded, representing morbidity and mortality rates of 9.21%. Young animals are more affected (810) than adults (12).\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: surveillance outside containment and/or protection zone; surveillance within containment and/or protection zone; official disposal of carcasses, by-products, and waste; control of wildlife reservoirs; disinfection; process to inactivate the pathogenic agent in products or by-products; vaccination prohibited; no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nNational Livestock and Veterinary Research Laboratory in Dakar - Senegalese Agricultural Research Institute (ISRA) (national laboratory) / great white pelican: _P. onocrotalus_ / real-time reverse transcriptase/polymerase chain reaction (RRT-PCR) / 28 Jan 2021 / positive\nISRA / great white pelican: _P. onocrotalus_ / reverse transcription/polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) / 28 Jan 2021 / positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[HealthMap/ProMED map of Saint-Louis, Senegal: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/53305]\n\n[This immediate notification from Senegal complements the information already published in ProMED-mail posting 20210201.8155983.\n\nHPAI viruses emerged in western Africa in 2006 and reemerged in 2015. No outbreaks of HPAI had been reported in Senegal until very recently (end of 2020; ProMED posting 20210108.8085504), when an outbreak in a poultry farm due to H5N1 was documented 200 km [124 mi] south of Djoudj bird sanctuary. This is the 1st report in the neighboring Mauritania. The temporal and spatial correlation between these 2 outbreaks strongly suggests they might be linked. - Mod.PMB]", "summary": "Measures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test "date": "2021-01-08 18:01:56", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (05): SENEGAL (THIES) POULTRY, HPAI H5N1, FIRST REPORT, OIE\n***************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 7 Jan 2021\nSource: OIE, WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database), weekly disease information 2021; 34(01) [edited]\nhttps://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=37472\n\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza, Senegal\n------------------------------------------\nInformation received on 7 Jan 2021 from Dr. Mbargou Lo, Director of Veterinary Services, Directorate of Veterinary Services, Ministry of Livestock and Animal Productions, Dakar, Senegal\n\nSummary\nReport type: Immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 23 Dec 2020\nDate of confirmation of the event: 30 Dec 2020\nReport date: 6 Jan 2021\nDate submitted to OIE: 7 Jan 2021\nReason for notification: 1st occurrence of a listed disease in the country\nCausal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: Clinical, laboratory (advanced), necropsy\nThis event pertains a defined zone within the whole country.\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak location: Ndiakhat, Pout, Thies\nDate of start of the outbreak: 23 Dec 2020\nOutbreak status: Resolved on 7 Jan 2021\nEpidemiological unit: Farm\nTotal animals affected:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered\nBirds / 100 000 / 58 000 / 58 000 / 42 000 / 0\n\nAffected population: Layers whose age range is between [9-18] months and [18-24] months. Poultry are kept in closed buildings with an automatic feed and water supply system. The poultry farm is located away from households.\n\nOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBirds / 58 / 58 / 100 / 100\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Unknown or inconclusive\nEpidemiological comments: The disease was detected by the farm manager on 23 Dec 2020, through a drop in water consumption and the recording of high fatalities. The morbidity and mortality rates are 58% and the lethality rate is 100%. The main clinical signs observed are oedema, cyanosis, congestion of the crests and barbs and prostration.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: Movement control inside the country; surveillance outside containment and/or protection zone; surveillance within containment and/or protection zone; quarantine; official destruction of animals products; official disposal of carcasses, by-products and waste; stamping out; control of wildlife reservoirs; disinfection; process to inactivate the pathogenic agent in products or by-products; vaccination prohibited; no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: Traceability\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nDakar National Laboratory for Livestock and Veterinary Research (LNERV) (national laboratory) / Birds / Real-time reverse transcriptase-polymerase chain reaction (RRT-PCR) / 30 Dec 2021 / Positive\nDakar National Laboratory for Livestock and Veterinary Research (LNERV) (national laboratory) / Birds / RRT-PCR / 30 Dec 2021 / Positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This is the 1st time that Senegal reports highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI). HPAI subtype H5N1 is endemic in some countries of the African continent.\n\nThe following information comes from a scientific article titled 'Evolution of Highly Pathogenic Avian Influenza A(H5N1) Virus in Poultry, Togo, 2018,' published December 2019 in the Emerging Infectious Diseases journal by the CDC:\n\n'In 2015, highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N1) viruses reemerged in poultry in West Africa. We describe the introduction of a reassortant clade 2.3.2.1c virus into Togo in April 2018. Our findings signal further local spread and evolution of these viruses, which could affect animal and human health.\n\n'Relatively little is known about the emergence, prevalence, and circulation of animal influenza viruses in Africa. Highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) H5N1 clade 2.2 viruses emerged in Africa in 2006 (cases were reported from Egypt, Nigeria, Cote d'Ivoire, Benin, Togo, Ghana, Sudan, Djibouti, and Cameroon), although the virus was only maintained long term in Egypt. We conducted surveillance in domestic poultry in Cote d'Ivoire, Benin, and Togo during 2008-2010 but were unable to find virologic or serologic evidence for influenza A virus circulation. Several factors, such as type of hosts, climate, and animal density, might have provided unfavorable conditions for the virus' circulation in the region.\n\n'In early 2015, HPAI H5N1 viruses of clade 2.3.2.1c were reported in Nigeria, followed closely by detections in Burkina Faso, Cote d'Ivoire, Ghana, Niger, Cameroon, and Togo. These viruses could be clustered into 2 genetic subgroups; cluster WA1 viruses were detected in Ghana, Burkina Faso, Cote d'Ivoire, Nigeria, and Niger, and cluster WA2 viruses were detected in Niger, Cote d'Ivoire, and Nigeria. In this study, we aimed to determine the origin and evolution of HPAI A(H5N1) viruses responsible for poultry outbreaks in Togo in April 2018 in the context of viruses from surrounding countries.'\n\nReference:\nFusade-Boyer M, Pato PS, Komlan M, et al. Evolution of Highly Pathogenic Avian Influenza A(H5N1) Virus in Poultry, Togo, 2018. Emerg Infect Dis. 2019; 25(12): 2287-9. https://dx.doi.org/10.3201/eid2512.190054\n- Mod.CRD\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map:\nThies, Senegal: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/44501]", "summary": "Measures applied: Movement control inside the country; surveillance outside containment and/or protection zone; surveillance within containment and/or protection zone; quarantine; official destruction of animals products; official disposal of carcasses, by-products and waste; stamping out; control of wildlife reservoirs; disinfection; process to inactivate the pathogenic agent in products or by-products; vaccination prohibited; no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: Traceability\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n 23 Dec 2020\nDate of confirmation of the event: 30 Dec 2020\nReport date: 6 Jan 2021\n \n\nOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\n AVIAN INFLUENZA (05): SENEGAL (THIES) POULTRY, HPAI H5N1, FIRST REPORT, OIE\n***************************************************************************\n Total outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak location: Ndiakhat, Pout, Thies\n Total animals affected:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered\n Serotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: Clinical, laboratory (advanced), necropsy\n Communicated by:\nProMED\n< Information received on 7 Jan 2021 from Dr. Mbargou Lo, Director of Veterinary Services, Directorate of Veterinary Services, Ministry of Livestock and Animal Productions, Dakar, Senegal\n\nSummary\nReport type: [The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\n Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology\n Causal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\n Dec 2021 / Positive\n\nFuture reporting\n \n\nNew outbreaks (1)\n Source: OIE, WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database), weekly disease information 2021; It is divided into 3 separate epidemiological units. Clinical signs (high mortality) were seen in unit 1 on [17 Jan 2021].\n\nOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBirds / 0.43 / 0.43 / 100 / 49.53\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Unknown or inconclusive\n\nEpidemiological comments: A protection zone (3 km) [approx. 1.8 mi] and a surveillance zone (10 km) [approx. 6.2 mi] have been put in place around the establishment. All other restrictions and necessary measures according to Directive 2005/94/EG are/will be applied. Birds in the epidemiological unit (unit 1) are currently being euthanized. The birds in all the other epidemiological units are closely monitored and are put under official surveillance.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: movement control inside the country; surveillance outside containment and/or protection zone; surveillance within containment and/or protection zone; traceability; stamping out; zoning; vaccination prohibited; no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: Official destruction of animal products; official disposal of carcasses, by-products and waste; disinfection\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nNational Veterinary Institute (national laboratory) / Birds / Real-time PCR / 18 Jan 2021 / Positive\nNational Veterinary Institute (national laboratory) / Birds / Virus sequencing / - / Pending\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n['Wild birds, particularly wild migratory water birds, are considered to be the main reservoir of avian influenza viruses. There is a constant risk of avian influenza being introduced into Ireland from wild birds particularly from November onwards each year as this is when migratory birds arrive and congregate on wetlands, mixing with resident species. Cold, short winter days also increase the risk of avian influenza due to increased virus survival times in the environment'. Source: https://www.gov.ie/en/publication/50ce4-avian-influenza-bird-flu/\n\nFurther information on the Avian Influenza situation in Ireland, can be seen at https://www.gov.ie/en/publication/50ce4-avian-influenza-bird-flu/#avian-influenza-updates (latest update 15 Jan 2021).\n\nA detailed overview as of 19 Jan 2021 on the situation in EU Member States and the adopted measures is given in the document titled 'Chronology of event' available at https://ec.europa.eu/food/sites/food/files/animals/docs/ad_control-measures_hapai_chrono_2021.pdf. 'This document summarizes basic information on the outbreaks of Avian Influenza (AI) in several EU Member States and related EU action. It focuses on the animal health aspects.'\n\nA series of outbreak maps of the HPAI affected European countries can be seen at https://izsvenezie.com/documents/reference-laboratories/avian-influenza/europe-updates/HPAI/2020-1/map.pdf\n(last update 21 Jan 2021). - Mod.CRD\n\nHealthMap/ProMED maps:\nLower Saxony, Germany: {"archive_id": "8156270", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (23): India, Nepal, Germany, poultry, wild bird, HPAI H5N1, H5N8, OIE", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=8156270", "date": "2021-02-02 16:43:10", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (23): INDIA, NEPAL, GERMANY, POULTRY, WILD BIRD, HPAI H5N1, H5N8, OIE\n*************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this post:\n[1] India (Chhattisgarh): poultry, H5N1\n[2] India (Gujarat): backyard poultry, H5N8\n[3] India (Punjab): wild bird, H5N1\n[4] Nepal (Province Three): backyard poultry, H5N8\n[5] Germany (Bayern): backyard poultry, H5N8\n\n******\n[1] India (Chhattisgarh): poultry, H5N1\nDate: Mon 1 Feb 2021\nSource: OIE, WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database), weekly disease information 2021; 34(05) [edited]\nhttps://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=37979\n\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza, India\n----------------------------------------\nInformation received on 1 Feb 2021 from Dr Atul Chaturvedi, secretary, Department of Animal Husbandry and Dairying, Ministry of Fisheries, Animal Husbandry and Dairying, New Delhi, India\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 14 Jan 2021\nDate of confirmation of the event: 25 Jan 2021\nReason for notification: recurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous recurrence: 30 Sep 2020\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza [AI] virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: laboratory (advance)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country.\n\nNew outbreaks: 1\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak location: Chhaati, Kurud, Dhamtari, Chattisgarh\nDate of start of the outbreak: 2 Jan 2021\nOutbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: farm\nTotal animals affected:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered\nBirds / 1817 / 3 / 3 / 1814 / 0\n\nOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBirds / 0.17 / 0.17 / 100 / 100\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: movement control inside the country; surveillance outside containment and/or protection zone; surveillance within containment and/or protection zone; screening; official disposal of carcasses, by-products and waste; stamping out; disinfection; vaccination prohibited; no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures.\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nNational Institute of High Security Animal Diseases (OIE Reference Laboratory) / birds / real-time reverse transcriptase/polymerase chain reaction (RRT-PCR) / 25 Jan 2021 / positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] India (Gujarat): backyard poultry, H5N8\nDate: Mon 1 Feb 2021\nSource: OIE, WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database), weekly disease information 2021; 34(05) [edited]\nhttps://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=37975\n\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza, India\n----------------------------------------\nInformation received on 1 Feb 2021 from Dr Atul Chaturvedi, secretary, Department of Animal Husbandry and Dairying, Ministry of Fisheries, Animal Husbandry and Dairying, New Delhi, India\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 1 Jan 2021\nDate of confirmation of the event: 21 Jan 2021\nReason for notification: recurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous recurrence: 30 Sep 2020\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza [AI] virus\nSerotype: H5N8\nNature of diagnosis: laboratory (advance)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country.\n\nNew outbreaks: 1\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1: Dolasa Revenue Area, Kodinar, Gir Somnath, Gujarat\nDate of start of the outbreak: 1 Jan 2021\nOutbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: backyard\nTotal animals affected:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered\nBirds / 220 / 0 / 0 / 220 / 0\n\nOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBirds / 0 / 0 / - / 100\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: movement control inside the country; surveillance outside containment and/or protection zone; surveillance within containment and/or protection zone; quarantine; official disposal of carcasses, by-products and waste; stamping out; disinfection; vaccination prohibited; no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures.\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nNational Institute of High Security Animal Disease (OIE Reference Laboratory) / birds / real-time reverse transcriptase/polymerase chain reaction (RRT-PCR) / 21 Jan 2021 / positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3] India (Punjab): wild bird, H5N1\nDate: Mon 1 Feb 2021\nSource: OIE, WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database), weekly disease information 2021; 34(05) [edited]\nhttps://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=37977\n\n\nHighly pathogenic influenza A viruses (infection with) (non-poultry including wild birds), India\n-------------------------------------------------------------------\nInformation received on 1 Feb 2021 from Dr Atul Chaturvedi, secretary, Department of Animal Husbandry and Dairying, Ministry of Fisheries, Animal Husbandry and Dairying, New Delhi, India\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 8 Jan 2021\nDate of confirmation of the event: 18 Jan 2021\nReason for notification: recurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous recurrence: 30 Sep 2020\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza [AI] virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: laboratory (advance)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country.\n\nNew outbreaks: 1\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1: Siswan Dam Catchment Area, Siswan / Majri, SAS Nagar, Punjab\nDate of start of the outbreak: 8 Jan 2021\nOutbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: forest\nTotal animals affected:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered\nBar-headed goose: _Anser indicus_ (Anatidae) / - / 1 / 1 / 0 / 0\n\nOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBar-headed goose: _Anser indicus_ (Anatidae) / ** / ** / 100 / **\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n* Not calculated because of missing information\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: screening; official disposal of carcasses, by-products and waste; disinfection; vaccination prohibited; no treatment of affected animals\n\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures.\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nNational Institute of High Security Animal Disease (OIE Reference Laboratory) / Bar-headed goose: _Anser indicus_ / real-time reverse transcriptase/polymerase chain reaction (RRT-PCR) / 18 Jan 2021 / positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[4] Nepal (Province Three): backyard poultry, H5N8\nDate: Sat 30 Jan 2021\nSource: OIE, WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database), weekly disease information 2021; 34(05) [edited]\nhttps://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=37973\n\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza, Nepal\n----------------------------------------\nInformation received on 30 Jan 2021 from Dr Damayanti Shrestha, acting OIE delegate deputy director general, Department of Livestock Services, NEPAL Ministry of Agriculture and Livestock Development, Kathmandu, Nepal\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 21 Jan 2021\nDate of confirmation of the event: 29 Jan 2021\nReason for notification: recurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous recurrence: 2 Sep 2019\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N8\nNature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory (basic, advance), necropsy\nThis event pertains to the whole country.\n\nNew outbreaks\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak location: Tarkeshwor-7, Tarkeshwor-7, Futung , Kathmandu, Bagmati [Province Three]\nDate of start of the outbreak: 21 Jan 2021\nOutbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: backyard\nTotal animals affected:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered\nBirds / 2576 / 32 / 32 / 2544 / 0\nAffected population: a backyard integrated epidemiological unit having clusters of ducks, chickens, quails and turkeys.\n\nOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]\nSpecies / apparent morbidity rate / apparent mortality rate / apparent case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBirds / 1.24 / 1.24 / 100 / 100\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\nEpidemiology\n\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\nEpidemiological comments: different types of wild birds like eagles, crows and egrets were seen near the affected epidemiological unit.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: vaccination prohibited; no treatment of affected animals;\nMeasures to be applied: movement control inside the country; surveillance outside containment and/or protection zone; surveillance within containment and/or protection zone; traceability; quarantine; official destruction of animals products; official disposal of carcasses, by-products and waste; stamping out; disinfection\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type: Central veterinary Laboratory, Tripureshwor (national laboratory)\nSpecies / Test / Test date / Result\nBirds / rapid test / 29 Jan 2021 / Positive\nBirds / real-time reverse transcriptase/polymerase chain reaction (RRT-PCR) / 29 Jan 2021 / Positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Since January 2021, India has officially reported 9 HPAI subtype H5N8 and H5N1 events to the OIE. So far, 16 outbreaks have been reported, affecting both poultry and wild birds. The outbreaks are located in the states of Kerala (6), Haryana (2), Maharashtra (2), Madhya Pradesh (2), Chhattisgarh (1), Gujarat (1), Rajasthan (1) and Punjab (1). To see the detailed information for these events, go to the following link in the OIE WAHIS database: https://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Countryinformation/Countryreports, select country, and time period. - Mod CRD]\n\n******\n[5] Germany (Bayern): backyard poultry, H5N8\nDate: Fri 29 Jan 2021\nSource: OIE, WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database), weekly disease information 2021; 34(05) [edited]\nhttps://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=37964\n\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza, Germany\n------------------------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 29 Jan 2021 from Dr Dietrich Rassow, director for animal health and animal welfare, chief veterinary officer, Directorate of Animal Health and Animal Welfare, Federal Ministry of Food and Agriculture, Berlin, Germany\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 28 Jan 2021\nDate of confirmation of the event: 29 Jan 2021\nReason for notification: recurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 13 May 2020\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N8\nNature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory (basic and advanced)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country.\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1: Pottenstein, Bayreuth, Bayern\nDate of start of the outbreak: 28 Jan 2021\nOutbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: Backyard\nTotal animals affected\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered\nBirds / 19 / 10 / 10 / 9 / 0\nAffected population: 17 chickens, 2 ducks.\n\nOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBirds / 53 / 53 / 100 / 100\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\nEpidemiological comments: all poultry have been culled and safely disposed of. Epidemiological investigation is ongoing.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: movement control inside the country; surveillance outside containment and/or protection zone; surveillance within containment and/or protection zone; screening; traceability; official destruction of animal products; official disposal of carcasses, by-products, and waste; stamping out; control of wildlife reservoirs; disinfection; vaccination prohibited; no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nFriedrich-Loeffler-Institut (National laboratory) / Birds / Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) / 29 Jan 2021 / positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n\n[In 2021 Germany has so far reported 9 events of HPAI affecting poultry, and captive and wild birds. Subtypes H5N8, H5N5, H5N4, H5N3, and H5N1 have been identified. The outbreaks are located in the states of Thuringia, Bayern, Lower Saxony, Rhineland Pfalz, and Baden-Wurttemberg. A map of these outbreaks occurring from 1 Oct 2020 to 2 Feb 2021 can be seen at https://www.fli.de/fileadmin/FLI/Images/Tierseuchengeschehen/H5N8/Karten_D/2021/Map_AI_D_2021-02-01.jpg. - Therefore, sporadic human cases are not unexpected.\n\n'With continued incidence of avian influenza due to existing and new influenza A(H5) viruses in poultry, there is a need to remain vigilant in the animal and public health sectors. Community awareness of the potential dangers for human health is essential to prevent infection in humans. Surveillance should be continued to detect human cases and early changes in transmissibility and infectivity of the viruses.' The case is a one-year old female from Saravan province, who had exposure to domestic poultry. She developed cough, fever, and difficulty breathing on [13 Oct 2020]. On [16 Oct 2020], she was hospitalised and had her sample collected. She was discharged on [19 Oct 2020]. All household contacts tested negative for Influenza A.\n\nAs of [5 Nov 2020], a total of 239 cases of human infection with avian influenza A(H5N1) virus were reported from 4 countries within the Western Pacific Region since January 2003 (Table 1). Of these cases, 134 were fatal, resulting in a case fatality rate (CFR) of 56 percent. The last case was reported from Lao PDR, with an onset date of [13 Oct 2020] (one case, no death).\n\nTable 1 (available at the source URL above): Cumulative number of laboratory-confirmed human cases (C) and deaths (D) of influenza A(H5N1) virus infection reported to WHO, by date of onset (January 2003 to 5 Nov 2020), Western Pacific Region.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Influenza viruses are constantly changing and animal flu viruses can change such that they may gain the ability to infect easily and spread among people. Whenever avian influenza viruses are circulating in poultry, there is a risk for sporadic infection and small clusters of human cases due to exposure to infected poultry or contaminated environments.\n\nHuman infections with novel avian influenza virus like Asian H5N1 are concerning because of their pandemic potential.\n\nGlobally, from January 2003 to 5 Nov 2020, there were 862 cases of human infection with avian influenza A(H5N1) virus reported from 17 countries. Of these 862 cases, 455 were fatal (CFR of 53%). As of 5 Nov 2020, a total of 239 cases of human infection with avian influenza A(H5N1) virus were reported from 4 countries within the Western Pacific Region (Cambodia, China, Laos, and Viet Nam) since January 2003. Of these cases, 134 were fatal, resulting in a case fatality rate (CFR) of 56%. The most recent case is the one reported above from Laos, with an onset date of 13 Oct 2020 (one case, no death) (https://www.who.int/influenza/human_animal_interface/H5N1_cumulative_table_archives/en/).\n\nWith continued incidence of avian influenza due to existing and new influenza A(H5) viruses in poultry, there is a need to remain vigilant in the animal and public health sectors. Community awareness of the potential dangers for human health is essential to prevent infection in humans. Surveillance should be continued to detect human cases and early changes in transmissibility and infectivity of the viruses. -Mod.UBA\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map of Laos: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/67857]", "summary": "All household contacts tested negative for Influenza A.\n\nAs of [5 Nov 2020], a total of 239 cases of human infection with avian influenza A(H5N1) virus were reported from 4 countries within the Western Pacific Region since January 2003 \n\nTable 1 (available at the source URL above): Cumulative number of laboratory-confirmed human cases (C) and deaths (D) of influenza A(H5N1) virus infection reported to WHO, by date of onset (January 2003 to 5 Nov 2020), Western Pacific Region. \n\n\nAvian influenza weekly update number 766\nHuman infection with avian influenza A(H5N1) virus\n As of 5 Nov 2020, a total of 239 cases of human infection with avian influenza A(H5N1) virus were reported from 4 countries within the Western Pacific Region (Cambodia, China, Laos, and Viet Nam) since January 2003. Globally, from January 2003 to 5 Nov 2020, there were 862 cases of human infection with avian influenza A(H5N1) virus reported from 17 countries. Between [30 Oct and 5 Nov 2020], one new case of human infection with avian influenza A(H5N1) virus was reported to WHO in the Western Pacific Region. 33(33) [edited]\nhttps://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=35343\n\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza, Viet Nam\n-------------------------------------------\nInformation received on 7 Aug 2020 from Dr. Dong Pham Van, director general, chief veterinary officer, Department of Animal Health, Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development, Hanoi, Viet Nam\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 23 Jul 2020\nDate of confirmation of the event: 25 Jul 2020\nReason for notification: recurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 6 Jun 2020\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: laboratory (advanced)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country.\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak location 1: Chau Dien, Chau Dien, Cau Ke, Tra Vinh\nDate of start of the outbreak: 23 Jul 2020\nOutbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: village\nTotal animals affected:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered\nBirds / 1040 / 500 / 200 / 840 / 0\n\nOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBirds / 48.08 / 19.23 / 40 / 100\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: vaccination permitted (if a vaccine exists); no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: surveillance outside containment and/or protection zone; surveillance within containment and/or protection zone; stamping out; disinfection\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nRegional Animal Health Office No 7 (RAHO7) (regional laboratory) / Birds / Real-time reverse transcriptase-polymerase chain reaction (RRT-PCR) / 25 Jul 2020 / Positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n['H5N1, a highly pathogenic AI virus, was initially diagnosed in humans in Hong Kong in 1997. The virus then re-emerged in 2003 and 2004, and spread from Asia to Europe and Africa causing several hundred human cases and deaths, as well as destruction of hundreds of millions of poultry. This Asiatic form of H5N1 triggered concern from scientists and authorities and remains under close surveillance due to its feared pandemic potential if a mutation allows it to be transmitted from human to human'. https://www.oie.int/en/animal-health-in-the-world/web-portal-on-avian-influenza/\n\nAbstract:\n\n'Despite strong commitments of the central and provincial veterinary authorities in Vietnam to control highly pathogenic avian influenza H5N1 (HPAI\u2010H5N1) in poultry and to diminish the risk of human infection, outbreaks continue to occur in poultry. This study describes the spatio\u2010temporal distribution of HPAI\u2010H5N1 outbreaks in Vietnam for the period December 2014-April 2018 using the space\u2010time K\u2010function and the space\u2010time scan statistic. The space\u2010time K\u2010function analyses showed statistically significant spatio\u2010temporal clustering of HPAI\u2010H5N1 outbreaks in poultry during the study period of up to 50 days and 60 km (approx. 37mi). The space\u2010time scan statistic test identified 3 statistically significant space\u2010time clusters of HPAI\u2010H5N1 in the south of the country where the incidence of HPAI\u2010H5N1 outbreaks was greater than that expected if outbreaks were randomly distributed in space and time. The analyses indicated shortfalls in the effectiveness of control measures used to control HPAI\u2010H5N1 throughout the study period. Development of a better understanding of the relative impact of HPAI\u2010H5N1 control measures (depopulation of infected flocks, vaccination, movement restrictions) on space\u2010time interaction would allow animal health authorities to focus their efforts on control measures shown to have the greatest relative effect'.\n\nReference: Transboundary and Emerging disease, special issue article, 'Spatio\u2010temporal distribution of outbreaks of highly pathogenic avian influenza virus subtype H5N1 in Vietnam, 2015- 2018' Loth L, Pham LT and Stevenson MA, https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/abs/10.1111/tbed.13259 (published 10 Jun 2019).\n- Mod.CRD\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map:\nTr\u00e0 Vinh Province, Vietnam: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/1042]", "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1997-03-24 00:00:00", "2053-03-24 00:00:00", "2020-03-24 00:00:00", "2020-08-07 00:00:00", "2019-06-10 00:00:00", "2003-03-24 00:00:00", "2020-06-06 00:00:00"], "unknown"}, {"location": "Hanoi", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Viet Nam \n\n Summary", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "7988670", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (102): Europe, wild bird, poultry, H5N8, H5N5, H5N1, spread", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7988670", "date": "2020-12-02 19:58:44", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (102): EUROPE, WILD BIRD, POULTRY, H5N8, H5N5, H5N1, SPREAD, OVERVIEW\n*************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 2 Dec 2020\nSource: Animal & Plant Health Agency (APHA), UK [abridged, edited]\nhttps://science.vla.gov.uk/flu-lab-net/docs/H5_SituationReport_021120.pdf\n\n\nSummary of highly pathogenic avian influenza H5 activity in Europe: 27 Oct - 28 Nov 2020\n----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nA total of 582 detections of HPAI H5 have been reported in Europe between 27 Oct 2020 and 28 Nov 2020. This new H5N8 2.3.4.4b clade variant was originally detected in poultry in Iraq in May 2020 with subsequent detections in Russia and Kazakhstan. It seems likely that migratory waterfowl played a key role in the incursion of this virus into Europe with over 500 detections in wild birds and spillover events into commercial poultry and captive birds.\n\nThis situation report provides an overview of the virological, epidemiological, and ornithological characteristics of this new epizootic, which involves H5N8, H5N5 and H5N1 subtypes suggesting local reassortment with wild bird Eurasian avian LPAI genes. We describe the geographical distribution and the variety of avian hosts demonstrating susceptibility to this emerging virus.\n\nThe 582 detections of HPAI H5 comprise 35 detections in poultry (6%), 8 in captive birds (1%) and 539 wild bird events (93%). Previous epizootics in Europe have had varied clinical and epidemiological presentations; the 2016/17 H5N8 epizootic affected both wild birds and poultry with over 2800 events recorded between October 2016 and July 2017. The H5N6 epizootic in 2017/18 primarily affected wild birds (80 events) with only 7 events in poultry and captive flocks.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nAdam Brouwer\nAnimal and Plant Health Agency - OIE/FAO International Reference Laboratory for Avian Influenza\nAPHA-Weybridge, UK\n<adam.brouwer@apha.gov.uk>\n\n[The authors of the above useful APHA situation report are Adam Brouwer, Nicola Lewis, Elliot Whittard, David Stroud, Ashley Banyard, Rowena Hansen, and Ian Brown. We are indebted to the submitter and his peers.\n\nThe following section, excerpted from the above-cited report, deserves inclusion:\n\nH5 HPAI (2.3.4.4b of putative African origin for some gene segments) was present in European poultry from 2 Jan 2020 to the last detection on 4 Jun 2020, with H5N8 detected in Eastern Europe with extensive spread within poultry in Hungary (276 events) and Poland (35 events).\n\nThere were 6 detections in wild birds of a closely related virus to the poultry-associated H5N8 between Jan and Mar 2020 suggesting a relatively low incidence in wild birds.\n\nIraq reported H5N8 in poultry in May 2020 with a new H5N8 2.3.4.4b clade variant genetically distinct from the previous 2020 strains in Europe. Genetically similar H5N8 viruses were subsequently detected in southern central Russia, northern Kazakhstan and south-western Russia. In western Europe, HPAI H5 in wild birds was suspected when there was an initial detection in Eurasian wigeons in the Netherlands on 16 Oct 2020 with disease confirmed on 27 Oct with one bird positive for H5N8 and 4 positive for H5N1. The H5N8 virus was similar to that reported in Russia, Kazakhstan and Iraq whilst the H5N1 characterisation suggested local reassortment with wild bird Eurasian avian LPAI genes. Detections in poultry followed with initial H5N8 cases in the Netherlands and the UK submitted to national reference laboratories on 28 Oct and 2 Nov 2020, respectively. Subsequently there has been a substantial increase in cases (principally H5N8) in wild birds particularly in northern Europe and spillover events to commercial poultry and captive birds involving reports from 14 European countries to date [28 Nov 2020].\n\nNearly all detections of HPAI H5 in wild birds have been found close to coastlines with significant clusters of cases in the Jutland peninsula and within the extensive Wadden Sea -- a continuous intertidal wetland stretching from Denmark to the Netherlands and where many of the Danish, German and Dutch cases occurred. However, wild bird cases also occurred in inland areas in those and other countries, with a 2nd cluster of wild bird detections in the Netherlands.\n\nThe lack of detections in other countries in Northern Europe does not imply that HPAIv is absent -- rather that a combination of varied disease prevalence and the sensitivity of wild bird surveillance programmes has inhibited detection thus far.\n\n---\nThe report includes a table presenting details of the 582 reported HPAI H5 disease events in Europe, 27 Oct - 28 Nov 2020, for the 14 addressed European countries. - Mod.AS\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nEurope: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/6010]", "summary": "\n\nThe following section, excerpted from the above-cited report, deserves inclusion:\n\nH5 HPAI (2.3.4.4b of putative African origin for some gene segments) was present in European poultry from 2 Jan 2020 to the last detection on 4 Jun 2020, with H5N8 detected in Eastern Europe with extensive spread within poultry in Hungary (276 events) and Poland (35 events). \n\nThere were 6 detections in wild birds of a closely related virus to the poultry-associated H5N8 between Jan and Mar 2020 suggesting a relatively low incidence in wild birds. Subsequently there has been a substantial increase in cases (principally H5N8) in wild birds particularly in northern Europe and spillover events to commercial poultry and captive birds involving reports from 14 European countries to date [28 Nov 2020]. Communicated by:\nAdam Brouwer\nAnimal and Plant Health Agency - OIE/FAO International Reference Laboratory for Avian Influenza\nAPHA-Weybridge, UK\n<adam.brouwer@apha.gov.uk>\n\n[The authors of the above useful APHA situation report are Adam Brouwer, Nicola Lewis, Elliot Whittard, David Stroud, Ashley Banyard, Rowena Hansen, and Ian Brown. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n The 582 detections of HPAI H5 comprise 35 detections in poultry (6%), 8 in captive birds (1%) and 539 wild bird events (93%). It seems likely that migratory waterfowl played a key role in the incursion of this virus into Europe with over 500 detections in wild birds and spillover events into commercial poultry and captive birds.
