Netherlands\n----------------------------------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 16 Dec 2020 from Dr. Christianne Bruschke, Chief Veterinary Officer, Agriculture, Nature and Food Quality, Ministry of Agriculture, Nature and Food Quality, The Hague, Netherlands\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 14 Dec 2020\nDate of confirmation of the event: 14 Dec 2020\nReason for notification: recurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 10 Jul 2018\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: laboratory (advanced)\nThis event pertains to the whole country.\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak location: Buitenpost, Friesland\nDate of start of the outbreak: 14 Dec 2020\nOutbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: farm\nTotal animals affected:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered\nBirds / 27 681 / 150 / 150 / 27 531 / 0\nAffected population: On [14 Dec 2020], a 3 km [1.9 mi] protection zone and a 10 km [6.2 mi] surveillance zone have been established. In the 3 km [1.9 mi] zone, there are no other premises with poultry. The subtype HPAI H5N1 is confirmed by the NRL. All susceptible animals on the infected premise have been killed.\n\nOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBirds / 0.54 / 0.54 / 100 / 100\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: movement control inside the country, screening, stamping out, zoning, disinfection, vaccination prohibited, no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type: Wageningen Bioveterinary Research Lelystad (national laboratory)\nSpecies / Test / Test date / Result\nBirds / polymerase chain reaction (PCR) / 14 Dec 2020 / positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[HealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nFriesland, Netherlands: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/30373]\n\n******\n[2] England (Tendring): wild bird HPAI H5N1\nDate: Thu 17 Dec 2020\nSource: OIE, WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database), weekly disease information 2020 [edited]\nhttps://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=37039\n\n\nHighly pathogenic influenza A viruses (infection with) (non-poultry including wild birds), United Kingdom\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 17 Dec 2020 from Dr. Christine Middlemiss, Chief Veterinary Officer, DEFRA, Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs, London, United Kingdom\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 3 Dec 2020\nDate of confirmation of the event: 9 Dec 2020\nReason for notification: new strain of a listed disease in the country\nCausal agent: highly pathogenic influenza A virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: laboratory (basic and advanced)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country.\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks:\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak location (WB 2020/34 Colchester, Tendring, England\nDate of start of the outbreak: 3 Dec 2020\nOutbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: other\nTotal animals affected:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nMute Swan: _Cygnus olor_ (Anatidae) / - / 1 / 1 / 0 / 0\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: contact with wild species\n\nEpidemiological comments: HPAI H5N1 virus belonging to the 2.3.4.4 B clade. This clade has acquired gene segments from low-pathogenic viruses and is not related to A(H5N1) viruses of e.g., clade 2.3.2.1c causing human infections outside of Europe.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: vaccination prohibited; no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type:\nWeybridge (OIE's reference laboratory)\nSpecies / Test / Test date / Result\nMute swan / gene sequencing / 10 Dec 2020 / positive\nMute swan / gene sequencing / 15 Dec 2020 / positive\nMute swan / reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RRT-PCR) / 9 Dec 2020 / positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[HealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nColchester, England, United Kingdom: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/1499]\n\n\n******\n[3] Denmark (West): captive bird, HPAI H5N8\nDate: Thu 10 Dec 2020\nSource: OIE, WAHIS (World Animal Health Information System), weekly disease information 2020 [edited]\nhttps://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=36981\n\n\nHighly pathogenic influenza A viruses (infection with) (non-poultry including wild birds), Denmark\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 10 Dec 2020 from Dr. Hanne Larsen, Chief Veterinary Officer, Danish Veterinary and Food Administration, Ministry of Environment and Food, Glostrup, Denmark\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 7 Dec 2020\nDate of confirmation of the event: 9 Dec 2020\nReason for notification: recurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 16 Nov 2020\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: highly pathogenic influenza A virus\nSerotype: H5N8\nNature of diagnosis: laboratory (advanced)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country.\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nOutbreak location 1: Jelling, Vejle, West\nDate of start of the outbreak: 7 Dec 2020\nOutbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: not applicable\nTotal animals affected\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered\nBirds / 901 / 14 / 10 / 891 / 0\n\nOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBirds / 1.55 / 1.11 / 71.43 / 100\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive, contact with wild species\n\nEpidemiological comments: According to article 10.4.1.8 of the Terrestrial Animal Health Code, Member Countries should not impose bans on the trade in poultry and poultry commodities in response to notification on the presence of any influenza A virus in birds other than poultry.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: movement control inside the country, traceability, zoning, vaccination prohibited, no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: surveillance outside containment and/or protection zone; official disposal of carcasses, by-products, and waste; stamping out; disinfection\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type: Statens Serum Institute (national laboratory)\nSpecies / Test / Test date / Result\nBirds / reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) / 9 Dec 2020 / positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreaks can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[HealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nDenmark: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/111]\n\n\n******\n[4] Italy (Venezia-Veneto): wild bird, HPAI H5N1\nDate: Wed 16 Dec 2020\nSource: OIE, WAHIS (World Animal Health Information System), weekly disease information 2020 [edited]\nhttps://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=37140\n\n\nHighly pathogenic influenza A viruses (infection with) (non-poultry including wild birds), Italy\n----------------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 16 Dec 2020 from Dr Davide Lecchini, Chief Veterinary Officer, Directorate General for Veterinary Health and Veterinary Medicinal Products (DGSAF), Ministry of Health, Rome, Italy\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 21 Nov 2020\nDate of confirmation of the event: 4 Dec 2020\nReason for notification: recurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 2006\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza [HPAI] A virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory (advanced), necropsy\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country.\n\nNew outbreaks (2)\nOutbreak location 1: [Valle Drago, Jesolo, Venezia, Veneto]\nDate of start of the outbreak: 21 Nov 2020\nOutbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: other\nAffected animals\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered\nWigeons: _Mareca penelope_ (Anatidae) / - / 1 / 0 / 1 / 0\nAffected population: One highly pathogenic avian influenza H5N1 virus has been detected on [4 Dec 2020] in a wigeon (_Mareca penelope_) sampled after being shot in a hunting area.\n\nOutbreak location 2: [Valle Figheri, Campagna Lupia, Venezia, Veneto]\nDate of start of the outbreak: 4 Dec 2020\nOutbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: other\nAffected animals\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered\nCommon teal: _Anas crecca_ (Anatidae) / - / 1 / 0 / 0 / 0\nAffected population: One highly pathogenic avian influenza H5N1 virus was detected on [4 Dec 2020] in a captured common teal (_Anas crecca_) sampled intra vitam.\n\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 2\nTotal animals affected\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered\nWigeons: _Mareca penelope_ (Anatidae) / - / 1 / 0 / 1 / 0\nCommon teal: _Anas crecca_ (Anatidae) / - / 1 / 0 / 0 / 0\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\n\nEpidemiological comments: One highly pathogenic avian influenza H5N1 virus belonging to the 2.3.4.4 B clade has been detected in a wigeon (_Mareca penelope_) sampled after being shot in a hunting area in the province of Venezia (Valle Drago, Jesolo) and in a common teal (_Anas crecca_) sampled intra vitam after being captured in the province of Venezia (Valle Figheri, Campagna Lupia). The HA sequence is closely related to those of HPAI strains currently circulating in Northern Europe. Characterization of the full genome is in progress.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: vaccination permitted (if a vaccine exists); no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nExperimental Zooprophylactic Institute of the Venezie-Padova (national laboratory) / common teal / polymerase chain reaction (PCR) / 4 Dec 2020 / positive\nExperimental Zooprophylactic Institute of the Venezie-Padova (national laboratory) / wigeons / polymerase chain reaction (PCR) / 10 Dec 2020 / positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreaks can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[HealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nVenezia, Veneto, Italy: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/6323]\n\n\n*****\n[5] Italy (Rovingo-Veneto): wild bird, HPAI H5N5\nDate: Wed 16 Dec 2020\nSource: OIE, WAHIS (World Animal Health Information System), weekly disease information 2020 [edited]\nhttps://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=37139\n\n\nHighly pathogenic influenza A viruses (infection with) (non-poultry including wild birds), Italy\n-------------------------------------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 16 Dec 2020 from Dr Davide Lecchini, Chief Veterinary Officer, Directorate General for Veterinary Health and Veterinary Medicinal Products (DGSAF), Ministry of Health, Rome, Italy\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 28 Nov 2020\nDate of confirmation of the event: 4 Dec 2020\nReason for notification: recurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 21 Mar 2017\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza [HPAI] A virus\nSerotype: H5N5\nNature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory (advanced), necropsy\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country.\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nOutbreak location 1: [Valle Chiusa, Porto Tolle, Venezia, Veneto]\nDate of start of the outbreak: 28 Nov 2020\nOutbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: other\nTotal animals affected\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered\nCommon teal: _Anas crecca_ (Anatidae) / - / 1 / 0 / 1 / 0\nAffected population: One virus among those detected in common teals (_Anas crecca_) has been characterized as the H5N5 subtype.\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\n\nEpidemiological comments: Highly pathogenic influenza H5 viruses belonging to the 2.3.4.4 B clade have been detected in 5 common teals (_Anas crecca_), 2 wigeons (_Mareca penelope_), and one mallard (_Anas platyrhynchos_) sampled after being shot in a hunting area in the province of Rovigo (Valle Chiusa, Porto Tolle). The HA sequences of these viruses are closely related to those of HPAI strains currently circulating in Northern Europe. Characterization of the full genome is in progress.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: vaccination permitted (if a vaccine exists); no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nExperimental Zooprophylactic Institute of the Venezie-Padova (national laboratory) / common teal / polymerase chain reaction (PCR) / 4 Dec 2020 / positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[HealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nPorto Tolle, Veneto, Italy: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/58564]\n\n[Unfortunately, HPAI continues to spread in Europe. The fact that HPAI subtypes H5N8, H5N5 and H5N1 currently circulating in the European continent have been detected in wild birds is indicative that these viruses spread wherever these wild birds migrate. Poultry producers, small and large alike, must implement all the biosecurity measures necessary to protect their flocks from exposure and infection.\n\nA map of the cases of HPAI outbreaks confirmed in different EU Member States and in the UK can be seen at https://ec.europa.eu/food/sites/food/files/animals/docs/ad_control-measures_hapai_chrono_2020_map.pdf (latest update 9 Dec 2020).\n\n'As the autumn migration of wild waterbirds to their wintering areas in Europe continues, and given the expected local movements of these birds, there is still a high risk of introduction and further spread of HPAI A(H5) viruses within Europe. The risk of virus spread from wild birds to poultry is high, and Member States should enforce in 'high risk areas' of their territories the measures provided for in Commission Implementing Decision (EU) 2018/1136.' Source: European Food Safety Authority, European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control and European Union Reference Laboratory for Avian Influenza. post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this post:\n[1] Madhya Pradesh: HPAI H5N1, poultry\n[2] India\n----------------------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 2 Jun 2020 from Dr Atul Chaturvedi, secretary, Department of Animal Husbandry and Dairying, Ministry of Fisheries, Animal Husbandry and Dairying, New Delhi, India\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 15 Mar 2020\nDate of confirmation of the event: 20 Mar 2020\nReason for notification: recurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 3 Sep 2019\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: laboratory (advanced)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country.\n\nNew outbreaks: 1\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak location: Meat Market, Mehgaon, Mehgaon, Bhind, Madhya Pradesh\nDate of start of the outbreak: 15 Mar 2020\nOutbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: livestock market\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered\nBirds / 137 / 76 / 76 / 61 / 0\n\nOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBirds / 55.47 / 55.47 / 100 / 100\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: movement control inside the country; surveillance outside containment and/or protection zone; screening; official disposal of carcasses, by-products and waste; stamping out; disinfection; vaccination prohibited; no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nICAR [Indian Council of Agricultural Research] National Institute of High Security Animal Diseases (OIE reference laboratory) / Birds / Real-time reverse transcriptase-polymerase chain reaction (RRT-PCR) / 20 Mar 2020 / Positive\n\nFuture Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreaks can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n['Wild birds, as natural hosts and reservoirs for all types of avian influenza viruses, play a major role in the evolution, maintenance, and spread of these viruses. The main wild species involved have proved to be waterfowls, gulls, and shorebirds, however the virus seem to pass easily between different bird species.\n\nThe incidence of infection appears to be seasonal, with the highest isolation rate being in juvenile birds in the fall of the year.\n\nSeveral routes of exposure of wild bird viruses to poultry have been documented or suspected of being the origins of outbreaks. Direct exposure to wild birds is the most likely transmission factor.\n\nTherefore, limiting exposure of poultry to wild birds through confinement rearing and other biosecurity measures provides an opportunity to reduce the risk of introduction of avian influenza virus from wild birds, and consequently is key to decrease the risk of evolution into highly pathogenic forms, exposure and infection of humans, and recombination with human viruses components to form viruses that can not only infect humans but readily transmit among humans.'\nSource: OIE Avian Influenza Portal https://www.oie.int/en/animal-health-in-the-world/avian-influenza-portal/what-is-avian-influenza. - Mod.CRD\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map of India: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/142]", "summary": "Total trogon: _Harpactes erythrocephalus_ (Trogonidae) / - / 7 / 7 / - / -\n\nOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / poultry, HPAI H5N1\nDate: Fri 18 Dec 2020\nSource: OIE, WAHIS (World Animal Health Information System), weekly disease information 2020; 33(52) [edited]\nhttps://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=37173\n\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza, United Kingdom\n-------------------------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 18 Dec 2020 from Dr Christine Middlemiss, Chief Veterinary Officer, DEFRA, Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs, London, United Kingdom\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 13 Dec 2020\nDate of confirmation of the event: 18 Dec 2020\nReason for notification: new strain of a listed disease in the country\nCausal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza [AI] virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: laboratory (basic and advanced)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country.\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak location: Nr Hawes, Richmond, England\nDate of start of the outbreak: 13 Dec 2020\nOutbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: backyard\nTotal animals affected:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered\nBirds / 20 / 17 / 17 / 3 / 0\nAffected population: backyard flock\n\nOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBirds / 85 / 85 / 100 / 100\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Unknown or inconclusive\n\nEpidemiological comments: Ongoing Epidemiological investigation. Initial presumption indicates that this HPAI H5N1 virus belongs to the 2.3.4.4 B clade. This clade has acquired gene segments from low pathogenic viruses and is not related to A(H5N1) viruses of e.g. clade 2.3.2.1c causing human infections outside of Europe. Further tests are being carried out to confirm.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: movement control inside the country; surveillance outside containment and/or protection zone; surveillance within containment and/or protection zone; official disposal of carcasses, by-products, and waste; stamping out; zoning; vaccination prohibited, no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: traceability; disinfection\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nWeybridge (OIE reference laboratory) / Birds / gene sequencing / 18 Dec 2020 / Positive\nWeybridge (OIE reference laboratory) / Birds / reverse transcription - polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) / 17 Dec 2020 / Positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[HealthMap/ProMED map of England, United Kingdom: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/67957]\n\n******\n[2] Germany (Schleswig-Holstein): wild bird, HPAI H5N3\nDate: Mon 21 Dec 2020\nSource: OIE, WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database), weekly disease information 2020; 33(52) [edited]\nhttps://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=37222\n\n\nHighly pathogenic influenza A viruses (infection with) (non-poultry including wild birds), Germany\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 21 Dec 2020 from Dr. Dietrich Rassow, Director for Animal Health and Animal Welfare, Chief Veterinary Officer, Directorate of Animal Health and Animal Welfare, Federal Ministry of Food and Agriculture, Berlin, Germany\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 17 Dec 2020\nDate of confirmation of the event: 19 Dec 2020\nReason for notification: New strain of a listed disease in the country\nCausal agent: Highly pathogenic influenza A virus\nSerotype: H5N3\nNature of diagnosis: laboratory (basic and advanced)\nThis event pertains to a defined within the country.\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nOutbreak 1 (20-015-00489): Nordfriesland, Nordfriesland, Schleswig-Holstein\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nDate of start of the outbreak: 17 Dec 2020\nOutbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: not applicable\nTotal animals affected\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered\nCharadriidae (unidentified): Charadriidae (incognita) (Charadriidae) / - Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[HealthMap/ProMED map of Germany: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/67958\n\nThe last outbreak assessment report no. 10 for the cases of HPAI in the UK and Europe, published on 21 Dec 2020 by DEFRA-APHA, mentions that 'Since [15 Dec 2020] in the United Kingdom there have been 3 further outbreaks of highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) H5N8 in poultry, including the first in Scotland, and an outbreak of HPAI H5N1 in poultry. There have also been many cases of HPAI H5N8 in wild birds, and smaller numbers of cases of HPAI H5N1 (2 reports) and HPAI H5N5 (6 reports) also in wild birds. Elsewhere in Europe, HPAI H5N8 has been reported in poultry in France and Poland. HPAI H5N8 in wild birds has been reported in Denmark, Germany, Italy, Norway, Poland, and Slovenia with HPAI H5N1 also in wild birds in Italy. HPAI H5Nx (N untyped) has been reported in poultry in the Netherlands, and in wild birds in the Netherlands and in France.' The full report is available at https://tinyurl.com/ybmtxrn8.\n\nMaps of the HPAI cases detected in Germany and Europe from 1 Jul to 17 Dec 2020 can be seen at:\nhttps://www.fli.de/fileadmin/FLI/Images/Tierseuchengeschehen/H5N8/Karten_D/2020/Map_AI_D_2020-12-17.jpg and https://www.fli.de/fileadmin/FLI/Images/Tierseuchengeschehen/H5N8/Karten_EU/2020/Map_AI_EU_2020-12-17.jpg, respectively. - In February 2019, 'Viet Nam has officially kicked off a USD 34.6 million national program for controlling avian influenza between 2019-2025. The objective is to control the spread of avian influenza; actively monitor for early detection; and early warning as well as solutions to prevent and tackle outbreaks. It also sees the establishment of safe poultry epidemic zones in accordance with OIE standards; contributing to minimizing the negative impact of avian influenza on Viet Nam's public health, food security and commercial activities, as well as creating favorable conditions for export of poultry products.' (https://asian-agribiz.com/2019/02/25/vietnam-launches-avian-influenza-control-program/).\n\nCurrently, HPAI H5N6 is also circulating in Viet Nam. Since January 2020, 16 outbreaks have been reported. "2020-01-30 20:30:48", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (18): DENMARK (NORTH JUTLAND) POULTRY, LPAI H5N1, OIE\n*********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 30 Jan 2020\nSource: OIE, WAHID [edited]\nhttps://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=33109\n\n\nInformation received on [and dated] 30 Jan 2020 from Dr Hanne Larsen, chief veterinary officer, Danish Veterinary and Food Administration, Ministry of Environment and Food, Glostrup, Denmark\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 27 Jan 2020\nDate of confirmation of the event: 29 Jan 2020\nReason for notification: recurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 1 Jul 2019\nManifestation of disease: Sub-clinical infection\nCausal agent: low pathogenic avian influenza [LPAI] virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: laboratory (advanced)\nThis event pertains to the whole country.\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak location: Saederup, Aalborg, West [North Jutland]\nDate of start of the outbreak: 27 Jan 2020\nOutbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: farm\nTotal animals affected\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered\nBirds / 48 000 / - / 0 / - / 0\n\nAffected population: On [29 Jan 2020], low pathogenic avian influenza H5 has been confirmed in a commercial poultry holding with organic laying hens. The layers were tested in accordance with the Danish surveillance programme for avian influenza in poultry. The holding consists of approximately 48 000 organic egg layers. The egg layers at the infected holding will be culled, and the carcasses will be disposed of by rendering.\n\nOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBirds / ** / 0 / ** / **\n* Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n**Not calculated because of missing information\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\n\nEpidemiological comment: The Danish Veterinary and Food Administration has established a restricted zone of 1 km [0.62 mi] around the holding and are implementing the necessary measures in accordance with Council Directive 2005/94/EC. There are no other commercial poultry holdings within the established restricted zone 1 km [0.62 mi] around the infected holding. There has been no trade of poultry from the holding to other EU countries or 3rd countries within the last 30 days.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: movement control inside the country, quarantine, zoning, vaccination permitted (if a vaccine exists), no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: traceability; official disposal of carcasses, by-products, and waste; stamping out; disinfection\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type: Statens Serum Institut (national laboratory)\nSpecies / Test / Test date / Result\nBirds / polymerase chain reaction (PCR) / 29 Jan 2020 / positive\nBirds / virus sequencing / 29 Jan 2020 / positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n['The outbreak is located in the town of Saederup in the municipality of Aalborg in the Northern part of Jutland.' No human cases have been reported in India since at least 2003.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This report relates to the 2nd HPAI H5N1 outbreak reported from east India since the start of 2020, heralding the seasonal recurrence of the virus, most probably synchronic with bird migration. The 1st outbreak, in Odisha's western neighbour Chattisgarh, reportedly started on 7 Jan 2020 (see 20200108.6877953). The previous season in India terminated in Apr 2019.\n\nFor further details on HPAI H5N1, subscribers may refer to OIE's Avian Influenza portal at https://www.oie.int/animal-health-in-the-world/avian-influenza-portal (The situation report was updated on 31 Dec 2019). - Mod.AS\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map available at:\nOdisha State, India: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/315]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This report relates to the 2nd HPAI H5N1 outbreak reported from east India since the start of 2020, heralding the seasonal recurrence of the virus, most probably synchronic with bird migration. \n\n\nAuthorities in an eastern Indian state will start culling chickens and destroying eggs from Tuesday [28 Jan 2020] to contain a bird flu virus of the H5N1 strain, a government statement said on Monday [27 Jan 2020]. The stable situations reported in the 6-monthly reports by 2 countries, namely, Egypt and Indonesia, are not described in this report, as these data for the 2nd semester 2019 will be collected throughout the 1st and 2nd semesters of 2020.\n\n'Asia: Chinese Taipei and the Philippines reported respectively 5 and 1 new outbreaks (H5, H5N2, H5N5 and H5N6) in poultry. Ongoing outbreaks are still present in Afghanistan, China (People's Rep. of), Chinese Taipei, India, Korea (DPR), Philippines and Viet Nam in poultry (subtypes H5, H5N1, H5N2, H5N5, H5N6 and H7N9) and Afghanistan, China (People's Rep. of) in non-poultry (H5, H5N6 and H7N9).\n\n'Veterinary authorities in the affected countries have responded to contain outbreaks in poultry with stamping out measures, heightened surveillance, and recommendations to poultry owners to increase biosecurity.\n\n'The OIE Standards, and the transparency of reporting through the OIE's World Animal Health Information System, provide the framework for veterinary services to implement effective surveillance, reporting, and controls for avian influenza. Wild bird surveillance can indicate periods of heightened risk, and at these times measures to improve on-farm biosecurity may reduce the likelihood of exposure of poultry'. - Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 8 Jun 2019, 8:00 AM\nSource: The Poultry Site [edited]\nhttps://thepoultrysite.com/news/2019/06/h5n1-high-pathogenic-avian-influenza-identified-in-a-recent-outbreak-in-bangladesh\n\n\nScientists have identified a novel strain of avian influenza that contained several genetic mutations.\n\nA team of researchers at Bangladesh Agricultural University examined 15 dead or sick birds from 13 clinical outbreaks of avian influenza in Bangladesh. The birds in their sample included ducks, geese, chickens and turkeys. Researchers used RT-PCR [reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction] (a laboratory method used to detect genetic material and specific proteins) to detect the virus that affected the birds in their sample. Results indicated that the birds were infected with a new variety of H5N1 influenza.\n\nThe new iteration of the virus combined various genetic markers from other low pathogenic influenza types that were found in the region since 2013. Researchers hypothesised that this newer version of the virus will supplant the current strain that is infecting poultry and wild birds in Southern Asia.\n\nThe researchers also concluded that the mutations, detected in the H5N1 samples, could be associated with increases in the virus' ability to infect mammals and reductions in its susceptibility to antiviral agents.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nMary Marshall\n<mjm2020@googlemail.com>\n\n[The paper cited in the above report is:\nNooruzzaman M, Mumu TT, Hasnat A, et al. A new reassortant clade 2.3.2.1a H5N1 highly pathogenic avian influenza virus causing recent outbreaks in ducks, geese, chickens and turkeys in Bangladesh. Transbound Emerg Dis. 2019 Jun 6. doi: 10.1111/tbed.13264. [Epub ahead of print]\n\nThe abstract follows:\n\n'A total of 15 dead or sick birds from 13 clinical outbreaks of avian influenza in ducks, geese, chickens and turkeys in 2017 in Bangladesh were examined. The presence of H5N1 influenza A virus in the affected birds was detected by RT\u2010PCR. Phylogenetic analysis based on full length gene sequences of all 8 gene segments revealed that these recent outbreaks were caused by a new reassortant of clade 2.3.2.1a H5N1 virus, which had been detected earlier in 2015 during surveillance in live bird markets (LBMs) and wet lands. This reassortant virus acquired PB2, PB1, PA, NP and NS genes from low pathogenic avian influenza viruses mostly of non\u2010H9N2 subtypes but retained HA, NA and M genes of the old clade 2.3.2.1a viruses. Nevertheless, the HA gene of these new viruses was 2.7% divergent from that of the old clade 2.3.2.1a viruses circulated in Bangladesh. Interestingly, similar reassortment events could be traced back in four 2.3.2.1a virus isolates of 2013 from backyard ducks. It suggests that this reassortant virus emerged in 2013, which took 2 years to be detected at a broader scale (i.e. in LBMs), another 2 years until it became widely spread in poultry and fully replaced the old viruses. Several mutations were detected in the recent Bangladeshi isolates, which are likely to influence possible phenotypic alterations such as increased mammalian adaptation, reduced susceptibility to antiviral agents and reduced host antiviral response.'\n\nHPAI H5N1 has been reported in poultry in Bangladesh since 2007; the 2008, the 1st human case was reported. Since then, 7 additional human cases have been reported, of which 1 fatal: 2011 (2 cases), 2012 (3), 2013 (1, fatal) and 2015 (1). - Mod.AS\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map available at:\nBangladesh: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/153]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Phylogenetic analysis based on full length gene sequences of all 8 gene segments revealed that these recent outbreaks were caused by a new reassortant of clade 2.3.2.1a H5N1 virus, which had been detected earlier in 2015 during surveillance in live bird markets (LBMs) and wet lands. The abstract follows:\n\n'A total of 15 dead or sick birds from 13 clinical outbreaks of avian influenza in ducks, geese, chickens and turkeys in 2017 in Bangladesh were examined. This reassortant virus acquired PB2, PB1, PA, NP and NS genes from low pathogenic avian influenza viruses mostly of non\u2010H9N2 subtypes but retained HA, NA and M genes of the old clade 2.3.2.1a viruses. It suggests that this reassortant virus emerged in 2013, which took 2 years to be detected at a broader scale (i.e. in LBMs), another 2 years until it became widely spread in poultry and fully replaced the old viruses. \n\nThe new iteration of the virus combined various genetic markers from other low pathogenic influenza types that were found in the region since 2013. Hunan is next to Hubei, the epicenter of the separate coronavirus outbreak.\n\nThe avian influenza, found in a farm in Shaoyang City, killed 4500 chickens, more than half the farm's flock, the ministry said. The city culled almost 18 000 poultry after the outbreak. The statement said the outbreak was of a 'highly pathogenic subtype' of the H5N1 flu.\n\nSince 2003, the H5N1 avian flu has killed 455 people worldwide, according to the World Health Organization.\n\n[Byline: Emma Dong]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nMary Marshall <mjm2020@googlemail.com>\n\n[Almost all cases of H5N1 infection in people have been associated with close contact with infected live or dead birds, or H5N1-contaminated environments. The virus does not infect humans easily, and spread from person to person appears to be unusual.\n\nUnfortunately, the newly emerged coronavirus behind the current pandemic, namely 2019nCoV, does cause person-to-person infection. Its animal reservoir animals are likely to be bats; in case an intermediate animal was/is involved in delivering a bat-borne pathogen to humans, its identity has not yet been discovered. If/when discovered, its discovery should be immediately reported to the OIE under the title 'emerging disease.'\n\nHPAI H5N1, similar to other bird-borne pathogens, is seasonal. - Mod.AS\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map available at:\nHunan Province, China: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/341]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\n\nA city in China's central Hunan province reported that it had culled almost 18 000 chickens after an outbreak of H5N1 bird flu, the Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Affairs said in statement on its website Saturday [1 Feb 2020]. Detailed information on each event reported during 2019 is available at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Countryinformation/Countryreports. To see this information, select country and year and click on the event.\n\n'People who are in close contact with infected birds are at risk for acquiring avian influenza. While many human cases are limited to conjunctivitis or mild respiratory disease, some viruses tend to cause severe illness.\n\n'However, there is no evidence to suggest that the consumption of poultry or eggs fit for human consumption could transmit the AI virus to humans. As a precautionary and regulatory measure, animals that have been culled as a result of measures to control an AI outbreak should not be allowed to enter the human food and animal feed chain, and precautionary measures for the cleaning and cooking process should be respected.' "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6466304", "date": "2019-05-14 11:46:07", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (09): NEPAL (BHAKTAPUR) H5N1, UPDATE\n***********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 11 May 2019\nSource: The Kathmandu Post[edited]\nhttp://kathmandupost.ekantipur.com/news/2019-05-11/authorities-to-send-more-specimens-abroad-to-test-for-bird-flu-virus.html\n\n\nThe Epidemiology and Disease Control Division says it is preparing to send specimens collected from the people who came in close contact with the person who died after contracting the H5N1 (bird flu) virus on [29 Mar 2019].\n\nThe division, under the Department of Health Services, had formed a team of medical doctors and lab technicians to carry out an epidemiological investigation after the death of a 21-year-old from Kavrepalanchok district [Province Three] from the bird flu virus.\n\n'We have collected specimens from doctors, nurses, close family members, relatives, and hospitals -- and also from homes,' Dr Bibek Kumar Lal, director at the division, told the Post.\n\nThe name of the deceased has not been disclosed yet, but he was said to be residing in Bhaktapur [district, Province Three] in a rented room and worked as a driver.\n\nThe Health Ministry, however, announced only on [30 Apr 2019] that the man had died from H5N1. Throat swabs of the deceased had been sent to the World Health Organisation's Collaborating Centre for Influenza in Japan, which confirmed that he had contracted influenza A(H5N1), which caused his death.\n\nFollowing the confirmation of deadly virus responsible for the death, health experts from the WHO's headquarters and its regional office in New Delhi, India arrived in Kathmandu to assist Nepali health officials to carry out an epidemiological investigation.\n\nAccording to Lal, his office would send samples to the country recommended by the UN health agency. Earlier, WHO officials suggested that specimens be sent to the Collaborating Center for Influenza in Japan that confirmed the virus. Such labs are in several countries and the UN health body may recommend any one of them. 'We are working closely with them and will decide our next step accordingly,' said Lal.\n\nThe division has secured all collected samples in the biosafety level-3 laboratory of the National Public Health Laboratory.\n\nHealth officials say it takes time to send samples to laboratories abroad, as manpower trained to handle the biohazard are required for that.\n\nAirlines do not easily carry such specimens and for that, protocols of international health regulations need to be followed, according to officials at the Health Ministry.\n\nMeanwhile, the ministry said it was still tracking some people, who came in contact with the deceased but are out of home for personal business.\n\nThe death of the 21-year-old from H5N1 virus, the 1st bird flu casualty in Nepal and 1st in the world since February 2017, has been a cause for concern. H5N1 is a lethal bird flu virus strain that is highly pathogenic.\n\n[Byline: Arjun Poudel]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[According to WHO guidance on regulations for the Transport of Infectious Substances 2015-2016. Annex 2 (https://apps.who.int/iris/bitstream/handle/10665/149288/WHO_HSE_GCR_2015.2_eng.pdf); and the available list for classification of infectious substances prior to shipment, highly pathogenic avian influenza 'Cultures only' are classified as category A shipments. These have more stringent shipping regulations and require certified shippers to package them and complete the relevant documentation.\n\nThe same classification does not apply to suspected samples/sample materials from patients that require testing for confirmation.\n\nThe report above highlights one of the key areas in outbreak response and preparedness, that is, availability of trained and/or certified shippers to prepare the shipments for international transport. Having mentioned that, use of national/WHO guidelines for safe transport of infectious materials must also be ensured during domestic or in-country transportation. -Mod.UBA\n\nMaps of Nepal: https://setopati.net/wp-content/uploads/2018/06/mapofnepal.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/10454]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nThe death of the 21-year-old from H5N1 virus, the 1st bird flu casualty in Nepal and 1st in the world since February 2017, has been a cause for concern. \n\n\nThe Epidemiology and Disease Control Division says it is preparing to send specimens collected from the people who came in close contact with the person who died after contracting the H5N1 (bird flu) virus on [29 Mar 2019]. \n\nHealth officials say it takes time to send samples to laboratories abroad, as manpower trained to handle the biohazard are required for that. \n\n'We have collected specimens from doctors, nurses, close family members, relatives, and hospitals -- and also from homes,' Dr Bibek Kumar Lal, director at the division, told the Post. Following the confirmation of deadly virus responsible for the death, health experts from the WHO's headquarters and its regional office in New Delhi, India arrived in Kathmandu to assist Nepali health officials to carry out an epidemiological investigation. \n\nThe same classification does not apply to suspected samples/sample materials from patients that require testing for confirmation. The division, under the Department of Health Services, had formed a team of medical doctors and lab technicians to carry out an epidemiological investigation after the death of a 21-year-old from Kavrepalanchok district Airlines do not easily carry such specimens and for that, protocols of international health regulations need to be followed, according to officials at the Health Ministry. {"location": "Hanoi", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Viet Nam \n\n Summary", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6420700", "headline": "PRO> Avian influenza (29): Bhutan (CK) poultry, HPAI H5N1", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6420700", "date": "2019-04-13 18:35:49", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (29): BHUTAN (CHHUKHA) POULTRY, HPAI H5N1\n*********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 13 Apr 2019\nSource: Kuensel Online [edited]\nhttp://www.kuenselonline.com/1130-poultry-birds-culled-after-bird-flu-outbreak/\n\n\nA bird flu (H5N1) outbreak has affected 13 poultry farms and one turkey farm at Dhamdara in Phuentsholing. The outbreak was confirmed on 8 Apr 2019 through laboratory testing from the National Centre for Animal Health (NCAH), Serbithang, Thimphu.\n\nNo human contact was reported.\n\nIn response, a total of 1130 poultry birds in the affected areas were culled, about 4002 eggs disposed, 613 kg (1351 lb) of feed disposed, and 12 chicken coops destroyed.\n\nThe National Incident Command Committee (NICC) has activated the Incident Operation Centre (IOC) at Thromde Veterinary Hospital in Phuentsholing with the Rapid Response Team (RRT) from different ministries and agencies for immediate containment and response to the outbreak.\n\nA press release from the ministry states, 'As the disease is brought under control at the source of outbreak the public should not panic. The public is also advised to take precautions like washing of hands after handling poultry, chicken and eggs with soap and water.'\n\nProgram director of NCAH, Dr. RB Gurung, the focal person of bird flu, said the outbreak was reported in the field on 6 Apr 2019. He said the outbreak is under control by about 80% yesterday [Fri 12 Apr 2019]. As the outbreak location was at the outskirt of town, there were not many vehicles on the road, which made it easier, he added.\n\nThe response team also created awareness in the community. Vehicles traveling out of the demarcated infected and restricted zones are also disinfected.\n\nDr. RB Gurung said poultry farmers are cautioned to comply with farm biosecurity measures and not allow visitors into the farms without proper safety measures. 'We need to observe the outbreak area for one month,' Dr. RB Gurung said.\n\nThe Department of Livestock, Chhukha Dzongkhag Livestock Sector, Department of Public Health, Royal Bhutan Police, Bhutan Agriculture and Food Regulatory Authority and the Regional Livestock Development Centre Tsimasham and local authorities in Phuentsholing have initiated the response to the H5N1 outbreak jointly.\n\n[Byline: Rajesh Rai]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Kunihiko Iizuka\n\n[Phuntsholing, also spelled as Phuentsholing, is a border town in southeastern Bhutan and is the administrative seat of Chhukha District. The town occupies parts of both Phuentsholing Gewog and Sampheling Gewog; map at http://tinyurl.com/y672je4t.\n\nIt may be assumed that the event in Bhutan is related to wild bird migration; 2 of the 3 earlier outbreaks notified by Bhutan to the OIE took place in a similar season, namely, March (2018) and April (2015). Bhutan has already reported the event to the OIE; see 20190413.6418964. - Mod.AS\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail maps:\nBhutan: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/154\nChhukha District, Bhutan: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/12668]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n In response, a total of 1130 poultry birds in the affected areas were culled, about 4002 eggs disposed, 613 kg (1351 lb) of feed disposed, and 12 chicken coops destroyed.\n\n \n\nProgram director of NCAH, Dr. RB Gurung, the focal person of bird flu, said the outbreak was reported in the field on 6 Apr 2019. On 23 Mar 2019, as many as 13 ducks died on the day in the farm. District veterinary office investigated into the incident and sent blood samples to the National Institute of High Security Animal Diseases (NIHSAD) in Bhopal. 'The samples tested positive for the H5N1 or avian influenza virus,' informed chief district veterinary officer Premananda Rout.\n\n'Following the test report, we culled ducks and chickens. Moreover, 3.6 quintal [360 kg] of foodgrains were destroyed as well.\n\nCarcasses of culled birds were buried in 10-foot deep pits. Bleaching powder and other disinfectants were sprinkled while filling up the pits to prevent spread of H5N1 virus,' added Rout.\n\nAll the poultry farms in 1-km radius of the breeding centre have been banned for the time being. The farms will remain closed for the next 6 months according to guidelines, added Rout.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[During the years 2016-2018, HPAI subtypes H5N1 and H5N8 circulated in India, generally in a seasonal pattern (October-February). This may follow the bird migration pattern/seasons.\n\nDetailed information on each event reported during 2018 is available at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Countryinformation/Countryreports. Nepal\n----------------------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 17 Mar 2019 from Dr Bimal Kumar Nirmal, Director General, Department of Livestock Services, Ministry of Agriculture and Livestock Development, Nepal\n\nSummary:\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 14 Feb 2019\nDate of confirmation of the event: 6 Mar 2019\nReason for notification: recurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 10 Sep 2018\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory (basic and advanced), necropsy\nThis event pertains to the whole country.\n\nNew outbreaks (2)\nOutbreak 1: Hetauda Submetropolitan, ward No. 7, Naksoti, Makawanpur, Narayani\nDate of start of the outbreak: 14 Feb 2019\nOutbreak status: Continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: Farm\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered\nBirds / 50 894 / 9769 / 9769 / 41 125 / 0\nAffected population: Commercial layers\n\nOutbreak 2: Tarkeshwor-1, Sanglafat, kathmandu, Bagmati\nDate of start of the outbreak: 28 Feb 2019\nOutbreak status: Continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: Farm\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered\nBirds / 5852 / 2600 / 2600 / 3252 / 0\nAffected population: Layers\n\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 2\nTotal animals affected:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered\nBirds / 56 746 / 12 369 / 12 369 / 44 377 / 0\n\nOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBirds / 21.80 / 21.80 / 100 / 100\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\n\nEpidemiological comments: Sudden deaths of large numbers of birds of laying stage showing clinical sign and symptoms, with swelling of head, cyanotic comb, and wattle.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: movement control inside the country, surveillance outside containment and/or protection zone, surveillance within containment and/or protection zone, screening, quarantine, official destruction of animal products, official disposal of carcasses, by-products and waste, stamping out, disinfection, vaccination prohibited, no treatment of affected animals\n\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type: Central veterinary laboratory (national laboratory)\nSpecies / Test / Test date / Result\nBirds / rapid tests / 6 Mar 2019 / Positive\nBirds / real-time PCR / 6 Mar 2019 / Positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreaks can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n['Some of the risk factors for avian influenza in Nepal are the following:\n- Formal and informal trade of domestic poultry, eggs, meat and wild/pet birds\n- Wintering of migratory birds\n- Sharing common habitat among migratory and residential wild birds\n- Unorganized markets of poultry and pet birds\n- Poor attention on biosecurity measures\n- Unorganized and densely poultry populated areas\n- Open porous border to India & China'\n\nThe above information as well a more detailed description about the passive and active surveillance national program on HPAI that Nepal has developed can be found in the presentation titled 'Panel session on Surveillance of Avian Influenza in Nepal.' This presentation was made within the framework of the OIE Regional Expert Group Meeting for the Control of Avian Influenza in Asia, Sapporo, Japan, 3-5 Oct 2017 and is available at https://tinyurl.com/y3grajy5. - Mod.CRD\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map available at:\nNepal: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/139]", "summary": "promed@promedmail.org>\n\n['Some of the risk factors for avian {"archive_id": "6453747", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (07): Nepal (BK) H5N1, fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6453747", "date": "2019-05-05 11:45:58", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (07): NEPAL (BHAKTAPUR) H5N1, FATAL\n**********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 2 May 2019 22:01 NPT\nSource: The Kathmandu Post [edited]\nhttp://kathmandupost.ekantipur.com/news/2019-05-02/first-bird-flu-death-in-the-country-exposes-passive-surveillance-and-poor-preparedness.html\n\n\nThe H5N1 bird flu virus that has been confirmed as the 1st cause of death in Nepal, 10 years after it was first detected in birds in 2009, is the world's 1st H5N1 human infection since February 2017 and has raised issues of public health emergency of international concern as government and WHO officials refuse further information on the case.\n\n'We are taking the help of the UN body to contain the disease,' Ministry of Health and Population spokesperson Mahendra Prasad Shrestha told the Post.\n\nAs experts from the World Health Organization headquarters and its Delhi office gather in the Capital to take stock of the situation, Shrestha says the government is taking the incident seriously and adhering to the standard protocols of international health regulations that Nepal is obligated to.\n\nThe deceased, a 21-year-old from Kavrepalanchok district, who had been residing in Bhaktapur and whose identity has not been revealed by the government, was first admitted to Nepal Medical College on [24 Mar 2019] after showing signs of fever and cough.\n\nDoctors, who had then suspected influenza infection sent throat swab specimens to the National Public Health Laboratory on [25 Mar 2019]. The same day, before the laboratory results were out, the patient was administered with oseltamivir, an influenza antiviral medication taken from the Epidemiology and Disease Control Division [EDCD]. But the laboratory failed to identify the strain of the virus, the ministry said in a statement on [Thu 2 May 2019].\n\nThe patient, who worked as a driver, was then transferred to Om Hospital [in Kathmandu] as his condition became critical, according to one official who wanted to remain anonymous. 4 days later, on [29 Mar 2019], the patient died due to respiratory complications while undergoing treatment.\n\nThroat swab specimens were then sent to the WHO Collaborating Center for Influenza in Japan, according to the ministry and laboratory results received on [30 Apr 2019] tested positive for influenza A(H5N1).\n\nH5N1 is a lethal bird flu virus strain that is highly pathogenic. The 1st infection in humans was reported in 1997 in Hong Kong and the virus has since spread to Asia, Africa, Middle East, and Europe and other parts of the world causing millions of poultry infections.\n\nAlthough rare, confirmed human cases for bird flu as reported by the WHO from 2003 to [9 Apr 2019] stands at 860 human cases and 454 deaths. According to the UN body, almost all cases of H5N1 infection have been associated with close contact with infected live or dead fowls or contaminated environment.\n\nWhile the virus does not seem to spread from human to human, a major concern among scientists is that the virus could mutate or combine with other influenza virus into something more infectious and result in a pandemic.\n\nBut least measures were taken since the 21-year-old boy first got admitted to a hospital with influenza-like symptoms and little was done to isolate mourning family members and relatives or anyone the patient had come in close contact with after his death.\n\nAdditionally, there was nothing done to contain the 2 hospitals to which the patient was admitted. But 5 weeks since the boy's death, EDCD director Dr Bibek Kumar Lal says epidemiological investigations have now started and that his office has stepped up surveillance to contain the disease.\n\n'The good thing is no one has come in contact with the virus. The incubation period of the virus is one week but we do not have any cases of infection, 5 weeks on,' Lal told the Post. 'No other patients in the area or elsewhere have been diagnosed with the disease as our laboratory records show.'\n\nNepal declared itself free from H5N1 in 2012 but this strain of the deadly bird flu virus continues to be found in poultry in Nepal and more recently even in some 350 crows in the Capital.\n\nAccording to Dr Bansi Sharma, director general at the Department of Livestock Services, this year [2019] alone, 52 samples collected from poultry farms examined by the central veterinary laboratory tested positive for the deadly H5N1 virus.\n\nFollowing the confirmations, rapid response teams of veterinary technicians were deployed to poultry farms in Kathmandu, Bhaktapur, Lalitpur, Makwanpur, Morang, Sunsari, and Kaski district and over 100 000 infected chickens were culled.\n\n'The outbreaks of H5N1 have serious public health, economic, and social implications, therefore its prevention is a priority across the globe and the human infection is evident of zoonotic disease spillover from animals to humans,' said Manisha Bista, a disease surveillance officer at the Center for Molecular Dynamics Nepal.\n\n'This is an opportunity to identify flaws in our passive surveillance programmes and invest in technical and human capacities to detect diseases and investigate outbreaks and inform the general public without creating public outcry.'\n\n[Byline: Arjun Poudel, Arpan Shrestha]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[Maps of Nepal can be seen at https://setopati.net/wp-content/uploads/2018/06/mapofnepal.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/10454.\nKavrepalanchok district, a part of Province Three, is one of the 77 (formerly 76) districts of Nepal (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kavrepalanchok_District). Bhaktapur district in the eastern part of Kathmandu valley, also in Province Three, is the smallest among the 77 districts of Nepal (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bhaktapur_District). An outbreak in a poultry farm was also reported in Bhaktapur district in early April [PRO/SOAS> Avian influenza (24): Nepal (Bhaktapur) poultry 20190406.6406753 & http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=30047]\n\nThe global cumulative number of confirmed human cases for avian influenza A(H5N1) reported to WHO, 2003-2019, is 860 with 454 fatalities (case fatality rate (CFR) 52.8 percent) as of 9 Apr 2019 (https://www.who.int/influenza/human_animal_interface/2019_04_09_table H5N1. pdf). Out of the 16 countries that have reported human cases of avian influenza A/H5N1, 2 countries Bangladesh (8 cases/1 death) and Pakistan (3 cases /1 death) are in South Asia. This is the 1st influenza A(H5N1) human case reported from Nepal.\n\nThe report above mentions that poultry outbreaks with A/H5N1 were reported from Nepal until 2012. There have been several OIE reports of poultry outbreaks since then. The report also mentions that recently dead crows were also reported from Kathmandu; these were confirmed to be infected with A/H5N1 [Avian influenza (20): Nepal, wild bird, HPAI H5N1, OIE 20190327.6389939].\n\nThe fatal case is mentioned as a driver by occupation, but no further details are provided. It is hoped that the epidemiological investigation launched by the Ministry of Health will provide more insight into the matter.\n\nFurthermore, it is imperative that reliable laboratory capacity be available at the country level to detect seasonal and non-human influenza subtypes in a timely manner and refer unsubtypable viruses to WHO reference laboratories at the earliest.\n\nLast but not least, strengthening routine surveillance capacity is the key to early detection of cases and public health response planning. - Mod.UBA\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map available at:\nBhaktapur District, Nepal: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/10454]", "summary": "An outbreak in a poultry farm was also reported in Bhaktapur district in early April [PRO/SOAS> Avian influenza (24): Nepal (Bhaktapur) poultry 20190406.6406753 & http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=30047]\n\nThe global cumulative number of confirmed human cases for avian influenza A(H5N1) reported to WHO, 2003-2019, is 860 with 454 fatalities (case fatality rate (CFR) 52.8 percent) as of 9 Apr 2019 (https://www.who.int/influenza/human_animal_interface/2019_04_09_table H5N1. \n\nWhile the virus does not seem to spread from human to human, a major concern among scientists is that the virus could mutate or combine with other influenza virus into something more infectious and result in a pandemic. \n\nNepal declared itself free from H5N1 in 2012 but this strain of the deadly bird flu virus continues to be found in poultry in Nepal and more recently even in some 350 crows in the Capital.\n\n A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\n'The outbreaks of H5N1 have serious public health, economic, and social implications, therefore its prevention is a priority across the globe and the human infection is evident of zoonotic disease spillover from animals to humans,' said Manisha Bista, a disease surveillance officer at the Center for Molecular Dynamics Nepal. \n\nThroat swab specimens were then sent to the WHO Collaborating Center for Influenza in Japan, according to the ministry and laboratory results received on [30 Apr 2019] tested positive for influenza A(H5N1). \n\nBut least measures were taken since the 21-year-old boy first got admitted to a hospital with influenza-like symptoms and little was done to isolate mourning family members and relatives or anyone the patient had come in close contact with after his death. Although rare, confirmed human cases for bird flu as reported by the WHO from 2003 to [9 Apr 2019] stands at 860 human cases and 454 deaths. \n\n'We are taking the help of the UN body to contain the disease,' Ministry of Health and Population spokesperson Mahendra Prasad Shrestha told the Post.\n\n \n\n'This is an opportunity to identify flaws in our passive surveillance programmes and invest in technical and human capacities to detect diseases and investigate outbreaks and inform the general public without creating public outcry.' Out of the 16 countries that have reported human cases of avian influenza A/H5N1, 2 countries Bangladesh (8 cases/1 death) and Pakistan (3 cases /1 death) are in South Asia. \n\n[Byline: Arjun Poudel, Arpan Shrestha]\n\n--\n \n\nLast but not least, strengthening routine surveillance capacity is the key to early detection of cases and public health response planning. According to Dr Bansi Sharma, director general at the Department of Livestock Services, this year [2019] alone, 52 samples collected from poultry farms examined by the central veterinary laboratory tested positive for the deadly H5N1 virus. AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (07): NEPAL (BHAKTAPUR) H5N1, FATAL\n**********************************************************\n \n\nH5N1 is a lethal bird flu virus strain that is highly pathogenic. 32(13) [edited]\nhttps://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=29966\n\n\nHighly pathogenic influenza A viruses (infection with) (non-poultry including wild birds)\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 26 Mar 2019 from Dr Bimal Kumar Nirmal, Director General, Department of Livestock Services, Ministry of Agriculture and Livestock Development, Nepal.\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification (final report)\nDate of start of the event: 17 Mar 2019\nDate of confirmation of the event: 21 Mar 2019\nReport date: 26 Mar 2019\nDate submitted to OIE: 26 Mar 2019\nDate event resolved: 22 Mar 2019\nReason for notification: Recurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous recurrence: 10 Sep 2018\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza [AI] virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: laboratory (advance), necropsy\nThis event pertains to the whole country.\n\nNew outbreaks\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1: [Bagmati (Lainchaur, Kathmandu)]\nTotal animals affected:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered\nCrow: _Corvus splendens_ (Corvidae) / -- / 200 / 200 / 0 / 0\nOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]\nSpecies / apparent morbidity rate / apparent mortality rate / apparent case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nCrow: _Corvus splendens_ (Corvidae) / ** / ** / 100 / **\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n** Not calculated because of missing information\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\nComments: there was a sudden death of a large number of crows in a bamboo tree area of the affected location. Proper cleaning and disinfection of the premises were done with the burial of dead crows. Post-operative surveillance is ongoing.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: surveillance outside containment and/or protection zone; surveillance within containment and/or protection zone; official disposal of carcasses, by-products and waste; control of wildlife reservoirs; disinfection; vaccination prohibited; no treatment of affected animals; measures to be applied; no other measures.\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is resolved. No more reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The Indian subcontinent has experienced HPAI outbreaks due to H5N1 virus infection in domestic poultry and other birds almost every year since the 1st report in 2006. Since November 2016, subtype H5N8 has also been reported in India, Pakistan, and Nepal. - Mod.PMB\n\nOn 15 March 2019, the Government of Nepal declared the occurrence of 3 earlier outbreaks of H5N1 in 3 districts of the country, namely in\nHetauda Sub Metropolitan area, in Makwanpur district, in Central region; Tarekeshower Municipality, Kathmandu district, Central region; and in Madi Rurral municipality, Kaski Pokhara district, Western region. Additional outbreaks were suspected in Makwanpur and Kathmandu districts. These were the first H5N1 HPAI events reported in 2019.\n\nLast earlier detections of HPAI H5N1 in Nepal were reported in May-June 2018 in the Central region, in Bagmati and Narayani areas.\n\nH5N1 HPAI events have been reported from India (in wild crows, mainly, and in poultry) in 2019, while in Indonesia and Viet Nam last events were reported in December 2018. - Mod.AS\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Nepal: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/30267]", "summary": "Recurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous recurrence: 10 Sep 2018\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza [AI] virus\n A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Outbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]\nSpecies / apparent morbidity rate / apparent mortality rate / apparent case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\n PMB\n\nOn 15 March 2019, the Government of Nepal declared the occurrence of 3 earlier outbreaks of H5N1 in 3 districts of the country, namely in\nHetauda Sub Metropolitan area, in Makwanpur district, in Central region; Tarekeshower Municipality, Kathmandu district, Central region; and in Madi Rurral municipality, Kaski Pokhara district, Western region. "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (06): India (JH) crow, HPAI H5N1", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6311901", "date": "2019-02-12 12:14:36", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (06): (JHARKHAND) CROW, HPAI H5N1\n*************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 11 Feb 2019 2:12 AM IST\nSource: The Telegraph [edited]\nhttps://m.telegraphindia.com/states/jharkhand/bird-flu-alert-in-bokaro-after-crows-start-dropping-dead/cid/1684162\n\n\nThe authorities in Bokaro [Jharkhand] are rushing quick response teams to 9 blocks in the district in the wake of bird flu confirmation in Gomia.\n\nThe state animal husbandry department had on [Sat 9 Feb 2019] said samples of dead crows sent to the National Institute of High Security Animal Diseases (NIHSAD), Bhopal, had tested positive for the H5N1 virus that is responsible for the highly infectious scourge in avian species.\n\nBesides Gomia, where crows began dropping dead in the last week of January [2019], Bermo, Chandrapura, Kasmar, Chas, Nawadih, Chandankyari, Jaridih, and Petarwar blocks have been put on high alert, said Bokaro animal husbandry officer Arun Kumar Sinha.\n\n'We have sent special teams to these areas. But, there is no need to panic, as bird flu has not been reported in poultry yet. No poultry death has taken place so far. Besides, we have sent poultry samples to the Bhopal lab as a precautionary measure,' he said, adding that reports were expected in a couple of days.\n\nThe animal husbandry officer nonetheless advised poultry farmers to isolate and cull sick birds, restrict access to healthy ones, clean cages and equipment regularly, disinfect footwear/gloves of workers, and stop borrowing supplies from other farms.\n\n'People who eat chicken and eggs need not worry. Boiling these above 70 deg C [158 deg F] kills the H5N1 virus. Also, to avoid human infection in case of an outbreak, one must avoid domesticating poultry birds,' Sinha said.\n\nThe 9 quick response teams, the officer said, would aid in containing the spread of bird flu. 'If need be, more than one team can be rushed to a particular block or area to assist in culling. Each team is lead by a veterinarian who will supervise culling, disposal of carcasses, vaccination, and disinfecting poultry farms,' he said.\n\nOn how the crows contracted the deadly H5N1 virus, Sinha said it was possible that some migratory avian species were the carriers. 'This winter [2018-19], several migratory birds were seen in and around Bokaro, including Gomia. It is possible they are responsible for the spread of avian influenza in crows.'\n\n[Byline: Praduman Choubey]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps of India: http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/306]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nThe state animal husbandry department had on [Sat 9 Feb 2019] said samples of dead crows sent to the National Institute of High Security Animal Diseases (NIHSAD), Bhopal, had tested positive for the H5N1 virus that is responsible for the highly infectious scourge in avian species. \n\nBesides Gomia, where crows began dropping dead in the last week of January [2019], Bermo, Chandrapura, Kasmar, Chas, Nawadih, Chandankyari, Jaridih, and Petarwar blocks have been put on high alert, said Bokaro animal husbandry officer Arun Kumar Sinha. \n\nThe 9 quick response teams, the officer said, would aid in containing the spread of bird flu. Most farmers raise chickens, but other types of poultry are also raised including ducks, pigeons, geese and a variety of caged birds. Since there are no large commercial poultry slaughtering establishments in the Lao People's Democratic Republic, processing is done primarily by owners or traders with small basic facilities.\n\nThe 1st outbreak of avian influenza (H5N1) in poultry was in January 2004 in Vientiane Capital, where 45 separate locations were affected, resulting in the death or culling of 155 000 birds. Since then, almost yearly outbreaks of H5N1 in poultry have been confirmed.'
