{"archive_id": "6210437", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (115): India (OR) poultry, HPAI H5N1", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6210437", "date": "2018-12-15 18:10:01", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (115): INDIA (ODISHA) POULTRY, HPAI H5N1\n********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 13 Dec 2018\nSource: Kalinga TV [edited]\nhttps://kalingatv.com/state/bird-flu-district-administration-orders-bird-culling-in-puris-brahmagiri-from-tomorrow/\n\n\nIn a precautionary measure after several blood samples from chickens were found positive with bird flu virus in at least 3 villages under Brahmagiri block, the district administration today [13 Dec 2018] ordered for bird culling and a ban on poultry sold in the area. Informing on the steps, Puri Collector Jyoti Prakash Das said a decision has been taken to start bird culling within the radius of 1 kilometre [0.62 mile] from the affected area. The culling will begin Friday [14 Dec 2018], he added.\n\nApart from bird culling, the selling of poultry products within a radius of 10 kilometres [6.2 miles] from the affected areas has been banned, along with a stoppage in supply of eggs for Mid-Day Meals provided in schools.\n\nNotably, bird flu fear loomed large in Brahmagiri block in the past 3 days after more than 20 000 hens died from a mysterious disease. While blood samples from the birds were sent to the National Institute of High Security Animal Diseases (NIHSAD) in Bhopal, a number of those [which had been collected] from Patharganj, Budhibar and Masasahi villages were found positive with H5N1 viruses.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[No HPAI activity has been reported from India since March 2018, when HPAI H5N1 was reported to the OIE from a backyard in Odisha, eradicated by stamping out ( 20180308.5673915). It was preceded by an H5N1 event, a few days earlier, involving a crow.\n\nThe current event may herald the start of the seasonal virus activity, related to bird migration. - Mod.AS\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nOdisha, India: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/56741]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n In a precautionary measure after several blood samples from chickens were found positive with bird flu virus in at least 3 villages under Brahmagiri block, the district administration today [13 Dec 2018] ordered for bird culling and a ban on poultry sold in the area. So far, around 150 outbreaks in poultry have been reported, and 4 genetic clades of the virus have been identified. In 2016 and 2017, several cases of HPAI H5N1 were reported in poultry farms, crows and Guinea fowl. Since November 2016, also subtype H5N8 outbreaks were reported in India. - Mod.PMB\n\nHealthMap/ProMED maps available at:\nOdisha, India: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/56741\nBihar, India: Currently the virus continues to be reported in Asia and Africa in both poultry and wild birds. The virus has become enzootic in Asia and Africa and continues to cause outbreaks in poultry and sporadic human infections.\n\n'As of July 2018, 860 human infections have been reported to WHO from 16 countries and territories. All cases of H5N1 infection in humans have been associated with close contact with infected live or dead birds or H5N1-contaminated environments. Countries affected should focus on strengthening biosecurity measures to prevent introduction of disease into flocks and avoid contact between wild birds and poultry.' OIE\n*********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 6 Aug 2018\nSource: OIE, WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database), weekly disease information 2018; 31(32) [edited] http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=27462\n\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza, Malaysia\n-------------------------------------------\nInformation received on 6 Aug 2018 from Dr Quaza Nizamuddin Bin Hassan Nizam, deputy director general (veterinary health), Department of Veterinary Services, Division of Livestock Resources & Technology Development, Putrajaya, Malaysia\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 27 Jul 2018\nDate of confirmation of the event: 30 Jul 2018\nReason for notification: reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 1 Apr 2017\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory (advanced), necropsy\nThis event pertains a defined zone within the country.\n\nNew outbreaks\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1 (Sabah_HPAI_2018/01): Kampung Kauluan, Tamparuli, Tuaran, Sabah\nDate of start of the outbreak: 27 Jul 2018\nOutbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: farm\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered\nBirds / 28 000 / 3000 / 3000 / 25 000 / 0\nAffected population: the affected population is flocks of layer chickens in one farm.\n\nOutbreak statistics [apparent rates, expressed as percentages]\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBirds / 10.7 / 10.7 / 100 / 100\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\nEpidemiological comments: the report of high mortality of layer chickens was received by Sabah Department of Veterinary Services on [27 Jul 2018]. Investigation and sampling were carried out on the same day. Movement of animals and animal products was banned on the same day. Upon confirmation of the laboratory of the samples positive for HPAI (H5N1), stamping out of the flock was carried out and the carcasses were officially disposed of. This is the 1st occurrence of HPAI in Sabah state. Sabah is a state of Malaysia located at East Malaysia, on the island of Borneo. Sabah and Peninsular Malaysia are separated by the South China Sea.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: movement control inside the country, surveillance outside containment and/or protection zone, surveillance within containment and/or protection zone, screening, quarantine, official disposal of carcasses, by-products and waste, stamping out, zoning, disinfection, vaccination prohibited, no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nSabah Veterinary Laboratory (regional reference laboratory) / Birds / polymerase chain reaction (PCR) / 30 Jul 2018 / Positive\nVeterinary Research Institute Ipoh Perak (regional reference laboratory) / Birds / inoculation test / 5 Aug 2018 / Positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In February 2017, Malaysia reported 36 outbreaks of HPAI H5N1 in the state of Kelantan (Peninsular Malaysia). The event was resolved on 1 Apr 2018. See event summary and updated map at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?reportid=23159.\n\n'The Asian lineage HPAI H5N1 virus first emerged in China in 1996 and spread to Asia, Europe, Middle East, and Africa, and following ongoing evolution is now grouped under different genetic clades. Currently the virus continues to be reported in Asia and Africa in both poultry and wild birds. The virus has become enzootic in Asia and Africa and continues to cause outbreaks in poultry and sporadic human infections.\n\n'In late 2005, the Asian lineage H5N1 was introduced to Europe and several European countries experienced outbreaks in poultry and wild birds in the subsequent years. The last outbreak of H5N1 occurred in France in 2015, but that virus was not related to the H5N1 viruses circulating in other parts of the world and appears to have evolved from a low pathogenic avian influenza virus circulating in Europe.\n\n'In 2015, America and Canada reported novel reassortant H5N1 outbreaks with Eurasian and North American origin in poultry. This virus was also different from the H5N1 strain circulating in Asia.\n\n'As of June 2018, 860 human infections have been reported to WHO from 16 countries and territories. All cases of H5N1 infection in humans have been associated with close contact with infected live or dead birds, or H5N1-contaminated environments. Countries affected should focus on strengthening biosecurity measures to prevent introduction of disease into flocks and avoid contact between wild birds and poultry.' (http://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Animal_Health_in_the_World/docs/pdf/OIE_AI_situation_report/OIE_SituationReport_AI_June2018.pdf). - Mod.CRD\n\nMaps of Malaysia: (90): Malaysia (SA) H5N1, poultry, comment", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5963743", "date": "2018-08-13 22:05:08", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (90): MALAYSIA (SABAH) H5N1, POULTRY, COMMENT\n*************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 13 Aug 2018\nFrom: Tin Tin Myaing <dr.tintinmyaing@gmail.com> [edited]\n\n\nRe: ProMED-mail post Avian influenza (89): Malaysia (SA) H5N1, poultry, OIE 20180807.5951109\n------------------------\nThe article referenced in the comment made by Mod.TTM in ProMED-MBDS posting 20180809.5956160 provides useful information on the avian influenza situation in Malaysia.\n\nThe abstract of the article indicated:\n'Malaysia has experienced avian influenza virus (AIV) outbreaks over the past 3 decades. Four waves of H5N1 high pathogenicity avian influenza (HPAI) took place in 2004, 2006, 2007, and 2017. The 1st epidemics of HPAI H5N1 subtype occurred in Kelantan, Kuala Lumpur, and Perak in 2004. At that time, the outbreak was caused by 1, 2.3, and 2.3.4 clades. Molecular analysis of AIV of the HA gene found that the H5N1 strain was highly homologous and grouped together in a Vietnam/Thailand/Malaysia (VTM) sublineage to the previously H5N1 isolates from domestic and migratory birds in Thailand, Viet Nam, Cambodia, and Hong Kong during 2003-2005. Genetic differences of these clades with 2.1 clade from Indonesia suggested that the virus was contained within poultry rather than through the repeated reintroduction of viruses from external sources. In 2006, H5N1 virus was detected in Kuala Lumpur and the states of Perak and Pulau Pinang. The outbreak at that time was genetically similar to the previous outbreaks of the Fujian-like sub-lineage (clade 2.3.4) in 2004. H5N1 isolates were detected in Selangor, Kelantan, and Kuala Lumpur in 2007 and only in Kelantan in 2017. During 1980-2017, outbreaks of low pathogenicity avian influenza (LPAI) included H4N3, H4N6, H3N6, H5N6, H2N9, H4N1, H7N1, H2N9, H3N8, H9N2, H10N5, H3N2, and H5N2 subtypes. The outbreaks in Malaysia suggest that culling has played an important role in the prevention of AIV infection in poultry, the reduction of virus containment in the environment, and the prevention of virus transmission from poultry to humans.' [1]\n\nReference\n---------\n1. Nur Adibah M, Zailina H, Arshad, SS: Avian influenza outbreaks in Malaysia, 1980-2017. Asia Pacific and Environ Jol. 2017: 3(2), 1-14; http://www.apeohjournal.org/index.php/v/article/download/46/58.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[See event summary and updated map of the current situation of HPAI H5N1 in Malaysia at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?fupser=&dothis=&reportid=27462. - Mod.CRD\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map available at:\nSabah, Malaysia: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/3969]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n AVIAN INFLUENZA (90): MALAYSIA (SABAH) H5N1, POULTRY, COMMENT\n*************************************************************\n The abstract of the article indicated:\n'Malaysia has experienced avian influenza virus (AIV) outbreaks over the past 3 decades. [edited]\n\n\nRe: ProMED-mail post Avian influenza (89): Malaysia (SA) H5N1, poultry, OIE 20180807.5951109\n The outbreaks in Malaysia suggest that culling has played an important role in the prevention of AIV infection in poultry, the reduction of virus containment in the environment, and the prevention of virus transmission from poultry to humans.' Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Four waves of H5N1 high pathogenicity avian influenza (HPAI) took place in 2004, 2006, 2007, and 2017. From that time through August 2017, 25 outbreaks were notified. The event was resolved on 10 Oct 2017. See event summary and updated map at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?fupser=&dothis=&reportid=16342\n\n'The Asian lineage HPAI H5N1 virus first emerged in China in 1996 and spread to Asia, Europe, Middle East, and Africa and grouped under different genetic clades. Currently the virus continued to be reported in Asia and Africa in both poultry and wild birds. The virus has become enzootic in Asia and Africa and continues to cause outbreaks in poultry and sporadic human infections.\n\nAs of May 2018, 860 human infections have been reported to WHO from 16 countries and territories. All cases of H5N1 infection in humans have been associated with close contact with infected live or dead birds, or H5N1-contaminated environments. Countries affected should focus on strengthening biosecurity measures to prevent introduction of disease into flocks and avoid contact between wild birds and poultry.' (http://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Animal_Health_in_the_World/docs/pdf/OIE_AI_situation_report/OIE_SituationReport_AI_31052018.pdf). - Mod.CRD\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Qinghai Province, Nepal\n----------------------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 18 May 2018 from Dr Bimal Kumar Nirmal, Doctor, Department of Livestock Services, DGA open RR, Nepal\n\nSummary:\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 3 May 2018\nDate of confirmation of the event: 15 May 2018\nReason for notification: recurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 10 Mar 2017\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory (basic and advanced), necropsy\nThis event pertains to the whole country.\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1: Khairehani-9, Khairehani, Chitwan, Narayani\nDate of start of the outbreak: 3 May 2018\nOutbreak status: resolved on 15 May 2018\nEpidemiological unit: farm\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered\nBirds / 1500/ 1500 / 1500 / 0 / 0\nAffected population: Commercial layers of 72 weeks exhibiting symptoms of cyanotic comb, swollen head, mucus discharge from nostril and sudden death.\n\nOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBirds / 100 / 100 / 100 / 100\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\nEpidemiological comments: Commercial layers of 72 weeks, reared by the farmer, started exhibiting symptoms of cyanotic comb, mucus discharge from nostril, swollen head, and sudden death. Loss of egg production and feed consumption were observed. Free ranged local domestic ducks nearby the infected farm started to die 2 weeks earlier. However, this mortality was not reported. Birds in the affected farm died within 2 weeks time. Dead birds were disposed of in the disposal pit nearby the farm with proper disinfection. Stamping out of the birds in the infected zone has started. The number of birds stamped out in the infected zone will be reported in the follow-up reports.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: movement control inside the country, surveillance outside containment and/or protection zone, screening, quarantine, official destruction of animal products, official disposal of carcasses, by-products and waste, stamping out, disinfection, vaccination prohibited, no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type: Central veterinary laboratory (national laboratory)\nSpecies / Test / Test date / Result\nBirds / rapid tests / 15 May 2018 / Positive\nBirds / real-time PCR / 15 May 2018 / Positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In 2017, Nepal reported 2 events associated with HPAI H5N1 and one event associated with H5N8. "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (61): FRANCE (PAYS DE LA LOIRE) POULTRY, LPAI H5N1, H5N5, OIE\n*****************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] France (Sarthe), poultry, LPAI H5N1, OIE\n[2] France (Sarthe), poultry, LPAI H5N5, OIE\n\n******\n[1] France (Sarthe), poultry, LPAI H5N1, OIE\nDate: Fri 30 Mar 2018\nSource: OIE, WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database), weekly disease information 2018; 31(14) [edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=26339\n\n\nLow pathogenic avian influenza (poultry), France\n------------------------------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 30 Mar 2018 from Dr Loic Evain, [Deputy Director General, CVO, General Directorate of Food, Ministry of Agriculture, Agrifood, and Forestry], Paris, France\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 22 Mar 2018\nDate of confirmation of the event: 27 Mar 2018\nReason for notification: Recurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 27 Apr 2017\nManifestation of disease: Clinical disease\nCausal agent: Low pathogenic avian influenza [LPAI] virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: laboratory (advanced)\nThis event pertains to the whole country\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1 (59): Notre Dame du Pe, Notre Dame du Pe, Sarthe\nDate of start of the outbreak: 22 Mar 2018\nOutbreak status: resolved 28 Mar 2018\nEpidemiological unit: farm\nTotal animals affected:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered\nBirds / 8897 / - / 0 / 8897 / 0\nAffected population: Suspicion based on a very light symptomatology (the laying phase did not start; prostration) in breeding turkeys ready for laying. The reference national laboratory confirmed the presence of low pathogenic H5N1 virus on [27 Mar 2018]. All the animals were killed and destroyed on [27 and 28 Mar 2018].\nOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBirds/ ** / 0 / ** / 100\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n** Not calculated because of missing information\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\nEpidemiological comments: Epidemiological investigation ongoing.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: screening, traceability, stamping out, vaccination prohibited, no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type: ANSES Reference national laboratory, Ploufragan (National laboratory)\nSpecies / Test / Test date / Result\nBirds / nucleotide sequencing / 27 Mar 2018 / Positive\nBirds / real-time reverse transcriptase/polymerase chain reaction (RRT-PCR) / 27 Mar 2018 / Positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] France (Sarthe), poultry, LPAI H5N5, OIE\nDate: Fri 30 Mar 2018\nSource: OIE, WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database), weekly disease information 2018; 31(14) [edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=26340\n\n\nLow pathogenic avian influenza (poultry), France\n------------------------------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 30 Mar 2018 from Dr Loic Evain, [Deputy Director General, CVO, General Directorate of Food, Ministry of Agriculture, Agrifood, and Forestry], Paris, France\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 22 Mar 2018\nDate of confirmation of the event: 27 Mar 2018\nReason for notification: New strain of a listed disease in the country\nDate of previous occurrence: 27 Apr 2017\nCausal agent: Low pathogenic avian influenza [LPAI] virus\nSerotype: H5N5\nNature of diagnosis: laboratory (advanced)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1 (60): Precigne, Precigne, Sarthe\nDate of start of the outbreak: 22 Mar 2018\nOutbreak status: resolved 29 Mar 2018\nEpidemiological unit: farm\nTotal animals affected:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered\nBirds / 13 000 / - / 0 / 13 000 / 0\nAffected population: Influenza has been suspected after a fairly important mortality episode (28 percent) in premises with over 2500 turkeys, among others. The farm also had 13 000 ducks ready for gavage which did not show any signs. Both units were subjected to sampling to detect influenza, notably. The reference laboratory detected histomoniasis in those turkeys and an H5N5 AI virus of low pathogenicity in ducks that were being prepared for fattening. All birds in this backyard flock were depopulated and destroyed between 23-29 Mar 2018.\n\nOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBirds/ ** / 0 / ** / 100\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n** Not calculated because of missing information\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\nEpidemiological comments: Epidemiological investigation ongoing.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: screening, traceability, stamping out, vaccination prohibited, no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type: ANSES Reference national laboratory, Ploufragan (National laboratory)\nSpecies / Test / Test date / Result\nBirds / nucleotide sequencing / 27 Mar 2018 / Positive\nBirds / real-time reverse transcriptase/polymerase chain reaction (RRT-PCR) / 27 Mar 2018 / Positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Avian influenza viruses are divided by subtypes, based on 2 proteins found in the viruses: a hemagglutinin, or 'H' protein, and a neuraminidase, or 'N' protein. There are 16 H types and 9 N types yielding a total 144 possible combinations.\n\nThe H5 and H7 subtypes are of particular concern, given the ability of these 2 H-types to mutate from low pathogenic to highly pathogenic strains. These 2 H-types have been known to cause serious disease and mortality in domestic poultry http://www.inspection.gc.ca/animals/terrestrial-animals/diseases/reportable/ai/fact-sheet/eng/1356193731667/1356193918453.\n\n'Most AI virus strains are low pathogenicity avian influenza (LPAI) and typically cause little or no clinical signs in infected poultry. The LPAI virus is excreted through infected birds' feces and secretions. It spreads primarily through direct contact between healthy and infected birds. It can also be spread through indirect contact with contaminated equipment and materials.\n\nTo prevent cases of LPAI, poultry producers must use special preventative measures and precautions on the farm. If LPAI is detected, farms must be thoroughly cleaned and disinfected. AI viruses are inactivated by heat and drying. They are also very sensitive to most disinfectants and detergents. To ensure thorough cleaning and disinfection, the area must be clear of organic material'. https://tinyurl.com/y7rfdhx8\n\nIn addition to these 2 new reported events, since 2015 to date, France also continues to have 2 active events associated with LPAI H5N2 and H5N3. The situation for each of these LPAI events is as follows:\n\n1. LPAI H5N2: event started Oct 2015; 27 outbreaks reported, and the event still continuing. See event summary and updated map: http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?reportid=19299\n\n2. LPAI H5N3: event started Dec 2015; 37 outbreaks reported, and the event still continuing. See event summary and updated map: http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?reportid=19341.\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Sarthe, Pays de la Loire, France: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/8393. - Mod.CRD]", "summary": "Recurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 27 Apr 2017\nManifestation of disease: Clinical disease\nCausal agent: Low The virus has become enzootic in Asia and Africa and continues to cause outbreaks in poultry and sporadic human infections. All cases of H5N1 infection in people have been associated with close contact with infected live or dead birds, or H5N1-contaminated environments. Countries affected should focus on strengthening biosecurity measures to prevent introduction of disease into flocks and avoid contact of wild birds with poultry Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 15 Feb 2017 20:26 ICT\nSource: The Phnom Penh Post [edited]\nhttp://www.phnompenhpost.com/national/bird-flu-detected-prey-veng\n\n\nA moratorium on the movement of chickens, dead or alive, has been put into effect in a commune of Prey Veng's Ba Phnom district after a chicken sample tested positive for avian influenza H5N1, the provincial Department of Agriculture, Forests and Fisheries said today [Thu 15 Feb 2017].\n\nThe infected bird originated from Prey Phdao village and was one among 100 tested from Sdao Korng commune, according to department director Ouk Samnang, who said that the Ministry of Agriculture had ordered the spray of suspected areas with disinfectant as well as a halt in the movement of birds throughout the commune.\n\n'Trafficking of animals in the area has to be prevented in order not to spread this disease to other places,' Samnang said.\n\nThe ban will remain in effect until authorities see fit to lift it, he noted, adding that no human cases have been found.\n\nLast month [January 2018], 135 chickens were culled in Phnom Penh's Sen Sok district as a preventative measure after a suspected case was found. Similarly, in December [2017] over 200 chickens were culled in Kampong Cham's Prey Chhor.\n\n[Byline: Kuoch Masy]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Cambodia has been experiencing HPAI H5N1 since 2005, when 4 human cases, all fatal, were recorded (compared to 8 cases, with 5 fatalities, in China during the same year). 'Health officials will check and follow up on the villagers' health. My department will also keep following up around the area. Right now, we have cut off an area of 3 km [approx. 1.8 mi] from exporting birds,' said Mr. Borin.\n\nAgriculture Minister Veng Sakhon said authorities must ensure there is no sale or movement of poultry from the cordoned off area.\n\nMr. Borin added that consumers should not buy meat originating from the area and also make sure any chickens they bought live were not sick, adding that vendors should notify authorities of any illnesses. 'If their chickens or ducks are sick, they must report it to officials immediately and not touch the sick birds,' he said, noting further tests would continue to be carried out before the movement ban was lifted.\n\nIn late December [2017], H5N1 spread to Kampong Thom province's Stoung district following an outbreak in Kampong Cham province, but it did not infect any villagers.\n\nHealth Ministry spokesman Ly Sovann said officials intervened in time in the Phnom Penh outbreak to ensure no villagers contracted the virus.\n\n'This is the 4th location for an outbreak of H5N1, with the others being 2 in Kampong Cham province and one location in Kampong Thom province's Stoung district,' he said.\n\nAccording to a report from the communicable disease control department, between 2005 and 2014, 56 people were infected by the disease, leading to 37 deaths.\n\n[Byline: Mom Kunthear]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This new outbreak has been notified to 30(50) [edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=25381\n\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza, Cambodia\n-------------------------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 9 Dec 2017 from Dr Sen Sovann, OIE Delegate/Deputy Secretary General, Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries, Phnom Penh, Cambodia\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 22 Nov 2017\nDate of confirmation of the event: 6 Dec 2017\nReason for notification: recurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 31 Jan 2017\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory (basic, advanced), necropsy\nThis event pertains to the whole country.\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1 (536/17 NAHPRI): Kos Svay, Tropang Preah, Prey Chhor, Kampong Cham\nDate of start of the outbreak: 22 Nov 2017\nOutbreak status: resolved on 8 Dec 2017\nEpidemiological unit: farm\nTotal animals affected:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered\nBirds / 1763 / 1739 / 1739 / 24 / 0\nAffected population: local chicken farm\n\nOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBirds / 98.64 / 98.64 / 100 / 100\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\nEpidemiological comments: On [28 Nov 2017], a poultry farm's owner in Kos Svay village (Tropang Preah commune, Prey Chhor district) reported sick and dead chicken to the Provincial Animal Health and Production Office (PAHPO). PAHPO tasked district veterinarians with verifying the cases. During that time, district veterinarians collected 4 samples on chicken from the farm and sent them to the National Animal Health and Production Research Institute (NAHPRI) to confirm the diagnosis in a laboratory. On [6 Dec 2017], the NAHPRI confirmed the positive result for H5N1.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: movement control inside the country; stamping out; disinfection; vaccination prohibited; no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: surveillance outside containment and/or protection zone\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nNational Animal Health and Production Research Institute (National laboratory) / Birds / anatomo-pathological examination / 6 Dec 2017 / Positive\nNational Animal Health and Production Research Institute (National laboratory) / Birds / real-time PCR / 6 Dec 2017 / Positive\nPasteur Institute on Cambodia (Regional Reference Laboratory) / Birds / real-time PCR / 7 Dec 2017 / Positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This immediate notification complements the information published in ProMED-mail posting 20171209.5493410\n\nA map of Cambodia can be seen at\nhttp://www.nationsonline.org/oneworld/map/cambodia-political-map.htm,\nand a HealthMap map at\nhttp://healthmap.org/promed/p/145. - Mod.CRD]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Measures applied: movement control inside the country; stamping out; disinfection; vaccination prohibited; no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: surveillance outside containment and/or protection zone\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nNational Animal Health and Production Research Institute (National laboratory) / promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This immediate notification complements the information published in ProMED-mail posting 20171209.5493410\n\nA map of Cambodia can be seen at\nhttp://www.nationsonline.org/oneworld/map/cambodia-political-map.htm,\nand a HealthMap map at\nhttp://healthmap.org/promed/p/145. - Mod. To date, no additional confirmed cases have been reported. 5 suspected cases were identified and are waiting for laboratory confirmation. A Ministry of Health Rapid Response Team is investigating the outbreak to find additional cases and possible source of infection. Bali Province Health Office heightened influenza surveillance'\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nEpiCore Global Surveillance Project\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Wed 20 Sep 2017\nSource: EpiCore Global Surveillance Project [edited]\n\n\n'One confirmed case has been reported in Banjar Minggir, Nusa Penida, Bali. The ministry informed Prime Minister Hun Sen on [Fri 8 Dec 2017], of the outbreak.\n\nPrey Chor district's [map at https://tinyurl.com/ybsklyly] Trapaeng Preah commune was hardest hit, with some 200 chickens perishing.\n\nAfter the alert from local authorities, the ministry immediately dispatched experts to inspect the site in Trapaeng Preah, and they took away 2 dead chickens to be sent to a laboratory in Phnom Penh.\n\n'The tests on [Wed 6 Dec 2017] confirmed that those chickens had contracted the avian influenza H5N1,' the lab report said.\n\nAgriculture Minister Veng Sakhonn asked the provincial governor and local authorities to strictly prohibit the transport of fowl in any form, living or dead, as poultry or as meat/meat product. This measure should contain the spread of this virus.\n\nThe ministry also appealed to the general public that they maintain a high standard of hygiene in their households - and be extra diligent when dealing with poultry.\n\n[Byline: Ros Chanveasna]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[The previous HPAI H5N1 outbreak affecting Cambodia's poultry started, reportedly, on [Fri 27 Jan 2017], was controlled by stamping out and declared as resolved on [Mon 30 Jan 2017]; a map and epidemiological statistics are available at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?fupser=&dothis=&reportid=22612.\n\nPoultry farms in Cambodia have been annually infected with HPAI H5N1 strains, in a seasonal pattern, since 2004. In 2005 a 1st human case was reported. Cases in humans continued until 2014, when the last (9) cases were reported, of which 4 died, bringing the total to 56 reported cases in humans, of which 37 died.\n\nA map of (Kampong Cham Province, Cambodia): http://healthmap.org/promed/p/9692. - Mod.AS]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[The previous HPAI H5N1 outbreak affecting Cambodia's poultry started, reportedly, on [Fri 27 Jan 2017], was controlled by stamping out and declared as resolved on [Mon 30 Jan 2017]; a map and epidemiological statistics are available at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?fupser=&dothis=&reportid=22612. \n\nAfter the alert from local authorities, the ministry immediately dispatched experts to inspect the site in Trapaeng Preah, and they took away 2 dead chickens to be sent to a laboratory in Phnom Penh. \n\nAgriculture Minister Veng Sakhonn asked the provincial governor and local authorities to strictly prohibit the transport of fowl in any form, living or dead, as poultry or as meat/meat product. Cases in humans continued until 2014, when the last (9) cases were reported, of which 4 died, bringing the total to 56 reported cases in humans, of which 37 died. \n\n'The tests on [Wed 6 Dec 2017] confirmed that those chickens had contracted the avian influenza H5N1,' the lab report said.", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2017-03-24 00:00:00", "2005-03-24 00:00:00", "2004-03-24 00:00:00", "2017-01-30 00:00:00", "2014-03-24 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Kampong Cham", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Phnom Penh", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Cambodia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kampong Cham Province", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5347871", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR>  Avian influenza, human (73): Indonesia, H5N1, preventing human exposure, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5347871", "date": "2017-09-29 09:04:39", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (73): INDONESIA, HPAI H5N1, PREVENTING HUMAN EXPOSURE, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n*****************************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 19 Sep 2017\nFrom: Andrew Clark <andrewaclark1940@gmail.com> [edited]\n\n\nRe: PRO/IN Avian Influenza, human (72): Indonesia, H5N1, RFI 20170919.532699\n\nA question about the human cases of H5N1 in Indonesia.\n\nIs there a program operational to reduce human exposure during the process of home slaughter?\n\nIn Egypt there has been an FAO project entitled the 'Exposure Reduction Project' that uses unique Behavior Change Communication techniques to reduce human exposure during halal-type slaughter. It is called Safe Contained Poultry Slaughter (SCOPS) and uses large pots or a bucket to capture the viral plume during the death struggle of the bird so that virus-laden aerosols are greatly reduced or eliminated. The program is designed for outreach to village-level women who do home slaughter and the outreach tool is easily altered to fit whatever area or culture is being addressed.\n\nBy using schools and teaching children who then take home [a flyer given to them at school], to teach their mothers, rapid dissemination of the [guidelines addressing] slaughter was accomplished. Additionally there were more than 1000 meetings and seminars held for adult attendees.\n\nThe 2 published posters/flyers illustrate the slaughter technique (11 panels) and then reiterate the most important steps (5 panels). For the flyers, the 2 illustrations were printed back-to-back on one sheet so that what is taken home has both sets of illustrations.\n\nThe posters are very visual in design and meant for limited literacy audiences so that the technique is clear to everyone regardless of educational background, i.e. there is no writing on the 11-step (although there is a version with writing available) and writing on the 5-step (and there is a version with no writing available).\n\nImplementation of this outreach program is very straightforward and the posters can be easily translated where writing is needed or wanted. Also, clothing, facial features, and skin color can be altered to fit the nation/area and culture.\n\n--\nAndrew A. Clark, DVM\nInternational Veterinary Consultant\nPendleton, OR 97801\nU.S.A.\n<andrewaclark1940@gmail.com>\n\n[Dr Clark is acknowledged for his observations and for the examples of public education in Egypt concerning preventive measures during traditional home-slaughter of poultry.\n\nFAO Regional Office for Near East and North Africa, situated in Cairo, published on 1 Feb 2016 a description of its anti-Avian influenza outreach campaign (see at http://www.fao.org/neareast/news/view/en/c/386133/). It is herewith summarized:\n\n'Launched by the FAO's Emergency Centre for Transboundary Animal Diseases (ECTAD) in November 2015, the Exposure Reduction Program (ERP) has proved a tangible success, raising awareness among households regarding the risks linked to the traditional Egyptian household poultry-slaughter and promoting safer manual bird-slaughter steps across Egypt.\n\nThe launched ERP encourages safe/contained poultry slaughter in covered pots (Halla). The objective is to protect individuals who slaughter poultry in the household sector and also to protect the people around them, who are usually women and children, from exposure to the high pathogenic avian influenza virus (HPAI), which can be transmitted during the manual slaughter of an apparently healthy but infected bird that is not yet showing symptoms.\n\nSohair Abel Kader, National Consultant to the program, commented: 'We researched the fact that women and children were the categories most affected by avian flu in Egypt and found that traditional manual slaughter as practiced in Egyptian homes is a main risk factor.' She added: 'The scientific research conducted on this issue proved that containing the bird in a covered pot for a few minutes immediately after slaughter, specifically till the completion of death struggle, protects those who carry out the slaughter and others around them.' Abel Kader said the 10 steps recommended by the FAO program require no special skills and are not costly, as every house has a Halla (pot) with cover, which can be washed with soap and water and is the main instrument needed for safe slaughter. She expressed optimism about the initial response to the campaign by Egyptian citizens.\n\nThe campaign's outreach field staff is formed from rural community health care workers (Raidat Reefiat) from the Ministry of Health and Population and the awareness campaign's professional veterinarians from both extension vets and community animal health and outreach (CAHO) vets, from the General Organization of Veterinary Services, representing the Ministry of Agriculture and Land Reclamation.'\n\nHPAI H5N1 circulation in Egypt reportedly started in March 2006; it was declared endemic in poultry since 2008 while human cases have been reported yearly. As of March 2017 a total of 359 human infections with, at least, 123 deaths have been registered. The disease, in both poultry and in humans, peaks during the cold season (November-March). Last human case was observed on 9 Apr 2017 in Cairo Governorate.\n\nIndonesia reported, between 2005 and 2015, 199 human HPAI H5N1 cases, of which 167 were fatal. No human case has been reported between 2015 and the single fatal case reported recently, which brings the total to 200 cases, 168 of them fatal. The country is endemic for the disease in poultry and, so far, in 2017, 115 H5N1 HPAI outbreaks in poultry were detected in 17 provinces. It may be assumed that the number of human cases in Indonesia is under reported. It is less likely, though not excluded, that human fatalities remain unnoticed.\nInformation on the measures undertaken in Indonesia to reduce human infection with HPAI H5N1, on top of the vaccination of poultry, from FAO, WHO and/or other, national or international agencies and NGO's, is anticipated.\n\nGlobally, from January 2003 to September 2017, there were 859 cases of human infection with avian influenza A(H5N1) virus reported from 16 countries worldwide, led by Egypt and Indonesia. Of these cases, 453 were fatal, resulting in a global CFR of 52.7 percent. - Mod.AS]\n\n[Even though human cases of avian influenza A/H5N1 have been consistently reported since 1997 when it first surfaced, the pandemic potential and its impending threat are compounded by the opportunities for circulation and re-assortment in human hosts leading to a virus that can transmit robustly between humans. So far that has not happened, but the continued and perhaps unnoticed cases in humans require vigilance, ongoing surveillance, and capacity for laboratory diagnosis. - Mod.UBA\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/184.]", "summary": "It is herewith summarized:\n\n'Launched by the FAO's Emergency Centre for Transboundary Animal Diseases (ECTAD) in November 2015, the Exposure Reduction Program (ERP) has proved a tangible success, raising awareness among households regarding the risks linked to the traditional Egyptian household poultry-slaughter and promoting safer manual bird-slaughter steps across Egypt.\n\n International Veterinary Consultant\nPendleton, OR 97801\nU.S.A.\n<andrewaclark1940@gmail.com>\n\n[Dr Clark is acknowledged for his observations and for the examples of public education in Egypt concerning preventive measures during traditional home-slaughter of poultry. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n The objective is to protect individuals who slaughter poultry in the household sector and also to protect the people around them, who are usually women and children, from exposure to the high pathogenic avian influenza virus (HPAI), which can be transmitted during the manual slaughter of an apparently healthy but infected bird that is not yet showing symptoms. AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (73): INDONESIA, HPAI H5N1, PREVENTING HUMAN EXPOSURE, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n She added: 'The scientific research conducted on this issue proved that containing the bird in a covered pot for a few minutes immediately after slaughter, specifically till the completion of death struggle, protects those who carry out the slaughter and others around them.'", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "influenza a/h5n1"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2015-11-24 00:00:00", "2008-03-24 00:00:00", "1997-03-24 00:00:00", "1973-03-24 00:00:00", "2016-02-01 00:00:00", "2017-03-24 00:00:00", "1972-03-24 00:00:00", "2006-03-24 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Cairo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Egypt", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Indonesia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North Africa", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5326997", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian Influenza, human (72): Indonesia, H5N1, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5326997", "date": "2017-09-19 17:25:12", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (72): INDONESIA, H5N1, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n*********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 18 Sep 2017\nSource: Bali Discovery Tours [edited]\nhttp://www.balidiscovery.com/messages/message.asp?Id=17194\n\n\nRadarBali.com reports that a confirmed case of bird flu (H5N1) has claimed a victim in Bali in Banjar Minggir in the Village of Batununggul on Nusa Penida.\n\nOfficials from the Sanglah General Hospital and the Department of Healthcare refused to identify the female victim infected with the virus. The victim died in the Nusa Indah isolation section of Denpasar's main hospital.\n\nRadarBali also reports that a much-feared human-to-human transmission was suspected when one of the doctors treating the Bird Flu victim was thought to be infected with the virus. Laboratory tests eventually confirmed that doctor was not infected with H5N1.\n\nAt the same time, the head of the Provincial Health Service, Dr. Ketut Suarjaya, did confirm one death due to H5N1 in Bali. The victim was from Banjar Minggir, Batununggul on Nusa Penida.\n\nHealth officials suspected that 2 other patients of being infected by bird flu, but who have now been cleared as free of the virus following laboratory tests.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[H5N1 is a type of influenza virus that causes a highly infectious, severe respiratory disease in birds called avian influenza (or 'bird flu'). Human cases of H5N1 avian influenza occur occasionally, but it is difficult to transmit the infection from person to person (http://www.who.int/influenza/human_animal_interface/avian_influenza/h5n1.../faqs/en/).\n\nAs per the latest WHO update on human cases of A/H5N1 avian influenza, a total of 199 cases with 167 deaths have been reported from Indonesia to date [September 2017]. This case makes a total of 200/168. It must be noted that the last 2 cases of A/H5N1 from Indonesia were reported in 2015; http://www.who.int/influenza/human_animal_interface/2017_07_25_tableH5N1.pdf?ua=1.\n\nThe success of avian influenza(AI) control is determined by the role and support of the whole community, especially the role of society in prevention efforts. The most important community messages are to avoid contact with birds that suddenly get sick or die; maintain personal hygiene and keep the environment clean and healthy; and to recognize the symptoms of bird flu that include fever, cough and sore throat and history of contact with sick poultry. If there are signs of AI immediately report to the clinic or hospital. - Mod.UBA\n\nThe source of infection of the victim (eg poultry farm, market, slaughterhouse, kitchen etc) has not been specified; available information will be appreciated. According to Indonesia's last available annual OIE report, covering 2016, the total annual number of HPAI outbreaks in poultry was 284, including HPAI H5N1 and other, unspecified, serotype(s). In Bali, the last (2) HPAI H5N1 outbreaks were recorded in Feb 2016, affecting 249 (dead) birds. The semi-annual report for January to June 2017 is not yet available. Indonesia's control measures on HPAI H5N1, during 2016, included modified stamping out and vaccination. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/184.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n The most important community messages are to avoid contact with birds that suddenly get sick or die; maintain personal hygiene and keep the environment clean and healthy; and to recognize the symptoms of bird flu that include fever, cough and sore throat and history of contact with sick poultry. \n\nHealth officials suspected that 2 other patients of being infected by bird flu, but who have now been cleared as free of the virus following laboratory tests. RadarBali also reports that a much-feared human-to-human transmission was suspected when one of the doctors treating the Bird Flu victim was thought to be infected with the virus. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[According to the report published by FAO-EMPRES on 'Sub-Saharan Africa HPAI situation update' (latest update on 7 Jun 2017), H5N1 has been confirmed in Burkina Faso, Cameroon, Cote d'Ivoire, Ghana, Niger, Nigeria and Togo.\n\nIn Togo:\n- FAO provided preliminary assistance to the Veterinary Services for disease control. This included assistance in the establishment of response teams, drafting of a short term action plan, meeting with WHO, participation in a press conference with the Minister in charge of livestock, WHO, and MoH as well as preparation of daily sitreps.\n- Advanced genetic characterization of the virus identified in Togo confirmed that it belongs to clade 2.3.2.1.c., which is the same clade circulating also in other West and Central African countries.\n\nMore detailed information is available at, http://www.fao.org/ag/againfo/programmes/en/empres/HPAI_Africa/2017/situation_update_2017_06_07.html. - Mod.CRD\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: unknown or inconclusive\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: movement control inside the country, quarantine, zoning, disinfection, vaccination permitted (if a vaccine exists), no treatment of affected animals\n\nMeasures to be applied: surveillance outside containment and/or protection zone, surveillance within containment and/or protection zone, screening, traceability, official destruction of animal products, official disposal of carcasses, by-products and waste, stamping out, control of wildlife reservoirs, selective killing and disposal, process to inactivate the pathogenic agent in products or by-products, slaughter, ante and post-mortem inspections\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nAnimal Disease Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreaks can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[According to the media, 'The Philippines will cull 200 000 chickens, quail and ducks after confirming the country's 1st outbreak of bird flu,' Agriculture Secretary Emmanuel Pinol said on Friday [4 Aug 2017?].\n\nThe avian flu outbreak was detected in a farm in San Luis municipality in Pampanga province, north of the capital Manila, which later spread to 5 neighbouring farms. There has been no case of human transmission, although health officials are conducting checks on farm workers.\n\n'We have declared a one-km quarantine radius with the epicenter being San Luis. All fowl found within the area will be culled and buried, and the estimated population is 200 000,' Pinol told reporters at a news conference.\n\nThe volume of birds to be culled was half of Pinol's initial estimate of 400 000, which he said was based on a preliminary evaluation and was later revised after inspection.\n\nThe government's report on Friday [4 Aug 2017?] to the World Organisation for Animal Health (OIE) described the flu virus in affected birds as an H5 subtype of highly pathogenic (high-path) avian influenza.\n\nInitial tests ruled out high-path H5N1 as the virus strain, Dr. Celia Carlos told reporters, and samples will be sent to Australia for further testing.\n\n'The Department of Health is doing surveillance of possible human cases, especially concentrating on people who have been exposed to the affected animals or poultry,' Carlos said.\n\nCulling should be completed within the next 3 days, said Pinol. The virus may have come from migratory birds from China or smuggled ducks, also from China, he said.\n\nThere were indications as early as April 2017 of bird flu hitting one farm, but the situation worsened in July 2017, with around 37 000 birds dying during the period, Pinol said.\n\nThe Philippines is the latest country in Asia, Europe and Africa where the bird flu viruses have spread in recent months. Many strains only infect birds, but the H7N9 strain has led to human cases, including fatalities, in China'. See https://www.agcanada.com/daily/philippines-reports-first-avian-flu-outbreak.\n\nRegarding Laos, during September 2016, Laos reported to the OIE one outbreak of HPAI H5N1. The outbreak was located in the province of Luangprabang. The event was declared resolved on 26 Oct 2016. See report and map at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?reportid=21176.\n\nAll outbreaks of HPAI (highly pathogenic avian influenza) reported from 1 Jan 2016 to date can be seen on the interactive map at http://tinyurl.com/yda2fxym (click on the section of interest on the map, and zoom in). - Mod.CRD\n\nProMED HealthMaps:\nPhilippines: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/158\nLaos: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/146]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4939591", "date": "2017-04-02 14:20:15", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (40): EGYPT (FAYOUM), H5N1, COMMENTS\n***********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nThe following comments were received in response to the RFI on ProMED post; Avian influenza, human (27): Egypt (Fayoum) H5N1, RFI 20170227.4866795\n\n******\n[1] Age discrepancy between age cited for Fayoum case by EMRO (45 years) and WHO and media sources (48 years)\nDate: Thu 16 Mar 2017\nSource: WHO Monthly Risk Assessment Summary [edited]\nhttp://www.who.int/influenza/human_animal_interface/Influenza_Summary_IRA_HA_interface_03_16_2017.pdf?ua=1\n\n\nInfluenza at the human-animal interface Summary and assessment, 14 Feb [2017] to 16 Mar 2017\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------\n\nA 4-year-old male resident of Menia Governorate, Egypt, had onset of illness on Thu 2 Feb 2017, was hospitalized on Fri 10 Feb [2017] and treated with antivirals for pneumonia. A sample collected on admission tested positive for influenza A(H5N1). The patient recovered and was discharged on Mon 20 Feb [2017]. Prior to his illness, the case had contact with domestic birds in his household.\n\nIn addition, a 48-year-old man from Fayoum Governorate had onset of illness on Fri 10 Feb 2017, was hospitalized on Wed 15 Feb [2017] and treated with antivirals for pneumonia. A sample collected on admission tested positive for influenza A(H5N1). The patient developed severe disease and passed away on Fri 24 Feb [2017]. Prior to his illness, the case had contact with sick and dead backyard poultry.\n\nInvestigation and follow up of contacts of the 2 cases took place for 14 days with no further cases reported. Avian influenza A(H5N1) viruses are enzootic in poultry in Egypt.\n\nSince 2003, a total of 858 laboratory-confirmed cases of human infection with avian influenza A(H5N1) virus, including 453 deaths, have been reported to WHO from 16 countries .\n\n----------------------------------\nDate: Tue 7 Mar 2017\nSource: EMRO Influenza update [edited]\nhttp://www.emro.who.int/surveillance-forecasting-response/surveillance-news/influenza-update-february-2017.html\n\n\nIn the WHO Eastern Mediterranean Region, influenza activity remained low in February, based on data received. All seasonal influenza sub-types were detected in the Region. In Qatar, moderate activity was reported for the predominant sub-type influenza A(H1N1)pdm09\n\nInfluenza activity by sub-type\n------------------------------\nEgypt reported 2 human cases caused by avian influenza A(H5N1) a 45-year-old man (dead) and a 4-year-old child from 2 governorates.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[WHO has corrected the age of the 2nd patient through a corrected version available on;http://www.who.int/influenza/human_animal_interface/Influenza_Summary_IRA_HA_interface_03_16_2017.pdf?ua=1. - Mod.UBA]\n\n******\n[2] FAO reports\nDate: Mon 27 Feb 2017\nSource: FAO [edited]\n\n\nFAO posted reports of confirmations on 2 fatal cases on Mon 27 Feb 2017, but both cases have observation dates from 1st week of February.\n\n5 Feb 17\n--------\nhttp://empres-i.fao.org/empres-i/2/obd?idOutbreak=224262&rss=tFAYOUM\n\n1 Feb 17\n--------\nhttp://empres-i.fao.org/empres-i/2/obd?idOutbreak=224264&rss=t\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/55.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Source: WHO Monthly Risk Assessment Summary [edited]\nhttp://www.who.int/influenza/human_animal_interface/Influenza_Summary_IRA_HA_interface_03_16_2017.pdf?ua=1\n\n\nInfluenza at the human-animal interface Summary and assessment, 14 Feb [2017] to 16 Mar 2017\n-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- \nEgypt reported 2 human cases caused by avian influenza A(H5N1) a 45-year-old man (dead) and a 4-year-old child from 2 governorates. AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (40): EGYPT (FAYOUM), H5N1, COMMENTS\n***********************************************************\n --------\nhttp://empres-i.fao.org/empres-i/2/obd?idOutbreak=224264&rss=t\n\n--\n The following comments were received in response to the RFI on ProMED post; Avian influenza, human (27): Egypt (Fayoum) H5N1, RFI 20170227.4866795\n\n******\n \n\nA 4-year-old male resident of Menia Governorate, Egypt, had onset of illness on Thu 2 Feb 2017, was hospitalized on Fri 10 Feb [2017] and treated with antivirals for pneumonia. \n\nInfluenza activity by sub-type\n------------------------------ Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< In addition, a 48-year-old man from Fayoum Governorate had onset of illness on Fri 10 Feb 2017, was hospitalized on Wed 15 Feb [2017] and treated with antivirals for pneumonia. Since then, 4 outbreaks have been notified; see latest follow-up report on 10 Jul 2017 at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?reportid=24127\n\nIn Africa, HPAI subtype H5N8 has been reported in Cameroon, Democratic Republic of the Congo, Egypt, Niger, Nigeria, Tunisia, Uganda, and Zimbabwe (http://www.fao.org/ag/againfo/programmes/en/empres/H5N8/situation_update.html). - Mod.CRD]\n\n******\n[2] Myanmar (Tanintharyi Region), H5N1, poultry\nDate: Sat 28 Feb 2015\nSource: OIE, WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database), weekly disease information 2017; 30(30) [edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=24401\n\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza, Myanmar\n------------------------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 25 Jul 2017 from Dr Ye Tun Win, Chief Veterinary Officer Director General, Livestock Breeding and Veterinary Department, Ministry of Livestock and Fisheries, Nay Pyi Taw, Myanmar\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 16 Jul 2017\nDate of pre-confirmation of the event: 23 Jul 2017\nReason for notification: reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 6 Apr 2016\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory (basic, advanced), necropsy\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1 (A / 1476 / 17 / I / OG): We kyun htein thit, Dawei, Dawei, Tanintharyi Region\nDate of start of the outbreak: 16 Jul 2017\nOutbreak status: continuing (or resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: farm\nTotal animals affected:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered\nBirds / 5000 / 3194 / 3194 / 1806 / 0\nAffected population: Lohman layers, 3 months, 5 months and 12 months old. Clinical signs are diarrhea, anorexia, drop in egg production, and sudden death.\n\nOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBirds / 63.88 / 63.88 / 100 / 100\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n** Not calculated because of missing information\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\nEpidemiological comment: Lack of bio security of the farm and a small holder has an illegal processing place located in front of the farm\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: movement control inside the country, surveillance outside containment and / or protection zone, surveillance within containment and / or protection zone, quarantine, stamping out, zoning, disinfection, vaccination prohibited, no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nYangon Diagnostic Laboratory (national laboratory) / Birds / rapid test / 23 Jul 2017 / Positive\nYangon Diagnostic Laboratory (national laboratory) / Birds / real-time PCR / 23 Jul 2017 / Positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreaks can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\nCommunicated The event was reported according to Iran passive surveillance in place.\n2. A post-outbreak investigation to trace the source of infection is ongoing to detect the probable spread and circulation of the subtype. 3. Active surveillance is ongoing.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: screening, disinfection/disinfestations, quarantine, stamping out, official disposal of carcasses, by-products and waste, surveillance within containment and/or protection zone, control of wildlife reservoirs, zoning, vaccination prohibited, no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: surveillance outside containment and/or protection zone\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nCentral Veterinary Laboratory of Iran Veterinary Organization (national laboratory) / Birds / real-time reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RRT-PCR) / 16 Jan 2017 / Positive\nExperimental Zooprophylactic Institute (IZS), Venezie (Italy) (OIE Reference Laboratory) / Birds / gene sequencing / 18 Apr 2017 / positive\nExperimental Zooprophylactic Institute (IZS), Venezie (Italy) (OIE Reference Laboratory) / Birds / real-time reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RRT-PCR) / 18 Apr 2017 / positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. ["2017-03-24 00:00:00", "2017-01-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-24 00:00:00", "2017-01-15 00:00:00", "2015-03-24 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Venezie", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Italy", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "WAHID", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "http://healthmap.org/promed/p/128", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4898451", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (74): Viet Nam (CB, HT) backyard, HPAI H5N1, H5N6, spread", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4898451", "date": "2017-03-13 18:09:21", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (74): VIET NAM (CAO BANG, HA TINH) BACKYARD, HPAI H5N1, H5N6, SPREAD\n************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 13 Mar 2017\nSource: Xinhua via Global Times [edited]\nhttp://www.globaltimes.cn/content/1037467.shtml\n\n\nViet Nam reported outbreaks of avian flu H5N1 and H5N6 in northern Cao Bang province, the National Institute of Hygiene and Epidemiology (NIHE) said on Monday [13 Mar 2017].\n\nAccordingly, in 34 households in Quoc Toan community, Cao Bang's Tra Linh district, and one household in Cao Bang City's Song Bang ward, massive deaths of chickens due to unknown causes were recorded, the local Tien Phong (Pioneer) newspaper reported.\n\nLocal animal health officials took samples and sent them to the NIHE for test. The test results showed that dead poultry in Tra Linh district were positive for avian influenza H5N1, while those in Cao Bang City were positive for the H5N6 strain.\n\nCao Bang's authorities have culled a total of 4015 chickens and 18 doves as well as sterilized poultry cages and the surrounding environment in 2 virus-hit areas.\n\nThe province has over 330 km of shared border with China, where avian influenza H7N9 virus has been detected.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Two new HPAI H5N1 outbreaks have been reported this week by Viet Nam to the OIE; one, as reported above, in Cao Bang and the other one in Ha Tinh. The respective follow-up report No 4 was submitted on 12 Mar 2017 and is available with map at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=23195. This H5N1 event had started on 14 Feb 2017, so far causing 9 outbreaks spread throughout the country from north to south (see map at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?fupser=&dothis=&reportid=22895).\n\nThe HPAI H5N6 outbreak, reported above, in the northern province Cao Bang, close to China's border, has been duly reported to the OIE in follow-up report No 1, submitted on 12 Mar 2017, available with map at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=23197.\n\nNo human cases have been reported, though both HPAI serotypes H5N1 and H5N6 are known to be zoonotic. For WHO's risk assessment of H5N6, please see 20161212.4689184. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/152.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nThe HPAI H5N6 outbreak, reported above, in the northern province Cao Bang, close to China's border, has been duly reported to the OIE in follow-up report No 1, submitted on 12 Mar 2017, available with map at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=23197. \n\nAccordingly, in 34 households in Quoc Toan community, Cao Bang's Tra Linh district, and one household in Cao Bang City's Song Bang ward, massive deaths of chickens due to unknown causes were recorded, the local Tien Phong (Pioneer) newspaper reported. "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4939832", "date": "2017-03-31 19:29:01", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (87): VIET NAM, BACKYARD, HPAI H5N1, H5N6, CONTROL\n******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 30 Mar 2017\nSource: VnEspress international [edited]\nhttp://e.vnexpress.net/news/news/vietnam-destroys-2-500-ducklings-smuggled-from-china-as-bird-flu-scare-looms-3563131.html\n\n\nOfficials in Vietnam's northern province of Quang Ninh have disposed of more than 2500 ducklings which were seized in a smuggled cargo from China, Vietnam News Agency said.\n\nThe ducklings, estimated to cost more than VND17 million (USD 750), were seized from a Vietnamese truck [Wed 29 Mar 2017] and the driver said they were taken in from China but failed to produce any legal transaction documents, the report cited market inspectors in Quang Ninh as saying.\n\nThe driver, who also owns the shipment, has been fined VND8 million (USD 351.60) while the ducklings were buried, the report said.\n\nVietnamese laws stipulate that any illegal goods have to be destroyed by crushing or burning. Last year [2016], Quang Ninh customs made global headlines when they destroyed around half a ton each of live cats and chickens smuggled from China.\n\nThe Vietnamese government has ordered strict control over poultry smuggling across the land border with China, where the deadly bird flu virus H7N9 has been rampaging.\n\nBird flu outbreaks in poultry have recurred in Vietnam in recent months. The H5N1 virus is active in Mekong Delta's Can Tho City, its neighbor Hau Giang Province and the central province of Ha Tinh while the nearby Quang Tri Province is dealing with a H5N6 virus outbreak, the government said in a statement earlier this week [week of Sun 26 Mar 2017].\n\nA locality is defined as free of bird flu if no new infection is detected within 21 days.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Viet Nam currently experiences the spread of 2 avian influenza virus strains, affecting backyard poultry holdings throughout the country: HPAI H5N1 and HPAI H5N6.\n\nThe HPAI H5N1 event has been subject to an immediate notification and 7 follow-up reports. The most recent reports were submitted on 22, 25 and 28 Mar 2017, adding 4 new outbreaks to the previous 9, bringing the total to 13. A map showing their respective locations throughout the country, from the Chinese border in the north to the country's southern tip, is available at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?fupser=&dothis=&reportid=22895\n\nSince the start of the HPAI H5N6 event on Sun 12 Feb 2017, 3 outbreaks were reported, all in backyard poultry holdings. The most recent one, in the central province Quang Tri, reportedly started on Thu 9 Mar 2017. The locations of all 3 are presented in the interactive map at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?fupser=&dothis=&reportid=22899.\n\nNo human cases have been reported, though both HPAI serotypes H5N1 and H5N6 are known to be zoonotic. For WHO's risk assessment of H5N6, please see 20161212.4689184. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/1024.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n A map showing their respective locations throughout the country, from the Chinese border in the north to the country's southern tip, is available at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?fupser=&dothis=&reportid=22895\n\nSince the start of the HPAI H5N6 event on Sun 12 Feb 2017, 3 outbreaks were reported, all in backyard poultry holdings. \n\nThe ducklings, estimated to cost more than VND17 million (USD 750), were seized from a Vietnamese truck [Wed 29 Mar 2017] and the driver said they were taken in from China but failed to produce any legal transaction documents, the report cited market inspectors in Quang Ninh as saying. 30(09) [edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=23016\n\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza, Nepal\n----------------------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 25 Feb 2017 from Dr Bimal Kumar Nirmal, Doctor, Department of Livestock Services, DGA openRR, Nepal, Nepal\n\nSummary:\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 17 Feb 2017\nDate of confirmation of the event: 22 Feb 2017\nReason for notification: reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 22 May 2017\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory (basic and advanced), necropsy\nThis event pertains to the whole country.\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1: Khalte masina, Pokhara Sub Metropolitan city-18, Gandaki [Kaski]\nDate of start of the outbreak: 17 Feb 2017\nOutbreak status: resolved on 25 Feb 2017\nEpidemiological unit: backyard\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nBirds / 395/ 98 / 98 / 297 / 0\nAffected population: chicken and ducks reared under a backyard system.\n\nOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBirds / 24.81 percent / 24.81 percent / 100 percent / 100 percent\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\nEpidemiological comments: ducks reared under a backyard system started to show torticollis and greenish white diarrhea and died. Chicken reared in the same premises also died acutely without showing any prominent clinical signs. Premises adjoining to the affected household also showed the similar symptoms with few deaths.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: movement control inside the country, screening, disinfection/disinfestation, quarantine, surveillance outside containment and/or protection zone, stamping out, official destruction of animal products, official disposal of carcasses, by-products and waste, surveillance within containment and/or protection zone, vaccination prohibited, no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type: Central veterinary laboratory (national laboratory)\nSpecies / Test / Test date / Result\nBirds / rapid tests / 22 Feb 2017 / Positive\nBirds / real-time PCR / 23 Feb 2017 / Positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In February 2014, Nepal reported an event of HPAI, subtype H5N1. Only an outbreak was reported in the province of Koshi. In their final report sent on 25 May 2014, Nepal declared that, 'After the completion of stamping out operation, surveillance activities were intensified outside the zone and throughout the country. During the period, morbidity and mortality in poultry were investigated; samples collected were tested for avian influenza virus. All samples were negative for HPAI H5N1. Therefore, Nepal declares itself free from HPAI H5N1 with effect from 22 May 2014.'
