23:35:38", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (27): EGYPT (FAYOUM) H5N1, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n*************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 25 Feb 2017\nSource: Flu Diary [edited]\nhttp://afludiary.blogspot.fr/2017/02/egypt-conflicting-media-reports-of.html\n\n\nAfter a record-setting 2015, where Egypt reported 136 H5N1 cases (39 deaths), 2016 saw only 10 cases (and 3 deaths) reported. The reasons behind this welcomed drop are not clear, but it should be noted that several studies have suggested that the majority of avian flu cases are never identified and reported (see EID Journal: H5N1 in Egypt).\n\nToday we have several Arabic media reports of a supposedly fatal case of avian flu (subtype not provided, but probably H5N1) in Fayoum, and at least 1 report from the Fayoum health department stating they had not received an official report.\n\nThe 1st report, from Youm7.com [Sat 25 Feb 2017]:\n\nDr. Jamal Sami governor of Fayoum, said in a special statement for the '7th day,' he demanded of Veterinary Medicine and the Department of Health to maintain an urgent report on the incident and the death of infected citizens by bird flu on [Sat 25 Feb 2017], and procedures that have been followed for Immunization and to eliminate the epicenter of the disease.\n\nThe Undersecretary of the Ministry of Health in Fayoum, Dr. Hisham El Shenawi, announced the death of the 1st cases of bird flu in 2017; a patient named O.A.M. (48 years-old) from the village of 'compromise' Senoras Center. He pointed out that he was attended Status General Hospital suffering from symptoms of a cold and high temperature, and was transferred to a hospital in Fayoum where samples were obtained and sent to laboratory in central Cairo. With the results proving bird flu, he was transferred to the Abbasid Fever, where he died.\n\nThe 2nd report, from VetoGate.com [Sat 25 Feb 2017]:\n\nDr. Hisham Shenawi, Undersecretary of the Ministry of Health in Fayoum, said he had not yet received a report on the death of A.A.B.M. (48 years-old), who died of bird flu, according to the statements of Veterinary Medicine Department in the governorate.\n\nThe victim was hit by a rise in temperature and shortness of breath, and went to the Chest Hospital where he remained 3 days. His samples were sent for analysis and confirmed a positive case after which he was transferred to the Abbasid Hospital and pronounced dead there.\n\nHis body was flown to his home village on [Fri 24 Feb 2017] night, where the Veterinary Medicine Department of the Committee was sent to deal with the sterilization of the area around the poultry farm.\n\nWhile this sounds like a probable case, hopefully they will get this sorted out and reported to the WHO shortly.\n\n[Byline: Michael Coston]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This is the 1st report on a suspected fatal case from Egypt in 2017, both reports refer to the same case. However, the information available from these media reports appears contradictory [i.e., the 1st report refers to the 48-year-old patient as O.A.M. and the 2nd report refers to the patient as A.A.B.M. - Mod.ML]. Any further updates to clarify the actual situation would be highly appreciated. - Mod.UBA\n\nMaps of Egypt can be seen at http://www.geoatlas.com/medias/maps/countries/egypt/eg3r92t/egypt_pol.jpg. - CopyEd.AO\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/58406.]", "summary": "The 1st report, from Youm7.com [Sat 25 Feb 2017]:\n\nDr. Jamal Sami governor of Fayoum, said in a special statement for the '7th day,' he demanded of Veterinary Medicine and the Department of Health to maintain an urgent report on the incident and the death of infected citizens by bird flu on [Sat 25 Feb 2017], and procedures that have been followed for Immunization and to eliminate the epicenter of the disease. (48 years-old), who died of bird flu, according to the statements of Veterinary Medicine Department in the governorate. Cambodia\n---------------------------------------\nInformation received on 31 Jan 2017 from Dr Sen Sovann, OIE Delegate/Deputy Secretary General, Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries, Phnom Penh, Cambodia\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 25 Jan 2017\nDate of confirmation of the event: 27 Jan 2017\nReason for notification: Reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 12 May 2016\nManifestation of disease: Clinical disease\nCausal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory (basic, advanced), necropsy\nThis event pertains to the whole country.\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1: Bayarb, Basak, Svay Chrum, Svay Rieng\nDate of start of the outbreak: 25 Jan 2017\nOutbreak status: resolved on 31 Jan 2017\nEpidemiological unit: backyard\nTotal animals affected:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nBirds / 390 / 68 / 68 / 322 / 0\nAffected population: Backyard poultry.\n\nOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBirds / 17.44 / 17.44 / 100 / 100\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\nEpidemiological comments: On 25 Jan 2017, after having received a report from a poultry owner declaring that the poultry were sick and dead, the National Animal Health and Production Research Institute (NAHPRI) and Provincial Veterinary teams went to the village to investigate and take samples. At the time, 3 local chicken samples were taken and sent to the NAHPRI for diagnosis. The sample test result was confirmed positive for H5N1.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: movement control inside the country; disinfection/disinfestation; dipping/spraying for control of vectors or parasites; stamping out; official disposal of carcasses, by-products and waste; vaccination prohibited; no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nNational Animal Health and Production Research Institute (National laboratory) / Birds / anatomo-pathological examination / 27 Jan 2017 / Inconclusive\nNational Animal Health and Production Research Institute (National laboratory) / Birds / real-time PCR / 27 Jan 2017 / Inconclusive\nInstitute Pasteur in Cambodia (Regional Reference Laboratory) / Birds / real-time PCR / 27 Jan 2017 / Positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\nThe location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The previous event of HPAI subtype H5N1 was notified on 4 May 2016; only an outbreak was reported in the province of Kampot. 30(03) [edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=22498\n\n\nHighly pathogenic influenza A viruses (infection with) (non-poultry including wild birds), Bangladesh\n---------------------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 21 Jan 2017 from Dr H.B.M Golam Mahmud, Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM), Director, Livestock Research Institute, Ministry of Fisheries and Livestock, Dhaka, Bangladesh\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 15 Jan 2017\nDate of confirmation of the event: 18 Jan 2017\nReason for notification: reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 4 Apr 2016\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: highly pathogenic influenza A virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory (basic and advanced)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country.\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1: Rajshashi Medical College Campus, Sadar, Rajshahi\nDate of start of the outbreak: 15 Jan 2017\nOutbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: other\nTotal animals affected:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nHouse crow: _Corvus splendens_ (Corvidae) / - / 17 / 17 / 0 / 0\nAffected population: The event started on 15 Jan 2017 and is still continuing as of 21 Jan 2017. One outbreak with HPAI was already detected in house crows last year (February 2016).\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Unknown or inconclusive\nEpidemiological comments: The surveillance is continuing in the affected premises and adjacent poultry farms.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: disinfection/disinfestation; dipping/spraying; surveillance outside containment and/or protection zone; official disposal of carcasses, by-products and waste; surveillance within containment and/or protection zone; vaccination permitted (if a vaccine exists); no treatment of affected animals\n\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\nThe location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] HPAI H5N1, poultry (Dhaka)\nDate: Sat 21 Jan 2017\nSource: OIE, WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database), weekly disease information 2017\nReason for notification: reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 4 Apr 2016\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory (basic and advanced)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country.\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal unit: farm\nTotal animals affected:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nBirds / 3000 / 3000 / 732 / 2268 / 0\nAffected population: On 16 Jan 2017, a poultry farm (Sonali type poultry, Age: 15 weeks) infected with highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) was reported by the livestock authority, and the birds were culled on the same day by burial method with proper disinfection.\n\nOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBirds / 100 / 24.40 / 24.40 / 100\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Unknown or inconclusive\nEpidemiological comments: Surveillance and monitoring in the infected farm is continuing.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: disinfection/disinfestation; dipping/spraying; surveillance outside containment and/or protection zone; stamping out; official disposal of carcasses, by-products and waste; surveillance within containment and/or protection zone; vaccination permitted (if a vaccine exists); no treatment of affected animals\n\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nNational Reference Laboratory for Avian Influenza (national laboratory) / Birds / real-time PCR / 16 Jan 2017 / Positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\nThe location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[On 1 Feb 2016, Bangladesh also reported an outbreak of highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) subtype H5N1 in the same division (Rajshahi). The affected species was also crows. The event was declared resolved on 4 Feb 2016. The source of infection was said to be 'eating of city waste.' The event summary and map are available at\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?reportid=19727\n\nAll outbreaks of HPAI (highly pathogenic avian influenza) reported from 1 Jan 2016 to date (23 Jan 2017) can be seen on the interactive map at http://tinyurl.com/husgawz (click on the section of interest on the map, and zoom in).\n\nThe Sonali breed is a cross-breed of Rhode Island Red cocks and Fayoumi hens and has a similar phenotypic appearance to that of local chickens; it was introduced in 1996-2000 in northern parts of Bangladesh http://www.thepoultrysite.com/articles/3523/can-the-sonali-chicken-crossbreed-improve-the-poultry-industry-in-bangladesh/.\n\nMaps of Bangladesh can be seen at http://www.ezilon.com/maps/images/asia/political-map-of-Bangladesh.gif. - Mod.CRD\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/14503.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Epidemiological unit: other\nTotal animals affected:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nHouse crow: _Corvus splendens_ (Corvidae) / - / 17 / 17 / 0 / 0\n Measures applied: disinfection/disinfestation; Culling was done after samples of some guinea fowls tested positive for H5N1 avian influenza virus,' said an official of district bird flu control room.\n\nAfter the culling operation carried out at the centre run by 'Sarva Dharma Rakshak Seva Trust', and to stop the bird flu from spreading, the city police issued a notification declaring the 1 km [approx 0.62 mi] area surrounding the centre as 'Affected Zone' while 10 km [approx 6.2 mi] area has been declared as 'Alert Zone'.\n\nWith this order, people are barred from taking out any birds, eggs or any machinery outside the farm. In addition, people are prohibited from going inside the farm. Police have also banned the sale and consumption of poultry products in 10 km [approx 6.2 mi] area.\n\nOn 4 Jan 2017, over 1400 birds kept at a rescue centre run by Asha Foundation in Hathijan area on the outskirts of the city, were culled after authorities found symptoms of bird flu in 7 guinea fowl, which had died under mysterious circumstances.\n\nEarlier on 2 Jan 2017, residents living near Vastral area caught a truck driver when he was off-loading over 800 guinea fowl near SP Ring Road. While 700 of these poultry birds were taken to Asha Foundation, around 150 were sent to Memnagar based rescue centre.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Odisha, India\nDate: Sun 15 Jan 2017\nSource: Odisha Sun Times [edited]\nhttp://odishasuntimes.com/2017/01/15/bird-flu-in-odisha-capital-as-crows-test-positive-for-h5n1/\n\n\nThe deadly H5N1 virus has appeared in Odisha capital [Bhubaneswar] as blood samples of dead crows have tested positive for the avian influenza [virus]. The samples were sent to the National Institute of High Security Animal Diseases (NIHSAD), Bhopal. Around 53 crows were found dead in Bhubaneswar in the last 2 weeks following which blood samples of some crows and poultry were sent to NIHSAD for H5N1 test.\n\nHowever, chicken sample test reports have not come yet and there is no evidence of suspected death of chickens. Therefore, denizens of Bhubaneswar can eat chicken and egg without any hesitation, informed an official of Fisheries and Animal Resources Development Department (FARDD), Odisha.\n\nAccording to a senior official of FARDD, blood samples of dead crows sent from Panposh in Sundargarh district, Saliasahi in Bhubaneswar and ward no 2 in Baripada Municipal Corporation, were confirmed for bird flu (H5N1) virus. Test reports of chicken and cranes have not come yet.\n\nThe state Housing and Urban Development (H&UD) department has issued a notification to take precautionary measures after bird flu was confirmed in Sundargarh, Bhubaneswar and Baripada. It has directed to burn carcass of crows and cranes found in the state and to administer preventive vaccine to poultry. Besides, it has asked to send blood samples of crows and cranes to the Animal Disease Research Institute at Phulnakhara on the outskirts of Odisha capital keeping the local veterinary doctor informed.\n\n'No chicken has been detected with bird flu in Bhubaneswar and we have not received death case of any chicken in the city,' said Bhubaneswar sub-divisional veterinary officer Dr Balaram Sahu. 'We are administering preventive vaccine to chickens as a precautionary measure and to date, 5000 chickens have been vaccinated,' he added.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In 2016, 3 outbreaks of HPAI H5N1 were detected in India, in poultry farms in January and May, and in crows in December (in Odisha). Since November 2016, also subtype H5N8 has been reported in India. - Mod.PMB\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/142.]", "summary": "\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In 2016, 3 outbreaks of HPAI H5N1 were detected in India, in poultry farms in January and May, and in crows in December (in Odisha). Germany\n-------------------------------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 7 Dec 2016 from Dr Karin Schwabenbauer, ministerial dirigentin and chief veterinary officer, Directorate of Animal Health, Animal Welfare, [Federal Ministry of Food, Agriculture and Consumer Protection] (BMELV), Bonn, Germany.\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 30 Nov 2016\nDate of confirmation of the event: 2 Dec 2016\nReason for notification: reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: March 2014\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: Low pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory (advanced), necropsy\nThis event pertains to the whole country.\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks:\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1 (16-015-00532): Oberkramer, Oberhavel, Brandenburg\nDate of start of the outbreak: 30 Nov 2016\nOutbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: farm\nTotal animals affected:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed\nBirds / 621 / 8 / 0 / 621 / 0\nAffected population: 154 hens, 76 geese, 172 ducks, 219 other birds\n\nOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]:\nSpecies / morbidity rate / mortality rate / case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBirds / 1.29 / 0 / 0 / 100\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\n\nEpidemiological comments: All poultry have been culled and safely disposed of. No poultry or poultry products have been dispatched. This low pathogenic avian influenza outbreak is not connected to highly pathogenic avian influenza outbreaks recently notified in Germany.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: movement control inside the country; screening; disinfection/disinfestations; traceability; quarantine; surveillance outside containment and/or protection zone; stamping out; official destruction of animal products; official disposal of carcasses, by-products and waste; surveillance within containment and/or protection zone; control of wildlife reservoirs; zoning; vaccination prohibited; no treatment of affected animals\n\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nFriedrich-Loeffler Institute (national laboratory) / birds / real-time PCR / 2 Dec 2016 / Positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[On 23 Nov 2016, Germany reported a finding of LPAI associated with an H5N2 subtype. around the outbreak.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: screening; disinfection/disinfestations; traceability; stamping out; vaccination permitted (if a vaccine exists); no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type: ANSES National Reference Laboratory for Avian Influenza, Ploufragan (national Nepal\n----------------------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 10 Mar 2017 from Dr Bimal Kumar Nirmal, Doctor, Department of Livestock Services, DGA open RR, Nepal\n\nSummary:\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 1 Mar 2017\nDate of confirmation of the event: 8 Mar 2017\nReason for notification: new strain of a listed disease in the country\nCausal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N8\nNature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory (basic and advanced), necropsy\nThis event pertains to the whole country.\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1: Itahari-12, Santitole, Khanar, Sunsari, Koshi\nDate of start of the outbreak: 1 Mar 2017\nOutbreak status: resolved on 10 Mar 2017\nEpidemiological unit: farm\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nBirds / 6200 / 3650 / 3650 / 2550 / 0\nAffected population: 40-weeks and 20-weeks old commercial layers birds reared in 2 different sheds.\n\nOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBirds / 58.81 / 58.81 / 100 / 100\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\nEpidemiological comments: A total of 2550 birds, 412 eggs, 200kg of food, 2213 egg trays and 26 local hens have been destroyed and disposed of by the Rapid Response Team. Stamping out, cleaning and disinfection and sealing of infected premises have been completed. Post-operative surveillance outside the containment area is ongoing.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: movement control inside the country, screening, disinfection/disinfestation, quarantine, surveillance outside containment and/or protection zone, stamping out, official destruction of animal products, official disposal of carcasses, by-products and waste, surveillance within containment and/or protection zone, vaccination prohibited, no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type: Central veterinary laboratory (national laboratory)\nSpecies / Test / Test date / Result\nBirds / rapid tests / 7 Mar 2017 / Positive\nBirds / real-time PCR / 8 Mar 2017 / Positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\nCommunicated Koshi\nDate of start of the outbreak: 2 Mar 2017\nOutbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: natural park\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nWhooper Swan: _Cygnus Cygnus_(Anatidae) / 14 / 6 / 6 / 0 / 0\nAsian Openbill: _Anastomus oscitans_(Ciconiidae)/ 1 / 1 / 1 / 0 / 0\nAffected population: Swans and storks (Harkhor) kept in a mini zoo within a community-based recreational park.\n\nOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nWhooper Swan: _Cygnus Cygnus_(Anatidae) / 42.86/ 42.86 / 100 / 42.86\nAsian Openbill: _Anastomus oscitans_(Ciconiidae) / 100 / 100 / 100 / 100\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\nEpidemiological comments: Within the mini zoo under the TalTalaiya community-based recreational park, there were different species of animals (monkey, leopard, jackal, rabbit, guinea pig, and deer) and birds (swans and storks). No mortality in animals. The park is surrounded by a large area of forest. There was high movement of people to the park. Therefore, it has been closed by the committee at this moment. Proper cleaning and disinfection of the shed was done with burial of dead birds. Post-operative surveillance is ongoing.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: movement control inside the country, screening, disinfection/disinfestation, quarantine, surveillance outside containment and/or protection zone, stamping out, official destruction of animal products, official disposal of carcasses, by-products and waste, surveillance within containment and/or protection zone, vaccination prohibited, no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type: Central veterinary laboratory (national laboratory)\nSpecies / Test / Test date / Result\nAsian Openbill / rapid tests / 6 Mar 2017 / Positive\nAsian Openbill / real-time PCR / 6 Mar 2017 / Positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. 09:05:36", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (84): BHUTAN (CHHUKHA) BACKYARD POULTRY, HPAI H5N1, OIE\n***********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 24 Oct 2016\nSource: OIE, WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database), weekly disease information 2016; 29(43) [edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=21337\n\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza, Bhutan\n-----------------------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 24 Oct 2016 from Dr Tashi Samdup, Director General, Department of Livestock, Ministry of Agriculture and Forests, Thimphu, Bhutan\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 10 Oct 2016\nDate of confirmation of the event: 20 Oct 2016\nReason for notification: reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: November 2016\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: laboratory (basic and advanced)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1: Alubari, Wangkha, Babcho, Chhukha\nDate of start of the outbreak: 10 Oct 2016\nOutbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: backyard\nTotal animals affected:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nBirds / 3000 / 13 / 13 / 61 / 0\nAffected population: backyard poultry in one household.\nOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]:\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBirds / 0.43 / 0.43 / 100 / 2.47\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\nEpidemiological comment: the outbreak has occurred in a backyard, free-ranging poultry population. While interviewing the owners of the birds, none of them mentioned source of infection. Further investigation on the source of infection will be followed-up. Only a small number of birds in an isolated pocket were affected. No further infection in flocks in close proximity was detected.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: movement control inside the country; screening; disinfection/disinfestations; dipping/spraying; quarantine; stamping out; zoning; vaccination prohibited; no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nNational Centre for Animal Health, Serbithang, Thimphu (national laboratory) / Birds / real-time PCR / 13 Oct 2016 / Positive\nNational Institute of High Security Animal Diseases (NIHSAD), Bhopal, India (OIE's reference laboratory) / Birds / real-time PCR / 20 Oct 2016 / Positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In 2015, Bhutan reported an outbreak of highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) subtype H5N1. The event was declared resolved on 23 Nov 2015. Zoo officials have said tests on 2 of the carcasses had confirmed H5N1 avian influenza. The other bodies have also been sent for testing.\n\nThe zoo curator said that the zoo was only shut as a precautionary measure and would reopen in a few days. Curator, Riaz Khan, told reporters that the casualties included ducks, pelicans and painted storks.\n\nDelhi's zoo is one of the biggest in India, and has an estimated 2.2 million visitors every year.\n\nThis incident marks the 2nd time the Delhi zoo has been shut over a health scare this year [2016]. In May [2016], it was closed for a few days after 46 of its spotted deer died of rabies.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Several H5N1 outbreaks were reported in India earlier this year and in 2015, involving mainly poultry. AVIAN INFLUENZA (81): H5N1, INDIA, DELHI ZOO\n********************************************\n \n\nThe zoo curator said that the zoo was only shut as a precautionary measure and would reopen in a few days. \n\nThis incident marks the 2nd time the Delhi zoo has been shut over a health scare this year [2016].", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "rabies"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2016-03-24 00:00:00", "2021-05-24 00:00:00", "2015-03-24 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "India", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "ZOO", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "INDIA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Delhi", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4554039", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (63): Egypt, H5N1", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4554039", "date": "2016-10-13 04:56:45", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (63): EGYPT, H5N1\n****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 10 Oct 2016\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/egypt-reports-10-human-h5n1-avian-influenza-cases-in-first-nine-months-of-2016/\n\n\nEgypt has reported 356 human cases of avian influenza A(H5N1) since March 2006, including 121 deaths, according to the World Health Organization (WHO) Eastern Mediterranean Region Office (EMRO). During the 1st 9 months of 2016, 10 cases have been reported. 4 of the patients died from the dangerous viral disease.\n\nAs Avian Flu Diary notes:\nAlthough Egypt leads the world with 356 H5N1 cases, that number must be taken with a sizable grain of salt, as only the 'sickest of the sick' are ever hospitalized and tested for the virus.\n\nWe know that H5N1 can sometimes present with mild or moderate symptoms, and so the assumption is some unknown number of cases go uncounted.\n\nAlthough only 10 cases reported this year [2016] is heartening the true scope of Egypt's avian flu problem remains largely unknown.\n\nH5N1 is a type of influenza virus that causes a highly infectious, severe respiratory disease in birds, called avian influenza (or 'bird flu'). Human cases of H5N1 avian influenza occur occasionally, but it is difficult to transmit the infection from person to person. When people do become infected, the mortality rate is about 60 per cent.\n\nAlmost all cases of H5N1 infection in people have been associated with close contact with infected live or dead birds, or H5N1-contaminated environments. The virus does not infect humans easily, and spread from person to person appears to be unusual.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[As only the hospitalized cases are included in the official reported numbers, the actual number of cases remains unknown, so we do not know how many 'mild' or asymptomatic cases are out there. - Mod.UBA\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/55.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[As only the hospitalized cases are included in the official reported numbers, the actual number of cases remains unknown, so we do not know how many 'mild' or asymptomatic cases are out there. \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\nH5N1 is a type of influenza virus that causes a highly infectious, severe respiratory disease in birds, called avian influenza (or 'bird flu'). Although only 10 cases reported this year [2016] is heartening the true scope of Egypt's avian flu problem remains largely unknown. "event_date": ["2016-03-24 00:00:00", "1980-03-24 00:00:00", "2015-03-24 00:00:00", "2016-01-01 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "WAHID", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Vientiane", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Laos", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LAOS", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4547262", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (62): Indonesia, H5N1 sero-prevalence", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4547262", "date": "2016-10-09 22:09:43", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (62): INDONESIA, H5N1 SERO-PREVALENCE\n************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 7 Oct 2016\nSource: J Infect Dis. [edited]\nhttp://jid.oxfordjournals.org/content/early/2016/10/06/infdis.jiw478.short?rss=1\n\n\nSeroevidence for High Prevalence of Subclinical Infection with Avian Influenza A(H5N1) Virus among Workers in a Live Poultry Market in Indonesia\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nBackground. In Indonesia, highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N1) virus has become endemic in poultry, and has caused sporadic deadly infections in human. Since 2012 we have conducted fixed-point surveillance of avian influenza viruses at a live poultry market in East Java, Indonesia. In this study we examined the seroprevalence of the virus infection among market workers.\n\nMethods. Sera were collected from 101 workers in early 2014 and examined for antibody activity against avian A(H5N1) Eurasian lineage virus by hemagglutination inhibition (HI) assay.\n\nResults. By the HI assay, 84 percent of the sera tested positive for antibody activity against the avian virus. Further analysis revealed the average HI titer in 2014 to be 2.9-fold higher than in 2012 and that seroconversion occurred in 44 percent of paired sera (11/25) between 2012 and 2014. A medical history survey was carried out in 2016; responses to questionnaires indicated that none of workers had suffered from severe acute respiratory illness during 2013.\n\nConclusions. This study provides evidence of a high prevalence of avian A(H5N1) virus infection in 2013 among workers of a live poultry market. However no instances of hospitalizations were reported, we can therefore conclude the virus did not manifest any clinical symptoms in workers.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The article titled 'Seroevidence for High Prevalence of Subclinical Infection with Avian Influenza A(H5N1) Virus among Workers in a Live Poultry Market in Indonesia' by Shimizu et al can be accessed at the above URL.\n\nThe 1st human cases in Indonesia occurred in July 2005. By then, Indonesia was the worst affected country, with more than 150 reported human cases to date and a case-fatality rate of around 83 percent [http://www.tm.mahidol.ac.th/seameo/2010-41-5/09-4850.pdf].\n\nA field study by van Beest Holle et al in 2007 did not find evidence of antibodies against avian influenza A(H5N1) among West Java poultry farmers, despite recent reports of H5N1 outbreaks among poultry in the area. This finding was consistent with other Asian studies that found limited seropositivity among poultry farmers exposed to H5N1-virus since 2004 [http://www.tm.mahidol.ac.th/seameo/2010-41-5/09-4850.pdf].\n\nStudies by another group in Bangladesh [http://journals.plos.org/plosone/article?id=10.1371/journal.pone.0073200] also showed that despite exposure to sick poultry, no farm or market poultry workers were seropositive for HPAI H5N1 virus antibodies while Chi Dung et al have reported overall seroprevalence of 6.1 percent with the highest proportion (7.2 percent) in poultry market workers in Hanoi, and the majority of seropositive subjects (70.3 percent) were slaughterers or sellers of poultry [https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4318972/].\n\nAmong serological assays, hemagglutination inhibition (HI) assay has been the main method used to investigate/document exposure related immune responses to influenza viruses. However, microneutralization tests (MNT) have been shown to be more sensitive and more specific for various influenza viruses [https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/21146560]. Furthermore, maximum sensitivity (80 percent) and specificity (96 percent) for the detection of anti-H5 antibody in adults aged 18 to 59 years have been shown by using the microneutralization assay combined with Western blotting [http://jcm.asm.org/content/37/4/937.full?view=long&pmid=10074505].\n\nThe results of the study described in this manuscript are based on data from paired sera taken 2 years apart and tested using HI test only and show definitive evidence of an immunological response in the farm workers. It would be interesting to compare the data if these samples are tested using MNT. - Mod.UBA\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/184.]", "summary": "\n\nStudies by another group in Bangladesh [http://journals.plos.org/plosone/article?id=10.1371/journal.pone.0073200] also showed that despite exposure to sick poultry, no farm or market poultry workers were seropositive for HPAI H5N1 virus antibodies while Chi Dung et al have reported overall seroprevalence of 6.1 percent with the highest proportion (7.2 percent) in poultry market workers in Hanoi, and the majority of seropositive subjects (70.3 percent) were slaughterers or sellers of poultry A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nA field study by van Beest Holle et al in 2007 did not find evidence of antibodies against avian influenza A(H5N1) among West Java poultry farmers, despite recent reports of H5N1 outbreaks among poultry in the area. This study provides evidence of a high prevalence of avian A(H5N1) virus infection in 2013 among workers of a live poultry market. \n\nThe results of the study described in this manuscript are based on data from paired sera taken 2 years apart and tested using HI test only and show definitive evidence of an immunological response in the farm workers. Virus among Workers in a Live Poultry Market in Indonesia\n Furthermore, maximum sensitivity (80 percent) and specificity (96 percent) for the detection of anti-H5 antibody in adults aged 18 to 59 years have been shown by using the microneutralization assay combined with Western blotting [http://jcm.asm.org/content/37/4/937.full?view=long&pmid=10074505]. AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (62): INDONESIA, H5N1 SERO-PREVALENCE\n************************************************************\n Virus among Workers in a Live Poultry Market in Indonesia' by Shimizu et al can be accessed at the above URL. In Indonesia, highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N1) virus has become endemic in poultry, and has caused sporadic deadly infections in human. By the HI assay, 84 percent of the sera tested positive for antibody activity against the avian virus. Since 2012 we have conducted fixed-point surveillance of avian influenza viruses at a live poultry market in East Java, Indonesia.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2016-03-24 00:00:00", "2013-03-24 00:00:00", "2004-03-24 00:00:00", "2005-07-24 00:00:00", "2014-03-24 00:00:00", "2012-03-24 00:00:00", "2007-03-24 00:00:00", "2062-03-24 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Hanoi", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bangladesh", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "East Java", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "West Java", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Indonesia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4534319", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (76): Viet Nam (CM) backyard, HPAI H5N1, OIE", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4534319", "date": "2016-10-04 08:04:25", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (76): VIET NAM (CA MAU) BACKYARD, HPAI H5N1, OIE\n****************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 2 Oct 2016\nSource: OIE, WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database), weekly disease information 2016; 29(40) [edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=21126\n\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza, Viet Nam\n-------------------------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 2 Oct 2016 from Dr Dong Pham Van, director general, chief veterinary officer, Department of Animal Health, Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development, Hanoi, Viet Nam\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 25 Sep 2016\nDate of confirmation of the event: 28 Sep 2016\nReason for notification: reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 23 May 2016\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: laboratory (advanced)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1: Khanh Binh Dong, Khanh Binh Dong, Tran Van Thoi, Ca Mau\nDate of start of the outbreak: 25 Sep 2016\nOutbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: backyard\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nBirds / 800 / 500 / 300 / 5000 / 0\n\nOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBirds / 62.50 / 37.50 / 60 / 100\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: vaccination in response to the outbreak(s); The outbreaks were located in the provinces of Ca Mau, Nghe An, Ha Tinh, Ba Ria-Vung Tau, Tra Vinh, and Can Tho. That event was resolved on 23 May 2016. The final report for this event was sent to the OIE on 10 Jun 2016. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreaks can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) subtype H5N1 continues to spread in West and Central Africa. Since 2015, countries that have reported the disease are Burkina Faso, Cameroon, Cote d'Ivoire, Ghana, Niger, Nigeria, and now Togo.\n\nAccording to the OIE WAHID database only Burkina Faso has reported the HPAI outbreak that started in February 2015 as resolved. The final report was sent to the OIE on 12 Aug 2016. See report at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/temp/reports/en_fup_0000020749_20160816_163621.pdf\n\nThe rest of the affected countries in the region continue to fight the disease. In July (2016), FAO (UN Food and Agriculture Organization) called for increased vigilance in the region and communicated that they are 'working closely with the World Health Organization (WHO) and the World Organisation for Animal Health (OIE) to offer member-countries assistance, such as risk assessments, contingency planning, technical advice and laboratory material. FAO is also helping with investigating potential avian influenza cases in animals and humans and locating the source of infection' (http://www.fao.org/news/story/en/item/424832/icode/. 29(34) [edited]\n Date of start of the event: 18 Aug 2016\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1971-03-24 00:00:00", "2016-03-24 00:00:00", "2015-01-01 00:00:00", "2021-07-24 00:00:00", "2016-08-25 00:00:00", "2016-08-12 00:00:00", "2015-03-24 00:00:00", "2015-02-24 00:00:00", "2009-01-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Ghana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "WAHID", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4492214", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (61): Cameroon (OU) H5N1, susp", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4492214", "date": "2016-09-17 12:21:08", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (61): CAMEROON (OUEST) H5N1, SUSPECTED\n*************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 15 Sep 2016\nSource: Camer.be [in French, translated Laurence Mialot, edited]\nhttp://camer.be/54575/1%3A13/cameroun-grippe-aviaire-trois-enfants-soupconnes-atteints-cameroon.html\n\n\nAfter the chickens, is it the Mifi's residents' turn to be infected by H5N1? The prefect of the department has been seeking answers. During a meeting that he chaired on Friday, 8 Sep [2016] to raise the poultry farmers' awareness on the importance of respecting measures enacted by the governor of the West [Ouest] region to fight avian flu, the prefect received some news from the livestock, fishing and animal industry's delegate of the 3rd district of Bafoussam.\n\n[The delegate] said that she was tipped off that several chickens died in a farm in the neighborhood of Tocket, belonging to a lady. Only when she visited this farm the next day, she got quite the surprise. The poultry farm was empty. All 600 chickens were gone. The neighbors revealed that the 3 children of the owner had the flu and a chronic cough. No one was at the house. The neighbors informed the delegate that the woman went to Yaounde with her sick children to consult a doctor. It was reported they got infected in Bafoussam and are now in Yaounde for treatment.\n\nThe authorities fear that the symptoms are the result of a transmission of H5N1 from poultry to humans, and that improper care could produce more infections. Joseph Tangwa Fover requested an investigation to find the woman and her sick children, in order to put them in quarantine, and identify the disease. Since last week the flu has made a comeback in the Mifi Department. On Friday, 8 Sep [2016], to fight the flu, the governor of the West region signed a decree containing the following measures: 'ban on the sale of poultry in the markets in all of Mifi'; 'ban on the movement of poultry, products and by-products entering or leaving Mifi'; 'containment of identified households in a 10 km [about 6 mile] radius and strengthening of biosecurity measures.'\n\nThe governor of the West region went one step further. He also ordered: 'slaughter and incineration of all suspicious or infected birds within a 3 km [about 2 mile] radius and burial of carcasses'; 'mandatory disinfection of all identified poultry farms and sites in a 3 km radius and observance of depopulation until further notice'; 'application of practical advice issued by Minepia and/or the Ministry of Health to manage the crisis'; 'all poultry sites to be inspected by veterinary services and health workers'; and finally evaluation on a regular basis of the 'highly pathogenic avian influenza' infection.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Based on information available from the above report, there is not enough epidemiological data on the suspected human cases, which could be flu-like illness resulting from seasonal flu. So we'll have to wait and see.\n\nWith the resurgence of avian flu in West Africa in December 2014 after nearly 7 years, H5N1 has quickly become entrenched in Cameroon, Burkina Faso, Cote d'Ivoire, Ghana, Niger, Togo, and Nigeria: http://afludiary.blogspot.com/2016/09/cameroon-unverified-media-reports-of.html.\n\nIn Cameroon, poultry outbreaks due to H5N1 were reported in May-June 2016 [http://www.voanews.com/a/h5n1-virus-resurfaces-claiming-40-thousand-birds/3358698.html].\n\nWhile no human infections have been reported in West Africa since 2007, there are serious doubts whether the limited medical and surveillance resources in the region would pick up sporadic cases. Even in countries where they are actively looking for avian flu infections, the evidence suggests only a fraction are ever identified [http://afludiary.blogspot.com/2016/01/eid-journal-h5n1-in-egypt.html]. - Mod.UBA\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/10690.]", "summary": "He also ordered: 'slaughter and incineration of all suspicious or infected birds within a 3 km [about 2 mile] radius and burial of carcasses'; 'mandatory disinfection of all identified poultry farms and sites in a 3 km radius and observance of depopulation until further notice'; 'application of practical advice issued by Minepia and/or the Ministry of Health to manage the crisis'; 'all poultry sites to be inspected by veterinary services and health workers'; and finally evaluation on a regular basis of the 'highly pathogenic avian influenza' infection. On Friday, 8 Sep [2016], to fight the flu, the governor of the West region signed a decree containing the following measures: 'ban on the sale of poultry in the markets in all of Mifi'; 'ban on the movement of poultry, products and by-products entering or leaving Mifi'; 'containment of identified households in a 10 km [about 6 mile] radius and strengthening of biosecurity measures.' The neighbors revealed that the 3 children of the owner had the flu and a chronic cough.", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2016-03-24 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 00:00:00", "2007-03-24 00:00:00", "2061-03-24 00:00:00", "2014-12-24 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Ghana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bafoussam", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "West Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Cameroon", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tocket", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nigeria", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4370398", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (56): Egypt, H5N1", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4370398", "date": "2016-07-27 19:33:49", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (56): EGYPT, H5N1\n****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 25 Jul 2016\nSource: CIDRAP [edited]\nhttp://www.cidrap.umn.edu/news-perspective/2016/07/avian-flu-scan-jul-25-2016\n\n\nEgypt recently reported 3 new H5N1 avian flu cases, all in people who had been exposed to poultry or their environments, according to a monthly update from the World Health Organization (WHO) on animal-to-human flu transmission events for the middle of June through the middle of July 2016.\n\nOne of the patients is a 2-year-old boy from Cairo who got sick on 30 May 2016 and whose H5N1 illness was detected as part of flulike illness surveillance. He was hospitalized, treated with antivirals for pneumonia, and recovered. Before he became ill, the boy had visited a family member who raised birds.\n\nThe other 2 are a 30-year-old woman from Menia governorate whose symptoms began on 11 Jun 2016 and an 8-year-old girl from Cairo governorate who got sick on 18 Jun 2016. Both had been exposed to poultry or their environments, were hospitalized with pneumonia, and recovered after antiviral treatment.\n\nThe WHO said no other cases were detected in any of the patients' contacts and that H5N1 is endemic in Egyptian poultry.\n\nSo far, 8 H5N1 cases have been reported globally this year [2016], all of them in Egypt. The WHO said since 2003, 854 cases have been reported, 450 of them fatal, from 16 countries.\n\nIn related developments, the WHO recently noted 7 more H7N9 avian flu cases reported from China on 12 Jul 2016, 4 of them fatal. In a 22 Jul 2016 statement, the WHO said onset dates range from 26 May to 23 Jun 2016, with ages spanning 52 to 68 years.\n\nThe patients were from 6 provinces and cities. Four of the patients are men, and 5 reported exposure to poultry or their environments before they became ill. One worked a market where live poultry is sold. None of the cases reflect human-to-human transmission, the agency said.\n\nMost of the cases had been noted earlier in other official reports from Chinese government agencies, according to FluTrackers, an infectious disease news message board. It put the global total at 800 cases since the 1st human cases were detected in 2012.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Human cases of H5N1 influenza continue to be reported from Egypt sporadically, generally in tandem with backyard or commercial poultry deaths in the surrounding regions and close contact of patients with poultry.\n\nA combination of factors, including recently increased H5N1 circulation in poultry in Egypt, as evidenced by an increased number of outbreak reports, may be partly responsible, along with an increase in the number of small farms and household flocks and lower risk awareness among the public and farmers, which could put people in closer proximity to poultry and create a more favorable environment for virus survival. - Mod.UBA\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/55.]", "summary": "\n\n\nEgypt recently reported 3 new H5N1 avian flu cases, all in people who had been exposed to poultry or their environments, according to a monthly update from the World Health Organization (WHO) on animal-to-human flu transmission events for the middle of June through the middle of July 2016. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Human cases of H5N1 influenza continue to be reported from Egypt sporadically, generally in tandem with backyard or commercial poultry deaths in the surrounding regions and close contact of patients with poultry. \n\nThe other 2 are a 30-year-old woman from Menia governorate whose symptoms began on 11 Jun 2016 and an 8-year-old girl from Cairo governorate who got sick on 18 Jun 2016. A combination of factors, including recently increased H5N1 circulation in poultry in Egypt, as evidenced by an increased number of outbreak reports, may be partly responsible, along with an increase in the number of small farms and household flocks and lower risk awareness among the public and farmers, which could put people in closer proximity to poultry and create a more favorable environment for virus survival. \n\nOne of the patients is a 2-year-old boy from Cairo who got sick on 30 May 2016 and whose H5N1 illness was detected as part of flulike illness surveillance. \n\nSo far, 8 H5N1 cases have been reported globally this year [2016], all of them in Egypt. In related developments, the WHO recently noted 7 more H7N9 avian flu cases reported from China on 12 Jul 2016, 4 of them fatal. \n\nMost of the cases had been noted earlier in other official reports from Chinese government agencies, according to FluTrackers, an infectious disease news message board.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2016-06-23 00:00:00", "2016-05-30 00:00:00", "2012-03-24 00:00:00", "2016-06-11 00:00:00", "2056-03-24 00:00:00", "2016-03-24 00:00:00", "2016-07-12 00:00:00", "2003-03-24 00:00:00", "2016-06-18 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Menia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Egypt", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Cairo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "EGYPT", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4345054", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (63): Iraq (WA) poultry, HPAI H5N1, spread", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4345054", "date": "2016-07-14 15:48:37", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (63): (WASIT) POULTRY, HPAI H5N1, SPREAD\n********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 12 Jul 2016\nSource: Almada Press [in Arabic, trans. Mod.SMA, edited]\nhttp://goo.gl/CjdyAV\n\n\nOn Tue 12 Jul 2016, the Wasit Provincial Council reported cases of bird flu in a number of poultry farms in the areas north of the province (city of Kut) and directed the concerned authorities to destroy more than 2.5 million chickens. They also called on the Ministry of Health to take urgent measures to control the spread of the disease.\n\nThe head of the Agriculture Committee, Hashim al-Awadi, held a press conference in the House of Wasit province, Kut's city center, and stated: 'The health and veterinary authorities recorded cases of infections of bird flu among poultry in farm areas of Essaouira and Aziziyah, north of the province.'\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-MENA\n<promed-mena@promedmail.org>\n\n[There are several additional reports on the event in Iraqi media (eg http://bit.ly/2a18iWF, dated 10 Jul 2016). The Iraqi veterinary services notified the OIE on 25 Apr 2016 an extensive HPAI H5N1 epizootic, spread from the governorate Dohuk on the Turkish border in the north to the southern governorate Al Qadisiyah (see, with a link to the outbreaks map, in post archive no. 20160426.4184541). According to the said OIE report, the event had started on 16 Dec 2015. On 4 May 2016, a follow-up/final report was submitted, claiming the event as resolved (see at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapEventSummary&reportid=20135).\n\nIt remains to be considered if a new epizootic has recently started in Iraq or that the claim on the event resolved was optimistic.\n\nHPAI H5N1 has been reported, during 2016, from eastern Lebanon, adjacent to the Syrian border, reportedly due to 'illegal movement of poultry'. This, and the reports from Iraq, may indicate that the circulation of the virus in Syria - situated between Lebanon and Iraq -- is most likely. Alertness in other countries in the region is essential.\n\nIn Lebanon, an HPAI H5N1 contingency plan, prepared with FAO support in 2007, has been activated. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/8659.]", "summary": "The head of the Agriculture Committee, Hashim al-Awadi, held a press conference in the House of Wasit province, Kut's city center, and stated: 'The health and veterinary authorities recorded cases of infections of bird flu among poultry in farm areas of Essaouira and Aziziyah, north of the province.'\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-MENA\n<promed-mena@promedmail.org>\n\n[There are several additional reports on the event in Iraqi media (eg http://bit.ly/2a18iWF, dated 10 Jul 2016). A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n On Tue 12 Jul 2016, the Wasit Provincial Council reported cases of bird flu in a number of poultry farms in the areas north of the province (city of Kut) and directed the concerned authorities to destroy more than 2.5 million chickens. The Iraqi veterinary services notified the OIE on 25 Apr 2016 an extensive HPAI H5N1 epizootic, spread from the governorate Dohuk on the Turkish border in the north to the southern governorate Al Qadisiyah (see, with a link to the outbreaks map, in post archive no. 20160426.4184541). AVIAN INFLUENZA (63): (WASIT) POULTRY, HPAI H5N1, SPREAD\n********************************************************\n \n\nIt remains to be considered if a new epizootic has recently started in Iraq or that the claim on the event resolved was optimistic. Date: Tue 12 Jul 2016\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2016-03-24 00:00:00", "2063-03-24 00:00:00", "2015-12-24 00:00:00", "2016-07-12 00:00:00", "2016-04-25 00:00:00", "2016-05-04 00:00:00", "2007-03-24 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Lebanon", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Iraq", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Syria", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4383461", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (69): Indonesia, poultry, HPAI H5N1", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4383461", "date": "2016-07-31 22:39:18", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (69): INDONESIA, POULTRY, HPAI H5N1\n***************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 31 Jul 2016\nSource: The Jakarta Post [edited]\nhttp://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2016/07/31/bird-flu-rates-rise-again-in-indonesia.html\n\n\nIndonesia has detected a sharp rise in bird flu cases in July [2016] since the country's last report of an unexpected climb earlier this year, bringing the total number of the cases so far in 2016 to 188.\n\n'The number of bird flu cases has risen in 7 consecutive months since January 2016, with the highest number of cases recorded in April 2016, which is quite alarming. It subsequently fell from May to June 2016, only to rise again this month [July 2016],' Agriculture Ministry official Muhammad Azhar said on Friday [29 Jul 2016].\n\nHe made the comments when explaining the results of the government's monitoring of bird flu trends in 2016 to the audience at a poultry health and production seminar in Jakarta.\n\nAzhar said as many as 92 014 poultry had died as a result of the bird flu virus in the last 7 months. Most of them were ducks and layer poultry, which made up almost 60 percent of the total number. The remainder were quails, free-range village chickens and broilers, he added.\n\nData show that the 3 provinces with the highest number of [outbreaks] are West Java with 65 in total, Lampung with 28 and South Sulawesi with 23 [outbreaks].\n\nAzhar said the highest number of poultry deaths nationwide was recorded in March 2016 with 48 066 deaths, followed by 15 581 in February 2016.\n\nThe following months saw vast improvements, with the number of poultry deaths declining to 9860 in April and to 558 in June 2016. However, the rates rose by more than tenfold in July 2016, with 6550 cases recorded, Azhar said.\n\nAzhar noted that the rainy season, which occurred throughout the 1st few months of the year, might have contributed to the deaths of the birds, which might have been vulnerable given poor farm conditions and sanitation.\n\nHe further said that monitoring by the ministry's officials had revealed that many farms failed to implement biosecurity measures, a framework in quality maintenance of farm and poultry products developed in collaboration with the United Nation's Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) more than a decade ago, after the virus was 1st detected in Indonesia.\n\n[Byline: Liza Yosephine]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A map of Indonesia is available at http://www.ezilon.com/maps/images/asia/political-map-of-Indonesia.gif.\n\nThe numbers of dead birds reported by the ministry are not excessive in relative terms and compared to other countries. This may be indicative of the rather small size of the affected holdings, which are, most probably, not commercial farms.\n\nSince the start of the HPAI H5N1 event in 2003, and as of 28 Jul 2016, human cases have been reported from 16 countries with 854 cases, of which 450 reportedly died. The countries most affected are Egypt (354 cases, 117 deaths), Indonesia (199, 167), Viet Nam (127, 64), Cambodia (56, 37), and mainland China (53, 31). Its incidence in poultry, and subsequently in humans, demonstrates a seasonal pattern. The countries which have reported human cases of avian influenza A(H5N1) during the past 6 months are Egypt and mainland China.\n\nDetailed quantitative information on HPAI H5N1 in poultry by state and month was last reported by Indonesia for the year 2014 (see at http://tinyurl.com/hyxly65, scroll down). According to the report, Indonesia applies vaccination of poultry against the disease. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/184.]", "summary": "\n\n'The number of bird flu cases has risen in 7 consecutive months since January 2016, with the highest number of cases recorded in April 2016, which is quite alarming. \n\nAzhar said the highest number of poultry deaths nationwide was recorded in March 2016 with 48 066 deaths, followed by 15 581 in February 2016. \n\n\nIndonesia has detected a sharp rise in bird flu cases in July [2016] since the country's last report of an unexpected climb earlier this year, bringing the total number of the cases so far in 2016 to 188. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nThe following months saw vast improvements, with the number of poultry deaths declining to 9860 in April and to 558 in June 2016. \n\nAzhar noted that the rainy season, which occurred throughout the 1st few months of the year, might have contributed to the deaths of the birds, which might have been vulnerable given poor farm conditions and sanitation.\n\n It subsequently fell from May to June 2016, only to rise again this month [July 2016],' Agriculture Ministry official Muhammad Azhar said on Friday [29 Jul 2016]. Since the start of the HPAI H5N1 event in 2003, and as of 28 Jul 2016, human cases have been reported from 16 countries with 854 cases, of which 450 reportedly died. \n\nAzhar said as many as 92 014 poultry had died as a result of the bird flu virus in the last 7 months. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A map of Indonesia is available at http://www.ezilon.com/maps/images/asia/political-map-of-Indonesia.gif. He made the comments when explaining the results of the government's monitoring of bird flu trends in 2016 to the audience at a poultry health and production seminar in Jakarta.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2016-03-24 00:00:00", "2056-03-24 00:00:00", "2021-04-24 00:00:00", "2021-07-24 00:00:00", "2016-06-24 00:00:00", "2016-07-24 00:00:00", "2016-04-24 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 00:00:00", "2016-02-24 00:00:00", "2003-03-24 00:00:00", "2016-01-24 00:00:00", "2037-03-24 00:00:00", "2064-03-24 00:00:00", "9860-03-24 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Cambodia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "West Java", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Viet Nam", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Jakarta", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Indonesia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Egypt", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4343176", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (62): West & Central Africa, poultry, HPAI H5N1, spread, FAO", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4343176", "date": "2016-07-13 19:08:19", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (62): WEST AND CENTRAL AFRICA, POULTRY, HPAI H5N1, SPREAD, FAO\n******************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 13 Jul 2016\nSource: FAO press release [edited]\nhttp://www.fao.org/news/story/en/item/424832/icode/\n\n\nCountries across West and Central Africa are on alert as the highly pathogenic avian influenza virus H5N1 continues to spread across the region, with Cameroon becoming the latest African country to detect the disease. The strain can infect and cause death in humans and kills poultry at a high rate.\n\nThe latest H5N1 outbreaks were recently confirmed on chicken farms in Cameroon putting poultry production in the country and its neighbours at high risk. This is the 1st time the disease has been found in Central Africa since 2006.\n\nThis brings the number of countries that have battled bird flu in West and Central Africa to 6, including Burkina Faso, Cote d'Ivoire, Ghana, Niger and Nigeria.\n\nNigeria continues to be most affected, with the total number of outbreaks exceeding 750, with nearly 3.5 million birds dead or culled. The newly recorded outbreaks in Cameroon raise significant concerns that the disease may be advancing southward, triggering national and global emergency responses to contain the disease and health screenings of poultry workers.\n\nFAO, meanwhile, is alerting neighbouring governments to be vigilant and continue their heightened surveillance and prevention efforts, including common messaging to the public and data sharing between the public health and agriculture sectors.\n\n'We're looking at a quickly spreading disease that has devastating effects on livelihoods in communities,' said Abebe Haile Gabriel, FAO Deputy Regional Representative for Africa. 'H5N1 causes major losses of nutritious food and threatens farmers' livelihoods, particularly in resource-poor environments where governments have difficulty providing financial compensation for losses,' he said, adding that 'trade restrictions often pose an additional hardship on already struggling economies.'\n\nThe H5N1 strain of avian influenza has caused the deaths of tens of millions of poultry and losses of tens of billions of USD worldwide since the virus 1st spread internationally in 2013; in Cameroon alone, losses have added up to an estimated USD 20 million, according to local media reports.\n\nFAO is working closely with the World Health Organization (WHO) and the World Organisation for Animal Health (OIE) to offer member-countries assistance, such as risk assessments, contingency planning, technical advice and laboratory material. They also help with investigating potential avian influenza cases in animals and humans and locating the source of infection.\n\nIn Cameroon, FAO is boosting the local veterinary services' capacity to respond rapidly to new outbreaks and is working with the government to finalize an action plan similar to effective plans applied in other countries stricken by the virus.\n\nResponse interventions include culling infected and exposed poultry, disinfecting premises and markets, and safely disposing of dead birds.\n\nVeterinary officers, meanwhile, are encouraged to use basic techniques like 'trace-forward' -- which looks at where infected animals have been sold or moved to -- and 'trace backward' -- examining where infected animals were purchased or where they came from -- to find sources, with the ultimate goal of halting continuous virus introduction or further spread.\n\nA major concern is that the disease may become endemic in the entire region, particularly in Nigeria, where avian influenza has become so entrenched in poultry production and marketing systems that it will be difficult to eliminate.\n\nFor that reason, producers and traders need to be made aware about the clinical signs of the disease symptoms, how and to whom to report it, and implement good hygiene practices to halt its spread.\n\nFAO will continue assisting governments in mobilizing funds to combat H5N1, in addition to the agency's own efforts to help boost local veterinary systems, strengthen laboratories, and deploy FAO specialists to affected and at-risk countries.\n\nThe 1st assessment mission and distribution of equipment in Cameroon was made possible by funding from the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID). FAO is seeking USD 20 million to support its regional response to H5N1.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[OIE's interactive map showing the accumulated outbreaks of HPAI H5N1 reported from southwest Africa since January 2015 is available at http://tinyurl.com/hkepfvp (click on the West-African cluster, zoom in). - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/6075.]", "summary": "\n\nVeterinary officers, meanwhile, are encouraged to use basic techniques like 'trace-forward' -- which looks at where infected animals have been sold or moved to -- and 'trace backward' -- examining where infected animals were purchased or where they came from -- to find sources, with the ultimate goal of halting continuous virus introduction or further spread. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n The H5N1 strain of avian influenza has caused the deaths of tens of millions of poultry and losses of tens of billions of USD worldwide since the virus 1st spread internationally in 2013; in Cameroon alone, losses have added up to an estimated USD 20 million, according to local media reports.
