regional alertness is essential. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/85.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Reason for notification: First occurrence of a listed disease\nManifestation of disease: Clinical disease\nCausal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\n AVIAN INFLUENZA (56): LEBANON (BEQAA) POULTRY, HPAI H5N1, OIE, RESOLVED\n***********************************************************************\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Serotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: Clinical, Laboratory (basic), Laboratory (advanced)\n Farm\nAffected animals:\n This event pertains to: a defined zone within the country\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\n Summary of outbreaks: Total outbreaks: 1\n\nEpidemiology\n Date of start of the event: 20 Apr 2016\n Source: OIE, WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database), weekly disease information 2016; 29 (24) [edited]\n", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2016-03-24 00:00:00", "2016-06-14 00:00:00", "2016-05-10 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Damascus", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Lebanon", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Syria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Beirut", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "WAHID", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LEBANON", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4511967", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (75): Middle East, HPAI H5N1 spread, risk assessment, FAO", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4511967", "date": "2016-09-23 21:07:46", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (75): MIDDLE EAST, HPAI H5N1 SPREAD, RISK ASSESSMENT, FAO\n*************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 23 Sep 2016\nSource: FAO EMPRES Watch Vol 36, September 2016, p 1-8 [summ. Mod.AS, edited]\nhttp://www.fao.org/3/a-i6155e.pdf\n\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza (H5N1 HPAI) spread in the Middle East: risk assessment\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nSummary\n-------\nThis risk assessment provides an estimate of the likelihood of introduction of H5N1 HPAI from recently infected countries (Lebanon and Iraq) to other countries in the Middle East region and neighbouring territories as a result of the movement of live poultry (both legal and illegal), poultry-related products and the migration of wild birds.\n\nThe preliminary assessment based on the available information and uncertainties associated indicate that the risk of introduction of H5N1 HPAI for each of the 9 regional and neighbouring countries or territories varies and is as follows:\n1. High: Iran (Islamic Republic of), Israel, Jordan, the Syrian Arab Republic and Turkey,\n2. Medium: Gaza Strip, Kuwait, Saudi Arabia and The West Bank,\n3. Low: Armenia, Azerbaijan and Georgia,\n4. Negligible: Cyprus.\n\nThe situation in the region is of concern given the existing poultry populations at risk and the potential for spread between countries. Given the presence of civil unrest and active civil war in some countries of the region, investment in agriculture and livestock is reduced, including limitations to public veterinary services. Underreporting of animal disease events is a significant challenge given the lack of reporting systems in those areas with ongoing conflict. It is therefore possible that, in addition to Iraq and Lebanon, the disease is already present in the Syrian Arab Republic. The cause of the recent incursions into the region is currently unknown but a combination of wild birds seeding infection and trade with neighbouring countries is likely. Poultry and poultry-related trade and movements play an important role in national and cross-border spread. The overall risk for the region in terms of potential spread to uninfected countries ranges from negligible to high depending on the country with Iran (Islamic Republic of), Israel, Jordan, the Syrian Arab Republic and Turkey being at highest risk of incursion.\n\nThe current H5N1 HPAI epizootic is expected to have a potential impact on food security, human health and poultry-dependent livelihoods in a region which is already suffering from political unrest and deteriorated public and animal health services.\n\n[Contributors: Caryl Lockhart, Silvia Kreindel, Claudia Pittiglio, Martina Escher, Sophie von Dobschuetz, Ludovic Plee, Elisa Palamara, Mirko Bruni, Juan Lubroth, Julio Pinto and Eran Raizman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The new EMPRES risk assessment includes, on top of the above summary, the following chapters:\nIntroduction; Risk questions; Hazard identification; Risk assessment; Factors contributing to introduction and spread of the virus in the region; Conclusions; Bibliography.\n\nThe following section has been extracted from the conclusions chapter:\n\n'Conclusions\n------------\nSince H5N1 HPAI is a zoonotic virus and therefore constitutes a public health threat, communication among ministries and enhanced surveillance are as important as prompt reporting. The regional risk map [see Fig 5 in the full document, source URL] based on risk factors such as extensive and intensive poultry density, lakes, rivers, estuaries and wetlands highlighted differences in HPAI risk within and between countries in the region.\n\nAreas within Israel, Lebanon, The West Bank and Gaza Strip, and western and northern parts of the Syrian Arab Republic are at high risk for H5N1 HPAI presence if the disease is introduced (i.e. greater than 80 percent).\n\nAreas with lower to medium risk probabilities were distributed across Azerbaijan, Georgia, Iran (Islamic Republic of), Iraq, Jordan, Kuwait and Saudi Arabia. Risk probabilities were driven primarily by extensive poultry density (greater than 80 percent) rather than the presence of lakes or wetlands (0 percent).\n\nIn conclusion, based on both the risk assessment and the risk factor analyses, countries at high risk include Turkey and the Syrian Arab Republic (particularly areas near the Kurdistan region and the western area near the border with Lebanon) and Iran (Islamic Republic of). Given the presence of high poultry production areas and low biosecurity along the Syrian Arab Republic border with Iraq and no information on the HPAI situation in the Syrian Arab Republic due to non-functional veterinary infrastructure, it is likely that H5N1 HPAI virus has already been introduced in poultry populations there, though they have not been reported to date. Iran (Islamic Republic of) is at similar risk judging from anecdotal evidence of informal trade at the Kurdish border with Iran (Islamic Republic of), but unlike the Syrian Arab Republic, the veterinary systems for detection and response are operational. Jordan shares borders with the Syrian Arab Republic and Iraq, and the movement of livestock, including live poultry across borders from the Syrian Arab Republic, is ongoing and is associated with refugee movements.\n\nCountries at medium risk of incursion of H5N1 HPAI include Gaza Strip, Israel, Kuwait, Saudi Arabia and the West Bank. For Gaza Strip, Israel and the West Bank, there is no evidence of substantive trade, either legal or illegal from the affected countries. Additionally, incursions may be mitigated by high security concerns implemented at borders. Kuwait and Saudi Arabia share borders with Iraq and given that the extent of spread in Iraq is not fully discerned, movement of infected live poultry is possible.\n\nArmenia, Azerbaijan and Georgia are located along spring migration pathways for wild birds travelling northwards but the risk of wild birds becoming infected and subsequently seeding viruses to these countries is considered low. The role of live poultry trade is considered low to negligible. The overall risk of introduction of H5N1 into the poultry population is low.\n\nCyprus is considered at negligible risk of incursion from the 2 infected countries given its geographic location (separated by sea), lack of poultry trade and the fact that it is not on the wild bird migratory route.\n\nThere is a high uncertainty on the reliability of available data related to trade, poultry value/marketing chains, poultry production systems, interactions between wild birds and poultry production systems, and local wild water bird species distribution patterns.' - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/12214.]", "summary": "promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The new EMPRES risk assessment includes, on top of the above summary, the following chapters:\nIntroduction; Risk questions; Hazard identification; Risk assessment; Factors contributing to introduction and spread of the virus in the region; Conclusions; Bibliography. This risk assessment provides an estimate of the likelihood of introduction of H5N1 HPAI from recently infected countries (Lebanon and Iraq) to other countries in the Middle East region and neighbouring territories as a result of the movement of live poultry (both legal and illegal), poultry-related products and the migration of wild birds. \n\nThere is a high uncertainty on the reliability of available data related to trade, poultry value/marketing chains, poultry production systems, interactions between wild birds and poultry production systems, and local wild water bird species distribution patterns.' - Mod. The regional risk map [see Fig 5 in the full document, source URL] based on risk factors such as extensive and intensive poultry density, lakes, rivers, estuaries and wetlands highlighted differences in HPAI risk within and between countries in the region. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n In conclusion, based on both the risk assessment and the risk factor analyses, countries at high risk include Turkey and the Syrian Arab Republic (particularly areas near the Kurdistan region and the western area near the border with Lebanon) and Iran (Islamic Republic of). \n\nCyprus is considered at negligible risk of incursion from the 2 infected countries given its geographic location (separated by sea), lack of poultry trade and the fact that it is not on the wild bird migratory route. \n\nThe preliminary assessment based on the available information and uncertainties associated indicate that the risk of introduction of H5N1 HPAI for each of the 9 regional and neighbouring countries or territories varies and is as follows:\n1. \n\nArmenia, Azerbaijan and Georgia are located along spring migration pathways for wild birds travelling northwards but the risk of wild birds becoming infected and subsequently seeding viruses to these countries is considered low. \n\nThe situation in the region is of concern given the existing poultry populations at risk and the potential for spread between countries. The overall risk for the region in terms of potential spread to uninfected countries ranges from negligible to high depending on the country with Iran (Islamic Republic of), Israel, Jordan, the Syrian Arab Republic and Turkey being at highest risk of incursion. [Contributors: Caryl Lockhart, Silvia Kreindel, Claudia Pittiglio, Martina Escher, Sophie von Dobschuetz, Ludovic Plee, Elisa Palamara, Mirko Bruni, Juan Lubroth, Julio Pinto and Eran Raizman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Given the presence of high poultry production areas and low biosecurity along the Syrian Arab Republic border with Iraq and no information on the HPAI situation in the Syrian Arab Republic due to non-functional veterinary infrastructure, it is likely that H5N1 HPAI virus has already been introduced in poultry populations there, though they have not been reported to date. AVIAN INFLUENZA (75): MIDDLE EAST, HPAI H5N1 SPREAD, RISK ASSESSMENT, FAO\n*************************************************************************\n \n\nAreas within Israel, Lebanon, The West Bank and Gaza Strip, and western and northern parts of the Syrian Arab Republic are at high risk for H5N1 HPAI presence if the disease is introduced (i.e. greater than 80 percent).", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1975-03-24 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Gaza Strip", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Syrian Arab Republic", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Azerbaijan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kurdistan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Iran", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the West Bank", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Georgia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Israel", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Iraq", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Turkey", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "area", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Jordan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Lebanon", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Armenia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kuwait", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Saudi Arabia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "RISK ASSESSMENT", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4263450", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (48): Niger (TL) poultry, HPAI H5N1, OIE", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4263450", "date": "2016-06-03 16:59:52", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (48): NIGER (TILLABERI), POULTRY, HPAI H5N1, OIE\n****************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 2 Jun 2016\nSource: OIE, WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database), weekly disease information 2016; 29(22) [edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=20272\n\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza, Niger\n----------------------------------------\nInformation received on 2 Jun 2016 from Dr Ibrahim Bangana, directeur general, Services Veterinaires, Services Veterinaires, Niamey, Niger.\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 21 Feb 2016\nDate of confirmation of the event: 26 May 2016\nReport date: 2 Jun 2016\nReason for notification: reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 2015\nManifestation of disease: clinical infection\nCausal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory (basic), laboratory (advanced), necropsy\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1: Poultry centre, Niamey, Niamey, Tillaberi\nDate of start of the outbreak: 21 Feb 2016\nOutbreak status: resolved 13 Apr 2016\nEpidemiological unit: farm\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nBirds / 86 000 / 86 000 / 86 000 / 0 / 0\nAffected population: ISA Brown layers in 5 pens.\n\nOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBirds / 100 / 100 / 100 / 100\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive; introduction of new live animals; fomites (humans, vehicles, feed, etc.)\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: disinfection/disinfestations; quarantine; surveillance outside containment and/or protection zone; surveillance within containment and/or protection zone; zoning; vaccination prohibited; no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: movement control inside the country; dipping/spraying; official destruction of animals products; official disposal of carcasses, by-products and waste\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nExperimental Zooprophylactic Institute (IZS), Padova (Italy) (OIE Reference Laboratory) / Birds / reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) / 26 May 2015 / Positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) subtype H5N1 continues to spread in West Africa.\n\nAll outbreaks of HPAI reported from 1 Jan 2015 to date can be seen on the interactive map at http://tinyurl.com/gq4ffym (click on the section of interest on the map, and zoom in).\n\nIn April 2015, Niger reported 1 outbreak of HPAI H5N1 in the region of Maradi, located some 664 km [about 413 miles] from the current outbreak. Based on information in follow-up report No 1 dated 27 Jan 2016, as of that date no new outbreaks had occurred. The epidemiological comment in that report stated that 'The promoter of the farm has many activities with Nigeria (purchase of feed, of young chickens, for example)'. The outbreak in Maradi is still showing as 'continuing', and several control measures are being applied. See event summary and updated map at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?reportid=17568.\n\nThe current outbreak of HPAI in Tillaberi was reported to have started at the end of February 2016, but it was confirmed 3 months later at the end of May 2016. Furthermore, even though the country is indicating that the outbreak was resolved 13 Apr 2016, the event is still active. In fact, the report indicates that certain sanitary measures such as 'official destruction of animals products and official disposal of carcasses, by-products and waste' are still to be applied. If, in fact, the outbreak was resolved 6 weeks ago, but disposal of dead birds is still to be accomplished, this should be of concern to both animal and human health.\n\nThe map of Niger can be seen at http://www.nationsonline.org/oneworld/map/niger-political-map.htm. - Mod.CRD\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/679.]", "summary": "no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: movement control inside the country; All were reported within 48 hours and laboratory confirmed within 24 hours through reverse transcriptase-polymerase chain reaction [RT-PCR].\n\nDistribution of outbreaks by location, species, and cases (all destroyed):\nOutbr nr / location / date observ / date report / date lab confirm / species / at risk / cases / deaths / destroyed / slaughtered\n1 / Menia (Elmenia) / 9 May 2016 / 11 May 2016 / 12 May 2016 / chicken / ? / 12 / 0 / 12 / 0\n5 / Fayoum (Mansia) / 11 May 2016 / 13 May 2016 / 14 May 2016 / duck / ? / 40 / 0 / 40 / 0\n6 / Qena (Eldeeb) / 11 May 2016 / 13 May 2016 / 14 May 2016 / chicken / ? / 24 / 0 / 24 / 0\n7 / Qena (Saiada) / 13 May 2016 / 15 May 2016 / 16 May 2016 / chicken / ? / 35 000 / 0 / 35 000 / 0\nTotal: 10 outbreaks in 6 governorates; 36 000 farms animals and 162 backyard birds including 69 chickens, 73 ducks, and 20 turkeys were destroyed.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-MENA\n<promed-mena@promedmail.org>\n\n[The compilation above shows that HPAI H5N1 continues to spread throughout Egypt and hits commercial farms as well as small familial backyard poultry of various species. - Mod.AB\n\nOut of the total world's HPAI H5N1 human cases (850 confirmed so far, of which there have been 449 deaths, since the emergence of HPAI H5N1 in humans in 2003 -- initially in mainland China), Egypt (reporting since 2006) has suffered a total of 350 confirmed human cases, of which 116 reportedly died. Indonesia ranks 2nd, reporting, since 2005, 199 confirmed human cases (of which 167 reportedly died). The 3rd on the list is Viet Nam, with a total of 127 confirmed human cases reported since 2003, of which 64 died (no new human cases reported there since 2015). - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map Cambodia (KP) poultry, HPAI H5N1", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4229595", "date": "2016-05-18 12:16:36", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (44): CAMBODIA (KAMPOT) POULTRY, HPAI H5N1\n**********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 17 May 2016\nSource: The Phnom Penh Post [edited]\nhttp://www.phnompenhpost.com/national/avian-flu-outbreak-kampot-confirmed\n\n\nThe 1st outbreak of H5N1 this year [2016] was confirmed in Kampot province on [10 May 20106], health officials said yesterday [Mon 16 May 2016].\n\nA total of 349 chickens, one duck, and 37 chicken eggs, belonging to 7 families in Chhouk district's Koh Russei village, were culled and burned by health officials to prevent the virus from spreading further, said Chan Rith, provincial agriculture department director.\n\nA total of 4 human cases were also suspected, but blood samples confirmed there was no infection, Rith said.\n\n'We advised the people not to eat the sick or dead animals, and they need to cage the sick animals in a separate place,' he said.\n\n'We will assign experts to monitor [the situation] to make sure that there is no transportation of animals from the nearby areas until we reach 30 days after the outbreak.'\n\nMinistry of Health spokesman Ly Sovann said the ministry will monitor the health of the villagers who were tested for the next 2 weeks.\n\nHe appealed to the public to practice proper hygiene, and not eat or touch sick animals. If a person who has handled an animal comes down with flu symptoms, the person is advised to seek medical attention.\n\n'Bird flu keeps happening rampantly in our country, so precaution is the most important [step],' Sovann said.\n\nA bird flu outbreak last November [2015] in Siem Reap and Battambang provinces saw more than 4000 ducks killed by the virus or culled to prevent further spread.\n\n[Byline: Pech Sotheary]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nEpiCore Surveillance Project member\nJohn T Cathey\n<jt.cathey@gmail.com>\n\n[As a recurrent event after absence of HPAI H5N1 outbreaks in Cambodia since November 2015, Cambodia submitted an immediate notification to the OIE on 17 May 2016. Cameroon\n-------------------------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 27 May 2016 from Dr Gaston Djonwe, directeur des services veterinaires, Services Veterinaires, Ministere de l'Elevage, des Peches & des Industries Animales, Yaounde, Cameroon\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 20 May 2016\nDate of confirmation of the event: 24 May 2016\nReason for notification: reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 12 Mar 2006\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory (advanced)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1: Poultry animals affected:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nBirds / 33 000 / 15 000 / 15 000 / 18 000 / 0\nAffected population: Population of breeders, broilers and layers: 7, 13, 31, 61 and 81 weeks old.\n\nOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBirds / 45.5 / 45. 5 / 100 / 100\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\nEpidemiological comments\nOn Sun 22 May 2016, the epidemiological surveillance network (RESCAM) of the Ministry of Livestock, Fisheries and Animal Industry observed high mortalities in poultry within the breeders rearing facilities of the poultry complex in Mvog Betsi, Yaounde. Epidemiological investigation staff from the veterinary services and the LANAVET laboratory performed sampling for analysis and implemented protective measures according to Law 006 of 16 Apr 2001 on zoo-sanitary standards applying to livestock diseases legally considered as contagious and subjected to compulsory reporting, and to the OIE Terrestrial Animal Health Code.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: movement control inside the country; screening; disinfection/disinfestations; dipping/spraying; quarantine; surveillance outside containment and/or protection zone; stamping out; official disposal of carcasses, by-products and waste; surveillance within containment and/or protection zone; zoning; no vaccination; no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nMilitary Health Research Center (CRESAR) - Cameroon (national laboratory) / Birds / real-time reverse transcriptase-polymerase chain reaction (RRT-PCR) / 26 May 2016 / Positive\nPasteur Centre of Cameroon (national laboratory) / Birds / real-time reverse transcriptase-polymerase chain reaction (RRT-PCR) / 25 May 2016 / Positive\nNational Veterinary Laboratory (LANAVET) (national laboratory) / Birds / real-time reverse transcriptase-polymerase chain reaction (RRT-PCR) / 24 May 2016 / Positive\nNational Veterinary Laboratory (LANAVET) (national laboratory) / Birds / reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) / 24 May 2016 / Positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Given the widespread occurrence of highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) in Nigeria [see ProMED-mail archive list below], it should not be surprising that HPAI has now been reported in neighboring Cameroon.\n\nAn FAO document published by EMPRES Watch (vol 32) in April 2015, titled 'H5N1 HPAI spread in Nigeria and increased risk for neighbouring countries in West Africa', already warned of the risk of spread to bordering countries: 'Traditional trading patterns, both formal and informal, between Nigeria and neighbouring countries provide an opportunity for cross-border or inter-regional disease spread.' See the complete document at http://www.fao.org/3/a-i4561e.pdf.\n\nAll outbreaks of HPAI reported from 1 Jan 2015 to date can be seen on the interactive map at http://tinyurl.com/jo7ws3s (click on the section of interest on the map, and zoom in).\n\nA map of Cameroon can be seen at http://www.nationsonline.org/oneworld/map/cameroon-political-map.htm. - Mod.CRD\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/21718.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n [The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Date of previous occurrence: 12 Mar 2006\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: avian influenza virus\n \n\nOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\n Measures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nMilitary Health Research Center (CRESAR) - Total outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1: Poultry complex of Mvog Besti, Yaound\u00e9 6, Mfoundi, Centre\n AVIAN INFLUENZA (46): CAMEROON (CENTRE) POULTRY, HPAI H5N1, OIE\n***************************************************************\n Serotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory (advanced)\n Measures applied: movement control inside the country; 29(20) [edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=20198\n\n\nInformation received on 17 May 2016 from Dr Sen Sovann, OIE Delegate/Deputy Secretary General, Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries, Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries, Phnom Penh, Cambodia\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 4 May 2016\nDate of confirmation of the event: 10 May 2016\nReason for notification: reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 18 Nov 2015\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory (advanced)\nThis event pertains to the whole country.\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1 (290/MAFF/Prakas): Koh Reussei, Trapaingbey, Chhuk, Kampot\nDate of start of the outbreak: 4 May 2016\nOutbreak status: resolved on 12 May 2016\nEpidemiological unit: backyard\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nBirds / 505 / 155 / 155 / 350 / 0\nAffected population: Local chickens and ducks in the village are affected.\nOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBirds / 30.69 / 30.69 / 100 / 100\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\nEpidemiological comments: On 9 May 2016 after having received a report from a poultry owner, saying that its chickens and ducks were sick or dead, provincial and district veterinarians went there to check and took 5 sick chickens which they sent to the National Veterinary Research Institute for diagnosis. The test result of the National Veterinary Research Institute was positive to H5N1.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: movement control inside the country; disinfection/disinfestation; dipping/spraying; stamping out; vaccination prohibited; no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type:\nNational Veterinary Research Institute (NAVRI) (National laboratory)\nSpecies / Test / Test date / Result\nBirds / anatomo-pathological examination / 10 May 2016 / Positive\nBirds / real-time PCR / 10 May 2016 / Positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\nThe location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Receiving timely information on events such as this one is always of value. However, with the specific case of Cambodia, an answer to a request for information made in posting 20160127.3970770 is still pending. In January 2016 thousands of birds (poultry) died in the province of Kampong Thum. Knowing the results of the epidemiological investigations, the type of laboratory tests used, and whether or not the cause of death was determined would be helpful.\n\nIn 2015, Cambodia reported to the OIE 2 outbreaks of HPAI H5N1. These outbreaks were located in the provinces of Battambang and Siem Reap. That event was resolved on 18 Nov 2015. See event summary and map at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?reportid=19082\n\nMaps of Cambodia can be seen at, http://www.nationsonline.org/oneworld/map/cambodia-political-map.htm. - Mod.CRD\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/145.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Measures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type:\nNational Veterinary Research Institute (NAVRI) (National laboratory)\n Date of previous occurrence: 18 Nov 2015\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\n http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=20198\n\n\nInformation received on 17 May 2016 from Dr Sen Sovann, OIE Delegate/Deputy Secretary General, Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries, Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries, Phnom Penh, Cambodia\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\n Outbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\n Total outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1 (290/MAFF/Prakas): Koh Reussei, Trapaingbey, Chhuk, Kampot\n Serotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory (advanced)\n Affected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\n AVIAN INFLUENZA (43): CAMBODIA (KAMPOT) POULTRY, HPAI H5N1, OIE\n****************************************************************\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Birds / anatomo-pathological examination / 10 May 2016 / Positive\nBirds / real-time PCR / 10 May 2016 / Source: OIE, WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database), weekly disease information 2016; ["unknown"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2016-03-24 00:00:00", "2016-05-12 00:00:00", "2016-05-24 00:00:00", "2016-05-07 00:00:00", "2016-05-01 00:00:00", "2042-03-24 00:00:00", "2016-05-10 "unknown"}, {"location": "Bidar", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "INDIA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4210295", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (41): India (KA) HPAI H5N1, poultry", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4210295", "date": "2016-05-09 12:55:56", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (41): INDIA (KARNATAKA) HPAI H5N1, POULTRY\n**********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 8 May 2016\nSource: The Hindu [edited]\nhttp://www.thehindu.com/news/national/karnataka/bird-flu-alert-sounded-across-karnataka/article8573012.ece\n\n\nAn alert has been sounded across Karnataka, after the outbreak of bird flu [avian influenza] in a privately-owned poultry farm at Melkera village of Humnabad taluk [sub-district] in Bidar district.\n\nA total of 1.5 lakh [150 000] heads of chicken of the private farm will now be culled to prevent the outbreak of avian influenza (H5N1 virus) to rest of the farms and areas.\n\nPoultry farm owners have been instructed to take precautionary measures to prevent infection of chicken with H5N1 virus. In the case of viral infection, scientists have advised farm owners not to sell or move any of the birds/eggs and material out of farm. They have been instructed to adopt adequate bio-security measures.\n\nThe State has around 7000 poultry farms -- both layer and broiler varieties. The farms have stock of more than 5 crore [50 million] birds. The state's daily egg production is about 1.2 crore [12 million], officials of the Animal Husbandry told The Hindu.\n\nMinister for Animal Husbandry, A Manju, who chaired an emergency meeting with top officials of the Department on [Sun 8 May 2016], told presspersons that the outbreak of bird flu was found in the farm owned by Ramesh Gupta. The State Government would provide compensation to the farmer immediately after culling. It was decided to cull all poultry birds within 1-km [0.62 mi] radius of the infected farm.\n\nDoctors and scientists of Institute of Animal Health and Veterinary, Biologicals [IAH&VB], Bengaluru, visited the private farm in Bidar and collected the samples for testing. The samples were tested at National Institute High Security Animal Diseases, Bhopal, and samples tested positive for H5N1, the Minister said.\n\nA team of experts would oversee the process of culling and preventive measures being taken to contain its spread.\n\nA team comprising Joint Director IAH&VB has been constituted to visit [the district] Bidar and take all measures to control and keep ready all the required materials, rapid response team for culling birds, and for sanitation. The Minister said, 'There is no need for panic as there are no others farms in the village.'\n\nThe officials of the Health and Family Welfare Department have appealed to the public not to consume chicken infected with H5N1, since it can be transmitted to humans.\n\nThe farm owners must step-up vigil and surveillance of potential sources of infection, such as indigenous chicken and poultry farm chicken, ducks, and migratory birds.\n\nThe spread of the disease not only entails loss to poultry farmers and the government because of stamping out of infected birds, but also in terms of payment of compensation to farmers and commercial loss in trade, officials said.\n\nFarmers have been told to regularly conduct inspections in the poultry farms and closely monitor the movement of wild and migratory birds, who carry the highly pathogenic H5N1 virus.\n\n[Byline: Nagesh Prabhu]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[India's most recent reported outbreak of HPAI H5N1 dates back to January 2016. It affected a state-run poultry farm of less than 10 000 chickens in the far north eastern state of Tripura, on the border with Bangladesh. The outbreak was controlled by stamping out and declared resolved on 28 Apr 2016.\n\nThe current event is situated thousands of kilometers away, in the Indian State of Karnataka, in the center of southern India. The previous HPAI H5N1 outbreak in this state was reported to the OIE in October 2012; see ProMED-mail post 20121026.1367316, which includes a link to a map showing the location of the outbreak.\n\nThe current outbreak affects a large commercial farm; it is important to trace its origin. Circulation of the virus in small, backyard poultry farms in the Indian subcontinent deserves to be ruled out. - Mod.AS\n\nMaps of India can be seen at http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/16307. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]", "summary": "\n\nThe farm owners must step-up vigil and surveillance of potential sources of infection, such as indigenous chicken and poultry farm chicken, ducks, and migratory birds. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nMinister for Animal Husbandry, A Manju, who chaired an emergency meeting with top officials of the Department on [Sun 8 May 2016], told presspersons that the outbreak of bird flu was found in the farm owned by Ramesh Gupta. \n\nPoultry farm owners have been instructed to take precautionary measures to prevent infection of chicken with H5N1 virus. \n\nFarmers have been told to regularly conduct inspections in the poultry farms and closely monitor the movement of wild and migratory birds, who carry the highly pathogenic H5N1 virus. A total of 1.5 lakh [150 000] heads of chicken of the private farm will now be culled to prevent the outbreak of avian influenza (H5N1 virus) to rest of the farms and areas. An alert has been sounded across Karnataka, after the outbreak of bird flu [avian influenza] in a privately-owned poultry farm at Melkera village of Humnabad taluk [sub-district] in Bidar district. \n\nA team comprising Joint Director IAH&VB has been constituted to visit [the district] Bidar and take all measures to control and keep ready all the required materials, rapid response team for culling birds, and for sanitation. The spread of the disease not only entails loss to poultry farmers and the government because of stamping out of infected birds, but also in terms of payment of compensation to farmers and commercial loss in trade, officials said. In the case of viral infection, scientists have advised farm owners not to sell or move any of the birds/eggs and material out of farm. \n\nThe State has around 7000 poultry farms -- both layer and broiler varieties. \n\nDoctors and scientists of Institute of Animal Health and Veterinary, Biologicals [IAH&VB], Bengaluru, visited the private farm in Bidar and collected the samples for testing. It affected a state-run poultry farm of less than 10 000 chickens in the far north eastern state of Tripura, on the border with Bangladesh.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2016-04-28 00:00:00", "2016-01-24 00:00:00", "2012-10-24 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Bangladesh", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bidar", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "INDIA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Karnataka", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bengaluru", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "India", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4194525", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (37): Ghana (EP,WP) poultry, HPAI H5N1, OIE, spread", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4194525", "date": "2016-04-30 19:09:49", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (37): GHANA (EASTERN, WESTERN), POULTRY, HPAI H5N1, OIE, SPREAD\n*******************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 27 Apr 2016\nSource: The Poultry Site [edited]\nhttp://www.thepoultrysite.com/poultrynews/36944/ghana-reports-first-bird-flu-outbreaks-since-february/\n\n\nTwo outbreaks of H5N1 highly pathogenic avian influenza have been reported in Eastern and Western areas of southern Ghana.\n\nGhana reported its most recent previous outbreak in early February [2016].\n\nThe 2 farms held layers, of which over 2000 died and nearly another 2000 were destroyed. The owner of the closed farm notified abnormal mortality among his birds, in Nabichit -- Bekaa Valley. The farm unit was immediately put under quarantine. Epidemiological investigation and epidemiological sampling are on-going on the area. The National Reference Laboratory identified a highly pathogenic H5N1 strain.\n\nOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]:\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBirds / 25 / 25 / 100 / 100\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: illegal movement of animals.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: disinfection/disinfestations; traceability; dipping/spraying; quarantine; stamping out; official destruction of animal products; official disposal of carcasses, by-products and waste; surveillance within containment and/or protection zone; zoning; vaccination prohibited; no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Egypt, H5N1", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4158642", "date": "2016-04-15 16:42:59", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (37): EGYPT, H5N1\n****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 4 Apr 2016\nSource: WHO Monthly Risk Assessment Summary [edited]\nhttp://www.who.int/influenza/human_animal_interface/HAI_Risk_Assessment/en/\n\n\nIn a monthly update on zoonotic flu strains, the World Health Organization (WHO) recently noted reports of human cases of H5N1, H5N6, and H7N9 avian flu that it received between 25 Feb and 4 Apr [2016], all of which were acknowledged in earlier reports from various official sources.\n\nThe WHO, however, included more details about 4 recent H5N1 patients in Egypt -- all female and 3 of them children, which fits with earlier patterns in the country.\n\nThe 4 Egyptian cases were previously reported but with very few epidemiologic details by the United Nations Food and Agricultural Organization. Health officials have been closely watching developments in Egypt, because the country had an unprecedented surge of cases at about this time last year [2015].\n\nTwo of the H5N1 patients are from Giza governorate, a 70-year-old woman who is in critical condition and a 5-year-old girl who recovered. A 1-year-old girl in Sohag governorate and a 7-year-old girl in Cairo have also recovered. The 3 girls were exposed to live or dead poultry, while the investigation into the virus source is still under investigation for the older woman, the WHO said.\n\nSince 2003 the agency has recorded 850 H5N1 infections, 449 of them fatal, in 16 countries.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Most A(H5) influenza human cases have history of exposure through contact with infected poultry or contaminated environments, including live poultry markets. Since the viruses continue to be detected in animals and environments, further human cases can be expected. Even though small clusters of A(H5N1) virus infections have been reported previously, including those involving healthcare workers, current epidemiological and virological evidence suggests that the A(H5) viruses are still essentially avian and have not acquired the ability of sustained transmission among humans. - Mod.UBA\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/55.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nTwo of the H5N1 patients are from Giza governorate, a 70-year-old woman who is in critical condition and a 5-year-old girl who recovered. AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (37): EGYPT, H5N1\n****************************************\n", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2003-03-24 00:00:00", "2037-03-24 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "EGYPT", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Egypt", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "A(H5", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Cairo", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4114052", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (33): Egypt (JZ) H5N1", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4114052", "date": "2016-03-23 13:24:15", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (33): EGYPT (GIZA) H5N1\n**********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 22 Mar 2016\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/egypt-reports-4th-human-h5n1-avian-influenza-case-2nd-from-giza-76084/\n\n\nAn individual from Giza, Egypt is the 4th confirmed human H5N1 avian influenza case reported in 2016, according to a report from the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO). This is the 2nd case reported from Giza; the others were reported in Sohag and Cairo. This follows a record year in H5N1 cases in Egypt in 2015, when more than 160 cases were seen.\n\nSince the 1st human cases were recorded in 2003, the World Health Organization puts the global total 846 cases and 449 deaths as of [25 Feb 2016].\n\nH5N1 is a type of influenza virus that causes a highly infectious, severe respiratory disease in birds called avian influenza (or 'bird flu'). Human cases of H5N1 avian influenza occur occasionally, but it is difficult to transmit the infection from person to person. When people do become infected, the mortality rate is about 60 per cent.\n\nAlmost all cases of H5N1 infection in people have been associated with close contact with infected live or dead birds, or H5N1-contaminated environments. The virus does not infect humans easily, and spread from person to person appears to be unusual.\n\n[byline: Robert Herriman]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[With the latest H5N1 case, the total number of confirmed cases in Egypt since 2003 now stands at 348, and the global total is 848 (449 confirmed deaths as of last WHO update, dated 25 Feb 2016 http://www.who.int/influenza/human_animal_interface/2016_02_25_tableH5N1.pdf?ua=1).\n\nAccording to a WHO EMRO region report published 15 May 2015 (http://www.emro.who.int/egy/egypt-news/upsurge-h5n1-human-poultry-cases-may-2015.html), 'The recent increase in the number of people affected by the avian influenza virus H5N1 in Egypt is not related to virus mutations, but rather to more people becoming exposed to infected poultry, according to a recent mission of 6 organizations assessing the H5N1 situation in the country. Since November 2014 to 30 Apr 2015, the period analysed by the international mission, a total of 165 cases, including 48 deaths were reported. This is by far the highest number of human cases ever reported by a country over a similar period. There are indications that H5N1 is circulating in all sectors of poultry production and in all parts of Egypt.'\n\n(Maps of Egypt can be seen at http://www.geoatlas.com/medias/maps/countries/egypt/eg3r92t/egypt_pol.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/8480.\n\nGiza is the 3rd-largest city in Egypt. It is located on the west bank of the Nile, some 20 km (12.43 miles) south west of central Cairo. - Mod.UBA]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n According to a WHO EMRO region report published 15 May 2015 (http://www.emro.who.int/egy/egypt-news/upsurge-h5n1-human-poultry-cases-may-2015.html), 'The recent increase in the number of people affected by the avian influenza virus H5N1 in Egypt is not related to virus mutations, but rather to more people becoming exposed to infected poultry, according to a recent mission of 6 organizations assessing the H5N1 situation in the country. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[With the latest H5N1 case, the total number of confirmed cases in Egypt since 2003 now stands at 348, and the global total is 848 (449 confirmed deaths as of last WHO update, dated 25 Feb 2016 http://www.who.int/influenza/human_animal_interface/2016_02_25_tableH5N1.pdf?ua=1). \n\n[byline: Robert Herriman]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\nSince the 1st human cases were recorded in 2003, the World Health Organization puts the global total 846 cases and 449 deaths as of [25 Feb 2016]. \n\nH5N1 is a type of influenza virus that causes a highly infectious, severe respiratory disease in birds called avian influenza (or 'bird flu'). 29(18) [edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=20124\n\n\nLow pathogenic avian influenza [LPAI] (poultry), United States of America\n---------------------------\nInformation received on 2 May 2016 from Dr John Clifford, deputy administrator, Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, United States Department of Agriculture, Washington, USA\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 26 Apr 2016\nDate of confirmation of the event: 30 Apr 2016\nReason for notification: reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 2016\nManifestation of disease: sub-clinical infection\nCausal agent: low pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: laboratory (advanced)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country.\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks:\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1: Jasper County, Jasper, Missouri\nDate of start of the outbreak: 26 Apr 2016\nOutbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: farm\nTotal animals affected:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nBirds / 39 000 / - / 0 / 39 000 / 0\nAffected population: commercial turkey flock\n\nOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBirds / ** / 0 / ** / 100\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n** Not calculated because of missing information\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\n\nEpidemiological comment\nThe USDA Animal Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) and the Missouri Department of Agriculture are conducting a comprehensive epidemiological investigation and have implemented enhanced surveillance and testing related to this event. Samples were initially collected from healthy, non-clinical turkeys as part of the routine, pre-slaughter surveillance that is done under the National Poultry Improvement Plan (NPIP) Avian Influenza Clean Program (H5 and H7). Through this routine surveillance, H5N1 low pathogenic avian influenza (LPAI) of North American wild bird lineage was identified and confirmed by partial HA/NA sequence. HA sequence is 98% similar to A/mallard/Ohio/11OS2229/2011(H5); amino acid sequence = NIPQRETR/GLFGAI. NA sequence is 99% similar to A/blue-winged teal/Louisiana/UGAI14-2494/2014(N1).\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: movement control inside the country; quarantine; stamping out; surveillance within containment and/or protection zone; zoning; vaccination prohibited; no treatment of affected animals\n\nMeasures to be applied: disinfection/disinfestations; official disposal of carcasses, by-products and waste\n\nDiagnostic test results:\nLaboratory name and type:\nNational Veterinary Services Laboratories (NVSL) (national laboratory)\nSpecies / Test / Test date / Result\nBirds / real-time reverse transcriptase/polymerase chain reaction (RRT-PCR) / 30 Apr 2016 / Positive\nBirds / virus sequencing / 30 Apr 2016 / Positive\nBirds / virus isolation / - / Pending\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\nThe location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The following information was obtained from the USDA's fact sheet on 'Avian Influenza' (updated April 2015) available at http://www.usda.gov/documents/usda-avian-influenza-factsheet.pdf\n\n'There are 2 types of avian influenza (AI) that are identified as H5N1. A difference exists in the virus classification; one is low pathogenic (LPAI) and the other is highly pathogenic (HPAI). Pathogenicity refers to the ability of the virus to produce disease. HPAI H5N1, often referred to as the Asian H5N1, is the type causing worldwide concern. LPAI H5N1, often referred to as the North American H5N1, is of less concern.\n\nLPAI H5N1 (North American H5N1): LPAI, or 'low path' AI, commonly occurs in wild birds. In most cases, it causes minor sickness or no noticeable signs of disease. It is rarely fatal in birds. LPAI strains are not known to be a human health concern. This includes LPAI H5N1. Evidence of LPAI H5N1 has been found in wild birds in the United States in recent years and is not closely related to the more severe HPAI H5N1 circulating overseas. Examples of historical reports of LPAI H5N1 received by USDA include:\n\n1975 - LPAI H5N1 was detected in a wild mallard duck and a wild blue goose in Wisconsin as part of routine sampling, not as a result of noticeable illness in the birds.\n\n1981 and 1985 - the University of Minnesota conducted a sampling procedure in which sentinel ducks were monitored in cages placed in the wild for a short period of time, and LPAI H5N1 was detected in those ducks in both years.\n\n1983 - LPAI H5N1 was detected in ring-billed gulls in Pennsylvania.\n\n1986 - LPAI H5N1 was detected in a wild mallard duck in Ohio as part of routine sampling, not as a result of noticeable illness in the birds.\n\n2002 - LPAI H5N1 antibodies were detected in turkeys in Michigan but the virus could not be isolated; therefore, this detection could not be confirmed.\n\n2005 - LPAI H5N1 was detected in ducks in Manitoba, Canada.\n\n2006 - LPAI H5N1 was confirmed in 2 Michigan mute swans and mallard ducks; Maryland resident wild mallard ducks, and Pennsylvania wild mallard ducks; and Delaware green-winged teals, all sampled as part of USDA's expanded avian influenza surveillance.\n\nIn the past, there was no requirement for reporting or tracking LPAI H5 or H7 detections in wild birds so states and universities tested wild bird samples independently of USDA. Because of this, the above list of previous detections might not be all inclusive of past LPAI H5N1 detections. However, the World Organization for Animal Health (OIE), from 2006, changed its requirement of reporting detections of avian influenza. Now, all confirmed LPAI H5 and H7 AI subtypes must be reported to the OIE because of their potential to mutate into highly pathogenic strains. Therefore, USDA now tracks these detections in wild birds, backyard flocks, commercial flocks and live bird markets.' - Mod.CRD\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/227.]", "summary": "Measures applied: movement control inside the country; quarantine; stamping out; surveillance within containment and/or protection zone; zoning; vaccination prohibited; no treatment of affected animals\n\nMeasures to be applied: disinfection/disinfestations; official disposal of carcasses, by-products and waste\n\nDiagnostic test results:\nLaboratory name and type:\nNational Veterinary Services Laboratories (NVSL) (national laboratory)\n A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \nInformation received on 2 May 2016 from Dr John Clifford, deputy administrator, Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, United States Department of Agriculture, Washington, USA\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\n Summary of outbreaks:\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1: Jasper County, Jasper, Missouri\n Affected population: commercial turkey flock\n\nOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\n \n\n2006 - LPAI H5N1 was confirmed in 2 Michigan mute swans and mallard ducks; Maryland resident wild mallard ducks, and Pennsylvania wild mallard ducks; and Delaware green-winged teals, all sampled as part of USDA's expanded avian influenza surveillance.\n\n Date of previous occurrence: 2016\nManifestation of disease: sub-clinical infection\n AVIAN INFLUENZA (39): USA (MISSOURI) POULTRY, LPAI H5N1, OIE\n************************************************************\n Total animals affected:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\n Serotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: laboratory (advanced)\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Examples of historical reports of LPAI H5N1 received by USDA include:\n\n1975 - LPAI H5N1 was detected in a wild mallard duck and a wild blue goose in Wisconsin as part of routine sampling, not as a result of noticeable illness in the birds. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The following information was obtained from the USDA's fact sheet on 'Avian Influenza' (updated April 2015) available at http://www.usda.gov/documents/usda-avian-influenza-factsheet.pdf\n\n'There are 2 types of avian influenza (AI) that are identified as H5N1. Source of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\n\nEpidemiological comment\n \n\nNew outbreaks (1)\n Causal agent: low pathogenic avian influenza virus\n Pending\n\nFuture of routine sampling, not as a result of noticeable illness in the birds.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2006-03-24 00:00:00", "1981-03-24 00:00:00", "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4068066", "date": "2016-03-04 19:50:32", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (22): VIET NAM (TRA VINH) POULTRY, HPAI H5N1, SPREAD, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n*********************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 3 Mar 2016\nSource: The Poultry Site [edited]\nhttp://www.thepoultrysite.com/poultrynews/36675/more-bird-flu-found-in\n\n\nAnother outbreak of highly pathogenic avian influenza has been discovered in village poultry in Viet Nam.\n\nOver 700 birds died and a further 300 were destroyed as a result of the H5N1 outbreak in Tra Vinh province.\n\nViet Nam is using vaccination as a measure to try and contain the disease.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The HPAI H5N1 outbreak in Tra Vinh mentioned above was reported to the OIE on 26 Feb 2016 in follow-up report no. 6, available with 'The figure is based on reports which we have received. It could be higher,' he was quoted by the newspaper.\n\nHe said his agency had ordered the Sidenreng Rappang Husbandry Agency to isolate the area affected by the H5N1 virus to prevent the spread of the disease.\n\nAbdul Aziz claimed the province was low in stocks of the vaccine and no longer had any medicine. The agency required a further one million doses of the vaccine as the province was home to about 10 million poultry, he said.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps of Indonesia can be seen at http://www.ezilon.com/maps/images/asia/political-map-of-Indonesia.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/562.\nFor a map of South Sulawesi (in Indonesian, Sulawesi Selatan) a province of the island of Sulawesi, see http://tinyurl.com/zeru4yv.\n\nSince the start of the HPAI H5N1 event in 2003, human cases have been reported from 16 countries with 846 cases, of which 449 reportedly died. The countries most affected are Indonesia (199 cases, 167 deaths), Egypt (346, 116), Viet Nam (127, 64), Cambodia (56, 37), and Mainland China (53, 31). Its incidence in poultry, and subsequently in humans, demonstrates a seasonal pattern.\n\nDetailed quantitative information on HPAI H5N1 in poultry, by state and month, has last been reported by Indonesia for the year 2013 (see at http://tinyurl.com/jpar6dp). According to the report, vaccination is applied. - Mod.AS]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Source: BorneoPost Online [edited]\nhttp://www.theborneopost.com/2016/04/02/bird-flu-hits-south-sulawesi-in-indonesia/\n\n\nBird flu has struck the Sidenreng Rappang regency, South Sulawesi and as of yesterday [Fri 1 Apr 2016], the avian flu virus is reported to have killed about 11 000 birds, mostly ducks.
