29(07) [edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=19727\n\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza, Bangladesh\n---------------------------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 15 Feb 2016 from Dr Jatindra Nath Das, director, Research Institute, Department of Livestock Services, Ministry of Fisheries and Livestock, Dhaka, Bangladesh\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 1 Feb 2016\nDate of confirmation of the event: 15 Feb 2016\nReason for notification: reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: June 2014\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory (basic and advanced)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country.\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1: Rajshahi city, Sadar, Rajshahi, Rajshahi\nDate of start of the outbreak: 1 Feb 2016\nOutbreak status: resolved 4 Feb 2016\nEpidemiological unit: not applicable\nTotal animals affected:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nHouse crow: _Corvus splendens_ (Corvidae) / - / 40 / 40 / 0 / 0\nAffected population: on 4 Feb 2016, the notice of crow deaths was reported to the livestock authority. It was primarily diagnosed as H5 on 10 Feb 2016 and confirmation of H5N1 was given on 15 Feb 2016 by the National Reference Laboratory for Avian Influenza.\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: eating of city waste\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: no vaccination; no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nNational Reference Laboratory for Avian Influenza (national laboratory) / House crow / real-time PCR / 15 Feb 2016 / Positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The report states that the source of infection was 'eating of city waste'. If the crows did in fact become infected with and died from H5N1 due to eating contaminated garbage, then the virus must likely be circulating extensively in the country. Based on Bangladesh's last available OIE annual report (January-December 2014; http://tinyurl.com/z2no972), HPAI was reported as being limited to certain zones of the country.\n\nAlthough West Nile fever has never been officially reported by the country, it would be of interest if this disease was considered in the differential diagnosis of this event. - Mod.CRD\n\nMaps of Bangladesh can be seen at http://www.ezilon.com/maps/images/asia/political-map-of-Bangladesh.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/1916. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n [The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Measures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\n Manifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\n Total outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1: Rajshahi city, Sadar, Rajshahi, Rajshahi\n Total animals affected:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nHouse crow: _Corvus splendens_ (Corvidae) / - / 40 / 40 / 0 / 0 AVIAN INFLUENZA (19): BANGLADESH (RAJSHAHI) CROW, HPAI H5N1, OIE\n****************************************************************\n Summary\nReport type: immediate notification\n Serotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory (basic and advanced)\n Source of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: eating of city waste\n\nControl measures\n Date of start of the event: 1 Feb 2016\n Date of confirmation of the event: 15 Feb 2016\n Source: OIE, WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database), weekly disease information 2016; 29(07) [edited]\n Date of start of the outbreak: 1 Feb 2016\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2016-02-01 00:00:00", "2016-02-15 00:00:00", "2014-06-24 00:00:00", "2016-03-24 00:00:00", "2016-02-04 00:00:00", "2016-02-10 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "WAHID", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bangladesh", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Dhaka", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Livestock", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3956280", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (14): Egypt A(H5N1,H9N2) CDC/EID", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3956280", "date": "2016-01-22 05:36:39", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (14): EGYPT A(H5N1, H9N2) CDC/EID\n********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 21 Jan 2016\nSource: Emerging Infectious Diseases journal [edited]\nhttp://dx.doi.org/10.3201/eid2203.150593\n\n\n[ref: Kayali G, El-Shesheny R, Kandeil A, et al. Avian influenza A(H5N1) virus in Egypt. Emerg Infect Dis. 2016 Mar [date cited]. DOI: 10.3201/eid2203.150593]\n---------------------------------------------------------------------\nAbstract\n--------\n'In Egypt, avian influenza A subtype H5N1 and H9N2 viruses are enzootic in poultry. The control plan devised by veterinary authorities in Egypt to prevent infections in poultry focused mainly on vaccination and ultimately failed. Recently, widespread H5N1 infections in poultry and a substantial increase in the number of human cases of H5N1 infection were observed. We summarize surveillance data from 2009 through 2014 and show that avian influenza viruses are established in poultry in Egypt and are continuously evolving genetically and antigenically. We also discuss the epidemiology of human infection with avian influenza in Egypt and describe how the true burden of disease is underestimated. We discuss the failures of relying on vaccinating poultry as the sole intervention tool. We conclude by highlighting the key components that need to be included in a new strategy to control avian influenza infections in poultry and humans in Egypt.'\n\nHuman cases [H5N1]\n------------------\nThe paper states that 'During 2006-2015, the estimated number of confirmed human cases of H5N1 infection in Egypt was 292, with a 34 per cent case fatality rate. The number of reported cases by year for 2006-2015 shows that, before the 2014-15 winter season, the annual number of cases never exceeded 40. However, in just 2 months, January and February 2015, a total of 88 cases were reported. The most recent cases occurred in persons who reported exposure to backyard poultry (70 per cent), bred domestic birds (26 per cent), slaughtered poultry (14 per cent), or were exposed to dead birds (4 per cent)...'\n\nExtent of avian influenza infection in Egypt\n--------------------------------------------\n'In Egypt, the number of reported human cases of avian influenza infection appears to be underestimated. An underestimation might result in an overestimation of the case-fatality rate, but it would certainly underestimate the extent of human infection with avian influenza viruses. Results from a controlled, serologic cohort study of persons in Egypt exposed and not exposed to poultry estimated the seroprevalence of antibodies against H5N1 (titers greater than 80) at 2 per cent. If this seroprevalence were to be extrapolated to the entire poultry-exposed population in Egypt, the true number of infections would amount to several hundred thousand. These figures are even more striking when it comes to human infection with H9N2 viruses. The seroprevalence of H9N2 antibodies detected in the same cohort study ranged from 5.6 per cent to 7.5 per cent, whereas just 1 case of H9N2 infection was reported...'\n\nProposed avian influenza control plan\n-------------------------------------\n'The avian influenza situation in Egypt is deteriorating, evident in the fact that H5N1 and H9N2 viruses are enzootic in poultry and that incidence of H5N1 and H9N2 infection is increasing. The problem is also evident in the sharp increase in human H5N1 cases and the detection of the 1st human H9N2 case. Thus, it is imperative that authorities in Egypt devise and implement an aggressive control plan to curb the spread of disease in human and animal populations. The control plan must include the following elements: 1) mapping of the unlicensed, small-scale poultry farms that have become abundant in rural areas; 2) increasing the biosecurity levels of these small farms by using inexpensive tools; 3) revamping veterinary and public health surveillance and conducting joint human-animal interface surveillance and risk-assessment exercises; 4) encouraging poultry owners to report outbreaks and providing them appropriate compensation; 5) intervening, when poultry outbreaks are reported, by culling infected poultry and setting monitoring zones around each focus point; 6) properly decontaminating infected farms; 7) encouraging the use of disinfectants in backyards where poultry are raised; 8) increasing awareness about the effects of avian influenza; 9) testing patients with suspected influenza for H5N1 and H9N2 virus; and 10) reevaluating the vaccination strategy, including that for H9N2 virus. If vaccination is to remain an important tool in the control plan, then the following aspects should be considered: 1) matching vaccine strains to currently circulating strains; 2) matching challenge strains to currently circulating strains; 3) maintaining high vaccination coverage; 4) ensuring vaccine efficacy not only in a laboratory setting but also in the field; and 5) evaluating vaccine efficacy on an annual basis.'\n\nConclusions\n-----------\n'Egypt is one of the few countries where H5N1 virus has become enzootic and is the only country with a high number of H5N1 outbreaks among poultry and cases among human. During the 2014-15 winter season, a sudden and substantial increase in human infection with H5N1 viruses was observed. There is no obvious or confirmed reason for this increase, but data indicate the following: 1) H9N2 virus is co-circulating and co-infecting with H5N1 viruses, 2) H5N1 viruses causing the infections possess some mutations that were rarely seen in the past, and 3) the poultry vaccination program is failing. However, our perspective was limited to the data available through our surveillance program, which might not be representative of the epizootiology of avian influenza virus in Egypt. Regardless of the causes of the recent increase in human H5N1 cases, this situation evolved because of the ineffective control strategy that was implemented. Controlling the situation requires a One Health approach, but certainly the greater share of responsibility now lies with the veterinary side.'\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[The full publication, including figures, can be viewed at the URL above. This well written and important overview of avian influenza A(H5N1 and H7N9) in Egypt raises serious concern over the increasing prevalence of infection in poultry and humans, especially considering the probable underreporting discussed in the paper. The authors recommend the steps they feel need to be taken to address this increasing public health threat, and the problems with the vaccination program. Recommended reading! - Mod.LK\n\nThe following data, extracted (slightly edited) from the paper's chapter 'Avian influenza in poultry in Egypt', may be of interest:\n\nIn Egypt, a systematic surveillance program for avian influenza viruses has been in place since 2009. Commercial and semicommercial farms, abattoirs, backyard flocks, and live bird markets located in different governorates are sampled on a monthly basis regardless of the presence of disease symptoms in poultry. In each governorate, the same locations are continuously sampled by a poultry veterinarian, who collects one swab sample per bird; depending on the size of the poultry population, as many as 5 birds are sampled per flock. Birds are not randomly selected, and samples also are collected from sick or dead birds found onsite. Samples are mostly from chickens, but ducks, geese, turkeys, pigeons, and quails also are sampled. This program enabled detection of genetic and antigenic changes in H5N1 viruses in Egypt. It provided important epizootiologic data and described the poultry sectors acting as reservoirs of H5N1 viruses. The rate of avian influenza infection during August 2009-July 2010 was 5 per cent, exclusively attributable to H5N1 infection, and was more concentrated in the commercial production sector. From August 2010 through January 2013, the positivity rate increased to 10 per cent, and the infection was detected in all poultry production sectors. In 2011, H9N2 viruses emerged and were detected by this program and other surveillance activities in Egypt. The monthly positivity rate of avian influenza infection from August 2009 through December 2014 is shown graphically (http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/22/3/15-0593-f1) with sharp increases during the colder months (November through March). Emergence of H9N2 virus in poultry and an increase in human H5N1 cases are indicated. After the detection of H9N2 virus in 2011 the positivity rate during colder months was higher than that in the period when H5N1 was the only virus infecting poultry, exceeding 20 per cent in some months. Furthermore, co-infection with H5N1 and H9N2 viruses was frequently detected. The same seasonal pattern was seen with both strains during the period February 2013-December 2014 (http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/22/3/15-0593-f2).\n\nAmong the authors' conclusions: 1) H9N2 virus is co-circulating and co-infecting with H5N1 viruses, 2) H5N1 viruses causing the infections possess some mutations that were rarely seen in the past, 3) the poultry vaccination program is failing. 'However, our perspective was limited to the data available through our surveillance program, which might not be representative of the epizootiology of avian influenza virus in Egypt. Regardless of the causes of the recent increase in human H5N1 cases, this situation evolved because of the ineffective control strategy that was implemented. Controlling the situation requires a One Health approach, but certainly the greater share of responsibility now lies with the veterinary side.' - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/55.]", "summary": "The control plan must include the following elements: 1) mapping of the unlicensed, small-scale poultry farms that have become abundant in rural areas; 2) increasing the biosecurity levels of these small farms by using inexpensive tools; 3) revamping veterinary and public health surveillance and conducting joint human-animal interface surveillance and risk-assessment exercises; 4) encouraging poultry owners to report outbreaks and providing them appropriate compensation; 5) intervening, when poultry outbreaks are reported, by culling infected poultry and setting monitoring zones around each focus point; 6) properly decontaminating infected farms; 7) encouraging the use of disinfectants in backyards where poultry are raised; 8) increasing awareness about the effects of avian influenza; 9) testing patients with suspected influenza for H5N1 and H9N2 virus; and 10) reevaluating the vaccination strategy, including that for H9N2 virus. The most recent cases occurred in persons who reported exposure to backyard poultry (70 per cent), bred domestic birds (26 per cent), slaughtered poultry (14 per cent), or were exposed to dead birds (4 per cent)...'\n\nExtent of avian influenza infection in Egypt\n The following data, extracted (slightly edited) from the paper's chapter 'Avian influenza in poultry in Egypt', may be of interest:\n\nIn Egypt, a systematic surveillance program for avian influenza viruses has been in place since 2009. There is no obvious or confirmed reason for this increase, but data indicate the following: 1) H9N2 virus is co-circulating and co-infecting with H5N1 viruses, 2) H5N1 viruses causing the infections possess some mutations that were rarely seen in the past, and 3) the poultry vaccination program is failing. The seroprevalence of H9N2 antibodies detected in the same cohort study ranged from 5.6 per cent to 7.5 per cent, whereas just 1 case of H9N2 infection was reported...'\n\nProposed avian influenza control plan\n Among the authors' conclusions: 1) H9N2 virus is co-circulating and co-infecting with H5N1 viruses, 2) H5N1 viruses causing the infections possess some mutations that were rarely seen in the past, 3) the poultry vaccination program is failing. ' If vaccination is to remain an important tool in the control plan, then the following aspects should be considered: 1) matching vaccine strains to currently circulating strains; 2) matching challenge strains to currently circulating strains; 3) maintaining high vaccination coverage; 4) ensuring vaccine efficacy not only in a laboratory setting but also in the field; and 5) evaluating vaccine efficacy on an annual basis.'\n\n A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n The avian influenza situation in Egypt is deteriorating, evident in the fact that H5N1 and H9N2 viruses are enzootic in poultry and that incidence of H5N1 and H9N2 infection is increasing. -----------\n'Egypt is one of the few countries where H5N1 virus has become enzootic and is the only country with a high number of H5N1 outbreaks among poultry and cases among human. We summarize surveillance data from 2009 through 2014 and show that avian influenza viruses are established in poultry in Egypt and are continuously evolving genetically and antigenically. Controlling the situation requires a One Health approach, but certainly the greater share of responsibility now lies with the veterinary side.'\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[The full publication, including figures, can be viewed at the URL above. This well written and important overview of avian influenza A(H5N1 and H7N9) in Egypt raises serious concern over the increasing prevalence of infection in poultry and humans, especially considering the probable underreporting discussed in the paper. An underestimation might result in an overestimation of the case-fatality rate, but it would certainly underestimate the extent of human infection with avian influenza viruses. The rate of avian influenza infection during August 2009-July 2010 was 5 per cent, exclusively attributable to H5N1 infection, and was more concentrated in the commercial production sector. Recently, widespread H5N1 infections in poultry and a substantial increase in the number of human cases of H5N1 infection were observed. AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (14): EGYPT A(H5N1, H9N2) CDC/EID\n********************************************************\n In Egypt, the number of reported human cases of avian influenza infection appears to be underestimated. After the detection of H9N2 virus in 2011 the positivity rate during colder months was higher than that in the period when H5N1 was the only virus infecting poultry, exceeding 20 per cent in some months. The paper states that 'During 2006-2015, the estimated number of confirmed human cases of H5N1 infection in Egypt was 292, with a 34 per cent case fatality rate.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2016-03-24 00:00:00", "2009-08-24 00:00:00", "2011-03-24 00:00:00", "2014-03-24 00:00:00", "2013-01-24 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2016-01-21 00:00:00", "2021-01-24 00:00:00", "2014-12-24 00:00:00", "2010-08-24 00:00:00", "2015-02-24 00:00:00", "2009-03-24 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "EGYPT", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Egypt", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4026033", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (20): Nigeria, poultry, HPAI H5N1, spread", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4026033", "date": "2016-02-16 16:55:41", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (20): NIGERIA, POULTRY, HPAI H5N1, SPREAD\n*********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 15 Feb 2016\nSource: The Poultry Site [edited]\nhttp://www.thepoultrysite.com/poultrynews/36564/poor-biosecurity-linked-to-further-bird-flu-spread-in-nigeria/\n\n\n23 more outbreaks of highly pathogenic avian influenza have been reported in Nigeria.\n\nOf the 4 outbreaks reported on 4 Feb 2016, 2 were in Kano and 2 were in Plateau province. Of the 19 reported on 8 Feb 2016, 8 were in Kano, 2 were in Jigawa, 3 were in Federal Capital Territory, 2 were in Adamawa, 2 were in Kaduna, one was in Plateau and one was in Ebonyi.\n\nThe outbreaks, of the H5N1 strain affected both backyard holdings and commercial farms and both broilers and layers of all ages. Poor farm biosecurity was once again implicated in the spread of disease.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Nigeria began undergoing 2 major HPAI H5N1 epizootics during 2015:\n\nThe 1st event reportedly started on 24 Dec 2014 in the south western part of the country, so far notified to the OIE in an immediate notification and 33 follow-up reports. It spread eastwards within the southern parts of the federation. All the reports and an interactive map showing all affected locations are available at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?fupser=&dothis=&reportid=16977. The most recent follow-up report, No. 33, was submitted on 21 Jan 2016, bringing the total number of outbreaks within this event to 92.\n\nThe 2nd event, to which the outbreaks included in the above report belong, reportedly started on 2 Jan 2015 in the northern part of the country, so far notified to the OIE in an immediate notification and 28 follow-up reports, 3 of which are later than the 2 reports included in the above media item. The epizootic spread westwards and particularly southwards into central Nigeria. The most recent follow-up report, No. 28, was submitted to the OIE on 15 Feb 2016, bringing the total number of outbreaks within this event to 306, of which 51 have happened since the start of February 2016. The immediate notification, 28 follow-up reports, and an interactive map showing the affected locations are available at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?fupser=&dothis=&reportid=16926.\n\nThe summarized accumulated statistics of this major event, as available in OIE's WAHID archive, updated 15 Feb 2016, are as follows:\nTotal outbreaks = 306 (submitted)\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nBirds / 1 570 393 / 127 385 / 124 947 / 1 360 853 / 258\n\nModified stamping out policy, without vaccination, is being applied in both events.\n\nSo far, no human infections have been reported. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/62.]", "summary": "The 2nd event, to which the outbreaks included in the above report belong, reportedly started on 2 Jan 2015 in the northern part of the country, so far notified to the OIE in an immediate notification and 28 follow-up reports, 3 of which are later than the 2 reports included in the above media item. The case was confirmed by RT-PCR on 10 Mar 2016 after being reported on 4 Mar 2016. No additional details are provided.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Egypt reported approximately 160 human cases of H5N1 avian influenza during 2014-2015. On 7 Mar 2016, the 1st case was reported from Sohag from 25 Feb 2016.\n\nThe number of confirmed cases in Egypt since 2003 now stands at 347, and the global total is now 847.\n\nAlmost all cases of H5N1 infection in people have been associated with close contact with infected live or dead birds, or H5N1-contaminated environments. The virus does not infect humans easily, and spread from person to person appears to be unusual. There is no evidence that the disease can be spread to people through properly prepared and thoroughly cooked food.\n\nCairo is the capital and largest city of Egypt. Greater Cairo is the largest metropolitan area in the Middle East and the Arab world, and 15th-largest in the world.\n\nMaps of Egypt can be seen at http://www.geoatlas.com/medias/maps/countries/egypt/eg3r92t/egypt_pol.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/32945. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[2] Egypt (Giza) 3rd human case H5N1\nDate: Tue 15 Mar 2016\nSource: EMPRES [edited]\nhttp://empres-i.fao.org/empres-i/2/obd?idOutbreak=211291&rss=t\n\n\nEMPRES reported today the 3rd case of H5N1 in Egypt in 2016, in Giza. The case was confirmed by RT-PCR on 12 Mar 2016 after being observed on 24 Feb 2016. No additional details are provided.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Giza is the 3rd-largest city in Egypt. It is located on the west bank of the Nile, some 20 km (12.43 miles) southwest of central Cairo. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[3] China (Guangdong) H5N6\nDate: Tue 15 Mar 2016\nSource: Info Hong Kong [edited]\nhttp://www.info.gov.hk/gia/general/201603/15/P201603150851.htm\n\n\nThe Centre for Health Protection (CHP) of the Department of Health (DH) was notified of an additional human case of avian influenza A(H5N6) in Guangdong by the National Health and Family Planning Commission today (15 Mar 2016), and again urged the public to maintain strict personal, food and environmental hygiene both locally and during travel.\n\nThe case involves a woman aged 40 in Huizhou, Guangdong. She developed fever and cough on 20 Feb 2016 and was admitted to a hospital in Huizhou on 22 Feb 2016. She is now in critical condition. Investigation revealed that the patient had visited a live poultry market before onset of symptoms.\n\nFrom 2014 to date, a total of 10 human cases of avian influenza A(H5N6) have been reported by the Mainland health authorities.\n\n'All novel influenza A infections, including H5N6, are statutory notifiable infectious diseases in Hong Kong,' a spokesman for the CHP said.\n\n'We will remain vigilant and work closely with the World Health Organization and relevant health authorities to monitor the latest developments,' the spokesman said.\n\nThe DH's Port Health Office conducts health surveillance measures at all boundary control points. Thermal imaging systems are in place for body temperature checks on inbound travellers. Suspected cases will be immediately referred to public hospitals for follow-up.\n\nThe display of posters and broadcast of health messages in departure and arrival halls as health education for travellers is underway. The travel industry and other stakeholders are regularly updated on the latest information.\n\nTravellers, especially those returning from avian influenza-affected areas with fever or respiratory symptoms, should immediately wear masks, seek medical attention and reveal their travel history to doctors. Health-care professionals should pay special attention to patients who might have had contact with poultry, birds or their droppings in affected areas.\n\nThe public should remain vigilant and take heed of the advice against avian influenza below:\n\n* Do not visit live poultry markets and farms. Avoid contact with poultry, birds and their droppings;\n* If contact has been made, thoroughly wash hands with soap;\n* Avoid entering areas where poultry may be slaughtered and contact with surfaces which might be contaminated by droppings of poultry or other animals;\n* Poultry and eggs should be thoroughly cooked before eating;\n* Wash hands frequently with soap, especially before touching the mouth, nose or eyes, handling food or eating; after going to the toilet or touching public installations or equipment (including escalator handrails, elevator control panels and door knobs); and when hands are dirtied by respiratory secretions after coughing or sneezing;\n* Cover the nose and mouth while sneezing or coughing, hold the spit with a tissue and put it into a covered dustbin;\n* Avoid crowded places and contact with fever patients; and\n* Wear masks when respiratory symptoms develop or when taking care of fever patients.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Avian influenza A (H5N6) emerged in 2014 as a reassortant of H5N1 and H6N6. Official data show that since the 1st case was discovered in 2014 through today, 15 Mar 2016, China has reported 10 cases of human infection of H5N6 avian influenza virus with 5 deaths, The 1st case was reported in Sichaun province in April 2014, the 2nd in Guangdong province in December 2014, the 3rd and 4th, Yunnan province in 2015, and the remaining 6 cases in Guangdong province in December 2015- Mar 2016. It is hoped that this increasing incidence of H5N6, albeit still low, does not portend further increase in activity.\n\nMaps of China can be found at http://www.sacu.org/maps/provmap.png and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/155. - Mod.LK\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/155.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Official data show that since the 1st case was discovered in 2014 through today, 15 Mar 2016, China has reported 10 cases of human infection of H5N6 avian influenza virus with 5 deaths, The 1st case was reported in Sichaun province in April 2014, the 2nd in Guangdong province in December 2014, the 3rd and 4th, Yunnan province in 2015, and the remaining 6 cases in Guangdong province in December 2015- Mar 2016. * Wash hands frequently with soap, especially before touching the mouth, nose or eyes, handling food or eating; {"archive_id": "3936791", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (11): China (SC) H5N1", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3936791", "date": "2016-01-14 19:46:55", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (11): CHINA (SICHUAN) H5N1\n*************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 13 Jan 2016\nSource: CIDRAP (Center for Infectious Disease Research and Policy) News and Flu Scan [edited]\nhttp://www.cidrap.umn.edu/news-perspective/2016/01/flu-scan-jan-13-2016\n\n\nChina reports H5N1 case in Sichuan province man\n-----------------------------------------------\nOfficials have confirmed a severe case of H5N1 avian flu in a man in Chengdu, the capital of Sichuan province in south central China, according to a statement from the Sichuan Health and Family Planning Commission translated and posted today [13 Jan 2016] by Avian Flu Diary (AFD), an infectious disease news blog.\n\nThe patient, age 42, is hospitalized in Chengdu in 'extremely critical' condition. He developed a fever and other symptoms on 27 Dec 2015, but his condition recently deteriorated and includes severe pneumonia and respiratory failure, the statement said.\n\nHe had contact with live poultry before falling ill, officials said. He tested positive for H5N1 today [13 Jan 2016]. 58 of his close contacts are under observation, with no further cases noted so far.\n\nThis appears to be the world's 1st H5N1 case of the year [2016]. Last year [2015] the country [China] reported 5 cases to the World Health Organization (WHO), according to WHO data, one of which was fatal. Since 2003 the country has confirmed 52 cases and 31 deaths. As of 14 Dec [2015], the WHO had confirmed 844 cases, including 449 deaths, for a case-fatality rate of 53 percent.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Although H5N1 does not usually infect humans, 844 human cases of H5N1 have been reported from 15 countries since 2003. The virus is a highly pathogenic avian (bird) flu virus that has caused serious outbreaks in domestic poultry in parts of Asia, Africa, and the Middle East. Activity has been reported throughout the years also from Europe, in poultry and wild birds, without human cases.\n\nMost human cases of 'highly pathogenic' H5N1 virus infection have occurred in people who had recent contact with sick or dead poultry that were infected with H5N1 viruses, as was the case with the individual reported above. H5N1 usually does not spread between people.\n\nA map of the provinces of China may be viewed at http://www.china-mike.com/china-travel-tips/tourist-maps/china-provinces-map, and a HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/350. - Mod.LK]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Most human cases of 'highly pathogenic' H5N1 virus infection have occurred in people who had recent contact with sick or dead poultry that were infected with H5N1 viruses, as was the case with the individual reported above. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Although H5N1 does not usually infect humans, 844 human cases of H5N1 have been reported from 15 countries since 2003. AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (11): CHINA (SICHUAN) H5N1\n*************************************************\n Officials have confirmed a severe case of H5N1 avian flu in a man in Chengdu, the capital of Sichuan province in south central China, according to a statement from the Sichuan Health and Family Planning Commission translated and posted today Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< As of 14 Dec [2015], the WHO had confirmed 844 cases, including 449 deaths, for a case-fatality rate of 53 percent. Last year [2015] the country [China] reported 5 cases to the World Health Organization (WHO), according to WHO data, one of which was fatal. Updates will be provided in the weekly reports as further information becomes available.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: movement control inside the country, screening, traceability, quarantine, surveillance outside containment and/or protection zone, surveillance within containment and/or protection zone, zoning, vaccination prohibited, no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: disinfection/disinfestations, stamping out, official destruction of animal products, official disposal of carcasses, by-products and waste\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type:\nAnimal and Plant Health Agency (APHA), Weybridge (OIE's reference laboratory)\nSpecies / Test / Test date / Result\nBirds / haemagglutination inhibition test (HIT) / 10 Jan 2016 / Positive\nBirds / intravenous pathogenicity index (IVPI) test / - / Pending\nBirds / neuraminidase inhibition assay / - / Pending\nBirds / nucleotide sequencing / 11 Jan 2016 / Positive\nBirds / real-time reverse transcriptase / polymerase chain reaction (RRT-PCR) / 10 Jan 2016 / Positive\nBirds / virus isolation / 13 Jan 2016 / Positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. The event published in that posting referred to low pathogenic avian influenza subtype H5N1.\n\nAccording to the Department for Environment, Food & Rural Affairs' (DEFRA) and the Animal and Plant Health Agency's (APHA) 'Guidance on Avian Influenza (Bird Flu)': 'On 13 Jan 2016 the Scottish authorities confirmed a case of low severity (H5N1) avian influenza (bird flu) [http://tinyurl.com/ho84zux] on a poultry breeding farm in Dunfermline. The restrictions imposed on [10 Jan 2016] remain in place as part of the robust procedures for dealing swiftly with avian influenza.' See information at https://www.gov.uk/avian-influenza-bird-flu. - Mod.CRD\n\nAccording to the OIE notification, the poultry flock involved includes approximately 40 000 housed 57-week-old broiler breeder hens. Not a single 'case' observed; what led the owner and/or authorities to suspect avian influenza? was the flock tested within an active surveillance plan? Obviously, the lack of clinical cases is indicative of an extremely mild virus strain. There are prescribed criteria/tests to determine the pathogenicity rate of avian influenza strains. Positive\nBirds / virus isolation / 13 Jan 2016 /", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2016-01-10 00:00:00", "2016-03-24 00:00:00", "2016-01-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2016-01-13 00:00:00", "2016-01-08 00:00:00", "2015-02-06 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Dunfermline", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "London", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United Kingdom", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "WAHID", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3930530", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (04): UK (Scotland) poultry, H5N1, pathogenicity pending, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3930530", "date": "2016-01-12 23:02:56", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (04): UK (SCOTLAND) POULTRY, H5N1, PATHOGENICITY PENDING, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n*************************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 11 Jan 2016\nSource: The Scottish Government, News-Press release [edited]\nhttp://news.scotland.gov.uk/News/Avian-influenza-update-2135.aspx\n\n\nA very mild strain of H5N1 avian influenza has been identified on a farm in Fife by initial test results, the Chief Veterinary Officer has said.\n\nThe results so far and the symptoms shown suggest it is a very mild strain of H5N1, less serious than other forms of the virus that have caused concern in recent years. However, further tests are being carried out to confirm precise details of the disease.\n\nSwift precautionary action is already being taken to prevent the spread of disease, including a humane cull of birds on the broiler breeder farm near Dunfermline.\n\nA 1-km Temporary Control Zone (TCZ) has also been put in place around the premises, which means restrictions on the movement of poultry, carcasses, eggs, used poultry litter and manure, and restrictions on bird gatherings.\n\nScotland's Chief Veterinary Officer Sheila Voas said: 'All the evidence so far suggests we are dealing with a very mild form of H5N1 avian influenza, which is not the same as the strain that has been causing problems in Asia and North Africa. Further tests are currently being carried out to confirm this, but in the meantime, we are taking no chances. As a precaution to prevent the spread of disease -- and in line with our robust procedures for dealing with avian flu -- we have already put in place movement restrictions around the farm, and all birds on the premises will be humanely culled. Consumers should not be concerned about eating eggs or poultry given the expert advice about food safety and human health. We are looking into possible sources of this infection in Scotland, but it is normal for such viruses to circulate among wild bird populations, especially waterfowl. However, it is important that poultry keepers remain vigilant for any signs of disease and to ensure they are maintaining good biosecurity on their premises.'\n\nCabinet Secretary for Rural Affairs, Food and the Environment Richard Lochhead said: 'We have seen a number of cases of avian influenza across Europe in the past few months, including 3 separate cases in England in the past year or so, but it looks like we are dealing with a very mild strain here. The Scottish Government and our partners continue to do all we can to contain and prevent the spread of disease. Any poultry producers who are concerned should immediately seek veterinary advice.'\n\nDr Jim McMenamin, Consultant Epidemiologist and Respiratory Infection lead for Health Protection Scotland said: 'Based on what we know about this strain of avian influenza and the actions that have been taken, the risk to human health in this case is considered very low. Health Protection Scotland continues to work closely with Animal Health throughout this investigation\n\nRita Botto, Head Veterinarian of Food Standard Scotland said: 'On the basis of current scientific evidence, Food Standards Scotland's advice is that bird flu does not pose a food safety risk for UK consumers.'\n\nThe owner of a farm in Dunfermline at which a suspect case of avian influenza has been identified does not wish to be approached for comment or interview.\n\nAvian Influenza is a notifiable disease. Anyone who suspects an animal may be affected by a notifiable disease must report it to their local Animal Plant & Health Agency (formerly AHVLA) office. Contact details can be found at http://www.defra.gov.uk/ahvla-en/about-us/contact-us/field-services/.\n\nThere have been a number of avian influenza cases across continental Europe in recent months, including 3 cases in other parts of the UK in 2014-15. More information about avian influenza -- including biosecurity guidance -- is available from the Scottish government website at http://www.scotland.gov.uk/avianinfluenza.\n\nAs part of routine wildlife disease surveillance, post-mortem examinations of birds are undertaken in incidents where 5 birds are found dead in the same location and at the same time.\n\nIn the United Kingdom, members of the public are asked to report these incidents to Defra's national helpline (Tel: 03459 335577, Monday-Friday 8am to 6pm).\n\nContact Information: SG Communications <SGCommunications@scot.gov.uk>.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nSabine Zentis\nCastleview English Longhorns\nGut Laach\nD-52385 Nideggen, Germany\n<cvlonghorns@aol.com>\n\n[The HPAI outbreaks in the UK during 2015 were serotyped H7N7.\n\nFinal results of the current event's investigation, particularly the definitive pathogenicity rate of the H5N1 strain involved, are anticipated. The poultry population affected is reportedly composed of broiler breeders; it would be interesting to note whether the birds were kept indoors. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/280.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nCabinet Secretary for Rural Affairs, Food and the Environment Richard Lochhead said: 'We have seen a number of cases of avian influenza across Europe in the past few months, including 3 separate cases in England in the past year or so, but it looks like we are dealing with a very mild strain here. AHMAR) H5N1\n**********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 6 Jan 2016\nSource: Daily News Egypt [edited]\nhttp://www.dailynewsegypt.com/2016/01/05/bird-flu-flying-south-for-the-winter/\n\n\nA medical source at a hospital in the Red Sea governorate has told local media that a woman infected with bird flu died at the Hurghada General Hospital on Tuesday [5 Jan 2016]. The source stated there were currently 6 other cases of bird flu in quarantine.\n\nThe source said the woman was suffering from severe pneumonia and was quarantined in intensive care. She later died late Mon [5 Jan 2016] night at the hospital.\n\nMahmoud Ibrahim, in charge of the Red Sea governorate's Directorate of Veterinary Medicine, said that health awareness campaigns targeting bird flu were ongoing through daily shop inspections.\n\nThe governor formed a committee, which includes the regional branch of the Environmental Affairs Agency, the Directorate of Veterinary Medicine, the Public Administration for Environmental Affairs, the Directorate of Supply, the Directorate of Health, and the Directorate of Agriculture. The committee also includes city councils, local units, and police facilities to provide health guidelines and emphasise hygiene practices in shops, such as sanitary ways to dispose of dead birds.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Hurghada is a city in the Red Sea Governorate (Al Bahr Al Ahmar) of Egypt. It is the 3rd largest city (after Suez and Ismailia) in Egypt located on the Red Sea coast.\n\nH5N1 is a highly pathogenic avian (bird) flu virus that has caused serious outbreaks in domestic poultry in parts of Asia, Africa, and the Middle East. The virus has been reported throughout the years also from Europe, in poultry and wild birds, without human cases. Highly pathogenic refers to the virus's ability to produce serious disease in poultry, according to internationally agreed pathogenicity criteria. Although H5N1 does not usually infect humans, 844 human cases of H5N1 have been reported from 15 countries since 2003.\n\nMost human cases of 'highly pathogenic' H5N1 virus infection have occurred in people who had recent contact with sick or dead poultry that were infected with H5N1 viruses.\n\nH5N1 usually does not spread between people. - Mod.LK\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/55.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nMost human cases of 'highly pathogenic' H5N1 virus infection have occurred in people who had recent contact with sick or dead poultry that were infected with H5N1 viruses. \n\nH5N1 is a highly pathogenic avian (bird) flu virus that has caused serious outbreaks in domestic poultry in parts of Asia, Africa, and the Middle East. http://www.dailynewsegypt.com/2016/01/05/bird-flu-flying-south-for-the-winter/\n\n\nA medical source at a hospital in the Red Sea governorate has told local media that a woman infected with bird flu died at the Hurghada General Hospital on Tuesday [5 Jan 2016]. \n\nMahmoud Ibrahim, in charge of the Red Sea governorate's Directorate of Veterinary Medicine, said that health awareness campaigns targeting bird flu were ongoing through daily shop inspections. The committee also includes city councils, local units, and police facilities to provide health guidelines and emphasise hygiene practices in shops, such as sanitary ways to dispose of dead birds. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2003-03-24 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-30 00:00:00", "2016-01-05 00:00:00", "2016-01-06 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "EGYPT", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Egypt", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3921222", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (03): Nigeria (KN, DE), poultry, HPAI H5N1, spread", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3921222", "date": "2016-01-08 18:39:00", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (03): NIGERIA (KANO, DELTA), POULTRY, HPAI H5N1, SPREAD\n***********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 8 Jan 2016\nSource: The Poultry Site [edited]\nhttp://www.thepoultrysite.com/poultrynews/36388/northern-southern-nigeria-both-hit-by-bird-flu-outbreaks/\n\n\nNigeria has reported more outbreaks of highly pathogenic avian influenza in its Kano and Delta regions.\n\n1 outbreak of the H5N1 strain on a farm in the Delta region caused 7973 deaths in a flock comprising broilers, layers and breeders at different ages of production.\n\nOver 330 000 poultry were destroyed as a result of the outbreak.\n\nIn the Kano region, H5N1 outbreaks on 3 different farms caused the death of 376 birds, and another 15 000 had to be destroyed to prevent the disease spreading.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Nigeria began undergoing 2 major HPAI H5N1 epizootics during 2015.\n\nThe 1st reportedly started on 24 Dec 2014 in the southwestern part of the country, so far notified to the OIE in an immediate notification and 29 follow-up reports. All the reports and an interactive map showing all affected locations are available at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=19461. The most recent follow-up report, No. 29, was submitted on 5 Jan 2016.\n\nThe 2nd epizootic reportedly started on 2 Jan 2015, also in the southwestern part of the country, so far notified to the OIE in an immediate notification and 16 follow-up reports. All the reports and an interactive map showing all affected locations are available at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=19447. The most recent follow-up report, No. 16, was submitted on 4 Jan 2016.\n\nModified stamping out policy, without vaccination, is being applied.\n\nSo far, no human infections have been reported. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/5476.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Nigeria began undergoing 2 major HPAI H5N1 epizootics during 2015. \n\nThe 2nd epizootic reportedly started on 2 Jan 2015, also in the southwestern part of the country, so far notified to the OIE in an immediate notification and 16 follow-up reports. \n\n1 outbreak of the H5N1 strain on a farm in the Delta region caused 7973 deaths in a flock comprising broilers, layers and breeders at different ages of production. The 1st reportedly started on 24 Dec 2014 in the southwestern part of the country, so far notified to the OIE in an immediate notification and 29 follow-up reports. AVIAN INFLUENZA (03): NIGERIA (KANO, DELTA), POULTRY, HPAI H5N1, SPREAD\n***********************************************************************\n \n\n--\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2015-01-02 00:00:00", "2015-03-24 00:00:00", "2016-01-04 00:00:00", "2016-01-05 00:00:00", "2014-03-24 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Nigeria", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3892179", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (133): France, HPAI (H5N1/H5N2/H5N9) LPAI (H5N2/H5N3) assessment", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3892179", "date": "2015-12-26 04:36:21", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (133): FRANCE, HPAI (H5N1/H5N2/H5N9) LPAI (H5N2/H5N3) ASSESSMENT\n********************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 23 Dec 2015\nSource: DEFRA International Disease Monitoring [edited]\nhttps://www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/488585/Update_H5_HPAI_France_23122015.pdf\n\n\nAvian influenza of high pathogenicity (H5N1, H5N2, and H5N9) and low pathogenicity (H5N2, H5N3) in poultry in France. Ref: VITT/1200 LPAI & HPAI in France\n---------------------------------------------------------------------\n1. Disease report\nSince the last update on 16 Dec 2015, more outbreaks in poultry have been reported as a result of increased surveillance in south west France (for the official map, updated 23 Dec 2015, see the source URL; not all outbreaks visible at this scale). To date, there are 61 outbreaks of HPAI H5 (N1, N2 and N9), 54 of which have been reported to the EU Animal Disease Notification System. Six regions are affected: Dordogne (12 outbreaks); Landes (27 outbreaks); Haute Vienne (1); Gers (9); Pyrenees Atlantique (10) and; Haute Pyrenees (2). [For the 24 Dec 2015 updated figures, see commentary].\n\nThe situation continues to evolve, and the French authorities have increased the size of restriction zones to cover more regions (hatched/grey area in map), and this has been adopted by the European Commission under special written procedure (SANTE/7135/2015). Movements of live birds from any control zone are subject to pre-movement testing, which has led to the detection of more infected flocks, but does provide some additional assurance (http://agriculture.gouv.fr/la-liste-des-communes-de-la-zone-reglementee-influenza-aviaire).\n\n2. Situation assessment\nANSES [Agence nationale de securite sanitaire de l'alimentation, de l'environnement et du travail; French Agency for Food, Environmental and Occupational Health & Safety], the French risk assessment agency, has published an assessment of the likely source of infection, limited partial virus gene sequence data, risk to public health, and relevance of restriction measures (https://www.anses.fr/fr/system/files/SANT2015sa0241.pdf).\n\nThe source considered most likely is that LPAI European origin avian influenza viruses were circulating in poultry and have mutated to HPAI, then silent spread has occurred in species which show few clinical signs (Anseriforme poultry) or which have been partially immunised by exposure to related LPAI viruses. This theory is given greater confidence by the knowledge that these LPAI viruses are often detected year after year in this area through the EU poultry survey. The preliminary sequence data suggest that there is a common H5 sequence to the LP/HPAI viruses.\n\nA less likely theory is that multiple LPAI viruses were circulating recently in wild birds, and then, after contact with the poultry, these viruses mutated. It is considered very unlikely that the HPAI viruses were circulating in wild birds, as there have been no reports of such in EU-wide surveys.\n\nOn the restriction measures, there is still some uncertainty around how the viruses are spread from one location to another given the significant increase in recent days of new infected premises, hence the large zone now in place.\n\nOn the public health risk, it is noted that only Eurasian strains of H5N1 HPAI have caused human disease (and derived from a different gene lineage to the viruses involved in the current outbreaks), and even so only for people in very close contact with poultry (during home slaughter for example), and no cases have been associated with H5N2 or H5N9 HPAI infection in poultry. See also ECDC (2015) [at http://ecdc.europa.eu/en/publications/_layouts/forms/Publication_DispForm.aspx?List=4f55ad51-4aed-4d32-b960-af70113dbb90&ID=1411].\n\nNevertheless, the full gene sequences for a multiple number of viruses will need to be determined and analysed before clear conclusions on pathways of origin, length of time the virus has been evolving in the field and implications for zoonotic risk can be concluded, as there may still be re-assortments or genetic adaptation occurring.\n\nBased on limited sequencing for just 3 viruses, the authors concluded there are a number of previously identified mutations which may promote the replication of the virus in the mammalian respiratory tract, but the combination of all these mutations in affecting host range is complex. Infection with any AI virus in particular circumstances of high exposure (such as those operatives in the field who are involved in control measures) cannot be ruled out.\n\nIt should be noted that understanding how widely LPAI viruses are circulating in poultry is important, as this could present a substantially immune population and needs to be considered in control decisions and surveillance design.\n\nIt would be helpful to understand more about the way the 'feeding' duck and geese industry in France is managed and whether this contributes to the spread. The method for raising birds for fois gras production, for example, is intensive and would involve handling the birds frequently, which may increase the likelihood of transmission with shared equipment or poultry handlers.\n\nFrom a trade perspective, we would like to highlight that the new EU Implementing Decision allows a derogation for movement of hatching eggs and day old chicks from the large restriction zone only under written agreement between competent authorities on a case by case basis.\n\n3. Conclusion\nThe publication of the ANSES risk assessment and the new restriction measures are welcome. The risk to the UK as a result of these outbreaks is primarily around pathways which involve lapses in biosecurity or trade routes rather than through wild birds, as these are apparently wholly European origin viruses. However, the situation in France simply reinforces what we already knew, that these LPAI viruses circulate in wild birds and cause occasional spill-over outbreaks in poultry and may be difficult to detect in domestic waterfowl species and which may then mutate into HPAI viruses following infection of galliforme hosts.\n\nWe will continue to monitor the situation closely. We would like to remind all poultry keepers to maintain high standards of biosecurity, remain vigilant, and report any suspect clinical signs promptly, and, in addition, to use the 'testing to exclude scheme' for avian notifiable disease where appropriate for early safeguards.\n\nThe risk level for the UK remains at low, but heightened.\n\n[authors: Professor Ian Brown, Dr Helen Roberts]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[As of 24 Dec 2015, the total number of HPAI (3 serotypes) in 6 south western regions of France has risen to 63, as follows (in brackets, number of reported outbreaks):\nDordogne (12), Landes (27), Haute Vienne (1), Gers (10), Pyrenees Atlantique (10) and Hautes-Pyrenees (3); (from http://www.poultrymed.com/Poultrymed/Templates/showpage.asp?DBID=1&LNGID=1&TMID=178&FID=1825&PID=0&IID=29230).\n\nThe updated (23 Dec 2015) official map, titled 'H5N1, H5N2 & H5N9 HPAI and H5N2, H5N3 LPAI outbreaks in backyard and commercial poultry, France' is available at the source URL. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/100.]", "summary": "\n\nThe source considered most likely is that LPAI European origin avian influenza viruses were circulating in poultry and have mutated to HPAI, then silent spread has occurred in species which show few clinical signs (Anseriforme poultry) or which have been partially immunised by exposure to related LPAI viruses. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[As of 24 Dec 2015, the total number of HPAI (3 serotypes) in 6 south western regions of France has risen to 63, as follows (in brackets, number of reported outbreaks):\nDordogne (12), Landes (27), Haute Vienne (1), Gers (10), Pyrenees Atlantique (10) and Hautes-Pyrenees (3); (from http://www.poultrymed.com/Poultrymed/Templates/showpage.asp?DBID=1&LNGID=1&TMID=178&FID=1825&PID=0&IID=29230). A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\n[authors: Professor Ian Brown, Dr Helen Roberts]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< On the public health risk, it is noted that only Eurasian strains of H5N1 HPAI have caused human disease (and derived from a different gene lineage to the viruses involved in the current outbreaks), and even so only for people in very close contact with poultry (during home slaughter for example), and no cases have been associated with H5N2 or H5N9 HPAI infection in poultry. \n\nA less likely theory is that multiple LPAI viruses were circulating recently in wild birds, and then, after contact with the poultry, these viruses mutated. However, the situation in France simply reinforces what we already knew, that these LPAI viruses circulate in wild birds and cause occasional spill-over outbreaks in poultry and may be difficult to detect in domestic waterfowl species and which may then mutate into HPAI viruses following infection of galliforme hosts. [Agence nationale de securite sanitaire de l'alimentation, de l'environnement et du travail; French Agency for Food, Environmental and Occupational Health & Safety], the French risk assessment agency, has published an assessment of the likely source of infection, limited partial virus gene sequence data, risk to public health, and relevance of restriction measures (https://www.anses.fr/fr/system/files/SANT2015sa0241.pdf). Since the last update on 16 Dec 2015, more outbreaks in poultry have been reported as a result of increased surveillance in south west France (for the official map, updated 23 Dec 2015, see the source URL; not all outbreaks visible at this scale). \n\nIt should be noted that understanding how widely LPAI viruses are circulating in poultry is important, as this could present a substantially immune population and needs to be considered in control decisions and surveillance design. \n\nThe updated (23 Dec 2015) official map, titled 'H5N1, H5N2 & H5N9 HPAI and H5N2, H5N3 LPAI outbreaks in backyard and commercial poultry, France' is available at the source URL. \n\nOn the restriction measures, there is still some uncertainty around how the viruses are spread from one location to another given the significant increase in recent days of new infected premises, hence the large zone now in place. The risk to the UK as a result of these outbreaks is primarily around pathways which involve lapses in biosecurity or trade routes rather than through wild birds, as these are apparently wholly European origin viruses. Nevertheless, the full gene sequences for a multiple number of viruses will need to be determined and analysed before clear conclusions on pathways of origin, length of time the virus has been evolving in the field and implications for zoonotic risk can be concluded, as there may still be re-assortments or genetic adaptation occurring. \n\nThe situation continues to evolve, and the French authorities have increased the size of restriction zones to cover more regions (hatched/grey area in map), and this has been adopted by the European Commission under special written procedure (SANTE/7135/2015).", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2015-12-24 00:00:00", "2015-03-24 00:00:00", "2015-12-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "FRANCE", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Landes", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "France", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3875709", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (132): France, HPAI (H5N1/H5N2/H5N9) LPAI (H5N2/H5N3) assessment", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3875709", "date": "2015-12-19 20:27:43", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (132): FRANCE, HPAI (H5N1/H5N2/H5N9) LPAI (H5N2/H5N3) ASSESSMENT\n********************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 16 Dec 2015\nSource: DEFRA (UK Department for Environment, Food, and Rural Affairs) International Disease Monitoring, outbreak assessment [edited]\nhttps://www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/487411/update-h5n1-hpai-france.pdf\n\n\nAvian influenza of high pathogenicity (H5N1, H5N2, and H5N9) and low pathogenicity (H5N2, H5N3) in poultry in France\nRef: VITT/1200 LPAI & HPAI in France\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\n1. Disease report\nSince the last update [of 7 Dec 2015], several new outbreaks in poultry have now been reported as a result of increased surveillance in South West France [Ministry of Agriculture], France, 2015; see map at the source URL above]; not all outbreaks visible at this scale]. To date [16 Dec 2015] there are 15 outbreaks of HPAI H5 (N1, N2, and N9) and 7 outbreaks of LPAI H5 (N2 and N3) which have been reported to the EU Animal Disease Notification System and in addition there may be a further 15 cases of HPAI reported on the French Surveillance platform.\n\nSeveral of the outbreaks are linked to one another, according to the disease reports, and the species affected include commercial ducks, geese, and guinea fowl. While ducks and geese are not exhibiting severe clinical signs, the guinea fowl may show severe clinical signs and high levels of mortality as expected for a galliform host infected with HPAI. The developing situation still carries significant uncertainties as the French authorities are using the legislative tools to limit further spread, through the use of restriction zones around each outbreak and enhanced surveillance and restrictions beyond the EU requirements for the Dordogne region as well as several communes in the Landes region, preventing international trade from these areas (hatched area in map). Movements of live birds from any control zone are subject to pre-movement testing, which has led to the detection of more infected flocks, but does provide additional assurance (http://agriculture.gouv.fr/sites/minagri/files/listes_communes_ia_11dec15.pdf)\n\n2. Conclusion\nAs before, there are still many unknowns and a lot of uncertainty. The risk to the UK as a result of these outbreaks is primarily around pathways which involve lapses in biosecurity or trade routes, rather than through wild birds as these are apparently wholly European origin viruses. However the situation in France simply reinforces what we already knew: that these LPAI viruses circulate in wild birds and cause occasional spill-over outbreaks in poultry that may be difficult to detect in domestic waterfowl species and which may then mutate into HPAI viruses following infection of galliform hosts.\n\nWhilst there is uncertainty over the identity of the index case(s) and the pathways for virus evolution (including the genesis of 3 HPAI subtypes) and the host populations/networks in which these occurred, introduction by other transmission pathways from other undisclosed sources cannot be excluded. However, it would appear based on information available to date and knowledge of the biology of these viruses, that the new cases in France may be related. Detailed genetic analyses of the causative viruses will be critical to understanding these events and defining with greater certainty risk pathways and periods for spread of infection. Whether the index case for the LPAI to HPAI mutation(s) has been found is uncertain.\n\nWe will continue to monitor the situation closely. We would like to remind all poultry keepers to maintain high standards of biosecurity, remain vigilant, and report any suspect clinical signs promptly and in addition using the testing to exclude scheme for avian notifiable disease where appropriate for early safeguard. For more information, please see http://www.defra.gov.uk/ahvla-en/disease-control/nad.\n\nThe risk level for the UK remains at low, but heightened.\n\n[Authors: Professor Ian Brown, Dr Helen Roberts]\n\n[You will note the repeated use of the words 'uncertain' and 'unknown' in the report above. We hope we will get some better answers soon.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\npromed@promedmail.org\n\n[Links to France's recent OIE notifications on all the HPAI and LPAI strains mentioned, are available:\n1. for the 3 highly pathogenic strains, at\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?fupser=&dothis=&reportid=19296,\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?fupser=&dothis=&reportid=19171, and\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?fupser=&dothis=&reportid=19217\n\n2. for the 2 low pathogenic strains at\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?fupser=&dothis=&reportid=19299 and\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?fupser=&dothis=&reportid=19341\n\nAll 5 links include a relevant interactive map. - On the farm, old white layers, pullets, and cockerels in deep litter were affected. Over 3500 birds were destroyed to prevent the disease from spreading.\n\nStamping out, quarantines, movement control, and disinfection are in use to control the virus.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The above information is derived from Ghana's follow-up report No. 11 to the OIE, submitted 23 Nov 2015. Links to the said and to all previous reports since the start of this event (13 Apr 2015), as well as a summarizing map showing the locations of the 28 accumulated outbreaks as of 23 Nov 2015, are available at\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?fupser=&dothis=&reportid=17828.\n\nOIE-WAHID's archive presents the following summary of the (continuing) event as of 23 Nov 2015 as follows:\nOutbreak summary:\nTotal outbreaks: 28 (submitted)\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nBirds / 68 398 / 20 797 / 20 479 / 47 572 / 336\n\nThe control policy applied in Ghana is stamping out, surveillance, and movement restrictions, without vaccination.\n\nGhana is one of several West African countries affected by the virus since its start (initially in Nigeria) at the beginning of 2015. AVIAN INFLUENZA (200): GHANA, POULTRY, HPAI H5N1, UPDATE\n********************************************************\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Birds / 68 398 / 20 797 / 20 479 / 47 572 / 336\n\nThe control policy applied in Ghana is stamping out, surveillance, and movement restrictions, without vaccination.", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2015-11-23 00:00:00", "2015-04-13 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "WAHID", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Trebakope", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ghana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nigeria", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3833041", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (202): France (DD) backyard poultry, HPAI H5N1, spread", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3833041", "date": "2015-12-01 16:21:52", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (202): FRANCE (DORDOGNE) BACKYARD POULTRY, HPAI H5N1, SPREAD\n****************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 30 Nov 2015\nSource: AFP via Midilibre [in French, trans. Corr.SB]\nhttp://www.midilibre.fr/2015/11/30/grippe-aviaire-de-retour-en-france-deux-nouveaux-cas-en-dordogne,1250421.php\n\n\nAn outbreak of avian influenza H5N1 was detected last week in a backyard flock in the Dordogne, marking the return to France of this potentially deadly virus to humans, more than 8 years after the last confirmed cases.\n\nBird flu has reappeared in particular in hens raised for personal consumption in Biras, said the prefect of Dordogne, Christophe Bay, at a press conference last Wed 25 Nov 2015. The government has just announced 2 new cases on 30 Nov 015, according to FranceTV Info. The Veterinary Services Department was alerted Fri 20 Nov 2015 after the death of the 30 birds. Analyses revealed the presence of virus, probably transmitted by wild ducks, according to the prefecture. Survivors were euthanized and the backyard disinfected. The samples were sent to the National Health Security Agency (ANSES), which confirmed on Tuesday the 1st results.\n\n'This is a highly pathogenic H5N1 in poultry, 'appearing corresponding [similar?] to' a strain detected already in Europe that presented a previously LPAI [low-pathogenic] profile,' said the Ministry of Agriculture in a statement. The risk of [transmission] to humans of this strain is not established at this stage. The Ministers of Agriculture, Stephane Le Foll, and health, Marisol Touraine, said 'as a precautionary measure, it will be necessary to evaluate the potential dangerousness of the strain to humans.'\n\nBird flu is however 'not transferable to humans through the consumption of meat, eggs, foie gras, or more generally any food product,' the ministry said. 'This virus has no effect in terms of consumption of anything derived from poultry products,' said Mr Le Foll, also spokesman for the government, from the council for ministers.\n\n'Poultry that have been slaughtered are healthy. Sick poultry do not reach the slaughterhouse,' said Denis Lambert, head of the poulterer LDC, showing its confidence in 'the quality of French veterinary services. We will identify the area and there is no reason to extend it.'\n\nAs expected in this situation, the Government has activated the national health emergency response plan. In Biras a protection zone of 3 km has been set up around the site, [within which] all pets must be confined, including dogs and cats, 'to prevent any further spread,' said Mr. Bay. 2 other Dordogne farms have been placed under special surveillance; the usual checks have revealed high levels of antibodies, suggesting that the birds were in contact with the disease, reported the prefect. [Specifically, these are] breeding geese in Domme, 90 km south of Biras, and a duck farm in Saint-Paul-la-Roche, 50 km north.\n\nThe most recent crisis caused by the H5N1 virus in France dates back to early 2006. After destroying all the poultry in a factory farm in Ain, the government of the time imposed the general containment of birds and free-range poultry held by individuals on the entire territory for 3 months. During this period, 64 cases were confirmed [among the] dead birds found, almost all in Ain. The latest isolated cases were detected in Moselle in the summer of 2007 among swans and wild ducks. Since its revival in Southeast Asia in late 2003, bird flu has killed 449 people out of 844 confirmed cases, mostly in Egypt, Indonesia and Vietnam, according to the latest report of the World Health Organization (WHO).\n\n[Byline: Mehdi Fedouach]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The initial outb5eak of this continuing event was reported to the OIE on 25 Nov 2015 (see 20151125.3819479).\n\nH5N1 HPAI was last reported in France in wild ducks in August 2007 in Lorraine, Moselle, eastern France. All H5N1 HPAI viruses detected in Europe since 2005 are derived from the common progenitor A/goose/Guandong/1/96 lineage of Asian origin.\n\nH5N1 LPAI of the European lineage has been isolated sporadically from both poultry and wild birds in Europe.\n\nResults of epidemiological investigations into the source of infection on the 3 holdings, and results of genotyping the virus strain(s) involved, are anticipated with interest. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/7202.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\n'This is a highly pathogenic H5N1 in poultry, 'appearing corresponding [similar?] to' a strain detected already in Europe that presented a previously LPAI [low-pathogenic] profile,' said the Ministry of Agriculture in a statement. \n\nBird flu has reappeared in particular in hens raised for personal consumption in Biras, said the prefect of Dordogne, Christophe Bay, at a press conference last Wed 25 Nov 2015. \n\nBird flu is however 'not transferable to humans through the consumption of meat, eggs, foie gras, or more generally any food product,' the ministry said. ' After destroying all the poultry in a factory farm in Ain, the government of the time imposed the general containment of birds and free-range poultry held by individuals on the entire territory for 3 months. \n\nResults of epidemiological investigations into the source of infection on the 3 holdings, and results of genotyping the virus strain(s) involved, are anticipated with interest. - Mod. \n\n\nAn outbreak of avian influenza H5N1 was detected last week in a backyard flock in the Dordogne, marking the return to France of this potentially deadly virus to humans, more than 8 years after the last confirmed cases. \n\nH5N1 LPAI of the European lineage has been isolated sporadically from both poultry and wild birds in Europe. This virus has no effect in terms of consumption of anything derived from poultry products,' said Mr Le Foll, also spokesman for the government, from the council for ministers. BACKYARD POULTRY, HPAI H5N1, SPREAD\n****************************************************************************\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The initial outb5eak of this continuing event was reported to the OIE on 25 Nov 2015 (see 20151125.3819479). Since its revival in Southeast Asia in late 2003, bird flu has killed 449 people out of 844 confirmed cases, mostly in Egypt, Indonesia and Vietnam, according to the latest report of the World Health Organization (WHO).", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2015-11-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-30 00:00:00", "2007-08-24 00:00:00", "2005-03-24 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Domme", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Egypt", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "FRANCE", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Moselle", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "France", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Saint - Paul - la - Roche", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Indonesia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Vietnam", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Biras", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3825777", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (199): Viet Nam, poultry, (HT) H5N1, (QG) H5N6, spread", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3825777", "date": "2015-11-28 16:42:03", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (199): VIET NAM, POULTRY, (HA TINH) H5N1, (QUANG NGAI) H5N6, SPREAD\n***********************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 27 Nov 2015\nSource: The Poultry Site [edited]\nhttp://www.thepoultrysite.com/poultrynews/36224/avian-flu-spreads-in-vietnamese-backyard-poultry/\n\n\nThere have been 2 outbreaks of H5N6 highly pathogenic avian influenza in Central Viet Nam.\n\nBoth the outbreaks occurred in backyard poultry in Quang Ngai province, causing 824 deaths. Another 861 birds were destroyed.\n\nOne outbreak of the highly pathogenic H5N1 version of the disease has also been reported in backyard poultry in Ha Tinh province. That outbreak caused 100 deaths, and 549 birds were destroyed.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[1. The mentioned HPAI H5N6 outbreak in Quang Ngai was reported to the OIE on 23 Nov 2015 in follow-up report No. 16, available with an interactive map at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?reportid=19152.
