This is the 4th death due to severe pneumonia in Sharia, Tebessa.\n\nThe source indicated that the 3 people died after being transferred to Constantine Hospital and they had the same symptoms including severe cough and dyspnea. The analysis of samples was done by the Pasteur Institute. The doctors in the university hospitals in Constantine recommended another testing for confirmation.\n\nThere is news about another 3 cases transferred to Constantine Hospital. These cases are not necessarily from Tebessa.\n\nThere is investigation to find out if the infected people consumed chicken meat. The manager of health in Tebessa indicated that they are taking all measures and they will transfer all suspected cases. He indicated that besides the 4 dead people there are 4 other cases in Constantine and Annaba in the intensive care.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps of Algeria can be found at http://www.infoplease.com/atlas/country/algeria.html and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/14863.\nTebessa is the capital city of Tebessa province, Algeria, 20 km (about 20 mi) west from the border with Tunisia.\n\nIf this case(s) is reconfirmed by the WHO, it will be the 1st case reported from Algeria. However, in the absence of any reports of H5N1 in poultry, I am skeptical. ProMED-mail would greatly appreciate more information on this from knowledgeable sources in the region. - Mod.DK\n\nH5N1 is a highly pathogenic avian (bird) flu virus that has caused serious outbreaks in domestic poultry in in parts of Asia, Africa, and the Middle East. The virus has been reported throughout the years also from Europe, in poultry and wild birds, without human cases. Highly pathogenic refers to the virus's ability to produce serious disease in poultry, according to internationally agreed pathogenicity criteria. Although H5N1 does not usually infect humans, 844 human cases of H5N1 have been reported from 15 countries since 2003.\n\nMost human cases of 'highly pathogenic' H5N1 virus infection have occurred in people who had recent contact with sick or dead poultry that were infected with H5N1 viruses.\n\nH5N1 usually does not spread between people.\n\nThere have been no reported infections with these viruses in birds, poultry, or people in the United States.\n\nYou cannot get infected with these viruses from properly handled and cooked poultry or eggs.\n\n(Partly excerpted from http://www.flu.gov/about_the_flu/h5n1/index.html). - Mod.LK\n\nSince 2003, 844 human infections with highly pathogenic H5N1 viruses have been reported to the World Health Organization (WHO) by 16 countries. About 53 percent of these people died from their illness http://www.who.int/influenza/human_animal_interface/H5N1_cumulative_table_archives/en/. - Mod.DK\n\nIn view of the recent occurrence of HPAI H5N1 in poultry in southeast France (see Avian influenza (202): France (DD) backyard poultry, HPAI H5N1, spread 20151201.3833041), the possible circulation of this (potentially zoonotic) virus in the region deserves alertness. In the past, there was a single report on a suspected case in a hen in Algeria (see Avian influenza (70): Algeria, RFI 20070414.1243; the RFI remained unanswered). Information on the surveillance in poultry and wild birds applied in Algeria and other Maghreb countries will be helpful. - Mod.AS]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nMost human cases of 'highly pathogenic' H5N1 virus infection have occurred in people who had recent contact with sick or dead poultry that were infected with H5N1 viruses. In view of the recent occurrence of HPAI H5N1 in poultry in southeast France (see Avian influenza (202): France (DD) backyard poultry, HPAI H5N1, spread 20151201.3833041), the possible circulation of this (potentially zoonotic) virus in the region deserves alertness. DK\n\nH5N1 is a highly pathogenic avian (bird) flu virus that has caused serious outbreaks in domestic poultry in in parts of Asia, Africa, and the Middle East. LK\n\nSince 2003, 844 human infections with highly pathogenic H5N1 viruses have been reported to the World Health Organization (WHO) by 16 countries. \n\nThere have been no reported infections with these viruses in birds, poultry, or people in the United States. \nEl Khabar was informed from a well-informed source that the laboratory analysis for a sample from a 40-year-old male who died in Sharia, Tebessa [province] was positive for avian influenza. The virus has been reported throughout the years also from Europe, in poultry and wild birds, without human cases. 28 (48) [edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=19171\n\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza, France\n-------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 25 Nov 2015 from Dr Loic Evain, Directeur General adjoint, CVO, Direction generale de l'alimentation, Ministere de l'Agriculture, de l'Agroalimentaire et de la Foret, Paris, France\n\nSummary\nReport type: Immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 14 Nov 2015\nDate of confirmation of the event: 24 Nov 2015\nReason for notification: Reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 2007\nManifestation of disease: Clinical disease\nCausal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: Clinical, Laboratory (advanced),\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country.\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks: Total outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1: Biras, Dordogne\nDate of start of the outbreak: 14 Nov 2015\nOutbreak status: Resolved (20 Nov 2015)\nEpidemiological unit: Backyard\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nBirds / 32 / 22 / 22 / 10 / 0\nAffected population: A backyard (non-commercial farm) consisting of 32 broiler chickens and layer hens showing acute mortalities leading to testing and preventive slaughter.\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Unknown or inconclusive\n\nEpidemiological comment: Zoning: protection (3 km) and surveillance (10 km) zones around the farm.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: movement control inside the country; screening; disinfection/disinfestations; stamping out; official disposal of carcasses, by-products and waste; surveillance within containment and/or protection zone; zoning; vaccination prohibited; no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: traceability; surveillance outside containment and/or protection zone; control of wildlife reservoirs\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nNational Reference Laboratory for Avian Influenza and Newcastle Disease (National laboratory) / Birds / nucleotide sequencing / 24 Nov 2015\nNational Reference Laboratory for Avian Influenza and Newcastle Disease (National laboratory) / Birds / real-time reverse transcriptase/polymerase chain reaction (RRT-PCR) / 24 Nov 2015\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2014-03-24 00:00:00", "2015-07-24 00:00:00", "2014-11-24 00:00:00", "2015-03-24 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": \n\n Summary", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3684780", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (190): Nigeria, poultry, HPAI H5N1, spread", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3684780", "date": "2015-10-02 05:44:12", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (190): NIGERIA, POULTRY, HPAI H5N1, SPREAD\n**********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 30 Sep 2015\nSource: The Nation (Nigeria) [edited]\nhttp://thenationonlineng.net/new-outbreak-of-bird-flu-spreads-to-21-states/\n\n\nA new outbreak of avian influenza (bird flu) has been reported in 85 local government areas in 21 states and the Federal Capital Territory (FCT), the Federal Government [Nigeria] has said. Cases of bird flu were 1st reported in January [2015] by the government in over 11 states.\n\nThe government said the new outbreak which has been reported in Lagos, Ogun, Rivers, Oyo, Enugu, Abia and the FCT, occurred between July [2015] and last month [September 2015]. The permanent secretary of the Federal Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development, Sonny Echono, who spoke at a meeting with stakeholders in the poultry industry, said that 491 farmers have been affected by the disease. Echono said that 1 597 191 birds have been depopulated so far.\n\nThe permanent secretary said government has started the decontamination of affected farms and birds to curtail the spread of the disease. He said: 'As you are probably aware, the resurgence of avian influenza as at today has spread to 85 local government areas (LGAs) in 21 states and the FCT, affecting 491 farms. The disease has continued to spread mainly in the southern states and the latest outbreaks reported between July and September, 2015 in Lagos, Oyo, Ogun, Enugu, Abia, Rivers, and FCT. These new outbreaks have been attributed to non-compliance to biosecurity in farms, limited awareness creation on disease among poultry farmers, disregard to public policy on sitting of poultry farms and other enforcement protocols which are expected to be implemented by the states.'\n\nEchono said government has agreed to pay NGN 1.1 billion [about USD 5.5 million] as compensation to 138 affected farmers.\n\n[byline: Frank Ikpefan]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Nigeria has been undergoing 2 major HPAI H5N1 epizootics during 2015.\n\nThe 1st one reportedly started on 24 Dec 2014 in the south western parts of the country, so far involving 64 outbreaks, notified to the OIE in an immediate notification and 18 follow-up reports. All the reports and an interactive map showing the 64 locations are available at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?fupser=&dothis=&reportid=16977. The most recent follow-up report, No. 18, was submitted on 28 Sep 2015. The disease is spreading in a north easterly direction.\n\nThe 2nd epizootic reportedly started on 2 Jan 2015 in the south western parts of the country, so far involving 189 outbreaks, notified to the OIE in an immediate notification and 12 follow-up reports. All the reports and an interactive map showing the 189 locations are available at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?fupser=&dothis=&reportid=16926. The most recent follow-up report, No. 12, was submitted on 19 Sep 2015. The disease has been spreading southwards to central Nigeria.\n\nModified stamping out policy, without vaccination, is being applied.\n\nSo far, no human infections have been reported. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/62.]", "summary": "\n\n[byline: Frank Ikpefan]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Nigeria has been undergoing 2 major HPAI H5N1 epizootics during 2015. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n These new outbreaks have been attributed to non-compliance to biosecurity in farms, limited awareness creation on disease among poultry farmers, disregard to public policy on sitting of poultry farms and other enforcement protocols which are expected to be implemented by the states.'\n\n \n\nThe 1st one reportedly started on 24 Dec 2014 in the south western parts of the country, so far involving 64 outbreaks, notified to the OIE in an immediate notification and 18 follow-up reports. The 2nd epizootic reportedly started on 2 Jan 2015 in the south western parts of the country, so far involving 189 outbreaks, notified to the OIE in an immediate notification and 12 follow-up reports. \n\nThe permanent secretary said government has started the decontamination of affected farms and birds to curtail the spread of the disease. A new outbreak of avian influenza (bird flu) has been reported in 85 local government areas in 21 states and the Federal Capital Territory (FCT), the Federal Government [Nigeria] has said. He said: 'As you are probably aware, the resurgence of avian influenza as at today has spread to 85 local government areas (LGAs) in 21 states and the FCT, affecting 491 farms. The disease has continued to spread mainly in the southern states and the latest outbreaks reported between July and September, 2015 in Lagos, Oyo, Ogun, Enugu, Abia, Rivers, and FCT.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2015-09-24 00:00:00", "2021-01-24 00:00:00", "2015-01-02 00:00:00", "2015-03-24 00:00:00", "2015-09-28 00:00:00", "2015-09-19 00:00:00", "2014-03-24 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Nigeria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Lagos", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3681714", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (189): Viet Nam (HT) poultry, H5N1 (LI) HPAI H5N6", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3681714", "date": "2015-09-30 18:25:31", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (189): VIET NAM (HA TINH) POULTRY, H5N1 (LAI CHAU) HPAI H5N6\n***********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 30 Sep 2015\nSource: Viet Nam News [edited]\nhttp://vietnamnews.vn/society/276462/ha-tinh-faces-h5n1-bird-flu-threat.html\n\n\nHa Tinh Province faces a high risk of the spread of the H5N1 avian flu due to inadequate community awareness and determination of local authorities to prevent its transmission. Nearly 1400 poultry birds were culled during a recent H5N1 outbreak in Thach Ha and Can Loc Districts of the central Ha Tinh Province, the provincial veterinary division said.\n\nPreviously, an outbreak hit the household of Phan Nhat Thanh in Phu Loc Commune in Can Loc District on 17 Sep 2015, when nearly 400 chickens and ducks fell sick and died with avian flu symptoms. All samples tested positive for the H5N1 virus.\n\nA week later, authorities detected another outbreak among 1000 poultry birds in Thach Tri Commune in Thach Ha District. The veterinary division said all sick and dead poultry birds were raised in unhygienic conditions and had not been vaccinated against the H5N1 virus.\n\nPhu Loc People's Committee vice-chairman Nguyen Xuan Chuong said that breeders' awareness was inadequate, especially regarding vaccination. Just 2000 of the commune's 10 000 poultry birds have been vaccinated in 2015. This showed that the local authority and the people were not yet involved in disease prevention in the area, Chuong said.\n\nThe division also said the poultry vaccination rate was low, at more than 12 per cent in the province. The rates were even lower in several districts, such as 3 per cent in Can Loc and 2 per cent in Thach Ha. There is, thus, a very high risk of the spread of the H5N1 virus in the coming months.\n\nThe provincial agriculture and rural development department has asked localities to take efforts to prevent the spread of the H5N1 disease, focus on improving communication and poultry vaccination, maintain close supervision, and to handle new outbreaks immediately.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Viet Nam submitted to the OIE on 22 Sep 2015 its follow-up report No 6 on the ongoing HPAI H5N1 epizootic, which reportedly had started on 18 Jul 2015. poultry, HPAI H5N1, spread", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3634538", "date": "2015-09-09 18:37:29", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (187): VIET NAM (NINH THUAN) POULTRY, HPA H5N1, SPREAD\n********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 7 Sep 2015\nSource: Vietnam News [edited]\nhttp://vietnamnews.vn/society/275464/ninh-thuan-alarm-bells-about-possible-return-of-h5n1-bird-flu-epidemic.html\n\n\nBird flu prevention authorities in the central Ninh Thuan Province have raised an alarm about the possible return of a new epidemic after an outbreak of H5N1 bird flu was discovered last week among a flock of poultry in the province's Ninh Son District.\n\nAbout 1000 ducks owned by Dang Hung Kien, a farmer in the Ninh Son District, were immediately culled after a variety of samples were confirmed to have been infected with H5N1 bird flu.\n\nThe farmer had earlier reported to the local health preventive authority that a large number of birds in his flock had died of symptoms of H5N1, such as blindness and paralysed legs.\n\nA series of preventive measures were undertaken to quarantine the infected areas.\n\nIn May 2015, an outbreak of H5N1 was discovered in the same district and a total of 2500 ducks were culled.\n\nThe Ministry of Health's Preventive Medicine Department has asked the health sector in Ninh Thuan to roll out precautionary measures to prevent any possible transmission of A/H5N1 bird flu strain to humans.\n\nThe provincial Health Department was tasked with intensifying communication campaigns regarding protection measures for those living in high-risk areas. It will also focus on management and supervision while keeping a close watch over vulnerable residents to detect infected cases immediately.\n\nLocal hospitals were requested to prepare necessary facilities, equipment and medicine stocks for supervising and treating suspected cases. The Preventive Medicine Department also recommended regular washing of hands with soap, practicing personal hygiene and avoiding direct contact with A/H5N1 patients or sick poultry to effectively prevent the disease.\n\nVietnam recorded its initial A/H5N1 cases in fowl and humans in December 2003. The virus has since spread and triggered a number of outbreaks, causing severe health and economic damage.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The above outbreak was reported to the OIE on 1 Sep 2015 as the 5th outbreak within an event which started on 18 Jul 2015. This was follow-up report No 4 addressing this HPAI H5N1 event, which is considered 'continuing'. The immediate notification and the 4 follow-up reports, with an interactive map showing the 5 outbreaks, are available on-line at\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?fupser=&dothis=&reportid=18221.\n\nViet Nam's HPAI control policy is based upon stamping out.\n\nThere is another HPAI event currently in Viet Nam, caused by serotype H5N6. It started on 18 Aug 2015, so far involving 2 outbreaks. See\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?fupser=&dothis=&reportid=18467.\n\nSince 2003, Viet Nam has suffered a total of 127 HPAI H5N1 cases in humans, including 64 deaths. During 2014, 2 human cases were reported, both of whom died. their duck flocks were sick and were dying, the district and provincial veterinary services went there to investigate and took some samples (sick ducks), which were sent to NaVRI for testing. The result of test samples were confirmed positive with H5N1.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: movement control inside the country, disinfection/disinfestations, dipping/spraying, vaccination prohibited, no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: stamping out\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / result\nNational Veterinary Research Institute (national laboratory) / birds / anatomo-pathological examination / 14 Nov 2015 / positive\nNational Veterinary Research Institute (national laboratory) / birds / real-time PCR / 14 Nov 2015 / positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. influenza (186): Ghana, poultry, HPAI H5N1, update", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3628046", "date": "2015-09-06 17:34:37", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (186): GHANA, POULTRY, HPAI H5N1, UPDATE\n*********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 4 Sep 2015\nSource: Pulse Ghana [edited]\nhttp://pulse.com.gh/news/bird-flu-disease-veterinary-services-destroys-40-154-birds-id4137102.html\n\n\nThe Veterinary Services Department (VSD) has destroyed 40 154 birds and 1103 crates of eggs as part of measures to contain the spread of the bird flu disease in the Greater Accra, Volta and Ashanti regions.\n\nIn addition, 37 bags of feed have been destroyed, with a feed mill situated in an outbreak area under investigation for destruction, while 23 987 birds have died from the disease.\n\nThe Deputy Minister of Food and Agriculture, Livestock, Dr Hanna Bisiw, made this known in an interview with the Daily Graphic shortly after the opening of a 3-day training programme for regional and district veterinary officers in Accra.\n\nAs part of the containment measures, the movement of poultry and poultry products from infected zones into free zones had also been banned.\n\nDr Bissiw cautioned that the ministry would not negotiate on the ban because that would encourage the spread of the virus. She stressed that movement from non-affected areas to affected areas would only be approved if the poultry and poultry products were accompanied with health certificates and movement permits issued by staff of the veterinary services department.\n\n'We understand when people are used to doing something freely, and [when] there are restrictions, it is uncomfortable, but we are in an outbreak, hence we need to take special decisions to contain the disease and also completely kick it out of the country. When we have an outbreak, it's like you are at war with the disease or virus, so you cannot negotiate.'\n\nIn a presentation on Bird Flu Update and Epidemiology, the Head of the Epidemiology Unit of MOFA, Dr Paul Polkuu, said that the 1st case was reported on 4 May 2015 and confirmed on 12 May 2015. Dr Polkuu mentioned commercial poultry, local poultry, guinea fowl, geese, ducks, turkeys, partridges, quails, and pigeons as species affected.\n\nAs part of facilitating the movement of the staff of the veterinary service and the fight against influenza, government has released 6 vehicles and 20 motorbikes to the veterinary services department and other things needed for the laboratory.\n\n[Byline: Emmanuel Tornyi]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Since the start of the HPAI H5N1 event in Ghana on 13 Apr 2015, 23 outbreaks have been recorded in this West African country and notified. The reports and a summarising map presenting the 9 accumulated outbreaks as of 14 Aug 2015 are available at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?fupser=&dothis=&reportid=17828.\n\nThe Ghana policy in relation to HPAI is 'stamping out.'\n\nThe disease has been spreading into and within other West African countries since early 2015 and so far has been reported from Nigeria, Burkina Faso, Cote d'Ivoire, Niger, and Ghana; see interactive map at http://tinyurl.com/oqenf47 (click on the West African cluster and zoom in). It would be surprising if neighbouring countries such as Togo and Benin remain uninfected.\n\nA follow up report from Cote d'Ivoire, dated 1 Sep 2015, reported spread of the disease there (6 new outbreaks; see\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=18537. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/53.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n She stressed that movement from non-affected areas to affected areas would only be approved if the poultry and poultry products were accompanied with health certificates and movement permits issued by staff of the veterinary services department. \n\nThe disease has been spreading into and within other West African countries since early 2015 and so far has been reported from Nigeria, Burkina Faso, Cote d'Ivoire, Niger, and Ghana; see interactive map at http://tinyurl.com/oqenf47 (click on the West African cluster and zoom in). \n\nIn a presentation on Bird Flu Update and Epidemiology, the Head of the Epidemiology Unit of MOFA, Dr Paul Polkuu, said that the 1st case was reported on 4 May 2015 and confirmed on 12 May 2015. "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3602516", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (183): Nigeria (DE) poultry, HPAI H5N1, spread", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3602516", "date": "2015-08-26 12:12:24", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (183): NIGERIA (DELTA) POULTRY, HPAI H5N1, SPREAD\n*****************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 24 Aug 2015\nSource: Leadership Newspaper [edited]\nhttp://leadership.ng/news/455947/flu-scare-rocks-delta-725-birds-destroyed\n\n\nDelta State Ministry of Agriculture and Natural Resources took proactive steps to avert the spread of the avian influenza disease in the state as it destroyed 750 birds, including chickens and turkeys, which were confirmed to be positive carriers of the disease.\n\nHowever, results for 3100 birds are still being expected from the National Veterinary Research Institute (NVRI) Vom, Jos, Plateau State.\n\nThe de-population exercise, which was carried out on 2 poultry farms in Agbor, Ika South, and Ika North East Local Government Areas of the state, was performed by a team of experts from the Veterinary Services Department of the ministry, led by the State Avian Influenza desk officer, Dr Orioko Edmund.\n\nOwners of the affected farms lamented their losses as veterinary experts gathered their livestock into the pit, dug for the stamping-out purposes, before disinfecting the farm against further outbreaks.\n\nSpeaking to our correspondent in Asaba, the Chief Veterinary Officer and Director of Veterinary Services in the ministry Dr Charles Osielukwe Diai, said that following the confirmation of the disease by NVRI, the measure was necessary to avert its possible spread to other farms in the state, as well as to prevent the infected birds from getting into the market.\n\nDiai averred that the progressive efforts of the ministry to check the spread of the virus had been productive and was yielding desired results, as it has effectively managed 6 cases this year [2015], while samples from 2 poultry farms had been sent to the NVRI to ascertain the nature of their ailments.\n\nWhile commiserating with the affected farmers, he advised them to remain calm and accept the action of the ministry in good faith, assuring that all efforts were in top gear to ensure that the federal government pay them compensation in due time.\n\nThe veterinary director advised all poultry farmers as well as private veterinary practitioners to report any case of suspected avian influenza to the ministry, adding that any act to the contrary 'amounts to predisposing the consuming public and other livestock in the state to the disease.'\n\nHe said: 'The loss of a single human is much more than the loss of thousands of birds, and if you, as a farmer, cherish your family, then, you should be able to endure what happened because it is not a total loss since the government will compensate you. 'It is painful, no doubt, but you have to take solace in the fact that you will be paid and, at the same time, in the fact that you have saved that community from the tragedy of having influenza in the human population because all we are doing is in the interest of public health.' According to him, 'Had the situation been such where human beings were affected, we [would] not be talking about birds anymore, and this is what we have averted over the years and will continue to avert. That is why, all over the world, thousands of birds are being destroyed to save the human population.'\n\nHe disclosed that the veterinary department was in collaboration with all stakeholders in the sector to ensure that the state was free of the disease.\n\n[Byline: Kola Eke Ogiugo]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Nigeria has been suffering 2 separately reported epizootics of HPAI H5N1 during 2015.\n\nThe 1st one reportedly started in southern Nigeria on 24 Dec 2014 and was notified on 16 Jan 2015. During the following months, 31 additional outbreaks have been reported in 11 follow-up reports, the most recent one submitted on 17 Aug 2015. The outbreak reported in the media dispatch above, when officially confirmed, will become the 33rd.\n\nMeasures applied include quarantine, movement control inside the country, disinfection/disinfestation, and modified stamping out.\nOutbreak summary (as of 17 Aug 2015):\nTotal outbreaks = 32 (submitted)\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nBirds / 190 235 / 34 438 / 33 958 / 87 531 / 0\n\nAn OIE interactive map showing the locations of the 32 outbreaks within this south Nigeria epizootic, as of 17 Aug 2015, is available at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?fupser=&dothis=&reportid=16977.\n\nA 2nd major epizootic started on 2 Jan 2015 in northern Nigeria, spreading to the centre. Nigeria reported this as a separate event to the OIE. So far, 169 outbreaks have been reported in 9 follow-up reports, the most recent submitted on 4 Aug 2015. Links to all these reports and an interactive map showing the locations of the 169 outbreaks, as of 4 Aug 2015, are available at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?fupser=&dothis=&reportid=16926. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/5476.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nThe veterinary director advised all poultry farmers as well as private veterinary practitioners to report any case of suspected avian influenza to the ministry, adding that any act to the contrary 'amounts to predisposing the consuming public and other livestock in the state to the disease.'\n\n Birds / 190 235 / 34 438 / 33 958 / 87 531 / 0\n\nAn OIE interactive map showing the locations of the 32 outbreaks within this south Nigeria epizootic, as of 17 Aug 2015, is available at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?fupser=&dothis=&reportid=16977. \n\nDiai averred that the progressive efforts of the ministry to check the spread of the virus had been productive and was yielding desired results, as it has effectively managed 6 cases this year [2015], while samples from 2 poultry farms had been sent to the NVRI to ascertain the nature of their ailments. Outbreak summary (as of 17 Aug 2015):\nTotal outbreaks = 32 (submitted)\n http://leadership.ng/news/455947/flu-scare-rocks-delta-725-birds-destroyed\n\n\nDelta State Ministry of Agriculture and Natural Resources took proactive steps to avert the spread of the avian influenza disease in the state as it destroyed 750 birds, including chickens and turkeys, which were confirmed to be positive carriers of the disease. Speaking to our correspondent in Asaba, the Chief Veterinary Officer and Director of Veterinary Services in the ministry Dr Charles Osielukwe Diai, said that following the confirmation of the disease by NVRI, the measure was necessary to avert its possible spread to other farms in the state, as well as to prevent the infected birds from getting into the market. The de-population exercise, which was carried out on 2 poultry farms in Agbor, Ika South, and Ika North East Local Government Areas of the state, was performed by a team of experts from the Veterinary Services Department of the ministry, led by the State Avian Influenza desk officer, Dr Orioko Edmund. \n\nWhile commiserating with the affected farmers, he advised them to remain calm and accept the action of the ministry in good faith, assuring that all efforts were in top gear to ensure that the federal government pay them compensation in due time. \n\nOwners of the affected farms lamented their losses as veterinary experts gathered their livestock into the pit, dug for the stamping-out purposes, before disinfecting the farm against further outbreaks. AVIAN INFLUENZA (183): NIGERIA (DELTA) POULTRY, HPAI H5N1, SPREAD\n*****************************************************************\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2015-03-24 00:00:00", "2014-12-24 00:00:00", "2015-01-16 00:00:00", "2015-01-02 00:00:00", "2015-08-04 00:00:00", "2015-08-17 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Nigeria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Asaba", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3583226", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (180): China, H5N2, H5N6, Ghana, H5N1, poultry, spread", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3583226", "date": "2015-08-17 14:25:23", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (180): CHINA H5N2, H5N6, GHANA H5N1, POULTRY, SPREAD\n********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 14 Aug 2015\nSource: CIDRAP (Center for Infectious Disease Research and Policy) [edited]\nhttp://www.cidrap.umn.edu/news-perspective/2015/08/flu-scan-aug-14-2015\n\n\n[2] countries [China and Ghana] reported fresh avian influenza outbreaks today from 4 different strains, 3 of them highly pathogenic, according to separate reports to the World Organization for Animal Health (OIE).\n\nChina's agriculture ministry today reported 2 outbreaks involving 2 different high-path strains: H5N6 at a commercial farm in Guangdong province and H5N2 on a farm in Jiangsu province.\n\nThe H5N6 outbreak started on 6 Aug 2015 and killed 1350 of 2170 susceptible birds. The remaining birds were culled to curb the spread of the virus.\n\nThe H5N2 outbreak struck a commercial goose farm in Jiangsu province. The event began on 3 Aug 2015, and the disease killed 3106 of 53 358 vulnerable geese. Authorities destroyed the rest as part of their control measures.\n\nGhana reported the other high-path outbreaks, which all involved H5N1. The virus recently reemerged in the country after a several-year hiatus. The newest Ghanian outbreaks are all reported from Greater Accra region, with start dates in late July and early August 2015. Sites included a live bird market, a commercial farm, and backyard birds. In total, the virus wiped out 1178 birds, with authorities culling the rest to contain the spread.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The above report, based upon follow-up reports to the OIE dated 14 Aug 2015, addresses HPAI 3 epizootics, 2 of them in China and 1 in Ghana.\nThe following additional information may be useful to subscribers.\n1. China, HPAI H5N2, follow-up report No 6.\nThe epizootic started on 21 Dec 2013, the causative agent, HPAI H5N2, described as 'A new strain of a listed disease'. So far, 12 outbreaks have been reported, spread throughout eastern and southern China. All reports and an interactive map showing the locations of all outbreaks are available at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?fupser=&dothis=&reportid=14553.\n\n2. China, HPAI H5N6, follow-up report No 9\nThis epizootic started on 23 Aug 2014. The reason for notification was described as 'reoccurrence of a listed disease'. So far, 30 outbreaks have been reported, spread throughout eastern and southern China. All reports and an interactive map showing the locations of all outbreaks are available at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?fupser=&dothis=&reportid=15957.\n\n3. Ghana, HPAI H5N1, follow-up report No 8.\nThis epizootic started on 13 Apr 2015, confirmed 12 May 2015 and initially reported to the OIE on 2 Jun 2015. So far, 23 outbreaks have been reported. All reports and an interactive map showing the locations of all outbreaks are available at\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?fupser=&dothis=&reportid=17828.\nThe Ghana events are to be seen in the context of HPAI H5N1 epizootics in several west-African countries since early 2015, so far reported from Nigeria, Burkina Faso, Cote d'Ivoire, Niger, and Ghana.\n\nFor a map showing all HPAI outbreaks worldwide since 1 Aug 2015, see the interactive map at http://tinyurl.com/o45vh8o. For details from each country, click on the relevant cluster and zoom in. - Mod.AS]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nChina's agriculture ministry today reported 2 outbreaks involving 2 different high-path strains: H5N6 at a commercial farm in Guangdong province and H5N2 on a farm in Jiangsu province. AVIAN INFLUENZA (180): CHINA H5N2, H5N6, GHANA H5N1, POULTRY, SPREAD\n********************************************************************\n For a map showing all HPAI outbreaks worldwide since 1 Aug 2015, see the interactive map at http://tinyurl.com/o45vh8o. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\nThe H5N6 outbreak started on 6 Aug 2015 and killed 1350 of 2170 susceptible birds. So far, 12 outbreaks have been reported, spread throughout eastern and southern China.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2015-08-06 00:00:00", "2015-08-01 00:00:00", "1178-03-24 00:00:00", "2015-06-02 00:00:00", "2015-08-03 00:00:00", "2015-05-24 00:00:00", "2170-03-24 00:00:00", "1350-03-24 00:00:00", "2015-08-14 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Nigeria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "CHINA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Jiangsu province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Guangdong province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ghana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Greater Accra", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3575741", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (178): Nigeria (SW) poultry, HPAI H5N1, spread", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3575741", "date": "2015-08-13 14:46:38", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (178): NIGERIA (SOUTH WEST) POULTRY, HPAI H5N1, SPREAD\n**********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 11 Aug 2015\nSource: Business Day [edited]\nhttp://businessdayonline.com/2015/08/new-cases-of-bird-flu-discovered-in-abia-enugu/#.Vcr45Z1_Okp\n\n\nThe National Veterinary Research Institute (NVRI), Vom, said on [Tue 11 Aug 2015] that new cases of highly pathogenic avian influenza [HPAI] (bird flu) have been discovered in Abia and Enugu states. Dr Mohammed Ahmed, the executive director of the institute, said that it was the 1st time the flu was found in the 2 eastern states. 'The last cases we stamped out in May [2015], after destroying more than 1.4 million birds, affected only 18 states. Now the 2 states have come down with the disease and brought the total to 20 states,' he said.\n\nHe said that the new cases had been traced to the purchase of birds in Ibadan at the 'point of lay' [when they are about ready to start laying] by some poultry farmers in the 2 states. 'Unfortunately, the young birds came down with the disease, which means that we have not been enforcing the restriction in movement that is a key step in controlling disease.'\n\nWhile advising farmers to be more proactive, he said that the purchase of birds at the point of lay was 'certainly not the best,' because farmers would not know how the birds were raised. He said that purchasing of birds at the point of lay was mostly done by 'lazy' farmers, adding that the attitude was 'very dangerous, deadly, and costly'. He therefore advised farmers to always patronize well established farms that have massive hatcheries and were meticulous on biosecurity. 'The small poultry farms do not take biosecurity seriously. But the big farms have massive investments and do not play with the safety of their birds.'\n\nAhmed also suggested a division of labor among poultry farmers that would enable some to specialize in feed mills, while others to devote themselves to hatchery, point of lay and point of cage. 'When that is done, we shall minimize the current tendency to pounce into all aspects that had consistently proved hazardous.' The executive director called for intensive surveillance by stakeholders in states to curtail outbreak of the bird flu. 'The only way we can contain the flu totally is by consistent surveillance; we must always pick samples from affected areas and areas not affected,' he said.\n\nThe NVRI boss said that the national technical committee on bird flu had suggested to the Federal Government, the establishment of an active surveillance unit and was still waiting for response. 'Once we receive the response and the go ahead, we shall start the active surveillance and I am sure that we shall then be able to check the spread of the flu.' Ahmed said that the institute was also working to protect the nation's birds from Newcastle and gumboro [infectious bursal disease] diseases. 'The Newcastle disease affects younger birds, while the gumboro disease affects the older ones but we are working to ensure none affects us,' he said.\n\nHe cautioned poultry farmers against cluster farms, saying that they would record massive casualties if the disease affects any of the farms. 'The cluster farms situation is particularly bad in Plateau and Kano [states] and we have tried to discourage farmers from it because it is dangerous,' he said. He also spoke on the payment of compensations to owners of farms, whose birds were destroyed, saying that the exercise was in progress. 'The compensation has been spread into batches; batches 1, 2, and 3 have been paid. The others have been verified and payment will resume soon.'\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps of Nigeria can be seen at http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/nigeria.pdf and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/62. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ\n\nThe 3 new outbreaks in south west Nigeria were reported to the OIE on 11 Aug 2015, in follow-up report no 10 of this epizootic, which started on 24 Dec 2014. According to the said report, the outbreaks are located in Omi Addio, Iddo, Oyo state (broilers and turkeys, but only broilers were affected), Erikorodu farm estate, Ikorodu, Lagos (layers of over 20 weeks old) and Omi, Iddo, Oyo (broilers). The report, including an interactive map, is available at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=18357.\n\nSince the start of the south western epizootic of HPAI H5N1 in Nigeria, 28 new outbreaks have been reported to the OIE from this region. Their total statistics, so far, are the following: out of 149 654 susceptible birds, there have been 33 769 disease cases, of which 33 289 died. 43 803 in-contact birds have been destroyed.\n\nDuring 2015, Nigeria has reported to the OIE 2 separate HPAI H5N1 epizootics within its territory. Both are at present officially regarded as 'continuing.' The 1st one, mentioned above, is located in south and southwest Nigeria.\n\nThe 2nd, and larger epizootic reportedly started on 2 Jan 2015, and has since spread within northern and central Nigeria (Kano, Plateau, and Bauchi states), causing 169 (reported) outbreaks so far. The most recent follow-up report (no 9) addressing this epizootic was submitted on 4 Aug 2015, reporting 'no new outbreaks'. All reports addressing this epizootic since its start, and a map showing the 169 infected locations as of 7 Jul 2015, are available at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?fupser=&dothis=&reportid=16926.\n\nThe disease has been spreading into and within other West African countries since early 2015, and so far has been reported from Burkina Faso, Cote d'Ivoire, Niger, and Ghana; see interactive map at http://tinyurl.com/oqenf47 (click on the West African cluster and zoom in). - Mod.AS]", "summary": "\n\nWhile advising farmers to be more proactive, he said that the purchase of birds at the point of lay was 'certainly not the best,' because farmers would not know how the birds were raised. He said that the new cases had been traced to the purchase of birds in Ibadan at the 'point of lay' [when they are about ready to start laying] by some poultry farmers in the 2 states. 28(31) [edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=18215\n\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza, Viet Nam\n-----------------------------\nInformation received on 24 Jul 2015 from Dr Dong Pham Van, director general, chief veterinary officer, Department of Animal Health, Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development, Hanoi, Viet Nam.\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 12 Jul 2015\nDate of confirmation of the event: 18 Jul 2015\nReason for notification: reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 24 Jun 2015\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N6\nNature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory (advanced)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1: Neighbourhood 5, Quynh Tan, Quynh Luu, Nghe An\nDate of start of the outbreak: 12 Jul 2015\nOutbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: backyard\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nBirds / 605 / - / 256 / 349 / 0\n\nOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBirds / ** / 42.31 / ** / 100\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n** Not calculated because of missing information\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: stamping out; disinfection/disinfestations; surveillance outside containment and/or protection zone; no vaccination; no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nRegional Animal Health Office (RAHO3) (national laboratory) / Birds / real-time reverse transcriptase/polymerase chain reaction (RRT-PCR) / 18 Jul 2015 / Positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\nThe location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] HPAI H5N1, OIE\nDate: Fri 24 Jul 2015\nSource: OIE, WAHID weekly disease information 2015; 28(31) [edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=18221\n\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza, Viet Nam\n----------------------------\nInformation received on 24 Jul 2015 from Dr Dong Pham Van, director general, chief veterinary officer, Department of Animal Health, Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development, Hanoi, Viet Nam.\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 18 Jul 2015\nDate of confirmation of the event: 22 Jul 2015\nReason for notification: reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 24 Jun 2015\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory (advanced)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1: Phu Quoi, Phu Quoi, Long Ho, Vinh Long\nDate of start of the outbreak: 18 Jul 2015\nOutbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: backyard\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nBirds / 300 / 300 / 117 / 183 / 0\n\nOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBirds / 100 / 39 / 39 / 100\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: stamping out; disinfection/disinfestations; surveillance outside containment and/or protection zone; no vaccination; no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nRegional Animal Health Office (RAHO7) (national laboratory) / Birds / real-time reverse transcriptase/polymerase chain reaction (RRT-PCR) / 22 Jul 2015 / Positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\nThe location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Previous outbreaks of HPAI H5N1 and H5N6 in Vietnam have taken place earlier this year as follows:\n\n1. HPAI H5N6\nstarted 12 Mar 2015\nTotal outbreaks: 3\nResolved: 25 May 2015\nInteractive map & reports available at: http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?fupser=&dothis=&reportid=17385\n\n2. HPAI H5N1\nStarted 27 May 2015\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nResolved: 24 Jun 2015\nInteractive map & reports available at: http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?fupser=&dothis=&reportid=17835.\n\nViet Nam's HPAI control policy is based upon stamping out.\n\nSince 2003, Viet Nam has suffered a total of 127 HPAI H5N1 cases in humans, of which 64 deaths.\nDuring 2014, 2 human cases were reported, both died. 28(30) [edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=18187 Follow-up report no 4 (19 Jun 2015)\n Follow-up report no 5 (17 Jul 2015)\n Date submitted to OIE: 22 Jul 2015\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2015-05-24 00:00:00", "2015-03-24 00:00:00", "2015-01-09 00:00:00", "2014-03-24 00:00:00", "2014-05-01 00:00:00", "2015-01-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Beijing", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "CHINA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Galongcuo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tibet", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Naqu", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "WAHID", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3512861", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (172): Nigeria, poultry, HPAI H5N1, update", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3512861", "date": "2015-07-15 18:23:07", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (172): NIGERIA, POULTRY, HPAI H5N1, UPDATE\n**********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 12 Jul 2015\nSource: Leadership.ng - News (Nigeria) [edited]\nhttp://leadership.ng/news/446488/bird-flu-1-4-million-birds-destroyed-nvri-boss\n\n\nMore than 1.4 million birds were destroyed to stamp out bird influenza that hit poultry farms early this year [2015], according to Dr. Mohammed Ahmed, the Executive Director, National Veterinary Research Institute, Vom.\n\nAhmed told the News Agency of Nigeria (NAN) in Vom on Sun [12 Jul 2015] that 18 states were affected by the flu, the last case being reported on 28 May 2015. He said that 800 [suspected samples] were [tested] in the institute's laboratory, out of which 500 tested positive to the disease. The NVRI boss said that compensation for the destroyed birds was already being paid by the Federal Government.\n\n'Payment of compensation for the destroyed birds is already in progress; it started and stopped at a point, but it has resumed,' he said. He observed that the compensation was being handled by the Federal Government and appealed to the states to help by initiating steps to assist farmers.\n\n'Since it is the economies of the affected states that are being largely affected, the states should augment the compensation as they did during the 1st outbreak years ago. The states should specifically help in the design of poultry farms to encourage bio-security of the farms,' he explained.\n\nAhmed particularly warned against cluster farms, and blamed that trend for the large number of birds that had to be destroyed.\n\nThe NVRI boss singled out Plateau and Kano as states with the largest concentration of cluster farms and explained that the flu usually spreads faster and engulfs more birds in cluster farms. He expressed satisfaction that the flu was contained in a few months compared to the 1st outbreak, which lasted from 2006-2008, but observed that more birds were destroyed this time.\n\n'More birds had to go because the production of poultry has changed with the cluster farms. In Rantya, a village in Jos South Local Government, for instance, the cluster farms are very close and heavily concentrated in one vicinity,' he said. Ahmed said that the disease had subsided but 'certainly was not over yet.'\n\n'We are not taking anything for granted and have, therefore, gone into active surveillance. We have already trained people to take samples; their task is to buy and test chickens randomly from farms and live bird markets all over the nation. We are virtually out of the passive, so we must go to look for possible cases. There are states and federal offices and officers to handle surveillance even in the remotest of the rural settlements. Such surveillance is usually the most expensive part of disease control, but Nigeria is being supported by some interventions from the World Bank, FAO, USAID and other development partners.'\n\nAhmed said that the Federal Government was also carrying out forensic investigation to ascertain how the disease came in. 'We are forced to do that because what was diagnosed in NVRI laboratories is not related to previous cases; it is a new introduction all together,' [he] explained.\n\nHe said that there were many speculations, with humans suspected to be possible carriers, while poultry importations could also be a source of disease dissemination.\n\nAhmed, however, expressed happiness that no human case had been found, saying that people tested, including farm workers, proved negative.\n\nThe NVRI boss disclosed that another poultry disease, Newcastle disease, was being zeroed in on for eradication by the international community through vaccinations like Thermostable and MDV12, which are usually targeted at poultry farmers in the hinterlands.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Nigeria has reported to the OIE during 2015 2 separate HPAI H5N1 epizootics within its territory, which are at present officially regarded as 'continuing.' The 1st one, which reportedly started on 24 Dec 2014, is located in south and southwest Nigeria. So far, a total of 16 outbreaks have been reported within the framework of this epizootic. The most recent follow-up report, No. 6, was submitted to the OIE on 13 May 2015, reporting 2 new outbreaks of which one was in Lagos State and the other one in Rivers. This and previous reports, as well as a map showing the 16 infected locations, are available at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?fupser=&dothis=&reportid=16977.\n\nThe 2nd and larger epizootic reportedly started on 2 Jan 2015 and has since spread within northern and central Nigeria (Kano, Plateau and Bauchi states), causing 169 (reported) outbreaks so far. The most recent follow-up report (No. 8) addressing this epizootic was submitted on 7 Jul 2015, reporting 46 'new' outbreaks (in fact, they took place during March-April 2015), all in the Plateau province. All reports addressing this epizootic since its start, and a map showing the 169 infected locations as of 7 Jul 2015, are available at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?fupser=&dothis=&reportid=16926.\n\nThe disease has been spreading into and within other West African countries since early 2015, so far reported from Burkina Faso, Cote d'Ivoire, Niger and Ghana; see interactive map at http://tinyurl.com/o9el63k (click on the West African cluster; zoom in). - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/62.]", "summary": "\n\nThe NVRI boss singled out Plateau and Kano as states with the largest concentration of cluster farms and explained that the flu usually spreads faster and engulfs more birds in cluster farms. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n http://leadership.ng/news/446488/bird-flu-1-4-million-birds-destroyed-nvri-boss\n\n\nMore than 1.4 million birds were destroyed to stamp out bird influenza that hit poultry farms early this year [2015], according to Dr. Mohammed Ahmed, the Executive Director, National Veterinary Research Institute, Vom.\n\n \n\nThe 2nd and larger epizootic reportedly started on 2 Jan 2015 and has since spread within northern and central Nigeria (Kano, Plateau and Bauchi states), causing 169 (reported) outbreaks so far. \n\nThe disease has been spreading into and within other West African countries since early 2015, so far reported from Burkina Faso, Cote d'Ivoire, Niger and Ghana; see interactive map at http://tinyurl.com/o9el63k (click on the West African cluster; zoom in). \n\nThe NVRI boss disclosed that another poultry disease, Newcastle disease, was being zeroed in on for eradication by the international community through vaccinations like Thermostable and MDV12, which are usually targeted at poultry farmers in the hinterlands. \n\n'Since it is the economies of the affected states that are being largely affected, the states should augment the compensation as they did during the 1st outbreak years ago. The most recent follow-up report (No. 8) addressing this epizootic was submitted on 7 Jul 2015, reporting 46 'new' outbreaks (in fact, they took place during March-April 2015), all in the Plateau province. Ahmed told the News Agency of Nigeria (NAN) in Vom on Sun [12 Jul 2015] that 18 states were affected by the flu, the last case being reported on 28 May 2015. \n\n'More birds had to go because the production of poultry has changed with the cluster farms. \n\n'Payment of compensation for the destroyed birds is already in progress; it started and stopped at a point, but it has resumed,' he said. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Nigeria has reported to the OIE during 2015 2 separate HPAI H5N1 epizootics within its territory, which are at present officially regarded as 'continuing.' The states should specifically help in the design of poultry farms to encourage bio-security of the farms,' he explained.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2014-03-24 00:00:00", "2015-05-13 00:00:00", "2015-01-02 00:00:00", "2015-03-24 00:00:00", "2015-05-28 00:00:00", "2015-02-24 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Ghana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nigeria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Lagos State", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Newcastle", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3504366", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (113): Turkey, susp, H5N1, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3504366", "date": "2015-07-12 12:30:27", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (113): TURKEY, SUSPECTED, H5N1, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n******************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 8 Jul 2015\nSource: Sunday's Zaman [edited]\nhttp://www.todayszaman.com/national_three-die-from-unidentified-virus-in-adana_393198.html\n\n\nThree people from the same family in Adana's Tufanbeyli district died from an unidentified new virus that is believed to have been transmitted from bovine animals to humans, the authorities have announced. According to a report in the Hurriyet daily, [3] farmers died one after the other on Wed 8 Jul 2015 after they were hospitalized late on Tue 7 Jul 2015 for high fever and shivering. The victims had reportedly treated their cows early on Tuesday.\n\nFollowing the deaths of the farmers, the town was placed under quarantine, and further measures have been taken in several other villages where bird flu was previously seen. Disinfection and hygienic measures have been increased in the affected neighborhood, and Adana municipal teams have been controlling all entries and exits from the district. In addition, hunting activities in the region have also been prohibited.\n\nSpeaking to the press following the incident, Balcali State Hospital head physician Dr Yesim Tasova said that even though the reason for the deaths of the farmers is unknown, they suspect the H5N1 bird flu virus. 'For now, we do not know. The deaths of the 3 individuals happened so quickly. We have sent the bodies for autopsy. When we have the results, we will know the reasons for sure,' Tasova stated.\n\nA total of 150 000 chickens are believed to have been culled since January [2015] due to this incidence of bird flu.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[ProMED-mail requests further information on these 3 deaths from suspected infection with avian influenza. While there have been a large number of birds culled in 2015, it is not clear whether these farmers who had been working with bovines also had contact with poultry or wild birds. For a report on the implication of wild birds in avian flu in Turkey and a request for information on the subject, see: Avian Influenza (168): Turkey (IB) wild birds, RFI 20150704.3485249.\n\nA HealthMap of Turkey can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/87. - Mod.LK]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< For a report on the implication of wild birds in avian flu in Turkey and a request for information on the subject, see: Avian Influenza (168): Turkey (IB) wild birds, RFI 20150704.3485249. According to a report in the Hurriyet daily, [3] farmers died one after the other on Wed 8 Jul 2015 after they were hospitalized late on Tue 7 Jul 2015 for high fever and shivering. While there have been a large number of birds culled in 2015, it is not clear whether these farmers who had been working with bovines also had contact with poultry or wild birds. \n\nA total of 150 000 chickens are believed to have been culled since January [2015] due to this incidence of bird flu. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[ProMED-mail requests further information on these 3 deaths from suspected infection with avian influenza. Speaking to the press following the incident, Balcali State Hospital head physician Dr Yesim Tasova said that even though the reason for the deaths of the farmers is unknown, they suspect the H5N1 bird flu virus. '", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-30 00:00:00", "2021-03-28 00:00:00", "2015-03-24 00:00:00", "2021-01-24 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Turkey", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Adana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "TURKEY", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3462638", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (112): Egypt, H5N1 cases", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3462638", "date": "2015-06-24 20:36:43", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (112): EGYPT, H5N1 CASES\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: 24 Jun 2015\nSource: The Cairo Post [edited]\nhttp://www.thecairopost.com/news/156919/inside_egypt/3-bird-flu-cases-one-death-reported-in-egypts-sohag\n\n\nA 40-year-old woman died of H5N1 avian flu in Upper Egypt's governorate of Sohag Tues [23 Jun 2015], undersecretary of the Ministry of Health for preventive medicine Amr Qandil told Youm7.\n\nDuring the past 3 months, 3 new human cases of H5N1 infection were detected, of which 1 was fatal and the other 2 are being hospitalized, Qandil said.\n\nMost avian flu cases in Egypt have been detected in impoverished rural areas, where villagers are accustomed to raising poultry on the rooftops of their homes to supplement their diet, Ahmed Abdel Hamed, a former Health Ministry official previously told Youm7.\n\nOn 29 Mar 2015, a 27-year-old woman died of bird flu in Upper Egypt's governorate of Sohag, marking the 15th death in the country from the disease in 2015, Youm7 reported.\n\nThe Health Ministry has repeatedly urged citizens who deal with poultry and livestock to be cautious and take preventive measures to avoid infection. It also called on those who suffer from symptoms of the flu to head to the nearest hospital within 24 hours to increase chances of their recovery.\n\nAccording to the State Information Service (SIS), around 2 million Egyptians directly deal with poultry; either by working in the poultry industry or raising poultry in their homes. In both cases, they are outside the scope of supervision by the ministries of agriculture and health.\n\nThe disease initially appeared in Egypt in 2006. The death toll from bird flu in the country reached 10 in 2014. From 2003 until October 2014, there were 686 cases testing positive for H5N1 globally, of which 393 people have died, according to a World Health Organization (WHO) report published in October [2014].\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail and Healthmap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The last report on H5N1 in Egypt posted by ProMED mail -- Avian influenza, human (107): WHO assessment 20150521.3376485 -- stated that 'From 2003 through 1 May 2015, 840 laboratory-confirmed human cases of avian influenza A(H5N1) virus infection have been officially reported to WHO from 16 countries. Of these cases, 447 have died.' See the ProMED post for more.\n\nFluTrackers [https://flutrackers.com/forum/forum/egypt/h5n1-tracking-egypt/720309-egypt-2015-who-moh-provincial-health-depts-h5n1-confirmed-case-list] accounts for 145 cases in 2015 alone in Egypt, clearly a dramatic increase in human cases of H5N1 avian flu in this country, 152 cases including China. The number of cases since November 2014 has exceeded the number of cases ever found in any country since the disease's reemergence in 2004. The number of deaths is unclear, ranging from reports 15 H5N1 deaths in Egypt as of 29 Mar 2015 (according to this report) to 33 deaths as indicated by WHO numbers 9 April [2015]. A panel of experts feels this is likely not related to virus mutations or changing epidemiology but rather to more people becoming exposed to infected poultry. While the warmer months this time of the year dampen transmission, it appears cases of H5N1 continue to occur, or at the least are being reported. This level of avian-to-human influenza virus transmission must be closely monitored because of the public health threat it presents, yet reports have been sparse and difficult to follow.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/55. - Mod.LK]", "summary": "Communicated by:\nProMED-mail and Healthmap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The last report on H5N1 in Egypt posted by ProMED mail -- Avian influenza, human (107): WHO assessment 20150521.3376485 -- stated that 'From 2003 through 1 May 2015, 840 laboratory-confirmed human cases of avian influenza A(H5N1) virus infection have been officially reported to WHO from 16 countries. FluTrackers [https://flutrackers.com/forum/forum/egypt/h5n1-tracking-egypt/720309-egypt-2015-who-moh-provincial-health-depts-h5n1-confirmed-case-list] accounts for 145 cases in 2015 alone in Egypt, clearly a dramatic increase in human cases of H5N1 avian flu in this country, 152 cases including China. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nMost avian flu cases in Egypt have been detected in impoverished rural areas, where villagers are accustomed to raising poultry on the rooftops of their homes to supplement their diet, Ahmed Abdel Hamed, a former Health Ministry official previously told Youm7. On 29 Mar 2015, a 27-year-old woman died of bird flu in Upper Egypt's governorate of Sohag, marking the 15th death in the country from the disease in 2015, Youm7 reported. AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (112): EGYPT, H5N1 CASES\n***********************************************\n The number of cases since November 2014 has exceeded the number of cases ever found in any country since the disease's reemergence in 2004. The number of deaths is unclear, ranging from reports 15 H5N1 deaths in Egypt as of 29 Mar 2015 (according to this report) to 33 deaths as indicated by WHO numbers 9 April [2015]. \n\n\nA 40-year-old woman died of H5N1 avian flu in Upper Egypt's governorate of Sohag Tues [23 Jun 2015], undersecretary of the Ministry of Health for preventive medicine Amr Qandil told Youm7.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2014-03-24 00:00:00", "2014-10-24 00:00:00", "2021-04-09 00:00:00", "2015-06-24 00:00:00", "2015-06-23 00:00:00", "2021-10-24 00:00:00", "2014-11-24 00:00:00", "2015-05-01 00:00:00", "2003-03-24 00:00:00", "2015-03-24 00:00:00", "2004-03-24 00:00:00", "2006-03-24 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Egypt", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Upper Egypt 's", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "EGYPT", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3527954", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (173): West Africa, poultry, HPAI H5N1, spread, FAO", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3527954", "date": "2015-07-22 17:17:38", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (173): WEST AFRICA, HPAI H5N1, SPREAD, FAO\n**********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 20 Jul 2015\nSource: AllAfrica, News24Wire.com, DPA report [edited]\nhttp://allafrica.com/stories/201507202177.html\n\n\nCountries in West Africa, which have been hard hit by the Ebola virus, may soon be battling with a serious bird flu crisis, the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) warned on [Mon 20 Jul 2015].\n\nThe H5N1 bird flu virus is highly contagious and is transmittable to humans. According to the World Health Organization, 447 people across the world have died from it since 2003. The most serious situation is currently in Egypt, with 133 human cases and 37 deaths this year [2015].\n\n'Avian flu [in West Africa] could trigger a mass die-off of chicken -- a nutritious and inexpensive source of food for many people -- with detrimental impacts on diets and on the economy of the region, exacerbating an already difficult situation,' FAO said.\n\n'Urgent action is needed to strengthen veterinary investigation and reporting systems in the region and tackle the disease at the root, before there is a spillover to humans,' Juan Lubroth, Chief of FAO's Animal Health Service Division, said.\n\nThe Rome-based UN agency launched a USD 20 million fundraising appeal for prevention and response activities.\n\nFAO said the H5N1 virus was first detected in West Africa in 2006 and eradicated 2 years later.\n\nIt reappeared in Nigeria in late 2014, has spread to Burkina Faso, Niger, Ivory Coast and Ghana, leading to the death by culling or from infection of more than 1.6 million birds, and may infect also Benin, Cameroon, Mali, and Togo.\n\n'We're looking at a disease -- H5N1 -- that has already spread to 5 countries in 6 months. We have to make a concerted effort to stop it in its tracks and we have to do it now,' Lubroth, the FAO executive, said.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nCeleste Whitlow\n<whitlow.celeste@gmail.com>\n\n[An OIE interactive map showing all HPAI H5N1 outbreaks reported since 1 Jan 2015 is available at http://tinyurl.com/pzvla6z.\nTo centre, click on the West African cluster and zoom in. - Mod.AS]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nCeleste Whitlow\n<whitlow.celeste@gmail.com>\n\n[An OIE interactive map showing all HPAI H5N1 outbreaks reported since 1 Jan 2015 is available at http://tinyurl.com/pzvla6z. \n\n'Avian flu [in West Africa] could trigger a mass die-off of chicken -- a nutritious and inexpensive source of food for many people -- with detrimental impacts on diets and on the economy of the region, exacerbating an already difficult situation,' FAO said. HPAI H5N1, SPREAD\n***************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 19 Jun 2015\nSource: Graphic.com.gn/news [edited]\nhttp://graphic.com.gh/news/general-news/44900-bird-flu-3600-birds-destroyed-at-denu-keta.html\n\n\n2 poultry farms with a total of 3600 birds at Denu and Keta in the Volta Region have been destroyed due to infection of the farms with avian flu.\nThe poultry farm at Keta started with 1800, but before it came to the notice of veterinary officers, 1100 had died, and 700 had also died at Denu within 3 days.\n\nThe Volta Regional Veterinary Officer, Dr Mark Kofi Tettey, who disclosed this to Tim Dzamboe, Graphic Online's Volta Regional correspondent, said the 2 farms had 1800 birds each. He said all the birds have been destroyed together with eggs. The drinking and feeding troughs have accordingly been disinfected. He said an intensive screening exercise had begun in the area and the entire Volta region to ensure that the disease was detected early enough to avoid further spread.\n\nDr Tettey said movement of livestock across markets has been banned as part of bio-security measures to hold the disease in check.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The above 2 outbreaks in the Volta region, bordering the 'Region Maritime' province of Togo, were included among the 5 new outbreaks reported by Ghana on 17 Jun 2015 to the OIE. The outbreak in Denu had, reportedly, started on 1 Jun 2015 and the one in Keta on 8 Jun 2015.\n\nSince the start of the HPAI H5N1 event in Ghana on 13 Apr 2015, 9 outbreaks have been recorded in this West African country and notified. The reports and a summarising map presenting the 9 accumulated outbreaks as of 16 Jun 2015 are available at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?fupser=&dothis=&reportid=17828.\n\nThe Ghana policy in relation to HPAI is 'stamping out.'\n\nThe disease is currently circulating also in 4 other West African countries: Nigeria, Burkina Faso, Cote d'Ivoire and Niger. It would be surprising if neighbouring countries such as Togo and Benin remain uninfected. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/53.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The above 2 outbreaks in the Volta region, bordering the 'Region Maritime' province of Togo, were included among the 5 new outbreaks reported by Ghana on 17 Jun 2015 to the OIE.
