international impact", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3468990", "date": "2015-06-27 11:40:56", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (167): IRAN (MAZANDARAN) HPAI H5N1, POULTRY, INTERNATIONAL IMPACT\n*********************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 23 Jun 2015\nSource: AzerNews [edited]\nhttp://www.azernews.az/business/84274.html\n\n\nAzerbaijan has suspended the import of poultry meat and products from Iran since 22 Jun 2015.\n\nYolchu Khanveli, the representative of the State Veterinary Service at the Azerbaijan Agriculture Ministry, said Azerbaijan banned import of poultry and eggs from the Iranian province of Mazandaran, citing immediate public health concerns.\n\nEarlier on [19 Jun 2015], a case of avian influenza virus had been reported in a flock of 25 birds in Amol village in the province of Mazandaran, according to the National Wildlife Health Center. 7 birds from the flock died and the rest were culled to prevent the further spread of the virus.\n\nThe highly pathogenic avian influenza virus is highly contagious among birds, and can be deadly, especially for domestic poultry. Since December 2003, the Asian HPAI H5N1 virus resulted in devastatingly high rate of mortality for poultry and wild birds in Asia, the Middle East, Europe, and Africa.\n\nIn order to prevent the spread of these viruses in the country, Azerbaijan temporarily halted the import of poultry into the country, Khanveli noted.\n\nThe situation has been under control as of [22 Jun 2015], and there have been no recorded cases of the virus thus far. To maintain stability, the government takes all the necessary measures, Khanveli stressed.\n\nThe poultry industry developed in Azerbaijan in the late 1990s, thanks to the privatization and modernization of Soviet era factory farms. The industry now uses modern automation technology in new, more technologically advanced facilities.\n\nExperts say that today, poultry is the most lucrative sector in Azerbaijan's domestic livestock, which helps to offset the amount of poultry imported into the country.\n\n'The state program on providing the Azerbaijani population of food products for 2008-2015,' aimed to increase the production of poultry meat in the country to 90 000 tons from 61 000 in 2007 and egg production to 1.3 billion pieces from 953 million in 2007.\n\nSince 2011, the demand for eggs was covered mainly by imports, due to a lack of breeding farms. Only 45 percent of domestic demand was covered by the country.\n\nAfter establishing a large poultry farm in Zira village in 2011, equipped with modern facilities made in Holland, Italy, and Turkey, the costs of producing eggs were significantly reduced.\n\n[Byline: Amina Nazarli]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Restrictions on imports of eggs from Iran, following the notification of HPAI H5N1, have been imposed by Iraq as well; see at http://en.trend.az/iran/business/2409366.html.\n\nThe disease was initially reported from Iran on 15 Jun 2015; see ProMED-mail archive no. 20150616.3440421.\n\nAccording to Iran's follow-up report no. 1 to OIE, dated 24 Jun 2015, no additional outbreaks have been reported in Iran since the 1st (and, so far, only) outbreak, which reportedly started on 12 Jun 2015 at Nogardan, Amol, Mazandaran. For both reports and a map, see http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?fupser=&dothis=&reportid=17926.\n\nThe following epidemiological comments were included in follow-up report no. 1:\n'1. The event was detected during intensified passive surveillance implemented in high risk area (risk-based surveillance).\n2. Based on OlE standards and EU directives on HPAI control measures and surveillance activities, an outbreak investigation is ongoing in risk-based surveillance zone; a total of 1,139 serological and molecular samples were collected and tested in Iran Central Veterinary Laboratory (CVL), and all results were negative to avian influenza type A viruses.\n3. To contain and mitigate the probable risk of Al viruses spread, biosecurity measures at all poultry sectors were increased through National communication component of AI surveillance protocol.\n4. Intensified passive surveillance (weekly) in live-bird markets (LBM) is in place. Test results of all collected LBM serological and molecular samples were negative to LPAI and HPAI viruses.\n5. Animal and Public Health sectors' coordinated HPAI surveillance program is active for public health issues.\n6. Through national Media, all people were briefed on management of HPAI risk exposure.\n\nPlease refer also to Mod.CDR's commentary in archive no. 20150616.3440421. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/21167.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\n'The state program on providing the Azerbaijani population of food products for 2008-2015,' aimed to increase the production of poultry meat in the country to 90 000 tons from 61 000 in 2007 and egg production to 1.3 billion pieces from 953 million in 2007. "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3447479", "date": "2015-06-18 10:02:05", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (163): PALESTINIAN AUTHORITY (GAZA) HPAI H5N1, POULTRY, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n***********************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 14 Jun 2015\nSource: Al Wattan [in Arabic, machine trans., summ., edited]\nhttp://www.wattan.tv/ar/news/136490.html\n\n\nThe general director of veterinary services in the Ministry of Agriculture in Gaza, Zakaria Kafarneh, has said: 'The ministry has culled during the past 2 days 8500 chickens infected with bird flu on 3 farms located in the Nuseirat area and Deir al-Balah (central Gaza Strip).\n\nKafarneh added that 'the chicken culling came after the completion of all the procedures and medical tests that proved the disease.'\n\nOn the reason for the emergence of the disease, he said: 'Research and analysis show that the farms hit by the flu are located near a duck farm which is suspected as source of infection.' He explained that the infected ducks do not show disease signs, in contrast to chickens where the disease causes serious clinical signs. In spite of absence of clinical disease, such ducks should be culled.\n\nKafarneh urged the competent veterinary authorities in Ramallah (West Bank) to urgently communicate with the ministry in Gaza in order to put an end to this disease before it spreads, pointing out that his ministry in Gaza lacks budgetary means to allow the required compensation to the owners of culled birds. Without safeguarded compensations, information from farmers may become incomplete and delayed.\n\nHe called upon citizens and farm owners to notify the ministry immediately in case of suspected symptoms of the disease while keeping the birds on farm, refraining from moving them to prevent spread, stressing that crews from the ministry are working with their maximal strength in the fight against any outbreak of the disease.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A serious problem in the densely populated Gaza strip is the presence of numerous backyard holdings in both rural and urban areas. Control of HPAI in such holdings is a complex undertaking.\n\nInformation on the genotype involved is requested; in case it is, as suspected, similar to the virus clade 2.2.1.2 with putative human health impact, circulating in Egypt, severe measures should be applied to protect exposed humans.\n\nHopefully, Dr Kafarneh's call for assistance from the central veterinary authorities in Ramallah is addressed the earliest. Addressing other agencies, including FAO and the reference laboratory for poultry diseases in the Kimron Veterinary Institute, Beit Dagan, in neighbouring Israel, deserve to be considered as well.\n\nThe 2015 epizootic of HPAI H5N1 in the territories of the Palestinian Authority and Israel started in January 2015; for an interactive map showing the locations of all outbreaks reported by both parties since January 2015, please go to http://tinyurl.com/q64kpuf (click on the Eastern Mediterranean cluster and zoom in). - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/88.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n He called upon citizens and farm owners to notify the ministry immediately in case of suspected symptoms of the disease while keeping the birds on farm, refraining from moving them to prevent spread, stressing that crews from the ministry are working with their maximal strength in the fight against any outbreak of the disease. \n\nKafarneh urged the competent veterinary authorities in Ramallah (West Bank) to urgently communicate with the ministry in Gaza in order to put an end to this disease before it spreads, pointing out that his ministry in Gaza lacks budgetary means to allow the required compensation to the owners of culled birds. The general director of veterinary services in the Ministry of Agriculture in Gaza, Zakaria Kafarneh, has said: 'The ministry has culled during the past 2 days 8500 chickens infected with bird flu on 3 farms located in the Nuseirat area and Deir al-Balah (central Gaza Strip). \n\nOn the reason for the emergence of the disease, he said: 'Research and analysis show that the farms hit by the flu are located near a duck farm which is suspected as source of infection.' \n\nThe 2015 epizootic of HPAI H5N1 in the territories of the Palestinian Authority and Israel started in January 2015; in case it is, as suspected, similar to the virus clade 2.2.1.2 with putative human health impact, circulating in Egypt, severe measures should be applied to protect exposed humans.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2015-06-14 00:00:00", "2015-01-24 00:00:00", "2015-03-24 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Israel", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ramallah", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nuseirat", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "West Bank", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Gaza", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Beit Dagan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Gaza Strip", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Egypt", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3436984", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (158): Ghana (AA) poultry, HPAI H5N1, spread", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3436984", "date": "2015-06-14 19:27:29", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (158): GHANA (GREATER ACCRA), POULTRY, HPAI H5N1, SPREAD\n************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 13 Jun 2015\nSource: Ghanaweb.com [edited]\nhttp://www.ghanaweb.com/GhanaHomePage/health/artikel.php?ID=362285\n\n\nThe Ministry of Health has asked Ghanaians to remain calm as the National Technical Coordinating Committee (NTCC) works to bring the outbreak of bird flu under control.\n\n'The public should remain calm. The situation is being technically and expertly handled by the NTCC,' a statement from the Ministry said.\n\nFor the past month, there has been an increase in the mortality of birds, particularly in the Greater Accra Region. On 12 May 2015, the Veterinary Services Directorate laboratory diagnosed influenza type A in a dead bird, which was further confirmed at the Noguchi Memorial Institute as H5N1.\n\nFollowing these preliminary results, a number of interventions have been instituted by the Veterinary Service Directorate and the Ministry of Health in anticipation of the final results.\n\nA further confirmatory result as influenza type A H5N1 was later received from the International Reference laboratory in Italy. Thus, Ghana has been declared as having a bird flu outbreak.\n\nThe statement said although the current bird flu threat to humans remains very low, a screening of the people on the affected farm is being conducted as a precaution.\n\n'All poultry farmers have been alerted to increase their levels of bio-security and to ensure that people do not unnecessarily enter their farms,' it said.\n\nThe statement said the NTCC would continue to organize more education and publicity programmes to educate the public about prevention measures to keep the bird flu disease out of their farms and homes.\n\nAt this stage, the public is assured that it is still quite safe to eat chicken, the statement said, adding that it was not advisable for the public to touch or handle any sick or dead birds with bare hands.\n\nThe public must also report the death of any bird to the nearest local veterinary or agricultural officer whilst desisting from dressing and eating sick or dead birds.\n\nIn addition, poultry products (chicken, turkey, duck, eggs) must be cooked properly (above 70 C [158 F]) before eating, as is the cultural norm in Ghana.\n\nThe statement asked the public to contact the local vet or agricultural officer if they find any sick or dead birds.\n\nFor further information, please contact the Director of Veterinary Services/Head of Public Health (VSD) on 0244289782 or Director of Public Health (GHS), 0244417911.\n\nSince the year 2003, when outbreaks of bird flu (avian influenza) were reported in Southeast Asia, Ghana has continued to monitor the global situation. In Ghana, intensive efforts have been put into the surveillance of the disease, and a national response has been prepared.\n\nThere have been outbreaks of avian influenza in other African countries, including Nigeria, Burkina Faso, Niger, and Ivory Coast within the past 2 months.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Joe Dudley\n\n[The initial 'immediate' notification on the HPAI H5N1 epizootic in Ghana (3 outbreaks) was submitted to the OIE on 2 Jun 2015, notifying about 3 outbreaks that reportedly had started on 13 Apr 2015. The immediate notification ascribed the causal agent to 'highly pathogenic avian influenza virus, serotype H5.' In follow-up report No. 1, submitted 10 Jun 2015, an additional (4th) outbreak was reported, and the completed diagnosis was included, performed by the Experimental Zooprophylactic Institute (IZS), Italy (OIE's Reference Laboratory). Applying reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR), the strain was designated HPAI H5N1.\n\nFor both reports and an interactive map, please access http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?fupser=&dothis=&reportid=17828.\n\nGhana has become the 5th H5N1-infected country in West Africa, joining Nigeria, Burkina Faso, Cote d'Ivoire and Niger. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/53.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nThe statement said the NTCC would continue to organize more education and publicity programmes to educate the public about prevention measures to keep the bird flu disease out of their farms and homes. \n\nThe statement asked the public to contact the local vet or agricultural officer if they find any sick or dead birds. At this stage, the public is assured that it is still quite safe to eat chicken, the statement said, adding that it was not advisable for the public to touch or handle any sick or dead birds with bare hands. \n\n'All poultry farmers have been alerted to increase their levels of bio-security and to ensure that people do not unnecessarily enter their farms,' it said. The public must also report the death of any bird to the nearest local veterinary or agricultural officer whilst desisting from dressing and eating sick or dead birds. \n\nThere have been outbreaks of avian influenza in other African countries, including Nigeria, Burkina Faso, Niger, and Ivory Coast within the past 2 months. The outbreak occurred in a susceptible population of 300 village birds, 200 of which died; another 100 were slaughtered to prevent the spread of the disease.\n\nThe affected village is located in the south of Viet Nam, in Vinh Long province. The source of the outbreak is unknown.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The current HPAI H5N1 event started on 29 Nov 2014, so far involving 9 outbreaks. The new outbreak in the Vinh Long province, reported above, has been notified to the OIE in follow-up report No 9, submitted 17 May 2015. A link to all reports, including the recent follow-up report, and a map are available at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?fupser=&dothis=&reportid=16728.\n\nThis 9th outbreak has been eradicated by the slaughter of the 100 remaining birds.\n\nHPAI H5N1 has been circulating in Viet Nam, causing several major events, since 2003. During this period 127 human cases of avian influenza have been reported, including 64 deaths (2 of them in 2014). The disease peaked in the 2 years 2004/2005 (90 cases, 39 deaths). Since then, control and prevention efforts of the animal health authorities were intensified, including vaccinations of poultry.\n\nAt present, another HPAI strain is circulating as well in Viet Nam, namely H5N6. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/46089.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< AVIAN INFLUENZA (130): VIET NAM, HPAI H5N1, SPREAD\n**************************************************\n Source: The Poultry Site [edited]\nhttp://www.thepoultrysite.com/poultrynews/35097/new-outbreak-of-h5n1-avian-flu-in-viet-nam/\n\n\nThere has been a new outbreak of highly pathogenic avian influenza H5N1 in Viet Nam. The event was reported according to Iran passive surveillance in place.\n2. A post-outbreak investigation is ongoing to trace the source of infection, and to detect a probable spread and circulation of the virus. 3. Active surveillance is ongoing.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: control of wildlife reservoir, stamping out, quarantine, movement control inside the country, screening, zoning, disinfection of infected premises/establishment(s), vaccination prohibited, no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nCentral Veterinary Laboratory of Iran Veterinary Organization (national laboratory) / Birds / real-time reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RRT-PCR) / 14 Jun 2015 / Positive\nRazi Vaccine and Serum Research Institute (national laboratory) / Birds / real-time reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RRT-PCR) / 15 Jun 2015 / positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Amol is located on the banks of the Haraz River 26 25'N 52 21'E, at an altitude of 76 m (250 ft) above sea level, about 18 km (11.2 mi) from the Caspian sea and about 10 km (6.2 mi) from the northern Alborz mountains (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amol).\n\nDuring April and May 2015, Russia and Kazakhstan reported HPAI in wild birds (see report below). These findings were located in areas around the Caspian Sea. Given the proximity of this recent outbreak in Iran to these previous findings, and the occurrence of HPAI H5N1 in wild birds in this area, there is a likely link between these events.\n\nA previous outbreak in Iran was also located in the Mazandaran province. Therefore, it should not be surprising that the disease has now been reported in Cote d'Ivoire.\n\nGiven the fairly recent historical events associated with HPAI in West Africa during 2006-2007, establishing cooperative efforts between the affected countries in the area aimed at reducing the spread of the disease should be a priority.\n\nIn 2006, 5 HPAI outbreaks were reported in Cote d'Ivoire; H5N1 was the subtype identified in all the cases. The outbreaks were located in the provinces of Abidjan (4) and San Pedro (1). See final report at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/temp/reports/en_fup_0000005135_20070327_171750.pdf.\n\nA map of Cote d'Ivoire can be seen at http://www.ephotopix.com/image/africa/ivory_coast_political_map.gif. - Mod.CRD\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/12411.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Measures applied: quarantine; About 6000 birds out of 123 000 died within 5 days. On 29 May 2015, 6 dead chickens were sent to the Pendik Veterinary Institute. A protection zone of 3 km radius around Balabanc\u0131k was declared. In other locations, the disease has not yet been confirmed. The Istanbul Pendik Veterinary Institute has confirmed the suspicion that this is an outbreak of HPAI H5N1.\n\nA surveillance area of 10 km radius has been established. There are suspicions of infection also in the Osmangazi district. About 90 people are involved in the control activities; there are strict animal movements restrictions in markets.\n\n--\ncommunicated by\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A map showing Bursa's districts Mudanya and Osmangazi (and the other 16 districts) in north west Turkey is available at http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Bursa_districts.png.\n\nBursa has become Turkey's 4th HPAI H5N1-infected province since the start of the epizootic, which is reportedly limited, so far, to western Turkey. It started in Kastamonu (24 Apr 2015), followed by the provinces of Balikesir (28 Apr 2015) and Manisa (14 May 2015). The 3 reported outbreaks are presented in the interactive map at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?fupser=&dothis=&reportid=17641. Turkey's policy is one of stamping out.\n\n5 follow-up reports have already been submitted to the OIE, the last on 29 May 2015. The reported total outbreak statistics, as of 29 May 2015, have been summarised by the OIE as follows:\n\nTotal outbreaks = 3 (submitted)\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nBirds / 2 048 083 / 2 048 083 / 322 / 2 047 761 / 0\n\nGenotyping of the strain involved is expected to assist the assessment of its pathogenicity to humans. During the 2005 H5N1 outbreak in Turkey, 12 human cases were reported (4 deaths) in the Eastern parts of the country; it was suggested that children were infected when engaged in collecting the eggs. According to WHO's data, the most recent symptom onset date (or hospital admission) in Turkey was dated 5 Jan 2006.\n\nOn 2 Jun 2015, Turkey's minister of health Mehmet Muezzinoglu reassured the public that it was safe to consume eggs and poultry.\n'We are entering a period where the avian flu will no longer be an issue as the weather gets warmer,' he said, adding that the Ministry of Health, Agriculture and Livestock had taken all necessary measures to prevent the virus from spreading, including imposing quarantines at some farms. See further at http://www.aa.com.tr/en/health/520963--health-minister-dismisses-bird-flu-concerns-in-turkey.\n\nThe outbreak in Bursa has yet to be reported to the OIE. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/87.]", "summary": "\n\n--\ncommunicated by\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A map showing Bursa's districts Mudanya and Osmangazi (and the other 16 districts) in north west Turkey is available at http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Bursa_districts.png. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n The reported total outbreak statistics, as of 29 May 2015, have been summarised by the OIE as follows:\n\nTotal outbreaks = 3 (submitted)\n Birds / 2 048 083 / 2 048 083 / 322 / 2 047 761 / 0\n\nGenotyping of the strain involved is expected to assist the assessment of its pathogenicity to humans. [Turkish, machine transl, summarised, edited]\nhttp://olaybursa.com/bursa-da-kus-gribi-hizla-yayiliyor_d123069.html\n\n\nAn outbreak of avian influenza has led to the culling of 170 000 chickens in a laying flock in the neighbourhood of Balabancik, district Mudanya, province of Bursa. \n\n5 follow-up reports have already been submitted to the OIE, the last on 29 May 2015. It started in Kastamonu (24 Apr 2015), followed by the provinces of Balikesir (28 Apr 2015) and Manisa (14 May 2015). Date: Fri, 5 Jun 2015\n During the 2005 H5N1 outbreak in Turkey, 12 human cases were reported (4 deaths) in the Eastern parts of the country; it was suggested that children were infected when engaged in collecting the eggs. \n\nBursa has become Turkey's 4th HPAI H5N1-infected province since the start of the epizootic, which is reportedly limited, so far, to western Turkey.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2006-01-05 00:00:00", "2015-06-02 00:00:00", "2015-05-29 00:00:00", "2015-04-28 00:00:00", "2015-05-14 00:00:00", "2015-04-24 00:00:00", "2005-03-24 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?fupser=&dothis=&reportid=17641", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Osmangazi", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Balabancik", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "TURKEY", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kastamonu", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Turkey", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mudanya", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3397148", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (140): Egypt, poultry, HPAI H5N1, control, revision", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3397148", "date": "2015-05-30 20:38:32", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (140): EGYPT, POULTRY, HPAI H5N1, CONTROL, REVISION\n********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 29 May 2015\nSource: Youm7 [in Arabic, trans. Mod.AB, edited]\nhttp://tinyurl.com/ptwrjm4\n\n\nThe Ministry of Agriculture and Land Reclamation, represented by the General Organization for Veterinary Services [GOVS] and the organization in charge of animal and poultry wealth, undertook, in coordination with poultry producers, the setting of a timetable for\nthe completion of the preparation of detailed maps for the project named 'poultry villages' in desert country zones. Other actions will consist of: ensuring adherence to preventive measures in feed mills; assessing the commitment to the requirements of bio-safety; preventing bird movements without prior examination; enhancing education; reducing household poultry husbandry and the indiscriminate use of vaccines to curb epidemic diseases; encouraging investment in poultry industry; and offering the possibility to unlicensed farms to obtain their licenses.\n\nAn official source at the Ministry of Agriculture, declared in a statement for 'Youm7', that the ministry, based on the instructions of Dr. Salah Helal, Minister of Agriculture, began to prepare an emergency plan for the transfer of poultry farms to the desert, providing an opportunity to overcome the present problems facing poultry industry and ensure the application of bio-safety and other preventive measures. Those areas will be designed in the modern way. He added that the transfer of poultry farms outside the urban space aims at protecting citizens from any epidemics of poultry origin, such as bird flu.\n\nThe Ministry of Agriculture, in cooperation with the General Union of Poultry Division, poultry Chamber of Commerce has prepared a plan for the transfer of poultry farms outside the Valley and Delta to back desert in 5 areas in order to control poultry diseases and epidemics. Of these there are 21 000 and 60 000 acres respectively east and west of the province of Minya; 28 000 and 60 000 acres respectively in eastern and western Beni Suef; and 95 000 acres in various oases, in addition to the approval of the Planning Commission to allocate 28 000 acres on the Suez and 33 000 acres in Natrun Valley.\n\n[Byline: Ezz Annouby]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-MENA\n<promed-mena@promedmail.org>\n\n[This sounds like good news for the containment of highly pathogenic influenza (HPAI) in poultry, and hence in humans, in Egypt. Hopefully, this series of decisions is backed by a realistic regulatory frame and incentives for the poultry producers and families who raise backyard\npoultry.\n\nThe dimensions reached by the infection in this country are so alarming that such a radical strategy is required. The genetic shifts\nof the virus are indeed of great concern to the scientific community, as it is feared that future mutants of the virus may acquire the\npotential for inter-human propagation. - Mod.AB\n\nBetween November 2014 and February 2015, Egypt saw a major rise in the number of human cases of avian influenza A(H5N1). In fact, the number of cases during this period exceeded the number of cases ever found in any country since the disease's reemergence in 2004. In view of the serious risk of a pandemic, the Ministry for Health and Population requested a joint assessment to better understand the recent upsurge, and to provide concrete measures to curb the trend of increasing infection. From 8-12 Mar 2015, a team representing the World Health Organization (WHO), the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO), the World Organisation for Animal Health (OIE), the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (US-CDC), the United States Naval Medical Research Unit 3 (US-NAMRU-3) and the United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF) met in Egypt with key stakeholders and analysed the situation.\n\nThe report of the team included -- among other issues -- the following comments, addressing the epizootic (poultry-health aspects) of the\nsubject:\n\n'A preponderance of the evidence examined by the team suggests that there has been a real and measurable increase in the incidence of H5N1 [in poultry] since June 2014. Between 1 Dec 2014 and 28 Feb 2015, 333 outbreaks in poultry were observed in Egypt, while between 1 Dec 2013 and 28 Feb 2014 there were only 44 reported outbreaks. Reports indicate that H5N1 is circulating in all sectors of poultry production and geographically in all parts of Egypt. The reasons for this increase are clearly complex and multi-factorial; however, certain factors associated with poultry production and disease control provide possible means of strengthening prevention and response. Changes in the economy and poultry industry since 2011 have had a negative impact on food safety and the capacity of the Ministry of Agriculture and Land Reclamation (MOALR) to prevent or respond to outbreaks of disease. With the reduction in control of poultry production nationally, many small farmers have turned to raising poultry for food and income in an unmonitored and uncontrolled farming sector. Evidence suggests that H5N1 virus is deeply entrenched on such farms and in household flocks. Further, implementation of a proper control strategy is currently impeded by weak response capacity, weak public-private partnerships, sub-optimal vaccination strategies and low levels of biosecurity in some poultry production sectors. [There are] 2 excellent national laboratories that contribute significantly to the diagnosis and control of avian influenza -- the National Laboratory for Quality Control of Poultry Production and Central Laboratory for Evaluation of Veterinary Biologics; both could be used more effectively by linking diagnosis with rapid response and monitoring of disease control and vaccine use.\n\nThe national HPAI Integrated National Plan for Avian and Human Influenza that was developed with support from FAO after the 2009 joint-UN evaluation mission addresses many of the current challenges, but has not been implemented. This strategy should be brought up to date and put into force'.\n\nThe report was presented and discussed in posting 20150516.3366602. It may be assumed that the current new measures have been undertaken following study of the experts' team report.\n\nIt remains to be seen if and how these measures will affect the H5N1 situation in the numerous backyard flocks in Egypt. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/55.]", "summary": "The Ministry of Agriculture, in cooperation with the General Union of Poultry Division, poultry Chamber of Commerce has prepared a plan for the transfer of poultry farms outside the Valley and Delta to back desert in 5 areas in order to control poultry diseases and epidemics. The report of the team included -- among other issues -- the following comments, addressing the epizootic (poultry-health aspects) of the\nsubject:\n\n'A preponderance of the evidence examined by the team suggests that there has been a real and measurable increase in the incidence of H5N1 [in poultry] since June 2014. The Ministry of Agriculture and Land Reclamation, represented by the General Organization for Veterinary Services [GOVS] and the organization in charge of animal and poultry wealth, undertook, in coordination with poultry producers, the setting of a timetable for\nthe completion of the preparation of detailed maps for the project named 'poultry villages' in desert country zones. \n\nAn official source at the Ministry of Agriculture, declared in a statement for 'Youm7', that the ministry, based on the instructions of Dr. Salah Helal, Minister of Agriculture, began to prepare an emergency plan for the transfer of poultry farms to the desert, providing an opportunity to overcome the present problems facing poultry industry and ensure the application of bio-safety and other preventive measures. Other actions will consist of: ensuring adherence to preventive measures in feed mills; assessing the commitment to the requirements of bio-safety; preventing bird movements without prior examination; enhancing education; reducing household poultry husbandry and the indiscriminate use of vaccines to curb epidemic diseases; encouraging investment in poultry industry; and offering the possibility to unlicensed farms to obtain their licenses. Of these there are 21 000 and 60 000 acres respectively east and west of the province of Minya; 28 000 and 60 000 acres respectively in eastern and western Beni Suef; and 95 000 acres in various oases, in addition to the approval of the Planning Commission to allocate 28 000 acres on the Suez and 33 000 acres in Natrun Valley. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n [There are] 2 excellent national laboratories that contribute significantly to the diagnosis and control of avian influenza -- the National Laboratory for Quality Control of Poultry Production and Central Laboratory for Evaluation of Veterinary Biologics; both could be used more effectively by linking diagnosis with rapid response and monitoring of disease control and vaccine use. He added that the transfer of poultry farms outside the urban space aims at protecting citizens from any epidemics of poultry origin, such as bird flu. AVIAN INFLUENZA (140): EGYPT, POULTRY, HPAI H5N1, CONTROL, REVISION\n********************************************************************\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2004-03-24 00:00:00", "2015-05-24 00:00:00", "2014-06-24 00:00:00", "2011-03-24 00:00:00", "2015-03-24 00:00:00", "2009-03-24 00:00:00", "2014-02-28 00:00:00", "2015-02-28 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "the United States Naval", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "POULTRY", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Minya", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "EGYPT", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Egypt", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Natrun Valley", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3373783", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (105): Egypt H5N1", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3373783", "date": "2015-05-20 09:20:54", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (105): EGYPT H5N1\n****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 15 May 2015\nSource: CIDRAP (Center for Infectious Disease Research & Policy) News [edited]\nhttp://www.cidrap.umn.edu/news-perspective/2015/05/avian-flu-scan-may-15-2015\n\n\nGlobal panel: H5N1 surge in Egypt likely due to more poultry contact\n--------------------------------------------------------------------\nThe recent dramatic increase in human cases of H5N1 avian flu in Egypt is likely not related to virus mutations or changing epidemiology but rather to more people becoming exposed to infected poultry, according to the joint findings of experts from 6 leading organizations, the World Health Organization (WHO) said in a press release today [15 May 2015].\n\nFrom November 2014 through April 2015, 165 Egyptian H5N1 cases were reported, including 48 deaths, the WHO release said. (That number, though, is a bit of an undercount, according to FluTrackers, an infectious disease news message board that has been tracking cases closely. FluTrackers, which bases its numbers on official reports, says at least 175 cases have occurred in that period. But either way, the surge is unprecedented in the history of the disease.)\n\n'Based on all the evidence we have, we believe the upsurge is not explained by changes in the virus itself,' said Keiji Fukuda, MD, MPH, WHO assistant director-general for health security and head of the H5N1 investigation team in Egypt, which included WHO, the World Organisation for Animal Health (OIE), the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO), the UN Children's Fund (UNICEF), the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, and US Naval Medical Research Unit 3 (NAMRU-3) in Cairo.\n\n'The most likely reason for the increase in cases is that more poultry in Egypt are infected by H5N1 and so more people are exposed to this virus,' Fukuda added. 'Coupled with insufficient awareness, behavioural patterns, and inadequate precautions taken by humans when interacting with poultry, this explains what we are seeing.' WHO noted, 'There are indications that H5N1 is circulating in all sectors of poultry production and in all parts of Egypt.'\n\nThe expert panel determined these factors about the surge of cases:\n- although human-to-human transmission cannot be excluded, key epidemiologic and demographic features of cases did not change significantly;\n- there was no evidence of transmission from patients to healthcare workers;\n- about 70 per cent of cases involved known exposure to infected backyard poultry;\n- genetic sequence data revealed no changes to indicate more efficient human-to-human transmission.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This report is basically a summary of the executive summary that resulted from an invitation Egypt extended 2 months ago to WHO, the FAO, NAMRU-3, CDC, and UNICEF for a joint investigation of H5N1 in the country, and to make recommendations on containing that outbreak. See ProMED-mail Avian influenza, human (104): Egypt H5N1 20150516.3366602.\n\nMaps of Egypt can be found at http://www.geoatlas.com/medias/maps/countries/egypt/eg3r92t/egypt_pol.jpg and <http://healthmap.org/promed/p/55. - Mod.LK]", "summary": "\n\nThe expert panel determined these factors about the surge of cases:\n- although human-to-human transmission cannot be excluded, key epidemiologic and demographic features of cases did not change significantly;\n- there was no evidence of transmission from patients to healthcare workers;\n- about 70 per cent of cases involved known exposure to infected backyard poultry;\n- genetic sequence data revealed no changes to indicate more efficient human-to-human transmission. 28(24) [edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=17878\n\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza, Russia\n-----------------------------------------\nInformation received on 11 Jun 2015 from Dr Evgeny Nepoklonov, Deputy Head, Federal Service for Veterinary and Phytosanitary Surveillance, Ministry of Agriculture, Moscow, Russia.\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 28 May 2015\nDate of pre-confirmation of the event: 9 Jun 2015\nReason for notification: reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 27 Apr 2015\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: laboratory (basic), laboratory (advanced)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nOutbreak 1: Ubsu-Nur, Ovyursky, Respublika Tyva [Tuva]\nDate of start of the outbreak: 28 May 2015\nOutbreak status: resolved 10 Jun 2015\nEpidemiological unit: not applicable\nAffected animals\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nGreat crested grebe: _Podiceps cristatus_ (Podicipedidae) / - / 2 / 2 / 0 / 0\nCommon tern: _Sterna hirundo_ (Laridae) / - / 2 / 2 / 0 / 0\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: contact with wild species\nEpidemiological comments: During the active monitoring of the ornithofauna in the surroundings of Ubsu-Nur Lake, a few wild birds were found dead. Highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) virus H5N1 was detected and isolated in samples from carcasses of 2 great crested grebes and 2 common terns. No HPAI virus H5N1 has been detected in samples from healthy migratory birds of different species: great crested grebes (_Podiceps cristatus_), great cormorant (_Phalacrocorax carbo_), red-crested pochard (_Netta rufina_), gadwall (_Anas strepera_), common tern (_Sterna hirundo_), common coot (_Fulica atra_), black-headed gull (_Larus ridibundus_). Sequence analysis of the isolates showed that they belonged to the Asian HPAI virus H5N1 lineage, clade 2.3.2.1, and had close similarity with previous Russian H5N1 virus isolates of years 2014-2015.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: control of wildlife reservoirs, screening, no vaccination, no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type: All-Russian Research Institute for Animal Health (FGBI-ARRIAH) (national laboratory)\nSpecies / Test / Test date / Result\nCommon tern / real-time reverse transcriptase-polymerase chain reaction (RRT-PCR) / 9 Jun 2015 / Positive\nCommon tern / virus isolation / 9 Jun 2015 / Positive\nGreat crested grebe / real-time reverse transcriptase/polymerase chain reaction (RRT-PCR)/ 9 Jun 2015/ Positive\nGreat crested grebe / virus isolation / 9 Jun 2015 / Positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The Ubsunur (Uvs Nuur) is a large (70 km by 80 km), shallow (up to 15 m) saline lake located between Russia's Tyva (Tuva) Republic and Mongolia in the western part of the vast internal drainage intermontane basin.\n\nThe fauna list of the Ubsunur Hollow Reserve counts about 80 mammals and over 350 bird species. Ubsunur lake with the adjacent bogged meadows and solonchaks (salt marshes) attracts a lot of geese, swans, Charadriiformes, herons, cormorants, gulls, terns and other waterfowl and nearwater bird species (http://www.nhpfund.org/nominations/uvs-nuur.html).\n\nThe great crested grebe is a widespread Old World grebe breeding in Eurasia, Africa and Australasia. In Eurasia, it breeds across most of the continent from Iberia and the British Isles eastwards ranging north to central parts of Sweden and Finland and south to the Mediterranean coast and Turkey. Its range extends eastwards across Asia to China and locally in Japan but absent from most of Arabia, India and Southeast Asia (http://www.birdforum.net/opus/Great_Crested_Grebe).\n\nThe common tern has a circumpolar distribution, breeding in temperate and sub-arctic regions of Europe, Asia and east and central North America. It is strongly migratory, wintering in the subtropical and tropical oceans. It is sometimes known as the sea swallow (http://www.birdforum.net/opus/Common_Tern). - Mod.CRD\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/409.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Date of previous occurrence: 27 Apr 2015\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\n Measures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type: All-Russian Research Institute for Animal Health (FGBI-ARRIAH) (national laboratory)\n Serotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: laboratory (basic), laboratory (advanced)\n Affected animals\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\n Summary\nReport type: immediate notification\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Common tern: _Sterna hirundo_ (Laridae) / - / 2 / 2 / 0 / 0\n\nEpidemiology\n Common tern / real-time reverse transcriptase-polymerase chain reaction (RRT-PCR) / 9 Jun 2015 / Positive\n Great crested grebe: _Podiceps cristatus_ (Podicipedidae) / - / 2 / 2 / 0 / 0\n Common tern / virus isolation / 9 Jun 2015 / Positive\n No HPAI virus H5N1 has been detected in samples from healthy migratory birds of different species: great crested grebes (_Podiceps cristatus_), great cormorant (_Phalacrocorax carbo_), red-crested pochard (_Netta rufina_), gadwall (_Anas strepera_), common tern (_Sterna hirundo_), common coot (_Fulica atra_), black-headed gull (_Larus ridibundus_). [The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\n This event pertains to a defined zone within the country\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\n Date of pre-confirmation of the event: 9 Jun 2015\n Source: OIE, WAHID weekly disease information 2015; 28(24) [edited]\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2015-06-11 00:00:00", "2015-05-24 00:00:00", "2015-06-10 00:00:00", "2015-03-24 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Charadriiformes", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Finland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Iberia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australasia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Turkey", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Arabia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ovyursky", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sweden", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sterna", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Eurasia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "WAHID", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "India", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Moscow", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3366602", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (104): Egypt H5N1", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3366602", "date": "2015-05-16 13:29:12", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (104): EGYPT H5N1\n****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 15 May 2015\nSource: WHO/FAO/OIE/US-CDC/US-NAMRU-3/UNICEF [edited]\nhttp://www.emro.who.int/images/stories/Executive_Summary_14_May_2015.pdf?ua=1\n\n\nJoint high-level mission on the current H5N1 situation in Egypt\n-----\nEgypt, 8-12 Mar 2015\n\nExecutive summary\n\nIntroduction\n----\nBetween November 2014 and February 2015, Egypt saw a major rise in the number of human cases of avian influenza A(H5N1). In fact, the number of cases occurring in this period exceeded the number of cases ever found in any country since the disease's reemergence in 2004. In view of the serious risk of a pandemic, which is enhanced by the enzootic state of H5N1 in Egypt, the Ministry for Health and Population requested a joint assessment to better understand the recent upsurge, and to provide concrete measures to curb the trend of increasing infection. From 8-12 Mar [2015], a team representing the World Health Organization (WHO), the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO), the World Organisation for Animal Health (OIE), the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (US-CDC), the United States Naval Medical Research Unit 3 (US-NAMRU-3) and the United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF) met with key stakeholders and analysed the current situation.\n\nSummary of findings\n----\n\nAnimal health (Please see in commentary below)\n\nHuman health\n----\nConcomitant with the dramatic increase in the number of poultry outbreaks, there has been an unprecedented increase in the number of human cases detected each month, particularly from December 2014 through February 2015. According to the Ministry of Health and Population, the numbers of H5N1 cases reported for these months greatly exceeded the expected numbers based on historical data.\n\nThis upsurge most likely results from increased exposure of people to infected poultry. Most recent human cases (approximately 70 percent) had exposure to backyard poultry. Children under 5 make up a significantly higher portion of all confirmed H5N1 cases in Egypt (33 percent) compared with the rest of the world (15 percent). Young children and women often are engaged in rearing backyard poultry, which puts them at high risk during poultry outbreaks.\n\nLikewise, the number of human samples being tested for H5N1 has increased compared with [during] earlier poultry outbreaks. Testing has also increased as a result of rapid response by the preventive sector and increased awareness among clinicians.\n\nDespite the unprecedented surge in human cases in Egypt, it does not appear that the risk of an H5N1 pandemic has changed appreciably. This conclusion is based on the following:\n1) although human-to-human transmission cannot be excluded, there has been no change in the size or number of clusters of human cases during the surge compared with previous years;\n2) there is no evidence of transmission from patients to healthcare workers during the surge;\n3) most recent human cases had direct or indirect poultry contact;\n4) genetic sequence data have not identified changes that would make human-to-human transmission efficient.\n\nNevertheless, the presence of H5N1 viruses in Egypt with the ability to jump more readily from birds to humans than viruses in other enzootic countries is of concern and requires a high level of vigilance from the Ministries of Health and Agriculture.\n\nThe Ministry of Health and Population has strengthened multiple disease surveillance [for] influenza-like illness (ILI), severe acute respiratory infections (SARI) and avian influenza [which has] generated valuable epidemiological information for this and other important influenza outbreaks. The Central Public Health Laboratory functions well and has provided training for regional and local laboratories.\n\nGenetic and antigenic data from human and poultry samples are being jointly analysed by staff in Egypt along with international counterparts. However, increased real-time sharing and analysis should be encouraged. The 4-way linking platform could be used to accomplish this; it should also meet fortnightly during a surge of cases and every 2 months when there are no outbreaks.\n\nThe Ministry of Health and Population has purchased antiviral drugs (neuraminidase inhibitors) [which] have been made available to clinicians for patients with suspected and laboratory-confirmed infections. This is particularly important to reduce mortality\n\nCoordination and collaboration\nCommunication for behavior change\n\nKey recommendations\n----\nCoordination and strategic planning\nMinistry of Agriculture and Land Reclamation\nMinistry of Health and Population\nCommunication for behavior change\n\nThe way forward\n----\nA successful approach to addressing H5N1 requires long-term, sustainable investments in agriculture, health and communities. In particular, close collaboration between sectors is required in communications, policy development, surveillance and response, and the production and sharing of information. Accurate, regular assessment of the impact of control measures is required to evaluate progress.\n\nThe government should undertake 1 or more pilot projects at the district level to determine which changes in policies and practices are most effective in reducing spread of infection among poultry and to humans and sustainable on a medium- to long-term basis. Addressing H5N1 nationally will require long-term changes in policies, practices, culture, awareness and community engagement.\n\nWithin 3 months, a 2-year action plan that encompasses these recommendations and includes clear outcomes and indicators for monitoring will be developed by the ministries of health, agriculture and local development. FAO, WHO and OIE will support development of the plan, which will be presented to the NSC.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This Executive summary is the result of an invitation Egypt extended 2 months ago to the WHO, FAO, NAMRU-3, CDC and UNICEF for a joint investigation of H5N1 in the country, and to make recommendations on containing that outbreak.\n\nThe updated H5N1 case count from WHO, which covers reported cases since November 2014 to 30 April 2015,, is 165 cases and 48 deaths. This represents an increase in human cases over what has been observed in previous years in Egypt. Case fatality appears to be lower in Egypt compared with other countries, likely because children are more commonly infected in Egypt. The task of controlling spread of the virus represents a serious challenge to Egypt. While there is no evidence for other than occasional spread from human to human, the risk exists and must be closely monitored.\n\nMaps of Egypt can be found at http://www.geoatlas.com/medias/maps/countries/egypt/eg3r92t/egypt_pol.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/55. - Mod.LK]\n\n[The executive summary of the mission includes a section on the animal health aspects of HPAI H5N1 in Egypt. The following extracts deserve attention:\n\n'A preponderance of the evidence examined by the team suggests that there has been a real and measurable increase in the incidence of H5N1 [in poultry] since June 2014. Between 1 Dec 2014 and 28 Feb 2015, 333 outbreaks in poultry were observed in Egypt, while between 1 Dec 2013 and 28 Feb 2014 there were only 44 reported outbreaks. Reports indicate that H5N1 is circulating in all sectors of poultry production and geographically in all parts of Egypt. The reasons for this increase are clearly complex and multi-factorial; however, certain factors associated with poultry production and disease control provide possible means of strengthening prevention and response. Changes in the economy and poultry industry since 2011 have had a negative impact on food safety and the capacity of the Ministry of Agriculture and Land Reclamation (MOALR) to prevent or respond to outbreaks of disease. With the reduction in control of poultry production nationally, many small farmers have turned to raising poultry for food and income in an unmonitored and uncontrolled farming sector. Evidence suggests that H5N1 virus is deeply entrenched on such farms and in household flocks. Further, implementation of a proper control strategy is currently impeded by weak response capacity, weak public-private partnerships, sub-optimal vaccination strategies and low levels of biosecurity in some poultry production sectors. [There are] 2 excellent national laboratories that contribute significantly to the diagnosis and control of avian influenza -- the National Laboratory for Quality Control of Poultry Production and Central Laboratory for Evaluation of Veterinary Biologics; both could be used more effectively by linking diagnosis with rapid response and monitoring of disease control and vaccine use.'\n\n'The national HPAI Integrated National Plan for Avian and Human Influenza that was developed with support from FAO after the 2009 joint-UN evaluation mission addresses many of the current challenges, but has not been implemented. This strategy should be brought up to date and put into force. Since 2007, through USAID-funded FAO projects, considerable investment has been made to improve the animal health surveillance system in Egypt, including the establishment of 230 epidemiological units covering almost all districts and governorate; 4 animal disease surveillance systems (passive reporting, community animal health outreach, targeted live bird market reporting, and active surveillance) are maintained by the Veterinary Services. Surveillance data are regularly shared between national stakeholders and with other relevant partners (OFFLU, EMPRES-i, etc.), including through publication in peer-reviewed journals'. - Mod.AS]", "summary": "This conclusion is based on the following:\n1) although human-to-human transmission cannot be excluded, there has been no change in the size or number of clusters of human cases during the surge compared with previous years;\n2) there is no evidence of transmission from patients to healthcare workers during the surge;\n3) most recent human cases had direct or indirect poultry contact;\n4) genetic sequence data have not identified changes that would make human-to-human transmission efficient. ----\nCoordination and strategic planning\nMinistry of Agriculture and Land Reclamation\nMinistry of Health and Population\nCommunication for behavior change\n\nThe way forward\n A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \nConcomitant with the dramatic increase in the number of poultry outbreaks, there has been an unprecedented increase in the number of human cases detected each month, particularly from December 2014 through February 2015. Egypt, 8-12 Mar 2015\n\nExecutive summary\n\nIntroduction\n [There are] 2 excellent national laboratories that contribute significantly to the diagnosis and control of avian influenza -- the National Laboratory for Quality Control of Poultry Production and Central Laboratory for Evaluation of Veterinary Biologics; both could be used more effectively by linking diagnosis with rapid response and monitoring of disease control and vaccine use.' \nBetween November 2014 and February 2015, Egypt saw a major rise in the number of human cases of avian influenza A(H5N1). AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (104): EGYPT H5N1\n****************************************\n Since 2007, through USAID-funded FAO projects, considerable investment has been made to improve the animal health surveillance system in Egypt, including the establishment of 230 epidemiological units covering almost all districts and governorate; 4 animal disease surveillance systems (passive reporting, community animal health outreach, targeted live bird market reporting, and active surveillance) are maintained by the Veterinary Services. [edited]\nhttp://www.emro.who.int/images/stories/Executive_Summary_14_May_2015.pdf?ua=1\n\n\nJoint high-level mission on the current H5N1 situation in Egypt\n (Please see in commentary below)\n\nHuman health\n \n\n'The national HPAI Integrated National Plan for Avian and Human Influenza that was developed with support from FAO after the 2009 joint-UN evaluation mission addresses many of the current challenges, but has not been implemented. Between 1 Dec 2014 and 28 Feb 2015, 333 outbreaks in poultry were observed in Egypt, while between 1 Dec 2013 and 28 Feb 2014 there were only 44 reported outbreaks. The following extracts deserve attention:\n\n'A preponderance of the evidence examined by the team suggests that there has been a real and measurable increase in the incidence of H5N1 [in poultry] since June 2014. \n\nGenetic and antigenic data from human and poultry samples are being jointly analysed by staff in Egypt along with international counterparts. From 8-12 Mar [2015], a team representing the World Health Organization (WHO), the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO), the World Organisation for Animal Health (OIE), the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (US-CDC), the United States Naval Medical Research Unit 3 (US-NAMRU-3) and the United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF) met with key stakeholders and analysed the current situation. FAO, WHO and OIE will support development of the plan, which will be presented to the NSC.\n\n--\n Communication for behavior change\n\nKey recommendations\n This is particularly important to reduce mortality\n\nCoordination and collaboration\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< The Ministry of Health and Population has strengthened multiple disease surveillance [for] influenza-like illness (ILI), severe acute respiratory infections (SARI) and avian influenza [which has] generated valuable epidemiological information for this and other important influenza outbreaks. With the reduction in control of poultry production nationally, many small farmers have turned to raising poultry for food and income in an unmonitored and uncontrolled farming sector. Likewise, the number of human samples being tested for H5N1 has increased compared with [during] earlier poultry outbreaks. In fact, the number of cases occurring in this period exceeded the number of cases ever found in any country since the disease's reemergence in 2004.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["influenza-like illness"], "event_date": ["2015-04-30 00:00:00", "2011-03-24 00:00:00", "2015-02-24 00:00:00", "2015-02-28 00:00:00", "2009-03-24 00:00:00", "2014-12-24 00:00:00", "2004-03-24 00:00:00", "2014-06-24 00:00:00", "2007-03-24 00:00:00", "2015-03-24 00:00:00", "2014-02-28 00:00:00", "2014-11-24 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "EGYPT", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States Naval", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Egypt", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3351552", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (117): Nigeria (Plateau) poultry, HPAI H5N1, update", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3351552", "date": "2015-05-09 14:50:39", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (117) : NIGERIA (PLATEAU) POULTRY, HPAI H5N1, UPDATE\n********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 8 May 2015\nSource: The Eagle online [summarized, edited]\nhttp://theeagleonline.com.ng/bird-flu-plateau-govt-quarantines-160-farms-culls-400000-birds/\n\n\nMr John Dasar, the Chairman, Poultry Farmers Association of Nigeria (PAN) in the [Plateau] state, announced at a sensitisation workshop on bio-security on Thursday [7 May 2015]:\n\n'Between January 2015 and now, more than 160 farms were affected by this dreaded disease and were quarantined, with 153 of them completely shut down.'\n\n'No fewer than 400 000 birds were culled. Poultry business has sustained many families in Plateau.'\n\n'The attitude of some farmers was not good, as many of them took measures that were not friendly, and so helping to spread the disease to farms of even close friends,'' he said.\n\nDasar appealed to the state government to look into the plights of poultry farmers by helping to proffer workable solution to the menace.\n\n[Byline: Moses Gbande]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Since the start of the current HPAI H5N1 epizootic in Nigeria, reportedly early January 2015, a total number of 55 outbreaks in poultry have been reported to the OIE, of which 14 were in the south and 41 in the north-centre (Kano, Plateau and Bauchi states). "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3336988", "date": "2015-05-02 10:36:34", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (106): BURKINA FASO, HPAI H5N1, POULTRY, SPREAD\n***************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 1 May 2015\nSource: The Poultry Site [edited]\nhttp://www.thepoultrysite.com/poultrynews/34962/seven-new-outbreaks-of-bird-flu-in-burkina-faso/\n\n\nThere have been 7 new outbreaks of H5N1 highly pathogenic avian influenza in the country.\n\nAccording to follow-up report no 2 to the World Organisation for Animal Health (OIE), dated 29 Apr 2015, the veterinary authority in Burkina Faso reports 7 new outbreaks of H5N1 [highly pathogenic avian influenza] on poultry farms, all starting on 19 Apr 2015.\n\nMost of the affected farms were in the provinces of Kadiogo (5) and Poni (1), which have reported previous outbreaks, but Bazega in central Burkina Faso now has its 1st cases.\n\nOf the 18 264 bird affected, 16 009 died and 2255 were slaughtered.\nThe presence of the H5N1 subtype of the virus has been confirmed.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Since the start of the current HPAI H5N1 epizootic in Burkina Faso, in early February 2015 (initially reported to the OIE 1 Apr 2015), a total of 18 outbreaks, in 6 provinces, have been reported to the OIE. This includes the 7 new outbreaks covered in follow-up report no. 2, submitted on 30 Apr 2015, and available (with an interactive map) at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapEventSummary&reportid=17625.\n\nThe epizootic continues it spread in Nigeria and has spread to Niger as well. The virus spreading in the 3 countries is considered to be caused by a novel clade of the A(H5N1) virus, specifically clade 2.3.2.1c, which, according to a recent 'ahead of print' paper (see reference below), most likely entered Nigeria in December 2014. The authors further indicate that the identification of genetic clustering between the strains from Nigeria and the HPAI A(H5N1) viruses originally identified in Asia, suggests an unknown epidemiologic link between these regions, probably associated with human activities, migratory bird movements, or both. They further state that this virus is an intersubtype reassortant which has already caused infection in humans, underlining the urgent need for its complete characterization in terms of virulence and host range.\n\nA map showing all 18 outbreaks in Burkina Faso is available at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?fupser=&dothis=&reportid=17455.\n\nFor further background, please refer to the commentary by Mod.CRD in ProMED-mail posting 20150402.3272825.\n\nReference\n---------\nMonne I, Meseko C, Joannis T, et al: Highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N1) virus in poultry, Nigeria, 2015 [letter]. Emerg Infect Dis. 2015; (21)7; http://dx.doi.org/10.3201/eid2107.150421. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/49.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n According to follow-up report no 2 to the World Organisation for Animal Health (OIE), dated 29 Apr 2015, the veterinary authority in Burkina Faso reports 7 new outbreaks of H5N1 [highly pathogenic avian influenza] on poultry farms, all starting on 19 Apr 2015. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Since the start of the current HPAI H5N1 epizootic in Burkina Faso, in early February 2015 (initially reported to the OIE 1 Apr 2015), a total of 18 outbreaks, in 6 provinces, have been reported to the OIE. \nMonne I, Meseko C, Joannis T, et al: Highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N1) virus in poultry, Nigeria, 2015 [letter]. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2015-04-19 00:00:00", "2015-03-24 00:00:00", "2014-12-24 00:00:00", "2255-03-24 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Nigeria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Burkina Faso", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3337773", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (107): India (MN) HPAI H5N1, poultry, susp, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3337773", "date": "2015-05-02 18:22:02", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (107): INDIA (MANIPUR) HPAI H5N1, POULTRY, SUSPECTED, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n*********************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 2 May 2015\nSource: Domain-b.com [edited]\nhttp://www.domain-b.com/economy/agriculture/20150502_operation.html\n\n\nClose on the heels of an outbreak of avian influenza in Telangana [state], the National Institute of High Security Animal Diseases (NIHSAD) on Thursday [30 Apr 2015] reported that the disease has affected poultry birds in Manipur [state] as well.\n\nThe NIHSAD on Thursday [30 Apr 2015] said a dead chicken referred to it by the director of ICAR Research Complex in Imphal, Manipur, was found positive for H5N1 avian flu virus. The institute has suggested an action plan to contain and control the spread of the disease and has sought a detailed report from the state veterinary authorities.\n\nSince then the state government has carried out control and containment operation and the authorities have, on Thursday, issued a sanitisation certificate for the epicentre.\n\nDuring the operation, 20 874 birds were culled while 940 had died out of a population of 21 814 birds in a 1 km [about 0.6 mile] radius. The department has issued a post-operation surveillance plan, which will be continued for a period of 3 months, an official release said.\n\nMeanwhile, in Telangana, the control and containment operation at the epicenter is over and the state authorities have issued a sanitisation certificate for the epicenter.\n\nDuring the operation, 16 024 birds were culled while 41 040 had died out of a population of 201 264 birds in a 1 km radius. The state veterinary department has issued the post-sanitisation surveillance, which will be continued for a period of 3 months, the release added.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Official confirmation on the spread of HPAI H5N1 into a 5th Indian state, namely Manipur, is anticipated. Since November 2014, the disease has been officially reported in poultry from Kerala, Uttar Pradesh, Chandigarh and Telangana. No human cases reported. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/311.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nMeanwhile, in Telangana, the control and containment operation at the epicenter is over and the state authorities have issued a sanitisation certificate for the epicenter. \n\n\nClose on the heels of an outbreak of avian influenza in Telangana [state], the National Institute of High Security Animal Diseases (NIHSAD) on Thursday [30 Apr 2015] reported that the disease has affected poultry birds in Manipur [state] as well. During the operation, 20 874 birds were culled while 940 had died out of a population of 21 814 birds in a 1 km [about 0.6 mile] radius. The state veterinary department has issued the post-sanitisation surveillance, which will be continued for a period of 3 months, the release added. During the operation, 16 024 birds were culled while 41 040 had died out of a population of 201 264 birds in a 1 km radius. Since then the state government has carried out control and containment operation and the authorities have, on Thursday, issued a sanitisation certificate for the epicentre. The department has issued a post-operation surveillance plan, which will be continued for a period of 3 months, an official release said.", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2014-11-24 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Manipur", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kerala", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Imphal", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "INDIA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Telangana", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3338904", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (109): Turkey (BK) poultry, HPAI H5N1, susp. RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3338904", "date": "2015-05-03 19:01:20", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (109): TURKEY (BALIKASIR) POULTRY, HPAI H5N1, SUSPECTED, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n************************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 3 May 2015\nSource: Hurriyet Daily [edited]\nhttp://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/bird-flu-found-in-turkeys-west-area-quarantined-.aspx?pageID=238&nID=81889&NewsCatID=341\n\n\nBird flu was found among dead birds in Turkey's western district of Bandirma's Edincik area, where around 1.2 million chickens are bred in poultry facilities. The 3 km surrounding the poultry facility where the flu was found was quarantined.\n\nBandirma District Governor Ali Manti said bird flu was discovered in a poultry facility in the Edincik region, the site of many chicken deaths in the past months.\n\n'All protection measures were taken in the facility where the disease was determined. The cleaning process has been done after the killing and extermination processes. Poultry which was near the infected facility or held the risk of being infected was slaughtered,' said Manti.\n\nManti said the investigation launched by the Ministry of Food, Agriculture and Livestock's district directorate after more than 40 000 chickens died in 4 months was finalized, and samples taken from the dead birds had been sent to labs.\n\nPoultry entrance and exit to and from Edincik have been banned. The regional governorate barred any kind of hunting in the region, while the gendarmerie blocked the road leading to Edincik. Only officials are allowed in the region.\n\nSait Koca, the head of the White Meat Industrialists' Union, said the reason for bird flu in Turkey was migrant birds, as the route of these birds included Bandirma, where the infection was reported.\n\n'The viruses that migrant birds carry cannot enter closed production facilities. The chickens that are bred in the open as 'natural' are exposed to all external threats,' said Koca.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Edincik is located on the south shore of the Marmara Sea, northwest Turkey; see map at http://tinyurl.com/lovaq9l.\n\nEarlier this year, January/February 2015, the virus was reported from wild birds (Rock dove, Black headed gull, Dalmatian pelican) and in a backyard poultry holding in neigbouring East Bulgaria (Burgas). An EU/ SCoPAFF presentation on the Bulgarian event, presented in Brussels on 17 Apr 2015, is available at http://ec.europa.eu/food/committees/regulatory/scfcah/animal_health/docs/2015041617_ai_bulgaria_en.pdf.\n\nDuring the same meeting, another country on the Black Sea shores, Romania, presented a report on a severe outbreak in March 2015 affecting the pelican population in its delta area. A mortality of 46 percent in these wild birds was reported; for details, see http://ec.europa.eu/food/committees/regulatory/scfcah/animal_health/docs/2015041617_hpai_h5n1_romania_en.pdf. (Thanks to Sabine Zentis for drawing our attention to the above presentations).\n\nTurkey's previous HPAI H5N1 reports date back to 2008, when 6 of the outbreaks, which occurred along its northern shores along the Black Sea, were considered to have had their source in wild birds. (See commentary in posting 20080325.1118).\n\nFurther information on the Turkish event and its official notification, if confirmed, are anticipated. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/87.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nSait Koca, the head of the White Meat Industrialists' Union, said the reason for bird flu in Turkey was migrant birds, as the route of these birds included Bandirma, where the infection was reported. \n\nManti said the investigation launched by the Ministry of Food, Agriculture and Livestock's district directorate after more than 40 000 chickens died in 4 months was finalized, and samples taken from the dead birds had been sent to labs. \n\nEarlier this year, January/February 2015, the virus was reported from wild birds (Rock dove, Black headed gull, Dalmatian pelican) and in a backyard poultry holding in neigbouring East Bulgaria (Burgas). The chickens that are bred in the open as 'natural' are exposed to all external threats,' said Koca.\n\n--\n http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/bird-flu-found-in-turkeys-west-area-quarantined-.aspx?pageID=238&nID=81889&NewsCatID=341\n\n\nBird flu was found among dead birds in Turkey's western district of Bandirma's Edincik area, where around 1.2 million chickens are bred in poultry facilities. \n\nTurkey's previous HPAI H5N1 reports date back to 2008, when 6 of the outbreaks, which occurred along its northern shores along the Black Sea, were considered to have had their source in wild birds.
