28 (19) [edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=17641\n\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza, Turkey\n-----------------------------------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 4 May 2015 from Prof. Dr Irfan Erol, Director General of Food and Control, Directorate of Food and Control, Ministry of Food, Agriculture and Livestock, Ankara, Turkey\n\nSummary\nReport type: Immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 23 Apr 2015\nDate of pre-confirmation of the event: 30 Apr 2015\nReason for notification: Reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: April 2008\nManifestation of disease: Clinical disease\nCausal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: Clinical, Laboratory (advanced)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country.\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks: Total outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1: Ikizciler, Kastamonu\nDate of start of the outbreak: 23 Apr 2015\nOutbreak status: Continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: Backyard\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nBirds / 127 / 127 / 35 / 92 / 0\n\nOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBirds / 100 / 27.56 / 27.56 / 100\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Unknown or inconclusive\nEpidemiological comment: Highly pathogenic avian influenza H5N1 was detected as a result of analysis. Protection and surveillance zones have been established in the area surrounding the outbreak. 92 backyard poultry were destroyed in a 3-km radius area. All holdings containing backyard poultry were cleaned and disinfected after the destruction process. Monitoring activities continue in the 10-km radius surveillance zone surrounding the 3-km radius protection zone.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: stamping out; quarantine; movement control inside the country; zoning; disinfection of infected premises/establishment(s); no vaccination; no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type:\nEtlik Central Research Veterinary Institute (National laboratory)\nSpecies / Test / Test date / Result\nBirds / haemagglutination (HA) test / 30 Apr 2015 / Positive\nBirds / haemagglutination inhibition test (HIT) / 30 Apr 2015 / Positive\nBirds / real-time reverse transcriptase/polymerase chain reaction (RRT-PCR) / 30 Apr 2015 / Positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\nThe location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This outbreak located in the Kastamonu Province confirms the presence of HPAI subtype H5N1 in Turkey. 28(20) [edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=17712\n\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza, Israel\n-----------------------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 12 May 2015 from Dr Nadav Galon, Director, Veterinary Services and Animal Health, Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development, Bet Dagan, Israel\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 8 May 2015\nDate of pre-confirmation of the event: 11 May 2015\nReason for notification: reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 11 Feb 2015\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: suspicion, clinical, laboratory (advanced), necropsy\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country.\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1: Bezet, Acco, Hazafon\nDate of start of the outbreak: 8 May 2015\nOutbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: farm\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nBirds / 13 000 / 2000 / 1000 / 12 000 / 0\nAffected population: 10-week-old turkeys. The flock contains 13 000 turkeys divided into 5 pens. Clinical signs have been seen in one of the pens.\n\nOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]:\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBirds / 15.38 / 7.69 / 50 / 100\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\nEpidemiological comment: the epidemiological investigation is in course.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: stamping out; quarantine; movement control inside the country; zoning, no vaccination; no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: screening, disinfection of infected premises/establishment(s)\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nNorthern Avian Diseases Laboratory (local laboratory) / Birds / real-time (PCR) / 11 May 2015 / Positive\nKimron Veterinary Institute, Avian Diseases Laboratory (national laboratory) / Birds / real-time (PCR) / 11 May 2015 / Positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Bezet borders southwest Lebanon. Earlier in 2015, Israel reported 8 outbreaks of HPAI H5N1 in commercial poultry farms; the control and eradication policy applied is based upon stamping out, compensating the affected holders, accompanied by severe animal movement restrictions in line with EU requirements. Several outbreaks were reported from the adjacent Palestinian Territories, both in the West Bank and the Gaza strip (which borders the North Sinai province of Egypt). All these outbreaks can be seen in the interactive map at http://tinyurl.com/o5tmqu6 (click on the Eastern Mediterranean cluster, zoom in).\n\nThe previous outbreaks in Israel were located in the Haifa and Hamerkaz (Central) districts. The event was resolved on 11 Feb 2015. See the event summary and map at, http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?reportid=16982\n\nGenotyping of the causative agent will be helpful in checking its origin. The Gaza strain was suspected to be related to a HPAI H5N1 strain circulating in Egypt. - Mods.AS/CRD]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Measures applied: stamping out; quarantine; movement control inside the country; zoning, no vaccination; no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: screening, disinfection of infected premises/establishment(s)\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nNorthern Avian Diseases Laboratory (local laboratory) / -----------------------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 12 May 2015 from Dr Nadav Galon, Director, Veterinary Services and Animal Health, Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development, Bet Dagan, Israel\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\n \n\nOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]:\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\n Manifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\n Total outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1: Bezet, Acco, Hazafon\n Serotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: suspicion, clinical, laboratory (advanced), necropsy\n Affected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\n AVIAN INFLUENZA (124): ISRAEL (HAZAFON) TURKEY, HPAI H5N1, OIE\n**************************************************************\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< [The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\n Date of pre-confirmation of the event: 11 May 2015\n Date of start of the event: 8 May 2015\n \n\nNew outbreaks (1)\n Source: OIE, WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database), weekly disease information 2015; 28(20) [edited]\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2015-05-24 00:00:00", "2015-05-08 00:00:00", "2015-02-11 00:00:00", "2015-05-12 00:00:00", "2015-03-24 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Israel", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Lebanon", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Haifa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the West Bank", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "WAHID", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "ISRAEL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bezet", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Gaza", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North Sinai", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "HAZAFON", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Egypt", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "TURKEY", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3334280", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (97): Egypt, H5N1, poultry", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3334280", "date": "2015-04-30 17:42:05", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (97): EGYPT, H5N1, POULTRY\n****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 29 April 2015\nSource: Al-Monitor [edited]\nhttp://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/originals/2015/04/egypt-health-birdflu-h5n1-poultry-fao-who-bekeham.html\n\n\nEgypt struggles to cope with bird flu\n-------------------------------------\nThe high number of reported bird flu cases in Egypt does not bode well, as the government is apparently falling short in efforts to contain the crisis. Egypt has the highest number of cases of the most infectious strain of bird flu, H5N1, despite being in the midst of its 3rd attempt in 9 years to control the disease.\n\nAccording to experts and documents reviewed by Al-Monitor, previous efforts were undermined ... and the government faces enormous challenges if it is to contain the virus this time around. The Animal Health and Livelihood Sustainability Strategy of 2010, the government's 1st attempt to contain the virus in 2006 through mass culling, vaccinations and compensation for farmers, suffered from poor management, a lack of transparency, widespread conflicts of interest among 'core institutions' and a suspected lack of effective hygienic measures practiced by control teams.\n\nIndustry experts say many of the recommendations of the 2010 report, written in collaboration with the UN Food and Agriculture Organization and approved by the government, were never implemented. Now the government is awaiting a final report on the problem from a broader spectrum of international organizations whose representatives gathered in Egypt in March [2015]: the FAO, the World Health Organization, the World Organization for Animal Health, the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, UNICEF and experts from Naval Medical Research Unit 3.\n\nThe WHO confirmed that from January to 31 Mar [2015], Egypt recorded 119 confirmed cases of H5N1, including 30 deaths. China ranks a distant 2nd, with 4 cases and 1 death [from H5N1, but see comment below regarding H7N9]. Indonesia, which at the beginning of the year [2015] was neck-and-neck with Egypt in total cases since 2003, has added just 2 new cases, for a total of 199. Egypt's now stand at 329.\n\nHendrik Jan Bekedam, WHO's Egypt representative, said this year's numbers already put Egypt ahead of all other countries dealing with H5N1, such as China, Indonesia, Vietnam and Cambodia, for any year on record. 'There's never been a country that in 100 days has had more than 100 cases,' Bekedam told Al-Monitor in Cairo. 'So there is something going on over here.'\n\nH5N1 has been found in 20 of Egypt's 27 governorates, and reducing the risk of further outbreaks won't be easy. At the moment, human-to-human transfer of H5N1 is inefficient, but one of the reasons for Egypt's increasing caseload is that many Egyptians live with chickens in their houses and apartments. According to the FAO, 66 of the 76 detected H5N1 outbreaks from 18 Jan through 7 Feb [2015] originated in households.\n\nAnother risk factor, according to health professionals, is the country's live bird markets, which account for a hefty 60-70 percent of domestic consumption, according to Tarek Tawfik, managing director of the Cairo Poultry Group and deputy chairman of the Federation of Egyptian Industries.\n\nBekedam, who was in China during the SARS outbreak in 2003, said that in addition to creating more opportunities to transfer the virus to humans, live bird markets give virus strains an opportunity to 'mingle' with each other. For example, another worrying bird flu strain, H9N2, is circulating among Egyptian poultry, and a boy from the southern city of Aswan tested positive for the virus in January [2015].\n\nIf H5N1 becomes transferable between humans, health professionals are concerned the proximity of millions of Egyptians to chickens will mean an outbreak could spread rapidly. Scientists in the Netherlands found H5N1 is 2-3 mutations away from becoming transferrable in ferrets, which are considered a reasonable proxy for humans. It should be stressed, that this conclusion stems from laboratory work. Bekedam, nonetheless, described the Dutch results as 'scary.' He said H5N1 is 'relatively stable' in Egypt, but also emphasized the need for constant monitoring, because virus mutations are unpredictable.\n\nH5N1 is fatal in 50 percent of cases worldwide. Egypt's survival rates have been noticeably better because a large proportion of infected individuals have been children. According to Bekedam, 'Most of the children under 5 survive. Somehow, their immune systems are better able to cope with the virus than when we get older.' Health professionals also suspect some milder cases of the virus are going unreported because healthcare in Egypt is costly.\n\n'It's a tough one for the people in rural areas,' said Bekeham, adding that for many, poultry do not just offer income, but also a cheap source of protein in an economy that has been in turmoil for years. 'Some of the decisions to reduce the virus are not easy. At the same time, what we do think is certain decisions need to be made.'\n\nPrime Minister Ibrahim Mahlab met with the delegation representing international organizations in March [2015], Bekeham said. The upper echelons of the Egyptian government recognize the seriousness of the problem. 'The political commitment from the government is very promising,' Bekeham asserted. 'It doesn't make the task any easier, but it's promising.'\n\nExperts note that in the past, the government had not committed to reforms that would have reduced the risk of outbreaks in Egypt. 'The government hasn't been heavy handed in enforcement in combating the bird flu,' said Tawfik.\n\nIn 2006, a ministerial decree banned the transport of live chickens between governorates to prevent the spread of the virus, but Egypt was unable to ensure compliance. 'The enforceability was not there, and it is still not there,' observed Tawfik.\n\nThere are also still problems in the design of the compensation scheme for farmers reporting bird flu cases. The scheme is paid for with a 1 percent levy on poultry imports. It has a board, a committee and about 500 million Egyptian pounds (USD 65.3 million) at its disposal. Once a farm reports a case of bird flu, however, it is quarantined for 6 months. According to Tawfik, many small operators choose not to report cases because the compensation would fall significantly short of the earnings lost.\n\nAnother problem is that the political instability since the 2011 uprising has pushed many opportunistic families out of traditional industries like tourism and into temporary chicken farming. Thus, growing numbers of unregistered chicken producers are ineligible for compensation if they get a sick bird.\n\nThe government has little idea how many unregistered poultry operators there are. A geographic mapping company estimated in 2012 that Husseiniya, one of 13 provinces in Sharqia governorate, alone had 860 unregistered farms.\n\nTawfik noted, 'It is very difficult to control the spread of the disease as long as your neighbors are raising chickens on their roof or in their backyards.'\n\n[Byline: Alexander Liddington-Cox]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[While Egypt has been struggling to contain H5N1, China has been battling H7N9, with a total of 141 cases reported in 2015 to date [according to FluTrackers (https://flutrackers.com/forum/forum/china-h7n9-outbreak-tracking/143874-flutrackers-2013-15-human-case-list-of-provincial-ministry-of-health-government-confirmed-influenza-a-h7n9-cases-with-links)]. The same pattern of infection has been observed with the 2 viruses, i.e., association of the infected patients with backyard or live market poultry. Similarly, both avian influenza viruses do not easily spread from human to human. But it is a major concern that the number of potential influenza pandemic virus candidates has increased significantly over the past few years.\n\nMaps of Egypt can be seen at http://www.geoatlas.com/medias/maps/countries/egypt/eg3r92t/egypt_pol.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/55. - Mod.LK\n\nSince HPAI H5N1 is regarded endemic in Egypt, no follow-up reports on the outbreaks in poultry are submitted to the OIE. The situation in Egypt should also concern other Middle-Eastern countries.\n\nAccording to a recently published paper (reference below; reviewed in ProMED-mail archive no. 20150402.3274191), 435 outbreaks in poultry were recorded in Egypt between October 2014 and February 2015. These outbreaks are claimed by the authors to have been caused by a novel cluster of influenza A(H5N1) virus clade 2.2.1.2 with putative human health impact. The paper includes a map showing the locations of the addressed outbreaks. Several outbreaks of the novel strain have been reported in northern Sinai. According to recent reports, the virus has spread to the adjacent Gaza strip (Palestinian authority). Genotyping results of the Gaza-strip isolates have not (yet) been published.\n\nReference\n---------\nArafa AS, Naguib MM, Luttermann C, et al: Emergence of a novel cluster of influenza A(H5N1) virus clade 2.2.1.2 with putative human health impact in Egypt, 2014/15. Euro Surveill. 2015; 20(13):pii: 21085. Available at http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=21085.\n- Mod.AS]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nBekedam, who was in China during the SARS outbreak in 2003, said that in addition to creating more opportunities to transfer the virus to humans, live bird markets give virus strains an opportunity to 'mingle' with each other. \n\nAnother risk factor, according to health professionals, is the country's live bird markets, which account for a hefty 60-70 percent of domestic consumption, according to Tarek Tawfik, managing director of the Cairo Poultry Group and deputy chairman of the Federation of Egyptian Industries. The Animal Health and Livelihood Sustainability Strategy of 2010, the government's 1st attempt to contain the virus in 2006 through mass culling, vaccinations and compensation for farmers, suffered from poor management, a lack of transparency, widespread conflicts of interest among 'core institutions' and a suspected lack of effective hygienic measures practiced by control teams. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[While Egypt has been struggling to contain H5N1, China has been battling H7N9, with a total of 141 cases reported in 2015 to date [according to FluTrackers (https://flutrackers.com/forum/forum/china-h7n9-outbreak-tracking/143874-flutrackers-2013-15-human-case-list-of-provincial-ministry-of-health-government-confirmed-influenza-a-h7n9-cases-with-links)]. \n\nThere are also still problems in the design of the compensation scheme for farmers reporting bird flu cases. \nArafa AS, Naguib MM, Luttermann C, et al: Emergence of a novel cluster of influenza A(H5N1) virus clade 2.2.1.2 with putative human health impact in Egypt, 2014/15. For example, another worrying bird flu strain, H9N2, is circulating among Egyptian poultry, and a boy from the southern city of Aswan tested positive for the virus in January [2015]. The high number of reported bird flu cases in Egypt does not bode well, as the government is apparently falling short in efforts to contain the crisis. Indonesia, which at the beginning of the year [2015] was neck-and-neck with Egypt in total cases since 2003, has added just 2 new cases, for a total of 199. Now the government is awaiting a final report on the problem from a broader spectrum of international organizations whose representatives gathered in Egypt in March [2015]: the FAO, the World Health Organization, the World Organization for Animal Health, the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, UNICEF and experts from Naval Medical Research Unit 3. AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (97): EGYPT, H5N1, POULTRY\n****************************************\n \n\nIf H5N1 becomes transferable between humans, health professionals are concerned the proximity of millions of Egyptians to chickens will mean an outbreak could spread rapidly. Egypt has the highest number of cases of the most infectious strain of bird flu, H5N1, despite being in the midst of its 3rd attempt in 9 years to control the disease. According to experts and documents reviewed by Al-Monitor, previous efforts were undermined ... and the government faces enormous challenges if it is to contain the virus this time around. \n\nPrime Minister Ibrahim Mahlab met with the delegation representing international organizations in March [2015], Bekeham said. LK\n\nSince HPAI H5N1 is regarded endemic in Egypt, no follow-up reports on the outbreaks in poultry are submitted to the OIE. \n\nH5N1 has been found in 20 of Egypt's 27 governorates, and reducing the risk of further outbreaks won't be easy. According to a recently published paper (reference below; reviewed in ProMED-mail archive no. 20150402.3274191), 435 outbreaks in poultry were recorded in Egypt between October 2014 and February 2015. \n\nHendrik Jan Bekedam, WHO's Egypt representative, said this year's numbers already put Egypt ahead of all other countries dealing with H5N1, such as China, Indonesia, Vietnam and Cambodia, for any year on record. ' \n\nAnother problem is that the political instability since the 2011 uprising has pushed many opportunistic families out of traditional industries like tourism and into temporary chicken farming. \n\nH5N1 is fatal in 50 percent of cases worldwide. [Byline: Alexander Liddington-Cox]\n\n--\n In 2006, a ministerial decree banned the transport of live chickens between governorates to prevent the spread of the virus, but Egypt was unable to ensure compliance. ' Health professionals also suspect some milder cases of the virus are going unreported because healthcare in Egypt is costly. The government hasn't been heavy handed in enforcement in combating the bird flu,' said Tawfik. \n\n\nEgypt struggles to cope with bird flu\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "sars"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2006-03-24 00:00:00", "2021-01-24 00:00:00", "2011-03-24 00:00:00", "2010-03-24 00:00:00", "2021-01-18 00:00:00", "2021-03-24 00:00:00", "2015-02-24 00:00:00", "2012-03-24 00:00:00", "2003-03-24 00:00:00", "2015-03-24 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Vietnam", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Cambodia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sharqia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Gaza", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Indonesia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Egypt", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "EGYPT", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Husseiniya", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Aswan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Cairo", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3330986", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (100): Russia (AS) HPAI H5N1, wild bird, OIE", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3330986", "date": "2015-04-29 22:11:35", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (100): RUSSIA (ASTRAKHAN) HPAI H5N1, WILD BIRD, OIE\n******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 27 Apr 2015\nSource: OIE, WAHID weekly disease information 2015; 28(18) [edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=17596\n\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza, Russia\n------------------------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 27 Apr 2015 from Dr Evgeny Nepoklonov, Deputy Head, Federal Service for Veterinary and Phytosanitary Surveillance, Ministry of Agriculture, Moscow, Russia.\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification (Final report)\nDate of start of the event: 17 Apr 2015\nDate of pre-confirmation of the event: 21 Apr 2015\nDate event resolved: 27 Apr 2015\nReason for notification: reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: Oct 2014\nManifestation of disease: sub-clinical infection\nCausal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: laboratory (basic), laboratory (advanced)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country.\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nOutbreak 1: Makarkin, Ikryaninsky, Astrakhanskaya Oblast [Astrakhan Oblast]\nDate of start of the outbreak: 17 Apr 2015\nOutbreak status: resolved 27 Apr 2015\nEpidemiological unit: not applicable\nAffected animals\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nDalmatian pelican: _Pelecanus crispus_(Pelecanidae) / - / 5 / 5 / 0 / 0\nAffected population: The dead water birds were found in the Damchinsky area of the FGBI (Federal Centre for Animal Health) Astrakhan State Biosphere Reserve.\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\n\nEpidemiological comments: The comparative analysis of the obtained nucleotide sequences of the H gene 258 bp fragment showed that the tested isolates belonged to an Asian lineage of highly pathogenic avian influenza (lineage A/Guandong/1/96 lineage, clade 2.3.2.1). Based on the H gene fragment nucleotide sequences, the given isolates were most similar to the type A H5N1 highly pathogenic avian influenza virus isolates recovered in Altay krai in 2014 (98.83 percent identity) and in Viet Nam and China over the period from 2012 to 2014 (98.44-98.04 percent identity). The hemagglutinin cleavage site of this virus includes several basic amino acids and has -RERRRKR- structure, which allows this virus to be characterized as potentially highly virulent.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: control of wildlife reservoirs, screening, no vaccination, no treatment of affected animals.\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nGovernment Budget Institution Astrakhan Oblast Veterinary Laboratory (Local laboratory) / Dalmatian pelican / polymerase chain reaction (PCR) / 21 Apr 2015 / Positive\nAll-Russian Research Institute for Animal Health (FGBI-ARRIAH) (National laboratory) / Dalmatian pelican/ gene sequencing / 24 Apr 2015 / Positive\nAll-Russian Research Institute for Animal Health (FGBI-ARRIAH) (National laboratory) / Dalmatian pelican / haemagglutination inhibition test (HIT) / 24 Apr 2015 / Positive\nAll-Russian Research Institute for Animal Health (FGBI-ARRIAH) (National laboratory) / Dalmatian pelican / real-time reverse transcriptase-polymerase chain reaction (RRT-PCR) / 24 Apr 2015 / Positive\nAll-Russian Research Institute for Animal Health (FGBI-ARRIAH) (National laboratory) / Dalmatian pelican / virus isolation / 24 Apr 2015 / Positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is resolved. No more reports will be submitted.\n\nThe location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[During 2015, highly pathogenic avian influenza H5N1 in Dalmatian pelicans has also been reported by Bulgaria and Romania.\n\nThe southern border of the Astrakhan Oblast is the Caspian Sea, eastern is Kazakhstan, northern is Volgograd Oblast, and western is the Republic of Kalmykia http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Astrakhan_Oblast.\n\n'Coastal areas of the Caspian Sea are a bird paradise, with many species of gulls, terns, and waterfowl. The northern (especially Volga delta), northeastern, and eastern coasts of the Caspian Sea lie on a major migration route between Europe and Asia. Tens of millions of migratory birds pass over the area twice a year, and hundreds of thousands nest there. Many birds stay for winter, and the wintering population of waterfowl in the Khazar Reserve is estimated to be over 600 000 birds' https://www.worldwildlife.org/ecoregions/pa1308.\n\nSee comments made by Mod.PMB in ProMED-mail post 20150129.3128713. - Mod.CRD\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/98.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Measures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\n Outbreak status: resolved 27 Apr 2015\nEpidemiological unit: not applicable\n Serotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: laboratory (basic), laboratory (advanced)\n AVIAN INFLUENZA (100): RUSSIA (ASTRAKHAN) HPAI H5N1, WILD BIRD, OIE\n******************************************************************\n Date of previous occurrence: Oct 2014\nManifestation of disease: sub-clinical infection\n Summary\nReport type: immediate notification (Final report)\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Source of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\n\nEpidemiological comments: The comparative analysis of the obtained nucleotide sequences of the H gene 258 bp fragment showed that the tested isolates belonged to an Asian lineage of highly pathogenic avian influenza (lineage A/Guandong/1/96 lineage, clade 2.3.2.1). Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 20 Apr 2015\nSource: Avian Flu Diary from the FAO RSS feed [edited]\nhttp://afludiary.blogspot.com/\n\n\nThe last official WHO H5N1 Update for Egypt [Thu 31 Mar 2015] listed 125 cases and 33 deaths (see ProMED-mail Avian influenza, human (93): WHO update H5N1 and H7N9, China H7N9 20150416.3301012), but since then, an update from the FAO (on 8 Apr 2015) added 7 further cases.\n\nToday, the FAO [Food and Agricultural Organization] has listed 6 more human cases on their RSS [Really Simple Syndication] feed [Location, Date illness observed -- dates from FluTrackers Egypt -- 2015 WHO/MoH/Provincial Health Depts H5N1 Confirmed Case List https://flutrackers.com/forum/forum/china-h7n9-outbreak-tracking/143874-flutrackers-2013-15-human-case-list-of-provincial-ministry-of-health-government-confirmed-influenza-a-h7n9-cases-with-links)].\n\n1. Confirmed Influenza - Avian in Behera, for human, [30 Mar 2015]\n2. Confirmed Influenza - Avian in Behera, for human, [6 Apr 2015]\n3. Confirmed Influenza - Avian in Behera, for human, [2 Apr 2015]\n4. Confirmed Influenza - Avian in Damietta, for human, [4 Apr 2015]\n5. Confirmed Influenza - Avian in Qena, for human, [29 Mar 2015]\n6. Confirmed Influenza - Avian in Kafr El-Shikh, for human, [1 Apr 2015]\n\nBased on the information currently available, FluTrackers conservatively shows 143 cases in Egypt since 1 Jan 2015, 3 times more than Egypt has ever previously reported and more than double the number that any country has ever reported in a single year.\n\nThe recent slowdown in case reports -- if indeed, that is the case -- would not be totally unexpected, as avian flu transmission tends to decline as the weather warms. But the caveat here is that out of these last 6 cases, 2 were observed in late March 2015, and the newest was observed on 6 Apr 2015.\n\nAlthough we've not seen any evidence of increased or efficient human-to-human transmission of the H5N1 virus in Egypt, it is worrisome that this outbreak has now gone on for 5 full months, and nearly 180 people have been infected.\n\nTo put that into some kind of perspective, Egypt, with a population 1/16th that of China, has racked up nearly as many H5N1 human cases over the past 6 months (180) as has China with H7N9 (200).\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[H5N1 in Egypt is now in its 5th month and remains a serious concern to public health. The high number of human cases observed this year (2015) in Egypt correlates with the reports of an increased number of outbreaks and detections of influenza A(H5N1) viruses in poultry in Egypt compared with previous months and compared with the month of April in previous years. See ProMED-mail post Avian influenza, human (93): WHO update H5N1 and H7N9, China H7N9 20150416.3301012 for the WHO update report (as of 31 Mar 2015) for further discussion.\n\nMaps of Egypt can be seen at http://www.geoatlas.com/medias/maps/countries/egypt/eg3r92t/egypt_pol.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/55. - Mod.LK]", "summary": "The last official WHO H5N1 Update for Egypt [Thu 31 Mar 2015] listed 125 cases and 33 deaths (see ProMED-mail Avian influenza, human (93): WHO update H5N1 and H7N9, China H7N9 20150416.3301012), but since then, an update from the FAO (on 8 Apr 2015) added 7 further cases. AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (94): EGYPT, FAO UPDATE H5N1\n***************************************************\n Confirmed Influenza - Avian in Behera, for human, [2 Apr 2015]\n4.", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2015-04-08 00:00:00", "2015-03-24 00:00:00", "2015-01-01 00:00:00", "2015-04-06 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "EGYPT", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Egypt", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Behera", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kafr El - Shikh", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Qena", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3306005", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (88): Burkina Faso, HPAI H5N1, poultry, spread", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3306005", "date": "2015-04-18 13:55:40", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (88): BURKINA FASO, HPAI H5N1, POULTRY, SPREAD\n**************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 16 Apr 2015\nSource: Spy Ghana, Xinhua News Agency report [edited]\nhttp://www.spyghana.com/bird-flu-kills-over-200000-chicken-in-burkina-faso/\n\n\nBy 13 Apr 2015, over 202 000 deaths of chicken and estimated losses of over 3 billion [West African] CFA Francs (about USD 5 million) had been reported in Burkina Faso following the confirmation of an outbreak of bird flu [avian influenza] in early April [2015].\n\nA source from the ministry in charge of animal resources said on [Wed 15 Apr 2015] that bird flu had been reported in 5 of the country's 45 provinces, and it had killed 200 000 hens and 2000 guinea fowls. Close to 11.4 million poultry are exposed to the disease.\n\nDue to this situation, the ministry has reinforced its counterattack measures that include destruction of bodies of birds that died from contamination, killing of already infected poultry, and sensitization of the population on measures to be taken, the director of veterinary services Lassiana Ouattara said.\n\nBurkina Faso has already mobilized 390 million CFA Francs to fund this counterattack plan, and has appealed for additional support of 2.6 billion CFA Francs [about USD 643 000] from technical and financial partners.\n\nThe H5N1 bird flu virus can affect individuals in close contact with infected or dead birds. Statistics from the World Health Organization show that the disease has killed over 400 people in the world since 2003.\n\nSince the confirmation of bird flu, several neighbouring countries have banned the importation of poultry from Burkina Faso, the 2nd highest foreign exchange earner for the country after the mining sector.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[On 1 Apr 2015 Burkina Faso submitted to the OIE a report on 4 new HPAI H5N1 outbreaks in 2 provinces; see, with map, at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?fupser=&dothis=&reportid=17455.\nAccording to the Xinhua News report above, the virus continued its spread into 3 additional provinces; a detailed follow-up report is expected.\n\nFor further background, please refer to the detailed commentary by Mod.CRD in ProMED-mail posting 20150402.3272825. - Mod.AS\n\nMaps of Burkina Faso can be seen at http://www.ezilon.com/maps/images/africa/political-map-of-Burkina-Fa.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/49. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nA source from the ministry in charge of animal resources said on [Wed 15 Apr 2015] that bird flu had been reported in 5 of the country's 45 provinces, and it had killed 200 000 hens and 2000 guinea fowls. By 13 Apr 2015, over 202 000 deaths of chicken and estimated losses of over 3 billion [West African] CFA Francs (about USD 5 million) had been reported in Burkina Faso following the confirmation of an outbreak of bird flu [avian influenza] in early April [2015]. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[On 1 Apr 2015 Burkina Faso submitted to the OIE a report on 4 new HPAI H5N1 outbreaks in 2 provinces; see, with map, at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?fupser=&dothis=&reportid=17455.\n \n\nSince the confirmation of bird flu, several neighbouring countries have banned the importation of poultry from Burkina Faso, the 2nd highest foreign exchange earner for the country after the mining sector. \n\nBurkina Faso has already mobilized 390 million CFA Francs to fund this counterattack plan, and has appealed for additional support of 2.6 billion CFA Francs [about USD 643 000] from technical and financial partners. no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: control of wildlife reservoirs; stamping out; quarantine; movement control inside the country; screening; zoning; disinfection of infected premises/establishment(s)\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type:\nIstituto Zooprofilattico Sperimentale delle Venezie, Padua, Italy (OIE's Reference Laboratory)\nSpecies / Test / Test date / Result:\nBirds / gene sequencing / 21 Apr 2015 / Positive\nBirds / real-time reverse transcriptase/polymerase chain reaction (RRT-PCR) / 21 Apr 2015 / Positive\nBirds / reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) / 21 Apr 2015 / Positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\nThe location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) subtype H5N1 continues to spread in West Africa. To date the disease has been reported in Burkina Faso and Nigeria, where the number of outbreaks continues to increase.\n\nDuring 2015 Nigeria reported 55 outbreaks of HPAI H5N1; including those reported in northern Nigeria (41 outbreaks), see event summary and updated map at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?fupser=&dothis=&reportid=16926) and those reported in southern Nigeria (14 outbreaks), see http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?fupser=&dothis=&reportid=16977.\n\nBurkina Faso has reported 11 outbreaks of HPAI H5N1; see last follow-up report No 1, 17 Apr 2015, at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/temp/reports/en_fup_0000017549_20150420_192129.pdf\n\nIn 2006, 2 HPAI outbreaks were reported in Niger: H5N1 was the subtype identified in both cases. The outbreaks were located in the provinces of Zinder and Maradi. See final report at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/temp/reports/en_fup_0000001792_20060615_180628.pdf\n\nThe map of Niger can be seen at http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/niger.pdf. - Mod.CRD\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/58.]", "summary": "Measures applied: vaccination prohibited; no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: control of wildlife reservoirs; stamping out; quarantine; movement control inside the country; screening; zoning; disinfection of infected premises/establishment(s)\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type:\nIstituto Zooprofilattico Sperimentale delle Venezie, Padua, Italy (OIE's Reference Laboratory)\n A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Laying hens and breeding parents\n\nOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\n Total outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1: Holding Dan Gona, Maradi, Maradi\n Date of previous occurrence: 9 Jun 2006\nManifestation of disease: clinical infection\n Serotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: suspicion, clinical, laboratory (basic), laboratory (advanced), necropsy\n Summary\nReport type: immediate notification\n AVIAN INFLUENZA (93): NIGER (MARADI) POULTRY, HPAI H5N1, OIE\n************************************************************\n Affected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\n \n\nDuring 2015 Nigeria reported 55 outbreaks of HPAI H5N1; including those reported in northern Nigeria (41 outbreaks), see event summary and updated map at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?fupser=&dothis=&reportid=16926) and those reported in southern Nigeria (14 outbreaks), see http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?fupser=&dothis=&reportid=16977. \n\nNew outbreaks (1)\n Apr 2015 / Positive\n\nFuture reporting\n Source of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\n\nControl measures\n Date of start of the event: 2 Apr 2015\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2006-03-24 00:00:00", "2015-03-24 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Maradi", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nigeria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Padua", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Venezie", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Italy", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "WAHID", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "West Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Niamey", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3310679", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (91): Nigeria, poultry, HPAI H5N1, risk of spread, FAO", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3310679", "date": "2015-04-21 04:20:43", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (91): NIGERIA, POULTRY, HPAI H5N1, RISK OF SPREAD, FAO\n**********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 20 Apr 2015\nSource: FAO EMPRES-watch, vol. 32, April 2015 [summarised, edited]\nhttp://www.fao.org/ag/againfo/programmes/en/empres/home.asp\n\n\nH5N1 HPAI spread in Nigeria and increased risk for neighbouring countries in West Africa\n------------------------\nSummary\nOn 16 Jan 2015, Nigeria confirmed the presence of H5N1 HPAI to the World Organisation for Animal Health (OIE). This was the 1st occurrence of H5N1 HPAI in the country since the last epidemic between 2006 and 2008. The virus involved is similar to recent isolates taken from birds in Bulgaria, India and Viet Nam as well as an environmental sample from China.\n\nThe disease has so far spread to nearly 400 enterprises including live bird markets (LBMs) and farms in 9 per cent (71 out of 775) of local government areas (LGAs) in 49 per cent (18 out of 37) of states across Nigeria.\n\nWhile the Nigerian Government has responded by implementing quarantine, culling and compensation, outbreaks continue to be reported. Agro-ecological drivers of HPAI H5N1 similar to those present in endemic regions of South East Asia are present in Nigeria and West Africa, thus implying an increased risk of disease spread in the region. Traditional trading patterns, both formal and informal, between Nigeria and neighbouring countries provide an opportunity for cross-border or inter-regional disease spread. The recent incursion into Burkina Faso only emphasizes this potential risk.\n\nCurrently, countries at immediate risk of spread are Benin, Cameroon, Chad, Ghana, the Niger and Togo. Other countries that had reported outbreaks in the past are also at risk. These include the Republic of Cote d'Ivoire, Djibouti and the Sudan. These countries need to prepare to detect and respond in a timely manner to possible incursions of the disease.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nOlutayo Olajide Babalobi (DVM, MPVM, PhD; FCVSN)\nDepartment of Veterinary Public Health and Preventive Medicine\nEruwa Veterinary (Rural) Field Station\nFaculty of Veterinary Medicine\nUniversity of Ibadan, Ibadan\nNigeria\n<tayobabalobi@gmail.com>\n\n[The following, final section of the above review is copied for readers' convenience:\n\n'Conclusions (and looking ahead)\n--------------------------------\n'The reoccurrence of H5N1 HPAI in Nigeria confirms the constant risk posed by this virus. The poultry in Nigeria and in bordering countries are highly susceptible to HPAI H5N1. All countries are officially free of this disease. It is expected that HPAI H5N1 will spread widely within Nigeria and may affect a high proportion of poultry until effective biosecurity measures are imposed. Continued circulation (that is, persistence) within the Nigerian poultry population is possible, but given previous experience with the disease during 2006-2008, this may be unlikely. The veterinary services of Nigeria have shown their ability to eliminate HPAI H5N1 during the 1st outbreaks of the disease in 2006-2008, and this could be replicated if resources are available to implement control measures.\n\n'Affected areas located in conflict zones such as Kaduna State, where the actions of veterinary services are limited, may result in continued spread. Currently, the outbreak continues to spread, and patterns are distinct from that of the previous epidemic. The current epidemic has spread faster and wider geographically than the previous epidemic (data not shown). Based on this evidence, the risk of the virus spreading throughout Nigeria is high.\n\n'The risk of spread to bordering countries will depend on quarantine controls at land borders with Nigeria that target the various routes through which infection could spread, including the movement of live birds, people or fomites. Establishment in bordering countries will also depend on the ability of the countries' surveillance systems to detect and respond to new incursions rapidly, if they do occur.\n\n'During the previous HPAI H5N1 incursion, almost all countries affected in the region were able to eliminate the disease with international support coordinated by FAO. However, regular training of veterinary services staff in the region in disease recognition, investigation and response is needed.\n\n'The outbreaks in Nigeria are currently concentrated in areas bordering Niger in the north and Benin in the south west. Movement of poultry from northern areas of Nigeria to be sold in the southern areas of Niger has been known to occur. Movement of people from south western Nigeria to Togo through transhumance [seasonal migration of livestock. - Mod.SH] is also likely. Given their proximity to Nigeria (through sharing of the border) and commercial trading links, the following countries are at immediate risk of disease spread: Benin, Cameroon, Chad and Niger. These countries have important poultry industries, and the potential consequences of HPAI H5N1 outbreaks there would be significant. Other countries that had reported outbreaks in the past are also at risk. These include Burkina Faso, Djibouti, the Republic of Cote d'Ivoire and Sudan.\n\n'FAO stands ready to provide assistance to member countries in West Africa to prevent the introduction of H5N1 HPAI to reduce the risk of disease spread and to safeguard vulnerable, livestock-related livelihoods. FAO assistance should be focused on improving capacities of animal health systems for\ni) rapid detection and disease early warning;\nii) laboratory capacity building;\niii) risk management;\niv) surveillance; and\nv) prevention and control.\n\n'Countries at risk in West Africa are recommended to:\n- review and assess their level of preparedness for possible incursions of HPAI, including their country's contingency plan for H5N1 HPAI and levels of surveillance;\n- conduct proper field disease investigation procedures and the measures required to manage the risks for poultry and human populations, including biosecurity;\n- review and assess the diagnostic capabilities relative to the specific requirements for laboratory analysis of H5N1 HPAI, including laboratory procedures, appropriate equipment and supplies;\n- review and assess communication and awareness strategies;\n- review coordination mechanisms between in-country, regional stakeholders, including compensation strategies;\n- evaluate technical capacity development needs, utilizing current knowledge and previous assessments;\n- consider the means of identifying and addressing resource needs for enhanced avian influenza prevention and control programmes.\n\n'At-risk countries would benefit from knowledge and information sharing by relevant countries in the region. FAO provides and assists countries with technical capacity to respond to emergencies. It also has a role in facilitating information exchange and collaboration between Nigeria and other countries at risk in West Africa.'\n\nSubscribers are encouraged to read the full (8 page) review -- FAO. 2015. H5N1 HPAI spread in Nigeria and increased risk for neighbouring countries in West Africa. EMPRES WATCH, Vol 32, April 2015. Rome -- including tables, figures and bibliography, at the source URL. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/62.]", "summary": "\n\n'Countries at risk in West Africa are recommended to:\n- review and assess their level of preparedness for possible incursions of HPAI, including their country's contingency plan for H5N1 HPAI and levels of surveillance;\n- conduct proper field disease investigation procedures and the measures required to manage the risks for poultry and human populations, including biosecurity;\n- review and assess the diagnostic capabilities relative to the specific requirements for laboratory analysis of H5N1 HPAI, including laboratory procedures, appropriate equipment and supplies;\n- review and assess communication and awareness strategies;\n- review coordination mechanisms between in-country, regional stakeholders, including compensation strategies;\n- evaluate technical capacity development needs, utilizing current knowledge and previous assessments;\n- consider the means of identifying and addressing resource needs for enhanced avian influenza prevention and control programmes. FAO assistance should be focused on improving capacities of animal health systems for\ni) rapid detection and disease early warning;\nii) laboratory capacity building;\niii) risk management;\niv) surveillance; and\nv) prevention and control. Samples taken from different locations in Khan Yunis, from different avian species (chickens and waterfowl) were found positive for H5N1\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The information above, from a reliable source, is cause for grave concern. The Gaza Strip is one of the most densely populated territories on earth. On top of the human population, estimated at 1.6-2.0 million, there are numerous backyard poultry holdings. The HPAI H5N1 virus strain involved is, most likely, similar or identical to the one circulating in Egypt. A significant increase in human infection has been observed in Egypt since the beginning of November 2014. Since the beginning of 2015, as of 31 Mar 2015, Egypt reported to the WHO 125 human cases, of which 33 (26.4 percent) died. The total number of cases reported there during the month of March 2015 stands at 30 cases, including 4 deaths (see 20150409.3287821).\n\nInternational support to the Veterinary and Public Health authorities in Gaza to control the epizootic seems vital. Since stamping out seems to be out of the question, public education is essential and, probably, mass vaccination of poultry deserves to be included in the considerations.\n\nA map showing the location of Khan Yunis is available at the source URL above.\n\nOfficial confirmation, and genotyping, are anticipated. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/88.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Samples taken from different locations in Khan Yunis, from different avian species (chickens and waterfowl) were found positive for H5N1\n\n--\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Since the beginning of 2015, as of 31 Mar 2015, Egypt reported to the WHO 125 human cases, of which 33 (26.4 percent) died. AVIAN INFLUENZA (79): PALESTINIAN AUTHORITY (GAZA), HPAI H5N1, SPREAD, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2015-03-24 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Israel", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Gaza Strip", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Gaza Strip", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Gaza", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Egypt", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3302128", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (83): Palestinian Auth (GZ) HPAI H5N1, regional alertness", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3302128", "date": "2015-04-16 19:07:31", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (83): PALESTINIAN AUTHORITY (GAZA STRIP) HPAI H5N1, REGIONAL ALERTNESS\n**************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Wed 15 Apr 2015\nSource: News1 (Israel) [in Hebrew, transl Mod.AS, edited]\nhttp://www.news1.co.il/PageLoad.aspx?adid=8212&pageUrl=Archive/001-D-363113-00.html\n\n\nBird flu could spill over into Israel from Gaza\n-----------------------------------------------\nMinistry of Agriculture is monitoring coops within a radius of 10 km [about 6.2 miles]; poultry growers are asked to bring them into cages.\n\nBird flu has been detected (Tue 14 Apr 2015) in the Gaza Strip town of Khan Yunis, seriously affecting chickens and water fowl.\n\nTeams of the [Israeli] Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development are monitoring poultry coops in Israel's territory adjacent to the affected area of the Gaza Strip, within 10 km distance from Khan Yunis [see comment]. Farms within the monitoring area are visited on a daily basis in order to minimize the risk of further dissemination of the disease.\n\nOn top of the said enhanced activity within the mentioned area, routine monitoring for avian influenza is being maintained throughout Israel.\n\nThe State Veterinary Services have called upon all holders of backyard poultry to keep their birds caged and under cover and to prevent their free roaming in open terrain, to reduce the risk of infection from wild birds.\n\n[Byline: Yoseph Iddan]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Khan Yunis, a town in the southern part of the Gaza Strip, is located about 5 km [about 3 miles] from Israel's territory to its east; see square 13 in the interactive map at http://www.eyeonisrael.com/Israel-touring-map.html.\n\nThe Gaza Strip, which borders Egypt's north Sinai territory, may have been infected by the H5N1 virus strain widely circulating in Egypt, becoming a potential linking step for the spread of that virus to southern Israel. From October 2014 to February 2015, 435 outbreaks in poultry were reported in Egypt, caused by a novel cluster of influenza A(H5N1) virus clade 2.2.1.2 with putative human health impact. Reportedly, 3 of the outbreaks have been diagnosed recently in Egypt's Northern Sinai, bordering southern Gaza Strip. For further details and a detailed map (on page 3), please refer to the following paper:\nArafa AS, Naguib MM, Luttermann C, Selim AA, Kilany WH, Hagag N, Samy A, Abdelhalim A, Hassan MK, Abdelwhab EM, Makonnen Y, Dauphin G, Lubroth J, Mettenleiter TC, Beer M, Grund C, Harder TC. Emergence of a novel cluster of influenza A(H5N1) virus clade 2.2.1.2 with putative human health impact in Egypt, 2014/15. Euro Surveill. 2015; 20(13):pii=21085. Available online: http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=21085. - Mod.AS\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Thu 16 Apr 2015\nSource: Alhadath (Palestinian Authority) [in Arabic, machine transl, edited]\nhttp://www.alhadath.ps/article.php?id=df056fy14615919Ydf056f\n\n\nThe Director of Veterinary Services in the Ministry of Agriculture in Gaza, Dr. Zakaria Kafarneh, told Alhadath that the Gaza Strip is currently free of new bird-flu outbreaks following the culling of hundreds of birds affected by the disease in Khan Yunis, a few days ago. He said that the ministry started an awareness and guidance campaign targeting owners of commercial poultry holdings and birds farmers in the Gaza Strip, to introduce them to the disease and its risks and provide guidance in assisting discovery of outbreaks and their control.\n\nKafarneh indicated that the real danger of the disease comes from backyard holdings within the municipalities and not through the intensively kept birds on commercial farms.\n\nKafarneh said that the Ministry of Agriculture focuses on the detection of the epidemic in the northern part of the Gaza Strip area, where the largest numbers of domestic birds are held and should be tightly controlled.\n\nKafarneh explained that the Ministry of Agriculture cooperates with other agencies and organizations to deal with any spread or outbreak of the disease.\n\nThe Ministry of Agriculture in Gaza culled on Monday [13 Apr 2015] about 800 broiler chickens and ducks in the city of Khan Yunis after the discovery of them being infected with HPAI H5N1 strain of bird flu. The crews utilised the assistance of the city's mayor and staff for the implementation of the process, with the participation of doctors from the Ministry of Agriculture.\n\n[Byline: Issa Mohammed]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[As indicated by Dr Kafarneh, the main problem on his and his dedicated staff's hands is the presence of numerous backyard holdings throughout the Gaza Strip, including urban areas. The number of such holdings, each of which may include few birds of various species, is estimated to be counted in figures of 5 (or even more?) digits.\n\nAs of 2014, about 1.8 million people are living in the Gaza Strip, of which nearly 1.5 million in refugee camps. 90 percent of the population is urban. The most densely populated area is Gaza City, where the density (2014 data) is 6859 people per sq km. Even within the City of Gaza, chickens and other poultry roam around and there are numerous backyard poultry holdings. The per capita income in Gaza is among the lowest in the world.\n\nAs rightly remarked by a subscriber, 'population numbers are not relevant to this strain, since human-to-human transmission is rare.' Indeed it is not the high density of the population in the Gaza Strip which is the main concern; there are other regions worldwide that are characterized by continuous urban area (such as Singapore, Hong Kong, Bahrain, Monaco and even the Israeli Dan district). It is the combination of dense human population, poor hygiene and the close proximity to large numbers of free-roaming or backyard domestic birds which should be of concern in case 'A(H5N1) virus clade 2.2.1.2 with putative human health impact' becomes endemic in Gaza. - Mod.AS]\n\n[Poultry farm in Khan Younis:\nhttp://cache1.asset-cache.net/gc/451189840-poultry-farm-in-khan-yunis-of-gaza-in-west-gettyimages.jpg?v=1&c=IWSAsset&k=2&d=GkZZ8bf5zL1ZiijUmxa7QbnhSTu1MedMYok2gn6lS9kIz59rBsYa%2BexpGTsvYxOlRk5cJUyjBBRiY5uOqQIjvQ%3D%3D - Mod.JW\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/88.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\n It is the combination of dense human population, poor hygiene and the close proximity to large numbers of free-roaming or backyard domestic birds which should be of concern in case 'A(H5N1) virus clade 2.2.1.2 with putative human health impact' becomes endemic in Gaza. \n\nThe State Veterinary Services have called upon all holders of backyard poultry to keep their birds caged and under cover and to prevent their free roaming in open terrain, to reduce the risk of infection from wild birds. \n\nKafarneh indicated that the real danger of the disease comes from backyard holdings within the municipalities and not through the intensively kept birds on commercial farms. \n\nTeams of the [Israeli] Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development are monitoring poultry coops in Israel's territory adjacent to the affected area of the Gaza Strip, within 10 km distance from Khan Yunis [see comment]. \n\nKafarneh said that the Ministry of Agriculture focuses on the detection of the epidemic in the northern part of the Gaza Strip area, where the largest numbers of domestic birds are held and should be tightly controlled. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Khan Yunis, a town in the southern part of the Gaza Strip, is located about 5 km [about 3 miles] from Israel's territory to its east; see square 13 in the interactive map at http://www.eyeonisrael.com/Israel-touring-map.html. \n\nThe Gaza Strip, which borders Egypt's north Sinai territory, may have been infected by the H5N1 virus strain widely circulating in Egypt, becoming a potential linking step for the spread of that virus to southern Israel. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[As indicated by Dr Kafarneh, the main problem on his and his dedicated staff's hands is the presence of numerous backyard holdings throughout the Gaza Strip, including urban areas. \n\nAs rightly remarked by a subscriber, 'population numbers are not relevant to this strain, since human-to-human transmission is rare.' [Byline: Yoseph Iddan]\n\n--\n [Byline: Issa Mohammed]\n\n--\n AS\n\n******\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1983-03-24 00:00:00", "2015-03-24 00:00:00", "2021-03-29 00:00:00", "2014-03-24 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Singapore", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Egypt", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Gaza City", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Monaco", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Gaza Strip", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Israel", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the City of Gaza", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mod", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bahrain", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Gaza", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Gaza Strip", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3301012", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (93): WHO update H5N1 and H7N9, China H7N9", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3301012", "date": "2015-04-16 14:20:56", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (93): WHO UPDATE H5N1 AND H7N9, CHINA H7N9\n******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] WHO update avian influenza H5N1 and H7N9\n[2] China: Avian influenza H7N9\n\n******\n[1] WHO update avian influenza H5N1 and H7N9\nDate: Tues 14 April 2015\nSource: WHO [edited]\nhttp://www.who.int/influenza/human_animal_interface/Influenza_Summary_IRA_HA_interface_31_March_2015.pdf?ua=1\n\n\nSummary and assessment as of 31 Mar 2015\n-------------------------\nHuman infection with avian influenza A(H5) viruses\n----------------------\n\nFrom 2003 through 31 Mar 2015, 826 laboratory-confirmed human cases of avian influenza A(H5N1) virus infection have been officially reported to WHO from 16 countries. Of these cases, 440 have died. Since the last WHO Influenza update on 3 Mar 2015, 42 new laboratory-confirmed human cases of avian influenza A(H5N1) virus infection, including 11 fatal cases, were reported to WHO from Egypt (37), China (3) and Indonesia (2).\n\nOf the 37 human cases of influenza A(H5N1) virus infection reported from Egypt, 14 had onset of disease in February 2015 and the rest had onset of disease in March 2015. The cases were reported from 14 different governorates of Egypt [see table 1 in the annex to the original source]. The age range of the 37 cases is from 1 to 77 years, with a median of 24 years and 38 percent of the cases are under 10 years of age. Almost twice as many females compared to males were affected. 8 of the 37 cases (22 percent) died and all 8 fatal cases were in patients 10 years of age and older. All but one case had exposure to poultry or poultry markets and the exposure history of the 1 case is still under investigation. All cases were hospitalized and all reportedly received treatment with antiviral medication. Contacts of the cases were followed for 14 days and there have not been reports of cases in any contacts of confirmed cases. The newly reported cases included 1 cluster of 2 confirmed cases in a mother and son from Sharkia governorate. The 2 cases had onset of illness on the same day and both had exposure to backyard poultry, suggesting common exposure.\n\nCurrently, there are reports of an increased number of outbreaks and detections of influenza A(H5N1) viruses in poultry in Egypt compared to previous months and compared to this month [April] in previous years.\n\nAlthough all influenza viruses evolve over time, preliminary laboratory investigation has not detected major genetic changes in the limited number of viruses isolated from the patients and animals compared to previously circulating isolates thus far, but further in-depth analysis is ongoing. A new candidate vaccine virus was proposed to better protect against the current circulating H5 clade 2.2.1. viruses (a group which all the recent influenza A( H5N1) virus isolates from Egypt belong to. See http://www.who.int/influenza/vaccines/virus/201502_zoonotic_vaccinevirusupdate.pdf?ua=12).\n\nFor the 4th consecutive month since December 2014, the number of laboratory-confirmed human cases of avian influenza A(H5N1) virus infection in Egypt with disease onset in each month are the highest numbers reported by any country in a single month. The characteristics of the affected population remain essentially unchanged from previous years in Egypt, with females more commonly affected than males and about 1/3 of the cases occurring in children under 10 years of age. The proportion of fatal cases has been consistently lower in Egypt than in other countries, especially in children, although the case fatality rate could change as many cases remain hospitalized.\n\nThe increase in the number of human cases is likely attributable to a mixture of factors, including increased circulation of influenza A(H5N1) viruses in poultry, an increasing number of small poultry farms and household flocks, lower public health awareness of risks and seasonal factors such as closer proximity to poultry because of cold weather and possible longer survival of the viruses in the environment.\n\nChina reported 3 human cases of infection with an avian influenza A(H5N1) virus from 2 provinces. 2 cases were reported to have had exposure to live poultry. 1 of the human cases was a fatal case while the other 2 cases were still under treatment at the time they were reported.\n\nIndonesia reported 2 fatal human cases of infection with an avian influenza A(H5N1) virus, in a father and a son from Banten province. The investigation surrounding these 2 cases indicates that they may have had indirect or direct contact with birds near their residence or in another district they visited prior to their onsets of illnesses. Both cases developed severe disease and were hospitalized but passed away. The last human case of infection with an avian influenza A(H5N1) virus in Indonesia was reported in June 2014.\n\nVarious influenza A(H5) subtypes, such as influenza A(H5N1), A(H5N2), A(H5N3), A(H5N6) and A(H5N8), have recently been detected in birds in Asia, Europe, and North America, according to reports received by OIE. Although these influenza A(H5) viruses might have the potential to cause disease in humans, so far no human cases of infection have been reported, with exception of the human infections with influenza A(H5N1) viruses and the 3 human infections with influenza A(H5N6) virus detected in China since 2014.\n\nOverall public health risk assessment for avian influenza A(H5) viruses: The cases reported from these 3 countries appear to be sporadic cases and the virus is known to be circulating endemically in poultry in these countries. Whenever avian influenza viruses are circulating in poultry, sporadic infections and small clusters of human cases are possible in people exposed to infected poultry or contaminated environments, therefore the additional sporadic human cases would not be unexpected.\n\nAlthough an increased number of animal-to-human infections have been reported by Egypt over the past few months, these influenza A(H5) viruses do not currently appear to transmit easily among people. As such, the risk of community-level spread of these viruses remains to be low. Although the risk assessment remains unchanged, further studies are needed to understand the risk factors for human infections and the potential role of mild cases if they are occurring. Further analyses on virus isolates from the animal sector and human cases need to be undertaken to better understand if changes in the transmissibility of the virus from animals to humans may be playing a role in the current situation.\n\nFigure 1: Epidemiological curve of avian influenza A(H5N1) cases in humans by reporting country and month of onset.\n\nHuman infection with other non-seasonal influenza viruses\n------------------------\nHuman infections with avian influenza A(H7N9) viruses in China\n------------------------\n\nA total of 631 laboratory-confirmed cases of human infection with avian influenza A(H7N9) virus, including 253 deaths, have been reported to WHO. The majority of recently reported human cases are associated with exposure to infected live poultry or contaminated environments, including markets where live poultry are sold. A(H7N9) viruses continue to be detected in poultry and their environments in the areas where human cases are occurring. There have been no major genetic changes in the viruses isolated from recent patients compared to previously isolated viruses from humans. Information to date suggests that these viruses do not transmit easily from human to human.\n\nOverall public health risk assessment for avian influenza A(H7N9) viruses:\nOverall, the public health risk from avian influenza A(H7N9) viruses has not changed since the assessment of 23 Feb 2015. See http://www.who.int/influenza/human_animal_interface/influenza_h7n9/Risk_Assessment/en/\n\nPlease find the most updated information at http://www.who.int/csr/don/11-march-2015-avian-influenza-china/en/\nand http://www.who.int/influenza/vaccines/virus/201502_zoonotic_vaccinevirusupdate.pdf?ua=14\n\nLinks:\nWHO human-animal interface web page http://www.who.int/influenza/human_animal_interface/en/\nCumulative Number of Confirmed Human Cases of Avian Influenza A/(H5N1) Reported to WHO http://www.who.int/influenza/human_animal_interface/H5N1_cumulative_table_archives/en/\n\nAvian influenza A(H7N9) information\n---------------\n\nhttp://who.int/influenza/human_animal_interface/influenza_h7n9/en/index.html\nWorld Organisation of Animal Health (OIE) web page: Web portal on Avian Influenza\nhttp://www.oie.int/animal-health-in-the-world/web-portal-on-avian-influenza/\nFood and Agriculture Organization of the UN (FAO) webpage: Avian Influenza http://www.fao.org/avianflu/en/index.html\nOFFLU\nhttp://www.offlu.net/index.htm\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[FluTrackers' count of H7N9 cases in China is significantly higher with a total of 656 since it was 1st noted in 2013 (https://flutrackers.com/forum/forum/china-h7n9-outbreak-tracking/143874-flutrackers-2013-15-human-case-list-of-provincial-ministry-of-health-government-confirmed-influenza-a-h7n9-cases-with-links). Similarly, discrepant numbers of cases have been reported for H5N1, but regardless, the 2 outbreaks (H5N1 and H7N9) are significant in their magnitude and duration. H5N1 in Egypt is now in its 5th month, and China is experiencing a 3rd wave of H7N9 cases since early Spring 2013. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[2] China: Avian influenza H7N9\nDate: Wed 15 Apr 2015\nWHO Global Alert and Response (GAR) [edited]\nhttp://www.who.int/csr/don/14-April-2015-avian-influenza-china/en/\n\n\nHuman infection with avian influenza A(H7N9) virus - China\n-----------------------\nOn 10 Apr 2015, the National Health and Family Planning Commission (NHFPC) of China notified WHO of 20 additional laboratory-confirmed cases of human infection with avian influenza A (H7N9) virus, including 4 deaths.\n\nOnset dates ranged from 14 Feb 2015 to 21 Mar 2015. Cases ranged in age from 32 to 80 years with a mean age of 55 years. Of these 20 cases, 15 (75 percent) were male. The majority (18 cases, 90 percent) reported exposure to live poultry. 1 case is a health care worker, who had also poultry exposure. No clusters were reported. Cases were reported from 5 provinces: Anhui (3), Fujian (2), Guangdong (4), Shandong (1), and Zhejiang (10).\n\nThe Chinese Government has taken the following surveillance and control measures\n- Strengthen epidemiological and etiological monitoring and situation analysis;\n- Strengthen case management and medical treatment;\n- Provide information to the public and conduct risk communication with the public.\n\nWHO is assessing the epidemiological situation and conducting further risk assessment based on the latest information. Overall, the public health risk from avian influenza A(H7N9) viruses has not changed. Comparing with the previous 2 months, the infection case number is decreasing and no new infected province has been reported. Further sporadic human cases of avian influenza A(H7N9) infection are expected in affected and possibly neighboring areas. Should human cases from affected areas travel internationally, their infection may be detected in another country during or after arrival. If this were to occur, community level spread is considered unlikely as the virus does not have the ability to transmit easily among humans.\n\nWHO advice\n--------\nWHO advises that travellers to countries with known outbreaks of avian influenza should avoid poultry farms, contact with animals in live bird markets, areas where poultry may be slaughtered, or any surfaces that appear to be contaminated with faeces from poultry or other animals. Travellers should also wash their hands often with soap and water. Travellers should follow good food safety and good food hygiene practices.\n\nWHO does not advise special screening at points of entry with regard to this event, nor does it currently recommend any travel or trade restrictions. As always, a diagnosis of infection with an avian influenza virus should be considered in individuals who develop severe acute respiratory symptoms while travelling or soon after returning from an area where avian influenza is a concern.\n\nWHO encourages countries to continue strengthening influenza surveillance, including surveillance for severe acute respiratory infections (SARI) and to carefully review any unusual patterns, in order to ensure reporting of human infections under the IHR (2005), and continue national health preparedness actions.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Since details of the individual cases are not provided, it is difficult to tell how many of the 20 cases have been reported previously.
