28 (16) [edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=17533\n\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza, Bhutan\n-----------------------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 16 Apr 2015 from Dr Tashi Samdup, Director, Department of Livestock, Ministry of Agriculture and Forests, Thimphu, Bhutan\n\nSummary\nReport type: Immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 3 Apr 2015\nDate of pre-confirmation of the event: 6 Apr 2015\nReason for notification: Reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 17 Apr 2013\nManifestation of disease: Clinical disease\nCausal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: Laboratory (advanced), necropsy\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks: Total outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1: Motithang City Camp, Thimphu Thromde, Thimphu\nDate of start of the outbreak: 3 Apr 2015\nOutbreak status: Continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: Backyard\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nBirds / 37 / 16 / 16 / 21 / 0\nOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]:\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBirds / 43.24 / 43.24 / 100 / 100\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Unknown or inconclusive\nEpidemiological comment: The outbreak has occurred in a backyard, free-ranging poultry population. While interviewing the owners of the birds, none of the mentioned source of infection could be ascertained. Further investigation on the source of infection will be followed-up. A host-pathogen interaction particularly in this case would be potential research topic. Only a small number of birds in an isolated pocket were affected. No further infection in flocks in close proximity was detected.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: Stamping out; quarantine; movement control inside the country; screening; zoning; disinfection of infected premises/establishment(s); dipping/spraying; vaccination prohibited; no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: No other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nNational Centre for Animal Health, Serbithang, Thimphu (national laboratory) / Birds / real-time PCR / 6 Apr 2015 / Positive\nNational Institute of High Security Animal Diseases (NIHSAD), Bhopal, India (OIE's Reference Laboratory) / Birds / real-time PCR / 14 Apr 2015 / Positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In 2012, Bhutan reported 14 outbreaks of highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) subtype H5N1. The event was resolved 17 Apr 2013. The event summary and map are available at: http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?fupser=&dothis=&reportid=11465.\n\nFor this current outbreak, the source of infection has not been determined. According to comments made in the epidemiologic section of the report, 'none of the mentioned sources of infection could be ascertained.' However, one should note that for the event reported in 2012, the introduction of new animals and the illegal movement of animals were identified as the source of infection. For this outbreak reported in Thimphu, these sources as well as the role of wildlife should not be completely discounted, especially given the occurrence of HPAI in the area.\n\nBhutan, officially the Kingdom of Bhutan, is a landlocked country in South Asia at the eastern end of the Himalayas. It is bordered to the north by China and to the south, east and west by India. To the west, it is separated from Nepal by the Indian state of Sikkim, while farther south it is separated from Bangladesh by the Indian states of Assam and West Bengal (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bhutan).\n\nSee a map of Bhutan at http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/f/fa/Bhutan_CIA_WFB_2010_map.png. - Mod.CRD]\n\n[Backyard poultry in Thrimshing, 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Bhutan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Serbithang", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bangladesh", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "India", "Thrimshing", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nepal", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3295430", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (92): ECDC update, H5N1 genetics", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3295430", "date": "2015-04-13 22:46:29", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (92): ECDC UPDATE, H5N1 GENETICS\n*******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Egypt: Avian influenza H5N1, ECDC update\n[2] Avian influenza H5N1 genetics\n\n******\n[1] Egypt: Avian influenza H5N1, ECDC update\nDate: 10 Apr 2015\nSource: European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control [edited]\nhttp://ecdc.europa.eu/en/press/news/_layouts/forms/News_DispForm.aspx?List=8db7286c-fe2d-476c-9133-18ff4cb1b568&ID=1199\n\n\nIn Egypt, as of 6 Apr 2015, the Ministry of Health and Population has reported 134 human cases of influenza A(H5N1), including 38 deaths. Since 2006, Egypt has reported 336 human cases, according to the World Health Organization (WHO)/Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO).\n\nThe number of laboratory-confirmed human cases of avian influenza A(H5N1) virus infection in Egypt with onsets of illness from January to March 2015 is the highest reported for a 3-month period since the start of the epidemic in 2006. New cases have been reported every month since the surge that started in November 2014 (Figure). No similar surge in cases has been reported in any other country.\n\nAs communicated by WHO, during the recent surge (November 2014 to March 2015), cases have been reported from 21 of the 29 Egyptian governorates. Females represented 60 percent of the cases. The number of fatal cases in Egypt in 2015 is the highest ever reported (Table). The case-fatality rate for 2015 so far is 28 percent, although, for recent cases, the final outcomes may not yet be known. There appears to have been no discernible trend in the case-fatality rate between 2006 and 2015. According to the WHO Regional Office for the Eastern Mediterranean (EMRO; see EMRO report in ProMED mail Avian influenza, human (89): WHO update, Egypt, H5N1 20150409.3287821), despite the recent surge in human cases, the demographic and epidemiological characteristics of the recently reported cases do not significantly differ from previous periods.\n\nThe increase in human cases in Egypt may be attributed to several factors, including increased circulation of influenza A(H5N1) viruses in poultry, lower public health awareness of risks in middle and upper Egypt, seasonal factors such as closer proximity to poultry because of cold weather and possibly longer survival of the viruses in the environment. A high-level joint WHO/FAO/OIE mission to Egypt was conducted in March 2015 to assess the risks associated with the influenza A(H5N1) viruses and to recommend control measures.\n\nECDC assessment\n----------------\nThis ongoing outbreak of influenza A(H5N1) among poultry and humans in Egypt has now caused more cases during one season than has been reported from any other country globally. The virus belongs to a clade [2.2.1] that appears to have been restricted to transmission in Egypt and neighbouring countries for several years. An emergence of a novel cluster within this clade was recently reported, which might explain the increase in poultry infections and/or human cases. No publicly available evidence is available to rule out ongoing human-to-human transmission in smaller clusters of cases, and detailed epidemiological studies are urgently needed.\n\nThe conclusions from the ECDC Rapid Risk Assessment published on 13 Mar 2015 remain valid.\n\nThe increase in human cases of A(H5N1) infection during the winter months 2014-2015 may be due to an increase in the circulation of A(H5N1) among backyard poultry and exposure to infected poultry across Egypt. Identification of such sporadic cases or small clusters is not unexpected, as avian influenza A(H5N1) viruses are known to be circulating there among poultry. Strict implementation of control measures to reduce and eliminate infection in poultry is essential for reducing the risk of zoonotic transmission and human cases. Enhanced human infectivity of the circulating virus and the protection conferred by the poultry vaccines currently in use should be further investigated. Surveillance in poultry as well as in humans needs to be strengthened and, ideally, coordinated. Intervention programmes to reduce virus circulation in the country should be reinforced. Travellers visiting Egypt should avoid direct contact with poultry and birds or uncooked/untreated poultry products.\n\nFigure: Distribution of human influenza A(H5N1) cases in Egypt, by month and year, March 2006 to March 2015\n\nTable: Number of human influenza A(H5N1) cases and deaths in Egypt, by year\n\nSee more at: http://ecdc.europa.eu/en/press/news/_layouts/forms/News_DispForm.aspx?List=8db7286c-fe2d-476c-9133-18ff4cb1b568&ID=1199 and\nClinical Infectious Diseases: http://cid.oxfordjournals.org/content/60/suppl_1.toc.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[See [2] below for a biological explanation for the surge in cases of H5N1 in humans, even though the New York Times title states a 'lack of explanation!' - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[2] Egypt: Avian influenza H5N1 surge\nDate: 13 Apr 2015\nSource: New York Times [edited]\nhttp://www.nytimes.com/2015/04/14/health/egypts-avian-flu-surge-lacks-an-explanation.html?_r=0\n\n\nCases of H5N1 avian flu have been surging in Egypt since the fall [2014]. Egypt has now passed Indonesia as the country with the most human cases in total since the virus was 1st found in Hong Kong almost 20 years ago. About 1/3rd of the 336 cases Egypt has reported to the World Health Organization since 2006 have been fatal. H5N1 avian flu still has killed more people in Indonesia. Despite the sudden unexplained increase -- Egypt has officially reported 125 cases since January 2015 -- the World Health Organization said the country's 'current risk status' has not changed.\n\nNearly all cases still appear to involve contact with poultry; the disease has long been endemic in birds throughout Egypt, where many households have small poultry flocks. Transmission from birds to humans continues to be sporadic, the W.H.O. said.\n\nVirologists have long feared that the highly lethal virus will mutate to become more transmissible among humans, but it is not clear exactly which mutations would do that. A study by Japanese and Egyptian scientists published last week in _mBio_, and noted by the University of Minnesota's Center for Infectious Disease Research and Policy, looked at viral genetic sequences found in Egyptian H5N1 victims and the effects of 59 mutations detected in them. When replicated in the laboratory, some of those mutations appeared to make it easier for the virus to attach to human airways cells; other mutations made the virus better at reproducing there.\n\nThat means if the virus circulating in Egyptian birds infects enough human victims, 'it could rapidly adapt to growth in the human airway microenvironment,' the authors of the new study concluded.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The full paper can be accessed at: Y. Watanabe, Y. Arai, T. Daidoji, et al. Characterization of H5N1 Influenza Virus Variants with Hemagglutinin Mutations Isolated from Patients. MBio. 2015 Apr 7;6(2). http://mbio.asm.org/content/6/2/e00081-15.full.\n\n'Abstract\n--------\nA change in viral hemagglutinin (HA) receptor binding specificity from alpha2,3- to alpha2,6-linked sialic acid is necessary for highly pathogenic avian influenza (AI) virus subtype H5N1 to become pandemic. However, details of the human-adaptive change in the H5N1 virus remain unknown. Our database search of H5N1 clade 2.2.1 viruses circulating in Egypt identified multiple HA mutations that had been selected in infected patients. Using reverse genetics, we found that increases in both human receptor specificity and the HA pH threshold for membrane fusion were necessary to facilitate replication of the virus variants in human airway epithelia. Furthermore, variants with enhanced replication in human cells had decreased HA stability, apparently to compensate for the changes in viral receptor specificity and membrane fusion activity. Our findings showed that H5N1 viruses could rapidly adapt to growth in the human airway microenvironment by altering their HA properties in infected patients and provided new insights into the human-adaptive mechanisms of AI viruses.\n\nImportance\n----------\nCirculation between bird and human hosts may allow H5N1 viruses to acquire amino acid changes that increase fitness for human infections. However, human-adaptive changes in H5N1 viruses have not been adequately investigated. In this study, we found that multiple HA mutations were actually selected in H5N1-infected patients and that H5N1 variants with some of these HA mutations had increased human-type receptor specificity and increased HA membrane fusion activity, both of which are advantageous for viral replication in human airway epithelia. Furthermore, HA mutants selected during viral replication in patients were likely to have less HA stability, apparently as a compensatory mechanism. These results begin to clarify the picture of the H5N1 human-adaptive mechanism.' ... -more\n\nThis is a significant advance elucidating at least one possible explanation for the increased level of transmission of H5N1 being observed in Egypt in 2015. Certainly, there may be other contributing factors as outlined in [1] in the ECDC report, but this is strong evidence of selection for genetic changes in the hemagglutinin (HA) in H5N1 virus strains isolated from infected humans that are associated with phenotypic changes in the virus. The investigators found that H5N1 clade 2.2.1 viruses can rapidly adapt to the human respiratory tract microenvironment by mutations that alter the balance of HA properties in H5N1-infected patients. The study provides new insight into H5N1 evolution in infected humans that needs to be followed up by experimental studies conducted with animal models in a biologically secure environment.\n\nBecause of concern over infection with H5N1, CDC advises travelers to Egypt to follow these recommendations to prevent being exposed to H5N1 (http://outbreaknewstoday.com/h5n1-avian-influenza-outbreak-in-egypt-prompts-cdc-travel-advisory-81499/):\n\nDo not touch birds or other animals: Do not touch animals, whether they are alive or dead; avoid live bird or poultry markets and avoid other markets or farms with animals (wet markets).\n\nEat food that is fully cooked: Eat meat and poultry that is fully cooked (not pink) and served hot; eat hard-cooked eggs (not runny); don't eat or drink dishes that include blood from any animal and don't eat food from street vendors.\n\nPractice hygiene and cleanliness: Wash your hands often; if soap and water aren't available, clean your hands with hand sanitizer containing at least 60 percent alcohol; don't touch your eyes, nose, or mouth. If you need to touch your face, make sure your hands are clean; cover your mouth and nose with a tissue or your sleeve (not your hands) when coughing or sneezing and try to avoid close contact, such as kissing, hugging or sharing eating utensils or cups, with people who are sick.\n\nSince its introduction in Egypt in 2006, avian influenza A(H5N1) virus has been circulating in domestic poultry in the country and has been the source of sporadic human infections. Almost all cases of H5N1 infection reported in humans in recent times have been associated with close contact with infected live or dead birds, or H5N1-contaminated environments, WHO states.\n\nH5N1 is a viral disease of birds. People rarely get H5N1, but when they do, it usually happens after close contact with infected birds (such as chickens, turkeys, geese, pigeons, and pheasants) or their body fluids. Human illness from H5N1 has ranged from mild eye infections and flu-like symptoms to pneumonia and death. H5N1 does not spread easily between people. The risk of H5N1 to travelers is extremely low, according to the CDC. - Mod.LK\n\nMaps of Egypt can be seen at http://www.geoatlas.com/medias/maps/countries/egypt/eg3r92t/egypt_pol.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/55. - Mod.LK]", "summary": "\n\nFigure: Distribution of human influenza A(H5N1) cases in Egypt, by month and year, March 2006 to March 2015\n\nTable: Number of human influenza A(H5N1) \n\nThe increase in human cases in Egypt may be attributed to several factors, including increased circulation of influenza A(H5N1) viruses in poultry, lower public health awareness of risks in middle and upper Egypt, seasonal factors such as closer proximity to poultry because of cold weather and possibly longer survival of the viruses in the environment. According to the WHO Regional Office for the Eastern Mediterranean (EMRO; see EMRO report in ProMED mail Avian influenza, human (89): WHO update, Egypt, H5N1 20150409.3287821), despite the recent surge in human cases, the demographic and epidemiological characteristics of the recently reported cases do not significantly differ from previous periods. \n\nThe number of laboratory-confirmed human cases of avian influenza A(H5N1) virus infection in Egypt with onsets of illness from January to March 2015 is the highest reported for a 3-month period since the start of the epidemic in 2006. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n In this study, we found that multiple HA mutations were actually selected in H5N1-infected patients and that H5N1 variants with some of these HA mutations had increased human-type receptor specificity and increased HA membrane fusion activity, both of which are advantageous for viral replication in human airway epithelia. The increase in human cases of A(H5N1) infection during the winter months 2014-2015 may be due to an increase in the circulation of A(H5N1) among backyard poultry and exposure to infected poultry across Egypt. ----------\nCirculation between bird and human hosts may allow H5N1 viruses to acquire amino acid changes that increase fitness for human infections. Our findings showed that H5N1 viruses could rapidly adapt to growth in the human airway microenvironment by altering their HA properties in infected patients and provided new insights into the human-adaptive mechanisms of AI viruses. [1] Egypt: Avian influenza H5N1, ECDC update\n[2] Avian influenza H5N1 genetics\n\n***** Since its introduction in Egypt in 2006, avian influenza A(H5N1) virus has been circulating in domestic poultry in the country and has been the source of sporadic human infections. An emergence of a novel cluster within this clade was recently reported, which might explain the increase in poultry infections and/or human cases. In Egypt, as of 6 Apr 2015, the Ministry of Health and Population has reported 134 human cases of influenza A(H5N1), including 38 deaths. Strict implementation of control measures to reduce and eliminate infection in poultry is essential for reducing the risk of zoonotic transmission and human cases. Almost all cases of H5N1 infection reported in humans in recent times have been associated with close contact with infected live or dead birds, or H5N1-contaminated environments, WHO states. \n\nEat food that is fully cooked: Eat meat and poultry that is fully cooked (not pink) and served hot; eat hard-cooked eggs (not runny); don't eat or drink dishes that include blood from any animal and don't eat food from street vendors. The investigators found that H5N1 clade 2.2.1 viruses can rapidly adapt to the human respiratory tract microenvironment by mutations that alter the balance of HA properties in H5N1-infected patients. This ongoing outbreak of influenza A(H5N1) among poultry and humans in Egypt has now caused more cases during one season than has been reported from any other country globally. Egypt has now passed Indonesia as the country with the most human cases in total since the virus was 1st found in Hong Kong almost 20 years ago. With this additional number, the total number of cases reported during the month of March 2015 now stands at 30 cases, including 4 deaths. This increase in reported human cases has been observed since the beginning of November last year [2014].\n\nSince its introduction in Egypt in 2006, avian influenza A(H5N1) virus has been circulating in domestic poultry in the country and has been the source of sporadic human infections. Almost all cases of H5N1 infection reported in humans in recent times have been associated with close contact with infected live or dead birds, or H5N1-contaminated environments. Though the number of cases reported is higher compared to last year, the increase in the number of cases does not change current risk status of avian influenza A(H5N1) virus that is currently circulating at the animal-human interface in the country.\n\nSince it was 1st reported in March 2006, a total of 336 cases of avian influenza A(H5N1) infections in humans have been reported, including 114 related deaths (case-fatality rate = 34 per cent).\n\nTable 1 (Cumulative number of laboratory-confirmed human cases of avian influenza A(H5N1) reported to WHO, 2006-2015 )\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nYear -- cases (deaths) / [case-fatality rate (per cent)]\n\n2006 -- 18 (10) / [55.6]\n2007 -- 25 (9) / [36]\n2008 -- 8 (4) / [50]\n2009 -- 39 (4) / [10.3]\n2010 -- 28 (13) / [46.4]\n2011 -- 40 (15) / [37.5]\n2012 -- 11 (5) / [45.5]\n2013 -- 4 (3) / [75]\n2014 -- 38 (18) / [47.4]\n2015 -- 125 (33) [as of 31 Mar 2015] / [26.4]\nTotal -- 336 (114) / [33.9]\n\nTotal number of cases includes number of deaths.\nWHO reports only laboratory-confirmed cases.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[2015 is striking in the sharp increase in human cases. The case-fatality rate (CFR) spans a broad range, from 10 per cent to 75 per cent, with an overall CFR of 33.9 per cent. The 75 per cent is derived from only 4 cases, so needs to be interpreted with caution. An infographic that is very informative is included in the WHO report, and can be viewed at the URL above. It includes highlights and figures of cases by location and year, week, gender and age group, outcome, and more.\n\nHighlights are:\n\nSince its emergence in March 2006, a total of 336 cases of avian influenza A(H5N1) infections in humans have been reported from Egypt, including 114 deaths (CFR = 33.8 per cent). Of these, a total of 159 cases including 47 deaths (CFR = 29 per cent) were reported since November 2014 when the country experienced a surge in human infections.\n\nCases were reported from 21 out of 29 governorates in the country during the recent surge. Amongst the cases reported since November 2014, the females comprised 60 per cent of all reported cases and had a higher death rate of 33 per cent, compared to 28 per cent reported amongst the males.\n\nSince the upsurge in cases began in November 2014, the age group of 30-45 years has been found to be the most at risk of acquiring the infection (31 per cent), followed by children in the under 5 years age group (28 per cent), while the age group above 45 years had the highest CFR (47 per cent), and the children under 5 years of age group had the lowest CFR (7 per cent).\n\nDespite the recent surge in human cases, the demographic and epidemiological characteristics of the reported cases do not show any significant change.\n\nMaps of Egypt can be seen at http://www.geoatlas.com/medias/maps/countries/egypt/eg3r92t/egypt_pol.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/55. - Mod.LK]", "summary": "Since the upsurge in cases began in November 2014, the age group of 30-45 years has been found to be the most at risk of acquiring the infection (31 per cent), followed by children in the under 5 years age group (28 per cent), while the age group above 45 years had the highest CFR (47 per cent), and the children under 5 years of age group had the lowest CFR (7 per cent). Amongst the cases reported since November 2014, the females comprised 60 per cent of all reported cases and had a higher death rate of 33 per cent, compared to 28 per cent reported amongst the males. \n\nSince it was 1st reported in March 2006, a total of 336 cases of avian influenza A(H5N1) infections in humans have been reported, including 114 related deaths (case-fatality rate = 34 per cent). A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nTable 1 (Cumulative number of laboratory-confirmed human cases of avian influenza A(H5N1) reported to WHO, 2006-2015 )\n Though the number of cases reported is higher compared to last year, the increase in the number of cases does not change current risk status of avian influenza A(H5N1) virus that is currently circulating at the animal-human interface in the country. Highlights are:\n\nSince its emergence in March 2006, a total of 336 cases of avian influenza A(H5N1) infections in humans have been reported from Egypt, including 114 deaths (CFR = 33.8 per cent). With this additional number, the total number of cases reported during the month of March 2015 now stands at 30 cases, including 4 deaths. Of these, a total of 159 cases including 47 deaths (CFR = 29 per cent) were reported since November 2014 when the country experienced a surge in human infections. Despite the recent surge in human cases, the demographic and epidemiological characteristics of the reported cases do not show any significant change. AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (89): WHO UPDATE, EGYPT, H5N1\n****************************************************\n \nYear -- cases (deaths) / The case-fatality rate (CFR) spans a broad range, from 10 per cent to 75 per cent, with an overall CFR of 33.9 per cent. [33.9]\n\nTotal number of cases includes number of deaths. \n\nCases were reported from 21 out of 29 governorates in the country during the recent surge.", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1989-03-24 00:00:00", "2006-03-24 00:00:00", "2007-03-24 00:00:00", "2010-03-24 00:00:00", "2015-03-24 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2014-11-24 00:00:00", "2009-03-24 00:00:00", "2014-03-24 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "EGYPT", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Egypt", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3274191", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (81): genetic changes H5N1", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3274191", "date": "2015-04-02 20:51:16", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (81): GENETIC CHANGES H5N1\n*************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 2 Apr 2015\nSource: Eurosurveillance [edited]\nhttp://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=21085\n\n\nEmergence of a novel cluster of influenza A(H5N1) virus clade 2.2.1.2 with putative human health impact in Egypt, 2014/15\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nAbstract\n--------\nA distinct cluster of highly pathogenic avian influenza viruses of subtype A(H5N1) has been found to emerge within clade 2.2.1.2 in poultry in Egypt since summer 2014 and appears to have quickly become predominant. Viruses of this cluster may be associated with increased incidence of human influenza A(H5N1) infections in Egypt over the last months.\n\nIn Egypt, highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) influenza A(H5N1) viruses of clade 2.2.1 and their descendants have been circulating in poultry populations since 2006, causing sporadic human infections [1]. Human influenza A(H5N1) infections in Egypt have been reported since the introduction of the virus in 2006 with \u2009204 cases occurring until end of 2014 and a fatality rate of 35.8 percent in laboratory-confirmed cases reported to the World Health Organization (WHO). However, since January 2015, the incidence of human H5N1 cases in Egypt has increased dramatically: as of 21 March 2015, 116 human cases including 36 deaths have been reported to WHO [2]. This study was initiated to analyse molecular properties of H5N1 viruses that have caused outbreaks in poultry in Egypt since summer 2014 and to compare them with published sequences from H5N1 viruses obtained from recent human cases. ... [more]\n\nTable 1. Influenza A(H5N1) viruses included in this study and collected from poultry, Egypt, June 2014-January 2015 (n=29)\nTable 2. Antigenic characterisation of highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N1) viruses from Egypt and elsewhere, based on haemagglutination inhibition assays\nTable 3. Amino acid residues distinguishing recently emerging highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N1) viruses from virus lineages circulating before November 2014, Egypt, March 2015\nFigure 1. Temporal (graph) and geographic (map) distribution of outbreaks of highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N1) in poultry, Egypt, October 2014-February 2015 (n=435)\nFigure 2. Phylogenetic analysis of the HA (A) and NA (B) genes (coding regions) and maximum clade credibility tree (C) based on the HA open reading frame of selected highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N1) viruses, Egypt, June 2014-January 2015 (n=29)\n\n1. Abdelwhab EM, Hafez HM. An overview of the epidemic of highly pathogenic H5N1 avian influenza virus in Egypt: epidemiology and control challenges. Epidemiol Infect. 2011;139(5):647-57. http://dx.doi.org/10.1017/S0950268810003122 PMID:21281550\n2. World Health Organization (WHO). Avian influenza A (H5N1) in Egypt update, 21 March 2015. Geneva: WHO. [Accessed: 2 Apr 2015]. Available from: http://www.emro.who.int/surveillance-forecasting-response/surveillance-news/avian-influenza-a-h5n1-in-egypt-update-21-march-2015.html\n... [more]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Arafa AS, Naguib MM, Luttermann C, Selim AA, Kilany WH, Hagag N, Samy A, Abdelhalim A, Hassan MK, Abdelwhab EM, Makonnen Y, Dauphin G, Lubroth J, Mettenleiter TC, Beer M, Grund C, Harder TC. Emergence of a novel cluster of influenza A(H5N1) virus clade 2.2.1.2 with putative human health impact in Egypt, 2014/15. Euro Surveill. 2015;20(13):pii=21085. Available online: http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=21085\n\nReaders are referred to the full text and figures available at the above URL.\n\nAccording to FluTrackers, the current tally of human H5N1 cases in Egypt is 128 (https://flutrackers.com/forum/forum/china-h7n9-outbreak-tracking/143874-flutrackers-2013-15-human-case-list-of-provincial-ministry-of-health-government-confirmed-influenza-a-h7n9-cases-with-links), a number greater than the 116 quoted above by WHO. In addition, there have been heavy losses in poultry due to high infection rates. 435 outbreaks of H5N1 infections in poultry in Egypt are noted in this paper between October 2014 and February 2015, as reported to the National Laboratory for Quality Control on Poultry Production (NLQP) by Egyptian veterinary authorities. Therefore, it cannot be ruled out that this increased level of transmission in the birds in Egypt (which includes chickens, ducks, turkeys and quail) has led to increased exposure of bird handlers and buyers and backyard bird owners, and consequently increased numbers of cases. However, another possibility proposed by this paper is that the genetic changes observed in the 2015 viruses have led to greater transmissibility of the virus. The investigators found that strains analyzed since November 2014 contain distinct fixed mutations in several genome segments PB2, PB1-F2, HA, NA, M1. The emerging cluster identified in this study seems to be predominant across all poultry production sectors and has already caused 1/3rd of all human H5N1 infections reported in Egypt since 2006, in only 3 months of 2015.\n\nBut questions remain -- what are the molecular determinants that increase fitness of these viruses? What are the selective pressures acting on the virus? Are the observed genetic changes random, or is natural selection acting to favor mutations that make the virus more transmissible? Studies of the pathogenicity and transmissibility of these viruses, most likely using the ferret model, need to be conducted to answer the question of whether the genetic changes are affecting the current outbreak.\n\nMaps of Egypt can be seen at http://www.geoatlas.com/medias/maps/countries/egypt/eg3r92t/egypt_pol.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/55. - Mod.LK]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Amino acid residues distinguishing recently emerging highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N1) viruses from virus lineages circulating before November 2014, Egypt, March 2015\n Phylogenetic analysis of the HA (A) and NA (B) genes (coding regions) and maximum clade credibility tree (C) based on the HA open reading frame of selected highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N1) viruses, Egypt, June 2014-January 2015 (n=29)\n\n1. In Egypt, highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) influenza A(H5N1) viruses of clade 2.2.1 and their descendants have been circulating in poultry populations since 2006, causing sporadic human infections [1]. Temporal (graph) and geographic (map) distribution of outbreaks of highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N1) in poultry, Egypt, October 2014-February 2015 (n=435)\n [more]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Arafa AS, Naguib MM, Luttermann C, Selim AA, Kilany WH, Hagag N, Samy A, Abdelhalim A, Hassan MK, Abdelwhab EM, Makonnen Y, Dauphin G, Lubroth J, Mettenleiter TC, Beer M, Grund C, Harder TC. A distinct cluster of highly pathogenic avian influenza viruses of subtype A(H5N1) has been found to emerge within clade 2.2.1.2 in poultry in Egypt since summer 2014 and appears to have quickly become predominant. Human influenza A(H5N1) infections in Egypt have been reported since the introduction of the virus in 2006 with \u2009204 cases occurring until end of 2014 and a fatality rate of 35.8 percent in laboratory-confirmed cases reported to the World Health Organization (WHO). However, since January 2015, the incidence of human H5N1 cases in Egypt has increased dramatically: as of 21 March 2015, 116 human cases including 36 deaths have been reported to WHO [2]. AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (81): GENETIC CHANGES H5N1\n*************************************************\n This study was initiated to analyse molecular properties of H5N1 viruses that have caused outbreaks in poultry in Egypt since summer 2014 and to compare them with published sequences from H5N1 viruses obtained from recent human cases. ... \n\n\nEmergence of a novel cluster of influenza A(H5N1) virus clade 2.2.1.2 with putative human health impact in Egypt, 2014/15\n Antigenic characterisation of highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N1) viruses from Egypt and elsewhere, based on haemagglutination inhibition assays\nTable 3. viruses included in this study and collected from poultry, Egypt, June 2014-January 2015 (n=29)\n The emerging cluster identified in this study seems to be predominant across all poultry production sectors and has already caused 1/3rd of all human H5N1 infections reported in Egypt since 2006, in only 3 months of 2015. 435 outbreaks of H5N1 infections in poultry in Egypt are noted in this paper between October 2014 and February 2015, as reported to the National Laboratory for Quality Control on Poultry Production (NLQP) by Egyptian veterinary authorities. Viruses of this cluster may be associated with increased incidence of human influenza A(H5N1) infections in Egypt over the last months.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2006-03-24 00:00:00", "2015-01-24 00:00:00", "1981-03-24 00:00:00", "2014-10-24 00:00:00", "2015-03-24 00:00:00", "2015-02-24 00:00:00", "2015-03-21 00:00:00", "2014-11-24 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Egypt", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3297244", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (78): India (TG) HPAI H5N1, poultry, spread", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3297244", "date": "2015-04-14 19:21:28", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (78): INDIA (TELANGANA) HPAI H5N1, POULTRY, SPREAD\n******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 14 Apr 2015\nSource: The Times of India (TOI), Times News Network (TNN) [edited]\nhttp://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/hyderabad/Telangana-reports-bird-flu-outbreak-culls-poultry/articleshow/46918588.cms\n\n\nThe Telangana government sounded a red alert after the highly pathogenic H5N1 bird flu virus broke out in Ranga Reddy district about 20 km [12.4 mi] from Hyderabad.\n\nIn wake of the outbreak, the government swung into action and initiated a process to cull about 200 000 birds within a 10 km [6.2 mi] radius and also ban sale of poultry and eggs in Hayathnagar, the main town in the district and issued an advisory to Andhra Pradesh as well.\n\n'We have decided to cull about 200 000 birds and we are taking all safety precautions as per the laid down protocol. Gunny sacks are being procured and pits are being dug,' said Dr K Vamsi Krishna Reddy, assistant veterinary surgeon.\n\nThe government also set up rapid response teams to help in the culling process.\n\nAbout a week ago, several birds mysteriously died in a poultry farm in Thorur village in Hayathnagar [Ranga Reddy district], following which dead chicken samples were sent to a testing laboratory in Bhopal.\n\nThe local veterinary doctor raised an alarm after he found hundreds of birds dead in the farm.\n\n'Yes we confirm it as the deadly H5N1 virus and we have advised the animal husbandry department in Telangana and the government to take all appropriate measures,' DD Kulkarni, joint director, High-Security Animal Disease Laboratory, Bhopal, told TOI from Bhopal.\n\nAn advisory to the central government and authorities in Andhra Pradesh, were sent to report any incident of dead poultry, officials said, as fears of the virus, spreading rose.\n\nSince 2003, there have been 209 human deaths globally from the H5N1 strain and 340 confirmed cases of infection.\n\n'All safety measures must be taken to contain the virus. We first detected the virus in Jalgaon, Maharashtra,' Kulkarni added. Andhra Pradesh reported an outbreak in 2009.\n\n[Byline: Siddharth Tadepalli]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nPavuluri Panduranga Rao\nElla Foundation\nHyderabad, India\n<raopp@ellafoundation.org>\n\n[The submitter kindly added the following data: 'Hayatnagar is on the out skirts of Hyderabad, state capital of Telangana and one of the biggest cities in India, with more than 10 million human population. In other parts of the country H5N1 has been detected in crows in wild. The report of the Indian Government on notifiable avian influenza (H5 and H7) for the period 16-29 Mar 2015 is available at http://dahd.nic.in/dahd/WriteReadData/Bfweekending29.03.2015.pdf.'\n\nWe are grateful to Pavuluri Panduranga Rao for the update from India. The OIE report on the cases in 2 crows in Haliapur, Sultanpur, Uttar Pradesh, 20 Mar 2015, is available, with map, at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapEventSummary&reportid=17426.\n\nMaps of India can be seen at http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/30972\nTelangana, the 12th largest state in India, is situated in the Southern region of India. Previous recent outbreaks of HPAI H5N1 were reported from 3 states -- Uttar Pradesh and Chandigar in North India, and Kerala (southern India). For information on those epizootics, please refer to ProMED-mail posting 20150319.3241127. - Mod.AS]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Hyderabad, India\n<raopp@ellafoundation.org>\n\n[The submitter kindly added the following data: 'Hayatnagar is on the out skirts of Hyderabad, state capital of Telangana and one of the biggest cities in India, with more than 10 million human population. \n\nAn advisory to the central government and authorities in Andhra Pradesh, were sent to report any incident of dead poultry, officials said, as fears of the virus, spreading rose. Identification of farms in the outbreak area. - Disinfection of premises. - Movement restrictions. - Strengthening epidemiological surveillance. - Sampling for detection of highly pathogenic avian influenza virus.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: movement control inside the country, disinfection of infected premises/establishment(s), modified stamping out, no vaccination, no treatment of The event summary and map are available at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?reportid=4590\n\nIn the article by Ducatez MF, Tarnagda Z, Tahita MC, et al: Genetic Characterization of HPAI (H5N1) Viruses from Poultry and Wild Vultures, Burkina Faso (Emerg Infect Dis. 2007; 13(4): 611-3.\ndoi: 10.3201/eid1304.061356; http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/13/4/pdfs/06-1356.pdf), there is a statement indicating that 'Genetic analysis of highly pathogenic avian influenza (H5N1) viruses from poultry and hooded vultures in Burkina Faso shows that these viruses belong to 1 of 3 sublineages initially found in Nigeria and later in other African countries. Hooded vultures (_Necrosyrtes monachus_) could potentially be vectors or sentinels of influenza subtype H5N1, as are cats and swans elsewhere.'\n\nAlthough the source of infection has not been determined, given the current HPAI events in Nigeria and the role of wild birds in the epidemiology of the disease, the recent outbreaks in Burkina Faso could be related to the events in Nigeria.\n\nDuring 2015 Nigeria has reported 55 outbreaks of HPAI H5N1; ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 3 Apr 2015\nSource: Hong Kong government information [edited]\nhttp://www.chp.gov.hk/en/view_content/39157.html\n\n\nThe Centre for Health Protection of the Department of Health today (3 Apr 2015) received notification from the National Health and Family Planning Commission (NHFPC) of a human case of avian influenza A(H5N1) affecting a boy aged 6 in Yunnan.\n\nAccording to the information provided by NHFPC, the patient lives in Chuxiong and presented with fever on 23 Mar 2015. He attended a local hospital on 25 Mar 2015 and has currently recovered after treatment. His specimen, which was tested by the relevant authority, was positive for avian influenza A(H5N1).\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This is the 5th case of avian influenza H5N1 in Mainland China since the beginning of 2015. The 1st case was a 37-year-old female with an onset date of 14 Jan 2015. The 2nd case occurred in Sichuan in a 46-year-old male with onset 18 Feb 2015 and ended in death. The next 3 cases occurred in Yunnan province: Male, 34, onset 13 Mar 2015; male 17, onset 17 Mar 2015; and this current case, a male 6 years old. The 2 previous cases were in Kumming, the capital and largest city (population 3 million) in the province, while this latest case is in Chuxiong, 175 km west. The highest number of cases of H5N1 in China was reported in 2009 (7 cases, 4 deaths).\n\nThis case brings the total number of (worldwide) cases in 2015 to 135, according to FluTrackers 2015 Global WHO & Ministries of Health Confirmed H5N1 Human Cases List https://flutrackers.com/forum/forum/flutrackers-high-pathogenic-h5n1-h1n08-h5n8-h5n6-h5n3-tracking-outbreaks-spread/720310-flutrackers-2015-global-who-ministries-of-health-confirmed-h5n1-human-cases-list.\n\nA discussion of the genetic changes observed in H5N1 in Egypt in 2015 can be found in the ProMED post 20150402.3274191; however, the virus strain(s) responsible for these 5 cases in China have not been reported.\n\nA map of the provinces of China may be viewed at http://www.china-mike.com/china-travel-tips/tourist-maps/china-provinces-map, and a HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/155 - Mod.LK]", "summary": "The next 3 cases occurred in Yunnan province: Male, 34, onset 13 Mar 2015; male 17, onset 17 Mar 2015; and this current case, a male 6 years old. Emergence of a novel cluster of influenza A(H5N1) virus clade 2.2.1.2 with putative human health impact in Egypt, 2014/15._Eurosurveillance_ 20(13) April 2015. http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=21085] -- [which has led to the Egyptian Ministry of Health] denying that any changes have appeared in the virus now circulating in Egypt.\n\nToday the FAO has published details on 7 new H5N1 cases (listed below) which increase the total in FluTrackers' Egypt - 2015 WHO/MoH/Provincial Health Depts H5N1 Confirmed Case List to 135 cases since 1 Jan 2015. Fatalities, which are less often reported by the media and the FAO, hover around 40 -- although that number is probably low and will be adjusted in future WHO updates. This from today's FAO RSS feed.\n\n1. Confirmed Influenza - Avian in Giza, for human\n2. Confirmed Influenza - Avian in Suhag, for human\n3. Confirmed Influenza - Avian in Suhag, for human\n4. Confirmed Influenza - Avian in Kalyoubia, for human\n5. Confirmed Influenza - Avian in Kafr El-Shikh, for human\n6. Confirmed Influenza - Avian in Shrkia, for human\n7. Confirmed Influenza - Avian in Shrkia, for human\n\nAs with Avian flu in China, Vietnam, and elsewhere, only the `sickest of the sick' generally show up at hospitals, and end up tested and counted. How many `mild' cases (or misdiagnosed severe cases) there might be is unknown.\n\nWhile we've not seen any evidence of increased or efficient human-to-human transmission of the H5N1 virus in Egypt, it is concerning that this outbreak has now gone on for 5 full months, and that in excess of 160 people have been infected. This is -- by far -- the largest and longest human outbreak of H5N1 we've seen.\n\nSo we continue to keep a close watch on Egypt for any signs that the virus, or its behavior, has begun to change.\n\n[Byline: Mike Coston]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[To read more discussion of the genetic changes in H5N1 and the possible consequences, see ProMED Avian influenza, human (81): genetic changes H5N1 20150402.3274191. What is behind the more intense transmission of H5N1 being observed in Egypt this flu season is not clear, but may be related to the genetic changes that have been detected in circulating viral strains or greater numbers of poultry with infection, increasing contact of humans and naive birds with the predominant source of infectious virus. The increased level of transmission is concerning as it may lead to increased opportunities for the virus to reassort or mutate.\n\nMaps of Egypt can be seen at http://www.geoatlas.com/medias/maps/countries/egypt/eg3r92t/egypt_pol.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/55. - Mod.LK]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nWhile we've not seen any evidence of increased or efficient human-to-human transmission of the H5N1 virus in Egypt, it is concerning that this outbreak has now gone on for 5 full months, and that in excess of 160 people have been infected. AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (88): EGYPT H5N1\n***************************************\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[To read more discussion of the genetic changes in H5N1 and the possible consequences, see ProMED Avian influenza, human (81): genetic changes H5N1 20150402.3274191. "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3265900", "date": "2015-03-30 16:18:57", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (62): ROMANIA (CONSTANTA) HPAI H5N1, WILD BIRD, OIE\n*******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 30 Mar 2015\nSource: OIE, WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database), weekly disease information 2015; 28(14) [edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=17445\n\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza, Romania\n------------------------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 30 Mar 2015 from Dr Maximilian Dragan, General Director, National Sanitary Veterinary and Food Safety Authority, Ministry of Agriculture and Food, Bucharest, Romania\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 25 Mar 2015\nDate of pre-confirmation of the event: 27 Mar 2015\nReason for notification: reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: April 2010\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: laboratory (advanced)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nOutbreak 1: Sinoe Lake, Ceaplace island, Constanta\nDate of start of the outbreak: 25 Mar 2015\nOutbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: not applicable\nAffected animals\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nDalmatian pelican: _Pelecanus crispus_(Pelecanidae) / 250 / 64 / 64 / 0 / 0\nAffected population: A colony of approximately 250 birds.\n\nOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBirds / 25.60 / 25.60 / 100 / 25.60\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and / or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\nEpidemiological comments: On 25 Mar [2015], the County Sanitary Veterinary and Food Safety Directorate (CSVFSD) of Tulcea was notified by the Danube Delta Biosphere Reserve Administration (ARBDD) about the identification of 64 carcasses of pelicans in an inhabited area, on Ceaplace island, Sinoe lake. This area is located at the border of Tulcea and Constanta Counties, and no other localities with domestic birds are found on a radius more than 10 km [6.2 miles]. The entire population of pelicans counted initially more than 250 birds, adults and young. Excluding the dead pelicans (found in different stages of putrefaction), no other birds were observed with clinical signs in the area. Also, in the area were observed other birds species, still unspecified.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: control of wildlife reservoirs, screening, zoning, vaccination prohibited, no treatment of affected animals.\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type: Institute for Diagnosis and Animal Health (national laboratory)\nSpecies / Test / Test date / Result\nDalmatian pelican / virus isolation / 27 Mar 2015 / Positive\nDalmatian pelican / reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) / 30 Mar 2015 / Positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[There have been several wild bird incidents of HPAI H5N1 in Eastern Europe. Almost simultaneously, there was a report on 21 pelicans dead to HPAI H5N1 in Bulgaria: http://afludiary.blogspot.com.ar/2015/03/oie-h5n1-kills-21-pelicans-in-bulgaria.html, where in January 2015 there had been reports of deaths attributed to HPAI H5N1 in pelicans and gulls.\n\nFor a HealthMap of the affected region, go to http://healthmap.org/promed/p/13443. - Mod.PMB]", "summary": "A "3265901", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (79): Egypt FAO update, Indonesia (BT) H5N1", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3265901", "date": "2015-03-30 16:21:48", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (79): EGYPT FAO UPDATE, INDONESIA (BANTEN) H5N1\n**********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Egypt: FAO update, avian influenza H5N1\n[2] Indonesia (Banten): avian influenza H5N1\n\n******\n[1] Egypt: FAO update, avian influenza H5N1\nDate: Mon 30 Mar 2015\nSource: Avian Flu Diary, FAO EMPRES Disease Event Details [edited]\nhttp://afludiary.blogspot.com/2015/03/fao-egypts-h5n1-case-count-continues-to.html\n\n\nThe FAO [Food and Agriculture Organization of the UN] has announced 11 more H5N1 cases [in Egypt]\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\n1. 30 Mar 2015: Egypt - Influenza - Avian - Confirmed Influenza - Assiut, human\n2. 30 Mar 2015: Egypt - Influenza - Avian - Confirmed Influenza - Port Said, human\n3. 30 Mar 2015: Egypt - Influenza - Avian - Confirmed Influenza - Fayoum, human\n4. 30 Mar 2015: Egypt - Influenza - Avian - Confirmed Influenza - Shrkia, human\n5. 30 Mar 2015: Egypt - Influenza - Avian - Confirmed Influenza - Shrkia, human\n6. 30 Mar 2015: Egypt - Influenza - Avian - Confirmed Influenza - Menoufia, human\n7. 30 Mar 2015: Egypt - Influenza - Avian - Confirmed Influenza - Dakahlia, human\n8. 30 Mar 2015: Egypt - Influenza - Avian - Confirmed Influenza - Suhag, human\n9. 30 Mar 2015: Egypt - Influenza - Avian - Confirmed Influenza - Shrkia, human\n10. 30 Mar 2015: Egypt - Influenza - Avian - Confirmed Influenza - Behera, human\n11. 30 Mar 2015: Egypt - Influenza - Avian - Confirmed Influenza - Shrkia, human\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The new cases reported by the FAO bring FluTrackers' tally of H5N1 cases since 1 Jan 2015 to 128, as only 7 cases on the list of 11 above had not previously been included on Sharon Sanders (Editor-in-Chief)'s list. See https://flutrackers.com/forum/forum/egypt/h5n1-tracking-egypt/720309-egypt-2015-who-moh-provincial-health-depts-h5n1-confirmed-case-list. No deaths are noted among these cases, although they may be reported in the future. The reporting problem continues even as the case numbers increase, with discrepant numbers coming from WHO and FluTrackers compared with the Egyptian MOH [see more discussion of this in ProMED-mail post Avian influenza, human (78): Indonesia (BT) RFI, Egypt (SJ) H5N1 20150329.3263924]. Egypt appears to be experiencing intense activity as evidenced not only by the increasing numbers of cases, but also from reports of serious losses to the poultry industry, most likely from H5N1 (see http://afludiary.blogspot.com/2015/02/egypt-h5n1-poultry-losses-climbing.html).\n\nMaps of Egypt can be seen at http://www.geoatlas.com/medias/maps/countries/egypt/eg3r92t/egypt_pol.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/55. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[2] Indonesia (Banten): avian influenza human H5N1\nDate: Sat 28 Mar 2015\nSource: Jakarta Globe [edited]\nhttp://thejakartaglobe.beritasatu.com/news/tangerang-woman-free-h5n1-remains-observation/\n\n\nTangerang Woman Free of H5N1, Remains Under Observation\n-------------------------------------------------------\nThe Ministry of Health will continue to monitor a woman from Tangerang [Banten province, Indonesia] for at least another day after her husband and 2-year-old child died of bird flu last week [see ProMED-mail post Avian influenza, human (78): Indonesia (BT) RFI, Egypt (SJ) H5N1 20150329.3263924].\n\nThe head of the ministry's research agency, Tjandra Yoga Aditama, said the woman was free of the H5N1 virus, and that health officials had run 2 separate tests. 'We will check the sample from her throat on the 3rd day to ensure that she is healthy,' Tjandra said. 'Overall she is in good condition; she no longer has fever.'\n\nA 40-year-old man from Tangerang died on Tuesday [24 Mar 2015], and his 2-year-old child died on Thursday [26 Mar 2015]. The government suspected the patients contracted the virus from an infected owl while visiting a relative's house in Bogor, West Java [Jawa Barat province].\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The Jakarta Post today (Mon 30 Mar 2015) indicates the 2 family members died from H5N1, which we suspected, but had not been able to confirm when the previous post was made by ProMED (Avian influenza, human (78): Indonesia (BT) RFI, Egypt (SJ) H5N1 20150329.3263924). This news report also indicated that the 2 were believed to have been exposed to poultry when they visited the Bogor home of a relative who owns a small poultry farm. See more at http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2015/03/30/greater-jakarta-two-die-bird-flu-tangerang.html. However, the post above suggests it may have been an infected owl that served as the source of the virus. The National Wildlife Health Center (US Geological Survey) indicates birds in the order _Strigiformes_ (owls) are infected by H5N1 and die from the infection. The role of wild birds in avian flu virus dissemination has been a subject of intense discussion. Most wild birds are thought to become infected when sharing water sources contaminated with the virus, as H5N1 is primarily a gastrointestinal infection in birds, and is generally believed to spread through infected feces. This is probably the case for waterfowl; however, owls, which are opportunistic hunters, likely may become infected by consumption of infected prey. Suggested further reading on the topic of wild bird involvement in H5N1 transmission includes: Tian H et al. 2015. PNAS 112(1). http://www.pnas.org/cgi/doi/10.1073/pnas.1405216112.\n\nMaps of Indonesia may be accessed at http://www.geographicguide.com/pictures/maps/indonesia-map.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/548 - Mod.LK]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The Jakarta Post today (Mon 30 Mar 2015) indicates the 2 family members died from H5N1, which we suspected, but had not been able to confirm when the previous post was made by ProMED (Avian influenza, human (78): Indonesia (BT) RFI, Egypt (SJ) H5N1 20150329.3263924). 30 Mar 2015: Egypt - Influenza - Avian - Confirmed Influenza - Shrkia, human\n\n--\n AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (79): EGYPT FAO UPDATE, INDONESIA (BANTEN) H5N1\n**********************************************************************\n 30 Mar 2015: Egypt - Influenza - Avian - Confirmed Influenza - Assiut, human\n2. 30 Mar 2015: Egypt - Influenza - Avian - Confirmed Influenza - Port Said, human\n3. 30 Mar 2015: Egypt - Influenza - Avian - Confirmed Influenza - Behera, human\n11. 30 Mar 2015: Egypt - Influenza - Avian - Confirmed Influenza - Menoufia, human\n7. 30 Mar 2015: Egypt - Influenza - Avian - Confirmed Influenza - Fayoum, human\n4. 30 Mar 2015: Egypt - Influenza - Avian - Confirmed Influenza - Shrkia, human\n5. 30 Mar 2015: Egypt - Influenza - Avian - Confirmed Influenza - Shrkia, human\n6. 30 Mar 2015: Egypt - Influenza - Avian - Confirmed Influenza - Dakahlia, human\n8. 30 Mar 2015: Egypt - Influenza - Avian - Confirmed Influenza - Suhag, human\n9. 30 Mar 2015: Egypt - Influenza - Avian - Confirmed Influenza - Shrkia, human\n10. Avian / H5N1 HPAI / FAO Field Officer\n\nSpecies affected\nAnimal type / Animal class / Species / At risk / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nDomestic / Birds / unspecified bird / - / - / 1100 / 4700 / -\n\nLaboratories\nDisease Tested / Species / Test / Result / Result Date / Reference Laboratory\nInfluenza - Avian / unspecified bird / real-time PCR / Positive / 24 Mar 2015 / -\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-MENA\n<promed-mena@promedmail.org>\n\n[In January 2015, the Gaza Ministry of Agriculture banned poultry imports from the West Bank and Israel (http://www.maannews.net/eng/ViewDetails.aspx?ID=755838) in order to reduce the risk of introducing avian influenza. Other control and prevention measures were not reported. The disease continues to spread in the region. The control and prevention measures for this disease should be reviewed carefully. - Mod.SMA\n\nSince early 2015, the Palestinian Authority (PA) notified to the OIE 4 HPAI H5N1 outbreaks in poultry, reportedly starting 20 Jan 2015, the most recent one starting 22 Mar 2015 (see archive no 20150326.3256159). Modified stamping out policy was applied. Starting 18 Jan 2015, Israel reported 8 HPAI H5N1 outbreaks; stamping out policy was applied. The disease was reportedly resolved 11 Feb 2015.\n\nIn case confirmed, this is to become the 1st HPAI H5N1 outbreak ever reported from the Gaza strip. The PA is composed of 2 main administrative divisions, the West Bank and the Gaza strip, separated by Israel's territory. All previous HPAI H5N1 outbreaks in the PA were restricted to the West Bank.\n\nInformation on the laboratory that diagnosed the outbreak and confirmation of the diagnosis by a reference laboratory are to be anticipated. Genotyping is expected as well. To the best of our knowledge, no information on this event, reportedly observed as early as 20 Mar 2015, has become available regionally. In case confirmed, this means a serious threat to southern Israel.\n\nAccording to reliable information, the 2015 outbreaks in Israel and the PA (West Bank) have been caused by a HPAI H5N1 virus strain genotyped as closely related to the strain recently circulating in Egypt. Details of the sequencing will, hopefully, become publicly available soon. - Mod.AS\n\nA map showing the location of Jabalya in the Gaza Strip can be seen at http://w0.fast-meteo.com/locationmaps/Jabalya.8.gif. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/88.]", "summary": "Domestic / Birds / unspecified bird / - / - / 1100 / 4700 / -\n\nLaboratories\nDisease Tested / Species / Test / Result / Result Date / Reference Laboratory\nInfluenza - Avian / unspecified bird / real-time PCR / Positive / 24 Mar 2015 / -\n\n--\n http://empres-i.fao.org/empres-i/2/obd?idOutbreak=201601\n\n\nGeneral info\nDisease Event ID / Reporting date / Observation date\n201601 / 25 Mar 2015 / 20 Mar 2015\n\nLocation\nRegion / Admin 1 (Country) / A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n / Alksasseb / 31.547359, 34.508798\n\nDisease\nStatus / Disease / Serotype / Source\nConfirmed / Influenza - Avian / H5N1 HPAI / FAO Field Officer\n\nSpecies affected\n Communicated by:\nProMED-MENA\n<promed-mena@promedmail.org>\n\n[In January 2015, the Gaza Ministry of Agriculture banned poultry imports from the West Bank and Israel (http://www.maannews.net/eng/ViewDetails.aspx?ID=755838) in order to reduce the risk of introducing avian influenza. Starting 18 Jan 2015, Israel reported 8 HPAI H5N1 outbreaks; stamping out policy was applied. To the best of our knowledge, no information on this event, reportedly observed as early as 20 Mar 2015, has become available regionally. Territories\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 22 Mar 2015\nDate of pre-confirmation of the event: 23 Mar 2015\nReason for notification: reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 16 Feb 2015\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: suspicion, clinical, laboratory (basic), laboratory (advanced)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country.\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nOutbreak 1: Jerusalem, Qatanna, Jerusalem, West Bank\nDate of start of the outbreak: 22 Mar 2015\nOutbreak status: resolved (24 Mar 2015)\nEpidemiological unit: backyard\nAffected animals\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nBirds / 40 / 25 / 15 / 25 / 0\nAffected population: 150 days old layers\n\nOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBirds / 62.5 / 37.5 / 60 / 100\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and / or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: fomites (humans, vehicles, feed, etc.)\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: control of wildlife reservoirs, stamping out, quarantine, movement control inside the country, screening, zoning, disinfection of infected premises / establishment(s), dipping/spraying, vaccination prohibited, no treatment of affected animals.\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nCentral Veterinary Laboratory (local laboratory) / Birds / real-time PCR / 23 Mar 2015 / Positive\nKimron Institute (regional reference laboratory) / Birds / real-time PCR / 23 Mar 2015 / Positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Earlier during 2015, the Palestinian Authority notified to the OIE 3 HPAI H5N1 outbreaks in poultry, reportedly starting 20 Jan 2015, declared resolved 16 Feb 2015.\n\nThe disease control policy applied, which may be defined as partial or modified stamping out policy, is reflected by the following total outbreak's statistics, as reported to the OIE:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nBirds / 26 600 / 26 600 / 16 600 / 1900 / 4000\nAccording to the said statistics, 4100 of the infected birds remained on the premises; see at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/temp/reports/en_fup_0000017232_20150220_190428.pdf.\nThe virus seems to continue its circulation within the said territories.\n\nAdjacent Israel has reported 8 HPAI H5N1 outbreaks in 2015, starting 18 Jan 2015, declared resolved 11 Feb 2015. Stamping-out policy was applied. The total statistics, as reported to the OIE, were:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nBirds / 303 000 / 52 400 / 22 630 / 126 940 / 0\nSpur-winged Lapwing / - / 1 / 0 / 1 / 0\nHopefully, the applied stamping out measure will exclude additional outbreaks. However, in view of the continued circulation of the virus within the Palestinian territories, alertness and vigilance by both parties are prescribed. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/45001.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Epidemiological unit: backyard\nAffected animals\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\n Affected population: 150 days old layers\n\nOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\n Measures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\n Territories\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\n Manifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\n Serotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: suspicion, clinical, laboratory (basic), laboratory (advanced)\n The total statistics, as reported to the OIE, were:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\n HPAI H5N1, OIE\n**********************************************************************\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Earlier during 2015, the Palestinian Authority notified to the OIE 3 HPAI H5N1 outbreaks in poultry, reportedly starting 20 Jan 2015, declared resolved 16 Feb 2015. He thought there may be lower numbers suspected of having bird flu as a result of high temperatures, which facilitate the disappearance of the virus.\n\nThere will be regular meetings held with officials of preventive medicine in various departments to raise awareness of the dangers of dealing directly with the birds, emphasizing the full safety of the citizens. He admonished all citizens to be aware of dealing with any birds suspected of being infected with the virus, stressing the need for immediate reporting in case of any suspicion of infection.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps of Egypt can be seen at http://www.geoatlas.com/medias/maps/countries/egypt/eg3r92t/egypt_pol.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/32945. - Mod.LK]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps of Egypt can be seen at http://www.geoatlas.com/medias/maps/countries/egypt/eg3r92t/egypt_pol.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/32945. AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (76): EGYPT (MENOUFIA), H5N1\n***************************************************\n", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1976-03-24 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Cairo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "EGYPT", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3263924", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (78): Indonesia (BT) RFI, Egypt (SJ) H5N1", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3263924", "date": "2015-03-29 21:34:22", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (78): INDONESIA (BANTEN) REQUEST FOR INFORMATION, EGYPT (SOHAG) H5N1\n*******************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Indonesia (Banten): avian influenza human (H5N1 suspected) request for information\n[2] Egypt (Sohag): avian influenza human H5N1 fatality\n\n******\n[1] Indonesia (Banten): avian influenza human (H5N1 suspected) request for information\nDate: Fri 27 Mar 2015\nSource: Jakarta Globe [edited]\nhttp://thejakartaglobe.beritasatu.com/news/tangerang-fath\n\n\nTesting has found a father and son from Tangerang, Banten [province], died after contracting the bird flu virus. The father and son died on 24 Mar 2015 and on 26 Mar 2015, respectively, after spending the past week hospitalized in Tangerang and East Jakarta with severe fevers and other flu-like symptoms.\n\n'The result from our laboratory showed that the 2 victims tested positive for avian flu,' said Tjandra Yoga Aditama, chief of the Health Ministry's research and development office on Fri 27 Mar 2015. On 8 Mar 2015, the pair, along with other family members, visited the Bogor home of a relative who owns a small poultry farm, state-owned news agency Antara reported. During their stay one of the fowl reportedly died due to unknown reasons.\n\nHowever, it is not yet clear how or from where the pair contracted the virus, or which strain they have been diagnosed with. Cases of avian influenza, or bird flu, are relatively rare in humans, but usually occur following direct or close contact with poultry.\n\nSymptoms can include fever, cough, sore throat, muscle aches to severe respiratory illness, among others. In severe cases it can lead to death. Other members of the family -- a woman and child -- have been tested and found negative for the virus, Tjandra said.\n\n[Byline: Herman Genie]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In mid-June 2014, Indonesia reported 197 cases of human avian influenza infections, making it the country with the highest number of H5N1 cases at that time. Egypt and Viet Nam followed with 175 and 127 cases, respectively. In 2015, Egypt leads the world with the greatest number of H5N1 cases, with no cases reported yet this year (2015) from Indonesia, with the possible exception of these 2 cases. No information is available on the actual strain of avian influenza that led to the death of these 2 individuals, although H5N1 is suspected from the circumstances. Nonetheless, with the number of avian influenza strains circulating in bird populations, other possibilities certainly exist and ProMED welcomes any further information a knowledgeable source may have on the details of the viral strain implicated in these 2 fatal cases.\n\nAvian influenza is an infectious viral disease that routinely affects birds. The 1st H5N1 human infection was documented in China in 1997. Transmission of the virus is from bird to bird, through contact with saliva, mucosal secretions, or feces. However, transmission can also occur from bird to human in situations where individuals have close contact with infected birds. There is no evidence that it can be spread through properly cooked food products.\n\nMaps of Indonesia may be accessed at http://www.geographicguide.com/pictures/maps/indonesia-map.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/22597. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[2] Egypt (Sohag): avian influenza human H5N1 fatality\nDate: Sun 29 Mar 2015\nSource: Egypt Independent, edited translation from Al-Masry Al-Youm [edited]\nhttp://www.egyptindependent.com//news/egypt-bird-flu-death-toll-16-2015\n\n\nA 27-year old woman who raised birds in her home in the Sohag governorate, died of bird flu on Sun 29 Mar 2015.\n\nTahta Fevers Hospital received the victim, who was suffering from bird flu symptoms, before she was transferred to Assiut Fevers Hospital upon the request of her family, according to a medical source at Tahta hospital.\n\nA medical team inspected the woman's house in Tahta and conducted tests on those who were in contact with the woman as a preventive measure.\n\nThe Al-Arabiya news website quoted Local Development Minister Adel Labib on 11 Mar 2015 as saying that the total bird flu death toll in Egypt since the start of the winter season in September 2014 amounted to 33 victims.\n\nThe largest number of victims during that time were in Sharqiya with 10 deaths, followed by Assiut with 7 victims, according to Labib.\n\nThe spread of the H5N1 virus is facilitated by the large number of unlicensed poultry farms outside the scope of supervision by the Agriculture Ministry, in addition to the lack of awareness among people who breed birds in their houses.\n\nThe death rate from bird flu is 37.4 percent in Egypt, compared to 55 percent on the international level, particularly in China.\n\nAccording to the State Information Service, around 2 million people working in the poultry industry and 8 million of their relatives have been affected since the emergence of bird flu in Egypt.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[While the number of deaths (33) in this report is close to the number reported by WHO (17 Mar 2015, and ProMED Avian influenza, human (77): China report week 12, H5N1, Viet Nam, Egypt 20150326.3255017), the number of cases estimated from the reported death rate of 37.4 per cent is significantly lower than that reported by WHO, that is, 116 cases (36 deaths) for the year. FluTrackers lists this case as number 120, closer to the WHO record for H5N1 in Egypt. Using the WHO count, the death rate would actually be lower than 37.4 per cent, rather 32.2 per cent, which is good news. But it is not at all clear where the cause for the discrepancy in tallies lies.\n\nWHO's International Health Regulations (IHR) which went into effect in June 2007, are an international legal instrument that is binding on 196 countries across the globe, including all the Member States of WHO. Their aim is to help the international community prevent and respond to acute public health risks that have the potential to cross borders and threaten people worldwide. The regulations require countries to report certain disease outbreaks and public health events to WHO. Therefore, one might expect a count from Egyptian media closer to that reported by WHO.\n\nMaps of Egypt can be seen at http://www.geoatlas.com/medias/maps/countries/egypt/eg3r92t/egypt_pol.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/22584. - Mod.LK]", "summary": "promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[While the number of deaths (33) in this report is close to the number reported by WHO (17 Mar 2015, and ProMED Avian influenza, human (77): China report week 12, H5N1, Viet Nam, Egypt 20150326.3255017), the number of cases estimated from the reported death rate of 37.4 per cent is significantly lower than that reported by WHO, that is, 116 cases (36 deaths) for the year.
