EGYPT (KAFR EL-SHEIKH) H5N1\n************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this posting:\n[1] China (Yunnan): avian influenza, human, H5N1\n[2] Egypt (Kafr el-Sheikh): avian influenza, human, H5N1\n\n******\n[1] China (Yunnan): avian influenza, human, H5N1\nDate: Mon 23 Mar 2015\nSource: Hong Kong Information Services, press releases [edited]\nhttp://www.info.gov.hk/gia/general/201503/23/P201503230716.htm\n\n\nThe Centre for Health Protection (CHP) of the Department of Health (DH) today [23 Mar 2015] received notification from the National Health and Family Planning Commission (NHFPC) of a human case of avian influenza A(H5N1) affecting a man aged 34 in Yunnan.\n\nAccording to the information provided by NHFPC, the patient lives in Kunming and had been exposed to poultry. He developed a fever on 13 Mar 2015 and attended a local hospital on 15 Mar 2015. He is currently hospitalised for treatment and is in a serious condition. His specimen, which was tested by the relevant authority, was positive for avian influenza A(H5N1).\n\n'Locally, we will remain vigilant and work closely with the World Health Organization and relevant health authorities to monitor the latest developments,' a spokesman for the DH said.\n\nHealth surveillance measures have been implemented at all boundary control points. Thermal imaging systems are in place for body temperature checks on inbound travellers and the DH also conducts temperature checks by handheld devices. Suspected cases will be immediately referred to public hospitals for follow-up. ... -- more\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This is the 3rd H5N1 case reported in China in 2015:\n1. Jiangsu: female, 37, onset 14 Jan 2015, hospitalized 20 Jan 2015\n2. Sichuan: male, 46, onset 18 Feb 2015, hospitalized 21 Feb 2015, died 27 Feb 2015\n3. Yunnan: male, 34, onset 13 Mar 2015, hospitalized 18 Mar 2015\nFluTrackers 2015 Global H5N1 Case List (https://flutrackers.com/forum/forum/china-h5n1-h5n8-h5n6-h5n3-h5n2-h10n8-outbreak-tracking/727743-china-yunnan-province-announces-new-h5n1-bird-flu-case-march-23-2015)\n\nExcerpted and edited from Outbreak News Today (http://outbreaknewstoday.com/china-reports-another-human-case-of-h5n1-avian-influenza-25816/): the most recent data on cumulative H5N1 cases from the WHO dated 3 Mar 2015 puts the count at 784 cases and 429 deaths since 2003. However, with recent cases in China and Egypt, the numbers reported are not up to date.\n\nH5N1 is a type of influenza virus that causes a highly infectious, severe respiratory disease in birds called avian influenza (or 'bird flu'). Human cases of H5N1 avian influenza occur occasionally, but it is difficult to transmit the infection from person to person. When people do become infected, the mortality rate is about 60 per cent.\n\nAlmost all cases of H5N1 infection in people have been associated with close contact with infected live or dead birds, or H5N1-contaminated environments. The virus does not infect humans easily, and spread from person to person appears to be unusual. There is no evidence that the disease can be spread to people through properly prepared and thoroughly cooked food.\n\nThe provinces of China may be viewed at http://www.china-mike.com/china-travel-tips/tourist-maps/china-provinces-map and a HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/351. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[2] Egypt (Kafr el-Sheikh): avian influenza, human, H5N1\nDate: Sun 22 Mar 2015\nSource: FluTrackers [edited with liberty from machine translated report]\nhttps://flutrackers.com/forum/forum/egypt/h5n1-tracking-egypt/727706-egypt-moh-reports-1-new-h5n1-bird-flu-case-and-healing-of-4-cases-march-22-2015\n\n\nThe Ministry of Health confirmed a case of avian H5N1 in a 4-year-old child. In addition, they announced the recovery of 4 confirmed cases of avian influenza: a 32-year-old female from the province of Kafr el-Sheikh, and 3 cases from the same eastern province, including an old man of 50 years, and 2 women, aged 32, bringing the total number of cases of avian influenza H5N1 receiving treatment at hospitals and the Ministry of Health to 5 cases.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps of Egypt can be seen at http://www.geoatlas.com/medias/maps/countries/egypt/eg3r92t/egypt_pol.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/32945.\n\nSee comment above regarding the numbers reported being outdated. [1] China (Yunnan): avian influenza, human, H5N1\n [23 Mar 2015] received notification from the National Health and Family Planning Commission (NHFPC) of a human case of avian influenza A(H5N1) affecting a man aged 34 in Yunnan.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2037-03-24 00:00:00", "2015-02-18 00:00:00", "2015-02-27 00:00:00", "2015-01-14 00:00:00", "2015-02-21 00:00:00", "2003-03-24 00:00:00", "2046-03-24 00:00:00", "2015-03-24 00:00:00", "2032-03-24 00:00:00", "2015-01-20 00:00:00", "1975-03-24 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Jiangsu", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kunming", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "YUNNAN", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "EGYPT", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "CHINA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yunnan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Egypt", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kafr el - Sheikh", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3222415", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (68): WHO case count, H5N1", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3222415", "date": "2015-03-11 15:44:48", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (68): WHO CASE COUNT, H5N1\n*************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 6 Mar 2015\nSource: WHO [edited]\nhttp://www.who.int/influenza/human_animal_interface/H5N1_cumulative_table_archives/en/\n\n\nCumulative number of confirmed human cases of avian influenza A(H5N1) reported to WHO\n--------------------------------------\nTable 1. 2003-2009 cumulative count and 2010-2015 annual count\nTable 2. 2003-2009, year by year\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The latest tally of cases has been posted by WHO in 2 tables, spanning from 2003 to 3 Mar 2015. This is the 1st posting by WHO since 26 Jan 2015. It should be noted that the number of cases (88) and deaths (26) reported in Egypt this year, 2015, are equal to the total number recorded from 2003-2009 (90 and 27, respectively). The total number of cases according to Flutrackers (https://flutrackers.com/forum/forum/china-h7n9-outbreak-tracking/143874-flutrackers-2013-15-human-case-list-of-provincial-ministry-of-health-government-confirmed-influenza-a-h7n9-cases-with-links) is 91, including one additional death in a 35-year-old female from Menoufia.\n\nIndonesia, which reported 162 cases (134 deaths) from 2005-2009, with diminishing numbers of cases and deaths from 2010-2014, reports no human cases in 2015.\n\nSee Avian influenza, human (59): Egypt, H5N1, WHO, warning 20150302.3201004 for concern expressed by WHO over the volatile situation with H5N1 in Egypt. They state: 'Although all influenza viruses evolve over time, preliminary laboratory investigation has not detected major genetic changes in the viruses isolated from patients or animals compared to previously circulating isolates that would help to explain the sudden increase in human cases.'\n\nHealth and agricultural officials in Egypt have extensive experience with this disease. In their view, more widespread circulation of H5N1 in poultry during this time, combined with the large number of households that keep small flocks with poor understanding of the associated health risks, is the most likely explanation for this spurt in new cases.\n\nThis observation, in turn, signals an urgent need for agricultural investigations to identify and reduce the source of this heavy viral contamination. A 2nd motivation is the very real risk that poultry trade, whether legal or illegal, will introduce the virus to new countries. The detection of cases with moderate illness suggests that surveillance on the human side is reasonably good.\n\nA map of Egypt may be found at http://www.mapsofworld.com/egypt/google-map.html.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/55. - Mod.LK]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nIndonesia, which reported 162 cases (134 deaths) from 2005-2009, with diminishing numbers of cases and deaths from 2010-2014, reports no human cases in 2015. Source: WHO [edited]\nhttp://www.who.int/influenza/human_animal_interface/H5N1_cumulative_table_archives/en/\n\n\nCumulative number of confirmed human cases of avian influenza A(H5N1) reported to WHO\n It should be noted that the number of cases (88) and deaths (26) reported in Egypt this year, 2015, are equal to the total number recorded from 2003-2009 (90 and 27, respectively). They state: 'Although all influenza viruses evolve over time, preliminary laboratory investigation has not detected major genetic changes in the viruses isolated from patients or animals compared to previously circulating isolates that would help to explain the sudden increase in human cases.' 28(12) [edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=17375\n\n\nInformation received on [and dated] 18 Mar 2015 from Mr Anup Kumar Thakur, Secretary, Government of India, Department of Animal Husbandry, Dairying & Fisheries, Ministry of Agriculture, New Delhi, India\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 4 Mar 2015\nDate of pre-confirmation of the event: 13 Mar 2015\nReason for notification: reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 18 Jan 2015\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: laboratory (advanced)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks:\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1: Sari Ka Purwa, Shukul Bazaar, Amethi, Uttar Pradesh\nDate of start of the outbreak: 4 Mar 2014\nOutbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: village\nTotal animals affected:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed /Slaughtered\nBirds / 1031 / 187 / 187 /844 / 0 /\nOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]:\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBirds / 18.14 / 18.14 / 100 / 100\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter.\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\nEpidemiological comments: epidemiological investigation is ongoing. An intensive surveillance campaign has been launched in 10 km [6 mi] radius zone.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: stamping out, quarantine, movement control inside the country, screening, disinfection of infected premises/establishment(s), vaccination prohibited, no treatment of affected animals.\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type: National Institute of High Security Animal Diseases, Bhopal (national laboratory)\nSpecies / Test / Test date / Result\nBirds / real-time reverse transcriptase, polymerase chain reaction (RRT-PCR) / 13 Mar 2015 / Positive\nBirds / reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) / 13 Mar 2015 / Positive\n\nThe location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[On top of the new outbreak described above, which was reported to the OIE 2 weeks after its start, India is currently experiencing 2 continuing HPAI H5N1 epizootics: one in Kerala (southern India) which started 20 Nov 2014, so far causing 5 outbreaks (the last one on a turkey farm, 18 Jan 2015); the other one started on 11 Dec 2014 on a duck farm in Chandigar, north India; so far, no spread from this farm has been reported. The current new outbreak is in the state of Uttar Pradesh, south-east of the outbreak in Chandigar (map at the source URL). Details on the production line involved on the holding involved, which reportedly includes 1037 birds, will be appreciated.\n\nAccording to Echo of India dated 11 Mar 2015, avian influenza was suspected in Malda, West Bengal State, from 9-11 Mar 2015, where a large number of chickens died at the state government-owned farm in the area of English Bazaar. Farm sources said at least 500 fowl died in 3 days, sparking a bird-flu scare, and the dead chickens were buried deep underground inside the farm premises. The report indicated that: there were about 5000 chickens in the poultry farm, that blood samples of the dead animals were sent to Kolkata [Calcutta] for laboratory tests, that chickens showing symptoms of weakness were isolated to mitigate risk, and the entire farm area was being thoroughly cleaned. However, other department sources said the symptoms were more indicative of Ranikhet/Newcastle disease and not bird flu. See http://echoofindia.com/malda-maldawitnessing-large-number-poultry-deaths-80172.\n\nOfficial information on the event, particularly a final lab-confirmed diagnosis, is requested. - Mod.AS\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail maps can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/142 and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/322.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/322.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Summary of outbreaks:\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1: Sari Ka Purwa, Shukul Bazaar, Amethi, Uttar Pradesh\n Epidemiological unit: village\nTotal animals affected:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed /Slaughtered\n http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=17375\n\n\nInformation received on [and dated] 18 Mar 2015 from Mr Anup Kumar Thakur, Secretary, Government of India, Department of Animal Husbandry, Dairying & Fisheries, Ministry of Agriculture, New Delhi, India\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\n Measures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type: National Institute of High Security Animal Diseases, Bhopal (national laboratory)\n Outbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]:\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\n Manifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[On top of the new outbreak described above, which was reported to the OIE 2 weeks after its start, India is currently experiencing 2 continuing HPAI H5N1 epizootics: one in Kerala (southern India) which started 20 Nov 2014, so far causing 5 outbreaks (the last one on a turkey farm, 18 Jan 2015); There were no new human cases of avian influenza A(H5N1) reported by the World Health Organization (WHO).* One new human case of avian influenza A(H5N1) involving a 34-year-old man from Yunnan Province (China) was reported by the National Health and Family Planning Commission (NHFPC) on 23 Mar 2015 [but see item [2] below, with a new case of H5N1 reported].\n\n2. From 2010 to 2014, 32 to 62 confirmed human cases of avian influenza A(H5N1) were reported to WHO annually (according to onset date). In 2015 (as of 23 Mar 2015), 89 cases were reported by WHO**, and 2 additional cases were reported by NHFPC.\n\n3. Since the previous issue of the Avian Influenza Report, there were no new human cases of avian influenza A(H7N9). Since March 2015 (as of 23 Mar 2015), there were a total of 638 cases reported.\n\n* Since 21 Nov 2012, WHO only publishes information on human cases with avian influenza A(H5N1) infection in 'Influenza at human-animal interface: Monthly Risk Assessment Summary.' Only cases of human infection with H5N1 involved in events that are unusual or associated with potential increased risks will be reported in Disease Outbreak News.\n\n** According to the latest report published on 3 Mar 2015 (http://who.int/influenza/human_animal_interface/Influenza_Summary_IRA_HA_interface_3_March_2015.pdf)\n\nTable 1. This report highlights global avian influenza activity in humans and birds.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] China (Yunnan): avian influenza H5N1\nDate: Tue 25 Mar 2015\nSource: Hong Kong Centre for Health Protection (CHP) [edited]\nhttp://www.chp.gov.hk/en/content/116/39024.html\n\n\nThe Centre for Health Protection (CHP) of the Department of Health (DH) today (25 Mar 2015) received notification from the National Health and Family Planning Commission (NHFPC) of a human case of avian influenza A(H5N1) affecting a man aged 17 in Yunnan.\n\nAccording to the information provided by NHFPC, the patient lives in Kunming and presented with fever and headache on 13 Mar 2015. He attended a local hospital on 20 Mar 2015. The patient is currently hospitalized for treatment in critical condition. His specimen, which was tested by the relevant authority, was positive for avian influenza A(H5N1).\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This makes the 4th H5N1 case reported by China since the new year, 2015, and the 3rd case in the past 2 weeks. There have been no further reports of H7N9 in China since 11 Mar 2015. See ProMED-mail post Avian influenza, human (69): China H7N9 20150312.3225992 and item [1] above.\n\nThe provinces of China may be seen on the map at http://www.china-mike.com/china-travel-tips/tourist-maps/china-provinces-map and a HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/4643. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[3] Viet Nam: avian influenza H5N1\nDate: Mon 23 Mar 2015\nSource: Global Times, Xinhua News Agency report [edited]\nhttp://www.globaltimes.cn/content/913523.shtml\n\n\nViet Nam has diagnosed the 1st outbreak of avian H1N1 flu in humans in 2015, said Viet Nam's Ministry of Health's General Department of Preventive Medicine (GDPM) in the capital Hanoi on [Mon 23 Mar 2015].\n\nOn 14-21 Mar 2015, a total of 33 victims, who mostly are students at a primary school in Central Highlands Lam Dong province, some 1050 km [about 652 mi] south of Hanoi, were reported with symptoms of fever, coughing, and running nose, stated the GDPM.\n\nSamples of these victims have been tested to give positive results with avian H1N1 flu, which caused an epidemic in Viet Nam in 2009, Viet Nam's state-run television VTV quoted a report by the GDPM as saying on [Mon 23 Mar 2015].\n\nThe 33 above-mentioned cases are temporarily dismissed from school for isolation and medical treatment. The GDPM representative advised local authorities to cooperate with the healthcare sector for early detection of new H1N1 flu cases so that they will be isolated, diagnosed and treated promptly.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Excerpted from WHO Western Pacific Region (http://www.wpro.who.int/vietnam/topics/avian_influenza/factsheeth5n1october2012/en/):\n\nViet Nam has had an active control programme against H5N1 avian influenza since the disease was first detected in 2003. This control programme has been successful, and cases of H5N1 in poultry and people have declined progressively and dramatically; however, many challenges remain.\n\nViet Nam's strong commitment to fight highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) is the major factor behind the success for containment of the disease. Several donors and agencies, including the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO) and World Health Organization (WHO), have been supporting the Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development (MARD) and the Ministry of Health (MOH) since the 1st HPAI outbreak in 2003 and continue to do so.\n\nH5N1 is a disease agent that has spread across many borders, and Viet Nam is no exception. Viet Nam has trade links with neighbouring countries, and formal or informal trade in poultry across the borders is known to introduce new diseases or new strains in a country.\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N1) infections in humans are generally caused by bird-to-human transmission of the virus and are rare and sporadic events, occurring mostly in areas where the virus is circulating endemically in poultry. The majority of human cases of H5N1 infection have been associated with direct or indirect contact with infected live or dead poultry.\n\nMaps of Viet Nam may be accessed at http://www.onlineasiatravel.com/images/vn/vietnam-map.png and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/44940. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[4] Egypt: avian influenza H5N1, WHO\nDate: Tues 24 Mar 2015\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/egypt-h5n1-avian-influenza-tally-is-116-for-2015-to-date-56314/\n\n\nThe World Health Organization (WHO) in a report from 21 Mar 2015 says the number of avian influenza A(H5N1) cases in Egypt stands at 116, including 36 deaths for the period of 1 Jan 2015 to 17 Mar 2015. This accounts for 36 percent of the total H5N1 avian influenza cases reported in Egypt since 2006.\n\nSince it was first reported in March 2006, a total of 318 human cases of avian influenza A(H5N1), including 112 related deaths (case fatality rate = 35.2 per cent) have been reported in Egypt.\n\nSince its introduction in Egypt, avian influenza A(H5N1) virus has been circulating in domestic poultry in the country and has been the source of sporadic human infections. Almost all cases of H5N1 infection in humans have been associated with close contact with infected live or dead birds or H5N1-contaminated environments.\n\nThough the number of cases reported is higher compared to last year [2014], the increase in the number of cases does not change the current risk status of avian influenza A(H5N1) virus that is currently circulating at the animal-human interface in the country.\n\nFrom 8-12 Mar 2015, a joint high level mission was conducted in Egypt comprising representatives of WHO, the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations, World Organisation for Animal Health, US Naval Medical Unit-3, and UNICEF on the current H5N1 situation in Egypt and to understand the current and future risks of transmission of the currently circulating avian influenza viruses. The mission reviewed the effectiveness of the recent and ongoing disease control measures implemented by both the human and animal health sectors, as well as assessed gaps in disease control policies and strategies. Recommendations were presented to the Ministry of Health and Population following conclusion of the mission.\n\nIn addition to Egypt, China has reported 3 human avian influenza A(H5N1) cases so far in 2015 [but see note above reporting an additional case, bringing the total to 4].\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps of Egypt can be seen at http://www.geoatlas.com/medias/maps/countries/egypt/eg3r92t/egypt_pol.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/55. - Mod.LK]", "summary": "Details of the recent confirmed human cases of avian influenza A(H5N1) reported to WHO/NHFPC (December 2014 to March 2015)\n\nAvian Influenza Report is a weekly report produced by the Respiratory Disease Office, Centre for Health Protection of the Department of Health. 11(12): week 12 (15-21 Mar 2015)", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2006-03-24 00:00:00", "2069-03-24 00:00:00", "2009-03-24 00:00:00", "2013-03-24 00:00:00", "2014-03-24 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2012-11-21 00:00:00", "2015-03-24 00:00:00", "2003-03-24 00:00:00", "2014-11-24 00:00:00", "2015-01-01 00:00:00", "1977-03-24 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Hong Kong Centre for Health Protection", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yunnan Province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kunming", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hanoi", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Viet Nam 's", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "VIET NAM", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yunnan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "EGYPT", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Guangdong", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Viet Nam", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Dong province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Egypt", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3236648", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (73): Egypt, H5N1 cases", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3236648", "date": "2015-03-17 22:13:56", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (73): EGYPT, H5N1 CASES\n**********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 16 Mar 2015\nSource: Avian Flu Diary [edited]\nhttp://afludiary.blogspot.com\n\n\nDespite the fact that Egypt is more than 4 months into the worst H5N1 outbreak since the virus emerged in the mid-1990s -- with at last count 115 human cases since 1 Nov 2014 -- we get very little day-to-day information about the crisis.\n\nThe Egyptian Ministry of Health stopped reporting publicly on a regular basis in late January 2015, and the media's coverage has been both sparse and confused.\n\nThe last `official' number we received was from the World Health Organization's 3 Mar 2015 update, which showed 88 cases and 26 deaths for the year [see ProMED mail Avian influenza, human (68): WHO case count, H5N1 20150311.3222415 and Monthly Risk Assessment Summary 03 Mar 2015 http://www.who.int/influenza/human_animal_interface/HAI_Risk_Assessment/en], based on reports provided to them by the Egyptian MOH].\n\nExactly how current Egypt's last notification to the WHO was, and how many cases have been detected since this update, are open questions. Based on media reports, new cases continue to emerge, but details are often absent and the YTD totals remain murky at best.\n\nSharon Sanders [editor FluTracker;\nhttps://flutrackers.com/forum/forum/egypt/h5n1-tracking-egypt/720309-egypt-2015-who-moh-provincial-health-depts-h5n1-confirmed-case-list.],\nwhose conservatively curated 2015 Egypt H5N1 Case List had 94 cases and 26 deaths as of this morning [15 Mar 2015], also has several `probables' in waiting.\n\nToday [16 Mar 2015], however, the FAO published notifications of 17 recent human H5N1 cases from Egypt that appear to be recent enough not to have been included in the last WHO update. Some of these, Sanders believes she's already captured on her list, but others appear to be `new'.\n\nAs these FAO updates lack identifying details, like age and gender, accurately matching them up to the FluTracker's list isn't possible at this time, but it is a pretty good indication that Egypt's bird flu outbreak continues to steamroll along.\n\nSanders estimates that perhaps 9 of these cases will end up added to her list, once the WHO publishes a usable line listing.\n\nAll of which puts Egypt's probable YTD case count approximately 100, and growing, shattering Vietnam's record year (2005) which saw 61 cases and 19 deaths, and Indonesia's 2006 total of 55 cases and 45 deaths.\n\nThe `good news', as far as we can tell from FAO, WHO, and Egyptian statements is that these human infections appear to be caused by direct contact with infected birds.\n\nA couple of small `family clusters' have been mentioned in recent months, but there's been nothing at this point to indicate the virus is transmitting easily, or efficiently, from person-to-person.\n\nBelow is a listing of today's FAO notifications [of confirmed human cases of avian influenza A(H5N1)]:\n\n1. 16 Feb 2015: Egypt - Influenza - Avian in Kafr-el-sheikh\n2. 16 Feb 2015: Egypt - Influenza - Avian in Al Jizah (giza)\n3. 16 Feb 2015: Egypt - Influenza - Avian in Al Daqahliyah (dakahlia)\n4. 16 Feb 2015: Egypt - Influenza - Avian in Ash Sharqiyah (sharkia),\n5. 16 Feb 2015: Egypt - Influenza - Avian in Al Buhayrah (behera),\n6. 16 Feb 2015: Egypt - Influenza - Avian in Al Buhayrah (behera),\n7. 16 Feb 2015: Egypt - Influenza - Avian in Ash Sharqiyah (sharkia),\n8. 16 Feb 2015: Egypt - Influenza - Avian in Al Minya (menia)\n9. 16 Feb 2015: Egypt - Influenza - Avian in Qina\n10. 16 Feb 2015: Egypt - Influenza - Avian in Qina\n11. 16 Feb 2015: Egypt - Influenza - Avian in Al Buhayrah (behera),\n12. 16 Feb 2015: Egypt - Influenza - Avian in Al Minya (menia)\n13. 16 Feb 2015: Egypt - Influenza - Avian in Al Qalyubiyah (kalyoubia)\n14. 16 Feb 2015: Egypt - Influenza - Avian in Al Qahirah (cairo)\n15. 16 Feb 2015: Egypt - Influenza - Avian in Al Jizah (giza)\n16. 16 Feb 2015: Egypt - Influenza - Avian in Al Buhayrah (behera),\n17. 16 Feb 2015: Egypt - Influenza - Avian in Ash Sharqiyah (sharkia),\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Since the report used World Health Organization's 3 Mar 2015 update figures of 88 cases and 26 deaths for the year, I have kept them here, although note comment in ProMED mail Avian influenza, human (71): Egypt, ECDC update, H5N1 20150314.3230812 regarding a possible error in accounting of cases. Flutrackers now has a tally of 103 cases, since 8 of the 17 new cases listed above were already included in their list\n(See https://flutrackers.com/forum/forum/egypt/h5n1-tracking-egypt/720309-egypt-2015-who-moh-provincial-health-depts-h5n1-confirmed-case-list).\n\nA map of Egypt may be found at http://www.mapsofworld.com/egypt/google-map.html.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/55. - Mod.LK]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nThe last `official' number we received was from the World Health Organization's 3 Mar 2015 update, which showed 88 cases and 26 deaths for the year [see ProMED mail Avian influenza, human (68): WHO case count, H5N1 20150311.3222415 and Monthly Risk Assessment Summary 03 Mar 2015 http://www.who.int/influenza/human_animal_interface/HAI_Risk_Assessment/en], based on reports provided to them by the Egyptian MOH]. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Since the report used World Health Organization's 3 Mar 2015 update figures of 88 cases and 26 deaths for the year, I have kept them here, although note comment in ProMED mail Avian influenza, human (71): Egypt, ECDC update, H5N1 20150314.3230812 regarding a possible error in accounting of cases. ,\nwhose conservatively curated 2015 Egypt H5N1 Case List had 94 cases and 26 deaths as of this morning [15 Mar 2015], also has several `probables' in waiting. 16 Feb 2015: Egypt - Influenza - Avian in Ash Sharqiyah (sharkia),\n\n--\n 16 Feb 2015: Egypt - Influenza - Avian in Al Jizah (giza)\n16. AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (73): EGYPT, H5N1 CASES\n**********************************************\n 16 Feb 2015: Egypt - Influenza - Avian in Al Buhayrah (behera),\n17. 16 Feb 2015: Egypt - Influenza - Avian in Al Jizah (giza)\n3. 16 Feb 2015: Egypt - Influenza - Avian in Ash Sharqiyah (sharkia),\n8. 16 Feb 2015: Egypt - Influenza - Avian in Al Buhayrah (behera),\n6. 16 Feb 2015: Egypt - Influenza - Avian in Al Buhayrah (behera),\n7. 16 Feb 2015: Egypt - Influenza - Avian in Al Buhayrah (behera),\n12. 16 Feb 2015: Egypt - Influenza - Avian in Ash Sharqiyah (sharkia),\n5.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2015-03-24 00:00:00", "2015-02-16 00:00:00", "1971-03-24 00:00:00", "2068-03-24 00:00:00", "1973-03-24 00:00:00", "2006-03-24 00:00:00", "2014-03-24 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Ash Sharqiyah", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Al Qalyubiyah", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Egypt", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Vietnam", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "EGYPT", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Qina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kafr - el - sheikh", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Al Minya", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Indonesia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3230812", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (71): Egypt, ECDC update, H5N1", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3230812", "date": "2015-03-14 22:56:48", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (71): EGYPT, ECDC UPDATE, H5N1\n*****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 13 Mar 2015\nSource: European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control\nhttp://ecdc.europa.eu/en/publications/_layouts/forms/Publication_DispForm.aspx?List=4f55ad51-4aed-4d32-b960-af70113dbb90&ID=1277\n\n\nRapid risk assessment: Human infection with avian influenza A(H5N1) virus, Egypt, 1st update\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nA PDF of the document European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control. Human infection with avian influenza A(H5N1) virus, Egypt -- first update. 13 Mar 2015. Stockholm: ECDC; 2015 is available online at the URL above for no cost.\n\nIt summarises the epidemiological, virological and environmental information about human infections with avian influenza A viruses of subtype A(H5N1) in Egypt; and assesses potential changes in the risk to public health in the EU/EEA and to EU/EEA citizens. The report includes: Disease background information (Human and avian surveillance of A(H5N1) in Egypt, Human and avian surveillance of A(H5N1) in Europe), Event background information (Human cases in the world, Human cases in Egypt, Situation of highly pathogenic avian influenza virus A(H5N1) in birds, Situation of highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N1) in birds in Egypt, A(H5N1) virus characteristics and circulating A(H9N2) in Egypt, Virus transmission and risk factors), ECDC threat assessment for the EU, Conclusions. The Abstract and Conclusions are posted below.\n\nAbstract\n--------\nHuman cases and fatalities due to influenza A(H5N1) virus continue to increase in Egypt, with cases from the country now accounting for the highest number of human cases reported worldwide.\n\nContinuous increase of virus circulation in backyard poultry and exposure to infected poultry are most probably contributing to the increase in human cases. Whenever avian influenza viruses circulate in poultry, sporadic infections and small clusters of human cases are possible in people exposed to infected poultry or contaminated environments.\n\nAlthough Egypt has reported an increased number of animal-to-human infections over the past few months, the influenza A(H5) viruses do not appear to transmit easily among people, and no sustained human-to-human transmission has been observed. As such, the risk of these viruses spreading in the community remains low.\n\nIncreased human infectivity of the circulating virus and the protection conferred by the poultry vaccines currently in use should be further investigated.\n\nThe current assessment remains that there is no risk for the general public in the EU. Travellers from the EU should avoid direct contact with poultry or poultry products when travelling to Egypt.\n\nThere is a low but ongoing and continuous risk of the virus being introduced and cases being imported into Europe and therefore both veterinary and public health authorities should maintain preparedness.\n\nConclusions\n-----------\nThe recently reported increase in human cases of A(H5N1) infection during the winter months 2014-2015 may be due to an increase in the circulation of A(H5N1) among backyard poultry and exposure to infected poultry across Egypt. Identification of such sporadic cases or small clusters is not unexpected as avian influenza A(H5N1) viruses are known to be circulating among poultry within the country. Strict implementation of control measures to reduce and eliminate infection in poultry is essential for reducing the risk of zoonotic transmission and human cases. Enhanced human infectivity of the circulating virus and the protection conferred by the poultry vaccines currently in use should be further investigated. Surveillance in poultry as well as in humans needs to be strengthened and, ideally, coordinated. Intervention programmes to reduce virus circulation in the country should be reinforced.\n\nTravellers visiting Egypt should avoid direct contact with poultry and birds or uncooked/untreated poultry products.\n\nTable 1. Distribution of A(H5N1) cases by country and year, February 2003 to 3 Mar 2015\nTable 2. A(H5N1) number of cases and deaths in Egypt, 2006-2015 (as of 3 Mar 2015)\n\nFigure 1. Cumulative number of global confirmed human cases of avian influenza A(H5N1) reported to WHO, 2003-2015, as of 3 Mar 2015\nFigure 2. Number of human cases of A(H5N1) observed in Egypt, by year and month, March 2006 to February 2015\nFigure 3. Number of human cases of A(H5N1) observed in Egypt, by year and week, week 46, 2014, to week 8, 2015\n\nMap 1. Geographical distribution of human cases and outbreaks of A(H5N1) in poultry reported in Egypt, 1 January 2015-12 Mar 2015\nMap 2. Geographic distribution of highly pathogenic avian influenza virus A(H5N1) reported in Africa, Asia and Europe in domestic poultry and wild birds with human cases reported in 2015\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The Editor and Senior Moderator of FluTrackers submitted a correction to the WHO report posted in ProMED-mail (Avian influenza, human (68): WHO case count, H5N1 20150311.3222415) and also cited in the ECDC report above (with a reference to the WHO report). He wrote [edited]: 'The line list of H5N1 cases from the 2015 monthly WHO reports enumerates 82 H5N1 cases in 2015. There is a discrepancy in the WHO cumulative table for H5N1 case counts in Egypt in 2014 and 2015. In the table, the 2014 case count is short 6 cases (based on onset dates) while the 2015 count (through 3 March 2015) is over counted by 6 cases. A link to the list of the 82 cases from Egypt in 2015 is included in my [the Editor's] blog post -- http://novel-infectious-diseases.blogspot.com/2015/03/egypt-leads-world-in-number-of-human.html.' In this blog post, he wrote [edited]: 'In late December 2014, Egypt surpassed Indonesia in the number of reported A(H5N1) cases.[1] As of 3 Mar 2015, the World Health Organization (WHO) has confirmed a worldwide cumulative total of 784 human H5N1 cases, about 37 per cent or 292 of these cases have been reported from Egypt (Table 1 [in the blog post]). 82 of those cases from Egypt occurred in the 1st 2 months of 2015 [2]. In addition, media reports suggests that another 4 cases have occurred since late February [2015] in Egypt and may be included in future monthly updates by WHO [3].\n\n'The recent WHO report from 3 Mar 2015 notes, 'The number of laboratory-confirmed human cases of avian influenza A(H5N1) virus infection in Egypt with onsets of illness in the months of December 2014, January and February 2015 are the highest numbers reported by any country in a single month.' To put these statistics in perspective, about 36 per cent of all H5N1 cases reported from Egypt have occurred in the last 3 months. The graph [in the blog post] shows the distribution of WHO confirmed cases by ISO week number in Egypt since December 2014.\n\n'Based on onset dates, since December 2014, there have been 105 H5N1 cases reported from Egypt. According to WHO, at least 28 of these individuals have died. The fatality rate among this group is 27 percent to date, although only 17 of these cases have been reported in media reports to have recovered.\n\n'Besides the 82 cases from Egypt since the beginning of 2015, only 1 other case of H5N1 has been confirmed by WHO in 2015, a 37-year-old woman from Suzhou, Jiangsu Province in the People's Republic of China. With 83 cases so far this year, the H5N1 case count for 2015 already exceeds the annual case count of H5N1 for the preceding 7 years [4]. [However, as posted in ProMED-mail (Avian influenza, human (70): China (SC) H5N1 20150313.3228528), the Centre for Health Protection (CHP) of the Department of Health (DH) on 13 Mar 2015 received notification from the National Health and Family Planning Commission (NHFPC) of a 2nd human case of avian influenza A(H5N1) affecting a man aged 46 in Sichuan, China. - Mod.LK]\n\n'While the spotlight is on human H5N1 infections in Egypt, the single case from Suzhou, China [and the 2nd case in Sichuan] is a reminder that the H5N1 influenza virus is endemic in many parts of the world and that human outbreaks of H5N1 in the size and the scope now occurring in Egypt could quickly develop elsewhere in the world.'\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. A(H5N1) number of cases and deaths in Egypt, 2006-2015 (as of 3 Mar 2015) promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The Editor and Senior Moderator of FluTrackers submitted a correction to the WHO report posted in ProMED-mail (Avian influenza, human (68): WHO case count, H5N1 20150311.3222415) and also cited in the ECDC report above (with a reference to the WHO report). \n\nThere is a low but ongoing and continuous risk of the virus being introduced and cases being imported into Europe and therefore both veterinary and public health authorities should maintain preparedness.\n\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2014-03-24 00:00:00", "2046-03-24 00:00:00", "2021-01-24 00:00:00", "2070-03-24 00:00:00", "2068-03-24 00:00:00", "2015-02-24 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 00:00:00", "2015-03-03 00:00:00", "1971-03-24 00:00:00", "2014-12-24 00:00:00", "2015-03-24 00:00:00", "2003-02-24 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "SC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Menoufiya", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Jiangsu Province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sichuan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Fayoum", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Egpyt", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Egypt", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kafr El - The women are from the governorates of Menufia and Sharqiya the Health Ministry said in a statement reported by MENA.\n\nThe virus has killed over a dozen this year [2015] alone, according to Health Ministry figures.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[According to the FAO/WHO, as of more than 2 weeks ago, there has been a net increase of 108 cases and 39 deaths since 1 Nov 2014. The Flutrackers (https://flutrackers.com/forum/forum/china-h7n9-outbreak-tracking/143874-flutrackers-2013-15-human-case-list-of-provincial-ministry-of-health-government-confirmed-influenza-a-h7n9-cases-with-links) tally of cases is currently 82 (without evidence of these 2 latest cases) since the start of 2015.\n\nIt has been extremely difficult to find accurate numbers of H5N1 cases in Egypt in 2015, even with searches of multiple sites. Mod.LK]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Source: Avian Flu diary via Aswat Asriya [in Arabic, trans. edited]\nhttp://afludiary.blogspot.com/\n\n\nEgypt's ministry of health reported on Sat [7 Mar 2015] the deaths of 2 women infected with the H5N1 bird flu virus, the state news agency MENA reported. \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[According to the FAO/WHO, as of more than 2 weeks ago, there has been a net increase of 108 cases and 39 deaths since 1 Nov 2014.", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2065-03-24 00:00:00", "2015-03-24 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Egypt", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "EGYPT", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3228528", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (70): China (SC) H5N1", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3228528", "date": "2015-03-13 16:46:31", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (70): CHINA (SICHUAN) H5N1\n*************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 13 Mar 2015\nSource: Hong Kong government information [edited]\nhttp://www.chp.gov.hk/en/view_content/38863.html\n\n\nThe Centre for Health Protection (CHP) of the Department of Health (DH) today (13 Mar 2015) received notification from the National Health and Family Planning Commission (NHFPC) of a human case of avian influenza A(H5N1) affecting a man aged 46 in Sichuan.\n\nAccording to the information provided by NHFPC, the patient is a poultry worker who lived in Suining. He developed a cough and chest discomfort on 18 Feb 2015. He attended a local hospital on 21 Feb 2015 and passed away on 27 Feb 2015. His specimen, which was tested by the relevant authority, was positive for avian influenza A(H5N1).\n\n'Locally, we will remain vigilant and work closely with the World Health Organization and relevant health authorities to monitor the latest developments,' a spokesman for the DH said.\n\nHealth surveillance measures have been implemented at all boundary control points. Thermal imaging systems are in place for body temperature checks on inbound travellers and the DH also conducts temperature checks by handheld devices. Suspected cases will be immediately referred to public hospitals for follow-up.\n\nRegarding health education for travellers, the display of posters and broadcasting of health messages in departure and arrival halls, environmental health inspection and provision of regular updates to the travel industry and other stakeholders are ongoing.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[From 2003 through 3 Mar 2015, 784 laboratory-confirmed human cases of avian influenza A(H5N1) virus infection have been officially reported to WHO from 16 countries. Of these cases, 429 have died.\n\nSince the last WHO Influenza update on 26 Jan 2015, 66 new laboratory-confirmed human cases of avian influenza A(H5N1) virus infection, including 13 fatal cases, were reported to WHO from Egypt (65) and China (1).\n\nOf the 65 human cases of influenza A(H5N1) virus infection reported from Egypt, 29 had onset of disease in January [2015] and the rest had onset of disease in February [2015]. The cases were reported from 18 different governorates of Egypt (see table 1 in URL below). The age range of the 65 cases is from 1 to 75 years, with a median of 26 years, and 23 per cent of the cases are under 10 years of age. All cases had exposure to poultry or poultry markets, were hospitalized and all but one reportedly received treatment with antiviral medication. Of the newly reported cases, there was 1 cluster which included 2 confirmed cases in a mother and daughter from Fayoum governorate. The mother had an onset of illness 2 days prior to the daughter's onset of illness and both had exposure to backyard poultry.\n\nCurrently, there are reports of an increased number of outbreaks and detections of influenza A(H5N1) viruses in poultry in Egypt compared to previous months and compared to this month in previous years.\n\nThe number of laboratory-confirmed human cases of avian influenza A(H5N1) virus infection in Egypt with onsets of illness in the months of December 2014, January and February 2015 are the highest numbers reported by any country in a single month. Although all influenza viruses evolve over time, preliminary laboratory investigation has not detected major genetic changes in the viruses isolated from the patients or animals compared to previously circulating isolates, but further in-depth analysis is ongoing. A new candidate vaccine virus was proposed to better protect against the current circulating H5 clade 2.2.1. viruses (a group which all the recent influenza A( H5N1) virus isolates from Egypt belong to; see http://www.who.int/influenza/vaccines/virus/201502_zoonotic_vaccinevirusupdate.pdf?ua=1).\n\nThe increase in the number of human cases is likely attributable to a mixture of factors, including increased circulation of influenza A(H5N1) viruses in poultry, lower public health awareness of risks in middle and upper Egypt and seasonal factors such as closer proximity to poultry because of cold weather and possible longer survival of the viruses in the environment. A high-level joint WHO/FAO/OIE mission to Egypt to assess the risks associated with the influenza A(H5N1) viruses and to recommend control measures is planned for early March 2015.\n\nChina reported a human infection with an avian influenza A(H5N1) virus in a 37-year-old woman from Jiangsu province. She developed symptoms on 14 Jan 2015, was admitted to hospital on 20 Jan [2015]. The patient had a history of exposure to poultry. No further cases among contacts were reported. [This was the 1st report of human infection with A(H5N1) in China in 2015.]\n\nChina reported a human infection with an avian influenza A(H5N6) virus in a 44-year-old man from Yunnan province. He developed symptoms on 27 Jan 2015, was admitted to hospital on 3 Feb [2015], and passed away on 6 Feb [2015]. The patient had a history of exposure to dead wild birds. No further cases among contacts were reported. This is the 3rd human case of influenza A(H5N6) reported from China.\n\nVarious influenza A(H5) subtypes, such as influenza A(H5N1), A(H5N2), A(H5N3), A(H5N6) and A(H5N8), have recently been detected in birds in Europe, North America, and Asia, according to reports received by OIE. Although these influenza A(H5) viruses might have the potential to cause disease in humans, so far no human cases of infection have been reported, with exception of the human infections with influenza A(H5N1) viruses and the 3 human infections with influenza A(H5N6) virus detected in China since 2014.\n\nOverall public health risk assessment for avian influenza A(H5) viruses\n---------------------------\n\nWhenever avian influenza viruses are circulating in poultry, sporadic infections and small clusters of human cases are possible in people exposed to infected poultry or contaminated environments. Although an increased number of animal-to-human infections have been reported by Egypt over the past few months, these influenza A(H5) viruses do not currently appear to transmit easily among people. As such, the risk of community-level spread of these viruses remains to be low.\n\nSee Figure 1 in url below: Epidemiological curve of avian influenza A(H5N1) cases in humans by reporting country and month of onset.\n\nFrom: WHO: Influenza at the human-animal interface, summary and assessment as of 3 Mar 2015 [edited]\nhttp://www.who.int/influenza/human_animal_interface/HAI_Risk_Assessment/en/\n\nDespite being the probable birthplace of H5N1, and having both the world's largest population and the greatest number of poultry -- for reasons that are less than clear -- China remains only 5th on the list of countries with the most reported human H5N1 cases, trailing well behind Egypt, Indonesia, Vietnam and Cambodia.\n\nThis disparity is even greater when you factor in the differences in population, making the incidence of H5N1 in Egypt more than 90 times higher (per capita) than reported in China.\n\nWhy this should be so isn't known, although some of the theories offered include:\n- Differences in H5N1 clades in circulation (China is predominantly 2.3.2 & 2.3.4 while Egypt is 2.2.1)\n- Differences in how poultry are kept and raised between the 2 countries\n- Suspected weaknesses or deficits in surveillance and reporting from within China\n\nWhatever the reason, over the past 5 years China has only reported an average of 2 human H5N1 cases a year.\n\nExcerpted from Avian Flu Diary (http://afludiary.blogspot.com/), Michael Coston [editor]\n\nMaps of China can be seen at http://www.sacu.org/maps/provmap.png and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/11274.\n\nThe provinces of China may be viewed at http://www.china-mike.com/china-travel-tips/tourist-maps/china-provinces-map.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/155. - Mod.LK]", "summary": "\n\nWhy this should be so isn't known, although some of the theories offered include:\n- Differences in H5N1 clades in circulation (China is predominantly 2.3.2 & 2.3.4 while Egypt is 2.2.1)\n- Differences in how poultry are kept and raised between the 2 countries\n- Suspected weaknesses or deficits in surveillance and reporting from within China\n\nWhatever the reason, over the past 5 years China has only reported an average of 2 human H5N1 cases a year. From: WHO: Influenza at the human-animal interface, summary and assessment as of 3 Mar 2015 [edited]\nhttp://www.who.int/influenza/human_animal_interface/HAI_Risk_Assessment/en/\n\nDespite being the probable birthplace of H5N1, and having both the world's largest population and the greatest number of poultry -- for reasons that are less than clear -- China remains only 5th on the list of countries with the most reported human H5N1 cases, trailing well behind Egypt, Indonesia, Vietnam and Cambodia. Since the last WHO Influenza update on 26 Jan 2015, 66 new laboratory-confirmed human cases of avian influenza A(H5N1) virus infection, including 13 fatal cases, were reported to WHO from Egypt (65) and China (1). \n\nOf the 65 human cases of influenza A(H5N1) virus infection reported from Egypt, 29 had onset of disease in January [2015] and the rest had onset of disease in February [2015]. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[From 2003 through 3 Mar 2015, 784 laboratory-confirmed human cases of avian influenza A(H5N1) virus infection have been officially reported to WHO from 16 countries. \n\nWhenever avian influenza viruses are circulating in poultry, sporadic infections and small clusters of human cases are possible in people exposed to infected poultry or contaminated environments. The number of laboratory-confirmed human cases of avian influenza A(H5N1) virus infection in Egypt with onsets of illness in the months of December 2014, January and February 2015 are the highest numbers reported by any country in a single month. Although these influenza A(H5) viruses might have the potential to cause disease in humans, so far no human cases of infection have been reported, with exception of the human infections with influenza A(H5N1) Source: Hong Kong government information [edited]\nhttp://www.chp.gov.hk/en/view_content/38863.html\n\n\nThe Centre for Health Protection (CHP) of the Department of Health (DH) today (13 Mar 2015) received notification from the National Health and Family Planning Commission (NHFPC) of a human case of avian influenza A(H5N1) affecting a man aged 46 in Sichuan. \n\nChina reported a human infection with an avian influenza A(H5N6) virus in a 44-year-old man from Yunnan province. \n\nChina reported a human infection with an avian influenza A(H5N1) virus in a 37-year-old woman from Jiangsu province. \n\nThe increase in the number of human cases is likely attributable to a mixture of factors, including increased circulation of influenza A(H5N1) A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nOverall public health risk assessment for avian influenza A(H5) viruses\n--------------------------- \n\nSee Figure 1 in url below: Epidemiological curve of avian influenza A(H5N1) cases in humans by reporting country and month of onset. Although an increased number of animal-to-human infections have been reported by Egypt over the past few months, these influenza A(H5) viruses do not currently appear to transmit easily among people. \n\nVarious influenza A(H5) subtypes, such as influenza A(H5N1), A(H5N2), A(H5N3), A(H5N6) and A(H5N8), have recently been detected in birds in Europe, North America, and Asia, according to reports received by OIE. HUMAN (67): EGYPT (MENUFIA, SHARQIYA, CAIRO) H5N1\n******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of ProMed Avian influenza, human (65): Egypt (MF,SQ) H5N1 20150308.3216173.], 2 women from Egypt's Delta governorates of Menoufia and Sharqia have died of H5N1 avian flu, marking the 12th and 13th deaths in the country from the disease in 2015.\n\n'3 cases, including a 2-year-old child from Cairo along with 2 men in their 40s from the delta area have also tested positive for the virus and have been hospitalized,' according to the statement.\n\nSo far, 38 bird flu cases have been diagnosed in 2015, including 10 cases who have recovered, 15 undergoing treatment and 13 deaths, Youm7 reported Sat [7 Mar 2015]. Most avian flu cases in Egypt have been detected in impoverished rural areas, where villagers traditionally raise poultry on the rooftops of their homes to supplement their diet.\n\nThe Health Ministry announced Thurs [5 Mar 2015] an 'exceptional plan to combat the virus.' It has repeatedly urged citizens who deal with poultry and livestock to be cautious and take preventive measures to avoid infection. It also called on those who suffer from symptoms of the flu to head to the nearest hospital within 24 hours to increase the chances of their recovery.\n\nThe disease 1st appeared in Egypt in 2006. The death toll of bird flu in the country reached 10 in 2014.\n\nFrom 2003 until October 2014, there were 686 cases testing positive for H5N1 globally, of which 393 were fatal, according to a World Health Organization (WHO) report published in October [2014].\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This report provides additional detail on H5N1 cases in Egypt beyond what was recently reported by ProMED Avian influenza, human (65): Egypt (MF,SQ) H5N1 20150308.3216173, which should be read for further discussion of the problem assessing total number of cases (deaths) from H5N1 during 2015. Mod", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "SQ", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3211783", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (48): Viet Nam (ST) HPAI H5N1, poultry, spread", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3211783", "date": "2015-03-06 14:16:31", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (48): VIET NAM (SOC TRANG) HPAI H5N1, POULTRY, SPREAD\n*********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 5 Mar 2015\nSource: Saigon Giai Phong (SGGP) [edited]\nhttp://www.saigon-gpdaily.com.vn/Health/2015/3/112890/\n\n\nAvian flu outbreak reported in Mekong Delta province\n----------------------------------------------------\nThe [Viet Nam] Department of Preventive Medicine, a part of the Ministry of Health, yesterday [4 Mar 2015] announced an outbreak of A/H5N1 avian flu in a farm at Dai Hai commune, in Ke Sach District of the Mekong delta province of Soc Trang.\n\nThe provincial Department of Animal Health liaised with the local government to bury 1100, 2-month-old chickens infected with the dangerous avian flu virus in the farm and implement measures against the disease as per the regulation.\n\nThe Department of Preventive Medicine said that A/H5N1 avian flu is the virus causing avian flu amongst chickens in Asia since 2003 and is plaguing other nations. From 2003 to January 2015, around 777 cases of bird flu were reported in 16 nations and 428 people succumbed to the disease (or accounting for 55.1 per cent).\n\nAccordingly, the Department of Preventive Medicine warned people not to eat diseased dead poultry; farms must be disinfected and people have to wear protective clothes when contacting with poultry to reduce the risk of transmission.\n\nWhen a person experiences symptoms of chest pain and breathing problem, he/she has to go to a nearby medical clinic for examination and treatment.\n\n[byline: Tuong Lam, trans. Uyen Phuong]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org\n\n[HPAI H5N1 started its circulation in Viet Nam in 2003. Its epidemiology there is characterised by a seasonal pattern, as reflected in the list of ProMED-mail postings on Viet Nam's HPAI H5N1 in humans and poultry, peaking each winter (see the list in 'see also' below).\n\nThe current seasonal epizootic in Viet Nam reportedly started on 29 Nov 2014; so far, 6 reports have been submitted to the OIE, addressing 6 outbreaks; the most recent report was submitted on 25 Feb 2015. All the 6 reports and an interactive map are available at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?fupser=&dothis=&reportid=16728.\n\nDuring the previous season (October 2013-March 2014) the outbreaks were attributed to virus clade 2.3.2.1. Strain 2.3.2.1C is regarded as particularly pathogenic. This epizootic involved a total of 39 outbreaks and was declared resolved on 11 Apr 2014. Genotyping of the current virus strain will be of interest.\n\nIn April 2014, a 'new strain', namely HPAI H5N6, was identified in Viet Nam for the 1st time. It caused 7 outbreaks and the event was declared resolved on 6 Oct 2014; all reports on this strain and a relevant interactive map are available at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?fupser=&dothis=&reportid=15802.\n\nSince 2003, 127 human cases of avian influenza have been reported from Viet Nam, including 64 deaths. The disease peaked in the 2 years 2004/2005 (90 cases, 39 deaths). Since then, control and prevention efforts by the animal health authorities were intensified, including vaccinations of poultry.\n\nDuring (early) 2014, 2 human HPAI H5N1 cases were reported from Viet Nam; unfortunately, both fatal. - Mod.AS\n\nMaps of Viet Nam can be seen at http://www.onlineasiatravel.com/images/vn/vietnam-map.png and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/44590. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Uyen Phuong]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\nThe current seasonal epizootic in Viet Nam reportedly started on 29 Nov 2014; so far, 6 reports have been submitted to the OIE, addressing 6 outbreaks; the most recent report was submitted on 25 Feb 2015. \n\nAccordingly, the Department of Preventive Medicine warned people not to eat diseased dead poultry; farms must be disinfected and people have to wear protective clothes when contacting with poultry to reduce the risk of transmission. Epidemiological linkage between the farms.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: stamping out; quarantine; movement control inside the country; zoning; disinfection of infected premises/establishment(s); dipping/spraying; vaccination prohibited; no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type/ Species / Test / Test date / Result\nMandalay Diagnostic Laboratory (national laboratory) / Birds / real-time PCR / 21 Feb 2015 / Positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreaks can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[According to a 27 Feb 2015 report in the media: 'Myanmar authorities have raised the alert levels, to prevent the rapid spread of the virus in the country. Thousands of birds have been culled in an attempt to contain the epidemic, particularly in Monywa, a town west of Mandalay, in the north western region of Sagaing. Since the beginning of the month [February 2015], when the 1st signs of bird flu appeared on a poultry farm in the area, more than 1400 chickens and about 10 000 quail have died from the H5N1 virus. As a precautionary measure, the authorities ordered the culling of another 1500 samples of poultry and over 20 000 quail. In the area there are more than 300 companies engaged in the production of poultry and 100 in quail, for a total of 140 000 chickens and more than 500 thousand quails.' (http://www.asianews.it/news-en/WHO-sounds-alarm-over-spread-of-Bird-flu-after-massive-cull-in-Myanmar-33576.html).\n\nThere is a discrepancy between the number of affected birds reported by the media and those reported officially to OIE. According to the official information submitted for this H5N1 event, only 350 birds were reported dead (including both chickens and quail), whereas the media reports '1400 chickens and about 10 000 quail' dead. There is also a discrepancy in the number of birds slaughtered or destroyed between the 2 reports. It would be useful to know the correct numbers of birds dead, affected, and slaughtered or destroyed, and whether these are associated with these 3 officially reported outbreaks or are associated with other additional outbreaks which have not yet been reported.\n\nSee also ProMED-mail posting 20150226.3194235. - The woman's death has raised the number of victims in Egypt [so far in 2015] to 15.\n\nThe ministry added in a statement that the number of bird flu cases receiving treatment at Health Ministry-affiliated hospitals is 11 to date. Other recent deaths include a young man who died on Wed 25 Feb [2015] and 2 other victims who passed away earlier in February. All were from Fayoum. The death rate from bird flu is at 37.4 per cent in Egypt, compared to 55 per cent on the international level, particularly in China.\n\nAccording to the State Information Service, approximately 2 million people involved in the poultry industry and 8 million of their relatives have been affected since the emergence of bird flu in Egypt.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail and Healthmap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Flutrackers lists this death as the 21st out of 78 cases of H5N1 in Egypt since 1 Jan 2015. (https://flutrackers.com/forum/forum/egypt/h5n1-tracking-egypt/720309-egypt-2015-who-moh-provincial-health-depts-h5n1-confirmed-case-list)\n\nA map of Egypt may be found at http://www.mapsofworld.com/egypt/google-map.html.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/55 - Mod.LK]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail and Healthmap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n \n\n\nThe Health Ministry announced on Tues [02 Mar 2015] the death of a 33 year old woman in Cairo of bird flu, the infection of a 16 year old girl in Sharqiya, and the cure of a 2 year old child in Beheira. AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (61): EGYPT (CAIRO, SHARQIYA, BEHEIRA) H5N1\n******************************************************************\n According to the State Information Service, approximately 2 million people involved in the poultry industry and 8 million of their relatives have been affected since the emergence of bird flu in Egypt.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2015-01-01 00:00:00", "2061-03-24 00:00:00", "2021-02-24 00:00:00", "2015-03-24 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Beheira", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Fayoum", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "http://healthmap.org/promed/p/55 - Mod", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "EGYPT", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Cairo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Egypt", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3201004", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (59): Egypt, H5N1, WHO, alert", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3201004", "date": "2015-03-02 13:47:58", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (59): EGYPT, H5N1, WHO, ALERT\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Egypt (Cairo): avian influenza H5N1 WHO delegation\n[2] Egypt: WHO warning H5 strains\n\n******\n[1] Egypt (Cairo): avian influenza H5N1 WHO delegation\nDate: Sun 1 Mar 2015\nSource: The Cairo Post [edited]\nhttp://www.thecairopost.com/news/139471/news/who-experts-to-visit-cairo-mid-march-to-curb-h5n1-health-minister\n\n\nAn international delegation from the World Health Organization (WHO) is due in Cairo mid-March [2015] to discuss ways to tackle Egypt's endemic outbreak of H5N1 avian influenza, health minister Adel Adawy announced [Sun 1 Mar 2015].\n\nThe international experts, in collaboration with the health ministry, will work on developing a strategy to ensure the eradication of the H5N1 avian influenza virus in Egypt in a short time, Adawy was quoted by Youm7 [Sun 1 Mar 2015]. The delegation will be headed by Dr Keiji Fukuda, assistant director-general of the (WHO) for Health Security Affairs, according to Adawy.\n\nIn 2006, Egypt reported the 1st avian influenza case, and since then new outbreaks have occurred every year, 'making it one of the world's few endemic countries for the virus with a case fatality rate of 36 per cent,' according to a WHO report. Egypt is one of the 6 nations suffering from an outbreak of H5N1 avian influenza alongside Bangladesh, China, India, Indonesia, and Viet Nam, the report added.\n\nOn 14 Feb [2015], a 35 year old man died of H5N1 avian flu in Cairo, marking the 11th death in the country from the disease in 2015, according to the Health Ministry. The death toll reached 10 in 2014.\n\nMost avian flu cases in Egypt have been detected in impoverished rural areas, where villagers traditionally raise poultry on the rooftops of their homes to supplement their diet, Ahmed Abdel Hamed, a former health ministry official previously told Youm7.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The reports of numbers of cases and deaths in 2015 in Egypt are discrepant among various groups reporting, with Egyptian authorities listing the fewest cases. Egypt Independent, as reported by ProMED-mail Avian influenza, human (55): Egypt (FY) H5N1, virus volatility, preparedness 20150226.3195148, noted the 14th death from H5N1 that recently occurred in Fayoum. In this post, the Health Ministry refers to a 14 Feb 2015 death as the 11th. FluTrackers (https://flutrackers.com/forum/forum/egypt/h5n1-tracking-egypt/720309-egypt-2015-who-moh-provincial-health-depts-h5n1-confirmed-case-list) lists 75 cases of H5N1 in Egypt since 1 Jan 2015 with 20 deaths to date. WHO, expressing concern over H5N1 infections in Egypt, noted, 'The sudden increase in the number of H5N1 human infections in Egypt that began in November 2014 and continued during January and February 2015 awakened concern. From the start of November 2014 to 23 Feb 2015, Egypt reported 108 human cases and 35 deaths. The number of cases over this period is larger than yearly totals reported by any country since human H5N1 virus infections re-emerged in late 2003.\n\nAccording to FAO, a total of 76 outbreaks of highly pathogenic H5N1 avian influenza were detected in 20 of Egypt's 27 governorates between 18 Jan 2015 and 7 Feb 2015. Of these outbreaks, the majority -- 66 -- occurred in household poultry. (See WHO http://www.who.int/influenza/publications/warningsignals201502/en/).\n\nRegardless of the exact number of cases, there is serious cause for concern over H5N1. It is a good sign that Egypt is addressing the threat this virus poses, but eradication is a lofty goal, especially in a short time, as health minister Adel Adawy proclaimed as the goal. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[2] Egypt: WHO warning H5 strains\nDate: Sun 1 Mar 2015\nSource: International Business Times [edited]\nhttp://www.ibtimes.co.uk/world-high-risk-flu-pandemics-worse-2009-swine-flu-outbreak-who-1489931\n\n\nWHO warns of pandemics worse than 2009 swine flu outbreak\n---------------------------------------------------------\nThe world is highly vulnerable to a severe flu pandemic and governments should increase surveillance, vigilance and preparedness, WHO has said. 'Nothing about influenza is predictable -- including where the next pandemic might emerge and which virus might be responsible,' the United Nations health agency warned while noting the next pandemic could be worse than the 2009 swine flu outbreak that killed over 284 000.\n\nThis year's [2015] seasonal flu season has been bad in many parts of the world, with Asia, the Americas, and Europe reporting high levels of circulating flu viruses and low levels of protection from vaccines that did not match the relevant strains.\n\nThe health organisation is particularly concerned about avian influenza noting that the diversity and geographical distribution of influenza viruses currently circulating in wild and domestic birds are unprecedented. 'The world needs to be concerned,' it said.\n\nThe highly pathogenic H5N1 avian influenza virus, which has been causing poultry outbreaks in Asia almost continuously since 2003 and is now endemic in several countries, is the influenza virus of greatest concern for human health. Over the past 2 years, H5N1 has been joined by newly detected H5N2, H5N3, H5N6, and H5N8 strains, all of which are currently circulating in different parts of the world.\n\nPraising virological research that had increased capability to detect, understand, and assess new viruses for pandemic risk, and to track their international spread, WHO noted that this has to be stepped up. More antiviral medicines, including peramivir and laninamivir as well as oseltamivir and zanamivir, are now available to treat influenza and reduce the duration and severity of infection. But better vaccines and shorter production times are required. More people would die in the 3 to 4 months currently needed to manufacture vaccines.\n\n[byline: Jayalakshmi K]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps of Egypt can be seen at http://www.geoatlas.com/medias/maps/countries/egypt/eg3r92t/egypt_pol.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/55. - Mod.LK]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\n[byline: Jayalakshmi K]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\nThe highly pathogenic H5N1 avian influenza virus, which has been causing poultry outbreaks in Asia almost continuously since 2003 and is now endemic in several countries, is the influenza virus of greatest concern for human health.
