28(05) [edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=17083\n\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza, Bulgaria\n-------------------------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 28 Jan 2015 from Pr Nikola T Belev, OIE Delegate, OIE Regional Representation for Eastern Europe, Ministry of Agriculture and Food, Sofia, Bulgaria\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 22 Jan 2015\nDate of pre-confirmation of the event: 26 Jan 2015\nReason for notification: reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: June 2010\nManifestation of disease: sub-clinical disease\nCausal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: laboratory (advanced)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country.\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1: Burgas, Burgas\nDate of start of the outbreak: 22 Jan 2015\nOutbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: not applicable\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nDalmatian pelican: _Pelecanus crispus_ (Pelecanidae) / - / 1 / 1 / 0 / 0\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: contact with wild species\nEpidemiological comment: Dalmatian pelican (_Pelecanus crispus_) real-time PCR positive for HPAI subtype H5N1 was found dead on [22 Jan 2015] in Poda Protected Area [located on the southeastern Bulgarian Black Sea Coast]. The samples will be tested for confirmation by inoculation of chicken embryos. The pelican was found dead together with a black-headed gull (_Chroicocephalus ridibundus_) in the framework of the passive surveillance under the national avian influenza surveillance and control program approved by European Commission. The black-headed gull was tested with negative result for avian influenza.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: control of wildlife reservoirs; screening; zoning; vaccination prohibited; no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nNational Reference Laboratory for avian influenza and Newcastle disease (Regional Reference Laboratory) / Dalmatian pelican / real-time (PCR) / 26 Jan 2015 / Positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The spatial spread of the highly pathogenic avian influenza virus H5N1 and its long-term persistence in Asia since 1996 have resulted in avian influenza outbreaks across Eurasia and Africa and enormous economic losses in the poultry sector.\n\nIn Eastern Europe, there have been several wild bird incidents of HPAI H5N1. There are migratory linkages between breeding and moulting areas in northern Kazakhstan and southern Siberia, with nonbreeding areas in the Caspian, Black, and eastern Mediterranean Sea basins. There are frequent movements of wild waterfowl between Kazakhstan and the Caspian Sea, Black Sea and eastern Mediterranean Sea basins during the autumn migration.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/18239. - Mod.PMB]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Manifestation of disease: sub-clinical disease\nCausal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\n immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 22 Jan 2015\n Total outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1: Burgas, Burgas\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Serotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: laboratory (advanced)\n Information received on [and dated] 28 Jan 2015 from Pr Nikola T Belev, OIE Delegate, OIE Regional Representation for Eastern Europe, Ministry of Agriculture and Food, Sofia, Bulgaria\n\nSummary\nReport type: Measures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results / Species / Test / Test date / Result\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The spatial spread of the highly pathogenic avian influenza virus H5N1 and its long-term persistence in Asia since 1996 have resulted in avian influenza outbreaks across Eurasia and Africa and enormous economic losses in the poultry sector. So far, 10 have died from the virus. The rate of infection appears to be higher than it was in 2014, when 27 infections and 11 fatalities were reported.\n\nMeanwhile, in Nigeria, 11 out of the country's 36 states have reported cases of the bird flu. Nigerian Agricultural and Rural Development Minister Akinwumi Adesina said Thursday [29 Jan 2015], 'At the time of my briefing the nation on 21 Jan 2015, 7 states had reported cases of the bird flu. As of yesterday [28 Jan 2015], a total of 11 states have reported positive cases.'\n\nIt's hardly Ebola, but H5N1 is the most highly pathogenic strain of bird flu and has reached throughout Asia, Europe, the Middle East and Africa. It is one strain out of dozens of bird flu types, 5 of which have been shown to be a threat to humans: H5N1, H7N3, H7N7, H7N9 and H9N2.\n\nNigeria recorded in 2007 the 1st human death from the H5N1 strain, which lives in poultry and is transmittable to humans. It predominately strikes rural areas where standards for handling meat and monitoring of livestock are lower.\n\nThe H5N8 strain was detected in a California [USA] turkey farm on 26 Jan 2015, just weeks after China banned US poultry in response to an outbreak of 2 separate virus strains of bird flu in Whatcom County, Washington, the USDA [US Department of Agriculture] said. No fatalities or human infections have been reported in the US or Canada in 2015.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[See ProMED-mail post Avian influenza, human (27): WHO update H5 & H7N9, China (GD) H7N9 20150129.3129613 for a summary with slightly different case numbers for H5N1 activity.\n\nA map of Egypt can be accessed at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Egypt/.\n\nA map of Nigeria can be accessed at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Nigeria/. - Mod.LK]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nThe H5N8 strain was detected in a California [USA] turkey farm on 26 Jan 2015, just weeks after China banned US poultry in response to an outbreak of 2 separate virus strains of bird flu in Whatcom County, Washington, [29 Jan 2015], 'At the time of my briefing the nation on 21 Jan 2015, 7 states had reported cases of the bird flu. POULTRY, HPAI H5N1 SPREAD, REGIONAL COOPERATION\n***************************************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 29 Jan 2015\nSource: The Jerusalem Post [edited]\nhttp://www.jpost.com/Israel-News/New-Tech/Israeli-Palestinian-agriculture-officials-cooperate-to-curb-bird-flu-spread-389434\n\n\nOfficials from the Agriculture Ministry met with their Palestinian counterparts on Wednesday [28 Jan 2015] for an information exchange regarding ongoing avian flu cases, the ministry said, since 'emerging diseases do not recognize borders.'\n\nIsraeli and Palestinian delegates met at the ministry's offices in Beit Dagan [HaMerkaz District, Israel], where they discussed disease eradication and continued modes of cooperation. The delegates included representatives from the Agriculture Ministry and Health Ministry, as well as Palestinian Veterinary Services managers from Ramallah and Gaza.\n\nAlso attending the meeting were representatives of the UN Food and Agriculture Organization [FAO] and of the World Organization for Animal Health [OIE], the ministry said.\n\nAt the same time as the meeting, a new case of 35 000 chickens infected with avian flu was identified at Moshav Beit-Halevi [HaMerkaz District], near Hadera, the Agriculture Ministry said.\n\nMinistry officials ordered the birds' immediate culling and burial.\n\nThis contamination case was the latest of several that have impacted farms in northern-central Israel and in the Palestinian Authority in the past 2 weeks.\n\nOther sites of infection this week included Kibbutz Magal -- a Menashe Regional Council community [Haifa district], just west of the Green Line -- and Binyamina-Givat Ada [Haifa District], according to a report that Dr. Nadav Galon, chief veterinarian at the Agriculture Ministry's Veterinary Services, submitted to the World Organization for Animal Health on Sunday [25 Jan 2015].\n\nAt Magal, 40 000 birds -- 10-week-old turkeys -- were deemed susceptible and 15 000 tested positive for avian flu, the report said.\n\nAbout 5000 died from the disease, while 35 000 were culled, the data said.\n\nThe Binyamina-Givat Ada site, containing 36-week-old broiler chickens, had 17 000 susceptible animals, Galon's report stated. With 3500 of them testing positive, 1700 of the chickens died from the disease, while 15 300 were culled, he wrote.\n\nAt the end of last week, Agriculture Ministry workers completed culling operations at the country's 1st facility to show signs of avian flu this year [2015]: the Aviel turkey-fattening farm in Hadera.\n\nAvian flu, or H5N1, is highly contagious among poultry.\n\nThe virus is zoonotic, meaning it could spread to humans. The 1st documented case in humans occurred in 1997, and it mainly circulates in southeast Asia and northeast Africa.\n\nIn addition to the cases recorded thus far in Israel proper, several West Bank Palestinian farms have encountered the virus in their poultry.\n\nAffected birds were discovered and culled last week at the Siris poultry farm near Jenin [West Bank], and in Beit Amin [West Bank], south of Qalqelia.\n\nLast week, the Civil Administration of Judea and Samaria facilitated the transfer of 100 safety suits for those handling infected birds, and 1000 anti-viral Tamiflu pills for Palestinian farmers at risk of infection.\n\nAt Wednesday's meeting, the delegates discussed further modes of cooperation regarding the prevention, diagnosis and control of the disease -- with the goal of establishing an umbrella group for regional cooperation on containing the virus, the ministry said.\n\n[Byline: Sharon Udasin]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-MENA\n<promed-mena@promedmail.org>\n\n[This effort is to be commended from both sides. Expertise and information exchange is extremely crucial in controlling transboundary and emerging infectious diseases. - Mod.SMA\n\nFollowing the identification of the new outbreak affecting a chicken farm in moshav Beit HaLevi, HaMerkaz (Hebrew for central) district, the Israeli Veterinary Services issued on Thu 29 Jan 2015 a detailed official list of all locations put under animal movement restrictions, underlining the ban upon transportation of poultry into and from them, including exports into the Palestinian territories. The list (in Hebrew) is available at http://www.vetserv.moag.gov.il/NR/rdonlyres/FF75F17A-2AEE-41E1-9E2E-DA2CC6904ED6/0/newcastle_29012015.pdf.\n\nThe new outbreak in moshav Beit HaLevi is the 4th since the start of the epizootic on 14 Jan 2015 and the 1st in Central Israel. For its location, see map at http://tinyurl.com/myndca5. - Mod.AS\n\nA map of the Palestinian Authority is at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/92. - Mod.JW\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/90.]", "summary": "\n\nAt Magal, 40 000 birds -- 10-week-old turkeys -- were deemed susceptible and 15 000 tested positive for avian flu, the report said. H5N1\n********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] China (Jiangsu) avian influenza case fatality H5N1\n[2] Egypt (Giza, Cairo, Sharqiya) avian influenza human H5N1\n\n******\n[1] China (Jiangsu) avian influenza case fatality H5N1\nDate: 28 Jan 2015\nSource: National Health and Family Planning Commission (NHFPC) [edited]\nhttp://www.chp.gov.hk/en/content/116/38106.html\n\n\nThe Centre for Health Protection (CHP) of the Department of Health (DH) today (28 Jan 2015) received notification from the National Health and Family Planning Commission (NHFPC) of a human case of avian influenza A(H5N1) affecting a woman aged 37 in Jiangsu.\n\nAccording to the information provided by NHFPC, the patient lived in Suzhou with poultry exposure history. She developed fever and cough on 14 Jan 2015 and attended a local hospital on 15 Jan 2015. She is currently in critical condition. Her specimen, which was tested by the relevant authority, was positive to avian influenza A(H5N1).\n\n'Locally, we will remain vigilant and work closely with the World Health Organization and relevant health authorities to monitor the latest developments,' a spokesman for the DH said. ... - more\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Egypt (Giza, Cairo, Sharqiya) avian influenza human H5N1\nDate: 28 Jan 2015\nSource: Cairo Post [edited]\nhttp://crofsblogs.typepad.com/h5n1/2015/01/egypt-ninth-h5n1-death-of-the-year.html\n\n\nA 31-year-old woman died of H5N1 avian flu in Giza Tuesday [27 Jan 2015], marking the 9th death in the country from the disease in 2015, the Health Ministry announced in a statement. The statement said that 2 new infections were detected on Tue [28 Jan 2015]; a 34-year-old woman and a 4-year-old, adding that that they are being hospitalized.\n\nSo far, the ministry reported 28 bird flu cases diagnosed this year [2015]. They include 10 cases, which have been treated, 9 undergoing treatment, and 9 deaths.\n\nMost avian flu cases in Egypt have been detected in impoverished rural areas, where villagers are accustomed to raising poultry on the rooftops of their homes to supplement their diet, Ahmed Abdel Hamed, a former health ministry official [said]. The disease 1st appeared in Egypt in 2006. The death toll of bird flu in the country reached 10 in 2014.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[H5N1 is a highly pathogenic avian (bird) flu virus that has caused serious outbreaks in domestic poultry in parts of Asia and the Middle East. Highly pathogenic refers to the virus's ability to produce disease. Although H5N1 does not usually infect humans, nearly 650 human cases of H5N1 have been reported from 15 countries since 2003. About 60 percent of these people died from their illnesses (http://www.flu.gov/about_the_flu/h5n1/). China has only reported 9 H5N1 cases to the World Health Organization over the past 5 years, but Egypt appears to be experiencing a recent upsurge in cases.\n\nA map of Jiangsu can be accessed at http://www.mapsofworld.com/china/provinces/jiangsu/. - Mod.LK\n\n& of Giza Governorate, Egypt at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/8480. - Mod.JW ]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (25): CHINA (JIANGSU), EGYPT H5N1\n********************************************************\n http://crofsblogs.typepad.com/h5n1/2015/01/egypt-ninth-h5n1-death-of-the-year.html\n\n\nA 31-year-old woman died of H5N1 avian flu in Giza Tuesday [27 Jan 2015], marking the 9th death in the country from the disease in 2015, the Health Ministry announced in a statement. An intensive surveillance campaign has been launched in 10 km [6 mi] radius zone.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: stamping out, quarantine, movement control inside the country, screening, vaccination prohibited, no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: disinfection of infected premises/establishment(s), dipping/spraying\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type: National Institute of High Security Animal Diseases, Bhopal (national laboratory)\nSpecies / Test / Test date / Result\nBirds / real-time reverse transcriptase/polymerase chain reaction (RRT-PCR) / 26 Jan 2015 / Positive\nBirds / reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) / 26 Jan 2015 / Positive\nBirds / virus isolation / 27 Jan 2015 / Positive\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The report confirms that the A influenza outbreak on the 'lone turkey farm' in Kerala, reported by the media on 22 Jan 2015 and published in ProMED-mail posting 20150126.3121257 (item 3), has since been serotyped H5N1. The said media report stated that 'another type of bird flu has hit the lone turkey farm' and that 'humans would not be infected by the strain'; both statements are now negated. HPAI H5N1 should be viewed as potentially zoonotic, with the required precautionary measures undertaken to prevent human infection.\n\nThe current outbreak has become the 5th HPAI H5N1 outbreak in poultry in the south Indian state Kerala, since the start of this epizootic on 20 Nov 2014. Israel, H5N1, OIE", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3126983", "date": "2015-01-28 20:01:47", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (26): POULTRY, HPAI, TAIWAN, H5N3, H5N2, ISRAEL H5N1, OIE\n*************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Taiwan, H5N2, H5N3, geese, OIE\n[2] Israel, 2 new H5 outbreaks confirmed to OIE\n\n******\n[1] Taiwan, H5N2, H5N3, geese, OIE\nDate: Wed 28 Jan 2015\nSource: OIE, WAHID weekly disease information 2015; 28(05) [edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapEventSummary&reportid=17042\n\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza, Chinese Taipei\n-----------------------------\nInformation received on 28 Jan 2015 from Dr Ping-Cheng Yang, Vice President, Agriculture Technology Research Institute, Council of Agriculture, Hsinchu City, Chinese Taipei\n\nSummary\nReport type: Follow-up report No. 3\nDate of start of the event: 11 Jan 2015\nDate of pre-confirmation of the event 13 Jan 2015\nReport date: 28 Jan 2015\nDate submitted to OIE: 28 Jan 2015\nReason for notification: Reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 23 Jul 2014\nManifestation of disease: Clinical disease\nCausal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N3 [but see 'affected population']\nNature of diagnosis: Clinical, Laboratory (advanced)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country.\n\nOutbreak 1 (pt19) Wandan Township, Pingtung County\nDate of start of the outbreak: 12 Jan 2015\nOutbreak status: Continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: Farm\nAffected animals\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nBirds / 2400 / 1811 / 1811 / 589 / 0\nAffected population: H5N2 HPAI virus was also detected on this goose farm.\n\nOutbreak 2 (pt48) Wandan Township, Pingtung County\nDate of start of the outbreak: 14 Jan 2015\nOutbreak status: Continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: Farm\nAffected animals\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nBirds / 7500 / 2400 / 2400 / - / -\nAffected population: H5N2 HPAI virus was also detected on this goose farm.\n\nOutbreak 3 (pt96): Wandan Township, Pingtung County\nDate of start of the outbreak: 22 Jan 2015\nOutbreak status: Continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: Farm\nAffected animals\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nBirds / 1300 / 100 / 100 / - / -\nAffected population: Geese\n\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 3\nTotal animals affected\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nBirds / 11 200 / 4311 / 4311 / 589 / 0\nOutbreak statistics (rates apparent, in percentages)\nSpecies / morbidity rate / mortality rate / case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBirds / 38.49 / 38.49 / 100.00**\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction and/or slaughter\n**Not calculated because of missing information\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Unknown or inconclusive\n\nEpidemiological comments: Abnormal mortalities were observed in 3 goose farms in Pingtung County. Samples were sent to the National Laboratory (AHRI) for diagnosis. H5N3 subtype HPAI was confirmed by AHRI on these farms. Among 3 farms, H5N2 subtype HPAI virus was also detected on 2 farms. The farms have been put under movement restrictions. All animals on the infected farms will be culled. The actual numbers of culled animals will be available when stamping out operation is finished and be reported in the next follow-up report. Thorough cleaning and disinfection will be conducted after stamping out operation. Surrounding poultry farms within 3 km radius of infected farms are under intensified surveillance for 3 months.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: Stamping out, Quarantine, Movement control inside the country, Screening, Zoning, Disinfection of infected premises/establishment(s), Vaccination prohibited, No treatment of affected animals\n\nMeasures to be applied: No other measures\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The simultaneous infection on 2 of the geese farms with HPAI H5N2 and H5N3 is noteworthy. The report includes an interactive map showing the locations of the 3 new outbreaks. The total accumulated number of H5N3 outbreaks, as of 28 Jan 2015, is 20.\n\nIn addition to the above follow-up report on the epizootic caused by HPAI H5N3, Taiwan has submitted on 28 Jan 2015 2 other follow-up reports informing the massive spread of other 2 HPAI strains, namely H5N8 and Novel H5N2, as follows:\n\nThe total accumulated number of H5N8 outbreaks is, as of 28 Jan 2015, 180; see, with map, at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?fupser=&dothis=&reportid=16935.\n\nThe total accumulated number of novel H5N2 outbreaks is, as of 28 Jan 2015, 224; see, with map, at\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapEventSummary&reportid=17043.\n\nThe 4th strain recently recorded in Taiwan is the reoccurring HPAI H5N2 strain. One outbreak was reported on 12 Jan 2015 (see, with map, at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapEventSummary&reportid=16923). - Mod.AS]\n\n******\n[2] Israel 2 new H5 outbreaks confirmed to OIE\nDate: Sun, 25 Jan 2015\nSource: OIE, WAHID [summarised, edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=17059\n\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza, Israel: follow-up report No 1, submitted 25 Jan 2015\n---------------------------------------\nEpidemiological commentary:\nThe epidemiological investigation is ongoing. The 1st time H5N1 occurred in Israel was in March 2006 revealing 9 outbreaks. Since then, all the outbreaks that occurred in commercial flocks were also in March (2011, 2012) except one outbreak that took place in January 2010, in the same region of the Aviel's outbreak (distance of 10 km). The disease had been also diagnosed in a kindergarden's minizoo at the end of December 2007, 3 km from the Aviel's outbreak. This area has numerous water ponds with water birds wintering in them. Backyard birds in the village have also been culled. A few days later, 2 additional outbreaks have been diagnosed in the same region as described in the report. The culling of the flocks has been terminated.'\n\n[For the full report and map, please go to the source URL.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The Israel report confirms the information included in posting 20150124.3116798, namely 2 new HPAI H5N1 outbreaks, one affecting 10-week turkeys in Magal (farm owned by the same company as the 1st outbreak in Aviel), and the other in a breeding farm in Benyamina-Givat-Ada, affecting '36-week broiler grand parents which are divided in 2 adjacent pens.' This brings the total number of outbreaks in Israel to 3.\n\nIsrael's ministry of agriculture has issued several updates, the most recent one dated 26 Jan 2015, informing of the absence of new outbreaks on top of the 3 reported ones. All culling and disinfection activities were accomplished, quarantine measures applied within 10-km around the outbreaks.\n\nOn 24 Jan 2015, the Palestinian authority submitted its follow-up report No 1, similarly confirming the media-derived information included in posting 20150124.3116798, notifying a 2nd outbreak of HPAI H5 on a layer hens farm in the Qalqelia district. The 1st outbreak affected turkeys in the Jenin district. The Palestinian follow-up report, with map, is available at\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=17035.\n\nThe H5 causative agent in the Palestinian territory is most likely similar to the H5N1 one in Israel; official confirmation of its serotyping is anticipated. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/90.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n No other measures\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The simultaneous infection on 2 of the geese farms with HPAI H5N2 and H5N3 is noteworthy. \n\n[For the full report and map, please go to the source URL.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Total outbreaks: 3\nTotal animals affected\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\n Date of previous occurrence: 23 Jul 2014\nManifestation of disease: Clinical disease\nCausal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\n Birds / 1300 / 100 / 100 / - / -\nAffected population: Geese\n\nSummary of outbreaks\n 3\nDate of start of the event: 11 Jan 2015\n In addition to the above follow-up report on the epizootic caused by HPAI H5N3, Taiwan has submitted on 28 Jan 2015 2 other follow-up reports informing the massive spread of other 2 HPAI strains, namely H5N8 and Novel H5N2, as follows:\n\nThe total accumulated number of H5N8 outbreaks is, as of 28 Jan 2015, 180; see, with map, at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?fupser=&dothis=&reportid=16935. Israel, spread\n\n******\n[1] West Bank, spread\nDate: Thu 22 Jan 2015\nSource: Ma'an News Agency [edited]\nhttp://www.maannews.net/eng/ViewDetails.aspx?ID=755528\n\n\nThe bird flu virus has been detected in a poultry farm in the Qalqiliya district [West Bank], vets from the PA [Palestinian Authority] Ministry of Agriculture said Wednesday [21 Jan 2015].\n\nDr. Samir al-Fuqaha said the farm holds some 5000 hens, 4000 of which have now been culled.\n\nVillages in a radius of 10 km [about 6 miles] from the farm in [Bayt Amin] have been put under strict supervision, and samples have already been taken to prevent the spread of the disease.\n\nThe Ministry of Agriculture on Monday [19 Jan 2015] culled 5000 turkeys infected with bird flu in the village of Siris in Jenin [West Bank].\n\nThe Israeli Civil Administration has provided equipment and medical supplies to the PA to control the outbreak.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Gaza, prevention\nDate: Fri 23 Jan 2015\nSource: Ma'an News Agency [edited]\nhttp://www.maannews.net/eng/ViewDetails.aspx?ID=755838\n\n\nGaza's Ministry of Agriculture on Thursday [22 Jan 2015] decided to stop importing poultry and other livestock from the West Bank and Israel via the Kerem Shalom crossing following an outbreak of bird flu.\n\nZakariya al-Kafarneh, General Director of the Veterinary Services of the ministry, told Ma'an that the decision was made to protect against the spread of bird flu in the coastal territory.\n\nGaza is nearly entirely self sufficient in poultry, producing enough chickens for 90 percent of local demand, while 10 percent is imported, he added.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3] Israel, spread\nDate: Sat 24 Jan 2015\nSource: Magazin Hamoshavot [in Hebrew, transl Mod.AS, summ., edited]\nhttp://www.magazin.org.il/inner.asp?page=181202\n\n\n17 000 breeding chickens have been destroyed on Fri 23 Jan 2015 in Binyamina [Haifa district] due to suspected avian influenza. Binyamina is situated about 3 km [about 2 miles] from the initial outbreak in Moshav Aviel, where 100 000 turkeys have been culled on Sat-Sun, 17-18 Jan 2015 (see 20150119.3102962).\n\nToday, Sat 24 Jan 2015, a turkey farm near Magal, about 20 km [about 12 miles] south of the mentioned farms, has been found suspected of avian influenza. This farm belongs to the same company operating the 1st outbreak in Aviel.\n\n[Byline: Yoav Etiel]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Confirmation (or otherwise) of the suspected outbreak in the turkey operation at Magal is anticipated soon. Magal is situated close to the old 'green line' separating Israel from the West Bank.\n\nThe spread in the West Bank should not surprise since, as reported by the authorities to the OIE (see 20150121.3108879), 'the farmer slaughtered 4000 birds from the infected flock before the confirmation of the outbreak.' During the 2006 outbreak, the virus spread extensively in the West Bank. case, 7th fatality of 2015\n-------------------------------------------\nThe Ministry of Health [Egypt], Reham Saeed, announced 3 new positive cases of bird flu. In addition, a 5-year-old child from Asyut province [Assiut governorate] has died from H5N1.\n\nThe Ministry said that the total number of cases of bird flu during 2015 to date is 25 (8 cases recovering, 9 cases under treatment, and 8 deaths).\n\n[Byline: Michael Coston]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Notes from Michael Coston's blog [edited]: This current streak of H5N1 cases in Egypt is unusual not only for the high number of cases reported (54 identified since mid-November 2014), but also for the number of pediatric deaths (4) reported since early December 2014.\n\nUnlike the pattern in Asia -- where children are often the most severely affected -- Egypt has enjoyed a much lower mortality rate among children with H5N1, with many youngsters presenting with only mild symptoms. While the reasons aren't well understood, the clade of H5N1 circulating in Egypt (2.2.1) is different from the clades circulating in Indonesia (2.1.3.2) or Cambodia and Vietnam (1.1.2) -- which might account for these epidemiological differences -- as could societal factors, such as seeking medical treatment much earlier in Egypt.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map is available at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/55. - Mod.LK]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Notes from Michael Coston's blog [edited]: This current streak of H5N1 cases in Egypt is unusual not only for the high number of cases reported (54 identified since mid-November 2014), but also for the number of pediatric deaths (4) reported since early December 2014. The Ministry said that the total number of cases of bird flu during 2015 to date is 25 (8 cases recovering, 9 cases under treatment, and 8 deaths). Source: Avian Flu Diary [summ., edited]\nhttp://afludiary.blogspot.com/2015/01/media-egypts-h5n1-count-continues-to.html\n\n\nEgypt: avian influenza cases\n While the reasons aren't well understood, the clade of H5N1 circulating in Egypt (2.2.1) is different from the clades circulating in Indonesia (2.1.3.2) or Cambodia and Vietnam (1.1.2) -- which might account for these epidemiological differences -- as could societal factors, such as seeking medical treatment much earlier in Egypt. AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (19): EGYPT (AL GHARBIYA, ASSIUT) H5N1\n*************************************************************\n", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2015-03-24 00:00:00", "2002-01-01 00:00:00", "2015-01-23 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Vietnam", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Indonesia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Western Province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Cambodia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "EGYPT", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tanta", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Egypt", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3115544", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (20): USA (WA) wild duck, HPAI H5N1", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3115544", "date": "2015-01-24 18:47:47", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (20): USA (WASHINGTON) WILD DUCK, HPAI H5N1\n***********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 23 Jan 2015\nSource: NBC News [edited]\nhttp://www.nbcnews.com/health/health-news/bird-flu-found-u-s-duck-first-time-n291781\n\n\nBird Flu Found in US Duck for 1st Time\n--------------------------------------\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza H5N1 has been found in a green-winged teal [_Anas carolinensis_ or _Anas crecca carolinensis_] in northern Washington state. It is a different strain from that in China, Asia and Egypt.\n\nA green-winged teal shot by a hunter in northern Washington state has tested positive for H5N1 bird flu -- a relative of the virus that's infected nearly 700 people globally and killed 400 of them.\n\nIt's the 1st case of highly pathogenic H5N1 avian influenza ever seen in the US. The good news is that the strain is genetically different from the strain that's circulated in China, across Asia and most recently in Egypt. It doesn't appear to have infected any people or even domestic poultry.\n\nBut it shows that wild migrating birds can carry dangerous viruses to the US, says Hon Ip, an expert on wildlife pathogens at the US Geological Survey in Madison, Wisconsin.\n\nThe US Department of Agriculture will need to keep a close eye out for other birds with H5N1, Ip said.\n\n'USDA and the Department of the Interior are going to have to spend time to understand the implication of this introduction,' Ip told NBC News. 'At the moment, we do not know of a single human case with our H5.'\n\nFlu is a mutation-prone virus and there are hundreds of strains. Even with precise-sounding names such as H5N1, there can be a large degree of genetic variation. Scientists are watching for mutations and other genetic changes that can make a virus strain more likely to infect people and poultry.\n\nThe H5N1 that most people are worried about has killed or forced the destruction of hundreds of millions of chickens around the world. It occasionally infects people, and the fear is it will mutate into a form that makes it pass easily from person to person. That would spark a pandemic that could kill millions.\n\nSince 2006, Ip's lab has been watching for H5N1 and other strains of bird flu in wild migrating birds along the US west coast, as well as in Alaska and Maine. They've found many different types -- most recently a pathogenic strain of H5N8, as well as many non-pathogenic strains that don't appear to make birds sick.\n\nTo make matters more complicated, this strain of H5N1 found in the teal appears to be a mix of H5N1 and the H5N8 found in Washington state and elsewhere in the US as well as in Europe, South Korea, Japan and Taiwan.\n\nThat makes it of concern to poultry farmers but not to people -- yet, Ip says. 'But because the H5 comes from the Asian H5N1, I would say the risk is not zero,' Ip adds.\n\nA wild bird can infect domestic flocks, which is why agriculture officials are on high alert. And infected domestic birds can infect people. Wild birds can infect hunters and other people who come into contact with them.\n\n'Whenever avian influenza viruses are circulating in poultry, sporadic infections or small clusters of human cases are possible in people exposed to infected poultry or contaminated environments, especially in households,' the World Health Organization says. 'Human infections remain rare and these influenza A(H5N1) viruses do not currently appear to transmit easily among people. As such, the risk of community-level spread of these viruses remains low.'\n\n[Byline: Maggie Fox]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Is this really the 1st time a US duck has had highly pathogenic influenza? Or is it the 1st time in 2014-2015 that highly pathogenic H5N1 has been found in a US duck? I am not sure which reflects the truth. Or maybe it is only the 1st time we have identified this strain in a US duck?\n\nRegardless, many have long suspected that migrating birds are capable of transmitting viruses such as this one over long distances and infecting commercial flocks.\n\nIncreased surveillance and biosecurity in commercial poultry operations in the United States needs to be maintained and/or strengthened to prevent an introduction into commercial poultry flocks.\n\nThis outbreak was previously reported in an OIE report, posted on ProMED-mail as posting 20150122.3109001.\n\nWashington state can be located on the map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/248. - Mod.TG]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\n'Whenever avian influenza viruses are circulating in poultry, sporadic infections or small clusters of human cases are possible in people exposed to infected poultry or contaminated environments, especially in households,' the World Health Organization says. ' Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Is this really the 1st time a US duck has had highly pathogenic influenza? \n\nA green-winged teal shot by a hunter in northern Washington state has tested positive for H5N1 bird flu -- a relative of the virus that's infected nearly 700 people globally and killed 400 of them. \n\n[Byline: Maggie Fox]\n\n--\n \n\nIncreased surveillance and biosecurity in commercial poultry operations in the United States needs to be maintained and/or strengthened to prevent an introduction into commercial poultry flocks. They've found many different types -- most recently a pathogenic strain of H5N8, as well as many non-pathogenic strains that don't appear to make birds sick. \n\nTo make matters more complicated, this strain of H5N1 found in the teal appears to be a mix of H5N1 and the H5N8 found in Washington state and elsewhere in the US as well as in Europe, South Korea, Japan and Taiwan. \n\nIt's the 1st case of highly pathogenic H5N1 avian influenza ever seen in the US. Highly pathogenic avian influenza H5N1 has been found in a green-winged teal [_Anas carolinensis_ or _Anas crecca carolinensis_] in northern Washington state. \n\nA wild bird can infect domestic flocks, which is why agriculture officials are on high alert. Scientists are watching for mutations and other genetic changes that can make a virus strain more likely to infect people and poultry. http://www.nbcnews.com/health/health-news/bird-flu-found-u-s-duck-first-time-n291781\n\n\nBird Flu Found in US Duck for 1st Time\n Human infections remain rare and these influenza A(H5N1) viruses do "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3108144", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (16): Egypt (MN,AT) H5N1 fatalities", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3108144", "date": "2015-01-21 16:33:52", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (16): EGYPT (MINYA, ASSIUT) H5N1 FATALITIES\n******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 19 Jan 2015\nSource: Reuters [edited]\nhttp://www.reuters.com/article/2015/01/19/health-birdflu-egypt-idUSL6N0UY3GZ20150119\n\n\nAn Egyptian woman and child died of H5N1 [avian influenza], the health ministry said on [Mon 19 Jan 2015], the 4th and 5th persons to die of the illness in the country this year. [The death of the 47 year old woman was reported in ProMED-mail post Avian influenza, human (14): Egypt, H5N1 susp. 20150119.3103703. This report adds the child's death. - Mod.LK]\n\nThe 6-year-old child died in Minya province on Monday evening [12 Jan 2015], after a 47-year-old woman succumbed to the disease in Assiut province earlier in the day, ministry spokesman Hossam Abdel Ghaffar said. Both Assiut and Minya provinces are rural areas that have seen a number of bird flu cases in the past year. The ministry announced one other case in treatment, bringing the total number of cases in Egypt to 20 this year [2015] so far. This includes 5 deaths as well as 6 recoveries and 9 cases still under treatment, Abdel Ghaffar said.\n\nThe World Health Organization says there has been a jump in the number of H5N1 infections in people in Egypt, but that there does not appear to have been any major genetic change in the flu strain to explain the rise in human cases. At least 10 people died from the disease in Egypt in 2014. The WHO said last week that between 4 Dec 2014 and 6 Jan 2015 there were 18 new laboratory-confirmed human cases of H5N1 infection in Egypt, including 4 deaths, the highest ever monthly number of human cases in the country.\n\nThe WHO says that whenever bird flu viruses are circulating in poultry, there is a risk of sporadic infections or small clusters of human cases.\n\nEgypt's H5N1 cases have largely been in poor rural areas in the south, where villagers tend to raise and slaughter poultry themselves.\n\n[Byline: Shadi Bushra]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Thus far, there have been no credible reports suggesting community spread of the virus, and nearly all appear to have had direct contact with infected poultry.\n\nThe Egyptian Government has announced the creation of a high-level 'Supreme National Committee On Bird Flu', ordered by the Chairman of the Council of Ministers, to be chaired the 1st year by the Minister of Agriculture (http://afludiary.blogspot.ch/2015/01/egypt-government-statements-on-h5n1.html).\n\nMaps of Egypt an be seen at http://www.geoatlas.com/medias/maps/countries/egypt/eg3r92t/egypt_pol.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/55. - Mod.LK]", "summary": "\n\nThe 6-year-old child died in Minya province on Monday evening [12 Jan 2015], after a 47-year-old woman succumbed to the disease in Assiut province earlier in the day, ministry spokesman Hossam Abdel Ghaffar said. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n The WHO said last week that between 4 Dec 2014 and 6 Jan 2015 there were 18 new laboratory-confirmed human cases of H5N1 infection in Egypt, including 4 deaths, the highest ever monthly number of human cases in the country. \n\nThe World Health Organization says there has been a jump in the number of H5N1 infections in people in Egypt, but that there does not appear to have been any major genetic change in the flu strain to explain the rise in human cases. http://www.reuters.com/article/2015/01/19/health-birdflu-egypt-idUSL6N0UY3GZ20150119\n\n\nAn Egyptian woman and child died of H5N1 [avian influenza], the health ministry said on [Mon 19 Jan 2015], the 4th and 5th persons to die of the illness in the country this year. The ministry announced one other case in treatment, bringing the total number of cases in Egypt to 20 this year [2015] so far. He said a 47-year-old woman in Assiut province, a rural area where an avian flu death was reported last week, has also died of the virus.\n\nAccording to Vanguard, Abdel-Ghaffar said that there are 2 other cases currently been treated, bringing the total number of cases in Egypt to 20 this year [2015] so far. 'This includes 4 deaths as well as 6 recoveries and 10 cases still under treatment,' he said.\n\nThe World Health Organisation stated that there has been an increase in the number of avian flu infections in people in Egypt, adding that more than 10 people died from the disease in Egypt in 2014. The organisation said that between 4 Dec 2014 and 6 Jan 2015, there had been 18 new laboratory confirmed human cases in Egypt, including 4 deaths, the highest ever monthly number of human cases in the country.\n\nIt also said that whenever bird flu viruses are circulating in poultry, there are risks of sporadic infections or small clusters of human cases. Egypt's avian flu cases have largely been in poor rural areas in the south, where villagers tend to keep and slaughter poultry products themselves. Meanwhile, all chicken markets in Lagos State and surrounding areas have been placed on red alert after the bird flu outbreak that was reported last week in 2 poultry [farms] in Lagos and Kano states.\n\n[Byline: Oluwatobi Bolashodun]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The particular avian flu strain is not stated but most likely is H5N1, the strain that led to an avian flu death last week and that has been associated with other recently infected patients in Egypt.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map is available at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/43383. - Mod.LK]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n The organisation said that between 4 Dec 2014 and 6 Jan 2015, there had been 18 new laboratory confirmed human cases in Egypt, including 4 deaths, the highest ever monthly number of human cases in the country. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The particular avian flu strain is not stated but most likely is H5N1, the strain that led to an avian flu death last week and that has been associated with other recently infected patients in Egypt. \n\n\nEgypt Health Ministry spokesman Hossam Abdel-Ghaffar said on Mon [19 Jan 2015] in Cairo that the country has recorded another death of bird flu, the 4th in the country this year [2015], Punch reports. \n\nThe World Health Organisation stated that there has been an increase in the number of avian flu infections in people in Egypt, adding that more than 10 people died from the disease in Egypt in 2014. 28(04) [edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=16982\n\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza, Israel\n-----------------------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 18 Jan 2015 from Dr Nadav Galon, Director, Veterinary Services and Animal Health, Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development, Bet Dagan, Israel\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 14 Jan 2015\nDate of pre-confirmation of the event: 17 Jan 2015\nReason for notification: reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 25 March 2012\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: suspicion, clinical, laboratory (basic), laboratory (advanced)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country.\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1: Aviel, Haifa\nDate of start of the outbreak: 14 Jan 2015\nOutbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: farm\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nBirds / 141 000 / 30 000 / 15 000 / 10 000 / 0\nAffected population: this turkey fattening farm contains 13 pens with a total of 55 000 males and 25 000 females aged 16-17 weeks. The mortality has been observed in 5 of the pens, whilst the mortality was very high and hyperacute in 3 of them. On post mortem examination, enteritis and enlarged spleen have been demonstrated. In addition, 350 meters away, there is a poultry farm of 61 000 5-week-old turkeys. No clinical signs have been seen in poultry at this farm. No other commercial flocks are located within the radius of 3 km [2 mi].\n\nOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]:\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBirds / 21.28 / 10.64 / 50 / 17.73\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\nEpidemiological comment: the epidemiological investigation is ongoing. The 1st time H5N1 occurred in Israel was in March 2006 revealing 9 outbreaks. Since then, all the outbreaks that occurred in commercial flocks were also in March (2011, 2012) except one outbreak that took place in January 2010, in the same region of the present outbreak (distance of 8 km/5 mi). The disease had been also diagnosed in a kindergarden minizoo at the end of December 2007, 3 km [2 mi] from the present outbreak. This area has numerous water ponds with water birds wintering in them. The culling of all the flocks is ongoing. Backyard birds in the village will also be culled.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: quarantine; movement control inside the country; zoning, vaccination prohibited; no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: stamping out, screening, disinfection of infected premises/establishment(s)\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type: Kimron Veterinary Institute, Avian Diseases Laboratory (National laboratory)\nSpecies / Test / Test date / Result\nBirds / real-time (PCR) / 17 Jan 2015 / Positive\nBirds / intravenous pathogenicity index (IVPI) test / - / Pending\nBirds / pathogen isolation by egg inoculation/ - / Pending\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\nCommunicated Held in Menoufiya\n---------------------------------------------------------\nA total of 13 cases suspected of being H5N1 bird-flu positive have been quarantined in the Nile Delta city of Menoufiya [governorate], the director of preventive medicine department said on Wednesday [14 Jan 2015].\n\nSamples from the suspected patients will be sent for analysis at the central labs, Department Director, Reda Aish, said.\n\nA 65-year-old woman from Assiut governorate died in hospital earlier on Wednesday [14 Jan 2015; see ProMED-mail post Avian influenza, human (11): Egypt H5N1, China H7N9 (SZ, Mainland) 20150114.3093018 - Mod.LK] after being diagnosed with H5N1, the health ministry announced.\n\nAt least 12 people have contracted the virus this year [2015]; 2 cases have died, 7 remain under treatment, and 3 have recovered, the health ministry said.\n\nInfection is usually centered in rural areas, where citizens, especially women, frequently come in direct contact with live poultry.\n\nThe World Health Organisation warned that there is a risk of human infection when the virus is circulating in poultry, especially to those in infected environments.\n\n--\nCommunicated AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (12): EGYPT (MENOUFIYA) H5N1, SUSPECTED\n**************************************************************\n", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2015-01-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-24 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "EGYPT", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Egypt", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mainland", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3099260", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (12): Israel (HA) turkey, HPAI H5N1, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3099260", "date": "2015-01-17 15:10:06", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (12): ISRAEL (HAIFA) TURKEY, HPAI H5N1, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n********************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 17 Jan 2015\nSource: Ynet [in Hebrew, transl. Mod.AS, edited]\nhttp://www.ynet.co.il/articles/0,7340,L-4615947,00.html\n\n\nAn outbreak of bird flu has been discovered today (17 Jan 2015) on a turkey farm in the village Aviel, near Pardes Hanna [Haifa district]. Ministry of Agriculture's [MOA] officials arrived at the scene and ordered the destruction of 100 000 turkeys. The decision was made after the ministry experts affirmed the disease. The infected holding is located in an isolated area within the village; culling has already become operational. It is being carried out by the dispersion of a special foam which brings about immediate death of the birds which are subsequently buried on spot. The Ministry made known that the undertaken activities are in accordance with the international requirements prevailing in Western countries. Tests are being carried out in poultry farms within 3 km [about 2 mile] radius from the affected coop. It is anticipated that 2 additional (smaller) units within the said radius will have to be culled.\n\nMOA is still unclear how the virus reached the coop; and the matter is under investigation.\n\n[Byline: Raanan Ben-Tzur & Ahiya Rabbed]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The current event is located in Haifa district; map at http://tinyurl.com/q8z5pb9.\n\nAccording to the website 'PoultryMed', the causative agent of this outbreak has been designated H5N1 (http://tinyurl.com/n4d7yg6 [in Hebrew]). Official confirmation will be appreciated.\n\nIsrael is situated on major bird migration routes; see an interactive map at http://www.flywaysmusic.org/the-birds/interactive-map/. Previous Israeli HPAI H5N1 outbreaks were assumed to be contracted from wild birds.\n\nThe application of foam for the mass destruction of the infected flock has been introduced in Israel in view of public disfavor of the application of gas for euthanasia. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/35084.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\nIsrael is situated on major bird migration routes; see an interactive map at http://www.flywaysmusic.org/the-birds/interactive-map/. AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/35084.] \n\n\nAn outbreak of bird flu has been discovered today (17 Jan 2015) on a turkey farm in the village Aviel, near Pardes Hanna \n\nMOA is still unclear how the virus reached the coop; and the matter is under investigation.", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2015-01-17 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "ISRAEL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pardes", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Israel", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "http://tinyurl.com/q8z5pb9", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "TURKEY", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Haifa", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3109001", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (18): USA (WA) wild duck, HPAI H5N1, OIE", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3109001", "date": "2015-01-22 12:32:55", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (18): USA (WASHINGTON) WILD DUCK, HPAI H5N1, OIE\n****************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 20 Jan 2015\nSource: OIE, WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database), weekly disease information 2015; 28(04) [edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=17014\n\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza, USA\n--------------------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 20 Jan 2015 from Dr John Clifford, Deputy Administrator, Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, United States Department of Agriculture, Washington, USA\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 29 Dec 2014\nDate of pre-confirmation of the event: 16 Jan 2015\nReason for notification: reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 2004\nManifestation of disease: sub-clinical disease\nCausal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: laboratory (advanced)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country.\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1: Whatcom County, Washington\nDate of start of the outbreak: 29 Dec 2014\nOutbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: not applicable\nTotal animals affected:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nGreen-winged teal: _Anas carolinensis_ (_Anatidae_) / - / - / - / - / -\nAffected population: wild American green-winged teal duck\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: contact with wild species\nEpidemiological comments: as part of the increased AI surveillance of wild birds (performed by testing hunter harvested birds), another Eurasian H5 clade 2.3.4.4 virus has been identified through whole genome sequencing of the virus isolate. Introduction of the Eurasian (EA) H5N8 virus into the Pacific Flyway sometime during late 2014 has allowed mixing with North American (AM) lineage viruses and generated new combinations with genes from both EA and AM origin (or 'reassortant' viruses) such as the EA/AM H5N2-reassortant detected in Canada and the United States. Such findings are not unexpected as the EA-H5N8 virus continues to circulate. A novel EA/AM H5N1-reassortant clade 2.3.4.4 was isolated from an American green-winged teal in Whatcom County, Washington. This H5N1 subtype is different from strain circulating in Asia. The gene constellation is as follows: Eurasian lineage genes (PB2, H5, NP, MP more than 99 percent identical to A/gyrfalcon/WA/41088/2014 H5N8); North American lineage genes (PB1 [98 percent identical to A/Northern pintail/Washington/40964/2014 H5N2], PA, N1, NS of North American LPAI wild bird lineage. The HA cleavage site is compatible with strains that are highly pathogenic. This novel HPAI EA/AM H5N1-reassortant virus has not been found in commercial poultry anywhere in the United States.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: vaccination prohibited; no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type:\nNational Veterinary Services Laboratories (NVSL) (national laboratory)\nSpecies / Test / Test date / Result\nGreen-winged teal/ gene sequencing / 16 Jan 2015 / Positive\nGreen-winged teal/ real-time reverse transcriptase/polymerase chain reaction (RRT-PCR) / 16 Jan 2015 / Positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[According to the epidemiological comments in the OIE report above, this novel subtype H5N1 is the result of a reassortment between the Eurasian (EA)-type H5N8 virus and North American avian influenza strains. Noteworthy is the information on the complete description of the constellation of gene segments. This novel HPAI EA/AM H5N1-reassortant virus has not been found in commercial poultry anywhere in the United States.\n\nIn poultry, HPAI has only been detected in small backyard flocks in the United States. The findings confirmed by USDA's National Veterinary Services Laboratories include (http://tinyurl.com/l9cg97s):\n- HPAI H5N8 in a backyard poultry flock in Winston, Oregon (19 Dec 2014)\n- HPAI H5N2 in a backyard poultry flock in Benton County, Washington (3 Jan 2015)\n- HPAI H5N2 in a backyard poultry flock in Benton County, Washington (9 Jan 2015)\n- HPAI H5N2 in a backyard poultry flock in Clallam County, Washington (16 Jan 2015)\n- HPAI H5N2 in a backyard poultry flock in Canyon County, Idaho (16 Jan 2015)\n\nCaptive wild bird findings confirmed by USDA's National Veterinary Services Laboratories:\n- HPAI H5N8 in captive gyrfalcons in Whatcom County, Washington (16 Dec 2014)\n- HPAI H5N2 in captive falcons in Canyon County, Idaho (16 Jan 2015)\n\nWild bird findings confirmed by USDA's National Veterinary Services Laboratories are available at http://tinyurl.com/k4rj59z.\n\nIncreased surveillance and biosecurity in commercial poultry operations in the United States needs to be maintained and/or strengthened to prevent an introduction into commercial poultry flocks. - Mod.CRD\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/4648.]", "summary": "The findings confirmed by USDA's National Veterinary Services Laboratories include (http://tinyurl.com/l9cg97s):\n- HPAI H5N8 in a backyard poultry flock in Winston, Oregon (19 Dec 2014)\n- HPAI H5N2 in a backyard poultry flock in Benton County, Washington (3 Jan 2015)\n- HPAI H5N2 in a backyard poultry flock in Benton County, Washington (9 Jan 2015)\n- HPAI H5N2 in a backyard poultry flock in Clallam County, Washington (16 Jan 2015)\n- HPAI H5N2 in a backyard poultry flock in Canyon County, Idaho (16 Jan 2015)\n\nCaptive wild bird findings confirmed by USDA's National Veterinary Services Laboratories:\n- HPAI H5N8 in captive gyrfalcons in Whatcom County, Washington (16 Dec 2014) Total animals affected:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nGreen-winged teal: _Anas carolinensis_ (_Anatidae_) / - "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3084116", "date": "2015-01-10 19:29:32", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (09): EGYPT, H5N1, MUTATIONS, COMMENT\n************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 10 Jan 2015\nFrom: Craig Pringle <epcrp@queenshill.u-net.com> [edited]\n\n\nRe: Avian influenza, human (08): Egypt, H5N1, mutations 20150109.3082553\n------------------------------------------------------------------------\nIt is an interesting observation that: 'Egyptian scientists have found H5N1 viruses in Egyptian poultry that have 2 mutations that are usually associated with adaptation to mammals', suggesting that this is associated with the recent increase in avian H5N1 cases of influenza in the general virus population of Egypt, and that this may have been responsible for the current upsurge of H5N1 avian influenza in Egypt, but which has been absent elsewhere.\n\nHowever, other observations do not support this conclusion. In particular, a recent analysis of viruses from 2 human patients in Egypt showed no major genetic changes.\n\nOf recent human cases in November/December 2014, all or nearly all of the patients had contact with poultry, and no signs of human-to-human transmission of H5N1 have been reported. No doubt these cases indicate that the virus has changed genetically in some way, but not by mutation at sites previously associated with ability to initiate avian-to-human transmission.\n\nMy assessment of this work is that it is too early to draw any definitive conclusions.\n\nIndeed it may require combinations of mutations rather than a mutation at single sites to change the host range of an avian virus.\n\n--\nCraig Pringle\n<epcrp@queenshill.u-net.com>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Dr. Pringle for his comments.\n\nA map of Egypt can be accessed at https://www.google.com/maps/d/viewer?mid=zvP4vccIyHic.kwFmYMSEnOAo. - Mod.LK\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/55.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n It is an interesting observation that: 'Egyptian scientists have found H5N1 viruses in Egyptian poultry that have 2 mutations that are usually associated with adaptation to mammals', suggesting that this is associated with the recent increase in avian H5N1 cases of influenza in the general virus population of Egypt, and that this may have been responsible for the current upsurge of H5N1 avian influenza in Egypt, but which has been absent elsewhere. \n\n--\nCraig Pringle\n<epcrp@queenshill.u-net.com>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Dr. Pringle for his comments. AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (09): EGYPT, H5N1, MUTATIONS, COMMENT\n************************************************************\n Of recent human cases in November/December 2014, all or nearly all of the patients had contact with poultry, and no signs of human-to-human transmission of H5N1 have been reported. [edited]\n\n\nRe: Avian influenza, human (08): Egypt, H5N1, mutations 20150109.3082553\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2015-01-10 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Egypt", "country": "Egypt"}, {"location": "EGYPT", "country": "Egypt"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3082553", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (08): Egypt, H5N1, mutations", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3082553", "date": "2015-01-09 20:01:20", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (08): EGYPT, H5N1, MUTATIONS\n***************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 7 Jan 2015\nSource: CIDRAP (Center for Infectious Disease Research and Policy) News [edited]\nhttp://www.cidrap.umn.edu/news-perspective/2015/01/fao-notes-mutations-h5n1-samples-egypts-poultry\n\n\nFAO notes mammal-adaptive mutations in H5N1 samples from Egypt's poultry\n------------------------------------------------------------------------\nAmid a flurry of human H5N1 influenza cases in Egypt, scientists have found H5N1 viruses in Egyptian poultry that have 2 mutations that are usually associated with adaptation to mammals, a United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) official reported today [7 Jan 2015].\n\nJuan Lubroth, DVM, PhD, the FAO's chief veterinary officer, told CIDRAP News that the mutations were identified through genetic sequencing of 52 recent isolates from poultry. But he also said a recent analysis of viruses from 2 human patients in Egypt showed no major genetic changes.\n\nEgypt has had a surge of human H5N1 cases over about the past 7 weeks, after reporting very few during the preceding 2 years. According to media reports based on health ministry statements, the country had 29 cases with 11 deaths in 2014, most of them in November and December. All or nearly all of the patients had contact with poultry, and no signs of human-to-human transmission have been reported, but the cases have prompted some speculation about whether the virus has changed in some way.\n\nIn addition, Egypt has had a big increase in reported poultry outbreaks of H5N1 recently, according to the FAO. A graph supplied by Lubroth showed about 70 outbreaks in November (2014) and close to 180 outbreaks in December [2014], compared with fewer than 10 in each of those months in 2013.\n\nMutations identified\n--------------------\nIn response to questions from CIDRAP News, Lubroth and 2 FAO colleagues (Filip Claes, PhD, and Gwenaelle Dauphin, DVM, PhD) prepared a statement about recent H5N1 surveillance findings in Egypt. They said 2 Egyptian agencies (the General Organization for Veterinary Services [GOVS] and the National Laboratory for Quality Control in Poultry Production), with FAO support, recently stepped up H5N1 surveillance and launched a study to characterize viruses circulating in Upper and Lower Egypt.\n\nGenetic sequencing of 52 isolates revealed that the hemagglutinin (H5) genes in the virus continue to evolve but that all the isolates belong to clade 2.2.1, the same as seen in previous years. However, the scientists also identified 2 'fixed mutations': a 'combination of [delta]129 and I151T,' and a 'T156A causing a loss of glycosylation at receptor binding site. Both mutations enhance alpha 2-6 receptor binding (which is associated with mammalian [i.e. human - Mod.JW] adaptation),' the statement said. It added that the virus is nonetheless still regarded as an avian one.\n\nHowever, the FAO also reported the emergence in 2014 of a new H5N1 cluster with 3 other mutations -- D54N, R189K, and R474K. It said this cluster also remains within clade 2.2.1, but the significance of the mutations needs to be assessed.\n\nEgypt's veterinary diagnostic laboratory plans to further analyze mutations seen in the recent avian H5N1 isolates, but the mutations' significance for human health needs to be examined in collaboration with Egypt's health ministry and the World Health Organization, Lubroth reported.\n\nHuman isolates unchanged\n------------------------\nHe also noted that US Naval Medical Research Unit 3 (NAMRU-3) in Cairo recently analyzed 2 human H5N1 isolates from Egypt and found 'no major genetic changes' in the virus as of 3 Dec 2014. The lab looked at the hemagglutinin and neuraminidase genes of isolates from cases in Minya (Menia) and Asyut (Assiut) governorates. Since the study was limited to just 2 isolates, more samples need to be shared and analyzed, Lubroth's statement said.\n\nConcerning the recent increase in reported poultry H5N1 outbreaks, Egypt's GOVS has suggested that it may be a result of increased surveillance, mainly through the FAO-founded Community-based Animal Health and Outreach (CAHO) system, the statement said. But it said other sources have voiced the view that the increase in outbreaks in both Upper and Lower Egypt 'is real but due to the expected seasonal factors conducive for increased viral activity.' [Which apparently didn't occur in 2013 -- see above. - Mod.JW]\n\nA recent report from the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC) included a graph that showed that H5N1 activity in Egypt has peaked between January and March most years since the virus surfaced there in 2006. The ECDC report, posted 23 Dec [2014], said there was no evidence of human-to-human transmission of H5N1 in Egypt and no increase in the low risk for visitors to the country.\n\nLubroth's statement cited a need to step up the response to H5N1 in Egypt. He suggested a possible multi-agency mission to the country to engage with government officials and provide technical or strategic help. In addition, he cited a need for high political authorities to renew their commitment to fighting H5N1 and for greater collaboration among public health, veterinary, epidemiology, and laboratory groups.\n\n[Byline: Robert Roos]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map is available at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/55.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nEgypt's veterinary diagnostic laboratory plans to further analyze mutations seen in the recent avian H5N1 isolates, but the mutations' significance for human health needs to be examined in collaboration with Egypt's health ministry and the World Health Organization \n\nConcerning the recent increase in reported poultry H5N1 outbreaks, Egypt's GOVS has suggested that it may be a result of increased surveillance, mainly through the FAO-founded Community-based Animal Health and Outreach (CAHO) system, the statement said. All or nearly all of the patients had contact with poultry, and no signs of human-to-human transmission have been reported, but the cases have prompted some speculation about whether the virus has changed in some way.\n\n Amid a flurry of human H5N1 influenza cases in Egypt, scientists have found H5N1 viruses in Egyptian poultry that have 2 mutations that are usually associated with adaptation to mammals, a United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) official reported today [7 Jan 2015]. \n\nGenetic sequencing of 52 isolates revealed that the hemagglutinin (H5) genes in the virus continue to evolve but that all the isolates belong to clade 2.2.1, the same as seen in previous years. \n\nJuan Lubroth, DVM, PhD, the FAO's chief veterinary officer, told CIDRAP News that the mutations were identified through genetic sequencing of 52 recent isolates from poultry. He also noted that US Naval Medical Research Unit 3 (NAMRU-3) in Cairo recently analyzed 2 human H5N1 isolates from Egypt and found 'no major genetic changes' in the virus as of 3 Dec 2014. But he also said a recent analysis of viruses from 2 human patients in Egypt showed no major genetic changes. Health Ministry spokesman, Hossam Abdel Ghaffar, said it occurred last week in the southern province of Aswan.\n\nA 42-year-old man was also diagnosed with bird flu and quarantined on 26 Dec 2014 in the capital, Cairo. He is the 25th case of bird flu in the country [in 2014], but the 1st infection reported in Cairo.\n\nBird flu 1st appeared in Egypt in 2006.\n\nMainly in Southeast Asia, the H5N1 strain has killed over 400 people since 1st appearing in 2003.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Menoufiya fatality\nDate: Wed 31 Dec 2014\nSource: World Bulletin [edited]\nhttp://www.worldbulletin.net/todays-news/151976/egypt-reports-fresh-bird-flu-fatality\n\n\nEgypt reports fresh bird flu fatality\n----------------------------\nA 30-year-old woman on Wed 31 Dec 2014 succumbed to the H5N1 avian influenza virus -- commonly known as 'bird flu' -- in Egypt's Nile Delta province of Menoufiya, the Health Ministry has said.\n\nAccording to the statement, the latest fatality brings to 11 the number of people to have recently succumbed to the virus, in addition to 16 infections.\n\nAt least 74 Egyptians have died of bird flu since the virus 1st appeared in the country in 2006.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Egypt is available at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/55.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n -----------------------------------------------\nEgyptian health authorities have reported the country's 10th death [in 2014] from bird flu as well as the 1st case of infection with the virus's H5N1 strain in Cairo. Corr.SB, edited]\nhttps://m.facebook.com/story.php?story_fbid=749536575135188&id=179576752131176&__tn__=%2As\n\n\nThe Technical Committee of the National Center for Disease Control that follows up pandemics held an emergency meeting at its Centre on Sun 28 Dec 2014, during which time the study of the current situation was discussed with regard to the current emergency cases of severe pneumonia: 10 cases of acute pneumonia with symptoms of 'cough, fever, phlegm, accompanied by bleeding and with acute respiratory failure.'\n\n5 cases have died. The cases were as follows (from the Tripoli Medical Center):\n\n- 2 cases of pregnant women in their 30s from Moatntan, one of them confirmed [diagnostically] infected with H1N1 influenza virus [by an unexplained procedure].\n- The 3rd case is a young man in his 40s still in intensive care and waiting for lab results.\n- The 4th case is a young man in his 30s who died, and whose lab results confirmed he was infected with influenza type A.\n- The 5th case is a young man in his 30s still receiving treatment in the intensive care unit and waiting for lab results.\n- A 6th case, a Libyan citizenship holder with the same symptoms, was taken from the Tripoli Medical Center to Asabieh Hospital and died at the hospital.\n\nCases in the city of Tobruk (4 cases with the same symptoms as 3 other patients):\n- 2 brothers aged 28 and 40 years, but samples were not taken from them;\n- 2nd case [3rd case?] died in Egypt, and there is no information about this patient; or\n- 4th case, a laboratory technician who is still under care.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Susan Baekeland for provision of this translation.
