{"location": "Egypt", "country": "Egypt"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3057877", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (119): Viet Nam, HPAI H5N1 & H5N6, spread", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3057877", "date": "2014-12-27 17:39:59", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (119): VIET NAM, HPAI H5N1 AND H5N6, SPREAD\n***********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 26 Dec 2014\nSource: Saigon Giai Phong (SGGP) [edited]\nhttp://www.saigon-gpdaily.com.vn/Health/2014/12/112044/\n\n\nDate: Fri 26 Dec 2014\nSource: Saigon Giai Phong (SGGP) [edited]\nhttp://www.saigon-gpdaily.com.vn/Health/2014/12/112044/\n\n\nThe Department of Animal Health declared an epidemic of H5N1 avian influenza in poultry in 3 communes of the Mekong Delta provinces of Vinh Long, and Tra Vinh, and the H5N6 avian flu on flocks of quail in Tinh Ha Commune in the central province of Quang Ngai's Son Tinh District.\n\nDeputy health minister Nguyen Thanh Long yesterday [25 Dec 2014] sent an urgent dispatch to chairpersons of people's committees nationwide asking to step up efforts to prevent bird flu and diseases in upcoming Tet (Lunar New Year) [19 Feb 2015] holidays when weather is conducive to outbreaks of [avian influenza].\n\nAs per the dispatch, the deputy health minister ordered local administrations to implement proper measures preventing winter disease, especially flu A/H5N1 and flu A/H5N6.\n\nLocal governments should coordinate with health sector and animal health department to manage food safety. They should conduct inspection of food safety and hygiene as well as issue harsh penalties on violators. Health workers must work around the clock during the holidays to control the urgent cases and provide timely treatment to patients.\n\nThe Health Ministry also proposed that the departments of agriculture and rural development enhance supervision in a bid to [detect outbreaks of diseases early and stop the spread of avian influenza.] Related agencies should liaise to tighten control of sales and transportation of diseased poultry out of the affected communes.\n\n[byline: Nguyen Quoc, trans. Uyen Phuong]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[HPAI H5N6 caused 7 outbreaks in Viet Nam earlier this year (2014). The event started on 22 Apr 2014 and was declared resolved on 6 Oct 2014. The relevant immediate and follow-up OIE reports, and an interactive map, are available at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapEventSummary&reportid=15802.\n\nThe current HPAI H5N1 event started 29 Nov 2014, so far involving 4 outbreaks; the reports and a map are available at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?fupser=&dothis=&reportid=16728.\n\nHPAI H5N1 has been circulating in Viet Nam, causing several major events, since 2003. During this period, 127 human cases of avian influenza have been reported, including 64 deaths (2 of them in 2014). The disease peaked in the 2 years 2004/2005 (90 cases, 39 deaths). Since then, control and prevention efforts of the animal health authorities were intensified, including vaccinations of poultry. - Mod.AS\n\nMaps of Viet Nam can be seen at http://www.onlineasiatravel.com/images/vn/vietnam-map.png and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/152. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Uyen Phuong]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\nThe Health Ministry also proposed that the departments of agriculture and rural development enhance supervision in a bid to [detect outbreaks of diseases early and stop the spread of avian influenza.] \n\nAs per the dispatch, the deputy health minister ordered local administrations to implement proper measures preventing winter disease, especially flu A/H5N1 and flu A/H5N6. The Department of Animal Health declared an epidemic of H5N1 avian influenza in poultry in 3 communes of the Mekong Delta provinces of Vinh Long, and Tra Vinh, and the H5N6 avian flu on flocks of quail in Tinh AVIAN INFLUENZA (119): VIET NAM, HPAI H5N1 AND H5N6, SPREAD\n***********************************************************\n Dec 2014\nSource: Saigon Giai Phong (SGGP) [edited]\nhttp://www.saigon-gpdaily.com.vn/Health/2014/12/112044/\n\n\n \n\nLocal governments should coordinate with health sector and animal health department to manage food safety. [25 Dec 2014] sent an urgent dispatch to chairpersons of people's committees nationwide asking to step up efforts to prevent bird flu and diseases in upcoming Tet (Lunar New Year) During this period, 127 human cases of avian influenza have been reported, including 64 deaths (2 of them in 2014).", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2003-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-12-25 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00", "2015-02-19 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Viet Nam", "country": "Vietnam"}, {"location": "VIET NAM", "country": "Vietnam"}, {"location": "Saigon", "country": "Vietnam"}, {"location": "Mekong", "country": "Vietnam"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3051376", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (128): India (CH,UP) H5N1, susp", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3051376", "date": "2014-12-23 17:39:00", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (128): INDIA (CHANDIGARH, UTTAR PRADESH) H5N1, SUSPECTED\n*******************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: 22 Dec 22014\nSource: The Daily Mail [edited]\nhttp://www.dailymail.co.uk/indiahome/indianews/article-2882920/Chandigarh-official-hospitalised-suspected-bird-flu-geese-cull.html\n\n\nFollowing the bird flu scare in Chandigarh, one of the workers involved in the culling of 110 domesticated geese in the city's Sukhna Lake has been admitted to a Panchkula hospital with symptoms similar to avian influenza (H5N1).\n\nAn employee of Chandigarh's forest department, the patient has been kept in an isolated ward in the hospital. 'His samples have been sent to PGI Chandigarh. A few symptoms similar to the avian flu have been found,' a doctor from the hospital said, requesting anonymity. The person admitted had complained of chest and throat congestion along with a headache. He had gathered the geese before killing and burning them. The Union government on Thursday [18 Dec 2014] allowed the Chandigarh administration to cull nearly 110 geese. 22 had died earlier, and one had tested positive for avian influenza. The lake will remain restricted to the public for a month to start with.\n\nThe bird flu scare has brought down the sale of poultry products in the region. The danger also looms large over other neighbouring wetlands, which receive migratory birds in large numbers. After a sample of geese from Sukhna lake here tested positive for bird flu, authorities culled 110 geese on 18 Dec 2014 on the island in the middle of the lake. The entire culling operation, which went on till midnight, was carried out as a precautionary measure to prevent any outbreak of bird flu in the city and adjoining areas.\n\n[byline: Manjeet Sehgal]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: 22 Dec 2014\nSource: Press Trust of India Business standard [edited]\nhttp://www.business-standard.com/article/pti-sEtories/bird-flu-samples-to-be-collected-in-chandigarh-5-geese-die-114122200963_1.html\n\n\nThe authorities here today [22 Dec 2014] decided to collect samples of poultry at random from the city, even as samples of 3 persons who were admitted to hospital here with flu-like symptoms have turned out to be negative [for H5N1 avian influenza].\n\nMeanwhile, 5 geese died in a pond at the village Bhambri of Fatehgarh Sahib district under mysterious circumstances, officials said. The Animal Husbandry department collected the samples and sent them to the Regional Disease Diagnostic Laboratory (RDDL), Jalandhar to test the samples for the deadly H5N1 virus. Dr J S Bhatia, deputy director of the Animal Husbandry Department, confirmed that samples have sent to RDDL Jalandhar.\n\nIn Chandigarh, samples were today [22 Dec 2014] collected around the Sukhna lake. 'Today, we collected samples from poultry farms located in the close vicinity of the Sukhna lake. The places from where the samples were lifted included Bhagwanpura and Kishangarh villages. We also held meetings with some village heads to create awareness and explained to them the precautionary measures they need to take,' sub divisional magistrate (central) Prince Dhawan, who is UT's nodal officer dealing with the avian flu, said.\n\n'Soon, we will expand this exercise to the entire city and take samples at random from different poultry farms here,' he said. Dhawan said that meetings were held today [22 Dec 2014] between officials of the Chandigarh administration and Punjab and Haryana governments in view of the bird flu scare.\n\nThe tests of 3 patients, who were admitted to hospitals here with flu-like symptoms, have turned out to be negative, said Lovelesh Kant Gupta, joint director of the Chandigarh Animal Husbandry department.\n\nThe Chandigarh administration has also been conducting a door-to-door survey in the localities close to the lake as a precautionary measure, officials said. The authorities at various zoos and wetlands across Punjab and Haryana have intensified monitoring and surveillance of the birds.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[This same report also appeared in another newswire dated 22 Dec 2014 from Tribune India: http://www.tribuneindia.com/news/nation/bird-flu-alert-in-up-import-of-poultry-products-banned/21183.html.\n\nSo far, there have been no confirmed human cases of avian H5N1 influenza virus infection among several humans suffering respiratory disease following exposure to or involvement in the culling of infected geese or ducks in Chandigarh, Punjab and Haryana. Previously, India has not been among the 16 countries reporting human cases of avian H5N1 virus infection. - Mod.CP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/325.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\n \n\n[byline: Manjeet Sehgal]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n******\n The authorities here today [22 Dec 2014] decided to collect samples of poultry at random from the city, even as samples of 3 persons who were admitted to hospital here with flu-like symptoms have turned out to be negative [for H5N1 avian influenza]. \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n Following the bird flu scare in Chandigarh, one of the workers involved in the culling of 110 domesticated geese in the city's Sukhna Lake has been admitted to a Panchkula hospital with symptoms similar to avian influenza (H5N1). In the past hour, however, multiple news reports have emerged in the Arabic and English press, indicating that there have been 4 recent (time frame not specified) H5N1 deaths: 3 in the Libyan capital of Tripoli, and one in Tobruk. According to these reports, a 5th case is suspected, and the WHO has been notified. I've found nothing yet on the Libyan MOH website, but we have several media reports.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Sun 28 Dec 2014\nSource: Channel News, Asia, Agence France Presse report [edited]\nhttp://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/world/four-die-of-bird-flu-in/1552914.html?\n\n\nFour people have died of bird flu in Libya in recent days, the health minister of the country's internationally recognised government said. Rida al-Awkali said a 5th person suspected of having contracted the virus is currently in hospital in the far eastern city of Tobruk.\n\nThree of the victims died in the capital Tripoli, while the 4th died in Tobruk, he added, without saying which strain of the disease they caught. Tobruk is across the border from Egypt where at least 8 people have died of bird flu this year [2014], according to health authorities in Cairo.\n\nAwkali said that he will visit Tobruk on Sunday [28 Dec 2014] and then travel on to Egypt to meet experts from the World Health Organization (WHO), which closely monitors the various strains of avian influenza.\n\nThe H5N1 strain of bird flu has killed more than 400 people, mainly in South East Asia, since 1st appearing in 2003. Another strain, H7N9, has claimed more than 170 lives since emerging in 2013.\n\nLibya's 1st case of bird flu was recorded at a Tobruk poultry farm in March [2014], but no people were infected. Again, officials did not reveal the strain of the virus. Awkali said that the WHO would be sending a delegation to Libya within 48 hours.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[If independently confirmed, Libya will become the 17th country to record confirmed human infections by avian H5N1 influenza virus, and the most westerly occurrence of human cases of avian H5N1 influenza virus. More detailed information is awaited. Elsewhere in recent months, human cases of avian A(H5N2) virus infection have been declining, with the exception of Egypt and Indonesia. - Mod.CP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/68.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\n \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n******\n \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n It's been a busy bird flu news day with H5N1 in Egypt, H7N9 in Hong Kong and mainland China, and for the past 10 hours, there have been cryptic Arabic twitter messages regarding supposed H5N1 cases in Libya, a country that has reported bird flu in poultry in the past but never any human infections. Dec 2014\nSource: Avian Flu Diary [abridged, edited]\n [If independently confirmed, Libya will become the 17th country to record confirmed human infections by avian H5N1 influenza virus, and the most westerly occurrence of human cases of avian H5N1 influenza virus. AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (133): LIBYA, FATAL, H5N1 SUSPECTED\n**********************************************************\n Dec 2014\nSource: Channel News, Asia, Agence France Presse report [edited]\nhttp://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/world/four-die-of-bird-flu-in/1552914.html? \n\nLibya's 1st case of bird flu was recorded at a Tobruk poultry farm in March [2014], but no people were infected. Four people have died of bird flu in Libya in recent days, the health minister of the country's internationally recognised government said.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2013-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00", "2003-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-12-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-28 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Tripoli", "country": "Libya"}, {"location": "Egypt", "country": "Egypt"}, {"location": "Cairo", "country": "Egypt"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "Hong Kong"}, {"location": "FATAL", "country": "Chile"}, {"location": "Libya", "country": "Libya"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Tobruk", "country": "Libya"}, {"location": "Indonesia", "country": "Indonesia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3056665", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (117): Europe, HPAI H5N8 & H5N1, routes of spread", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3056665", "date": "2014-12-27 03:23:54", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (117): EUROPE, HPAI H5N8 & H5N1, ROUTES OF SPREAD\n*****************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 18 Dec 2014\nSource: Euro Surveill. 2014;19(50):pii=20996. Rapid communications [summarized, edited]\nhttp://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=20996\n\n\nref: C Adlhoch, C Gossner, G Koch, I Brown, R Bouwstra, F Verdonck, et al. Comparing introduction to Europe of HPAI A(H5N8) in 2014 and A(H5N1) in 2005.\n\nAbstract:\nSince the beginning of November 2014, 9 outbreaks of highly pathogenic avian influenza virus (HPAIV) A(H5N8) in poultry have been detected in 4 European countries. In this report, similarities and differences between the modes of introduction of HPAIV A(H5N1) and A(H5N8) into Europe are described. Experiences from outbreaks of A(H5N1) in Europe demonstrated that early detection to control HPAIV in poultry has proven pivotal to minimise the risk of zoonotic transmission and prevention of human cases.\n\n[The full paper follows; references omitted. For the references please go to the source URL].\n\n1. Highly pathogenic avian influenza virus A(H5N1) and A(H5N8) outbreaks in domestic poultry and wild birds in Europe.\n\nOutbreaks of highly pathogenic avian influenza virus (HPAIV) A(H5N8) in domestic poultry and wild birds in Europe in 2014 have some similarities to the previous introduction of HPAIV A(H5N1). Since beginning of November 2014, 9 outbreaks have been detected in 4 countries in Europe. Comparisons between these incursions may help to better understand potential risks to public health.\n\nIn autumn 2005, Romania and Croatia were the 1st European countries reporting influenza A(H5N1) virus infections in wild birds and domestic poultry; hereafter, it spread rapidly across central Europe starting in February 2006. When HPAIV A(H5N1) finally disappeared in 2010, it had been detected in wild birds and poultry in 21 European countries [for the table 'European countries with reported outbreaks of influenza A(H5N1) and influenza A(H5N8) virus infection in domestic poultry and wild birds, 2003 to 2014', please go to the source URL]. Prior to the introduction into Europe, HPAIV A(H5N1) was extensively circulating in poultry, with recurrent spillovers to wild birds, in Asia.\n\nInfluenza A(H5N8) virus is a complex reassortant virus carrying genes from A(H5N1) as one of its parental viruses. An ancestral strain was 1st reported in China in 2010. In 2014, following further virus evolution via reassortment, several outbreaks with HPAIV A(H5N8) viruses occurred in aquatic migratory birds, chickens, geese and ducks in China, Japan, and Republic of Korea. Between 5 Nov and 16 Dec 2014, Germany, Italy, the Netherlands, and the United Kingdom (UK) reported HPAIV A(H5N8) outbreaks in 9 holdings in total, with turkeys, chickens or ducks [for Figure & Table 'Countries reporting outbreaks of influenza A(H5N8) virus infection in domestic poultry and wild birds, 2014', please go to the source URL].\n\nIn November and December 2014, HPAIV A(H5N8) was detected in a healthy common teal (_Anas crecca_) in Germany and in 2 faecal samples from Eurasian wigeons (_Anas penelope_) in the Netherlands. The region in Germany currently affected by HPAIV A(H5N8) largely matches the area that was 1st affected by HPAIV A(H5N1), whereas in the UK, cases of A(H5N1) were initially located in eastern and southern regions and in Italy in central and southern regions, but not in the areas affected in November 2014. The Netherlands had not been affected by HPAIV A(H5N1) at all.\n\nInfluenza A(H5N8) virus infection does not appear to be associated with severe illness or excessive mortality in wild mallard ducks. In contrast, in galliform poultry (turkey, chickens), HPAIV A(H5N8) causes mass mortality as seen in affected holdings. The low to moderate virulence of HPAIV A(H5N8) in domestic ducks seen in the UK resembles the situation in wild mallards. Many strains of HPAIV A(H5N1), in contrast, cause high mortality not only in galliformes but also in anseriform poultry and in wild birds.\n\n2. Routes of introduction into Europe\n\nThe spread of HPAIV A(H5N1) from east Asia to Europe via central Asia may have occurred by a complex mixture of activities associated with poultry production, illegal poultry transports, spillover infections to wild birds, and migratory bird dispersal, but no consistent route of infection into poultry holdings within Europe has been identified. The sudden occurrence of HPAIV A(H5N1) in central Europe in 2006 was probably associated with cold spells in western Russia that drove out substantial numbers of putatively infected wild birds further west.\n\nMutual transmission of HPAIV between migratory birds and domestic poultry might occur through direct or indirect contacts. Genetic analyses of the recent European influenza A(H5N8) viruses revealed very high similarity to Japanese wild bird isolates, suggesting a common source of infection.\n\nImport of live poultry and live captive birds as well as poultry commodities from affected Asian regions to the European Union (EU) is illegal but cannot be formally excluded as a route of introduction for HPAIV A(H5N8); however, this seems unlikely considering the simultaneous nature and geographic spread of the outbreaks. No epidemiological links have been identified between the initially affected holdings in Germany, the Netherlands and the UK. Findings of HPAIV A(H5N8) in wild birds in Europe also open a possibility for an importation from Asia to Europe via migratory wild birds, although this remains hypothetical until the virus is found in further wild bird populations in central and western Asia.\n\nAffected holdings in Europe so far were indoor facilities with nominally good biosecurity, yet indirect contact between wild birds and poultry (via any material contaminated by infected wild birds, such as faeces) might be possible. The fact that in several of the holdings stable units closest to the entrance of the compound were the 1st affected in the outbreak might suggest the introduction of A(H5N8) from a focal source close to the compound.\n\n3. Surveillance of highly pathogenic avian influenza viruses in the European Union\n\nThe experience of large HPAIV outbreaks in the Netherlands, Belgium and Germany, e.g. A(H7N7) in 2003, prompted the EU to better prepare for large scale incursions of HPAIV. The establishment and implementation of surveillance systems, diagnostic tools for early detection of HPAIV and harmonised restriction and control measures were laid down in the EU legislation. This included introducing programmes of passive surveillance of wild bird populations as an early warning system, which proved to be a useful tool in detecting presence of HPAIV A(H5N1). This was complemented by active monitoring of poultry. In the current epizootic, enhanced wild bird monitoring might also help to further elucidate the role of wild birds transmitting A(H5N8), although the apparently asymptomatic presentation in wild bird species in Europe indicates that potentially scaling up elements of targeted active rather than passive surveillance may be appropriate to better understand the distribution, prevalence and introduction pathways into Europe.\n\n4. Risk for human transmission and resulting public health measures\n\nAlthough to date, HPAIV A(H5N1) has caused 676 human cases worldwide, including 398 deaths, no human cases have ever been reported in Europe, and these viruses lack the capability for sustained human-to-human transmission. Cats and mustelids were the only mammals found to be infected in Europe. No human cases due to A(H5N8) have so far been reported anywhere. Mammals such as mice, ferrets, dogs and cats proved to be susceptible to experimental A(H5N8) infection, yet, only mild clinical disease, if any, ensued, and so their role as amplification or reservoir hosts appears less likely.\n\nBinding of avian influenza viruses to mammalian 2-6 sialic acid receptors is a prerequisite for transmission to humans. HPAIV A(H5N8) binds strongly to avian 2-3 receptors and, to a markedly lesser degree, to 2-6 receptors, indicating limited zoonotic potential. Antiviral resistance has not been described in the recent isolates. Candidate vaccine viruses for human use have been proposed for pandemic preparedness.\n\nPeople at risk of spillover infections are those directly exposed to infected birds and their carcasses, such as during culling measures in affected holdings. Personal protective equipment and other protective measures are a prerequisite for preventing zoonotic transmission. Passive or active monitoring of exposed persons enables early identification of transmission events. There is no evidence of human infection through consumption of contaminated food. Recommended diagnostic tests for animal and human samples showed reliable detection of HPAIV A(H5N8).\n\n5. Conclusions\n\nThe current simultaneous occurrence of A(H5N8) in different European countries is comparable to the introduction of A(H5N1) around a decade ago. These similarities may point to common routes of introduction into Europe, although these are not fully understood and the exact sources of infection of the affected indoor poultry holdings have not been identified yet. More outbreaks seem possible. Although HPAIV A(H5N8) might have the potential to transmit to humans, no human cases have been detected so far. Based on the experience from HPAIV A(H5N1) in Europe, efficient biosecurity, early detection, and stringent control measures are able to minimize risks of spillover transmission to humans. The rapid geographic dispersion of yet another reassortant, highly pathogenic avian influenza A virus underlines the need for enhanced preparedness.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The above review, written by prominent European avian influenza researchers is a timely and needed updated analysis of HPAI H5N8 Asian/European spread; in addition, the authors addressed the routes along which the zoonotic strain HPAI H5N1 may have spread in the past with possible involvement of migrating birds. Further consolidating data are yet to be added.\n\nGermany has, in the meantime, reported its 4th and 5th HPAI H5N8 events. They are described in follow-up report No. 4, submitted to the OIE on 21 Dec 2014: one in Lower Saxony on a poultry farm (species/branch not specified) and the other one in Saxony-Anhalt, involving a wild mallard (_Anas platyrhynchos_).\n\nSee all Germany's HPAI H5N8 OIE reports since 4 Nov 2014 and an interactive map showing the 5 dispersed 'outbreaks,' of which there are 3 in poultry and 2 in wild birds, at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?fupser=&dothis=&reportid=16474. - Mod.AS]", "summary": "When HPAIV A(H5N1) finally disappeared in 2010, it had been detected in wild birds and poultry in 21 European countries [for the table 'European countries with reported outbreaks of influenza A(H5N1) and influenza A(H5N8) virus infection in domestic poultry and wild birds, 2003 to 2014', please go to the source URL]. Routes of introduction into Europe\n\nThe spread of HPAIV A(H5N1) from east Asia to Europe via central Asia may have occurred by a complex mixture of activities associated with poultry production, illegal poultry transports, spillover infections to wild birds, and migratory bird dispersal, but no consistent route of infection into poultry holdings within Europe has been identified. Between 5 Nov and 16 Dec 2014, Germany, Italy, the Netherlands, and the United Kingdom (UK) reported HPAIV A(H5N8) outbreaks in 9 holdings in total, with turkeys, chickens or ducks [for Figure & Table 'Countries reporting outbreaks of influenza A(H5N8) virus infection in domestic poultry and wild birds, 2014', please go to the source URL]. \n\nOutbreaks of highly pathogenic avian influenza virus (HPAIV) A(H5N8) in domestic poultry and wild birds in Europe in 2014 have some similarities to the previous introduction of HPAIV A(H5N1). \n\nAffected holdings in Europe so far were indoor facilities with nominally good biosecurity, yet indirect contact between wild birds and poultry (via any material contaminated by infected wild birds, such as faeces) might be possible. In the current epizootic, enhanced wild bird monitoring might also help to further elucidate the role of wild birds transmitting A(H5N8), although the apparently asymptomatic presentation in wild bird species in Europe indicates that potentially scaling up elements of targeted active rather than passive surveillance may be appropriate to better understand the distribution, prevalence and introduction pathways into Europe. Findings of HPAIV A(H5N8) in wild birds in Europe also open a possibility for an importation from Asia to Europe via migratory wild birds, although this remains hypothetical until the virus is found in further wild bird populations in central and western Asia. \n\nImport of live poultry and live captive birds as well as poultry commodities from affected Asian regions to the European Union (EU) is illegal but cannot be formally excluded as a route of introduction for HPAIV A(H5N8); however, this seems unlikely considering the simultaneous nature and geographic spread of the outbreaks. In autumn 2005, Romania and Croatia were the 1st European countries reporting influenza A(H5N1) virus infections in wild birds and domestic poultry; hereafter, it spread rapidly across central Europe starting in February 2006. Highly pathogenic avian influenza virus A(H5N1) and A(H5N8) outbreaks in domestic poultry and wild birds in Europe. The rapid geographic dispersion of yet another reassortant, highly pathogenic avian influenza A virus underlines the need for enhanced preparedness.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< H5N8 OIE reports since 4 Nov 2014 and an interactive map showing the 5 dispersed 'outbreaks,' of which there are 3 in poultry and 2 in wild birds, at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?fupser=&dothis=&reportid=16474. Since the beginning of November 2014, 9 outbreaks of highly pathogenic avian influenza virus (HPAIV) A(H5N8) in poultry have been detected in 4 European countries. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The above review, written by prominent European avian influenza researchers is a timely and needed updated analysis of HPAI H5N8 Asian/European spread; in addition, the authors addressed the routes along which the zoonotic strain HPAI H5N1 may have spread in the past with possible involvement of migrating birds. \n\nInfluenza A(H5N8) virus infection does not appear to be associated with severe illness or excessive mortality in wild mallard ducks. Surveillance of highly pathogenic avian influenza viruses in the European Union\n\nThe experience of large HPAIV outbreaks in the Netherlands, Belgium and Germany, e.g. A(H7N7) in 2003, prompted the EU to better prepare for large scale incursions of HPAIV. \n\nMutual transmission of HPAIV between migratory birds and domestic poultry might occur through direct or indirect contacts. Although to date, HPAIV A(H5N1) has caused 676 human cases worldwide, including 398 deaths, no human cases have ever been reported in Europe, and these viruses lack the capability for sustained human-to-human transmission. \n\nPeople at risk of spillover infections are those directly exposed to infected birds and their carcasses, such as during culling measures in affected holdings. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n In 2014, following further virus evolution via reassortment, several outbreaks with HPAIV A(H5N8) viruses occurred in aquatic migratory birds, chickens, geese and ducks in China, Japan, and Republic of Korea. They are described in follow-up report No. 4, submitted to the OIE on 21 Dec 2014: one in Lower Saxony on a poultry farm (species/branch not specified) and the other one in Saxony-Anhalt, involving a wild mallard (_Anas platyrhynchos_). Experiences from outbreaks of A(H5N1) in Europe demonstrated that early detection to control HPAIV in poultry has proven pivotal to minimise the risk of zoonotic transmission and prevention of human cases. Prior to the introduction into Europe, HPAIV A(H5N1) was extensively circulating in poultry, with recurrent spillovers to wild birds, in Asia. The region in Germany currently affected by HPAIV A(H5N8) largely matches the area that was 1st affected by HPAIV A(H5N1), whereas in the UK, cases of A(H5N1) were initially located in eastern and southern regions and in Italy in central and southern regions, but not in the areas affected in November 2014.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2014-12-25 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00", "2003-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-11-25 00:00:00", "2006-03-25 00:00:00", "2005-03-25 00:00:00", "2006-02-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Netherlands", "country": "Netherlands"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "Japan"}, {"location": "Italy", "country": "Italy"}, {"location": "Croatia", "country": "Croatia"}, {"location": "the United Kingdom", "country": "United Kingdom"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Germany", "country": "Germany"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Romania", "country": "Romania"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Republic of Korea", "country": "South Korea"}, {"location": "Belgium", "country": "Belgium"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3043523", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (113): India (CH) H5N1, ducks, OIE, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3043523", "date": "2014-12-19 18:09:50", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (113): INDIA (CHANDIGARH) H5N1, DUCKS, OIE: REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n***********************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 18 Dec 2014\nSource: OIE, WAHID weekly disease information 2014; 27(51) [edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=16780\n\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza, India\n----------------------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 18 Dec 2014 from Mr Anup Kumar Thakur, Secretary, Government of India, Department of Animal Husbandry, Dairying and Fisheries, Ministry of Agriculture, New Delhi, India\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 11 Dec 2014\nDate of pre-confirmation of the event: 16 Dec 2014\nReason for notification: reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 21 Feb 2014\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: laboratory (advanced)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1: Sukhna lake, Chandigarh, Chandigarh\nDate of start of the outbreak: 11 Dec 2014\nOutbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: not applicable\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nBirds / 100 / 22 / 22 / - / -\nAffected population: ducks in captivity\n\nOutbreak statistics:\nSpecies / Apparent morbidity rate / Apparent mortality rate / Apparent case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBirds / 22 percent / 22 percent / 100 percent / **\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction and/or slaughter\n**Not calculated because of missing information\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: stamping out; quarantine; movement control inside the country; screening; disinfection of infected premises/establishment(s); dipping/spraying; vaccination prohibited; no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type: National Institute of High Security Animal Disease, Bhopal (national laboratory)\nSpecies / Test / Test date / Result\nBirds / real-time reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RRT-PCR) / 16 Dec 2014 / Positive\nBirds / reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) / 16 Dec 2014 / Positive\nBirds/ virus isolation/ 16 Dec 2014/ Positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[On 25 Nov 2014, India reported an event of highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) in the state of Kerala. HPAI serotype H5N1 was identified. To date, 4 outbreaks have been reported and all affected birds were ducks -- susceptible: 387 928; cases: 18 554; deaths: 18 554; destroyed: 369 374.\n\nThe updated data and map are available in the last follow-up report sent to the OIE on 17 Dec 2014; see http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/temp/reports/en_fup_0000016766_20141217_164912.pdf.\n\nRegarding the current report, it would be interesting to know the exact avian species that was affected. Based on a report from the media: 'Bird flu has been confirmed in one of the 30 domesticated geese that died at Sukhna Lake in Chandigarh. Of the 6 samples sent to the National Institute of High Security Animal Diseases Laboratory in Bhopal, one has tested positive for the dreaded avian influenza (H5N1). The Bhopal lab has communicated its findings to the Chandigarh-based northern region office of the Central Poultry Development Organisation. The samples were sent to Bhopal after more than 2 dozen geese (ducks) had died under mysterious circumstances at the lake in the past 2 weeks. Sources in the Department of Animal Husbandry (under the Ministry of Agriculture) told The Tribune that some samples (from Chandigarh) had tested positive for highly pathogenic H5N1.' Also included is a photograph of the dead goose found at Sukhna Lake in Chandigarh. See media report at http://www.tribuneindia.com/news/nation/dead-goose-tests-positive-for-bird-flu-in-chandigarh/19605.html.\n\nHowever, the official report sent to the OIE mentions that the species affected in this event are 'ducks in captivity'. While ducks and geese belong to the same phylogenetic order (Anseriformes) and family (Anatidae), neither swans nor geese are considered ducks. Ducks are mostly aquatic birds, mostly smaller than swans and geese, and may be found in both fresh water and sea water (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Duck). Geese are waterfowl belonging to the tribe Anserini of the family Anatidae. This tribe comprises the genera Anser (the grey geese), Branta (the black geese) and Chen (the white geese) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Goose).\n\nClarity on what species was actually affected would be useful to have.\n\nA map of India is available at http://www.ephotopix.com/image/asia/india_state_map.gif. - Mod.CRD\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/325.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n / -\nAffected population: ducks in captivity\n\nOutbreak statistics:\nSpecies / Apparent morbidity rate / Apparent mortality rate / Apparent case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\n 18 Dec 2014 from Mr Anup Kumar Thakur, Secretary, Government of India, Department of Animal Husbandry, Dairying and Fisheries, Ministry of Agriculture, New Delhi, India\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\n Dec 2014 / Positive\nBirds/ virus isolation/ 16 Dec 2014/ Positive\n\nFuture reporting\n Affected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nBirds / 100 / 22 / 22 / - Manifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\n Total outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1: Sukhna lake, Chandigarh, Chandigarh\n Serotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: laboratory (advanced)\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< [The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\n This event pertains to a defined zone within the country\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\n no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type: National Institute of High Security Animal Disease, Bhopal (national laboratory) Measures applied: stamping out; The statement added 72 cases have died and 2 patients are still receiving treatment at hospital.\n\nThe infected human cases which emerged during the year 2014 were exposed to infected dead birds, according to the statement.\n\nThe woman who died of bird flu [Wed 17 Dec 2014] was a 20-year-old student from al-Ghanayem City, Assiut, Al-Masry Al-Youm reported. Assiut University Hospital received the woman 3 days ago but her condition deteriorated. She was placed on a ventilator before she caught pneumonia and died.\n\nThe death rate of bird flu in Egypt is 37.4 percent compared to 55 percent on the international level, mostly in China. Around 2 million workers involved in the poultry industry and 8 million people of their relatives have been harmed since the emergence of bird flu in Egypt, according to the State Information Service.\n\nThe World Health Organization published a report in 2014 on influenza A (H5) activity from 18 Feb to 23 Sep 2014 (http://www.who.int/influenza/vaccines/virus/201409_zoonotic_vaccinevirusupdate.pdf). The report mentioned that the infections by the A(H5) [virus] reported to the WHO by Egypt included poultry and humans.\n\nWHO advised that travelers to countries with known outbreaks of avian influenza should avoid poultry farms, or contact with animals in live bird markets, or entering areas where poultry may be slaughtered, or contact with any surfaces that appear to be contaminated with feces from poultry or other animals. Travelers should also wash their hands often with soap and water. Travelers should follow standard food safety and hygiene practices.\n\n[Byline: Mai Mohsen]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Human cases of avian influenza H5N1 virus infection first appeared in 2003, affecting 16 countries in middle Asia and the Far East. Although there has been a gradual decline in the number of cases overall, Egypt and Indonesia still predominate.\n\nThere has been little evidence of direct transmission of H5N1 virus from person to person, and case numbers have correlated with the habit of rearing various species of poultry in homes and allotments. In Egypt the positive cases have been widely distributed among the governorates. See the most recent WHO table of cumulative cases at http://www.who.int/influenza/human_animal_interface/EN_GIP_20141002CumulativeNumberH5N1cases.pdf.\n\nAn epidemiological curve of avian influenza A(H5N1) cases in humans by reporting country and month of onset produced by WHO, summarises the available information and can be accessed at http://www.who.int/influenza/human_animal_interface/Influenza_Summary_IRA_HA_interface_04December2014.pdf. - Mod.CP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/37853.]", "summary": "Source: Egypt Independent [edited]\nhttp://www.egyptindependent.com/news/woman-dies-bird-flu-assiut-raising-deaths-9-2014\n\n\nAn Egyptian woman died on [Wed 17 Dec 2014] of bird flu [avian influenza] bringing the number of deaths of bird flu to 9 cases since the beginning of the year [2014], Al-Masry Al-Youm [the Arabic version of the newspaper Egypt Independent] reports. \n\nWHO advised that travelers to countries with known outbreaks of avian influenza should avoid poultry farms, or contact with animals in live bird markets, or entering areas where poultry may be slaughtered, or contact with any surfaces that appear to be contaminated with feces from poultry or other animals. China (GD) H7N9", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3077378", "date": "2015-01-07 19:33:44", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (06): EGYPT H5N1, CHINA (GUANGDONG) H7N9\n***************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Egypt: H5N1\n[2] China (Guangdong): H7N9\n\n******\n[1] Egypt: H5N1\nDate: Mon 5 Jan 2015\nSource: CIDRAP (Center for Infectious Disease Research and Policy) News [edited]\nhttp://www.cidrap.umn.edu/news-perspective/2015/01/avian-flu-scan-jan-05-2015\n\n\n4 more H5N1 cases reported in Egypt\n-----------------------------------\nA recent flurry of human H5N1 influenza cases in Egypt continued with at least 4 more over the past 5 days, along with 2 deaths, according to media and government reports.\n\nTwo cases involved a 6-year-old girl from Giza governorate who was in critical condition and a 45-year-old man from Menoufiya governorate who was on a respirator, according to a machine-translated Egyptian Ministry of Health (MOH) statement that was posted 1 Jan [2015] on the infectious-disease blog Avian Flu Diary (AFD).\n\nThe 2 cases raised Egypt's H5N1 count for 2014 to 29 cases, with 11 deaths, the MOH said.\n\nThe 45-year-old man apparently died of his illness, as a 3 Jan [2015] English-language report from Ahram Online noted the death of a 45-year-old Menoufiya man that day. It said he had had pneumonia and had been on a ventilator.\n\nTwo additional cases, both in Minya governorate, were revealed today [5 Jan 2015] in a machine-translated AhramOnline report posted on AFD (with a note that a subsequent MOH statement matched it). They involve a 30-year-old man in 'medium' condition and an 11-year-old boy in critical condition.\n\nThe other death involved a 3-year-old child from Giza governorate, according to a story today [5 Jan 2015] in the Jerusalem Post, citing the MOH. The description matched that of a case-patient reported by the MOH on 31 Dec [2014]. It was not clear today whether the 3-year-old Giza child had any connection with the 6-year-old Giza girl whose case was reported 1 Jan [2015].\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] China (Guangdong): H7N9\nDate: Wed 7 Jan 2015\nSource: Hong Kong Centre for Health Protection [edited]\nhttp://www.chp.gov.hk/en/view_content/37773.html\n\n\nCHP notified of human case of avian influenza A(H7N9) in Zhaoqing [Guangdong province]\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nThe Centre for Health Protection (CHP) of the Department of Health (DH) is today [7 Jan 2015] closely monitoring an additional human case of avian influenza A(H7N9) in Zhaoqing notified by the Health and Family Planning Commission of Guangdong Province (GDHFPC), and again urged the public to maintain strict personal, food and environmental hygiene both locally and during travel.\n\nAccording to the GDHFPC, the male patient, aged 56 with underlying illnesses, was hospitalised for management in critical condition.\n\nTo date, 458 human cases of avian influenza A(H7N9) have been reported by the Mainland health authorities, respectively in Zhejiang (141 cases), Guangdong (115 cases), Jiangsu (59 cases), Shanghai (42 cases), Hunan (24 cases), Fujian (23 cases), Anhui (17 cases), Jiangxi (8 cases), Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region (8 cases), Beijing (5 cases), Shandong (5 cases), Henan (4 cases), Guangxi (3 cases), Jilin (2 cases), Guizhou (1 case) and Hebei (1 case).\n\nAll boundary control points have implemented health surveillance measures. Thermal imaging systems are in place for body temperature checks on inbound travellers. Suspected cases will be immediately referred to public hospitals for follow-up. The DH's Port Health Office has enhanced body temperature checks by handheld devices. ... -- more\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[How is China going to distinguish a flu fever from an Ebola fever? - Mod.JW]\n\n[Maps of China can be accessed at https://www.google.com/maps/place/China and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/34106.\n\nMaps of Egypt can be accessed at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Egypt and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/55.\n\nSuggested reading:\nWyrzucki A, Bianchi M, Kohler I, et al. Heterosubtypic antibodies to influenza A virus have limited activity against cell-bound virus but are not impaired by strain-specific serum antibodies. J Virol. 2014 Dec 31. pii: JVI.03069-14. [Epub ahead of print] http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/m/pubmed/25552718/\n\n'Abstract\n---------\nThe majority of influenza virus-specific antibodies elicited by vaccination or natural infection is only effective against the eliciting or closely related viruses. Rare stem-specific heterosubtypic monoclonal antibodies (hmAbs) can neutralize multiple strains and subtypes by preventing hemagglutinin (HA)-mediated fusion of the viral with the endosomal membrane. The epitopes recognized by these hmAbs are therefore considered promising targets for the development of pan-influenza vaccines. Here we report the isolation of a novel human HA-stem-reactive monoclonal antibody, mAb 1.12, with exceptionally broad neutralizing activity encompassing viruses from 15 distinct HA subtypes. Using mAb 1.12 and 2 other monoclonal antibodies, we could demonstrate that neutralization by hmAbs is virtually irreversible but becomes severely impaired following virus attachment to cells. In contrast, no interference by human anti-influenza serum antibodies was found, indicating that apically binding antibodies do not impair access to the membrane-proximal heterosubtypic epitopes. Our findings therefore encourage development of new vaccine concepts aiming at the induction of stem-specific heterosubtypic antibodies, as we provide support for their effectiveness in individuals previously exposed to influenza virus.'\n\nOdagiri T, Matsuzaki Y, Okamoto et al. Isolation and characterization of influenza C viruses in the Philippines and Japan. J Clin Microbiol_. 2014 Dec 31. pii: JCM.02628-14. [Epub ahead of print] http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/m/pubmed/25552361/\n\n'Abstract\n---------\nFrom November 2009 to December 2013, 15 influenza C viruses were isolated, using MDCK cells, from specimens obtained from children with severe pneumonia and influenza-like illness (ILI), in the Philippines. This is the 1st report of influenza C virus isolation in the Philippines. In addition, from January 2008 to December 2013, 7 influenza C viruses were isolated from specimens that were obtained from children with acute respiratory illness (ARI) in Sendai city, Japan. Antigenic analysis with monoclonal antibodies to the hemaggultinin-esterase (HE) glycoprotein showed that 19 strains (12 from Philippines and 7 from Japan) were similar to the reference strain C/Sao Paulo/378/82(SP82). Phylogenetic analysis of the HE gene showed that strains from the Philippines and Japan formed distinct clusters within an SP82-related lineage. The clusters including the Philippine and Japanese strains were shown to have diverged from a common ancestor around 1993. In addition, phylogenetic analysis of internal genes showed that all strains isolated in the Philippines and Japan had emerged through reassortment events. The composition of the internal genes of the Philippine strains was different from that of the Japanese strains, although all strains were classified into an SP82-related lineage by HE gene sequence analysis. These observations suggest that the influenza C viruses analyzed here had emerged through different reassortment events; however, the time and place at which the reassortment events occurred could not be determined.' - Mod.LK]", "summary": "To date, 458 human cases of avian influenza A(H7N9) have been reported by the Mainland health authorities, respectively in Zhejiang (141 cases), Guangdong (115 cases), Jiangsu (59 cases), Shanghai (42 cases), Hunan (24 cases), Fujian (23 cases), Anhui (17 cases), Jiangxi (8 cases), Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region (8 cases), Beijing (5 cases), Shandong (5 cases), Henan (4 cases), Guangxi (3 cases), Jilin (2 cases), Guizhou (1 case) and Hebei (1 case). A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nTwo cases involved a 6-year-old girl from Giza governorate who was in critical condition and a 45-year-old man from Menoufiya governorate who was on a respirator, according to a machine-translated Egyptian Ministry of Health (MOH) statement that was posted 1 Jan [2015] on the infectious-disease blog Avian Flu Diary (AFD). Source: Hong Kong Centre for Health Protection [edited]\nhttp://www.chp.gov.hk/en/view_content/37773.html\n\n\nCHP notified of human case of avian influenza A(H7N9) in Zhaoqing [Guangdong province]\n \n\nThe 45-year-old man apparently died of his illness, as a 3 Jan [2015] English-language report from Ahram Online noted the death of a 45-year-old Menoufiya man that day. AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (06): EGYPT H5N1, CHINA (GUANGDONG) H7N9\n***************************************************************\n \n\nThe other death involved a 3-year-old child from Giza governorate, according to a story today [5 Jan 2015] in the Jerusalem Post, citing the MOH. It was not clear today whether the 3-year-old Giza child had any connection with the 6-year-old Giza girl whose case was reported 1 Jan [2015]. A recent flurry of human H5N1 influenza cases in Egypt continued with at least 4 more over the past 5 days, along with 2 deaths, according to media and government reports. They involve a 30-year-old man in 'medium' condition and an 11-year-old boy in critical condition. [Epub ahead of print] http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/m/pubmed/25552361/\n\n'Abstract\n \n\nSuggested reading:\nWyrzucki A, Bianchi M, Kohler I, et al. Our findings therefore encourage development of new vaccine concepts aiming at the induction of stem-specific heterosubtypic antibodies, as we provide support for their effectiveness in individuals flu human H5N1\nDate: Wed 14 Jan 2015\nSource: Ahram Online\nhttp://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/120274/Egypt/Politics-/Woman-dies-from-bird-flu-in-Upper-Egypt-.aspx\n\n\nWoman dies from bird flu in Upper Egypt\n-----------------------------------------------------\nA 65-year-old woman has died of bird flu in Upper Egypt, the 2nd fatality from the virus this year, the health ministry announced in a statement on Wed [14 Jan 2105].\n\nThe woman died at the Assiut Chest hospital.\n\nThe statement also announced that a 3-year-old boy from Beheira in the Nile Delta was infected by bird flu but has since recovered.\n\nThe ministry said there have been 12 bird flu cases in Egypt this year. 3 cases have recovered, 7 others are still being treated and 2 have died. 2 people have been infected in Minya, Menoufiya and Cairo. One each in Sharqiya, Qalioubiya, Gharbiya, Aswan, Assiut and Beheira.\n\nLast year, 11 people died of bird flu nationwide.\n\nMost cases of bird flu in Egypt have been identified in rural areas, where villagers tend to raise poultry in their homes, increasing exposure to live or dead infected birds.\n\nThe virus first appeared in Egypt in 2006.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The news item does not state which avian flu strain, but previous cases in Egypt have been H5N1.\n\n[Maps of Egypt can be accessed at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Egypt and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/55 - MOD.LK].\n\n\n******\n[2] China: Avian flu human H7N9 [Shenzhen]\nDate: Wed 14 Jan 2015\nSource: CHP [edited]\nhttp://www.flu.org.cn/en/news-18034.html\n\n\nThe Centre for Health Protection [CHP] has learned of 2 new avian influenza A (H7N9) cases in Shenzhen. They involve a 57-year-old woman and a 41-year-old man. They bring the total number of confirmed H7N9 cases on the Mainland to 462.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n\n******\n[3] China: Avian flu human H7N9 China [Mainland]\nDate: 12 Jan 2015\nSource: CHP Hong Kong [edited]\nhttp://www.flu.org.cn/en/news-18037.html\n\n\nThe Centre for Health Protection (CHP) of the Department of Health (DH) is today [14 Jan 2015] closely monitoring 16 additional human cases of avian influenza A(H7N9) notified by the Mainland health authorities and again urged the public to maintain strict personal, food and environmental hygiene both locally and during travel.\n\nAccording to the Health and Family Planning Commission of Guangdong Province, the 2 cases from Dongguan include a female patient aged 52 and a male patient aged 37 who were hospitalised for treatment in critical and serious condition, respectively. The remaining 14 cases (including 3 deaths) in Fujian (5 cases), Jiangsu (4 cases), Zhejiang (4 cases) and Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region (Xinjiang) (1 case) were notified by the National Health and Family Planning Commission. The patients include 7 men and 7 women aged 20 to 83. Apart from the 3 deaths, the other 11 patients were in critical condition.\n\nTo date, 478 human cases of avian influenza A(H7N9) have been reported by the Mainland health authorities, respectively in Zhejiang (145 cases), Guangdong (121 cases), Jiangsu (63 cases), Shanghai (42 cases), Fujian (28 cases), Hunan (24 cases), Anhui (17 cases), Xinjiang (9 cases), Jiangxi (8 cases), Beijing (5 cases), Shandong (5 cases), Henan (4 cases), Guangxi (3 cases), Jilin (2 cases), Guizhou (1 case) and Hebei (1 case).\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/155.]", "summary": "To date, 478 human cases of avian influenza A(H7N9) have been reported by the Mainland health authorities, respectively in Zhejiang (145 cases), Guangdong (121 cases), Jiangsu (63 cases), Shanghai (42 cases), Fujian (28 cases), Hunan (24 cases), Anhui (17 cases), Xinjiang (9 cases), Jiangxi (8 cases), Beijing (5 cases), Shandong (5 cases), Henan (4 cases), Guangxi (3 cases), Jilin (2 cases), Guizhou (1 case) and Hebei (1 case). H5N1, CHILD\n********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 6 Dec 2014\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/egyptian-toddler-from-sohag-sickened-with-h5n1-avian-influenza-18979/\n\n\nEgyptian health authorities have confirmed an additional human case of H5N1 avian influenza [AI] in a 2-year-old child from Sohag [Suhaj] governorate, according to a Forbes report (computer translated).\n\nThe report notes the child was suffering from fever, cough and sore throat after exposure to birds. The toddler was admitted at a hospital in Sohag on Thursday [4 Dec 2014] and given the drug Tamiflu. H5N1 avian influenza was confirmed by the central laboratory of the Ministry of Health, and the child is currently in stable condition. This is the 15th H5N1 AI case reported by the Health Ministry in 2014.\n\nNumerous health warnings have been issued by the Egyptian Ministry of Health in light of the H5N1 avian influenza outbreak to include the risks of trading in live birds, increasing awareness of avian influenza in rural districts and starting bird vaccination campaigns to slow the spread of the disease.\n\nIn Minya governorate, where the bulk of the human AI cases have been reported since November 2014, special ambulance crews dedicated to transporting and dealing with patients with suspected bird flu have been established.\n\n[Byline: Robert Herriman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[According to the WHO, the overall public health risk assessment for avian influenza A(H5N1) viruses is the following: Whenever influenza viruses are circulating in poultry, sporadic infections or small clusters of human cases are possible, especially in people exposed to infected poultry or contaminated environments. Human infections remain rare, and these influenza A(H5N1) viruses do not currently appear to transmit easily among people. As such, the risk of community-level spread of these viruses remains low.\n\nAn epidemiological curve of avian influenza A(H5N1) cases in humans by reporting country and month of onset is available at http://www.who.int/influenza/human_animal_interface/Influenza_Summary_IRA_HA_interface_October14.pdf?ua=1. This reveals an overall decline in case numbers, Egypt excepted. - Mod.CP\n\nMaps of Egypt can be seen at http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Governorates_of_Egypt.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/55.]", "summary": "Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[According to the WHO, the overall public health risk assessment for avian influenza A(H5N1) viruses is the following: Whenever influenza viruses are circulating in poultry, sporadic infections or small clusters of human cases are possible, especially in people exposed to infected poultry or contaminated environments. \n\nNumerous health warnings have been issued by the Egyptian Ministry of Health in light of the H5N1 avian influenza outbreak to include the risks of trading in live birds, increasing awareness of avian influenza in rural districts and starting bird vaccination campaigns to slow the spread of the disease. 'A woman of 33 originally from Sohag province (in the south) has died of the H5N1 virus,' health ministry spokesman Hossam Abdel Ghafar told AFP. He said another person is still being treated, and added that 7 patients diagnosed this year with bird flu were cured.\n\nThe H5N1 strain has killed more than 400 people worldwide since 1st appearing in 2003, mainly in Southeast Asia. It is one of several deadly or potentially deadly strains of bird flu that are closely monitored by the World Health Organisation. The strain is different from the H5N8 version, whose spread on European poultry farms has prompted WHO calls for vigilance. A 3rd strain of bird flu -- H7N9 -- has killed more than 170 people since emerging in 2013.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Human cases of avian influenza H5N1 virus infection 1st appeared in 2003, affecting 16 countries in middle Asia and the Far East. Subsequently there has been a gradual decline in the number of cases, but still with Egypt and Indonesia predominating. There has been little evidence of direct transmission of H5N1 virus from person to person, and case numbers have correlated with the habit of rearing various species of poultry in homes and allotments. See the most recent WHO Cumulative Table at: http://www.who.int/influenza/human_animal_interface/EN_GIP_20141002CumulativeNumberH5N1cases.pdf?ua=1Who.\n\nAn epidemiological curve of avian influenza A(H5N1) cases in humans by reporting country and month of onset produced by WHO summarises the available information and is available at: http://www.who.int/influenza/human_animal_interface/Influenza_Summary_IRA_HA_interface_04December2014.pdf?ua=1. - Mod.CP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/4048.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Human cases of avian influenza H5N1 virus infection 1st appeared in 2003, affecting 16 countries in middle Asia and the Far East. "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3022048", "date": "2014-12-09 12:47:03", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (103): VIET NAM (TRA VINH) HPAI H5N1\n****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 8 Dec 2014\nSource: Malaysian National News Agency (Bernama) [edited]\nhttp://www.bernama.com.my/bernama/v7/wn/newsworld.php?id=1091557\n\n\nA total of 177 chickens in Mekong Delta province of Tra Vinh have tested positive for H5N1 strain of avian influenza, Vietnam News Agency (VNA) reported.\n\nThe Provincial Department of Agriculture and Rural Development said the chickens were in Phong Thanh commune, Cau Ke district.\n\nTra Vinh People's Committee has instructed all relevant agencies to step up prevention measures including vaccinating livestock and poultry against flu strains, sterilizing farms and abattoirs and alerting residents about the outbreak.\n\nAgencies have been told to set up checkpoints along waterways and roads traversing flu-hit communes, and localities near other provinces such as Cang Long, Cau Quan, Thong Hoa, and Dinh An.\n\nQuarantine staff members have been dispatched to markets, wharfs, and bus stations to monitor livestock and fowl trade and transport.\n\nIn the 1st quarter of this year [2014], Tra Vinh recorded 25 cases of avian influenza in 12 communes which killed 16 500 chickens.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Last avian influenza season (October 2013 - March 2014) Viet Nam suffered a recurrent HPAI H5N1 epizootic, caused by virus clade 2.3.2.1. The strain 2.3.2.1C was, reportedly, of the highest pathogenicity. This epizootic involved a total of 39 outbreaks and was declared resolved on 11 Apr 2014. Genotyping of the current virus strain will be of interest.\n\nIn April 2014, a new strain, HPAI H5N6, was identified in Viet Nam for the 1st time. It caused 7 outbreaks and was declared resolved on 6 Oct 2014; all reports and an interactive map are available at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?fupser=&dothis=&reportid=15802.\n\nSince 2003, 127 human cases of avian influenza have been reported from Viet Nam, including 64 deaths (2 of them in 2014). The disease peaked in the 2 years 2004/2005 (90 cases, 39 deaths). Since then, control and prevention efforts of the animal health authorities were intensified, including vaccinations of poultry.- Mod.AS\n\nMaps of Viet Nam can be seen at http://www.onlineasiatravel.com/images/vn/vietnam-map.png and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/43034. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]", "summary": "In the 1st quarter of this year [2014], Tra Vinh recorded 25 cases of avian influenza in 12 communes which killed 16 500 chickens.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nAgencies have been told to set up checkpoints along waterways and roads traversing flu-hit communes, and localities near other provinces such as Cang Long, Cau Quan, Thong Hoa, and Dinh An.\n\n Since 2003, 127 human cases of avian influenza have been reported from Viet Nam, including 64 deaths (2 of them in 2014). promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Last avian influenza season (October 2013 - March 2014) A total of 177 chickens in Mekong Delta province of Tra Vinh have tested positive for H5N1 strain of avian influenza, Vietnam News Agency (VNA) reported. Tra Vinh People's Committee has instructed all relevant agencies to step up prevention measures including vaccinating livestock and poultry against flu strains, sterilizing farms and abattoirs and alerting residents about the outbreak. This epizootic involved a total of 39 outbreaks and was declared resolved on 11 Apr 2014. It caused 7 outbreaks and was declared resolved on 6 Oct 2014; all reports and an interactive map are available at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?fupser=&dothis=&reportid=15802.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2003-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-04-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Viet Nam", "country": "Vietnam"}, {"location": "Mekong Delta", "country": "Vietnam"}, {"location": "poultry.- Mod", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Phong Thanh", "country": "Vietnam"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3006388", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (122): Egypt (MN,BN) H5N1, fatalities", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3006388", "date": "2014-12-02 15:28:41", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (122): EGYPT (MINYA, BENI SUEF) H5N1, FATALITIES\n***********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Mon 1 Dec 2014\nSource: BBC News Middle East [edited]\nhttp://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-30283864\n\n\nEgypt's health ministry has said 3 people have died in the past week after contracting the H5N1 avian influenza virus. Egypt has now confirmed 11 cases of the virus in people this year [2014], including 6 who have died. The most recent victims were a 40-year-old man and a 29-year-old woman from the central province of Minya, and a 25-year-old woman in nearby Beni Suef. A 2-year-old girl who had the virus was meanwhile said to have recovered.\n\nH5N1 is a type of influenza virus that causes a highly infectious, severe respiratory disease in birds. Human cases of H5N1 avian influenza virus infection occur occasionally, but it is difficult to transmit the infection from person to person. When people do become infected, the mortality rate is about 60 percent. Between 2003 and October 2014 there were 668 confirmed human cases of H5N1 infection in 15 countries, leading to 393 deaths, according to the World Health Organization (WHO).\n\nEgypt has reported 177 of the confirmed cases and 63 of the deaths. The al-Ahram newspaper reported that emergency procedures were put in place at hospitals in November [2014] after 2 deaths in the same week -- a 30-year-old woman in Minya and a 19-year-old woman in Assiut.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Mon 1 Dec 2014\nSource: Xinhua News Agency [edited]\nhttp://news.xinhuanet.com/english/africa/2014-12/01/c_133825815.htm\n\n\nA Health Ministry statement said on [Mon 1 Dec 2014], 3 Egyptian women have died of H5N1 bird flu after coming into contact with infected birds. A 29-year-old woman from Minya province, south of Cairo, died on [Mon 1 Dec 2014] after suffering breathing difficulties and pneumonia, the statement said. 2 other women, aged 25 and 40, died in the Upper Egyptian province of Assiut. One of them worked in a bird farm. [This information is erroneous -- according to the report on the MOPH website, there have been 4 recent cases - a 2 year old girl in Minya who recovered, a 40 year old male in Minya who died, a 29 year old woman in Minya who died, and a 25 year old woman in Beni Suef who died. (see http://www.mohp.gov.eg/News_webpart/dispNews3.aspx?ID=580). - Mod.MPP]\n\nThe Health Ministry has confirmed a total of 11 cases this year [2014], including 6 deaths.\n\nThe statement urged people in direct contact with birds to go to the nearest hospital when feeling flu symptoms. It added there are stocks of the antiviral drug Tamiflu at hospitals across the country. Egypt's H5N1 infections usually take place in rural areas in the south of the country, where villagers, mostly women, breed and slaughter poultry in their homes.\n\nOn its website, the Ministry said the bird flu infection rate has dropped since 2012. Egypt reported 180 cases of bird flu in 2006-2012, of whom 66 died.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps of Egypt can be seen at http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Governorates_of_Egypt and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/55. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\nAccording to the WHO the overall public health risk assessment for avian influenza A(H5N1) viruses is the following: Whenever influenza viruses are circulating in poultry, sporadic infections or small clusters of human cases are possible, especially in people exposed to infected poultry or contaminated environments. Human infections remain rare and these influenza A(H5N1) viruses do not currently appear to transmit easily among people. As such, the risk of community-level spread of these viruses remains low.\n\nAn epidemiological curve of avian influenza A(H5N1) cases in humans by reporting country and month of onset is available at http://www.who.int/influenza/human_animal_interface/Influenza_Summary_IRA_HA_interface_October14.pdf?ua=1. This reveals an overall decline in case numbers, Egypt excepted. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "[This information is erroneous -- according to the report on the MOPH website, there have been 4 recent cases - a 2 year old girl in Minya who recovered, a 40 year old male in Minya who died, a 29 year old woman in Minya who died, and a 25 year old woman in Beni Suef who died. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\n Egypt reported 180 cases of bird flu in 2006-2012, of whom 66 died.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< The most recent victims were a 40-year-old man and a 29-year-old woman from the central province of Minya, and a 25-year-old woman in nearby Beni Suef. The statement notes the patient exhibited symptoms on Tue 11 Nov 2014, including fever, sore throat and cough, difficulty breathing and pain in the joints. She started treatment with Tamiflu. She was hospitalsed with double pneumonia and placed in intensive care several days later. She is reportedly in a stable condition.\n\nThe Ministry says this is the 7th H5N1 AI case this year [2014]; however, an additional case was reported earlier this year by the Beheira Ministry of Health, a regional health ministry, which would bring the count total to 8.\n\nThere have been 2 deaths attributed to the virus so far this year [2014] in Egypt.\n\n[Byline: Robert Herriman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[As yet, the WHO listing has not been updated to include the most recent cases in 2014, and the discrepancy in number of cases recorded by different Health Ministries in Egypt cannot be resolved at the present time. The characteristics of the cases are similar: Severe disease affecting mainly women (and often their children) who have been rearing flocks in their homes, and early death despite comprehensive treatment. The 19-year-old woman died in hospital in the region of Assiut in the south of the country. It was the 2nd death in Egypt this year [2014] out of a total of 7 confirmed cases, said Egyptian health officials.\n\nIt comes after several cases of birds infected with a different type of the virus were discovered in commercial farms in England, Germany, and the Netherlands. [H5N8 avian influenza virus in Germany and the Netherlands, and probably in England]. There have been 667 human cases of H5N1 worldwide since 2003, according to the World Health Organization (WHO). Egypt's health ministry said 2 other people were infected, according to Reuters news agency. One of them was a 3-year-old child who was recovering well in hospital and the other was a 30-year-old woman, the news agency added. Health ministry official Amr Kandil said the 1st death from H5N1 in Egypt this year [2014] had happened in June.\n\nH5N1 was first seen in a human patient in Hong Kong in 1993 but has since spread worldwide. It has a death rate of about 60 percent in humans.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[The current outbreaks of H5 high pathogenicity avian influenza virus infection affecting commercial poultry flocks in Germany and the Netherlands, (and now probably England) have been characterised as a strain of H5N8 avian influenza virus, probably originating in the Far East and transmitted by migratory birds.\n\nThe H5N1 virus responsible for current illness and death in Egypt, on the other hand, has been associated with sporadic human illness and deaths over a wide area particularly where domestic fowl are reared at home.\n\nAccording to the WHO (http://www.who.int/influenza/human_animal_interface/EN_GIP_20140124CumulativeNumberH5N1cases.pdf), Egypt ranks 2nd (after Indonesia) among the 15 countries where H5N1 avian influenza virus has been responsible for human cases (and deaths from) of avian H5N1 avian influenza virus infection. - Mod.CP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/37853.]", "summary": "Communicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[The current outbreaks of H5 high pathogenicity avian influenza virus infection affecting commercial poultry flocks in Germany and the Netherlands, (and now probably England) have been characterised as a strain of H5N8 avian influenza virus, probably originating in the Far East and transmitted by migratory birds.
