"https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2960328", "date": "2014-11-16 16:41:46", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (115): EGYPT (ASSIUT, AL MINYA) H5N1, NEW CASES\n****************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 16 Nov 2014\nSource: Avian Flu Diary [edited]\nhttp://afludiary.blogspot.ca/2014/11/egyptian-moh-two-new-h5n1-cases-minya.html\n\n\nIn what is turning out to be a bird-flu centric morning, we have an announcement from the Egyptian Ministry of Health on 2 new (apparently unrelated) human avian influenza H5N1 cases. The last case reported previously out of Egypt was in late September 2014 (Egyptian MOH: 4th H5N1 case of 2014).\n\n[While today's [16 Nov 2014] cases bring Egypt's total to 6 cases for the year, the FluTrackers website has an additional case confirmed by the regional (Beheira) Ministry of Health, which would bring the total to 7. In addition, the 2nd case mentioned above has a daughter who is being examined and tested for the virus.]\n\nThe Ministry of Health has announced the discovery of 2 cases of human infection with avian A/H5N1 influenza virus, thus bringing the number of cases of the disease during the current year to 6 cases, after the discovery of these 2 cases. The ministry said that the 1st case is a 3 year old child in Minoya Governorate and has already being exposed to birds at her home and is in good health and receiving treatment at a hospital in Minoya Governorate.\n\nAs for the 2nd case, the patient is a woman aged 19 in Assiut Governorate, who has been slaughtering birds at home after the deaths of several [of them]. She was admitted to one of the private clinics from where she was transferred to a hospital at Assiut University [and found to be suffering from] from double pneumonia. She is currently on a ventilator in critical condition and has been given a double dose of Tamiflu [oseltamivir] and remains under treatment.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[Avian influenza or 'bird flu' is an infectious disease of animals (usually birds, and less commonly pigs) caused by type A strains of the influenza virus. Transmission to humans is rare, but there is recent cause for concern. In mid-2003, the largest and most severe avian flu outbreak in history began in South East Asia, caused by a sub-type of the virus called H5N1 and resulting in widespread transmission to poultry and some documented transmission to humans. Transmission of H5N1 to humans is of particular concern because it mutates rapidly and may, therefore, change into a form that is highly infectious for humans and more easily spread. In addition, unlike normal seasonal influenza, H5N1 often causes severe disease in humans.\n\nThe cumulative number of confirmed human cases of avian influenza A(H5N1) reported to WHO, 2003-2014, can be found at http://www.who.int/influenza/human_animal_interface/EN_GIP_20140124CumulativeNumberH5N1cases.pdf?ua=1.\n\nA map of the governorates of Egypt can be accessed at http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Governorates_of_Egypt. - Mod.CP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/55.]", "summary": "\n\nThe Ministry of Health has announced the discovery of 2 cases of human infection with avian A/H5N1 influenza virus, thus bringing the number of cases of the disease during the current year to 6 cases, after the discovery of these 2 cases. In what is turning out to be a bird-flu centric morning, we have an announcement from the Egyptian Ministry of Health on 2 new (apparently unrelated) human avian influenza H5N1 cases. He was transferred to another hospital, and later put on a ventilator in a 3rd hospital where he died. His mother said he had had contact with sick birds, the spokesman added.\n\nOut of the 12 other surviving infected patients, 8 have been discharged and 4 others are still sick in hospital, Abdel Ghaffar said.\n\nAccording to the World Health Organization (WHO), from 2003 to 2 Oct 2014, 668 laboratory-confirmed human cases of H5N1 infection have been officially reported by 16 countries. Of these cases, 393 have died.\n\nWHO has warned that whenever bird flu viruses are circulating in poultry, there is a risk of sporadic infections or small clusters of human cases, especially in people exposed to infected birds or contaminated environments.\n\nEgypt's H5N1 cases have largely been in poor rural areas in the south, where villagers, particularly women, tend to keep and slaughter poultry in the home.\n\n[byline: Mahmoud Mourad and Ahmed Tolba]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[Indonesia and Egypt remain the only countries where human cases of H5N1 avian influenza is continuing to occur in the human population. In Egypt, H5N1 avian influenza virus occurs sporadically throughout the country and is associated with the breeding of poultry domestically. Transmission from human to human is rare. - Mod.CP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/12468.]", "summary": "\n\n[byline: Mahmoud Mourad and Ahmed Tolba]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[Indonesia and Egypt remain the only countries where human cases of H5N1 avian influenza is continuing to occur in the human population. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nWHO has warned that whenever bird flu viruses are circulating in poultry, there is a risk of sporadic infections or small clusters of human cases, especially in people exposed to infected birds or contaminated environments. A 5 year old Egyptian child died from bird flu on Wednesday [24 Dec 2014], the 10th death from the virus in the country out of 22 identified cases this year, the Health Ministry said. AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (132): EGYPT (ASWAN) H5N1, FATAL\n*******************************************************\n \n\nEgypt's H5N1 cases have largely been in poor rural areas in the south, where villagers, particularly women, tend to keep and slaughter poultry in the home.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2003-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-29 00:00:00", "2014-12-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Indonesia", "country": "Indonesia"}, {"location": "Egypt", "country": "Egypt"}, {"location": "Aswan", "country": "Egypt"}, {"location": "EGYPT", "country": "Egypt"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2916917", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (111): Indonesia (Jakarta), H5N1", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2916917", "date": "2014-10-30 18:10:56", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (111): INDONESIA (JAKARTA), H5N1\n*******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 30 Oct 20144\nSource: Liputan6 [in Indonesian, machine transl., summ., edited]\nhttp://health.liputan6.com/read/2126759/2-pasien-flu-burung-di-rs-sardjito-meninggal-dunia\n\n\nAvian Influenza Virus A(H5N1), human, Indonesia (Jakarta), fatal\n----------------------------------------------------------------\nIndonesia has reported 2 fatal cases of human infection with avian influenza virus A(H5N1). According to Liputan6.com, Jakarta Hospital Sardjito has reported a maximum of 2 patients diagnosed as avian influenza H5N1 cases. The 2 patients of Bantul origin diagnosed with bird flu have died. Consultant specialist pulmonary physicians said both patients had passed away on Saturday (25 Oct 2014). According to another hospital physician, both patients had been treated in isolation for about a week. One patient died of avian influenza early on Saturday and the other later in the day.\n\nDoctor Sumardi, the attending physician, admitted that handling cases of bird flu is very difficult and time-consuming. Because the disease is so deadly, bird flu patients respond to medical treatment poorly and few survive. Frequently their arrival is delayed and death is inevitable. Only one so far has survived in Jakarta hospital.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nGiuseppe Michieli\n<gimi69@libero.it>\n\n[According to the WHO table of confirmed human cases of avian influenza H5N1 virus infection, previously, since the 1st cases in 2003, there have been 197 cases, of whom 165 had fatal outcomes. Indonesia has been the most affected country in the world, possibly due to a high population density and the abundance of domestic poultry. ProMED-mail thanks Giuseppe Michieli for locating this report (http://www.who.int/influenza/human_animal_interface/EN_GIP_20140727CumulativeNumberH5N1cases.pdf?ua=1). - Mod.CP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/546.]", "summary": "Communicated by:\nGiuseppe Michieli\n<gimi69@libero.it>\n\n[According to the WHO table of confirmed human cases of avian influenza H5N1 virus infection, previously, since the 1st cases in 2003, there have been 197 cases, of whom 165 had fatal outcomes. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n [in Indonesian, machine transl., summ., edited]\nhttp://health.liputan6.com/read/2126759/2-pasien-flu-burung-di-rs-sardjito-meninggal-dunia\n\n\nAvian Influenza Virus A(H5N1), human, Indonesia (Jakarta), fatal\n \nIndonesia has reported 2 fatal cases of human infection with avian influenza virus A(H5N1). AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (111): INDONESIA (JAKARTA), H5N1\n*******************************************************\n According to Liputan6.com, Jakarta Hospital Sardjito has reported a maximum of 2 patients diagnosed as avian influenza H5N1 cases.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2003-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-27 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Indonesia", "country": "Indonesia"}, {"location": "Jakarta", "country": "Indonesia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2921788", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (112): Egypt, H5N1 seroprevalence", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2921788", "date": "2014-11-01 15:05:34", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (112): EGYPT, H5N1 SEROPREVALENCE\n********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 31 Oct 2014\nSource: CIDRAP News [abbreviated & edited]\nhttp://www.cidrap.umn.edu/news-perspective/2014/10/news-scan-oct-31-2014\n\n\nA 2-year serology study using stringent criteria found antibodies to H5N1 avian flu in 2.1 percent of Egyptians exposed to poultry, a finding that National Institutes of Health (NIH) officials said demonstrates that the virus poses a low pandemic risk.\n\nScientists from St. Jude Children's Research Hospital in Memphis, Tenn., and the National Research Center in Giza, Egypt, analyzed blood samples from 750 people with poultry exposure, 731 of whom were exposed to backyard poultry, according to their paper published in the Journal of Infectious Diseases [Oct 29 J Infect Dis http://jid.oxfordjournals.org/content/early/2014/10/25/infdis.jiu529]. Of those, 455 (61.3 percent) reported daily exposure to poultry. They also collected serum samples from 250 people who had no poultry exposure. To avoid the cross-reactivity that can result from antibodies to H1N1 and H3N2 viruses, the researchers considered an antibody titer of 80 or higher to indicate seropositivity, which matches the World Health Organization diagnostic criterion. Measurements were taken at baseline (from November 2010 to July 2011), one year later and 2 years later.\n\nThey found that 15 of 708 poultry-exposed volunteers (2.1 percent) had antibodies to H5N1 at baseline, with the prevalence dropping to 0.4 percent after one year and 0.6 percent after 2 years. The control group had no seropositive results at all 3 test times. The team also found that seropositive rates for H9N2 antibodies were 1.1 percent at baseline, 7.5 percent after one year, and 5.9 percent after 2 years, compared with 0 percent, 0.7 percent, and 1.0 percent in controls, respectively. Regarding their H5N1 findings, the authors conclude, 'This prevalence demonstrates that the number of cases is greatly underreported and that the case-fatality rate [CFR] is consequently greatly overestimated.' They note, however, that, given Egypt's low CFR, the results might not apply to other regions.\n\nIn an accompanying commentary [http://jid.oxfordjournals.org/content/early/2014/10/25/infdis.jiu530.short], David Morens, MD and Jeffery Taubenberger, MD, PhD of the NIH's National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, wrote: 'While it is important to be vigilant about the potential risks posed by all influenza viruses, including A(H5N1), and while we cannot conclude that the A(H5N1) risk is nonexistent, we see no compelling virologic or epidemiologic evidence to suggest that A(H5N1) or any other avian influenza virus is currently evolving toward human transmissibility, let alone pandemicity, or that such viruses are even capable of doing so.' They said that greater pandemic threats include reassortment of circulating H1N1 and H3N2 strains with zoonotic strains, lab release of the 1957 H2N2 pandemic strain, or evolving influenza strains in swine.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Marianne Hopp\n\n[A recent WHO listing of human cases of avian H5N1 influenza virus infection places Egypt 2nd among the 16 countries that have so far recorded human cases of avian H5N1 avian influenza. Egypt is ranked 2nd after Indonesia, another country where the population is frequently exposed to diseased fowl in domestic settings [see: http://www.who.int/influenza/human_animal_interface/EN_GIP_20140727CumulativeNumberH5N1cases.pdf?ua=1]. Nonetheless, the analysis referred to above is reassuring that no more than 2.1 percent of the Egyptian population may have responded to exposure to avian H5N1 virus infection.\n\nThe publication is entitled: Avian Influenza A(H5N1) and A(H9N2) Seroprevalence and Risk Factors for Infection Among Egyptians: A Prospective, Controlled serological study by Mokhtar R. Gomaa and 11 others. Their abstract reads:\n\n'- Background: A(H5N1) and A(H9N2) avian influenza viruses are enzootic in Egyptian poultry, and most A(H5N1) human cases since 2009 have occurred in Egypt. Our understanding of the epidemiology of avian viruses in humans remains limited. Questions about the frequency of infection, the proportion of infections that are mild or subclinical, and the case-fatality rate remain largely unanswered.\n- Methods: We conducted a 3-year, prospective, controlled, sero-epidemiological study that enrolled 750 poultry-exposed and 250 unexposed individuals in Egypt.\n- Results: At baseline, the seroprevalence of anti-A(H5N1) antibodies (titer, 80 or higher) among exposed individuals was 2 percent, significantly higher than that among the controls (0 percent). Having chronic lung disease was a significant risk factor for infection. Antibodies against A(H9N2) were not detected at baseline when A(H9N2) was not circulating in poultry. At follow-up, A(H9N2) was detected in poultry, and, consequently, the seroprevalence among exposed humans was between 5.6 percent and 7.5 percent. Vaccination of poultry, older age, and exposure to ducks were risk factors for A(H9N2) infection.\n- Conclusions: Results of this study indicate that the number of humans infected with avian influenza viruses is much larger than the number of reported confirmed cases. In an area where these viruses are enzootic in poultry, human exposure to and infection with avian influenza becomes more common.' - Mod.CP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/55.]", "summary": "The team also found that seropositive rates for H9N2 antibodies were 1.1 percent at baseline, 7.5 percent after one year, and 5.9 percent after 2 years, compared with 0 percent, 0.7 percent, and 1.0 percent in controls, respectively. \n\nThey found that 15 of 708 poultry-exposed volunteers (2.1 percent) had antibodies to H5N1 at baseline, with the prevalence dropping to 0.4 percent after one year and 0.6 percent after 2 years. Source: CIDRAP News [abbreviated & edited]\nhttp://www.cidrap.umn.edu/news-perspective/2014/10/news-scan-oct-31-2014\n\n\nA 2-year serology study using stringent criteria found antibodies to H5N1 avian flu in 2.1 percent of Egyptians exposed to poultry, a finding that National Institutes of Health (NIH) officials said demonstrates that the virus poses a low pandemic risk. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Marianne Hopp\n\n[A recent WHO listing of human cases of avian H5N1 influenza virus infection places Egypt 2nd among the 16 countries that have so far recorded human cases of avian H5N1 avian influenza. In an accompanying commentary [http://jid.oxfordjournals.org/content/early/2014/10/25/infdis.jiu530.short], David Morens, MD and Jeffery Taubenberger, MD, PhD of the NIH's National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, wrote: 'While it is important to be vigilant about the potential risks posed by all influenza viruses, including A(H5N1), and while we cannot conclude that the A(H5N1) risk is nonexistent, we see no compelling virologic or epidemiologic evidence to suggest that A(H5N1) or any other avian influenza virus is currently evolving toward human transmissibility, let alone pandemicity, or that such viruses are even capable of doing so.' : At baseline, the seroprevalence of anti-A(H5N1) antibodies (titer, 80 or higher) among exposed individuals was 2 percent, significantly higher than that among the controls (0 percent). In an area where these viruses are enzootic in poultry, human exposure to and infection with avian influenza becomes more common.'", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2010-11-25 00:00:00", "2011-07-25 00:00:00", "2009-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00", "1957-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Memphis", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Indonesia", "country": "Indonesia"}, {"location": "Egypt", "country": "Egypt"}, {"location": "EGYPT", "country": "Egypt"}, {"location": "Giza", "country": "Egypt"}, {"location": "Tenn.", "country": "Austria"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2822498", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (107): Egypt (JZ) H5N1, infant", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2822498", "date": "2014-10-01 23:51:17", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (107): EGYPT (GIZA), H5N1, INFANT\n********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 30 Sep 2014\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/egypt-reports-human-h5n1-avian-flu-in-giza-infant-58305/\n\n\nThe Egyptian Minister of Health and Population, Dr. Adel Adawi, announced a human case of H5N1 avian influenza (AI) in a 3-month-old girl from the Giza governorate. According to the Minister, the date of onset of the illness was Monday, 22 Sep 2014; she was presenting symptoms of fever, sore throat, cough and vomiting.\n\nThe girl's parents took her to the Hospital of the Abbasid, and she was released 3 days later. They said the child had exposure to dead birds. A throat sample was taken and analyzed and confirmed positive for avian influenza virus (A/H5N1). The child was treated with Tamiflu and is reportedly in stable condition.\n\nAccording to the Health Ministry, this is the 4th human H5N1 AI case of 2014. However, the people at FluTrackers point out that this is the 5th case of the bird flu, writing on their site: 'We have a record of 4 previous cases. 3 were announced by the Ministry of Health of Egypt, and one was announced by the Ministry of Health of Beheira governorate:\n\nNo. 14 Egypt - Female, 56, hospitalized in critical condition,\nNo. 15 Egypt - Child, 4, mild condition,\nNo. 16 Egypt - Female, 86, hospitalized in serious condition and\nNo. 19 Egypt - Male, 34, hospitalized on ventilator, Death.'\n\nSee: http://www.flutrackers.com/forum/sho...d.php?t=217148.\n\n[Byline: Robert Herriman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nNati Elkin\n<natielkin@gmail.com>\n\n[Avian influenza or 'bird flu' is an infectious disease of animals (usually birds, and less commonly pigs) caused by type A strains of the influenza virus. Transmission to humans is rare, but there is recent cause for concern. In mid-2003, the largest and most severe avian flu outbreak in history began in South-east Asia, caused by a sub-type of the virus called H5N1 and resulting in widespread transmission to poultry and some documented transmission to humans. Transmission of H5N1 to humans is of particular concern because it mutates rapidly and may therefore change into a form that is highly infectious for humans and more easily spread. In addition, unlike normal seasonal influenza, H5N1 can cause severe disease in humans.\n\nThe cumulative number of confirmed human cases of avian influenza A(H5N1) reported to WHO, 2003-2014, can be found at http://www.who.int/influenza/human_animal_interface/EN_GIP_20140124CumulativeNumberH5N1cases.pdf?ua=1. - Mod.CP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/55.]", "summary": "Communicated by:\nNati Elkin\n<natielkin@gmail.com>\n\n[Avian influenza or 'bird flu' is an infectious disease of animals (usually birds, and less commonly pigs) caused by type A strains of the influenza virus. "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2014-09-30 00:00:00", "1975-03-25 00:00:00", "2012-12-25 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2571119", "date": "2014-06-28 15:03:18", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA HUMAN (103): EGYPT, H5N1\n****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 26 Jun 2014\nSource: Egypt Independent [edited]\nhttp://www.egyptindependent.com//news/health-ministry-man-catches-bird-flu-minya\n\n\nThe Ministry of Health and Population announced that a 34-year-old man in Minya [Al Minya governorate, Egypt] has been inflected with the A(H5N1) virus known as bird flu.\n\nIt added the patient was currently on a ventilator at hospital and his condition was unstable.\n\nThe ministry said in a statement on Wednesday evening [25 Jun 2014] that it has taken preventive measures once the case was suspected and isolated the patient in Minya Fever Hospital. A sample for the patient was sent to Cairo labs for analysis, and his infection with bird flu was confirmed, according to results.\n\nA team from the Preventive Medicine Sector was dispatched to the patient's residence in Minya, the statement said. His wife and children were inspected, and they are in good health and have no bird flu symptoms, according to the statement. They will be reinspected after 10 days, it added.\n\nThe patient was transferred to a Cairo hospital in Abbasiya and placed on a ventilator, said the statement.\n\nEgypt has not witnessed bird flu cases since April 2013 [there were 2 cases of human avian influenza A(H5N1) reported by Egypt in March 2014; see below for more details - Mods.AB/MPP], according to the Health Ministry.\n\n[Edited translation from Al-Masry Al-Youm]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[After over 2 months without any occurrence of avian influenza H5N1 in Egypt, this post should be considered as a new alert pointing fingers to the possible comeback of the disease in humans in the country. In March 2014, there were 2 cases of human influenza A(H5N1) infection reported by Egypt -- one in a 56-year-old female resident of Behaira governerate, the other a 4-year-old male in Damitta governerate -- both had a history of exposure to dead and sick poultry (see prior ProMED-mail posts Avian influenza, human (91): Egypt, H5N1 20140406.2385849 and Avian influenza, human (88): Egypt, H5N1, RFI 20140324.2353435 and http://who.int/influenza/human_animal_interface/Influenza_Summary_IRA_HA_interface_24March14.pdf?ua=1 for more details). As every human case can only originate from epizootics taking place in birds, one should review the situation of bird flu in the country between April 2014 and now. At the onset of the 1st influenza H5N1 epizootics in domestic birds in February 2006, Minya governorate was considered as one of the most heavily affected governorates in Egypt, according to a mission conducted by Mod.AB for WHO. Given the type of husbandry of chicken and ducks in and around this region and the high density of animals as well as their proximity to households, residual foci of the infection may have persisted in the area, making the bird population from Minya a continuous source of infection to other birds and to humans.\n\nIncluding this newly reported case, since 2006 when the 1st cases were reported, there have been a total of 176 cases of human infection with influenza A(H1N5) virus including 63 deaths in Egypt (see http://www.who.int/influenza/human_animal_interface/EN_GIP_20131210CumulativeNumberH5N1cases.pdf).\n\nA map of Egypt showing Minya can be accessed at: https://www.google.com/maps/place/Al+Minya/@28.0952232,30.7507212,13z/data=!3m1!4b1!4m2!3m1!1s0x145b2501ca8ed45f:0x1682970743a18080. For a map of Egypt showing governorates, see http://www.ephotopix.com/egypt_governorate_map.html. A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/2658. - Mods.AB/MPP]", "summary": "infection reported by Egypt -- one in a 56-year-old female resident of Behaira governerate, the other a 4-year-old male in Damitta governerate -- both had a history of exposure to dead and sick poultry (see prior ProMED-mail posts Avian influenza, human (91): Egypt, H5N1 20140406.2385849 and Avian influenza, human (88): Egypt, H5N1, RFI 20140324.2353435 and http://who.int/influenza/human_animal_interface/Influenza_Summary_IRA_HA_interface_24March14.pdf?ua=1 for more details). A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nIncluding this newly reported case, since 2006 when the 1st cases were reported, there have been a total of 176 cases of human infection with influenza A(H1N5) virus including 63 deaths in Egypt (see http://www.who.int/influenza/human_animal_interface/EN_GIP_20131210CumulativeNumberH5N1cases.pdf). At the onset of the 1st influenza H5N1 epizootics in domestic birds in February 2006, Minya governorate was considered as one of the most heavily affected governorates in Egypt, according to a mission conducted by Mod.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1988-03-25 00:00:00", "2013-04-25 00:00:00", "1991-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-06-25 00:00:00", "2006-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00", "2006-02-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Abbasiya", "country": "Israel"}, {"location": "Behaira", "country": "Egypt"}, {"location": "EGYPT", "country": "Egypt"}, {"location": "Cairo", "country": "Egypt"}, {"location": "Egypt", "country": "Egypt"}, {"location": "Minya", "country": "Egypt"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2497716", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (97): Indonesia (JT) H5N1", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2497716", "date": "2014-05-25 18:11:57", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (97): INDONESIA (CENTRAL JAVA) H5N1\n**********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 22 May 2014\nSource: Center for Infectious Disease Research and Policy (CIDRAP) [edited]\nhttp://www.cidrap.umn.edu/news-perspective/2014/05/news-scan-may-22-2014\n\n\nA 2 year old boy died of H5N1 avian flu in Indonesia last month [April 2014], WHO said in an update posted yesterday [21 May 2014].\n\nThe boy, from Central Java [Jawa Tengah province], 1st had symptoms on [10 Apr 2014], was hospitalized [13 Apr 2014], and died [20 Apr 2014], WHO said in its most recent 'Influenza at the Human-Animal Interface' report, dated [5 May 2014]. 'In the weeks before disease onset of the child, some backyard chickens died around the house,' the report said.\n\nThe boy's death represents the 1st case of H5N1 this year [2014] in Indonesia, a country that has seen as many as 55 confirmed cases in a year (in 2006), but last year reported only 3.\n\nIn the report, WHO placed the global number of lab-confirmed H5N1 cases since 2003 at 665, 392 of which have been fatal. That number represents 15 new cases and 6 newly reported deaths since the agency last updated its case count, on [24 Jan 2014].\n\nThe 15 cases not included in WHO's [24 Jan 2014] count reflect 9 in Cambodia, 3 in Egypt, and 1 each in Canada, Vietnam, and China, according to previous news reports. In addition, Hong Kong officials on [25 Feb 2014] reported an H5 infection in a child in mainland China but did not issue a follow-up report about the specific strain.\n\n[5 May 2014] WHO report: http://www.who.int/influenza/human_animal_interface/Influenza_Summary_IRA_HA_interface_5May14.pdf\n[24 Jan 2014] WHO global case count: http://www.who.int/influenza/human_animal_interface/H5N1_cumulative_table_archives/en/\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[As mentioned above, this is the 1st reported case of human infection with influenza A, H5N1 in Indonesia this year (2014). Since 2003, Indonesia has reported 195 human cases of H5N1 infection, including 163 deaths.\n\nIn 2014, ProMED-mail has reported on human infections with H5N1 in a Canadian with a history of visiting China, Egypt and Viet Nam in January; in Viet Nam, China and Cambodia in February; in Cambodia and Egypt in March; and in Egypt in April (see prior ProMED-mail posts below).\n\nFor a map of Indonesia, see http://healthmap.org/promed/p/184. Maps showing the locations of human cases of H5N1 can be found at http://gamapserver.who.int/mapLibrary/app/searchResults.aspx. - Mod.MPP]", "summary": "\n\nThe boy, from Central Java [Jawa Tengah province], 1st had symptoms on [10 Apr 2014], was hospitalized [13 Apr 2014], and died [20 Apr 2014], WHO said in its most recent 'Influenza at the Human-Animal Interface' report, dated [5 May 2014]. The following types of birds were affected: chickens, ducks and geese. The samples were collected according to the requirements of the national surveillance plan. The samples tested positive. See details of each outbreak in the URL above. - Mod.CRD]\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: quarantine; movement control inside the country; screening; zoning; disinfection of infected premises/establishment(s); dipping/spraying; no vaccination; no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nHarbin veterinary research institute, Chinese academy of agricultural sciences (OIE's Reference Laboratory) / Birds / reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) / 15 Sep 2014 / Positive\nHarbin veterinary research institute, Chinese academy of agricultural sciences (OIE's Reference Laboratory) / Birds / virus isolation / 15 Sep 2014 / Positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[With these additional strains, 5 HPAI subtypes have now been identified in China: H5N1, H5N2, H5N3, H5N6 and H5N8.\n\nThe detection of HPAI H5N3, within the commendable surveillance efforts on China's live bird markets, is unusual. Most H5N3 strains known to be detected (in wild or domestic birds) were designated as of low pathogenicity. It would be interesting to obtain details on the tests performed on the current isolate from a duck. No HPAI H5N3 could be found among earlier postings in the ProMED-mail archive. A Danish report on H5N3 (2006) was eventually found to be H5N2 (see ProMED- mail report 20060623.1740).\n\nAccording to the HPAI H5N1 report provided by China, the following control measures were applied: quarantine; movement control inside the country; screening; zoning; disinfection of infected premises/establishment(s); dipping/spraying; no vaccination; no treatment of affected animals.\n\nGiven that these 16 H5N1 outbreaks were associated with the live bird and local trade markets, it would be both interesting and useful to know how the quarantine and zoning measures are actually being applied to manage these cases.\n\nThe OIE uses the following definitions:\n- Quarantine: means that infected establishments are placed under quarantine with a standstill on the animals therein until all sanitary measures considered necessary to eradicate the disease have been completed.\n- Zoning: means a delineation (by regulatory means) of free, surveillance and/or buffer, and infected zones within the country for disease control purposes.\n\nIt would also be useful to know how the control measures of 'dipping and spraying' are applied since these measures are generally used to control parasites and potential vectors.\n\nIn addition, during this week, China sent follow-up repots for their H5N2 and H5N6 high pathogenicity events.\n\nFor the H5N2 event, 10 outbreaks have been reported. See follow-up report No. 3 at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/temp/reports/en_fup_0000016061_20141024_184114.pdf. See also the event summary and updated map at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?reportid=14553.\n\nFor the H5N6 event, 25 outbreaks have been reported. See follow up report No. 2 at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/temp/reports/en_fup_0000016060_20141024_193420.pdf. See also event summary and updated map at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?reportid=15957.\n\nFinally, regarding their low pathogenicity AI H7N9 event, only 43 outbreaks have been reported through July 2014.\n\nSee the last official follow up report at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/temp/reports/en_fup_0000015547_20140709_121859.pdf. However, animals and human cases continue being reported; see ProMED mail report 20141020.2882752 and 20140919.2788651. - Mods.CRD/AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/155.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n infected establishments are placed under quarantine with a standstill on the animals therein until all sanitary measures considered necessary to eradicate the disease have been completed. "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2550053", "date": "2014-06-18 18:11:48", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (102): INDONESIA, H5N1\n*********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: 18 Apr 2014\nSource: Jakarta Post [edited]\nhttp://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2014/06/18/avian-flu-claims-victim-jakarta.html\n\n\nThe Health Ministry has confirmed the 2nd case of human infection from avian influenza H5N1 in the country this year [2014], which claimed the life of a 33-year-old man in Jakarta.\n\nThe ministry's health research and development center head, Tjandra Yoga Aditama, said that the victim was pronounced dead at Pondok Kopi Islamic Hospital, East Jakarta, last month [May 2014].\n\n'The laboratory confirmed the H5N1 [infection], based on real-time and conventional PCR [polymerase chain reaction] diagnostics on the victim's specimen,' he said in a press statement released on Tuesday [17 Jun 2014].\n\nIt is the 2nd laboratory-confirmed case of human infection of avian influenza following a case in Wonogiri, Central Java.\n\nOn [20 Apr 2014], a 2-year-old toddler died of avian flu following exposure to live poultry. An inquiry by the Health Ministry found that prior to RNA's death, almost 70 chickens had died from apparent avian flu infection.\n\nAccording to Tjandra, there have been 17 confirmed cases worldwide of avian flu in humans this year [2014]. Cambodia has recorded the most so far, with 9 cases, while Indonesia, Egypt, Viet Nam and China have recorded 2 cases each.\n\nCumulatively, Indonesia has witnessed 197 cases of humans infected with avian flu, making it the nation with the highest number of H5N1 human infection cases to date. Egypt and Viet Nam follow with 175 cases and 127 cases, respectively.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[As mentioned above, this is the 2nd reported case of human infection with influenza A, H5N1 in Indonesia this year (2014). Since 2003, Indonesia has reported 197 human cases of H5N1 infection, including 164 deaths.\n\nAccording to the most recent H5N1 human case summary report from WHO dated 5 May 2014, since 2003 through 5 May 2014, there were 665 laboratory-confirmed human cases of avian influenza A(H5N1) virus infection from 15 countries that were officially reported to WHO, including 392 deaths (see http://who.int/influenza/human_animal_interface/Influenza_Summary_IRA_HA_interface_5May14.pdf?ua=1).\n\nIn 2014, ProMED-mail has reported on human infections with H5N1 in a Canadian with a history of visiting China, Egypt and Viet Nam in January 2014; in Viet Nam, China and Cambodia in February 2014; in Cambodia and Egypt in March 2014; in Egypt in April 2014 and in Indonesia in May 2014 (see prior ProMED-mail posts below).\n\nFor a map of Indonesia, see http://healthmap.org/promed/p/184. Maps showing the locations of human cases of H5N1 can be found at http://gamapserver.who.int/mapLibrary/app/searchResults.aspx. - Mod.MPP]", "summary": "\n\nIn 2014, ProMED-mail has reported on human infections with H5N1 in a Canadian with a history of visiting China, Egypt and Viet Nam in January 2014; in Viet Nam, China and Cambodia in February 2014; in Cambodia and Egypt in March 2014; in Egypt in April 2014 and in Indonesia in May 2014 (see prior ProMED-mail posts below). H5N1 susp, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2396190", "date": "2014-04-10 17:23:13", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (48): NORTH KOREA (PYONGYANG) HPAI H5N1 SUSPECTED, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n******************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 9 Apr 2014\nSource: Yonhap News Agency [edited]\nhttp://english.yonhapnews.co.kr/national/2014/04/09/0302000000AEN20140409005400315.html\n\n\nNorth Korea has experienced an outbreak of bird flu [avian influenza] since last month [March 2014], culling tens of thousands of poultry so far, its news agency said on Wed [9 Apr 2014].\n\nA chicken farm in the capital city of Pyongyang first reported symptoms of avian influenza (AI), known as the H5N1 virus, on 21 Mar 2014, and the virus has been spreading to other poultry farms, the North's Korean Central News Agency (KCNA) reported, citing director Ri Kyung-kun of its agricultural ministry. '(We) are suffering from extensive economic damage as tens of thousands (of poultry) have either fallen dead or been culled,' the KCNA said.\n\nAs part of efforts to contain the highly contagious virus, the North Korean authorities 'set up an emergency quarantine commission and declared an emergency prevention situation across the nation,' the report added. '(The government) has controlled traffic, come up with quarantine measures, and buried the culled. But the disease shows no sign of dying down and continues to spread,' the KCNA said.\n\nNorth Korea sustained extensive damage by AI last year [2013].\n\nEarlier this year [2014], South Korea also experienced an outbreak of the highly contagious virus, the first since 2011. More than 10 million poultry have been destroyed to prevent the disease from spreading, with the government testing samples from pig and dog farms to confirm it's spread to different species.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[An official immediate notification to the OIE on the suspected H5N1 outbreak(s) described, including details of diagnostic methods and control measures applied, is anticipated. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/23344.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nA chicken farm in the capital city of Pyongyang first reported symptoms of avian influenza (AI), known as the H5N1 virus, on 21 Mar 2014, and the virus has been spreading to other poultry farms, the North's Korean Central News Agency (KCNA) reported, citing director Ri Kyung-kun of its agricultural ministry. "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (88): EGYPT, H5N1, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n*****************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 23 Mar 2014\nSource: The Global Dispatch [edited]\nhttp://www.theglobaldispatch.com/egypt-reports-two-human-h5n1-avian-influenza-cases-73227/\n\n\nAccording to a report in the Egypt Independent today, 2 people, an adult woman and a child, have tested positive for H5N1 avian influenza.\n\nAccording to the report by Al-Masry Al-Youm [newspaper], 'A 56-year-old woman in Beheira's Damanhour, and a 4-year-old child in Damietta, who are in critical condition, have been transferred to ICU and administered Tamiflu treatment.\n\n'These 2 patients are the 1st bird flu cases to be discovered since April 2013.'\n\nThere is no notice of the infections on the Egyptian Health Ministry website as of this publication.\n\nAs Avian Flu Diary blogger, Mike Coston noted in a post Friday [21 Mar 2014] concerning the precipitous drop in cases in Egypt in recent years: 'After reporting the most human infections with the H5N1 virus for 4 years running (2009=39, 2010=29, 2011=39, 2012=11), the reported number of cases out of Egypt plummeted last year (2013) to only 4.'\n\nAccording to the WHO, the primary risk factor for human infection with the virus appears to be direct or indirect exposure to infected live or dead poultry or contaminated environments.\n\nThey go on to say there is no evidence to suggest that the H5N1 virus can be transmitted to humans through properly prepared poultry or eggs. A few human cases have been linked to consumption of dishes made of raw, contaminated poultry blood. However, slaughter, defeathering, handling carcasses of infected poultry, and preparing poultry for consumption, especially in household settings, are likely to be risk factors.\n\n[Byline: Robert Herriman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-EAFR\n<promed-eafr@promedmail.org>\n\n[According to the WHO Influenza at the human-animal interface Summary and assessment as of [25 Feb 2014] (available at http://who.int/influenza/human_animal_interface/Influenza_Summary_IRA_HA_interface_25Feburary14.pdf?ua=1), during the period 2003 to [25 Feb 2014], there were 658 laboratory-confirmed human cases of avian influenza A(H5N1) virus infection reported including 388 deaths, from a total of 15 countries that have been reported to WHO. During the period 2005 through the beginning of 2014, there have been a total of 173 laboratory confirmed cases of human avian influenza A(H5N1) virus infection including 63 deaths reported by Egypt (see http://who.int/influenza/human_animal_interface/EN_GIP_20140124CumulativeNumberH5N1cases.pdf?ua=1 for a table showing the cumulative number of confirmed human cases of avian influenza A(H5N1) reported to WHO, 2003-2014). (This table is current as of 24 Jan 2014 and does not include cases confirmed in Viet Nam (1), Cambodia (9), and China (2) since 24 Jan 2014).\n\nAs the media report above suggests, Egypt had been reporting 20+ cases annually up through 2012, when there were 11 cases (including 5 deaths) and 2013 when there were 4 cases (including 3 deaths) reported. As with other more eastern Asian countries reporting cases of human avian influenza A(H5N1) infections, most cases were associated with 'backyard flocks' of poultry, where human cases were associated with retrospectively identified poultry die-offs. We await further information on contact histories of these 2 newly confirmed cases in Egypt.\n\nFor a map of Egypt showing governorates, see http://www.ephotopix.com/egypt_governorate_map.html.\nDamanhur is the capital of the Beheira Governorate (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Damanhur) and is located 160 km (99 mi) northwest of Cairo, and 70 km (43 mi) east/southeast of Alexandria in the middle of the western Nile Delta (see no. 2 on the map above).\nDamietta, also known as Damiata, or Domyat, (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Damietta) is the capital of the Damietta Governorate, located at the Damietta branch of the Nile, 15 km (9.3 mi) from the Mediterranean Sea, about 200 km (120 mi) north of Cairo (see no 9 on the referenced map above).\nFor the HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Egypt, see http://healthmap.org/promed/p/55.\n\nOf note, earlier this year (2014), ProMED-mail reported on media reports of cases of human avian influenza A(H5N1) infections in Dakahlia governorate in Egypt (see Avian influenza, human (25): Egypt (DK) H5N1, RFI 20140120.2184238). These cases were never confirmed by official sources. (Dakahlia governorate is no 8 on the map of Egypt showing governorates mentioned above, and neighbors with Damietta Governorate). - Mod.MPP]", "summary": "Communicated by:\nProMED-EAFR\n<promed-eafr@promedmail.org>\n\n[According to the WHO Influenza at the human-animal interface Summary and assessment as of [25 Feb 2014] (available at http://who.int/influenza/human_animal_interface/Influenza_Summary_IRA_HA_interface_25Feburary14.pdf?ua=1), during the period 2003 to [25 Feb 2014], there were 658 laboratory-confirmed human cases of avian influenza A(H5N1) virus infection reported including 388 deaths, from a total of 15 countries that have been reported to WHO. During the period 2005 through the beginning of 2014, there have been a total of 173 laboratory confirmed cases of human avian influenza A(H5N1) virus infection including 63 deaths reported by Egypt (see http://who.int/influenza/human_animal_interface/EN_GIP_20140124CumulativeNumberH5N1cases.pdf?ua=1 for a table showing the cumulative number of confirmed human cases of avian influenza A(H5N1) reported to WHO, 2003-2014). \n\nAs Avian Flu Diary blogger, Mike Coston noted in a post Friday [21 Mar 2014] concerning the precipitous drop in cases in Egypt in recent years: 'After reporting the most human infections with the H5N1 virus for 4 years running (2009=39, 2010=29, 2011=39, 2012=11), the reported number of cases out of Egypt plummeted last year (2013) to only 4.' As with other more eastern Asian countries reporting cases of human avian influenza A(H5N1) infections, most cases were associated with 'backyard flocks' of poultry, where human cases were associated with retrospectively identified poultry die-offs. \n\nOf note, earlier this year (2014), ProMED-mail reported on media reports of cases of human avian influenza A(H5N1) infections in Dakahlia governorate in Egypt (see Avian influenza, human (25): Egypt (DK) H5N1, RFI 20140120.2184238). \n\nAs the media report above suggests, Egypt had been reporting 20+ cases annually up through 2012, when there were 11 cases (including 5 deaths) and 2013 when there were 4 cases (including 3 deaths) reported. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n (This table is current as of 24 Jan 2014 and does not include cases confirmed in Viet Nam (1), Cambodia (9), and China (2) since 24 Jan 2014). \n\n'These 2 patients are the 1st bird flu cases to be discovered since April 2013.' movement control inside the country; screening; disinfection of infected premises/establishment(s); no vaccination; no treatment of affected animals.\n\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results:\nLaboratory name and type: Central Veterinary Laboratory and Veterinary Research Institute (National laboratory)\nSpecies / Test / Test date / Result\nBirds / polymerase chain reaction (PCR) / 26 Mar 2014 / Positive\n\nFuture Reporting:\nThe event is continuing. The outbreak was resolved in December 2008. These were located in the provinces of Phongsaly (1 outbreak) and Vientiane Capital (1 outbreak). It is noteworthy that if HPAI is one of the trans-boundary animal diseases having a significant impact in both trade and human health, it is not a notifiable disease in the country and no surveillance is being done as a basic control measure.\n\nBased on the information Laos provided the OIE, it begs the question of whether or not the disease has been present prior to this reported event in this and other provinces. She is being treated with Tamiflu.\n\nThis human H5N1 avian flu case follows 2 confirmed cases 2 weeks ago (one case was from Damanhur also) (see prior ProMED-mail post Avian influenza, human (88): Egypt, H5N1, RFI 20140324.2353435 for details).\n\nSince 2006, Egypt has reported 175 (not including this current case) cases of human H5N1 bird flu with 63 deaths (Case fatality ratio - 36 percent).\n\nAccording to the WHO, the primary risk factor for human infection with the virus appears to be direct or indirect exposure to infected live or dead poultry or contaminated environments.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[In the most recent WHO Influenza at the Human Animal Interface monthly Summary and assessment as of 24 March 2014 there was confirmation of the 2 cases reported in ProMED-mail post Avian influenza, human (88): Egypt, H5N1, RFI 20140324.2353435. (see\nhttp://www.who.int/influenza/human_animal_interface/Influenza_Summary_IRA_HA_interface_24March14.pdf?ua=1 for the full report).\n\nIn this summary report, during the period 2003 to [24 Mar 2014], there were 664 laboratory-confirmed human cases of avian influenza A(H5N1) virus infection reported including 391 deaths, from a total of 15 countries that have been reported to WHO. This represents an increase of 6 cases and 3 deaths since the last report (as of 25 Feb 2014). Of note, all 6 of the cases reported in the past month have a history of exposure to dead or sick poultry. During the period 2005 through the beginning of 2014, there have been a total of 173 laboratory confirmed cases of human avian influenza A(H5N1) virus infection including 63 deaths reported by Egypt (see http://who.int/influenza/human_animal_interface/EN_GIP_20140124CumulativeNumberH5N1cases.pdf?ua=1 for a table showing the cumulative number of confirmed human cases of avian influenza A(H5N1) reported to WHO, 2003-2014). (This table is current as of 24 Jan 2014 and does not include cases confirmed in Egypt (2), Viet Nam (1), Cambodia (13), and China (2) since 24 Jan 2014). With the addition of this current case and the 2 cases reported last month (March 2014) the total number of cases of human avian influenza A(H5N1) reported in Egypt will increase to 176 including 63 deaths.\n\n\nFor a map of Egypt showing governorates, see http://www.ephotopix.com/egypt_governorate_map.html.\nDamanhur is the capital of the Beheira Governorate (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Damanhur) and is located 160 km (99 mi) northwest of Cairo, and 70 km (43 mi) east/southeast of Alexandria in the middle of the western Nile Delta (see no. 2 on the map above).\nFor the HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Egypt, see http://healthmap.org/promed/p/55. - Mod.MPP]", "summary": "During the period 2005 through the beginning of 2014, there have been a total of 173 laboratory confirmed cases of human avian influenza A(H5N1) virus infection including 63 deaths reported by Egypt (see http://who.int/influenza/human_animal_interface/EN_GIP_20140124CumulativeNumberH5N1cases.pdf?ua=1 for a table showing the cumulative number of confirmed human cases of avian influenza A(H5N1) reported to WHO, 2003-2014). Contact with wild species cannot be excluded. Note by the OIE Animal Health Information Department: H5 and H7 avian influenza in its low pathogenic form in poultry is a notifiable disease as per Chapter 10.4. on avian influenza of the Terrestrial Animal Health Code (2013).\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: stamping out; screening; zoning; disinfection of infected premises/establishment(s); vaccination prohibited; no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nFriedrich-Loeffler Institute (national laboratory) / Birds / real-time (PCR) / 11 Mar 2014 / positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. "2014-03-10 16:32:25", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (83): CAMBODIA (KAMPONG CHHNANG, KANDAL) H5N1, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n*********************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 10 Mar 2014\nSource: The Phnom Penh Post [edited]\nhttp://www.phnompenhpost.com/national/boy-11-dies-avian-flu-hospital-doctor\n\n\nFollowing the death of a 3-year-old due to avian flu on [2 Mar 2014], an 11-year-old boy died in Phnom Penh's Kantha Bopha Hospital on Friday [7 Mar 2014], a hospital representative said yesterday [9 Mar 2014].\n\nThe boy, from Kampong Chhnang province, was one of 2 admitted to the hospital last week [week of 3 Mar 2014] suffering from H5N1 [avian influenza], according to Dr Denis Laurent.\n\n'The good news is that the 8-year-old boy from Kandal province is in stable condition,' Laurent said.\n\nSok Touch, director of the Ministry of Health's communicable diseases control department, and deputy director Ly Sovann, could not be reached yesterday [9 Mar 2014].\n\nVicky Houssiere, a spokeswoman for the World Health Organization in Cambodia, declined to confirm the 2 new cases of H5N1.\n\n'We can't confirm any new cases before the Ministry of Health releases a statement,' Houssiere said.\n\nThe news from Kantha Bopha comes on the heels of a joint statement released by ministry officials and the WHO on Friday [7 Mar 2014], announcing the death of a 3-year-old boy, who was the 6th confirmed case of avian influenza in Cambodia this year [2014], and the 53rd person to become infected.\n\nThe boy, from Chom Chao commune in the capital's [Phnom Penh] Por Sen Chey district, was admitted to the National Pediatric Hospital on [28 Feb 2014], and transferred to Calmette Hospital on [2 Mar 2014], where he died an hour later, says Friday's [7 Mar 2014] statement from the Ministry of Health and WHO.\n\n'In mid-February [2014], over 90 per cent of the chickens and small numbers of ducks suddenly died in the village,' the press release details.\n\n'The boy was often going to a neighbour's house where their poultry died. The relatives reported that the boy had no direct contact but the chickens died in close proximity to the house of the case.'\n\nWhile 3 cases were confirmed in Phnom Penh last year [2013], this case marks the 1st in the capital this year [2014], Houssiere wrote in an email yesterday [9 Mar 2014].\n\nAt least 22 cases of bird flu in Cambodia were recorded by the Ministry of Health last year [2013], more than any previous year.\n\n[Byline: Amelia Woodside]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[The Phnom Penh post is usually a reliable media source for information on health events occurring in Cambodia. When these cases are officially confirmed by the MOH (usually with laboratory confirmation from the Pasteur Institute in Cambodia) these will be the 7th and 8th cases of human H5N1 infection in Cambodia this year (2014). All confirmed human cases of H5N1 infection in Cambodia this year (2014) have been in children, and all have had a history of exposure to sick or dead poultry.\n\nMore information on these cases from official sources would be appreciated, including history of exposure to sick or dead poultry.\n\nFor a map of Cambodia showing provinces, see http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/7/7e/Cambodia,_administrative_divisions_-_de_-_colored.svg. For the HealthMap/ProMED map of Cambodia, see http://healthmap.org/r/1iGB. - Mod.MPP]", "summary": "Following the death of a 3-year-old due to avian flu on [2 Mar 2014], an 11-year-old boy died in Phnom Penh's Kantha Bopha Hospital on Friday [7 Mar 2014], a hospital representative said yesterday [9 Mar 2014]. \n\nThe news from Kantha Bopha comes on the heels of a joint statement released by ministry officials and the WHO on Friday [7 Mar 2014], announcing the death of a 3-year-old boy, who was the 6th confirmed case of avian influenza in Cambodia this year [2014], and the 53rd person to become infected. \n\nWhile 3 cases were confirmed in Phnom Penh last year [2013], this case marks the 1st in the capital this year [2014], Houssiere wrote in an email yesterday [9 Mar 2014]. Chey district, was admitted to the National Pediatric Hospital on [28 Feb 2014], and transferred to Calmette Hospital on [2 Mar 2014], where he died an hour later, says Friday's [7 Mar 2014] statement from the Ministry of Health and WHO. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n When these cases are officially confirmed by the MOH (usually with laboratory confirmation from the Pasteur Institute in Cambodia) these will be the 7th and 8th cases of human H5N1 infection in Cambodia this year (2014). \n\nAt least 22 cases of bird flu in Cambodia were recorded by the Ministry of Health last year [2013], more than any previous year. All confirmed human cases of H5N1 infection in Cambodia this year (2014) have been in children, and all have had a history of exposure to sick or dead poultry. \n\n'In mid-February [2014], over 90 per cent of the chickens and small numbers of ducks suddenly died in the village,' the press release details. \n\n'The good news is that the 8-year-old boy from Kandal province is in stable condition,' Laurent said. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[The Phnom Penh post is usually a reliable media source for information on health events occurring in Cambodia.", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2014-03-25 00:00:00", "1983-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Phnom Penh 's", "country": "Cambodia"}, {"location": "Phnom Penh", "country": "Cambodia"}, {"location": "Kandal province", "country": "Cambodia"}, {"location": "Cambodia", "country": "Cambodia"}, {"location": "Kampong Chhnang", "country": "Cambodia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2329866", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (39): Libya (Tubruq) HPAI H5N1, poultry, OIE", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2329866", "date": "2014-03-13 01:21:15", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (39): LIBYA (TUBRUQ) HPAI H5N1, POULTRY, OIE\n************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 12 Mar 2014\nSource: OIE, WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database), weekly disease information 2014; 27(11) OIE [edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=14942\n\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza, Libya\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------\nInformation received on [and date] 12 Mar 2014 from Dr Abdunaser Dayhum, Director General, National Centre of Animal Health, Ministry of Agriculture, Animal & Marine Wealth , Zawia, Libya\n\nSummary:\nReport type: Immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 4 Mar 2014\nDate of pre-confirmation of the event: 9 Mar 2014\nReport date: 12 Mar 2014\nReason for notification: First occurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 26 May 2011\nManifestation of disease: Clinical disease\nCausal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory (basic), laboratory (advanced), necropsy\nThis event pertains to the whole country\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks: Total outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1: Kroum Alkhail, Tubruq\nDate of start of the outbreak: 4 Mar 2014\nOutbreak status: Resolved ( 6 Mar 2014)\nEpidemiological unit: Farm\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed /Slaughtered\nBirds / 50/ 19 / 15 / 35 / 0 /\nAffected population: 45 local backyard chickens and 5 ducks.\n\nOutbreak statistics:\nSpecies / Apparent morbidity rate / Apparent mortality rate / Apparent case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBirds/38 percent/ 30 percent/ 78.95 percent/ 100 percent\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology:\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection:Unknown or inconclusive\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: stamping out; quarantine; movement control inside the country; screening; zoning;\ndisinfection of infected premises/establishment(s); vaccination prohibited ; dipping/ spraying; vaccinated prohibited; no treatment of affected animals\n\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results:\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nNational Center of Disease Control Laboratory (National laboratory)/ Birds/ real-time PCR/ 11 Mar 2014/ Positive\nNational Central Veterinary Laboratory, National Center of Animal Health (National laboratory)/ Birds/ antigen (Ag) detection ELISA/ 9 Mar 2014/ Positive\nNational Central Veterinary Laboratory, National Center of Animal Health (National laboratory)/ Birds/ real-time PCR/ 10 Mar 2014/ Positive\n\nFuture Reporting:\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\nThe location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.\n\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This is the first time that Highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) H5N1 has been reported in Libya.\n\nLibya is a country in the Maghreb region of North Africa bordered by the Mediterranean Sea to the north, Egypt to the east, Sudan to the southeast, Chad and Niger to the south, and Algeria and Tunisia to the west. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Libya\n\nLibya is divided into 22 sha`biyat (sing. sha`biyah: districts). Tubruq (Tobruk) is the capital of the district of Al Butnan. http://www.statoids.com/lkl.html which borders to the east with Egypt's Matruh Governorate. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Butnan_District\n\nAccording to the OIE's WAHID database, from January to June 2013 Egypt reported 86 outbreaks of HPAI H5N1. For further details of these outbreaks, select the disease, region/country and year at: http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Diseaseinformation/statusdetail\n\nOther countries which border Libya report HPAI as being absent [Sudan (April 2006) and Niger (June 2006)], and as never reported (Algeria and Tunisia). Sudan, Algeria y Tunisia indicate that they apply 'general and targeted surveillance' as control measures, and Niger indicates only applying 'general surveillance'. There is no information on Chad. http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Diseaseinformation/statuslist\n\nThe Asian strain of avian influenza H5N1 virus has been confirmed in poultry and wild birds in several countries in the following regions: Asia, Europe, Africa and the Middle East. While this demonstrates the rapid and ongoing geographical spread of the virus, information to date has shown that the greatest risk to humans arises when the virus becomes established in small backyard poultry flocks, which allow continuing opportunities for close human contact, exposures, and infections to occur. http://www.phac-aspc.gc.ca/h5n1/index-eng.php\n\nA map of the administrative divisions of Libya is available at, http://www.ephotopix.com/image/africa/libya_admin_map.gif. - Mod.CRD\n\nProMED-mail would like to thank Rapporteur Mary Marshall for submitting a similar report on this outbreak. - Mod.MPP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/aio9.]", "summary": "Measures applied: stamping out; quarantine; movement control inside the country; [edited]\n Date of start of the event: 4 Mar 2014\n Date of start of the outbreak: 4 Mar 2014\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2014-03-25 00:00:00", "2011-05-25 00:00:00", "2006-04-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Libya", "country": "Libya"}, {"location": "Sudan", "country": "Sudan"}, {"location": "North Africa", "country": "Cameroon"}, {"location": "Libya", "country": "Libya"}, {"location": "Algeria", "country": "Algeria"}, {"location": "Egypt", "country": "Egypt"}, {"location": "Chad", "country": "Chad"}, {"location": "Tunisia", "country": "Tunisia"}, {"location": "WAHID", "country": "Oman"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2338293", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (85): Cambodia (KP, KN, KG), H5N1", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2338293", "date": "2014-03-17 19:41:17", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (85): CAMBODIA (KAMPOT, KANDAL, KAMPONG CHHNANG), H5N1\n*****************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this posting:\n[1] Kampot, 9th case confirmed - MOH\n[2] Media report, 9th case\n[3] Kantal, Kampong Chnnang, 7th and 8th cases confirmed - MOH\n\n******\n[1] Kampot, 9th case confirmed - MOH\nDate: Mon 17 Mar 2014\nSource: Cambodia Ministry of Health press release [edited]\nhttp://www.cdcmoh.gov.kh/PressRelease/56-PressRelease.Eng.pdf\n\n\n9th New Human Case of Avian Influenza H5N1 in Cambodia in 2014\n--------------------------------------------------------------\nThe Ministry of Health (MoH) of the Kingdom of Cambodia wishes to advise members of the public that one new human case of avian influenza has been confirmed for the H5N1 virus. This is the 9th case this year [2014] and the 56th person to become infected with the H5N1 virus in Cambodia. The case is from Kampot province. Of the 56 confirmed cases, 44 were children under 14, and 30 of the 56 were female. In addition, since the 1st case happened in Cambodia in 2005, only 19 cases have survived.\n\nA 2-year-old girl from Kandal village, Vat Ang Khang Tboung commune, Banteay Meas district, Kampot province, was tested positive by Institut Pasteur du Cambodge on [14 Mar 2014]. The girl had onset symptom of fever on [8 Mar 2014]. Her parents sought treatment at a private practitioner on the same day [8 Mar 2014] and on the next day [9 Mar 2014]. The girl was admitted to a private clinic on [10 Mar 2014] and in Kantha Bopha Hospital on [13 Mar 2014]. She had symptoms of fever, cough and dyspnea, and Tamiflu was administrated on the same day [13 Mar 2014]. The girl died on [14 Mar 2014].\n\nIn the beginning of February [2014], chickens started dying in the village and in the house of the case. At the end of February [2014] and beginning of March [2014], it is estimated that 90 percent of poultries of the village died. The girl had direct contact with dead chickens while her relatives prepared them for food and the girl ate them.\n\nThe national and local Rapid Response Teams (RRTs) are conducting outbreak investigation and responses following the national protocol.\n\n'Avian influenza H5N1 remains a serous threat to the health of all Cambodians and more so for children, who seem to be most vulnerable and are at high risk. There have been 56 cases of H5N1 infection in humans since 2005 and here is the 9th case of this year [2014]. Children often care for domestic poultry by feeding them, cleaning pens and gathering eggs. Children may also have closer contact with poultry as they often treat them as pets and also seem to be most vulnerable and are at high risk because they like to play where poultry are found. I urge parents and guardians to keep children away from sick or dead poultry and prevent them from playing with chickens and ducks. Parents and guardians must also make sure children thoroughly wash their hands with soap and water before eating and after any contact with poultry. Hands may carry the virus that cannot be seen by the naked eye. Soap washes away the virus on hands. If children have fast or difficult breathing, their parents should seek medical attention at the nearest health facility and attending physicians must be made aware of any exposure to sick or dead poultry,' said H.E. Dr. Mam Bunheng, Minister of Health.\n\nA nationwide public health education campaign using radio has been launched at the end of January [2014], with prevention messages. Also, public health education campaign is being conducted in Kandal village, Kampot province using information, education and communications materials to inform families on how to protect themselves from contracting avian influenza. The government's message is: wash hands often with soap and water before eating and after coming into contact with poultry; keep children away from poultry; keep poultry away from living areas; do not eat dead or sick poultry; and all poultry eaten should be well cooked.\n\nH5N1 influenza is a flu that normally spreads between sick poultry, but it can sometimes spread from poultry to humans. Human H5N1 avian influenza is a very serious disease that requires hospitalization. Although the virus currently does not easily spread among humans, if the virus changes it could easily be spread like seasonal influenza. Hence, early recognition of cases is important.\n\nThe Ministry of Health will continue to keep the public informed of developments via the MoH website (http://www.cdcmoh.gov.kh), where relevant health education materials can also be downloaded.\n\nFor more information on human influenza please call the MoH Influenza Hotline numbers: 115 (free call); 012 488 981 or 089 669 567.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Media report, 9th case\nDate: Mon 17 Mar 2014\nSource: Xinhua News Agency [edited]\nhttp://news.xinhuanet.com/english/health/2014-03/17/c_133192908.htm\n\n\nA 2-year-old girl from southwestern Kampot province died of H5N1 human avian influenza on Friday [14 Mar 2014], bringing the number of cases to 9 so far this year, said a joint statement from the World Health Organization (WHO) and the Cambodian Health Ministry on Monday [17 Mar 2014].\n\nA total of 5 out of the 9 cases this year [2014] survived.\n\n'The girl died on [14 Mar 2014] -- a day after being admitted to the Kantha Bopha Children Hospital,' the statement said, adding that the toddler had symptoms of fever, cough and dyspnea.\n\nThe statement said that last month [February 2014], about 90 percent of chickens in her village died, and the girl had direct contact with dead chickens while her relatives prepared them for food and the girl ate them.\n\nBird flu remains a serious threat to the health of all Cambodians and children seem to be most vulnerable and are at high risk, Health Minister Mam Bunheng said.\n\n'I urge parents and guardians to keep children away from sick or dead poultry and make sure children wash their hands with soap and water after any contact with poultry,' he said.\n\nH5N1 influenza is a flu that normally spreads between sick poultry, but it can sometimes spread from poultry to humans, according to the WHO.\n\nThe virus was 1st identified in Cambodia 10 years ago. To date, the country has reported 56 human cases of the virus, killing 37 people, the statement said.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n******\n[3] Kantal, Kampong Chhnang, 7th and 8th cases confirmed - MOH\nDate: Tue 11 Mar 2014\nSource: Cambodia Ministry of Health press release [summ., edited]\nhttp://www.cdcmoh.gov.kh/PressRelease/54-55-PressRelease.Eng.pdf\n\n\n7th and 8th New Human Case of Avian Influenza H5N1 in Cambodia in 2014\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nThe Ministry of Health (MoH) of the Kingdom of Cambodia wishes to advise members of the public that 2 new human cases of avian influenza have been confirmed for the H5N1 virus. These are the 7th and 8th cases this year [2014] and the 54th and 55th persons to become infected with the H5N1 virus in Cambodia. The cases are from Kandal and Kampong Chhnang provinces. Of the 55 confirmed cases, 43 were children under 14, and 29 of the 55 were female. In addition, since the 1st case happened in Cambodia in 2005, only 19 cases have survived.\n\nThe 7th case, an 8-year-old boy from Spean-Dek village, Prek-TunLoab commune, Leuk-Dek district, Kandal province, was tested positive by lnstitut Pasteur du Cambodge on [6 Mar 2014]. The boy had onset symptoms of fever, chill, running nose, sore throat, and cough on [24 Feb 2014]. His parents sought treatment at a private practitioner in the village on the same day [24 Feb 2014]. His condition worsened and the boy was admitted to Kantha Bopha Hospital on [4 Mar 2014]. On [4 Mar 2014], the boy had symptoms of fever, chill, running nose, sore throat, cough, dyspnoea, convulsion and somnolence. The specimen was collected on [5 Mar 2014] and Tamiflu was administered on the same day [5 Mar 2014]. The boy is recovering.\n\nAround mid-February [2014], about 90 percent of poultries died in the village. Chickens died in the case's house and the family buried them. There is also a poultry slaughter house near to the case's house. The parents reported that the boy had no direct contact but the chickens died in close proximity.\n\nThe 8th case, an 11-year-old boy from Toeuk Laak village, Toeuk Haut commune, Rolea Paear district, Kampong Chhnang province, was tested positive by Institut Pasteur du Cambodge on [6 Mar 2014]. The boy had onset symptoms of fever and headache on [3 Mar 2014]. His parents sought treatment at a private practitioner next to their house on the same day and on the next day [4 Mar 2014]. His condition worsened and the boy was admitted to Kampong Chhnang Provincial Hospital on [5 Mar 2014]. On [6 Mar 2014] the boy had symptoms of fever, cough, and shortness of breath and was referred to Kantha Bopha Hospital in the afternoon on the same day [6 Mar 2014]. The boy died a few hours after his admission on [6 Mar 2014].\n\nIn the beginning of February [2014], chickens started dying in the village and in the case's house and continued for a month. The boy helped to prepare dead chickens and ducks for food and ate them.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The above reports provide confirmation of the previously reported 7th and 8th cases of H5N1 human infection in Cambodia occurring in Kandal and Kampong Chhnang provinces [see prior ProMED-mail post Avian influenza, human (83): Cambodia (KG, KN) H5N1, RFI 20140310.2324247], and now a 9th confirmed case occurring in Kampot province. To date in 2014 there have been human cases of H5N1 infection in 7 provinces. Provinces where cases in 2014 have occurred: Kampot, Kandal, Kampong Chhnang, Phnom Penh, Kampong Cham (newly named Tboung Khmum) (2 cases, different districts), Kratie (2 cases, same commune), Kampong Thom. Of the 9 confirmed cases to date, 4 have died (case fatality rate -- CFR -- to date in 2014 is 44 percent). Overall there have been 56 human cases since 2005, of which 37 have died (CFR 66 percent). All cases this year have been in children who have all had either known direct contact with ill or dead poultry or have lived in close proximity to known poultry die-offs.\n\nFor a map of Cambodia showing provinces, see http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/7/7e/Cambodia,_administrative_divisions_-_de_-_colored.svg. For the HealthMap/ProMED map of Cambodia, see http://healthmap.org/r/1iGB. - Mod.MPP]", "summary": "http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/health/2014-03/17/c_133192908.htm\n\n\nA 2-year-old girl from southwestern Kampot province died of H5N1 human avian influenza on Friday [14 Mar 2014], bringing the number of cases to 9 so far this year, said a joint statement from the World Health Organization (WHO) and the Cambodian Health Ministry on Monday [17 Mar 2014]. The girl died on [14 Mar 2014] -- a day after being admitted to the Kantha Bopha Children Hospital,' the statement said, adding that the toddler had symptoms of fever, cough and dyspnea.
