Communicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n******\n \n\nA nationwide public health education campaign using radio has been launched at the end of January [2014], with prevention messages.", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1985-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-29 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 00:00:00", "1983-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-02-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2014-02-24 00:00:00", "2005-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Kandal province", "country": "Cambodia"}, {"location": "KG", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kampong Chhnang", "country": "Cambodia"}, {"location": "Kandal", "country": "Cambodia"}, {"location": "KN", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kandal village", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Cambodia", "country": "Cambodia"}, {"location": "the Kingdom of Cambodia", "country": "Colombia"}, {"location": "Kampot", "country": "Cambodia"}, {"location": "Kampot province", "country": "Cambodia"}, {"location": "Phnom Penh", "country": "Cambodia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2327174", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (38): Viet Nam, H5N1, mutation, spread, poultry, vaccine", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2327174", "date": "2014-03-11 21:22:20", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (38): VIET NAM, H5N1, MUTATION, SPREAD, POULTRY, VACCINE\n************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 7 Mar 2014\nSource: Xinhua News Agency [edited]\nhttp://news.xinhuanet.com/english/health/2014-03/07/c_133168675.htm\n\n\nThe H5N1 strain of avian influenza virus, clade 2.3.2.1C, which has been prevalent in Viet Nam's northern regions, was discovered for the 1st time in a number of dead ducks in southern Dong Nai province, about 1120 km [about 696 miles] from capital Hanoi, local media reported Friday [7 Mar 2014].\n\nState-run Viet Nam News Agency quoted an official from Dong Nai province's Animal Health Department as reporting that results were confirmed after a sample from the birds tested positive for the virus.\n\nPreviously, the A/H5N1 strain, clade 1.1, was found in affected poultry sold at many markets across Viet Nam, with the availability rate up to 6 percent in 2013.\n\nFrom late 2013 and particularly in the 1st 2 months of 2014, the A/H5N1 strain, clade 2.3.2.1.C, has penetrated into southern regions, along with clade 1.1. To date [7 Mar 2014], 8 out of 13 cities and provinces in southern Mekong delta were reported to be struck with avian flu outbreaks.\n\nDong Nai province is home to the largest number of poultry raised nationwide, with over 12 million. It is also located at the gateway of Ho Chi Minh City, the key economic hub in the south. As such, the transportation of poultry products is more likely to trigger the outbreak of bird flu, according to the local animal health department.\n\nCurrently, only 10 percent of the poultry in Dong Nai has been vaccinated against the A/H5N1 strain of the virus. Earlier, the province detected 2 bird flu cases in Trang Bom and Cam My districts.\n\nThe latest statistics from the National Steering Committee on Bird Flu Prevention and Control revealed that the H5N1 virus hit 23 provinces and cities across Viet Nam, with over 80 000 infected poultry culled. A total of 2 Vietnamese died from the virus so far this year [2014], one in southern Binh Phuoc and the other in Dong Thap provinces.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Since the start of the reoccurring HPAI H5N1 epizootic in Viet Nam (early October 2013), a total of 37 new outbreaks, affecting chicken and duck farms, have been reported to the OIE. Their updated summary, including an interactive map showing the virus spread throughout the entire country, is available at http://tinyurl.com/pngnrqw. The most recent 2 follow-up reports have been submitted on 10 Mar 2014 (follow-up report No 12, addressing one outbreak in Dong Nai province), and on 11 Mar 2014 (follow-up report No 13, addressing 2 outbreaks in Quang Nam and Ha Giang provinces). Unfortunately, the species of the affected 'birds' is not given. The submission of 2 follow-up reports in 2 consecutive days might reflect an upsurge of the disease incidence beyond the anticipated seasonal rise.\n\nA strain of H5N1 HPAI virus (clade 1 virus) probably entered Viet Nam sometime in 2003. It was widespread by early 2004, when reported to the OIE affecting poultry throughout the country. While clade 1.1 viruses persisted in southern regions since, during the recent 2-3 years, 3 genetically distinct subgroups of clade 2.3.2.1 have been found in northern and central Viet Nam, with clade 2.3.2.1C recently spreading southwards. This virus strain demonstrates higher pathogenic risk.\n\nSince June 2012, a decline in protection against the 2.3.2.1C viruses by H5N1 poultry vaccines used in Viet Nam was observed (Ref 1). For additional information on Viet Nam's H5N1 vaccination problem, also addressing clades 2.3.2.1A and 2.3.2.1B, see references.\n\nReferences:\n1. Creanga A., Thi Nguyen D., Gerloff N. et al. (2013). Emergence of multiple clade 2.3.2.1 influenza A(H5N1) virus subgroups in Vietnam and detection of novel reassortants. Virology 444 (2013)12-20. http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.virol.2013.06.005.\n2. Cha R.M., Smith D., Shepherd E., Davis C.T. et al (2013). Suboptimal protection against H5N1 highly pathogenic avian influenza viruses from Vietnam in ducks vaccinated with commercial poultry vaccines. Vaccine 31(43):4953-4960.\n- Mod.AS]", "summary": "The most recent 2 follow-up reports have been submitted on 10 Mar 2014 (follow-up report No 12, addressing one outbreak in Dong Nai province), and on 11 Mar 2014 (follow-up report No 13, addressing 2 outbreaks in Quang Nam and Ha Giang provinces). The H5N1 strain of avian influenza virus, clade 2.3.2.1C, which has been prevalent in Viet Nam's northern regions, was discovered for the 1st time in a number of dead ducks in southern Dong Nai province, about 1120 km [about 696 miles] from capital Hanoi, local media reported Friday [7 Mar 2014]. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n While clade 1.1 viruses persisted in southern regions since, during the recent 2-3 years, 3 genetically distinct subgroups of clade 2.3.2.1 have been found in northern and central Viet Nam, with clade 2.3.2.1C recently spreading southwards. From late 2013 and particularly in the 1st 2 months of 2014, the A/H5N1 strain, clade 2.3.2.1.C, has penetrated into southern regions, along with clade 1.1. \n\nA strain of H5N1 HPAI virus (clade 1 virus) probably entered Viet Nam sometime in 2003. \n\nThe latest statistics from the National Steering Committee on Bird Flu Prevention and Control revealed that the H5N1 virus hit 23 provinces and cities across Viet Nam, with over 80 000 infected poultry culled. AVIAN INFLUENZA (38): VIET NAM, H5N1, MUTATION, SPREAD, POULTRY, VACCINE\n************************************************************************\n Previously, the A/H5N1 strain, clade 1.1, was found in affected poultry sold at many markets across Viet Nam, with the availability rate up to 6 percent in 2013. \n\nState-run Viet Nam News Agency quoted an official from Dong Nai province's Animal Health Department as reporting that results were confirmed after a sample from the birds tested positive for the virus. To date [7 Mar 2014], 8 out of 13 cities and provinces in southern Mekong delta were reported to be struck with avian flu outbreaks. A total of 2 Vietnamese died from the virus so far this year [2014], one in southern Binh Phuoc and the other in Dong Thap provinces. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Since the start of the reoccurring HPAI H5N1 epizootic in Viet Nam (early October 2013), a total of 37 new outbreaks, affecting chicken and duck farms, have been reported to the OIE. 27(10) [edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=14866\n\n\nLow pathogenic avian influenza (poultry), Netherlands\n--------------------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 28 Feb 2014 from Dr Christianne Bruschke, Chief Veterinary Officer, Ministry of Agriculture, Nature and Food Quality, The Hague, Netherlands\n\nSummary:\nReport type: Immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 26 Feb 2014\nDate of pre-confirmation of the event: 27 Feb 2014\nReport date: 28 Feb 2014\nDate submitted to OIE: 28 Feb 2014\nReason for notification: Reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 10 Dec 2013\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: Low pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: clinical\nThis event pertains to a defined within the country\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks: Total outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1: Swifterbant, Flevoland\nDate of start of the outbreak: 26 Feb 2014\nOutbreak status: Continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: Farm\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nBirds / 40 327 / - / 0 / 40 237 / 0 /\n\n[Note: There appears to be a typographical error with the figure associated with the number of animals destroyed. It should be 40 327 (rather than 40 237), particularly since the epidemiologic comment below indicates that all susceptible animals were destroyed. - Mod.CRD]\n\nEpidemiology:\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Unknown or inconclusive\n\nEpidemiological comment: On 27 Feb 2014, a one-km protection zone has been established. In this one-km zone, there is one other premise. All susceptible animals on the infected premise have been killed.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: stamping out; movement control inside the country; screening; zoning; vaccination prohibited; no treatment of affected animals\n\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results:\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nCentral Veterinary institute, Lelystad (National laboratory) / Birds / polymerase chain reaction (PCR) / 27 Feb 2014 / Positive\nFuture Reporting:\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted. The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[According to the information found on the web-site of the Dutch Central Veterinary Institute in Lelystad, the virus was sequenced as LPAI H5N1 (circulating in fauna in Europe) http://www.wageningenur.nl/nl/Expertises-Dienstverlening/Onderzoeksinstituten/central-veterinary-institute/show/Vogelgriep-Swifterbant-LP-H5N1.htm. - Mod.AS]\n\n[This is the 1st time that low pathogenicity H5N1 has been identified in the Netherlands. During the last 2 years, LPAI H5N1 has also been confirmed in Germany. See details at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Diseaseinformation/statusdetail (Note: to view the information on LPAI you need to scroll down to the name of the disease, choose the country/region and time period).\n\nThe Netherlands reported several cases of low pathogenic avian influenza (LPAI) in 2013. For further information on LPAI affecting poultry in the Netherlands during 2013, please refer to commentaries in the ProMED report archive number 20131202.2087148.\n\nA map of the provinces of Netherlands is available at http://www.ephotopix.com/image/europe/netherlands_province_map.gif. - Mod.CRD\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1r1l.]", "summary": "Measures applied: stamping out; 27(10) [edited]\n Date of pre-confirmation of the event: 27 Feb 2014\n Date of start of the event: 26 Feb 2014\n Report date: 28 Feb 2014\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2014-02-25 00:00:00", "2035-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-02-27 00:00:00", "2013-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "the Hague", "country": "Netherlands"}, {"location": "Germany", "country": "Germany"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "Netherlands"}, {"location": "NETHERLANDS", "country": "Netherlands"}, {"location": "WAHID", "country": "Oman"}, {"location": "Lelystad", "country": "Netherlands"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2320936", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (82): Cambodia, H5N1", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2320936", "date": "2014-03-08 10:01:35", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (82): CAMBODIA, H5N1\n*******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Phnom Penh, 6th case, fatal\n[2] Phnom Penh - MOH report\n[3] Kampong Cham, 4th and 5th cases - MOH report\n\n******\n[1] Phnom Penh, 6th case, fatal\nDate: Fri 7 Mar 2014\nSource: Global Times, Xinhua News Agency report [edited] http://www.globaltimes.cn/content/846832.shtml\n\n\nA 3-year-old boy from capital Phnom Penh's Por Senchey district has died of H5N1 human avian influenza earlier this month [March 2014], said a joint statement from the World Health Organization (WHO) and the Cambodian Health Ministry Friday [7 Mar 2014].\n\n'The boy died on [2 Mar 2014] after being admitted to the National Pediatric Hospital for 3 days,' the statement said. The boy had onset symptoms of fever, cough, running nose and vomiting on [22 Feb 2014] and his parents sent him to the National Pediatric Hospital on [28 Feb 2014] after his condition worsened.\n\nThe boy became the 6th person infected with the virus in 2014.\n\nThe statement said in mid-February [2014], over 90 percent of the chickens and small number of ducks suddenly died in the boy's village, and the boy often went to the house of a neighbor whose poultry died.\n\nBird flu remains a serious threat to the health of all Cambodians, and children seem to be the most vulnerable, Health Minister Mam Bunheng said.\n\n'I urge parents and guardians to keep children away from sick or dead poultry and make sure children wash their hands with soap and water after any contact with poultry,' he said.\n\nH5N1 influenza is a flu that normally spreads between sick poultry, but it can sometimes spread from poultry to human beings, according to the WHO.\n\nThe virus was 1st identified in Cambodia 10 years ago. To date [7 Mar 2014], the country has reported 53 human cases of the virus, killing 35 people, the statement said.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n******\n[2] Phnom Penh - MOH report\nDate: 7 Mar 2014\nSource: Cambodia Ministry of Health press release [edited]\nhttp://www.cdcmoh.gov.kh/PressRelease/53-PressRelease.Eng.pdf\n\n\nThe Ministry of Health (MoH) of the Kingdom of Cambodia wishes to advise members of the public that one new human case of avian influenza has been confirmed for the H5N1 virus. This is the 6th case this year [2014] and the 53rd person to become infected with the H5N1 virus in Cambodia. The case is from Phnom Penh City. Of the 53 confirmed cases, 41 were children under 14, and 29 of the 53 were female. In addition, since the 1st case happened in Cambodia in 2005, only 18 cases have survived.\n\nA 3-year-old boy from Prey Lyea village, Sangkat Chom-Chao commune, Khan Por-SenChey district, Phnom Penh province, was detected by the National Institute of Public Health (NIPH) on [3 Mar 2014] and confirmed positive by lnstitut Pasteur du Cambodge (IPC) on [3 Mar 2014]. The boy had onset symptoms of fever, cough, running nose and vomiting on [22 Feb 2014]. His parents sought treatment at a private clinic on the same day. His condition worsened and the boy was admitted to National Pediatric Hospital (NPH) on [28 Feb 2014]. On [2 Mar 2014], the boy had symptoms of fever, cough, running nose, vomiting, dyspnea, and cyanoses and was transferred to Calmette Hospital on the same day. The boy died about one hour after his admission on [2 Mar 2014].\n\nAround mid-February [2014], over 90 percent of the chickens and small number of ducks suddenly died in the village. The boy was often going to a neighbour's house where their poultry died. The relatives reported that the boy had no direct contact, but the chickens died in close proximity to the house of the case.\n\n'Avian influenza H5N1 remains a serious threat to the health of all Cambodians and more so for children, who seem to be most vulnerable and are at high risk. There have been 53 cases of H5N1 infection in humans since 2005, and here is the 6th case of this year [2014]. Children often care for domestic poultry by feeding them, cleaning pens and gathering eggs. Children may also have closer contact with poultry as they often treat [the birds] as pets, and also seem to be most vulnerable and are at high risk because they like to play where poultry are found. I urge parents and guardians to keep children away from sick or dead poultry and prevent then from playing with chickens and ducks. Parents and guardians must also make sure children thoroughly wash their hands with soap and water before eating and after any contact with poultry. Hands may carry the virus that cannot be seen by the naked eye. Soap washes away the virus on hands. If children have fast or difficult breathing, their parents should seek medical attention at the nearest health facility, and attending physicians must be made aware of any exposure to sick or dead poultry,' said H.E. Dr. Mam Bunheng, Minister of Health.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3] Kampong Cham, 4th and 5th cases - MOH report\nDate: Thu 27 Feb 2014\nSource: Cambodia Ministry of Health press release [edited]\nhttp://www.cdcmoh.gov.kh/PressRelease/51-52-PressRelease.Eng.pdf\n\n\nThe Ministry of Health (MoH) of the Kingdom of Cambodia wishes to advise members of the public that 2 new human cases of avian influenza have been confirmed for the H5N1 virus. These are the 4th and 5th cases this year [2014] and the 51st and 52nd persons to become infected with the H5Nl virus in Cambodia. The cases are from Kampong Cham (newly named Tboung Khmun) province. Of the 52 confirmed cases, 40 were children under 14, and 29 of the 52 were female. In addition, since the 1st case happened in Cambodia in 2005, only 18 cases have survived.\n\nThe 4th case, a 10-year-old girl from Rorveang village, Knor Damborng commune, Cheung Prey district, Kampong Cham (newly named Tboung Khmun) province, was detected by the Naval Medical Research Unit 2 (NAMRU-2) through fever surveillance on [20 Feb 2014] and confirmed positive by Institut Pasteur du Cambodge on [20 Feb 2014]. The girl had onset symptom of fever on [26 Jan 2014]. Her mother bought medicine in the village. From [27 Jan 2014], she continued to develop symptoms and had fever, running nose, cough, and abdominal pain. On [29 Jan 2014], the health staff of the NAMRU-2 project took samples from the girl. Upon confirmation of H5N1, she was referred to Kampong Cham Provincial Hospital on [20 Feb 2014] and Tamiflu was administered on the same day. Currently, she has recovered and [has resumed] normal activities.\n\nThe case had direct exposure with dead and sick poultry. Farm ducks in the village started to suddenly die around [15 Jan 2014]. The mother of the case bought sick/dead ducks on [25 Jan 2014] and the family prepared them, with the help of the case, for food on the same day.\n\nThe 5th case, an 11-year-old girl from La Ork village, Krek commune, Ponhea Krek district, Kampong Cham (newly named Tboung Khmum) province, was detected by the Naval Medical Research Unit 2 (NAMRU-2) through fever surveillance on [20 Feb 2014] and confirmed positive by Institut Pasteur du Cambodge on [20 Feb 2014]. The girl had onset symptoms of fever and cough on [9 Feb 2014]. On [10 Feb 2014] her symptoms were fever, running nose, sore throat, cough and vomiting. The health staff of the NAMRU-2 project took samples from the girl on [10 Feb 2014]. Upon confirmation of H5N1, she was referred to Kampong Cham Provincial Hospital on [20 Feb 2014] and Tamiflu was administered on the same day. Currently she has recovered and [has resumed] normal activities.\n\nFrom [7 to 10 Feb 2014], all 30 chickens owned by the family died around the house. The relatives reported that the girl had no direct contact, but the chickens died in close proximity to the case.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[According to the most recent WHO update on H5N1 infections dated 25 Feb 2014, there have been 8 cases of human infection with influenza A(H1N5) in 2014, of which 5 were reported in Cambodia. 'Cambodia reported 5 confirmed and 1 probable case of human infection with influenza A(H5N1) virus. All cases were children: a 5-year-old boy from Kampong Thom, and 3 cases from the same village in Kratie province: an 8-year-old boy and his 2-year-old sister (probable case) and a 4-year-old boy. The siblings died from severe respiratory infection, but samples were collected only from the 8-year-old boy. The 4-year-old boy was detected during the contact tracing around this family cluster. Exposure of the last 3 children to a common poultry source is likely as a high number of poultry were reported to have died in the village in mid-January [2014], and all had direct exposure to dead and sick poultry. The last 2 reported cases were a 10-year-old girl and an 11-year-old girl from 2 different districts in Kampong Cham province. Both presented with mild disease and fully recovered. Poultry die-off was reported in their neighbourhood' (from http://who.int/influenza/human_animal_interface/Influenza_Summary_IRA_HA_interface_25Feburary14.pdf).\n\nAll cases thus far this year (2014) were in children, all of whom had a history of exposure to poultry or resided in proximity to known poultry die-offs.\n\nFor a map of Cambodia showing provinces, see http://www.vidiani.com/maps/maps_of_asia/maps_of_cambodia/cambodia_provinces_detailed_map.jpg. For the HealthMap/ProMED map of Cambodia, see http://healthmap.org/r/1iGB. - Mod.MPP]", "summary": "All cases were children: a 5-year-old boy from Kampong Thom, and 3 cases from the same village in Kratie province: an 8-year-old boy and his 2-year-old sister (probable case) and a 4-year-old boy. \n\nThe 4th case, a 10-year-old girl from Rorveang village, Knor Damborng commune, Cheung Prey district, Kampong Cham (newly named Tboung Khmun) province, was detected by the Naval Medical Research Unit 2 (NAMRU-2) through fever surveillance on [20 Feb 2014] and confirmed positive by Institut Pasteur du Cambodge on [20 Feb 2014]. \n\nThe 5th case, an 11-year-old girl from La Ork village, Krek commune, Ponhea Krek district, Kampong Cham (newly named Tboung Khmum) province, was detected by the Naval Medical Research Unit 2 (NAMRU-2) through fever surveillance on [20 Feb 2014] and confirmed positive by Institut Pasteur du Cambodge on [20 Feb 2014]. \n\nA 3-year-old boy from Prey Lyea village, Sangkat Chom-Chao commune, Khan Por-SenChey district, Phnom Penh province, was detected by the National Institute of Public Health (NIPH) on [3 Mar 2014] and confirmed positive by lnstitut Pasteur du Cambodge (IPC) on [3 Mar 2014]. KANDAL) H5N1, SPREAD, POULTRY, OIE\n********************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of [edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=14842\n\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza, Cambodia\n-------------------------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 26 Feb 2014 from Dr Sen Sovann, Deputy Secretary General, Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries, Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries, Phnom Penh, Cambodia\n\nSummary\nReport type: follow-up report no 1\nDate of start of the event: 7 Feb 2014\nDate of pre-confirmation of the event: 10 Feb 2014\nReport date: 26 Feb 2014\nDate submitted to OIE: 26 Feb 2014\nReason for notification: reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 18 Aug 2014\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory (basic), laboratory (advanced), necropsy\nThis event pertains to the whole country\n\nNew outbreaks (2)\nOutbreak 1 (100/14 NaVRI): Peam Lvea, Trapang Chau, Aoral, Kampong Speu\nDate of start of the outbreak: 18 Feb 2014\nOutbreak status: resolved [25 Feb 2104]\nEpidemiological unit: village\nAffected animals: Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nBirds / 450 / 210 / 210 / 240 / 0\nAffected population: backyard poultry\n\nOutbreak 2 (101/14 NaVRI): Tuol Sangkae, Kampong Kong, Koh Thom, Kandal\nDate of start of the outbreak: 19 Feb 2014\nOutbreak status: resolved [25 Feb 2104]\nEpidemiological unit: village\nAffected animals: Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nBirds / 250 / 200 / 200 / 50 / 0\nAffected population: duck flocks in 2 households.\n\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 2\nTotal animals affected: Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nBirds / 700 / 410 / 410 / 290 / 0\nOutbreak statistics:\nSpecies / Apparent morbidity rate / Apparent mortality rate / Apparent case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBirds / 58.57 percent / 58.57 percent / 100 percent / 100 percent\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\nEpidemiological comments: after receiving the report from farmers, the district and provincial veterinarians went there. They collected some samples from chickens and ducks and sent them to the National Veterinary Research Institute (NaVRI). Results were positive for highly pathogenic avian influenza H5N1.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: stamping out, movement control inside the country, disinfection of infected premises/establishment(s), dipping/spraying, vaccination prohibited, no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / result\nNational Veterinary Research Institute (national laboratory) / birds / anatomo-pathological examination / 24 Feb 2014 / positive\nNational Veterinary Research Institute (national laboratory) / birds / real-time PCR / 24 Feb 2014 / positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreaks can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In 2012 Cambodia reported to the OIE only one case of HPAI, and in 2013 the country reported 7 cases. The number of cases of HPAI in poultry is likely to be under-reported given the number of human cases reported and the large number of poultry (primarily backyard poultry) that are raised in the country (http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Countryinformation/Animalpopulation).\n\nIn Cambodia there is no compensation for the destruction of affected poultry. There is much debate on whether compensation would help with any efforts to control the disease. See http://www.cambodiadaily.com/archives/compensation-for-culled-poultry-is-a-catch-22-52485/.\nHowever, compensation should be considered as a tool that could help with control efforts. Effective educational outreach campaigns, basic biosecurity, and compensation are all good tools which together will help control this disease. - Mod.CRD\n\nMaps of Cambodia can be seen at http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/7/7e/Cambodia,_administrative_divisions_-_de_-_colored.svg and http://healthmap.org/r/1iGB. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]", "summary": "Measures to be applied: no influenza (31): Viet Nam, H5N1, spread, poultry, OIE", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2302719", "date": "2014-02-26 22:03:57", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (31): VIET NAM, H5N1, SPREAD, POULTRY, OIE\n**********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Wed 26 Feb 2014\nSource: The Borneo Post [edited]\nhttp://www.theborneopost.com/2014/02/26/bird-flu-hits-21-provinces-in-vietnam/\n\n\nBird flu has hit 21 provinces and cities across Viet Nam with around 64 000 infected chickens culled, according to latest statistics from the Animal Health Department.\n\nThe number of birds killed in the central province of Khanh Hoa and the northwestern province of Lao Cai has reached almost 20 000, members of the National Steering Committee for Bird Flu Prevention and Control heard at a meeting here on Wednesday [26 Feb 2014].\n\nViet Nam News Agency (VNA) reports the outbreak was attributed to the complicated weather in the 1st 2 months of the year [2014] and the increase in shipping and trading of poultry during the recently-ended Lunar New Year (Tet) festival. 'If localities fail to intensify scrutiny and take swift measures, bird flu could develop into an epidemic,' warned the department's deputy head Dam Xuan Thanh.\n\nParticipants at the meeting agreed that all localities where the disease has reoccurred or has yet to be detected should focus on preventing illegal import and trading of poultry. Local authorities will also tighten inspections at border gates and take prompt preventive measures against the bird flu virus and human-transmission strains such as H5N1 and H7N9.\n\nWith a population of around 10 million, Ho Chi Minh City consumes a large amount of poultry on a daily basis with many brought in from other localities. The city has signed cooperation agreements with localities such as Dong Nai, Ba Ria-Vung Tau, Binh Duong, Long An and Tien Giang in monitoring and preventing epidemic diseases and managing food safety.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Tue 25 Feb 2014\nSource: OIE, WAHID weekly disease information 2014; 27(09) [edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=14822 and http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=14834\n\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza, Viet Nam\n-------------------------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 25 Feb 2014 from Dr Dong Pham Van, Director General, Chief Veterinary Officer, Department of Animal Health, Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development, Hanoi, Viet Nam\n\nSummary:\nReport type: Follow-up reports No. 7 and No. 8\n\n[Note: This report pertains to several outbreaks associated with the same event but which were reported in 2 separate OIE follow-up reports. Nepal\n--------------------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 26 Feb 2014 from Dr Nar Bahadur Rajwar, Director General, Department of Livestock Services, Lalitpur, Nepal.\n\nSummary:\nReport type: Immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 13 Feb 2014\nDate of pre-confirmation of the event: 18 Feb 2014\nReport date: 26 Feb 2014\nDate submitted to OIE: 26 Feb 2014\nReason for notification: Reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 10 Oct 2013\nManifestation of disease: Clinical disease\nCausal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory (advanced), necropsy\nThis event pertains to the whole country.\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks:\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1: Itahari Municipality 7, Itahari, Sunsari, Koshi\nDate of start of the outbreak: 13 Feb 2014\nOutbreak status: Continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: Farm\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nBirds / 2000 / 570 / 570 / 1430 / 0\nAffected population: A commercial layer farm in production stage kept in deep litter system.\n\nOutbreak statistics:\nSpecies / Apparent morbidity rate / Apparent mortality rate / Apparent case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBirds / 28.5 percent / 28.5 percent / 100 percent / 100 percent\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology:\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Unknown or inconclusive\n\nEpidemiological comments: Birds showed depression, decreased egg production followed by death with cyanosis, respiratory distress, and paralysis.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: stamping out; vaccination prohibited; no treatment of affected animals\n\nMeasures to be applied: quarantine; movement control inside the country; disinfection of infected premises/establishment(s); dipping/spraying\n\nDiagnostic test results:\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nCentral veterinary laboratory (National laboratory) / Birds / real-time PCR / 18 Feb 2014 / Positive\n\nFuture Reporting:\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[According to information found in the WAHID database, on 27 Aug 2012, Nepal reported an event of HPAI, subtype H5N1. The last outbreak reported during this event was dated 14 Sep 2013. A total of 210 outbreaks were reported in the zones of Bagmati, Bheri Gandaki, Janakpur, Lumbini, Mechi, Narayani, and Seti.\n\nThe affected population was:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nBirds / 2 076 755 / 184 776 / 184 776 / 1 891 879 / 0\nHouse Crow / - / 2 / 2 / 0 / 0\n\nIn their final report sent on 3 Jan 2014, Nepal declared the event as resolved in October 2013. See the report at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/temp/reports/en_fup_0000014609_20140103_132713.pdf.\n\nNepal is now organized into 14 zones. See http://www.statoids.com/unp.html. A map of the zone divisions is available at, http://www.ephotopix.com/image/asia/nepal_zone_map.gif. - Mod.CRD\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/9Xpf.]", "2014-02-21 09:52:28", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (26): VIET NAM, H5N1, POULTRY, SPREAD, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n*************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 20 Feb 2014\nSource: Saigon Giai Phong (SGGP) [summ., edited]\nhttp://www.saigon-gpdaily.com.vn/Health/2014/2/108025/\n\n\nAccording to the Department of Animal Health on 19 Feb 2014, 16 provinces in the country have reported 64 outbreaks of bird flu.\n\nProvinces affected are Dak Lak, Long An, Kon Tum, Tay Ninh, Ca Mau, Khanh Hoa, Quang Ngai, Nam Dinh, Phu Yen, Lao Cai, Ba Ria-Vung Tau, Nghe An, Quang Binh, Ha Tinh, Can Tho, and Vinh Long.\n\nTransmission of the virus comes from chicken smuggled through the China border and free range flocks of poultry in the southwest border areas.\n\nTesting of live poultry in 147 markets in 44 provinces revealed that 6 percent of poultry sold is positive for the A/H5N1 virus. About 60 percent of the markets tested revealed the sale of some form of infected poultry.\n\nQuang Ngai Province supplied more than 600 000 vaccinations to its districts. The province was asked to vaccinate one million poultry by March [2014]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[Official updated information on the rapidly spreading epizootic is expected to be included in the due follow-up report to the OIE, expected next week. 27(09) [edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=14814\n\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza, India\n----------------------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 21 Feb 2014 from Mr Anup Kumar Thakur, Secretary, Government of India, Department of Animal Husbandry, Dairying and Fisheries, Ministry of Agriculture, New Delhi, India.\n\nSummary\nReport type: Immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 31 Jan 2014\nDate of pre-confirmation of the event: 6 Feb 2014\nReport date: 21 Feb 2014\nDate submitted to OIE: 21 Feb 2014\nReason for notification: Reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 11 Nov 2013\nManifestation of disease: Clinical disease\nCausal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: laboratory (basic), laboratory (advanced)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1: Joda, Bileipada, Keonjhar, Orissa [Odisha]\nDate of start of the outbreak: 31 Jan 2014\nOutbreak status: Resolved (21 Feb 2014)\nEpidemiological unit: Not applicable\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nHouse crow: _Corvus splendens_ (Corvidae) / - / 2 / 2 / 0 / 0\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Unknown or inconclusive\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: disinfection of infected premises/establishment(s); vaccination prohibited; no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nHigh Security Animal Disease Laboratory, Bhopal (national laboratory) / house crow / real-time PCR/ 6 Feb 2014\nHigh Security Animal Disease Laboratory, Bhopal (national laboratory) / house crow / reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) / 6 Feb 2014\nHigh Security Animal Disease Laboratory, Bhopal (national laboratory) / house crow / virus isolation / 6 Feb 2014\n\nFuture Reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\nThe location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The fact that India has reported outbreaks and confirmed occurrences of highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) each year for at least the past 7or 8 years suggests that the virus is endemic in certain regions of the country. India may consider conducting targeted surveillance to determine where the virus may be naturally circulating and where it may be truly absent.\n\nDetailed information on these outbreaks (from 2006 to 2013) can be obtained from OIE's WAHID database, in the section 'Detailed country (ies) disease incidence' at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Diseaseinformation/statusdetail (note: to view the information on HPAI, you need to choose the country and scroll down to the name of the disease and time period).\n\nThe house crow (_Corvus splendens_) is a widespread resident in India. The plumage is glossy black, except for the nape, sides of the head, upper back and breast, which are grey. The bill, legs, and feet are also black. It is found in villages, towns, and cities throughout its range. It is distributed all over India except in high altitudes and forests. The crow is also found in Iran, Sri Lanka, Pakistan and Burma, and was self-introduced to East Africa, Indian Ocean islands, Malaysia, and South Africa (http://www.birding.in/birds/Passeriformes/Corvidae/house_crow.htm).\n\nA picture of the house crow (_C. splendens_) can be seen at http://www.birding.in/birds/Passeriformes/Corvidae/house_crow.htm.\n\nA map showing the states of India is available at http://www.ephotopix.com/image/asia/india_state_map.gif, and a HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map is available at http://healthmap.org/r/2i2v. - Mod.CRD]", "summary": "Measures applied: disinfection of infected premises/establishment(s); 27(09) [edited]\n High Security Animal Disease Laboratory, Bhopal (national laboratory) / house crow / virus isolation / 6 Feb 2014\n\n Date of pre-confirmation of the event: 6 Feb 2014\n Date of start of the event: 31 Jan 2014\n Date submitted to OIE: 21 Feb 2014\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2014-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-02-06 00:00:00", "2014-01-31 00:00:00", "2021-03-27 00:00:00", "2014-02-21 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "INDIA", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Sri Lanka", "country": "Sri Lanka"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "East Africa", "country": "Namibia"}, {"location": "Keonjhar", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Malaysia", "country": "Malaysia"}, {"location": "Pakistan", "country": "Pakistan"}, {"location": "WAHID", "country": "Oman"}, {"location": "Iran", "country": "Iran"}, {"location": "Burma", "country": "Myanmar"}, {"location": "New Delhi", "country": "India"}, {"location": "South Africa", "country": "South Africa"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2287700", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (76): Cambodia, H5N1", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2287700", "date": "2014-02-19 16:19:55", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (76): CAMBODIA, H5N1\n*******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: 19 Feb 2014\nSource: Cambodia MOH press release [edited]\nhttp://www.cdcmoh.gov.kh/PressRelease/50-PressRelease.Eng.pdf\n\n\nThe Ministry of Health (MoH) of the Kingdom of Cambodia wishes to advise members of the public that one new human case of avian influenza has been confirmed to be the H5Nl virus. This is the 3rd case this year [2014] and the 50th person to become infected with the H5Nl virus in Cambodia.\n\nThe case is from Kratie province. Of the 50 confirmed cases, 38 were children under 14, and 27 of the 50 were female. In addition, since the 1st case happened in Cambodia in 2005, only 16 cases have survived.\n\nA 4-year-old boy from KbalTraclt village, Sre Cha commune, Snourl district, Kratie province was confirmed positive by Institut Pasteur du Cambodge (IPC) on [14th Feb 2014]. The boy had onset of fever and vomiting on [8 Feb 2014]. The boy was detected by the mobile surveillance team during contact tracing of the 2nd confirmed case on [12 Feb 2014]. His symptoms were fever, running nose, vomiting, sore throat and cough. He was admitted to Kratie Provincial Hospital on [13 Feb 2014], and Tamiflu was administered on the same day. The symptoms were mild, and the boy is now in good condition.\n\nThe case had direct exposure to dead and sick poultry. The boy played with and carried dead chickens 6 days before developing symptoms. Around mid-January [2014], a high number of poultry (around 350 animals comprising chickens, ducks, and geese) started to die in the village. Animal Health officers took samples from sick/dead chickens on [9 Feb 2014], and they were tested negative for H5N1 by the National Veterinary Research Institute (NAVRI).\n\nNational and local Rapid Response Teams (RRTs) are conducting an outbreak investigation and responses following the national protocol.\n\n'Avian influenza H5N1 remains a serious threat to the health of all Cambodians and more so for children, who seem to be most vulnerable and are at high risk. There have been 50 cases of H5N1 infection in humans since 2005, and here is the 3rd case of this year [2014]. Children often care for domestic poultry by feeding them, cleaning pens, and gathering eggs. Children may also have closer contact with poultry, as they often treat them as pets and also seem to be most vulnerable and are at high risk because they like to play where poultry are found. I urge parents and guardians to keep children away from sick or dead poultry and prevent them from playing with chickens and ducks. Parents and guardians must also make sure children thoroughly wash their hands with soap and water before eating and after any contact with poultry. Hands may carry the virus that cannot be seen by the naked eye. Soap washes away the virus on hands. If children have rapid or difficult breathing, their parents should seek medical attention at the nearest health facility, and attending physicians must be made aware of any exposure to sick or dead poultry,' said H.E. Dr. Mam Bunheng, Minster of Health.\n\nA nationwide public health education campaign using the radio was launched at the end of January 2014 with prevention messages. Also, a public health education campaign is being conducted in KhalTrach village, Kratie province, using information, education and communications materials to inform families on how to protect themselves from contracting avian influenza. The government's message is to wash hands often with soap and water, before eating and after coming into contact with poultry; keep children away from poultry; keep poultry away from living areas; do not eat dead or sick poultry; and all poultry eaten should be well cooked.\n\nH5N1 influenza is a flu that normally spreads between sick poultry, but it can sometimes spread from poultry to humans. Human H5N1 avian influenza is a very serious disease that requires hospitalization. Although the virus currently does not easily spread among humans, if the virus changes, it could easily be spread like seasonal influenza. Hence, early recognition of cases is important.\n\nThe Ministry of Health will continue to keep the public informed of developments via the MoH website http://www.cdcmoh.gov.kh, where relevant health education materials can also be downloaded.\n\nFor more information on human influenza, please call the MoH Influenza Hotline numbers: 115 (free call): 012 488 981 or 089 669 567.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[The majority of cases of human infection with avian influenza viruses reported this year [2014] have been infected with LPAI A(H7N9) in China. A(H5N1) human infections have been reported in Canada (imported from Beijing, China), Egypt, Viet Nam, and Cambodia since the beginning of 2014 (see prior ProMED-mail posts Avian influenza, human (13): Canada ex China (BJ) H5N1, fatal, case report 20140112.2167282, Avian influenza, human (25): Egypt (DK) H5N1, RFI 20140120.2184238, Avian influenza, human (29): Viet Nam (BP) H5N1, fatal 20140121.2221781, Avian influenza, human (53): China, H5N1, H7N9, update 20140202.2249920, Avian influenza, human (57): Cambodia, H5N1, 1st case in 2014 20140204.2254871, and Avian influenza, human (69): Cambodia (KC) H5N1, death of siblings 20140212.2273521). This represents the 4th reported case of H5N1 infection in Cambodia this year (2014).\n\nKratie province is located in the central eastern part of Cambodia. Prior cases of human H5N1 infection reported by Cambodia this year (2014) included 2 siblings who died in the same district in Kratie province earlier this month (7 Feb 2014) and a 5-year-old boy from Kampong Thom province (bordering Kratie province to the west). For a map of Cambodia showing provinces, see http://www.vidiani.com/?p=3257. For a map of Cambodia, see http://healthmap.org/r/1iGB. - Mod.MPP]", "summary": "human infections have been reported in Canada (imported from Beijing, China), Egypt, Viet Nam, and Cambodia since the beginning of 2014 (see prior ProMED-mail posts Avian influenza, human (13): Canada ex China (BJ) H5N1, fatal, case report 20140112.2167282, Avian influenza, human (25): Egypt (DK) H5N1, RFI 20140120.2184238, Avian influenza, human (29): Viet Nam (BP) H5N1, fatal 20140121.2221781, Avian influenza, human (53): China, H5N1, H7N9, update 20140202.2249920, Avian influenza, human (57): Cambodia, H5N1, 1st case in 2014 20140204.2254871, and Avian influenza, human (69): Cambodia (KC) H5N1, death of siblings 20140212.2273521). The government's message is to wash hands often with soap and water, before eating and after coming into contact with poultry; keep children away from poultry; keep poultry away from living areas; do not eat dead or sick poultry; and all poultry eaten should be well cooked. Prior cases of human H5N1 infection reported by Cambodia this year (2014) included 2 siblings who died in the same district in Kratie province earlier this month (7 Feb 2014) and a 5-year-old boy from Kampong Thom province (bordering Kratie province to the west). "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (25): China (GZ) HPAI H5N1, poultry, spread, OIE", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2287573", "date": "2014-02-19 15:10:51", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (25): CHINA (GUIZHOU) HPAI H5N1, POULTRY, SPREAD, OIE\n*********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 18 Feb 2014\nSource: Shanghai Daily, Xinhua news Agency report [summ., edited]\nhttp://www.shanghaidaily.com/article/article_xinhua.aspx?id=201295\n\n\nThe Ministry of Agriculture (MOA) on Tuesday [18 Feb 2014] confirmed outbreaks of H5N1 bird flu in poultry in southwest China's Guizhou Province.\n\nOn 13 Feb 2014, a farm in a village of Xixiu District in Anshun City of Guizhou reported [that] 3629 chickens had showed symptoms of suspected avian flu and that 976 of them had died.\n\nThe National Avian Influenza Reference Laboratory confirmed the epidemic was H5N1 after testing collected samples, according to the MOA.\n\nLocal authorities have sealed off and sterilized the infected area. The infected chickens have been culled and safely disposed of to prevent the disease from spreading, said the MOA.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[This is the 3rd HPAI H5N1 in China since the start (on 27 Dec 2013) of this recurring epizootic. A follow-up report on this outbreak has been submitted to the OIE on 18 Feb 2014, including the following data on 'total animals affected':\nSusceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\n324 268 / 3629 / 976 / 323 292 / 0\n\nAdditional information is available in the follow-up report above at http://tinyurl.com/kh5ussc.\n\nAn interactive map showing the 3 recent outbreaks is available in OIE's 'event summary' at http://tinyurl.com/l4omevo. Of these outbreaks, 2 are located in Guizhou province and one in Hubei province. The distant locations may be indicative of a wider circulation of the virus. Such a concern has been underlined by the recent information from Canada on a person returning from a visit to China, who has become the 1st case of A(H5N1) infection in North America. The (unfortunately, fatal) infection had, most probably, been acquired in Beijing, suspectedly by the patient's passing through or near an illegal live bird market (see ProMED-mail archive no 20140212.2274077).\n\nThe current HPAI H5N1 Chinese outbreak in poultry is regarded as 'continuing'. - Mod.AS\n\nMaps of China can be seen at http://www.sacu.org/maps/provmap.png and http://healthmap.org/r/ao4Q. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n A follow-up report on this outbreak has been submitted to the OIE on 18 Feb 2014, including the following data on 'total animals affected':\nSusceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\n324 268 / 3629 / 976 / 323 292 / 0\n\n The infected chickens have been culled and safely disposed of to prevent the disease from spreading, said the MOA.\n\n--\n AVIAN INFLUENZA (25): CHINA (GUIZHOU) HPAI H5N1, POULTRY, SPREAD, OIE\n*********************************************************************\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n \n\nAn interactive map showing the 3 recent outbreaks is available in OIE's 'event summary' at http://tinyurl.com/l4omevo. \n\n\nThe Ministry of Agriculture (MOA) on Tuesday [18 Feb 2014] confirmed outbreaks of H5N1 bird flu in poultry in southwest China's Guizhou Province. The last question addressed H5N1].\n\nQ: Apart from the risk of A/H7N9 flu, the Central and Central Highland provinces of our country currently have an A/H5N1 influenza outbreak. What can the minister recommend to the people in this respect?\n\nMinister Cao Duc Phat: During this time, the influenza A/H5N1 is on the drive [upswing]. The prevention of this virus has been ascribed to the local authorities who are directed to coordinate the implementation of the relevant regulations. Special attention should be paid to the organization of surveillance activities to detect outbreaks promptly and to handle them thoroughly. In particular, we conduct vaccination in accordance with the provisions of the veterinary authority. Regarding the ongoing outbreak, we suggest that farmers comply with recommendations of the veterinary surgeons concerning disinfection measures to prevent the spread of the virus to poultry. In particular, be wary of the virus capacity to infect humans.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Viet Nam has submitted its follow-up report no 4 on the recent epizootic on Thu 13 Feb 2014. The current epizootic reportedly started in October 2013 and has caused, so far, 11 outbreaks, including the 6 new outbreaks covered in the current report, which are located in 6 separate provinces distributed throughout the country, from north to south (Nam Dinh, Khanh Hoa, Tay Ninh, Quang Ngai, Ca Mau, and Kon Tum).\n\nThe report does not specify the species affected (that is, chickens, ducks, geese, etc.).\n\nAccording to the report above, Viet Nam's applied control measures are: stamping out, movement control inside the country, vaccination in response to the outbreak(s), disinfection of infected premises/establishment(s).\n\nViet Nam is known to be infected by HPAI H5N1 since 2003. Its last major epizootic reportedly started in December 2006, with 360 outbreaks reported to the OIE throughout the years 2007-2012. Several outbreaks have been reported since. In September 2012, the Vietnamese noted the spread in the north of a new, extremely pathogenic strain of the H5N1 virus, suspected to have originated in China (see ProMED-mail posts 20120908.1286497, 20120910.1288966, and 20120920.1300398).\n\nSince 2003, Viet Nam has reported 126 human cases of avian influenza H5N1, of which 63 died. Of the 126, a total of 112 were recorded in the year 2003. Since that time, there have only been sporadic human cases of H5N1 virus infection in Viet Nam. As noted by Mod.CP (in ProMED-mail post 20140201.2248635) '...therefore, it is too early to conclude that the human case in 2014 is the harbinger of a new outbreak.'\n\nFor an updated event summary with links to all follow-up reports and an interactive map, please go to http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?fupser=&dothis=&reportid=14229 (click for a larger map, zoom in). - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1jtz.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n The current epizootic reportedly started in October 2013 and has caused, so far, 11 outbreaks, including the 6 new outbreaks covered in the current report, which are located in 6 separate provinces distributed throughout the country, from north to south (Nam Dinh, Khanh Hoa, Tay Ninh, Quang Ngai, Ca Mau, and Kon Tum). "2014-02-17 09:30:15", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (23): VIET NAM, H5N1, SPREAD, POULTRY\n*****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 17 Feb 2014\nSource: World Poultry [edited]\nhttp://www.worldpoultry.net/Broilers/Health/2014/2/Vietnamese-bird-flu-outbreak-spreads-to-eight-provinces-1464843W/\n\n\nViet Nam has reported outbreaks of A/H5N1 avian influenza in 8 provinces, the country's Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development (MARD) has stated.\n\nAvian flu outbreaks have been noted in Nam Dinh province in northern Viet Nam, and provinces including Ca Mau, Dak Lak, Khanh Hoa, Kon Tum, Long An, Quang Ngai, and Tay Ninh in the central and southern regions, Xinhua [News Agency] has reported.\n\nCullings have been taking place across the provinces resulting in the death of 30 000 infected birds. Quang Ngai province has been most effected with the death of 5000 birds. Other provinces are also being put on high alert as some 4 million birds in Quang Nam province have not been vaccinated against the disease yet, the Quang Nam Veterinary Department stated.\n\nReports suggest that Prime Minister Nguyen Tan Dung has urged the establishment of inspection teams to promote anti-bird flu efforts at localities, especially those vulnerable to the epidemic. The dispatch requested the minister of MARD, who is also the head of the National Steering Committee for Bird Flu Prevention and Control, to take immediate action to prevent the transfer of avian flu to human. So far this year [2014], Viet Nam has reported 2 human deaths from A/H5N1 avian flu in southern Binh Phuoc and Dong Thap provinces.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[A local newspaper has reported on 17 Feb 2014 the spread of H5N1 to 10 of Viet Nam's provinces (see http://www.trust.org/item/20140217005245-u7n10).\n\nViet Nam has submitted to the OIE its follow-up report on Thu 13 Feb 2014, mentioning outbreaks in 6 provinces (see ProMED-mail posting 20140214.2278294). Its next weekly report is expected to provide the actual, updated geographic distribution of the spreading epizootic. - Mod.AS\n\nMaps of Viet Nam can be seen at http://www.vietbando.com/maps/#&t=0&st=0&l=6&kv=17.6440220,107.237548 (with provinces) and http://healthmap.org/r/1jtz. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[A local newspaper has reported on 17 Feb 2014 the spread of H5N1 to 10 of Viet Nam's provinces (see http://www.trust.org/item/20140217005245-u7n10). \n\nAvian flu outbreaks have been noted in Nam Dinh province in northern Viet Nam, and provinces including Ca Mau, Dak Lak, Khanh Hoa, Kon Tum, Long An, Quang Ngai, and Tay Ninh in the central and southern regions, Xinhua [News Agency] has reported. \n\nViet Nam has submitted to the OIE its follow-up report on Thu 13 Feb 2014, mentioning outbreaks in 6 provinces (see ProMED-mail posting 20140214.2278294). AVIAN INFLUENZA (23): VIET NAM, H5N1, SPREAD, POULTRY\n*****************************************************\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2014-02-13 00:00:00", "2014-02-17 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Viet Nam", "country": "Vietnam"}, {"location": "Quang Nam", "country": "Vietnam"}, {"location": "Viet Nam 's", "country": "Armenia"}, {"location": "Nam Dinh", "country": "Vietnam"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2274077", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (70): Canada (AB) ex China, H5N1, bird market origin susp.", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2274077", "date": "2014-02-12 22:55:14", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (70): CANADA (ALBERTA) ex CHINA, H5N1, BIRD MARKET ORIGIN SUSPECTED\n******************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 11 Feb 2014\nSource: The Canadian Press [edited]\nhttp://www.ctvnews.ca/health/health-headlines/canadian-who-died-from-h5n1-flu-may-have-caught-it-in-illegal-bird-market-1.1680939#ixzz2t2Sp0Tqw\n\n\nChinese researchers are suggesting Canada's 1st H5N1 influenza patient may have contracted the [avian influenza] virus passing through or near an illegal live bird market in Beijing. And Canadian scientists have published a report on the full genetic sequence of virus taken from the Alberta woman, who died in early January 2014 after returning from a 3-week trip to her native China. The source of the woman's infection has been a mystery; she spent her entire trip in Beijing, where H5N1 reportedly hasn't been discovered for some time, and her travelling companion said she did not have contact with live birds while there. But scientists from Beijing's Centre for Disease Prevention and Control are hypothesizing that illegal live bird markets may have been the source of the woman's infection.\n\nIn a letter to the Journal of Infection, they say that even though Beijing banned live poultry markets in 2005, an illegal trade in live poultry continues in the city. They say it is possible the woman was infected while passing market stalls that surreptitiously sell live poultry. It is the custom in China to eat chicken when it has been freshly killed, and the sale of live poultry remains common in many parts of the country. The scientists point to a previous H5N1 case in Beijing, a woman who died in early January 2009. She had bought a live duck at a market in Hebei province, near Beijing, and prepared it for cooking by de-feathering it and gutting it.\n\nTesting of the area around the market stall where the woman bought the duck revealed the presence of H5N1 viruses that were closely related to the ones that infected her. As well, they note that several human infections with the newer [more recently isolated] H7N9 bird flu virus have been reported in Beijing. The scientists suggest the illegal trade in live poultry in Beijing may pose a high risk of human infection with bird flu viruses for people living in the city.\n\n'The enhanced inspection of illegal selling of live poultry, the strict regulation of transporting live poultry from regions outside of Beijing as well as the health education on changing dietetic culture is greatly warranted in Beijing in order to reduce the risk of infection with avian influenza viruses in the general population of Beijing including visiting foreigners,' they write in their letter.\n\nMeanwhile, scientists from Alberta's provincial laboratory, the universities of Calgary and Edmonton, the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and the Public Health Agency of Canada's National Microbiology Laboratory in Winnipeg have published an analysis of the full genetic sequence of the virus recovered from the Alberta woman. Their report will be in the May 2014 issue of the CDC's journal Emerging Infectious Diseases, but it has been published early online. They say the virus is from a clade -- a subgroup of the main H5N1 family -- that has been found recently in China, Viet Nam and Indonesia. Analysis suggests the virus is a close match for one [isolate] that has been made into a vaccine seed strain that manufacturers could use if H5N1 vaccine is required. The authors say additional study of the virus is needed to see whether its characteristics are responsible for the unusual symptoms the Alberta woman suffered.\n\nWhile she had the respiratory infection that is characteristic of influenza infection, she also had evidence of meningoencephalitis, infection in the brain.\n\n[Byline: Helen Branswell]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[These findings are consistent with the expectation that the [China-born] Canadian contracted H5N1 virus infection in China during vacation and not during her residence in Alberta. - Mod.CP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/73a6.]", "summary": "\n\n'The enhanced inspection of illegal selling of live poultry, the strict regulation of transporting live poultry from regions outside of Beijing as well as the health education on changing dietetic culture is greatly warranted in Beijing in order to reduce the risk of infection with avian influenza viruses in the general population of Beijing including visiting foreigners,' they write in their letter. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n In a letter to the Journal of Infection, they say that even though Beijing banned live poultry markets in 2005, an illegal trade in live poultry continues in the city. The scientists suggest the illegal trade in live poultry in Beijing may pose a high risk of human infection with bird flu viruses for people living in the city. \n\n\nChinese researchers are suggesting Canada's 1st H5N1 influenza patient may have contracted the [avian influenza] virus passing through or near an illegal live bird market in Beijing. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[These findings are consistent with the expectation that the [China-born] Canadian contracted H5N1 virus infection in China during vacation and not during her residence in Alberta. But scientists from Beijing's Centre for Disease Prevention and Control are hypothesizing that illegal live bird markets may have been the source of the woman's infection. And Canadian scientists have published a report on the full genetic sequence of virus taken from the Alberta woman, who died in early January 2014 after returning from a 3-week trip to her native China. \n\nWhile she had the respiratory infection that is characteristic of influenza infection, she also had evidence of meningoencephalitis, infection in the brain.", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2005-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2070-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-05-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "ALBERTA", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Indonesia", "country": "Indonesia"}, {"location": "CHINA", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Viet Nam", "country": "Vietnam"}, {"location": "Alberta", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Calgary", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Hebei province", "country": "China"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "CANADA", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Beijing", "country": "China"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2275510", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (20): Cambodia (KC) H5N1, poultry, OIE", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2275510", "date": "2014-02-13 16:48:32", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (19): CAMBODIA (KAMPONG CHAM) H5N1, POULTRY, OIE\n****************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 13 Feb 2014\nSource: OIE, WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database), weekly disease information 2014; 27(07) [edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=14759\n\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza, Cambodia\n-------------------------------------------\nInformation received on 13 Feb 2014 from Dr Sen Sovann, Deputy Secretary General, Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries, Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries, Phnom Penh, Cambodia\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 7 Feb 2014\nDate of pre-confirmation of the event: 10 Feb 2014\nReport date: 12 Feb 2014\nDate submitted to OIE: 13 Feb 2014\nReason for notification: reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 18 Aug 2013\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory (basic), laboratory (advanced), necropsy\nThis event pertains to the whole country\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks:\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1: Svay Prey, Sandaek, Batheay, Kampong Cham\nDate of start of the outbreak: 7 Feb 2014\nOutbreak status: resolved (11 Feb 2014)\nEpidemiological unit: village\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nBirds / 5250 / 4466 / 4466 / 784 / 0 /\n\nOutbreak statistics:\nSpecies / Apparent morbidity rate / Apparent mortality rate / Apparent case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBirds / 85.07 percent / 85.07 percent / 100 percent / 100 percent\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\nEpidemiological comments: on 7 Feb 2014, owners of duck flocks reported that their ducks were sick and died in the village. District and provincial veterinarians went there for examination and found that 2 duck flocks of 2 owners were sick and died, with clinical signs as leg weakness, white diarrhea, twisted necks, blank eye, motionless, and seizures. They then took 5 samples from each duck flock (10 samples) and sent them to the National Veterinary Research Institute (NaVRI) for diagnostic testing.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: stamping out; movement control inside the country; disinfection of infected premises/establishment(s); dipping/spraying; vaccination prohibited; no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: control of wildlife reservoirs.\n\nDiagnostic test results:\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nNational Veterinary Research Institute (NaVRI) (national laboratory) / Birds / anatomo-pathological examination / 10 Feb 2014 / Positive\nNational Veterinary Research Institute (NaVRI) (national laboratory) / Birds / real-time PCR / 10 Feb 2014 / Positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This OIE immediate report officially confirms highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) in birds in the Kampong Champ province. The H5N1 subtype was isolated in Kampong Champ and determined to be the cause of death of the 2 siblings reported in ProMED-mail archive 20140212.2273521. Please refer to Mod.CP's commentary in the same report.\n\nDuring 2013, Cambodia reported 7 outbreaks of HPAI, serotype H5N1: 1in Battambang province, 1 in Kampot, 2 in Kampong Cham, 1 in Kampong Speu, 1 in Siem Reap, and 1 in Takeo. Detailed information on these outbreaks is available at, http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapEventSummary&reportid=12931 and http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapEventSummary&reportid=13939.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Cambodia can be seen at http://healthmap.org/r/8azs. 27(07) [edited]\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2014-02-11 00:00:00", "2014-02-10 00:00:00", "2014-02-13 00:00:00", "2014-02-25 00:00:00", "2014-02-07 00:00:00", "2013-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Battambang province", "country": "Cambodia"}, {"location": "Kampot", "country": "Cambodia"}, {"location": "WAHID", "country": "Oman"}, {"location": "Cambodia", "country": "Cambodia"}, {"location": "Kampong Speu", "country": "Cambodia"}, {"location": "Mod", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Takeo", "country": "Cambodia"}, {"location": "Phnom Penh", "country": "Cambodia"}, {"location": "Kampong Champ", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2273521", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (69): Cambodia (KC) H5N1, death of siblings", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2273521", "date": "2014-02-12 22:12:33", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (69): CAMBODIA (KAMPONG CHAM) H5N1, DEATH OF SIBLINGS\n****************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 12 Feb 2014\nSource: The Cambodia Daily [edited]\nhttp://www.cambodiadaily.com/news/two-siblings-from-kratie-die-from-bird-flu-on-same-day-51979/\n\n\nA 7-year-old boy and his 3-year-old sister died from bird flu [avian H5N1 influenza virus infection] at Kampong Cham Provincial Referral Hospital on Friday [7 Feb 2014], Hong Palla, team leader of the rapid response unit at Kratie Provincial Health Department, said Tuesday [11 Feb 2014]. The 2 young siblings from Snuol district's Sre Cha commune contracted the H5N1 virus on Sat 1 Feb 2014 and were taken by their parents for treatment at Kampong Cham provincial hospital 5 days later.\n\n'Before the children were sick they had touched and eaten poultry,' Mr Palla said, explaining that the siblings' parents had found a dead bird in the village and cooked it for dinner. [The 3-year-old girl] died at about 1 a.m. on [7 Feb 2014] and her older brother died at 6 p.m. on the same day, Mr Palla said. At the time of the children's deaths almost all of the birds in the village had also died of an illness, he said.\n\nKratie provincial hospital cooperated with Kampong Cham provincial hospital to check if the children had avian influenza, Mr Palla said. 'Test results show that the boy victim really had H5N1 but the girl victim died before she could be tested.' However, he said it was concluded that the girl had also died from avian influenza because the pair had shown similar symptoms at the same time, after eating the chicken. On Saturday [8 Feb 2014], an official from the Provincial Health Department 'came to the victim's village to educate locals about the H5N1 virus...[telling them] not to eat or touch a sick bird,' Mr Palla said.\n\nA 5-year-old boy from Kampong Thom province's Santuk district, who was confirmed positive for H5N1 on [1 Feb 2014], was named the 1st case of avian influenza this year [2014] by the Ministry of Health last week, after 2013 saw the worst outbreak of the virus the country has ever seen, with 12 fatalities.\n\nVicky Houfrie, communications officer at the World Health Organization in Phnom Penh, confirmed that there had been new fatalities from H5N1 but said, 'We are waiting for the press release from the Ministry of Health before we can comment.'\n\n[Byline: Ben Sokhean]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[So far the only avian influenza viruses to cause severe respiratory disease in the human population are the H7N9 virus which has been prevalent only in the Chinese population during the period 2013/14, and the H5N1 virus that appeared in 2003 and has spread to 15 countries during the period 2003-2014. Up to the end of 2013 avian H5N1 influenza virus has been responsible for 648 cases and 384 deaths in 15 countries since 2003 (see\nhttp://www.who.int/influenza/human_animal_interface/EN_GIP_20131210CumulativeNumberH5N1cases.pdf?ua=1%3E).\n\nMaps of Cambodia can be accessed at http://ephotopix.com/image/asia/cambodia_province_map.gif and http://healthmap.org/r/aaFd. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A 7-year-old boy and his 3-year-old sister died from bird flu [avian H5N1 influenza virus infection] at Kampong Cham Provincial Referral Hospital on Friday [7 Feb 2014], Hong Palla, team leader of the rapid response unit at Kratie Provincial Health Department, said Tuesday [11 Feb 2014]. \n\nA 5-year-old boy from Kampong Thom province's Santuk district, who was confirmed positive for H5N1 on [1 Feb 2014], was named the 1st case of avian influenza this year [2014] by the Ministry of Health last week, after 2013 saw the worst outbreak of the virus the country has ever seen, with 12 fatalities.
