"https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2273278", "date": "2014-02-12 20:30:20", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (18): VIET NAM (KON TUM, THANH HOA) H5N1, POULTRY, SUSPECTED, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n*****************************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 11 Feb 2014\nSource: Xinhua News Agency [edited]\nhttp://news.xinhuanet.com/english/health/2014-02/11/c_133106603.htm\n\n\nCentral Viet Nam's province of Thanh Hoa and central highlands province of Kon Tum have reported [avian influenza] outbreaks in poultry, local media reported Tuesday [11 Feb 2014]\n\nViet Nam's state-run radio Voice of Vietnam (VOV) said on Tuesday [11 Feb 2014] that 186 chickens died on 8 Feb 2014 with positive test results of H5N1 bird flu from samples collected on a farm in Tinh Gia district, Viet Nam's central Thanh Hoa province.\n\nDepartment of Agriculture and Rural Development of Thanh Hoa province have asked the district to cull [kill] and safely dispose of all chickens in the infected farm and neighboring families to prevent the disease from spreading.\n\nViet Nam's state-run news agency VNA reported Tuesday [11 Feb 2014] that another outbreak of H5N1 bird flu in chickens has been announced in the country's central highlands province of Kon Tum. About 600 chickens in Kon Tum province showed symptoms of suspected avian flu and 470 died on 8 Feb 2014. Some 130 chickens [that were] left have been culled on Tuesday [11 Feb 2014] after the official conclusion was reached that they were positive for avian influenza or H5N1 virus.\n\nAccording to VNA, [a veterinarian] was reported to be hospitalized with symptoms of fever, fatigue and loss of appetite after contact with the above-mentioned outbreak in Kon Tum province. The patient was now quarantined for follow-up treatment for the suspected H5N1 bird flu, said VNA.\n\nEarlier on 28 Jan 2014, another avian influenza outbreak was reported with nearly 1000 chickens sick and dead in Kon Tum province, according to VNA.\n\nThese outbreaks raise the alarm over the spread of H5N1 virus in Viet Nam among both local people and international communities.\n\nIn a related development, the United States Agency for International Development [USAID] announced on Tuesday [11 Feb 2014] a project worth USD 800 000 for preventing bird flu in Viet Nam. The project aims at helping reduce risks to community health caused by bird flu, epidemic and other emerging infectious diseases in Viet Nam from now till September 2015, VNA reported.\n\nBird flu, or avian influenza, is a contagious disease of animal origin caused by viruses that normally infect only birds and, less commonly, pigs. It can be fatal to humans.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[The current HPAI H5N1 epizootic in Viet Nam started on 7 Oct 2013; so far 5 outbreaks have been reported, all in North Viet Nam: the 1st one in Hoa Binh province (reported in October 2013) and the last 4 in Bac Ninh province (recorded in follow-up report no 3, submitted on 10 Jan 2014). An OIE summary, with an interactive map showing the 4 outbreaks reported in 2014, is available at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?fupser=&dothis=&reportid=14229 (click on the outbreak cluster and zoom in). Further commentary and background information are available in ProMED-mail post 20131015.2002852.\nAccording to the media report above, the disease is spreading into central Viet Nam (Thanh Hoa and Kon Tum provinces). An official update in a 4th follow-up report to OIE is anticipated. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1jtz.]", "summary": "[11 Feb 2014]\n\nViet Nam's state-run radio Voice of Vietnam (VOV) said on Tuesday [11 Feb 2014] that 186 chickens died on 8 Feb 2014 with positive test results of H5N1 bird flu from samples collected on a farm in Tinh Gia district, Viet Nam's central Thanh Hoa province. (57): Cambodia, H5N1, 1st case in 2014", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2254871", "date": "2014-02-04 17:24:40", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (57): CAMBODIA, H5N1, FIRST CASE IN 2014\n***************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 4 Feb 2014\nSource: Global Dispatch, Outbreak News [edited]\nhttp://www.theglobaldispatch.com/h5n1-avian-influenza-first-human-case-reported-in-cambodia-in-2014/\n\n\nAfter reporting 26 human H5N1 avian influenza cases in 2013, by far the most of any country, the Kingdom of Cambodia has announced its 1st case of the lethal bird flu in 2014, according to a Ministry of Health press release on Tue 4 Feb 2014.\n\nThe case is a 5 year old boy from Chongda village, Tbaung Kropeur commune, Santuk district, Kampong Thom province, who presented with fever and headache on 24 Jan 2014. His condition worsened, and he was admitted to Jayavarman VII Hospital, Siem Reap, on 30 Jan 2014. He was given Tamiflu [oseltamivir] the next day. Testing by L'Institut Pasteur du Cambodge confirmed the presence of H5N1 avian influenza virus. He is currently in a stable condition.\n\nThe investigation into the case revealed that some 200 chickens had died suddenly in mid-January [2014], some of which were prepared for food. In addition, the boy had exposure to the affected area. This case represents the 48th human H5N1 avian influenza case in Cambodia since the 1st case was seen in 2005.\n\n[byline: Robert Herriman]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[According to the WHO table of the cumulative number of confirmed human cases of avian influenza in Cambodia, there have been 47 cases of H5N1 avian influenza virus infection in Cambodia since the 1st cases were reported to the WHO in 2003, 33 of whom died http://www.who.int/influenza/human_animal_interface/EN_GIP_20131210CumulativeNumberH5N1cases.pdf?ua=1%3E. More than half of the cases were recorded in 2013, in contrast to most other countries, where H5N1 cases have been declining. It is not clear why this has occurred. - Mod.CP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1iGB.]", "summary": "\n\n[byline: Robert Herriman]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[According to the WHO table of the cumulative number of confirmed human cases of avian influenza in Cambodia, there have been 47 cases of H5N1 avian influenza virus infection in Cambodia since the 1st cases were reported to the WHO in 2003, 33 of whom died http://www.who.int/influenza/human_animal_interface/EN_GIP_20131210CumulativeNumberH5N1cases.pdf?ua=1%3E. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n http://www.theglobaldispatch.com/h5n1-avian-influenza-first-human-case-reported-in-cambodia-in-2014/\n\n\nAfter reporting 26 human H5N1 avian influenza cases in 2013, by far the most of any country, the Kingdom of Cambodia has announced its 1st case of the lethal bird flu in 2014, according to a Ministry of Health press release on Tue 4 Feb 2014. The investigation into the case revealed that some 200 chickens had died suddenly in mid-January [2014], some of which were prepared for food. It is not clear why this has occurred.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2057-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-01-30 00:00:00", "2003-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-01-24 00:00:00", "2005-03-25 00:00:00", "2013-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-02-04 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "the Kingdom of Cambodia", "country": "Colombia"}, {"location": "Chongda village", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Kampong Thom", "country": "Cambodia"}, {"location": "Cambodia", "country": "Cambodia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2248635", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (51): Viet Nam (DT) H5N1, fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2248635", "date": "2014-02-01 21:12:30", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (51): VIET NAM (DONG THAP) H5N1, FATAL\n************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 30 Jan 2014\nSource: The Voice of Vietnam [edited]\nhttp://english.vov.vn/Society/First-person-dies-of-AH5N1-in-Dong-Thap/272854.vov\n\n\nThe 1st Vietnamese victim of the A/H5N1 avian flu has been identified as a person born in 1954, in Tan Long village, Thanh Binh district, Dong Thap province. Dong Thap Department of Health Vice Director Doan Tuan Buu said the patient was admitted to hospital suffering a high fever on 22 Jan 2014. She was transferred to An Giang Province General Hospital on 27 Jan 2014 but died on 28 Jan 2014. Her blood tested positive for A/H5N1. She recalled having contact with poultry before falling ill.\n\nAfter receiving the official blood test result, conducted by HCM City's Pasteur Institute, provincial medical and veterinary authorities immediately implemented quarantine measures to contain any contamination. The Pasteur Institute began coordinating with local authorities on 30 Jan 2014 to ensure the disease spreads no further.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[Of the 648 human cases of avian A/H5N1 influenza virus infection recorded world-wide up to the end of 2013, a total of 125 were recorded in Viet Nam. Of these 125, a total of 112 were recorded in the year 2003 (see: http://www.who.int/influenza/human_animal_interface/EN_GIP_20131210CumulativeNumberH5N1cases.pdf?ua=1). Since that time, there have only been sporadic cases of H5N1 virus infection in Viet Nam; therefore, it is too early to conclude that the above case in 2014 is the harbinger of a new outbreak.\n\nThe above case is identified as the 1st in 2014, but in fact, the 1st death attributed to H5N1 bird flu in Viet Nam in 2014 occurred in southern Binh Phuc province. This was announced by the country's Department of Preventive Medicine of the Ministry of Health on 20 Jan 2014. The victim, a man aged 52, was hospitalized on 11 Jan 2014 due to symptoms of fever, cough, and shortness of breath. He died on 18 Jan 2014, the 1st death in Viet Nam in 2014, 9 months after the most recent previous case.\n\nThe locations of the provinces of Viet Nam can be found on the map at: http://www.vietnamtourism.com/e_pages/country/province.asp?mt=84651&uid=1238. A HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map is available at: http://healthmap.org/r/9-aG. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nThe above case is identified as the 1st in 2014, but in fact, the 1st death attributed to H5N1 bird flu in Viet Nam in 2014 occurred in southern Binh Phuc province. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[Of the 648 human cases of avian A/H5N1 influenza virus infection recorded world-wide up to the end of 2013, a total of 125 were recorded in Viet Nam. He died on 18 Jan 2014, the 1st death in Viet Nam in 2014, 9 months after the most recent previous case. She was transferred to An Giang Province General Hospital on 27 Jan 2014 but died on 28 Jan 2014. Since that time, there have only been sporadic cases of H5N1 virus infection in Viet Nam; therefore, it is too early to conclude that the above case in 2014 is the harbinger of a new outbreak. AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (51): VIET NAM (DONG THAP) H5N1, FATAL\n************************************************************\n", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2014-01-22 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-01-28 00:00:00", "2014-01-27 00:00:00", "2014-01-18 00:00:00", "2052-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-01-30 00:00:00", "2014-01-11 00:00:00", "2051-03-25 00:00:00", "1954-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-01-20 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "HCM City 's", "country": "Vietnam"}, {"location": "Thanh Binh", "country": "Vietnam"}, {"location": "Dong Thap", "country": "Vietnam"}, {"location": "an Giang Province General Hospital", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Viet Nam", "country": "Vietnam"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2221781", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (29): Viet Nam (BP) H5N1, fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2221781", "date": "2014-01-21 15:46:08", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (29): VIET NAM (BINH PHUOC), H5N1, FATAL\n***************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Mon 20 Jan 2014\nSource: Xinhua, English News [edited]\nhttp://news.xinhuanet.com/english/world/2014-01/20/c_133060530.htm\n\n\nThe 1st death caused by H5N1 bird flu in Viet Nam in 2014 has been reported in southern Binh Phuc province, the country's Department of Preventive Medicine under the Ministry of Health announced late Monday [20 Jan 2014].\n\nThe victim, a man aged 52, was hospitalized on 11 Jan 2014 due to symptoms of fever, cough, and shortness of breath. The patient was later confirmed infected with the virus, said the announcement, adding that his lung was damaged quickly. He died on 18 Jan 2014, the 1st death in Viet Nam in 2014 after 9 months without any H5N1 bird flu cases reported in humans.\n\nThe department recommended that local people should not eat sick, dead, or unknown-origin poultry. When poultry are detected sick or dead, local authorities should be informed immediately.\n\nBird flu, or avian influenza, is a contagious disease of animal origin caused by viruses that normally infect only birds and, less commonly, pigs. It can be fatal to humans.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Mon 20 Jan 3014\nSource: Xinhuanet, English news [edited]\nhttp://english.vov.vn/Society/Health/Vietnam-reports-1st-H5N1-birth-flu-death/272538.vov\n\n\nViet Nam's health officials on 20 Jan 2014 confirmed a 1st H5N1 avian flu death in the southern province of Binh Phuoc, the 1st in 2014.\n\nThe 52-year-old man, living in Binh Minh commune, Bu Dang district, was hospitalised on 11 Jan 2014, showing flu-like symptoms such as fever, coughing, and breathing difficulties. The patient was moved to Binh Phuoc provincial General Hospital 6 days later, yet his health continued deteriorating quickly. He was then brought to HCM City Hospital for Tropical Diseases on 18 Jan 2014 for emergency treatment, but he died on the same day. His blood sample tested positive for the deadly virulent strain A/H5N1. He was said to have slaughtered ducks and eaten duck meat. Epidemiological examinations show that a number of chickens raised by the patient's family and neighbours died of unknown causes.\n\nThe Preventive Medicine Department directed the Binh Phuoc provincial Department of Health to conduct epidemiological tests and intensify measures against a possible outbreak of bird flu in the locality. The HCM City Pasteur Institute was required to fan out to the affected commune to help with prevention.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[Binh Phuoc is in the south of Viet Nam. It is surrounded by Cambodia on the north and northwest, Dak Nong and Lam Dong provinces on the east, Dong Nai and Binh Duong provinces on the south, and Tay Ninh Province on the west. Binh Phuoc has plenty of forests with industrial trees such as rubber, coffee, cashew nut, and pepper. The main rivers are Saigon, Be, and Dong Nai.\n\nIts location can be found in the map at: http://www.vietnamtourism.com/e_pages/country/province.asp?mt=84651&uid=1238. - Mod.CP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1jtz.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\n Source: Xinhuanet, English news [edited]\nhttp://english.vov.vn/Society/Health/Vietnam-reports-1st-H5N1-birth-flu-death/272538.vov\n\n\nViet Nam's health officials on 20 Jan 2014 confirmed a 1st H5N1 avian flu death in the southern province of Binh Phuoc, the 1st in 2014. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n******\n He died on 18 Jan 2014, the 1st death in Viet Nam in 2014 after 9 months without any H5N1 bird flu cases reported in humans. AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (29): VIET NAM (BINH PHUOC), H5N1, FATAL\n***************************************************************\n The 1st death caused by H5N1 bird flu in Viet Nam in 2014 has been reported in southern Binh Phuc province, the country's Department of Preventive Medicine under the Ministry of Health announced late Monday \n\nThe victim, a man aged 52, was hospitalized on 11 Jan 2014 due to symptoms of fever, cough, and shortness of breath. The 52-year-old man, living in Binh Minh commune, Bu Dang district, was hospitalised on 11 Jan 2014, showing flu-like symptoms such as fever, coughing, and breathing difficulties. \n\nBird flu, or avian influenza, is a contagious disease of animal origin caused by viruses that normally infect only birds and, less commonly, pigs. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[Binh Phuoc is in the south of Viet Nam. \n\n--\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2014-01-18 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-01-20 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2014-01-11 00:00:00", "3014-01-20 00:00:00", "2052-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Cambodia", "country": "Cambodia"}, {"location": "Binh Minh", "country": "Vietnam"}, {"location": "Viet Nam 's", "country": "Armenia"}, {"location": "Saigon", "country": "Vietnam"}, {"location": "Viet Nam", "country": "Vietnam"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2182743", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (23): Canada ex China (BJ) H5N1 strain similarity", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2182743", "date": "2014-01-18 18:09:30", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (23): CANADA ex CHINA (BEIJING) H5N1 STRAIN SIMILARITY\n*****************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 15 Jan 2014\nSource: CBC News [edited]\nhttp://www.cbc.ca/news/health/h5n1-strain-from-alberta-nurse-resembles-chinese-strain-1.2498128\n\n\nCompleting the genome sequence of the Albertan [Alberta province, Canada] H5N1 virus became a research priority. Canadian scientists studying H5N1 bird flu virus samples taken from an Alberta woman who died with the infection say that so far it seems to resemble a Chinese strain. Researchers at Canada's National Microbiology Laboratory [NML] and Alberta's provincial laboratory isolated samples of the virus and are working on sequencing it. They're looking to see if the sequence is the same as previous ones in the search for clues to the [3 Jan 2014] death.\n\n'Based on the genome sequence data collected to date, researchers at the [NML] have found it to be consistent with a previously circulating H5N1 strain from China,' a spokesperson said in an email Wednesday [15 Jan 2014]. 'The 1st research priority for the NML is to complete the whole genome sequence of the virus, and then analyze the data to learn more about the specific traits and characteristics of the virus. The genome analysis will help inform and guide all future research priorities.' If the sample differs from previous samples, then researchers could take a closer look. The sample will also be shared with the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Once the genome sequencing is complete, the information will be uploaded to the Global Initiative on Sharing All Influenza Data (GISAID) and be made available to researchers around the world.\n\nThe Red Deer Hospital nurse, who was in her 20s, had travelled to Beijing for a 3-week visit. Earlier this week, investigators with Alberta Health Services and the NML provided more clinical details about the patient. Virologist Kevin Fonseca of Alberta Health Services and his colleagues said the patient experienced symptoms of malaise, chest pain, and fever during the return flight on [27 Dec 2013] and went to the local emergency department on [28 Dec 2013]. One of the mysteries is that she had no known contact with poultry during her trip, public health officials said in announcing the case -- the 1st reported death from avian flu in North America. No H5N1 outbreaks have been reported in Beijing recently. After a chest x-ray and CT scan suggested a diagnosis of pneumonia, the woman was prescribed an antibiotic and discharged home. The patient came back to the same emergency department on [1 Jan 2014] with worsening inflammation of the membrane surrounding the lung, chest pain, shortness of breath, a mild headache that felt worse when she moved her head, nausea, vomiting and other symptoms, Fonseca's team said in their posting on ProMED-mail, an internet-based disease alert system [see posts listed below].\n\nOn [2 Jan 2014], the patient reported visual changes and a continuing headache. As oxygen needs increased, doctors admitted her to the ICU for intubation and ventilation. In the early morning of [3 Jan 2014], she had sudden tachycardia or fast heart rate and severe hypertension, followed by hypotension. Doctors took steps to keep her heart beating. At this point, the patient's pupils were dilated and there was no response to pain. Further tests and a neurologic exam indicated brain death. 'The attending physician felt that, while unlikely, avian influenza was possible given the travel history and neurological symptoms, and contacted the local medical officer of health on 3 Jan 2014 to report to public health. Contact tracing of family and hospital contacts was initiated as a precaution, given the severity of the illness and its rapid progression,' the team wrote.\n\n'This case identifies a number of key issues, the 1st being the rapid onset and tragic death of a young, healthy traveller due to an avian influenza A(H5N1) infection. The index of suspicion was low as travel was to an area in China where there have been no recent reports of the circulation of this virus, and coupled with no obvious exposure to poultry, the diagnostic work-up and consideration for A(H5N1) infection was very low. 'The clinical course, detection of the virus in the [cerebrospinal fluid], and results of imaging studies are consistent with an infection of the brain. A review of the literature indicates that such events are uncommon in humans.' From a laboratory perspective, they said, the case also showed the value of having screening tests to identify influenza subtypes.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Kunihiko Iizuka\n\n[This statement is consistent with the conclusion that the patient's illness was contracted during her visit to China and developed during and after her return to Canada. This incident does not indicate the presence of H5N1 virus in Canadian birds. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "The patient came back to the same emergency department on [1 Jan 2014] with worsening inflammation of the membrane surrounding the lung, chest pain, shortness of breath, a mild headache that felt worse when she moved her head, nausea, vomiting and other symptoms, Fonseca's team said in their posting on ProMED-mail, an internet-based disease alert system [see posts listed below]. 17 Jan 2014\n\n(2) Egypt -- Media reports: Man, 65, and 3 other (?) bird flu H5N1 cases at Mansoura Hospitals -- Dakahlia governorate -- 18 Jan 2014 - MoH denies\n\n(3) Egypt -- Media: 2 H5N1 bird flu cases reported by a health official in Port Said -- 1 case reportedly transferred to Dakahalia governorate -- Alert level increased in Port Said hospitals on 18 Jan 2014.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[According to the WHO Table of the Cumulative number of confirmed human cases for avian influenza A(H5N1) reported to WHO, 2003-2013 (http://www.who.int/influenza/human_animal_interface/EN_GIP_20131210CumulativeNumberH5N1cases.pdf), human cases of H5N1 virus infection have been recorded annually without break.\n\nConfirmation of the occurrence of human cases of H5N1 avian influenza virus in Dakahalia Governorate of Egypt would be appreciated. - A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Source: Flutrackers.com, Egypt, Emerging Diseases [edited]\nhttp://www.flutrackers.com/forum/showthread.php?t=217053\n\n\nEgypt -- Emerging Diseases, & Other Health Threats\n------------------------------------ H1N5 (?) flu reported from Dakahlia governorate - 17 Jan 2014\n\n(2) Egypt -- Media reports: Man, 65, and 3 other (?)", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2014-01-18 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2065-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Port Said", "country": "Egypt"}, {"location": "EGYPT", "country": "Egypt"}, {"location": "Dakahalia Governorate", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Dakahlia", "country": "Egypt"}, {"location": "Egypt", "country": "Egypt"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2167852", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (14): Canada ex China (BJ) H5N1, fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2167852", "date": "2014-01-12 11:00:55", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (14): CANADA ex CHINA (BEIJING), H5N1, FATAL\n*******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 10 Jan 2013\nSource: Red Deer Advocate [edited]\nhttp://www.reddeeradvocate.com/news/Family_of_H5N1_victim_issues_public_statement_239633511.html\n\n\nThe young Red Deer woman who is the 1st North American known to have contracted and died from the H5N1 avian flu virus worked hard and saved money for a vacation to her home country that would turn out to be her last.\n\nBorn in China, the woman who died on 3 Jan [2014] from the rare virus came to Red Deer to fulfill a dream of becoming a nurse, putting herself through her studies at Red Deer College. The woman graduated with her degree in 2010 before earning a job as a registered nurse in the operating room at the Red Deer Regional Hospital.\n\nThe family of the woman, who was in her late 20s, released a statement through Alberta Health Services this morning [10 Jan 2014] talking about the 'energetic ... driven, and passionate' victim. The family wishes that the woman not be identified, citing privacy, and is not providing media with any interviews.\n\nThe woman died last week after falling ill upon her return from a 3-week vacation to Beijing in December 2013. Health officials are investigating her death, which has been determined to be the 1st fatality relating to avian flu in the Americas.\n\n'Our beloved daughter and wife was a hard-working, independent young woman,' starts the statement. 'She married her husband a year and a half ago, and together they created a happy life in Red Deer. She worked hard and had saved for a vacation, which she took in December 2013 with her mother. Together, they travelled on a trip which would sadly turn out to be her last,' it reads. 'We are devastated by her death, and we request time to grieve in privacy.'\n\nThe case has puzzled health officials, as the deadly form of influenza is usually transmitted to humans who come in close contact with infected birds. Officials investigating the case say the woman stayed in Beijing during her trip to China and did not visit any farms or poultry markets.\n\nThe cause of the woman's death, from inflammation of the brain and the lining that covers the brain, is also rather rare. The women is reported to have initially not had a cough or other respiratory-type symptoms, which are common among bird flu sufferers and which made her diagnosis a challenge early on.\n\nHealth officials have said there is little risk to other humans relating to the virus, as it is not known to spread person-to-person. In the last 10 years, 649 people worldwide have contracted the virus -- the majority of whom lived in East Asia -- with 385 of those cases resulting in deaths.\n\n--\nCommunicated by\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[This is the 1st case of infection of a human with A(H5N1) in North America. The infection must have been acquired in China, although the conditions under which the virus was acquired are unknown. The previous ProMED-mail report from Kevin Fonseca and colleagues with the detailed case report answers most of the questions raised in the earlier reports by Mod.CP. There are many lessons to be learned from this unfortunate fatal case. Travel histories are critical in initial patient workups, even though there was no reported history of exposure to poultry in this case. Competent and thorough laboratory support was essential in establishing the diagnosis.\n\nAlert ProMED subscriber Mo Laidlaw (<molaidlaw@videotron.ca>) cited a recently published report in the 9 Jan 2014 issue of the New Scientist (http://www.newscientist.com/article/dn24850-threatwatch-h5n1-death-highlights-global-flu-danger.html#.UtFukSjeyTN) that indicated that, 'Both the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and the World Health Organization recommend testing for H5N1 only in patients with respiratory symptoms such as pneumonia. This [Canadian] patient had fever, headache, malaise, but no coughing etc.' Perhaps the criteria for tests should be expanded to include milder respiratory symptoms in patients who have been recently in countries where A (H5N1) virus is endemic.\n\nOne hopes that all the contacts with whom the patient had contact prove to be uninfected with the A(H5N1) virus that caused the death of the young woman.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/73a6. - Mod.TY\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/3han.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n In the last 10 years, 649 people worldwide have contracted the virus -- the majority of whom lived in East Asia -- with 385 of those cases resulting in deaths.\n\n--\n The young Red Deer woman who is the 1st North American known to have contracted and died from the H5N1 avian flu virus worked hard and saved money for a vacation to her home country that would turn out to be her last. \n\nOne hopes that all the contacts with whom the patient had contact prove to be uninfected with the A(H5N1) virus that caused the death of the young woman. \n\nThe family of the woman, who was in her late 20s, released a statement through Alberta Health Services this morning [10 Jan 2014] talking about the 'energetic ... driven, and passionate' victim. \n\nHealth officials have said there is little risk to other humans relating to the virus, as it is not known to spread person-to-person. \n\nThe case has puzzled health officials, as the deadly form of influenza is usually transmitted to humans who come in close contact with infected birds. \n\n'Our beloved daughter and wife was a hard-working, independent young woman,' starts the statement. ' Born in China, the woman who died on 3 Jan [2014] from the rare virus came to Red Deer to fulfill a dream of becoming a nurse, putting herself through her studies at Red Deer College. Officials investigating the case say the woman stayed in Beijing during her trip to China and did not visit any farms or poultry markets. AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (14): CANADA ex CHINA (BEIJING), H5N1, FATAL\n*******************************************************************\n The woman died last week after falling ill upon her return from a 3-week vacation to Beijing in December 2013.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2013-12-25 00:00:00", "2014-01-10 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "CHINA", "country": "China"}, {"location": "CANADA", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Beijing", "country": "China"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2170865", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (04): China (HU) HPAI H5N1, poultry, OIE, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2170865", "date": "2014-01-14 02:57:13", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (04): CHINA (HUBEI), HPAI H5N1, POULTRY, OIE, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n*************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 13 Jan 2014\nSource: OIE, WAHID weekly disease information 2014; 27 (03) [summarised, edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?reportid=14646\n\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza, China (People's Rep. of)\n-----------------------------------------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 13 Jan 2014 from Dr Zhang Zhongqui, director general, China Animal Disease Control Centre, Veterinary Bureau, Ministry of Agriculture, Beijing, China (People's Rep. of)\n\nSummary\nReport type: follow-up report No. 1\nDate of start of the event: 27 Dec 2013\nDate of pre-confirmation of the event: 02 Jan 2014\nReason for notification: reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 18 Jun 2013\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: suspicion, clinical, laboratory (basic and advanced)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country.\nRelated reports: immediate notification (2 Jan 2014)\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nOutbreak 1: Wanjia Village, Paishi, Huangshi, Hubei\nDate of start of the outbreak: 7 Jan 2014\nOutbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: farm\nAffected animals\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nBirds / 50 000 / 6700 / 3200 / 46 800 / 0\n\nOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]\nSpecies / morbidity rate / mortality rate / case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBirds / 13.40 / 6.40 / 47.76 / 100.00\n\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: stamping out, quarantine, movement control inside the country, screening, zoning, disinfection of infected premises/establishment(s), dipping/spraying\nNo vaccination\nNo treatment of affected animals\n\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type: Harbin Veterinary Research Institute, Chinese Academy of Agricultural Sciences (OIE's Reference Laboratory)\n\nSpecies / Test / Test date / Result\nBirds / haemagglutination inhibition test (HIT) / 13 Jan 2014 / Positive\nBirds / reverse transcription - polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) / 13 Jan 2014 / Positive\nBirds / virus isolation / 13 Jan 2014 / Positive\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Details of the actual species of the affected 'birds' (for example, chickens, turkeys, ducks, geese) are not included and would be appreciated.\n\nThe previous H5N1 epizootic in China's poultry occurred on 13 May 2013 in Tibet and was declared as resolved on 16 Jun 2013. During January 2014, a new epizootic is emerging: 2 outbreaks have been reported so far to the OIE, both reportedly starting on the same day (27 Dec 2013). Their geographic positions in 2 different, non-neighbouring provinces, Guizhou and Hubei (map at the bottom of OIE's summarising report at http://tinyurl.com/o4xhlrn), may be indicative of wide circulation of the virus.\n\nRecently, a young woman returning from a visit to China (Beijing) has become the 1st case of A(H5N1) infection in North America. The unfortunately fatal infection must have been acquired in China, although the source and conditions under which the virus was acquired are, so far, unknown; no contact with fowl could be traced.\n\nAccording to a detailed case report (see 20140112.2167282), the sequencing results of the said isolate show that it belongs to A(H5N1) clade 2.3.2.1. It could be useful to check the genetic relationship between the Canadian human isolate and the virus currently circulating in birds in China. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1zaU.]", "summary": "Result\nBirds / haemagglutination inhibition test (HIT) / 13 Jan 2014 / Positive\nBirds / reverse transcription - polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) / 13 Jan 2014 / Positive\nBirds / virus isolation / 13 Jan 2014 / Positive\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Details of the actual species of the affected 'birds' (for example, chickens, turkeys, ducks, geese) are not included and would be appreciated. 27 (03) [summarised, edited]\n Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2014-01-25 00:00:00", "2013-05-13 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2014-01-02 00:00:00", "2014-01-07 00:00:00", "2014-01-13 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "CHINA", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Wanjia Village", "country": "Taiwan"}, {"location": "Tibet", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Hubei", "country": "China"}, {"location": "WAHID", "country": "Oman"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Guizhou", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Beijing", "country": "China"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2249920", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (53): China, H5N1, H7N9, update", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2249920", "date": "2014-02-02 13:57:34", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (53): CHINA, H5N1, H7N9, UPDATE\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Sun 2 Feb 2014\nSource: National Health and Family Planning Commission (NHFPC), Press Release [edited]\nhttp://www.info.gov.hk/gia/general/201402/02/P201402020205.htm\n\n\nThe Centre for Health Protection (CHP) of the Department of Health (DH) received notification yesterday [Sat 1 Feb 2014] of 2 additional human cases of avian influenza A(H7N9) in Zhejiang from the National Health and Family Planning Commission (NHFPC). The 2 cases involve 2 men aged 54 and 80. They are now hospitalised for treatment.\n\nAs of yesterday [Sat 1 Feb 2014], a total of 275 human cases of avian influenza A(H7N9) have been confirmed in the mainland, including Zhejiang (113 cases), Shanghai (41 cases), Jiangsu (36 cases), Guangdong (43 cases), Fujian (16 cases), Jiangxi (6 cases), Anhui (4 cases), Henan (4 cases), Hunan (4 cases), Beijing (3 cases), Shandong (2 cases), Hebei (one case), Guizhou (one case, imported from Zhejiang), and Guangxi (one case).\n\nAdditionally, the CHP received notification of a confirmed human case of avian influenza A(H5N1) in Guangxi from the NHFPC. The patient is a 75-year-old man who had poultry exposure. He was admitted to a hospital for severe pneumonia on 29 Jan 2014. His specimen tested positive for avian influenza A(H5N1) virus by the relevant Guangxi health authorities. He is currently in critical condition.\n\n'Locally, enhanced disease surveillance, port health measures and health education against avian influenza are ongoing. We will remain vigilant and maintain liaison with the World Health Organization (WHO) and relevant health authorities. Local surveillance activities will be modified upon the WHO's recommendations,' a spokesman for the DH said. 'In view of human cases of avian influenza A(H7N9) confirmed in Hong Kong and multiple cases reported in the mainland, the activity of the virus is expected to be higher in the winter season.\n\nThose planning to travel outside Hong Kong during the Lunar New Year should maintain good personal, environmental and food hygiene at all times,' the spokesman urged. 'All boundary control points have implemented disease prevention and control measures. Thermal imaging systems are in place for body temperature checks of inbound travellers. Random temperature checks by handheld devices have also been arranged. Suspected cases will be immediately referred to public hospitals for follow-up investigation,' the spokesman added.\n\nRegarding health education for travellers, distribution of pamphlets, display of posters in departure and arrival halls, in-flight public announcements, environmental health inspection, and provision of regular updates to the travel industry via meetings and correspondence are all proceeding. The spokesman advised travellers, especially those returning from avian influenza-affected areas and provinces with fever or respiratory symptoms, to immediately wear masks, seek medical attention, and reveal their travel history to doctors. Health-care professionals should pay special attention to patients who might have had contact with poultry, birds, or their droppings in affected areas and provinces.\n\nMembers of the public should remain vigilant and take heed of the preventive advice against avian influenza below:\n\n* Do not visit live poultry markets. Avoid contact with poultry, birds and their droppings. If contact has been made, thoroughly wash hands with soap;\n* Poultry and eggs should be thoroughly cooked before eating;\n* Wash hands frequently with soap, especially before touching the mouth, nose or eyes, handling food or eating; after going to the toilet or touching public installations or equipment (including escalator handrails, elevator control panels and door knobs); or when hands are dirtied by respiratory secretions after coughing or sneezing;\n* Cover the nose and mouth while sneezing or coughing, hold the spit with a tissue and put it into a covered dustbin;\n* Avoid crowded places and contact with fever patients; and\n* Wear masks when respiratory symptoms develop or when taking care of fever patients.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Sun 2 Feb 2014\nSource: Xinhuanet, English News [edited]\nhttp://news.xinhuanet.com/english/health/2014-02/02/c_133089785.htm\n\n\nSouth China's Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region reported a human case of H7N9 on Sunday [2 Feb 2014], its 1st this year [2014].\n\nThe patient is a 75-year-old man from the city of Liuzhou. He is in critical condition, the regional health department said in a statement. The man had been in contact with live poultry before he fell sick on 27 Jan 2014, the department said. Medical workers have disinfected his home and neighborhood, while 16 people who had close contact with him are under observation. Local health authorities are investigating the source of the infection. They will not rule out the possibility of suspending live poultry trading. It is the 2nd case in Guangxi since 2009.\n\nChina has reported more than 100 human H7N9 cases, including over 20 deaths, this year [2014], with Zhejiang and Guangdong most affected.\n\nHealth authorities have strengthened H7N9 prevention and control measures including the closure of live poultry markets in some affected cities.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nRyan McGinnis\n<ryan@bigstormpicture.com>\n\n[Both the H7N9 and H5N1 avian influenza viruses are circulating in mainland China at the present time but retaining their characteristic features. H5N1 avian influenza virus remains dispersed, although potentially transmissible from person to person. In contrast, the H7N9 virus is more abundant although still without the potential to spread from person to person. There is no indication yet that the H7N9 outbreak is in decline. - Mod.CP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1zaU.]", "summary": "As of yesterday [Sat 1 Feb 2014], a total of 275 human cases of avian influenza A(H7N9) have been confirmed in the mainland, including Zhejiang (113 cases), Shanghai (41 cases), Jiangsu (36 cases), Guangdong (43 cases), Fujian (16 cases), Jiangxi (6 cases), Anhui (4 cases), Henan (4 cases), Hunan (4 cases), Beijing (3 cases), Shandong (2 cases), Hebei (one case), Guizhou (one case, imported from Zhejiang), and Guangxi (one case). RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2162075", "date": "2014-01-10 09:23:37", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (12): CANADA ex CHINA (BEIJING), H5N1, FATAL, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n********************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Wed 8 Jan 2014\nSource: BBC News [edited]\nhttp://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-25662730\n\n\nCanadian health officials have confirmed the 1st known fatal case of the H5N1 avian influenza strain in North America. Canadian Health Minister Rona Ambrose said the deceased person was an Alberta [province] resident who had recently travelled to Beijing. Calling the death an 'isolated case,' Ms Ambrose said the risk to the general population was low.\n\nA total of 10 people have died in Alberta this season [2013-2014] from swine flu, or H1N1.\n\nH5N1 infects the lower respiratory tract deep in the lung, where it can cause deadly pneumonia. The World Health Organisation (WHO) says it is difficult to transmit the virus from person to person but when people do become infected, the mortality rate is about 60 percent.\n\nIn the latest incident, the infected person 1st showed symptoms of the flu on an Air Canada flight from Beijing to Vancouver on [27 Dec 2013], officials said. The passenger continued on to Edmonton, and on [1 Jan 2014] was admitted to hospital where [the case] died 2 days later. Canadian federal health officials said they would not identify the patient's sex, age or occupation. Ms Ambrose said Canadian officials were working with Chinese authorities on the case. 'The risk of getting H5N1 is very low. This is not the regular seasonal flu. This is an isolated case,' she said.\n\nAccording to the WHO, between 2003 and December 2013 there were 648 confirmed human cases of H5N1 infection in 15 countries, leading to 384 deaths. Experts say that if the H5N1 virus were to mutate and become easily transmissible between humans, the consequences for public health could be very serious.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nLewis B. Sckolnick\nRector Press Limited\nLeverett, Massachusetts 01054-9726\nUSA\n<info@rectorpress.com>\n\n******\n[2] Request for information\nDate: Wed 8 Jan 2014\nFrom: Neil Rau <nrau@haltonhealthcare.on.ca>\n\n\nWhat lab methodology has been used other than PCR? Aside from a travel history, there is no epidemiologic risk factor such as exposure to live animal markets, based on what we are hearing. Is virus isolation being performed? Was immunohistochemistry on lung tissue performed on lung tissue? Did another lab confirm the PCR findings, which presumably are from a respiratory specimen? Was the CSF tested by PCR as well? More laboratory information would be most welcome, given the unprecedented nature of this case.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nNeil Rau\n<nrau@haltonhealthcare.on.ca>\n\n[This fatality is the 1st case of avian H5N1 influenza virus infection to have been recorded in North America, and undoubtedly the infection was contracted during a visit to Beijing. Many relevant details, such as the purpose of the visit, the sex of the victim, duration of residence in Beijing, exposure to live poultry, etc., have been withheld in order avoid unnecessary panic. So far there has been no evidence of transmission of infection to the victim's companions, relatives, fellow airline passengers, or medical staff. Human cases of avian H5N1 virus infection have been restricted to Middle Eastern and Asian countries with relatively few occurring in China. It is unlikely that the H5N1 infection will spread beyond this single fatality in Edmonton, Alberta, but until the Canadian authorities release more details of the diagnosis and characteristics of the virus obtained from the patient, that will remain uncertain for the present. - Mod.CP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/73a6.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\n Experts say that if the H5N1 virus were to mutate and become easily transmissible between humans, the consequences for public health could be very serious.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nLewis B. Sckolnick\nRector Press Limited\n Communicated by:\nNeil Rau\n<nrau@haltonhealthcare.on.ca>\n\n[This fatality is the 1st case of avian H5N1 influenza virus infection to have been recorded in North America, and undoubtedly the infection was contracted during a visit to Beijing. USA\n<info@rectorpress.com>\n\n******\n Source: BBC News [edited]\nhttp://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-25662730\n\n\nCanadian health officials have confirmed the 1st known fatal case of the H5N1 avian influenza strain in North America. AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (12): CANADA ex CHINA (BEIJING), H5N1, FATAL, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n \n\n--\n In the latest incident, the infected person 1st showed symptoms of the flu on an Air Canada flight from Beijing to Vancouver on [27 Dec 2013], officials said. It is unlikely that the H5N1 infection will spread beyond this single fatality in Edmonton, Alberta, but until the Canadian authorities release more details of the diagnosis and characteristics of the virus obtained from the patient, that will remain uncertain for the present. Date: Wed 8 Jan 2014\n Date: Wed 8 Jan 2014\n The World Health Organisation (WHO) says it is difficult to transmit the virus from person to person but when people do become infected, the mortality rate is about 60 percent.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-12 00:00:00", "2014-01-08 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Edmonton", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Vancouver", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "CANADA", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "CHINA", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Alberta", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Beijing", "country": "China"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2160514", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (10): Canada ex China (Beijing) H5N1, fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2160514", "date": "2014-01-08 22:41:29", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (10): CANADA ex CHINA (BEIJING) H5N1, FATAL\n********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Wed 8 Jan 2014\nSource: Government of Alberta [edited]\nhttp://alberta.ca/release.cfm?xID=3565183693F2C-9E0D-1406-AF11D53248E7B8B2\n\n\nHealth Minister Fred Horne released the following statement today regarding Alberta's first rare and isolated case of avian influenza:\n\nResults that were received from the provincial laboratory on Monday [6 Jan 2014], and confirmed by the National Microbiology Laboratory on Tuesday, indicate that an Albertan has died from H5N1 avian influenza. This individual travelled to China in December. Upon returning to Alberta, this person was admitted to hospital on Jan. 1 and passed away on Jan. 3.\n\n'I would like to extend my condolences to the family for the loss of their loved one. I also want to thank our health care workers and our Chief Medical Officer of Health for their swift action and for their close co-ordination with the Government of Canada,' said Health Minister Fred Horne.\n\n'This is a very rare and isolated case,' said Dr. James Talbot, Alberta's Chief Medical Officer of Health. 'Avian influenza is not easily transmitted from person to person. It is not the same virus that is currently present in seasonal influenza in Alberta. Public Health has followed up with all close contacts of this individual and offered Tamiflu [oseltamivir] as a precaution. None of them have symptoms and the risk of developing symptoms is extremely low. Precautions for health care staff were also taken as part of this individual's hospital treatment. I expect that with the rarity of transmission and the additional precautions taken, there will be no more cases in Alberta.'\n\nIn 2013, there were 38 worldwide cases of H5N1 avian influenza reported to the World Health Organization and 24 deaths.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Joseph Dudley\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Wed 8 Jan 2014\nSource: CBC News [edited]\nhttp://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/h5n1-bird-flu-death-confirmed-in-alberta-1st-in-north-america-1.2489160\n\n\nAlberta health officials have confirmed an isolated, fatal case of H5N1 or avian influenza, federal Health Minister Rona Ambrose said Wednesday [8 Jan 2014]. But officials repeatedly emphasized that there is no risk of transmission between humans.\n\nThe infected person, an Alberta resident who recently travelled to Beijing, China, died Jan. 3 [2014]. The case was confirmed in a lab test last night. It's the first such case in North America.\n\nThe person first showed symptoms of the flu on a Dec. 27 [2013] flight from Beijing to Vancouver aboard Air Canada flight 030. The passenger continued on to Edmonton on Air Canada flight 244, after spending a few hours in the Vancouver airport, and was admitted to hospital Jan. 1 [2014]. The symptoms of fever, malaise and headache worsened and the patient died two days later. The Public Health Agency of Canada was notified Jan. 5.\n\nThere were no respiratory symptoms, said Dr. James Talbot, Alberta's chief medical officer of health. Dr. James Talbot, Alberta's chief medical officer of health, noted the patient did not leave Beijing, or visit any farms or markets.\n\nThe diagnosis at the time of death was an inflammation of the brain and the linings that cover the brain. 'That is one of the ways that H5N1 patients die,' Talbot said.\nIt is not known how the patient contracted the disease. 'Virtually every case has a pretty strong link to a close contact with birds,' Talbot said, though he noted there are other settings in which a person might catch H5N1, such as a restaurant that kept live birds for slaughter.\n\nDr. Gregory Taylor, deputy chief public health officer, said the avian form of influenza has been found in birds, mainly poultry, in Asia, Europe, Africa and the Middle East.\n\nThere have been fewer than 650 human cases of bird flu in 15 countries over the last decade, primarily among people who have spent time around infected birds, he said. 'The illness [H5N1] causes in humans is severe and kills about 60 per cent of those who are infected,' Taylor said. 'No other illnesses of this type have been identified in Canada since the traveller returned from China. This is an isolated case.' The officials added that the patient was otherwise healthy and it's not yet clear how the person contracted H5N1.\n\n'This was a relatively young -- well, a young person compared to me, with no underlying health conditions,' he said. Taylor is 58.\n\nOfficials emphasized that this is not a disease transmitted between humans. There were two people travelling with the infected person, whom officials are following for 10 days to ensure they don't have any symptoms. They are also going to notify the other passengers from the flights between Beijing and Edmonton, and are following a group of the patient's 'close contacts.' Talbot said family members of the victim are being monitored and treated with medication, but noted that there's no sign they are sick.\n\nOfficials created confusion by referring to the patient as 'him' and 'her' in order to avoid identifying anyone. Officials said that they would not identify the sex, age or occupation of the patient. They also refused to say whether the infected passenger was an Edmonton resident or whether the patient went to hospital in Edmonton, although the final leg of the flight ended there. Talbot said reports that the patient was from Edmonton are erroneous.\n\nAmbrose, who phoned into a news conference in Ottawa, said Canadian officials are working with Chinese authorities on the case, as well as the World Health Organization. 'The risk of getting H5N1 is very low. This is not the regular seasonal flu. This is an isolated case,' she said.\n\nAn Air Canada spokeswoman said in a statement the airline is co-operating with officials, but referred any questions on the matter to the Public Health Agency of Canada.\n\n[Byline: Laura Payton]\n\n[A graph of H5N1 human cases by country reported to WHO, 2003-2013, is available at the source URL]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Mary Marshall, Jamie Rothenburger, Greg Appleyard, Hasana Birk, Geoffrey Taylor, and David Fisman for submitting similar new reports.]\n\n\n[\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/3han.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\n [Byline: Laura Payton]\n\n[A graph of H5N1 human cases by country reported to WHO, 2003-2013, is available at the source URL]\n\n--\n \n\n\nAlberta health officials have confirmed an isolated, fatal case of H5N1 or avian influenza, federal Health Minister Rona Ambrose said Wednesday [8 Jan 2014]. \n\nDr. Gregory Taylor, deputy chief public health officer, said the avian form of influenza has been found in birds, mainly poultry, in Asia, Europe, Africa and the Middle East. http://alberta.ca/release.cfm?xID=3565183693F2C-9E0D-1406-AF11D53248E7B8B2\n\n\nHealth Minister Fred Horne released the following statement today regarding Alberta's first rare and isolated case of avian influenza:\n\nResults that were received from the provincial laboratory on Monday \n\n'This is a very rare and isolated case,' said Dr. James Talbot, Alberta's Chief Medical Officer of Health. ' \n\nThere have been fewer than 650 human cases of bird flu in 15 countries over the last decade, primarily among people who have spent time around infected birds, he said. ' Communicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Joseph Dudley\n\n******\n \n\nAmbrose, who phoned into a news conference in Ottawa, said Canadian officials are working with Chinese authorities on the case, as well as the World Health Organization. ' \n\n'This was a relatively young -- well, a young person compared to me, with no underlying health conditions,' he said. \n\nAn Air Canada spokeswoman said in a statement the airline is co-operating with officials, but referred any questions on the matter to the Public Health Agency of Canada. \n\nThere were no respiratory symptoms, said Dr. James Talbot, Alberta's chief medical officer of health. Virtually every case has a pretty strong link to a close contact with birds,' Talbot said, though he noted there are other settings in which a person might catch H5N1, such as a restaurant that kept live birds for slaughter. I also want to thank our health care workers and our Chief Medical Officer of Health for their swift action and for their close co-ordination with the Government of Canada,' said Health Minister Fred Horne. AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (10): CANADA ex CHINA (BEIJING) H5N1, FATAL\n********************************************************************\n \n\nIn 2013, there were 38 worldwide cases of H5N1 avian influenza reported to the World Health Organization and 24 deaths. \n\nThe infected person, an Alberta resident who recently travelled to Beijing, China, died Jan. 3 [2014]. \n\n--\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\nThe person first showed symptoms of the flu on a Dec. 27", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-12-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-29 00:00:00", "2021-01-05 00:00:00", "2014-01-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-30 00:00:00", "2058-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2014-01-06 00:00:00", "2013-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-01-03 00:00:00", "2021-01-01 00:00:00", "2021-12-27 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Alberta", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Vancouver", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Beijing", "country": "China"}, {"location": "CHINA", "country": "China"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Edmonton", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Ottawa", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Albertan", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "CANADA", "country": "Canada"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2167282", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (13): Canada ex China (BJ) H5N1, fatal, case report", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2167282", "date": "2014-01-12 10:23:15", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (13): CANADA ex CHINA (BEIJING), H5N1, FATAL, CASE REPORT\n********************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 11 Jan 2014\nFrom: Kevin Fonseca <kevin.fonseca@albertahealthservices.ca> [edited]\n\n\nAvian influenza A(H5N1) was detected in the respiratory samples and CSF [cerebrospinal fluid] of a young adult, who died from the infection 7 days after returning from a vacation in Beijing, China accompanied by a family member.\n\nThe individual left Canada for China on 6 Dec 2013 and was exclusively in Beijing, in urban locations. There was no contact reported with live poultry, no visits to wet markets, or handling of fresh poultry. Work is ongoing to obtain a detailed account of activities during the trip.\n\nDuring the return flight on 27 Dec 2013, the individual experienced symptoms of malaise, chest pain, and fever and presented to the local Emergency Department on 28 Dec 2013. The complete blood count (CBC) showed a total white blood count (WBC) of 12.6 x 10 to the power of 9/L (reference range 4.0 - 10.0 x10 to the power of 9/L) with raised neutrophils (11.1 x 10 to the power of 9/L) and low lymphocytes (0.8 x 10 to the power of 9/L). A chest X-ray and CT scan revealed a right apical infiltrate. A diagnosis of pneumonia was made; the patient was prescribed levofloxacin and discharged home.\n\nThe individual returned to the same Emergency Department on 1 Jan 2014, now with worsening pleuritic [inflammation of the membrane surrounding the lung] chest pains and shortness of breath, a mild headache, exacerbated by head movement, right upper quadrant and epigastric pain, nausea and vomiting with no diarrhea. A chest X-ray showed a multi-lobar pneumonia, with moderate effusion, reflecting significant progression when compared with the X-ray from the 1st ED visit. A thoracentesis [a procedure to remove excess fluid in the space between the lungs and the chest wall], performed while in the ED, revealed a dark amber cloudy fluid that was sterile in bacterial culture. The CBC again showed a WBC count of 10.2 x 10 to the power of 9/L, neutrophil count of 9.5 x 10 to the power of 9/L, platelet count within the normal range, normal ALT, slightly elevated AST at 46 U/L (reference range 7 - 40 U/L) and LDH at 288 U/L (reference range 100 - 225 U/L).\n\nAdmission to a general medicine ward for investigation was facilitated, and treatment was initiated with intravenous piperacillin-tazobactam. On 2 Jan 2014, the individual reported visual changes and ongoing headache, and, coupled with increasing oxygen requirements, was admitted to the ICU for intubation and ventilation. In the early morning of 3 Jan 2014, the individual developed a sudden episode of tachycardia and severe hypertension followed by hypotension requiring inotropic support. At this point, pupils were dilated, and there was no response to pain.\n\nA CT brain scan suggested diffuse encephalitis and intracranial hypertension. The neurological examination was consistent with brain death. An MRI/MRA showed significant generalized edema, evidence of meningitis and ventriculitis [inflammation of the ventricles in the brain] and significant reduction in cerebral blood flow. A lumbar puncture was performed after brain death determination and prior to removal of ventilatory and inotropic support. The attending physician felt that, while unlikely, avian influenza was possible given the travel history and neurological symptoms, and contacted the local Medical Officer of Health on 3 Jan 2014 to report to public health. Contact tracing of family and hospital contacts was initiated as a precaution, given the severity of the illness and its rapid progression.\n\nLaboratory investigations: Blood cultures were negative as were cultures of the broncho-alveolar lavage (BAL) fluids for a range of bacterial pathogens. Nasopharyngeal swabs and BAL were sent to the Provincial Laboratory for complementary viral investigations for influenza and other respiratory viral agents, and CSF for the herpesvirus group, enterovirus and parechoviruses.\n\nScreening for influenza A and B and other respiratory viruses was performed on the respiratory samples (2 nasopharyngeal swabs and a BAL) through a combination of a direct fluorescent antigen (DFA) test (D3 Ultra DFA Influenza A/B reagent, Diagnostic Hybrids, Ohio), real time singleplex Taqman assays to influenza A and B assays targeting the matrix (M) gene of influenza A and NS1 gene of influenza B (1), and Luminex Respiratory Viral panel (Luminex, Ontario).\n\nThe swabs were negative by the DFA, however all these samples were positive for influenza A, with good Ct values in the Taqman assay, and were immediately subtyped, using real time assays to A(H1N1) pdm09 and seasonal H3 (2,3). Negative subtyping results were obtained on 2 independent runs, and when viewed in conjunction with recent travel history, strongly pointed to the possibility that this strain could be one of the avian subtypes known to occasionally infect humans. To investigate this possibility, a combination of real time and gel-based assays were performed to target the following genes H5, H7 and N9, on the viral RNA from the BAL, which had the highest titre of virus. Additionally, the M (matrix), NA (neuraminidase) and HA (haemagglutinin) genes were amplified and sequenced.\n\nA compilation of the results from all these assays indicated that this strain was an influenza A(H5N1) subtype. Supplementary testing performed at the National Microbiology Reference Laboratory, Winnipeg, confirmed our findings that this was an avian influenza A (H5N1) virus.\n\nSequence data of the HA and NA genes from both laboratories showed the following. From the HA sequence this virus; (a) belongs to clade 2.3.2.1, (b) is a highly pathogenic influenza A(H5), based upon the presence of multiple basic amino-acid residues occurring at the cleavage site, (c) has a wild-type receptor binding site, consistent with preferential affinity for the avian alpha-2-3 sialic-acid receptor. The NA sequence shows genotypic sensitivity to oseltamivir (Tamiflu) based upon the histidine residue at position 275. This genotypic susceptibility result was considered to be helpful information as chemoprophylaxis with oseltamivir had been prescribed for close contacts of the individual.\n\nOf interest is that the respiratory samples tested negative for influenza A in the Luminex Respiratory Viral panel but identified a human coronavirus 229E in the nasopharyngeal swabs, but not from the BAL. The negative influenza A results from this commercial assay were in contrast to the positive results obtained from the in-house Taqman assays.\n\nThe CSF collected also tested positive for influenza A and subtyped as H5.\n\nAn autopsy was not done due to concerns regarding the risk of virus transmission.\n\nThis case identifies a number of key issues, the 1st being the rapid onset and tragic death of a young, healthy traveler due to an avian influenza A(H5N1) infection. The index of suspicion was low as travel was to an area in China where there have been no recent reports of the circulation of this virus, and coupled with no obvious exposure to poultry, the diagnostic work-up and consideration for A(H5N1) infection was very low.\n\nThe clinical course, detection of the virus in the CSF, and results of imaging studies are consistent with an infection of the brain. A review of the literature indicates that such events are uncommon in humans, although animal models show that this virus is neurotropic and neuroinvasive (4,5).\n\nFrom a laboratory diagnosis aspect, this case shows the value of having screening assays, in-house or commercial, known to be capable of identifying all influenza subtypes. Often, the proprietary information of the target and detection sites of commercial assays makes it difficult to know if non-seasonal subtypes can be detected (6). In this case, the discrepant results between our in-house screening Taqman assays and the Luminex Respiratory Viral Panel were very helpful in indicating this strain was not a seasonal subtype.\n\nThe availability of advanced molecular tools at the Alberta Provincial Laboratory allowed us to suspect, within 24 hours of testing these samples, that this was an unusual strain. Such information was valuable in implementing appropriate communication processes to healthcare workers who cared for this patient and to regularly update the appropriate authorities.\n\nFinally, this infection of a Canadian resident is the 1st case of influenza A(H5N1) occurring in North America. With the rapidity of travel between countries and continents and the globalization of many cultures, this will likely not be the last case to occur in North America.\n\nReferences\n---------\n1. Swine Influenza CDC Realtime RTPCR (rRTPCR) Protocol for Detection and Characterization of Swine Influenza (version 2009). CDC REF. #I-007-05 Page 1 of 8 Version 2009.\n\n2. CDC Realtime RTPCR (rRTPCR) Protocol for Detection and Characterization of Influenza (version 2007).\n\n3. Pabbaraju K, S Wong, AW Wong, GD Appleyard, et al. Design and Validation of Real-Time Reverse Transcription-PCR Assays for Detection of Pandemic (H1N1) 2009 Virus. J Clin Microbiol 2009;47(11):3454-60.\n\n4. Gambatto A, SM Barratt-Boyes, MD de Jong and Y Kawaoka. Human infections with highly pathogenic H5N1 influenza virus. Lancet 2007;371:1464-75.\n\n5. Lipatov AS, A Krauss, Y Guan, M Peiris et al. Neurovirulence in mice of H5N1 influenza virus genotypes isolated from Hong Kong poultry in 2001. J. Virol 2003;77(6):3816-3823.\n\n6. Hatchette TF, SJ Drews, N Bastien, Y. Li et al. Detection of Influenza H7N9 virus: all molecular tests are not equal. J Clin Microbiol 2013;51(11):3835-38.\n\nLead and corresponding authors\n---------------------------\nKevin Fonseca, Clinical Virologist, Provincial Laboratory, Alberta Health Services, Canada\nMartin Lavoie, Deputy Medical Officer of Health, Alberta Health, Canada\n\nAdditional authors in alphabetical order by organization and last name:\n\nAlberta Health:\nJames Talbot, Chief Medical Officer of Health, Alberta Health, Canada\n\nAlberta Health Services:\nJeff Fuller, Clinical Microbiologist, Provincial Laboratory, Alberta Health Services, Canada\nRobyn Harrison, Communicable Disease Consultant Workplace Health & Safety, Alberta Health Services\nMark Joffe, Senior Medical Director, Infection Prevention and Control, Alberta Health Services\nKanti Pabbaraju, Senior Scientist, Provincial Laboratory, Alberta Health Services, Canada\nRaymond Tellier, Medical Microbiologist, Provincial Laboratory, Alberta Health Services, Canada\nGraham Tipples, Medical Director, Provincial Laboratory, Alberta Health Services, Canada\nStephen Tsekrekos, Medical Director, Workplace Health & Safety, Alberta Health Services\nSallene Wong, Scientist, Provincial Laboratory, Alberta Health Services, Canada\n\nNational Microbiology Laboratory:\nNatalie Bastien, Research Scientist, Influenza and Respiratory Virus Section, National Microbiology Laboratory, Winnipeg, Canada\nYan Li, Chief, Influenza and Respiratory Virus Section, National Microbiology Laboratory, Winnipeg, Canada\n\nAcknowledgments\n---------------\nThe named authors would like to acknowledge the timely, thorough and expert contributions made by local medical, nursing, public health, infection control, and health care professionals to this work and this publication. At the request of the family, to preserve confidentiality, additional contributing authors have agreed not to be named. We would also like to express particular thanks to the family for their kind cooperation in this difficult time for them.\n\n--\nKevin Fonseca, PhD, D(ABMM)\nClinical Virologist, Provincial Laboratory of Public Health\nAlberta Health Services\nCanada\n<kevin.fonseca@albertahealthservices.ca>\n\n[ProMED is grateful to Kevin Fonseca and colleagues for providing this authoritative information.\n\nThis report provides many additional historical, clinical and laboratory details of the recent fatal case of H5N1 influenza in a Canadian traveler returned from Beijing. (Media reports have stated that the patient was a female healthcare worker originally from China, in her 20s.) Notable features include the absence of apparent contact with poultry (though investigation is ongoing), the presence of pneumonia progressing from the right apex to multiple lobes and pleural effusion, the presence of intracranial edema, and radiographic evidence of inflammation of the meninges. It does not appear that influenza was suspected early enough to institute timely antiviral therapy.\n\nH5N1 influenza A virus was detected from respiratory samples and from cerebrospinal fluid by nucleic acid amplification methods. Sequence analysis confirmed the identity of the virus and is indicative of viral features including high-pathogenicity, absence of oseltamivir resistance mutations at position 275, and wild-type affinity for the avian sialic acid receptor. - Mod.LM\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1zaU.]", "summary": "Kanti Pabbaraju, Senior Scientist, Provincial Laboratory, Alberta Health Services, Canada\nRaymond Tellier, Medical Microbiologist, Provincial Laboratory, Alberta Health Services, Canada\nGraham Tipples, Medical Director, Provincial Laboratory, Alberta Health Services, Canada\nStephen Tsekrekos, Medical Director, Workplace Health & Safety, Alberta Health Services\nSallene Wong, Scientist, Provincial Laboratory, Alberta Health Services, Canada\n\nNational Microbiology Laboratory:\nNatalie Bastien, Research Scientist, Influenza and Respiratory Virus Section, National Microbiology Laboratory, Winnipeg, Canada\nYan Li, Chief, Influenza and Respiratory Virus Section, National Microbiology Laboratory, Winnipeg, Canada\n\nAcknowledgments\n ---------------------------\nKevin Fonseca, Clinical Virologist, Provincial Laboratory, Alberta Health Services, Canada\nMartin Lavoie, Deputy Medical Officer of Health, Alberta Health, Canada\n\nAdditional authors in alphabetical order by organization and last name:\n\nAlberta Health:\nJames Talbot, Chief Medical Officer of Health, Alberta Health, Canada\n\nAlberta Health Services:\nJeff Fuller, Clinical Microbiologist, Provincial Laboratory, Alberta Health Services, Canada\n was performed on the respiratory samples (2 nasopharyngeal swabs and a BAL) through a combination of a direct fluorescent antigen (DFA) test (D3 Ultra DFA Influenza A/B reagent, Diagnostic Hybrids, Ohio), real time singleplex Taqman assays to influenza A and B assays targeting the matrix (M) gene of influenza A and NS1 gene of influenza B (1), and Luminex Respiratory Viral panel (Luminex, Ontario).
