"https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2149620", "date": "2014-01-03 11:11:29", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (01): CHINA (GUIZHOU) HPAI H5N1, POULTRY\n********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 2 Jan 2014\nSource: Xinhua News Agency [edited]\nhttp://news.xinhuanet.com/english/health/2014-01/02/c_133014326.htm\n\n\nThe southwest China province of Guizhou has reported an outbreak of H5N1 [avian influenza infection] in poultry, the Ministry of Agriculture (MOA) announced Thursday [2 Jan 2014].\n\nSome chickens at a farm in a village of Libo County in the prefecture of Qiannan in Guizhou showed symptoms of suspected avian flu and 8500 chickens died on 27 Dec 2013.\n\nThe National Avian Influenza Reference Laboratory confirmed the epidemic was H5N1 bird flu after testing samples collected at the farm, according to the MOA.\n\nLocal authorities have sealed off and sterilized the infected area, where a total of 23 067 chickens have been culled and safely disposed of to prevent the disease from spreading, according to the MOA.\n\n[Editor: Zhu Ningzhu]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[China has already reported to the OIE the new HPAI H5N1 outbreak described above and its stamping out; see the immediate notification, with map, at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=14598.\n\nThe immediate notification included the following outbreak data:\n\nLocation: Yijue village, Libo, Qiannan, Guizhou province.\nStarted: 27 Dec 2013\nPre-confirmed: 2 Jan 2014\nSubmitted to OIE: 3 Jan 2014\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nBirds / 31 567 / 9300 / 8500 / 23 067 / 0\n\nAll the cases (9300) were recorded in chickens; 18 250 chickens, 4569 ducks, and 248 geese were destroyed.\n\nOutbreak statistics:\nSpecies / Apparent morbidity rate / Apparent mortality rate / Apparent case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBirds / 29.46 percent / 26.93 percent / 91.40 percent / 100 percent.\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n\nThe very high case fatality rate is typical for HPAI outbreaks in susceptible birds (chickens).\n\nThe previous HPAI H5N1 outbreak in poultry took place in a small holding in Tibet. Reportedly, it started on 13 May 2013 and was declared resolved on 18 Jun 2013. Out of 376 birds there were 35 cases (died). The 341 remaining chickens and 31 geese were destroyed (see ProMED-mail post 20130513.1710726). See, with map, at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?reportid=13445. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/5kNo.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nOutbreak statistics:\nSpecies / Apparent morbidity rate / Apparent mortality rate / Apparent case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\n Birds / 31 567 / 9300 / 8500 / 23 067 / 0\n\nAll the cases (9300) were recorded in chickens; 18 250 chickens, 4569 ducks, and 248 geese were destroyed. \n\nSome chickens at a farm in a village of Libo County in the prefecture of Qiannan in Guizhou showed symptoms of suspected avian flu and 8500 chickens died on 27 Dec 2013. AVIAN INFLUENZA (01): CHINA (GUIZHOU) HPAI H5N1, POULTRY\n********************************************************\n \n\nThe immediate notification included the following outbreak data:\n\nLocation: \n\nLocal authorities have sealed off and sterilized the infected area, where a total of 23 067 chickens have been culled and safely disposed of to prevent the disease from spreading, according to the MOA. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n [Editor: Zhu Ningzhu]\n\n--\n", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2014-01-02 00:00:00", "2013-06-18 00:00:00", "2014-01-03 00:00:00", "4569-03-25 00:00:00", "2013-05-13 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2013-12-27 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Libo County", "country": "Kenya"}, {"location": "CHINA", "country": "China"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Guizhou", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Qiannan", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Libo", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Tibet", "country": "China"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2060088", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (141): China: southern, H5N1 seroprevalence", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2060088", "date": "2013-11-17 15:10:25", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (141): CHINA: SOUTHERN, H5N1 SEROPREVALENCE\n*******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 14 Nov 2013\nSource: Journal of Clinical Virology, (Article in Press), [edited]\nhttp://www.journalofclinicalvirology.com/article/S1386-6532(13)00408-3/abstract\n\n\nAvian influenza A (H5N1) virus antibodies in pigs and residents of swine farms, southern China. By: Nan Cao and 11 others, published online 14 Nov 2013.\n\nAbstract\n----------\nBackground\nSince 1997, the H5 avian influenza viruses (AIVs) circulating in China have become an international concern. Clade 2.3.2 of H5N1 avian influenza viruses are genetically distinct from the viruses isolated before 2007 and antigenically different from the [veterinary] vaccine strains widely used in China. Swine farms in rural China are thought to play an important role in the ecology of avian influenza viruses.\n\nObjectives\nA seroepidemiological study was undertaken among swine farm residents and pigs to understand the prevalence of antibodies against H5N1 avian influenza viruses in southern China.\n\nStudy design\nDuring the period 24 Mar 2008 to 25 Dec 2012, serum samples were collected from 1606 swine farm residents on 40 swine farms in southern China. A total of 1980 pigs' serum samples were collected in the same swine farms where swine workers' serum samples were collected from March 2009 to March 2013. For a control group, 104 serum samples were collected from healthy city residents in Nanchang. All the serum samples were collected to perform hemagglutination inhibition (HI) and (neutralization) NT assays to investigate the prevalence of H5N1 avian influenza virus infections in southern China.\n\nResults\n16 human samples were positive by hemagglutination test assay, and 10 of these were also positive by neutralisation test assay against H5N1. No serum samples from human controls and pigs were positive for H5N1 avian influenza virus by hemagglutination assay.\n\nDiscussion\nOur results demonstrate minimal transmission of H5N1 avian influenza viruses from birds to pigs in the swine farms studied in this investigation, and the risk of poultry-to-human and poultry-to-pig transmission for at least clades 2.3.2 [viruses] seemed very low. This study provides the 1st data regarding antibodies against H5N1 avian influenza viruses in humans and pigs on swine farms in China.\n\nThe findings of this study can serve as a baseline for additional serologic studies to assess transmission of H5N1 viruses between avian species, pigs and swine workers.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[Since the 1st confirmed human cases of H5N1 avian influenza virus infection were detected in 2003, there have been a total of 641 cases reported in 15 countries with 380 fatalities (as of 8 Oct 2013; see http://www.who.int/influenza/human_animal_interface/EN_GIP_20131008CumulativeNumberH5N1cases.pdf). Of these cases, 45 (with 30 fatalities) occurred in China. By 2013, with increased awareness of the potential risk for the human population, the global total of human cases of H5N1 virus infection had dwindled to 31 (only 2 of which occurred in China).\n\nThroughout this period, there have been no unambiguous records of human-to-human transmission of the H5N1 avian virus. But supportive seroprevalence data have been lacking. The investigation by Nan Cao and colleagues described above provides seroprevalence data that indicate that the risk of poultry-to-human and, additionally, poultry-to-pig transmission of at least the clades 2.3.2 avian H5N1 viruses has so far been very low in southern China.\n\nOnly the situation in Cambodia, with 20 (mostly children) of the 31 cases recorded so far in 2013, may show a different pattern. - Mod.CP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1zaU.]", "summary": "Our results demonstrate minimal transmission of H5N1 avian influenza viruses from birds to pigs in the swine farms studied in this investigation, and the risk of poultry-to-human and poultry-to-pig transmission for at least clades 2.3.2 [viruses] seemed very low. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n A total of 1980 pigs' serum samples were collected in the same swine farms where swine workers' serum samples were collected from March 2009 to March 2013. The investigation by Nan Cao and colleagues described above provides seroprevalence data that indicate that the risk of poultry-to-human and, additionally, poultry-to-pig transmission of at least the clades 2.3.2 avian H5N1 viruses has so far been very low in southern China. AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (141): CHINA: SOUTHERN, H5N1 SEROPREVALENCE\n*******************************************************************\n [Since the 1st confirmed human cases of H5N1 avian influenza virus infection were detected in 2003, there have been a total of 641 cases reported in 15 countries with 380 fatalities (as of 8 Oct 2013; see http://www.who.int/influenza/human_animal_interface/EN_GIP_20131008CumulativeNumberH5N1cases.pdf). A seroepidemiological study was undertaken among swine farm residents and pigs to understand the prevalence of antibodies against H5N1 avian influenza viruses in southern China. This study provides the 1st data regarding antibodies against H5N1 avian influenza viruses in humans and pigs on swine farms in China. No serum samples from human controls and pigs were positive for H5N1 avian influenza virus by hemagglutination assay. http://www.journalofclinicalvirology.com/article/S1386-6532(13)00408-3/abstract\n\n\nAvian influenza A (H5N1) virus antibodies in pigs and residents of swine farms, southern China. During the period 24 Mar 2008 to 25 Dec 2012, serum samples were collected from 1606 swine farm residents on 40 swine farms in southern China. \n\nThroughout this period, there have been no Note by the OIE Animal Health Information Department: H5 and H7 avian influenza in its low pathogenic form in poultry is a notifiable disease as per Chapter 10.4. on avian influenza of the Terrestrial Animal Health Code (2013).\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied:\n- stamping out\n- zoning\n- disinfection of infected premises/establishment(s)\n- vaccination prohibited\n- no treatment of affected animals\n\nMeasures to be applied:\n- stamping out\n- so other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results:\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nFriedrich-Loeffler Institute (national laboratory) / Birds / polymerase chain reaction (PCR) / 15 Nov 2013 / Positive\n\nFuture Reporting:\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\nThe location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Information obtained from EMPRES shows the affected premises as having the following susceptible species: 242 chickens, 150 ducks, 29 guinea fowl, 382 geese, and 27 turkeys. All birds were destroyed. The strain, which was isolated from chickens, was identified as LPAI H5N1 http://empres-i.fao.org/eipws3g/#h=0.\n\nOIE Terrestrial Code Chapter 10.4. on infection with avian influenza viruses, Article 10.4.1., defines poultry as: all domesticated birds, including backyard poultry, used for the production of meat or eggs for consumption, for the production of other commercial products, for restocking supplies of game, or for breeding these categories of birds, as well as fighting cocks used for any purpose. Birds that are kept in captivity for any reason other than those reasons referred to in the preceding paragraph, including those that are kept for shows, races, exhibitions, competitions or for breeding or selling these categories of birds as well as pet birds, are not considered to be poultry http://www.oie.int/index.php?id=169&L=0&htmfile=chapitre_1.10.4.htm.\n\nQuantitative information provided by OIE's WAHID database shows that from January 2010 to June 2013, Germany reported 32 outbreaks of LPAI:\nYear / No. outbreaks\n2010 / 1\n2011 / 22\n2012 / 1\n2013 / 8\n\nThe LPAI strains identified during these years were H5N1, H5N2 and H7N7.\n\nFor further details of these outbreaks, select the disease, region/country and year at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Diseaseinformation/statusdetail.\n\nLow pathogenic avian influenza (LPAI) typically causes only minor illness, poses no risk to human health, and often causes no clinical signs. "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2046967", "date": "2013-11-09 12:30:20", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (137): CAMBODIA (KAMPOT) H5N1\n****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 8 Nov 2013\nSource: Global Times, Xinhua News Agency report [edited]\nhttp://www.globaltimes.cn/content/823534.shtml#.Un5SYZROoa7\n\n\nA 10-year-old boy from southern Kampot province has been confirmed positive for the H5N1 avian influenza virus, bringing the number of the cases to 24 so far this year [2013], the World Health Organization and the Cambodian Health Ministry stated in a joint statement on Friday [8 Nov 2013]. The boy was confirmed positive for human H5N1 avian influenza on Thursday [7 Nov 2013] after he was admitted to the Kantha Bopha Hospital in Phnom Penh with fever, cough, sore throat, a distended abdomen, and dyspnea. 'The boy has been treated with Tamiflu. Currently, his condition is critical,' the statement said. Only 12 out of the 24 cases this year [2013] have survived. 'Investigations in his village found that a month before the 10-year-old boy's illness, about 30 chickens had died suddenly in the village, and the boy helped carry dead chickens for his brother who was preparing a meal from them,' the statement said.\n\nHealth Minister Mam Bunheng said [H5N1] bird flu remains a serious threat to the health of all Cambodians and children seem to be most vulnerable and are at high risk. 'Once again, I'd like to appeal to parents and guardians to keep children away from sick or dead poultry and make sure children wash their hands with soap and water after any contact with poultry,' he said.\n\nH5N1 avian influenza virus is a virus that usually spreads between sick poultry, but it can sometimes spread from poultry to humans, according to the World Health Organization. Cambodia is seeing the worst outbreak of the virus this year [2013] since it was first identified in 2004. To date, the country has reported 45 human cases of the virus, killing 31 people.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A total of 15 countries have reported human cases of avian H5N1 influenza since the 1st human cases appeared in 2003. Now, of these, only 6 countries are still reporting cases of H5N1 and of these 6, only Cambodia is reporting significant numbers of cases (see: WHO table of cumulative number of confirmed human cases for avian influenza A(H5N1) reported to WHO, 2003-2013 at http://www.who.int/influenza/human_animal_interface/EN_GIP_20131008CumulativeNumberH5N1cases.pdf). Of the 35 confirmed human cases of H5N1 avian influenza virus recorded globally during 2013, a total of 24 have occurred in Cambodia. The fatality in 2013 remains 13. The majority of cases in Cambodia have been children and as yet Cambodian authorities seem unable to address this problem.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/5miC. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "\n\n\nA 10-year-old boy from southern Kampot province has been confirmed positive for the H5N1 avian influenza virus, bringing the number of the cases to 24 so far this year [2013], the World Health Organization and the Cambodian Health Ministry stated in a joint statement on Friday [8 Nov 2013]. The case is a 31-year-old female resident of East Bekasi, West Java Province with symptoms of fever and nausea commencing on 1 Nov 2013. On 3 Nov 2013 the patient attended a private outpatient clinic and was advised to check into a laboratory within 3 days if there was no change in her condition. When there was no improvement by 5 Nov 2013, the patient then went to a private hospital outpatient clinic with laboratory facilities and was diagnosed with typhoid fever. On 6 Nov 2013 the patient went to a different private hospital emergency department complaining of fever, nausea, and vomiting and was treated at that hospital. On 8 Nov 2013 the patient's condition worsened with development of coughing and shortness of breath. On 11 Nov 2013 at around 2:00 in the morning, [the patient died following transfer] to avian influenza referral hospital.\n\nEpidemiological investigations have been conducted in the homes of neighbours of the victim and their environment by the Ministry of Health Integrated Team, West Java Provincial Health Office, Department of Health and Department of Animal Husbandry of Bekasi to identify possible risk factors [which in this case may have been proximity to ornamental bird aviaries]. There were about 50-60 birds in 4 adjacent locations. About 500 metres from the patient's house there is also a general market that the deceased visited.\n\nThe cumulative number of [human] cases [of H5N1 influenza] since the 1st appearance of the disease in Indonesia in 2005 is now 195 cases with 163 deaths. The Director General of Disease Control and Environmental Health Yoga Aditama Prof. Dr. Tjandra as the focal point of the International Health Regulations (IHR) has communicated this information to the World Health Organisation.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[Official confirmation is awaited from an English language source, or an international agency, to confirm some of the uncertainties in this translation. This is only the 3rd case and 3rd fatality to have been reported by Indonesia during 2013 (see the WHO cumulative table of H5N1 cases at: http://www.who.int/influenza/human_animal_interface/EN_GIP_20131008CumulativeNumberH5N1cases.pdf). - Mod.CP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/2HZy.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n On 6 Nov 2013 the patient went to a different private hospital emergency department complaining of fever, nausea, and vomiting and was treated at that hospital. When there was no improvement by 5 Nov 2013, the patient then went to a private hospital outpatient clinic with laboratory facilities and was diagnosed with typhoid fever. On 3 Nov 2013 the patient attended a private outpatient clinic and was advised to check into a laboratory within 3 days if there was no change in her condition. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[Official confirmation is awaited from an English language source, or an international agency, to confirm some of the uncertainties in this translation. AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (140): INDONESIA (WEST JAVA) H5N1, FATAL\n***************************************************************\n On 11 Nov 2013 at around 2:00 in the morning, [the patient died following transfer] to avian influenza referral hospital.", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2013-03-25 00:00:00", "2005-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Indonesia", "country": "Indonesia"}, {"location": "West Java Province", "country": "Iran"}, {"location": "Bekasi", "country": "Indonesia"}, {"location": "WEST JAVA", "country": "Indonesia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2073200", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (144): H5N1, vaccine approved", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2073200", "date": "2013-11-25 11:39:36", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (144): H5N1, VACCINE APPROVED\n****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 24 Nov 2013\nSource: Reuters [edited]\nhttp://www.reuters.com/article/2013/11/24/us-glaxosmithkline-vaccine-pandemic-idUSBRE9AL14Q20131124\n\n\nThe GSK [GlaxoSmithKline] H5N1 [influenza] vaccine will be added to the [US] national stockpile and will not be available for commercial use, the FDA [United States Food and Drug Administration] said. The vaccine does not have a trade name in the United States. It is the 1st H5N1 vaccine approved in the United States to contain an adjuvant, or booster, that turbo-charges the body's immune response to the vaccine.\n\n'This vaccine could be used in the event that the H5N1 avian influenza virus develops the capability to spread efficiently from human to human, resulting in the rapid spread of disease across the globe,' Dr Karen Midthun, director of the FDA's biologics division, said in a statement. The FDA approved the vaccine for use in people over the age of 18 who are at increased risk of exposure to the virus. It would be distributed by public health officials if needed. The approval comes amid some uncertainty over the safety of modern adjuvants such as the one used in GSK's bird flu vaccine.\n\nHowever, there are no truly effective traditional vaccines against bird flu. GSK's super-charged [that is, adjuvant-containing] product is the first to show it can confer protection in the event of a pandemic. European regulators have approved it under the brand name Pumarix. Data show that children in England who received a similar adjuvanted vaccine, Pandemrix, during the 2009-10 H1N1 swine flu epidemic had a 14-fold heightened risk of developing narcolepsy, a chronic and potentially debilitating sleep disorder that can cause hallucinations, daytime sleepiness, and cataplexy, a form of muscle weakness precipitated by strong emotion. According to GSK, some 30 million doses of Pandemrix were administered across Europe and 800 people, mostly children, developed narcolepsy. While GSK has acknowledged an association between the vaccine and the narcolepsy cases, it has said there is insufficient evidence to prove the adjuvant was to blame.\n\nAdjuvants have been used in vaccines for diseases such as diphtheria and tetanus for decades. Now, a new, more powerful generation of adjuvants, including one known as AS03 that is contained in the bird flu vaccine, is being developed whose safety is relatively untested. Previously, the United States has taken a more cautious approach toward adjuvants than some other countries. The FDA did not, for example, approve Pandemrix. US experts felt that traditional, non-adjuvanted H1N1 vaccines made by Sanofi SA and others offered enough protection against the virus. But an advisory panel voted unanimously that the FDA should approve the vaccine against bird flu, which kills nearly 60 percent of those who become infected. By comparison, the H1N1 virus kills fewer than 1 percent of those infected.\n\nThe H5N1 bird flu virus was first isolated in a human in Hong Kong in 1997 and began to spread throughout Southeast Asia in 2003. A 2011 report by the World Health Organization showed only 566 people had been infected with bird flu worldwide [641 through 7 Oct 2013], compared with millions infected with the 2009 H1N1 swine flu virus. But the death rate for bird flu is far higher.\n\n[Byline: Toni Clarke]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[According to WHO's assessment as of 7 Oct 2013 (http://www.who.int/influenza/human_animal_interface/Influenza_Summary_IRA_HA_interface_7October13.pdf), from 2003 through 7 Oct 2013, there have been 641 laboratory-confirmed human cases of avian influenza A(H5N1) virus infection officially reported to WHO from 15 countries. Of these cases, 380 died. All cases are considered to be sporadic, with no evidence of community-level transmission. Currently influenza A(H5N1) virus is thought to be circulating widely in poultry in Cambodia and Indonesia, and additional sporadic human cases or small clusters might be expected in the future.\n\nThe overall human public health risk assessment for avian influenza A(H5N1) viruses is low. Whenever influenza viruses are circulating in poultry, sporadic infections or small clusters of human cases are possible, especially in people exposed to infected household poultry or contaminated environments. However, influenza A(H5N1) virus does not currently appear to transmit easily among people.\n\nThe recent cases of H5N1 virus infection in Cambodia have predominantly involved children, therefore the GSK adjuvanted vaccine would have no immediate use. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "\n\n'This vaccine could be used in the event that the H5N1 avian influenza virus develops the capability to spread efficiently from human to human, resulting in the rapid spread of disease across the globe,' Dr Karen Midthun, director of the FDA's biologics division, said in a statement. [According to WHO's assessment as of 7 Oct 2013 (http://www.who.int/influenza/human_animal_interface/Influenza_Summary_IRA_HA_interface_7October13.pdf), from 2003 through 7 Oct 2013, there have been 641 laboratory-confirmed human cases of avian influenza A(H5N1) virus infection officially reported to WHO from 15 countries. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Data show that children in England who received a similar adjuvanted vaccine, Pandemrix, during the 2009-10 H1N1 swine flu epidemic had a 14-fold heightened risk of developing narcolepsy, a chronic and potentially debilitating sleep disorder that can cause hallucinations, daytime sleepiness, and cataplexy, a form of muscle weakness precipitated by strong emotion. Whenever influenza viruses are circulating in poultry, sporadic infections or small clusters of human cases are possible, especially in people exposed to infected household poultry or contaminated environments. AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (144): H5N1, VACCINE APPROVED\n****************************************************\n \n\nThe recent cases of H5N1 virus infection in Cambodia have predominantly involved children, therefore the GSK adjuvanted vaccine would have no immediate use. \n\nThe H5N1 bird flu virus was first isolated in a human in Hong Kong in 1997 and began to spread throughout Southeast Asia in 2003. Currently influenza A(H5N1) virus is thought to be circulating widely in poultry in Cambodia and Indonesia, and additional sporadic human cases or small clusters might be expected in the future. But an advisory panel voted unanimously that the FDA should approve the vaccine against bird flu, which kills nearly 60 percent of those who become infected. Now, a new, more powerful generation of adjuvants, including one known as AS03 that is contained in the bird flu vaccine, is being developed whose safety is relatively untested. The FDA approved the vaccine for use in people over the age of 18 who are at increased risk of exposure to the virus.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1997-03-25 00:00:00", "2009-03-25 00:00:00", "2009-10-25 00:00:00", "2003-03-25 00:00:00", "2011-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Cambodia", "country": "Cambodia"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pandemrix", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "Hong Kong"}, {"location": "Indonesia", "country": "Indonesia"}, {"location": "England", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2041724", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (136): Cambodia (PO) H5N1, WHO", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2041724", "date": "2013-11-06 16:26:15", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (136): CAMBODIA (PURSAT), H5N1, WHO\n**********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 5 Nov 2013\nSource: WHO Joint Press Release with Ministry of Health of the Kingdom of Cambodia [edited]\nhttp://www.wpro.who.int/mediacentre/releases/2013/20131105/en/index.html\n\n\nThe Ministry of Health (MoH) of the Kingdom of Cambodia wishes to advise members of the public that one new human case of avian influenza has been confirmed for the H5N1 virus. This is the 23rd case this year [2013] and the 44th person to become infected with the H5N1 virus in Cambodia. The 23rd case died on 26 Oct 2013. Of the 44 confirmed cases, 33 were children under 14, and 27 of the 44 were female. In addition, only 11 cases out of the 23 cases this year survived.\n\nThe 23rd case, a 2-year-old girl from Svay Chrum village, Borng Bort Kandal commune, Bakane district, Pursat province was confirmed positive for H5N1 human avian influenza on 30 Oct 2013 by Institut Pasteur du Cambodge. The girl developed fever on 17 Oct 2013. On 19 Oct 2013, her parents sought treatment for her at a local private practitioner. Her condition worsened, and she was admitted to Jayavarman VII Hospital in Siem Reap on 25 Oct 2013 with fever, running nose, lethargy, dyspnea [shortness of breath], cough and breathing difficulties. Laboratory samples were taken the same day, but no Tamifu was administered. The girl died on 26 Oct 2013.\n\nInvestigations in Svay Chrum village by the Ministry of Health's Rapid Response Teams (RRT) and the Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Fishery's Animal Health Task Force revealed that 2 months before the girl's illness, poultry had suddenly died at her grandparent's house. The child often stayed with her grandparent in this house. Human and animal investigations are underway to determine whether the girl had direct exposure or handled the dead chickens.\n\nThe Ministry of Health's RRTs and the Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Fishery's Animal Health Task Force are working together closely in Svay Chrum village in Pursat to investigate and implement control measures. The RRTs are trying to identify the case's close contacts, any epidemiological linkage among the 23 [2013] cases, and initiating preventive treatment as required. The Animal Health Task Force is investigating cases of poultry deaths in the village.\n\n'Avian influenza H5N1 remains a serious threat to the health of all Cambodians and more so for children, who seem to be most vulnerable and are at high risk. There have been 23 cases of H5N1 infection in humans this year [2013]. Children often care for domestic poultry by feeding them, cleaning pens and gathering eggs. Children may also have closer contact with poultry as they often treat them as pets and also seem to be most vulnerable and are at high risk because they like to play where poultry are found. I urge parents and guardians to keep children away from sick or dead poultry and prevent them from playing with chickens and ducks. Parents and guardians must also make sure children thoroughly wash their hands with soap and water before eating and after any contact with poultry. Hands may carry the virus, which cannot be seen by the naked eye. Soap washes away the virus on hands. If children have fast or difficult breathing, their parents should seek medical attention at the nearest health facility, and attending physicians must be made aware of any exposure to sick or dead poultry,' said H.E. Dr. Mam Bunheng, Minister of Health.\n\nA nationwide public health education campaign using radio was launched in early October 2013. Also, public health education campaigns are being conducted in Svay Chrum village in Pursat using information, education, and communications materials to inform families on how to protect themselves from contracting avian influenza. The government's message is to wash hands often with soap and water before eating and after coming into contact with poultry; keep children away from poultry; keep poultry away from living areas; do not eat dead or sick poultry, and all poultry eaten should be well cooked.\n\nH5N1 influenza is a flu that normally spreads between sick poultry, but it can sometimes spread from poultry to humans. Human H5N1 avian influenza is a very serious disease that requires hospitalization. Although the virus currently does not easily spread among humans, if the virus changes, it could easily be spread like seasonal influenza. Hence, early recognition of cases is important.\n\nThe Ministry of Health will continue to keep the public informed of developments via the MoH website http://www.cdcmoh.gov.kh, where relevant health education materials can also be downloaded.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A total of 15 countries have reported human cases of avian H5N1 since the 1st human cases appeared in 2003. Now, of these, only 6 countries are still reporting cases of H5N1. Of these 6, only Cambodia is reporting significant numbers of cases [see: WHO Table of the Cumulative number of confirmed human cases for avian influenza A(H5N1) reported to WHO, 2003-2013 at: http://www.who.int/influenza/human_animal_interface/EN_GIP_20131008CumulativeNumberH5N1cases.pdf]. Of the 34 confirmed human cases of H5N1 avian influenza virus recorded globally during 2013, a total of 23 have occurred in Cambodia. The case described above is the 12th fatality in 2013. - Mod.CP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1iGB.]", "summary": "The government's message is to wash hands often with soap and water before eating and after coming into contact with poultry; keep children away from poultry; keep poultry away from living areas; do not eat dead or sick poultry, and all poultry eaten should be well cooked. \n\nThe 23rd case, a 2-year-old girl from Svay Chrum village, Borng Bort Kandal commune, Bakane district, Pursat province was confirmed positive for H5N1 human avian influenza on 30 Oct 2013 by Institut Pasteur du Cambodge. Of these 6, only Cambodia is reporting significant numbers of cases [see: WHO Table of the Cumulative number of confirmed human cases for avian influenza A(H5N1) reported to WHO, 2003-2013 at: http://www.who.int/influenza/human_animal_interface/EN_GIP_20131008CumulativeNumberH5N1cases.pdf]. According to the release (http://www.cdcmoh.gov.kh/PressRelease/43-Pressrelease_Eg.pdf): The case is a 6-year-old girl from Romdoul village, Romdoul commune, Phnom Preuk district, Battambang province confirmed positive for H5N avian influenza virus infection on 24 Oct 2013 by Institut Pasteur du Cambodge. The girl developed fever on 14 Oct 2013. On 15 Oct 2013, her parents sought treatment for her in the village. The girl's condition worsened and the girl was referred to the Jayavarman VII Hospital in Siem Reap. On 19 Oct 2013 she was admitted to the Jayavarman VII Hospital with fever, cough, abdominal pain, running nose, sore throat and dyspnea. Laboratory samples were taken on 22 Oct 2013 and Tamiflu administered on 24 Oct 2013. The girl is currently in a stable condition.\n\nThis brings the total number of human H5N1 avian influenza cases to 22 this year [2013]. The investigation reveals that chickens and ducks have recently died in the girl's neighbor's house and in nearly villages. Health officials in Cambodia are identifying the child's close contacts as well as studying whether there are any epidemiologic links among the 22 patients infected this year. Animal health workers are investigating deaths in birds in the area. A statement from Minister of Health Dr. Mam Bunheng points out the special danger of H5N1 to children in that they commonly care for, feed, and clean the cages of domestic poultry and often treat them as pets. Parents are being urged through public health education campaigns to keep children away from sick or dead poultry, not allow them to play with chickens and ducks, and make sure they wash their hands with soap and water before eating and after contact with poultry.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Of the 33 confirmed human cases of H5N1 avian influenza virus recorded globally during 2013, a total of 22 have occurred in Cambodia.\n\nA map of the administrative divisions of Cambodia, showing the location of Battambang province, can be accessed at: http://www.vidiani.com/?p=3257. - Mod.CP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/90qV.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n According to the release (http://www.cdcmoh.gov.kh/PressRelease/43-Pressrelease_Eg.pdf): The case is a 6-year-old girl from Romdoul village, Romdoul commune, Phnom Preuk district, Battambang province confirmed positive for H5N avian influenza virus infection on 24 Oct 2013 by Institut Pasteur du Cambodge. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Of the 33 confirmed human cases of H5N1 avian influenza virus recorded globally during 2013, a total of 22 have occurred in Cambodia. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Laboratory samples were taken on 22 Oct 2013 and Tamiflu administered on 24 Oct 2013.", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2013-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Battambang province", "country": "Cambodia"}, {"location": "the Kingdom of Cambodia", "country": "Colombia"}, {"location": "Cambodia", "country": "Cambodia"}, {"location": "Romdoul village", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Battambang Province", "country": "Cambodia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2016517", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (124): Cambodia (KT) H5N1, WHO", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2016517", "date": "2013-10-23 12:51:49", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (124): CAMBODIA (KAMPONG THOM) H5N1, WHO\n***************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 22 Oct 2013\nSource: WHO, Western Pacific Region, Media centre, Joint news release between the Ministry of Health of the Kingdom of Cambodia and WHO [edited]\nhttp://www.wpro.who.int/mediacentre/releases/2013/20131022h5n1/en/index.html\n\n\n21st new human case of avian influenza H5N1 in Cambodia in 2013\n---------------------------------------------------------------\nThe Ministry of Health (MoH) of the Kingdom of Cambodia wishes to advise members of the public that one new human case of avian influenza has been confirmed for the H5N1 virus. This is the 21st case this year [2013] and the 42nd person to become infected with the H5N1 virus in Cambodia. Of the 42 confirmed cases, 31 were children under 14, and 25 of the 42 were female. In addition, only 10 cases out of the 21 cases this year [2013] survived.\n\nThe 21st case, an 8 year old girl from O-Raing village, Pung Ror commune, Baray district in Kampong Thom province confirmed positive for human H5N1 avian influenza on [17 Oct 2013] by Institut Pasteur of Cambodia. The girl developed fever on [8 Oct 2013], together with sneezing. On [9 Oct 2013], her parents sought treatment for her in the village clinic. On [10 Oct 2013], the girl developed a cough together with fever and vomiting and her parents sought treatment for her outside the village at a private clinic in Taing Kor in Kampong Thom province. On [11 Oct 2013], the girl's condition worsened and the private clinic referred her to the Jayavarman VII Hospital in Siem Reap [province].\n\nThe girl was admitted to the Jayavarman VII Hospital, on [11 Oct], with fever, cough, vomiting, and dyspnea. Laboratory samples were taken on [11 Oct] and [14 Oct 2013] and Tamiflu [oseltamivir] administered on [14 Oct 2013]. The girl is currently in a stable condition.\n\nInvestigations by the Ministry of Health's Rapid Response Teams (RRT) in O-Raing village revealed that the girl had come into direct contact with dead poultry when she helped prepare a meal from a chicken that had died earlier. The Ministry of Health's RRTs and the Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Fishery's Animal Health Task Force are working together closely in O-Raing village in Kampong Thom to investigate and implement control measures. The RRTs are trying to identify the cases' close contacts, any epidemiological linkage among the 21 cases and initiate preventive treatment as required. The Animal Health Task Force is investigating cases of poultry deaths in the villages.\n\n'Avian influenza H5N1 remains a serious threat to the health of all Cambodians and more so for children, who seem to be most vulnerable and are at high risk. There have been 21 cases of H5N1 infection in humans this year [2013]. Children often care for domestic poultry by feeding them, cleaning pens, and gathering eggs. Children may also have closer contact with poultry as they often treat them as pets and also seem to be most vulnerable and are at high risk because they like to play where poultry are found. I urge parents and guardians to keep children away from sick or dead poultry and prevent them from playing with chickens and ducks. Parents and guardians must also make sure children thoroughly wash their hands with soap and water before eating and after any contact with poultry. Hands may carry the virus that cannot be seen by the naked eye. Soap cleans the virus on hands. If children have fast or difficult breathing, their parents should seek medical attention at the nearest health facility and attending physicians must be made aware of any exposure to sick or dead poultry,' said HE Dr Mam Bunheng, minister of health.\n\nA nationwide public health education campaign using radio has been launched in early October [2013]. Also, public health education campaigns are being conducted in O-Raing village in Kampong Thom using information, education, and communications materials to inform families on how to protect themselves from contracting avian influenza. The government's message is, wash hands often with soap and water, before eating and after coming into contact with poultry; keep children away from poultry; keep poultry away from living areas; do not eat dead or sick poultry; and all poultry eaten should be well cooked.\n\nH5N1 influenza is a [virus] that normally spreads between sick poultry, but it can sometimes spread from poultry to humans. Human H5N1 avian influenza is a very serious disease that requires hospitalization. Although the virus currently does not easily spread among humans, if the virus changes it could easily be spread like seasonal influenza. Hence, early recognition of cases is important.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In summary: avian influenza H5N1 remains a serious threat to the health of all Cambodians and more so for children, who seem to be the most vulnerable and are at high risk. There have been 21 cases of H5N1 infection in humans in Cambodia this year (2013). In Cambodia children often care for domestic poultry by feeding them, cleaning pens, and gathering eggs. Children may also have closer contact with poultry as they often treat them as pets and also seem to be most vulnerable and are at high risk because they like to play where poultry are found.\n\nAs of 8 Oct 2013 there had been 31 human cases of avian H5N1 virus infection globally, 20 of whom have died. Of this total 20 human cases occurred in Cambodia with 11 fatalities (See http://www.who.int/influenza/human_animal_interface/EN_GIP_20131008CumulativeNumberH5N1cases.pdf).\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Cambodia can be seen at http://healthmap.org/r/8TH0. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Children may also have closer contact with poultry as they often treat them as pets and also seem to be most vulnerable and are at high risk because they like to play where poultry are found. Children may also have closer contact with poultry as they often treat them as pets and also seem to be most vulnerable and are at high risk because they like to play where poultry are found. \n\nInvestigations by the Ministry of Health's Rapid Response Teams (RRT) in O-Raing village revealed that the girl had come into direct contact with dead poultry when she helped prepare a meal from a chicken that had died earlier. If children have fast or difficult breathing, their parents should seek medical attention at the nearest health facility and attending physicians must be made aware of any exposure to sick or dead poultry,' said HE Dr Mam Bunheng, minister of health. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In summary: avian influenza H5N1 remains a serious threat to the health of all Cambodians and more so for children, who seem to be the most vulnerable and are at high risk. As of 8 Oct 2013 there had been 31 human cases of avian H5N1 virus infection globally, 20 of whom have died. \n\n'Avian influenza H5N1 remains a serious threat to the health of all Cambodians and more so for children, who seem to be most vulnerable and are at high risk. On [10 Oct 2013], the girl developed a cough together with fever and vomiting and her parents sought treatment for her outside the village at a private clinic in Taing Kor in Kampong Thom province. \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Parents and guardians must also make sure children thoroughly wash their hands with soap and water before eating and after any contact with poultry.", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2013-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Baray", "country": "Cambodia"}, {"location": "Cambodia", "country": "Cambodia"}, {"location": "Kampong Thom", "country": "Cambodia"}, {"location": "the Kingdom of Cambodia", "country": "Colombia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2007097", "headline": "PRO/AH> Avian influenza, human (123): H7N9, H5N1, age and sex-specific morbidity", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2007097", "date": "2013-10-18 23:30:32", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (123): H7N9, H5N1, AGE AND SEX-SPECIFIC MORBIDITY\n************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 3 Oct 2013\nSource: Journal of Clinical Virology (2013), in press [edited]\nhttp://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jcv.2013.09.004\n\nRef: Dudley JP, Mackay IM: Age-specific and sex-specific morbidity and mortality from avian influenza A(H7N9). J Clin Virol. 2013; pii: S1386-6532(13)00395-8. doi: 10.1016/j.jcv.2013.09.004. [Epub ahead of print]\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nAbstract\n--------\nWe used data on age and sex for 136 laboratory confirmed human A(H7N9) cases reported as of 11 Aug 2013 to compare age-specific and sex-specific patterns of morbidity and mortality from the avian influenza A(H7N9) virus with those of the avian influenza A(H5N1) virus. Human A(H7N9) cases exhibit high degrees of age and sex bias: mortality is heavily biased toward males older than 50 years, no deaths have been reported among individuals younger than 25 years old, and relatively few cases documented among children or adolescents. The proportion of fatal cases (PFC) for human A(H7N9) cases as of 11 Aug 2013 was 32 percent, compared to a cumulative PFC for A(H5N1) of 83 percent in Indonesia and 36 percent in Egypt. Approximately 75 percent of cases of all A(H7N9) cases occurred among individuals older than 45 years old.\n\nMorbidity and mortality from A(H7N9) are lowest among individuals between 10 and 29 years, the age group which exhibits the highest cumulative morbidity and case fatality rates from A(H5N1). Although individuals younger than 20 years old comprise nearly 50 percent of all human A(H5N1) cases, only 7 percent of all reported A(H7N9) cases and no deaths have been reported among individuals in this age group. Only 4 percent of A(H7N9) cases occurred among children younger than 5 years old, and only one case from the 10 to 20 year age group.\n\nAge- and sex-related differences in morbidity and mortality from emerging zoonotic diseases can provide insights into ecological, economic, and cultural factors that may contribute to the emergence and proliferation of novel zoonotic diseases in human populations.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This new analysis of age and sex-specific morbidity and mortality in human patients reveals interesting common features of the A/(H5N1) and A/(H7N9) avian influenza virus infections.\n\nHuman infections with avian A/(H5N1) have occurred over a period of 10 years and have been reported in 15 countries from Turkey in the West to China in the East. In contrast, so far, avian influenza A/(H7N9) human infections has been restricted to China (and a single case in Taiwan) during the current influenza season. Fortunately so far neither of these 2 avian influenza viruses has developed potential for sustained human-to-human transmission. But it cannot be assumed the this situation will continue. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "We used data on age and sex for 136 laboratory confirmed human A(H7N9) cases reported as of 11 Aug 2013 to compare age-specific and sex-specific patterns of morbidity and mortality from the avian influenza A(H7N9) virus with those of the avian influenza A(H5N1) virus. Human A(H7N9) cases exhibit high degrees of age and sex bias: mortality is heavily biased toward males older than 50 years, no deaths have been reported among individuals younger than 25 years old, and relatively few cases documented among children or adolescents. Although individuals younger than 20 years old comprise nearly 50 percent of all human A(H5N1) cases, only 7 percent of all reported A(H7N9) cases and no deaths have been reported among individuals in this age group. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (123): H7N9, H5N1, AGE AND SEX-SPECIFIC MORBIDITY\n************************************************************************\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This new analysis of age and sex-specific morbidity and mortality in human patients reveals interesting common features of the A/(H5N1) and A/(H7N9) avian influenza virus infections. The proportion of fatal cases (PFC) for human A(H7N9) cases as of 11 Aug 2013 was 32 percent, compared to a cumulative PFC for A(H5N1) of 83 percent in Indonesia and 36 percent in Egypt. \n\nMorbidity and mortality from A(H7N9) are lowest among individuals between 10 and 29 years, the age group which exhibits the highest cumulative morbidity and case fatality rates from A(H5N1). Only 4 percent of A(H7N9) cases occurred among children younger than 5 years old, and only one case from the 10 to 20 year age group.", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": [], "event_date": The boy was confirmed positive for human H5N1 avian influenza virus infection on 17 Aug 2013 after he caught fever, headache, abdominal pain, vomiting, cough, and lethargy, the statement said, adding that the boy came into contact with sick poultry. 'The boy has now recovered,' the statement said. Only 7 out of the 17 cases this year [2013] survived, the statement said. The latest death from the virus was a 9-year-old boy from northwestern Battambang Province, who died on Sunday [18 Aug 2013].\n\nAvian influenza H5N1 remained a serious threat to the health of all Cambodians, Health Minister Mam Bunheng said. 'Children also seem to be most vulnerable and are at high risk because they like to play where poultry are found,' he said in the statement. 'I urge parents and guardians to keep children away from sick or dead poultry and make sure children wash their hands with soap and water after any contact with poultry.'\n\nCambodia sees the worst outbreak of the virus this year [2013] since the disease was first identified in 2004. To date, the country has recorded 38 human cases of the virus, killing 29 people.\n\n[Editor: Yang Yi]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This case brings the total for Cambodia this year to 17, with 10 deaths. And what can be highlighted is that there is a more-than-24-hours gap between the time when the physician suspected that the patient had bird flu and his referral to the better equipped hospital. It shows that the health community had let down their guard, perhaps because previously there is only one bird flu case this year [2013] (and it was September already). Here's my translation:\n\nBird flu case report no 194\n---------------------------\nThe Ministry of Health Republic of Indonesia, Directorate General of Disease Control and Environmental Health announced one new H5N1 case that had been confirmed by the Health Biomedic and Basic Technology Center, Health Research and Development Agency.\n\nThe patient was a 28-year-old male, resident of Cibitung Sub District, Bekasi District, West Java Province, who worked as a driver in a bottled drinking water company.\n\nCase chronology:\n- 16 Sep 2013: patient developed fever and muscle stiffness/pain\n- 18 Sep 2013: patient sought medical help in a private hospital in the Bekasi District, but [his fever increased, accompanied by coughing and dyspnea (shortness of breath) and he] was back and hospitalised in the same hospital on 20 Sep 2013\n- 25 Sep 2013: patient's condition got worse, still with high fever and greater difficulty breathing, and was transferred to the intensive care unit\n- 26 Sep 2013: at predawn the hospital's physician suspected that the patient had bird flu\n- 27 Sep 2013: patient was transferred to Persahabatan referral hospital for avian influenza in Jakarta, but the patient passed away at 8.10 pm.\n\nEpidemiological investigation had been conducted at the hospital, patient's home, and surrounding neighborhood by a joint team consisting of personnel from the Ministry of Health, Ministry of Agriculture, Bekasi District, and West Java Province Health Services Offices, and Bekasi District and West Java Province Livestock Services Offices. The risk factor found was environmental contact based on the fact that patient owned ornamental birds and pigeons. Less than 50 meters [55 yards] in front of the patient's house a field was used once a week to stage pigeon races. Furthermore, a lot of birds, especially pigeons, kept by local residents, can be found in the surrounding neighbourhood.\n\nWith this additional case, cumulative cases of bird flu in Indonesia since 2005 up to date is 194 cases with 162 fatalities.\n\nProf Tjanda Yoga Aditama, MD, Director General of Disease Control and Environmental Health as the focal point for International Health Regulation had reported this latest case to the WHO.\n\nThis news was broadcasted by the Public Communication Center, Secretariat General, Ministry of Health, RI. Further information can be obtained by contacting phone: +6221-52907416 through 52907419, fax: +6221-52921669, Rapid Response Center (PTRC): <Indonesian local code> 500-567 and +6281281562620 (text message), or e-mail to <kontak@depkes.go.id>.\n\n--\nC. Baso Darmawan, DVM\nFAO ECTAD Indonesia HPAI Programme\n<baso.darmawan@fao.org>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks correspondent C Baso Darmawan for providing this alternative translation of the Ministry of Health statement that was included as part of the previous ProMED-mail report.\n\nThis new translation includes some additional relevant information not included in the previous version. In particular the information that the deceased had extensive contact with pigeons and other birds not in his home and in adjacent ground. It is likely that exposure to avian H5N1 influenza virus was a consequence of these particular circumstances. - Mod.CP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1Aiz.]", "summary": "Sep 2013: patient developed fever and muscle stiffness/pain\n- 18 Sep 2013: patient sought medical help in a private hospital in the Bekasi District, but [his fever increased, accompanied by coughing and dyspnea (shortness of breath) and he] was back and hospitalised in the same hospital on 20 Sep 2013\n- 25 Sep 2013: patient's condition got worse, still with high fever and greater difficulty breathing, and was transferred to the intensive care unit\n- 26 Sep 2013: at predawn the hospital's physician suspected that the patient had bird flu\n- 27 Sep 2013: patient was transferred to Persahabatan referral hospital for avian influenza in Jakarta, but the patient passed away at 8.10 pm. \n\n--\nC. [Re: ProMED-mail Avian influenza, human (119): Indonesia (WJ) H5N1, fatality 20131008.1990523]\n If this can be of any help, I have made this alternative translation of the Ministry of Health's announcement, which was weirdly dated 26 Sep 2013, a day before the patient died.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-09-25 00:00:00", "2005-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "West Java Province Health Services Offices", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Jakarta", "country": "Indonesia"}, {"location": "West Java Province", "country": "Iran"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "RI", "country": "Saudi Arabia"}, {"location": "West Java", "country": "Indonesia"}, {"location": "Indonesia", "country": "Indonesia"}, {"location": "WEST JAVA", "country": "Indonesia"}, {"location": "Bekasi District", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1892436", "headline": "PRO/AH> Avian influenza, human (109) China: H5N1 & H7N9 emergence", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1892436", "date": "2013-08-22 12:26:32", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (109) CHINA: H5N1 AND H7N9 EMERGENCE\n***********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 20 Aug 2013\nSource: CIDRAP (Center for Infectious Disease Research & Policy) News [edited]\nhttp://www.cidrap.umn.edu/news-perspective/2013/08/news-scan-aug-20-2013\n\n\nScientists cite parallels, differences in emergence of H7N9 and H5N1\n--------------------------------------------------------------------\nIn a lengthy perspective article in Lancet Infectious Diseases [see below and http://www.thelancet.com/journals/laninf/article/PIIS1473-3099(13)70167-1/fulltext], Chinese scientists find many parallels between the human outbreak of H7N9 avian influenza in China this year [2013] and H5N1 avian influenza as it emerged in Hong Kong in 1997, but also some major differences.\n\nThe Hong Kong H5N1 outbreak involved 18 cases with 6 deaths. So far this year [2013], there have been 135 H7N9 cases, including 43 deaths. H5N1 reemerged in 2003 and has caused 633 human illnesses with 377 deaths since then, according to the World Health Organization. Both viruses showed a predilection for infecting the lower respiratory tract, caused severe pneumonia with high mortality, and involved primarily poultry-to-human transmission, says the report by researchers from Hong Kong and Hangzhou. Also, both pathogens cropped up in growing megacities (Shanghai and Hong Kong) that lie on migratory bird flyways with major river deltas and many poultry farms in the vicinity.\n\nGenetically, both viruses are reassortants that have internal genes from H9N2 viruses found in Asian poultry, and both have genetic markers of mammalian adaptation in their hemagglutinin and polymerase PB2 segments, the report says. Among the differences, the researchers note that the H7N9 cases were not preceded by poultry outbreaks, unlike the H5N1 emergence. Also, H7N9 patients on average were much older and were more likely to be male than those in the 1997 event.\n\nNoting that the rapid increase in human H7N9 infections from March to May of this year [2013] is unprecedented for avian flu viruses, the authors comment, 'Why H7N9 seems to be more readily transmitted from poultry to people than H5N1 is still unclear.' In other observations, they predict that stringent measures to control H7N9 in poultry will stop the human epidemic, but caution that increasing problems with avian flu are expected as poultry consumption rises in China and demand increases. Also, they write that further research is needed on whether the widespread use of H5N1 poultry vaccines in East Asia, along with lax biosecurity measures in the poultry industry, contributed to the emergence of H7N9.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The publication summarised above is entitled: 'The emergence of influenza A H7N9 in human beings 16 years after influenza A H5N1: a tale of two cities', authored by Kelvin KW To and 4 others, in The Lancet Infectious Diseases, September 2013;13(9):809-21; http://www.thelancet.com/journals/laninf/article/PIIS1473-3099(13)70167-1/fulltext.\n\nAbstract\n--------\n'Infection with either influenza A H5N1 virus in 1997 or avian influenza A H7N9 virus in 2013 caused severe pneumonia that did not respond to typical or atypical antimicrobial treatment, and resulted in high mortality. Both viruses are reassortants with internal genes derived from avian influenza A H9N2 viruses that circulate in Asian poultry. Both viruses have genetic markers of mammalian adaptation in their haemagglutinin and polymerase PB2 subunits, which enhanced binding to human-type receptors and improved replication in mammals, respectively. Hong Kong (affected by H5N1 in 1997) and Shanghai (affected by H7N9 in 2013) are 2 rapidly flourishing cosmopolitan megacities that were increasing in human population and poultry consumption before the outbreaks. Both cities are located along the avian migratory route at the Pearl River delta and Yangtze River delta. Whether the widespread use of the H5N1 vaccine in east Asia -- with suboptimal biosecurity measures in live poultry markets and farms -- predisposed to the emergence of H7N9 or other virus subtypes needs further investigation. Why H7N9 seems to be more readily transmitted from poultry to people than H5N1 is still unclear.'\n\nIt seems likely that reliance on poultry production as a source of food to sustain developing populations has been a contributory factor in the emergence of avian influenza as a human disease. The authors of 'Tale of Two Cities' develop the idea that both pathogens cropped up in growing megacities (Shanghai and Hong Kong) that lie on migratory bird flyways with major river deltas and many poultry farms in the vicinity. - Mod.CP]\n\n[From a veterinary perspective, the striking difference between A/H7N9 and the HPAI H5N1 is in their respective pathogenicity to animals (birds, particularly poultry). According to accumulated information, contrary to HPAI H5N1 which may cause severe disease in birds with high mortality rates, the A/H7N9 virus srain which has caused morbidity and deaths in humans in China, is of very low if any pathogenicity in birds. For additional information, subscribers may refer to OIE's 'Questions and Answers on influenza A(H7N9)' at http://tinyurl.com/kcf6nq2. - Mod.AS]", "summary": "--------\n'Infection with either influenza A H5N1 virus in 1997 or avian influenza A H7N9 virus in 2013 caused severe pneumonia that did not respond to typical or atypical antimicrobial treatment, and resulted in high mortality. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nNoting that the rapid increase in human H7N9 infections from March to May of this year [2013] is unprecedented for avian flu viruses, the authors comment, 'Why H7N9 seems to be more readily transmitted from poultry to people than H5N1 is still unclear.' In a lengthy perspective article in Lancet Infectious Diseases [see below and http://www.thelancet.com/journals/laninf/article/PIIS1473-3099(13)70167-1/fulltext], Chinese scientists find many parallels between the human outbreak of H7N9 avian influenza in China this year [2013] and H5N1 avian influenza as it emerged in Hong Kong in 1997, but also some major differences. In other observations, they predict that stringent measures to control H7N9 in poultry will stop the human epidemic, but caution that increasing problems with avian flu are expected as poultry consumption rises in China and demand increases. \n\nIt seems likely that reliance on poultry production as a source of food to sustain developing populations has been a contributory factor in the emergence of avian influenza as a human disease. AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (109) CHINA: H5N1 AND H7N9 EMERGENCE\n***********************************************************\n Both viruses showed a predilection for infecting the lower respiratory tract, caused severe pneumonia with high mortality, and involved primarily poultry-to-human transmission, says the report by researchers from Hong Kong and Hangzhou. Also, they write that further research is needed on whether the widespread use of H5N1 poultry vaccines in East Asia, along with lax biosecurity measures in the poultry industry, contributed to the emergence of H7N9. Genetically, both viruses are reassortants that have internal genes from H9N2 viruses found in Asian poultry, and both have genetic markers of mammalian adaptation in their hemagglutinin and polymerase PB2 segments, the report says. Hong Kong (affected by H5N1 in 1997) and Shanghai (affected by H7N9 in 2013) are 2 rapidly flourishing cosmopolitan megacities that were increasing in human population and poultry consumption before the outbreaks. The authors of 'Tale of Two Cities' develop the idea that both pathogens cropped up in growing megacities (Shanghai and Hong Kong) that lie on migratory bird flyways with major river deltas and many poultry farms in the vicinity.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2003-03-25 00:00:00", "1997-03-25 00:00:00", "2013-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Hangzhou", "country": "China"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Shanghai", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "Hong Kong"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1990523", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (119): Indonesia (WJ) H5N1, fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1990523", "date": "2013-10-08 14:18:34", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (119): INDONESIA (WEST JAVA) H5N1, FATAL\n***************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 7 Oct 2013\nSource: CIDRAP (Center for Infectious Disease Research & Policy) News [edited]\nhttp://www.cidrap.umn.edu/news-perspective/2013/10/news-scan-oct-07-2013\n\n\nIndonesia confirms H5N1 death\n-----------------------------\nThe Indonesia Ministry of Health has confirmed the country's 2nd H5N1 case this year [2013], in a 28-year-old man from Bekasi [West Java]. The man died from the disease, according to a machine-translated health ministry statement today [7 Oct 2013] on FluTrackers, the web-based infectious disease message board. The health ministry statement is dated 3 Oct 2013.\n\nThe man, a truck driver, developed a fever, aches, and back pain on 16 Sep 2013 and received outpatient treatment on 18 Sep 2013 at a private hospital in Bekasi, which is on the outskirts of Jakarta. He was admitted to the hospital on 20 Sep 2013. He died at a different hospital on 27 Sep 2013 of suspected avian flu.\n\nTests by the Center for Biomedical and Healthcare Technology Association later confirmed H5N1 avian influenza, the statement said. Indonesia has now had 194 H5N1 cases, including 162 deaths, since 2005, the Ministry of Health said.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[The following is the machine translation [edited] of the Ministry of Health statement, dated 3 Oct 2013, reproduced in 'Avian Flu Diary' http://afludiary.blogspot.ca/2013/10/indonesia-reports-194th-h5n1-case.html.\n\n'The Ministry of Health, Directorate General of Disease Control and Environmental Health announced a new case of H5N1 has been confirmed by the Center for Biomedical and Healthcare Technology Association, Balitbangkes. The case on behalf of the US (male, 28 years) from Cibitung, Bekasi, West Java Province, was a driver for a bottled water company.\n\nChronology of the case: on 16 Sep 2013 the man presented fever, aches, and back pain. Then, on 18 Sep 2013, he was referred for outpatient treatment to one of the private hospitals in Bekasi. But because there was no improvement, the case went back for treatment and was admitted to the hospital on 20 Sep 2013. While in hospital care, the fever increased and was accompanied by cough and shortness of breath. On 25 Sep 2013 the disease became more severe, with higher fever and increased difficulty breathing, and the patient was placed in intensive care in the ICU. The next day, on 26 Sep 2013, avian influenza was suspected. On 27 Sep 2013, the patient was referred to the Friendship Hospital for treatment. However, the man died at about 20:10 pm on the same day.\n\nEpidemiological investigations have been carried out by the Ministry of Health Integrated Team, the Ministry of Agriculture, Department of Animal Husbandry, the Health Department of West Java Province, the Department of Health, and the Bekasi District Veterinary Office, at the hospital, at the man's home and surrounding environment to determine possible risk factors for contact in the environment, such as ornamental birds and pigeons. Furthermore, approximately 50 m in front of the house there is an area used once a week as an arena for pigeon racing. In addition, in the neighborhood there are many birds, especially pigeons kept by the residents.\n\nWith this new case, the cumulative number of avian influenza cases in Indonesia, since 2005 until this news broadcast, is 194 cases with 162 deaths.\n\nThe Director General of Disease Control and Environmental Health, Prof Dr Tjandra Yoga Aditama, as the focal point for the International Health Regulations (IHR) has reported this case to the WHO.'\n\nHuman cases of avian A/(H5N1) influenza virus infection remain sporadic with no onward transmission of infection. - Mod.CP\n\nMaps of Indonesia can be seen at http://www.nationsonline.org/oneworld/map/indonesia_admin_map.htm and http://healthmap.org/r/7oq_. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n The man, a truck driver, developed a fever, aches, and back pain on 16 Sep 2013 and received outpatient treatment on 18 Sep 2013 at a private hospital in Bekasi, which is on the outskirts of Jakarta. \n\nEpidemiological investigations have been carried out by the Ministry of Health Integrated Team, the Ministry of Agriculture, Department of Animal Husbandry, the Health Department of West Java Province, the Department of Health, and the Bekasi District Veterinary Office, at the hospital, at the man's home and surrounding environment to determine possible risk factors for contact in the environment, such as ornamental birds and pigeons. The man died from the disease, according to a machine-translated health ministry statement today [7 Oct 2013] on FluTrackers, the web-based infectious disease message board. AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (119): INDONESIA (WEST JAVA) H5N1, FATAL\n***************************************************************\n", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2013-09-18 00:00:00", "2005-03-25 00:00:00", "2013-09-20 00:00:00", "2013-03-25 00:00:00", "2013-09-26 00:00:00", "2013-09-27 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "West Java Province", "country": "Iran"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Indonesia", "country": "Indonesia"}, {"location": "WEST JAVA", "country": "Indonesia"}, {"location": "Bekasi", "country": "Indonesia"}, {"location": "Jakarta", "country": "Indonesia"}, {"location": "Cibitung", "country": "Indonesia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1879077", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (107): Cambodia, H5N1, update", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1879077", "date": "2013-08-13 15:56:41", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (107): CAMBODIA, H5N1, UPDATE\n****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 13 Aug 2013\nSource: English News, Xinhua report [edited]\nhttp://news.xinhuanet.com/english/health/2013-08/13/c_132626829.htm\n\n\nTwo more new human cases of avian influenza have been confirmed for the H5N1 virus in Cambodia, bringing the number of cases to 16 so far this year [2013], a joint statement by the World Health Organization and the Cambodian Health Ministry said on Tuesday [13 Aug 2013].\n\nThe statement said that one case is a 9 year old boy from north western Battambang Province, who was admitted to the Jayavarman VII Hospital in Siem Reap with fever, cough, vomiting, abdominal pain, and dyspnea [difficulty breathing] on 4 Aug 2013, and was confirmed positive for human H5N1 avian influenza on Friday last week [9 Aug 2013]. 'The boy is currently in a stable condition,' the statement said.\n\nThe other case is a 5 year old girl from Southern Kandal Province who was admitted to Kantha Bopha Hospital in Phnom Penh on Friday last week [9 Aug 2013] with fever, cough, sore throat, abdominal pain, diarrhea, and dyspnea, and she was confirmed positive for human H5N1 avian influenza a day later. 'The girl was treated with Tamiflu and is currently in a critical condition,' it said.\n\nThe 2 patients touched dead or sick poultry before they became sick, the statement said. Avian influenza H5N1 remains a serious threat to the health of all Cambodians, Health Minister Mam Bunheng said. 'Children also seem to be most vulnerable and are at high risk because they like to play where poultry are found,' he said in the statement. 'I urge parents and guardians to keep children away from sick or dead poultry and make sure children wash their hands with soap and water after any contact with poultry.'\n\nAvian H5N1 influenza is a virus that normally spreads between sick poultry, but it can sometimes spread from poultry to humans, the statement said, adding that it is a very serious disease that requires hospitalisation. Cambodia has seen the worst outbreak of the virus this year [2013] since the disease was 1st identified in 2004. To date, the country has recorded 37 human cases of the virus, killing 28 people. This year, only 5 out of the 16 cases survived.\n\nGlobally since 2003, there have been 636 laboratory confirmed human cases of H5N1 virus with 377 related deaths, the statement said.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The confirmation of these 2 cases represents the 15th and 16th cases of human H5N1 infection in Cambodia during 2013 and increases the total number of cases of human H5N1 in Cambodia to 37 since 2004, including 28 deaths. This is the 1st confirmed case of human infection in Battambang province. There was one prior case of human infection with H5N1 confirmed in Kandal province in 2008.\n\nDuring the period January through March 2013, there have been 4 outbreaks of H5N1 in backyard flocks of poultry reported to OIE in Cambodia involving 3 provinces: Takeo, Kampong Cham (2 outbreaks), and Kampong Speu (see http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public%5C..%5Ctemp%5Creports/en_fup_0000013142_20130315_133056.pdf for more details).\n\nMore information on these newly confirmed cases (such as age, gender, history of contact with avians, history of known avian die-offs geographically close to locations where cases have been, clinical status) would be appreciated.\n\nFor a map of Cambodia showing provinces, see http://ephotopix.com/image/asia/cambodia_province_map.gif. For the HealthMap/ProMED map of Cambodia, see http://healthmap.org/r/1iGB. - Mod.MPP]", "summary": "\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The confirmation of these 2 cases represents the 15th and 16th cases of human H5N1 infection in Cambodia during 2013 and increases the total number of cases of human H5N1 in Cambodia to 37 since 2004, including 28 deaths. \n\n\nTwo more new human cases of avian influenza have been confirmed for the H5N1 virus in Cambodia, bringing the number of cases to 16 so far this year [2013], a joint statement by the World Health Organization and the Cambodian Health Ministry said on Tuesday [13 Aug 2013].
