The District Avian Influenza Technical Coordination Committee of Bhaktapur, chaired by chief district officer (CDO) Himnath Dawadi had then concluded that the district will be kept under 'closer surveillance' for 3 more days before taking further steps.\n\nSpokesperson of the Department of Livestock Services (DoLS) Dr Narayan Ghimire said they will have no option but to declare emergency and go for blanket slaughtering of the fowls if the situation does not change much after the 3-day surveillance.\n\nHowever, CDO Dawadi claimed that Monday's [12 Aug 2013] confirmation was made in samples sent for tests some days ago and that they are not fresh outbreaks. 'There is no need to worry. Rapid tests conducted in 19 poultry farms on Monday confirmed only one case of bird flu,' he said. Government inspection teams have been visiting every farm in Bhaktapur since Thursday [8 Aug 2013] and conducting on-the-spot tests with a special kit they now have.\n\nMeanwhile, in Kavre, over 32 000 chickens have been infected in the 3 poultry farms, according to the district veterinary office there. Dr Ghimire attributed the spread of the flu to the mobility of the owners and workers from one farm to another without adopting bio-safety measures. 'One person owns many farms and labourers are shared. As such, chances of the virus spreading from one farm to another are high,' he said.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Confirmation or otherwise of the apparently new outbreaks described above is anticipated.\n\nThe most recent OIE follow-up report (no. 9) from Nepal on H5N1 was submitted on 30 Jun 2013. The report included the following epidemiological comments: 'Birds showed respiratory distress, nervous signs, and all affected birds died. Cleaning and disinfection activities in the infected premises are completed. Intensive surveillance activities are ongoing throughout the country.' The report, with a map, is available at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=13682.\n\nSince the start of the current H5N1 epizootic in Nepal in August 2012, 61 outbreaks have been reported as of 30 Jun 2013, involving a total of 170 607 susceptible birds (poultry), of which 61 577 cases died; the remaining 108 930 birds were, reportedly, destroyed. An OIE summary report with a map is available at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/temp/reports/en_fup_0000013682_20130701_152420.pdf.\n\nEarlier H5N1 outbreaks affecting domestic poultry in Nepal were recorded between January 2009 and October 2010. No case has been recorded in Nepal in wild birds or in humans. - Mod.AS\n\nMaps of Nepal can be seen at http://ncthakur.itgo.com/map04.htm and http://healthmap.org/r/7_Be. Bhaktapur and Kavrepalanchok districts are located in the Bagmati Zone of the Central Region of Nepal. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]", "summary": "A day after the government failed to declare bird flu emergency in Bhaktapur, the H5N1 strain of [avian influenza] was confirmed in chickens on 5 poultry farms in the district on Monday [12 Aug 2013], the day the flu was also confirmed in 3 farms in adjoining Kavre [Kavrepalanchok] district. Since 2003, there have been 633 laboratory-confirmed human cases of H5N1 virus globally with 376 related deaths, the statement said.", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2003-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 00:00:00", "2004-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-29 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Cambodia", "country": "Cambodia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1866838", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (81): India (CT) H5N1, poultry, OIE", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1866838", "date": "2013-08-06 15:03:26", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (81): INDIA (CHHATTISGARH) H5N1, POULTRY, OIE\n*************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 6 Aug 2013\nSource: The Poultry Site [edited]\nhttp://www.thepoultrysite.com/poultrynews/29696/india-reports-two-outbreaks-of-h5n1-in-poultry\n\n\nThere have been 2 outbreaks of H5N1 highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) on poultry farms in the central state of Chhattisgarh.\n\nThe Indian veterinary authority sent an immediate notification dated 5 Aug 2013 to the World Organisation for Animal Health (OIE).\n\nThe report describes 2 outbreaks of HPAI at farms in the central Indian state of Chhattisgarh, both starting on 30 Jul 2013.\n\nOf the 2149-strong flock at Anjora, the poultry production unit at the College of Veterinary Sciences and Animal Husbandry in Durg, 464 birds died.\n\nAt a government poultry farm in Jagadalpur, there were 3600 affected birds including 2392 deaths in the flock of 6293.\n\nThe presence of the H5N1 subtype of the virus has been confirmed.\n\nThis is the 1st outbreak of HPAI in the country since mid-June 2013.\n\nThe report adds that an epidemiological investigation is ongoing. An intensive surveillance campaign has been launched in a 10 km [6 mi] radius zone. Restocking will be applied in accordance with a specified protocol.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The cited OIE notification, including a map, is available at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=13864.\n\nIndia is one of the countries where H5N1 has been, thus far, reported only in poultry; no human infections have been reported. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/4GFa.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nThe report describes 2 outbreaks of HPAI at farms in the central Indian state of Chhattisgarh, both starting on 30 Jul 2013. AVIAN INFLUENZA (81): INDIA (CHHATTISGARH) H5N1, POULTRY, OIE\n*************************************************************\n \n\nOf the 2149-strong flock at Anjora, the poultry production unit at the College of Veterinary Sciences and Animal Husbandry in Durg, 464 birds died. The girl was taken to a private clinic until, last Friday, she was admitted to the Kantha Bopha Hospital with fever, dyspnea and cough, it said. 'In the Kantha Bopha Hospital, the girl was treated with Tamiflu but died later in the night,' it said. 'There have been recent poultry deaths in the girl's village, and the girl was likely exposed to sick and dead poultry before she became sick.'\n\n'Avian influenza H5N1 remains a serious threat to the health of all Cambodians. This is the 13th case of H5N1 infection in humans this year [2013],' Health Minister Mam Bunheng said in the statement. He said children also seem to be most vulnerable and are at high risk because they like to play where poultry are found. 'I urge parents and guardians to keep children away from sick or dead poultry and prevent them from playing with chickens and ducks,' he said. 'Parents and guardians must also make sure children wash their hands with soap and water after any contact with poultry.'\n\nH5N1 influenza is a flu that normally spreads among sick poultry, but it can sometimes spread from poultry to humans, the statement said, adding that it is a very serious disease that requires hospitalisation. Cambodia has seen the worst outbreak of the virus this year [2013] since the disease was 1st identified in 2004. To date, the country has recorded 34 human cases of the virus, which has killed 28 people. Globally since 2003, there have been 632 laboratory confirmed human cases of H5N1 avian influenza with 376 related deaths, said the statement.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Cambodia now ranks 5th among the 15 countries reporting human cases of avian A/(H5N1) influenza virus infection, after Indonesia, Egypt, Viet Nam and China.\n\nThe coastal province of Kampot can be located in the map of Cambodia at http://phnompenhtour.com/cambodia-provinces/2.html.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1iGB. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/health/2013-07/02/c_132506048.htm\n\n\nA 6-year-old girl from Cambodia's southwestern Kampot province has died of avian influenza H5N1, bringing the death toll to 9 and the number of cases to 13 so far this year [2013], a joint statement by the World Health Organization and the Cambodian Health Ministry said Tuesday [2 Jul 2013]. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\n--\n", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2013-06-30 00:00:00", "1976-03-25 00:00:00", "2010-10-25 00:00:00", "1165-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-29 00:00:00", "2000-03-25 00:00:00", "2012-08-25 00:00:00", "2009-01-25 00:00:00", "1675-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Nepal", "country": "Nepal"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1790894", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (75): Egypt, H5N1, poultry, update", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1790894", "date": "2013-06-25 11:43:13", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (75): EGYPT, H5N1, POULTRY, UPDATE\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 24 Jun 2013\nSource: CIDRAP (Center for Infectious Disease Research & Policy) News [edited]\nhttp://www.cidrap.umn.edu/cidrap/content/influenza/avianflu/news/jun2413scan.html\n\n\nH5N1 prevalence may surpass 10 percent in Egyptian backyard, market poultry\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nAn Egyptian surveillance study found that while H5N1 avian flu viruses were uncommon on commercial poultry farms, more than 10 percent of backyard and live-market birds harbored the virus, according to a report in the Journal of Virology [see comment]. Throughout 2009 Egyptian and German scientists took tracheal and cloacal swabs from 22 024 farm poultry, of which 23 birds (0.1 percent) were positive by polymerase chain reaction for the H5N1 virus. In comparison, 151 (10.5 percent) of 1435 birds in backyard flocks and 108 (11.4 percent) of 944 birds in live-bird markets were infected. Incidence was highest in spring and summer, particularly in backyard birds. The team also sampled 1297 wild birds of 28 different species in 2009 and 2010 and detected no H5N1. They conclude that backyard flocks may play a key role in maintaining H5N1 in Egyptian poultry, especially in live-bird markets.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The report above was derived from the abstract of the following paper:\nElham F El-Zoghby, Mona M Aly, Soad A Nasef , Mohamed K Hassan et al: Surveillance on A/H5N1 virus in domestic poultry and wild birds in Egypt. Virology Journal 2013; 10: 203 doi:10.1186/1743-422X-10-203 (http://www.virologyj.com/content/pdf/1743-422X-10-203.pdf).\n\nThe following 2 chapters are copied from the paper's original abstract:\n\n'Results\n--------\nIn this surveillance, A/H5N1 was detected from 0.1 percent (n=23) of examined commercial poultry farms, 10.5 percent (n=151) of backyard birds and 11.4 percent (n=108) of LBMs [live bird markets] but no wild bird tested positive for A/H5N1. The virus was detected from domestic poultry year-round with higher incidence in the warmer months of summer and spring particularly in backyard birds. Outbreaks were recorded mostly in Lower Egypt where 95.7 percent (n=22), 68.9 percent (n=104) and 52.8 percent (n=57) of positive commercial farms, backyards and LBMs were detected, respectively. Higher prevalence (56 percent, n=85) was reported in backyards that had mixed chickens and waterfowl together in the same vicinity and LBMs that had waterfowl (76 percent, n=82).\n\nConclusion\n----------\nOur findings indicated broad circulation of the endemic A/H5N1 among poultry in 2009 in Egypt. In addition, the epidemiology of A/H5N1 has changed over time with outbreaks occurring in the warmer months of the year. Backyard waterfowl may play a role as a reservoir and/or source of A/H5N1 particularly in LBMs. The virus has been established in poultry in the Nile Delta where major metropolitan areas, dense human population and poultry stocks are concentrated. Continuous surveillance, tracing the source of live birds in the markets and integration of multifaceted strategies and global collaboration are needed to control the spread of the virus in Egypt.'\n\nSince 2006 and as of June 2013, Egypt has reported 173 human cases of HPAI H5N1, of which 63 died.\n\nIn its annual OIE report for 2012, Egypt reported 12 HPAI H5N1 outbreaks in domestic poultry. Mass routine vaccination of poultry was, reportedly, applied. For further statistical data, please refer to the full report at http://tinyurl.com/nsjfxsf.\n\nConfirmed human cases/deaths have, so far, been reported during 2013 from the following 5 countries:\nBangladesh (1/1); Cambodia (11/8); China (2/2); Egypt (4/3); Vietnam (2/1). Though the disease is also considered to be endemic in Indonesia (since 2005 there have been 192 confirmed human cases, of which 160 died), no human cases have been reported there yet during 2013; in 2012, Indonesia reported 9 cases (all died). - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1zkM.]", "summary": "In this surveillance, A/H5N1 was detected from 0.1 percent (n=23) of examined commercial poultry farms, 10.5 percent (n=151) of backyard birds and 11.4 percent (n=108) of LBMs [live bird markets] but no wild bird tested positive for A/H5N1. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The report above was derived from the abstract of the following paper:\nElham F El-Zoghby, Mona M Aly, Soad A Nasef , Mohamed K Hassan et al: Surveillance on A/H5N1 virus in domestic poultry and wild birds in Egypt. An Egyptian surveillance study found that while H5N1 avian flu viruses were uncommon on commercial poultry farms, more than 10 percent of backyard and live-market birds harbored the virus, according to a report in the Journal of Virology [see comment]. In comparison, 151 (10.5 percent) of 1435 birds in backyard flocks and 108 (11.4 percent) of 944 birds in live-bird markets were infected. Outbreaks were recorded mostly in Lower Egypt where 95.7 percent (n=22), 68.9 percent (n=104) and 52.8 percent (n=57) of positive commercial farms, backyards and LBMs were detected, respectively. \n\nConfirmed human cases/deaths have, so far, been reported during 2013 from the following 5 countries:\nBangladesh (1/1); Cambodia (11/8); China (2/2); Egypt (4/3); Vietnam (2/1). Throughout 2009 Egyptian and German scientists took tracheal and cloacal swabs from 22 024 farm poultry, of which 23 birds (0.1 percent) were positive by polymerase chain reaction for the H5N1 virus. http://www.cidrap.umn.edu/cidrap/content/influenza/avianflu/news/jun2413scan.html\n\n\nH5N1 prevalence may surpass 10 percent in Egyptian backyard, market poultry\n Though the disease is also considered to be endemic in Indonesia (since 2005 there have been 192 confirmed human cases, of which 160 died), no human cases have been reported there yet during 2013; in 2012, Indonesia reported 9 cases (all died). The report, including an interactive map, is available at http://tinyurl.com/blf7xx9.\n\nThis is the 1st HPAI H5N1 outbreak in poultry reported from China since Sep 2012. - Mod.AS\n\nA "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2012-09-25 00:00:00", "2013-05-07 00:00:00", "2013-05-13 00:00:00", "2057-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Mainling County", "country": "unknown"}, "2013-05-13 15:41:25", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (56): NORTH KOREA (PYONGYANG) HPAI H5N1, DUCK, OIE\n********************************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 13 May 2013\nSource: OIE, WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database), weekly disease information 2013; 26(20) [summ., edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=13447\n\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza, Korea (Dem. People's Rep.)\n-------------------------------------------------------------\nInformation received on (and dated) 13 May 2013 from Mr Ri Kyong Gun, Director of the Veterinary and Anti-Epizootic Department, Ministry of Agriculture, Pyongyang, Korea (Dem. People's Rep.)\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 19 Apr 2013\nDate of pre-confirmation of the event: 2 May 2013\nReport date: 13 May 2013\nDate submitted to OIE: 13 May 2013\nReason for notification: new strain of a listed disease\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory (advanced)\nThis event pertains to the whole country\n\nNew outbreaks\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak location: (Tudan Duck Factory) [Pyongyang]\nTotal animals affected\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nBirds / 164 000 / ** / - / - / -\nAffected population: ducks in one of the 20 cages showed clinical signs on 19 Apr 2013 but recovered 3-4 days later. As mortality increased, samples were sent to the Central Veterinary Station on 2 May 2013. In total, one adult cage, 12 fattening cages, and 7 duckling cages were infected. More than 2000 adult ducks, 42 000 fattening ducks and 120 000 ducklings younger than 20 days were dead or killed.\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive; contact with wild species\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: stamping out; quarantine; movement control inside the country; screening; disinfection of infected premises/establishment(s); no vaccination; no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type: Central Veterinary Station (national laboratory)\nTests and results\nSpecies / Test / Test date / Result\nBirds / pathogen isolation by egg inoculation / 2 May 2013 / Positive\n\nLaboratory name and type: Veterinary Institute of the Academy of Agricultural Sciences (national laboratory)\nTests and results\nSpecies / Test / Test date / Result\nBirds / reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) / 7 May 2013 / Positive\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The following, gratefully acknowledged, additional information has been kindly provided by 'FAO EMPRES - AH' [Emergency Prevention System for Animal Health]:\n\n'Democratic People's Republic of Korea, confirmed H5N1 highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) outbreak in poultry:\n\n'On 19 Apr 2013, a decrease in appetite and egg production was noticed in ducks in one of 20 cages of a duck factory in Pyongyang. Soon after, other ducks in fattening cages also showed the same signs with some mortalities. Initially, these signs were thought to be due to a problem in the feed. On 2 May 2013, with increasing mortality noticed in the ducks, the Central Veterinary Station (CVS) was informed and some samples were sent for testing. Testing confirmed the samples to be positive for H5 HPAI. Follow-up testing with RT-PCR on 7 May 2013, confirmed the samples as positive for H5N1. More than 2000 adult ducks, 42 000 fattening ducks, and 129 000 ducklings (younger than 20 days) died or were culled. It is assumed that some ducks were free-range and might have had the opportunity to contact H5N1 infected wild birds.\n\n'Disease control measures were strictly taken and appropriate biosecurity was strictly enforced. Public awareness activities for the factory workers and residents around, as well as an epidemiological survey, have vigorously been conducted, and to date [9 May 2013], no human illness due to H5N1 has been found. Delay in testing and confirmation was related to the lack of appropriate reagents. A request has been made to FAO and OIE to provide needed laboratory, field control support, and technical training support, so the country may be appropriately prepared for the next potential incursion of H5N1 HPAI. [9 May 2013, National authority].\nNote: This is the 1st outbreak of HPAI since the H7N7 outbreak in February 2007 in the DPR Korea. In 2011, a number of H5N1 HPAI outbreaks were reported in the Republic of Korea'.\n\nThe current OIE notification includes an interactive map (available at the source URL above) showing the location of the new outbreak. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/6Vb5.]", "summary": "Result\nBirds / reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) / 7 May 2013 / Positive\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The following, gratefully acknowledged, additional information has been kindly provided by 'FAO EMPRES - AH' [Emergency Prevention System for Animal Health]:\n\n'Democratic People's Republic of Korea, confirmed H5N1 highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) outbreak in poultry:\n\n'On 19 Apr 2013, a decrease in appetite and egg production was noticed in ducks in one of 20 cages of a duck factory in Pyongyang. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Measures applied: stamping out; quarantine; movement control inside the country; screening; disinfection of infected premises/establishment(s); no vaccination; no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type: Central Veterinary Station (national laboratory)\n Reason for notification: new strain of a listed disease\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\n Result\nBirds / pathogen isolation by egg inoculation / 2 May 2013 / Positive\n\nLaboratory name and type: Veterinary Institute of the Academy of Agricultural Sciences (national laboratory)\n People's Rep.)\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\n Birds / 164 000 / ** / - / - / -\nAffected population: ducks in one of the 20 cages showed clinical signs on 19 Apr 2013 but recovered 3-4 days later. AVIAN INFLUENZA (56): NORTH KOREA (PYONGYANG) HPAI H5N1, DUCK, OIE\n********************************************************************************************************\n Serotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory (advanced)\n Total animals affected\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\n Source of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive; contact with wild species\n\nControl measures\n Source: OIE, WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database), weekly disease information 2013; 26(20) [summ., edited]\n This event pertains to the whole country\n\nNew outbreaks\n Date submitted to OIE: 13 May 2013\n Date: Mon 13 May 2013\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2013-05-09 00:00:00", "2007-02-25 00:00:00", "2013-03-25 00:00:00", "2013-05-02 00:00:00", "2013-05-07 00:00:00", "2011-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "People 's Republic of Korea", "country": "North Korea"}, {"location": "the DPR Korea", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "WAHID", "country": "Oman"}, {"location": "Korea", "country": "South Korea"}, {"location": "Pyongyang", "country": "North Korea"}, {"location": "the Republic of Korea '", "country": "South Korea"}, {"location": "NORTH KOREA", "country": "North Korea"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1680779", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (65): H5N1", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1680779", "date": "2013-04-30 04:06:52", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (65): H5N1\n*********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 28 Apr 2013\nSource: The Global Dispatch, Outbreak News [edited]\nhttp://www.theglobaldispatch.com/who-reports-six-human-h5n1-avian-influenza-cases-during-past-six-weeks-60184/\n\n\nWHO reports 6 human H5N1 avian influenza cases during past 6 weeks\n------------------------------------------------------------------\nAccording to a World Health Organization (WHO) summary and assessment on Friday [26 Apr 2013], from 12 Mar to 26 Apr 2013, there were a total of 6 new laboratory confirmed human cases with avian influenza A(H5N1) virus infection. The cases were from the following countries: Bangladesh (1), Cambodia (1), Egypt (2), and Viet Nam (2). The UN agency says that after investigation, the 6 cases are considered sporadic.\n\nSo far this year [2013], Cambodia has reported 10 cases of the lethal virus in humans, resulting in 8 fatalities. Health authorities say cases do not seem to be linked directly, and most had contact with sick poultry in their villages. Since 2003, there have been 628 laboratory confirmed human cases of avian influenza A(H5N1) virus infection officially reported to WHO from 15 countries, of which 374 died (about 60 per cent).\n\nAccording to WHO, the H5N1 virus subtype (different from the H7N9 strain circulating in the current China outbreak) is a highly pathogenic AI virus, which first infected humans in 1997 during a poultry outbreak in Hong Kong SAR, China. Since its widespread re-emergence in 2003 and 2004, this avian virus has spread from Asia to Europe and Africa and has become entrenched in poultry in some countries, resulting in millions of poultry infections, several hundred human cases, and many human deaths.\n\nThe case fatality rate for H5N1 virus infections in people is much higher than that of seasonal influenza infections. Clinically, in many patients, the disease caused by the H5N1 virus follows an unusually aggressive clinical course, with rapid deterioration and high fatality. Like most emerging disease, H5N1 influenza in humans is poorly understood.\n\nThe incubation period for H5N1 avian influenza may be longer than that for normal seasonal influenza, which is around 2 to 3 days. Current data for H5N1 infection indicate an incubation period ranging from 2 to 8 days and possibly as long as 17 days. WHO currently recommends that an incubation period of 7 days be used for field investigations and the monitoring of patient contacts. Initial symptoms include a high fever, usually with a temperature higher than 38 deg C [100.4 deg F], and other influenza-like symptoms. Diarrhoea, vomiting, abdominal pain, chest pain, and bleeding from the nose and gums have also been reported as early symptoms in some patients.\n\nOne feature seen in many patients is the development of lower respiratory tract early in the illness. On present evidence, difficulty in breathing develops around 5 days following the 1st symptoms. Respiratory distress, a hoarse voice, and a crackling sound when inhaling are commonly seen. Sputum production is variable and sometimes bloody.\n\n[byline: Robert Herriman]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[All these recent human cases of avian A/(H5N1) influenza virus infection have been recorded in detail in ProMED-mail during the past few weeks. Robert Herriman's review serves to remind us, however, that the H7N9 avian influenza virus is not the only avian influenza virus threatening the human population. These 2 avian viruses interact differently with the human population and their control will necessitate different strategies. - Mod.CP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1yvE, http://healthmap.org/r/1iGB, http://healthmap.org/r/1zkM, http://healthmap.org/r/1jtz.]", "summary": "\n\n[byline: Robert Herriman]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[All these recent human cases of avian A/(H5N1) influenza virus infection have been recorded in detail in ProMED-mail during the past few weeks. According to a World Health Organization (WHO) summary and assessment on Friday [26 Apr 2013], from 12 Mar to 26 Apr 2013, there were a total of 6 new laboratory confirmed human cases with avian influenza A(H5N1) virus infection. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Robert Herriman's review serves to remind us, however, that the H7N9 avian influenza virus is not the only avian influenza virus threatening the human population. Since 2003, there have been 628 laboratory confirmed human cases of avian influenza A(H5N1) virus infection officially reported to WHO from 15 countries, of which 374 died (about 60 per cent). Since its widespread re-emergence in 2003 and 2004, this avian virus has spread from Asia to Europe and Africa and has become entrenched in poultry in some countries, resulting in millions of poultry infections, several hundred human cases, and many human deaths. http://www.theglobaldispatch.com/who-reports-six-human-h5n1-avian-influenza-cases-during-past-six-weeks-60184/\n\n\nWHO reports 6 human H5N1 avian influenza cases during past 6 weeks\n AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (65): H5N1\n*********************************\n The incubation period for H5N1 avian influenza may be longer than that for normal seasonal influenza, which is around 2 to 3 days. According to WHO, the H5N1 virus subtype (different from the H7N9 strain circulating in the current China outbreak) is a highly pathogenic AI virus, which first infected humans in 1997 during a poultry outbreak in Hong Kong SAR, China. So far this year [2013], Cambodia has reported 10 cases of the lethal virus in humans, resulting in 8 fatalities.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2003-03-25 00:00:00", "2065-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 00:00:00", "1997-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Cambodia", "country": "Cambodia"}, {"location": "Bangladesh", "country": "Bangladesh"}, {"location": "Egypt", "country": "Egypt"}, {"location": "http://healthmap.org/r/1yvE", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Viet Nam", "country": "Vietnam"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Hong Kong SAR", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "http://healthmap.org/r/1igb", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1691399", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (51): H5N1/H1N1 hybrids, transmissibility", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1691399", "date": "2013-05-04 15:29:56", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (51): H5N1/H1N1 HYBRIDS, TRANSMISSIBILITY IN GUINEA PIGS\n************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 2 May 2013\nSource: CIDRAP News [abridged and edited]\nhttp://www.cidrap.umn.edu/cidrap/content/influenza/avianflu/news/may0213h5n1.html\n\n\nChinese scientists report that lab-generated hybrid viruses combining genes from avian H5N1 and pandemic 2009 H1N1 (pH1N1) influenza viruses can achieve airborne spread between guinea pigs, a finding that seems likely to renew the debate about the risks of creating novel viruses that might be able to spark a human pandemic. Writing in Science, the researchers say that 5 of 127 hybrids they generated by shuffling genes [that is, genome subunits] from the 2 subtypes showed 'highly efficient' transmission in guinea pigs. None of the guinea pigs died, but some mice that were infected with the reassortant strains did succumb.\n\nGuinea pigs are not regarded as the best experimental model for human flu, a distinction that belongs to ferrets [that is, the most susceptible mammal]. The Chinese team did not test any of the hybrid viruses in ferrets, because a voluntary moratorium on 'gain of function' research on H5N1 virus -- studies involving the creation of potentially dangerous new strains -- intervened in January 2012 and lasted a year. The moratorium was prompted by the controversy that erupted in late 2011 over 2 earlier studies in which researchers generated novel H5N1 strains that spread among ferrets via respiratory droplets. One of the studies involved an H5N1-H1N1 reassortant, while the other involved an H5N1 virus in which specific mutations were induced. The US National Science Advisory Board for Biosecurity (NSABB) sought to prevent publication of full details of the 2 studies but eventually reversed itself, and the studies were published in May and June of 2012. In a statement to reporters, the editors of Science said the new Chinese study 'provides evidence that H5N1 viruses spread by air between mammals can be generated by reassortment. Reassortment, as it occurs in nature, however, is much slower.'\n\nIn another study on H5N1 transmissibility, also published today [2 May 2013] in Science, another team of Chinese researchers examined how hemagglutinin (HA) from H5N1 attaches to human cell receptors. They identified a mutation, Q226L, that enables a mutant form of H5N1 HA to bind to both avian and human receptors.\n\nIn the reassortant study, the team focused on H5N1 and pH1N1 because both viruses can infect pigs, suggesting the possibility that reassortants could arise naturally. The researchers, led by Ying Zhang of the Harbin Veterinary Research Institute, conducted their experiments in enhanced animal biosafety level 3 (ABSL-3) conditions at that institute. They say all the experiments were done before the moratorium began. The scientists used an H5N1 virus isolated from a duck in China in 2001 and the 1st pH1N1 strain that was identified in China during the 2009 pandemic. Using reverse genetics, they generated 127 reassortants that combined the H5N1 virus's HA gene with all possible combinations of the other 7 genes from the pH1N1 isolate. The reassortants were easily generated, and all grew efficiently in chicken eggs, the report says. The authors used genetically modified mice to test the virulence of the hybrid viruses. They found that 54 of the reassortants had about the same virulence as the original H5N1 duck virus, killing some of the mice; 38 viruses were less pathogenic than the H5N1 strain; and 35 viruses were more virulent, killing all the mice.\n\nThe researchers say guinea pigs are comparable with ferrets as models of human flu transmission. Although guinea pigs have both avian and mammalian types of airway receptors, flu viruses that bind only to avian receptors (alpha2,3-linked sialic acids) don't spread by respiratory droplets in the animals, they report. The team used the original H5N1 and pH1N1 viruses and 19 of their reassortants to test for airborne transmission in guinea pigs. For each strain, 3 guinea pigs were dosed with the virus, and 3 other guinea pigs were placed in cages near them but not close enough for direct contact. The scientists found 'highly efficient' airborne transmission of the pH1N1 virus in 5 of the 19 reassortants. The results indicated that the PA (acidic polymerase) and NS (nonstructural protein) genes of the pH1N1 virus can make H5N1 highly transmissible by respiratory droplets in guinea pigs and that the NA (neuraminidase) and M (matrix) genes from the pH1N1 also promote such transmission of H5N1. 'These transmission studies indicate that many of the H5N1 hybrid viruses bearing one or more of the PA, NA, M, or NS genes of 2009/H1N1 were transmissible in guinea pigs,' the report states.\n\nThe scientists say they previously showed that a mutant strain of a duck H5N1 isolate, with changes at HA positions 226 and 228, bound exclusively to human receptors (alpha2,6-linked sialic acids). They found that this mutant, which contains the same combination of mutations as reported in the ferret-transmissible H5N1 virus reported by Ron Fouchier, PhD and colleagues in 2012, did not transmit in guinea pigs. 'Our studies provide evidence that H5N1 viruses that are capable of respiratory droplet transmission between mammals can be generated by reassortment between mammalian 2009/H1N1 and avian H5N1 viruses,' the report concludes. 'Since the internal genes of these reassortants can already replicate efficiently in mammalian hosts, we predict that similar reassortants could infect humans and subsequently acquire mutations that improve binding efficacy for alpha2,6-linked sialic acids,' it states.\n\nThe Science statement says that studies in a more human-like animal model, such as ferrets, were halted by the research moratorium, 'but these are the potential next steps if the influenza research community decides it is important to quantify the degree of threat from avian influenza viruses.'\n\n[These experiments are described in the following publications:\n\nZhang Y, Zhang Q, Kong H, et al. H5N1 hybrid viruses bearing 2009/H1N1 virus genes transmit in guinea pigs by respiratory droplet. Science 2013 May 2 (Early online publication) [abstract http://www.sciencemag.org/content/early/2013/05/01/science.1229455]\n\nZhang W, Shi R, Lu X, et al. An airborne transmissible avian influenza H5 hemagglutinin seen at the atomic level. Science 2013 May 2 (Early online publication) [abstract http://www.sciencemag.org/content/early/2013/05/01/science.1236787]\n\nThe reactions\n-------------\nThe report drew varied reactions from other experts consulted by CIDRAP News, with one hailing it as a useful contribution and others questioning whether the findings were worth the risks involved in the experiments.\n\nAndrew Pekosz, PhD, a virologist at Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health in Baltimore, said the study provides new information about the kinds of genetic combinations that can lead to flu transmission, which is useful for flu surveillance. 'The more we understand how wide-ranging those combinations of genetic changes are that can lead to this kind of transmission, the better off we'll be,' he said. 'That knowledge helps inform us what we should be looking for regarding viruses that are potential human pathogens.' He commented that the study doesn't provide 'any kind of lightning-strike or light-bulb observations, but it helps tell us what to be looking for in terms of viruses acquiring transmissibility.'\n\nPekosz said he thinks the findings justify any risks involved in the experiments: 'As far as I could tell from reading this and being familiar with the group and how they do their research, everything falls under the guidelines that apply to labs in the US regarding biocontainment, respiratory protection, and monitoring. ... I think the safety concerns are well taken care of.' He also commented that it's difficult to make 'direct leaps' from the guinea pig findings to what would happen in the human population, but the results suggest the possibility that the reassortants could spread in humans. He noted that guinea pigs are not as widely used as ferrets in flu transmission experiments because they've only been rediscovered in that regard in the past decade or so. 'I think another important thing about this paper is this is a directed or systematic creation of reassortant viruses, which makes it hard to say if these would occur in natural infection,' Pekosz said. 'You're not allowing for the natural competition that would take place in an infected animal.'\n\nDavid Relman, MD, a microbiologist and infectious disease expert at Stanford University, expressed concern over the biosecurity implications of the study. 'It clearly has biosecurity concerns,' he said in an interview. 'I would have liked to see these experiments discussed by a wider community of scientists and nonscientists before they were undertaken. ... I would have some grave questions about doing these without having a clearer idea of how exactly the results would lead to tangible real-time benefits. Having a BSL-3 lab and not working during the moratorium does not address the issue,' he said.\n\nSimon Wain-Hobson, PhD, a veteran HIV researcher and an opponent of gain-of-function experiments, was more sharply critical of the study. He is a professor at the Pasteur Institute in Paris and chairs the board of the Foundation for Vaccine Research, a privately funded group that recently asked President Obama's Commission for the Study of Bioethical Issues to review the ethics of experiments designed to increase the transmissibility of H5N1 viruses. In a written statement, Wain-Hobson said this study, along with the earlier ones by Fouchier and Yoshihiro Kawaoka, DVM, PhD, show that many different starting points and different experimental protocols can lead to a flu virus capable of airborne transmission. He said it's impossible to predict the pathway that might lead to a pandemic flu virus in nature. 'Which evolutionary trajectory will nature take?' he said. 'We don't know because there are simply too many. So what is the use [of the findings] for surveillance? What we learn [from the H5N1 transmissibility studies in general] is that, qualitatively, flu can exploit a huge fraction of sequence space and can adapt to almost anything given time,' Wain-Hobson said. 'But this we knew, not only from flu work, but also from RNA virology in general. ... The benefits are general knowledge which we basically knew, while the risks are increased by this work.'\n\nWain-Hobson said the authors did 'a super piece of work' from the science standpoint and undoubtedly meant well. But he labeled the study 'very dangerous work disguised as big science. Given this, one wonders why it is published in Science.'\n\n[byline: Robert Roos]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[These experiments provide evidence that H5N1 viruses that are capable of respiratory droplet transmission between mammals can be generated by reassortment between mammalian 2009/H1N1 and avian H5N1 viruses. The authors conclude since the internal genes of these reassortants facilitate efficient replication in mammalian hosts, it is likely that similar reassortants could promote infection of humans and subsequently acquire mutations that improve binding efficacy to the alpha2,6-linked sialic acids receptors.\n\nThese are remarkable experiments in molecular genetics that provide better understanding of the determinants of host range of influenza viruses. Whether such experiments should have been carried out at all, even under BSL-3 conditions, is another matter. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "http://www.cidrap.umn.edu/cidrap/content/influenza/avianflu/news/may0213h5n1.html\n\n\nChinese scientists report that lab-generated hybrid viruses combining genes from avian H5N1 and pandemic 2009 H1N1 (pH1N1) influenza viruses can achieve airborne spread between guinea pigs, a finding that seems likely to renew the debate about the risks of creating novel viruses that might be able to spark a human pandemic. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[These experiments provide evidence that H5N1 viruses that are capable of respiratory droplet transmission between mammals can be generated by reassortment between mammalian 2009/H1N1 and avian H5N1 viruses. Although guinea pigs have both avian and mammalian types of airway receptors, flu viruses that bind only to avian receptors (alpha2,3-linked sialic acids) don't spread by respiratory droplets in the animals, they report. Our studies provide evidence that H5N1 viruses that are capable of respiratory droplet transmission between mammals can be generated by reassortment between mammalian 2009/H1N1 and avian H5N1 viruses,' the report concludes. ' These transmission studies indicate that many of the H5N1 hybrid viruses bearing one or more of the PA, NA, M, or NS genes of 2009/H1N1 were transmissible in guinea pigs,' the report states. The Science statement says that studies in a more human-like animal model, such as ferrets, were halted by the research moratorium, 'but these are the potential next steps if the influenza research community decides it is important to quantify the degree of threat from avian influenza viruses.' The Chinese team did not test any of the hybrid viruses in ferrets, because a voluntary moratorium on 'gain of function' research on H5N1 virus -- studies involving the creation of potentially dangerous new strains -- intervened in January 2012 and lasted a year. They found that 54 of the reassortants had about the same virulence as the original H5N1 duck virus, killing some of the mice; 38 viruses were less pathogenic than the H5N1 strain; and 35 viruses were more virulent, killing all the mice. The results indicated that the PA (acidic polymerase) and NS (nonstructural protein) genes of the pH1N1 virus can make H5N1 highly transmissible by respiratory droplets in guinea pigs and that the NA (neuraminidase) and M (matrix) genes from the pH1N1 also promote such transmission of H5N1. ' H5N1 hybrid viruses bearing 2009/H1N1 virus genes transmit in guinea pigs by respiratory droplet. The authors conclude since the internal genes of these reassortants facilitate efficient replication in mammalian hosts, it is likely that similar reassortants could promote infection of humans and subsequently acquire mutations that improve binding efficacy to the alpha2,6-linked sialic acids receptors. \n\nAndrew Pekosz, PhD, a virologist at Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health in Baltimore, said the study provides new information about the kinds of genetic combinations that can lead to flu transmission, which is useful for flu surveillance. ' The team used the original H5N1 and pH1N1 viruses and 19 of their reassortants to test for airborne transmission in guinea pigs. Writing in Science, the researchers say that 5 of 127 hybrids they generated by shuffling genes [that is, genome subunits] from the 2 subtypes showed 'highly efficient' transmission in guinea pigs. For each strain, 3 guinea pigs were dosed with the virus, and 3 other guinea pigs were placed in cages near them but not close enough for direct contact. \n\n[byline: Robert Roos]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< In a written statement, Wain-Hobson said this study, along with the earlier ones by Fouchier and Yoshihiro Kawaoka, DVM, PhD, show that many different starting points and different experimental protocols can lead to a flu virus capable of airborne transmission. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nIn another study on H5N1 transmissibility, also published today [2 May 2013] in Science, another team of Chinese researchers examined how hemagglutinin (HA) from H5N1 attaches to human cell receptors. ' \n\nThese are remarkable experiments in molecular genetics that provide better understanding of the determinants of host range of influenza viruses.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2001-03-25 00:00:00", "2009-03-25 00:00:00", "2013-03-25 00:00:00", "2012-01-25 00:00:00", "2012-03-25 00:00:00", "2013-05-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Guinea", "country": "Guinea"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Baltimore", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "HYBRIDS", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "alpha2,6", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Zhang Q , Kong H", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Paris", "country": "France"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1643546", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (36): Viet Nam, H5N1, swallow", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1643546", "date": "2013-04-13 18:35:12", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (36): VIET NAM, H5N1, SWALLOW\n*********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 12 Apr 2013\nSource: Xinhua [edited]\nhttp://news.xinhuanet.com/english/health/2013-04/12/c_132304553.htm\n\n\nNearly 5000 salangane birds, which are raised by local people in Viet Nam's central Phan Rang city, were found dead and said to be infected with the avian flu strain H5N1, the local Tuoi Tre newspaper reported on Friday [13 Apr 2013].\n\nAccording to Vice Chairwoman of Phan Rang City People's Committee Nguyen Thi Hue, from 28 Mar 2013 to 11 Apr 2013, about 4900 salangane birds out of the flock's 10 000 head raised by the Yen Viet Company Limited were found dead in Phan Rang City of Ninh Thuan province. Among the dying birds to be tested at the local Veterinary Department No. 6, 8 samples were found positive to the avian flu strain H5N1.\n\nThis is the 1st time human-raised salangane birds were found dead in Viet Nam because of the avian flu strain H5N1, so there are not yet specific measures to control the expansion of the disease, except those applied to the H5N1-infected poultry, said Nguyen Xuan Binh, director of the Veterinary Department 6.\n\nSince the news about the deaths of the H5N1-infected salangane birds was reported, local veterinary agencies have brought samples of the young and grown-up salangane birds and their manure and nests to be tested, results of which will not be announced until 16 Apr 2013.\n\nMeanwhile, strict supervision is being applied to 54 salangane breeding houses in Phan Rang City until final results of the tests are reported.\n\nPreventive measures are also being implemented in other localities where salangane birds are breeding en mass, including central Khanh Hoa province, southern Tien Giang province, and Ho Chi Minh City.\n\nSpecifically, 12 salangane samples from Can Gio district (HCM City) are now being tested at the HCM City Veterinary Department, Phan Xuan Thao, head of the department told a Tuoi Tre reporter, adding that in 2012 and during the 1st quarter of this year [2013], the department had tested 94 samples from salanganes, and all results showed negative to the H5N1 virus.\n\nSalangane birds are raised for the highly nutritious value of their nests. Currently in Viet Nam, one kg of salangane nests is sold for USD 125-158, depending on their quality.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Kunihiko Iizuka\n\n[Bird's nest soup, or swallow's nest, is the name of a traditional delicacy in Viet Nam as well as in other east-Asian countries, e.g. China, and is known as 'Caviar of the East.' An illustrated description of this specialsed industry can be accessed at http://salanganesnest.blogspot.co.il/2012/10/about-bird-nest-salanganes-nestby-bao.html.\n\nHPAI H5N1 has been identified in barn swallows (_Hirundo rustica_) earlier, namely in Hong Kong. The outbreak was officially published by the HK government's Agriculture, Fisheries and Conservation Department on 1 Apr 2010; see http://www.afcd.gov.hk/english/publications/publications_press/pr1580.html. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1jtz.]", "summary": "\n\nSince the news about the deaths of the H5N1-infected salangane birds was reported, local veterinary agencies have brought samples of the young and grown-up salangane birds and their manure and nests to be tested, results of which will not be announced until 16 Apr 2013. \n\nThis is the 1st time human-raised salangane birds were found dead in Viet Nam because of the avian flu strain H5N1, so there are not yet specific measures to control the expansion of the disease, except those applied to the H5N1-infected poultry, said Nguyen Xuan Binh, director of the Veterinary Department 6. http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/health/2013-04/12/c_132304553.htm\n\n\nNearly 5000 salangane birds, which are raised by local people in Viet Nam's central Phan Rang city, were found dead and said to be infected with the avian flu strain H5N1, the local Tuoi Tre newspaper reported on Friday [13 Apr 2013]. Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 9 Apr 2013\nSource Channel NewsAsia, Agence France-Presse (AFP) report [edited]\nhttp://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/asiapacific/vietnam-reports-first-bir/632732.html\n\n\nA 4-year-old child has become Viet Nam's 1st victim of the H5N1 bird flu [avian influenza] virus in more than a year, a health worker said, amid growing regional concerns about the virulent disease.\n\nThe death comes as neighbouring China scrambles to contain a new H7N9 strain that had not previously been transmitted from birds to humans but has now killed 7 [now 9] people since February 2013.\n\n'A test result confirmed the 4-year-old boy was infected with H5N1,' a staff member at the healthcare centre in Viet Nam's southern province of Dong Thap, which handled the case, told AFP.\n\nIt was not immediately clear exactly when the child died and health officials in Hanoi were unavailable for comment.\n\nIt was Viet Nam's 1st fatality from the H5N1 virus since late January 2012.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[ProMED-mail would like to thank rapporteur Kunihiko Iizuka for submitting a similar article. - Mod.MPP]\n\n[Previously there have been 123 confirmed cases of avian influenza A/(H5N1) virus infection in Viet Nam and 61 fatalities. 112 cases and 57 fatalities were recorded in 2003/2004, and very few subsequently. This new case in the first to be recorded in 2013. Mahmudur Rahman, head of the country's Institute of Epidemiology, Disease Control and Research (IEDCR), told Xinhua [News Agency] that 'the 7th case of influenza A (H5N1) has been confirmed from one of our surveillance sites in Comilla.' Comilla is 96 km [60 mi] east of the capital Dhaka. Mahmudur Rahman said the male child was from Chauddogram sub-district of Comilla.\n\nThe child was admitted to Comilla Medical College Hospital, later transferred to Dhaka Shishu Hospital and then to a private clinic, Rahman said. 'The child died 18 Feb 2013,' he said. 'This is the 1st fatal case of H5N1 in Bangladesh. As this child had no typical features of influenza-like illness, his throat and nasal samples were sent for reconfirmation to CDC Atlanta, US and received confirmation Sat 6 Apr 2013,' he added. According to the official, a detailed outbreak investigation was conducted. There was a strong epidemiological link with backyard poultry deaths. No other case was found among contacts during the investigation, he said.\n\nBangladeshi authorities in December last year [2012] destroyed 150 000 birds and 300 000 eggs as the season's major outbreak of bird flu was detected in a poultry farm in Gazipur, on the outskirts of capital Dhaka.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[As of 12 Mar 2013 globally there have been 622 human cases of avian A/(H5N1) influenza virus infection, resulting in 371 deaths in 15 countries. Of these cases 6 occurred in Bangladesh (3 of which occurred in 2012). The case described above is the 1st case in 2013, and the 1st fatality overall in Bangladesh. - Mod.CP]\n\n[Maps of Bangladesh can be seen at http://tinyurl.com/bvosk6v and http://healthmap.org/r/6eBW. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\n\nA 2-year-old baby from eastern Bangladesh has died of H5N1 [avian influenza] virus, the 1st bird flu [avian A/(H5N1) virus] death in this South Asian country, a senior health official said Monday [8 Apr 2013]. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[As of 12 Mar 2013 globally there have been 622 human cases of avian A/(H5N1) influenza virus infection, resulting in 371 deaths in 15 countries. \n\nBangladeshi authorities in December last year [2012] destroyed 150 000 birds and 300 000 eggs as the season's major outbreak of bird flu was detected in a poultry farm in Gazipur, on the outskirts of capital Dhaka. Restocking will be permitted with a specified protocol.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: quarantine; movement control inside the country; screening; vaccination prohibited; no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: stamping out; disinfection of infected premises/establishment(s); dipping/spraying\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type: High Security Animal Disease Laboratory, Bhopal (National laboratory)\nTests and results\nSpecies / Test / Test date / Result\nBirds / real-time reverse transcriptase polymerase chain reaction / 7 Mar 2013 / Positive\nBirds / reverse transcription - polymerase chain reaction / 07 Mar 2013 / Positive\nBirds / virus isolation / 7 Mar 2013 / Positive\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Additional information on the outbreak, including the avian species/husbandry of the affected flock, and the biosafety measures undertaken between the start of the outbreak (reportedly, 23 Feb 2013) and its diagnosis (7 Mar 2013)/stamping-out (announced as planned on 9 Mar 2013) would be helpful. The location of the current outbreak is shown on the map included in the report and available at the source URL above.\n\nIndia's previous H5N1 event in domestic poultry started on 12 Oct 2012, affecting a turkey unit of the Central Poultry Development Organization, Bangalore Urban, Karnataka. It was controlled by stamping out (killing 33 006 birds ) and declared as resolved on 13 Feb 2013. Earlier during 2012, 11 other outbreaks were reported in 2 clusters. the described event upon Reuters' reports. This outbreak of a low-pathogenic H5N1 in the East German state of Brandenburg (see map at the source URL) was thus initially reported as suspected with request for information and later as refuted. The current OIE report provides the official, apparently correct information. Since the species in this and other OIE reports addressing poultry/avians is unspecified (are 'birds' conceived, systematically, as 'species'?!), it will be helpful to obtain from the authorities/OIE information on the affected population (according to the Reuters reports, the outbreak occurred on 'a duck farm, which was carrying out its own tests').\n\nWe are grateful to Sabine Zentis for providing another, earlier source confirming the outbreak's diagnosis http://www.mugv.brandenburg.de/cms/detail.php/bb1.c.322948.de. - Mod.AS.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1zJl.]", "summary": "Species/ Test/ Test date/ Result\nBirds/ real-time PCR/ 15 Feb 2013/ Positive\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In the absence of an immediate official report, ProMED-mail had to base its earlier reports on the described event upon Reuters' reports. 26(05) [edited] http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=12939\n\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza, Hong Kong (SAR - PRC)\n--------------------------------------------------------\nInformation received on (and dated) 29 Jan 2013 from Dr Thomas Sit, chief veterinary officer/assistant director (Inspection & Quarantine), Agriculture, Fisheries and Conservation Department, Hong Kong Special Administrative Region Government, Hong Kong, Hong Kong (SAR - PRC)\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification (final report)\nStart date: 25 Jan 2013\nDate of pre-confirmation of the event: 29 Jan 2013\nReason for notification: reoccurrence of a listed disease\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: laboratory (advanced)\nThis event pertains to the whole country\n\nNew outbreaks\nOutbreak 1: Mouse Island children's playground, Hoi Wing Road, Tuen Mun, Hong Kong\nDate of start of the outbreak: 25 Jan 2013\nOutbreak status: resolved (25 Jan 2013)\nAffected animals\nSpecies: black-headed gull (_Larus ridibundus_)\nCases: 1\nDeaths: 1\nAffected population: a black-headed gull was collected on 25 Jan 2013 at Mouse Island children's playground, Hoi Wing Road, Tuen Mun. The black-headed gull is a common winter visitor in Hong Kong.\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\nEpidemiological comments: an intensive surveillance system is in place for all poultry farms, poultry markets, and pet bird shops in Hong Kong. The H5N1 infected wild bird was detected in our ongoing surveillance program on wild birds. No spread of disease was evident. The date of closure of the event is the date of end of the outbreak, which is the date the bird was found (that is, 25 Jan 2013).\n\nControl measures applied: screening, disinfection of infected premises/establishment(s); no vaccination; no treatment of affected animals\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type: Tai Lung Veterinary Laboratory, Agriculture, Fisheries & Conservation Department (National laboratory)\nSpecies / Test / Test date / Result\nBlack-headed gull / immunohistochemical test / 29 Jan 2013 / Positive\n\nTai Lung Veterinary Laboratory, Agriculture, Fisheries & Conservation Department (National laboratory)\nSpecies / Test / Test date / Result\nBlack-headed gull / polymerase chain reaction (PCR) / 29 Jan 2013 / Positive\n\nTai Lung Veterinary Laboratory, Agriculture, Fisheries & Conservation Department (National laboratory)\nSpecies / Test / Test date / Result\nBlack-headed gull / virus isolation / - / Pending\n\nCentre of Influenza Research, School of Public Health, Li Ka Shing Faculty of Medicine, University of Hong Kong (Regional Reference Laboratory)\nSpecies / Test / Test date / Result\nBlack-headed gull / gene sequencing / - / Pending\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is resolved. No more reports will be submitted.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Several cases of highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) H5N1 infection were confirmed in Hong Kong last year (2012; see previous ProMED-mail postings listed below).\n\nThe black-headed gull (_Chroicocephalus ridibundus_) is a small gull, which breeds in much of Europe and Asia and also in coastal eastern Canada. Most of the population is migratory, wintering further south. Mortal infection by HPAI H5N1 has been reported repeatedly in this species. For a picture of the gull see http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/2/29/Chroicocephalus_ridibundus_%28summer%29.jpg.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the area can be found at http://healthmap.org/r/5d5Y. - Mod.PMB]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Several cases of highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) H5N1 infection were confirmed in Hong Kong last year (2012; see previous ProMED-mail postings listed below). Reason for notification: reoccurrence of a listed disease\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\n \n\nControl measures applied: screening, disinfection of infected premises/establishment(s); no vaccination; no treatment of affected animals\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type: Tai Lung Veterinary Laboratory, Agriculture, Fisheries & Conservation Department (National laboratory)\n Species / Test / Test date / Result\nBlack-headed gull / virus isolation / - / Pending\n\nCentre of Influenza Research, School of Public Health, Li Ka Shing Faculty of Medicine, University of Hong Kong (Regional Reference Laboratory)\n Cases: 1\nDeaths: 1\nAffected population: a black-headed gull was collected on 25 Jan 2013 at Mouse Island children's playground, Hoi Wing Road, Tuen Mun. "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2013-01-25 00:00:00", "2013-03-25 00:00:00", "2013-01-29 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2012-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Hong Kong Special {"location": "HONG KONG", "country": "Hong Kong"}, {"location": "WAHID", "country": "Oman"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1507896", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (05): Indonesia, duck, H5N1 2.3.2 clade", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1507896", "date": "2013-01-21 11:02:57", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (05): INDONESIA, DUCK, H5N1, 2.3.2 CLADE\n********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 17 Jan 2013\nSource: Jakarta Globe, UN Integrated Regional Information Networks (IRIN) News report [summ., edited]\nhttp://www.thejakartaglobe.com/home/indonesian-bird-flu-outbreak-has-only-infected-ducks-health-official/566198#Scene_1\n\n\nIndonesian health officials have downplayed concerns over a fresh outbreak of avian influenza which has killed some 160 000 reared ducks since September 2012.\n\n'So far no Indonesians have been infected by the new clade (virus group) of the H5N1 virus,' Tjandra Yoga Aditama, the director of disease control and public health at the Health Ministry, told IRIN.\n\n'The outbreak has only affected ducks. There have been no known cases in humans,' said Muhammad Azhar, coordinator of the Avian Influenza Disease Control Unit. 'We have taken necessary measures to control the outbreak.'\n\nMore than a dozen subsets of the H5N1 virus have been identified -- with numerous variants within each clade. Although new to Indonesia, clade 2.3.2 H5N1 has been circulating across Asia for several years, say experts.\n\nReared ducks began dying on Indonesia's populous Java Island in September [2012], with the disease spreading to 80 villages in 12 of Indonesia's 34 provinces. Affected ducks show clinical symptoms such as torticollis, paralysis, seizures, incoordination, and sudden death.\n\nMost poultry kept by Indonesians are chickens; only a small minority keep ducks.\n\n'The origin of the infection was apparently uncertified imported ducks,' said Emil Agustiono, head of the National Commission on Zoonosis. 'But luckily we have discovered the vaccine [for poultry] and will start production in Feb [2013]. For now we're using the old vaccine and it's still effective.'\n\nThe government needs at least another 25 million doses of the H5N1 clade 2.3.2 vaccine, and will compensate farmers affected by the outbreak, though the amount of compensation has not been decided, he added.\n\nThe Health Ministry's Aditama said many countries had reported the presence of clade 2.3 and there had been 8 known bird flu cases in humans caused by the strain -- 3 in Bangladesh and 5 in China.\n\n'So far Indonesia has not seen infection from ducks to humans or bird flu cases in humans caused by clade 2.3, but I expect that generally the medium of infection is similar to that of clade 2.1,' he said.\n\nHealth officials have advised that control activities in humans had not changed with the new clade, he said. 'Data on antiviral sensitivity is limited from the human cases, but there is no reason to expect a change.'\n\nIn response to the outbreak, Agustiono said the government was strengthening surveillance and tightening the movement of poultry between provinces to stem the outbreak.\n\nMillions of domestic chickens and ducks have been culled worldwide. 'The spread of the virus is epidemiologically controllable and we're doing what we can to stop it,' he said, adding: 'This outbreak has disrupted the animal husbandry sector and more importantly, is a public health issue.'\n\nIndonesia stopped importing poultry from Australia in December [2012] following a bird flu outbreak there, he said. However, there has been no ban on imports of certified ducks from other countries.\n\nAbout 60 million Indonesians keep poultry, including ducks, in their homesteads. Indonesia's animal husbandry sector is worth USD 2 billion, government statistics show.\n\nAgriculture Minister Suswono, who like many Indonesians goes by only one name, said the outbreak was not yet an emergency.\n\n'According to our data, 160 000 ducks have died and compared to the population of 50 million reared ducks that's a small number,' he told reporters.\n\nHumans in Indonesia have been more affected by avian influenza than in any other country: of the 189 confirmed bird flu cases since 2005, 157 were fatal.\n\nOn 20 Dec [2012], the World Health Organization (WHO) said sporadic human cases reported that month in countries with known H5N1 virus activity in poultry were within the expected range. 'No onward sustained human-to-human transmission was reported,' it said.\n\nSince the H5N1 virus first appeared in 2003, there have been 610 laboratory-confirmed human cases globally -- 363 of them fatal -- with Indonesia seeing the largest number of deaths, according to WHO.\n\nGlobally, H5N1 has killed or forced the culling of more than 400 million domestic chickens and ducks, and caused an estimated USD 20 billion of economic damage. It was eliminated from most of the 63 countries infected at its peak in 2006, the UN Food and Agriculture Organization reports.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The following relevant commentary, by Mod.CP, was included in ProMED-mail archive no 20111024.3168:\n\n'The amount of sequence data now available is remarkable and has allowed the definition of some 13 clades, indicative of the rapid and extensive diversification of the H5 avian influenza viruses. This analysis is restricted to the HA-coding genome sub-unit and does not consider the role of variation in the remaining 7 sub-units of the influenza virus genome or the reassortment of these sub-units. Nonetheless, the haemagglutinin gene data are likely to be directly related to the antigenic and virulence properties of the H5 avian influenza viruses, although not necessarily of direct relevance to their transmissibility to humans and/or pathogenicity for mammals'.\n\nFor the evolution of the Asian H5 hemagglutinin, see WHO's conceptual diagram of ongoing H5N1 evolution at http://www.who.int/influenza/gisrs_laboratory/201101_h5n1evoconceptualdiagram.pdf.\n\nAccording to Indonesia's annual report to the OIE, an inactivated HPAI vaccine is locally produced; during 2011, nearly 264 million doses were manufactured.\n\nOIE's press release addressing a vaccine against the novel H5N1 clade 2.3.2.1 virus was addressed in ProMED-mail posting 20110901.2678.\n\nHPAI H5N1 was declared by Indonesia as an endemic animal disease in September 2006. Following a reoccurrence of the disease in Gorontalo province after its absence there since June 2007, a new declaration on endemicity was submitted to the OIE on 21 Sep 2011. No follow-up reports are required in relation to endemic diseases.\n\nThe detection of a new strain of the causative agent or a sudden and unexpected increase in the distribution, incidence, morbidity, or mortality of HPAI prevalent within a country may require notification to the OIE (Article 1.1.3.1, c and d, in OIE's terrestrial code, available at http://www.oie.int/international-standard-setting/terrestrial-code/access-online/). - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1Aiz.]", "summary": "The spread of the virus is epidemiologically controllable and we're doing what we can to stop it,' he said, adding: 'This outbreak has disrupted the animal husbandry sector and more importantly, is a public health issue.'\n\nIndonesia stopped importing poultry from Australia in December [2012] following a bird flu outbreak there, he said. \n\n'So far Indonesia has not seen infection from ducks to humans or bird flu cases in humans caused by clade 2.3, but I expect that generally the medium of infection is similar to that of clade 2.1,' he said. \n\nThe Health Ministry's Aditama said many countries had reported the presence of clade 2.3 and there had been 8 known bird flu cases in humans caused by the strain -- 3 in Bangladesh and 5 in China.
