The report describes one new outbreak of HPAI at a commercial farm with 42-day-old broiler chickens reared in a closed farm premises in the region of Bagmati in central Nepal, starting on 13 Dec 2012. Of the 3000-bird flock, all but 150 broilers died, and those were subsequently destroyed.\n\nAccording to the report, the birds showed swollen heads with respiratory distress and started to die. High morbidity and mortality were recorded in the affected farm. All remaining birds, poultry products, and poultry production materials were destroyed and disposed of as per the standard operating procedure. Cleaning and disinfection activities are being continued. Intensive surveillance activities are ongoing throughout the country. The neuraminidase type is not yet known.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The current outbreak has been preceded by 2 previous H5N1 outbreaks, in the same district, Bagmati (Central Region). Both have been reported to the OIE from Nepal.\n\nNepal's follow-up report No. 2 is available at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?reportid=12793.\nIt includes an interactive map and epidemiological comments identical to the final paragraph in the report above.\n\nRegarding the statement 'The neuraminidase type is not yet known', the report has been titled, similarly to the previous 2 reports, as H5N1. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1COd.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The current outbreak has been preceded by 2 previous H5N1 outbreaks, in the same district, Bagmati (Central Region). The report describes one new outbreak of HPAI at a commercial farm with 42-day-old broiler chickens reared in a closed farm premises in the region of Bagmati in central Nepal, starting on 13 Dec 2012. \n\nNepal's follow-up report No. 2 is available at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?reportid=12793.\n AVIAN INFLUENZA (70): NEPAL (CENTRAL REGION) H5N1, OIE\n******************************************************\n Source: The Poultry Site [edited]\nhttp://www.thepoultrysite.com/poultrynews/27666/new-h5n1-outbreak-reported-in-central-nepal\n\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI), probably of the H5N1 subtype, has broken out in farmed broilers in the region of Bagmati.", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2070-03-25 00:00:00", "2012-12-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Bagmati", "country": "Nepal"}, {"location": "Nepal", "country": "Nepal"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1494731", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (03): USA (NY) H5N1 LPAI, poultry, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1494731", "date": "2013-01-12 20:45:55", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (03): USA (NEW YORK) H5N1 LPAI, POULTRY, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n**********************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 11 Jan 2013\nSource: Washington Report: National Chicken Council [edited]\nhttp://nccwashingtonreport.com/2013/01/11/avian-influenza-found-new-york-live-bird-market-japan-taiwan-halt-poultry-exports-new-york/\n\n\nAvian Influenza Found in New York Live Bird Market; Japan and Taiwan Halt Poultry Exports from New York\n--------------------\nUSDA's National Veterinary Services Laboratories (NVSL) has confirmed H5N1 (presumably low pathogenic) from a live bird market in New York. According to USDA's agreement with Taiwan, FSIS has been notified to amend the FSIS Export Library to state that the export of poultry meat and meat products from the State of New York to Taiwan is prohibited effective immediately.\n\nThis is also the situation for Japan. Japan's avian influenza bans cover product produced from birds from farms in the banned state, as well as from birds slaughtered/eggs laid in the state; product processed in the state; and product that was stored in or transited the state, except after final packaging for FSIS meat products and after official sealing for table shell eggs.\n\nJapan has agreed to exempt product from poultry slaughtered (or eggs laid) and shipped out of (or packaged with final packaging for FSIS meat products or officially sealed for table shell eggs) New York prior to 12 Dec 2012. Combined with previous 'ineligible dates' from other bans, this means that the following dates are now ineligible for Japan (from New York):\n\n- Products produced prior to 22 Feb 2008;\n- Product produced on or after 11 Apr 2008, but before 15 Jan 2009;\n- Product produced on or after 11 Feb 2009 but before 25 Dec 2009;\n- Product produced on or after 20 Dec 2011 but before 31 Aug 2012; and\n- Product produced on or after 12 Dec 2012.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nGert van der Hoek\nSenior Moderator, FluTrackers.com\nhttp://www.flutrackers.com/forum/index.php\n<gertvanderhoek@gmail.com>\n\n[It has become expected that Japan, Taiwan and often times Russian markets will ban poultry/poultry products, including eggs from markets identified as having low pathogenic strains of avian influenza.\n\nAvian influenza (AI), commonly known as 'bird flu,' is caused by a virus that can infect domesticated and wild birds, including chickens, turkeys, pheasants, quail, ducks, geese, and guinea fowl. AI virus strains are classified into 2 groups by pathogenicity, or the ability of the virus to produce disease, in domestic chickens. Highly pathogenic (HPAI) virus strains are extremely infectious, often fatal to domestic poultry, and can spread rapidly from flock-to-flock. Low pathogenic (LPAI) virus strains occur naturally in wild birds without causing illness, but some are capable of mutating into HPAI viruses. It is believed to be this capacity to mutate that causes other countries to ban the poultry products.\n\nPortions of this comment extracted from: http://www.aphis.usda.gov/publications/animal_health/content/printable_version/fs_AI_diagnostics%26testing.pdf\n\nNew York may be found on the interactive Healthmap/ProMED-mail map at: http://healthmap.org/r/35Bp - Mod.TG]", "summary": "Combined with previous 'ineligible dates' from other bans, this means that the following dates are now ineligible for Japan (from New York):\n\n- Products produced prior to 22 Feb 2008;\n- Product produced on or after 11 Apr 2008, but before 15 Jan 2009;\n- Product produced on or after 11 Feb 2009 but before 25 Dec 2009;\n- Product produced on or after 20 Dec 2011 but before 31 Aug 2012; and\n- Product produced on or after 12 Dec 2012. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Japan's avian influenza bans cover product produced from birds from farms in the banned state, as well as from birds slaughtered/eggs laid in the state; product processed in the state; and product that was stored in or transited the state, except after final packaging for FSIS meat products and after official sealing for table shell eggs. http://www.flutrackers.com/forum/index.php\n<gertvanderhoek@gmail.com>\n\n[It has become expected that Japan, Taiwan and often times Russian markets will ban poultry/poultry products, including eggs from markets identified as having low pathogenic strains of avian influenza. \n\nJapan has agreed to exempt product from poultry slaughtered (or eggs laid) and shipped out of (or packaged with final packaging for FSIS meat products or officially sealed for table shell eggs) \n\nAvian influenza (AI), commonly known as 'bird flu,' is caused by a virus that can infect domesticated and wild birds, including chickens, turkeys, pheasants, quail, ducks, geese, and guinea fowl. According to USDA's agreement with Taiwan, FSIS has been notified to amend the FSIS Export Library to state that the export of poultry meat and meat products from the State of New York to Taiwan is prohibited effective immediately. \n\n\nAvian Influenza Found in New York Live Bird Market; Japan and Taiwan Halt Poultry Exports from New York\n Highly pathogenic (HPAI) virus strains are extremely infectious, often fatal to domestic poultry, and can spread rapidly from flock-to-flock.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2009-12-25 00:00:00", "2008-02-22 00:00:00", "2009-01-15 00:00:00", "2009-02-11 00:00:00", "2012-08-31 00:00:00", "2011-12-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Washington", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "Japan"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Taiwan", "country": "Taiwan"}, {"location": "the State of New York", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "New York Live Bird Market", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NEW YORK", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1480226", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (01): Nepal (MM) H5N1", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1480226", "date": "2013-01-03 12:11:48", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (01): NEPAL (CENTRAL REGION), H5N1\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 2 Jan 2013\nSource: MyRepublica.com [edited]\nhttp://www.myrepublica.com/portal/index.php?action=news_details&news_id=47531\n\n\nA case of bird flu was confirmed on Wednesday [2 Jan 2013] morning in a poultry farm in Sitapaila in the 3rd such occurrence in just over a week in the capital.\n\nAccording to Narayan Prasad Ghimire, a senior veterinarian at the Directorate of Animal Health (DoAH), bird flu virus was detected in a poultry farm jointly owned by Prem Manandhar and Rajendra Budhathoki in Sitapaila-1. A DoAH team culled 2640 bird flu-tainted chickens and destroyed 550 eggs at the farm this morning [2 Jan 2013], Ghimire said, adding that another 200 chickens had died Tuesday [1 Jan 2013] night due to avian influenza.\n\nThe poultry farm lies some 500 meters from another farm owned by Surya Mohan Pokharel in Sitapaila-1, where some 2240 chickens were destroyed on 26 Dec 2012 after the virus was detected in the farm. Before that, the disease was confirmed at Subir Singh Basnet's farm at Ramkot-6, where all 2500 chickens died. Veterinary technicians destroyed over 19 000 eggs from the farm.\n\nAll 3 infected poultry farms lie within less than one km distance [from each other].\n\n[Byline: Arjun Poudel]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[From official sources, we are gratefully informed that the number of birds destroyed is not exactly same as published in the above news report, but the information regarding the outbreak is correct. Outbreaks in these 3 farms are epidemiologically linked, so it is regarded as a single event which continued in 3 farms, one after another, reported to the OIE (see 20121229.1474284). Control operations were carried out in all of them.\n\nFor a map of Sitapaila, see http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sitapaila. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1COd.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n A DoAH team culled 2640 bird flu-tainted chickens and destroyed 550 eggs at the farm this morning [2 Jan 2013], Ghimire said, adding that another 200 chickens had died Tuesday [1 Jan 2013] night due to avian influenza. India\n----------------------------------------\nInformation received on 26 Oct 2012 from Mr Gokul Chandra Pati, Secretary, Animal Husbandry, Dairying and Fisheries, Ministry of Agriculture, New Delhi, India\nSummary\nReport type: Immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 12 Oct 2012\nDate of pre-confirmation of the event: 22 Oct 2012\nReport date 26 Oct 2012\nDate submitted to OIE: 26 Oct 2012\nReason for notification: 1st occurrence of a listed disease\nManifestation of disease: Clinical disease\nCausal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: Clinical, Laboratory (basic), Laboratory (advanced)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country\nNew outbreaks\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak Location: 3481/ 3481/ 784/ 0\n\nOutbreak statistics:\nSpecies/ Apparent morbidity rate/ Apparent mortality rate/ Apparent case fatality rate/ Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBirds/ 81.62 percent/ 81.62 percent/ 100.00 percent/ 100.00 percent\n\n* Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction and/or slaughter;\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Unknown or inconclusive\nEpidemiological comments: Epidemiological investigation is ongoing. An intensive surveillance campaign has been launched in 10 km radius zone. Restocking will be applied in accordance with a specified protocol.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: Stamping out; Quarantine; Movement control inside the country; Screening; No vaccination; No treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: Disinfection of infected premises/establishment(s)\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type: High Security Animal Disease Laboratory, Bhopal (National laboratory)\nTests and results\nSpecies/ Test/ Test date/ Result\nBirds/ real-time reverse transcriptase -- polymerase chain reaction (RRT-PCR)/ 22 Oct 2012/ Positive\nBirds/ reverse transcription - polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR)/ 22 Oct 2012/ Positive\nBirds/ virus isolation/ 22 Oct 2012/ Positive\n\nFuture Reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The location of the outbreak, in Karnataka state (southern India), is indicated in the interactive map, available at the source URL. The 11 previous HPAI H5N1 outbreaks in India during 2012 (7 in poultry, 4 in wild birds) were, reportedly, identified in the north-east.\n\nThe species involved in the current outbreak is described in the OIE report as 'birds.' From the data in the location description ('turkey unit'), it may be assumed that the affected birds were turkeys (_Meleagris gallopavo_); confirmation or otherwise will be helpful. - Mod.AS\n\nA "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2012-03-25 00:00:00", "2058-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "INDIA", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Karnataka", "country": "India"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "WAHID", "country": "Oman"}, {"location": "New Delhi", "country": "India"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1448403", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (68): Indonesia (Java) duck, H5N1 2.3.2.1 clade", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1448403", "date": "2012-12-12 15:23:10", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (68): INDONESIA (JAVA) DUCK, H5N1 2.3.2.1 CLADE\n***************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Tue 11 Dec 2012\nSource: ChannelNewsAsia, Agence France-Press (AFP) report [edited]\nhttp://www.channelnewsasia.com/stories/afp_asiapacific/view/1242219/1/.htm\n\n\nIndonesia has identified the bird flu [avian A/(H5N1)] virus that killed hundreds of thousands of ducks in recent weeks as a more virulent type which is new to the country, according to a letter seen Tuesday [11 Dec 2012].\n\n'We found a highly pathogenic avian influenza sub-type H5N1 (virus) with clade 2.3...' the agriculture ministry's veterinary chief Syukur Iwantoro said in the letter obtained by AFP.\n\n'This clade is a new clade found for the 1st time in Indonesia, that is very different to the avian influenza found before, which is clade 2.1.' A clade is a group of organisms, usually species, with a common ancestor.\n\nA poultry breeders' association had reported the death of more than 300 000 ducks in several provinces on Java Island since November [2012] to the ministry.\n\nThe veterinary office found the H5N1 virus involved was a different clade to that usually found in Indonesia, said Iwantoro's letter to local government offices and the World Health Organisation (WHO).\n\nIwantoro called for further research into whether there had been a genetic shift in the virus previously found in the country, or whether the new strain originated overseas.\n\n'There is a suspicion that the virus has spread from other countries, possibly from Viet Nam or Thailand,' Emil Agustiono, secretary of the national commission of zoonosis control that oversees bird flu, told AFP.\n\nHealth officials have told local governments to stop and check motorbikes and pick-up trucks commonly used to transport poultry, to try to reduce the spread of the virus.\n\nThe health ministry has told local offices to be vigilant for more massive poultry deaths, or for deaths of people in the vicinity, its head of communicable disease Tjandra Yoga Aditama told AFP.\n\nBird flu typically spreads from birds to humans through direct contact, but experts fear it could mutate into a form that is easily transmissible between humans.\n\nIndonesia has suffered the world's worst human fatalities from bird flu with 159 deaths since 2003 out of 359 worldwide, according to the WHO.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Mon 10 Dec 2012\nSource: FluTrackers [summ., edited]\nhttp://www.flutrackers.com/forum/showthread.php?t=196156\n\n\nHundreds of thousands of ducks have died in several regions from a bird flu strain recently discovered in Indonesia.\n\nDirector of Animal Health, Ministry of Agriculture, told Radio Australia that the Ministry has detected the presence of a new type derived from bird flu since last September [2012].\n\nThe Ministry of Agriculture said the bird flu virus is a newly discovered variant of the H5N1 strain.\n\nIt was said that the new clade 2.3.2. could have mutated from the previous strains. New types of bird flu in Indonesia are expected because of the bird flu virus mutation; this is under detailed research.\n\nAnother possibility is that the new clade has been introduced from outside by migratory birds such as wild ducks and/or by poultry imports from abroad.\n\nFor the prevention of the spread, the Ministry has instructed destruction of affected birds and advised Local Government to instruct farmers to refrain from keeping ducks with other bird species.\n\n'We will also coordinate with the Ministry of Health about the findings, in relation to the significance of the new type of AI [avian influenza] concerning public health,' said Pujiatmoko.\n\nSo far there have been no reports of a new type strain of bird flu in humans in Indonesia.\n\nThis type of bird flu virus has previously been found in India, Viet Nam and China.\n\nMeanwhile, the Indonesian Entrepreneurs Association of Local Poultry has reported more than 300 thousand ducks died last week [week of 3 Dec 2012].\n\nDeaths of ducks have recently been discovered in 4 provinces of the island of Java, West Java, Central Java, East Java, and Yogyakarta.\n\nResearchers of avian influenza from Airlangga University, Surabaya are engaged in the research related to these new findings, especially the role of ducks as reservoirs.\n\n[Byline: Laban Laisila, Iffah Nur Arifah]\n\n[The original report is from Radio Australia (in Indonesian, machine translated)\nhttp://www.radioaustralia.net.au/indonesian/2012-12-10/jenis-baru-virus-flu-burung-ditemukan-di-indonesia/1058696]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nGert van der Hoek\nSenior Moderator\nFluTrackers\nhttp://flutrackers.com\n\n[As of 9 Dec 2012, a total of 191 human cases of H5N1 have been reported by Indonesia since the start of the local epizootic there in 2005, of which 159 patients have, reportedly, died. During 2012, 8 cases have been reported, all of whom died. Indonesia ranks first globally, followed by Egypt (168 cases including 60 deaths) and Viet Nam (123 cases including 61 deaths).\n\nWorldwide, 608 human cases have been reported since the start of the panzootic (initially, in 2003, in China and Viet Nam), of which 359 have reportedly died.\n\nFor the evolution of the Asian H5 hemagglutinin, see WHO's conceptual diagram of ongoing H5N1 evolution at http://www.who.int/influenza/gisrs_laboratory/201101_h5n1evoconceptualdiagram.pdf. Also, see commentary by Mod.CP in ProMED-mail archive no 20111024.3168.\n\nHPAI H5N1 was declared by Indonesia as an endemic disease on 21 Sep 2011; since then, no follow-up reports were required and have not been submitted. A change in the pathogenicity/epidemiology of the causative agent may require its immediate notification to the OIE. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/21SD.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\n Senior Moderator\nFluTrackers\nhttp://flutrackers.com\n\n[As of 9 Dec 2012, a total of 191 human cases of H5N1 have been reported by Indonesia since the start of the local epizootic there in 2005, of which 159 patients have, reportedly, died. \n\nDirector of Animal Health, Ministry of Agriculture, told Radio Australia that the Ministry has detected the presence of a new type derived from bird flu since last September [2012]. \n\n'This clade is a new clade found for the 1st time in Indonesia, that is very different to the avian influenza found before, which is clade 2.1.' \n\nThe veterinary office found the H5N1 virus involved was a different clade to that usually found in Indonesia, said Iwantoro's letter to local government offices and the World Health Organisation (WHO). \n\n\nIndonesia has identified the bird flu [avian A/(H5N1)] virus that killed hundreds of thousands of ducks in recent weeks as a more virulent type which is new to the country, according to a letter seen Tuesday [11 Dec 2012]. \n\nThe Ministry of Agriculture said the bird flu virus is a newly discovered variant of the H5N1 strain. \n\n'There is a suspicion that the virus has spread from other countries, possibly from Viet Nam or Thailand,' Emil Agustiono, secretary of the national commission of zoonosis control that oversees bird flu, told AFP. \n\nThis type of bird flu virus has previously been found in India, Viet Nam and China. \n\n'We found a highly pathogenic avian influenza sub-type H5N1 (virus) with clade 2.3...' \n\nThe health ministry has told local offices to be vigilant for more massive poultry deaths, or for deaths of people in the vicinity, its head of communicable disease Tjandra Yoga Aditama told AFP. \n\nIndonesia has suffered the world's worst human fatalities from bird flu with 159 deaths since 2003 out of 359 worldwide, according to the WHO. \n\n'We will also coordinate with the Ministry of Health about the findings, in relation to the significance of the new type of AI [avian influenza] concerning public health,' said Pujiatmoko. \n\nIwantoro called for further research into whether there had been a genetic shift in the virus previously found in the country, or whether the new strain originated overseas. \n\nBird flu typically spreads from birds to humans through direct contact, but experts fear it could mutate into a form that is easily transmissible between humans. \n\nAnother possibility is that the new clade has been introduced from outside by migratory birds such as wild ducks and/or by poultry imports from abroad. "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1300398", "date": "2012-09-20 09:13:42", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (56): VIET NAM, H5N1, SPREAD\n********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 19 Sep 2012\nSource: Viet Nam News (VNS) [edited]\nhttp://vietnamnews.vnagency.com.vn/social-issues/230295/virulent-bird-flu-strain-emerges.html\n\n\nA highly-virulent, newly-mutated bird flu H5N1 strain is feared to [be] spreading from north Viet Nam to the south at a menacing pace, warned deputy head of Animal Health Department Pham Van Dong.\n\nSpeaking in Ha Noi yesterday [18 Sep 2012], Dong, whose department comes under the Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development, said the outbreak of this strain started in July [2012] and has so far attacked 7 northern provinces plus the central province of Quang Ngai.\n\nTo prevent further spreading to the south, the ministry has ordered provinces to strengthen inspection and control activities.\n\nIn the meantime, live poultry due to be carried from north to south will not pass through the central provinces of Quang Ngai or Kon Tum until the outbreak is completely under control.\n\nThe ministry also asked local authorities to clamp down on illegal poultry imports and to tighten inspections of trans-border poultry loads destined for Viet Nam.\n\nAt the same time, vaccination and disinfection activities should be strengthened in affected areas.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[According to the report above, the central province of Quang Ngai has now been added to the 7 northern provinces reported to be infected by the mutated H5N1 strain in ProMED-mail posting 20120908.1286497.\n\nThe said strain was suspected to have been introduced from China, mainly by means of culled layers, which come in large numbers across the border from China. These spent hens (also known as 'disqualified chickens') fetch higher prices in Viet Nam than in China. Viet Nam Ministry's intention to 'clamp down on illegal poultry imports and tighten inspections of trans-border poultry loads' will have to overcome the powerful economic interests driven by the tempting price difference.\n\nViet Nam's most recent follow-up report (no 77) was submitted to the OIE on 17 Sep 2012, notifying a single outbreak in the northern Hoa Binh province, where all 400 infected birds (species not given) reportedly died. The report, including an interactive map, is available at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?reportid=12349.\n\nThe epizootic started in December 2006; since then, 359 outbreaks have been reported. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/2bxT.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[According to the report above, the central province of Quang Ngai has now been added to the 7 northern provinces reported to be infected by the mutated H5N1 strain in ProMED-mail posting 20120908.1286497. The virus has infected 14 050 ducks and killed 6300 of them since 11 Sept 2012, when symptoms were 1st reported, a Ministry of Agriculture official said.\n\nAfter the epidemic was confirmed, local authorities cordoned off an infected area in the city and killed all poultry in the area before starting to decontaminate it, the official said.\n\nChina is particularly prone to bird flu epidemics, as it has the world's largest poultry population and many rural farmers live in close proximity to their poultry.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[China submitted on 18 Sep 2012 an official 'immediate notification' to the OIE, reporting the above outbreak; the report includes an interactive map and is available at http://tinyurl.com/97ode5t.\n\nOn 29 Aug 2012, China submitted a final report concerning its previous H5N1 epizootic, which had -- reportedly -- started on 2 Dec 2011 and caused a total of 6 scattered outbreaks. The said epizootic was declared as 'resolved.' A map showing the mentioned 6 outbreaks is available at http://tinyurl.com/98npgrp.\n\nViet Nam recently reported the circulation of a particularly pathogenic new H5N1 virus strain in its poultry; there were some indications of this strain originating in China (see 20120908.1286497, 20120909.1287382, 20120910.1288966). Genotyping of the virus involved in the current outbreak in Guangdong may shed some light on its relationship with the Vietnamese strain. The efficiency of available vaccine strains to provide satisfactory protection against this strain is of particular value. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1zaU.]", "summary": "promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[China submitted on 18 Sep 2012 an official 'immediate notification' to the OIE, reporting the above outbreak; the report includes an interactive map and is available at http://tinyurl.com/97ode5t.\n\nOn 29 Aug 2012, China submitted a final report concerning its previous H5N1 epizootic, which had -- reportedly -- started on 2 Dec 2011 and caused a total of 6 scattered outbreaks. 25(42) [edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=12441\n\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza, Nepal\n-----------------------------------------\nInformation received on (and dated) 14 Oct 2012 from Dr Nar Bahadur Rajwar, Director General, Department of Livestock Services, Department of Livestock Services, Lalitpur, Nepal\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification (final report)\nDate of start of the event: 27 Aug 2012\nDate of pre-confirmation of the event: 3 Sep 2012\nReport date: 14 Oct 2012\nDate submitted to OIE: 14 Oct 2012\nDate event resolved: 4 Oct 2012\nReason for notification: reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 30 Mar 2012\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory (basic), laboratory (advanced), necropsy\nThis event pertains to the whole country\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1 Sanepa-2, Sanchal, Lalitpur, Bagmati\nDate of start of the outbreak: 27 Aug 2012\nOutbreak status: resolved (04 Oct 2012)\nEpidemiological unit: farm\nTotal animals affected\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nBirds [see comment] / 2500 / 2500 / 2500 / 0 / 0\nAffected population: a commercial layer farm rearing dual purpose breed of different age group.\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\nEpidemiological comments: stamping out followed by cleaning, disinfection, disposal, and sealing of the infected premises has been completed. Post-operative surveillance activities are being intensively carried out throughout the country.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: stamping out; quarantine; movement control inside the country; screening; zoning; disinfection of infected premises/establishment(s); dipping-spraying/vaccination prohibited; no treatment of affected animals.\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type: Central Veterinary Laboratory (national laboratory)\nSpecies / Test / Test date / Result\nBirds / polymerase chain reaction (PCR) / 3 Sep 2012 / Positive\n\nLaboratory name and type: Australian Animal Health Laboratory, Geelong, Australia (OIE's reference laboratory)\nSpecies / Test / Test date / Result\nBirds / haemagglutination inhibition test (HIT) / 21 Sep 2012 / Positive\nBirds / polymerase chain reaction (PCR) / 21 Sep 2012 / Positive\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The Nepal Vet Services commendably applied immediate stamping out, the outbreak thus resolved. For its location, please refer to the interactive map at the source URL above.\n\nThe 'birds' species affected is not specified; avian influenza virus has been shown to be able to infect various species of birds. The affected population in the outbreak above is, reportedly, 'a commercial layer farm rearing dual purpose breed of different age group'; most probably, chickens (_Gallus gallus domesticus_). - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/3IfJ.]", "summary": "Birds / haemagglutination inhibition test (HIT) / 21 Sep 2012 / Positive\nBirds / polymerase chain reaction (PCR) / 21 Sep 2012 / Positive\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The Nepal Vet Services commendably applied immediate stamping out, the outbreak thus resolved. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Date of previous occurrence: 30 Mar 2012\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\n 14 Oct 2012 from Dr Nar Bahadur Rajwar, Director General, Department of Livestock Services, Department of Livestock Services, Lalitpur, Nepal\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification (final report)\n Measures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name ["unknown", "other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2057-03-25 00:00:00", "2012-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "WAHID", "country": "Oman"}, {"location": "gallus", "country": "Germany"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1288966", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (53): Viet Nam, H5N1 virus evolution", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1288966", "date": "2012-09-10 22:29:04", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (53): VIET NAM, H5N1 VIRUS EVOLUTION\n****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 10 Sep 2012\nSource: Xinhua via Globaltimes [summarised, edited]\nhttp://www.globaltimes.cn/content/732250.shtml\n\n\nA new bird flu strain is developing unexpectedly in Viet Nam and causing great concern to the government and public.\n\nAccording to the National Animal Health Diagnosis Center, the new strain of bird flu virus, which is suspected to have higher risk of causing human death than previously known ones [see comment], appeared in July 2012 and widely spread in August 2012 in Viet Nam's 7 central and northern provinces.\n\nHoang Van Nam, head of Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development (MARD)'s Animal Health Department, said that this virus, thought to belong to H5N1 Clade 2.3.2.1, is different from the 2 strains of A and B that appeared in Viet Nam in 2011, due to its higher pathogenic risk [pathogenicity].\n\nAccording to the department, as of 6 Sep 2012, the new virus strain has attacked 7 central and northern cities and provinces, including Hai Phong, Thanh Hoa, Ha Tinh, Ninh Binh, Nam Dinh, Bac Can and Quang Ngai, and over 180 000 infected poultry have been culled so far this year [2012].\n\nApart from the newly-found strain of the virus, the bird flu has developed unexpectedly in the country so far this year [2012]. Normally, avian influenza appears shortly before or after the traditional lunar Tet holidays (which often fall in late January and early February). However, it has appeared since July this year [2012] and spread fast without warning. In the Central Highlands' Dak Lak province, about 30 influenza epidemic spots were found in only one day.\n\nAccording to local experts, the epidemic will become more complicated once it reaches its peak in the coming months.\n\nMARD has instructed the department to strictly supervise the import of poultry, especially breeding chicks, which are believed to make the suspected new strain virus spread faster [Are imported breeding chicks (from where?) suspected of introducing infection or of being excessively susceptible to local infection? Clarification will help. - Mod.AS].\n\nMeanwhile, according to the Central Epidemic Prevention Institute, since August last year [2011], the UN Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) has warned of the change of the virus A/H5N1. Clade 2.3.2 is in many Asian countries, including Viet Nam, and that change is usual during the natural evolution of the virus.\n\n'This is a small change of the virus that creates a new strain, not yet a new virus. However, close supervision of the virus which is spreading among poultry should be taken so as to discover its change and set forth an appropriate strategy to fight the epidemic and protect human health,' the Institute Director Nguyen Tran Hien told local media late last week.\n\n'Through strict supervision on human flu infected cases, we found nothing unusual. The most concern is that the virus A/H5N1 is spreading among poultry, and it can continue to have small changes, re-arrange the gene, and reunite with virus circulated among animals and human beings to become a new, highly-toxic strain and transmissible to human beings,' Hien said.\n\nHe also suggested the veterinary sector closely cooperate with the health service to enhance supervision on the avian flu among poultry and human beings as well as apply preventive measures so as to prevent the spreading of the disease among poultry and from poultry to human beings.\n\nAs of 6 Sep 2012 [since the beginning of 2012], 4 [human] cases of A/H5N1 infection have been recorded with 2 deaths in Viet Nam, but the new strain of bird flu virus has not yet been found in humans, reported MARD.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nNati Elkin\n<Nati@poultrymed.com>\n\n[The above report, from Chinese sources, adds complementary information to posting 20120908.1286497.\n\nWe are indebted to Joseph P. Dudley, Ph.D. for the following comment, following the information included in posting 20120909.1287382:\n\n'The cross-border smuggling trade in spent layers [hens] between China and Viet Nam is huge, highly sophisticated, and has been going on for at least a decade and probably longer.\n\nThe spent layer trade may have played a significant role in the H5N1 outbreaks in Turkey during 2006, and may potentially be [or] have been a major enabling factor in the establishment and proliferation of H5N1 in Egypt.'\n\nThe statement included in the above Xinhua report, arguing that the new strain of bird flu virus 'is suspected to have higher risk of causing human death than previously known ones' is not supported by evidence and is in need of substantiation.\n\nAccording to WHO data, since 2003, Viet Nam has suffered 123 human cases of H5N1, of which 61 died. Most of the cases occurred during 2004/5. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1jtz.]", "summary": "According to the National Animal Health Diagnosis Center, the new strain of bird flu virus, which is suspected to have higher risk of causing human death than previously known ones [see comment], appeared in July 2012 and widely spread in August 2012 in Viet Nam's 7 central and northern provinces. \n\nThe statement included in the above Xinhua report, arguing that the new strain of bird flu virus 'is suspected to have higher risk of causing human death than previously known ones' is not supported by evidence and is in need of substantiation. The most concern is that the virus A/H5N1 is spreading among poultry, and it can continue to have small changes, re-arrange the gene, and reunite with virus circulated among animals and human beings to become a new, highly-toxic strain and transmissible to human beings,' Hien said. \n\nMARD has instructed the department to strictly supervise the import of poultry, especially breeding chicks, which are believed to make the suspected new strain virus spread faster [Are imported breeding chicks (from where?) suspected of introducing infection or of being excessively susceptible to local infection? According to the department, as of 6 Sep 2012, the new virus strain has attacked 7 central and northern cities and provinces, including Hai Phong, Thanh Hoa, Ha Tinh, Ninh Binh, Nam Dinh, Bac Can and Quang Ngai, and over 180 000 infected poultry have been culled so far this year [2012]. [since the beginning of 2012], 4 [human] cases of A/H5N1 infection have been recorded with 2 deaths in Viet Nam, but the new strain of bird flu virus has not yet been found in humans, reported MARD. \n\nApart from the newly-found strain of the virus, the bird flu has developed unexpectedly in the country so far this year [2012]. He also suggested the veterinary sector closely cooperate with the health service to enhance supervision on the avian flu among poultry and human beings as well as apply preventive measures so as to prevent the spreading of the disease among poultry and from poultry to human beings. "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1286497", "date": "2012-09-08 19:22:04", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (51): VIET NAM, H5N1 VIRUS EVOLUTION\n*****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: 6 Sep 2012\nSource: VietNamNet Bridge [edited]\nhttp://english.vietnamnet.vn/fms/society/43608/new-fatal-bird-flu-virus-appears-in-vietnam.html\n\n\nNew fatal bird-flu virus appears in Vietnam\n-------------------------------------------\nA new highly-pathogenic avian flu virus is quickly spreading in northern and central Vietnam, reported the National steering board for bird flu and foot-and-mouth disease [FMD] prevention.\n\nThe acting head of the Veterinary Agency, Mr. Hoang Van Nam, said the new virus still belongs to the 2.3.2.1 virus branch but it is different from the 2.3.2.1 virus (both A and B groups,) which caused the avian flu epidemic in Vietnam last year.\n\nNam said that this virus can make the avian flu epidemic to spread widely in Vietnam in the coming time.\n\nSeven provinces in Vietnam currently have bird flu epidemics, with more than 180 000 poultry being culled.\n\nAccording to experts, the new virus type appeared in Vietnam in July [2012] and quickly spread in the country's northern and central regions in August. This type of virus is quite similar to virus of A group but its [pathogenicity] is much higher. The Central Veterinary Diagnosis Center is about to test the protection of current vaccine on the new virus.\n\nVice head of the Animal Husbandry Agency, Mr. Nguyen Thanh Son said that the new virus may come from China's disqualified chickens, which were illegally imported into Vietnam via the border.\n\n'Wherever Chinese disqualified chickens come, the new virus appears. It attacked both chickens and ducks,' Son said.\n\nTwo weeks ago, the National steering board for bird flu and FMD prevention defined that the new virus is similar to the H5N1 virus in China. The board and the Market Control Agency doubted the connection between smuggled chickens and the spread of new virus.\n\nDeputy Minister of Agriculture and Rural Development Diep Kinh Tan asked the Animal Husbandry to strictly control the import of breeding chickens from China, because the new virus can more quickly spread from breeding chickens than from chickens for meat.\n\n'The new fatal bird flu virus is quickly spreading and this is the big concern of the government,' Tan said.\n\nThe Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development's officials asked relevant agencies to give priority to using Vietnam's vaccines to avoid dependence on imported products.\n\n[Byline: Nam Nguyen]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[Since the start of the H5N1 epizootic in Vietnam in 2007, 358 outbreaks have been reported to the OIE. The most recent follow-up report, No 76, submitted on 6 Sep 2012, notifying 3 new outbreaks, is available at http://tinyurl.com/cvd222r.\n\nThe term 'China's disqualified chickens', as well as the claim that a new H5N1 virus strain, apparently of Chinese origin, is circulating, are in need of clarification.\n\nAvian influenza will be one of the main topic on the agenda of next week's 'Influenza2012' conference in Oxford; for the agenda, see http://www.lpmhealthcare.com/Influenza2012/Agenda.htm. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1jtz.]", "summary": "The acting head of the Veterinary Agency, Mr. Hoang Van Nam, said the new virus still belongs to the 2.3.2.1 virus branch but it is different from the 2.3.2.1 virus (both A and B groups,) which caused the avian flu epidemic in Vietnam last year. A new highly-pathogenic avian flu virus is quickly spreading in northern and central Vietnam, reported the National steering board for bird flu and foot-and-mouth disease [FMD] prevention.\n\n \n\nTwo weeks ago, the National steering board for bird flu and FMD prevention defined that the new virus is similar to the H5N1 virus in China. \n\nDeputy Minister of Agriculture and Rural Development Diep Kinh Tan asked the Animal Husbandry to strictly control the import of breeding chickens from China, because the new virus can more quickly spread from breeding chickens than from chickens for meat. "country": "China"}, {"location": "http://tinyurl.com/cvd222r", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1197681", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (43): China (HK) H5N1, pet birds, surveillance", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1197681", "date": "2012-07-11 09:59:06", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (43): CHINA (HONG KONG) H5N1, PET BIRDS, SURVEILLANCE\n*********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 5 Jul 2012\nSource: Hong Kong Special Administrative Region (HKSAR) press release [edited]\nhttp://www.info.gov.hk/gia/general/201207/05/P201207050468.htm\n\n\nH5N1 virus detected from swab sample in Bird Garden\n---------------------------------------------------\nA spokesman for the Agriculture, Fisheries and Conservation Department (AFCD) said today (5 Jul 2012) that the H5N1 virus was detected on a swab sample collected from a bird cage holding an Oriental magpie robin at a pet bird shop in the Yuen Po Street Bird Garden (Bird Garden) in Mong Kok.\n\nThe swab sample was collected on 25 Jun 2012 for laboratory tests with other swab samples under the AFCD's routine avian influenza surveillance programme.\n\nThe Director of Agriculture, Fisheries and Conservation has declared the pet bird shop as an infected place. The AFCD has closed the shop and removed all the birds to the Department's animal management centre in Sheung Shui for disposal.\n\nAs a precautionary measure, the Bird Garden will be closed for 21 days starting today [5 Jul 2012].\n\nThe AFCD has required all pet bird shop operators in the Bird Garden to undertake a thorough cleansing of their stalls. The Leisure and Cultural Services Department will step up cleansing of the Bird Garden. The Food and Environmental Hygiene Department (FEHD) will also enhance street cleansing in the vicinity of the Bird Garden.\n\nPet bird stalls in the Bird Garden are being closely monitored. So far nothing abnormal has been detected. AFCD staff will step up the inspection of all the stalls and collect swab samples for testing.\n\nThe Centre for Health Protection (CHP) of the Department of Health has put all stall operators and workers under medical surveillance.\n\nThe spokesman said that the AFCD collects some 300 swab samples each month from 39 pet bird stalls across the territory, including the 18 stalls at the Bird Garden, to test for avian flu viruses. More than 1700 swab samples have been collected from the stalls so far this year [2012].\n\nOf the 3200 samples that were tested last year [2011], none was positive for avian influenza.\n\nThe CHP has set up a hotline (2125 1122) to provide health advice to the public who might have recently visited pet bird shops located in the Bird Garden and had close contact with birds in the area. They are advised to seek medical advice as soon as possible if they develop respiratory symptoms.\n\nSeparately, avian influenza testing on a dead house crow collected at 10 Osmanthus Road, Yau Yat Chuen, Kowloon Tong on 29 Jun 2012 has returned a positive result for the H5N1 virus today [5 Jul 2012]. Cleansing and disinfection have been stepped up at the venue.\n\nThe AFCD has phoned poultry farmers to remind them to strengthen precautionary and biosecurity measures against avian influenza.\n\nLetters have been issued to farmers, pet bird shop owners, and licence holders of pet poultry and racing pigeons reminding them that proper precautions must be taken.\n\nThe spokesman said the department would conduct frequent inspections of poultry farms and the wholesale market to ensure that proper precautions against avian influenza have been implemented. The department will continue its wild bird monitoring and surveillance.\n\n'People should avoid personal contact with wild birds and live poultry and their droppings. They should clean their hands thoroughly after coming into contact with them. The public can call 1823 for follow-up if they come across suspicious sick or dead birds, including the carcasses of wild birds and poultry,' the spokesman said.\n\nThe FEHD will continue to be vigilant over imported live poultry as well as live poultry stalls. It will also remind stall operators to maintain good hygiene.\n\nThe AFCD, the FEHD, the Customs and Excise Department and the Police will strive to deter the illegal import of poultry and birds into Hong Kong to minimise the risk of avian influenza outbreaks caused by imported poultry and birds that have not gone through inspection and quarantine.\n\nAll relevant government departments will continue to remain highly vigilant and strictly enforce preventive measures against avian influenza.\n\nHealth advice is available from the 'H5N1 Health Advice' on the AFCD website at http://www.afcd.gov.hk/eindex.html.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The communication above is presented as a reminder of the exemplary, official avian influenza control and surveillance programme, which has been operational for several years in HKSAR to protect man and animal. Subscribers are encouraged to visit their website, which also includes continuously updated local and global statistics of avian influenza, at http://www.chp.gov.hk/en/view_content/24244.html. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/2JFG.]", "summary": "\n\nThe spokesman said that the AFCD collects some 300 swab samples each month from 39 pet bird stalls across the territory, including the 18 stalls at the Bird Garden, to test for avian flu viruses. (Taiwan) ex China, H5N1", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1205053", "date": "2012-07-17 18:19:44", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (45): (TAIWAN) ex CHINA, H5N1\n*********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 17 Jul 2012\nSource: ChannelnewsAsia.com [edited]\nhttp://www.channelnewsasia.com/stories/afp_asiapacific/view/1214019/1/.html\n\n\nTaiwan finds H5N1 virus in birds smuggled from China\n----------------------------------------------------\nDozens of pet birds smuggled from southern China into Taiwan tested positive for the deadly H5N1 avian flu virus and were destroyed, Taiwanese authorities said Tuesday [17 Jul 2012].\n\nThe smuggler bought the 38 birds in the Chinese city of Guangzhou and was caught at the Taoyuan international airport in northern Taiwan when he returned via Macau earlier this month, said the Centers for Disease Control.\n\nThe birds later tested positive for the H5N1 virus and were killed, it said, adding that 9 people who had contact with the birds had not shown any flu symptoms during a 10-day screening.\n\nTaiwan has no recorded cases of the deadly H5N1 strain, although in 2005 health authorities said 8 pet birds smuggled from China tested positive for the strain and destroyed.\n\nThe island has reported several outbreaks of the H5N2 bird flu, a less virulent strain of the virus, in recent years.\n\nChina is considered one of the nations most at risk of bird flu epidemics because it has the world's biggest poultry population and many chickens in rural areas are kept close to humans.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[According to China's Taipei (OIE's terminology for Taiwan) annual report to the OIE for 2011, HPAI H5N1 has never been recorded there. Low pathogenic avian influenza had been recorded in the country in domestic poultry several times in the past; during 2011, 5 new outbreaks, caused by serotypes H5N2 and H7N3, were reported.\n\nThe timely detection and culling of smuggled H5N1-infected birds at an international airport may have prevented the 1st H5N1 outbreak in the country. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1zaU.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Tuesday [17 Jul 2012]. \n\nThe birds later tested positive for the H5N1 virus and were killed, it said, adding that 9 people who had contact with the birds had not shown any flu symptoms during a 10-day screening. \n\nTaiwan has no recorded cases of the deadly H5N1 strain, although in 2005 health authorities said 8 pet birds smuggled from China tested positive for the strain and destroyed. \n\nThe smuggler bought the 38 birds in the Chinese city of Guangzhou and was caught at the Taoyuan international airport in northern Taiwan when he returned via Macau earlier this month, said the "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (46): Taiwan ex China, H5N1, OIE", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1207742", "date": "2012-07-19 14:25:53", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (46): TAIWAN ex CHINA, H5N1, OIE\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: 19 Jul 2012\nSource: OIE WAHID Interface [edited]\nhttp://web.oie.int/wahis/public.php?page=weekly_report_index&admin=0\n\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza, Chinese Taipei\n--------------------------------\nInformation received on 17 Jul 2012 from Dr Kwo-Ching Huang, Chief Veterinary Officer and Deputy Director General, Bureau of Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine Council of agriculture, Executive Yuan, Taipei, Chinese Taipei\n\nSummary\nReport type Immediate notification (Final report)\nStart date 7 Jul 2012\nDate of 1st confirmation of the event 16 Jul 2012\nReport date 17 Jul 2012\nDate submitted to OIE 17 Jul 2012\nDate event resolved 7 Jul 2012\nReason for notification 1st occurrence of a listed disease\nManifestation of disease Sub-clinical infection\nCausal agent Highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype H5N1\nNature of diagnosis Laboratory (advanced)\nThis event pertains to the whole country\n\nNew outbreaks\nOutbreak 1 Luchu Township, T'AO-YUAN\nDate of start of the outbreak 7 Jul 2012\nOutbreak status Resolved (7 Jul 2012)\nEpidemiological unit Not applicable\n\nSpecies Birds\nSusceptible 38\nCases 37\nDeaths 0\nDestroyed 38\nSlaughtered 0\n\nAffected Population Illegal movement of pet birds\nSummary of outbreaks Total outbreaks: 1\n\nEpidemiology: Source of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection. Illegal movement of animals\n\nEpidemiological comments 38 birds were intercepted at Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport on 7 Jul 2012. The birds were smuggled by a passenger travelling from Macao to Taiwan and euthanized immediately on the spot and sent to National Laboratory, Animal Health Research Institute, for further investigation. H5N1 HPAI virus has been identified from these birds, and HA0 cleavage sequencing demonstrated its high pathogenicity.\n\nThe cleaning and disinfection of the environment and facilities were completed on 7 Jul 2012. All staff in contact with the birds have been under monitoring of the Health Authority for 10 days and found healthy.\n\nAccording to the OIE Terrestrial Code, this event does not affect the free status of H5N1 HPAI in Chinese Taipei.\n\nControl measures:\nMeasures applied:\n\nStamping out\nQuarantine\nDisinfection of infected premises/establishment(s)\nVaccination prohibited\nNo treatment of affected animals\n\nMeasures to be applied No other measures\n\nLaboratory name and type Animal Health Research Institute (National laboratory)\n\nSpecies Birds\nTest gene sequencing\nTest date 16 Jul 2012\nResult Positive\n\nSpecies Birds\nTest reverse transcription - polymerase chain reaction\nTest date 13 Jul 2012\nResult Positive\n\nSpecies Birds\nTest virus isolation\nTest date 13 Jul 2012\nResult Positive\n\nFuture Reporting\nThe event is resolved. No more reports will be submitted.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This is an extremely good example of the important public health work done by port inspection officials. One can only imagine how these birds were being smuggled into Taiwan and how they were found. Unfortunately, the welfare of these smuggled birds was probably not a high priority for the smugglers, but another, absolutely key question is what kind of potential human contacts ensued because these HPAI H5N1 birds were subjected to smuggling.\n\nAlso, smuggled birds are not the only concern when it comes to protection of human and animal health. Meats and other foods that can cause foot and mouth disease or African swine fever are always a big concern. The movement of smuggled bushmeat has global ecosystem health implications as well as the potential to aid the emergence of a novel virus, as Nathan Wolfe's work has indicated.\n\nSo, when budget cutters around the world want to sharpen their respective axes, they should think carefully of how to preserve a viable, effective system and what it costs to do so.\n\nFor those who have further interest in this vital subject, the Institute of Medicine's (IOM) report from the US National Academies is available. See: 'Quarantine Stations at Ports of Entry: Protecting the Public's Health. By Institute of Medicine (U.S.). http://iom.edu/Reports/2005/Quarantine-Stations-at-Ports-of-Entry-Protecting-the-Publics-Health.aspx. - Mod.PC\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1ob5.]", "summary": "\n\nControl measures:\nMeasures applied:\n\nStamping out\nQuarantine\nDisinfection of infected premises/establishment(s)\n A ProMED-mail INFLUENZA (42): CHINA (XINJIANG) H5N1, POULTRY\n****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 2 Jul 2012\nSource: Xinhua News Agency [edited]\nhttp://english.cri.cn/6909/2012/07/02/3241s709736.htm\n\n\nChina's north western Xinjiang Uygur autonomous region has reported an outbreak of H5N1 in poultry, the Ministry of Agriculture (MOA) announced on Monday [2 Jul 2012]. The disease has killed 1600 chickens raised by the Xinjiang Production and Construction Corps (XPCC), a unique economic and semi-military government organization of about 2.5 million people.\n\nA total of 5500 XPCC-farmed chickens showed symptoms of suspected avian flu on 20 Jun 2012, according to the MOA. The National Avian Influenza Reference Laboratory on Monday [2 Jul 2012] confirmed the epidemic was H5N1 bird flu after testing samples collected at the farm, the MOA said.\n\nLocal authorities have sealed off and sterilized the infected area, where a total of 156 439 chickens have been culled and safely disposed of to prevent the disease from spreading, according to the MOA.\n\nBird flu, or avian influenza, is a contagious disease of animal origin caused by viruses that normally infect only birds and, less commonly, pigs. It can be fatal to humans.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nNati Elkin\n<nati@poultrymed.com>\n\n[The outbreak, diagnosed by the Harbin Veterinary Research Institute, Chinese Academy of Agricultural Sciences (national reference laboratory for avian influenza) (OIE's Reference Laboratory), has been duly reported to the OIE on 2 Jul 2012; see, with an interactive map, at http://web.oie.int/wahis/public.php?page=single_report&pop=1&reportid=12085.\n\nThe report has also been received from ProMED-mail rapporteur Mary Marshall, who is gratefully acknowledged. - More than 6200 chickens at a farm in a village in Luyang, a town in Jingtai county, showed symptoms of suspected avian flu on Friday [1 Jun 2012], and 260 of them have died, according to the MOA.\n\nThe National Avian Influenza Reference Laboratory on Tuesday [5 Jun 2012] confirmed the epidemic was H5N1 bird flu after testing samples collected at the farm, the MOA said.\n\nLocal authorities have sealed off and sterilized the infected area, where a total of 18 460 chickens have been culled and safely disposed of in order to prevent the disease from spreading since the case was confirmed, according to the MOA. A team was dispatched by the ministry to the quarantined area to guide epidemic prevention and monitoring.\n\nBird flu, or avian influenza, is a contagious disease of animal origin caused by viruses that normally infect only birds and, less commonly, pigs. It can be fatal to humans.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[China has already informed the OIE about this HPAI H5N1 outbreak in poultry, which is the 5th in mainland China since the start of the current wave on 2 Dec 2011. Data on all 5 outbreaks and an interactive map are available at http://web.oie.int/wahis/public.php?page=event_summary&reportid=11376.\n\nChina's wet-markets have recently been again shown to be a potential source for human infection; see the postings on the current case in Hong Kong, apparently infected in Guangdong. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/2wKC.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n \n\nLocal authorities have sealed off and sterilized the infected area, where a total of 18 460 chickens have been culled and safely disposed of in order to prevent the disease from spreading since the case was confirmed, according to the MOA. "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1071313", "date": "2012-03-15 14:17:20", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (23): CHINA (HONG KONG) H5N1, GULL, PEREGRINE FALCON, CONFIRMED\n*******************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 12 Mar 2012\nSource: Flu Information Center (FIC) [edited]\nhttp://www.flu.org.cn/en/news_detail?action=ql&uid=&pd=&newsId=16791\n\n\nA black-headed gull and a peregrine falcon [have] tested positive for H5N1 virus in Hong Kong.\n\nA spokesman for the Agriculture, Fisheries and Conservation Department (AFCD) said today [12 Mar 2012] that the carcasses of a black-headed gull and a peregrine falcon found in Tuen Mun and Ma On Shan in early March [2012] were confirmed to be H5N1-positive after a series of laboratory tests.\n\nThe black-headed gull was collected at Castle Peak Power Station Plant B, Tuen Mun, on 2 Mar 2012, while the peregrine falcon was found at Kam Kwai House, Kam Fung Court, Ma On Shan, on 3 Mar 2012.\n\nThe black-headed gull is a common winter visitor to Hong Kong, while the peregrine falcon is a rare winter visitor.\n\nThe AFCD will continue to conduct inspections of poultry farms to ensure that proper precautions against avian influenza have been implemented.\n\nThe spokesman reminded people to observe good personal hygiene. 'They should avoid personal contact with wild birds or live poultry and clean their hands thoroughly after coming into contact with them,' he said.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Although the dates and exact locations of the findings do not match, the 2 species are the same as those found dead in Hong Kong in January 2012, which had tested positive to H5 virus, pending further confirmation [see ProMED-mail 20120202.1029495]. H5N1 outbreaks involving poultry and wild birds in Hong Kong have been occurring since December 2011.\n\nThe peregrine falcon (_Falco peregrinus_) is a widespread bird of prey in the family Falconidae (see photo at http://www.allaboutbirds.org/guide/PHOTO/LARGE/MJH_040302_00123Z_L.jpg).\n\nIn the region, it is usually a breeding resident, but it is not commonly seen in Hong Kong during the winter. Wintering falcons, however, might move over large regions. The black-headed gull (_Chroicocephalus[=Larus] ridibundus_) is a small gull which breeds in much of Europe and Asia, and also in coastal eastern Canada (see photo at http://www.rosscarbery.ie/userfiles/Black%20headed%20gull.jpg). Most of the population is migratory, wintering further south, but some birds in the milder westernmost areas of Europe are resident.\n\nBecause falcons and gulls are very susceptible to H5N1, it is very unlikely that they can carry the virus long distances through migration/movement. Both species reported here were found dead from H5N1 in the past.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the area can be found at http://healthmap.org/r/1s3-. - Mod.PMB]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n A spokesman for the Agriculture, Fisheries and Conservation Department (AFCD) said today [12 Mar 2012] that the carcasses of a black-headed gull and a peregrine falcon found in Tuen Mun and Ma On Shan in early March [2012] were confirmed to be H5N1-positive after a series of laboratory tests. \n\nThe black-headed gull was collected at Castle Peak Power Station Plant B, Tuen Mun, on 2 Mar 2012, while the peregrine falcon was found at Kam Kwai House, Kam Fung Court, promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Although the dates and exact locations of the findings do not match, the 2 species are the same as those found dead in Hong Kong in January 2012, which had tested positive to H5 virus, pending further confirmation [see ProMED-mail 20120202.1029495]. \n\nThe black-headed gull is a common winter visitor to Hong Kong, while the peregrine falcon is a rare winter visitor. "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (27): Israel (HD), turkey, H5N1, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1086593", "date": "2012-03-31 13:09:09", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (27): ISRAEL (HADAROM), TURKEY, H5N1, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n*****************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri, 30 Mar 2012\nSource: The Times of Israel [summarised, edited]\nhttp://www.timesofisrael.com/health-officials-plan-20000-turkey-cull-after-bird-flu-found/\n\nHealth officials plan 20 000-turkey cull after bird flu found\n-------------------------------------------------------------\nDiscovery at Moshav Zavdiel is 3rd case in recent weeks.\nThe Agriculture Ministry plans to slaughter 20 000 turkeys from the same coop after avian flu was discovered there.\n\nThe coop, on Moshav Zavdiel, near Lachish in the lower Judean plain, is the 3rd farming community discovered in Israel in recent weeks with an avian flu outbreak.\n\nOfficials hope they can stem the spread of the disease by killing the birds.\n\nA number of cats were found dead before the last cull, with signs pointing to them having eaten the carcasses of infected turkeys near Shalva, in the south, according to a report by the World Organization for Animal Health.\n\nIn 2006, southern Israel's poultry industry was brought nearly to the brink of collapse, growers said, after a number of culls following the discovery of bird flu.\n\nThe H5N1 virus, as this strain of avian flu is officially known, can be deadly if transferred to humans. It has lead to the deaths of millions of birds in Europe and Asia as health officials attempt to contain the virus.\n\n[Byline: Joshua Davidovich]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[According to reliable sources, the above event is related to the sighting, by a veterinary inspector, of a truck transporting 6-week-old turkeys from location(s) within the HPAI H5N1 protection zone (10 km around the infected village Shalva; see map at 20120312.1068423) to Moshav Zavdiel which is situated 10.5 km to the north of Shalva, just beyond the 10-km boundary. Investigation was undertaken at the destination site; it included sampling of the transported turkey poults. These samples were found in the national laboratory (Kimron Veterinary Institute) positive to H5N1 by the real time PCR test. Remarkably, the positive birds, which were apparently transported to a farm outside the declared zone for further fattening there, did not show clinical signs of disease and would not have been tested if their illegal transportation would not have been detected.\n\nThough, most likely, the virus involved is similar to the causative agent of the earlier HPAI H5N1 outbreak in Shalva, its pathogenicity has yet to be demonstrated. The absence of clinical signs in these PCR-positive birds deserves clarification. In this context, subscribers are referred to a 2009 paper (see ref 1), according to which, chickens inoculated with H9N2 (a virus known to circulate in the Israel/Middle East) showed 90-100 percent survival after inoculation 1 to 35 days later with HPAI H5N1 virus. Chickens that survived did not show signs of disease but did shed lethal H5N1 virus from the cloaca. It would be interesting to note if the turkey poults in the above consignment were have been tested also for H9N2; if affirmative - results, as well as the pathogenicity rate of the relevant H5N1 virus, are requested.\n\nReferences:\n1. A. Khalenkov, S. Perk et al. (2009). Modulation of the severity of highly pathogenic H5N1 influenza in chickens previously inoculated with Israeli H9N2 influenza viruses. Virology 383, 32-38. - Mod.AS]\n\n[For a map of Israel showing the location of Moshav Zavdiel, see http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zavdiel. For the HealthMap/ProMED map of Israel, see http://healthmap.org/r/1z-1. - Mod.MPP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[According to reliable sources, the above event is related to the sighting, by a veterinary inspector, of a truck transporting 6-week-old turkeys from location(s) within the HPAI H5N1 protection zone (10 km around the infected village Shalva; see map at 20120312.1068423) to Moshav Zavdiel which is situated 10.5 km to the north of Shalva, just beyond the 10-km boundary. In this context, subscribers are referred to a 2009 paper (see ref 1), according to which, chickens inoculated with H9N2 (a virus known to circulate in the Israel/Middle East) showed 90-100 percent survival after inoculation 1 to 35 days later with HPAI H5N1 virus. \n\nA number of cats were found dead before the last cull, with signs pointing to them having eaten the carcasses of infected turkeys near Shalva, in the south, according to a report by the World Organization for Animal Health. reported Wed [18 Apr 2012], AFP reports.\n\nThe outbreak in Touying township of the Ningxia region was discovered on Friday last week [13 Apr 2012] after over 23 000 chickens began showing symptoms, Xinhua news agency said, citing the Ministry of Agriculture.\n\nThe ministry said the 'epidemic is now under control,' the report said, while work teams have been sent to the area to step up prevention measures.\n\nChina is considered one of the nations most at risk of bird flu epidemics because it has the world's largest poultry population, and many chickens in rural areas are kept close to humans.\n\nIn January 2012, a man in southwest China's Guizhou province died after contracting the bird flu virus, the 2nd such fatality reported in China this year [2012], health authorities said.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The above outbreak has already been officially reported by China to the OIE on 18 Apr 2012; see follow-up report No. 2, with an district, Guyuan, Ningxia. post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: 9 Mar 2012\nSource: OIE, WAHID, 25(11) [edited]\nhttp://web.oie.int/wahis/public.php?page=single_report&pop=1&reportid=11725\n\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza, Israel\n-----------------------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 9 Mar 2012 from Dr Nadav Galon, director, Veterinary Services and Animal Health, Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development, BET DAGAN, Israel\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nStart date: 7 Mar 2012\nDate of 1st confirmation of the event: 8 Mar 2012\nDate submitted to OIE: 9 Mar 2012\nReason for notification: reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 7 Apr 2011\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: suspicion, clinical, laboratory (advanced), necropsy\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country\n\nNew outbreaks\n-------------\nOutbreak 1: HOLIT, Beer-sheva, HADAROM\nDate of start of the outbreak: 7 Mar 2012\nOutbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: village\nAffected animals\nSpecies: birds\nSusceptible: 40 000\nCases: 19 000\nDeaths: 10 000\nDestroyed\nSlaughtered\n\nAffected population 12-week old turkeys. In one of the 2 pens, there were 19 000 turkeys with very high morbidity and more than 50 per cent mortality.\n\nOutbreak 2: SHALWA, Ashkelon, HADAROM\nDate of start of the outbreak: 7 Mar 2012\nOutbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: village\nAffected animals\nSpecies: Birds\nSusceptible: 11 000\nCases: 500\nDeaths: 500\nDestroyed\nSlaughtered\n\nAffected population: 8-week old turkeys. The flock is divided in 3 pens. Mortality was found in 2 pens.\n\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 2\nTotal animals affected\nSpecies: birds\nSusceptible: 51 000\nCases: 19 500\nDeaths: 10 500\nDestroyed\nSlaughtered\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\n\nEpidemiological comments\nThe epidemiological investigation is ongoing. Almost all the cases of H5N1 that have ever been in Israel occurred in March.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: quarantine, movement control inside the country, zoning, vaccination prohibited, no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: stamping out, screening, disinfection of infected premises/establishment(s)\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type: Avian Diseases Division, Kimron Veterinary Institute (national laboratory)\n\nSpecies: birds\nTest: polymerase chain reaction (PCR)\nTest date: 8 Mar 2012\nResult: positive\n\nSpecies: birds\nTest: real-time PCR\nTest date: 8 Mar 2012\nResult: positive\n\nSpecies: birds\nTest: real-time PCR\nTest date: 9 Mar 2012\nResult: positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Israel showing 2 outbreaks in the southern district Hadarom near Gaza, as well in the middle of the country, can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/1ZeG. The larger outbreak, while still in the Hadarom district (Hadarom means the south in Hebrew), is in the middle of Israel a good distance from the outbreak near Gaza. - Mods.FE/PC]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Total outbreaks: 2\nTotal animals affected\nSpecies: birds\nSusceptible: 51 000\n Date of previous occurrence: 7 Apr 2011\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\n Epidemiological unit: village\nAffected animals\nSpecies: birds\n Epidemiological unit: village\nAffected animals\nSpecies: Birds\n \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Israel showing 2 outbreaks in the southern district Hadarom near Gaza, as well in the middle of the country, can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/1ZeG.
