susp.", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1059627", "date": "2012-03-03 11:50:17", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (18): CHINA (HONG KONG) MAGPIE ROBIN, H5N1 SUSPECTED\n********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu, 1 Mar 2012\nSource: The Standard Hong Kong [edited]\nhttp://www.thestandard.com.hk/news_detail.asp?we_cat=4&art_id=120255&sid=35586287&con_type=1&d_str=20120301&fc=4\n\n\nSecond Cheung Chau bird flu scare in days\n------------------------------------\nA dead oriental magpie robin, which was found in Cheung Chau, has tested positive for the H5 bird flu virus in preliminary checks, the Agriculture, Fisheries and Conservation Department said yesterday [29 Feb 2012]. This is the second bird of the species found with the H5 virus on the island within two days this month. In the latest incident, the robin, which is common to Hong Kong, was found and collected at Hok Loo Lane. The department is now conducting further confirmatory tests to check if the virus is the deadly H5N1.\n\nA dead oriental magpie robin was found on the rooftop of a building on Hing Lung Back Street in Cheung Chau on Saturday [25 Feb 2012]. Testing also revealed H5 and confirmatory test results are pending. 'It is not a huge surprise that the two birds of the same species were found dead in Cheung Chau within two days, especially in winter,' said Billy Hau Chi-hang, University of Hong Kong assistant professor in biodiversity and conservation. 'One bird may come in contact with another, which has already contracted the H5 avian influenza virus.'\n\nThe department also announced on Tuesday [28 Feb 2012] that a crested goshawk, which is not common to Hong Kong, also tested positive for H5. [This goshawk] was found at Diocesan Boys' School in Argyle Street, Mong Kok, on Friday [24 Feb 2012].\nSeven dead birds were confirmed with bird flu H5N1 in January and February this year.\n\nThe department has stepped up disinfection and cleansing work.\n\n[Byline: Alice So]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n\n[H5N1 outbreaks involving poultry and wild birds in Hong Kong have been occurring since December 2011 (http://web.oie.int/wahis/reports/en_fup_0000011553_20120127_123726.pdf).\n\nOriental magpie robins (_Copsychus saularis_) are small passerine birds distributed in most of the Indian Subcontinent and parts of Southeast Asia; they are common birds in urban gardens as well as forests. They are not migratory birds. For a picture of an oriental magpie robin see http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/f/f8/Copsychus_saularis_-_Ang_Khang.jpg.\n\nA map of Cheung Chan Island can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/1Wc7. Mod. PMB\n]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n A dead oriental magpie robin, which was found in Cheung Chau, has tested positive for the H5 bird flu virus in preliminary checks, the Agriculture, Fisheries and Conservation Department said yesterday [29 Feb 2012]. \n\nOriental magpie robins (_Copsychus saularis_) are small passerine birds distributed in most of the Indian Subcontinent and parts of Southeast Asia; they are common birds in urban gardens as well as forests. MAGPIE ROBIN, H5N1 SUSPECTED\n********************************************************************\n \n\nA dead oriental magpie robin was found on the rooftop of a building on Hing Lung Back Street in Cheung Chau on Saturday [25 Feb 2012]. ' \n\n\nSecond Cheung Chau bird flu scare in days\n \n\nThe department also announced on Tuesday [28 Feb 2012] that a crested goshawk, which is not common to Hong Kong, also tested positive for H5.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2012-02-24 00:00:00", "2021-01-25 00:00:00", "2012-02-29 00:00:00", "2021-03-30 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 00:00:00", "2011-12-25 00:00:00", "2012-02-28 00:00:00", "2012-02-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-27 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "CHINA", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "Hong Kong"}, {"location": "HONG KONG", "country": "Hong Kong"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1039996", "headline": "PRO/AH> Avian influenza (15): WHO Meeting on H5N1 virus research", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1039996", "date": "2012-02-12 21:20:17", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (15): WORLD HEALTH ORGANISATION MEETING ON H5N1 VIRUS RESEARCH\n*******************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 10 Feb 2012\nFrom: Daniel R. Lucey, MD, MPH <DRL23@georgetown.edu>\n\n\nComments re: Avian influenza (14): H5N1 WHO 20120210.1038410\n---------------------------------------------------------\nThis 09 Feb 2012 article by Helen Branswell states that the H5N1 Avian influenza virus used by the Dutch laboratory at Erasmus Medical Centre in Rotterdam originated from Indonesia and that scientists from the Indonesian laboratory that provided the virus isolate are invited to WHO conference on 16 Feb 2012. This information provides clarifying context to comments made by Dr. Ron Fouchier, who led the Rotterdam lab that created [i.e. isolated] a mutant H5N1 avian influenza virus that became respiratory-transmissible while still maintaining its ability to kill some of the ferrets used in the experiments.\n\nFor example, in the [20 Jan 2012] Science Insider article by Martin Enserink based on an interview with Dr. Fouchier, and translated from Dutch, he states: 'Also, as researchers, we work very closely with people in Indonesia. It would be very unwise not to share our results with our close collaborators.'\n\nIn response to the question: 'You also want to repeat the experiments with more H5N1 strains?' Dr. Fouchier replied: 'Yes. We did this with one genetic lineage of the H5N1 virus. The question is whether all lineages can become aerosol-transmissible. If they can't, if it's just this lineage, perhaps you can focus on the region where it came from and try to stop H5N1 outbreaks there to prevent a pandemic. If it can happen everywhere, you've got to work everywhere.' The genetic lineage, or clade, of the H5N1 avian influenza virus that has circulated in Indonesia is one found predominately only in Indonesia and is a distinct clade from those found in other parts of Asia or Africa. Thus, it is rational to have one or more scientists from Indonesia participating in the WHO meeting next week, even if the sharing of the H5N1 virus isolate from Indonesia with the Rotterdam lab occurred before the May 2011 WHO's Pandemic Influenza Preparedness (PIP) Framework went into effect.\n\nThe rationale for the leading role of Indonesia from 2007-2011 in what would, after much controversy and debate, become the PIP Framework document is detailed in the Ann Acad Med Singapore 2008; 37: 482-88 paper co-authored by the current and immediate past Minister of Health entitled: 'Towards Mutual Trust, Transparency and Equity in Virus Sharing Mechanism: The Avian Influenza Case of Indonesia'.\n\n--\nContributed by:\nDaniel R. Lucey, MD, MPH\nAdjunct Professor, Department of Microbiology and Immunology\nGeorgetown University Medical Center, Washington, DC\n<DRL23@georgetown.edu>\n\n[The WHO meeting, to be held on 16 and 17 Feb 2012 at the WHO's headquarters, will focus on the most basic problems that have arisen as a result of the Avian A/(H5N1) influenza virus controversy. In essence: should the 2 papers at the heart of the dispute be published? In full or in abbreviated form? If they must be abbreviated, which sections must be held back?\n\nFurther comment on this topic will be withheld until the outcome of the meeting and the identities of the participants become available. - Mod.CP]]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Contributed by:\nDaniel R. Lucey, MD, MPH\nAdjunct Professor, Department of Microbiology and Immunology\nGeorgetown University Medical Center, Washington, DC\n<DRL23@georgetown.edu>\n\n This 09 Feb 2012 article by Helen Branswell states that the H5N1 Avian influenza virus used by the Dutch laboratory at Erasmus Medical Centre in Rotterdam originated from Indonesia and that scientists from the Indonesian laboratory that provided the virus isolate are invited to WHO conference on 16 Feb 2012. AVIAN INFLUENZA (15): WORLD HEALTH ORGANISATION MEETING ON H5N1 VIRUS RESEARCH\n*******************************************************************************\n The rationale for the leading role of Indonesia from 2007-2011 in what would, after much controversy and debate, become the PIP Framework document is detailed in the Ann Acad Med Singapore 2008; 37: 482-88 paper co-authored by the current and immediate past Minister of Health entitled: 'Towards Mutual Trust, Transparency and Equity in Virus Sharing Mechanism: The Avian Influenza Case of Indonesia'. [The WHO meeting, to be held on 16 and 17 Feb 2012 at the WHO's headquarters, will focus on the most basic problems that have arisen as a result of the Avian A/(H5N1) influenza virus controversy. This information provides clarifying context to comments made by Dr. Ron Fouchier, who led the Rotterdam lab that created [i.e. isolated] a mutant H5N1 avian influenza virus that became respiratory-transmissible while still maintaining its ability to kill some of the ferrets used in the experiments. The genetic lineage, or clade, of the H5N1 avian influenza virus that has circulated in Indonesia is one found predominately only in Indonesia and is a distinct clade from those found in other parts of Asia or Africa. Thus, it is rational to have one or more scientists from Indonesia participating in the WHO meeting next week, even if the sharing of the H5N1 virus isolate from Indonesia with the Rotterdam lab occurred before the May 2011 WHO's Pandemic Influenza Preparedness (PIP) Framework went into effect.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2012-01-20 00:00:00", "2012-02-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Indonesia", "country": "Indonesia"}, {"location": "Rotterdam", "country": "Netherlands"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Washington ,", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1065592", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (19): Israel (HD) turkey, H5N1", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1065592", "date": "2012-03-09 11:38:09", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (19): ISRAEL (HADAROM), TURKEY, H5N1\n****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 9 Mar 2012\nSource: YNET [in Hebrew, trans., summ., edited]\nhttp://www.ynet.co.il/articles/0,7340,L-4200505,00.html\n\n\nThousands of avians to be killed in the south due to bird flu\n-------------------------------------------------------------\nThe Ministry of Agriculture is to cull today [9 Mar 2012] 11 000 turkeys in Moshav Shalva, south of Kiryat Gat, following the discovering of avian influenza H5N1.\n\nThe director of Veterinary Services in the Ministry of Agriculture, Dr Nadav Galon, has announced quarantine measures in the affected village and animal movement restrictions within a 10 km [6 mi] zone around it. Teams of the Ministry's Plant and Animal Control Unit (PACU) have marked the area around the outbreak and are going to cull the birds today.\n\nNeighbouring holdings are to be sampled for laboratory tests, to exclude additional foci. There are no reports on similar disease in any other settlement within 10 km around Shalva.\n\nThis is the 1st HPAI case in Israel since March 2011, when it was diagnosed in Kibbutz Rosh Zturim; in May 2010, cases [2 emus] were diagnosed in a small petting farm in Kibbutz Ein Gedi, 4 months after an outbreak in Kibbutz Ein-Shemer, near Hadera.\n\nThe Ministry of Agriculture said that temperatures above 70 deg C [160 deg F] kill all influenza viruses; there is no reason to avoid eating well-cooked chicken and well-boiled eggs. Prescribed elementary hygienic requirements in kitchens should be adhered to, such as hand washing and cleaning of utensils and working surfaces.\n\n[byline: Neri Brenner]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[During the morning of Fri 9 Mar 2012, Israeli Radio reported a 2nd HPAI H5N1 outbreak, namely in Kibbutz Holit, involving, similarly to Shalva, a large commercial turkey enterprise. This information has been directly confirmed with the Ministry. Reportedly, both outbreaks have already been notified to the OIE. Indeed, OIE has already disseminated a notification, including a map, available at http://web.oie.int/wahis/public.php?page=single_report&pop=1&reportid=11725.\n\nHolit, situated 2.3 km (about 1.5 mi) from the Gaza strip and 5.9 km (about 4 mi) from Sinai (Egypt), had already been found infected once in the past, namely in 2006 (see ProMED-mail archive no 20060320.0858).\n\nIsrael's previous experience with H5N1 outbreaks and their immediate notification and eradication are documented in the 'see also' items listed below. HPAI H5N1 is endemic (including human cases) in Egypt, Israel's south west neighbour.\n\nThe OIE notification includes the following epidemiological comments: 'The epidemiological investigation is ongoing. Almost all the cases of H5N1 that have ever been in Israel occurred in March.' If the outbreaks are indeed that seasonal, a possible explanation deserves to be sought in bird migration (as, apparently, suggested in the past).\n\nFor the location of Shalva (spelled 'Shalwa' in OIE's notification) see map at http://healthmap.org/r/1Yir and for Holit, http://healthmap.org/r/1Yis. Both places are located within 'Hadarom' (Hebrew for 'south') region. - Mod.AS]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\n[byline: Neri Brenner]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\nHolit, situated 2.3 km (about 1.5 mi) from the Gaza strip and 5.9 km (about 4 mi) from Sinai (Egypt), had already been found infected once in the past, namely in 2006 (see ProMED-mail archive no 20060320.0858). \nThe Ministry of Agriculture is to cull today [9 Mar 2012] 11 000 turkeys in Moshav Shalva, south of Kiryat Gat, following the discovering of avian influenza H5N1. \n\nThis is the 1st HPAI case in Israel since March 2011, when it was diagnosed in Kibbutz Rosh Zturim; in May 2010, cases [2 emus] were diagnosed in a small petting farm in Kibbutz Ein Gedi, 4 months after an outbreak in Kibbutz Ein-Shemer, near Hadera. AVIAN INFLUENZA (19): ISRAEL (HADAROM), TURKEY, H5N1\n****************************************************\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[During the morning of Fri 9 Mar 2012, Israeli Radio reported a 2nd HPAI H5N1 outbreak, namely in Kibbutz Holit, involving, similarly to Shalva, a large commercial turkey enterprise. \n\nThe Ministry of Agriculture said that temperatures above 70 deg C [160 deg F] kill all influenza viruses; there is no reason to avoid eating well-cooked chicken and well-boiled eggs. \n\nThe OIE notification includes the following epidemiological comments: 'The epidemiological investigation is ongoing.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2010-05-25 00:00:00", "2011-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2006-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2012-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "ISRAEL", "country": "Israel"}, {"location": "Sinai", "country": "Egypt"}, {"location": "Gaza", "country": "Palestine"}, {"location": "Egypt", "country": "Egypt"}, {"location": "Israel", "country": "Israel"}, {"location": "Hadera", "country": "Israel"}, {"location": "TURKEY", "country": "Turkey"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1046187", "headline": "PRO/AH> Avian influenza (16): India (BH) crow, H5N1", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1046187", "date": "2012-02-19 10:17:29", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (16): INDIA (BIHAR) CROW, H5N1\n*******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat, 18 Feb 2012\nSource: The Times of India [edited]\nhttp://www.downtoearth.org.in/content/avian-flu-killing-jharkhand-crows-virology-institute\n\n\nCrows are dying in Bihar from bird flu\n--------------------------------------\nIt is official now. Crows are dying in Bihar because of bird flu. This was revealed in the report of the Bhopal-based High Security Animal Disease Laboratory (HSADL), officials said on Saturday [18 Feb 2012].\n\nThe HSADL has confirmed in its report that avian influenza was killing the crows in Gaya district.\n\nAfter the confirmation, the Bihar government has directed the animal husbandary department officials to begin necessary measures to deal with the situation.\n\nAccording to reports reaching Patna, crows are continuing to die across the state. Hundreds of crows have died in Bihar in the last one and a half months, particularly in Gaya, Banka, Nawada, Jamui, Bhagalpur, Munger, and Aurangabad districts.\n\nThe Bihar Animal Husbandry Department (AHD) has sounded an alert and has asked people not to touch the dead crows. It has issued advertisements in local dailies asking people to keep away from the dead birds and inform the administration when they spot any.\n\n'Some measures have been taken to control the situation and check possible spread of any kind of infection,' officials said. Health department officials suspect the crows are infected with the H5 and H1 avian viruses. 'Human beings should stay away from the crows.' Last month, neighbouring Jharkhand had reported similar mass deaths of crows.\n\n--\n\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Avian influenza outbreaks in poultry caused by H5N1 highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) virus were confirmed in a nearby state, West Bengal, in Aug/Sep 2011 (ProMED-mail archives 20110909.2747 and 20110923.2882). Then there were reports of crows dead due to H5N1 in the neighboring state Jharkhand. No associated poultry cases were reported in this episode nor in the past one of Jharkhand. HPAI H5N1 virus is not transmitted from human to human, so an outbreak in people would depend on the exposure to infected reservoir hosts.\n\nA map of the area can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/1ix2. Mod.PMB]", "summary": "\n\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Avian influenza outbreaks in poultry caused by H5N1 highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) virus were confirmed in a nearby state, West Bengal, in Aug/Sep 2011 (ProMED-mail archives 20110909.2747 and 20110923.2882). The Bihar Animal Husbandry Department (AHD) has sounded an alert and has asked people not to touch the dead crows. Health department officials suspect the crows are infected with the H5 and H1 avian viruses. 25(9) [edited]\nhttp://web.oie.int/wahis/public.php?page=single_report&pop=1&reportid=11686\n\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza, Myanmar\n------------------------------------------\nInformation received on 29 Feb 2012 from Prof Dr Myint Thein, Director General, Livestock Breeding and Veterinary Department, Ministry of Livestock & Fisheries, Yangon, Myanmar\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nStart date: 20 Feb 2012\nDate of 1st confirmation of the event: 24 Feb 2012\nReport date: 28 Feb 2012\nDate submitted to OIE: 29 Feb 2012\nReason for notification: reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 14 Apr 2011\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory (basic), laboratory (advanced), necropsy\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country\n\nNew outbreaks\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1 (10317): Myothit Quarter, Chaung U, Monywa, Sagaing\nDate of start of the outbreak: 20 Feb 2012\nOutbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: farm\nAffected animals\nSpecies: birds\nSusceptible: 1060\nCases: 61\nDeaths: 61\nDestroyed: 999\nSlaughtered: 0\nAffected population: layers\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\nEpidemiological comments: 5-month and 18-month-old layer chickens in 2 establishments, with a total of 1060 chickens. A few chickens were found dead on 20 Feb 2012. A total of 61 chickens died within 4 days. There are 40 000 chickens reared in 139 farms in Chaung U township. All are layers and broilers of different ages.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: stamping out, quarantine, movement control inside the country, zoning, disinfection of infected premises/establishment(s), dipping/spraying, vaccination prohibited, no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type: Regional Veterinary Diagnostic Laboratory, Mandalay (local laboratory)\nTests and results\nSpecies / Test / Test date / Result\nBirds / polymerase chain reaction (PCR) / 24/02/2012 / Positive\nBirds / rapid tests / 24 Feb 2012 / Positive\n\nLaboratory name and type: Central Veterinary Diagnostic Laboratory, Yangon (national laboratory)\nTests and results\nSpecies / Test / Test date / Result\nBirds / real-time PCR / 26 Feb 2012 / Positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Since 2005, Myanmar has reported 10 outbreaks of avian influenza. They occurred in 2009 and 2010, and all but one occurred during the period from January to March. But from looking at the reporting in both animals and humans from surrounding countries such as Cambodia, Bangladesh, Viet Nam, Nepal, Bhutan, and China, it is clear that highly pathogenic avian influenza still lurks in the background and deserves our attention and surveillance.\n\nThe location of the outbreak can be seen on the map included in the OIE report at the source URL above. (HK) H5N1, gull, peregrine falcon", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1029495", "date": "2012-02-02 12:53:51", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (06): CHINA (HONG KONG) H5N1, GULL, PEREGRINE FALCON\n********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 1 Feb 2012\nSource: Xinhua News Agency [edited]\nhttp://news.xinhuanet.com/english/china/2012-02/01/c_131386998.htm\n\n\nThe Hong Kong Special Administrative Region government said on Wednesday [1 Feb 2012] that preliminary testing of a dead peregrine falcon and a dead black-headed gull [is] positive for the H5 avian influenza virus.\n\nA spokesman for the city's Agriculture, Fisheries and Conservation Department (AFCD) said that further confirmatory tests are being conducted.\n\nAccording to AFCD, on 30 Jan 2012, the dead peregrine falcon and black-headed gull were found and collected in the park of Seaview Crescent, Man Tung Road, Tung Chung, and Chun Yin Square Playground, Yuen Long, respectively.\n\nPeregrine falcons are rare winter visitors to Hong Kong, while the black-headed gull is a common visitor.\n\nThe spokesman said that there were no poultry farms within 3 km [around 2 mi] of where the dead peregrine falcon was found, but 4 chicken farms are within 3 km of where the dead black-headed gull was found. AFCD staff inspected the farms and found no abnormal mortality or symptoms of avian influenza among the chicken flocks. These farms will be put under enhanced surveillance.\n\n'People should avoid personal contact with wild birds and live poultry and their droppings. They should clean their hands thoroughly after coming into contact with them,' he said, adding that all relevant government departments will continue to remain highly vigilant and strictly enforce preventive measures against avian influenza.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[H5N1 outbreaks involving poultry and wild birds in Hong Kong have been occurring since December 2011 (http://web.oie.int/wahis/reports/en_fup_0000011553_20120127_123726.pdf). The peregrine falcon (_Falco peregrinus_) is a widespread bird of prey in the family Falconidae. In the region, it is usually a breeding resident, but it is not commonly seen in Hong Kong during the winter. The black-headed gull (_Chroicocephalus [=Larus] ridibundus_) is a small gull which breeds in much of Europe and Asia, and also in coastal eastern Canada. Most of the population is migratory, wintering further south, but some birds in the milder westernmost areas of Europe are resident. Because gulls are very susceptible to H5N1, it is very unlikely that they can carry the virus long distances through migration.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of the area can be found at http://healthmap.org/r/1Jqr. - Mod.PMB]\n\n[Peregrines have a home range of up to 15 miles radius, so this one could have come from the Chinese mainland.\nPhoto of peregrine falcon at:\nhttp://allyouneedtoknow.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/05/peregrine-falcon.jpg\nand blackheaded gull at:\nhttp://www.kenyabirds.org.uk/pics/gull-bha.jpg\n- Mod.JW]", "summary": "\n\nThe spokesman said that there were no poultry farms within 3 km [around 2 mi] of where the dead peregrine falcon was found, but 4 chicken farms are within 3 km of where the dead black-headed gull was found. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n< The black-headed gull (_Chroicocephalus [=Larus] ridibundus_) is a small gull which breeds in much of Europe and Asia, and also in coastal eastern Canada.", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2012-01-30 00:00:00", "2012-02-01 00:00:00", "2011-12-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "Hong Kong"}, {"location": "HONG KONG", "country": "Hong Kong"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "CHINA", "country": "China"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1035842", "headline": "PRO/AH> Avian influenza (12): H5N1 research controversy", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1035842", "date": "2012-02-07 22:44:27", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (12): H5N1 RESEARCH CONTROVERSY\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 5 Feb 2012\nFrom: Prof. H. Tolou [edited]\n<htolou@imassa.fr>\n\n\nI wish to comment on information on the 2 Feb 2012 NYAS symposium on H5N1 dual use research you recently published [Avian influenza (10): H5N1 research controversy 20120204.1032857].\n\nI am disappointed by the debate you report. I think the good questions are not addressed, so there cannot be good answers.\n\nI think the main questions to answer are:\n\n- Has the concerned work on H5N1 mutation demonstrated that H5N1 will evolve the proposed way and that it will undoubtedly appear without human intervention? The answer is no.\n\n- Has the concerned work produced the virus that will certainly appear in nature and constitute a new threat for human beings, so that it deserves and allows new research, looking for vaccine or antivirals? Again, the answer is no. H5N1 could naturally evolve in a way different enough to pose different problems, particularly regarding vaccine design. However, a potentially dangerous virus now exists and it could 'leak' from a laboratory. 'Mother Nature' is not the 'mother of bioterrorism,' as some scientists are now used to saying!\n\n- Has the concerned work given the signal to evil-minded people that a terrifying agent could be obtained from H5N1 virus? The answer is yes: Make some efforts, they will probably be successful!\n\n- Has the concerned work sufficient scientific or technical originality or interest (Using particular, non-natural conditions, a pathogenic virus can mutate to a -- potentially -- more pathogenic one: What's new?) to deserve publication in journals we generally regard as prestigious? I am not sure, unless media impact has became the main criteria for good research. As V. Racaniello says, 'If you think you can (do a risk-benefit analysis), you are wrong.' I totally agree. But it is not a reason to do hazardous research when you know it is essentially hazardous research.\n\nI totally disagree with any encouragement given to that kind of research. My point of view is strictly personal. I hope it will contribute to this important debate.\n\n--\nCommunicated by\nProf. H. Tolou\nArmed Forces Biomedical Research Institute - IRBA\nFrance\n<htolou@imassa.fr>\n\n[There are a number of different views on this subject, but as the report quoted has not stirred up any other comments from our readers, this thread is now closed. - Mod.JW]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Has the concerned work sufficient scientific or technical originality or interest (Using particular, non-natural conditions, a pathogenic virus can mutate to a -- potentially -- more pathogenic one: What's new?) to deserve publication in journals we generally regard as prestigious? Has the concerned work produced the virus that will certainly appear in nature and constitute a new threat for human beings, so that it deserves and allows new research, looking for vaccine or antivirals? France\n<htolou@imassa.fr>\n\n[There are a number of different views on this subject, but as the report quoted has not stirred up any other comments from our readers, this thread is now closed. - Mod. AVIAN INFLUENZA (12): H5N1 RESEARCH CONTROVERSY\n***********************************************\n I wish to comment on information on the 2 Feb 2012 NYAS symposium on H5N1 dual use research you recently published [Avian influenza (10): H5N1 research controversy 20120204.1032857]. \n\nI think the main questions to answer are:\n\n- \n\n--\n \n\nI totally disagree with any encouragement given to that kind of research. Has the concerned work on H5N1 mutation demonstrated that H5N1 will evolve the proposed way and that it will undoubtedly appear without human intervention?", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": [], "locations": []}]}, {"archive_id": "1031448", "headline": "PRO/AH> Avian influenza (07): China (HK) H5N1, gull, peregrine falcon", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1031448", "date": "2012-02-03 07:02:32", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (07): CHINA (HONG KONG) H5N1, GULL, PEREGRINE FALCON\n*********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 2 Feb 2012\nFrom: Patrick Redig <redig001@umn.edu> [edited]\n\n\n[Re: ProMED-mail Avian influenza (06): China (HK) H5N1, gull, peregrine falcon 20120202.1029495]\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nRegarding the finding of a dead peregrine falcon in Hong Kong from which an H5 influenza virus was recovered, it is worth noting that the peregrine is a nearly obligate predator of other birds, especially shore birds. While the home range of a nesting pair of birds may be on the order of 15 mi [25 km], as noted, wintering birds, living up to their name, the wandering falcon, may in fact move over large regions. It is entirely probable that this particular individual was a wintering arctic or tundra peregrine, one which has a circumpolar distribution throughout the arctic. Peregrines have been casualties of H5 influenza in Hong Kong in the past.\n\n--\nPatrick T Redig DVM, PhD\n<redig001@umn.edu>\nThe Raptor Center\nUniversity of Minnesota\nUSA\n<redig001@umn.edu>\n\n[For earlier reports of peregrines found dead from H5N1 infection in Hong Kong see:\n\n2003\n'Pathogenic H5N1 Avian Influenza in Waterfowl and Wild birds, Final Report, Hong Kong, China\nReport date: 30 July 2003\nC. Wild birds: ... Dead peregrine falcon submitted on 9/3/2003 was positive for H5N1 virus.'\nhttp://www.afcd.gov.hk/english/publications/publications_qua/files/oiebirds.pdf\n\n2004\n'NY Times January 22, 2004 By Keith Bradsher\nHONG KONG, Jan. 21 -- A dead peregrine falcon found near two chicken farms here was infected with the avian influenza virus, agricultural officials here said Wednesday. The dead falcon was the first sign that the disease, which is spreading in chicken flocks in Vietnam, South Korea and Japan, may also be present in China.'\nhttp://www.rense.com/general62/facon.htm ['facon' is correct]\n\n2006\nhttp://www.savethefalcons.org/another_falcon_with_avian_flu.asp\n\n2007 & 2008\nhttp://www.mendeley.com/research/characterization-of-avian-influenza-viruses-a-h5n1-from-wild-birds-hong-kong-20042008/#page-1\n\nThere are also refs. in the literature to strains dated 2009 & 2011.\n\nA map of the worldwide range of peregrines:\nhttp://www.planetofbirds.com/Master/FALCONIFORMES/Falconidae/maps/Peregrine%20Falcon.jpg\n- Mod.JW]", "summary": "The Raptor Center\nUniversity of Minnesota\nUSA\n<redig001@umn.edu>\n\n[For earlier reports of peregrines found dead from H5N1 infection in Hong Kong see:\n\n2003\n'Pathogenic H5N1 Avian Influenza in Waterfowl and Wild birds, Final Report, Hong Kong, China\nReport date: A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\n--\nPatrick T Redig DVM, PhD\n<redig001@umn.edu>\n ['facon' is correct]\n\n2006\nhttp://www.savethefalcons.org/another_falcon_with_avian_flu.asp\n\n2007 & 2008\n AVIAN INFLUENZA (07): CHINA (HONG KONG) H5N1, GULL, PEREGRINE FALCON\n*********************************************************************\n \n\nA map of the worldwide range of peregrines:\nhttp://www.planetofbirds.com/Master/FALCONIFORMES/Falconidae/maps/Peregrine%20Falcon.jpg\n- Mod. By Keith Bradsher\nHONG KONG, Jan. 21 -- A dead peregrine falcon found near two chicken farms here was infected with the avian influenza virus, agricultural officials here said Wednesday.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2003-07-30 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2004-01-22 00:00:00", "2006-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-01-21 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2003-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "CHINA", "country": "China"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "Hong Kong"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "Japan"}, {"location": "HONG KONG", "country": "Hong Kong"}, {"location": "Vietnam", "country": "Vietnam"}, {"location": "South Korea", "country": "South Korea"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1032857", "headline": "PRO/AH> Avian influenza (10): H5N1 research controversy", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1032857", "date": "2012-02-04 14:02:20", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (10): H5N1 RESEARCH CONTROVERSY\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 3 Feb 2012\nSource: CIDRAP News [excerpted, edited]\nhttp://www.cidrap.umn.edu/cidrap/content/influenza/avianflu/news/feb0312webinar-jw.html\n\n\nLive debate airs major divisions in H5N1 research battle\n--------------------------------------------------------\nBy: Robert Roos, News Editor\n\nThe controversy over research about potentially dangerous H5N1 viruses heated up last night in a New York City debate that featured some of the leading voices exchanging blunt comments on the alleged risks and benefits of publishing or withholding the full details of the studies.\n\nThe debate, sponsored by the New York Academy of Sciences, involved 2 members of the biosecurity advisory board that called for 'redacting' the 2 studies in question to delete details, along with scientists who want the full studies published and representatives of Science and Nature, the two journals involved. The 2-hour session, which was live-streamed on the Web, left no clear impression of how the current controversy or future dilemmas over conduct and publication of 'dual use' research might be resolved. One of very few points on which the panelists were unanimous was the hope that the current battle won't be repeated.\n\nThe 2 studies involved the generation of an H5N1 virus and an H5N1-H1N1 reassortant that spread among ferrets via respiratory droplets. In December the National Science Advisory Board for Biosecurity (NSABB), which advises the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS), recommended that the details be deleted from the two reports before they are published. HHS agreed and passed the recommendation to Science and Nature. The journals have signaled they will go along with the recommendation if a way can be found to provide the details of the reports to scientists with a legitimate need for them. But since the NSABB recommendation was unveiled, scientists, biosecurity experts, and public health officials have vigorously debated the issue in the media and in journal commentaries.\n\nMichael T. Osterholm, PhD, MPH, an NSABB member, said the board set up a working group to consider the two manuscripts and brought in outside expert advisors, [which] spent 'hundreds and hundreds of hours' discussing the problem, leading to unanimous support for the recommendation to withhold the details of the studies. Osterholm is director of the University of Minnesota's Center for Infectious Disease Research and Policy, which publishes CIDRAP News.\n\nArturo Casadevall, MD, PhD, the other NSABB member on the panel, said he initially thought the studies should be published in full, 'but as a result of the deliberative process, I changed my mind.' He is a professor of microbiology and immunology at Albert Einstein College of Medicine in the Bronx, N.Y. When panel moderator Ian Lipkin, MD, later asked Casadevall if any other NSABB members changed their minds during the discussions, he declined comment other than to say there was a long deliberative process. Lipkin is a professor of epidemiology and of neurology and pathology at Columbia University. Both Osterholm and Casadevall emphasized they were speaking as individuals and not on behalf of the NSABB.\n\nDebate over case-fatality ratio\n--------------------------------------\nMuch of the debate focused on questions related to how much of a threat the mutant viruses represent. That began early in the session, when Osterholm and Peter Palese, PhD, argued about the case-fatality ratio (CFR) for human H5N1 infections. Palese is a professor of microbiology and chair of the Department of Microbiology at Mount Sinai School of Medicine in New York City.\n\nThe World Health Organization (WHO) lists 583 confirmed H5N1 cases with 344 deaths since 2003, for a CFR of 59%. Palese contended, as he has previously in other forums, that this ratio is too high, because only severe cases are being counted. 'Only hospital cases are counted. People who are asymptomatically infected are not being counted,' he said. 'The unfortunate WHO estimate is very high.'\n\nFlu researchers have sought to detect unreported and asymptomatic H5N1 cases by looking for H5N1 antibodies in the blood of people with potential past exposures to the virus. Palese said that in 10 studies with at least 500 subjects each, the infection rates ranged from 0.2% to 5.6%. If one assumes a 2% infection rate for people who are exposed to the virus but don't have recognized cases, 'the case-fatality with H5N1 really is much lower than what the WHO tries to say,' he asserted.\n\nOsterholm replied that in 13 studies that met the WHO criteria for H5N1 serology, only 26 of 5,533 subjects were positive for H5N1 antibodies, for a rate of 0.469%. 'But none of this is critical, because if this virus was 20 times less virulent than it is now, it would still be worse than [the] 1918 [pandemic flu virus],' he added. 'The data are clear and compelling. It'd still be the worst flu pandemic in history.'\n\nFerrets on trial\n-------------------\nParticipants also disagreed about the reliability of ferrets as models of flu effects in humans. Virologist Vincent Racaniello, PhD, a professor of microbiology and immunology at Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons, said that when he began studying viral pathogenesis under Albert Sabin and other eminent experts, 'The first thing they said was when you study viruses in animals, don't think you'll learn much about what happens in humans.' Casadevall agreed that transmissibility in ferrets doesn't necessarily predict transmissibility in humans, but he said it was 'striking' that so many flu experts view ferrets as a suitable model for studying human flu.\n\nThe NSABB contacted many flu experts from around the world, and with few exceptions, they said the ferret model 'is a reasonable estimate of what might happen,' said Osterholm. Moreover, Fouchier himself, when he discussed his study at a European meeting last September, ended his talk saying, ''This is now a very dangerous virus,'' Osterholm added.\n\nLaurie Garrett, PhD, senior fellow for global health at the Council on Foreign Relations, commented, 'The public health asset argument is that these experiments provide predictive value to help public health and identify genetic changes that should be monitored. If the ferret is useless, with no predictive value, then I do not understand why the experiment was ever done.' Palese responded, 'In fact the ferret is much too sensitive as an animal model, so I think an animal model is just that, an animal model, and not predictive.'\n\nIn other exchanges about how dangerous the mutant H5N1 viruses might be, Osterholm contrasted H5N1 with smallpox. 'I would not like to see smallpox get out of a BSL-4 [biosafety level 4, the highest level] lab, but it wouldn't be overly concerning' in view of the vaccine and other countermeasures available, he said. He noted that the WHO had a quick-response plan to contain an incipient flu pandemic, but the 2009 pandemic showed its futility. 'Once [flu] is out, it's gone, it's a worldwide issue,' he said. Palese responded, 'I'm shocked to hear that you wouldn't be concerned if smallpox got out. Two hundred million people died [of smallpox] in the 20th century, 500 for H5N1. H5N1 virus is so much less dangerous from what we know than smallpox.' Casadevall defended Osterholm's position, commenting, 'We have a smallpox vaccine, and there's a long period of incubation.' The last outbreak in Europe was stopped with a quick vaccination campaign, he added.\n\nSome of the discussion focused on the potential benefits of the H5N1 studies and full publication of the details. Garrett questioned the benefits, saying, 'One of the other great arguments in favor of public health benefits is that they tell us what we should watch for in nature. ... Nothing could be further from the truth. Most of the viral samples of H5 are fragmentary, and there's no routine capacity, especially in developing countries.'\n\nIn response to an assertion from Osterholm that both the risks and benefits of research must be carefully weighed, Racaniello said, 'For much of science you can't do a risk-benefit analysis. If you think you can, you're wrong.'\n\nQuestions about governmental role\n----------------------------------------------\nOn the question of the governmental role in regulating dual-use research, Garrett said basic notions about the purposes of government lead to a contradiction. One of the prime duties of government is to protect the public from perceived threats, she said. 'If you define the threat as a natural pandemic, you could argue that government should promote this kind of research, because it can lead to defenses,' she said. 'But if you define the threat as bioterrorism or biosecurity or lab leaks, then government has an absolute mandate to intervene to control that research.'\n\nIf the question is difficult at the national level, it's even more so at the international level, Garrettt said. 'If you go to the international level, we have only the International Health Regulations and the 2011 virus-sharing agreement' hammered out by the WHO, she said. 'We have absolutely no consensus as to what is the appropriate role of international governing bodies.'\n\nCasadevall voiced concern about the overregulation of science, especially clinical research. 'I have to write a 100-page animal [research] protocol to do something to help society, when you can walk into a Home Depot and find many ways to kill a mouse without any protocol,' he said. 'With this system in place, you're going to kill science.'\n\nOn the question of publication versus secrecy, Jasny estimated that about 1,000 people have already seen Fouchier's data, including 800 who attended the European meeting where he discussed it, plus government officials and editors. Osterholm and Casadevall said the NSABB hasn't suggested that the details can be kept secret for long, but they argued that withholding them nonetheless has short-term value. 'Everyone knows you can make a fertilizer bomb. But I don't think they want you to have the exact specifications on how to make a fertilizer bomb,' said Casadevall.\n\nWhen Lipkin raised the issue of lab security and containment levels, the debate turned heated once again. Osterholm said significant lab leaks of infectious agents don't happen often, but added, 'We can't un-ring a bell. One day maybe it'll be shown that this can't transmit to people, but if we're wrong and we find it does end up being transmitted ... it'll be just like 9/11. I don't understand why it's not going to be put into BSL-4 until we understand what we're doing.'\n\nPalese, who had said earlier that the type of research in question is already very restricted, reiterated his argument that all the existing evidence does not suggest the mutant H5N1 would spread among humans. 'There are many reasonable scientists who disagree with you,' Osterholm replied. Referring to the Sep 11 attacks, he added, 'Damn it, this is a real possibility, and if we are wrong, the consequences could be so catastrophic that we'll all go back and ask ourselves why did we let it happen.'\n\nGarrett warned that the debate over the research needs to include representatives of the general public, not just scientists. If an upcoming conference being planned by the WHO leads to some sort of agreement based only on discussion among scientists, she said, 'It's all going to backfire. It's going to explode in our face.' The WHO has scheduled the conference for Feb 16 and 17, but the agenda and participants are still being firmed up, spokesman Gregory Hartl told CIDRAP News today.\n\nThe value of a gutted paper\n-----------------------------------\nIn response to question from Lipkin, Veronique Kiermer, PhD, executive editor of Nature, said the two H5N1 studies are worth publishing even if the details must be left out. 'I think these 2 papers are very important and the overall message needs to be published,' she said. 'Also the scientists who have done this work deserve to have credit.' She added that it will be important for any mechanism for disseminating the details to be fair, so that anyone with a real need to know can get the data. But how to define who those people are remains to be worked out, she acknowledged.\n\nJasny commended the authors of the two H5N1 studies for being very responsible. 'They could've withdrawn the papers and published them elsewhere if they so chose. They're tried to work through the system, realizing the problems that are inherent in the situation. That's another reason to publish a redacted manuscript, because they've played fair.'\n\nRefer to:\nInformation on Feb 2 NYAS symposium on H5N1 dual use research\nhttp://www.nyas.org/Events/Detail.aspx?cid=f7d2e65c-9f8d-4418-b25e-bff21bb0a6cb\n\nList of panelists\nhttp://www.nyas.org/AboutUs/MediaRelations/Detail.aspx?cid=546b5ad2-9ead-4b45-bf26-03258eaa5294\n\nDec 23, 2011, CIDRAP News story 'Fears about mutant H5N1 hinge on ferrets as flu model'\nhttp://search.cidrap.umn.edu/cidrap/content/influenza/avianflu/news/dec2311ferrets-jw.html\n--\nCommunicated by ProMED\n<promed@promedmail.org>", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Casadevall agreed that transmissibility in ferrets doesn't necessarily predict transmissibility in humans, but he said it was 'striking' that so many flu experts view ferrets as a suitable model for studying human flu.\n\n Information on Feb 2 NYAS symposium on H5N1 dual use research\nhttp://www.nyas.org/Events/Detail.aspx?cid=f7d2e65c-9f8d-4418-b25e-bff21bb0a6cb\n\nList of panelists\n \n\nMichael T. Osterholm, PhD, MPH, an NSABB member, said the board set up a working group to consider the two manuscripts and brought in outside expert advisors, [which] spent 'hundreds and hundreds of hours' discussing the problem, leading to unanimous support for the recommendation to withhold the details of the studies. The debate, sponsored by the New York Academy of Sciences, involved 2 members of the biosecurity advisory board that called for 'redacting' the 2 studies in question to delete details, along with scientists who want the full studies published and representatives of Science and Nature, the two journals involved. Virologist Vincent Racaniello, PhD, a professor of microbiology and immunology at Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons, said that when he began studying viral pathogenesis under Albert Sabin and other eminent experts, 'The first thing they said was when you study viruses in animals, don't think you'll learn much about what happens in humans.' \n\nPalese, who had said earlier that the type of research in question is already very restricted, reiterated his argument that all the existing evidence does not suggest the mutant H5N1 would spread among humans. ' \n\nArturo Casadevall, MD, PhD, the other NSABB member on the panel, said he initially thought the studies should be published in full, 'but as a result of the deliberative process, I changed my mind.' http://www.nyas.org/AboutUs/MediaRelations/Detail.aspx?cid=546b5ad2-9ead-4b45-bf26-03258eaa5294\n\nDec 23, 2011, CIDRAP News story 'Fears about mutant H5N1 hinge on ferrets as flu model'\n The NSABB contacted many flu experts from around the world, and with few exceptions, they said the ferret model 'is a reasonable estimate of what might happen,' said Osterholm. \n\nLaurie Garrett, PhD, senior fellow for global health at the Council on Foreign Relations, commented, 'The public health asset argument is that these experiments provide predictive value to help public health and identify genetic changes that should be monitored. \n\nIf the question is difficult at the national level, it's even more so at the international level, Garrettt said. ' The controversy over research about potentially dangerous H5N1 viruses heated up last night in a New York City debate that featured some of the leading voices exchanging blunt comments on the alleged risks and benefits of publishing or withholding the full details of the studies. \n\nFlu researchers have sought to detect unreported and asymptomatic H5N1 cases by looking for H5N1 antibodies in the blood of people with potential past exposures to the virus. \n\nOn the question of publication versus secrecy, Jasny estimated that about 1,000 people have already seen Fouchier's data, including 800 who attended the European meeting where he discussed it, plus government officials and editors. AVIAN INFLUENZA (10): H5N1 RESEARCH CONTROVERSY\n***********************************************\n \n\nGarrett warned that the debate over the research needs to include representatives of the general public, not just scientists. On the question of the governmental role in regulating dual-use research, Garrett said basic notions about the purposes of government lead to a contradiction. \n\nSome of the discussion focused on the potential benefits of the H5N1 studies and full publication of the details. In response to question from Lipkin, Veronique Kiermer, PhD, executive editor of Nature, said the two H5N1 studies are worth publishing even if the details must be left out. ' If you define the threat as a natural pandemic, you could argue that government should promote this kind of research, because it can lead to defenses,' she said. ' \n\nFerrets on trial\n \n\nQuestions about governmental role\n I would not like to see smallpox get out of a BSL-4 [biosafety level 4, the highest level] lab, but it wouldn't be overly concerning' in view of the vaccine and other countermeasures available, he said. I have to write a 100-page animal [research] protocol to do something to help society, when you can walk into a Home Depot and find many ways to kill a mouse without any protocol,' he said. ' In response to an assertion from Osterholm that both the risks and benefits of research must be carefully weighed, Racaniello said, 'For much of science you can't do a risk-benefit analysis. If you go to the international level, we have only the International Health Regulations and the 2011 virus-sharing agreement' hammered out by the WHO, she said. \n\nRefer to:\n http://search.cidrap.umn.edu/cidrap/content/influenza/avianflu/news/dec2311ferrets-jw.html\n--\n Osterholm and Casadevall said the NSABB hasn't suggested that the details can be kept secret for long, but they argued that withholding them nonetheless has short-term value. ' \n\n\nLive debate airs major divisions in H5N1 research battle\n I think these 2 papers are very important and the overall message needs to be published,' she said. ' \n\nCasadevall voiced concern about the overregulation of science, especially clinical research. ' Palese said that in 10 studies with at least 500 subjects each, the infection rates ranged from 0.2% to 5.6%. \n\nIn other exchanges about how dangerous the mutant H5N1 viruses might be, Osterholm contrasted H5N1 with smallpox. ' If an upcoming conference being planned by the WHO leads to some sort of agreement based only on discussion among scientists, she said, 'It's all going to backfire.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "smallpox"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-09-11 00:00:00", "2021-12-25 00:00:00", "2017-02-16 00:00:00", "2011-12-23 00:00:00", "2009-03-25 00:00:00", "2003-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-02-02 00:00:00", "2011-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bronx", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Osterholm", "country": "Sweden"}, {"location": "New York City", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Lipkin", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "N.Y.", "country": "Papua New Guinea"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1038410", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (14): H5N1 WHO meeting announcement", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1038410", "date": "2012-02-10 11:33:33", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (14): H5N1, WHO MEETING ANNOUNCEMENT\n****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 10 Feb 2012\nSource: Winnipeg Free Press, The Canadian Press [edited]\nhttp://www.winnipegfreepress.com/world/breakingnews/to-publish-what-to-publish-those-will-be-the-questions-at-who-bird-flu-meeting-139034654.html\n\n\nTo publish and what to publish? Those will be the questions on the table when the World Health Organisation (WHO) convenes a special meeting next week about controversial bird flu studies. The meeting will be small, with only 22 invitees from outside the WHO, senior communications staff of the Geneva-based global health agency said.\n\nPotentially among them will be representatives of the Vietnamese and Indonesian laboratories that provided the original viruses on which the research was done.\n\nPeople looking for solutions to broader issues such as whether and where similar research should be conducted in future may need to dial down their expectations for the meeting.\n\n'In this 1st meeting, we've got to sort out the deadlock, I think, that we're in with the scientific community. I don't think anyone anticipates that to happen very quickly,' says Christy Feig, the WHO's director of communications.\n\nThe session, to be held on 16 and 17 Feb 2012 at the WHO's headquarters, will focus on the most basic problems that have arisen as a result of the controversy. In essence: Should the 2 papers at the heart of the dispute be published? In full or in abbreviated form? If they must be abbreviated, which sections must be held back?\n\nThat disclosure suggests the tentative agreement on the part of the research teams and the journals involved to publish only redacted versions is not yet set in stone. In fact, the belief in Geneva is that the distance between the meeting participants is wide. As a result, expectations for how much can be achieved next week are the opposite. 'The focus is very narrow,' Feig said from Geneva. 'There's only so much ground you can cover in 2 days.'\n\nThe controversy relates to 2 studies, done by Dutch and American researchers, which reportedly show how H5N1 flu viruses could be made to spread like seasonal flu viruses among ferrets. Such viruses could not be tested in humans, and ferrets are considered the best -- though not foolproof -- animal model for predicting how flu viruses will act in people.\n\nA U.S. panel of biosecurity experts is urging that the studies not be published in full, arguing the details of how the work was done would be dangerous in the wrong hands. Invitations to the meeting are directed to individuals in some cases. In others, they have been issued to an institution that is playing a role in the controversy.\n\nRepresentatives of the Vietnamese and Indonesian labs that provided the source viruses have not yet indicated whether they'll attend, Feig said. Viet Nam provided viruses to Yoshihiro Kawaoka of the University of Wisconsin-Madison, while Ron Fouchier, of Erasmus Medical Center in Rotterdam, the Netherlands received his viruses from Indonesia. Their inclusion is a nod on the WHO's part to the Pandemic Influenza Preparedness (PIP) Framework, a multi-country agreement forged after years of painful negotiations. The framework, ratified last spring [2011], is meant to ensure that countries that share viruses with foreign scientists will in turn share in the benefits that flow from that research. The talks that led to the framework were triggered by a 2007 move by Indonesia to stop sharing H5N1 viruses with the broader world unless it was guaranteed access to pandemic vaccine and other benefits. While the transfer of viruses from Viet Nam and Indonesia to the American and Dutch labs occurred well before the PIP agreement was put in place, the WHO wants to observe the spirit of that agreement going forward, said spokesperson Gregory Hartl.\n\nThe director of the U.S. scientific agency that funded the research -- Dr. Anthony Fauci of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases -- will be there. So too will be a representative of the National Science Advisory Board on Biosecurity, the expert panel charged by the U.S. government with reviewing potential dual-use research, legitimate science that could be put to illegitimate use.\n\nOthers attending the meeting will be the researchers themselves, people who reviewed the research proposals to see whether they triggered dual-use concerns (both when the work was in the proposal stage and when the studies were being readied for publication) and representatives of the journals Science and Nature, which plan to publish the studies.\n\nAt least several of the directors of laboratories in the network of WHO collaborating labs for influenza have been invited and are expected to attend.\n\nA list of the participants and their declarations of interest will be posted on the WHO website the day the meeting begins. Hartl said the list can only be posted after the meeting participants formally go through and accept one another's declarations of interests.\n\nOne of the conditions the researchers and journals made before tentatively agreeing to redact the studies was that the full details of how the work was done would be shared with other scientists and public health officials on a need-to-know basis.\n\nThe system for doing that -- vetting applications to see the work, figuring out how to share the material -- has not yet been devised. And that work probably won't happen at this meeting, said Feig, adding that people with the expertise needed to set up that type of system won't be in the room.\n\nThe WHO has repeatedly said that it envisages helping to organize a 2nd meeting with broader goals and wider international involvement after this initial gathering is completed. Hartl said that is still the plan, but planning won't begin until this meeting occurs.\n\n[By: Helen Branswell]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nDan Lucey\nGeorgetown University\n<DRL23@georgetown.edu>\n\n[The WHO is concerned that the Pandemic Influenza Preparedness (PIP) Framework, a multi-country agreement ratified last spring 2011, has not been damaged by this research work. That apart, perhaps the most interesting information in this announcement are the facts that the avian A/(H5N1) influenza virus used by the Dutch group of Ron Fouchier at the Erasmus Medical Center in Rotterdam, the Netherlands was an isolate obtained from Indonesia, whereas the virus used by Yoshihiro Kawaoka at the University of Wisconsin-Madison had been isolated in Viet Nam. The outcome of this meeting may shed light on the similarity of these 2 isolates and the extent to which this may have determined the outcome of the projects. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "[By: Helen Branswell]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nDan Lucey\nGeorgetown University\n<DRL23@georgetown.edu>\n\n A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nThe controversy relates to 2 studies, done by Dutch and American researchers, which reportedly show how H5N1 flu viruses could be made to spread like seasonal flu viruses among ferrets. Others attending the meeting will be the researchers themselves, people who reviewed the research proposals to see whether they triggered dual-use concerns (both when the work was in the proposal stage and when the studies were being readied for publication) and representatives of the journals Science and Nature, which plan to publish the studies. \n\nPeople looking for solutions to broader issues such as whether and where similar research should be conducted in future may need to dial down their expectations for the meeting. \n\nOne of the conditions the researchers and journals made before tentatively agreeing to redact the studies was that the full details of how the work was done would be shared with other scientists and public health officials on a need-to-know basis. Such viruses could not be tested in humans, and ferrets are considered the best -- though not foolproof -- animal model for predicting how flu viruses will act in people. \n\nRepresentatives of the Vietnamese and Indonesian labs that provided the source viruses have not yet indicated whether they'll attend, Feig said. And that work probably won't happen at this meeting, said Feig, adding that people with the expertise needed to set up that type of system won't be in the room. \n\nPotentially among them will be representatives of the Vietnamese and Indonesian laboratories that provided the original viruses on which the research was done. \n\nA list of the participants and their declarations of interest will be posted on the WHO website the day the meeting begins. \n\nA U.S. panel of biosecurity experts is urging that the studies not be published in full, arguing the details of how the work was done would be dangerous in the wrong hands. The framework, ratified last spring [2011], is meant to ensure that countries that share viruses with foreign scientists will in turn share in the benefits that flow from that research.
