"https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=999620", "date": "2012-01-04 12:32:50", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA: CHINA (HONG KONG) H5N1, GULL\n*********************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 3 Jan 2012\nSource: GovHK (Hong Kong Special Administrative Region Government)\npress release [edited]\nhttp://www.info.gov.hk/gia/general/201201/03/P201201030396.htm\n\n\nBlack-headed gulls test positive for H5 virus\n---------------------------------------------\nA spokesman for the Agriculture, Fisheries and Conservation Department\n(AFCD) said today (3 Jan 2012) that 2 dead black-headed gulls found in\nTuen Mun and Lantau have tested positive for the H5 avian influenza\nvirus in preliminary testing, adding that further confirmatory tests\nare being conducted.\n\nThe 1st gull was collected at EcoPark, 133 Lung Mun Road, Tuen Mun, on\n30 Dec 2011 while the 2nd one was found at a drain near Sha Lo Wan\nSoccer Pitch, Lantau, on 1 Jan 2012.\n\nThe black-headed gull is a common winter visitor.\n\nThe spokesman said there were no poultry farms within 3 kilometres [2\nmi] of where the dead birds were found.\n\nThe AFCD has phoned poultry farmers to remind them to strengthen\nprecautionary and biosecurity measures against avian influenza.\nLetters have been issued to farmers, pet bird shop owners and licence\nholders of pet poultry and racing pigeons, reminding them that proper\nprecautions must be taken.\n\nThe spokesman said the department would conduct frequent inspections\nof poultry farms and the wholesale market to ensure that proper\nprecautions against avian influenza have been implemented. The\ndepartment will continue its wild bird monitoring and surveillance.\n\n'People should avoid personal contact with wild birds and live poultry\nand their droppings. They should clean their hands thoroughly after\ncoming into contact with them. The public can call 1823 for follow-up\nif they come across suspicious sick or dead birds, including the\ncarcasses of wild birds and poultry,' the spokesman said.\n\nThe Food and Environmental Hygiene Department (FEHD) will continue to\nbe vigilant over imported live poultry as well as live poultry stalls.\nIt will also remind stall operators to maintain good hygiene.\n\nThe Department of Health will keep up with its health education to\nremind the public to maintain strict personal and environmental\nhygiene to prevent avian influenza.\n\nThe AFCD, the FEHD, the Customs and Excise Department, and the Police\nwill strive to deter the illegal import of poultry and birds into Hong\nKong to minimise the risk of avian influenza outbreaks caused by\nimported poultry and birds that have not gone through inspection and\nquarantine.\n\nAll relevant government departments will continue to remain highly\nvigilant and strictly enforce preventive measures against avian\ninfluenza.\n\nHealth advice is available from the 'H5N1 Health Advice' on the AFCD\nwebsite at http://www.afcd.gov.hk.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Two H5N1 outbreaks involving poultry and wild birds in Hong Kong were\nreported to OIE in December 2011\n(http://web.oie.int/wahis/public.php?page=single_report&pop=1&reportid=11404).\n\nThe black-headed gull (_Chroicocephalus [=Larus] ridibundus_) is a\nsmall gull which breeds in much of Europe and Asia, and also in\ncoastal eastern Canada. Most of the population is migratory, wintering\nfurther south, but some birds in the milder westernmost areas of\nEurope are resident. A picture of this species can be found at\nhttp://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Chroicocephalus_ridibundus_(summer).jpg.\nBecause gulls are very susceptible to H5N1, it is very unlikely that\nthey can carry the virus long distances through migration.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the area can be found at\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/1BC7. - Mod.PMB]", "summary": "AVIAN INFLUENZA: CHINA (HONG KONG) H5N1, GULL\n*********************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n The AFCD, the FEHD, the Customs and Excise Department, and the Police\nwill strive to deter the illegal import of poultry and birds into Hong\nKong to minimise the risk of avian influenza outbreaks caused by\nimported poultry and birds that have not gone through inspection and\nquarantine. A spokesman for the Agriculture, Fisheries and Conservation Department\n(AFCD) said today (3 Jan 2012) that 2 dead black-headed gulls found in\nTuen Mun and Lantau have tested positive for the H5 avian influenza\nvirus in preliminary testing, adding that further confirmatory tests\nare being conducted. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Two H5N1 outbreaks involving poultry and wild birds in Hong Kong were\nreported to OIE in December 2011\n \n\nThe spokesman said the department would conduct frequent inspections\nof poultry farms and the wholesale market to ensure that proper\nprecautions against avian influenza have been implemented. The public can call 1823 for follow-up\nif they come across suspicious sick or dead birds, including the\ncarcasses of wild birds and poultry,' the spokesman said. Letters have been issued to farmers, pet bird shop owners and licence\nholders of pet poultry and racing pigeons, reminding them that proper\nprecautions must be taken. The Department of Health will keep up with its health education to\nremind the public to maintain strict personal and environmental\nhygiene to prevent avian influenza. All relevant government departments will continue to remain highly\nvigilant and strictly enforce preventive measures against avian\ninfluenza. Most of the population is migratory, wintering\nfurther south, but some birds in the milder westernmost areas of\n \n\nThe spokesman said there were no poultry farms within 3 kilometres [2\nmi] of where the dead birds were found. is a\nsmall gull which breeds in much of Europe and Asia, and also in\ncoastal eastern Canada.", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2012-01-03 00:00:00", "1823-03-25 00:00:00", "2011-12-25 00:00:00", "2012-01-01 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Hong Kong Special Administrative Region Government", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "HONG KONG", "country": "Hong Kong"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Hong \n Kong", "country": "Thailand"}, {"location": "CHINA", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "Hong Kong"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "997708", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human: China (GD) H5N1", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=997708", "date": "2012-01-02 20:31:11", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN: CHINA (GUANGDONG) H5N1\n**********************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 2 Jan 2012\nSource: Xinhua News Agency [edited]\nhttp://news.xinhuanet.com/english/china/2012-01/02/c_131339151.htm\n\n\nHealth authorities in south China's Guangdong province have identified\nthe virus that led to the death of a local bus driver, although the\nsource of the virus remains unclear, a local disease control center\nsaid Monday [2 Jan 2012]. The highly pathogenic avian A/(H5N1)\ninfluenza virus is carried by poultry and birds, according to a\nstatement released by the Shenzhen Disease Control Center.\n\nGenetic analysis of the virus has indicated that it is similar to a\nvirus found in dead migrant birds in a 2011 avian influenza outbreak\nin Hong Kong. However, it is not known if the case in Guangdong is\nrelated to migrant birds, the center said.\n\nA 39-year-old man from the Bao'an district of Shenzhen was\nhospitalized for a fever on 21 Dec 2011 and tested positive for the\nH5N1 avian influenza virus. He died of multiple organ failure Saturday\nafternoon [31 Dec 2011].\n\nPoultry and migrant birds are the only vectors for human H5N1\ninfection, according to He Jianfeng, director of the Epidemics Studies\nInstitute of the Guangdong Disease Control Center. However, he said\nthat there is no clear evidence that the bus driver had close contact\nwith poultry or migrant birds. Health authorities are still working to\nfigure out where and when he acquired the virus. Although it is highly\npathogenic, the virus cannot be spread from person-to-person, the\ncenter said in a previous statement, adding that there is no need for\npeople to panic.\n\nThe Guangdong Department of Agriculture also announced on Saturday\nthat no epidemics of avian flu among poultry have been reported in the\nprovince.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[The origin of the bus driver's infection remains unknown, other than\nthat the infecting virus is closely related to a virus isolated from\nmigrant birds in Hong Kong in 2011. A ProMED-mail correspondent has\ncommented that this information probably implies that the virus\nisolated from the victim retains an avian-type alpha 2-3 sialic acid\nreceptor site. - Mod.CP]\n\n[Shenzhen can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map\nat http://healthmap.org/r/1B7i. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]", "summary": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN: CHINA (GUANGDONG) H5N1\n**********************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Source: Xinhua News Agency [edited]\nhttp://news.xinhuanet.com/english/china/2012-01/02/c_131339151.htm\n\n\nHealth authorities in south China's Guangdong province have identified\nthe virus that led to the death of a local bus driver, although the\nsource of the virus remains unclear, a local disease control center\nsaid Monday [2 Jan 2012]. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[The origin of the bus driver's infection remains unknown, other than\nthat the infecting virus is closely related to a virus isolated from\nmigrant birds in Hong Kong in 2011. A ProMED-mail correspondent has\ncommented that this information probably implies that the virus\nisolated from the victim retains an avian-type alpha 2-3 sialic acid\nreceptor site. Although it is highly\npathogenic, the virus cannot be spread from person-to-person, the\ncenter said in a previous statement, adding that there is no need for\npeople to panic. \n\nGenetic analysis of the virus has indicated that it is similar to a\nvirus found in dead migrant birds in a 2011 avian influenza outbreak\nin Hong Kong.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2011-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-27 00:00:00", "2021-03-29 00:00:00", "2011-12-21 00:00:00", "2012-01-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "Hong Kong"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "CHINA", "country": "China"}, {"location": "GUANGDONG", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Guangdong", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Shenzhen", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Guangdong province", "country": "China"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "986623", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (78): China (HK) H5N1, poultry, susp. RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=986623", "date": "2011-12-21 20:05:08", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (78): CHINA (HONG KONG), H5N1, POULTRY, SUSPECTED,\nREQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n******************************************************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 21 Dec 2011\nSource: CNN News [edited]\nhttp://www.cnn.com/2011/12/21/world/asia/hong-kong-bird-flu/index.html\n\n\nThe Hong Kong government said Wed [21 Dec 2011] that more than 17 000\nchickens were being culled at a poultry market after a chicken carcass\ntested positive for avian flu.\n\nThe territory's Director of Agriculture, Fisheries & Conservation\ndeclared the Cheung Sha Wan Temporary Wholesale Poultry Market an\ninfected place, the government said in a statement.\n\nLocal farmers will be prevented from sending chickens to the market\nfor 21 days.\n\nThe government said that it was working to trace the origin of the\nchicken, which was infected with the H5N1 avian influenza virus, but\nthat it did not know at this point whether it was from a local farm or\nwas imported.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Notably, on 19 Dec 2011, the HK authorities submitted to the OIE an\n'Immediate Notification' on the discovery of an H5N1-positive case 'in\na Black-headed Gull (_Chroicocephalus ridibundus_), which had been\ncollected on 13 Dec 2011 at 7 Tai Yuk Road, Yuen Long. The\nBlack-headed Gull is a common winter visitor in Hong Kong. The\nfollowing epidemiological comments were included:\n\n'An intensive surveillance system is in place for all poultry farms,\npoultry markets, and pet bird shops in Hong Kong. The H5N1-infected\nwild bird was detected in the framework of the ongoing surveillance\nprogram on wild birds. No spread of disease was evident. As this was a\nwild bird case, the date the event ended is the same as the date the\nbird was found (i.e. 13 Dec 2011). Important note by the OIE Animal\nHealth Information Department: According to Chapter 10.4 on avian\ninfluenza of the OIE Terrestrial Animal Health Code (2011), the\nnotification of this outbreak does not change the HPAI free status of\nHong Kong and should not affect trade of poultry and their products,\nsince the bird involved in this outbreak does not fall within the OIE\ndefinition of poultry.'\n\nSee, with map, at\nhttp://web.oie.int/wahis/public.php?page=event_summary&reportid=11388.\n\nThe current identification of H5N1 in domestic fowl, if officially\nconfirmed, will probably change the HPAI-free status of Hong Kong. -\nMod.AS]", "summary": "According to Chapter 10.4 on avian\ninfluenza of the OIE Terrestrial Animal Health Code (2011), the\nnotification of this outbreak does not change the HPAI free status of\nHong Kong and should not affect trade of poultry and their products,\nsince the bird involved in this outbreak does not fall within the OIE\ndefinition of poultry.' Communicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Notably, on 19 Dec 2011, the HK authorities submitted to the OIE an\n'Immediate Notification' on the discovery of an H5N1-positive case 'in\na Black-headed Gull (_Chroicocephalus ridibundus_), which had been\ncollected on 13 Dec 2011 at 7 Tai Yuk Road, Yuen Long. *****************************************************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n The government said that it was working to trace the origin of the\nchicken, which was infected with the H5N1 avian influenza virus, but\nthat it did not know at this point whether it was from a local farm or\nwas imported. The Hong Kong government said Wed [21 Dec 2011] that more than 17 000\nchickens were being culled at a poultry market after a chicken carcass\ntested positive for avian flu. The\nfollowing epidemiological comments were included:\n\n'An intensive surveillance system is in place for all poultry farms,\npoultry markets, and pet bird shops in Hong Kong. As this was a\nwild bird case, the date the event ended is the same as the date the\nbird was found (i.e. 13 Dec 2011). The H5N1-infected\nwild bird was detected in the framework of the ongoing surveillance\nprogram on wild birds.", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2011-03-25 00:00:00", "1978-03-25 00:00:00", "2011-12-19 00:00:00", "2011-12-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "Hong Kong"}, {"location": "CHINA", "country": "China"}, {"location": "HONG KONG", "country": "Hong Kong"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "998693", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (02): China (GD) H5N1", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=998693", "date": "2012-01-03 17:51:44", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (02): CHINA (GUANGDONG) H5N1\n***************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 3 Jan 2012\nSource: The Standard [edited]\nhttp://www.thestandard.com.hk/news_detail.asp?we_cat=11&art_id=118460&sid=34949960&con_type=1&d_str=20120103&fc=1\n\n\nBird flu fears spread last night [2 Jan 2012] after Shenzhen experts\nrevealed the virus that killed a bus driver is similar to the one\nfound in a dead migratory bird in Yuen Long last month [December\n2011]. Health officials are racing to track down the source of the\n[mutant ?] H5N1 amid growing fears. The 39-year-old Shenzhen driver\ndied on Saturday [31 Dec 2011] in the 1st reported case of bird flu in\na human in 18 months in China.\n\nHong Kong has declared a 'control zone' banning the import of live and\nfrozen chickens and poultry products from inside a 13-kilometer [8 mi]\nradius of the driver's home in the Shaijing area of Baoan district.\nThe ban will be effective until 21 Jan 2012 -- 2 days before Lunar New\nYear [celebration].\n\nThe Shenzhen Centre for Disease Control said initial genetic analysis\nshows the virus that killed the man is similar to that in the Yuen\nLong bird. However, the genes of the virus that killed him are not as\nclose to the virus found in dead poultry in Hong Kong, the centre\nadded. The virus found on the victim is H5N1 clade 2.3.2.1. The center\nsaid that although the mutated [?] virus is highly pathogenic, it\ncannot be spread from human to human so people do not need to panic.\n\nFurther analysis is under way to confirm whether [the bus driver]\ncaught the virus through wild birds. There is no evidence that\nsuggests this virus is more contagious or deadly,' said centre officer\nWu Chunli. 'Natural mutations happen in all flu viruses.'\n\nThe victim developed a fever on 21 Dec 2011 and was sent to hospital\non 25 Dec 2011 with severe pneumonia. On Saturday [31 Dec 2011] he was\nconfirmed to have H5N1. The center said earlier that Chen regularly\nvisited the wetland at Waterlands Resort for morning exercise. About\n120 people who had close contact with him have not developed any\nabnormal symptoms, health authorities said.\n\nThe Guangdong Department of Agriculture announced on Saturday that no\nepidemic of bird flu among poultry has been reported in the province.\nHong Kong infectious diseases specialist Lo Wing-lok criticized the\ncenter's report as 'confusing' and 'nonsense.' Lo said: 'They cannot\nsay that the virus is similar to that found in wild birds and say the\nman may have contracted the virus from wild birds. There is no\nevidence in the whole world that suggests people contract H5N1 through\nwild birds. It is always through poultry. Does that mean the virus\nsimply fell from the sky?'\n\nLo said H5N1 clade 2.3.2.1. is found in many H5N1 cases and is not\nespecially deadly. He said further analysis is needed to compare this\nvirus with that found on a dead chicken in Cheung Sha Wan last month\n[December 2011]. But Lo stressed mutation does not mean it is more\ndeadly because flu viruses always mutate naturally. He called on\npeople to wash their hands after handling live chickens and to cook\nthem thoroughly before consumption.\n\nThe government said on 20 Dec 2011 that Hong Kong would have no live\nchicken supplies for 21 days after a dead chicken at the Cheung Sha\nWan poultry market was found to have H5N1. The government culled 19\n451 birds at the market, including 15 569 chickens.\n\n[Byline: Phila Siu]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[This report does not add much clarification, apart from the\ninformation that the deceased Shenzhen driver had a habit of spending\ntime at the wetland of the Waterlands Resort. However, Dr Lo\nWing-lok's strictures regarding the use of the term 'mutant' are\nrelevant.\n\nReaders' attention is draw to an 'Original Paper' newly compiled by\nFluTrackers.com, entitled: 'A Summary of Worldwide Human H5N1 Cases in\n2011', that is fully sourced including charts, graphs, and maps, all\nor part of which may be freely reproduced (see\nhttp://www.flutrackers.com/forum/showthread.php?t=179069).\n\nThe Abstract reads: 'In 2011, 59 human cases of H5N1 were reported\nfrom around the world, a 23 percent increase over 2010. 5 countries\nreported cases in 2011, Bangladesh, Cambodia, China, Egypt, and\nIndonesia. Almost half of the 59 cases (about 45 percent) were\nchildren under 10 years old. The fatality rate did not appreciably\ndecline in 2011, about half of all the reported cases died. 4 small\nfamily clusters were noted during the year. The source of exposure for\nall of the cluster cases has been reported as exposure to sick and\ndying poultry. None of these clusters resulted in sustained\nhuman-to-human transmission. Based on an analysis of the 2011 data,\nthe potential for a virulent H5N1 pandemic has not diminished.'\n\nThe document begins: 'The big H5N1 news of 2011 was the bioethical\ndebate surrounding the publication of the details of genetic research\nby 2 groups of scientists who were able to create a laboratory strain\nof H5N1 that maintained its virulence and was easily transmissible\n[among ferrets] in aerosolized droplets. A few of the many media\nreports and commentaries are referenced in this FluTrackers report\n[http://www.flutrackers.com/forum/showthread.php?t=177126]. Equally\nas important, but without the accompanying media hype, is that there\nwas a 23 percent increase in the number of worldwide H5N1 human cases\nover the number of cases in 2010. In 2011, at least 59 cases were\nrecorded; in 2010 the total was only 48. The following summary of\nhuman cases from 2011 is generally organized according to the outlined\npresented last year in 'A Summary of Human H5N1 Cases in 2010'\n(http://www.flutrackers.com/forum/showthread.php?t=157504).\n\nPerhaps of greatest interest is the section on High H5N1 Infection\nRates Among Small Children. 'Since 2009, there has been an observable\ntrend of an increasing number of H5N1 infections among very young\nchildren. This should not be surprising since H5N1 is a novel\ninfluenza virus, and young children are more susceptible to influenza\nviruses in general. What is surprising is the recovery rate (that is,\nlow CFR) for this age group. As virulent as H5N1 is, many of the\ninfected children survive. The children survive at a much higher rate\nthan their infected adult counterparts. These children would not have\ntime to build up cross-protective immunity, so the recovery process\nfor these young people is worthy of further study. Also, most of these\nchild infections do not occur in family clusters so questions arise\nabout the exposure source for these children. What is the nature of\ncontact between exposed poultry and these young children? Is there a\nmild asymptomatic strain of H5N1 circulating in some countries?' But\nperhaps there is greater resort to treatment with neuraminidase\ninhibitors in the case of young children?\n\nThe original diagrams in this paper provide an elegant and easily\nassimilable condensation of the information contained in the text. -\nMod.CP]\n\n[The HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Shenzhen can be found at\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/1B7i. - Mod.MPP]", "summary": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (02): CHINA (GUANGDONG) H5N1\n***************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nThe document begins: 'The big H5N1 news of 2011 was the bioethical\ndebate surrounding the publication of the details of genetic research\nby 2 groups of scientists who were able to create a laboratory strain\nof H5N1 that maintained its virulence and was easily transmissible\n Readers' attention is draw to an 'Original Paper' newly compiled by\nFluTrackers.com, entitled: 'A Summary of Worldwide Human H5N1 Cases in\n2011', that is fully sourced including charts, graphs, and maps, all\nor part of which may be freely reproduced (see\nhttp://www.flutrackers.com/forum/showthread.php?t=179069). The following summary of\nhuman cases from 2011 is generally organized according to the outlined\npresented last year in 'A Summary of Human H5N1 Cases in 2010'\n Equally\nas important, but without the accompanying media hype, is that there\nwas a 23 percent increase in the number of worldwide H5N1 human cases\nover the number of cases in 2010. \n\n\nBird flu fears spread last night [2 Jan 2012] after Shenzhen experts\nrevealed the virus that killed a bus driver is similar to the one\nfound in a dead migratory bird in Yuen Long last month Lo said: 'They cannot\nsay that the virus is similar to that found in wild birds and say the\nman may have contracted the virus from wild birds. \n\nThe Shenzhen Centre for Disease Control said initial genetic analysis\nshows the virus that killed the man is similar to that in the Yuen\nLong bird. The government said on 20 Dec 2011 that Hong Kong would have no live\nchicken supplies for 21 days after a dead chicken at the Cheung Sha\nWan poultry market was found to have H5N1. The 39-year-old Shenzhen driver\ndied on Saturday [31 Dec 2011] in the 1st reported case of bird flu in\na human in 18 months in China. However, the genes of the virus that killed him are not as\nclose to the virus found in dead poultry in Hong Kong, the centre\nadded. The center\nsaid that although the mutated [?] virus is highly pathogenic, it\ncannot be spread from human to human so people do not need to panic. He said further analysis is needed to compare this\nvirus with that found on a dead chicken in Cheung Sha Wan last month\n This should not be surprising since H5N1 is a novel\ninfluenza virus, and young children are more susceptible to influenza\nviruses in general. The source of exposure for\nall of the cluster cases has been reported as exposure to sick and\ndying poultry. 5 countries\nreported cases in 2011, Bangladesh, Cambodia, China, Egypt, and\nIndonesia. Hong Kong has declared a 'control zone' banning the import of live and\nfrozen chickens and poultry products from inside a 13-kilometer [8 mi]\nradius of the driver's home in the Shaijing area of Baoan district. There is no evidence that\nsuggests this virus is more contagious or deadly,' said centre officer\nWu Chunli. ' These children would not have\ntime to build up cross-protective immunity, so the recovery process\nfor these young people is worthy of further study. However, Dr Lo\nWing-lok's strictures regarding the use of the term 'mutant' are\nrelevant.\n\n Also, most of these\nchild infections do not occur in family clusters so questions arise\nabout the exposure source for these children. About\n120 people who had close contact with him have not developed any\nabnormal symptoms, health authorities said. Since 2009, there has been an observable\ntrend of an increasing number of H5N1 infections among very young\nchildren. There is no\nevidence in the whole world that suggests people contract H5N1 through\nwild birds.", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2011-03-25 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2011-12-20 00:00:00", "2012-01-02 00:00:00", "2011-12-31 00:00:00", "2011-12-25 00:00:00", "2011-12-21 00:00:00", "2012-01-03 00:00:00", "2009-03-25 00:00:00", "2012-01-21 00:00:00", "2021-03-27 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Shenzhen", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Egypt", "country": "Egypt"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "Hong Kong"}, {"location": "Baoan", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Indonesia", "country": "Indonesia"}, {"location": "CHINA", "country": "China"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Cambodia", "country": "Cambodia"}, {"location": "Bangladesh", "country": "Bangladesh"}, {"location": "GUANGDONG", "country": "China"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "989434", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (80): China (HK) H5N1, poultry, wild bird", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=989434", "date": "2011-12-24 10:49:56", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (80): CHINA (HK) H5N1, POULTRY, WILD BIRD\n*********************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat, 24 Dec 2011\nSource: Today Online (Singapore) [edited]\nhttp://www.todayonline.com/World/EDC111224-0000060/HK-finds-second-case-of-bird-flu\n\nHK finds second case of bird flu\n---------------------------------\nThe Hong Kong authorities say a 2nd dead bird in a week [but 3rd in a\nfortnight; see comment] has tested positive for a dangerous strain of\nbird flu, raising health concerns in the city.\n\nThe agricultural department said yesterday that lab tests confirmed an\nOriental magpie robin found dead on 17 Dec 2011 in the New Territories\nwas infected with H5N1 avian influenza.\n\nThis type of robin is commonly found in Hong Kong.\n\nOn Wednesday, Hong Kong raised its alert level to 'serious' after a\nchicken at a wholesale market tested positive for bird flu. A total of\n19 451 birds, including more than 15 000 chickens, were culled as a\nprecaution.\n\nBut Secretary for Food and Health York Chow said none of the birds\nculled had tested positive for the disease. No local poultry workers\nhave been found to be infected either.\n\n'According to the information gathered from the mainland, they do not\nhave any abnormalities in the mainland farms that supply to Hong Kong\nso we cannot conclude if this is a bird that came from the mainland or\nHong Kong. We have checked all the farms, and all the places that\nwould have chickens ... I can only say that we are safer than what we\nsuspected earlier on.'\n\nThe government said 2 new measures will be put in place as a\nprecaution.\n\nIt will set up a system for collecting dead birds at the wholesale\npoultry market. The Agriculture, Fisheries and Conservation Department\nwill also be on duty 24 hours a day to gather information from traders\nabout dead birds.\n\n'Hong Kong has the best H5N1 contingency plan to be found in any part\nof the world,' said Dr Yuen Kwok-yung, chairman of infectious diseases\nat the University of Hong Kong's department of microbiology. 'We\nshould not panic. Every winter there is increased H5N1 activity in\npoultry and migratory birds.'\n\nThe Chinese Ministry of Agriculture said it has ordered veterinarians\nin Guangzhou and Shenzhen - cities nearest to Hong Kong - to prepare\nfor emergencies and strengthen surveillance.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nNati Elkin\n<nati@poultrymed.com>\n\n\n\n[Hong Kong's authorities have submitted to the OIE a notification\nconcerning 2 outbreaks of H5N1 on 23 Dec 2011; see, with map, at\nhttp://web.oie.int/wahis/public.php?page=single_report&pop=1&reportid=11404.\n\nThe notification includes the following description of the 'affected\npopulations':\n1. An Oriental Magpie Robin (_Copsychus saularis_) was collected on 17\nDec 2011 at Tin Shui Wai. The Oriental Magpie Robin is a common local\nresident in Hong Kong'.\n2. A chicken carcass tested positive for highly pathogenic H5N1 avian\ninfluenza virus during regular surveillance on 20 Dec 2011.\n\nThe following epidemiological comments were included:\n\n'An intensive surveillance system is in place for all poultry farms,\npoultry markets and pet bird shops in Hong Kong. The H5N1 infected\nwild bird was detected in ongoing surveillance program on wild birds.\nThe date of the outbreak concerning wild birds ended is the same as\nthe date the bird was found (17 Dec 2011).\nA total of 19 451 poultry, including 15 569 chickens, 810 pigeons,\n1950 pheasants and 1122 silky fowls were culled in the Cheung Sha Wan\nTemporary Wholesale Poultry Market on 21 Dec 2011. Importation of live\npoultry and movement of poultry in local farms is banned for 21 days.\nSurveillance and monitoring of local chicken farms has been stepped\nup. So far, no H5 virus was detected in samples taken from the 30\nchicken farms in Hong Kong'.\n\nIn fact, the current 2 'outbreaks' are the 2nd and 3rd during the last\n2 weeks. On 19 Dec 2011, the HK authorities submitted to the OIE an\n'Immediate Notification' on the discovery of an H5N1-positive case in\na Black-headed Gull (_Chroicocephalus ridibundus_), which had been\ncollected on 13 Dec 2011. The Black-headed Gull is a common winter\nvisitor in Hong Kong. Suspected infection in a woman who came in\ncontact with the bird was excluded (see 20111216.3611).\n\nThe oriental magpie robin, _Copsychus saularis_ (Order: Passeriformes,\nFamily: Muscicapidae) is an insectivorous species which is a resident\nbreeder in tropical southern Asia. It is a commonly found species in\nHong Kong; according to birdwatchers, usually seen at large urban\nparks and the countryside, protected by law. This bird was found\ninfected by H5N1 for the 1st time in Hong Kong in Jan 2006; see at\n20060120.0183. - Mod.AS\n\n\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at:\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/1s3-]", "summary": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (80): CHINA (HK) H5N1, POULTRY, WILD BIRD\n*********************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Date: Sat, 24 Dec 2011\nSource: Today Online (Singapore) [edited]\nhttp://www.todayonline.com/World/EDC111224-0000060/HK-finds-second-case-of-bird-flu\n\nHK finds second case of bird flu\n On 19 Dec 2011, the HK authorities submitted to the OIE an\n'Immediate Notification' on the discovery of an H5N1-positive case in\na Black-headed Gull (_Chroicocephalus ridibundus_), which had been\ncollected on 13 Dec 2011. \n\nThe agricultural department said yesterday that lab tests confirmed an\nOriental magpie robin found dead on 17 Dec 2011 in the New Territories\nwas infected with H5N1 avian influenza. A total of 19 451 poultry, including 15 569 chickens, 810 pigeons,\n1950 pheasants and 1122 silky fowls were culled in the Cheung Sha Wan\nTemporary Wholesale Poultry Market on 21 Dec 2011. The Hong Kong authorities say a 2nd dead bird in a week [but 3rd in a\nfortnight; see comment] has tested positive for a dangerous strain of\nbird flu, raising health concerns in the city. \n\n'Hong Kong has the best H5N1 contingency plan to be found in any part\nof the world,' said Dr Yuen Kwok-yung, chairman of infectious diseases\nat the University of Hong Kong's department of microbiology. The H5N1 infected\nwild bird was detected in ongoing surveillance program on wild birds.\n \n\nThe Chinese Ministry of Agriculture said it has ordered veterinarians\nin Guangzhou and Shenzhen - cities nearest to Hong Kong - to prepare\nfor emergencies and strengthen surveillance. \n\nThe oriental magpie robin, _Copsychus saularis_ (Order: Passeriformes,\nFamily: Muscicapidae) is an insectivorous species which is a resident\nbreeder in tropical southern Asia. [Hong Kong's authorities have submitted to the OIE a notification\nconcerning 2 outbreaks of H5N1 on 23 Dec 2011; see, with map, at\nhttp://web.oie.int/wahis/public.php?page=single_report&pop=1&reportid=11404. \n\nThe notification includes the following description of the 'affected\npopulations':\n1. A total of\n19 451 birds, including more than 15 000 chickens, were culled as a\nprecaution. This bird was found\ninfected by H5N1 for the 1st time in Hong Kong in Jan 2006; see at\n20060120.0183. - Mod. The Agriculture, Fisheries and Conservation Department\nwill also be on duty 24 hours a day to gather information from traders\nabout dead birds.", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2011-12-21 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00", "1980-03-25 00:00:00", "1950-03-25 00:00:00", "2011-12-19 00:00:00", "2011-03-25 00:00:00", "2011-12-25 00:00:00", "2006-01-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Shenzhen", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Guangzhou", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "Hong Kong"}, {"location": "Hong Kong '", "country": "Hong Kong"}, {"location": "Hong Kong 's", "country": "Hong Kong"}, {"location": "CHINA", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Singapore", "country": "Singapore"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "987535", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (79): China (HK) H5N1, poultry, conf.", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=987535", "date": "2011-12-22 12:07:22", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (79): CHINA (HONG KONG) H5N1, POULTRY, CONFIRMED\n****************************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n******\n[1]\nDate: Wed 21 Dec 2011\nSource: Hong Kong Government News [edited]\nhttp://www.news.gov.hk/en/categories/health/html/2011/12/20111221_015612.shtml\n\n\nBird flu prompts market chicken cull\n------------------------------------\nMore than 17 000 chickens will be culled at the Cheung Sha Wan\nTemporary Wholesale Poultry Market today [21 Dec 2011] after a chicken\ncarcass there tested positive for the H5N1 avian influenza virus. The\nmarket will be closed until 12 Jan 2012.\n\nThe Director of Agriculture, Fisheries and Conservation declared the\nmarket an infected place after Secretary for Food and Health Dr York\nChow raised the response level for bird flu to 'serious' from 'alert'\nafter the discovery of the virus in the carcass yesterday.\n\nLocal farms are stopped from sending chickens to the market for 21\ndays. The Agriculture, Fisheries and Conservation department will step\nup farm inspections and collect more samples for tests.\n\nThe government is tracing the source of the carcass and it is not\nknown whether the chicken was from a local farm or imported.\n\nAll 30 chicken farms were inspected yesterday. No abnormality was\ndetected. Live poultry imports including day-old chicks are suspended\nfor 21 days. Mainland authorities say no abnormality has been found at\nregistered live poultry farms.\n\n'It is unfortunate that an avian influenza case is detected before the\nwinter solstice, necessitating a halt to the supply of live chickens.\nI understand that it will cause inconvenience to the public, and the\npoultry trade will also encounter losses,' Dr Chow said. 'However, to\nsafeguard public health, we need to adopt decisive and effective\nmeasures to prevent and control the spread of the virus.'\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nDr Irene Lai, MD\nInternational SOS (Australasia) Pty Ltd\n<irene.lai@internationalsos.com>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Wed 21 Dec 2011\nSource: Press release, The Government of the Hong Kong Special\nAdministrative Region - Centre for Health Protection [edited]\nhttp://www.chp.gov.hk/en/content/599/24252.html\n\n\nCHP enhances surveillance on human influenza A(H5N1) infection\n--------------------------------------------------------------\nThe Centre for Health Protection (CHP) of the Department of Health\n(DH) has enhanced its surveillance on human influenza A (H5N1)\ninfection after the government has raised the response level for avian\ninfluenza from 'Alert' to 'Serious' as a chicken carcass sample taken\nfrom the Cheung Sha Wan Temporary Wholesale Poultry Market (Wholesale\nPoultry Market) was tested positive of the highly pathogenic H5N1\navian influenza virus.\n\nA telephone hotline has been set up to answer public enquiries today\n[21 Dec 2011] from 9am to 6pm.\n\nCHP is carrying out medical surveillance of poultry wholesalers and\nworkers in the Wholesale Poultry Market as well as local chicken\nfarmers to follow up on their health condition.\n\nAt the moment, there is no human case of avian influenza infection in\nHong Kong. DH and the Hospital Authority (HA) have enhanced the work\non testing of human infection of avian influenza. Particular attention\nwill be paid to those who visited or worked in the Cheung Sha Wan\nWholesale Market.\n\nA spokesman for the CHP has called on members of the public to seek\nmedical treatment immediately if they develop symptoms of high fever\nor influenza-like illness. Public and private hospitals as well as\nclinics should report to CHP immediately when there is any suspected\ncase of avian influenza.\n\nThe CHP has written to all medical practitioners alerting them of the\nlatest development and has liaised closely with HA to step up\nsurveillance. The department has also sent letters to institutions,\nelderly homes and schools to remind them to be vigilant against avian\ninfluenza.\n\nThe spokesman reminded the public to remain vigilant against avian\ninfluenza infection and to observe the following measures:\n\n- Avoid direct contact with poultry and birds or their droppings; if\ncontact is made, wash hands thoroughly with soap and water;\n- Cook poultry and eggs thoroughly before eating;\n- Wash hands frequently;\n- Cover nose and mouth while sneezing or coughing, hold the [mucus]\nwith tissue and put it into a covered dustbin;\n- Avoid crowded places and contact with sick people with fever;\n- Wear a mask when you have respiratory symptoms or need to take care\nof patients with fever;\n- When you have fever and influenza-like illnesses during a trip or\nwhen coming back to Hong Kong, consult doctors promptly and reveal\nyour travel history.\n\nFor further information on avian influenza, please visit the CHP\nwebsite: http://www.chp.gov.hk.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nDr Irene Lai, MD\nInternational SOS (Australasia) Pty Ltd\n<irene.lai@internationalsos.com>\n\n[The Hong Kong Training Portal on Infection Control and Infectious\nDisease maintains a web-page dedicated to avian influenza (AI) at\nhttp://icidportal.ha.org.hk/sites/en/webpages/avian%20influenza.aspx\n\nThe following issues are among those addressed by the Hospital\nAuthority (HA) in documents available on line:\n- HA AI contingency plan\n- HA AI infection control plan\n- HA fact sheet on avian influenza\n- HA fact sheet on antiviral therapy against influenza\n- HA guideline on management approach of ILI and CAP suspected of\navian influenza\n- Guideline on Transport of Clinical Specimens and Infectious\nSubstances\n- HA Operational Plan on Laboratory Testing for Human Influenza A\n(H5N1) Infection\n- Supplementary Guideline on Handling of Clinical Specimens in the\nLaboratory.\n\nThe scheme developed and applied by the HK authorities in preventing\nspread of H5N1, is exemplary. - Mod.AS\n\nThe interactive HealthMap/ProMED map for Hong Kong is available at:\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/1s3- - CopyEd.EJP]", "summary": Source: Press release, The Government of the Hong Kong Special\nAdministrative Region - Centre for Health Protection [edited]\n", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": ["influenza-like illness"], "event_date": ["1979-03-25 00:00:00", "2012-01-12 00:00:00", "2011-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "Hong Kong"}, {"location": "CHINA", "country": "China"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "HONG KONG", "country": "Hong Kong"}, {"location": "the Hong Kong Special \n Administrative Region - Centre for Health Protection", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "969083", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (76): India (JH) crow, H5N1", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=969083", "date": "2011-12-05 14:19:18", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (76) - INDIA: (JHARKHAND) CROW, H5N1\n****************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 3 Dec 2011\nSource: Downtoearth.org [edited]\nhttp://www.downtoearth.org.in/content/avian-flu-killing-jharkhand-crows-virology-institute\n\n\n\nAvian flu killing Jharkhand crows: virology institute\n-----------------------------------------------------\nDeaths of crows have been reported in large numbers across Jharkhand\nin the past week [last week of November 2011]. Carcasses have been\nspotted in Jamshedpur, Bokaro, Hazaribagh, and other areas. Media\nreports estimate the number of crow deaths to be between 500 and\n1000.\n\nScientists at National Institute of Virology (NIV) in Pune have found\nthe virus to be H5N1. It is a highly pathogenic virus that can even\nspread to humans.\n\nResidents report that incidents of crow deaths started surfacing in\nthe beginning of September [2011]. However, the event captured media\nattention only towards the end of November [2011]. Several teams,\nincluding that of the Indian Institute of Veterinary Research (IVRI)\nin Bareilly, have collected carcasses and are presently conducting\ntests to ascertain the cause of the deaths. The IVRI results are still\nawaited. NIV, in the meanwhile, has confirmed the presence of the HN51\nvirus in the dead crows.\n\nThe crows tested negative for Japanese encephalitis or West Nile\nvirus. M Sharma at IVRI Bareilly says the report will be out in a\ncouple of days. He says the deaths of crows in such huge numbers have\nnot been reported before.\n\nMD Dwivedi, bird watcher and researcher at Vinobha Bhave University in\nHazaribagh in Jharkhand, claims he has seen several crows die.\nExplaining their symptoms, he says, 'It appears the right side of\ntheir body is not working. They seem to have concussion.' After\nspeaking to labourers in the Bokaro steel plant, he concluded there\nhave been 500 deaths in the region.\n\n[byline: Dinsa Sachan]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Avian influenza outbreaks in poultry caused by H5N1 highly pathogenic\navian influenza (HPAI) virus were confirmed in a neighboring state,\nWest Bengal, in August/September 2011 (see ProMED-mail archives\n20110909.2747 and 20110923.2882). However, no associated poultry cases\nwere reported in this episode. Since 2002, a substantial number of\ndeaths associated with H5N1 HPAI virus infection were reported in\nseveral domestic and wildlife species. This virus strain proved to be\npathogenic to a majority of the species exposed to it, and thus it is\nsurprising that only crows are reported affected in this die-off. The\nresults of tests being carried out by IVRI will clarify the situation.\nHPAI H5N1 virus is not transmitted from human to human, so an outbreak\nin people would depend on the exposure to sick reservoir hosts. -\nMod.PMB\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of India can be seen at\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/1vLj. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]", "summary": "\n\n[byline: Dinsa Sachan]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Avian influenza outbreaks in poultry caused by H5N1 highly pathogenic\navian influenza (HPAI) virus were confirmed in a neighboring state,\nWest Bengal, in August/September 2011 (see ProMED-mail archives\n20110909.2747 and 20110923.2882). AVIAN INFLUENZA (76) - INDIA: (JHARKHAND) CROW, H5N1\n****************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Several teams,\nincluding that of the Indian Institute of Veterinary Research (IVRI)\nin Bareilly, have collected carcasses and are presently conducting\ntests to ascertain the cause of the deaths. This virus strain proved to be\npathogenic to a majority of the species exposed to it, and thus it is\nsurprising that only crows are reported affected in this die-off. Since 2002, a substantial number of\ndeaths associated with H5N1 HPAI virus infection were reported in\nseveral domestic and wildlife species. Media\nreports estimate the number of crow deaths to be between 500 and\n1000. After\nspeaking to labourers in the Bokaro steel plant, he concluded there\nhave been 500 deaths in the region. virology institute\n-----------------------------------------------------\n Deaths of crows have been reported in large numbers across Jharkhand\nin the past week [last week of November 2011]. \n\nResidents report that incidents of crow deaths started surfacing in\nthe beginning of September [2011]. He says the deaths of crows in such huge numbers have\nnot been reported before. HPAI H5N1 virus is not transmitted from human to human, so an outbreak\nin people would depend on the exposure to sick reservoir hosts.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2002-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Jharkhand", "country": "India"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "West Bengal", "country": "India"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "996088", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (75): China (GG) H5N1", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=996088", "date": "2011-12-31 17:38:25", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (75): CHINA (GUANGDONG), H5N1\n****************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Sat 31 Dec 2011\nSource: Asia Pacific News, Agence Fance-Presse report [edited]\nhttp://www.channelnewsasia.com/stories/afp_asiapacific/view/1174126/1/.htm=\n\nChina reports first bird flu case in 18 months\n----------------------------------------------\nChina has reported its first human case of bird flu[avian influenza\nA/H5N1 influenza virus infection] in 18 months, after a bus driver in\nthe massive southern boomtown of Shenzhen tested positive for the\ndeadly virus. The city borders Hong Kong, which has already culled\nthousands of chickens and ordered a suspension of live poultry imports\nfrom the mainland after 3 birds tested positive for the H5N1 strain of\nthe virus in mid-December [2011].\n\nThe victim developed a fever on 21 Dec 2011 and was taken to hospital\non 25 Dec 2011 and diagnosed with severe pneumonia, said the health\ndepartment in Shenzhen, a city of more than 10 million. The\n39-year-old later tested positive for the H5N1 avian influenza virus,\nthe department said in a statement posted online late Friday [30 Dec\n2011]. He was in critical condition and receiving emergency treatment.\nAuthorities said the man had apparently had no direct contact with\npoultry in the month before he was taken ill, nor had he left the\ncity.\n\nThe H5N1 virus is fatal in humans in about 60 percent of cases. There\ntends to be a spike in infections during the early months of the year.\nSymptoms include fever, coughing, a sore throat, pneumonia and\nrespiratory disease. However, it does not pass easily from human to\nhuman, and the World Health Organization says it has never identified\na 'sustained human-to-human spread' of the virus since it re-emerged\nin 2003.\n\nChinese and Hong Kong authorities have been working closely together\nsince 21 Dec 2011 after live poultry supplies were suspended to the\nglitzy financial hub [i.e. Hong Kong] following the discovery of\ninfected birds. A spokesman for the Hong Kong health department said\nin a statement authorities would heighten their vigilance 'and\ncontinue to maintain stringent port health measures in connection with\nthis development.' Health authorities in China have also vowed to stay\nin 'close contact and work together' with Hong Kong and 'jointly step\nup measures in controlling the epidemic', the official Xinhua news\nagency said.\n\nChina is considered one of the nations most at risk of bird flu\nepidemics because it has the world's biggest poultry population and\nmany chickens in rural areas are kept close to humans. In the last\nreported human case in China, a young pregnant woman died of bird flu\nin June 2010 in the central province of Hubei. Her death brought to 26\nthe number of people who have died in China since 2003, out of 40\nreported human cases, according to the World Health Organization.\n\nAuthorities in Hong Kong have raised the bird flu alert level to\n'serious' since they discovered infected chickens, resulting in major\ndisruptions to poultry supplies over the busy Christmas period; 2\nschools were ordered to close after dead birds infected with the virus\nwere found on their premises.\n\nHong Kong was the site of the world's first major outbreak of bird flu\namong humans in 1997, when 6 people died. Millions of birds were then\nculled. The avian influenza virus has killed more than 330 people\naround the world, with Indonesia the worst-hit country. Most human\ninfections are the result of direct contact with infected birds.\n\nScientists fear H5N1 could mutate into a form readily transmissible\nbetween humans, with the potential to cause millions of deaths.\nHighlighting those fears, the World Health Organization said on Friday\n[30 Dec 2011] that it was 'deeply concerned' about research into\nwhether H5N1 could be made more transmissible between humans after\nmutant strains were produced in labs. Two separate research teams --\none in the Netherlands and the other in the USA -- separately found\nways to alter the virus H5N1 so it could pass easily between mammals.\n\nHong Kong is particularly nervous about infectious diseases after an\noutbreak of the respiratory disease SARS in 2003 killed 300 people in\nthe city and a further 500 worldwide. A 59-year-old woman tested\npositive for bird flu in 2010 in Hong Kong's first human case of the\nillness since 2003.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n\n******\n[2]\nDate:Fri 30 Dec 2011\nSsource: Reuters US [eedited]\nhttp://www.reuters.com/article/2011/12/30/us-china-birdflu-idUSTRE7BT0WP20111230\n\nChina reports suspected human bird flu case\n-------------------------------------------\nChina has reported a suspected human case of the H5N1 [avian\ninfluenza] virus, or bird flu, in a southern city bordering Hong Kong,\nofficials said on Friday [30 Dec 2011]. The patient, a 39-year-old man\nliving in Shenzhen, developed symptoms on 21 Dec 2011 and was admitted\nto a hospital on 25 Dec 2011 because of severe pneumonia, the Centre\nof Health Protection of Hong Kong said in a statement. He is now in\ncritical condition. China's Ministry of Health said preliminary\nlaboratory tests on the patient's specimen by the Centre for Disease\nControl and Prevention of Guangdong Province had yielded a positive\nresult for H5N1.\n\nAbout 10 days ago Hong Kong culled 17 000 chickens at a wholesale\npoultry market and suspended all imports of live chickens from\nmainland China for 21 days after a dead chicken there tested positive\nfor the H5N1 virus. The virus is normally found in birds but can jump\nto people who do not have immunity to it, and researchers worry it\ncould mutate into a form that would spread around the world and kill\nmillions of people.\n\nIn recent years, the virus has become active in various parts of the\nworld, mainly in east Asia, during the cooler months. Authorities in\nChina are especially worried about the spread of infectious diseases\naround this time when millions of Chinese travel in crowded buses and\ntrains across the country to go home to celebrate the Lunar New Year.\n\nThe current strain of H5N1 is highly pathogenic [in birds], kills most\nspecies of birds and up to 60 percent of the people it infects. Since\n2003, it has infected 573 people around the world, killing 336. The\nvirus also kills migratory birds but species that manage to survive\ncan carry and disperse the virus to new, uninfected locations.\n\nThe virus can kill birds and humans in a matter of days but can\nsurvive far longer durations in a moist, cool environment. It\ntransmits less easily [almost never] between people but there have\nbeen clusters of infections in people in Indonesia and Thailand in the\npast, where the virus is believed to have been passed between family\nmembers through direct contact with contaminated respiratory\nsecretions.\n\n(By Alison Leung; Editing by Alessandra Rizzo)\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nNati Elkin\nnati@poultrymed.com\n\n[China is one of 15 countries which have reported human cases of avian\nH/(H5N1) virus infection. The World Health Orgaisation (WHO) table of\nthe Cumulative number of confirmed human cases for avian influenza\nA(H5N1) (2003-2011)\nhttp://www.who.int/influenza/human_animal_interface/H5N1_cumulative_table_archives/en/index.html)\nindicates that as of 15 Dec 2011 there had been 40 cases with 26\nfatalities in China since 2003, compared with the global total of 573\ncases and 336 fatalities. The case described above brings the number\nof cases in China to 41. It remains to be seen whether the current\ncase will add to the number of fatalites.\n\nSo far there has been no evidence of sustained transmission of\ninfection from person-to-person and in almost all cases there has been\nevidence of contact with diseased poultry. The current case in\nShenzhen appears to be exceptional in the latter respect, and will\nremain a cause for concern until this case has is fully investigated.\n\nThe city of Shenzhen can be located by accessing the HealthMap\ninteractive map of the Chinese province of Guangdong at:\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/1AXb. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "The World Health Orgaisation (WHO) table of\nthe Cumulative number of confirmed human cases for avian influenza\nA(H5N1) (2003-2011)\nhttp://www.who.int/influenza/human_animal_interface/H5N1_cumulative_table_archives/en/index.html)\nindicates that as of 15 Dec 2011 there had been 40 cases with 26\nfatalities in China since 2003, compared with the global total of 573\ncases and 336 fatalities. AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (75): CHINA (GUANGDONG), H5N1\n****************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\n It\ntransmits less easily [almost never] between people but there have\nbeen clusters of infections in people in Indonesia and Thailand in the\npast, where the virus is believed to have been passed between family\nmembers through direct contact with contaminated respiratory\nsecretions. \n\nAuthorities in Hong Kong have raised the bird flu alert level to\n'serious' since they discovered infected chickens, resulting in major\ndisruptions to poultry supplies over the busy Christmas period; 2\nschools were ordered to close after dead birds infected with the virus\nwere found on their premises. However, it does not pass easily from human to\nhuman, and the World Health Organization says it has never identified\na 'sustained human-to-human spread' of the virus since it re-emerged\nin 2003. The city borders Hong Kong, which has already culled\nthousands of chickens and ordered a suspension of live poultry imports\nfrom the mainland after 3 birds tested positive for the H5N1 strain of\nthe virus in mid-December [2011]. The\n39-year-old later tested positive for the H5N1 avian influenza virus,\nthe department said in a statement posted online late Friday [30 Dec\n2011]. The virus is normally found in birds but can jump\nto people who do not have immunity to it, and researchers worry it\ncould mutate into a form that would spread around the world and kill\nmillions of people. The patient, a 39-year-old man\nliving in Shenzhen, developed symptoms on 21 Dec 2011 and was admitted\nto a hospital on 25 Dec 2011 because of severe pneumonia, the Centre\nof Health Protection of Hong Kong said in a statement. Health authorities in China have also vowed to stay\nin 'close contact and work together' with Hong Kong and 'jointly step\nup measures in controlling the epidemic', the official Xinhua news\nagency said. A spokesman for the Hong Kong health department said\nin a statement authorities would heighten their vigilance 'and\ncontinue to maintain stringent port health measures in connection with\nthis development.' China's Ministry of Health said preliminary\nlaboratory tests on the patient's specimen by the Centre for Disease\nControl and Prevention of Guangdong Province had yielded a positive\nresult for H5N1. China has reported a suspected human case of the H5N1 [avian\ninfluenza] virus, or bird flu, in a southern city bordering Hong Kong,\nofficials said on Friday [30 Dec 2011]. \n\nThe victim developed a fever on 21 Dec 2011 and was taken to hospital\non 25 Dec 2011 and diagnosed with severe pneumonia, said the health\ndepartment in Shenzhen, a city of more than 10 million. \n\nChina is considered one of the nations most at risk of bird flu\nepidemics because it has the world's biggest poultry population and\nmany chickens in rural areas are kept close to humans. A 59-year-old woman tested\npositive for bird flu in 2010 in Hong Kong's first human case of the\nillness since 2003. Her death brought to 26\nthe number of people who have died in China since 2003, out of 40\nreported human cases, according to the World Health Organization. \n\nHong Kong is particularly nervous about infectious diseases after an\noutbreak of the respiratory disease SARS in 2003 killed 300 people in\nthe city and a further 500 worldwide. \n\nChinese and Hong Kong authorities have been working closely together\nsince 21 Dec 2011 after live poultry supplies were suspended to the\nglitzy financial hub The\nvirus also kills migratory birds but species that manage to survive\ncan carry and disperse the virus to new, uninfected locations.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "sars"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2011-12-25 00:00:00", "1975-03-25 00:00:00", "2003-03-25 00:00:00", H5N1,OIE\n********************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 12 Dec 2011\nSource: OIE, WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database), weekly\ndisease information 2011; 24(50) [edited]\nhttp://web.oie.int/wahis/public.php?page=single_report&pop=1&reportid=11376\n\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza, China\n----------------------------------------\nInformation received on (and dated) 12 Dec 2011 from Dr Zhang\nZhongqui, Director General, China Animal Disease Control Centre,\nVeterinary Bureau, Ministry of Agriculture, Beijing, China (People's\nRep. of)\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nStart date: 2 Dec 2011\nDate of 1st confirmation of the event: 12 Dec 2011\nReport date: 12 Dec 2011\nDate submitted to OIE: 12 Dec 2011\nReason for notification: reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 25 May 2010\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory (advanced)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country\n\nNew outbreaks\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1: Sangda, Duilongdeqing, Lhasa, Tibet [Xizang]\nDate of start of the outbreak: 2 Dec 2011\nOutbreak status: resolved (12 Dec 2011)\nEpidemiological unit: village\nSpecies: birds\nSusceptible: 1865\nCases: 290\nDeaths: 290\nDestroyed: 1575\nSlaughtered: 0\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or\ninconclusive\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: stamping out; quarantine; movement control inside\nthe country; screening; zoning; vaccination in response to the\noutbreak(s); disinfection of infected premises/establishment(s);\ndipping/spraying; no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type: Harbin Veterinary (HIT)\nTest date: 12 Dec 2011\nResult: positive\n\nSpecies: birds\nTest: intravenous pathogenicity index (IVPI) test\nTest date: 12 Dec 2011\nResult: positive\n\nSpecies: birds\nTest: reverse transcription - polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR)\nTest date' 12 Dec 2011\nResult: positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This is a high mortality outbreak reaching 100 percent, with 290\nbirds dying out of 290 cases in the population of 1865 susceptible\nbirds. The rest were destroyed.
