Cases: 290\nDeaths: 290\nDestroyed: 1575\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This is a high mortality outbreak reaching 100 percent, with 290\nbirds dying out of 290 cases in the population of 1865 susceptible\nbirds. Test date: 12 Dec 2011\nResult: positive\n\nSpecies: birds\n Test date: 12 Dec 2011\nResult: positive\n\nSpecies: birds\n Date submitted to OIE: 12 Dec 2011\nReason for notification: reoccurrence of a listed disease\n Source of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or\ninconclusive\n\nControl measures\n Source: OIE, WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database), weekly\ndisease information 2011; 24(50) [edited]\n Manifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\n Total outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1: Sangda, Duilongdeqing, Lhasa, Tibet [Xizang]\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1865-03-25 00:00:00", "2011-03-25 00:00:00", "2010-05-25 00:00:00", "1575-03-25 00:00:00", "1977-03-25 00:00:00", "2011-12-12 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Sangda", "country": "China"}, {"location": "CHINA", "country": "China"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Duilongdeqing", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Lhasa", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Beijing", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Xizang", "country": "China"}, {"location": "WAHID", "country": "Oman"}, {"location": "Tibet", "country": "China"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "941619", "headline": "PRO/AH> Avian influenza (68): H5N1 transmissibility to ferrets", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=941619", "date": "2011-11-08 17:33:06", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (68): H5N1 TRANSMISSIBILITY TO FERRETS\n******************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 7 Nov 2011\nSource: CIDRAP news [edited]\nhttp://www.cidrap.umn.edu/cidrap/content/influenza/avianflu/news/nov0711flluscan.html\n\n\nComplex steps needed for airborne H5N1 spread in ferrets\n--------------------------------------------------------\nA series of complex changes allowed the H5N1 avian flu virus to become\ntransmissible via airborne droplets in ferrets, US researchers\nreported in the journal 'Virology' [see Abstract of this publication\nbelow]. Working on the assumption that acquisition of alpha-2-6\nsialoside receptor specificity by alpha-2-3-specific H5N1 is a\nprerequisite for efficient transmission in humans, they identified 4\nvariant viruses that had modestly increased alpha-2-6 and minimally\ndecreased alpha-2-3 binding. They then created a mutant virus\ncombining one of these variants (Q196R) with mutations from previous\npandemic viruses (Q226L and G228S) that had predominantly alpha-2-6\nbinding. This novel virus was transmitted between ferrets, which are\nseen as good models of flu transmission in humans. Spread, however,\noccurred by direct contact, not by airborne droplets. The team then\ncreated a reassortant virus containing the mutant hemagglutinin, a\nhuman N2 neuraminidase, and internal genes from an H5N1 virus, and\nobserved that it was 'partially transmitted via respiratory droplets.'\nThe researchers conclude, 'The complex changes required for airborne\ntransmissibility in ferrets suggest that extensive evolution is needed\nfor H5N1 transmissibility in humans.'\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The paper referred to above is titled; 'In vitro evolution of H5N1\navian influenza virus toward human-type receptor specificity'. By\nLi-Mei Chen and 8 others, in: Virology online 5 Nov 2011\ndoi:10.1016/j.virol.2011.10.006:\nhttp://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0042682211004752.\n\nThe Abstract reproduced below provides more specific information.\n\n'Acquisition of alpha 2-6 sialoside receptor specificity by alpha 2-3\nspecific highly-pathogenic avian influenza viruses (H5N1) is thought\nto be a prerequisite for efficient transmission in humans. By in vitro\nselection for binding alpha 2-6 sialosides, we identified 4 variant\nviruses with amino acid substitutions in the hemagglutinin (S227N,\nD187G, E190G, and Q196R) that revealed modestly increased alpha 2-6\nand minimally decreased alpha 2-3 binding by glycan array analysis.\nHowever, a mutant virus combining Q196R with mutations from previous\npandemic viruses (Q226L and G228S) revealed predominantly alpha 2-6\nbinding. Unlike the wild type H5N1, this mutant virus was transmitted\nby direct contact in the ferret model although not by airborne\nrespiratory droplets. However, a reassortant virus with the mutant\nhemagglutinin, a human N2 neuraminidase and internal genes from an\nH5N1 virus was partially transmitted via respiratory droplets. The\ncomplex changes required for airborne transmissibility in ferrets\nsuggest that extensive evolution is needed for H5N1 transmissibility\nin humans.'\n\nThese experiments demonstrated that multiple genetic changes were\nrequired to produce experimentally a predominantly avian H5 influenza\nvirus that could be transmitted to ferrets (the mammal most\nsusceptible to influenza virus infection) by respiratory droplet\ninfection. These results are consistent with the rarity of H5N1 virus\ninfection in humans despite the extent of their exposure to avian H5N1\nvirus infection from diseased poultry. While these experiments do not\nexclude the rapid evolution of a novel H5N1 human pandemic virus, this\nis likely to be a rare event. The priority must remain to reduce the\nexposure of humans to the avian virus in domestic poultry. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "By in vitro\nselection for binding alpha 2-6 sialosides, we identified 4 variant\nviruses with amino acid substitutions in the hemagglutinin (S227N,\nD187G, E190G, and Q196R) that revealed modestly increased alpha 2-6\nand minimally decreased alpha 2-3 binding by glycan array analysis.\n The researchers conclude, 'The complex changes required for airborne\ntransmissibility in ferrets suggest that extensive evolution is needed\nfor H5N1 transmissibility in humans.'\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< AVIAN INFLUENZA (68): H5N1 TRANSMISSIBILITY TO FERRETS\n******************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Working on the assumption that acquisition of alpha-2-6\nsialoside receptor specificity by alpha-2-3-specific H5N1 is a\nprerequisite for efficient transmission in humans, they identified 4\nvariant viruses that had modestly increased alpha-2-6 and minimally\ndecreased alpha-2-3 binding. The team then\ncreated a reassortant virus containing the mutant hemagglutinin, a\nhuman N2 neuraminidase, and internal genes from an H5N1 virus, and\nobserved that it was 'partially transmitted via respiratory droplets.'\n They then created a mutant virus\ncombining one of these variants (Q196R) with mutations from previous\npandemic viruses (Q226L and G228S) that had predominantly alpha-2-6\nbinding. A series of complex changes allowed the H5N1 avian flu virus to become\ntransmissible via airborne droplets in ferrets, US researchers\nreported in the journal 'Virology' [see Abstract of this publication\nbelow]. The\ncomplex changes required for airborne transmissibility in ferrets\nsuggest that extensive evolution is needed for H5N1 transmissibility\nin humans.'", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2068-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "911200", "headline": "PRO/AH> Avian influenza (64): vaccination & H5N1 virus evolution", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=911200", "date": "2011-10-16 19:28:35", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (64): VACCINATION AND H5N1 VIRUS EVOLUTION\n**********************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Fri 14 Oct 2011\nSource: CIDRAP News [edited]\nhttp://www.cidrap.umn.edu/cidrap/content/influenza/general/news/oct1411newsscan-jrw2.html\n\n\nHighly pathogenic H5N1 avian flu viruses in countries that\nmass-vaccinate poultry appear to evolve more rapidly than viruses in\ncountries that do not, a study in Vaccine revealed. An international\nresearch team analyzed 751 H5N1 sequences from Egypt, Indonesia,\nNigeria, Turkey, and Thailand, noting that the 1st 2 nations practice\nmass vaccination, while the other 3 do not. The team wrote: 'Although\nthe direct association between H5N1 vaccination and virus evolution is\ndifficult to establish, we found evidence for a difference in the\nevolutionary dynamics of H5N1 viruses among countries where\nvaccination was or was not adopted.' The mean rates of evolution among\nviruses, in thousandths of a nucleotide substitution per site per\nyear, were: Egypt, 5.36; Indonesia, 6.13; Nigeria, 5.20; Turkey, 4.04;\nand Thailand, 2.52. In Egypt, the subclade most widely circulating in\npoultry, subclade B, had a rate of 8.87. As a measure of selection\npressure, the investigators also assessed the number of positively\nselected sites in the hemagglutinin gene of viruses from the various\ncountries: Egypt, 9; Indonesia, 6; Nigeria, 2; Turkey, 0; and\nThailand, 3. The authors emphasize that vaccination, when properly\nplanned and adopted, is a powerful tool against H5N1. But they\nconclude that, if it is not properly implemented, 'vaccination may\ncontribute to the rapid evolution and antigenic change of H5N1\nviruses, creating opportunities for the viruses to escape from vaccine\nprotection.'\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Sat 15 Oct 2011 [accessed]\nSource: Vaccine (2011), article in press, abstract [edited]\nhttp://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0264410X11015842\n\n\nRef: Cattoli G, et al. Evidence for differing evolutionary dynamics of\nA/H5N1 viruses among countries applying or not applying avian\ninfluenza vaccination in poultry. Vaccine (2011),\ndoi:10.1016/j.vaccine.2011.09.127. [Accepted for publication 30 Sep\n2011; Available online 12 Oct 2011]\n-------------------\nAbstract\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) H5N1 (clade 2.2) was\nintroduced into Egypt in early 2006. Despite the control measures\ntaken, including mass vaccination of poultry, the virus rapidly spread\namong commercial and backyard flocks. Since the initial outbreaks, the\nvirus in Egypt has evolved into a 3rd order clade (clade 2.2.1) and\ndiverged into antigenically and genetically distinct subclades. To\nbetter understand the dynamics of HPAI H5N1 evolution in countries\nthat differ in vaccination policy, we undertook an in-depth analysis\nof those virus strains circulating in Egypt between 2006 and 2010 and\ncompared countries where vaccination was adopted (Egypt and Indonesia)\nto those where it was not (Nigeria, Turkey and Thailand). This study\nincorporated 751 sequences (Egypt n = 309, Indonesia n = 149, Nigeria\nn = 106, Turkey n = 87, Thailand n = 100) of the complete\nhaemagglutinin (HA) open reading frame, the major antigenic\ndeterminant of influenza A virus. Our analysis revealed that 2 main\nEgyptian subclades (termed A and B) have co-circulated in domestic\npoultry since late 2007 and exhibit different profiles of positively\nselected codons and rates of nucleotide substitution. The mean\nevolutionary rate of subclade A H5N1 viruses was 4.07 x 10 -3\nnucleotide substitutions per site, per year (HPD 95 percent,\n3.23-4.91), whereas subclade B possessed a markedly higher\nsubstitution rate (8.87 x 10 -3; 95 percent HPD 7.0-10.72 x 10 -3) and\na stronger signature of positive selection. Although the direct\nassociation between H5N1 vaccination and virus evolution is difficult\nto establish, we found evidence for a difference in the evolutionary\ndynamics of H5N1 viruses among countries where vaccination was or was\nnot adopted. In particular, both evolutionary rates and the number of\npositively selected sites were higher in virus populations circulating\nin countries applying avian influenza vaccination for H5N1, compared\nto viruses circulating in countries which had never used vaccination.\nWe, therefore, urge a greater consideration of the potential\nconsequences of inadequate vaccination on viral evolution.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Highly pathogenic avian influenza H5N1 has become endemic in 6\ncountries: Bangladesh, India, the People's Republic of China, Egypt,\nIndonesia and Viet Nam, of which the 4 latter ones practice a\nvaccination policy. The analysis described in the above paper\naddressed 2 of these countries, Egypt and Indonesia, comparing them to\n3 countries where the disease is not endemic and vaccination is not\napplied (Nigeria, Turkey and Thailand).\n\nThe following concluding remarks from the discussion chapter are of\ninterest:\n\n'The direct association between H5N1 vaccination and virus evolution\nis clearly difficult to establish since other factors, difficult to\nevaluate under field conditions, might contribute to the apparent\ndifferences in evolutionary dynamics observed here. For example,\npoultry density, a variety of ecological factors or environmental\nchanges may contribute to the different rates of nucleotide\nsubstitution and strength of natural selection in those viruses\ncirculating in poultry. In addition, the endemicity of H5N1 viruses,\nthe number of distinct introductions of H5N1 (e.g. in Nigeria and\nTurkey), may also have influenced the pattern of viral evolution. When\nproperly planned and adopted, vaccination is a powerful tool for the\ncontrol and eradication of avian influenza in poultry, as demonstrated\nby past experiences in Italy, Viet Nam and Hong Kong, where it reduced\neconomic losses and the risks for zoonotic transmission. However, if\nnot properly applied and not coupled with careful surveillance, robust\nvaccine strategies and strict bio-security precautions, vaccination\nmay contribute to the rapid evolution and antigenic change of H5N1\nviruses, creating opportunities for the viruses to escape from vaccine\nprotection. Clearly, more sophisticated and effective animal health\ncontrol and prevention measures are urgently required, such as\nsustainable and efficacious vaccination strategies for poultry.'\n\nThe issue has been discussed earlier this year [2011] in FAO Animal\nProduction and Health paper No 171: 'Approaches to controlling,\npreventing and eliminating H5N1 HPAI in endemic countries,'\n(extensively cited in archived 20110424.1286). It included, inter\nalia, the following passage:\n\n'In several countries where vaccination has been used, antigenic\nvariant viruses have been detected, although it is not yet clear\nwhether the vaccine was responsible. In the People's Republic of\nChina, this problem has been addressed by introduction of new vaccine\nantigens. In countries such as Egypt and Indonesia, despite access to\nthe necessary technology, it has proven difficult to make the\nnecessary changes to vaccines quickly. Systems need to be in place to\ndetect antigenic variants rapidly through antigenic testing and\nexperimental challenge of vaccinated poultry with suspected antigenic\nvariants, and to make adjustments to vaccines.'\n\nAs recently published by the OIE ( 20110901.2678), a vaccine against\nthe novel H5N1 clade 2.3.2.1 virus, reportedly identified in Viet Nam\nand China, is already in the testing phase in China.\n\nDoes a non-vaccination approach in an endemic situation deserve\nconsideration? The Bangladeshi experience (519 outbreaks in poultry\nsince March 2007, as of 6 Sep 2011; a total of 3 human cases, no\nmortality) may serve as a useful test-case, deserving a thorough\nepidemiological and socio-economical analysis, taking into\nconsideration both human and animal health aspects as well as\ntechnical and cost-effectiveness issues.\n\nUpdated animal-health related epidemiological observations of the\nBangladeshi epizootic are included in a recent paper (Ahmed SSU,\nErsboll AK, Biswas PK, Christensen JP, Toft N (2011) Spatio-Temporal\nMagnitude and Direction of Highly Pathogenic Avian Influenza (H5N1)\nOutbreaks in Bangladesh. PLoS ONE 6(9): e24324.\ndoi:10.1371/journal.pone.0024324. Available on-line\nhttp://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3170297/pdf/pone.0024324.pdf).\n- Mod.AS]", "summary": "But they\nconclude that, if it is not properly implemented, 'vaccination may\ncontribute to the rapid evolution and antigenic change of H5N1\nviruses, creating opportunities for the viruses to escape from vaccine\nprotection.'\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail < AVIAN INFLUENZA (64): VACCINATION AND H5N1 VIRUS EVOLUTION\n**********************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\n To\nbetter understand the dynamics of HPAI H5N1 evolution in countries\nthat differ in vaccination policy, we undertook an in-depth analysis\nof those virus strains circulating in Egypt between 2006 and 2010 and\ncompared countries where vaccination was adopted (Egypt and Indonesia)\nto those where it was not (Nigeria, Turkey and Thailand). However, if\nnot properly applied and not coupled with careful surveillance, robust\nvaccine strategies and strict bio-security precautions, vaccination\nmay contribute to the rapid evolution and antigenic change of H5N1\nviruses, creating opportunities for the viruses to escape from vaccine\nprotection. The mean\nevolutionary rate of subclade A H5N1 viruses was 4.07 x 10 -3\nnucleotide substitutions per site, per year (HPD 95 percent,\n3.23-4.91), whereas subclade B possessed a markedly higher\nsubstitution rate (8.87 x 10 -3; 95 percent HPD 7.0-10.72 x 10 -3) and\na stronger signature of positive selection. The Bangladeshi experience (519 outbreaks in poultry\nsince March 2007, as of 6 Sep 2011; a total of 3 human cases, no\nmortality) may serve as a useful test-case, deserving a thorough\nepidemiological and socio-economical analysis, taking into\nconsideration both human and animal health aspects as well as\ntechnical and cost-effectiveness issues. The team wrote: 'Although\nthe direct association between H5N1 vaccination and virus evolution is\ndifficult to establish, we found evidence for a difference in the\nevolutionary dynamics of H5N1 viruses among countries where\nvaccination was or was not adopted.' Although the direct\nassociation between H5N1 vaccination and virus evolution is difficult\nto establish, we found evidence for a difference in the evolutionary\ndynamics of H5N1 viruses among countries where vaccination was or was\nnot adopted. \n\nThe following concluding remarks from the discussion chapter are of\ninterest:\n\n'The direct association between H5N1 vaccination and virus evolution\nis clearly difficult to establish since other factors, difficult to\nevaluate under field conditions, might contribute to the apparent\ndifferences in evolutionary dynamics observed here. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Highly pathogenic avian influenza H5N1 has become endemic in 6\ncountries: Bangladesh, India, the People's Republic of China, Egypt,\nIndonesia and Viet Nam, of which the 4 latter ones practice a\nvaccination policy. vaccine was responsible.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2007-03-25 00:00:00", "1987-03-25 00:00:00", "2011-03-25 00:00:00", "2064-03-25 00:00:00", "2011-09-06 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "the People 's Republic of", "country": "Bangladesh"}, {"location": "Bangladesh", "country": "Bangladesh"}, {"location": "Italy", "country": "Italy"}, {"location": "Egypt", "country": "Egypt"}, {"location": "Turkey", "country": "Turkey"}, {"location": "the People 's Republic of China", "country": "Macao"}, {"location": "Thailand", "country": "Thailand"}, {"location": "Indonesia", "country": "Indonesia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "853778", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (58): H5N1 2.3.2.1 clade, WHO", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=853778", "date": "2011-09-02 02:25:46", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (58): H5N1 2.3.2.1 CLADE, WHO\n****************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this posting:\n[1] WHO report\n[2] CIDRAP News report\n\n******\n[1] WHO report\nDate: Tue 30 Aug 2011\nSource: WHO press statement [edited]\nhttp://www.who.int/influenza/human_animal_interface/avian_influenza/h5n1-2011_08_30/en/index.html\n\n\nEvolution of H5N1 avian influenza virus does not increase risk to\npublic health\n--------------------------------------------------------------\nThe World Health Organization closely monitors the evolution of\ninfluenza viruses and is aware of recent reports of an H5N1 virus\n(described as H5N1 clade 2.3.2.1) circulating in poultry in parts of\nAsia. Based on available information, this evolution of the H5N1 virus\nposes no increased risk to public health. It is not considered unusual\nbecause influenza viruses are constantly evolving, especially in areas\nwhere they circulate regularly in poultry. The WHO Global Influenza\nSurveillance and Response System, the group of experts that studies\nanimal and human influenza viruses that may impact human health,\nrecognized this new clade in February 2011.\n\nWHO also routinely assesses the public health risk from all animal\ninfluenza viruses. Based on available information, the identification\nof this newly reported H5N1 virus clade does not change the current\npublic health implications of the H5N1 avian influenza viruses for\nhumans. Human cases of H5N1 infection remain rare and sporadic events,\noccurring mostly in areas where H5N1 viruses circulate regularly in\npoultry. Human cases could occur wherever the viruses are present in\npoultry and when humans might be exposed to infected birds or\ncontaminated environments.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] CIDRAP News report\nDate: Wed 31 Aug 2011\nSource: CIDRAP (Center for Infectious Disease Research & Policy) News\n[edited]\nhttp://www.cidrap.umn.edu/cidrap/content/influenza/avianflu/news/aug3111h5n1.html\n\n\nWHO, OIE downplay importance of new H5N1 variant\n------------------------------------------------\nThe World Health Organization (WHO) and the World Organisation for\nAnimal Health (OIE) took pains today [31 Aug 2011] to downplay the\nsignificance of a new H5N1 avian influenza variant that another major\ninternational organisation warned about this week.\n\nIn a 29 Aug 2011 statement, the United Nations Food and Agriculture\nOrganization (FAO) said a new H5N1 strain called clade 2.3.2.1 had\nemerged recently in Viet Nam and China and that existing poultry\nvaccines were ineffective against it. The statement also cited recent\nincreases in H5N1 bird outbreaks and warned about a possible major\nresurgence of the virus.\n\nWHO said today that its Global Influenza Surveillance and Response\nSystem recognized the H5N1 variant in February [2011]. 'Based on\navailable information, this evolution of the H5N1 virus poses no\nincreased risk to public health,' the WHO statement said. 'It is not\nconsidered unusual because influenza viruses are constantly evolving,\nespecially in areas where they circulate regularly in poultry.'\n\nThe agency further said clade 2.3.2.1 does not change the public\nhealth implications of H5N1 viruses, given the available information.\n'Human cases of H5N1 infection remain rare and sporadic events,\noccurring mostly in areas where H5N1 viruses circulate regularly in\npoultry,' the statement said.\n\nThe OIE made similar points in a statement today [31 Aug 2011; see\nProMED-mail Avian influenza (56): mutation, vaccine efficacy, OIE\n20110901.2678]. It said the emergence of clade 2.3.2.1 is a result of\nminor genetic changes that typify the natural evolution of the virus.\n'This is not immediate cause for alert but, as with the emergence of\nany new strain, reinforces the need for sustained monitoring of\nviruses in animal populations so that changes in viruses circulating\nin the field are detected at an earliest stage and that most\nappropriate disease control strategies are chosen to best protect\nanimal and public health', the OIE said.\n\nThe agency also commented that avian flu vaccines, like human flu\nvaccines, need to be tested regularly to see if they are effective\nagainst the viruses in circulation. The OIE reference laboratory in\nHarbin, China, has developed a vaccine that, in trials, has protected\npoultry from clade 2.3.2.1, the statement said. Once available for\nfield use, the vaccine will be employed in countries where the new\nvariant has been identified.\n\n'Registration and manufacturing of a poultry vaccine with the new seed\nstrain is in progress,' the OIE said.\n\nMeanwhile, a clade 2.3.2.1 virus caused the illness of a 59 year old\nHong Kong woman who contracted an H5N1 infection last November (2010)\n[see ProMED-mail Avian influenza, human (60): China (Hong Kong)\n20101122.4228], probably while traveling in Mainland China, according\nto a report today [31 Aug 2011] by The Standard, a Hong Kong\nnewspaper. The story cited Hong Kong's Centre for Health Protection\n(CHP) as the source of the information. Hong Kong health officials\nsaid at the time that the virus in the woman's case belonged to clade\n2.3.2. She recovered from her illness, according to online information\nfrom the CHP.\n\n[byline: Robert Roos]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Information on H5N1 clade structure, as of February 2011, can be\nobtained from the WHO document 'Antigenic and genetic characteristics\nof influenza A(H5N1) and influenza A(H9N2) viruses for the development\nof candidate vaccine viruses for pandemic preparedness', which can be\nviewed at\nhttp://www.who.int/influenza/resources/documents/2011_02_h5_h9_vaccinevirusupdate.pdf.\n- Mod.CP]", "summary": "promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Information on H5N1 clade structure, as of February 2011, can be\nobtained from the WHO document 'Antigenic and genetic characteristics\nof influenza A(H5N1) and influenza A(H9N2) viruses for the development\nof candidate vaccine viruses for pandemic preparedness', which can be\nviewed at\nhttp://www.who.int/influenza/resources/documents/2011_02_h5_h9_vaccinevirusupdate.pdf. This is not immediate cause for alert but, as with the emergence of\nany new strain, reinforces the need for sustained monitoring of\nviruses in animal populations so that changes in viruses circulating\nin the field are detected at an earliest stage and that most\nappropriate disease control strategies are chosen to best protect\nanimal and public health', the OIE said. AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (58): H5N1 2.3.2.1 CLADE, WHO\n****************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n The WHO Global Influenza\nSurveillance and Response System, the group of experts that studies\nanimal and human influenza viruses that may impact human health,\nrecognized this new clade in February 2011. Based on available information, the identification\nof this newly reported H5N1 virus clade does not change the current\npublic health implications of the H5N1 avian influenza viruses for\nhumans. The World Health Organization closely monitors the evolution of\ninfluenza viruses and is aware of recent reports of an H5N1 virus\n(described as H5N1 clade 2.3.2.1) circulating in poultry in parts of\nAsia. The World Health Organization (WHO) and the World Organisation for\nAnimal Health (OIE) took pains today [31 Aug 2011] to downplay the\nsignificance of a new H5N1 avian influenza variant that another major\ninternational organisation warned about this week. In a 29 Aug 2011 statement, the United Nations Food and Agriculture\nOrganization (FAO) said a new H5N1 strain called clade 2.3.2.1 had\nemerged recently in Viet Nam and China and that existing poultry\nvaccines were ineffective against it. \n\n[byline: Robert Roos]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\nThe OIE made similar points in a statement today [31 Aug 2011; see\nProMED-mail Avian influenza (56): mutation, vaccine efficacy, OIE\n20110901.2678]. It is not\nconsidered unusual because influenza viruses are constantly evolving,\nespecially in areas where they circulate regularly in poultry.' It is not considered unusual\nbecause influenza viruses are constantly evolving, especially in areas\nwhere they circulate regularly in poultry.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2011-03-25 00:00:00", "2060-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-02-25 00:00:00", "2058-03-25 00:00:00", "2011-02-25 00:00:00", "2056-03-25 00:00:00", "2011-08-31 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Harbin", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "Hong Kong"}, {"location": "Viet Nam", "country": "Vietnam"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Hong Kong 's", "country": "Hong Kong"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "883655", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (60): India (WB) H5N1 conf, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=883655", "date": "2011-09-23 17:36:05", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (60): INDIA (WEST BENGAL) H5N1 CONFIRMED, REQUEST FOR\nINFORMATION\n*********************************************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 22 Sep 2011\nSource: MSN-News, Press Trust of India (PTI) report [edited]\nhttp://news.in.msn.com/national/article.aspx?cp-documentid=5460063\n\n\n30 000 birds culled in Nadia: DM [district magistrate]\n------------------------------------------------------\nAbout 30 000 birds have been culled till today [23 Sep 2011] at\nTehatta 1 block in Nadia district where there has been an outbreak of\nbird flu. ['While about 14000 birds were culled on Tue 20 Sep 2011,\nabout 6000 birds were culled Wed 21 Sep 2011, and about 10 000 on Thu\n22 Sep 2011],' Nadia district magistrate Avinaba Chanda said.\n\n'60 teams were deployed for culling ,' he said adding about 8000 birds\nwould be culled [on Fri 23 Sep 2011].\n\nThe Nadia administration was providing coupons to the bird owners as\nper the order of the state government through which they would get the\ncompensation later. But government of India has ordered to arrange for\nspot compensation, official sources said.\n\nAccording to the district magistrate, there are 3 check points to stop\nthe birds from going out of the protected area within 3 km [2 mi]\nradius of the affected area.\n\nThe confirmation of the outbreak of [avian influenza] from laboratory\nwas received on Monday night [19 Sep 2011], the DM said after which\nculling started.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nRonan Kelly\nfor FluTrackers.com\n<ronankelly@comcast.net>\n\n[This outbreak has been reported to the OIE on 19 Sep 2011 (follow-up\nreport no 1, available with map at\nhttp://web.oie.int/wahis/public.php?page=single_report&pop=1&reportid=11026).\nIt is the 2nd H5N1 outbreak in India since the immediate notification\nof a new epizootic, claimed to have started on 29 Aug 2011\n(ProMED-mail archive no 20110909.2747).\n\nThe 1st outbreak was located in Dhuburi, Assam, northern to\nBangladesh; the 2nd, current outbreak, is located south to Bangladesh,\nnamely in Nadia, West Bengal, about 840 km (522 mi) distant from the\n1st outbreak (see map at\nhttp://web.oie.int/wahis/public.php?page=event_summary&reportid=10993).\nThe likely common denominator of both outbreaks is their proximity to\nBangladesh, a country that has reported, since March 2007, 519\noutbreaks of avian influenza (see map at\nhttp://web.oie.int/wahis/public.php?page=event_summary&reportid=5154).\n\nThe applied 'control measures' in relation to HPAI, as reported by\nboth countries to the OIE, are the following:\nBangladesh:\nStamping out, movement control inside the country, disinfection of\ninfected premises/establishment(s), vaccination prohibited.\n\nIndia:\nStamping out, quarantine, movement control inside the country,\ndisinfection of infected premises/establishment(s), screening, no\nvaccination.\n\nWe have sought OIE's explanation to the difference between\n'vaccination prohibited' and 'no vaccination' policies. The following\nexplanatory note has been kindly provided:\n\n'Vaccination prohibited' means that the use of a vaccine to control\nthe outbreak(s) is prohibited under any circumstances.\nVaccination in response to the outbreak(s)\nVaccination as a measure to control the outbreak(s) (such as ring\nvaccination).\nWhere there is no vaccination, it means that they do not apply\nvaccination around the outbreak(s).\n\nSo for Bangladesh the use of vaccine is prohibited in the country\n(ring and routine vaccination), while in India, the Government does\nnot vaccinate but the use of vaccine is not forbidden.'\n\nUpon further inquiry, the following details were kindly added:\n'These definitions are used mainly for immediate notifications and\nfollow-up reports when dealing with emergencies.\n\nFor routine vaccination you should look at 6-monthly reports to see if\nthe country practices mass vaccination. In general, when vaccination\nis prohibited, it is already mentioned in the 6-monthly report and\nwhen an exceptional event occurs vaccination remains prohibited.'\n\nWe are very grateful to the head of OIE's Information Department, Dr\nKarim Ben Jebara, for the clarifications above.\n\nSubscribers are thus advised that OIE's immediate notifications and\nfollow-up reports do not address the vaccination status of the\naffected holdings in countries, which do not prohibit vaccination. To\nobtain that kind of information, subscribers are advised to refer to\nthe 6-month or annual detailed reports.\n\nTo clear the current issue, we referred to OIE's information on\n'Disease control measures' as reported in the annual reports of the 2\nabove countries in relation to HPAI.\n\nThe following results (annual reports 2010) were found:\n1. India: notifiable disease, Qf, M, Te, GSu, Qi, S\n2. Bangladesh: notifiable disease, Qf, M, Gsu, Tsu, Qi, S, Z, Vp\n\nKey:\nQf= precautions at the border\nM= monitoring\nTe= screening\nGsu= general surveillance\nTsu= targetted surveillance\nQi= movement control inside the country\nS= stamping out\nSp= modified stamping out\nZ= zoning\nVp= vaccination prohibited.\nV= routine vaccination\nT= treatment\nCr= control of wildlife reservoirs\nCn= control of arthropods\n\nSince India's policy does not mention either Vp or V, it is not clear\nif vaccination is allowed to be carried out by non-governmental\nentities, and if HPAI H5N1 vaccines have been certified for such\n(unofficial) use; this information is herewith requested. - Mod.AS]", "summary": "T= treatment\nCr= control of wildlife reservoirs\nCn= control of arthropods\n\nSince India's policy does not mention either Vp or V, it is not clear\nif vaccination is allowed to be carried out by non-governmental\nentities, and if HPAI H5N1 vaccines have been certified for such\n(unofficial) use; this information is herewith requested. \n\nThe applied 'control measures' in relation to HPAI, as reported by\nboth countries to the OIE, are the following:\nBangladesh:\nStamping out, movement control inside the country, disinfection of\ninfected premises/establishment(s), vaccination prohibited. \n\nThe 1st outbreak was located in Dhuburi, Assam, northern to\nBangladesh; the 2nd, current outbreak, is located south to Bangladesh,\nnamely in Nadia, West Bengal, about 840 km (522 mi) distant from the\n1st outbreak (see map at\nhttp://web.oie.int/wahis/public.php?page=event_summary&reportid=10993). ********************************************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n \nStamping out, quarantine, movement control inside the country,\ndisinfection of infected premises/establishment(s), screening, no\nvaccination. Bangladesh: notifiable disease, Qf, M, Gsu, Tsu, Qi, S, Z, Vp\n\nKey:\nQf= precautions at the border\nM= monitoring\n The likely common denominator of both outbreaks is their proximity to\nBangladesh, a country that has reported, since March 2007, 519\noutbreaks of avian influenza (see map at\nhttp://web.oie.int/wahis/public.php?page=event_summary&reportid=5154). Communicated by:\nRonan Kelly\nfor FluTrackers.com\n<ronankelly@comcast.net>\n\n The following\nexplanatory note has been kindly provided:\n\n'Vaccination prohibited' means that the use of a vaccine to control\nthe outbreak(s) is prohibited under any circumstances. \n\nSubscribers are thus advised that OIE's immediate notifications and\nfollow-up reports do not address the vaccination status of the\naffected holdings in countries, which do not prohibit vaccination. In general, when vaccination\nis prohibited, it is already mentioned in the 6-monthly report and\nwhen an exceptional event occurs vaccination remains prohibited.' \n\nTo clear the current issue, we referred to OIE's information on\n'Disease control measures' as reported in the annual reports of the 2\nabove countries in relation to HPAI. Mod.AS, edited]\n<http://www.moag.gov.il/NR/exeres/B217BA1D-5BA5-4D55-95E7-396176E0CBDA,frame\n\nless.htm?NRMODE=Published>\n\n\nAvian influenza suspected in Rosh Zurim; preliminary notification\n-----------------------------------------------------------------\nAvian influenza H5 has been diagnosed in a turkey farm in the Kibbutz\nRosh Zurim, district BetLehem, province of Judea and Samaria. The\naffected farm includes 13 400 birds. Quarantine measures and\nsurveillance have immediately been applied.\n\nNo unusual mortality has been detected in poultry farms 10 km [6 mi]\naround the affected farm. Veterinarians, to whom the circular is being\nelectronically distributed, are called to alertness.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The Israeli Veterinary Services have kindly provided the following\nadditional information, for which ProMED-mail is grateful:\n\n'H5N1 has been confirmed by PCR. Virus isolation is pending. Out of\nthe 13 400 14 week old turkeys in the infected flock, about 1000\nshowed clinical disease, of which 200 died.\n\n'The entire affected flock, as well as 2 additional turkey flocks on\nthe same farm (14 000 each, one 6 weeks old and the other 4 days old)\nare to be immediately culled. An immediate notification has already\nbeen submitted to the OIE'.\n\nA map showing the location of Rosh Zurim is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/0yWZ>. - Mod.AS]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 7 Mar 2011\n \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\n'The entire affected flock, as well as 2 additional turkey flocks on\nthe same farm (14 000 each, one 6 weeks old and the other 4 days old)\n Out of\nthe 13 400 14 week old turkeys in the infected flock, about 1000\nshowed clinical disease, of which 200 died. -----------------------------------------------------------------\nAvian influenza H5 has been diagnosed in a turkey farm in the Kibbutz\nRosh Zurim, district BetLehem, province of Judea and Samaria. 24(7) [edited]\nhttp://web.oie.int/wahis/public.php?page=single_report&pop=1&reportid=10478\n\n\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza, Israel\n-----------------------------------------\nInformation received on 11 Apr 2011 from Dr Michel Bellaiche,\nDirector, Veterinary Services and Animal Health, Ministry of\nAgriculture and Rural Development, Beit Dagan, Israel\n\nSummary\nReport type Immediate notification (Final report)\nStart date 06 Apr 2011\nDate of 1st confirmation of the event 11 Apr 2011\nReport date 11 Apr 2011\nDate submitted to OIE 11 Apr 2011\nDate event resolved 07 Apr 2011\nReason for notification Reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence 15 Mar 2011\nManifestation of disease Clinical disease\nCausal agent Highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype H5N1\nNature of diagnosis Suspicion, Clinical, Laboratory (advanced)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country\n\nNew outbreaks\nOutbreak 1 (Nature - Jordan Valley) Nature - Jordan Valley, Jericho,\nJehuda and Samaria\nDate of start of the outbreak 06 Apr 2011\nOutbreak status Resolved (07 Apr 2011)\nEpidemiological unit Not applicable\nAffected animals\nSpecies Wild species\nSusceptible\nCases 1\nDeaths 1\nDestroyed 0\nSlaughtered 00\n\nAffected Population: A Marsh Harrier (Circus aeruginosus) with\nrespiratory signs was found in the wild. It was brought to the\nwildlife veterinary hospital where it died a few hours afterwards. The\nbody was sent to the Avian Laboratory of the Kimron Veterinary\nInstitute.\n\nNote by the OIE Animal Health Information Department: This outbreak\nis located into Israeli Settlements in the West Bank.\n\nEpidemiology - Source of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection.\nContact with wild species\n\nEpidemiological comments: The sick bird had no contact with other\nbirds since it was discovered till its death. The cage has been\ndisinfected. Some other wild birds, staying in the Wildlife Veterinary\nHospital, were sampled and put under quarantine.\n\nControl measures: Measures applied. Quarantine; Screening;\nDisinfection of infected premises/establishment(s); No vaccination;\nNo treatment of affected animals\n\nMeasures to be applied - No other measures\n\nLaboratory name and type: Avian Diseases Division, Kimron\nVeterinary\nInstitute (National laboratory)\nSpecies Birds\nTest real-time PCR\nTest date 11 Apr 2011\nResult Positive\n\nFuture Reporting\nThe event is resolved. No more reports will be submitted.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Having been associated with a wildlife hospital, I know it is\nimportant to understand that diseases can be transmitted there as well\nas cured. Strict quarantine should be observed as part of the disease\ncontrol strategy. Although the epidemiologic description would not\nlead one to suspect the Marsh Harrier did indeed spread the H5N1 virus\nto other birds, wildlife hospitals often are volunteer organizations\nand strong veterinary supervision should be in place - especially in\nthis case. The aim of most wildlife hospitals is to release the wild\nbirds that can be returned safely to the wild, but in this case they\nshould be sure that any released birds are free of H5N1.\n\nA map of this West Bank location can be see appended to the OIE WAHID\nreport referenced above or seen at the Healthmap website\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/0Gik. - Mod.PC]", "summary": "Quarantine; Screening;\nDisinfection of infected premises/establishment(s); No vaccination;\nNo treatment of affected animals\n\nMeasures to be applied - No other measures\n\nLaboratory name and type: Avian Diseases Division, Kimron\nVeterinary\nInstitute (National laboratory)\n AVIAN INFLUENZA (36): ISRAEL, H5N1,  OIE\n*****************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Although the epidemiologic description would not\nlead one to suspect the Marsh Harrier did indeed spread the H5N1 virus\nto other birds, wildlife hospitals often are volunteer organizations\nand strong veterinary supervision should be in place - especially in\nthis case. "910588", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (62): Iran (MN), H5N1 - OIE", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=910588", "date": "2011-10-15 21:02:57", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (62): IRAN (MAZANDARAN), H5N1 - OIE\n***************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: 15 Oct 2011\nSource: OIE, WAHID [edited]\nhttp://web.oie.int/wahis/public.php?page=single_report&pop=1&reportid=11139\n\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza, Iran\n---------------------------------------\nInformation received on 13 Oct 2011 from Dr Seyed Mohsen Dastoor, Head\nof Iran Veterinary Organization, Iran Veterinary Organization,\nMinistry of Jihad-e-Agriculture, Tehran, Iran\n\nSummary\n-------\nReport type Immediate notification\nStart date 13 Sep 2011\nDate of 1st confirmation of the event 15 Sep 2011\nReport date 13 Oct 2011\nDate submitted to OIE 13 Oct 2011\nReason for notification Reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence 03 Aug 2008\nManifestation of disease Clinical disease\nCausal agent Highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype H5N1\nNature of diagnosis Clinical, Laboratory (basic), Laboratory\n(advanced)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country\n\nNew outbreaks\n-------------\nOutbreak 1 Balazarrin Kola, Jooybar, Mazandaran\nDate of start of the outbreak 13 Sep 2011\nOutbreak status Continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit Village\n\nSpecies Birds\nSusceptible 2285\nCases 450\nDeaths 310\nDestroyed 1975\nSlaughtered 0\nAffected Population Free-range ducks (backyard)\n\nOutbreak 2 Khaj Kola, Zirab, Savadkooh, Mazandaran\nDate of start of the outbreak 13 Sep 2011\nOutbreak status Continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit Village\nSpecies Birds\nSusceptible 397\nCases 85\nDeaths 35\nDestroyed 362\nSlaughtered 0\nAffected Population Free-range ducks (backyard)\n\nSummary of outbreaks Total outbreaks: 2\nTotal animals affected\nSpecies Birds\nSusceptible 2682\nCases 535\nDeaths 345\nDestroyed 2337\nSlaughtered 0\n\nEpidemiology Source of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection. Under\ninvestigation\n\nEpidemiological comments The event was reported according to the\nIranian passive surveillance in place; a post-outbreak investigation\nto trace the source of infection is ongoing to detect the probable\nspread and circulation of H5 serotype. Active surveillance is\nongoing.\n\nControl measures\n----------------\nMeasures applied\n- Control of wildlife reservoirs\n- Stamping out\n- Quarantine\n- Movement control inside the country\n- Screening\n- Zoning\n- Disinfection of infected premises/establishment(s)\n- Vaccination prohibited\n- No treatment of affected animals\n\nMeasures to be applied - No other measures\n\nLaboratory name and type: Central Veterinary Laboratory of Iran\nVeterinary Organization (National laboratory)\nSpecies Birds\nTest reverse transcription - polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR)\nTest date 15 Sep 2011\nResult Positive\n\nLaboratory name and type Reference Laboratory for Avian Influenza,\nPadova (Italy) (OIE's Reference Laboratory)\nSpecies Birds\nTest reverse transcriptase/polymerase chain reaction (RRT-PCR\nTest date 10 Oct 2011\nResult Positive\n\nFuture Reporting\n----------------\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-Mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[ProMED-mail is very pleased to have the official report of the\noutbreak and especially information from an official source indicating\nthe avian influenza subtype, the quantitative scope of the outbreak\nand location. It is to be noted that we have had previous reports this\nyear from unofficial sources in June and April [2011] indicating\noutbreaks in poultry, rather than wild ducks. ProMED-mail is very\nappreciative of having these previous reports so that we can provide a\ncomplete global picture of this most important disease.\n\nThis is an example of excellent international scientific cooperation\nin that results were confirmed at Ilaria Capua's OIE reference\nlaboratory in Padova as a comparison of the outbreak strain with other\nstrains in the world and that this outbreak strain can be put in\nproper context with other global information. Any results in terms of\nsubtype, quantitative descriptions or geographic location from\nprevious outbreaks in poultry or any results from the current active\nsurveillance would also be most welcome. The location of the current\noutbreak in wild ducks is in the same general region of the country\nthat our previous reports of outbreaks in poultry. For more details,\nplease see Mod.AS comments in the archives, listed below.\n\nThe location of the outbreak can be seen appended to the OIE report\nreference above or at the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map\nshowing the location of Mazandaran, Iran:\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/1l0y. - Mod.PC]", "summary": "----------------\nMeasures applied\n- Control of wildlife reservoirs\n- Stamping out\n- Quarantine\n- Movement control inside the country\n- Screening\n- Zoning\n- Disinfection of infected premises/establishment(s) AVIAN INFLUENZA (62): IRAN (MAZANDARAN), H5N1 - OIE\n***************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nThis is an example of excellent international scientific cooperation\nin that results were confirmed at Ilaria Capua's OIE reference\nlaboratory in Padova as a comparison of the outbreak strain with other\nstrains in the world and that this outbreak strain can be put in\nproper context with other global information. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[ProMED-mail is very pleased to have the official report of the\noutbreak and especially information from an official source indicating\nthe avian influenza subtype, the quantitative scope of the outbreak\nand location. \n- Vaccination prohibited\n- No treatment of affected animals\n\nMeasures to be applied - No other measures\n\nLaboratory name and type: Central Veterinary Laboratory of Iran\n Information received on 13 Oct 2011 from Dr Seyed Mohsen Dastoor, Head\nof Iran Veterinary Organization, Iran Veterinary Organization,\nMinistry of Jihad-e-Agriculture, Tehran, Iran\n\nSummary\n Any results in terms of\nsubtype, quantitative descriptions or geographic location from\nprevious outbreaks in poultry or any results from the current active\nsurveillance would also be most welcome. Manifestation of disease Clinical disease\nCausal agent Highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\n \nOutbreak 1 Balazarrin Kola, Jooybar, Mazandaran\n Species Birds\nTest reverse transcriptase/polymerase chain reaction (RRT-PCR\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-06-25 00:00:00", "2011-03-25 00:00:00", "2062-03-25 00:00:00", "1975-03-25 00:00:00", "2011-09-13 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Savadkooh", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mazandaran", "country": "Iran"}, {"location": "Italy", "country": "Italy"}, {"location": "Iran", "country": "Iran"}, {"location": "Tehran", "country": "Iran"}, {"location": "Padova", "country": "Italy"}, {"location": "Zirab", "country": "Saudi Arabia"}, {"location": "Jooybar", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "669096", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (26): Hong Kong, H5N1, goose", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=669096", "date": "2011-03-06 22:00:07", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (26): HONG KONG, H5N1, GOOSE\n********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 4 Mar 2011\nSource: Government of Hong Kong, Prevention of Avian Influenza, Press\nrelease [edited]\n<http://www.info.gov.hk/gia/general/201103/04/P201103040127.htm>\n\n\nA spokesman for the Agriculture, Fisheries and Conservation\nDepartment (AFCD) said today [4 Mar 2011] that a goose carcass found\nin Lantau was confirmed to be H5N1 positive after laboratory testing.\n\nThe goose carcass was found and collected at a beach near Sham Shek\nTsuen, Lantau on 1 Mar 2011. It was highly decomposed when found and\nrequired a series of tests before H5N1 avian influenza was confirmed\ntoday [4 Mar 2011].\n\nThe spokesman said there were no poultry farms within 3 km of where\nthe dead goose was found. AFCD staff have conducted inspections and\nfound no evidence of any backyard poultry being kept there. The AFCD\nwill continue to monitor the situation and conduct inspections of the\narea.\n\nA ban on backyard poultry has been in force since 2006. Unauthorised\nkeeping of 5 kinds of poultry -- chickens, ducks, geese, pigeons or\nquail -- is an offence with a maximum fine of HKD 50 000 [USD 6400].\nRepeat offenders are subject to a maximum fine of HKD 100 000 [USD 12\n840].\n\nAll relevant government departments will continue to remain highly\nvigilant and strictly enforce preventive measures against avian\ninfluenza.\n\nThe AFCD has phoned poultry farmers to remind them to strengthen\nprecautionary and biosecurity measures against avian influenza.\nLetters have also been issued to farmers, pet bird shop owners,\nlicence holders of pet poultry and racing pigeons reminding them that\nproper precautions must be taken.\n\nThe spokesman said the department would conduct frequent inspections\nof poultry farms and the wholesale market to ensure that proper\nprecautions against avian influenza have been implemented. The\ndepartment will continue its wild bird monitoring and surveillance.\n\n'People should avoid personal contact with wild birds and live\npoultry and their droppings. They should clean their hands thoroughly\nafter coming into contact with them. The public can call the Call\nCentre on 1823 for follow up if they come across suspicious sick or\ndead birds, including the carcasses of wild birds and poultry,' the\nspokesman said.\n\nThe Food and Environmental Hygiene Department (FEHD) will continue to\nbe vigilant over imported live poultry as well as live poultry stalls.\nIt will also remind stall operators to maintain good hygiene.\n\nThe Department of Health will keep up with its health education to\nremind the public to maintain strict personal and environmental\nhygiene to prevent avian influenza.\n\nAFCD, FEHD, the Customs and Excise Department and the Police will\nstrive to deter the illegal import of poultry and birds into Hong Kong\nto minimise the risk of avian influenza outbreaks caused by imported\npoultry and birds that have not gone through inspection and\nquarantine.\n\nHealth advice is available from the 'H5N1 Health Advice' on the AFCD\nwebsite at <http://www.afcd.gov.hk>.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The above event is reminiscent of the previous H5N1 case in Hong\nKong, namely the detection of a duck carcass at a beach in Tai O on 3\nFeb 2011; the carcass was similarly highly decomposed when found and\nrequired a series of tests before H5N1 avian influenza was confirmed.\n\nHong Kong was the site of the very 1st case of human infection with\nHPAI H5N1, in August 1997. Since then, the HK government has been\napplying the following exemplary measures to reduce the risk of\ninfection spreading from poultry to humans:\n\n(a) vaccination of chickens in local farms and imported chickens;\n(b) regulation of local farms including tightened biosecurity\nmeasures (for example, all farms should be (wild) bird-proof);\n(c) import control (for instance, imported chickens must come from\nregistered farms with health certificates);\n(d) segregation policy (no waterfowl, which are natural carriers of\navian influenza viruses, can be sold in retail outlets);\n(e) market rest days to break the virus cycle and reduce the viral\nload;\n(f) hygiene requirements on wholesale market and retail outlets; and\n(g) surveillance targeted at humans, poultry and wild birds to ensure\ntimely detection of the presence of any avian influenza viruses in our\nenvironment.\n\nThe said measures and additional background information are described\nin the document 'Hong Kong's preparedness for influenza pandemic --\nPrevention and Protection,' which is included, with additional updated\ninformation, in Hong-Kong's website 'Prevention of Avian Influenza,'\navailable at <http://www.info.gov.hk/info/flu/eng/index.htm>. This\nuseful web-site covers continuously also the H5N1 situation worldwide,\nincluding 2 tables under the title 'Global statistics of avian\ninfluenza,' (which has been last updated on 3 Mar 2011). - Mod.AS]", "summary": "Since then, the HK government has been\napplying the following exemplary measures to reduce the risk of\ninfection spreading from poultry to humans:\n\n(a) vaccination of chickens in local farms and imported chickens;\n(b) regulation of local farms including tightened biosecurity\nmeasures (for example, all farms should be (wild) bird-proof);\n(c) import control (for instance, imported chickens must come from\nregistered farms with health certificates);\n(d) segregation policy (no waterfowl, which are natural carriers of\navian influenza viruses, can be sold in retail outlets);\n(e) market rest days to break the virus cycle and reduce the viral\nload;\n(f) hygiene requirements on wholesale market and retail outlets; and\n(g) surveillance targeted at humans, poultry and wild birds to ensure\ntimely detection of the presence of any avian influenza viruses in our\nenvironment. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 4 Mar 2011\n \n\nAFCD, FEHD, the Customs and Excise Department and the Police will\nstrive to deter the illegal import of poultry and birds into Hong Kong\nto minimise the risk of avian influenza outbreaks caused by imported\npoultry and birds that have not gone through inspection and\nquarantine. The said measures and additional background information are described\nin the document 'Hong Kong's preparedness for influenza pandemic --\nPrevention and Protection,' which is included, with additional updated\ninformation, in Hong-Kong's website 'Prevention of Avian Influenza,'\navailable at <http://www.info.gov.hk/info/flu/eng/index.htm>. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The above event is reminiscent of the previous H5N1 case in Hong\nKong, namely the detection of a duck carcass at a beach in Tai O on 3\nFeb 2011; the carcass was similarly highly decomposed when found and\nrequired a series of tests before H5N1 avian influenza was confirmed. The public can call the Call\nCentre on 1823 for follow up if they come across suspicious sick or\ndead birds, including the carcasses of wild birds and poultry,' the\nspokesman said. This\nuseful web-site covers continuously also the H5N1 situation worldwide,\nincluding 2 tables under the title 'Global statistics of avian\ninfluenza,' (which has been last updated on 3 Mar 2011). \n\nThe spokesman said the department would conduct frequent inspections\nof poultry farms and the wholesale market to ensure that proper\nprecautions against avian influenza have been implemented. \n\nAll relevant government departments will continue to remain highly\nvigilant and strictly enforce preventive measures against avian\ninfluenza. Unauthorised\nkeeping of 5 kinds of poultry -- chickens, ducks, geese, pigeons or\nquail -- is an offence with a maximum fine of HKD 50 000 The Department of Health will keep up with its health education to\nremind the public to maintain strict personal and environmental\nhygiene to prevent avian influenza. It was highly decomposed when found and\nrequired a series of tests before H5N1 avian influenza was confirmed\ntoday", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1997-08-25 00:00:00", "2006-03-25 00:00:00", "2011-03-25 00:00:00", "1823-03-25 00:00:00", "2011-02-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Hong Kong 's", "country": "Hong Kong"}, {"location": "HONG KONG", "country": "Hong Kong"}, {"location": "Lantau", "country": "Hong Kong"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "Hong Kong"}, {"location": "Hong - Kong 's", "country": "Hong Kong"}, {"location": "Hong \n Kong", "country": "Thailand"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "801848", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (55): Cambodia (TA) wild birds, H5N1, OIE", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=801848", "date": "2011-07-29 12:16:11", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (55): CAMBODIA (TAKEO), WILD BIRDS, H5N1, OIE\n*************************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 26 Jul 2011\nSource: OIE, WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database), weekly\ndisease information 2011; 24(30) [edited]\nhttp://web.oie.int/wahis/public.php?page=single_report&pop=1&reportid=10831\n\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza, Cambodia\n-------------------------------------------\nInformation received on 28 Jul 2011 from Dr Sen Sovann, deputy\nsecretary general, Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries,\nMinistry of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries, Phnom Penh, Cambodia\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification (final report)\nStart date: 13 Jul 2011\nDate of 1st confirmation of the event: 18 Jul 2011\nReport date: 26 Jul 2011\nDate submitted to OIE: 28 Jul 2011\nDate event resolved: 25 Jul 2011\nReason for notification: reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 1 Oct 2010\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: suspicion, clinical, laboratory (basic),\nnecropsy\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country\n\nNew outbreaks\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1 (304/11): Phnom Tamao zoo, Trapang Sap, Bati, Takeo\nDate of start of the outbreak: 13 Jul 2011\nOutbreak status: resolved (25 Jul 2011)\nEpidemiological unit: not applicable\nAffected animals\nSpecies: wild species\nSusceptible: --\nCases: 29\nDeaths: 19\nDestroyed: 10\nSlaughtered: 0\nAffected population: it is a rescue center providing feed to wild\nbirds to prevent undernourishment. The area where wild birds gather in\nthe zoo is about one hectare [2.5 acres] with several ponds of limited\nsize and one pond about 5000 m2. Every evening 2 workers distribute\nfish on the bank of this big pond to provide supplement diet to the\nwild birds. This distribution of feed is done from June to December,\nduring the rainy season because wild birds are numerous to pass\nthrough of the zoo. The origin of these birds is not clear; possibly\nthey come from Tonle Sap River.\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or\ninconclusive\nEpidemiological comments: on 13 Jul 2011, in the morning, a worker\nfound 11 dead wild birds around different ponds and 3 birds dead in\nthe quarantine. The carcasses were buried and TH4 was sprayed\neverywhere. The veterinarian indicated that Newcastle or fowl cholera\nwere originally suspected.\nOn 14 Jul 2011, 3 dead birds and 10 sick birds were found; symptoms\nwere immobility, wings down, severe depression. The sick birds were\nculled. 2 carcasses were sent to the National Veterinary Research\nInstitute (NaVRI).\nOn 15 Jul 2011, 2 dead birds were found and buried.\nOn 16 Jul 2011, no new mortality was observed.\nOn 18 Jul 2011 the result of test by NaVRI confirmed positive H5N1.\nThe investigation team from NaVRI with the cooperation of the Phnom\nTamao zoo veterinary conducted an investigation in the zoo and carried\nout surveillance in neighboring village near the zoo from 19-25 Jul\n2011.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: quarantine; movement control inside the country;\nzoning; disinfection of infected premises/establishment(s);\ndipping/spraying; vaccination prohibited; no treatment of affected\nanimals\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type: National Veterinary Research Institute\n(NaVRI) (national laboratory)\nSpecies: wild species\nTest: inoculation test\nTest date: 18 Jul 2011\nResult: positive\n\nSpecies: wild species\nTest: real-time PCR\nTest date: 18 Jul 2011\nResult: positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is resolved. No more reports will be submitted.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Over the last few months there have been human cases in Prey Vang,\nKampong Cham, Phnom Penh, and in the northwest province of Banteay\nMeanchey. There have been previous poultry outbreaks in Kampong Cham\nprovince in 2009.\n\nThe location of the outbreak can be seen on the map appended to the\nOIE report referenced above. A map of the provinces of Cambodia,\nshowing Takeo province near Phnom Penh, can be accessed at\nhttp://www.canbypublications.com/maps/simpleprov.htm. The\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Cambodia can be accessed at\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/15wT. - Mod.PC]", "summary": "Measures applied: quarantine; movement control inside the country;\nzoning; disinfection of infected premises/establishment(s);\ndipping/spraying; vaccination prohibited; no treatment of affected\nanimals\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type: National Veterinary Research Institute\n AVIAN INFLUENZA (55): CAMBODIA (TAKEO), WILD BIRDS, H5N1, OIE\n*************************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Information received on 28 Jul 2011 from Dr Sen Sovann, deputy\nsecretary general, Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries,\nMinistry of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries, Phnom Penh, Cambodia\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification (final report)\n The investigation team from NaVRI with the cooperation of the Phnom\nTamao zoo veterinary conducted an investigation in the zoo and carried\nout surveillance in neighboring village near the zoo from 19-25 Jul\n2011. Date of previous occurrence: 1 Oct 2010\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\n Serotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: suspicion, clinical, laboratory (basic),\nnecropsy\n Epidemiological comments: on 13 Jul 2011, in the morning, a worker\nfound 11 dead wild birds around different ponds and 3 birds dead in\nthe quarantine. The\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Cambodia can be accessed at\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/15wT. - Mod.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "cholera"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2011-07-14 00:00:00", "2009-03-25 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2055-03-25 00:00:00", "2011-07-25 00:00:00", "2011-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Takeo", "country": "Cambodia"}, {"location": "Cambodia", "country": "Cambodia"}, {"location": "Fisheries", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Newcastle", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "Kampong Cham", "country": "Cambodia"}, {"location": "WAHID", "country": "Oman"}, {"location": "Phnom Penh", "country": "Cambodia"}, {"location": "destroy", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "657611", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (16): Bangladesh (DA, RP), H5N1, OIE", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=657611", "date": "2011-02-19 12:00:04", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (16): BANGLADESH (DHAKA, RANGPUR) H5N1, OIE\n***********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 13 Feb 2011 [ProMED regrets the delay in posting]\nSource: OIE WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database) Disease\nInformation 2011; 24(7) [edited]\n<http://web.oie.int/wahis/public.php?page=single_report&pop=1&reportid=10253>\n\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza, Bangladesh\n---------------------------------------------\nInformation received on 13 Feb 2011 from Dr Muhammad Abdul Baqi,\nDirector General, Department of Livestock Services, Ministry of\nFisheries and Livestock, Dhaka, Bangladesh\n\nSummary\nReport type Follow-up report Number 28\nStart date 05 Feb 2007\nDate of 1st confirmation of the event 22 Mar 2007\nReport date 13 Feb 2011\nDate submitted to OIE 13 Feb 2011\nReason for notification 1st occurrence of a listed disease\nManifestation of disease Clinical disease\nCausal agent Highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype H5N1\nNature of diagnosis Suspicion, Clinical, Laboratory (basic),\nLaboratory (advanced), Necropsy\nThis event pertains to the whole country\n\nNew outbreaks\nSummary of outbreaks Total outbreaks: 6\nSpecies Birds\nSusceptible 14277\nCases 2530\nDeaths 2530\nDestroyed 11747\nSlaughtered 0\n\nEpidemiology - Source of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection:\nUnknown or inconclusive\n\nControl measures - Measures applied: Stamping out; Movement control\ninside the country; Disinfection of infected\npremises/establishment(s); Vaccination prohibited; No treatment of\naffected animals\n\nMeasures to be applied - No other measures\n\nLaboratory name and type Bangladesh Livestock Research Institute,\nDhaka (national reference laboratory) (National laboratory)\nSpecies Birds\nTest reverse transcription - polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR)\nTest date 01 Feb 2011\nResult Positive\n\nSpecies Birds\nTest reverse transcription - polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR)\nTest date 07 Feb 2011\nResult Positive\n\nLaboratory name and type Central Disease Investigation Laboratory,\nDhaka (National laboratory)\nSpecies Birds\nTest rapid tests\nTest date 31 Jan 2011\nResult Positive\n\nSpecies Birds\nTest rapid tests\nTest date 06 Feb 2011\nResult Positive\n\nField Disease Investigation Laboratory, Gaibandha (National laboratory)\nSpecies Birds\nTest rapid tests\nTest date 31 Jan 2011\nResult Positive\n\nSpecies Birds\nTest rapid tests\nTest date 06 Feb 2011\nResult Positive\n\nFuture Reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This report summarizes 6 outbreaks in both commercial and backyard\npoultry. Unfortunately, they are spread out across different parts of\nthe country. These outbreaks are due to a highly pathogenic Avian\nInfluenza H5N1 virus and this is the 3rd Update Report in 2011. Given\nthat the outbreak started in 2007, it appears as if it will be some\ntime before it is cleaned up completely, so we should all not forget\nthat H5N1 is still circulating in Southeast Asia and Egypt.\n\nThe location of these outbreaks can be seen appended to the OIE WAHID\nreport referenced above or at the HealthMap site\n<http://healthmap.org/r/00t_>.\nA summary and very crowded map can also seen at the OIE website at\n<http://web.oie.int/wahis/public.php?page=event_summary&reportid=5154>\n- Mod.PC]", "summary": "Slaughtered 0\n\nEpidemiology - Source of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection:\nUnknown or inconclusive\n\nControl measures - Measures applied: Stamping out; Movement control\ninside the country; Disinfection of infected\npremises/establishment(s); Vaccination prohibited; No treatment of\naffected animals\n\nMeasures to be applied - No other measures\n\nLaboratory name and type Bangladesh Livestock Research Institute,\nDhaka (national reference laboratory) A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 13 Feb 2011 [ProMED regrets the delay in posting]\n Information received on 13 Feb 2011 from Dr Muhammad Abdul Baqi,\nDirector General, Department of Livestock Services, Ministry of\nFisheries and Livestock, Dhaka, Bangladesh\n\nSummary\nReport type Follow-up report Number 28\n Reason for notification 1st occurrence of a listed disease\nManifestation of disease Clinical disease\nCausal agent Highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\n Disease\nInformation 2011; 24(7) [edited]\n<http://web.oie.int/wahis/public.php?page=single_report&pop=1&reportid=10253>\n\n\n The location of these outbreaks can be seen appended to the OIE WAHID\nreport referenced above or at the HealthMap site\n<http://healthmap.org/r/00t_>.
