"https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=668598", "date": "2011-03-05 19:00:10", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (24): PALESTINIAN AUTHORITY, WEST BANK, H5N1 CONFIRMED\n**********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Sat 5 Mar 2011\nSource: Maan News Agency (Bethlehem) [edited]\n<http://www.maannews.net/eng/ViewDetails.aspx?ID=365697>\n\n\n2000 turkeys diagnosed with bird flu near Jenin\n-----------------------------------------------\nA flock of 2000 turkeys has been diagnosed with the H5N1 'bird flu'\nvirus in the northern West Bank village of Silat Al-Harithiya near\nJenin, government officials said.\n\nThe veterinary department of the Palestinian Authority Agriculture\nMinistry said it had managed to prevent an epidemic.\n\nDirector of the department in Jenin Jamil Makhamra told Ma'an that\ngovernment and private vets examined the flock on 27 Feb 2011 after\nmany of the birds died.\n\nSamples were examined at the veterinary medicine center in Ramallah,\nwhere it was confirmed that the birds had influenza A subtype of H5N1,\nalso known as 'bird flu.'\n\nMakhamra said further samples were sent to a veterinary lab in Israel\non 2 Mar 2011, but that even before the results were received, vets\nburied the dead birds, and killed and buried the rest of the flock\naccording to international regulations. The whole farm was sterilized,\nMakhamra added.\n\nResults from the Israeli lab confirmed that the turkeys had bird\nflu.\n\nThe ministry official said all necessary procedures were carried out\naccording to international standards. All farms within 3 kilometers\nwere examined once every 48 hours, and a quarantine was imposed on a\n10-kilometer [6.2-mile] radius for 3 days preventing the exit or entry\nof any farm birds, he said.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n\n[An official notification from Dr Saed Seyam, Head, Veterinary\nServices and Animal Health, Ministry of Agriculture, Ramallah,\nPalestinian Autonomous Territories, submitted to OIE on 3 Mar 2011, is\navailable with map at\n<http://web.oie.int/wahis/public.php?page=event_summary&reportid=10302>.\n- Mod.AS]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Sat 5 Mar 2011\n [An official notification from Dr Saed Seyam, Head, Veterinary\nServices and Animal Health, Ministry of Agriculture, Ramallah,\nPalestinian Autonomous Territories, submitted to OIE on 3 Mar 2011, is\navailable with map at\n<http://web.oie.int/wahis/public.php?page=event_summary&reportid=10302>. \n\nMakhamra said further samples were sent to a veterinary lab in Israel\non 2 Mar 2011, but that even before the results were received, vets\nburied the dead birds, and killed and buried the rest of the flock\naccording to international regulations. All farms within 3 kilometers\nwere examined once every 48 hours, and a quarantine was imposed on a\n10-kilometer [6.2-mile] radius for 3 days preventing the exit or entry\nof any farm birds, he said. \n\nSamples were examined at the veterinary medicine center in Ramallah,\nwhere it was confirmed that the birds had influenza A subtype of H5N1,\nalso known as 'bird flu.' \n\nDirector of the department in Jenin Jamil Makhamra told Ma'an that\ngovernment and private vets examined the flock on 27 Feb 2011 after\nmany of the birds died.", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2011-02-27 00:00:00", "2011-03-02 00:00:00", "2011-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Israel", "country": "Israel"}, {"location": "WEST BANK", "country": "Palestine"}, {"location": "Jenin", "country": "Palestine"}, {"location": "West Bank", "country": "Palestine"}, {"location": "Ramallah", "country": "Palestine"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "668916", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (25): Palestinian Authority, West Bank, H5N1, OIE", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=668916", "date": "2011-03-06 14:00:08", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (25): PALESTINIAN AUTHORITY, WEST BANK, H5N1, OIE\n*****************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 6 Mar 2011\nSource: OIE WAHID Disease Information 2011; 24(7) [edited]\n<http://web.oie.int/wahis/public.php?page=single_report&pop=1&reportid=10302>\n\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza, Palestinian Auton. Territories\n\nInformation received on 3 Mar 2011 from Dr Saed Seyam, Head,\nVeterinary Services and Animal Health, Ministry of Agriculture ,\nRamallah, Palestinian Auton. Territories.\n\nSummary\nReport type: Immediate notification\nStart date 27 Feb 2011\nDate of 1st confirmation of the event 3 Mar 2011\nReport date 3 Mar 2011\nDate submitted to OIE 3 Mar 2011\nReason for notification: Reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence 19 Apr 2006\nManifestation of disease: Clinical disease\nCausal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: Clinical, Laboratory (advanced), Necropsy\nThis event pertains to the whole country\n\nNew outbreaks\nOutbreak 1 Sealet al Harthieh, Jenin, WEST BANK\nDate of start of the outbreak 27 Feb 2011\nOutbreak status: Continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: Farm\nSpecies Birds\nSusceptible 2000\nCases 2000\nDeaths 2000\nDestroyed 0\nSlaughtered 0\n\nAffected Population: A farmer complained of 50 birds that died in one\nday on a turkey farm of 2000 birds, 65 days old. In 3 days, all the\nbirds died with some respiratory signs.\n\nEpidemiology: Source of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection.\nUnknown or inconclusive\n\nEpidemiological comments: It is the only turkey farm in that area.\nAll farms around are negative to avian influenza virus via PCR. A\ncontinuous sampling will follow every 24 hours for the 1st 3 days.\nTraceability study is in progress.\n\nControl measures - Measures applied: Control of wildlife reservoirs;\nQuarantine; Movement control inside the country; Screening; Zoning;\nDisinfection of infected premises/establishment(s); Modified stamping\nout; Vaccination prohibited; No treatment of affected animals\n\nMeasures to be applied: Vaccination in response to the outbreak(s);\nDipping/Spraying\n\nLaboratory name and type: Kimron Veterinary Institute (Regional\nReference Laboratory)\nSpecies Birds\nTest polymerase chain reaction (PCR)\nTest date 3 Mar 2011\nResult Positive\n\nFuture Reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The description of the population affected highlights for us once\nagain just how devastating a disease H5N1 avian influenza really is.\nOne day, the farmer had a normal flock of 2000 65-day-old turkeys who\nwere healthy and productive. The next day, much higher than baseline\nmortality, with 50 birds dying, and over the course of the next 2\ndays, all the rest of the 1950 turkeys died.\n\nOf course, it is hoped this is an isolated event and the reasonable\ncontrol measures taken (quarantine, stamping out, serological\nmonitoring, etc.) will prevent further spread. With such a volatile\ndisease, however, it is difficult to predict the future.\n\nFor the location of the village Silat al Harithiyah in the northern\npart of the West Bank, Jenin district, about 3 km from the boundary\nwith Israel, see map at <http://healthmap.org/r/0xKm> or the map\nappended to the OIE report referenced above. - Mod.PC]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 6 Mar 2011\n Date of previous occurrence 19 Apr 2006\nManifestation of disease: Clinical disease\nCausal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\n For the location of the village Silat al Harithiyah in the northern\npart of the West Bank, Jenin district, about 3 km from the boundary\nwith Israel, see map at <http://healthmap.org/r/0xKm> or the map\nappended to the OIE report referenced above. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The description of the population affected highlights for us once\nagain just how devastating a disease H5N1 avian influenza really is. \n\nOf course, it is hoped this is an isolated event and the reasonable\ncontrol measures taken (quarantine, stamping out, serological\nmonitoring, etc.) will prevent further spread. \n\nControl measures - Measures applied: Control of wildlife reservoirs;\nQuarantine; Movement control inside the country; Screening; Zoning;\nDisinfection of infected premises/establishment(s); Territories\n\nInformation received on 3 Mar 2011 from Dr Saed Seyam, Head,\nVeterinary Services and Animal Health, Ministry of Agriculture ,\nRamallah, Palestinian Auton. This event pertains to the whole country\n\nNew outbreaks\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1950-03-25 00:00:00", "2011-02-27 00:00:00", "2011-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Israel", "country": "Israel"}, {"location": "Ramallah", "country": "Palestine"}, {"location": "territory", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Jenin district", "country": "Czechia"}, {"location": "WEST BANK", "country": "Palestine"}, {"location": "the West Bank", "country": "Pakistan"}, {"location": "Silat al Harithiyah", "country": "Palestine"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "649334", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (15): China (HK) H5N1, duck", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=649334", "date": "2011-02-09 18:00:05", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (15): CHINA (HONG KONG) H5N1, DUCK\n********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 7 Feb 2011\nSource: Hong Kong Agriculture, Fisheries and Conservation Department\n(AFCD) press release [edited]\n<http://www.afcd.gov.hk/english/publications/publications_press/pr1642.html>\n\n\nDuck carcass found in Tai O tests positive for H5N1 virus\n---------------------------------------------------------\nA spokesman for the Agriculture, Fisheries and Conservation\nDepartment (AFCD) said today (7 Feb 2011) that a duck carcass found in\nTai O was confirmed to be H5N1 positive after laboratory testing.\n\nThe duck carcass was found and collected at a beach near Po Chue Tam,\nYeung Hau Temple, Tai O on 3 Feb 2011. It was highly decomposed when\nfound and required a series of tests before H5N1 avian influenza was\nconfirmed today [7 Feb 2011].\n\nThe spokesman said there were no poultry farms within 3 km [1.8 mi]\nof where the dead duck was found. AFCD staff have conducted\ninspections and found no evidence of any backyard poultry being kept\nthere. AFCD will continue to monitor the situation and conduct\ninspections of the area.\n\nA ban on backyard poultry has been in force since 2006. Unauthorized\nkeeping of 5 kinds of poultry -- chickens, ducks, geese, pigeons, or\nquails -- is an offense with a maximum fine of HKD 50 000 [about USD\n6400]. Repeat offenders are subject to a maximum fine of HKD 100 000\n[about USD 12 800].\n\nAll relevant government departments will continue to remain highly\nvigilant and strictly enforce preventive measures against avian\ninfluenza.\n\nAFCD has phoned poultry farmers to remind them to strengthen\nprecautionary and biosecurity measures against avian influenza.\nLetters have been issued to farmers, pet bird shop owners, licence\nholders of pet poultry, and racing pigeons reminding them that proper\nprecautions must be taken.\n\nThe spokesman said the department would conduct frequent inspections\nof poultry farms and the wholesale market to ensure that proper\nprecautions against avian influenza have been implemented. The\ndepartment will continue its wild bird monitoring and surveillance.\n\n'People should avoid personal contact with wild birds and live\npoultry and their droppings. They should clean their hands thoroughly\nafter coming into contact with them. The public can call the Call\nCentre on 1823 for follow up if they come across suspicious sick or\ndead birds, including the carcasses of wild birds and poultry,' the\nspokesman said.\n\nThe Food and Environmental Hygiene Department (FEHD) will continue to\nbe vigilant over imported live poultry as well as live poultry stalls.\nIt will also remind stall operators to maintain good hygiene.\n\nThe Department of Health will keep up with its health education to\nremind the public to maintain strict personal and environmental\nhygiene to prevent avian influenza.\n\nAFCD, FEHD, the Customs and Excise Department, and the Police will\nstrive to deter the illegal import of poultry and birds into Hong Kong\nto minimise the risk of avian influenza outbreaks caused by imported\npoultry and birds that have not gone through inspection and\nquarantine.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This report is a continuation of H5N1 incidents in Hong Kong this\nyear (2011), of which this is the 6th incident:\n\n17 Jan 2011: oriental magpie robin\n18 Jan 2011: large-billed crow\n24 Jan 2011: black-headed gull\n25 Jan 2011: chicken\n28 Jan 2011: chicken (2 carcasses)\n3 Feb 2011: duck\n\nThis press release does not state what species of duck was found.\nKnowing the species of duck or whether it is a domestic or wild duck\nwould be important in a management plan. The only clue given is that\nthere are no poultry farms within 3 km (1.8 mi) of where this duck was\nfound.\n\nAll reports from Hong Kong so far this year (2011) have been from\nfound bird carcasses. No outbreak in poultry farms has yet occurred.\nThe present poultry farming management seems to be effective in\npreventing outbreaks of H5N1, but due vigilance must continue.\n\nTai O is a little village of 5000 inhabitants on the western shore of\nLantau Island, which is to the west of the city of Hong Kong. -\nMod.KL\n\n[A map of Hong Kong showing incidents of H5N1 in dead birds can be\nfound at\n<http://www.afcd.gov.hk/english/quarantine/qua_vetlab/qua_vetlab_ndr/files/common/20110207.pdf>.\n- Mod.AS]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 7 Feb 2011\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This report is a continuation of H5N1 incidents in Hong Kong this\nyear (2011), of which this is the 6th incident:\n\n17 Jan 2011: oriental magpie robin\n18 Jan 2011: large-billed crow\n24 Jan 2011: black-headed gull\n \n\nAFCD, FEHD, the Customs and Excise Department, and the Police will\nstrive to deter the illegal import of poultry and birds into Hong Kong\nto minimise the risk of avian influenza outbreaks caused by imported\npoultry and birds that have not gone through inspection and\nquarantine. The public can call the Call\nCentre on 1823 for follow up if they come across suspicious sick or\ndead birds, including the carcasses of wild birds and poultry,' the\nspokesman said. Unauthorized\nkeeping of 5 kinds of poultry -- chickens, ducks, geese, pigeons, or\nquails -- is an offense with a maximum fine of HKD 50 000 [about USD\n6400]. 24(3) [edited]\n<http://www.oie.int/wahis/public.php?page=single_report&pop=1&reportid=10174>\n\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza, Hong Kong (SAR - PRC)\n--------------------------------------------------------\nInformation received on 21 Jan 2011 from Dr Thomas Sit, Chief\nVeterinary Officer / Assistant Director (Inspection & Quarantine),\nAgriculture, Fisheries and Conservation Department, Hong Kong Special\nAdministrative Region Government, Hong Kong , Hong Kong (SAR - PRC)\n\nSummary\nReport type: Immediate notification\nStart date 17 Jan 2011\nDate of 1st confirmation of the event 19 Jan 2011\nReport date 21 Jan 2011\nDate submitted to OIE 21 Jan 2011\nReason for notification: Reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence 18 Dec 2010\nManifestation of disease: Clinical disease\nCausal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: Laboratory (advanced)\nThis event pertains to the whole country\n\nNew outbreaks\nOutbreak 1 Tai O, Lantau Island, Hong Kong\nDate of start of the outbreak 18 Jan 2011\nOutbreak status: Resolved (18 Jan 2011)\nEpidemiological unit: Not applicable\nSpecies Wild species\nSusceptible\nCases 1\nDeaths 1\nDestroyed 0\nSlaughtered 0\nAffected Population A Large-billed Crow (Corvus macrorhynchus)\ncarcass was collected on 18 Jan 2011 at Tai O. Large-billed Crow is a\ncommon and widespread resident in Hong Kong.\n\nOutbreak 2 Fairview Park, Yuen Long, Hong Kong\nDate of start of the outbreak 17 Jan 2011\nOutbreak status Resolved (17 Jan 2011)\nEpidemiological unit Not applicable\nSpecies Wild species\nSusceptible\nCases 1\nDeaths 1\nDestroyed 0\nSlaughtered 0\nAffected Population An Oriental Magpie Robin (Copsychus saularis)\nwas collected on 17 Jan 2011 at the Fairview Park. Oriental Magpie\nRobin is a common and widespread resident in Hong Kong.\n\nEpidemiology - Source of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection.\nUnknown or inconclusive\n\nEpidemiological comments: An intensive surveillance system is in\nplace for all poultry farms, poultry markets, pet bird shops and wild\nbirds in Hong Kong. The H5N1 infected wild birds were detected in our\nongoing surveillance programme on wild birds. No spread of disease\nwas evident. As this report concerns wild birds, the dates of end of\nthe outbreaks are the same as the dates on which the birds were found\n(17 and 18 Jan 2011, respectively).\n\nControl measures - Measures applied. Screening; Disinfection of\ninfected premises/establishment(s); No vaccination; No treatment of\naffected animals\n\nMeasures to be applied - No other measures\n\nLaboratory name and type Tai Lung Veterinary Laboratory, Agriculture,\nFisheries and Conservation Department (National laboratory)\nSpecies Wild species\nTest immunohistochemical test\nTest date 19 Jan 2011\nResult Positive\n\nSpecies Wild species\nTest immunohistochemical test\nTest date 20 Jan 2011\nResult Positive\n\nSpecies Wild species\nTest polymerase chain reaction (PCR)\nTest date 19 Jan 2011\nResult Positive\n\nSpecies Wild species\nTest polymerase chain reaction (PCR)\nTest date 20 Jan 2011\nResult Positive\n\nSpecies Wild species\nTest virus isolation\nTest date 21 Jan 2011\nResult Positive\n\nLaboratory name and type Department of Microbiology, University of\nHong Kong (Regional Reference Laboratory)\nSpecies Wild species\nTest gene sequencing\nTest date\nResult Pending\n\nFuture Reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Oriental Magpie Robins are a common bird in Hong Kong and have\npreviously yielded H5N1 virus in 2009, 2008 and 2006. A Large Billed\nCrow also yielded H5N1 virus in 2009 in Hong Kong. H5N1 has also been\nisolated from both of these wild bird species in Japan and other\nsites in Asia, so the current isolation of virus from these birds is\nfar from unprecedented. It does serve to remind us that we have seen\ndead poultry, wild birds and a person this season in Hong Kong and\ntherefore, Avian influenza still requires intensive surveillance as\nis being done in this instance.\n\nFor pictures of the Oriental Magpie Robin and Large Billed Crows see:\n<http://www.thaibirding.com/features/commonbirdsofthailand.htm>\n\nFor the location of the outbreak, see the map appended to the OIE\nWAHID report or the Healthmap website at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/0nTt> - Mod.PC]", "summary": "Screening; Disinfection of\ninfected premises/establishment(s); No vaccination; No treatment of\naffected animals\n\nMeasures to be applied - No other measures\n\nLaboratory name and type Tai Lung Veterinary Laboratory, Agriculture,\nFisheries and Conservation Department (National laboratory)\n A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 22 \nInformation received on 21 Jan 2011 from Dr Thomas Sit, Chief\nVeterinary Officer / Assistant Director (Inspection & Quarantine),\nAgriculture, Fisheries and Conservation Department, Hong Kong Special\nAdministrative Region Government, Hong Kong , Hong Kong (SAR - PRC) Susceptible\nCases 1\nDeaths 1\nDestroyed 0\n Susceptible\nCases 1\nDeaths 1\nDestroyed 0\n H5N1 has also been\nisolated from both of these wild bird species in Japan and other\nsites in Asia, so the current isolation of virus from these birds is\nfar from unprecedented. Date of previous occurrence 18 Dec 2010\nManifestation of disease: Clinical disease\nCausal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\n It does serve to remind us that we have seen\ndead poultry, wild birds and a person this season in Hong Kong and\ntherefore, Avian influenza still requires intensive surveillance as\nis being done in this instance. For pictures of the Oriental Magpie Robin and Large Billed Crows see:\n<http://www.thaibirding.com/features/commonbirdsofthailand.htm>\n\nFor the location of the outbreak, see the map appended to the OIE\nWAHID report or the Healthmap website at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/0nTt> - Mod. As this report concerns wild birds, the dates of end of\nthe outbreaks are the same as the dates on which the birds were found\n(17 and 18 Jan 2011, respectively). Unknown or inconclusive\n\nEpidemiological comments: An intensive surveillance system is in\nplace for all poultry farms, poultry markets, pet bird shops and wild\nbirds in Hong Kong. Affected Population A Large-billed Crow (Corvus macrorhynchus)\ncarcass was collected on 18 Jan 2011 at Tai O. Large-billed Crow is a\ncommon and widespread resident in Hong Kong. Epidemiological unit Not applicable\nSpecies Wild species\n Disease\nInformation 2011; 24(3) [edited]\n<http://www.oie.int/wahis/public.php?page=single_report&pop=1&reportid=10174>\n\n\n AVIAN INFLUENZA (07): HONG KONG, H5N1, WILD BIRDS, OIE\n******************************************************\n Test gene sequencing\nTest date\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Result Positive\n\nSpecies Wild species\n Result Positive\n\nSpecies Wild species\n Result Positive\n\nSpecies Wild species\n Result Positive\n\nSpecies Wild species\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Oriental Magpie Robins are a common bird in Hong Kong and have\npreviously yielded H5N1 virus in 2009, 2008 and 2006. Date of start of the outbreak 18 Jan 2011\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2011-01-20 00:00:00", "2011-01-18 00:00:00", "2006-03-25 00:00:00", "2017-01-18 20:11:00", "2008-03-25 00:00:00", "2010-12-18 00:00:00", "2009-03-25 00:00:00", "2011-01-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2011-01-21 00:00:00", "2011-01-17 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "Hong Kong"}, {"location": "Hong Kong Special \n Administrative Region Government", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Lantau Island", "country": "Hong Kong"}, {"location": "HONG KONG", "country": "Hong Kong"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "Japan"}, {"location": "WAHID", "country": "Oman"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "637309", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (08): China (HK), H5N1, wild birds", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=637309", "date": "2011-01-25 22:00:04", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (08): CHINA (HONG KONG), H5N1, WILD BIRDS\n*********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nIn this posting:\n[1] Oriental magpie robin\n[2] Oriental magpie robin, large-billed crow\n\n******\n[1] Oriental magpie robin\nDate: Wed 19 Jan 2011\nSource: Hong Kong Agriculture, Fisheries and Conservation Department\n(AFCD) press release [edited]\n<http://www.afcd.gov.hk/english/publications/publications_press/pr1631.html>\n\n\nPreliminary testing of a dead oriental magpie robin found in Yuen Long\nhas come out positive for H5 avian influenza virus, a spokesman for\nthe Agriculture, Fisheries and Conservation Department (AFCD) said\ntoday (19 Jan 2011), adding that further confirmatory tests were being\nconducted.\n\nThe bird's carcass was found and collected on 17 Jan 2011 near a\nrefuse collection point at Fairview Park, Yuen Long. The oriental\nmagpie robin is a common resident bird in Hong Kong.\n\nThe AFCD has reminded the property management company to step up\ncleansing and disinfection.\n\nThe spokesman said that the Mai Po Nature Reserve (MPNR) and 3 chicken\nfarms are within 3 km [1.8 mi] of where the bird was found. AFCD staff\ninspected the farms and found no abnormal mortality or symptoms of\navian influenza among the chicken flocks. These farms will be put\nunder enhanced surveillance.\n\nThe MPNR will remain open to the public. The AFCD will maintain close\ncommunication with the MPNR to ensure that the existing precautionary\nmeasures against avian influenza will be enhanced to safeguard public\nhealth.\n\nIn view of this case, the AFCD has called on poultry farmers reminding\nthem to strengthen precautionary and biosecurity measures against\navian influenza. Letters will be issued to farmers, pet bird shop\nowners, licence holders of pet poultry and racing pigeons, reminding\nthem that proper precautions must be taken.\n\nThe spokesman said the department would conduct frequent inspections\nof poultry farms and the wholesale market to ensure that proper\nprecautions against avian influenza have been implemented. The\ndepartment will continue its wild bird monitoring and surveillance.\n\nIn addition, AFCD staff has inspected 369 villages in Hong Kong since\n4 Jan 2011. So far, unauthorised keeping of poultry has not been\nobserved. The inspections will continue.\n\nA ban on backyard poultry has been in force since 2006. Unauthorised\nkeeping of 5 kinds of poultry -- chickens, ducks, geese, pigeons and\nquails -- is an offence with a maximum fine of [HKD] 50 000 [approx.\nUSD 6400]. Repeat offenders are subject to a maximum fine of [HKD] 100\n000 [approx. USD 12 800].\n\n'People should avoid personal contact with wild birds and live poultry\nand their droppings. They should clean their hands thoroughly after\ncoming into contact with them. The public can call the Call Centre on\n1823 for followup if they come across suspicious sick or dead birds,\nincluding the carcasses of wild birds and poultry,' the spokesman said.\n\nThe Food and Environmental Hygiene Department (FEHD) will continue to\nbe vigilant over imported live poultry as well as live poultry stalls.\nIt will also remind stall operators to maintain good hygiene.\n\nThe Department of Health will keep up with its health education to\nremind the public to maintain strict personal and environmental\nhygiene to prevent avian influenza.\n\nThe AFCD, FEHD, the Customs and Excise Department, and the Police will\nstrive to deter the illegal import of poultry and birds into Hong Kong\nto minimise the risk of avian influenza outbreaks caused by those that\nhave not gone through inspection and quarantine.\n\nAll relevant government departments will continue to remain highly\nvigilant and strictly enforce preventive measures against avian\ninfluenza.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Oriental magpie robin, large-billed crow\nDate: Fri 21 Jan 2011\nSource: Hong Kong Agriculture, Fisheries and Conservation Department\n(AFCD) press release [edited]\n<http://www.afcd.gov.hk/english/publications/publications_press/pr1634.html>\n\n\nUnder the present avian influenza surveillance programme on dead wild\nbirds, test results showed that a dead large-billed crow found in Tai\nO was confirmed to be H5N1 positive, a spokesman for the Agriculture,\nFisheries and Conservation Department (AFCD) said.\n\nThe bird carcass was collected at Sun Ki Street, Tai O on 18 Jan 2011.\nIt was highly decomposed when found and required a series of tests\nbefore avian influenza was confirmed today [21 Jan 2011].\n\nThe spokesman said there were no poultry farms within 3 km [1.8 mi] of\nwhere the dead bird was found. The large-billed crow is a common\nresident bird in Hong Kong.\n\nIn addition, a dead oriental magpie robin collected on 17 Jan 2011\nnear a refuse collection point at Fairview Park, Yuen Long was also\nconfirmed to be H5N1 positive after laboratory testing.\n\nThe AFCD has phoned poultry farmers to remind them to strengthen\nprecautionary and biosecurity measures against avian influenza.\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This report adds details to the previous OIE report posted on ProMED\non 22 Jan 2011, Avian influenza (07): Hong Kong, H5N1, wild birds, OIE\n20110122.0266. Subscribers are encouraged to read the report and\ncomments.\n\nTai O is a little village of 5000 inhabitants on the western shore of\nLantau Island, which is to the west of the city of Hong Kong.\n\nThis winter season (2010-2011) we have had H5N1 confirmation from Hong\nKong in humans, poultry, and wildlife, but no widespread outbreak. The\nsurveillance and regulations enacted in Hong Kong, including the\ninspection of 369 villages since 4 Jan 2011, a ban on backyard poultry\nsince 2006, and heavy fines for unauthorised keeping of poultry so far\nseems to be effective in controlling the spread of the disease.\n\nAlthough all cases from China this season have been concentrated in\nHong Kong, the human case from Hong Kong likely contracted H5N1 in\nMainland China (Shanghai, Nanjing, or Hangzhou) during her travels\nbetween 23 Oct 2010 and 1 Nov 2010. But to this day, no source of the\ninfection has been found in Mainland China.\n(See Avian influenza, human (60): China (Hong Kong) 20101122.4228)\n\nThe confirmation in a large-billed crow is not surprising, since crows\nare scavengers. If there are dead chicken carcasses infected with H5N1\nin the open, as previously reported in ProMED-mail Avian influenza\n(66): Hong Kong, HPAI H5, chicken, OIE 20101224.4529, any scavenging\nbirds ingesting the infected carcass could become infected. Notice\nalso that the oriental magpie robin was found near a refuse collection\npoint. As backyard poultry keeping is banned and almost all poultry\nfarms are now in a closed system, no wild birds should be able to get\ninto the pens. But chickens infected with H5N1, if not properly\ndestroyed and left in the open, could be a source of H5N1 infection\nfor scavenging birds.\n\nOngoing vigilance and surveillance in both poultry and wildlife must continue.\n\nFrom 22 to 25 Jan 2011, no further cases have been reported in Hong Kong.\n\nA map of Hong Kong can be found at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/0oah> - Mod.KL]\n\n[Photos\nOriental magpie robin\n<http://www.avianweb.com/orientalmagpierobins.html>\nLarge-billed crow\n<http://ibc.lynxeds.com/photo/large-billed-crow-corvus-macrorhynchos/adult-0>.\n- Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nIn this posting:\n Preliminary testing of a dead oriental magpie robin found in Yuen Long\nhas come out positive for H5 avian influenza virus, a spokesman for\nthe Agriculture, Fisheries and Conservation Department (AFCD) said\ntoday (19 Jan 2011), adding that further confirmatory tests were being\nconducted. The\nsurveillance and regulations enacted in Hong Kong, including the\ninspection of 369 villages since 4 Jan 2011, a ban on backyard poultry\nsince 2006, and heavy fines for unauthorised keeping of poultry so far\nseems to be effective in controlling the spread of the disease. Under the present avian influenza surveillance programme on dead wild\nbirds, test results showed that a dead large-billed crow found in Tai\nO was confirmed to be H5N1 positive, a spokesman for the Agriculture,\nFisheries and Conservation Department (AFCD) said. If there are dead chicken carcasses infected with H5N1\nin the open, as previously reported in ProMED-mail Avian influenza\n(66): Hong Kong, HPAI H5, chicken, OIE 20101224.4529, any scavenging\nbirds ingesting the infected carcass could become infected. The AFCD, FEHD, the Customs and Excise Department, and the Police will\nstrive to deter the illegal import of poultry and birds into Hong Kong\nto minimise the risk of avian influenza outbreaks caused by those that\nhave not gone through inspection and quarantine. Source: Hong Kong Agriculture, Fisheries and Conservation Department\n(AFCD) press release [edited]\n<http://www.afcd.gov.hk/english/publications/publications_press/pr1634.html>\n\n\n Source: Hong Kong Agriculture, Fisheries and Conservation Department\n(AFCD) press release [edited]\n<http://www.afcd.gov.hk/english/publications/publications_press/pr1631.html>", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2060-03-25 00:00:00", "2011-01-19 00:00:00", "2011-01-04 00:00:00", "2011-01-22 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2011-01-21 00:00:00", "2011-01-17 00:00:00", "2006-03-25 00:00:00", "1823-03-25 00:00:00", "2011-01-18 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "CHINA", "country": "China"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "Hong Kong"}, {"location": "Shanghai", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Nanjing", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Hong \n Kong", "country": "Thailand"}, {"location": "Hangzhou", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Hong Kong Agriculture", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "HONG KONG", "country": "Hong Kong"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "637269", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (08): Japan (MZ), H5N1, poultry, wild birds", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=637269", "date": "2011-01-25 21:00:05", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (08): JAPAN (MIYAZAKI), H5N1, POULTRY, WILD BIRDS\n*****************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 25 Jan 2011\nSource: Wall street Journal [edited]\n<http://blogs.wsj.com/japanrealtime/2011/01/25/bird-flu-blow-to-miyazaki/>\n\n\nBird Flu Blow to Miyazaki\n-------------------------\nSome 410 000 chickens are expected to be culled over the next few days\nin the prefecture. That comes after 20 chickens were found dead 23 Jan\n2011, and a simple examination of 6 of the birds found 5 as being\ninfected by the H5N1 virus in the southern Japanese prefecture that's\nfamous for its agricultural produce, and one of the top producers of\npoultry in the country.\n\nThe ongoing cull follows that of 10 200 chickens over the weekend\nafter 36 of the birds were discovered dead 21 Jan 2011 in a separate\nfarm 8.5km [5.3 miles] away. The government has ordered all birds and\neggs within 10km [6.2 miles] of the farms to be destroyed and has\nagreed to deploy 170 members of the Ground Self-Defense Force to help\nwith the process. While the chickens culled over the weekend were\nincinerated, the 410 000 birds doomed in the latest episode are simply\ntoo many for incineration \u00ad- the bodies will be buried instead.\n\nThe new cases will fuel concerns after an H5N1 outbreak in Shimane\nPrefecture in November 2010, the country's 1st case [in domestic\npoultry] of [HPAI] in 3 years.\n\nStill, Japan is not the only country in the region suffering from the\nscourge of the poultry industry; South Korea's and China have\noutbreaks also.\n\n[Byline: By Yuri Tomikawa]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The current outbreak in Miyazaki is the 4th since the start of this\nepizootic on 29 Nov 2010. It has been promptly reported by Japan to\nthe OIE in follow-up report Number 5. See, with map, at\n<http://www.oie.int/wahis/public.php?page=single_report&pop=1&reportid=10185>.\n\nThe report includes the following epidemiological comments:\n\n'On 21 Jan 2011, a local veterinary officer visited a farm immediately\nafter notification from the farmer and collected specimens for\ninspection. On 22 Jan 2011, Miyazaki prefecture confirmed the samples\nwere positive to influenza A subtype H5 by RT-PCR. All poultry kept in\nthe farm were destroyed by 23 Jan 2011.\n\n'On 23 Jan 2011, the prefecture confirmed [that] samples collected in\nanother farm located at about 8.5 km away from the 1st farm were also\npositive to influenza A subtype H5 by RT-PCR. All poultry kept in the\nsame site (12 henhouses) are being destroyed as susceptible animals.\n\n'The National Institute of Animal Health confirmed [on 24 Jan 2011]\nthat an isolate from the 1st farm contained highly pathogenic avian\ninfluenza [HPAI] viruses subtype H5N1. The virus is a closely-related\nstrain to the viruses isolated in Shimane prefecture, Toyama\nprefecture and Kagoshima prefecture. An isolate from the other farm is\nbeing tested.\n\n'Movement restrictions have been instituted within 10 km around the\n1st farm since 21 Jan 2011, and within 10 km around the other affected\nfarm since 23 Jan 2011.'\n\nSince 16 Dec 2010, 5 H5N1 foci of infection have been reported in wild\nbirds, stretched throughout Japan; a summary of this wildlife event,\nreported separately and including an interactive map, is available at\n<http://www.oie.int/wahis/public.php?page=event_summary&reportid=10072>. The\nmost recent case was covered in follow-up report Number 3, submitted\nto the OIE on 25 Jan 2011. It includes the following epidemiological\ncomments:\n\n'On 19 Jan 2011, a weak whooper swan was detected near a swamp in\nHamanaka-cho, Hokkaido. On 22 Jan 2011, Hokkaido University confirmed\nthat an isolate from the bird contained HPAI virus subtype H5N1.\n\n'In addition, on 23 Jan 2011, the university confirmed that 4 other\ndead wild birds (2 whooper swans, 1 northern pintail and 1 wild duck\n(_Aythya_ genus) collected near the swamp between 12 Jan 2011 and 19\nJan 2011 were also positive to HPAI subtype H5N1.\n\n'There are 4 poultry holdings within 10 km around the swamp. Hokkaido\nconfirmed there was no case in the holdings.' - Mod.AS]\n\n[Whooper swan:\n<http://valerieham.net/graphics/whooperswan.jpg>\nNorthern pintail:\n<http://www.focusonnature.com/BirdLi950.jpg>\nWild duck (_Aethya sp._):\n<http://www.milbourne.net/HOSTEDSITES/blagdonlakebirds/Assets/images/1DS03077%20Drake%20Aythya%20hybrid,%20Cheddar%20Water.JPG>\n- Mod.JW]", "summary": "\n\n[Whooper swan:\n<http://valerieham.net/graphics/whooperswan.jpg>\nNorthern pintail:\n<http://www.focusonnature.com/BirdLi950.jpg>\nWild duck (_Aethya sp._):\n<http://www.milbourne.net/HOSTEDSITES/blagdonlakebirds/Assets/images/1DS03077%20Drake%20Aythya%20hybrid,%20Cheddar%20Water.JPG>\n- Mod. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: In addition, on 23 Jan 2011, the university confirmed that 4 other\ndead wild birds (2 whooper swans, 1 northern pintail and 1 wild duck\n(_Aythya_ genus) collected near the swamp between 12 Jan 2011 and 19\n \n\n'Movement restrictions have been instituted within 10 km around the\n1st farm since 21 Jan 2011, and within 10 km around the other affected\nfarm since 23 Jan 2011.' \n\n'On 23 Jan 2011, the prefecture confirmed [that] samples collected in\nanother farm located at about 8.5 km away from the 1st farm were also\npositive to influenza A subtype H5 by RT-PCR. The\nmost recent case was covered in follow-up report Number 3, submitted\nto the OIE on 25 Jan 2011.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2010-12-16 00:00:00", "2011-01-21 00:00:00", "2011-01-19 00:00:00", "2010-11-25 00:00:00", "2011-01-22 00:00:00", "2011-01-25 00:00:00", "2011-01-24 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2011-01-23 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 {"location": "Hamanaka", "country": "Japan"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "634098", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (06): Japan (FS), H5N1, wild birds", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=634098", "date": "2011-01-21 11:00:05", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (06): JAPAN (FUKUSHIMA), H5N1, WILD BIRDS\n*********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 20 Jan 2011\nSource: The Mainishi Daily News [edited]\n<http://mdn.mainichi.jp/mdnnews/news/20110120p2a00m0na017000c.html>\n\n\nBird flu detected in 2 wild duck corpses at Fukushima reservoir\n---------------------------------------------------------------\nHighly pathogenic H5N1 bird flu has been detected in the corpses of 2\nmigratory wild ducks found at a reservoir here [Koriyama, Fukushima],\nprefectural authorities announced on 19 Jan 2011.\n\nFrom [4 to 7 Jan 2011], the prefecture gathered 7 bird corpses from\nthe reservoir and sent them for testing at the National Institute for\nEnvironmental Studies in Tsukuba, Ibaraki Prefecture. 4 of the\ncorpses tested positive for Type-A influenza, and further\ninvestigation at Hokkaido University in Sapporo found that 2 had the\nhighly pathogenic H5N1 bird flu. The other corpses are still being\ninvestigated.\n\nThe prefecture set up a response center on 19 Jan 2011, and on the\nmorning of 20 Jan 2011 began sending inspectors clad in protective\nsuits to 59 poultry farms in a 10-km [6.2-mile] radius area under\nsupervision that includes neighboring towns. The inspectors are\ninterviewing farmers, looking for signs of contagion such as changes\nin the death or egg-laying rates of chickens, and checking that farms\nhave anti-contagion measures in place such as nets to keep out wild\nbirds and supplies of disinfectant on hand.\n\nFurthermore, nearby roads are being disinfected to prevent possible\ncontagion from bird droppings, and inspectors are watching for any\nbird corpses in the areas where the ducks migrate to. The reservoir\nwhere the duck corpses were found has been disinfected, and the\nprefecture is stepping up observation for wild birds in agricultural\nwater reservoirs in the city.\n\nThe reservoir where the duck corpses were found is located in an\nurban area west of Koriyama Station. According to the Koriyama city\nwater department, the reservoir supplies water to around 22 000\nhomes. The department says the reservoir, treated with chlorine,\npresents no danger to humans. Still, to ease the concerns of\ncitizens, it was decided to temporarily use water from nearby\nInawashiro lake in place of the reservoir.\n\nThe discovery of H5N1 bird flu in Koriyama is the 6th confirmed case\nin the country since October of last year [2010] when it was detected\nin duck droppings in Wakkanai, Hokkaido. Further cases were confirmed\nin Yasugi, Shimane Prefecture, Takaoka, Toyama Prefecture, Yonago,\nTottori Prefecture, and Izumi, Kagoshima Prefecture.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[The above event is included in Japan's follow-up report No 2 of 19\nJan 2011, available at\n<http://www.oie.int/wahis/public.php?page=single_report&pop=1&reportid=10168>.\n\nThe report addresses 2 new outbreaks:\n1. 2 infected dead tufted ducks (_Aythya fuligula_) found at the\nToyoda-cho water purification facility, Koriyama city, Fukushima;\n2. 5 infected hooded cranes (_Grus monacha_) found at the Izumi Crane\nPark, Izumi city, Kagoshima.\n\nThe report includes an interactive map. - Mod.AS]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 20 Jan 2011\n The inspectors are\ninterviewing farmers, looking for signs of contagion such as changes\nin the death or egg-laying rates of chickens, and checking that farms\nhave anti-contagion measures in place such as nets to keep out wild\nbirds and supplies of disinfectant on hand. ---------------------------------------------------------------\nHighly pathogenic H5N1 bird flu has been detected in the corpses of 2\nmigratory wild ducks found at a reservoir here [Koriyama, Fukushima],\nprefectural authorities announced on 19 Jan 2011. The reservoir\nwhere the duck corpses were found has been disinfected, and the\nprefecture is stepping up observation for wild birds in agricultural\nwater reservoirs in the city.\n\n The prefecture set up a response center on 19 Jan 2011, and on the\nmorning of 20 Jan 2011 began sending inspectors clad in protective\nsuits to 59 poultry farms in a 10-km [6.2-mile] radius area under\nsupervision that includes neighboring towns. The report addresses 2 new outbreaks:\n1. 2 infected dead tufted ducks (_Aythya fuligula_) found at the\nToyoda-cho water purification facility, Koriyama city, Fukushima;\n 4 of the\ncorpses tested positive for Type-A influenza, and further\ninvestigation at Hokkaido University in Sapporo found that 2 had the\nhighly pathogenic H5N1 bird flu. Source: The Mainishi Daily News [edited]\n<http://mdn.mainichi.jp/mdnnews/news/20110120p2a00m0na017000c.html>\n\n\nBird flu detected in 2 wild duck corpses at Fukushima reservoir\n From [4 to 7 Jan 2011], the prefecture gathered 7 bird corpses from\nthe reservoir and sent them for testing at the National Institute for\nEnvironmental Studies in Tsukuba, Ibaraki Prefecture. Furthermore, nearby roads are being disinfected to prevent possible\ncontagion from bird droppings, and inspectors are watching for any\nbird corpses in the areas where the ducks migrate to.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2011-01-19 00:00:00", "2011-01-20 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Wakkanai", "country": "Japan"}, {"location": "JAPAN", "country": "Japan"}, {"location": "Kagoshima", "country": "Japan"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "Japan"}, {"location": "Inawashiro", "country": "Japan"}, {"location": "Izumi city", "country": "Japan"}, {"location": "Yasugi", "country": "Japan"}, {"location": "Tsukuba", "country": "Japan"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "623174", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (02): S. Korea (GN, CB) H5N1, conf., update", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=623174", "date": "2011-01-08 17:00:04", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (02): SOUTH KOREA (CHUNGCHEONGNAM-DO, CHOLLA-BUKDO)\nH5N1, CONFIRMED, UPDATE\n*******************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 7 Jan 2011\nSource: Korea Times [edited]\n<http://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/nation/2011/01/113_79336.html>\n\n\n2nd bird flu confirmed\n----------------------\nAnother outbreak of bird flu was confirmed at a duck farm in South\nJeolla Province, Friday [7 Jan 2011]. The government said ducks at\nthe farm in Yeongam tested positive for the virulent strain of the\nH5N1 avian influenza.\n\nThis comes just one week after outbreaks of the highly contagious\nbird disease in Iksan, North Jeolla Province, and Cheonan, North\nChungcheong Province, on 31 Dec 2010, raising concerns that the\ndisease may be spreading across the country.\n\nThe country has already been grappling for more than 2 months with\nthe fast-spreading foot-and-mouth disease.\n\nQuarantine officials said initial on-site tests confirmed that the\nducks in the latest case were infected with the H5N1 strain. All 14\n500 birds on the farm and 84 400 birds on 4 other farms within a\n500-meter radius from the outbreak have been ordered to be culled as\na precautionary measure.\n\nSouth Korea had been hit by avian influenza 3 times before.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The above information is also officially available, namely in South\nKorea's follow-up report Number 3, submitted to the OIE on 7 Jan\n2011. The report, as well as an interactive map showing all 8 HPAI\nH5N1 outbreaks since 20 Nov 2010, is available at\n<http://www.oie.int/wahis/public.php?page=event_summary&reportid=10029>.\n\nOut of the 8 HPAI H5N1 outbreaks, 5 outbreaks related to wild birds,\nnamely 3 in mallard ducks, one in a eagle owl and one in a mandarin\nduck. 3 outbreaks were recorded on commercial farms, of which 2 were\nduck farms and one a chicken farm. - Mod.AS]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 7 Jan 2011\n All 14\n500 birds on the farm and 84 400 birds on 4 other farms within a\n500-meter radius from the outbreak have been ordered to be culled as\na precautionary measure. \n\nOut of the 8 HPAI H5N1 outbreaks, 5 outbreaks related to wild birds,\nnamely 3 in mallard ducks, one in a eagle owl and one in a mandarin\nduck. Korea (GN, CB) H5N1, susp, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=617066", "date": "2011-01-01 10:00:04", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (01): SOUTH KOREA (SOUTH CHUNGCHEON, NORTH JEOLLA),\nH5N1, SUSPECTED, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n**********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 31 Dec 2010\nSource: China Radio International (CRI), Xinhua News Agency report [edited]\n<http://english.cri.cn/6966/2010/12/31/189s612801.htm>\n\n\nS. Korea confirms outbreak of H5N1 bird flu\n-------------------------------------------\nSouth Korea Friday [31 Dec 2010] confirmed an outbreak of bird flu\n[avian A/(H5N1) influenza virus infection] at 2 poultry farms in the\ncentral and southwestern parts of the country.\n\nSuspected cases reported on 29 Dec 2010 from a duck farm in Cheonan,\nSouth Chungcheong province, and a chicken farm in Iksan, North Jeolla\nprovince, tested positive for the H5N1 bird flu virus, the Ministry\nfor Food, Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries said. Both farms have\nbeen placed under quarantine with authorities moving to cull and bury\ntheir ducks and chickens to prevent the spread of the disease. The\nministry has raised the alert level for the disease to 'caution.'\n\nThe country confirmed 3 cases of bird flu from migratory birds earlier\nin the month [December 2010]. In August 2008, South Korea declared\nitself free of bird flu after the country suffered its worst outbreak\nof the disease with nearly 8.5 million birds culled.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[HPAI H5N1 virus was detected on 7 Dec 2010 from a mallard duck,\ncaptured in Iksan city, North Jeolla province, on 29 Nov 2010.\nSimilarly, the said virus was recovered from 2 dead eagle owls, found\non 29 Nov 2010 in Seosan city, South Chungcheong province (more than\n100 km (62 mi) distant from Iksan city). In their OIE notification on\nthe 2 wild ducks, the South Korean veterinary services included the\nfollowing commentary:\n'As part of continuous avian influenza surveillance, avian influenza\ntests in wild birds were conducted. 2 dead eagle owls were found in\nBuseok-myun (Seosan city, [South Chungcheong]) on 29 Nov 2010. Samples\n(faeces, laryngo-pharyngeal swab) were collected. The NVRQS [National\nVeterinary Research and Quarantine Service] found HPAI (H5N1 subtype)\nvirus antigen by PCR and gene sequencing on 10 Dec 2010. Clinical\nsurveillance and disinfection on the neighbouring poultry farms within\n10 km [6.2] around the detection spot were enhanced. So far, no highly\npathogenic avian influenza positive has been detected in poultry.'\n\nThe current information on the detection of H5N1 in domestic ducks and\nchickens on 2 commercial farms in South Korea (still to be officially\nconfirmed), may be a reflection of the virus circulation in wild\nbirds. Genotyping may help in checking this possible connection.\n\nSubscribers are referred to Martin Gilbert's recent commentary in\nProMED-mail archive no. 20101230.4596. - Mod.AS]\n\n[Maps of South Korea can be seen at\n<http://www.nationsonline.org/maps/korea-south-admin-map.jpg> and\n<http://healthmap.org/r/00bh>. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]", "summary": "In their OIE notification on\nthe 2 wild ducks, the South Korean veterinary services included the\nfollowing commentary:\n'As part of continuous avian influenza surveillance, avian influenza\ntests in wild birds were conducted. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 31 \n\nSuspected cases reported on 29 Dec 2010 from a duck farm in Cheonan,\nSouth Chungcheong province, and a chicken farm in Iksan, North Jeolla\nprovince, tested positive for the H5N1 bird flu virus, the Ministry\nfor Food, Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries said. The current information on the detection of H5N1 in domestic ducks and\nchickens on 2 commercial farms in South Korea (still to be officially\nconfirmed), may be a reflection of the virus circulation in wild\nbirds. Similarly, the said virus was recovered from 2 dead eagle owls, found\non 29 Nov 2010 in Seosan city, South Chungcheong province (more than\n100 km (62 mi) distant from Iksan city). In August 2008, South Korea declared\nitself free of bird flu after the country suffered its worst outbreak\nof the disease with nearly 8.5 million birds culled. The NVRQS [National\nVeterinary Research and Quarantine Service] found HPAI (H5N1 subtype)\nvirus antigen by PCR and gene sequencing on 10 Dec 2010. Clinical\nsurveillance and disinfection on the neighbouring poultry farms within\n10 km [6.2] around the detection spot were enhanced. Both farms have\nbeen placed under quarantine with authorities moving to cull and bury\ntheir ducks and chickens to prevent the spread of the disease. Dec 2010\nSource: China Radio International (CRI), Xinhua News Agency report [edited]\n<http://english.cri.cn/6966/2010/12/31/189s612801.htm>\n\n\n AVIAN INFLUENZA (01): SOUTH KOREA (SOUTH CHUNGCHEON, NORTH JEOLLA),\nH5N1, SUSPECTED, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2010-12-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2010-12-07 00:00:00", "2010-12-25 00:00:00", "2010-12-29 00:00:00", "2008-08-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "South Chungcheong", "country": "South Korea"}, {"location": "S. Exports of poultry will not be affected\nby the discovery, it stressed.\n\nThe wild birds were found dead in Seosan, 151 km south of Seoul [map\nat <http://healthmap.org/r/0iMv>]. Local quarantine officials carried\nout routine tests and discovered the birds had the H5N1 strain of the\ninfluenza virus, the ministry said.\n\nBird flu is an air-borne disease that is usually transmitted between\nanimals. The disease can spread to humans, but no human cases have\nbeen reported in the country so far.\n\nThe country's quarantine authorities, meanwhile, have stepped up an\nexisting bird flu prevention campaign after a wild duck on the\nMangyeong River tested positive for the influenza virus earlier in\nthe week [archived 20101208.4377].\n\nThe country was hit a total of 3 times by avian influenza, with the\nlatest outbreak occurring in April of 2008 and resulting in a record\n8.46 million birds being culled at a cost of around 264 billion won\n[USD 215.7 million]. Previous outbreaks took place in the winter\nmonths of 2003-2004 and 2006-2007.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[The above newswire reports that the 2 eagle owls were 'infected with\nthe virulent strain of bird flu' and that 'routine tests discovered\nthe birds had the H5N1 strain.' Official laboratory confirmation,\nincluding pathogenicity, are anticipated.\n\nThe HPAI H5N1 case detected in a wild mallard (_Anas platyrhynchos_)\ncollected on 29 Nov 2010 in the Cholla-Bukdo province (also known as\nJeollabuk-do, or North Jeolla), as reported in archived\n20101208.4377, has been laboratory confirmed on 7 Dec 2010.\nAccordingly, S. Korea notified the OIE about this finding on 9 Dec\n2010 [see 20101211.4410]. The immediate notification, with map, is\navailable at\n<http://www.oie.int/wahis/public.php?page=single_report&pop=1&reportid=10029>.\nIt includes the following epidemiological comment:\n\n'As part of a continuous avian influenza surveillance programme, 39\nwild birds were captured, and samples (faeces, laryngo-pharyngeal\nswab) were collected. The NVRQS found avian influenza antigen (H5) by\nPCR and confirmed it as highly pathogenic avian influenza (H5N1)\nvirus by gene sequencing from one mallard duck on 7 Dec 2010.\nClinical surveillance and disinfection on the neighbouring poultry\nfarms were enhanced.'\n\nThe current case, in Seosan, in the province Chungcheongnam-do (South\nChungcheong or Chungnam), is situated at a distance of at least 120\nkm from the mallard duck case, mentioned above. If confirmed as HPAI\nH5N1, it means a wider circulation of the virus within wild birds.\n\nIn any event, such findings demonstrate the merit of the surveillance\npolicy applied by the S. Korean authorities. Early detection of\ncirculating virus enables preventive measures to be undertaken in a\ntimely manner in commercial farms. - Mod.AS]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 10 Dec 2010\n \n\nThe country was hit a total of 3 times by avian influenza, with the\nlatest outbreak occurring in April of 2008 and resulting in a record\n8.46 million birds being culled at a cost of around 264 billion won\n Source: Yonhap News [edited]\n<http://english.yonhapnews.co.kr/business/2010/12/10/0501000000AEN20101210007700320.HTML>\n\n\nSouth Korean quarantine officials found 2 dead eagle owls infected\nwith the virulent strain of bird flu in the central western part of\nthe country on Friday [10 Dec 2010]. see summary and map at\n<http://www.oie.int/wahis/public.php?page=event_summary&reportid=6934>.\n\nSince September 2008, a surveillance protocol has been operational in\nall parent stock duck farms. Consequently, low-pathogenic avian\ninfluenza (LPAI) strains have been discovered several times (October\n2008, H5N2; December 2008, H5N2; December 2009, H7N2; December 2009,\nH5N2; June-July 2010, H7N7; October 2010, H7N7; November 2010, H7N6).\n\nSouth Korea maintains exemplary transparency and a meticulous, timely\nreporting system regarding its AI situation. Details on the identity\nof the affected bird and the pathogenicity of the H5N1 virus strain\nare anticipated soon. - Mod.AS]\n\n[The HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of South Korea can be seen at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/0in*>. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 8 Dec 2010\n Consequently, low-pathogenic avian\ninfluenza (LPAI) strains have been discovered several times (October\n2008, H5N2; December 2008, H5N2; December 2009, H7N2; December 2009,\nH5N2; June-July 2010, H7N7; October 2010, H7N7; November 2010, H7N6). The ministry conducted an emergency disinfection of the area around\nthe Mangyeong River, where the infected wild bird was found, and put\nan area within a 10-km [6 mi] radius from the site of the outbreak\nunder intensive care. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[South Korea's last HPAI H5N1 epizootic occurred between January and\nMay 2008, involving 33 outbreaks; see summary and map at\n<http://www.oie.int/wahis/public.php?page=event_summary&reportid=6934>. \n\n'This case of bird influenza was found in a wild bird, so the virus\nmay not have been spread to farm-raised poultry yet,' a senior\nministry official said, requesting anonymity. \n\nThe agricultural ministry said the state veterinary service confirmed\nthat the bird flu virus was found in one of the blood samples sent\nfrom Iksan, The South Korean government confirmed on Tuesday [7 Dec 2010] a bird\nflu [avian influenza] outbreak in a southwestern region of the\ncountry, a main winter habitat of migratory birds.", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-30 00:00:00", "2009-12-25 00:00:00", "2008-10-25 00:00:00", "2008-12-25 00:00:00", "2008-09-25 00:00:00", "2008-05-25 00:00:00", "2010-10-25 00:00:00", "2010-11-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "SOUTH KOREA", "country": "South Korea"}, {"location": "South Korea 's", "country": "North Korea"}, {"location": "Iksan", "country": "South Korea"}, {"location": "North Jeolla", "country": "South Korea"}, {"location": "South Korea", "country": "South Korea"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "602564", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (61): South Korea (CB), H5N1, OIE", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=602564", "date": "2010-12-11 11:00:04", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (61): SOUTH KOREA (CHOLLA-BUKDO), H5N1, OIE\n************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 10 Dec 2010\nSource: OIE WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database) Disease\nInformation 2010; 23(49) [edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis/public.php?page=single_report&pop=1&reportid=10029\n\n\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza, Korea (Rep. of)\n--------------------------------------------------\nInformation received on 09 Dec 2010 from Dr Kiyoon Chang, CVO and\nDirector, Quarantine Policy Division, Food Safety and Consumer\nAffairs Policy Bureau, MIFAFF (Ministry of Food, Agriculture,\nForestry and Fisheries), Gyeonggi-Do, Korea (Rep. of)\n\nSummary\nReport type: Immediate notification (Final report)\nStart date 29 Nov 2010\nDate of 1st confirmation of the event 07 Dec 2010\nReport date 09 Dec 2010\nDate submitted to OIE 09 Dec 2010\nDate event resolved 07 Dec 2010\nReason for notification:Reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence 15 May 2008\nManifestation of disease: Sub-clinical infection\nCausal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virus Serotype H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: Laboratory (advanced)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country\n\nNew outbreaks\nOutbreak 1 Chunpo-ri, Chunpo-myun, Iksan city, Cholla-Bukdo\nDate of start of the outbreak 29 Nov 2010\nOutbreak status: Resolved (07 Dec 2010)\nEpidemiological unit Not applicable\nAffected animals\nSpecies Wild species\nSusceptible 39\nCases 1\nDeaths 0\nDestroyed 0\nSlaughtered 0\n\nAffected Population Anas platyrhynchos (mallard duck)\n\nEpidemiology- Source of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection.\nUnknown or inconclusive\n\nEpidemiological comments: As part of a continuous avian influenza\nsurveillance programme, 39 wild birds were captured and samples\n(faeces, laryngo-pharyngeal swab) were collected. The NVRQS found\navian influenza antigen (H5) by PCR and confirmed it as highly\npathogenic avian influenza (H5N1) virus by gene sequencing from one\nmallard duck on 7 December 2010. Clinical surveillance and\ndisinfection on the neighbouring poultry farms were enhanced.\n\nControl measures - Measures applied: Movement control inside the\ncountry; Zoning; Disinfection of infected premises/establishment(s);\nVaccination prohibited; No treatment of affected animals\n\nMeasures to be applied - No other measures\n\nLaboratory name and type: National Veterinary Research and\nQuarantine Service (NVRQS) (National laboratory)\nSpecies Wild species\nTest gene sequencing\nTest date 07 Dec 2010\nResult Positive\n\nSpecies Wild species\nTest reverse transcription - polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR)\nTest date 07 Dec 2010\nResult Positive\n\nFuture Reporting\nThe event is resolved. No more reports will be submitted.\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The finding of H5N1 in a single mallard duck as part of South Korea\nmulti-sectorial surveillance program should not cause undue concern.\nThat they will not be embarking on a 2nd eradication program in the\ncountry must be a relief indeed as the South Korea animal health\nauthorities certainly have their work cut out for them battling the\ncurrent FMD outbreak there.\n\nHowever, it is commendable that the South Koreans are doing intensive\nsurveillance which can identify events such as these. Mallard can\nharbor both low pathogenic and high pathogenic strains of avian\ninfluenza and either type can be transmitted efficiently from Mallard\nto other wild or commercial ducks. Webster's group at St. Jude's\nsummarized their studies in this regard below: This Article, in\nsummary, suggests that close monitoring of H5N1 in mallard ducks is\nessential to protecting both human and animal health.\n\nSee abstract below for the following journal publication: Are Ducks\nContributing to the Endemicity of Highly Pathogenic H5N1 Influenza\nVirus in Asia? K. M. Sturm-Ramirez,1 D. J. Hulse-Post,1 E. A.\nGovorkova,1 J. Humberd,1 P. Seiler,1 P. Puthavathana,2 C.\nBuranathai,3 T. D. Nguyen,4 A. Chaisingh,5 H. T. Long,6 T. S. P.\nNaipospos,7 H. Chen,8 T. M. Ellis,9 Y. Guan,10,11 J. S. M.\nPeiris,10,11 and R. G. Webster1,12*\n\nJournal of Virology, September 2005, p. 11269-11279, Vol. 79, No. 17\n1269-11279. <http://jvi.asm.org/cgi/content/short/79/17/11269>\n\nWild waterfowl are the natural reservoir of all influenza A viruses,\nand these viruses are usually nonpathogenic in these birds. However,\nsince late 2002, H5N1 outbreaks in Asia have resulted in mortality\namong waterfowl in recreational parks, domestic flocks, and wild\nmigratory birds. The evolutionary stasis between influenza virus and\nits natural host may have been disrupted, prompting us to ask whether\nwaterfowl are resistant to H5N1 influenza virus disease and whether\nthey can still act as a reservoir for these viruses.\n\nTo better understand the biology of H5N1 viruses in ducks and attempt\nto answer this question, we inoculated juvenile mallards with 23\ndifferent H5N1 influenza viruses isolated in Asia between 2003 and\n2004. All virus isolates replicated efficiently in inoculated ducks,\nand 22 were transmitted to susceptible contacts. Viruses replicated\nto higher levels in the trachea than in the cloaca of both inoculated\nand contact birds, suggesting that the digestive tract is not the\nmain site of H5N1 influenza virus replication in ducks and that the\nfecal-oral route may no longer be the main transmission path. The\nvirus isolates' pathogenicities varied from completely nonpathogenic\nto highly lethal and were positively correlated with tracheal virus\ntiters.\n\nNevertheless, the 8 virus isolates that were nonpathogenic in ducks\nreplicated and transmitted efficiently to naive contacts, suggesting\nthat highly pathogenic H5N1 viruses causing minimal signs of disease\nin ducks can propagate silently and efficiently among domestic and\nwild ducks in Asia and that they represent a serious threat to human\nand veterinary public health.\n\nThe location of the outbreak can be seen on a map appended to the OIE\nreport or on the Healthmap reporting system at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/00bh>. - Mod.PC]", "summary": "Nevertheless, the 8 virus isolates that were nonpathogenic in ducks\nreplicated and transmitted efficiently to naive contacts, suggesting\nthat highly pathogenic H5N1 viruses causing minimal signs of disease\nin ducks can propagate silently and efficiently among domestic and\nwild ducks in Asia and that they represent a serious threat to human\nand veterinary public health. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 10 Dec 2010\n Information received on 09 Dec 2010 from Dr Kiyoon Chang, CVO and\nDirector, Quarantine Policy Division, Food Safety and Consumer\nAffairs Policy Bureau, MIFAFF (Ministry of Food, Agriculture,\nForestry and Fisheries), Gyeonggi-Do, Korea (Rep. of)\n\nSummary\nReport type: Immediate notification (Final report)\n \n\nControl measures - Measures applied: Movement control inside the\ncountry; Zoning; Disinfection of infected premises/establishment(s);\nVaccination prohibited; No treatment of affected animals\n\nMeasures to be applied - No other measures\n\nLaboratory name and type: National Veterinary Research and\nQuarantine Service (NVRQS) (National laboratory)\n Viruses replicated\nto higher levels in the trachea than in the cloaca of both inoculated\nand contact birds, suggesting that the digestive tract is not the\nmain site of H5N1 influenza virus replication in ducks and that the\nfecal-oral route may no longer be the main transmission path. The NVRQS found\navian influenza antigen (H5) by PCR and confirmed it as highly\npathogenic avian influenza (H5N1) virus by gene sequencing from one\nmallard duck on 7 December 2010. \n\nTo better understand the biology of H5N1 viruses in ducks and attempt\nto answer this question, we inoculated juvenile mallards with 23\ndifferent H5N1 influenza viruses isolated in Asia between 2003 and\n2004. The evolutionary stasis between influenza virus and\nits natural host may have been disrupted, prompting us to ask whether\nwaterfowl are resistant to H5N1 influenza virus disease and whether\nthey can still act as a reservoir for these viruses. Mallard can\nharbor both low pathogenic and high pathogenic strains of avian\ninfluenza and either type can be transmitted efficiently from Mallard\nto other wild or commercial ducks. That they will not be embarking on a 2nd eradication program in the\ncountry must be a relief indeed as the South Korea animal health\nauthorities certainly have their work cut out for them battling the\ncurrent FMD outbreak there.\n\n The\nvirus isolates' pathogenicities varied from completely nonpathogenic\nto highly lethal and were positively correlated with tracheal virus\ntiters. Webster's group at St. Jude's\nsummarized their studies in this regard below: This Article, in\nsummary, suggests that close monitoring of H5N1 in mallard ducks is\nessential to protecting both human and animal health. However,\nsince late 2002, H5N1 outbreaks in Asia have resulted in mortality\namong waterfowl in recreational parks, domestic flocks, and wild\nmigratory birds. \nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Unknown or inconclusive\n\nEpidemiological comments: As part of a continuous avian influenza\nsurveillance programme, 39 wild birds were captured and samples\n(faeces, laryngo-pharyngeal swab) were collected. ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 6 Dec 2010\nSource: USAgNet via Wisconsin Ag connection [edited]\n<http://www.wisconsinagconnection.com/story-national.php?Id=2425&yr=2010>\n\n\nAuthorities in Japan have confirmed that the earlier outbreak of bird\nflu on a layer farm was caused by the H5N1 sub-type of the highly\npathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) virus.\n\nThe veterinary authorities sent an immediate notification last week\nto the World Organisation for Animal Health [see comment].\n\nThe report confirms that the outbreak of bird flu at a layer farm at\nYasugi city in Shimane prefecture in the southwest of Honshu was\ncaused by the H5N1 HPAI virus. The outbreak started on 27 Nov 2010.\nIn total, 57 birds died, but the remaining 21 549 layers have been destroyed.\n\nAccording to the report, the outbreak of HPAI was confirmed on 2 Dec\n2010 in Shimane prefecture. The previous outbreak of HPAI in Japan\nstarted in April 2008.\n\nThe event has been contained in the affected farm by control measures\nincluding stamping-out and movement restrictions.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Japan's immediate OIE notification on this outbreak, dated 2 Dec\n2010, was included in posting 20101202.4330; it referred to the\ncausative agent as HPAI H5. Up till 25\nMay 2010, a total of 170 dead wild birds have been seen, including 141\nbrown-headed gulls, 27 bar-headed geese, one chough and one wigeon. No\nmore dead wild birds showed up after 25 May 2010.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Brown-headed gull (_Larus brunnicephalus_):\n<http://commondatastorage.googleapis.com/static.panoramio.com/photos/original/23231179.jpg>\nBar-headed goose (Anser indicus_):\n<http://farm4.static.flickr.com/3185/2626953609_15de6210f6_b.jpg>\nChough (_Pyrrhocorax pyrrhocorax_):\n<http://www.abdn.ac.uk/mediareleases/uploadedimages/images/Chough-image.jpg>\nEurasian Wigeon (_Anas penelope_):\n<http://www.birdskorea.org/Images/images2009/02/Eurasian-Wigeon_RN.jpg.\n\n- Mod.JW]\n\n[Nagqu Prefecture (also Naqu or Nagchu) is the largest prefecture of\nthe Tibet Autonomous Region; see map at\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nagqu_Prefecture>.\n- Mod.AS]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 10 Jun 2010\n \n\nSoon after receiving the report, the Ministry of Agriculture sent\nexperts to Co Nyi to take preventive measures together with the local\nDepartments of Forestry and Veterinary services, such as monitoring\nwild birds and informing farmers and herdsmen of the related measures.
