worldwide (55)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=211882", "date": "2009-06-03 23:00:07", "main_text": "INFLUENZA A (H1N1) - WORLDWIDE (55)\n***********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Clinical outreach\n[2] Cruise ships\n\n******\n[1] Clinical outreach\nDate: Mon 1 Jun 2009\nFrom: Clinician Outreach and Communication Activity, Centers for\nDisease Control and Prevention (CDC) [edited]\n<http://www.cdc.gov>\n\n\n[The following sources provide regularly updated information on\nclinical aspects of infection with the novel 2009 strain of A (H1N1)\nvirus infection - Mod.CP]\n\nNovel H1N1 Influenza\n--------------------\nInformation on the novel H1N1 influenza investigation is posted daily\nto the CDC website at\n<http://www.cdc.gov/h1n1flu>.\n\nNovel H1N1 Influenza: Resources for Clinicians - CDC (1 Jun 2009)\n-----------------------------------------------------------------\nThis page is designed to give clinicians access to the latest\nguidelines and information on the evolving novel H1N1 influenza\ninvestigation.\n<http://www.cdc.gov/h1n1flu/clinicians>\n\nRecent Research Results: 2009 H1N1 Influenza Virus - USDA - 2 May 2009\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nUSDA's Agricultural Research Service researchers tested serum samples\nfrom pigs previously infected with U.S. swine influenza viruses or\nvaccinated with commercial vaccines to determine whether U.S.\ncommercial swine herds are susceptible to the new swine origin (S/O)\nH1N1 influenza virus. They found that there was limited cross\nreactivity against the new S/O H1N1 influenza virus.\n<http://www.ars.usda.gov/2009H1N1/#results>\n\nClinical Resources: The Electronic Preventive Services Selector (ePSS)\n- AHRQ (26 May 2009)\n-------------\nThe ePSS application is designed to help primary care clinicians\nidentify the screening, counseling, and preventive medication services\nthat are appropriate for their patients. This web-based and\nPDA-downloadable application is continually expanding its mobile\ndevice support and is now available for download to the Apple iPhone\n<http://epss.ahrq.gov/PDA/index.jsp>.\n\n--\nCommunicated by::\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n******\n[2] Cruise ships\nDate: Tue 2 Jun 2009\nSource: ABC News [edited]\n<http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2009/06/02/2586888.htm>\n\n\nAn Australian cruise ship has been turned away from New Caledonia amid\nfears of swine flu. The Dawn Princess cruise liner was prevented from\nstopping after up to 5 people on board started showing flu-like\nsymptoms. Swabs have been taken from the sick passengers and sent to\nSydney for testing.\n\nDr Jeremy McAnulty from New South Wales Health says the ship has not\nbeen to any swine flu infected countries, but they are still being\ncautious. 'We've learnt a lot from cruise ships and transmission of\ndiseases over the last few years, but also particularly in the past\nweek or so,' he said. 'We're working to identify people who may have\nhad infections on board to help determine whether it was swine flu or\nsomething else.' The ship is now heading back to Sydney and will\narrive on Friday [5 Jun 2009].\n\nToday [2 Jun 2009], the number of confirmed cases of swine flu in\nAustralia has risen to about 500, with Victoria's tally now at 395.\nCruise ships have been in the spotlight since late last month [May\n2009], when about 3000 passengers and crew on board the Dawn Princess\nwere not allowed to leave the ship [on its return to] Sydney because 4\npassengers displayed mild flu symptoms. The passengers and crew were\nthen allowed to disembark but told to remain in home isolation until\nthe all clear was given.\n\nThen cases of swine flu appeared on the P&O cruise ship Pacific Dawn,\nwhich docked in Sydney yesterday [1 Jun 2009]. The 1800 passengers on\nthe ship were cleared of swine flu and were allowed to disembark,\nalthough 3 crew members were confirmed to have the virus. Passengers\non the ship's previous cruise were found to have swine flu. Yesterday\n[1 Jun 2009], the chief executive of Carnival Cruises, which runs P&O,\nsaid passengers might be screened before they boarded the ship for its\nnext cruise to the South Pacific.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nKen Cokanasiga <kenc@spc.int>\n\n[Passengers disembarking from cruise ships clearly could be a risk\nfactor for introduction of the novel 2009 influenza A (H1N1) virus\ninto island communities previously free of infection. For the cruise\nship passengers, on the other hand, the presence of a few infected\nindividuals so far has not had the dire consequences accompanying\noutbreaks of norovirus infection on board cruise ships. It would be\ninteresting to know whether the age spectrum of the passengers has\naffected the spread of infection among them and the crew, since older\nage groups seem to have been less vulnerable to the swine-derived A\n(H1N1) strain infection than younger age groups. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Clinical outreach\n ----------------------------------------------------------------------\nUSDA's Agricultural Research Service researchers tested serum samples\nfrom pigs previously infected with U.S. swine influenza viruses or\nvaccinated with commercial vaccines to determine whether U.S.\ncommercial swine herds are susceptible to the new swine origin (S/O)\n It would be\ninteresting to know whether the age spectrum of the passengers has\naffected the spread of infection among them and the crew, since older\nage groups seem to have been less vulnerable to the swine-derived A\n(H1N1) strain infection than younger age groups. Cruise ships have been in the spotlight since late last month [May\n2009], when about 3000 passengers and crew on board the Dawn Princess\nwere not allowed to leave the ship [on its return to] Sydney because 4\npassengers displayed mild flu symptoms. For the cruise\nship passengers, on the other hand, the presence of a few infected\nindividuals so far has not had the dire consequences accompanying\noutbreaks of norovirus infection on board cruise ships. This web-based and\nPDA-downloadable application is continually expanding its mobile\ndevice support and is now available for download to the Apple iPhone\n<http://epss.ahrq.gov/PDA/index.jsp>. ' This page is designed to give clinicians access to the latest\nguidelines and information on the evolving novel H1N1 influenza\ninvestigation.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "norovirus infection"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2009-05-26 00:00:00", "2009-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 00:00:00", "2009-06-01 00:00:00", "2009-06-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Caledonia", "country": "New Caledonia"}, {"location": "Sydney", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "Australia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "167018", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (26): France, LPAI, (CV) H5N1, (PC) H5", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=167018", "date": "2009-03-22 18:00:50", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (26): FRANCE, LPAI, (CALVADOS) H5N1, (PAS-DE-CALAIS) H5\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 19 Mar 2009\nSource: Defra Global Animal Health, Food and Farming Group,\nReference: VITT/LPAI - France [edited]\n<http://www.defra.gov.uk/animalh/diseases/monitoring/pdf/hpa-france.pdf>\n\n\n1) Disease Report: France has reported an outbreak of H5N1 LPAI in\ndecoy ducks on a premises in Calvados and a 2nd outbreak of H5 (not\nN1) in decoy ducks in Pas-de Calais [see map at the above URL]. The\nsite in Calvados contains 45 ducks in 2 aviaries covered with fencing\nand kept by one hunter. Two of 10 ducks tested positive for H5N1\nLPAI. The 2nd premises in Pas-de-Calais contained 563 ducks in 32\nadjacent aviaries owned by a hunter cooperative.\n\nDuring routine surveillance, 5 ducks each from 3 of the 32 aviaries\nwere tested for avian influenza. Two ducks from one aviary were\npositive, while the other 10 ducks from the 2 aviaries were negative.\nBoth the infected premises have been placed under surveillance, and\nbiosecurity has been increased, but other disease controls have not\nbeen applied, and the affected birds were not culled (European\nCommission 2009).\n\n2) Situation Assessment: Decoy ducks are used as captive birds to\nlure wild birds to a shooting area for hunting. They are kept\ntethered when they are taken out to water and have little direct\ncontact with wild birds. The French authorities will continue to\nconduct surveillance for the time being. As there are no commercial\npoultry premises within a one-km radius of the 2 premises, no\nrestriction zones have been imposed.\n\nAccording to EU rules, immediate culling of birds infected with LPAI\nis not required, but they must be kept under restrictions.\n\nThere have been previous reports of LPAI H5N1 being detected in wild\nbirds in Italy and France. Laboratory tests of these viruses\nsuggested there was no relationship to Asian HPAI H5N1 strains. There\nmay be some limited wild bird movements between North France and\nSouth East England at this time of year.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nSabine Zentis\nGut Laach\n52385 Nideggen\nGermany\n<CVLonghorns@aol.com>", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 19 Mar 2009\n Both the infected premises have been placed under surveillance, and\nbiosecurity has been increased, but other disease controls have not\nbeen applied, and the affected birds were not culled (European\nCommission 2009). Germany's eastern state government of Saxony said the H5N1\nbird flu strain had been confirmed in a duck at a poultry farm near Dresden.\n\n'Tests have confirmed that this involves the highly contagious\nversion of the H5N1 virus epidemic,' said Ralph Schreiber, spokesman\nfor Saxony's social welfare ministry.\n\nThe flu strain was detected during a routine examination at the farm,\nwhich held some 1400 birds. All birds at the farm have been\nslaughtered as a precaution, the state said.\n\nA 3-km (2-mile) radius quarantine zone has been established around\nthe farm and a 10-km [6.2-mile] radius observation zone also was\nestablished in which all poultry must be locked up in buildings.\n\nBird flu was last detected in farm birds in Germany in December 2007.\nA spokeswoman for Germany's federal Agriculture Ministry stressed\nstate authorities were responsible for combating bird flu. Officials\nwere currently assessing the risk level. Relevant international\norganisations including the European Union plus neighbouring\ncountries had been informed of the case, she said.\n\nThe virus has infected 387 people worldwide in 15 countries, killing\n245 of them, according to the World Health Organization's 10 Aug 2008\ntally. Indonesia has the highest toll of any nation. Although bird\nflu remains an animal disease, experts fear that the virus might\nmutate into a form easily passed from human to human.\n\n[Byline: Michael Hogan]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[Germany submitted today (10 Oct 2008) to the OIE an 'Immediate\nnotification' on this outbreak. It included a map, demonstrating the\nvicinity of the affected holding to the Polish and Czech borders, and\n-- among others -- the following remarks:\n\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Unknown or inconclusive.\n\nEpidemiological comments: There were no movements of animals into or\nout of the holding concerned within the last 21 days.\nThe detection of HPAI H5N1 was performed in relation to routine\nlaboratory investigation.\n\nSee at\n<http://www.oie.int/wahid-prod/public.php?page=single_report&pop=1&reportid=7416>.\n- Mod.AS]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 10 Oct 2008\n --------------------------------------------\nGerman authorities said on Friday [10 Oct 2008] that the lethal\nstrain of bird flu has been confirmed on a farm in the east of the\ncountry. \n\nA 3-km (2-mile) radius quarantine zone has been established around\nthe farm and a 10-km [6.2-mile] radius observation zone also was\nestablished in which all poultry must be locked up in buildings. \n\nThe virus has infected 387 people worldwide in 15 countries, killing\n245 of them, according to the World Health Organization's 10 Aug 2008\ntally. \n\n'Tests have confirmed that this involves the highly contagious\nversion of the H5N1 virus epidemic,' said Ralph Schreiber, spokesman\nfor Saxony's social welfare ministry. Total deaths 2003-2009\n\nAzerbaijan / nil / nil / 8 / 5\nBangladesh / nil / nil / 1 / nil\nCambodia / 1 / nil / 9 / 7\nChina / 7 / 4 / 38 / 25\n A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 30 Dec 2009\n The following human cases of avian influenza A (H5N1) have been\nreported to WHO as of 30 Dec 2009:\n\nCountry / Cases in 2009 / Deaths in 2009 / Total cases 2003-2009 /\n Djibouti / nil / nil / 1 / nil\nEgypt / 39 / 4 / 90 / 27\n Indonesia / 20 / 19 / 161 / 134\nIraq / nil / nil / 3 / 2\n", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2009-12-25 00:00:00", "2009-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2003-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Djibouti", "country": "Djibouti"}, {"location": "Indonesia", "country": "Indonesia"}, {"location": "Pakistan", "country": "Pakistan"}, {"location": "Egypt", "country": "Egypt"}, {"location": "Cambodia", "country": "Cambodia"}, {"location": "Myanmar", "country": "Myanmar"}, {"location": "Thailand", "country": "Thailand"}, {"location": "Iraq", "country": "Iraq"}, {"location": "Turkey", "country": "Turkey"}, {"location": "Viet Nam", "country": "Vietnam"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "158383", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (14): S Korea LPNAI H5, Viet Nam HPNAI H5N1", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=158383", "date": "2009-02-19 19:00:47", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (14): SOUTH KOREA LPNAI H5, VIET NAM HPNAI H5N5\n***************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nIn this update:\n[1] South Korea: LPNAI H5\n[2] Viet Nam: HPNAI H5N1\n\n******\n[1] South Korea: LPNAI H5\nDate: Wed 18 Feb 2009\nSource: Xinhua News Agency [in Chinese, trans. Rappt.DS, edited]\n<http://news.xinhuanet.com/world/2009-02/18/content_10842186.htm>\n\n\nKorea's Ministry for Food, Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries\nconfirmed on 18 Feb 2009 that avian influenza recently occurred on 3\nchicken farms in Korea's Suncheon and other parts of Jeollanam-do\n[South Jeolla] Province.\n\nThe Ministry said that tests carried out on blood samples taken from\npoultry on 3 chicken farms in Suncheon, Gokseong County, and Boseong\nCounty in Jeollanam-do Province confirmed that the avian influenza\nvirus found on all 3 chicken farms is low pathogenic H5 subtype.\n\nA total of 22 000 chickens on the 3 farms have been culled.\n\n[Byline: Gan Yulan]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Dan Silver\n\n[According to OIE's International Animal Health Code, all\nlow-pathogenic avian influenza viruses of the H5 or H7 subtypes are\nnotifiable, hence termed 'low pathogenic notifiable avian influenza'\n(LPNAI). The pathogenicity of avian influenza viruses is defined\naccording to criteria which are detailed in the code: highly\npathogenic viruses are those which have an intravenous pathogenicity\nindex (IVPI) greater than 1.2 in 6-week-old chickens, or, as an\nalternative, cause at least 75 percent mortality in 4-to 8-week-old\nchickens infected intravenously. H5 and H7 viruses which do not have\nan IVPI of greater than 1.2 or cause less than 75 percent mortality\nin an intravenous lethality test, should be sequenced to determine\nwhether multiple basic amino acids are present at the cleavage site\nof the haemagglutinin molecule; if the amino acid motif is similar to\nthat observed for other highly pathogenic isolates, the isolate being\ntested should be considered as highly pathogenic notifiable avian\ninfluenza (HPNAI).\n\nLPNAI are all influenza A viruses of H5 and H7 subtype that are not\nHPNAI viruses. Further background on the laboratory diagnosis of\navian influenza is available at\n<http://oie.int/eng/normes/mmanual/2008/pdf/2.03.04_AI.pdf>\n\nIn October 2008, LPNAI H5N2 was identified in Southern Chungcheong\nand reported to the OIE. This event was reportedly resolved on 31 Dec\n2008 (see OIE report at\n<http://www.oie.int/wahis/public.php?page=single_report&pop=1&reportid=7646>).\n\nConfirmation (or otherwise) of the Xinhua News Agency information and\n-- in case confirmed -- typing of the neuraminidase component of the\ncurrent South Korean LPNAI virus, and its notification to the OIE,\nare expected soon. - Mod.AS]\n\n[The HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of South Korea is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed/en?g=1845788&v=36.75,127,6>. - CopyEd.MJ]\n\n******\n[2] Viet Nam: HPNAI H5N1\nDate: Wed 18 Feb 2009\nSource: Xinhua News Agency [edited]\n<http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2009-02/18/content_10842509.htm>\n\nBird flu hits 9 of Viet Nam's provinces\n-----------------------------------------------------\nBird flu is plaguing in 9 provinces in Vietnam with a newly-reported\ncoastal province Khanh Hoa also finding the virus, according to the\nDepartment of Animal Health under the Ministry of Agriculture and\nRural Development on Wednesday.\n\nIn Khanh Hoa province of south central Vietnam, bird flu has killed\n27 fowls raised at a local farm, said the department, Vietnam\nwatchdog of bird flu.\n\nSamples of dead ducks found in the province tested positive to the\nH5N1 virus, said the department.\n\nSo far this year, 9 provinces of Vietnam nationwide have been hit by\navian flu, including 4 provinces in Mekong Delta, namely Ca Mau, Soc\nTrang, Hau Giang and Bac Lieu, 2 northern provinces of Bac Ninh and\nQuang Ninh, 2 central provinces of Nghe An and Quang Tri, and the\nnewly-confirmed southern Khanh Hoa, said the department.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[On Mon 16 Feb 2009, Viet Nam submitted its follow-up report on H5N1\nto the OIE, with details concerning 15 new outbreaks recorded between\n26 Jan-14 Feb 2009. The total number of susceptible birds in the said\noutbreaks was 7751, of which 2997 were clinically affected and 1819\ndied. 5832 birds were culled. The report, including a map showing the\nrespective locations of the 15 outbreaks, is available at\n<http://www.oie.int/wahis/public.php?page=single_report&pop=1&reportid=7794>.\n- Mod.AS]\n\n[Maps of Viet Nam with provinces are available at\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/middle_east_and_asia/vietnam_admin01.jpg> and\n<http://www.angelfire.com/co/hongnam/vnmap.html>.\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Viet Nam can be accessed at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed/en?v=16.9,108.5,5>. - CopyEd.MJ]", "summary": "H5 and H7 viruses which do not have\nan IVPI of greater than 1.2 or cause less than 75 percent mortality\nin an intravenous lethality test, should be sequenced to determine\nwhether multiple basic amino acids are present at the cleavage site\nof the haemagglutinin molecule; if the amino acid motif is similar to\nthat observed for other highly pathogenic isolates, the isolate being\ntested should be considered as highly pathogenic notifiable avian\ninfluenza (HPNAI). The pathogenicity of avian influenza viruses is defined\naccording to criteria which are detailed in the code: highly\npathogenic viruses are those which have an intravenous pathogenicity\nindex (IVPI) greater than 1.2 in 6-week-old chickens, or, as an\nalternative, cause at least 75 percent mortality in 4-to 8-week-old\nchickens infected intravenously. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nIn this update:\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Dan Silver\n\n[According to OIE's International Animal Health Code, all\nlow-pathogenic avian influenza viruses of the H5 or H7 subtypes are\nnotifiable, hence termed 'low pathogenic notifiable avian influenza'\n(LPNAI). So far this year, 9 provinces of Vietnam nationwide have been hit by\navian flu, including 4 provinces in Mekong Delta, namely Ca Mau, Soc\nTrang, Hau Giang and Bac Lieu, 2 northern provinces of Bac Ninh and\nQuang Ninh, 2 central provinces of Nghe An and Quang Tri, and the\nnewly-confirmed southern Khanh Hoa, said the department. \nBird flu is plaguing in 9 provinces in Vietnam with a newly-reported\ncoastal province Khanh Hoa also finding the virus, according to the\nDepartment of Animal Health under the Ministry of Agriculture and\nRural Development on Wednesday. The Ministry said that tests carried out on blood samples taken from\npoultry on 3 chicken farms in Suncheon, Gokseong County, and Boseong\nCounty in Jeollanam-do Province confirmed that the avian influenza\nvirus found on all 3 chicken farms is low pathogenic H5 subtype. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[On Mon 16 Feb 2009, Viet Nam submitted its follow-up report on H5N1\nto the OIE, with details concerning 15 new outbreaks recorded between\n26 Jan-14 Feb 2009. Further background on the laboratory diagnosis of\navian influenza is available at\n<http://oie.int/eng/normes/mmanual/2008/pdf/2.03.04_AI.pdf>\n\nIn October 2008, LPNAI H5N2 was identified in Southern Chungcheong\nand reported to the OIE. \n\nConfirmation (or otherwise) of the Xinhua News Agency information and\n-- in case confirmed -- typing of the neuraminidase component of the\ncurrent South Korean LPNAI virus, and its notification to the OIE,\nare expected soon. "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=253647", "date": "2009-07-28 17:00:06", "main_text": "INFLUENZA PANDEMIC (H1N1) 2009 (19): VIET NAM, H1N1, H5N1 (SUSPECTED)\n*********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 27 Jul 2009\nSource: LookAtVietnam, VietNamNet/SGGP (Liberated Saigon) report [edited]\n<http://www.lookatvietnam.com/2009/07/ministry-cautions-about-swine-flu-spread-on-public-vehicles.html>\n\n\nMinistry cautions about swine flu spread on public vehicles\n-----------------------------------------------------------\nAfter 3 people with swine flu were found traveling by train from Ho\nChi Minh City to Hanoi on 26 Jul 2009, the Ministry of Health has\nsounded a warning about the threat of contracting [influenza pandemic\n(H1N1) virus infection] by using public transport. The passengers on\nthe train were told to isolate them at homes, monitor their health\ncondition, and inform health authorities immediately if they suffer\nflu symptoms of fever, cough, and sore throat.\n\nMeanwhile, the disease continues to spread in Viet Nam, with 45 more\nnew cases reported on 26 Jul 2009, taking the total number so far to\n612, health officials said. The Department of Preventive Medicine in\nthe southern province of Binh Duong said an expatriate working for\nTHP Company tested positive for the virus and he is also suspected of\ntransmitting it to a colleague. Health authorities have quarantined\nthem as well as a 3rd person with flu symptoms who had been in\ncontact with them.\n\nThe deputy director of the Department of Preventive Health in the\ncentral province of Ha Tinh, Nguyen Luong Tam, confirmed on 26 Jul\n2009 that a 30-year-old man died of bird flu at the General Hospital.\nThe man had been rushed to hospital the previous day with pneumonia,\nhigh fever, headache, muscular and joint pain, cough, breathing\ndifficulty, and vomiting. Doctors diagnosed him as having avian\ninfluenza and isolated him. They found his lung to be seriously\ndamaged. He died on 26 Jul 2009. Health workers later found diseased\npoultry at the man's house. He also had contact with a female\nrelative, a teacher at Ngo Thoi Nhiem private High School in District\n9, where 73 students and 5 teachers have contracted swine flu [that\nis, influenza pandemic (H1N1) 2009 virus infection].\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[This suspected case of avian influenza A (H5N1) virus infection, if\nconfirmed, will become the 112th case and the 57th death to have\noccurred in Viet Nam. The most recent previous case died on 27 Apr\n2009 in Thanh Hoa province.\n\nThe concern in the current (suspected) case is that there is a\npotential epidemiological link with an outbreak of influenza pandemic\n(H1N1) 2009 virus infection among teachers and children at a school\nin the same province.\n\nConfirmation of the H5N1 diagnosis is awaited as are more details of\nthe investigation of the outbreak at Ngo Thoi Nhiem private High School.\n\nA map of the provinces of Viet Nam, showing Ha Tinh province in the\ncentral region, can be accessed at\n<http://www.angelfire.com/co/hongnam/vnmap.html>.\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Viet Nam is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/008c>. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 27 Jul 2009\n After 3 people with swine flu were found traveling by train from Ho\nChi Minh City to Hanoi on 26 Jul 2009, the Ministry of Health has\nsounded a warning about the threat of contracting [influenza pandemic\n The Department of Preventive Medicine in\nthe southern province of Binh Duong said an expatriate working for\nTHP Company tested positive for the virus and he is also suspected of\ntransmitting it to a colleague. "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (25): Germany, wild duck, H5N1, Japan, H7", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=164050", "date": "2009-03-11 11:00:48", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (25): GERMANY, WILD DUCK, H5N1, JAPAN, H7\n*********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Germany (Bavaria): H5N1, wild duck\n[2] Japan (Aichi): H7, quail, 3rd focus\n\n******\n[1] Germany (Bavaria): H5N1, wild duck\nDate: Tue 10 Mar 2009\nSource: Thomson Reuters Foundation AlertNet [edited]\n<http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/LA952510.htm>\n\n\nEU's 1st 2009 bird flu case found in Germany\n--------------------------------------------\nGermany has informed the European Commission of an outbreak of H5N1\nbird flu, the EU's 1st case of the lethal strain of the contagious\ndisease in poultry this year [2009].\n\nThe outbreak 'was found in a wild duck shot during a hunt near the\ntown of Starnberg in the German state of Bavaria,' the European\nUnion's executive arm said in a statement.\n\nThe district office in Starnberg, just southwest of Munich, said in a\nstatement the duck was shot on [10 Jan 2009] and tested as part of an\nEU-wide monitoring programme. None of the 39 birds shot on the hunt\nshowed signs of illness.\n\nExperts said the positive test was not surprising as wild birds are a\nnatural 'virus reservoir', the Starnberg district office added.\n'Individual positive findings in the framework of the monitoring of\nwild birds are, furthermore, to be expected,' the office said.\n\n'There are no indications that during the last 8 weeks a highly\npathogenic virus has, directly or indirectly via a wild bird, been\nintroduced into a poultry stock, or carried on from there,' the\ndistrict office added.\n\n'There are so far no indications of the virus spreading in the wild\nbird population,' the office said.\n\nThe Starnberg authorities had not made any area off-limits or set up\na monitoring area following the positive test. 'On basis of the\nfavourable result of a risk assessment, Germany may refrain from the\nestablishment of a control area and a surrounding monitoring area\naround a positive finding,' the European Commission said in its statement.\n\nThe last wild-bird case of bird flu in the 27-nation bloc was found\nin a Canadian goose in Britain in February last year [2008], while\nthe last outbreak in poultry of H5N1 in the EU was detected last\nOctober [2008] in the German state of Saxony.\n\n[Byline: Darren Ennis, Christoph Dreyer]\n\n-\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[Germany submitted on 10 Mar 2009 an immediate notification to the\nOIE addressing the case above. The following information is derived\nfrom the said notification:\n1. Affected population: one of 39 wild ducks shot in January [2009]\nwas positive for HPAI H5N1, 38 were negative for influenza A.\n2. Epidemiological comments: the place where the birds were killed is\ninside a risk zone, thus free-range holding of poultry is forbidden.\nThere are no poultry holdings in the neighbourhood.\n\nFor the said notification, which includes a map, see\n<http://www.oie.int/wahis/public.php?page=single_report&pop=1&reportid=7874>.\n- Mod.AS]\n\n[The HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Germany is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/0069>. - CopyEd.MJ]\n\n******\n[2] Japan (Aichi): H7, quail, 3rd focus\nDate: Wed 11 Mar 2009\nSource: Xinhua News Agency [edited]\n<http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2009-03/11/content_10992721.htm>\n\n\n3rd H7 strain of avian flu found in Japan\n-----------------------------------------\nA 3rd Aichi prefecture farm has been tested positive for the H7\nstrain of bird flu virus, the Japanese Agriculture, Forestry and\nFisheries Ministry said Wednesday [11 Mar 2009].\n\nThe government departments are trying to identify what N-subtype the\nvirus belongs to, the ministry said in a press release.\n\nThe 3rd case of avian flu virus was also found on a quail farm in\nToyohashi, Aichi Prefecture, where 2 weak-virulent H7N6 subtype of\nbird flu virus were identified since the end of February [2009].\n\nThe quail farm tested positive raises about 110 000 birds and has\nbeen quarantined for further investigation.\n\nThe prefectural government has limited the outflow of egg products\nfrom 2 farms near the quail farm.\n\n[Editor: Lu Yanan]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[Most likely, the causative agent in the new case will be similar to\nthe previous ones, namely LPNAI H7N6. Confirmation is anticipated. - Mod.AS]\n\n[The HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Japan is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/005I>. - CopyEd.MJ]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nIn this update:\n [Byline: Darren Ennis, Christoph Dreyer]\n\n-\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[Germany submitted on 10 Mar 2009 an immediate notification to the\nOIE addressing the case above. \n\n'There are no indications that during the last 8 weeks a highly\npathogenic virus has, directly or indirectly via a wild bird, been\nintroduced into a poultry stock, or carried on from there,' the\ndistrict office added. The last wild-bird case of bird flu in the 27-nation bloc was found\nin a Canadian goose in Britain in February last year [2008], while\nthe last outbreak in poultry of H5N1 in the EU was detected last\nOctober [2008] in the German state of Saxony. \nA 3rd Aichi prefecture farm has been tested positive for the H7\nstrain of bird flu virus, the Japanese Agriculture, Forestry and\nFisheries Ministry said Wednesday --------------------------------------------\nGermany has informed the European Commission of an outbreak of H5N1\nbird flu, the EU's 1st case of the lethal strain of the contagious\ndisease in poultry this year [2009]. On basis of the\nfavourable result of a risk assessment, Germany may refrain from the\nestablishment of a control area and a surrounding monitoring area\naround a positive finding,' the European Commission said in its statement. \n\nThe 3rd case of avian flu virus was also found on a quail farm in\nToyohashi, Aichi Prefecture, where 2 weak-virulent H7N6 subtype of\nbird flu virus were identified since the end of February [2009]. \n\nThe outbreak 'was found in a wild duck shot during a hunt near the\ntown of Starnberg in the German state of Bavaria,' the European\nUnion's executive arm said in a statement. The district office in Starnberg, just southwest of Munich, said in a\nstatement the duck was shot on [10 Jan 2009] and tested as part of an\nEU-wide monitoring programme. \n'Individual positive findings in the framework of the monitoring of\nwild birds are, furthermore, to be expected,' the office said. Affected population: one of 39 wild ducks shot in January [2009]\nwas positive for HPAI H5N1, 38 were negative for influenza A.\n2. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[Most likely, the causative agent in the new case will be similar to\nthe previous ones, namely LPNAI H7N6. AVIAN INFLUENZA (25): GERMANY, WILD DUCK, H5N1, JAPAN, H7\n*********************************************************\n The following information is derived\nfrom the said notification:\n1. \n\nExperts said the positive test was not surprising as wild birds are a\nnatural 'virus reservoir', the Starnberg district office added.", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2009-01-10 00:00:00", "2009-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-01-25 00:00:00", "2021-10-25 00:00:00", "2009-01-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Germany", "country": "Germany"}, {"location": "LPNAI", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Starnberg", "country": "Germany"}, {"location": "Munich", "country": "Germany"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "Japan"}, {"location": "Aichi", "country": "Japan"}, {"location": "Saxony", "country": "Germany"}, {"location": "Bavaria", "country": "Germany"}, {"location": "Britain", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "GERMANY", "country": "Germany"}, {"location": "JAPAN", "country": "Japan"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "135943", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (117): China (HK), H5N1, India (Assam)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=135943", "date": "2008-12-12 15:00:42", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (117): CHINA (HONG KONG), H5N1, INDIA (ASSAM)\n************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Hong Kong - H5N1 confirmed\n[2] India, Assam - spread\n\n******\n[1] Hong Kong - H5N1 confirmed\nDate: Thu 11 Dec 2008\nSource: CIDRAP News [edited]\n<http://www.cidrap.umn.edu/cidrap/content/influenza/avianflu/news/dec1108birds-jw.html>\n\n\nTests confirm H5N1 in Hong Kong outbreak\n----------------------------------------\nAgriculture officials in Hong Kong today [11 Dec 2008] confirmed that the\navian influenza virus that recently hit a large commercial chicken farm was\nthe lethal H5N1 strain, as authorities vowed to explore potential\nprotection gaps in the poultry vaccine and the possibility that smuggled\neggs might be a source of the virus.\n\nJolly Choi, spokeswoman for Hong Kong's agriculture, fisheries, and\nconservation department said earlier tests on 9 Dec 2008 were positive for\nan H5 virus, but further testing showed that 3 chickens found dead on the\nfarm had the H5N1 subtype, according to a report today from the Associated\nPress.\n\nMeanwhile, York Chow, Hong Kong's secretary for food and health, told\nreporters at a press conference yesterday [Wed 10 Dec 2008; see posting\n20081210.3879 - Mod.AS] that experts are focusing on 2 lines of\ninvestigation: a possible biosecurity lapse at the farm and if a change in\nthe circulating virus has hobbled Hong Kong's poultry vaccine.\n\nThe outbreak, China's 1st on a farm since 2003, prompted the culling of\nmore than 80 000 birds and restrictions on poultry imports.\n\nChow said Hong Kong been using an H5N2 vaccine manufactured in the\nNetherlands since 2003. 'Over the last few years it has been proven to be\neffective, but we also think that because the change of the virus, we might\nhave to look for a more appropriate vaccine,' he said in a government press\nrelease.\n\nThe Chinese mainland has been using H5N1 vaccine for poultry over the past\nfew years, which is modified periodically, Chow said, adding that\nveterinary officials have contacted mainland authorities to explore if a\nswitch to the H5N1 vaccine would be more protective. He said that\ngovernment officials would also be seeking guidance from experts at Hong\nKong University, where vaccine studies in poultry have already been under\nway since June [2008].\n\nSo far there is no evidence that the virus has spread to other farms, Chow\nsaid in the statement. Investigators have collected samples from farms to\nconduct polymerase chain reaction (PCR) testing, and the results should be\navailable in a day or 2.\n\nIn other developments, poultry trade representatives in Hong Kong said\ntoday that smuggled fertilized eggs from China could be the source of the\nrecent H5N1 outbreak, according to a report today from Agence France-Presse\n(AFP).\n\nThe Hong Kong Poultry Wholesalers Association said smuggling has become\nmore common since the government banned the import of 1-day-old chickens\nfrom China as an H5N1 prevention measure earlier this year [2008], the AFP\nreport said.\n\nThe South China Morning Post reported today that the eggs, ostensibly\nimported as food, contain potentially infected embryos that are less than a\nweek from hatching, according to AFP. However, the owner of the farm that\nwas struck by the H5N1 virus denied having smuggled any fertilized eggs\nfrom China, the report said.\n\nElsewhere, health ministry officials in India said today that the H5N1\nvirus has now spread to 6 of 27 districts in Assam state, according to a\nreport from Indo-Asian News Service (IANS) [see item 2, below]. Parthajyoti\nGogoi, a health ministry official, told IANS that more than 200 000\nchickens and ducks have been culled since the outbreak was 1st detected 2\nweeks ago. The culling activities have affected 200 villages in Kamrup\n(Metro), Kamrup (Rural), Dibrugarh, Nalbari, Barpeta, and Chirang districts.\n\nTeams of doctors and paramedics are taking measures to prevent human H5N1\ninfections, the report said.\n\n[byline: Lisa Schnirring]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] India, Assam - spread\nDate: Thu 11 Dec 2008\nSource: ZeeNews [edited]\n<http://www.zeenews.com/states/2008-12-11/490211news.html>\n\n\nBird flu spreads its wings, affects 9 Assam districts\n-----------------------------------------------------\nWith the avian influenza spreading to fresh areas, 9 Assam districts are\nnow bird flu affected and health minister Himanta Biswa Sarma on Thursday\n[11 Dec 2008] warned that it could become a major human disaster. The\naffected districts were Kamrup (Rural), Kamrup (Metro), Barpeta, Nalbari,\nChirang, Baksa, Dibrugarh, Goalpara and Bongaigaon, official sources said.\n\nSale of poultry and eggs, either cooked or raw, has been banned in Guwahati\nand Kamrup (Metro) district which comprises Guwahati and adjoining areas.\n\nCulling of poultry, ducks and other birds has been continuing in the\naffected districts with over 1.5 lakh [150 000] birds killed so far, the\nsources said.\n\n'People are taking the disease very casually. Chicken and ducks are being\nkept away from culling without realising the seriousness of the disease,'\nSarma told reporters here. 'We will not be able to handle it, if the\ndisease spreads to humans from the birds. The way the disease is spreading,\nit will be a greater disaster than bomb blasts or floods,' Sarma said. 'The\nhuman disaster will be immense. The health department is very worried about\nhuman transmission of the disease as it is not 100 percent equipped to\nhandle a large scale outbreak as there are no isolation facilities here,'\nhe said.\n\nThe disease, starting from Hajo revenue circle in Kamrup (Rural) district\nabout 20 km [12.4 miles] from here [Guwahati] on 2 Dec 2008 and spread to\nGuwahati in Kamrup (Metro) district, Nalbari, Barpeta, Chirang, Baksa,\nBongaigaon and Goalpara districts in Lower Assam spreading to Dibrugarh\ndistrict in Upper Assam.\n\nTaking in view that the bird flu is spreading to new areas in neighbouring\nAssam, Meghalaya banned the entry of poultry and poultry products from\nAssam and Bangladesh.\n\n'The ban comes into force with immediate effect. However, the ban does not\nimply to the sale of poultry and poultry products produced within the\nstate,' a Veterinary Department release here said. A senior veterinary\nofficial told media that they were preparing to cull birds and poultry in\nthe bordering areas with Assam as soon as the centre asks to do so.\n\n'Normally culling operations are done in a radius of 3 km [1.8 miles] of\nthe place of disease outbreak. With the bird flu outbreak in Assam's\nKhanapara, lying along Assam-Meghalaya border, it is likely that culling\nwould be done in the bordering areas of Meghalaya too,' he said.\n\nDeputy commissioner of Ri Bhoi district that borders Khanapara in Assam's\nKamrup (Rural) district is on a visit to the bordering areas along with a\nteam of veterinary officials to take stock of the situation. The government\nhas set up control rooms in all districts to facilitate information to the\npoultry farms. Veterinary officials have been regularly adopting measures\nto prevent spread of the disease into the state and deputy commissioners of\nall the districts have been alerted, sources said. Meghalaya already has in\nplace 150 rapid response teams along with 2170 personnel protective\nequipment that were constituted last year [2007] after the outbreak of\navian flu in West Bengal.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[Since January 2006, India reported 51 outbreaks of HPAI H5N1; its current\nspread in Assam seems to become India's 2nd major outbreak, following the\none observed in January 2008 on its north eastern regions, bordering\n(infected) Bangladesh. The previous outbreaks occurred in Jan-Apr 2006 (7\noutbreaks); see OIE's time-series analysis for the period Jan 2005-Dec 2008\nby inserting India at\n<http://www.oie.int/wahis/public.php?page=country_disease_time_series&disease_id=15&disease_type=Terrestrial&selected_analysis=tot_new&selected_start_month=7&selected_start_year=2005&selected_end_month=12&selected_end_year=2008>.\n\n\nIndia's last report to the OIE on H5N1 in the Assam state was submitted on\n28 Nov 2008, addressing an outbreak in Hajo (Rajabazar, Kamrup). It\nincluded the following epidemiological commentary:\n\n'Epidemiological investigation is ongoing. Stamping out of all domestic\npoultry is being applied in an approximately 5-km-radius [3.1 mile] zone\naround the outbreaks followed by compensation of the owners. An intensive\nsurveillance campaign has been launched in a 10-km-radius [6.2 mile] zone\nincluding:\n- closure of poultry markets and prohibition on sale and transportation of\npoultry products in the infected zone;\n- disinfection of premises after culling and sealing of premises where\nappropriate.\nRestocking will be applied in accordance with a specific protocol.'\n\nFor the report, including map, see\n<http://www.oie.int/wahis/public.php?page=event_summary&reportid=7566> and\nposting 20081129.3757. In view of avian influenza's pattern of seasonal\nactivity, further spread during the coming winter months may be\nanticipated, requiring enhanced and drastic control measures. - Mod.AS]", "summary": "An intensive\nsurveillance campaign has been launched in a 10-km-radius [6.2 mile] zone\nincluding:\n- closure of poultry markets and prohibition on sale and transportation of\npoultry products in the infected zone;\n- disinfection of premises after culling and sealing of premises where\nappropriate. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nIn this update:\n \n\nJolly Choi, spokeswoman for Hong Kong's agriculture, fisheries, and\nconservation department said earlier tests on 9 Dec 2008 were positive for\nan H5 virus, but further testing showed that 3 chickens found dead on the\nfarm had the H5N1 subtype, according to a report today from the Associated\nPress.\n\n Agriculture officials in Hong Kong today [11 Dec 2008] confirmed that the\navian influenza virus that recently hit a large commercial chicken farm was\nthe lethal H5N1 strain, as authorities vowed to explore potential\nprotection gaps in the poultry vaccine and the possibility that smuggled\neggs might be a source of the virus. \n\nThe disease, starting from Hajo revenue circle in Kamrup (Rural) district\nabout 20 km [12.4 miles] from here [Guwahati] on 2 Dec 2008 and spread to\nGuwahati in Kamrup (Metro) district, Nalbari, Barpeta, Chirang, Baksa,\nBongaigaon and Goalpara districts in Lower Assam spreading to Dibrugarh\ndistrict in Upper Assam. \n\nThe Hong Kong Poultry Wholesalers Association said smuggling has become\nmore common since the government banned the import of 1-day-old chickens\nfrom China as an H5N1 prevention measure earlier this year [2008], the AFP\nreport said. \n\nThe Chinese mainland has been using H5N1 vaccine for poultry over the past\nfew years, which is modified periodically, Chow said, adding that\nveterinary officials have contacted mainland authorities to explore if a\nswitch to the H5N1 vaccine would be more protective. In other developments, poultry trade representatives in Hong Kong said\ntoday that smuggled fertilized eggs from China could be the source of the\nrecent H5N1 outbreak, according to a report today from Agence France-Presse\n He said that\ngovernment officials would also be seeking guidance from experts at Hong\nKong University, where vaccine studies in poultry have already been under\nway since June [2008]. \n\n[byline: Lisa Schnirring]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< [Since January 2006, India reported 51 outbreaks of HPAI H5N1; its current\nspread in Assam seems to become India's 2nd major outbreak, following the\none observed in January 2008 on its north eastern regions, bordering\n(infected) Bangladesh. Over the last few years it has been proven to be\neffective, but we also think that because the change of the virus, we might\nhave to look for a more appropriate vaccine,' he said in a government press\nrelease. Parthajyoti\nGogoi, a health ministry official, told IANS that more than 200 000\nchickens and ducks have been culled since the outbreak was 1st detected 2\nweeks ago. The health department is very worried about\nhuman transmission of the disease as it is not 100 percent equipped to\nhandle a large scale outbreak as there are no isolation facilities here,'\n Meghalaya already has in\nplace 150 rapid response teams along with 2170 personnel protective\nequipment that were constituted last year [2007] after the outbreak of\navian flu in West Bengal. The previous outbreaks occurred in Jan-Apr 2006 (7\noutbreaks); see OIE's time-series analysis for the period Jan 2005-Dec 2008\nby inserting India at\n<http://www.oie.int/wahis/public.php?page=country_disease_time_series&disease_id=15&disease_type=Terrestrial&selected_analysis=tot_new&selected_start_month=7&selected_start_year=2005&selected_end_month=12&selected_end_year=2008>. \n\nElsewhere, health ministry officials in India said today that the H5N1\nvirus has now spread to 6 of 27 districts in Assam state, according to a\nreport from Indo-Asian News Service (IANS) Culling of poultry, ducks and other birds has been continuing in the\naffected districts with over 1.5 lakh [150 000] birds killed so far, the\nsources said. However, the ban does not\nimply to the sale of poultry and poultry products produced within the\nstate,' a Veterinary Department release here said. Veterinary officials have been regularly adopting measures\nto prevent spread of the disease into the state and deputy commissioners of\nall the districts have been alerted, sources said. \n\nDeputy commissioner of Ri Bhoi district that borders Khanapara in Assam's\nKamrup (Rural) district is on a visit to the bordering areas along with a\nteam of veterinary officials to take stock of the situation. \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n \n\nThe South China Morning Post reported today that the eggs, ostensibly\nimported as food, contain potentially infected SUSPECTED\n************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1]\nDate: Thu 9 Oct 2008\nSource: PR Inside.com, Associated Press (AP) report [edited]\n<http://www.pr-inside.com/farm-duck-positive-for-h5n1-bird-r853103.htm>\n\n\nFarm duck positive for H5N1 bird flu in Germany\n-----------------------------------------------\nAuthorities say a duck at a farm in eastern Germany has tested\npositive for the H5N1 strain of the bird flu virus.\n\nThe social affairs ministry in the eastern state of Saxony says the\nfarm near Goerlitz on the Polish border has been sealed off. The\nministry said Thursday [9 Oct 2008] that the farm has more than 1000\nbirds, including turkeys and geese.\n\nGermany has seen several cases of bird flu in the past, most recently\nin December [2007].\n\nThe disease has ravaged poultry stocks in Asia, and scientists\nbelieve it spread to both Europe and Africa with migratory wild birds.\n\nThough bird flu is difficult for people to catch, the H5N1 strain has\nkilled at least 206 people worldwide.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Thu 9 Oct 2008\nSource: Deutsche Welle [edited]\n<http://www.dw-world.de/dw/article/0,2144,3702691,00.html>\n\n\nBird flu returns to Germany\n---------------------------\nBird flu has returned to Germany, with the H5N1 influenza virus\nbreaking out among farm ducks in the eastern state of Saxony,\nofficials said Thursday [9 Oct 2008].\n\nIt was the 1st proven appearance of the disease this year [2008] in\nGermany. Officials said they had sealed off the farm and planned to\nslaughter the whole flock of ducks at Goerlitz, near the Polish\nborder. The property contains more than 1000 birds, mainly turkeys and geese.\n\nGermany's national animal health laboratory on the Baltic island of\nRiems said the find was 'somewhat surprising' as the infection alert\nhad been reduced to moderate after an outbreak was beaten last\nDecember [2007]. Then, officials launched the largest-ever bird cull\nin Germany, exterminating a massive 160 000 geese over a weekend in\nWachenroth, Bavaria.\n\nIt remained unknown what proportion of wild birds in Germany were\ninfected, a spokeswoman said.\n\nNone of Germany's neighbours are currently reporting any H5N1\ndetections, with the virus having recently shown up in Asia, from\nwhich scientists believe it had earlier spread to both Europe and\nAfrica with migratory wild birds.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[According to additional information, published on 10 Oct 2008 by the\nSaxony Radio Station MDR (for which we are grateful to Sabine\nZentis), the affected holding is a breeding unit with approx 1100\nducks. Turkeys, geese, and chickens are kept on this unit as well. A\ntotal of about 1400 birds were to be culled on Friday [10 Oct 2008].\nThe Friedrich-Loeffler-Institut (FLI) is investigating samples to\nestablish whether the H5N1 strain is highly pathogenic. Final results\nshould be available today (10 Oct 2008). - Mod.AS\n\nGoerlitz, near the Polish border, can be located on the\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Germany at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed?g=2918987&v=51.1,13.4,7>. - CopyEd.MJ]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1]\n \nBird flu has returned to Germany, with the H5N1 influenza virus\nbreaking out among farm ducks in the eastern state of Saxony,\nofficials said Thursday [9 Oct 2008]. \n\nNone of Germany's neighbours are currently reporting any H5N1\ndetections, with the virus having recently shown up in Asia, from\nwhich scientists believe it had earlier spread to both Europe and\nAfrica with migratory wild birds. \n\nGermany's national animal health laboratory on the Baltic island of\nRiems said the find was 'somewhat surprising' as the infection alert\nhad been reduced to moderate after an outbreak was beaten last\nDecember [According to additional information, published on 10 Oct 2008 by the\nSaxony Radio Station MDR (for which we are grateful to Sabine\nZentis), the affected holding is a breeding unit with approx 1100\nducks. It came from a surveillance programme\nresearching the presence of avian influenza.\n\nKnown as LPAI [low pathogenic avian influenza] H5N1, the Ministry of\nAgriculture and Forestry says it is different to 'bird flu,' which is\nthe highly pathogenic form of the virus.\n\nSpokesman Dr Andre van Haldren says the samples were taken from\nhealthy birds and there have been no reported bird deaths or disease.\nHe says this confirms that strains of non disease causing avian\ninfluenza viruses are present in our wild bird populations.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[Even though this was a research project it demonstrates that when\none looks for disease, however unexpected, it may be present. As the\npostings below indicate there is virus circulating in the wild bird\npopulation. Wild birds variously influence the captive birds by a\nvariety of interactions.\n\nThis is a low pathogenicity strain but officials will certainly be\nwatching for sick birds or evidence of mutation to a more virulent\nstrain. - Mod.TG\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of New Zealand can be accessed at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed?v=-42.4,172.7,5>. - CopyEd.MJ]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 17 Sep 2008\n \n\nSpokesman Dr Andre van Haldren says the samples were taken from\nhealthy birds and there have been no reported bird deaths or disease.\n \n\nThis is a low pathogenicity strain but officials will certainly be\nwatching for sick birds or evidence of mutation to a more virulent\nstrain. [edited]\n<http://www.iht.com/articles/ap/2008/09/15/africa/AF-Togo-Bird-Flu.php>\n\n\nTogo: recent bird flu outbreak is deadly H5N1\n---------------------------------------------\nTogo state television says lab tests performed after a recent\noutbreak of bird flu have confirmed the presence of the deadly H5N1\nstrain of the virus, which has the potential to infect humans.\n\nNo human cases have been detected so far in Togo, however.\n\nState media reported Monday [15 Sep 2008] the lab tests were carried\nout by experts in Ghana and Italy after the outbreak was discovered\nlast week [week of 8 Aug 2008] among several thousand birds in Agbata\noutside the capital, Lome.\n\nThe Health Ministry says 'precautionary measures have been taken to\ncontain the situation.'\n\nAt least 235 people have died of bird flu worldwide since 2003,\naccording to the World Health Organization (WHO).\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[An official confirmation of H5N1, in a notification to the OIE\n(World Organisation for Animal Health), is not yet available.\n\nTogo's eastern neighbor, Benin, notified the OIE of an H5N1 outbreak,\nreportedly starting 29 Jul 2008, on its southern border with Togo\n(see, with interactive map, at\n<http://www.oie.int/wahid-prod/public.php?page=event_summary&reportid=7299>).\n\nTogo's reports to the OIE on the 3 outbreaks
