20(46) [edited]\n<http://www.oie.int/wahid-prod/public.php?page=weekly_report_index&admin=0>\n\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza, United Kingdom\n-------------------------------------------------\nInformation received on (and dated) 13 Nov 2007 from Dr Debby\nReynolds, director general & chief veterinary officer, Department for\nEnvironment, Food and Rural Affairs (DEFRA), director general for\nAnimal Health & Welfare, London, United Kingdom\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nStart date: 11 Nov 2007\nDate of confirmation of event: 13 Nov 2007\nReport date: 13 Nov 2007\nDate submitted to OIE: 13 Nov 2007\nReason for notification: reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 25 Jun 2007\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza virus, serotype H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: laboratory (advanced)\nReport pertains to: entire country\n\nNew outbreaks\nSummary of outbreaks\nOutbreak 1 (AI 2007/1) Redgrave, England\nDate of start of outbreak: 11 Nov 2007\nOutbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not submitted)\nEpidemiological unit: farm\nAffected animals\nSpecies: birds\nSusceptible: 6500\nCases: 350\nDeaths: 200\nDestroyed: 6300\nSlaughtered: 0\nAffected population: a free-range turkey flock (5000 birds) affected.\nThese, and all remaining poultry (1000 ducks and 500 geese) are being\nkilled on site and rendered.\n\nOutbreak statistics\nSpecies: birds\nApparent morbidity rate: 5.38 percent\nApparent mortality rate: 3.08 percent\nApparent case fatality rate: 57.14 percent\nProportion susceptible removed*: 100 percent\n* Removed from the susceptible population either through death,\ndestruction, or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of infection: unknown or inconclusive\n\nEpidemiological comments: epidemiological inquiry is underway.\nControl zones established. Vaccination in poultry is prohibited,\nvaccination is permitted in zoo birds subject to strict controls in\naccordance with EU rules.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures already applied:\n- movement control inside the country\n- screening\n- disinfection of infected premises/establishment(s)\n- quarantine\n- stamping out\n- zoning\n- vaccination prohibited\n- no treatment of affected animals.\nMeasures to be applied: none specified\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type: Veterinary Laboratories Agency, Weybridge\n(OIE's Reference Laboratory)\nSpecies: birds\nTest: real-time PCR (polymerase chain reaction)\nTest date: 13 Nov 2007\nResult: positive\n\nLaboratory name and type: VLA, Weybridge (OIE's Reference Laboratory)\nSpecies: birds\nTest: haemagglutination inhibition test (HIT)\nTest date: 13 Nov 2007\nResult: positive\n\nSpecies: birds\nTest: neuraminidase inhibition assay\nTest date: 13 Nov 2007\nResult: positive\n\nSpecies: birds\nTest: virus isolation\nTest date: 13 Nov 2007\nResult: positive\n\nSpecies: birds\nTest: virus sequencing\nTest date: 13 Nov 2007\nResult: positive\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The epidemiologic investigation is of the utmost importance in\nregard to the establishment of the source of the infection. Animal\nhealth authorities around the world, who may have become complacent\nabout H5N1 in commercial poultry or in any aspect of its epidemiology\nshould take note of this outbreak. Moreover, a careful economic\nimpact study is, one hopes, being considered. - Mod.PC]", "summary": "Measures already applied:\n- movement control inside the country\n- screening\n- disinfection of infected premises/establishment(s)\n- quarantine\n- stamping out\n- zoning\n- vaccination prohibited\n- no treatment of affected animals. Information received on (and dated) 13 Nov 2007 from Dr Debby\nReynolds, director general & chief veterinary officer, Department for\nEnvironment, Food and Rural Affairs (DEFRA), director general for\nAnimal Health & Welfare, London, United Kingdom\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\n A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 14 Nov 2007\n \n\nOutbreak statistics\nSpecies: birds\nApparent morbidity rate: 5.38 percent\n Result: positive\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Affected animals\nSpecies: birds\nSusceptible: 6500\n Animal\nhealth authorities around the world, who may have become complacent\nabout H5N1 in commercial poultry or in any aspect of its epidemiology\nshould take note of this outbreak. Test: neuraminidase inhibition assay\nTest date: 13 Nov 2007\n Source: OIE, WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database), weekly\ndisease information 2007; 20(46) [edited]\n<http://www.oie.int/wahid-prod/public.php?page=weekly_report_index&admin=0>\n\n\n Vaccination in poultry is prohibited,\nvaccination is permitted in zoo birds subject to strict controls in\naccordance with EU rules. Removed from the susceptible population either through death,\ndestruction, or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology\n Manifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza virus, serotype H5N1\n Apparent case fatality rate: 57.14 percent\nProportion susceptible removed*: 100 percent\n* Species: birds\nTest: real-time PCR (polymerase chain reaction)\n AVIAN INFLUENZA (170): UK (ENGLAND), TURKEYS, H5N1, OIE\n********************************************************\n Cases: 350\nDeaths: 200\n Date of confirmation of event: 13 Nov 2007\n Date submitted to OIE: 13 Nov 2007\n Test date: 13 Nov 2007\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2007-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "London", "country": "United Kingdom"}, {"location": "WAHID", "country": "Oman"}, {"location": "United Kingdom", "country": "United Kingdom"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "74553", "headline": "PRO/AH> Avian influenza (H5N1) strain nomenclature", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=74553", "date": "2008-04-23 19:00:20", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (H5N1) STRAIN NOMENCLATURE\n******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 23 Apr 2008\nSource: Nature online [edited]\n<http://www.nature.com/news/2008/080423/full/452923a.html>\n\n\nNames of flu viruses appearing in the scientific literature have\nundergone something of a mutation this year [2008]. The group of H5N1\navian flu viruses, once known as 'Fujian-like,' has morphed into\n'Clade 2.3.4,' and its 'Qinghai-like' cousin is now called 'Clade\n2.2.' They are part of a complete revision of H5N1 nomenclature\nrecommended by the World Health Organization (WHO).\n\nThe system is now more politically correct. It avoids the\n'stigmatizing labelling of clades by geographical reference,'\naccording to the WHO. In 2006, when scientists assigned the name\n'Fujian-like virus' to a vaccine-resistant strain of H5N1 that spread\nacross Asia, China objected strongly to the name. Government\nofficials argued that the southeastern Chinese province of Fujian was\ntainted by association as the virus spread.\n\nBut a WHO official told Nature [journal] that discussions for a\nrevised nomenclature were underway before the spat and that the\n'impetus was scientific. We recognized that naming based on geography\nwas probably not a good idea for other reasons,' she says.\n\nFlu experts say that the new naming recommendations, which have been\nposted on the WHO website [see reference below] and have been\nsubmitted for publication in the journal Emerging Infectious\nDiseases, make a lot of sense. They replace an ad-hoc system -- in\nwhich researchers would invent their own names for newly isolated\ngroups -- with a systematic one in which names have greater\nbiological relevance.\n\nH5N1 viruses are classified on the basis of their hemagglutinin\ngenetic sequence into 10 phylogenetic clades -- distinct branches of\nthe virus's family tree -- and the new system names the viral\nsubgroups according to their position in the tree. It aims to be more\nlogical. For example, Clade 2.3.4 viruses are not restricted to\nFuijan province, as they have caused cases in humans in China, Laos,\nMyanmar and Viet Nam. Clade 2.1 viruses dominate in poultry and\nhumans in Indonesia, for example, whereas Clade 2.2 viruses have the\nlargest geographical spread, causing outbreaks in more than 60\ncountries from Azerbaijan to Nigeria and Pakistan.\n\n'I find the geographical naming system rather confusing and\nunspecific; this more precise numbering system is far more rigorous,'\nsays Edward Holmes, a flu genomicist at Pennsylvania State University\nin University Park. The new system does not affect the naming of\nindividual H5N1 virus sequences -- held in the GenBank database --\nthat make up such clades. These will continue to display geographic\nand species data on the sample. Geographic information is relevant,\nsays the WHO official, because it locates the sample's place of\norigin.\n\nBut experts say that the location data in GenBank flu names is\nwoefully inadequate for serious spatial science, such as analyzing\nthe spread of virus genotypes or how spread relates to other spatial\ndata on land use, climate and trade. 'There's nothing more\nfrustrating and useless to a phylogeographer than a perfectly\nsequenced isolate labeled 'China,'' says Rob Wallace, an evolutionary\necologist at the University of California, Irvine. 'With Global\nPositioning System (GPS) coordinates and fine enough sampling, we\nwould really be able to tease out how the virus evolves and spreads\nacross farms and wetlands.'\n\nIndeed, not one H5N1 sequence in GenBank currently contains GPS\ncoordinates, often because those submitting sequences have no use for\nsuch data. 'Given the importance of avian flu, I've been amazed to\nfind out how difficult it has been to get information on the\ngeographical distribution of essential variables,' says ecologist\nMarius Gilbert of the Free University of Brussels. The WHO official\nagrees that the current sequence-naming system is not as useful as\nGPS coordinates, but says that 'the WHO doesn't see its business as\nmaking that sort of requirement.'\n\nGenBank only introduced fields for latitude and longitude in\nsubmitted entries in 2005, and few scientists have so far used them,\nexcept in spatially aware fields, such as forest entomology and\nbiodiversity.\n\n[Byline: Declan Butler]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[An up-to-date (February 2008) phylogenetic tree with the current\nclade nomenclature is presented as Figure 1 of the WHO document\nentitled: 'Antigenic and genetic characteristics of H5N1 viruses and\ncandidate H5N1 vaccine viruses developed for potential use as human\nvaccines,' which is available at:\n<http://www.who.int/csr/disease/avian_influenza/guidelines/H5VaccineVirusUpdate20080214.pdf>.\n- Mod.CP]\n....................................cp/msp/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. ISID\nand its associated service providers shall not be held\nresponsible for errors or omissions or held liable for any\ndamages incurred as a result of use or reliance upon posted\nor archived material.\n************************************************************\nBecome a ProMED-mail Premium Subscriber at\n<http://www.isid.org/ProMEDMail_Premium.shtml>\n************************************************************\nVisit ProMED-mail's web site at <http://www.promedmail.org>.\nSend all items for posting to: promed@promedmail.org\n\n(NOT to an individual moderator). If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "summary": "CP]\n....................................cp/msp/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[An up-to-date (February 2008) phylogenetic tree with the current\nclade nomenclature is presented as Figure 1 of the WHO document\nentitled: 'Antigenic and genetic characteristics of H5N1 viruses and\ncandidate H5N1 vaccine viruses developed for potential use as human\nvaccines,' which is available at:\n<http://www.who.int/csr/disease/avian_influenza/guidelines/H5VaccineVirusUpdate20080214.pdf>. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 23 Apr 2008\n ISID\nand its associated service providers shall not be held\nresponsible for errors or omissions or held liable for any\ndamages incurred as a result of use or reliance upon posted\nor archived material.\n ***********************************************************\nBecome a ProMED-mail Premium Subscriber at\n<http://www.isid.org/ProMEDMail_Premium.shtml>\n************************************************************\n \n\nH5N1 viruses are classified on the basis of their hemagglutinin\ngenetic sequence into 10 phylogenetic clades -- distinct branches of\nthe virus's family tree -- and the new system names the viral\nsubgroups according to their position in the tree. \n\n'I find the geographical naming system rather confusing and\nunspecific; this more precise numbering system is far more rigorous,'\nsays Edward Holmes, a flu genomicist at Pennsylvania State University\nin University Park. But experts say that the location data in GenBank flu names is\nwoefully inadequate for serious spatial science, such as analyzing\nthe spread of virus genotypes or how spread relates to other spatial\ndata on land use, climate and trade. ' \n\nFlu experts say that the new naming recommendations, which have been\nposted on the WHO website [see reference below] and have been\nsubmitted for publication in the journal Emerging Infectious\nDiseases, make a lot of sense. They replace an ad-hoc system -- in\nwhich researchers would invent their own names for newly isolated\ngroups -- with a systematic one in which names have greater\nbiological relevance. Clade 2.1 viruses dominate in poultry and\nhumans in Indonesia, for example, whereas Clade 2.2 viruses have the\nlargest geographical spread, causing outbreaks in more than 60\ncountries from Azerbaijan to Nigeria and Pakistan. The WHO official\nagrees that the current sequence-naming system is not as useful as\nGPS coordinates, but says that 'the WHO doesn't see its business as\nmaking that sort of requirement.' \n\nGenBank only introduced fields for latitude and longitude in\nsubmitted entries in 2005, and few scientists have so far used them,\nexcept in spatially aware fields, such as forest entomology and\nbiodiversity. The group of H5N1\navian flu viruses, once known as 'Fujian-like,' has morphed into\n'Clade 2.3.4,' and its 'Qinghai-like' cousin is now called 'Clade\n2.2.'", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2008-02-25 00:00:00", "2005-03-25 00:00:00", "2006-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Nigeria", "country": "Nigeria"}, {"location": "Fuijan province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "University Park", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Viet Nam", "country": "Vietnam"}, {"location": "Indonesia", "country": "Indonesia"}, {"location": "Qinghai", "country": "China"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Pakistan", "country": "Pakistan"}, {"location": "Azerbaijan", "country": "Azerbaijan"}, {"location": "Laos", "country": "Laos"}, {"location": "Myanmar", "country": "Myanmar"}, {"location": "Fujian", "country": "China"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "47420", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (08): Israel (H5N1), Portugal (LP H5N2), OIE", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=47420", "date": "2008-01-08 17:00:13", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (08): ISRAEL (H5N1), PORTUGAL (LOW PATHOGENIC H5N2), OIE\n*********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nIn this update:\n[1] Israel: OIE, final report\n[2] Portugal: H5N2, OIE\n******\n[1] Israel: OIE, final report\nDate: Mon 7 Jan 2008\nSource: OIE, WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database), weekly\ndisease information 2008; 21(2) [edited]\n<http://www.oie.int/wahid-prod/public.php?page=single_report&pop=1&reportid=6659>\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza, Israel\n-----------------------------------------\nInformation received on (and dated) 7 Jan 2008 from Dr Moshe\nChaimovitz, Director, Veterinary Services and Animal Health, Ministry\nof Agriculture and Rural Development, Beit Dagan, Israel\nSummary\nReport type: follow-up report no. 1 (final report)\nStart date: 27 Dec 2007\nDate of confirmation of event: 3 Jan 2008\nReport date: 7 Jan 2008\nDate submitted to OIE: 7 Jan 2008\nDate event resolved: 7 Jan 2008\nReason for notification: reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: March 2006\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza virus, serotype H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: suspicion, clinical, laboratory (basic),\nlaboratory (advanced), necropsy\nReport pertains to: defined zone within the country\nRelated reports:\n1. Immediate notification (3 Jan 2008)\n2. Follow-up report no. 1 (7 Jan 2008)\nOutbreaks: There are no new outbreaks in this report\nEpidemiology\nSource of infection: unknown or inconclusive\nEpidemiological comments: A 3-km (2 mi)-radius protection zone and a\n10-km (6 mi)-radius surveillance zone were set up.\nThe epidemiological investigation did not reveal evidence of\nintroduction of new birds into the cage during the 40 days prior to\nthe outbreak. Apparently, people who were taking care of the pet\nbirds had no contact with other birds during the 40 days prior to the\noutbreak. The birds' feed containers remained closed and there was no\napparent possibility of entrance of wild birds into the feed\ncontainers (which were situated outside the cage). Sparrows were\nabundant in the cage during the feeding of the pet birds.\nIncrease of monitoring activities of sick and dead wild birds in the zone.\nControl measures\nMeasures already applied\n- stamping out\n- quarantine\n- movement control inside the country\n- screening\n- disinfection of infected premises/establishment(s)\n- vaccination prohibited\n- no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: none specified\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type: Kimron Veterinary Institute (National laboratory)\nTests and results\nSpecies: Birds\nTests: Polymerase chain reaction (PCR): 3 Jan 2008\nResult: positive\nVirus isolation: 5 Jan 2008\nResult: positive\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[The timely and efficient manner by which this outbreak at Binyamina\n(map included in the report) was eradicated, has become possible by\nthe immediate application of pre-prepared contingency plans; a\nsignificant contribution for its success was the behaviour of the\nowner, who called upon a vet immediately when 3 chickens died, and the\nresponse of the vet who involved the laboratory, even though avian\ninfluenza was initially not suspected.\nThe main puzzling issue in this outbreak the source of infection.\nProMED-mail's posting 20080104.0045 included a moderator's comment\nregarding the point in time when 3 hens were introduced from a\nbroiler breeding flock in Kefar Menachem (south-east Israel; see map\nat\n<http://www.fallingrain.com/world/IS/1/Kefar_Menahem.html>).\nIt seems that the media report cited, according to which the transfer\ntook place a week before the discovery of the 1st 3 dead chickens,\nwas inaccurate, since the follow-up report above says: 'The\nepidemiological investigation did not reveal evidence of introduction\nof new birds into the cage during the 40 days prior to the outbreak'.\nThis is in line with the epidemiological investigation report of 3\nDec 2007, kindly forwarded to us by the Israeli Veterinary Services,\nwhich indicates that the exact date of the transfer cited above (3\nhens) was 20 Nov 2007. Reportedly, the breeding flock of origin was\n(routinely) slaughtered during the beginning of December (2007), and\nin any case prior to 9 Dec 2007, without observable morbidity or\nexceptional mortality.\nThe epidemiological investigation (carried out commonly by the\nMinistries of Agriculture and Health) concludes as follows:\n'It is plausible to conclude that the disease was not introduced by\nthe animals brought from Kefar Menachem. This, in view of the long\ntime lapse and the fact that no exceptional event was seen in Kefar\nMenachem.\nNo other suspected contacts could be traced, either by birds or by\nhumans. Since the cage's roof (cover) was impervious, it is not\nplausible that droppings from birds flying over the cage could have\nentered it. On the other hand, the free entrance of sparrows, in\nlarge numbers, makes them [a] suspected source.'\nHopefully, this will remain a solitary event. Though the source of\ninfection remains enigmatic, sequencing results and their comparison\nwith other isolates from the region (such as, Egypt, Saudi Arabia)\nmay help in elucidating the route of virus spread. - Mod.AS]\n******\n[2] Portugal: H5N2, OIE\nDate: 7 Jan 2007\nSource: OIE, WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database), weekly\ndisease information 2008; 21(2) [edited]\n<http://www.oie.int/wahid-prod/public.php?page=weekly_report_index&admin=0>\n\nLow pathogenic avian influenza (poultry), Portugal\n--------------------------------------------------\nInformation received on (and dated) 4 Jan 2008 from Mr Carlos Agrela\nPinheiro, Chief Veterinary Officer, Director General, Veterinary\nMedicine General Directorate, Ministry of Agriculture, Lisbon,\nPortugal\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nStart date: 21 Dec 2007\nDate of confirmation of event: 21 Dec outbreaks\nOutbreak 1 (002/2007): Atalaia - Lourinha, Oeste\nDate of start of outbreak: 21 Dec 2007\nOutbreak status: resolved (21 Dec 2007)\nEpidemiological unit: farm\nAffected animals\nSpecies: birds\nSusceptible: 988\nCases: -\nDeaths: 0\nDestroyed: 988\nSlaughtered: 0\nAffected population: a farm with red-legged partridges (_Alectoris\nrufa_) for hunting restocking\nOutbreak 2 (003/2007): Santo Estevao das Gales - Mafra, Oeste\nDate of start of outbreak: 21 Dec 2007\nOutbreak status: resolved (22 Dec 2007)\nEpidemiological unit: farm\nAffected animals\nSpecies: birds\nSusceptible: 9527\nCases: -\nDeaths: 0\nDestroyed: 9527\nSlaughtered: 0\nAffected population: a farm with red-legged partridges (_Alectoris\nrufa_) for hunting restocking (9522 animals) and an annex including 5\npheasants\nOutbreak 3 (004/2007): Santo Estevao das Gales - Mafra, Oeste\nDate of start of outbreak: 31 Dec 2007\nOutbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not submitted)\nEpidemiological unit: farm\nAffected animals\nSpecies: birds\nSusceptible: 16800\nCases: -\nDeaths: 0\nDestroyed: 16800\nSlaughtered: 0\nAffected population: a broiler farm 350 m (0.2 mi) from the outbreak\nno. 003/2007\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 3\nTotal animals affected\nSpecies: birds\nSusceptible: 27315\nCases -\nDeaths: 0\nDestroyed: 27315\nSlaughtered: 0\nOutbreak statistics\nSpecies: birds\nApparent morbidity rate: 0 percent\nApparent mortality rate: 0 percent\nApparent case fatality rate: -\nProportion susceptible removed*: 100 percent\n* Removed from the susceptible population either through death,\ndestruction, or slaughter\nEpidemiology\nSource of infection: unknown or inconclusive\nEpidemiological comments\nTests were carried out in the partridge farms (outbreaks No. 002/2007\nand 003/2007) within the framework of the national surveillance plan\nfor avian influenza; tests in the chicken farm were part of the\nscreening measures implemented following the outbreak no. 003/2007.\nThere is no other poultry farm within a 1-km radius from the\noutbreaks.\nNote by the OIE Animal Health Information Department: H5 and H7 avian\ninfluenza in its low pathogenic form in poultry is a notifiable\ndisease as per Chapter 2.7.12. on avian influenza of the Terrestrial\nAnimal Health Code.\nDiagnostic test results:\nLaboratory name and type: Laboratorio Nacional de Investigacao\nVeterinaria (national laboratory)\nSpecies: birds\nTest: RT-PCR (reverse transcriptase polymerase chain reaction)\nTest date: 21 Dec 2007\nResult: positive\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[The distance separating the 1st 2 farm locations is substantial.\nThere are many different ways both farms could have been infected but\nthe fact that both farms are populated by red-legged partridges used\nfor hunting would make one suspect traffic between the 2 farms. The\n3rd outbreak farm has poultry and is located nearby, within 350 meters\n(0.2 mi) of the Mafra partridge farm, and possibly indicates local\nspread or same source infections for both farms.\nLocations can be seen at OIE/WAHID map appended to the report\nreferenced above or by visiting\n<http://www.glosk.com/PO/Mafra/-3002513/gmap_en.htm#>. - Mod.PC]", "summary": "Measures already applied\n- stamping out\n- quarantine\n- movement control inside the country\n- screening\n- disinfection of infected premises/establishment(s)\n- vaccination prohibited\n- no treatment of affected animals\n [The timely and efficient manner by which this outbreak at Binyamina\n(map included in the report) was eradicated, has become possible by\nthe immediate application of pre-prepared contingency plans; a\nsignificant contribution for its success was the behaviour of the\nowner, who called upon a vet immediately when 3 chickens died, and the\nresponse of the vet who involved the laboratory, even though avian\ninfluenza was initially not suspected. Source of infection: unknown or inconclusive\nEpidemiological comments\nTests were carried out in the partridge farms (outbreaks No. 002/2007\nand 003/2007) within the framework of the national surveillance plan\nfor avian influenza; tests in the chicken farm were part of the\nscreening measures implemented following the outbreak no. 003/2007. -----------------------------------------\nInformation received on (and dated) 7 Jan 2008 from Dr Moshe\nChaimovitz, Director, Veterinary Services and Animal Health, Ministry\nof Agriculture and Rural Development, Beit Dagan, Israel\nSummary\nReport type: follow-up report no. \nProMED-mail's posting 20080104.0045 included a moderator's comment\nregarding the point in time when 3 hens were introduced from a\nbroiler breeding flock in Kefar Menachem (south-east Israel; see map\nat\n<http://www.fallingrain.com/world/IS/1/Kefar_Menahem.html>). Affected population: a farm with red-legged partridges (_Alectoris\nrufa_) for hunting restocking (9522 animals) and an annex including 5\npheasants\n The epidemiological investigation (carried out commonly by the\nMinistries of Agriculture and Health) concludes as follows:\n'It is plausible to conclude that the disease was not introduced by\nthe animals brought from Kefar Menachem. Removed from the susceptible population either through death,\ndestruction, or slaughter\nEpidemiology\n Outbreak 1 (002/2007): Atalaia - Lourinha, Oeste\nDate of start of outbreak: 21 Dec 2007\n The epidemiological investigation did not reveal evidence of\nintroduction of new birds into the cage during the 40 days prior to\nthe outbreak. Dec 2007, kindly forwarded to us by the Israeli Veterinary Services,\nwhich indicates that the exact date of the transfer cited above (3\nhens) was 20 Nov 2007. Apparently, people who were taking care of the pet\nbirds had no contact with other birds during the 40 days prior to the\noutbreak. The birds' feed containers remained closed and there was no\napparent possibility of entrance of wild birds into the feed\ncontainers (which were situated outside the cage). Manifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza virus, serotype H5N1\n Date of previous occurrence: 23 Oct 2007\nManifestation of disease: sub-clinical infection\n There are many different ways both farms could have been infected but\nthe fact that both farms are populated by red-legged partridges used\nfor hunting would make one suspect traffic between the 2 farms. Note by the OIE Animal Health Information Department: H5 and H7 avian\ninfluenza in its low pathogenic form in poultry is a notifiable\ndisease as per Chapter 2.7.12. Since the cage's roof (cover) was impervious, it is not\nplausible that droppings from birds flying over the cage could have\nentered it. Affected population: a farm with red-legged partridges (_Alectoris\nrufa_) for hunting restocking\n AVIAN INFLUENZA (08): ISRAEL (H5N1), PORTUGAL (LOW PATHOGENIC H5N2), OIE\n*********************************************************************\n Outbreak statistics\nSpecies: birds\n --------------------------------------------------\nInformation received on (and dated) 4 Jan 2008 from Mr Carlos Agrela\n Affected animals\nSpecies: birds\n Affected animals\nSpecies: birds\n Affected animals\nSpecies: birds\n Species: birds\nTest: RT-PCR (reverse transcriptase polymerase chain reaction)\n Result: positive\nVirus isolation: 5 Jan 2008\n In this update:\n[1] Israel: OIE, final report\n Nature of diagnosis: suspicion, clinical, laboratory (basic),\nlaboratory (advanced), necropsy\n Locations can be seen at OIE/WAHID map appended to the report\nreferenced above or by visiting\n<http://www.glosk.com/PO/Mafra/-3002513/gmap_en.htm#>. This, in view of the long\ntime lapse and the fact that no exceptional event was seen in Kefar\nMenachem.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2008-01-07 00:00:00", "2007-03-25 00:00:00", "2008-03-25 00:00:00", "2008-01-05 00:00:00", "2008-01-03 00:00:00", "2006-03-25 00:00:00", "2007-01-07 00:00:00", "2007-12-25 00:00:00", "2021-01-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2008-01-04 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Portugal", "country": "Portugal"}, {"location": "Egypt", "country": "Egypt"}, {"location": "Saudi Arabia", "country": "Saudi Arabia"}, {"location": "Binyamina", "country": "Israel"}, {"location": "WAHID", "country": "Oman"}, {"location": "ISRAEL", "country": "Israel"}, {"location": "Beit Dagan", "country": "Israel"}, {"location": "Israel", "country": "Israel"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "44110", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (191): Benin, H5N1 conf", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=44110", "date": "2007-12-20 16:00:19", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (191): BENIN, H5N1 CONFIRMED\n********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 17 Dec 2007\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: CIDRAP News [edited]\n<http://www.cidrap.umn.edu/cidrap/content/influenza/avianflu/news/dec1707benin.html>\n\n\nTests in Italy have confirmed the 1st poultry outbreaks of H5N1 avian\ninfluenza in the West African country of Benin, according to news services.\n\nAgriculture minister Robert Dovonou said that suspected cases found on 2\nfarms earlier this month [December 2007] were confirmed by the World\nOrganisation for Animal Health (Office International des Epizooties; OIE)\nin Padua, Italy, according to a 15 Dec 2007 report by Agence France-Presse\n(AFP).\n\nThe farms are north of Porto Novo, the capital, and in Cotonou, the\ncommercial capital, both in Benin's southern coastal strip, AFP and Reuters\nreported.\n\nBenin is surrounded by countries that have faced poultry outbreaks within\nthe last 2 years: Nigeria, Togo, Niger, and Burkina Faso. Nigeria has had\none human H5N1 case. Ivory Coast and Ghana are other West African states\nthat have had poultry outbreaks.\n\nBenin officials reported the 2 suspected outbreaks to the OIE on 5 Dec\n2007, saying 100 birds had died and 245 had been killed to stop the\noutbreak. Most of the birds were chickens, but 8 turkeys were among\naffected poultry on the Cotonou farm.\n\nAccording to the Reuters report, published today [17 Dec 2007], health\nexperts have expressed concern that Benin's Voodoo priests could be at risk\nfor avian flu because of their practice of tearing out the throats of live\nchickens in ritual sacrifices.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[In its 'immediate notification' to the OIE on 5 Dec 2007, Benin reported\nthe identification of 2 outbreaks caused by the highly pathogenic avian\ninfluenza virus (see 20071206.3934). One outbreak involved a layer chicken\nflock into which there had been illegal introduction of poultry from Ghana.\nThe other (earlier) outbreak occurred in a small flock wandering in the\nvillage.\n\nThe diagnosis was performed by the national laboratory; the serotype of the\nvirus was, reportedly, 'pending'. ProMED-mail commented: 'It may be assumed\nthat the virus involved is similar to the one in neighbouring Ghana, namely\nH5N1; however, this should be verified and confirmed by a reference\nlaboratory.' The current information provides the said anticipated piece of\ninformation. - Mod.AS]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 17 Dec 2007\n \n\nAgriculture minister Robert Dovonou said that suspected cases found on 2\nfarms earlier this month [December 2007] were confirmed by the World\nOrganisation for Animal Health (Office International des Epizooties; OIE)\nin Padua, Italy, according to a 15 Dec 2007 report by Agence France-Presse\n According to the Reuters report, published today [17 Dec 2007], health\nexperts have expressed concern that Benin's Voodoo priests could be at risk\nfor avian flu because of their practice of tearing out the throats of live\nchickens in ritual sacrifices. ProMED-mail commented: 'It may be assumed\nthat the virus involved is similar to the one in neighbouring Ghana, namely\nH5N1; however, this should be verified and confirmed by a reference\nlaboratory.' \n\nBenin officials reported the 2 suspected outbreaks to the OIE on 5 Dec\n2007, saying 100 birds had died and 245 had been killed to stop the\noutbreak. [In its 'immediate notification' to the OIE on 5 Dec 2007, Benin reported\nthe identification of 2 outbreaks caused by the highly pathogenic avian\ninfluenza virus (see 20071206.3934). Source: CIDRAP News [edited]\n<http://www.cidrap.umn.edu/cidrap/content/influenza/avianflu/news/dec1707benin.html>\n\n\nTests in Italy have confirmed the 1st poultry outbreaks of H5N1 avian\ninfluenza in the West African country of Benin, according to news services. \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2007-12-25 00:00:00", "2007-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Nigeria", "country": "Nigeria"}, {"location": "Ivory Coast", "country": "Ivory Coast"}, {"location": "Padua", "country": "Italy"}, {"location": "Ghana", "country": "Ghana"}, {"location": "Italy", "country": "Italy"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "36829", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (169): UK (England), turkeys, H5N1 conf.", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=36829", "date": "2007-11-13 18:00:12", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (169): UK (ENGLAND), TURKEYS, H5N1 CONFIRMED\n************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1]\nDate: Tue 13 Nov 2007\nSource: BBC News [edited]\n<http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/7092988.stm>\n\n\nThe type of bird flu found in turkeys on a Suffolk farm is the\nvirulent H5N1 strain, according to government vets.\n\nThe virus was discovered on Sunday [11 Nov 2007] at Redgrave Park\nFarm near Diss, where all 6500 birds, most of them turkeys, are being\nslaughtered.\n\nA 3 km (2 mi) protection zone and a 10 km (6 mi) surveillance zone\nhave been set up and the farm is co-operating with vets. Acting chief\nveterinary officer Fred Landeg made the announcement at a press\nconference in London.\n\nAll birds at the affected premises -- including approximately 5000\nturkeys, 1000 ducks, and 500 geese -- will be slaughtered.\n\nPolice officers are at the entrance to the farm, and vehicles are\nbeing sprayed with a jet hose.\n\nThe Department for Environment Food and Rural Affairs (Defra) said\nsome 10 percent of birds in one shed at the farm had died during one\nnight.\n\nMr Landeg said there was 'still some uncertainty' over the situation.\n'We are at a very early stage of the investigation,' he added. 'The\ninitial sequence data suggests that it's closely related to outbreaks\nin the Czech Republic and Germany, which does suggest a possible wild\nbird source. However, at this stage we are looking with an open mind\nas to the origin and all potential sources of the origin will be\ninvestigated.'\n\nMr Landeg also said there was a lake at the affected site with a\nnumber of wild fowl on it.\n\n'We are still at a very early stage of the investigation and no 2\noutbreaks of the disease are ever the same.\n\n'This will not be a quick exercise. This is a particularly\nchallenging site and our priority is to adhere to strict\nbio-security, and the health and safety of staff on site is paramount.\n\n'It is extremely important that poultry keepers, particularly in the\nlocality, are vigilant and on the lookout for disease, and report it\nquickly. In addition we want every poultry keeper in the area to be\nwell aware of bio-security.'\n\nEarlier, Mr Landeg had said the risk of bird flu spreading was\nincreased during the autumn months because of wild bird migration.\n\nThe affected birds were free-range -- meaning they had access to the\noutdoors and may have been of greater risk of catching the disease.\n\nThere was a H5N1 outbreak at a turkey farm, also in Suffolk, in\nFebruary [2007] [see commentary].\n\nThe BBC's Andrew Sinclair, who is at the farm in Suffolk, said large\ntrucks and gas canisters had been moved on to the premises earlier in\npreparation for the cull. It is expected that all the birds will be\ngassed and then put in sealed containers.\n\nOfficials said further local surveillance work would happen before\ndeciding on any culls on neighbouring farms.\n\nHeather Peck, Defra's regional operations manager for animal health,\nsaid: 'The top priority is to get controls in place, to inform people\nof the controls in place and that's largely done electronically these\ndays.\n\n'The immediate priority for us here is both to cull the affected\nbirds on the infected premises and to establish any possible contact\nor any potential traces of movement between those premises, or\nrelated premises or premises in the immediate vicinity.'\n\nEnvironment secretary Hilary Benn is due to make a statement to the\nHouse of Commons on Tuesday afternoon [13 Nov 2007].\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Tue 13 Nov 2007\nSource: DEFRA news release, ref 418/07 [edited]\n<http://www.defra.gov.uk/news/2007/071113b.htm>\n\n\nH5N1 avian influenza confirmed in poultry\n-----------------------------------------\nFollowing further test results from the Veterinary Laboratories\nAgency (VLA) the acting chief veterinary officer has confirmed that\nthe strain of avian influenza present at the Infected Premises near\nDiss is the highly pathogenic H5N1 strain. Further characterisation\nof the virus is in progress, which may give an indication of the\norigin of the strain.\n\nLocal authorities and Animal Health are enforcing a 3 km (2 mi)\nProtection Zone, a 10 km (6 mi) Surveillance Zone and a wider\nRestricted Zone covering the whole of Suffolk and most of Norfolk\naround the Infected Premises. In these zones, movement restrictions\nwill be imposed and poultry must be isolated from wild birds. In\naddition, it has been announced that the national general licence on\nbird gatherings has been revoked, and bird shows and pigeon racing\nwill not be permitted for the time being.\n\nA full epidemiological investigation and tracings of any dangerous\ncontacts are underway and all possible sources of the outbreak will\nbe investigated.\n\nFred Landeg, the acting chief veterinary officer said: 'We are\nkeeping all poultry keepers registered on the Great Britain Poultry\nregister informed of the developing situation and I must stress how\nimportant it is for all poultry keepers in the locality to be\nextremely vigilant. They must report any suspicions of disease to\ntheir Animal Health office immediately and practice the highest\nlevels of biosecurity.\n\n'We have faced H5N1 once already this year [2007], but there is still\nsignificant uncertainty surrounding this outbreak. Swift reporting of\ndisease and stringent biosecurity is essential to controlling this\ndisease and we are working to our established contingency plans.\n\nThe European Commission has been informed of this development.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The distance between the location of the current outbreak, at Diss,\nand the previous, February 2007 outbreak, which affected turkeys in\nUpper Holton, Halesworth, Suffolk (red circle) -- is about 16 miles\n(25 km); see map at\n<http://www.multimap.com/maps/?&t=l&map=52.364791.52224|14|4&loc=GB:52.36479:1.52224:14&dp=841#t=l&map=52.36258,1.39881|11|4&dp=841&loc=GB:52.36479:1.52224:14>.\n\n\nMr Landeg's statement that the initial sequence data (of the current\nH5N1 strain) suggests close relatedness to outbreaks in the Czech\nRepublic and Germany, deserves attention. A very high similarity\n(99.96 percent) at the whole genome level was revealed in February\n(2007) between the H5N1 viruses found in Suffolk and the Hungarian\noutbreaks. These results were said to indicate that the viruses were\nessentially identical (see\n<http://www.defra.gov.uk/news/latest/2007/animal-0213.htm>).\n\nThe relatively short distance between the 2 foci in Suffolk is\nintriguing; it will be interesting to obtain information on the\nsimilarity level between the H5N1 strains isolated from them. The\npossible involvement of wild avians -- to which Mr Landeg referred --\ndeserves further investigation. - Mod.AS]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1]\n \n\nFred Landeg, the acting chief veterinary officer said: 'We are\nkeeping all poultry keepers registered on the Great Britain Poultry\nregister informed of the developing situation and I must stress how\nimportant it is for all poultry keepers in the locality to be\nextremely vigilant. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The distance between the location of the current outbreak, at Diss,\nand the previous, February 2007 outbreak, which affected turkeys in\nUpper Holton, Halesworth, Suffolk (red circle) -- is about 16 miles\n(25 km); see map at\n<http://www.multimap.com/maps/?&t=l&map=52.364791.52224|14|4&loc=GB:52.36479:1.52224:14&dp=841#t=l&map=52.36258,1.39881|11|4&dp=841&loc=GB:52.36479:1.52224:14>. \n\n'The immediate priority for us here is both to cull the affected\nbirds on the infected premises and to establish any possible contact\nor any potential traces of movement between those premises, or\nrelated premises or premises in the immediate vicinity.' \n\nHeather Peck, Defra's regional operations manager for animal health,\nsaid: 'The top priority is to get controls in place, to inform people\nof the controls in place and that's largely done electronically these\ndays. However, at this stage we are looking with an open mind\nas to the origin and all potential sources of the origin will be\ninvestigated.'\n\n The\npossible involvement of wild avians -- to which Mr Landeg referred --\ndeserves further investigation. (216) - SOUTH KOREA: H5N1, OIE, CONFIRMED\n****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 28 Nov 2006\nFrom: ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: OIE Disease Alert [edited]\n<http://www.oie.int/Messages/061128KOR.htm>\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza in the Republic of Korea (diagnosis\nconfirmation): (Date of previous outbreak of highly pathogenic avian\ninfluenza in the Republic of Korea reported to the OIE: 2004).\nInformation received on 26 Nov 2006 from Dr Chang-Seob Kim, Chief\nVeterinary Officer, Animal Health Division, Ministry of Agriculture\nand Forestry (MAF), Gwacheon:\nReport date: 26 Nov 2006.\nIdentification of agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza virus subtype H5N1.\nDate of 1st confirmation of the event: 22 Nov 2006.\nNature of diagnosis: clinical, post-mortem and laboratory.\nLocation of the outbreak: Iksan city (Jeollabuk-do province).\nNumber of animals in the outbreak: 6500 cases, 13 300 susceptible\nanimals, 6500 deaths and 6800 animals destroyed.\nDescription of affected population: a parent stock farm for broiler\nchickens (45 weeks old).\nLaboratory where diagnostic tests were performed: National Veterinary\nResearch and Quarantine Service, Anyang, Kyonggi.\nDiagnostic tests used: PCR, haemagglutination inhibition test,\nsequence analysis: amino acid sequence at cleavage site reveals a\nHPAI profile, cytopathic effect on cell culture, neutralisation.\nSource of outbreak or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive.\nControl measures undertaken: control of wildlife reservoirs;\nstamping out (all poultry in the affected farm); quarantine (removal\nof feed, manure and egg plates out of the farms within a 3-km radius\nzone around the outbreak is prohibited); movement control inside the\ncountry (a 10-km radius zone around the infected holding); screening;\nzoning; burial of dead and destroyed poultry as well as of feed,\nmanure and egg plates in the affected farm; disinfection and\nsurveillance intensified in the poultry holdings.\nControl measure to be undertaken: stamping out (all poultry within a\n0.5-km radius zone around the outbreak).\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[As expected and as reported previously, this outbreak is an H5N1.\nThis report indicates that multiple tests have been completed. Of\ncourse, it is also important to know at the molecular level, which\nprevious strain, if any, is most closely related to this new outbreak\nof the virus.\nThe location of the outbreak can be seen at\n<http://www.fallingrain.com/world/KS/3/Iksan.html> - Mod.PC]", "summary": "Control measures undertaken: control of wildlife reservoirs;\nstamping out (all poultry in the affected farm); quarantine (removal\nof feed, manure and egg plates out of the farms within a 3-km radius\nzone around the outbreak is prohibited); movement control inside the\ncountry (a 10-km radius zone around the infected holding); screening;\nzoning; burial of dead and destroyed poultry as well as of feed,\nmanure and egg plates in the affected farm; disinfection and\nsurveillance intensified in the poultry holdings. AVIAN INFLUENZA (216) - SOUTH KOREA: H5N1, OIE, CONFIRMED\n****************************************************\n Number of animals in the outbreak: 6500 cases, 13 300 susceptible\nanimals, 6500 deaths and 6800 animals destroyed. Control measure to be undertaken: stamping out (all poultry within a\n0.5-km radius zone around the outbreak). Description of affected population: a parent stock farm for broiler\nchickens (45 weeks old).", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2004-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Anyang", "country": "South Korea"}, {"location": "the Republic of Korea", "country": "South Korea"}, {"location": "Kyonggi", "country": "North Korea"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "7292", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (24): UK (England), turkeys H5N1", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7292", "date": "2007-02-03 12:00:02", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (24): UK (ENGLAND), TURKEYS H5N1\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Sat, 3 Jan 2007\nFrom: Mary Marshall <tropical.forestry@btinternet.com>\nSource: DEFRA News Release ref 34/07, 3 Feb 2007 [edited]\n<http://www.defra.gov.uk/news/2007/070203a.htm>\n\nH5N1 avian influenza confirmed in poultry\n-----------------------------------------\nTests from the Veterinary Laboratories Agency (VLA) have confirmed that the\nsample from the poultry found dead on a farm near Lowestoft in Suffolk did\ncontain the H5N1 avian flu virus. Further tests are underway to determine\nwhether the strain of the virus is similar to that found in Asia. Results\nare expected later today.\nThe State Veterinary Service are enforcing a Protection Zone of 3 km radius\nand a Surveillance Zone of 10 km around the premises where movement\nrestrictions will be imposed and poultry must be isolated from wild birds.\nThe farm itself has been under restrictions since Thursday [1 Feb 2007]\nevening. In addition the national general licence on bird gatherings has\nbeen revoked, and bird shows and pigeon racing will no longer be permitted.\nAn urgent veterinary risk assessment is being carried out in consultation\nwith ornithological experts to consider the specific circumstances of this\ncase and determine the level of risk, if any, it may pose to poultry and\nother kept birds. On the basis of this risk assessment further wider\nrestrictions will be imposed in the area.\nFred Landeg, the Deputy Chief Veterinary Officer said: 'I urge keepers of\nbirds to be vigilant, to take care if handling birds which appear to be\nunwell and to observe high levels of biosecurity. Owners that suspect\ndisease, should act quickly consult their vet. Avian influenza is a\nnotifiable disease and must be reported to the local Divisional Veterinary\nManager in the State Veterinary Service'.\nThere is no reason for public health concern. Avian Influenza is a disease\nof birds and whilst it can pass very rarely and with difficulty, to humans\nthis requires extremely close contact with infected birds, particularly faeces.\nThe Health Protection Agency has advised that, despite this incident, the\ncurrent level of risk to humans from H5N1 remains extremely low.\n'Any possibility of exposure is taken very seriously and the Health\nProtection Agency has worked closely with Defra and local NHS to ensure\nthat all the necessary actions are being taken to protect those people on\nthe farm who may have been exposed to the virus.'\nThe European Commission has been informed of this development.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[The UK has become Europe's 3rd country infected by H5N1 during the current\nwinter season, preceded by reported outbreaks in Hungary (24 Jan 2007) and\nRussia (Krasnodar, 29 Jan 2007). It will be interesting to obtain updated\nresults of EU's surveillance in wild birds; the ADNS (Animal Disease\nNotification System) summary report for highly pathogenic avian influenza\nin wild birds, accessible at\n<http://ec.europa.eu/food/animal/diseases/adns/adns_wildbirds.pdf>,was last\nupdated on 30 Nov 2006. - Mod.AS]", "summary": "It will be interesting to obtain updated\nresults of EU's surveillance in wild birds; the ADNS (Animal Disease\nNotification System) summary report for highly pathogenic avian influenza\nin wild birds, accessible at\n<http://ec.europa.eu/food/animal/diseases/adns/adns_wildbirds.pdf>,was last\nupdated on 30 Nov 2006. - Mod. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n An urgent veterinary risk assessment is being carried out in consultation\nwith ornithological experts to consider the specific circumstances of this\ncase and determine the level of risk, if any, it may pose to poultry and\nother kept birds. From: Mary Marshall <tropical.forestry@btinternet.com>\nSource: DEFRA News Release ref 34/07, 3 Feb 2007 [edited]\n<http://www.defra.gov.uk/news/2007/070203a.htm>\n\nH5N1 avian influenza confirmed in poultry\n -----------------------------------------\nTests from the Veterinary Laboratories Agency (VLA) have confirmed that the\nsample from the poultry found dead on a farm near Lowestoft in Suffolk did\ncontain the H5N1 avian flu virus. Any possibility of exposure is taken very seriously and the Health\nProtection Agency has worked closely with Defra and local NHS to ensure\nthat all the necessary actions are being taken to protect those people on\nthe farm who may have been exposed to the virus.' The State Veterinary Service are enforcing a Protection Zone of 3 km radius\nand a Surveillance Zone of 10 km around the premises where movement\nrestrictions will be imposed and poultry must be isolated from wild birds. Fred Landeg, the Deputy Chief Veterinary Officer said: 'I urge keepers of\nbirds to be vigilant, to take care if handling birds which appear to be\nunwell and to observe high levels of biosecurity. [The UK has become Europe's 3rd country infected by H5N1 during the current\nwinter season, preceded by reported outbreaks in Hungary (24 Jan 2007) and\nRussia (Krasnodar, 29 Jan 2007). Avian Influenza is a disease\nof birds and whilst it can pass very rarely and with difficulty, to humans\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2007-01-24 00:00:00", "2007-02-01 00:00:00", "2006-11-30 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2007-02-03 00:00:00", "2007-01-29 00:00:00", "2007-01-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-24 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Hungary", "country": "Hungary"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Surveillance Zone", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Lowestoft", "country": "United Kingdom"}, {"location": "Protection Zone", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Suffolk", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6795", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (13): Japan H5N1, Viet Nam, Indonesia", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6795", "date": "2007-01-20 00:00:00", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (13): JAPAN H5N1, VIET NAM, INDONESIA\n*****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1] Japan (Miyazaki) - HPAI H5N1 confirmed\n[2] Viet Nam, Can Tho\n[3] Indonesia\n******\n[1] Japan (Miyazaki) - HPAI H5N1 confirmed\nDate: Thu 18 Jan 2007\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Kyodo News via Japan Times [edited]\n<http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/nn20070119a4.html>\n\nBird flu virus in Miyazaki outbreak highly virulent\n---------------------------------------------------\nThe avian influenza that broke out last week at a poultry farm in Miyazaki\nPrefecture involved a highly virulent virus, the Agriculture, Forestry and\nFisheries Ministry said on Thursday [18 Jan 2007]. The ministry determined\nthe degree of virulence through a laboratory examination of virus samples\ntaken from chickens that died of bird flu on the Miyazaki farm.\nThe National Institute of Animal Health, which identified the virus as the\nhighly pathogenic H5N1 strain on Tuesday [16 Jan 2007], drew the conclusion\nafter 8 chickens inoculated with the sampled virus were dead by Thursday\n[18 Jan 2007], the ministry said. Based in Tsukuba, Ibaraki Prefecture, the\ninstitute will continue genetic analysis for the consideration of the\nministry's panel of experts.\nThe H5N1 strain, a subtype of the influenza A virus circulating basically\nin birds, has spread mainly in Asia and has killed more than 160 people in\n10 countries since 2003, according to the World Health Organization. Its\nlatest outbreak in poultry in Japan -- the 5th bird-flu case here since\n2004 -- occurred at Taniguchi Furanjo Kurosaka Farm in Kiyotake, Miyazaki\nPrefecture, causing the death of 3500 birds in one of the farm's 3 poultry\nhouses, mostly last week.\nIn the town of Kiyotake, inspectors from the Miyazaki Prefectural\nGovernment's task force Thursday [18 Jan 2007] checked bird-keeping\nhouseholds and homes within a 10 km radius of the farm, after they finished\nexamining the 11 poultry farms with more than 1000 chickens in the area\nWednesday [17 Jan 2007].\nTen households with at least 20 birds, including chickens and bantams\n[small breeds of chickens], were selected for Thursday's [18 Jan 2007]\non-site inspections to take blood and fluid samples from 5 birds per\nhousehold, task force officials said, adding that results will be released\nwithin a few days.\nMore than 150 households are breeding a total of around 1600 avian species\nin the town, including parakeets and other small birds kept as pets, town\nofficials said.\n******\n[2] Viet Nam, Can Tho\nDate: Fri 19 Jan 2007\nFrom: Mary Marshall <tropical.forestry@btinternet.com>\nSource: Reuters Alertnet [edited]\n<http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/HAN277071.htm>\n\nBird flu found in ducks in Viet Nam city of Can Tho\n---------------------------------------------------\nBird flu has killed ducks in the southern Mekong delta's largest city of\nCan Tho, as Viet Nam's animal health experts increase measures to contain\nthe H5N1 virus, a government report said on Friday [19 Jan 2007]. The\nAnimal Health Department said that tests showed H5N1 had killed ducklings\nin Can Tho 4 days after the virus was found in neighboring Soc Trang\nprovince. The report said the domesticated ducks had not been vaccinated\nagainst the virus.\nThe Agriculture Ministry has ordered a new round of poultry vaccinations\nand sent more animal health experts to try to stem the bird flu, which has\nstruck 7 provinces and Can Tho city in the southern rice basket region in\nthe past month as a harvest nears.\nThis week, the government ordered farmers to stop ducks from roaming in the\nMekong delta. Animal health officials said H5N1 has killed nearly 19 000\npoultry in the delta, mostly ducks. Not all ducks are killed by the virus,\nsome being infected without showing symptoms. The birds still excrete the\nvirus in their droppings as they paddle through muddy rice paddies looking\nfor insects and leftover grain.\nViet Nam has had no human H5N1 cases since November 2005, but the virus\nthat 1st hit the south east Asian country in late 2003 returned to the\nMekong delta last month [December 2006]. Thursday's [18 Jan 2007] Lao Dong\n(Labour) newspaper said 23 people who ate ducks that died from unknown\ncauses in Bac Lieu province have been put under surveillance.\nThe government is anxious to stop bird flu spreading ahead of the Tet Lunar\nNew Year festival in mid-February [2007], when poultry is part of the\ntraditional feast. Officials fear the disease could spread nationwide on\nthe wings of migrating birds and through the movement of poultry, including\nthe smuggling of chickens and ducks from neighboring countries.\nBird flu killed 42 of the 93 people infected in Viet Nam in 2003-2005. It\nhas killed 161 people out of 267 infections globally since 2003, World\nHealth Organization figures show.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[For Can Tho, see province 18 in the interactive map at\n<http://www.angelfire.com/co/hongnam/vnmap.html>. - Mod.AS]\n******\n[3] Indonesia\nDate: Fri 19 Jan 2007\nFrom: Mary Marshall <tropical.forestry@btinternet.com>\nSource: Reuters Alertnet [edited]\n<http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/JAK212987.htm>\n\nIndonesian capital's bird cull gets mixed reaction\n--------------------------------------------------\nA campaign to rid the Indonesian capital of backyard fowl to fight bird flu\ngot a mixed reaction from residents on Friday [19 Jan 2007], with some\nwelcoming it, while others worried about losing a key source of income.\nJakarta governor Sutiyoso set fire to about 1600 chickens, ducks, and\npigeons that had been slaughtered and dumped into a pit overnight in a\ndensely populated neighborhood. Some residents responded with cheers of\n'Hurray!' at the launch of the campaign, although the culled birds were not\nknown to have been infected by bird flu.\nSutiyoso told city residents on Wednesday [17 Jan 2007] that their backyard\nfowl would be confiscated and destroyed if they failed to get rid of the\nbirds by the end of the month. The move followed the deaths of 4 people in\nJakarta and its surrounding areas since the start of the year [2007], which\ntook the number of confirmed human deaths from the virus in Indonesia to\n61, the highest in the world. 'We support the government's program. It's\nbetter to do this than worrying about being infected,' a resident said. But\nsome residents were worried about the cost. Many people in Indonesia keep\npoultry to supplement their meager incomes. 'The program is good but how\ncan we eat eggs but not chicken?' she asked.\nA trader at a nearby bird market said he had not sold a single bird since\nthe governor announced the ban. He said that, even though traders like him\ncould still sell birds, traders and owners would need to get a clean bill\nof health for birds from authorities. This could discourage buyers. 'I hope\nofficials can be present here to facilitate the certification,' he said.\nHealth minister Siti Fadilah Supari on Thursday [18 Jan 2007] said the ban\nin Jakarta would be extended to 8 other provinces that had reported human\ninfections of the H5N1 bird flu virus. More than a dozen people have been\nadmitted to hospital with bird flu-like symptoms since the start of the\nyear [2007], although many have been discharged or tested negative for the\nvirus.\nIndonesia faces an uphill task controlling the disease. Millions of\nbackyard fowl live in close proximity to humans, and health education\ncampaigns have often been patchy and rules difficult to enforce.\nIllustrating this, chickens roam freely just a few minutes walk from the\ncapital's central business district.\nOfficial calls for culling have also met stiff resistance in the past due\nto meager compensation and difficulties enforcing rules in the provinces.\nOfficials said poultry owners would be paid compensation of 12 500 rupiah\n(USD 1.4) for each sick bird killed. A fully grown chicken costs about 35\n000 rupiah [USD 4] in Jakarta. The governor said on Wednesday [17 Jan 2007]\nthat there would be no payment for healthy birds.\n[byline: By Heru Asprihanto]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[No cases of avian influenza have been detected in Europe during the\ncurrent winter season. It will be interesting to follow the results of this\nyear's (2007) EU surveillance in wild birds. In 2006, infected wild birds\nwere detected between February and May. Avian influenza is one of the main\nsubjects for discussion during the due 25th Plenary meeting of EFSA'a\n(European Food Safety Authority) Animal Health & Animal Welfare panel, to\nbe convened in Parma, Italy, 31 Jan - 1 Feb 2007. Among the topics: avian\ninfluenza - zoo birds vaccination; avian influenza vaccines; situation -\nmigratory birds. - Mod.AS]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Its\nlatest outbreak in poultry in Japan -- the 5th bird-flu case here since\n2004 -- occurred at Taniguchi Furanjo Kurosaka Farm in Kiyotake, Miyazaki\nPrefecture, causing the death of 3500 birds in one of the farm's 3 poultry\nhouses, mostly last week. KOREA: H5N1, OIE, SUSPECTED\n*********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 24 Nov 2006\nFrom: ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: OIE Disease Alert, 24 Nov 2006 [edited]\n<http://www.oie.int/Messages/061124KOR.htm>\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza in the Republic of Korea (suspicion)\n----------------------------------------------------------\n(Date of previous outbreak of highly pathogenic avian influenza in the\nRepublic of Korea reported to the OIE: 2004)\nInformation received on 23 Nov 2006 (dated 22 Nov 2006) from Dr Chang-Seob\nKim, chief veterinary officer, Animal Health Division, Ministry of\nAgriculture and Forestry (MAF), Gwacheon:\nReason for immediate notification: re-occurrence of a listed disease or\ninfection in a country or zone/compartment following a report declaring the\noutbreak(s) ended.\nIdentification of agent: avian influenza virus subtype H5.\nDate of first confirmation of the event: 22 Nov 2006.\nNature of diagnosis: clinical, post-mortem and laboratory.\nLocation of the outbreak: Iksan city (Jeollabuk-do province).\nNumber of animals in the outbreak: 6500 cases, 13 000 susceptible animals,\n6500 deaths.\nDescription of affected population: a parent stock farm for broiler chickens\n(45 weeks old).\nLaboratory where diagnostic tests were performed: National Veterinary\nResearch and Quarantine Service, Anyang, Kyonggi.\nDiagnostic test used: PCR\nSource of outbreak or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive.\nControl measures undertaken:\ncontrol of wildlife reservoirs;\nstamping out;\nquarantine;\nmovement control inside the country (a 10 km radius zone around the infected\nholding);\nscreening;\nzoning.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[In the spirit of not getting ahead of the data, it is important to remember\nthat there has been no confirmation of H5N1 yet; only the H5 virus is\nconfirmed in this report. However, there is high mortality and an H5 subtype\nthat is now identified. Therefore, further information would be appreciated\nand is eagerly anticipated. - Mod.PC]", "summary": "Control measures undertaken:\ncontrol of wildlife reservoirs;\nstamping out;\nquarantine;\nmovement control inside the country (a 10 km radius zone around the infected\nholding);\nscreening;\nzoning.\n A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Agriculture and Forestry (MAF), Gwacheon:\nReason for immediate notification: re-occurrence of a listed disease or\ninfection in a country or zone/compartment following a report declaring the\noutbreak(s) ended. Source: OIE Disease Alert, 24 Nov 2006 [edited]\n<http://www.oie.int/Messages/061124KOR.htm>\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza in the Republic of Korea (suspicion)\n (Date of previous outbreak of highly pathogenic avian influenza in the\nRepublic of Korea reported to the OIE: 2004)\n [In the spirit of not getting ahead of the data, it is important to remember\nthat there has been no confirmation of H5N1 yet; only the H5 virus is\nconfirmed in this report. AVIAN INFLUENZA (213) - SOUTH KOREA: H5N1, OIE, SUSPECTED\n*********************************************************\n --\nProMED-mail\n< Dr Chang-Seob\nKim, chief veterinary officer, Animal Health Division, Ministry of\n Number of animals in the outbreak: 6500 cases, 13 000 susceptible animals,\n6500 deaths.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2006-11-23 00:00:00", "2004-03-25 00:00:00", "2006-11-24 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "the Republic of Korea", "country": "South Korea"}, {"location": "Kyonggi", "country": "North Korea"}, {"location": "the \n Republic of Korea", "country": "South Korea"}, {"location": "Anyang", "country": "South Korea"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4781", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (214) - South Korea: H5N1 conf", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4781", "date": "2006-11-25 00:00:00", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (214) - SOUTH KOREA: H5N1 CONFIRMED\n***************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1]\nDate: Sat 25 Nov 2006\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Bloomberg.com [edited]\n<http://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601087&sid=aZJE9kmhwbc8&refer=home>\n\nA highly pathogenic strain of the H5N1 bird flu was responsible for the\ndeaths of 6000 poultry on a South Korean farm, the nation's agriculture\nministry says. It has ordered the slaughter of 236 000 nearby animals to\nstem the spread of the disease.\nThe farm in the south western town of Iksan housed 13 000 head of poultry.\nAlmost half of the brood have died since 19 Nov 2006, the Seoul-based\nagriculture ministry said in a statement today. All animals within 500\nmeters (1640 feet) of the farm will be culled, it said. 'The H5N1 strain was\nverified as highly pathogenic,' the ministry said.\nThis is the first time H5N1 bird flu has reappeared in South Korea since the\n1st outbreak almost 3 years ago.\nJapan is temporarily suspending poultry imports from South Korea because of\nbird flu concerns. The imports constituted 0.2 per cent of Japan's total in\n2005, according to Kenichi Takemoto, head of the Japanese ministry of\nagriculture's meat and egg division.\n[byline: Heejin Koo]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[2]\nDate: Sat, 25 Nov 2006\nFrom: Mary Marshall <tropical.forestry@btinternet.com>\nSource: Reuters alertnet [edited]\n<http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/SP275176.htm>\n\nSouth Korea said on Saturday [25 Nov 2006] that a poultry farm had been hit\nby bird flu, saying it found the H5N1 strain of avian influenza in the\ncountry's 1st outbreak in 3 years of the virus that is potentially fatal for\nhumans.\nThe agriculture ministry said earlier this week it suspected that a highly\nvirulent strain of bird flu killed 6000 chickens at a farm in the southwest\npart of the country that lies on a path for migratory birds.\n'It is the H5N1 strain,' the agriculture ministry official said by telephone\nof test results. It was too early to say whether the strain found at the\nfarm was highly pathogenic, he added. The virus virulence could be known\nlater on Saturday, he said. [But see information in the previous item,\nconfirming the high pathogenicity. This is also apparent from the reported\nmortality rates. - Mod.AS]\nThe remaining 6000 or so poultry at the farm in North Cholla province have\nbeen culled, South Korean news reports said.\nBetween December 2003 and March 2004, about 400 000 poultry at South Korean\nfarms were infected by bird flu. During that outbreak, the country culled\n5.3 million birds and spent about 1.5 trillion won [USD 161 million] to\nprevent the disease spreading, officials said.\nSubsequent testing in the United States indicated at least 9 South Korean\nworkers involved in the mass cull had been infected with the H5N1 virus, but\nnone of them developed any major illnesses, South Korean health officials\nhave said.\nSince the virus re-emerged in Asia in 2003, outbreaks have been confirmed in\naround 50 countries and territories, according to data from the World\nOrganisation for Animal Health. [For a list of the affected countries, see\ncommentary in posting 20061118.3304].\nNorth Korea had an outbreak of bird flu at poultry farms near the capital,\nPyongyang, in February 2005, which caused it to cull more than 200 000\nchickens and vaccinate 1.1 million poultry. [An analysis made by the\nAustralian Animal Health Laboratory (FAO/OIE Reference Laboratory for HPAI)\nshowed that the AI strain which caused the March 2005 outbreak of avian\ninfluenza in chickens in the Democratic People's Republic of Korea (DPRK,\nNorth Korea) was H7N7. - Mod.AS]\nThe World Health Organization says that, as of 13 Nov 2006, there have been\n258 cases of human infection of the H5N1 strain since 2003, killing 153\npeople. Many of the victims have been Asians, with 98 deaths in Vietnam and\nIndonesia, WHO says.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>", "summary": "Source: Reuters alertnet [edited]\n<http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/SP275176.htm>\n\nSouth Korea said on Saturday [25 Nov 2006] that a poultry farm had been hit\nby bird flu, saying it found the H5N1 strain of avian influenza in the\ncountry's 1st outbreak in 3 years of the virus that is potentially fatal for\nhumans. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n [An analysis made by the\nAustralian Animal Health Laboratory (FAO/OIE Reference Laboratory for HPAI)\nshowed that the AI strain which caused the March 2005 outbreak of avian\ninfluenza in chickens in the Democratic People's Republic of Korea (DPRK,\nNorth Korea) was H7N7. Source: Bloomberg.com [edited]\n<http://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601087&sid=aZJE9kmhwbc8&refer=home>\n\nA highly pathogenic strain of the H5N1 bird flu was responsible for the\ndeaths of 6000 poultry on a South Korean farm, the nation's agriculture\nministry says. Subsequent testing in the United States indicated at least 9 South Korean\nworkers involved in the mass cull had been infected with the H5N1 virus, but\nnone of them developed any major illnesses, South Korean health officials\nhave said. The imports constituted 0.2 per cent of Japan's total in\n2005, according to Kenichi Takemoto, head of the Japanese ministry of\nagriculture's meat and egg division.\n [byline: Heejin Koo]\n--\nProMED-mail\n< The agriculture ministry said earlier this week it suspected that a highly\nvirulent strain of bird flu killed 6000 chickens at a farm in the southwest\npart of the country that lies on a path for migratory birds. North Korea had an outbreak of bird flu at poultry farms near the capital,\nPyongyang, in February 2005, which caused it to cull more than 200 000\nchickens and vaccinate 1.1 million poultry. During that outbreak, the country culled\n5.3 million birds and spent about 1.5 trillion won [USD 161 million] to\nprevent the disease spreading, officials said. \nBetween December 2003 and March 2004, about 400 000 poultry at South Korean\nfarms were infected by bird flu. The World Health Organization says that, as of 13 Nov 2006, there have been\n258 cases of human infection of the H5N1 strain since 2003, killing 153\npeople. Since the virus re-emerged in Asia in 2003, outbreaks have been confirmed in\naround 50 countries and territories, according to data from the World\nOrganisation for Animal Health. \nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org> AVIAN INFLUENZA (214) - SOUTH KOREA: H5N1 CONFIRMED\n***************************************************\n", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2005-03-25 00:00:00", "2006-11-19 00:00:00", "2003-03-25 00:00:00", "2005-02-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-27 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Seoul", "country": "South Korea"}, {"location": "Indonesia", "country": "Indonesia"}, {"location": "North Cholla", "country": "South Korea"}, {"location": "North Korea", "country": "North Korea"}, {"location": "South Korea", "country": "South Korea"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pyongyang", "country": "North Korea"}, {"location": "Vietnam", "country": "Vietnam"}, {"location": "Iksan", "country": "South Korea"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "Japan"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2230", "headline": "PRO/AH> Avian influenza (181) - Netherlands, H5N1 susp.", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2230", "date": "2006-08-14 00:00:00", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (181) - NETHERLANDS, H5N1 SUSPECTED\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Mon 14 Aug 2006\nFrom: Name withheld by request\nSource: Rotterdam Zoo website, 13 Aug 2006 [trans. from Dutch by\ncontributor, edited]\n<http://www.rotterdamzoo.nl>\n\nThe animals (4) -- all deceased or culled -- were young Northern Hawk\nOwls [_Surnia ulula_, picture at\n<http://www.schmoker.org/BirdPics/Photos/Owls/NOHO58.jpg>]\nborn in May 2006 after the last vaccination of the zoo animals.
