We are glad to publish the following response,\nreceived on 30 Aug 2006. - Mod.AS]\nDate: Wed 30 Aug 2006\nFrom: Joost Philippa <j.philippa@erasmusmc.nl>\n\nResponse to 'Avian influenza (186) - Netherlands, H5N1: NOT, RFI'\n-----------------------------------------------\nWe hereby respond to the request for information in the recent post (Avian\ninfluenza (186) - Netherlands, H5N1: NOT, RFI) about suspected H5N1 virus\ninfection in northern hawk owls (_Surnia ulula_) from Rotterdam Zoo.\nIn total, 4 hawk owls were examined. As reported previously (Avian\ninfluenza (186) - Netherlands, H5N1: NOT, RFI), 2 of these birds (birds 2\nand 3), which died with neurological signs, were initially suspected of\ninfection with highly pathogenic avian influenza virus of the subtype H5N1,\nbut no influenza virus could be isolated from their tissues. Tissues of the\n2 other birds (birds 1 and 4), which also showed neurological signs and\nwere euthanized, tested negative in PCRs for the influenza virus matrix\ngene and for subtype H5 of the hemagglutinin gene, and no further\nvirological tests were performed.\nBased on histopathology and bacteriology, bird 3 had a meningo-encephalitis\nand septicemia due to _Escherichia coli_ infection. Bird 2 had an\nencephalitis of unknown origin.\nThe cause of neurological disease in the remaining 3 birds is still open.\nThe tissues of birds 2 and 3 tested negative in PCRs for Newcastle disease\nvirus, paramyxovirus, and West Nile virus. Further tests are ongoing and\nwill be reported if a diagnosis is made.\nAn extensive epidemiological investigation was started in the zoo. In\nthroat and cloaca swabs of 72 birds that were looked after by the same\nanimal care takers as the PCR-positive owls all tested negative by PCR. In\naddition, sera of 50 non-vaccinated birds housed in the same cages tested\nnegative in the hemagglutination inhibition test against H5N1 antigen.\nJoost Philippa(1), Ron Fouchier(1), Francis Balk(2), Hans Kramps(2), Guus\nKoch(2), Thijs Kuiken(1), Ab Osterhaus(1). (1) Department of Virology\nEramus MC, Rotterdam (2) Central institute of animal disease control\n(CIDC-Lelystad), Wageningen UR.\n--\nJoost Philippa\nDepartment of Virology Eramus MC, Rotterdam\n<j.philippa@erasmusmc.nl>\n[This is a prompt response to our request, providing detailed, firsthand\ninformation. ProMED-mail is very grateful for this exemplary expression of\ntransparency and professionalism. We look forward to the results of the\nongoing tests. - Mod.AS]", "summary": "As reported previously (Avian\ninfluenza (186) - Netherlands, H5N1: NOT, RFI), 2 of these birds (birds 2\nand 3), which died with neurological signs, were initially suspected of\ninfection with highly pathogenic avian influenza virus of the subtype H5N1,\nbut no influenza virus could be isolated from their tissues. Tissues of the\n2 other birds (birds 1 and 4), which also showed neurological signs and\nwere euthanized, tested negative in PCRs for the influenza virus matrix\ngene and for subtype H5 of the hemagglutinin gene, and no further\nvirological tests were performed. Final results of laboratory\ninvestigations of samples from the 2 northern hawk owls found dead in the\nzoo have been obtained today. According to their outcome, it could not be\nconfirmed with certainty that the birds died due to H5N1.\nThe initial suspicion of H5N1 was raised at the beginning of August 2006,\nfollowing tests which were carried out within the avian influenza\nsurveillance undertaken by the Wild Life Health Centre (Erasmus MC\nRotterdam/Utrecht University). Further investigations at the Lelystad\nLaboratory [The Central Institute for Animal Disease Control, CIDC]\nconfirmed the above initial suspicion. However, the investigators have not\nbeen able to isolate the virus.\nThe [Dutch] Food and Consumer Product Safety Authority has sent various\n[additional] samples from birds in the Blijdorp zoo for [laboratory]\ninvestigations. The avian influenza virus could not be detected in any of\nthese samples, including the ones coming from the direct vicinity of the 2\ndead young owls.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[According to the information released by the Blijdorp zoo in Rotterdam\n(see archived post 20060814.2276), there were 4 AI suspected birds, all\ndeceased or culled. Further investigations at the\nLelystad Laboratory [The Central Institute for Animal Disease Control\nLelystad, CIDC] confirmed the above suspicion. Further investigations\nare underway to obtain final confirmation of an HPAI infection. The 2\nyoung infected owls had not been vaccinated. Additional sampling and\ntesting will be carried out in the zoo during the coming days.\nThough most birds in the zoo are vaccinated, the birds should be\nkept, as far as possible, protected indoors.\nHumans may be infected with H5N1 only by close contact with infected\nbirds or their excrement. Therefore, the zoo will remain open for\nvisitors, while specific protective measures are prescribed for\npersonnel engaged in animal handling. However, to be on the safe\nside, the zoo will take measures to prevent contact between visitors and birds.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[2]\nDate: Sun 13 Aug 2006\nFrom: Mary Marshall <tropical.forestry@btinternet.com>\nSource: Reuters Alertnet, 12 Aug 2006 [edited]\n<http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/MIK280312.htm>\n\nSuspected case of H5N1 bird flu in Rotterdam zoo - owls\n-----------------------------------------------\n2 young owls that died in a zoo in Rotterdam are suspected of having\nthe H5N1 bird flu virus, the Dutch farm ministry said late on\nSaturday [12 Aug 2006].\nThe Netherlands, Europe's 2nd biggest poultry producer after France,\nhas never reported a case of the highly pathogenic avian flu strain,\nwhich is endemic in parts of Asia and has spread to birds in a number\nof European Union countries.\nA ministry spokeswoman said further tests were being conducted, but\nit was suspected that the birds died of a highly pathogenic strain of\nthe virus. Final test results are due in the coming days.\nThe H5N1 virus has spread rapidly from late 2003 from Asia to Europe,\nthe Middle East and Africa. The virus can occasionally infect people\nand has killed 138 people over the past 3 years, according to figures\nfrom the World Health Organization [WHO].\nNo other dead birds have been found, and authorities are currently\ntesting other birds in the zoological garden, most of which were\nvaccinated, the spokeswoman said.\nThe Netherlands found a low-pathogenic [LPAI] H7 bird flu strain at a\nfarm earlier this month [August 2006 -- see ref. below]], prompting 5\ncountries to ban imports of Dutch poultry.\nThe Dutch suffered a devastating outbreak of an H7N7 avian flu strain\nin 2003 that led to the culling of about 1/3rd of the poultry flock,\nsome 30 million birds.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[A map presenting Avian Flu Disease Monitoring in Europe (updated May\n2006) is available at\n<http://disasters.jrc.it/AvianFlu/Europe/>.\nThe detection of an H5N1 virus in young (most probably indigenous)\nowls in a Dutch zoo reflects, most probably, virus presence in\n(migrating?) wild fauna in the Netherlands; it seems unlikely that\ninfected birds have been introduced into the zoo otherwise.\nGenotyping might help in identifying the possible source or route of\nintroduction.\nThe Netherlands is a ardent proponent of (selective) vaccination\nagainst H5N1. The vaccination of the caged birds in the zoo reflects\nthe applied vaccination policy, updated recently (4 Jul 2006) and\nlaid out in detail in 'Problems solved: 2nd round of poultry\nvaccination,' available at\n<http://www9.minlnv.nl/servlet/page?_pageid=104&_dad=portal30&_schema=PORTAL30&p_item_id=127985>.\n- Mod.AS]", "summary": "Source: Press release, Dutch Ministry of Agriculture, Nature and Food\nSafety, 12 Aug 2006 [translated from Dutch, edited]\n<http://www9.minlnv.nl/servlet/page?_pageid=104&_dad=portal30&_schema=PORTAL30&p_item_id=129003>\n\n2 dead young owls from the Blijdorp Zoo in Rotterdam have been tested\nwithin the ongoing [avian influenza] surveillance undertaken by the\nWild Life Health Centre (Erasmus MC Rotterdam/Utrecht University) and\nfound infected with the H5N1 virus. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n The vaccination of the caged birds in the zoo reflects\nthe applied vaccination policy, updated recently (4 Jul 2006) and\nlaid out in detail in 'Problems solved: 2nd round of poultry\nvaccination,' available at\n<http://www9.minlnv.nl/servlet/page?_pageid=104&_dad=portal30&_schema=PORTAL30&p_item_id=127985>. -----------------------------------------------\n2 young owls that died in a zoo in Rotterdam are suspected of having\nthe H5N1 bird flu virus, the Dutch farm ministry said late on\nSaturday The Netherlands, Europe's 2nd biggest poultry producer after France,\nhas never reported a case of the highly pathogenic avian flu strain,\nwhich is endemic in parts of Asia and has spread to birds in a number\nof European Union countries. The Dutch suffered a devastating outbreak of an H7N7 avian flu strain\nin 2003 that led to the culling of about 1/3rd of the poultry flock,\nsome 30 million birds.\n The detection of an H5N1 virus in young (most probably indigenous)\nowls in a Dutch zoo reflects, most probably, virus presence in\n(migrating?) Source: Reuters Alertnet, 12 Aug 2006 [edited]\n<http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/MIK280312.htm>\n\nSuspected case of H5N1 bird flu in Rotterdam zoo - owls\n No other dead birds have been found, and authorities are currently\ntesting other birds in the zoological garden, most of which were\nvaccinated, the spokeswoman said. A ministry spokeswoman said further tests were being conducted, but\nit was suspected that the birds died of a highly pathogenic strain of\nthe virus. However, to be on the safe\nside, the zoo will take measures to prevent contact between visitors and birds.\n Therefore, the zoo will remain open for\nvisitors, while specific protective measures are prescribed for\npersonnel engaged in animal handling. [A map presenting Avian Flu Disease Monitoring in Europe (updated May\n2006) is available at\n<http://disasters.jrc.it/AvianFlu/Europe/>. The virus can occasionally infect people\nand has killed 138 people over the past 3 years, according to figures\nfrom the World Health Organization [WHO]. Additional sampling and\ntesting will be carried out in the zoo during the coming days.\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-27 00:00:00", "2006-05-25 00:00:00", "2003-03-25 00:00:00", "2006-08-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Rotterdam", "country": "Netherlands"}, {"location": "France", "country": "France"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "Netherlands"}, {"location": "the Netherlands", "country": "Netherlands"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3489", "headline": "PRO/AH> Avian influenza, cats: H5N1 systemic infection", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3489", "date": "2006-01-15 23:50:00", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, CATS: H5N1 SYSTEMIC INFECTION\n**********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Sat 14 Jan 2006\nFrom: Joseph Dudley <fnjpd@uaf.edu>\nSource: American Journal of Pathology, Fri 13 Jan 2006, via\nEurekAalert, Sat 14 Jan 2006 [edited]\n<http://www.eurekalert.org/pub_releases/2006-01/ajop-aiv011306.php>\n\nAvian influenza virus in mammals spreads beyond the site of infection\nto other organ systems\n---------------------------------------------------\nResearchers at the Erasmus Medical Center have demonstrated systemic\nspread of avian influenza virus in cats infected by respiratory,\ndigestive, and cat-to-cat contact. The paper by Rimmelzwaan et al.,\n'Influenza A virus (H5N1) infection in cats causes systemic disease\nwith potential novel routes of virus spread within and between\nhosts,' appears in the January issue of The American Journal of\nPathology and is accompanied by a commentary.\nAvian influenza (H5N1) is of great concern because of the current\noutbreaks in Asia and the potential for pandemic spread. This virus\nis highly contagious in birds and spreads easily due to the\nagricultural and migratory nature of the bird species infected,\nincluding poultry, waterfowl, and other migratory species (See\ncommentary by Brown for more information). While spread of avian\ninfluenza from bird to man is known to occur, as first reported\nduring the 1997 Hong Kong outbreak, human-to-human spread is\nextremely rare. Thus, the disease events that take place during\nmammal-to-mammal spread are not well characterized.\nTo assess the spread of H5N1 influenza virus in mammalian hosts,\nRimmelzwaan et al. examined cats infected via the respiratory tract,\nvia the digestive tract (by feeding on infected chicks), or by close\ncontact with respiratory-infected cats. The researchers, led by Dr.\nThijs Kuiken, then examined mucous membranes (throat, nasal, and\nrectal swabs) and organ systems (respiratory, digestive, nervous,\ncardiovascular, urinary, lymphoid, and endocrine) for the presence of\nvirus and viral protein.\nAs expected, all cats were infected with H5N1 virus and exhibited\nclinical signs of disease (fever, lethargy, labored breathing, etc.),\nand virus was detected in throat, nasal, and rectal swabs, regardless\nof the original site of infection. Most interesting, virus spread\nthroughout the organ systems with virus being found in respiratory\nand digestive tracts, liver, kidney, heart, brain, and lymph nodes.\nFurthermore, examination of infected tissues revealed cellular damage\nat sites containing viral proteins, providing an explanation for the\nincreased severity of disease in humans.\nThese data underscore the potential for influenza virus to spread not\nonly from the respiratory tract but also from the digestive and\nurinary tracts, greatly increasing the possible routes of mammalian\ntransmission. Systemic disease has long been known to occur in birds,\nwith the fecal-oral route of transmission being most important.\nHowever, this is the 1st demonstration of systemic replication in\ncats, providing a cautionary tale for humans regarding how influenza\nis spread and how the disease presents itself.\nRimmelzwaan and colleagues caution that because of the systemic\nnature of avian influenza, 'H5N1 virus infection needs to be included\nin the differential diagnosis of a broader range of clinical\npresentations than is currently done.' In addition better\nunderstanding of the mechanisms of spread, including possible\nfecal-oral route in humans, 'may limit the risk of H5N1 virus\ndeveloping into a pandemic influenza virus.'\n(This work was performed at the Department of Virology, Erasmus\nMedical Center, Rotterdam, The Netherlands, and was supported by a\nNovaflu EU grant. The reference for the published text is:\n'Rimmelzwaan GF, van Riel D, Baars M, Bestebroer TM, van Amerongen G,\nFouchier RAM, Osterhaus ADME, and Kuiken T: Influenza A virus (H5N1)\ninfection in cats causes systemic disease with potential novel routes\nof virus spread within and between hosts. Am J Pathol 2006 168:\n176-183'. The paper is accompanied by a Commentary by C.Brown: Avian\ninfluenza: Virchow's reminder. Am J Pathol 2006 168: 6-8.)\n--\nJoseph P. Dudley, Ph.D\nResearch Associate\nInstitute of Arctic Biology - University of Alaska Fairbanks\nDepartment of Earth Science - University of Alaska Museum\n<fnjpd@uaf.edu>\n[The susceptibility of carnivores to avian influenza A virus was\nfirst recorded in a paper published in the China Journal of\nVeterinary Science in 2003, demonstrating that tigers had died of\ninfluenza A virus infection in China in 2002.\nSubsequently in 2004 during the H5N1 avian influenza outbreak in\nThailand considerable mortality occurred among zoo tigers and\nleopards probably as a result of ingestion of diseased poultry. More\nrecently, deaths of chickens and dogs were reported in a rural\nvillage (Bozkurt) in Turkey, although the cause was not determined.\nNow Rimmelzwaan et al. have used domestic cats as a model to\ninvestigate factors affecting the spread of avian influenza A viruses\nfrom mammal to mammal. Their data clearly demonstrate systemic spread\nof virus in cats and multiplication of virus in several organ\nsystems. The wider importance of their findings resides in their\nfinal conclusion: '....better understanding of the mechanisms of\nspread, including possible fecal-oral route in humans, 'may limit the\nrisk of H5N1 virus developing into a pandemic influenza virus.' - Mod.CP]", "summary": "The paper by Rimmelzwaan et al.,\n'Influenza A virus (H5N1) infection in cats causes systemic disease\nwith potential novel routes of virus spread within and between\nhosts,' appears in the January issue of The American Journal of\nPathology and is accompanied by a commentary. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Source: American Journal of Pathology, Fri 13 Jan 2006, via\nEurekAalert, Sat 14 Jan 2006 [edited]\n<http://www.eurekalert.org/pub_releases/2006-01/ajop-aiv011306.php>\n\nAvian influenza virus in mammals spreads beyond the site of infection\nto other organ systems\n The researchers, led by Dr.\nThijs Kuiken, then examined mucous membranes (throat, nasal, and\nrectal swabs) and organ systems (respiratory, digestive, nervous,\ncardiovascular, urinary, lymphoid, and endocrine) for the presence of\nvirus and viral protein. This virus\nis highly contagious in birds and spreads easily due to the\nagricultural and migratory nature of the bird species infected,\nincluding poultry, waterfowl, and other migratory species (See\ncommentary by Brown for more information). The wider importance of their findings resides in their\nfinal conclusion: '....better understanding of the mechanisms of\nspread, including possible fecal-oral route in humans, 'may limit the\nrisk of H5N1 virus developing into a pandemic influenza virus.' In addition better\nunderstanding of the mechanisms of spread, including possible\nfecal-oral route in humans, 'may limit the risk of H5N1 virus\ndeveloping into a pandemic influenza virus.' As expected, all cats were infected with H5N1 virus and exhibited\nclinical signs of disease (fever, lethargy, labored breathing, etc.),\nand virus was detected in throat, nasal, and rectal swabs, regardless\nof the original site of infection. These data underscore the potential for influenza virus to spread not\nonly from the respiratory tract but also from the digestive and\nurinary tracts, greatly increasing the possible routes of mammalian\ntransmission. Most interesting, virus spread\nthroughout the organ systems with virus being found in respiratory\nand digestive tracts, liver, kidney, heart, brain, and lymph nodes.\n Rimmelzwaan and colleagues caution that because of the systemic\nnature of avian influenza, 'H5N1 virus infection needs to be included\nin the differential diagnosis of a broader range of clinical\npresentations than is currently done.' While spread of avian\ninfluenza from bird to man is known to occur, as first reported\nduring the 1997 Hong Kong outbreak, human-to-human spread is\nextremely rare. Influenza A virus (H5N1)\ninfection in cats causes systemic disease with potential novel routes\nof virus spread within and between hosts. More\nrecently, deaths of chickens and dogs were reported in a rural\nvillage (Bozkurt) in Turkey, although the cause was not determined.\n Researchers at the Erasmus Medical Center have demonstrated systemic\nspread of avian influenza virus in cats infected by respiratory,\ndigestive, and cat-to-cat contact. Institute of Arctic Biology - University of Alaska Fairbanks\nDepartment of Earth Science - University of Alaska Museum\n<fnjpd@uaf.edu>\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2003-03-25 00:00:00", "2004-03-25 00:00:00", "2002-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-01-25 00:00:00", "1997-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "the Netherlands", "country": "Netherlands"}, {"location": "Thailand", "country": "Thailand"}, {"location": "Bozkurt", "country": "Turkey"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Rotterdam", "country": "Netherlands"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "Hong Kong"}, {"location": "Novaflu", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Turkey", "country": "Turkey"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2022", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (159) - Thailand, H5N1 confirmed", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2022", "date": "2006-07-24 00:00:00", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (159) - THAILAND, H5N1 CONFIRMED\n**********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1]\nDate: Mon, 24 Jul 2006\nFrom: Joe Dudley <jdudley@eaicorp.com>\nSource: Bangkok Post, 24 Jul 2006 [edited]\n<http://www.bangkokpost.com/News/25Jul2006_news03.php>\n\nAvian flu disease returns after 8 months\nH5N1 virus outbreak confirmed in Phichit\n---------------------\nThe 8-month bird flu-free hiatus in Thailand ended yesterday as the\nAgriculture and Cooperatives Ministry confirmed a fresh outbreak of\nthe H5N1 virus in the northern province of Phichit. The confirmation\ncame shortly after poultry farmers and an outgoing senator accused\nthe ministry of covering up the re-emergence of the deadly disease\nafter massive deaths of poultry in many provinces from early this\nmonth [see prior ProMED-mail postings on Undiagnosed deaths, poultry\n- Thailand listed below - Mod.MPP].\nThe ministry had repeatedly denied bird flu had recurred but\neventually verified the outbreak yesterday.\nThe Livestock Development Department's lab detected the avian flu\nvirus in a fighting cock carcass from Bang Mun Nak district. This was\nwhere almost 300 fowls had been culled after the mysterious deaths of\naround 30 fighting cocks and free-range chickens 2 weeks ago,\ncaretaker Agriculture Minister Sudarat Keyuraphan told a press conference.\nKhunying Sudarat, however, tried to ease public concerns over the\ndetection of the bird flu virus.\n''Finding the virus in an area that used to be plagued with the\ndisease like Bang Mun Nak district is considered to be a common\nthing. It would be more frightening if the virus was found in a bird\nflu-free zone,'' she said.\nNirundorn Aungtragoolsuk, director of the Livestock Development\nDepartment's Disease Control Bureau insisted that test results had\nconfirmed the bird flu outbreak late yesterday morning and the\nministry had informed the public right away.\nDr Nirundorn said the virus was unlikely to spread since all fowls in\nthe infected area had been culled from Saturday [22 Jul 2006].\nThe department had now employed extreme measures to contain the\noutbreak, including imposing a total ban on fowl movements in the\nprovince and sealing borders to prevent smuggling of poultry from\nneighbouring countries.\nThe department had reported the re-emergence of the disease to the\nWorld Organisation for Animal Health and major importers of Thai\ncooked chicken.\nThe area within a 10-km radius of the infected farm had been put\nunder a 21-day surveillance.\nThe Public Health Ministry, meanwhile, reported yesterday that an\n11-year-old boy from Phichit had been listed as the country's latest\nsuspected bird flu case.\nA blood sample from the boy had been sent for testing. Results were\npending for another 7 suspected cases.\n--\nJoseph P. Dudley, Ph.D.\nChief Scientist,\nEAI Corporation\nArlington, VA 22203\n<jdudley@eai.com>\n******\n[2]\nDate: Mon 24 Jul 2006\nFrom: Joe Dudley <jdudley@eaicorp.com>\nSource: Reuters Alertnet, 24 Jul 2006 [edited]\n<http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/BKK302025.htm>\n\nThailand finds bird flu, testing for H5N1\n-----------------------------------------------\nA strain of bird flu has been found in chickens in Thailand, and it\nmay prove to be the deadly H5N1 virus, senior Agriculture Ministry\nofficial Yukol Limlaemthong said on Monday [24 Jul 2006].\n'There is a high possibility it is the N1 strain, given that the area\nhas had outbreaks before,' Yukol told Reuters.\nOfficials said the H5 virus was detected on a farm in the northern\nprovince of Pichit, one of 7 'red zone' provinces where surveillance\nwas stepped up this month [July 2006], and test results were expected\nin a few days.\nIf H5N1 is confirmed, it would be Thailand's 1st confirmed outbreak\nof the virus in nearly 9 months.\nLivestock officials culled all chickens in the affected area and\nrestricted poultry movements within a 10-km (6-mile) radius for at\nleast 30 days.\nThe H5N1 virus has killed 14 Thais since it 1st arrived in the\ncountry in late 2003. The last death occurred in December 2005.\nAn 11-year-old girl was in a Pichit hospital on Monday [24 Jul 2006]\nwith flu-like symptoms, after chickens died on her family farm, a\ndoctor told Reuters. Test results are due on Tuesday [25 Jul 2006].\n'The chickens started to die on 8 Jul 2006, and she helped her mother\nbury the dead chickens without any protective gear,' said Sunee\nThirakaroonwongse of the Pichit Provincial Hospital.\nThailand was slow to respond to bird flu when it began ravaging\npoultry flocks in late 2003, but it now has one of the strongest\nsurveillance systems in the region.\nHowever, recent incidents in which villagers have ignored government\nwarnings and handled dead chickens have raised fears that public\nvigilance against the disease is waning.\nThe global human death toll is now at least 132 since the virus\nreemerged in east Asia in 2003.\n--\nJoseph P. Dudley, Ph.D.\nChief Scientist,\nEAI Corporation\nArlington, VA 22203\n<jdudley@eai.com>\n******\n[3]\nDate: Mon 24 Jul 2006\nFrom: Joe Dudley <jdudley@eaicorp.com>\nSource: TNA via Etna.mcot.net, 24 Jul 2006 [edited]\n<http://etna.mcot.net/query.php?nid=23580>\n\nThailand bans poultry imports to prevent new bird flu outbreak\n-----------------------------------------------\nThailand has banned poultry imports from neighboring countries to\nprevent a new outbreak of bird flu.\nAgriculture and Cooperatives Minister Khunying Sudarat Keyuraphan\nsaid on Monday [24 Jul 2006] that the ministry had ordered a total\nban on importing poultry from any neighboring country to prevent the\noutbreak of bird flu.\nThe ban was imposed after some neighboring countries sent dead fowl\nsamples for laboratory tests in Thailand and some samples tested\npositive for the virus.\nKhunying Sudarat affirmed that no outbreak had been reported in areas\nwhere many fowl died of unknown causes, and some weakened and became\nvulnerable to bird flu virus. The minister, however, admitted the\npresence of bird flu after an absence of nearly a year.\nKhunying Sudarat announced that tests conducted on samples of dead\nfighting cocks and domestic fowl in Bangmoonnak District of the\nnorthern Phichit Province were positive. The laboratory technicians\nhave not yet been able to identify which strain it is. The fighting\ncocks and domestic fowl sickened and died. The lab test showed that\nthey died of bird flu after Thailand had not confirmed the presence\nof avian influenza for 254 days.\nThe Department of Livestock Development culled the remaining 260\nchickens at the site and banned the movement of poultry within a 10-km radius.\nUntil now, there has been no report of bird flu patients in the area\nwhere the chickens died.\nAvian influenza outbreaks occurred in 14 locations in Phichit in 2004\nand 3 locations last year [2005].\nMeanwhile, Thailand's public health establishment breathed a\ncollective sigh of relief Monday [24 Jul 2006] as laboratory tests\nconfirmed that no new cases of H5N1 bird flu virus have been\ntransmitted to humans in recent months. [However, a suspected case is\nmentioned in the 1st item above. - Mod.AS]\nNo deaths have occurred since February last year [2005], and no new\nhuman bird flu cases have been found in Thailand over the past year\nand a half, a senior Public Health Ministry official confirmed here\nMonday [24 Jul 2006].\nDirector-General of the Department of Disease Control Dr. Thawat\nSuntrajarn said, according to laboratory tests, patients who were\npreviously reported to have bird flu-like symptoms in many provinces\nhad all been proven to be bird-flu free.\n'The patients, including 2 men in Phichit, were all found not having\ncontracted avian flu, but a strain of human influenza,' he told journalists.\nDr. Thawat said, however, that more public health workers would be\nsent to Phichit to help control the situation, following an official\nreport from the Department of Livestock Development that chickens in\nBangmoonnak District were found to have contracted the H5N1 virus.\n--\nJoseph P. Dudley, Ph.D.\nChief Scientist,\nEAI Corporation\nArlington, VA 22203\n<jdudley@eai.com>\n[Thailand's official alert message to the OIE regarding an outbreak\nof HPAI caused by an H5 virus in Bangmulnarg district (Pichit\nprovince), was sent on 24 Jul 2006; see\n<http://www.oie.int/Messages/060724THA.htm>.\nReportedly, the outbreak was found during the 2nd active surveillance\nprogram for 2006, in progress since 1 Jun 2006 in high risk areas.\nThe previous outbreak of HPAI in poultry in Thailand was reported to\nthe OIE in November 2005.\nProMED-mail has been repeatedly reporting about mortalities in Thai\npoultry, allegedly caused by fowl cholera, since 4 Jul 2006. In view\nof the doubtful diagnosis, these postings were titled 'undiagnosed\ndeaths,' and information was requested, with special reference to\nHPAI. The course of the current outbreak seems to be reminiscent of\nthe history of H5N1 diagnosis/reporting in Thailand in December\n2003/January 2004 (see references).\nFinal confirmation of the causative agent by a reference laboratory\nis anticipated. - Mod.AS]", "summary": "--\nJoseph P. Source: Reuters Alertnet, 24 Jul 2006 [edited]\n<http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/BKK302025.htm>\n\nThailand finds bird flu, testing for H5N1\n The lab test showed that\nthey died of bird flu after Thailand had not confirmed the presence\nof avian influenza for 254 days. "other", "cholera", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-29 00:00:00", "2021-12-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-30 00:00:00", "2005-12-25 00:00:00", "2006-07-25 00:00:00", "2006-03-25 00:00:00", "2003-03-25 00:00:00", "2006-06-01 00:00:00", "2006-07-04 00:00:00", "2005-11-25 00:00:00", "2006-07-24 00:00:00", "2004-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-27 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Arlington", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Phichit Province", "country": "Thailand"}, {"location": "Bangmoonnak District", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bangmulnarg", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yukol", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Thailand", "country": "Thailand"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5346", "headline": "PRO/AH> Avian influenza virus (02): two clades of H5N1", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5346", "date": "2006-03-21 23:50:00", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA VIRUS (02): TWO CLADES OF H5N1\n******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Mon 20 Mar 2006\nFrom: Mary Marshall <tropical.forestry@btinternet.com>\nSource: Reuters Foundation AlertNet, Mon 20 Mar 2006 [edited]\n<http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/N20119418.htm>\n\nThe H5N1 avian influenza virus in humans has evolved into 2 separate\nstrains, a development that will complicate the search for a vaccine and\nthe prevention of a pandemic, U.S. researchers reported on Mon [20 Mar 2006].\nThe genetic diversification of the pool of H5N1 avian influenza viruses\nwith the potential to cause a human influenza pandemic heightens the need\nfor careful surveillance, researchers said at the International Conference\non Emerging Infectious Diseases in Atlanta.\n'Back in 2003 we only had one genetically distinct population of H5N1 with\nthe potential to cause a human pandemic. Now we have 2,' said Rebecca\nGarten of the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), who\nhelped conduct the study. One of the 2 strains, or clades, made people sick\nin Vietnam, Cambodia and Thailand in 2003 and 2004 and the 2nd, a cousin of\nthe 1st, caused the disease in people in Indonesia in 2005.\n2 clades may share the same ancestor but are genetically distinct -- as are\ndifferent clades, or strains, of the AIDS virus, the team from the CDC\nfound. 'This does complicate vaccine development. But we are moving very\nswiftly to develop vaccines against this new group of viruses,' said Dr.\nNancy Cox, chief of the CDC's influenza branch.\nThe H5N1 strain of bird flu has spread across Europe, Africa and parts of\nAsia and killed nearly 100 people worldwide and infected about 180 since it\nreemerged in 2003. Although it is difficult to catch bird flu, people can\nbecome infected if they come into close contact with infected birds.\nScientists fear the virus could mutate into a form that could pass easily\nbetween humans, triggering a pandemic in which millions could die.\nAll influenza viruses mutate easily, and H5N1 appears to be no exception.\nBut Cox said the evolution of a 2nd clade does not move the virus closer to\nhuman-to-human transmission. 'Like the group one or clade one viruses, the\ngroup 2 or clade 2 viruses are not easily transmitted from person to\nperson,' she said. 'It really doesn't take us closer to a pandemic. It\nsimply makes preparing for the pandemic a bit more difficult.'\nThe U.S. Health and Human Services Department has already recognized the 2\nstrains and approved the development of a 2nd H5N1 vaccine based on the 2nd\nclade. Several companies are working on H5N1 vaccines experimentally,\nalthough current formulations are not expected to protect very well, if at\nall, against any pandemic strain. A vaccine against a pandemic flu strain\nwould have to be formulated using the actual virus passing from person to\nperson.\nResearchers said while vaccines were needed against different strains of\nthe virus, a vaccination against one clade could provide partial protection\nagainst another. 'We would expect the priming (of a patient) with a clade\none (vaccine) could potentially reduce the severity of disease,' Cox said.\nFor their study, Garten and colleagues analyzed more than 300 H5N1 virus\nsamples taken from both infected birds and people from 2003 through the\nsummer of 2005. Garten said the bird flu strains being detected in Europe\nwere generally clade 2 strains.\n[Byline: Jim Loney and Maggie Fox]\n--\nMary Marshall\n<tropical.forestry@btinternet.com>\n[The term 'clade' is derived from the style of presentation of phylogenetic\ndata, which are most conveniently presented in the form of trees consisting\nof 2 elements; nodes and branches. A branch is a line which connects 2\nnodes. Nodes can be external (the tips of the branches) or internal\n(representing the common ancestor of 2 nodes) A cladogram shows only the\nbranching order of nodes, and the lengths of the branches contain no\ninformation. All of the descendents of a common ancestor represented by a\ncommon node belong to the same clade. A clade is a monphyletic group.\nA phylogram, on the other hand, displays both branching order and distance\ninformation, where distance provides an indication of the number of amino\nacid changes (or nucleotide substitutions) from the ancestral node (i.e.\ngiving an indication of the extent of relative evolution from a common\nnode). - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n A phylogram, on the other hand, displays both branching order and distance\ninformation, where distance provides an indication of the number of amino\nacid changes (or nucleotide substitutions) from the ancestral node (i.e.\ngiving an indication of the extent of relative evolution from a common\nnode). Source: Reuters Foundation AlertNet, Mon 20 Mar 2006 [edited]\n<http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/N20119418.htm>\n\nThe H5N1 avian influenza virus in humans has evolved into 2 separate\nstrains, a development that will complicate the search for a vaccine and\nthe prevention of a pandemic, U.S. researchers reported on Mon The genetic diversification of the pool of H5N1 avian influenza viruses\nwith the potential to cause a human influenza pandemic heightens the need\nfor careful surveillance, researchers said at the International Conference\non Emerging Infectious Diseases in Atlanta. \n2 clades may share the same ancestor but are genetically distinct -- as are\ndifferent clades, or strains, of the AIDS virus, the team from the CDC\nfound. ' Like the group one or clade one viruses, the\ngroup 2 or clade 2 viruses are not easily transmitted from person to\nperson,' she said. ' \nMary Marshall\n<tropical.forestry@btinternet.com>\n Garten said the bird flu strains being detected in Europe\nwere generally clade 2 strains.\n The U.S. Health and Human Services Department has already recognized the 2\nstrains and approved the development of a 2nd H5N1 vaccine based on the 2nd\nclade. One of the 2 strains, or clades, made people sick\nin Vietnam, Cambodia and Thailand in 2003 and 2004 and the 2nd, a cousin of\nthe 1st, caused the disease in people in Indonesia in 2005. Researchers said while vaccines were needed against different strains of\nthe virus, a vaccination against one clade could provide partial protection\nagainst another. ' [The term 'clade' is derived from the style of presentation of phylogenetic\ndata, which are most conveniently presented in the form of trees consisting\nof 2 elements; nodes and branches. A vaccine against a pandemic flu strain\nwould have to be formulated using the actual virus passing from person to\nperson. For their study, Garten and colleagues analyzed more than 300 H5N1 virus\nsamples taken from both infected birds and people from 2003 through the\nsummer of 2005.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2005-03-25 00:00:00", "2004-03-25 00:00:00", "2006-03-25 00:00:00", "2003-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Thailand", "country": "Thailand"}, {"location": "Vietnam", "country": "Vietnam"}, {"location": "Cambodia", "country": "Cambodia"}, {"location": "Atlanta", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Indonesia", "country": "Indonesia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1512", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza - Eurasia (23): Croatia, H5N1, swan", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1512", "date": "2005-10-21 23:50:00", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA - EURASIA (23): CROATIA, H5N1, SWAN\n****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSponsored by Elsevier, publisher of\nTropical Infectious Diseases, 2nd Edition\n<http://thelancet.url123.com/a5445>\nDate: Fri, 21 Oct 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Reuters alertnet, 21 Oct 2005 [edited]\n<http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/HAM169395.htm>\n\nCroatian scientists have detected a bird flu virus in wild swans\nfound dead at a fish pond, the agriculture ministry said on Friday\n[21 Oct 2005]. Croatia immediately banned hunting and transport of\nwild fowl and poultry.\n'We have sent samples to Britain for further checks. There were 6\ndead swans found in Orahovica fish pond in eastern Croatia,' ministry\nspokesman Mladen Pavic told Reuters. [See map at\n<http://www.fallingrain.com/world/HR/17/Orahovica.html>].\nA government statement issued by Prime Minister Ivo Sanader said the\nresults of those checks were expected in 2 days but added there was\nno cause for alarm:\n'We are taking all necessary measures to prevent the virus from\nspreading. We don't think there is any danger for people.'\n'The European Commission is preparing a decision to ban the import of\nlive poultry and poultry products from Croatia which will be adopted\nby urgent procedure on Monday [24 Oct 2005],' the EU executive said\nin a statement.\nThe Croatian government had assured the Commission that no live\npoultry and poultry products would be dispatched from the former\nYugoslav republic to the European Union, the Commission added.\nThe Croatian agriculture ministry banned hunting of wild fowl and\ntransport of poultry and told farmers to keep poultry indoors. It\nalso banned the slaughter and sale of poultry in an area of 20 km (13\nmiles) around the fish pond.\n'I expect more indirect damage from this, as it will be difficult to\nconvince people that eating locally raised poultry is safe,'\nAgriculture Minister Petar Cobankovic told an emergency news conference.\nIn Romania, which shares the Danube waterway with Croatia, and in\nTurkey, hundreds of miles to the south, the deadly H5N1 strain of the\nvirus has been confirmed in wild birds and poultry. This is the\nstrain that some experts warn could cause a devastating pandemic\namong humans. [This should have been better phrased as\nfollows:'....that some experts warn might be involved, under certain\nconditions and if allowed to spread among animals, in the emergence\nof an influenza strain which could cause a devastating pandemic among\nhumans.' - Mod.AS]\nCases in Greece and Macedonia, south of Croatia but closer, are still\nbeing examined to determine exactly what virus may be involved in\nbird deaths there.\nZoologists say the Danube is a natural pathway for some species of\nmigratory birds moving west and south for the winter, which may have\nbeen in contact with the most recent flu virus to the east. It\noriginated in Asia several years ago.\n'These swans almost certainly did not come from Romania or Turkey,\nwhich means there is a source of bird flu somewhere else in Europe,'\nornithologist Dragan Radovic told reporters.\n[Byline: Zoran Radosavljevic]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[The active involvement of ornithologists in the study of H5N1\nepidemiology should be encouraged. An increasing incidence of\nclinical avian influenza has been observed in various wild avian\nspecies. Though members of the Anseriformes order (particularly the\nAnatidae family, to which swans belong) have been traditionally\nconsidered as the main reservoir and vectors of avian influenza\nviruses, the role of Passeriformes should be studied as well. - Mod.AS]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n [This should have been better phrased as\nfollows:'....that some experts warn might be involved, under certain\nconditions and if allowed to spread among animals, in the emergence\nof an influenza strain which could cause a devastating pandemic among\nhumans.' - Mod. A government statement issued by Prime Minister Ivo Sanader said the\nresults of those checks were expected in 2 days but added there was\nno cause for alarm:\n'We are taking all necessary measures to prevent the virus from\nspreading. Source: Reuters alertnet, 21 Oct 2005 [edited]\n<http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/HAM169395.htm>\n\nCroatian scientists have detected a bird flu virus in wild swans\nfound dead at a fish pond, the agriculture ministry said on Friday\n Though members of the Anseriformes order (particularly the\nAnatidae family, to which swans belong) have been traditionally\nconsidered as the main reservoir and vectors of avian influenza\nviruses, the role of Passeriformes should be studied as well. - Mod. [Byline: Zoran Radosavljevic]\n--\nProMED-mail\n< Sponsored by Elsevier, publisher of\nTropical Infectious Diseases, 2nd Edition\n<http://thelancet.url123.com/a5445>\n In Romania, which shares the Danube waterway with Croatia, and in\nTurkey, hundreds of miles to the south, the deadly H5N1 strain of the\nvirus has been confirmed in wild birds and poultry. The European Commission is preparing a decision to ban the import of\nlive poultry and poultry products from Croatia which will be adopted\nby urgent procedure on Monday The Croatian government had assured the Commission that no live\npoultry and poultry products would be dispatched from the former\nYugoslav republic to the European Union, the Commission added. It\nalso banned the slaughter and sale of poultry in an area of 20 km (13\nmiles) around the fish pond. Zoologists say the Danube is a natural pathway for some species of\nmigratory birds moving west and south for the winter, which may have\nbeen in contact with the most recent flu virus to the east. There were 6\ndead swans found in Orahovica fish pond in eastern Croatia,' ministry\nspokesman Mladen Pavic told Reuters. I expect more indirect damage from this, as it will be difficult to\nconvince people that eating locally raised poultry is safe,'\n", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-29 00:00:00", "2005-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Orahovica", "country": "Croatia"}, {"location": "Greece", "country": "Greece"}, {"location": "Britain", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Croatia", "country": "Croatia"}, {"location": "Turkey", "country": "Turkey"}, {"location": "Romania", "country": "Romania"}, {"location": "Macedonia", "country": "North Macedonia"}, {"location": "Passeriformes", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2208807", "headline": "PRO/ERR> Avian influenza - Eurasia (13): H5N1, corr.", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2208807", "date": "2005-10-17 23:50:00", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA - EURASIA (13): H5N1, CORRECTION\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nJournal of Hospital Infection\n<http://thelancet.url123.com/a5wh7>\nDate: 16 Oct 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail would like to thank Alan Shlosberg <alans@moag.gov.il> for\npointing out that there was a mistake in ProMED-mail posting Avian\ninfluenza - Eurasia (13): H5N1 20051016.3018 '...to allocate ILS 150\nmillion [USD 181 million].' A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": [], "event_date": [], "locations": []}]}, {"archive_id": "2483", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza - Eurasia (61): wild ducks, Italy, LPAI H5N1", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2483", "date": "2005-11-12 23:50:00", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA - EURASIA (61): WILD DUCKS, ITALY, LPAI H5N1\n************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nInternational Journal of Infectious Disease\n<http://thelancet.url123.com/a58n7>\nDate: Sat, 12 Nov 2005\nFrom: Communications Office, Istituto Zooprofilattico Sperimentale\ndelle Venezie (IZSVe) <comunicazione@izsvenezie.it>\n\nReport on the H5N1 Low Pathogenic Avian Influenza (LPAI) Isolate in\nItaly - November 2005\n--------------------------------------------------\nOn 8 Nov 2005, a type A influenza virus isolate was submitted to the\nNational Reference Laboratory for Avian Influenza in Legnaro (Padova,\nItaly) for detailed characterization. The virus was isolated from a\ncloacal swab collected from a wild duck hunted in an area located in\nthe municipality of Mirandola, province of Modena, in Emilia-Romagna\nRegion.[Lat: 4:53:16N (44.8878), Lon: 11:04:03E (11.0674), about 45\nkm north of the city Modena].\nOn 9 Nov 2005, the isolate was typed as a Low Pathogenic H5N1 by\nhaemagglutination inhibition test, neuraminidase inhibition test, and\ngenetic analysis.\nThe amino acids sequence deduced from the cleavage site of the\nhaemagglutinin molecule (PQRETRG) is typical of low pathogenicity\navian influenza viruses (LPAI). Therefore it is a completely\ndifferent pathotype than the Asiatic highly pathogenic (HPAI) H5N1\nviruses.\nThe Italian H5N1 represents a different virus, not related\ngenetically to the aggressive Asiatic H5N1. This has been\ndemonstrated by the analysis of the HA gene. The preliminary results\nindicate that the Italian virus is genetically related to other LPAI\nviruses commonly isolated in wild birds in Europe. The HA gene of the\nisolate correlated with the following LPAI strains sequences\ndeposited in international databases: A/mallard/NL/3/99(H5N2);\nA/mallard/Sweden/7/02(H5N2); A/mallard/DK/64650/03(H5N7).\nMore than 1000 samples collected from wild waterfowl in Italy have\npreviously been tested with negative results for H5N1 HPAI.\n--\nDr. Romano Marabelli\nGeneral director\nDirectorate General for Veterinary Health and Food\nMinistry of Health, Rome - Italy\n\n[This expedient and detailed report on the topics included in our\nrequest for information is gratefully acknowledged.\nTraditionally, the pathogenicity of avian influenza isolates is\ndefined in terms of intravenous pathogenicity index (IVPI) based upon\nin vivo trials in susceptible chickens 4-8 weeks old. However, this\nsystem has been undergoing modifications in the light of contemporary\ngenetic knowledge. See the following explanatory comment from 2005's\nedition of OIE's terrestrial manual of Diagnostic tests and Vaccines:\n'Now that the presence of multiple basic amino acids at the HA0\ncleavage site is well-established as an accurate indicator of\nvirulence or potential virulence for H5 and H7 influenza viruses, it\nappears inevitable that determination of the cleavage site by\nsequencing or other methods will become the method of choice for\ninitial assessment of the virulence of these viruses and incorporated\ninto agreed definitions. This will have the advantage of reducing the\nnumber of in-vivo tests, although at present the inoculation of birds\nmay still be required to confirm a negative result as the possibility\nof virus cultures containing mixed populations of viruses of high and\nlow virulence cannot be ruled out'.\nThe virological laboratory at IZSVe (Istituto Zooprofilattico\nSperimentale delle Venezie) in Legnaro, Padova, directed by Dr Ilaria\nCapua, is one of the 6 HPAI reference laboratories of the OIE. The\nother laboratories are situated in Riems, Germany; Weybridge, UK;\nGeelong, Australia; Ames, Iowa, USA; and Sapporo, Japan. - Mod.AS]", "summary": "See the following explanatory comment from 2005's\nedition of OIE's terrestrial manual of Diagnostic tests and Vaccines:\n'Now that the presence of multiple basic amino acids at the HA0\ncleavage site is well-established as an accurate indicator of\nvirulence or potential virulence for H5 and H7 influenza viruses, it\nappears inevitable that determination of the cleavage site by\nsequencing or other methods will become the method of choice for\ninitial assessment of the virulence of these viruses and incorporated\ninto agreed definitions. --\nDr. Romano Marabelli\nGeneral director\nDirectorate General for Veterinary Health and Food\nMinistry of Health, Rome - Italy\n\n[This expedient and detailed report on the topics included in our\nrequest for information is gratefully acknowledged. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n This will have the advantage of reducing the\nnumber of in-vivo tests, although at present the inoculation of birds\nmay still be required to confirm a negative result as the possibility\nof virus cultures containing mixed populations of viruses of high and\nlow virulence cannot be ruled out'. The virus was isolated from a\ncloacal swab collected from a wild duck hunted in an area located in\nthe municipality of Mirandola, province of Modena, in Emilia-Romagna\nRegion.[Lat: 4:53:16N (44.8878), Lon: 11:04:03E (11.0674), about 45\nkm north of the city Modena]. From: Communications Office, Istituto Zooprofilattico Sperimentale\ndelle Venezie (IZSVe) <comunicazione@izsvenezie.it>\n\nReport on the H5N1 Low Pathogenic Avian Influenza (LPAI) Isolate in\nItaly - November 2005\n The HA gene of the\nisolate correlated with the following LPAI strains sequences\ndeposited in international databases: A/mallard/NL/3/99(H5N2);\nA/mallard/Sweden/7/02(H5N2); A/mallard/DK/64650/03(H5N7). Therefore it is a completely\ndifferent pathotype than the Asiatic highly pathogenic (HPAI) H5N1\nviruses.\n Sponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nInternational Journal of Infectious Disease\n<http://thelancet.url123.com/a58n7>\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2061-03-25 00:00:00", "2005-11-09 00:00:00", "2005-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Geelong", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "Venezie", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Italy", "country": "Italy"}, {"location": "Mirandola", "country": "Italy"}, {"location": "Iowa", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Padova", "country": "Italy"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "IZSVe", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Legnaro", "country": "Italy"}, {"location": "Ames", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "Japan"}, {"location": "Asiatic", "country": "Brunei"}, {"location": "Germany", "country": "Germany"}, {"location": "Riems", "country": "Germany"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2002", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza - Eurasia (16): Romania (Tulcea), H5N1", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2002", "date": "2005-10-18 23:50:00", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA - EURASIA (16): ROMANIA (TULCEA), H5N1\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSponsored by Elsevier, publisher of\nThe Journal of Hospital Infection\n<http://thelancet.url123.com/a5wh7>\n[1]\nDate: Tue, 18 Oct 2005\nFrom: Mary Marshall <tropical.forestry@btinternet.com>\nSource: Reuters alert news, 18 Oct 2005 [edited]\n<http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/L18297949.htm>\n\nRomania detected new cases of suspected bird flu in the Danube delta,\none of them close to the border with Ukraine, Agriculture Minister\nGheorghe Flutur said on Tuesday [18 Oct 2005].\n'A swan tested positive with (bird flu) antibodies close to the\nborder with Ukraine, near the village of C.A. Rosetti,' Flutur told\nreporters. 'A few swans in Maliuc and a wild duck in Ceamurlia de Jos\nalso tested seropositive.'\nThe village of C.A. Rosetti is 10 km away from the border with\nUkraine, in southeastern Romania. [About 60 km to the east of Maliuc. - Mod.AS]\nOn Monday, 17 Oct 2005, Romania said the bird flu outbreak was\nlimited to Ceamurlia de Jos and Maliuc, 40 km (25 miles) to the\nnorth. All 21 000 domestic birds in these 2 villages have been culled.\nOn Saturday [15 Oct 2005], British tests identified the H5N1 strain\nof the disease in 3 ducks found dead in Ceamurlia de Jos -- the first\nincidence in mainland Europe of H5N1, which has killed more than 60\npeople and millions of birds in Asia since 2003.\nRomania has not reported any cases of bird flu in humans.\nTurkey, which also detected the H5N1 strain in birds, tested 9 people\nfor possible bird flu last week, but no immediate sign of illness was detected.\nGreece was conducting tests on Monday on a turkey with bird flu found\non an Aegean island to establish whether it was infected with the\ndeadly strain. [The island is Chios; in another newswire of 17 Oct\n2005, the disease was reportedly suspected 'in 8 dead birds found in\nthe northeastern Evros river delta', situated on mainland Greece,\nadjacent to the Turkish border; see 20051017.3034. - Mod.AS]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[2]\nDate: 18 Oct 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Nineoclock, Bucharest, issue 3538 page 5, 18 Oct 2005 [edited]\n<http://www.nineoclock.ro/homenews_details.php>\n\nAuthorities have taken supplemental measures to ensure that the bird\nflu will not spread. Foreign experts present in Bucharest these days\nwarned that all efforts must now be focused on preventing the virus\nfrom spreading to other areas than Ceamurlia and Maliuc and in\nparticular from infecting humans.\nThe Emergency Response Committee decided that bird breeding farm\nstaff would be strictly checked. Furthermore, Avicola employees are\nno longer permitted to take birds home; they must sacrifice all birds\nin order to avoid virus spread.\nOfficials for Roche, the producer of Tamiflu, acknowledged as the\nmost effective medicine against bird flu, offered support to Romania\nand Turkey, announcing they will send medicines to these countries.\nExperts with the World Health Organisation (WHO) present in Romania\nto support Romanian authorities in implementing the National Action\nPlan regarding prevention of a flu pandemic stated that for the time\nbeing the virus is present only in birds, not in humans. WHO experts\nonce again urged the population in affected areas to avoid contacts\nwith dead birds. The same appeal was addressed to journalists in the\narea. 'For the time being, the bird flu is only a veterinary\nsituation, and it is important that human health and veterinary\nauthorities work together,' Guenael Rodier, special adviser for\ninfectious disease of the WHO Regional Directorate, pointed out. WHO\nspecialists believe the absence of human infection is encouraging and\ncongratulated authorities for the measures taken so far. 'So far the\nmeasures have been good, and as we work we will adjust them to the\ngiven situation,' the WHO official added.\nIn a week's time authorities will send healthy chickens to Ceamurlia\nand Maliuc to test the presence of the virus after protection\nmeasures are applied. 'We prepare the introduction of a lot of\nhealthy chicken to see if they pick up the virus. If they do, we will\ncarry on measures to prevent the virus spread,' Minister of\nAgriculture Gheorghe Flutur said yesterday. He explained that the\nrisk of a new bird flu focus emergence has not been overcome, as\nthere are still locals who leave their fowl free, and they can get in\ncontact with migrating birds, from which they can pick up the virus.\nFlutur added that migrating birds will also be monitored around the\ncountry, and that traps will be installed to catch them alive. The\nMinister urged the population outside risk areas to avoid travels to\nthe Danube Delta.\nRomania requested a mobile test lab from the USA, to conduct virus\ntests on the birds in the Danube Delta more rapidly. According to the\nAgriculture Minister, talks are underway with officials of the USA\nEmbassy. Tests can be completed in one day with this mobile lab.\nMinister Flutur added that a list of equipment and protection\nmaterials has been drawn up, for the purchase of which Romania will\nrequest support from the USA and EU.\nCharge d'Affaires of the American Embassy Mark Taplin met yesterday\nwith Romanian Minister of Health Eugen Nicolaescu and talked about\nthe current situation regarding avian flu in Romania.\nThe Charge d'Affaires expressed his support for the Government of\nRomania's efforts to date to contain the outbreak of the avian flu\nvirus, along with the readiness of the United States government to\nactively assist Romania in responding to this public health\nchallenge. The 2 agreed that one important priority was raising\npublic awareness of practical steps for avoiding transmission of the\nvirus from birds to humans. [Mr Taplin] offered the help of the U.S.\nAgency for International Development in working with the Government\nof Romania to develop public advisory messages for the population in\nthe affected region.\nSwiss company Roche yesterday announced it will donate Romania 2400\ndoses of Tamiflu, acknowledged for the time being as the most\neffective medicine against bird flu. The doses will be used for\nprotecting employees of veterinary agencies who come in direct\ncontact with infected birds. Turkey will also receive Tamiflu from\nRoche, but in a higher amount - 20 000 doses.\nAlso, Roche announced it will increase the Tamiflu output as soon as\npossible, although it will remain the only producer of the medicine,\nafter having announced last week that it intended to cooperate with\nseveral companies to produce the medicine.\nIn the meantime, in Romania pharmacies sold out their stocks of\nanti-flu vaccines for October-December in 2 weeks only, but promised\nthey will [obtain] further amounts. Not only pharmacies, but also\nvaccine producers sold out their stocks, after distributing many of\nthe anti-virus doses to areas affected by floods this spring and summer.\nIn full crisis of bird flu, the Union of Poultry Breeders of Romania\n(UCPR) has asked for the government's support in [curbing] the likely\nimports [of poultry], yesterday announced Ilie Van, the UCPR\npresident. At the moment, according to the Ministry of Agriculture,\nForest and Rural Development (MAPDR), the imports of poultry meet in\nRomania represent 40 per cent of the urban market. 'In return, our\ncountry exports approx 4000 tons/year, meaning only 2 per cent of the\nlocal production.'\nUCPR, which includes 166 registered poultry farms, has implemented a\nbio-security programme against the bird flu. The programme implies\nthe monitoring and strict control of chickens, starting with the egg\nstage, breeding the poultry in [a system securing] isolation from\npossible contact with other animal or wild birds and vaccinating\ntheir employees.\n[Byline: Alina Grigoras].\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[According to the above and previous reports, obtained from official\nand unofficial sources, the presence of H5N1 seems to have been\nrecorded so far in 4 sites within Tulcea County:\n1. Ceamurlia-de-Jos locality, close to Golovita Lake. Initially,\nvirus isolation from samples taken from 2 hens and a duck in the\nbackyard premises of 2 inhabitants. Additional information in current\nnewswire: a seropositive wild duck;\n2. Maliuc, about 20 km east of the city of Tulcea. Initially, a hen\nand a swan, probably virus isolation. Additional information included\nin the current newswire: a few swans seropositive;\n3. C.A. Rosetti, about 60 km east-north-east of Maliuc, close to the\nUkrainian border. Initial information, included in the current\nnewswire: swan seropositive;\n4. Jurj Vasile (information on its exact location will be\nappreciated). OIE news release of 17 Oct 2005, see 20051017.3036:\nSamples from chickens, analyzed at the OIE Reference Laboratory,\nconfirmed to contain Influenza A subtype H5N1.\nFor a map showing Tulcea county within Romania, see\n<http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/a/a6/Tulcea.png>.\nFor a map of Tulcea county, where the locations of Ceamurlia de Jos,\nMariuc and C.A. Rosetti are visible, see\n<http://www.cormoran.ro/Images/tulcea.jpg>.\nClearly, the virus is present within the Danube Delta region in wild\nbirds (swans, ducks) and domestic fowl (chickens, ducks). Official,\nfirst-hand updates will help in elucidating the picture. - Mod.AS]", "summary": "The programme implies\nthe monitoring and strict control of chickens, starting with the egg\nstage, breeding the poultry in [a system securing] isolation from\npossible contact with other animal or wild birds and vaccinating\ntheir employees.\n A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Source: Reuters alert news, 18 Oct 2005 [edited]\n<http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/L18297949.htm>\n\nRomania detected new cases of suspected bird flu in the Danube delta,\none of them close to the border with Ukraine, Agriculture Minister\nGheorghe Flutur said on Tuesday [18 Oct 2005].
