Charge d'Affaires of the American Embassy Mark Taplin met yesterday\nwith Romanian Minister of Health Eugen Nicolaescu and talked about\nthe current situation regarding avian flu in Romania. The doses will be used for\nprotecting employees of veterinary agencies who come in direct\ncontact with infected birds. Additional information in current\nnewswire: a seropositive wild duck;\n2. If they do, we will\ncarry on measures to prevent the virus spread,' Minister of\nAgriculture Gheorghe Flutur said yesterday.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-29 00:00:00", "2021-03-30 00:00:00", "2003-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-27 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Bucharest", "country": "Romania"}, {"location": "Ukraine", "country": "Ukraine"}, {"location": "Ceamurlia", "country": "Romania"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "EU", "country": "France"}, {"location": "Turkey", "country": "Turkey"}, {"location": "Tulcea", "country": "Romania"}, {"location": "Tulcea county", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Maliuc", "country": "Romania"}, {"location": "Romania", "country": "Romania"}, {"location": "Tulcea County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Greece", "country": "Greece"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1494", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza - Eurasia (15): Romania, H5N1 conf., OIE", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1494", "date": "2005-10-17 23:50:00", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA - EURASIA (15): ROMANIA, H5N1 CONFIRMED, OIE\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nTropical Infectious Diseases, 2nd edition\n<http://thelancet.url123.com/a5445>\nDate: 17 Oct 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: OIE Press Release [edited]\n<http://www.oie.int/fr/press/fr_051017.htm>\n\nH5N1 virus confirmed in Romania\n---------------------------------------\nSamples from chickens collected in Jurj Vasile (Romania) and analyzed at\nthe OIE Reference Laboratory for Avian Influenza, Weybridge, UK have been\nconfirmed to contain Influenza A subtype H5N1.\n\nAs already expected by the OIE on Thursday (see OIE press release 13 Oct\n2005 <http://www.oie.int/eng/press/en_051013.htm>), the analyses carried\nout show a direct relationship with the avian influenza viruses detected\nrecently in central Asia and Turkey.\nA 2nd Romanian outbreak has been reported to the OIE. It is located in\nMaliuc County, 60 km from the 1st one reported in Ceamurlia-de-Josle.\nWith regard to Turkey, more information is currently being requested from\nthe Turkish authorities concerning a 2nd possible outbreak at the border\nwith Iran.\nThe active role of migratory birds carrying the Asian H5N1 influenza virus\nunder certain conditions to other parts of the world seems now to be more\nlikely.\nFollowing the situation very closely, the OIE again gives a reminder of the\nimportance of eliminating the virus at the animal source, emphasizing the\nneed for early detection and rapid response mechanisms carried out by\nVeterinary Services in countries at risk.\nIt is urgent to take the relevant measures to tackle avian influenza at its\nanimal source in order to prevent a possible human pandemic. Indeed, the\npossibility of a human pandemic is directly linked to the quantity of the\nH5N1 virus circulating among animals worldwide.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[For a map of the 2nd outbreak area, see\n<http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/a/a6/Tulcea.png>.\nIn the last few days, we have confirmed evidence of H5N1 in 2 countries,\nTurkey and Romania. There appear to be unconfirmed indications of a 2nd\nfoci in each of these countries. Moreover, there is some information in\nthis OIE report that indicates that the 2nd outbreak in Turkey is close to\nthe border with Iran. Thus, the possibility is raised that the wild bird\ndie off in Iran will turn out to be due to H5N1 avian influenza because of\nthe close geographic location and proximity in timing. Finally, there\nappear to be reports of avian influenza in Greece.\nThis flurry of reports should be treated with caution because of the\npossibilities of over reaction and speculation that accompany any\nunconfirmed report. However, the OIE confirmation is from World Reference\nLaboratories, and we can rely on these. Put all this together, and it is\nclear that something is happening in the swath of land surrounding the\nCaspian and Black Seas. Today's OIE press release certainly speculates that\nthe migratory birds are a suspected means of spread.\nAs difficult as it is to deal with, we have to face the possibility of\navian influenza establishing a new major foci of infection in large parts\nof Central Asia and Eurasia. Will we have the political will and resources\nto control and eradicate these new incursions of the virus? Such was\nclearly lacking in Southeast Asia, or we wouldn't be in this situation.\nUnfortunately, if the scenario in Eurasia keeps developing, we will soon\ncome to another question: can we stamp H5N1 out, or do we 'learn to live\nwith it,' again? 'Learning to live with it' appears not to have worked too\nwell the 1st time around, and it is always better to stamp out a small foci\nof disease rather than control or eradicate a well-established one. - Mod.PC]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n \n\nAs already expected by the OIE on Thursday (see OIE press release 13 Oct\n2005 <http://www.oie.int/eng/press/en_051013.htm>), the analyses carried\nout show a direct relationship with the avian influenza viruses detected\nrecently in central Asia and Turkey. Following the situation very closely, the OIE again gives a reminder of the\nimportance of eliminating the virus at the animal source, emphasizing the\nneed for early detection and rapid response mechanisms carried out by\nVeterinary Services in countries at risk. Sponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nTropical Infectious Diseases, 2nd edition\n<http://thelancet.url123.com/a5445>\n \nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n As difficult as it is to deal with, we have to face the possibility of\navian influenza establishing a new major foci of infection in large parts\nof Central Asia and Eurasia. Samples from chickens collected in Jurj Vasile (Romania) and analyzed at\nthe OIE Reference Laboratory for Avian Influenza, Weybridge, UK have been\nconfirmed to contain Influenza A subtype H5N1. Thus, the possibility is raised that the wild bird\ndie off in Iran will turn out to be due to H5N1 avian influenza because of\nthe close geographic location and proximity in timing. The active role of migratory birds carrying the Asian H5N1 influenza virus\nunder certain conditions to other parts of the world seems now to be more\nlikely. With regard to Turkey, more information is currently being requested from\nthe Turkish authorities concerning a 2nd possible outbreak at the border\nwith Iran. Moreover, there is some information in\nthis OIE report that indicates that the 2nd outbreak in Turkey is close to\nthe border with Iran. Source: OIE Press Release [edited]\n<http://www.oie.int/fr/press/fr_051017.htm>\n\nH5N1 virus confirmed in Romania\n Indeed, the\npossibility of a human pandemic is directly linked to the quantity of the\nH5N1 virus circulating among animals worldwide. AVIAN INFLUENZA - EURASIA (15): ROMANIA, H5N1 CONFIRMED, OIE\n***********************************************\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Eurasia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Turkey", "country": "Turkey"}, {"location": "Maliuc County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Iran", "country": "Iran"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Jurj Vasile", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Greece", "country": "Greece"}, {"location": "Romania", "country": "Romania"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1968", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza - Eurasia (15): Romania, H5N1 conf., OIE", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1968", "date": "2005-10-17 23:50:00", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA - EURASIA (15): ROMANIA, H5N1 CONFIRMED, OIE\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nTropical Infectious Diseases, 2nd edition\n<http://thelancet.url123.com/a5445>\nDate: 17 Oct 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: OIE Press Release [edited]\n<http://www.oie.int/fr/press/fr_051017.htm>\n\nH5N1 virus confirmed in Romania\n---------------------------------------\nSamples from chickens collected in Jurj Vasile (Romania) and analyzed at\nthe OIE Reference Laboratory for Avian Influenza, Weybridge, UK have been\nconfirmed to contain Influenza A subtype H5N1.\n\nAs already expected by the OIE on Thursday (see OIE press release 13 Oct\n2005 <http://www.oie.int/eng/press/en_051013.htm>), the analyses carried\nout show a direct relationship with the avian influenza viruses detected\nrecently in central Asia and Turkey.\nA 2nd Romanian outbreak has been reported to the OIE. It is located in\nMaliuc County, 60 km from the 1st one reported in Ceamurlia-de-Josle.\nWith regard to Turkey, more information is currently being requested from\nthe Turkish authorities concerning a 2nd possible outbreak at the border\nwith Iran.\nThe active role of migratory birds carrying the Asian H5N1 influenza virus\nunder certain conditions to other parts of the world seems now to be more\nlikely.\nFollowing the situation very closely, the OIE again gives a reminder of the\nimportance of eliminating the virus at the animal source, emphasizing the\nneed for early detection and rapid response mechanisms carried out by\nVeterinary Services in countries at risk.\nIt is urgent to take the relevant measures to tackle avian influenza at its\nanimal source in order to prevent a possible human pandemic. Indeed, the\npossibility of a human pandemic is directly linked to the quantity of the\nH5N1 virus circulating among animals worldwide.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[For a map of the 2nd outbreak area, see\n<http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/a/a6/Tulcea.png>.\nIn the last few days, we have confirmed evidence of H5N1 in 2 countries,\nTurkey and Romania. There appear to be unconfirmed indications of a 2nd\nfoci in each of these countries. Moreover, there is some information in\nthis OIE report that indicates that the 2nd outbreak in Turkey is close to\nthe border with Iran. Thus, the possibility is raised that the wild bird\ndie off in Iran will turn out to be due to H5N1 avian influenza because of\nthe close geographic location and proximity in timing. Finally, there\nappear to be reports of avian influenza in Greece.\nThis flurry of reports should be treated with caution because of the\npossibilities of over reaction and speculation that accompany any\nunconfirmed report. However, the OIE confirmation is from World Reference\nLaboratories, and we can rely on these. Put all this together, and it is\nclear that something is happening in the swath of land surrounding the\nCaspian and Black Seas. Today's OIE press release certainly speculates that\nthe migratory birds are a suspected means of spread.\nAs difficult as it is to deal with, we have to face the possibility of\navian influenza establishing a new major foci of infection in large parts\nof Central Asia and Eurasia. Will we have the political will and resources\nto control and eradicate these new incursions of the virus? Such was\nclearly lacking in Southeast Asia, or we wouldn't be in this situation.\nUnfortunately, if the scenario in Eurasia keeps developing, we will soon\ncome to another question: can we stamp H5N1 out, or do we 'learn to live\nwith it,' again? 'Learning to live with it' appears not to have worked too\nwell the 1st time around, and it is always better to stamp out a small foci\nof disease rather than control or eradicate a well-established one. - Mod.PC]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n \n\nAs already expected by the OIE on Thursday (see OIE press release 13 Oct\n2005 <http://www.oie.int/eng/press/en_051013.htm>), the analyses carried\nout show a direct relationship with the avian influenza viruses detected\nrecently in central Asia and Turkey. Following the situation very closely, the OIE again gives a reminder of the\nimportance of eliminating the virus at the animal source, emphasizing the\nneed for early detection and rapid response mechanisms carried out by\nVeterinary Services in countries at risk. Sponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nTropical Infectious Diseases, 2nd edition\n<http://thelancet.url123.com/a5445>\n \nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n As difficult as it is to deal with, we have to face the possibility of\navian influenza establishing a new major foci of infection in large parts\nof Central Asia and Eurasia. Samples from chickens collected in Jurj Vasile (Romania) and analyzed at\nthe OIE Reference Laboratory for Avian Influenza, Weybridge, UK have been\nconfirmed to contain Influenza A subtype H5N1. Thus, the possibility is raised that the wild bird\ndie off in Iran will turn out to be due to H5N1 avian influenza because of\nthe close geographic location and proximity in timing. The active role of migratory birds carrying the Asian H5N1 influenza virus\nunder certain conditions to other parts of the world seems now to be more\nlikely. With regard to Turkey, more information is currently being requested from\nthe Turkish authorities concerning a 2nd possible outbreak at the border\nwith Iran. Moreover, there is some information in\nthis OIE report that indicates that the 2nd outbreak in Turkey is close to\nthe border with Iran. Source: OIE Press Release [edited]\n<http://www.oie.int/fr/press/fr_051017.htm>\n\nH5N1 virus confirmed in Romania\n Indeed, the\npossibility of a human pandemic is directly linked to the quantity of the\nH5N1 virus circulating among animals worldwide. AVIAN INFLUENZA - EURASIA (15): ROMANIA, H5N1 CONFIRMED, OIE\n***********************************************\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Iran", "country": "Iran"}, {"location": "Romania", "country": "Romania"}, {"location": "Greece", "country": "Greece"}, {"location": "Jurj Vasile", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Maliuc County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Eurasia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Turkey", "country": "Turkey"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1546", "headline": "PRO/AH> Avian influenza - Eurasia (41): WHO H5N1 timeline", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1546", "date": "2005-10-29 23:50:00", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA - EURASIA (41): WHO H5N1 TIMELINE\n*******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nAntiviral Research\n<http://thelancet.url123.com/xrd85>\nDate: Sat, 29 Oct 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: WHO EPR web-site, Avian influenza, accessed 29 Oct 2005 [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/disease/avian_influenza/Timeline_28_10a.pdf>\n\n[The following chronological list, summarising the main events since the\nbeginning of the current H5N1 panzootic as well as relevant research, is\ncopied -- with some editorial modifications -- from the WHO influenza home\npage. Only the animal-health related column is presented here; however,\nresearch from the public-health column is included as well. - Mod.AS]\nH5N1 influenza time-line: 28 Oct 2005\n-------------------------------------\n1.1996 Highly pathogenic H5N1 virus is isolated from a farmed goose in\nGuangdong Province, China.\n2. 1997 Outbreaks of highly pathogenic H5N1 are reported in poultry at\nfarms and wet markets in Hong Kong.\n3. Mid-2003: H5N1 virus begins to cause outbreaks in Asia, but these go\nundetected and unreported.\n4. Dec 2003: 2 tigers and 2 leopards, fed on fresh chicken carcasses, die\nunexpectedly at a zoo in Thailand. Subsequent investigation identifies H5N1\nin tissue samples. This is the 1st report of influenza causing disease and\ndeath in big cats.\n5. 19 Dec 2003: Republic of Korea confirms highly pathogenic H5N1 as cause\nof poultry deaths at 3 farms.\n6. 8 Jan 2004: Viet Nam reports H5N1 in poultry.\n7. 12 Jan 2004: Japan reports H5N1 in poultry.\n8. 23 Jan 2004: Thailand reports H5N1 in poultry.\n9. 24 Jan 2004: Cambodia reports H5N1 in poultry.\n10. 27 Jan 2004: Lao PDR reports H5N1 in poultry.\n11. 2 Feb 2004: Indonesia reports H5N1 in poultry.\n12. 4 Feb 2004: China reports H5N1 in poultry.\n13. 20 Feb 2004: Anecdotal evidences suggests H5N1 infection in a single\nhousehold of domestic cats in Thailand.\n14. 18 Mar 2004: Research (1) case studies of 10 patients in Viet Nam point\nto close contact with infected poultry as the probable source of infection\nin most cases, but conclude that, in 2 family clusters, limited\nhuman-to-human transmission within the family cannot be ruled out.\n15. Jun./Jul 2004: China, Indonesia, Thailand and Viet Nam report\nrecurrence of H5N1 in poultry.\n16. 8 Jul 2004: Research (2) identifies the dominant Z genotype in poultry,\nconsiders possible role of wild birds in spread, and concludes that H5N1\nhas found a new ecological niche in poultry, but is not yet fully adapted\nto this host.\n17. 13 Jul 2004: Research (3) shows that H5N1 has become progressively more\nlethal for mammals and can kill wild waterfowl, long considered a\ndisease-free natural reservoir. Japan announces control of the H5N1 poultry\noutbreak and is considered disease-free by OIE.\n18. Jul 2004: Research (4).A case report is published indicating atypical\nhuman H5N1 infection in Thailand (from Mar 04), with fever and diarrhoea\nbut no respiratory symptoms. The report suggests that the clinical spectrum\nof disease may be broader than previously thought.\n19. 7 Aug 2004: Malaysia reports H5N1 in poultry.\n20. 20 Aug 2004: Research (5). Chinese researchers report preliminary\nfindings of H5N1 infection in pigs. No evidence suggests that pig\ninfections are widespread, and the finding appears to have limited\nepidemiological significance.\n21. 2 Sep 2004: Research (6) shows that domestic cats experimentally\ninfected with H5N1 develop severe disease and can spread infection to other\ncats. Prior to this research, domestic cats were considered resistant to\ndisease from all influenza A viruses.\n22. 21 Sep 2004: Republic of Korea announces control of the H5N1 poultry\noutbreak and is considered disease-free by OIE.\n23. 11 Oct 2004: Outbreak begins in zoo tigers in Thailand said to have\nbeen fed chicken carcasses. Altogether, 147 tigers out of a population of\n441 die or are euthanized.\n24. 22 Oct 2004: Highly pathogenic H5N1 is confirmed in 2 eagles illegally\nimported into Europe (Brussels) from Thailand.\n25. 29 Oct 2004: Research (7) confirms that domestic ducks can act as\nsilent reservoirs,\nexcreting large quantities of highly pathogenic virus yet showing few if\nany signs of illness.\n26. December 2004: Poultry outbreaks ongoing in Indonesia, Thailand, and\nVietnam and possibly also in Cambodia and Lao PDR.\n27. 3 Jan 2005: Malaysia (Peninsular) announces control of the H5N1 poultry\noutbreak and is now considered disease-free by OIE.\n28. 27 Jan 2005: Research (8) concludes that a girl in Thailand probably\npassed the virus to at least her mother in September 2004, causing fatal\ndisease. This is the 1st published account of probable secondary human\ntransmission, resulting in severe disease, of any avian influenza virus.\n29. 17 Feb 2005: Research (9) retrospectively identifies at least one fatal\natypical case in\nViet Nam (from February 2004), presenting with diarrhoea and encephalitis,\nbut normal chest X-rays.\n30. 30 April 2005: Wild birds begin dying at Qinghai Lake in central China,\nwhere hundreds of thousands of migratory birds congregate. Altogether, 6345\nbirds from different species die in the coming weeks.\n31. 8 June 2005: China reports poultry outbreak in Xinjiang Autonomous Region.\n32. 6 Jul 2005: Research (10) on viruses isolated from dead birds in\nQinghai Lake suggests the outbreak was caused by a new H5N1 variant that\nmay be more lethal to wild birds and experimentally infected mice.\n33. 14 Jul 2005: Research (11) on viruses isolated from dead birds in\nQinghai Lake demonstrates transmission of the virus among migratory geese\nand suggests that the virus may be carried along winter migratory routes.\n34. 15 Jul 2005: Tests on 3 civets that died in late June in Viet Nam\ndetect H5N1, marking the 1st infection of this species with the virus. The\nendangered Owston's palm civets were raised in captivity; source of\ninfection is unknown.\n35. 23 Jul 2005: Russia reports outbreaks of highly pathogenic avian\ninfluenza, subsequently confirmed as H5N1, in poultry in western Siberia.\nThe outbreak spreads to affect 6 administrative regions in Siberia. Dead\nmigratory birds are reported in the vicinity of outbreaks.\n36. 2 Aug 2005: Kazakhstan reports an outbreak of highly pathogenic avian\ninfluenza, subsequently confirmed as H5N1, in poultry in areas adjacent to\nSiberia. Dead migratory birds are reported in the vicinity of outbreaks.\n37. 10 Aug 2005: China reports outbreak in Tibet Autonomous Region.\n38. 12 Aug 2005: Mongolia reports the death of 89 migratory birds at 2\nlakes. H5N1 is subsequently identified in these birds.\n39. 29 Sep 2005: Research (12) describes the clinical features of H5N1\ninfection in humans and reviews recommendations for the management of cases.\n40. October 2005: Research (13) on the evolution of human and animal\nviruses circulating in Asia in 2005 suggests that several amino acids\nlocated near the receptor-binding site are undergoing change, some of which\nmay affect antigenicity or transmissibility.\n41. 6 Oct 2005: Research (14, 15) describes reconstruction of the lethal\n1918 pandemic virus, concludes that this virus was entirely avian, and\nfinds some similarities with H5N1.\n42. 13 Oct 2005: Highly pathogenic H5N1 is confirmed in poultry in Turkey.\n43. 15 Oct 2005: Highly pathogenic H5N1 is confirmed in poultry in Romania.\n44. 20 Oct 05: Taiwan, China, reports the detection of highly pathogenic\nH5N1 in a cargo of exotic songbirds smuggled from mainland China. Thailand\nreports its 1st new case since 8 Oct 2004.\n45. 23 Oct 2005: Highly pathogenic H5N1 is confirmed in an imported parrot,\nheld in quarantine in the UK, that died 3 days earlier.\n46. 24 Oct 2005: China reports outbreak in Anhui Province. Thailand and\nIndonesia report more cases.\n47. 26 Oct 2005: China reports outbreak in Hunan, making this the 6th\nprovince reporting outbreaks during 2005. Croatia confirms H5N1 in wild birds.\nReferences\n----------\n1 Hien TT et al. Avian influenza A (H5N1) in 10 patients in Vietnam. N Engl\nJ Med 2004; 350:1179-88.\n2 Li KS et al. Genesis of a highly pathogenic and potentially pandemic\ninfluenza virus in eastern Asia. Nature 2004; 430: 209-213.\n3 Chen H et al. The evolution of H5N1 influenza viruses in ducks in\nsouthern China. Proc Natl Acad Sci USA 2004; 101: 10452-57.\n4 Apisarnthanarak A et al. Atypical avian influenza (H5N1). Emerg Infect\nDis 2004; 10: 1321-24.\n5 Verbal report at WHO international consultation.\n6 Kuiken T et al. Avian H5N1 influenza in cats. Published online by Science:\n<http://www.sciencemag.org/cgi/content/abstract/1102287>\n7 Issued (prior to publication) on WHO website: Avian influenza - situation\nin Asia: altered role of domestic ducks, 29 Oct 2004; available online at:\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2004_10_29/en/index.html>\n8 Ungchusak K et al. Probable person-to-person transmission of avian\ninfluenza A (H5N1). N Engl J Med 2005; 352:4 333-40.\n9 De Jong M et al. Fatal avian influenza A (H5N1) in a child presenting\nwith diarrhea followed by coma. N Engl J Med 2005; 352:7 686-91.\n10 Liu J et al. Highly pathogenic H5N1 influenza virus infection in\nmigratory birds. Science 2005. Published by Science online at:\n<http://www.sciencemag.org/cgi/contents/abstract/1115273>.\n11 Chen H et al. H5N1 virus outbreak in migratory waterfowl. Nature 2005;\n436: 191-92.\n12 Writing Committee of the World Health Organization (WHO) Consultation on\nHuman Influenza A/H5. N Engl J Med 2005; 353:13 54-65.\n13 World Health Organization Global Influenza Program Surveillance Network.\nEmerg Infect Dis 2005; 11: 1515-21.\n14 Taubenberger JK et al. Characterization of the 1918 influenza virus\npolymerase genes. Nature 2005; 437: 889-93.\n15 Tumpey et al. Characterization of the reconstructed 1918 Spanish\ninfluenza pandemic virus. Science 2005; 310: 77-80.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>", "summary": "Published online by Science:\n<http://www.sciencemag.org/cgi/content/abstract/1102287>\n7 Issued (prior to publication) on WHO website: Avian influenza - situation\nin Asia: altered role of domestic ducks, 29 Oct 2004; available online at:\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2004_10_29/en/index.html>\n8 Ungchusak K et al. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/disease/avian_influenza/Timeline_28_10a.pdf>\n\n[The following chronological list, summarising the main events since the\nbeginning of the current H5N1 panzootic as well as relevant research, is\ncopied -- with some editorial modifications -- from the WHO influenza home\npage. 8 Jul 2004: Research (2) identifies the dominant Z genotype in poultry,\nconsiders possible role of wild birds in spread, and concludes that H5N1\nhas found a new ecological niche in poultry, but is not yet fully adapted\nto this host. 18 Mar 2004: Research (1) case studies of 10 patients in Viet Nam point\nto close contact with infected poultry as the probable source of infection\nin most cases, but conclude that, in 2 family clusters, limited\nhuman-to-human transmission within the family cannot be ruled out. October 2005: Research (13) on the evolution of human and animal\nviruses circulating in Asia in 2005 suggests that several amino acids\nlocated near the receptor-binding site are undergoing change, some of which\nmay affect antigenicity or transmissibility. 29 Oct 2004: Research (7) confirms that domestic ducks can act as\nsilent reservoirs,\nexcreting large quantities of highly pathogenic virus yet showing few if\nany signs of illness. 17 Feb 2005: Research (9) retrospectively identifies at least one fatal\natypical case in\nViet Nam (from February 2004), presenting with diarrhoea and encephalitis,\nbut normal chest X-rays. Sponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nAntiviral Research\n<http://thelancet.url123.com/xrd85>\n 2 Aug 2005: Kazakhstan reports an outbreak of highly pathogenic avian\ninfluenza, subsequently confirmed as H5N1, in poultry in areas adjacent to\nSiberia. 14 Jul 2005: Research (11) on viruses isolated from dead birds in\nQinghai Lake demonstrates transmission of the virus among migratory geese\nand suggests that the virus may be carried along winter migratory routes. 6 Jul 2005: Research (10) on viruses isolated from dead birds in\nQinghai Lake suggests the outbreak was caused by a new H5N1 variant that\nmay be more lethal to wild birds and experimentally infected mice. 6 Oct 2005: Research (14, 15) describes reconstruction of the lethal\n1918 pandemic virus, concludes that this virus was entirely avian, and\nfinds some similarities with H5N1. 27 Jan 2005: Research (8) concludes that a girl in Thailand probably\npassed the virus to at least her mother in September 2004, causing fatal\ndisease. 2 Sep 2004: Research (6) shows that domestic cats experimentally\ninfected with H5N1 develop severe disease and can spread infection to other\ncats. Jul 2004: Research (3) shows that H5N1 has become progressively more\nlethal for mammals and can kill wild waterfowl, long considered a\ndisease-free natural reservoir. AVIAN INFLUENZA - EURASIA (41): WHO H5N1 TIMELINE\n*******************************\n References\n----------\n1 Hien TT et al. The\nendangered Owston's palm civets were raised in captivity; source of\ninfection is unknown. No evidence suggests that pig\ninfections are widespread, and the finding appears to have limited\nepidemiological significance. --\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org> 23 Jul 2005: Russia reports outbreaks of highly pathogenic avian\ninfluenza, subsequently confirmed as H5N1, in poultry in western Siberia. 26 Oct 2005: China reports outbreak in Hunan, making this the 6th\nprovince reporting outbreaks during 2005. 3 Jan 2005: Malaysia (Peninsular) announces control of the H5N1 poultry\noutbreak and is now considered disease-free by OIE. 12 Aug 2005: Mongolia reports the death of 89 migratory birds at 2\nlakes. 21 Sep 2004: Republic of Korea announces control of the H5N1 poultry\noutbreak and is considered disease-free by OIE. Highly pathogenic H5N1 influenza virus infection in\nmigratory birds. 15 Jul 2005: Tests on 3 civets that died in late June in Viet Nam\ndetect H5N1, marking the 1st infection of this species with the virus. 23 Oct 2005: Highly pathogenic H5N1 is confirmed in an imported parrot,\nheld in quarantine in the UK, that died 3 days earlier. This is the 1st published account of probable secondary human\ntransmission, resulting in severe disease, of any avian influenza virus. 22 Oct 2004: Highly pathogenic H5N1 is confirmed in 2 eagles illegally\nimported into Europe (Brussels) from Thailand. 29 Sep 2005: Research (12) describes the clinical features of H5N1\ninfection in humans and reviews recommendations for the management of cases. Thailand\nreports its 1st new case since 8 Oct 2004. Dec 2003: Republic of Korea confirms highly pathogenic H5N1 as cause\nof poultry deaths at 3 farms. Jun./Jul 2004: China, Indonesia, Thailand and Viet Nam report\nrecurrence of H5N1 in poultry. 11 Oct 2004: Outbreak begins in zoo tigers in Thailand said to have\nbeen fed chicken carcasses. Genesis of a highly pathogenic and potentially pandemic\ninfluenza virus in eastern Asia. Japan announces control of the H5N1 poultry\noutbreak and is considered disease-free by OIE. 1997 Outbreaks of highly pathogenic H5N1 are reported in poultry at\nfarms and wet markets in Hong Kong. Prior to this research, domestic cats were considered resistant to\ndisease from all influenza A viruses. This is the 1st report of influenza causing disease and\ndeath in big cats. 20 Oct 05: Taiwan, China, reports the detection of highly pathogenic\nH5N1 in a cargo of exotic songbirds smuggled from mainland China. Wild birds begin dying at Qinghai Lake in central China,\nwhere hundreds of thousands of migratory birds congregate. Dec 2003: 2 tigers and 2 leopards, fed on fresh chicken carcasses, die\nunexpectedly at a zoo in Thailand. Characterization of the reconstructed 1918 Spanish\ninfluenza pandemic virus. Date: Sat, 29 Oct 2005\n Characterization of the 1918 influenza virus\npolymerase genes. Probable person-to-person transmission of avian\ninfluenza Science 2005; 310: 77-80.\n Nature 2005;\n436: 191-92. Dead\nmigratory birds are reported in the vicinity of outbreaks. N Engl\nJ Med 2004; 350:1179-88. Poultry outbreaks ongoing in Indonesia, Thailand, and\nVietnam and possibly also in Cambodia and Lao PDR. The evolution of H5N1 influenza viruses in ducks in\nsouthern China. Anecdotal evidences suggests H5N1 infection in a single\nhousehold of domestic cats in Thailand. The report suggests that the clinical spectrum\nof disease may be broader than previously thought. \n6 Kuiken T et al. Mid-2003: H5N1 virus begins to cause outbreaks in Asia, but these go\nundetected and unreported. \n13 World Health Organization Global Influenza Program Surveillance Network. \n15 Tumpey et al. \n9 De Jong M et al. Consultation on\nHuman Influenza A/H5. Altogether, 6345\nbirds from different species die in the coming weeks. Chinese researchers report preliminary\nfindings of H5N1 infection in pigs. Only the animal-health related column is presented here; however,\nresearch from the public-health column is included as well. - Mod.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other"], "syndromes": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza - Eurasia (17): H5N1", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2154", "date": "2005-10-18 23:50:00", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA - EURASIA (17): H5N1\n*************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nTropical Infectious Diseases, 2nd edition\n<http://thelancet.url123.com/a5445>\n[1]\nDate: Tue 18 Oct 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Reuters alertnet, 18 Oct 2005 [edited]\n<http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/L18703250.htm>\n\nScientists say bird flu cases back migration theory\n-----------------------------------------------\nThe discovery of bird flu in Romania and Turkey supports the theory\nthe deadly virus is being spread by migrating wildfowl, scientists\nsaid on Tuesday [18 Oct 2005].\nEver since the discovery in July 2005 that H5N1 bird flu, which has\nkilled more than 60 people in Asia, had spread to birds in Siberia,\nexperts have feared that migratory wildfowl would bring the virus westwards.\n'These latest cases in Romania and Turkey have reinforced that\ntheory,' Alex Thiermann, President of the International Animal Health\nCode at the World Organization for Animal Health (OIE) in Paris, told Reuters.\nH5N1 is particularly deadly for chickens and can wipe out a flock\nwithin hours. But wild water-birds such as ducks and geese can harbor\nthe virus for long periods, most of the time showing no symptoms or\nbecoming ill.\nWhilst any bird can in theory become infected, wildfowl are the\nprimary carriers, and many species fly south from Siberia seeking\nwarmer climes at the onset of winter, scientists say.\n'The existence of known migration flyways of several birds species\nconnecting South East Asia, Siberia and Europe shows a possibility of\nthe introduction of the H5N1 virus to both eastern and western\nEurope,' the OIE said this week in a report on the outbreak in Russia.\nIt said surveillance should be increased in the Caspian Sea region,\nwhich was recognized as 'a significant wintering area for water birds\nof various origins (Europe and western Asia) and can be considered as\na so-called biological 'hub'.'\nWhat scares experts most is that the virus could mutate and pass\neasily between humans, possibly sparking a pandemic to rival the\nkiller global flu outbreaks of the last century.\nThe spread of bird flu in parts of Asia and earlier this year [2005]\nfrom Russia to Kazakhstan has also been linked to cross-border trade\nin live poultry, either legal or illegal.\nThiermann said the widespread practice of cock-fighting in Asia,\nwhere it was big business, may have played a role there.\nBut trade was an unlikely source of the latest cases.\n'The role of migratory birds carrying the Asian H5N1 influenza virus\nunder certain conditions to other parts of the world seems now more\nlikely,' the OIE said after the latest test results from Romania and Turkey.\nThe OIE and U.N. Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) have\npinpointed the Caspian and Black Sea regions, as well as the Balkans,\nas a 'gateway to central Europe for the virus.'\nBird migration routes also ran across Azerbaijan, Iran, Iraq,\nGeorgia, Ukraine and some Mediterranean countries to Africa, where\noutbreaks were possible.\nDidier Houssin, the French government official in charge of the\ncountry's bird flu defense, told Le Monde newspaper that migrating\nbirds were the most likely source of transmission, using flyways\nbetween the Black Sea region and Mediterranean.\n'This axis raises fears that pockets will emerge in the Middle East\nand then in Africa. It then becomes a very serious threat. One can\nimagine the virus becoming endemic in Africa as it is in several\nAsian countries,' Houssin said.\n'We'd be confronted with great difficulties in controlling the\ndisease, and, in a few months, with the threat of potentially\ninfected birds flying back up to western Europe from Africa.'\n[Byline: David Evans]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Pablo Nart has kindly drawn our attention to a recent map of bird\nmigratory routes and countries where avian influenza has been reported:\n<http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/4348404.stm#map>.\nFurther reading:\n1. Zdenek Hubalek. An annotated checklist of pathogenic\nmicroorganisms associated with migratory birds. J Wildlife diseases\n2004; 40: 639-659.\n2. FAO's (special report): Potential risk of Highly Pathogenic Avian\nInfluenza (HPAI) spreading through wild water bird migration, 1 Sep 2005,\n<http://www.fao.org/ag/againfo/subjects/documents/ai/AVIbull033.pdf>.\n- Mod.AS]\n******\n[2]\nDate: Tue 18 Oct 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: European Commission website, 18 Oct 2005 [edited]\n<http://europa.eu.int/comm/food/animal/diseases/controlmeasures/avian/ai_romania_chrono_18-10-2005.pdf>\n\nAvian influenza - response to outbreaks in 2005, Romania/Turkey:\nChronology of main events, updated 18 Oct 2005\n-----------------------------------------------\nThe following data, compiled from the above document, might help in\nreviewing the recent events around the Black Sea in an orderly manner.\nFri 7 Oct 2005: The Romanian authorities notify to the Commission and\nto the OIE an outbreak of avian influenza on their territory\n(positive serology).\nSat 8 Oct 2005: The Turkish authorities notify to the Commission and\nto the OIE an outbreak of avian influenza on their territory. The\nvirus has been identified as an influenza virus type A, strain H5.\nSun 9 Oct 2005: An EU expert mission is dispatched to Romania to\nassist the authorities in the control of the outbreak of avian\ninfluenza. The team consists of 3 experts. They will arrive in\nRomania on Mon 10 Oct 2005 and will bring with them all necessary\nlaboratory reagents requested by the Romanian authorities.\nMon 10 Oct 2005: The Commission adopts an urgent safeguard Decision\nfor Turkey, suspending imports of birds and products for which Turkey\nis authorized (birds other than poultry and untreated feathers) and\nwhich present a direct threat to animal health in Europe.\nTue 11 Oct 2005: The Commission informs the European Parliament's\nAGRI Committee about the outbreaks in Romania and Turkey.\nWed 12 Oct 2005: A Decision is put for a vote to the Committee to\nprolong the measures adopted on Monday for Turkey for a further 6\nmonths. The proposal was adopted by the Committee.\nThu 13 Oct 2005: The Commission expert experts team in Romania has\nfound avian influenza virus type H5 in 2 samples from a chicken and a\nduck (laboratory results with reagents of AI CRL, Community Reference\nLaboratory for avian influenza in Weybridge, UK).\nThe strain of bird flu found in Turkey has been identified as the\nhighly pathogenic H5N1 Asia strain by the AI CRL.\nThe same measures that have been adopted for Turkey are now proposed\nby the Commission for Romania. The Committee is asked to vote on a\ndraft proposal suspending all imports of avian species and their\nproducts from Romania. The draft safeguard Decision endorsed by the\nCommittee is adopted by the Commission the same afternoon.\nFri 14 Oct 2005: Romania informs the Commission of a 2nd outbreak in\ndomestic poultry and the fact that the AI virus H5 has also been\nidentified in swans found dead in the Danube delta.\nSat 15 Oct 2005: The AI CRL at Weybridge, UK confirms that the virus\nin Romania is the highly pathogenic H5N1 Asia strain.\nSun 16 Oct 2005: An EU expert mission is dispatched to Turkey to\nassist the authorities with the control of the outbreak of avian\ninfluenza. The team will consist of Dr. E. Stougaard (former CVO\nDenmark) and Dr. P. Houdart (Belgian Federal Food-chain safety Agency).\nA team of experts is also dispatched to Bulgaria to see with the\nauthorities how best to prepare for possible introduction in Bulgaria\nof the virus. The team will consist of Dr. G. Cattoli (Istituto\nZooprofilattico Sperimentale, Italy) and Dr. C. Poetzsch (Institute\nof Epidemiology, Germany).\nMon 17 Oct 2005: The Commission is made aware of AI suspicion in a\nturkey on the island of Innusis (Chios nomos), Greece.\nTue 18 Oct 2005: UK Presidency request AI is considered as part of an\nExtraordinary General Affairs Council (GAERC) meeting, Luxembourg.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[3]\nDate: Tue 18 Oct 2005\nFrom: A-Lan Banks <A-Lan.Banks@thomson.com>\nSource: Xinhuannet, China, 18 Oct 2005 [edited]\n<http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2005-10/18/content_3640529.htm>\n\nViet Nam reports new bird flu outbreak\n---------------------------------------------\nViet Nam has just seen the death of some 110 ducks in southern Bac\nLieu province, a local official told Xinhua on Tuesday [18 Oct 2005].\n'According to tests by the Regional Veterinary Center in Can Tho\ncity, the fowl were infected with a bird flu virus strain,' said\nNguyen Phuc Tai, director of the Provincial Veterinary Department.\nThe 110 out of over 300 ducks raised by a local farmer in Hong Dan\ndistrict died last week, he said, adding that the whole flock, which\nhad yet to be vaccinated against bird flu, was culled Tuesday [18 Oct\n2005] morning.\nBac Lieu has vaccinated more than 600 000 fowl out of its poultry\npopulation of over 1.1 million.\nThe Vietnamese government has recently decided to spend 700 billion\nVietnamese dong (VND) (USD 44.3 million) on vaccinating fowl. Viet\nNam is importing more bird flu vaccines from China so as to complete\nthe 1st batch of vaccination by late next month [November 2005].\nAll fowl will have been vaccinated by late March 2007. To date, 37\nout of 64 cities and provinces have vaccinated over 54 million fowl.\nViet Nam has detected 22 bird flu outbreaks in 10 provinces since\nApril 2005, which have killed and led to the forced culling of nearly\n14 400 fowl, according to the Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development.\nTo deal with possible bird flu outbreaks among humans in the coming\ntime, the government will upgrade hospitals and ensure sufficient\nreserves of anti-virus drugs with an estimated cost of some 6870\nbillion VND (nearly USD 434.8 million), according to delegates to an\nanti-bird flu meeting hosted by the Government Office on Monday [17 Oct 2005].\nLast week [2nd week October 2005], foreign donors pledged to disburse\nUSD 6.8 million in the next 6 months to meet short-term needs of Viet\nNam's animal breeding and health care sectors.\nUp to 91 Vietnamese people have been infected with bird flu since the\ndisease started to break out in the country in late 2003. Of them, 41\nhave died.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[4]\nDate: Tue 18 Oct 2005\nFrom: Mary Marshall <tropical.forestry@btinternet.com>\nSource: The Nation, Bangkok, 18 Oct 2005 [edited]\n<http://nationmultimedia.com/2005/10/18/national/index.php?news=national_18900500.html>\n\nBird flu: Lab tests reveal virus in local sparrows, pigeons\n-----------------------------------------------\nOfficials order high-risk poultry farms to be sprayed as migration\nseason nears. In an alarming development, amid frenzied attempts by\nthe Department of Livestock Development (DLD) to control the spread\nof the deadly H5N1 strain of avian influenza, laboratory tests have\nrevealed the virus has already spread to such migratory birds as\nsparrows, pigeons and mynas.\nChawal Talhikorn, deputy director-general of the Department of\nNational Parks, said the lab tests, conducted by Mahidol University's\nVeterinary Department, had found 18 out of 11 705 samples collected\nfrom wild birds nationwide between June and 7 Oct 2005 had been\ninfected with the H5N1 virus.\nChawal said most positive cases had been collected from\ninfection-prone provinces, including Ratchaburi and Kanchanaburi. He\nsaid his department would collaborate closely with DLD and Public\nHealth Ministry officials in increased efforts to control the spread\nof the virus, a possible mutation of which, it is feared, might jump\nthe species barrier and kill countless humans.\nThe laboratory findings have deepened fears of a new outbreak of\navian influenza at Thai poultry farms because the Eurasian tree\nsparrow (some specimens of which were found to be infected) is a very\ncommon species in the country.\nHowever, Rattapan Pattana-rangsan, a veterinarian at Mahidol\nUniversity, cautioned the public against undue panic, saying the\nchance for the disease to be spread widely by sparrows was slim.\nKhunying Nattanon Taweesin, deputy permanent secretary of the Bangkok\nMetropolitan Administration, said she had ordered all district\noffices across the capital to monitor pigeon populations closely. The\ncarcasses of dead birds are to be sent for lab tests, she explained.\nWith the cold season approaching, Thai authorities are bracing for a\npotential resurgence of the deadly epidemic brought on by migratory birds.\nSumeth Chailertwanitchkul, Nakhon Sawan's deputy provincial governor,\nspearheaded a disinfecting team yesterday [17 Oct 2005] to the\nprovince's largest swamp, Beung Borapetch, where migratory birds from\nSiberia normally come to winter.\nAlso yesterday [17 Oct 2005], Agricultural Minister Khunying Sudarat\nKeyuraphan headed a group of senior ministry officials on an\ninspection tour of infected areas in Nakhon Pathom and Suphan Buri.\nSudarat ordered all poultry farms in the localities to be disinfected.\nYukol Limleamthong, director general of the DLD, said there had been\nno new outbreak of the virus, adding chicken meat available at\nmarkets was safe for consumption.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[The recent developments on the doorstep of Europe have brought the\nH5N1 issue into the very focus of world media and public concern, but\nit is the epizootic in Southeastern Asia which should be mainly\ntargeted for control and ultimately eradication efforts if a global\npandemic is to be prevented. Sporadic cases of human infection might\noccur anywhere; the evolvement of a recombinant which might spread\namong humans might be expected in Southeast Asia if the virus is\nallowed to continue its march among the dense and close avian,\nporcine and human populations there. Therefore, the events in Viet\nNam, and similar ones in Indonesia and other countries in the region,\nare of particular concern. - Mod.AS]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n To deal with possible bird flu outbreaks among humans in the coming\ntime, the government will upgrade hospitals and ensure sufficient\nreserves of anti-virus drugs with an estimated cost of some 6870\nbillion VND (nearly USD 434.8 million), according to delegates to an\nanti-bird flu meeting hosted by the Government Office on Monday [17 Oct 2005]. Chawal Talhikorn, deputy director-general of the Department of\nNational Parks, said the lab tests, conducted by Mahidol University's\nVeterinary Department, had found 18 out of 11 705 samples collected\nfrom wild birds nationwide between June and 7 Oct 2005 had been\ninfected with the H5N1 virus. The 110 out of over 300 ducks raised by a local farmer in Hong Dan\ndistrict died last week, he said, adding that the whole flock, which\nhad yet to be vaccinated against bird flu, was culled Tuesday [18 Oct\n2005] morning.\n In an alarming development, amid frenzied attempts by\nthe Department of Livestock Development (DLD) to control the spread\nof the deadly H5N1 strain of avian influenza, laboratory tests have\nrevealed the virus has already spread to such migratory birds as\nsparrows, pigeons and mynas. He\nsaid his department would collaborate closely with DLD and Public\nHealth Ministry officials in increased efforts to control the spread\nof the virus, a possible mutation of which, it is feared, might jump\nthe species barrier and kill countless humans. \nSumeth Chailertwanitchkul, Nakhon Sawan's deputy provincial governor,\nspearheaded a disinfecting team yesterday [17 Oct 2005] to the\nprovince's largest swamp, Beung Borapetch, where migratory birds from\n The laboratory findings have deepened fears of a new outbreak of\navian influenza at Thai poultry farms because the Eurasian tree\nsparrow (some specimens of which were found to be infected) is a very\ncommon species in the country.\n Sporadic cases of human infection might\noccur anywhere; the evolvement of a recombinant which might spread\namong humans might be expected in Southeast Asia if the virus is\nallowed to continue its march among the dense and close avian,\nporcine and human populations there. [The recent developments on the doorstep of Europe have brought the\nH5N1 issue into the very focus of world media and public concern, but\nit is the epizootic in Southeastern Asia which should be mainly\ntargeted for control and ultimately eradication efforts if a global\npandemic is to be prevented. Mon 10 Oct 2005: The Commission adopts an urgent safeguard Decision\nfor Turkey, suspending imports of birds and products for which Turkey\nis authorized (birds other than poultry and untreated feathers) and\nwhich present a direct threat to animal health in Europe. Didier Houssin, the French government official in charge of the\ncountry's bird flu defense, told Le Monde newspaper that migrating\nbirds were the most likely source of transmission, using flyways\nbetween the Black Sea region and Mediterranean. AVIAN INFLUENZA - EURASIA (17): H5N1\n*************************************\n Khunying Nattanon Taweesin, deputy permanent secretary of the Bangkok\nMetropolitan Administration, said she had ordered all district\noffices across the capital to monitor pigeon populations closely. The Committee is asked to vote on a\ndraft proposal suspending all imports of avian species and their\nproducts from Romania. These latest cases in Romania and Turkey have reinforced that\ntheory,' Alex Thiermann, President of the International Animal Health\nCode at the World Organization for Animal Health (OIE) in Paris, told Reuters. The OIE and U.N. Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) have\npinpointed the Caspian and Black Sea regions, as well as the Balkans,\nas a 'gateway to central Europe for the virus.' \nOfficials order high-risk poultry farms to be sprayed as migration\nseason nears. However, Rattapan Pattana-rangsan, a veterinarian at Mahidol\nUniversity, cautioned the public against undue panic, saying the\nchance for the disease to be spread widely by sparrows was slim. Thiermann said the widespread practice of cock-fighting in Asia,\nwhere it was big business, may have played a role there.\n Therefore, the events in Viet\nNam, and similar ones in Indonesia and other countries in the region,\nare of particular concern. --\nProMED-mail\n< --\nProMED-mail\n<", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2005-09-01 00:00:00", "2005-07-25 00:00:00", "2005-11-25 00:00:00", "2005-10-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-29 00:00:00", "2005-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-30 00:00:00", "2005-04-25 00:00:00", "2004-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Ukraine", "country": "Ukraine"}, {"location": "Paris", "country": "France"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bulgaria", "country": "Bulgaria"}, {"location": "Hong Dan \n district", "country": "Vietnam"}, {"location": "Greece", "country": "Greece"}, {"location": "Bangkok", "country": "Thailand"}, {"location": "Georgia", "country": "Georgia"}, {"location": "Azerbaijan", "country": "Azerbaijan"}, {"location": "Kazakhstan", "country": "Kazakhstan"}, {"location": "Turkey", "country": "Turkey"}, {"location": "Romania", "country": "Romania"}, {"location": "Iraq", "country": "Iraq"}, {"location": "Iran", "country": "Iran"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Indonesia", "country": "Indonesia"}, {"location": "Luxembourg", "country": "Luxembourg"}, {"location": "Italy", "country": "Italy"}, {"location": "Houssin", "country": "Morocco"}, {"location": "Germany", "country": "Germany"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Viet Nam", "country": "Vietnam"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1631", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza - Eurasia (13): H5N1", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1631", "date": "2005-10-16 23:50:00", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA - EURASIA (13): H5N1\n************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nJournal of Hospital Infection\n<http://thelancet.url123.com/a5wh7>\n[1]\nDate: Sun 16 Oct 2005\nFrom: Mary Marshall <tropical.forestry@btinternet.com>\nSource: Reuters alertnet, 15 Oct 2005 [edited]\n<http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/L15489494.htm>\n\nThe World Health Organization's top influenza expert,\nechoing previous warnings, said the virus could mutate into\na form that could kill thousands or millions of people\naround the world and urged governments to prepare for such a\npandemic.\nBut encouraging news came from China, where state media said\na new, improved vaccine for birds had been developed, a\nlow-cost spray that could protect them from the H5N1 strain\nof avian flu.\nThe spread of the virus in Asia has been blamed on backyard\nfarms and open-air markets where humans and birds mingle in\noften unsanitary conditions, and authorities have been\nunable to wipe it out despite large-scale culling and\nvaccination.\nIn Turkey, the state Anatolian news agency reported that\nnearly 1000 chickens had died in the east, near the Iranian\nborder, after being transported from the west of the\ncountry. It said samples had been sent for tests for\npossible bird flu, but did not say where exactly the birds\nhad been moved from. [Updated information on this event\nwould be appreciated. - Mod.AS]. Turkish officials also said\nthe incubation period for the avian flu found on a farm in\nthe north west was over, and the danger to humans had\npassed.\nThe EU Commission in Brussels confirmed that the H5N1 strain\nfound in Romanian ducks was exactly the same as that\ndetected in Turkish birds. 'The link has now been\nconfirmed,' Health and Consumer Protection Commissioner\nMarkos Kyprianou said in a statement. Kyprianou said the\nEuropean Union had already banned poultry and live bird\nimports from Romania, so no further measures were needed. EU\nveterinary experts will meet on Thu 20 Oct 2005 to review\nthe situation, he added.\nIn Romania, pharmacies ran out of regular flu vaccine and\nlocal media reported that worried citizens had bought up to\n2 million doses of the vaccine in the past few days.\nFlu vaccine protects people only against the latest strain\nof regular flu. Only if H5N1 mutates into a form that passes\neasily between humans will pharmaceutical firms be able to\ndevelop a vaccine specifically against that strain.\nIn Romania's south east Danube delta area, 6 counties were\ncordoned off. Television footage showed masked and gloved\nveterinarians gassing poultry and disinfecting farms in the\ndelta village of Ceamurlia de Jos, part of a cull of more\nthan 60 000 birds aimed at stopping the virus from\nspreading. The Danube delta contains Europe's largest\nwetlands and is a major resting place for migratory wild\nbirds -- the carriers of the virus -- coming from Russia,\nScandinavia, Poland and Germany and heading for North Africa\nfor winter.\nPoland, responding to European Commission calls, said all\npoultry must be kept indoors from Monday [17 Oct 2005] to\nkeep it away from migratory wild birds. 'The situation means\nquite a large danger for poultry in Poland, so I decided to\nimpose some restrictions ... including a ban on keeping\npoultry in open spaces,' Farm Minister Jerzy Pilarczyk told\na news conference.\n[byline: Martin Dokoupil]\n******\n[2]\nDate: Sun 16 Oct 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Haaretz, 16 Oct 2005 [edited]\n<http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/pages/ShArtVty.jhtml?sw=avian&itemNo=635329>\n\nAgriculture ministry buys 8 million doses of avian flu\nvaccine\n-----------------------------------------------\nThe Agriculture Ministry has purchased 8 million doses of\nvaccine for the 2 violent strains of avian flu, H-7 and H-5,\nit was reported on Sunday [16 Oct 2005]. The ministry has\nalso purchased a protective kit prepared for ministry\nemployees who could have contact with infected birds. The\nvaccine and the kit come from the Netherlands, Israel Radio\nreported.\nHealth Minister Dan Naveh told Haaretz on Sunday [16 Oct\n2005] that the government will discuss in its next meeting a\nrequest by his ministry to allocate ILS 150 million [USD 181\nmillion] for medication that combats the avian flu.\nSpeaking at a meeting of Health Ministry officials, Naveh\nsaid he will tell the government how the ministry is\npreparing for a possible outbreak of the pandemic in Israel.\nThe preparations were being made in the wake of fears that\nthe strain of bird flu currently circulating in the world\nhas mutated into a strain that is dangerous for humans, in\nwhich case it could be immune to known drugs.\nThe Agriculture Ministry has also opened a 24-hour,\n7-day-a-week hotline to report birds suspected of being\ninfected with avian flu. The public is asked to call\n03-968-1609 to report the location of straying birds that\nappear to be sick or bird carcasses.\nThe ministry announced it has been testing migratory birds\nand poultry in collaboration with the Israel Nature and\nParks Authority to locate infections and examine bird\ncarcasses. So far, all tests have been negative.\nThe director general of the Health Ministry, Professor Avi\nYisraeli, told Haaretz over the weekend that the main thing\nIsrael has to do now is to have Agriculture Ministry\nofficials watch out for possible cases of avian flu among\nmigratory birds and domesticated birds in agricultural\ncommunities.\nYisraeli also recommended that residents of Israel go to\ntheir health clinics to get the regular flu shot\nadministered around this time every year to babies, the\nelderly and health care workers.\nOfficials believe that a dose of the regular seasonal flu\nvaccine may reduce the incidence of sickness in case of an\navian flu epidemic, and that the ordinary flu shot could\nlessen the chance of contracting both viruses together,\nordinary influenza and avian flu.\nFears for an outbreak of the pandemic in Israel emerged\nafter the World Organization for Animal Health released\nfindings indicating flocks of migratory birds nesting in\nChina were responsible for the outbreak outside South East\nAsia. Israel faces this risk since it is located on one of\nthe major seasonal migratory routes of birds.\n[byline: Ran Reznik, Amiram Cohen and Assaf Oni]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[The concern of the Israeli authorities is understandable in\nview of Israel's geographical situation as a crossway of\nmigratory birds on their route from Asia and Europe to\nAfrica. The number of birds annually migrating through\nIsrael in each direction is estimated to be around 500\nmillion; see map\nat<http://www.eilat-guide.com/images/maps/bird_map.gif>. -\nMod.AS]", "summary": "\nHealth Minister Dan Naveh told Haaretz on Sunday [16 Oct\n2005] that the government will discuss in its next meeting a\nrequest by his ministry to allocate ILS 150 million [USD 181\nmillion] for medication that combats the avian flu.\n The spread of the virus in Asia has been blamed on backyard\nfarms and open-air markets where humans and birds mingle in\noften unsanitary conditions, and authorities have been\nunable to wipe it out despite large-scale culling and\nvaccination.\n http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/L15489494.htm>\n\nThe World Health Organization's top influenza expert,\nechoing previous warnings, said the virus could mutate into\na form that could kill thousands or millions of people\naround the world and urged governments to prepare for such a\npandemic.\n The situation means\nquite a large danger for poultry in Poland, so I decided to\nimpose some restrictions ... including a ban on keeping\npoultry in open spaces,' Farm Minister Jerzy Pilarczyk told\na news conference.\n A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Officials believe that a dose of the regular seasonal flu\nvaccine may reduce the incidence of sickness in case of an\navian flu epidemic, and that the ordinary flu shot could\nlessen the chance of contracting both viruses together,\nordinary influenza and avian flu. The Danube delta contains Europe's largest\nwetlands and is a major resting place for migratory wild\nbirds -- the carriers of the virus -- coming from Russia,\nScandinavia, Poland and Germany and heading for North Africa\nfor winter. {"archive_id": "1511", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, Eurasia (22): H5N1", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1511", "date": "2005-10-21 23:50:00", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, EURASIA (22): H5N1\n***********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSponsored by Elsevier, publisher of\nTropical Infectious Diseases, 2nd Edition\n<http://thelancet.url123.com/a5445>\n\n[1]\nDate: Fri, 21 Oct 2005\nFrom: Mary Marshall <tropical.forestry@btinternet.com>\nSource: Reuters alertnet, 21 Oct 2005 [edited]\n<http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/L2191294.htm>\n\nRomania detected a new suspected case of bird flu close to the border with\nMoldova, in the eastern county of Vaslui, some 100 km (60 miles) north of the\nDanube delta, the Agriculture Ministry said on Friday.\nEarlier this month Romania became the 1st European mainland country to detect\nthe deadly H5N1 strain of the disease which has killed more than 60 people and\nmillions of birds in Asia.\nThe Danube delta on the Black Sea, Europe's largest wetlands, is a major way\nstation for migratory wild birds heading from Asia towards winter habitats in\nNorth Africa.\n'A sample coming from a heron found on the shore of the river Prut, in Vaslui\ncounty, tested positive for bird flu antibodies,' Agriculture Ministry\nspokesman Adrian Tibu said.\nThe presence of antibodies does not necessarily mean the birds have the deadly\nstrain of the virus, and further tests including at a centre in Britain must\nbe carried to determine the type of the virus.\nFarm Minister Gheorghe Flutur said the samples would be sent to a specialised\nlaboratory in Britain as soon as possible to see whether the new case is the\nH5N1 strain of the disease.\nLocal officials said measures were being taken to help contain the virus.\n'First of all we will tell people to keep chickens shut in their pens. We have\nclosed the bird and animal markets,' Ioan Zaharia, the government's\nrepresentative in the Vaslui county, told private TV station Realitatea.\nThe farm ministry said earlier in the day that hundreds of samples tested over\nthe past few days across the country had proved negative, and that he hoped\nthe measures taken would help contain the disease.\nSo far the deadly strain was found in samples taken from 2 villages in the\nDanube delta, 40 km (25 miles) away from each other. Authorities said 21 000\ndomestic birds in the 2 villages, which were quarantined, had been slaughtered.\n\n[Our posting 20051020.3055 'Avian influenza, Eurasia (19): Taiwan ex China,\nsuspected' included the following remark: 'it might be assumed that the\nconfiscated birds were probably not domestic poultry. Were they pet-birds?\nOtherwise? Which species? Did they show disease symptoms? Any pathological\nchanges? Details, if available, will be appreciated'.\nIn response, we received the following report which answers one of the said\nquestions. A similar report has been provided by Nati Elkin\n<nati@poultrymed.com>. - Mod.AS]\n******\n[2]\nDate: Fri, 21 Oct 2005\nFrom: Tang Kin fai <kftang@singnet.com.sg>\nSource: Channelnewsasia, 20 Oct 2005 [edited]\n\nThe infected birds were hill myna, red-billed leiothrix and black-naped\noriole, according to the [Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine]\nbureau's director Sung Hua-tsong.\nIt was the 2nd time Taiwan had seized pet birds smuggled from mainland China\nsince coastguards launched a dragnet in August [2005] to crack down on the\nillegal trade.\nThe Chinese crew member who smuggled the birds has been detained in central\nTaiwan while the authorities offered up to 3.6 million Taiwan dollars (USD 107\n462) for tip-offs on bird smuggling.\nSmuggling is rampant between Taiwan and the Chinese mainland, which are\nseparated by the Taiwan Strait, 170 kilometres wide at its most narrow point.\n--\nTang Kin fai, PhD\nSingapore\n<kftang@singnet.com.sg>\n[Clearly, this consignment included pet birds. According to encyclopaedic\ndata, Hill myna is a starling, _Gracula religiosa_,family: Sturnidae, order:\nPasseriformes, native to Europe and North America. It has the capacity to\nmimic human speech and often kept as a pet. Red-billed leiothrix, _Leiothrix\nlutea_, family: Timaliidae, order: Passeriformes, is a babbler, native to\nSouthern Asia. The black-naped oriole,_Oriolus chinensis chinensis_, order:\nPasseriformes, family: Corvidae, is a songbird, native to India, southeast\nAsia and China. It will be interesting to note which of the said species was\nfound infected and whether they were clinically affected or asymptomatic.\nThe risk of H5N1 spread by smuggled birds has been raised in the past;\nrecently, the issue has been dealt with in updated European measures to\nprevent the introduction of the virus (see items 3 and 5 below). - Mod.AS]\n******\n[3]\nDate: Fri, 21 Oct 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: EU Observer, 21 Oct 2005\n<http://euobserver.com/9/20144>\n\nEU health ministers decided on Thu (20 Oct 2005) to extend a ban on poultry\nimports to Russia, and impose new measures that would keep the Asian bird flu\nthreat under control.\nThe only areas to which the ban on Russia will not apply are Kaliningrad and\nsome regions on the border of Finland.\nThe ministers and the European Commission agreed on the 1st day of the 2-day\nhealth council in England, that EU member states must make national\nevaluations and identify what actions are needed to prevent contact between\nwild birds and domestic poultry.\nMember states must also inform the Commission Standing Committee on the Food\nChain and Animal Health (SCFCAH) -- and each other -- about the measures taken.\nSpecial permission will be needed to keep birds at markets and exhibitions,\nshows and cultural events, and member states have to present special\nprogrammes for keeping and vaccinating birds in zoos.\nChicken and chicken fodder must also be kept beyond reach of wild birds.\nThe World Health Organisation (WHO) and several experts in Europe have said\nthat the bird virus is likely to mutate into a form transmittable to humans,\nand create an influenza pandemic in Europe.\nBut EU health ministers said at Thursday's council meeting that the pandemic\nfears have been exaggerated.\nAlarms about possible bird flu in Greece seemed to be false, the EU Laboratory\nfor Avian Influenza in Weybridge, UK reported on Thursday, saying that tests\nshowed the Greek birds had not died from the H5 bird flu virus.\nThe commission said that although the 1st results had proved negative, it did\nnot exclude the presence of the virus in the country.\nHealth ministers in England also discussed pandemic preparedness in the\ndifferent member states.\nThe commission has suggested that each member state should stockpile enough\nvirus treatment, like Tamiflu, to treat a fourth of the population.\n'None of the countries reach those numbers today', Swedish health minister\nMorgan Johansson told wires after the meeting.\n[Byline: Teresa Kuchler]\n******\n[4]\nDate: Fri, 21 Oct 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: News Nine MSN, 21 Oct 2005 [edited]\n<http://news.ninemsn.com.au/article.aspx?id=68107\n\nThe EU has said initial tests for bird flu in Greece were negative, in a\nrelief after outbreaks in Turkey and Romania, but stressed it cannot yet\nexclude the presence of the virus in the EU state.\nThe provisional good news was also tempered by wrangling in Greece over\nexactly which sample was sent for testing by European Union (EU) experts\nfollowing a suspected case on an Aegean island earlier this week.\nConfirmation of the H5N1 strain in Greece would mark its 1st-ever arrival in\nthe 25-nation bloc.\nWhile announcing the negative result, the EU's executive arm underlined that\nprecautionary measures slapped on the eastern Aegean Sea islet of Oinousses\n[some 5 km from the region's main island, Chios] will therefore remain in\nplace, pending further tests.\nA 'preliminary test was carried out ... which proved negative but it is not\npossible at this point definitively to conclude from this that the suspicion\nof avian influenza' can be entirely excluded, said spokeswoman Pia Ahrenkilde.\n'Therefore, precautionary measures remain in place,' she added. 'At this point\nwe cannot exclude the possibility of avian flu in Greece and in the area.'\nEU-certified laboratories in Britain and Greece have been testing samples from\nbirds in the same flock where a suspect case was found to determine if it was\nthe H5N1 strain of bird flu that has killed about 60 people in Asia.\nThe EU spokesman said that the tests, carried out at an EU laboratory in\nWeybridge, southwest of London, had proved negative for the H5 strain of the\nvirus.\nShe also downplayed reports that there had been problems surrounding the\nsamples provided by Greece -- centred on the fate of a lone turkey that\noriginally sparked the scare.\nAgriculture Minister Evangelos Bassiakos has drawn fire after his ministry\nfirst said it sent tissues from the ailing bird to Britain for follow-up\ntests, but then changed track, saying it sent samples from the general flock.\nOn Wed [19 Oct 2005] night, Supreme Court prosecutor Dimitris Linos ordered a\npreliminary investigation on the procedure followed by the authorities.\nBut said the EU spokesman in Brussels: 'I have nothing giving me reason to\ncomplain about cooperation from the Greek authorities.'\nThe Greek suspected case has come under the spotlight following the\nconfirmation of the H5N1 strain in Romania and Turkey last week, which\ntriggered the EU to bolster its defences against the virus.\nEU member states have been ordered to take measures to ensure that poultry do\nnot come into contact with migratory birds which could carry the virus, and\nhave also been urged to stockpile anti-viral drugs.\nIn Greece itself, 3 EU experts arrived Thursday on the island of Chios to help\ninvestigate the suspected case of bird flu, before heading for the Oinousses\nlater in the day. [Both Chios and its satellite island Oinousses have been\nmentioned in newswires as sites of suspected avian influenza. Clarification\nwill help. - Mod.AS]\nGovernment spokesman Theodoros Roussopoulos on Wednesday said tests conducted\non 56 bird samples collected from across the country had turned up negative\nfor bird flu.\nBut ordinary Greeks have clearly been alarmed by the outbreak: sales of\npoultry in Greece have plummeted by up to 70 percent since the suspected case\nwas reported on Monday, a union of Greek meat vendors said.\nThe Greek poultry industry is having difficulty adapting, said Spyros Nonikas,\ngeneral director of the association of Greek poultry companies.\nIn neighbouring Albania, meanwhile, local television reported that thousands\nof Greek chickens were buried alive on the border after authorities refused to\nlet them enter the country for fears that they could carry bird flu.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[5]\nDate: Fri, 21 Oct 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Defra News release 469/05, 21 Oct 2005 [edited]\n<http://www.defra.gov.uk/news/2005/051021f.htm>\n\nA highly pathogenic H5 Avian Flu virus has been isolated in a parrot imported\nfrom Suriname, South America. The birds were in quarantine with a consignment\nof birds from Taiwan.\nThe H5 virus was discovered in samples taken from a bird that died in\nquarantine. The bird was part of a mixed consignment of 148 parrots and 'soft\nbills' that arrived on 16 Sep 2005.\nChief Veterinary Officer Debby Reynolds said: 'The confirmed case does not\naffect the UK's official disease free status because the disease has been\nidentified in imported birds during quarantine.'\nThe bird was in a biosecure quarantine unit. All the birds in the unit are\nbeing culled humanely.\nIt is very difficult for humans to contract avian influenza. However, the\nnecessary actions to protect human health have been taken in this instance.\nThese include culling of the bird consignment and giving antiviral treatment\nas a precautionary measure to the small number of people who have been in\ncontact with the birds.\nChief Veterinary Officer Debby Reynolds added 'the incident showed the\nimportance of the UK's quarantine system. We have had similar incidents in the\npast where disease has been discovered but successfully contained as a result\nof our quarantine arrangements.'\nAnother consignment of 216 birds from Taiwan, also housed in the unit, were\nhumanely culled.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Subscribers are reminded that all H5 and H7 strains are regarded, by the OIE,\nas Notifiable avian influenza (NAI) strains -- even if their pathogenicity is\nfound not to be high.\nThis week ProMED-mail has received several reports on suspected avian\ninfluenza cases from various countries. We try to select for posting only\ncases which seem to warrant credible suspicion. Fortunately, even selected\nones may eventually be found negative. Hopefully, the (awaited) final verdict\nof the Greek case will be confirmed as negative.\nElevated alertness of inspection authorities and the raised public awareness\nare enhancing detection of suspected cases. The recent discovery of infected\nbirds in quarantine stations and confiscations of smuggled birds are not\nunrelated to the said trend. - Mod.AS]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n \nTang Kin fai, PhD\nSingapore\n<kftang@singnet.com.sg>\n Source: Reuters alertnet, 21 Oct 2005 [edited]\n<http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/L2191294.htm>\n\nRomania detected a new suspected case of bird flu close to the border with\nMoldova, in the eastern county of Vaslui, some 100 km (60 miles) north of the\nDanube delta, the Agriculture Ministry said on Friday. Source: EU Observer, 21 Oct 2005\n<http://euobserver.com/9/20144>\n\nEU health ministers decided on Thu (20 Oct 2005) to extend a ban on poultry\nimports to Russia, and impose new measures that would keep the Asian bird flu\nthreat under control. AS]\nGovernment spokesman Theodoros Roussopoulos on Wednesday said tests conducted\non 56 bird samples collected from across the country had turned up negative\nfor bird flu. \nEU-certified laboratories in Britain and Greece have been testing samples from\nbirds in the same flock where a suspect case was found to determine if it was\nthe H5N1 strain of bird flu that has killed about 60 people in Asia. The ministers and the European Commission agreed on the 1st day of the 2-day\nhealth council in England, that EU member states must make national\nevaluations and identify what actions are needed to prevent contact between\nwild birds and domestic poultry. The farm ministry said earlier in the day that hundreds of samples tested over\nthe past few days across the country had proved negative, and that he hoped\nthe measures taken would help contain the disease.\n \nChief Veterinary Officer Debby Reynolds said: 'The confirmed case does not\naffect the UK's official disease free status because the disease has been\nidentified in imported birds during quarantine.' \nEU member states have been ordered to take measures to ensure that poultry do\nnot come into contact with migratory birds which could carry the virus, and\nhave also been urged to stockpile anti-viral drugs. \nSpecial permission will be needed to keep birds at markets and exhibitions,\nshows and cultural events, and member states have to present special\nprogrammes for keeping and vaccinating birds in zoos. In neighbouring Albania, meanwhile, local television reported that thousands\nof Greek chickens were buried alive on the border after authorities refused to\nlet them enter the country for fears that they could carry bird flu.\n We have had similar incidents in the\npast where disease has been discovered but successfully contained as a result\nof our quarantine arrangements.'\n Sponsored by Elsevier, publisher of\nTropical Infectious Diseases, 2nd Edition\n<http://thelancet.url123.com/a5445>\n\n[1]\n Alarms about possible bird flu in Greece seemed to be false, the EU Laboratory\nfor Avian Influenza in Weybridge, UK reported on Thursday, saying that tests\nshowed the Greek birds had not died from the H5 bird flu virus. The EU has said initial tests for bird flu in Greece were negative, in a\nrelief after outbreaks in Turkey and Romania, but stressed it cannot yet\nexclude the presence of the virus in the EU state. The recent discovery of infected\nbirds in quarantine stations and confiscations of smuggled birds are not\nunrelated to the said trend. The presence of antibodies does not necessarily mean the birds have the deadly\nstrain of the virus, and further tests including at a centre in Britain must\nbe carried to determine the type of the virus. 'I cannot\nconfirm or deny (the report) but the Commission was acting\nwith the presumption that it would be this more dangerous\ntype and took all the preventative measures,' the spokesman,\nRobert Soltyk, said.\nTurkey also reported an outbreak of the deadly strain\nearlier this week.\nExperts fear H5N1 could mutate into a virus which spreads\neasily among humans, creating a pandemic that might kill\ntens of millions. Romania has not reported any cases of bird\nflu so far in humans.\nThe Danube delta contains Europe's largest wetlands and is a\nmajor migratory area for wild birds coming from Russia,\nScandinavia, Poland, and Germany.
