The OIE\nreport indicates that in one reported outbreak none of the 10 infected\nchickens died, and in another only 5 of 15 infected chickens died.\n<http://www.oie.int/eng/info/hebdo/aIS_55.htm#Sec3>\nIf the phenomenon is widespread, it seems that this could indicate that\nnative chicken flocks as well as domestic ducks are serving as reservoirs\nfor H5N1 virus in SE Asia.\nDoes anyone know of any available reports or technical analyses of this issue?\n--\nJoseph P Dudley, PhD\nChief Scientist\nEAI Corporation\n4301 North Fairfax Drive\nSuite 200\nArlington, VA 22203\n<jdudley@eaicorp.com>", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n --\nJoseph P Dudley, PhD\nChief Scientist\nEAI Corporation\n4301 The data provided in the Office International des Epizooties (OIE) report\nof 30 Aug 2005 submitted by Thailand cited in ProMED-mail posting\n20050903.2603 seem to suggest the existence -- or appearance -- of possible\nresistance to H5N1 in one or more native Thai chicken breeds. The measures will be\ndiscussed at an emergency meeting of the Standing Committee\non the Food Chain and Animal Health in Brussels this\nafternoon.\nThe Commission is adopting today a decision to ban imports\nof live birds, poultry meat, and other poultry products from\nRomania following new tests by EU experts, which identified\nthe presence of avian influenza. Imports of live birds and\nfeathers from Turkey have been banned since Monday following\nthe finding of avian influenza there.\nFurther actions decided by EU Health and Consumer Protection\nCommissioner Markos Kyprianou are:\na Commission framework decision on preventive measures and\nincreased biosecurity (hygiene), which will be presented at\ntoday's Committee meeting. Member states will take\nappropriate measures to reduce the risk of transmission of\navian influenza. This should include strengthening\nbiosecurity in poultry farms across the EU and in particular\nin high risk areas.\nan emergency meeting of experts on avian influenza and\nmigratory birds will be held tomorrow. The purpose of the\nmeeting is to evaluate the risk that migratory birds may\npose for the EU. The experts' group will then issue\nrecommendations on the potential risk for humans in contact\nwith such birds.\nThe offer of EU and member state experts to assist Romania,\nTurkey, and other countries which are concerned about\nsuspected cases of avian influenza.\nCommission and ECDC advice on precautions to be taken by\npeople travelling to Romania and Turkey and other countries\nwhere avian influenza has been found.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[In retrospect, the severe precautionary measures, taken by\nTurkey and Romania since the initial suspicion of an H5\npresence there was raised, seem justified. - Mod.AS]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n The Commission is taking further action following the\nconfirmation last night of the presence of avian influenza\nH5 virus in Romania and the results from the EU laboratory\nthis morning indicating that the avian influenza virus in\n Further actions decided by EU Health and Consumer Protection\nCommissioner Markos Kyprianou are:\na Commission framework decision on preventive measures and\nincreased biosecurity (hygiene), which will be presented at\ntoday's Committee meeting. The spokesman said the laboratory was continuing\nto work to pin down the origin of the virus and the link to\na strain found in Turkey.\nThe Danube delta contains Europe's largest wetlands and is a\nmajor way station for migratory wild birds coming from\nRussia, Scandinavia, Poland and Germany and heading for\nwarmer North Africa, including the Nile delta, for winter.\n'People must pay attention to our recommendations and they\nhave to be calm, because we have the situation under\ncontrol,' Romanian agriculture minister Gheorghe Flutur told\njournalists.\nOfficials have sealed off the affected area and vaccinated\nthe population against regular flu to boost their immunity.\nFlutur said preventive measures such as checkpoints on roads\nto disinfect those who travel out of the area and medical\nsurveillance of all domestic birds would be taken in 6\ncounties in the south-eastern Dobrogea region [A territory\nbetween the lower Danube River and the Black Sea, which\nincludes the Danube Delta and the Romanian seashore. The\nTulcea region is situated in south Dobrogea. - Mod.AS].\nTransport of live birds from these counties was forbidden,\nand domestic birds must be closed indoors or in yards to\navoid contact with wild birds, Flutur said. He said pigs\nmust also be isolated because the virus can be passed on to\nthem.\n'We are fighting to prevent an expansion (of outbreaks),\nthis is why we take measures even in areas where there are\nno problems,' he said. Fairs selling live birds and pigs\nwere forbidden across Romania, Flutur added.\nTelevision footage showed masked and gloved veterinarians\ngassing poultry, burning their carcasses and disinfecting\nfarms in the Danube delta village of Ceamurlia de Jos on\nSaturday.\nRomanian authorities have culled 18 000 domestic birds so\nfar in the village this week and said 45 000 birds in the\narea would have to be killed to prevent the disease from\nspreading.\n'We are now thoroughly checking the entire village with\nveterinarian experts,' Ceamurlia de Jos Mayor Mihai\nCarciumaru told Reuters. 'We are gathering all the faeces\nfrom birds and will burn them. People have all been\nvaccinated and we have advised the population to alert us if\nthey experience any symptoms.'\nOn Friday, officials isolated the bird flu virus in 2 more\nbirds -- a hen and a swan -- in Maliuc, a village 40 km (25\nmiles) north of Ceamurlia de Jos where the 1st outbreak\noccurred.\nRomania's government has asked the Swiss drug company Roche\nHolding AG to provide 45 000 doses of the antiviral drug\nTamiflu as a precautionary move to fight a possible spread\nto humans.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[An official confirmation -- or otherwise -- of the\ndetection of a 2nd focus of disease, in Maliuc, is\nanticipated. Maliuc commune is situated in the center of\nTulcea County, about 15 km east of the region's capital, the\ncity of Tulcea. For a map showing Tulcea county within\nRomania, see\n<http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/a/a6/Tulcea.png>.\nFor a map of Tulcea county, where the locations of Ceamurlia\nde Jos and Mariuc are visible, see\n<http://www.cormoran.ro/Images/tulcea.jpg>.\nOn 8 Oct 2005 (see 20051010.2950), suspected avian influenza\ncases in another village within the Danube delta, Smardan,\nsituated in the north western part of the Tulcea region,\nwere mentioned. No further data followed; details on this\nsuspected case would help. - Mod.AS]", "summary": "Flutur said preventive measures such as checkpoints on roads\nto disinfect those who travel out of the area and medical\nsurveillance of all domestic birds would be taken in 6\ncounties in the south-eastern Dobrogea region [A territory\nbetween the lower Danube River and the Black Sea, which\nincludes the Danube Delta and the Romanian seashore. Asia (18): Thailand, H5N1", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1186", "date": "2005-09-03 23:50:00", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA - ASIA (18): THAILAND, H5N1\n*******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nDrug Resistance Updates\n<http://intl.elsevierhealth.com/journals/drup>\nDate: Sat, 3 Sep 2005\nFrom: Nati Elkin <nati@poultrymed.com>\nSource: Xinhua via People's daily online, China, 3 Sep 2005 [edited]\n<http://english.people.com.cn/200509/03/eng20050903_206207.html>\n\nLocal authorities have acted promptly to contain a new bird flu outbreak in\nKamphaeng Phet, announcing that an outbreak identified in 4 districts has been\ncontained.\nThe provincial governor and local health officials visited Ban Sabmanao in\nKlongthalung district to cull chickens and spray disinfectant after native\nchickens in the village were found to be infected with the H5N1 avian flu\nvirus.\nProvincial animal husbandry officials were quoted by the Thai News Agency as\nsaying Friday [2 Sep 2005] that the province has enforced preventive measures\nto ban moving poultry in the 4 districts.\nThe cause of the new outbreak may be the movement of fighting cocks from other\nareas where they had contracted the disease, the official said.\nThere is no report of the deadly disease in chickens raised in closed farming\nsystems or free-range ducks, he added.\nThe poultry have been under close surveillance and free-range ducks are\nregistered with the authorities.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Thailand has been meticulously sending to the OIE detailed weekly disease\ninformation updates on avian influenza since 12 Mar 2004. The disease was\nreportedly absent between 12 Apr 2005 and 5 Jul 2005, when new cases were\nreported from native poultry and fighting cocks in villages where biosecurity\nis minimal. These findings resulted from a nationwide active surveillance\ncampaign conducted since 1 Jul 2005. The purpose of this surveillance is to\nevaluate the present status of highly pathogenic avian influenza after the 2nd\nwave of outbreaks between 3 Jul 2004 and 12 Apr 2005.\nAs a result of this 2-month campaign, 29 new outbreaks have been confirmed in\n4 provinces:\nAffected province/ No. of outbreaks\nAyudhaya/ 1\nChainat/ 1\nKampaengphet/ 8\nSuphanburi/ 19\nAll cases involved either free-range poultry or poultry raised in farms with\ntraditional husbandry practices with poor sanitation and insufficient\nbiosecurity, notably in the 3 outbreaks involving quail.\nFurther details on the said surveillance campaign, as well as the last follow-\nup report (No 66) notifying data on 6 outbreaks which had started between 23-\n30 Aug 2005, are available at\n<http://www.oie.int/eng/info/hebdo/aIS_55.htm#Sec3>.\nAn administrative map of Thailand is available at\n<http://www.visit-thailand.info/information/political-map-of-thailand.htm>.\nThailand seems to have successfully eradicated the disease in commercial\nflocks, without vaccination, in an effort to restore exports (applying the\nzoning/compartmentalisation principles, this might be achieved). The struggle\nto control the continued infection in small holdings has to be continued. -\nMod.AS].", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n The disease was\nreportedly absent between 12 Apr 2005 and 5 Jul 2005, when new cases were\nreported from native poultry and fighting cocks in villages where biosecurity\nis minimal. Source: Xinhua via People's daily online, China, 3 Sep 2005 [edited]\n<http://english.people.com.cn/200509/03/eng20050903_206207.html>\n\nLocal authorities have acted promptly to contain a new bird flu outbreak in\nKamphaeng Phet, announcing that an outbreak identified in 4 districts has been\ncontained. All cases involved either free-range poultry or poultry raised in farms with\ntraditional husbandry practices with poor sanitation and insufficient\nbiosecurity, notably in the 3 outbreaks involving quail.\n Further details on the said surveillance campaign, as well as the last follow-\nup report (No 66) notifying data on 6 outbreaks which had started between 23-\n30 Aug 2005, are available at\n<http://www.oie.int/eng/info/hebdo/aIS_55.htm#Sec3>. The provincial governor and local health officials visited Ban Sabmanao in\nKlongthalung district to cull chickens and spray disinfectant after native\nchickens in the village were found to be infected with the H5N1 avian flu\nvirus. Ayudhaya/ 1\nChainat/ 1\nKampaengphet/ 8\n Sponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nDrug Resistance Updates\n<http://intl.elsevierhealth.com/journals/drup>\n The purpose of this surveillance is to\nevaluate the present status of highly pathogenic avian influenza after the 2nd\nwave of outbreaks between 3 Jul 2004 and 12 Apr 2005. Provincial animal husbandry officials were quoted by the Thai News Agency as\nsaying Friday [2 Sep 2005] that the province has enforced preventive measures\nto ban moving poultry in the 4 districts. As a result of this 2-month campaign, 29 new outbreaks have been confirmed in\n4 provinces:\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2005-09-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 00:00:00", "2004-03-25 00:00:00", "2005-09-02 00:00:00", "2005-07-01 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Thailand", "country": "Thailand"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1185", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza - Asia (17): Mongolia, migratory birds, H5N1, OIE", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1185", "date": "2005-09-02 23:50:00", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA - ASIA (17): MONGOLIA, MIGRATORY BIRDS, H5N1, OIE\n*****************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nDrug Resistance Updates\n<http://intl.elsevierhealth.com/journals/drup>\nDate: 2 Sep 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: OIE Disease Information 26 Aug 2005 Vol. 18 - No. 35 [edited]\n<http://www.oie.int/eng/info/hebdo/a_current.htm#Sec0>\n\nHighly Pathogenic Avian Influenza in Mongolia in migratory birds (OIE follow-\nup report No. 2)\nSee also: 19 Aug 2005, 12 Aug 2005\nInformation received on 27 Aug 2005 from Dr Doloonjin Orgil, Director,\nDepartment of Veterinary Services, Ministry of Food and Agriculture,\nUlaanbaatar:\nEnd of previous report period: 18 Aug 2005 (see Disease Information, 18 [33],\n272, dated 19 Aug 2005).\nEnd of this report period: 27 Aug 2005.\nWith regard to the suspicious samples sent on 15 Aug 2005 to the OIE Reference\nLaboratory for avian influenza at Hokkaido University, Japan, the following\nadditional test results were received on 24 Aug 2005:\nSample / Bird species / Location / virus subtype\nNo. 1/bar-headed goose (Anser indicus)/Erhel lake,Huvsgel province/ H5N1\nNo. 3/ whooper swan (Cygnus cygnus)/ Erhel lake, Huvsgel province /H5N1\nNo. 4/ whooper swan (Cygnus cygnus)/ Erhel lake, Huvsgel province /H5N1\nNo. 6/ whooper swan (Cygnus cygnus)/ Erhel lake, Huvsgel province /H5N1\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[This report confirms previous postings and information obtained by the joint\nmission that included the Wildlife Conservation Society -- see references\nbelow, particularly 20050831.2578. As pointed out by Mod.AS, the important\nnews is that an H5N1 -- most likely the same one currently circulating in\nSoutheast Asia -- has extended its geographic range.\nThe challenge now is to gather good information and understand the evolving\nepidemiology in the newly established geographic location. Foremost among\nthese unanswered questions is the prevalence of infection in the migratory\nbird population. As put elegantly in previous moderator comments, dead birds\ndon't migrate -- i.e., waterfowl species typically identified in recent\noutbreaks appear to be victims rather than effective carriers of the disease.\nComprehensive surveillance is the key to this question. Given the stakes, the\ncollective effort in surveillance has been weak. Additionally, surveillance\nshould not be limited to wildlife populations. We have already seen this\noutbreak show up in commercial poultry in Kazakhstan and various places in\nRussia. Surveillance will best tell us how firm the H5N1 viral foothold is in\nboth poultry and migratory bird populations.\nPrevious cases of human infection in this pandemic resulted from either direct\nor indirect contact with commercial poultry. How efficiently the H5N1 virus\ncrosses the interface between wildlife and domestic poultry is salient in\npredicting the magnitude of the eventual threat to people. Migratory birds\nalone will not likely threaten people, but if poultry farms or backyard\npoultry become infected because migratory birds have spread the H5N1 virus to\na new geographic region, then the risk to humans has indeed increased.\nThe OIE in a recent press release entitled, 'Evolution of the animal health\nsituation with regard to avian influenza,' puts it well:\n'The OIE is vigilantly following the international animal health situation\nwith regard to avian influenza. Following the recent concerns caused by\noutbreaks of avian influenza in Russia and Kazakhstan and by the risk of\nspread of the virus to other regions of the world by migratory birds, the OIE\nrecalls the necessity of intensifying the fight against the disease at its\nsource -- that is in the avian production plants in contaminated countries.\nThis represents the best way of limiting the spread of the disease, of\neradicating it and of reducing the risk of the virus concerned acquiring the\nattributes necessary for a human pandemic to occur....'.\nFor the full statement see: <http://www.oie.int/eng/press/en_050829.htm>\n- Mod.PC.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Following the recent concerns caused by\noutbreaks of avian influenza in Russia and Kazakhstan and by the risk of\nspread of the virus to other regions of the world by migratory birds, the OIE\nrecalls the necessity of intensifying the fight against the disease at its\nsource -- that is in the avian production plants in contaminated countries. Migratory birds\nalone will not likely threaten people, but if poultry farms or backyard\npoultry become infected because migratory birds have spread the H5N1 virus to\na new geographic region, then the risk to humans has indeed increased. With regard to the suspicious samples sent on 15 Aug 2005 to the OIE Reference\nLaboratory for avian influenza at Hokkaido University, Japan, the following\nadditional test results were received on 24 Aug 2005:\nSample / Bird species 18 - No. 35 [edited]\n<http://www.oie.int/eng/info/hebdo/a_current.htm#Sec0>\n\nHighly Pathogenic Avian Influenza in Mongolia in migratory birds (OIE follow-\nup report No. 2)\n Information received on 27 Aug 2005 from Dr Doloonjin Orgil, Director,\nDepartment of Veterinary Services, Ministry of Food and Agriculture,\nUlaanbaatar:\n Sponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nDrug Resistance Updates\n<http://intl.elsevierhealth.com/journals/drup>\n As put elegantly in previous moderator comments, dead birds\ndon't migrate -- i.e., waterfowl species typically identified in recent\noutbreaks appear to be victims rather than effective carriers of the disease. This represents the best way of limiting the spread of the disease, of\neradicating it and of reducing the risk of the virus concerned acquiring the\nattributes necessary for a human pandemic to occur....'. [This report confirms previous postings and information obtained by the joint\nmission that included the Wildlife Conservation Society -- see references\nbelow, particularly 20050831.2578. AVIAN INFLUENZA - ASIA (17): MONGOLIA, MIGRATORY BIRDS, H5N1, OIE\n*****************************************************************\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2005-08-24 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2005-08-19 00:00:00", "2005-08-15 00:00:00", "2005-08-27 00:00:00", "2005-08-18 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Mongolia", "country": "Mongolia"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "Japan"}, {"location": "Huvsgel province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kazakhstan", "country": "Kazakhstan"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1180", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza - Asia (16): Mongolia, migratory birds, H5N1", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1180", "date": "2005-08-31 23:50:00", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA - ASIA (16): MONGOLIA, MIGRATORY BIRDS, H5N1\n************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nDrug Resistance Updates\n<http://intl.elsevierhealth.com/journals/drup>\nDate: Wed, 31 Aug 2005\nFrom: Mary Marshall <tropical.forestry@btinternet.com>\nSource: CIDRAP News, 30 Aug 2005 [edited]\n<http://www.cidrap.umn.edu/cidrap/content/influenza/avianflu/news/aug3005avian.\nhtml>\n\nMongolian officials said tests have detected an H5N1 avian influenza virus in\nseveral wild birds, confirming earlier indications that the virus had reached\nthe central Asian country.\nOne bar-headed goose and 3 whooper swans from Erhel Lake tested positive for\nH5N1, a Mongolian official said in an 27 Aug 2005 report to the World\nOrganization for Animal Health (OIE). Hokkaido University in Japan ran the\ntests, and Dooloojin Orgil, director of Mongolia's Department of Veterinary\nService, reported the results.\nMongolian officials told the OIE on 19 Aug 2005 that an H5 virus had been\nfound in 3 wild birds. About the same time, preliminary testing by the US\nDepartment of Agriculture detected an H5N1 virus in 1 of about 100 birds found\ndead at Erhel Lake.\nThe virus's appearance in Mongolia follows its emergence in parts of Siberian\nRussia and Kazakhstan in recent weeks. Last spring the virus killed several\nthousand birds in the Qinghai Lake wildlife refuge in north-central China,\nwhich borders Mongolia on the south [see map at\n<http://www.paulnoll.com/China/Provinces/Province-Qinghai.html>. - Mod.JW]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Mongolia's follow-up report No 2 of 27 Aug 2005 can be seen at\n<http://oie.int/downld/AVIAN%20INFLUENZA/Mongolia%20Follow%20up%20Report%\n20No2.pdf>.\nIt relates to samples from Lake Erhel (Huvsgel [Hovsgol] province in northern\nMongolia) [see map at <http://media.maps.com/magellan/Images/MONGOL-W1.gif> --\nnear north central border with Russia. - Mod.JW] which were sent by the\nMongolian authorities on 15 Aug 2005 to the OIE Reference laboratory in the\nHokkaido University, Japan. Final results on 4 of them (samples No 1,3,4 and\n6), one Bar-headed goose (_Anser indicus_) and 3 whooper swans (_Cygnus\ncygnus_), were received on 24 Aug 2005 from Dr. H. Kida and Dr. Y. Sakoda at\nthe Japanese laboratory. The virus was identified as H5N1; the laboratory is\nexpected to further study the isolate, particularly comparing it with previous\nisolates from the region.\nThis finding is in line with a report obtained on 19 Aug 2005 from the\nWildlife Conservation Society, notifying the identification of H5N1 in one\ndead whooper swan collected at the same site and tested in USDA's Poultry\nResearch Laboratory in Athens, Georgia (see 20050819.2443). The WCS posting\nalso provided other important results from the same lab: 30 live whooper swans\nliving at the same site and also a nearby lake were negative for the virus.\nSamples collected from other live birds at the 2 sites, including 60 ruddy\nshelducks, 24 bar-headed geese, and 25 black-headed gulls, were found to be\nnegative for the virus. It has been argued that these (as well as previous\nobservations in China's Qinghai Lake wildlife refuge) may indicate that the\nwaterfowl species typically identified in recent outbreaks appear to be\nvictims rather than effective carriers of the disease. Further research is\nurgently in need.\nThis event reflects an exemplary proactive, transparent attitude of the\nMongolian authorities and a commendable cooperative effort of international\nexperts and laboratories. Lake Erhel is just 350 km southwest of Lake Baikal\nin Siberia, the largest freshwater lake in Eurasia; it will be interesting to\nnote if surveillance in wild birds has been undertaken there as well. - Mod.AS]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n JW]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n Final results on 4 of them (samples No 1,3,4 and\n6), one Bar-headed goose (_Anser indicus_) and 3 whooper swans (_Cygnus\ncygnus_), were received on 24 Aug 2005 from Dr. H. Kida and Dr. Y. Sakoda at\nthe Japanese laboratory. This finding is in line with a report obtained on 19 Aug 2005 from the\nWildlife Conservation Society, notifying the identification of H5N1 in one\ndead whooper swan collected at the same site and tested in USDA's Poultry\nResearch Laboratory in Athens, Georgia (see 20050819.2443). Last spring the virus killed several\nthousand birds in the Qinghai Lake wildlife refuge in north-central China,\nwhich borders Mongolia on the south [see map at\n<http://www.paulnoll.com/China/Provinces/Province-Qinghai.html>. It has been argued that these (as well as previous\nobservations in China's Qinghai Lake wildlife refuge) may indicate that the\nwaterfowl species typically identified in recent outbreaks appear to be\nvictims rather than effective carriers of the disease. Sponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nDrug Resistance Updates\n<http://intl.elsevierhealth.com/journals/drup>\n Samples collected from other live birds at the 2 sites, including 60 ruddy\nshelducks, 24 bar-headed geese, and 25 black-headed gulls, were found to be\nnegative for the virus. html>\n\nMongolian officials said tests have detected an H5N1 avian influenza virus in\nseveral wild birds, confirming earlier indications that the virus had reached\nthe central Asian country. One bar-headed goose and 3 whooper swans from Erhel Lake tested positive for\nH5N1, a Mongolian official said in an 27 Aug 2005 report to the World\nOrganization for Animal Health (OIE). The WCS posting\nalso provided other important results from the same lab: 30 live whooper swans\nliving at the same site and also a nearby lake were negative for the virus.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2005-08-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-08-19 00:00:00", "2005-03-25 00:00:00", "2005-08-24 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Japan", "country": "Japan"}, {"location": "Kazakhstan", "country": "Kazakhstan"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Georgia", "country": "Georgia"}, {"location": "Athens", "country": "Greece"}, {"location": "Eurasia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1475", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza - Eurasia (06): H5N1", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1475", "date": "2005-10-14 23:50:00", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA - EURASIA (06): H5N1\n************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSponsored by Elsevier, publisher of\nThe Journal of Hospital Infection\n<http://thelancet.url123.com/a5wh7>\n[1]\nDate: Fri, 14 Oct 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Nineoclock, Bucharest, issue 3536 page 2, 14 Oct\n2005 [edited]\n<http://www.nineoclock.ro/homenews_details.php>\n\nRomanian and European authorities are on alert after the\navian flu virus was confirmed in Romania. The samples\nindicative of the virus' presence in the 3 dead birds at\nCeamurlia de Jos, Tulcea County, will however be sent for\nconfirmation by expert laboratories in the UK [see further\ncomment below].\nThe European Commission met in an emergency meeting Thu, 13\nOct 2005, whose 1st measure was to ban imports of live birds\nand poultry from Romania.\nMeanwhile, the slaughtering of the birds from certain areas\nin Tulcea County carried on, and quarantine measures taken\nby authorities have been stepped up. Expert doctors did not\nrule out that the residents of Ceamurlia might have come\ninto contact with the virus, yet no such case has been\nreported. It is however reassuring to know that the avian\nflu virus is not transmitted from human to human but only\nfrom the sick birds to humans.\nAuthorities urged population to stay calm, but also asked\npeople to comply with the minimum of hygienic measures, to\navoid purchasing poultry from unauthorised sources and to\ntake antiviral medicines.\nThe National Audiovisual Council (CAN) also called on radio\nand television stations to broadcast information from\nauthorised sources to avoid creating panic among the\npopulation.\nThe European Commission banned Thursday the imports of live\nbirds and poultry from Romania. Brussels made the\nannouncement Wednesday night, which then was reported by\npress agencies. The 3 European experts that the EC sent to\nBucharest confirmed that the H5 virus of the avian influenza\nwas found in the Romanian samples. The embargo comes a day\nafter European experts said the test results in Romania were\nnegative. [again, see further comment below].\nThe risks of the bird flu spreading in Romania are small,\nsay experts of the European Commission who came to Romania.\n'Given that the virus emerged in a small locality, where\nlocals do not buy birds from outside their community,\nchances of the disease spreading are smaller compared with\nwhat would be in a similar case in western Europe,' says\nDanish expert Jorgen Westergaard.\nThe European Commission has announced it will provide\nassistance to Romania in eliminating the bird flu focus at\nLower Ceamurlia.\nFowl farmers are claiming that the contradictory information\nregarding the existence of the bird flu in Romania has\ntriggered a fall of 40 per cent in the sales of fowl and\nproducts, although the risks of an epidemic are minimal as\nlong as the population eats only tested meat.\nThe same farmers are warning that the confirmation of the\nbird flu virus does not mean there is a pandemic. 'There is\ntalk of a pandemic only when this virus has undergone some\nmutations, when the mutated DNA of it further replicates. If\nthere are deficiencies in the replication process, there\nwill be equally odds of the virus being pathogenic or\nnon-pathogenic for humans,' Chairman of the Union of\nRomanian Fowl Farmers Ilie Van told a conference on Thursday\nabout the measures against and the consequences of the bird\nflu.\nRomanian authorities confirmed late Wednesday night into the\nearly hours of Thursday the existence of the avian influenza\nvirus in Romania. Veterinary experts succeeded to isolate\nthe virus 6 days after identifying the viral antibodies in\nthe samples taken from the dead birds at Ceamurlia de Jos,\nTulcea County. [This piece of information, repeatedly\npublished by the Romanians, will need explanation. Were the\nantibodies against H5? Could the birds/geese have died from\nother cause/s? - Mod.AS]\nThe BBC reports it is the 1st time that the avian flu has\nbeen discovered in Europe, since the virus had originated\nand spread through South East Asia. The samples taken from\nthe geese in Ceamurlia de Jos proved positive for the H5\nvirus. Still, whether this is the subtype N1 that had been\ntransmitted to humans and killed 50 people in Asia is yet to\nbe proved.\nThe samples will be sent for analysis to expert laboratories\nin the UK, whose confirmation is expected in a few days. The\nlab tests sent to UK will clearly indicate whether the virus\nsuspected in Romania is the same as the one detected in\nAsia, and also if it is highly or slightly pathogenic. [The\ncontinued confusion about the fate of the said samples and\nthe test results is puzzling. A Romanian statement of 8 Oct\n2005 said that samples were sent by them to the EU/OIE\nReference laboratory in Weybridge; this was refuted by the\nlaboratory, who stated that their experts were due to arrive\nin Romania on Tue, 12 Oct 2005, to take samples. On 13 Oct\n2005, several hours after a Romanian newswire saying that\nthe samples were found negative by EU experts, the EU\nCommission officially announced that 'its experts had\ndetected the H5 virus strain in 2 samples taken in a\nsuspected backyard farm in the Danube delta, while further\ntests were necessary to ascertain if the virus in question\nis the H5N1 strain'. In addition, a statement of Defra,\ndated 13 Oct 2005, said that 'results from further tests to\nfind out the exact strain of (the Romanian H5) virus will be\navailable in a few days'; see\n<http://www.defra.gov.uk/news/latest/2005/animal-1013.htm>.\nClarification will help. - Mod.AS]\nAgriculture Minister Gheorghe Flutur said that measures had\nbeen taken to completely isolate the village in Tulcea\nCounty, and that European officials have also been informed\nthat the virus had been confirmed.\nThe bird flu does not spread by human contact, and it is\ncaught only through direct contact with infected birds.\nDoctors assure that the virus only passes from contaminated\nanimals to humans and not from human to human, but they are\nwarning about the danger of the emergence of a crossbred\nvirus between bird flu and a human influenza virus.\nMeanwhile, birds continue being slaughtered in the area of\nCeamurlia de Jos, with local authorities asking for more\nstaff to take care of the action. 'All the birds at\nCeamurlia de Jos and within a radius of 3 kilometres around\nthe village are being slaughtered,' said the Agriculture\nminister. Authorities in Tulcea requested the sending in the\narea of expert chemical weapons troops, to avoid\nveterinarians from becoming overworked, and to allow bird\nslaughtering to continue at a fast pace.\nMeanwhile, neighbouring counties stepped up the safety\nmeasures. Teams made up of border police and representatives\nof the Braila Veterinary Department (DSV) beefed up the road\nblocks at the Bac Smardan crossing point that connects the\ncounty to the neighbouring county of Tulcea. All the\nvehicles crossing the Danube and entering the municipality\nthrough that point are inspected and disinfected with a\nspecial pump installed at the Bac crossing point.\nAlso, all ship captains received written advisories against\ntransporting birds and animals from Tulcea. Similar safety\nmeasures have also been taken at the Small Island of Braila\nCounty, which is on the list of places with a high risk of\navian flu, given its opening to the Danube and the large\nnumber of migratory birds that take shelter here each year.\nAuthorities in Constanta have also been on alert in the\nnorthern part of the Constanta County, at the border with\nthe Tulcea County, where they are conducting preventive,\ndisinfection, and control measures. The dead body of a\npelican was found on Wednesday night on a field between\nMangalia and Albesti. Given the bird's advanced state of\ndecomposition, no samples have been taken. There are also\nsignals that hundreds of birds had died in the village of\nSilistea over the past few weeks, yet the deaths went\nunreported.\nAnswering a request for medicines by Romania's Health\nMinister, Eugen Nicolaescu, the representatives of the World\nHealth Organisation (WHO) agreed to supply, at no charge,\n1000 of the 5000 doses of antiviral medicines the government\nneeds for the preventive treatment of the population that\ncame into contact with the identified focus of avian flu.\nA special commission was set up at the Health Ministry on\nThursday. The chairmen of the Ministry's expert commissions\nfor infectious diseases and epidemiology respectively, have\nalso been convened. During the next few days, the Health\nMinistry will be made available 25 000 doses of antiviral\nmedicine. In about 10 days, the ministry emergency stock\nwill be supplemented by another 20 000 doses.\nHealth minister Eugen Nicolaescu said that aside from the\nprotection offered by the ministry, 'citizens need to know 3\nbasic things: firstly, to wash their hands with water and\nsoap, secondly, to only purchase poultry and egg from\nauthorised sources, namely veterinary-certified stores, and\nthirdly, to keep away from dead birds or birds that had come\nin contact with dead birds'.\nThe National Audiovisual Council (CNA) requested the radio\nand TV channels to avoid speculations over the bird flu, and\ngive priority to the official information, in order to avoid\nalarming the population. CNA requests the radio companies to\nnot enhance the concern of the people and the speculations,\nto show responsibility and to use insomuch as possible the\nopinion of the specialists in their programmes. CNA recalls\nthat mass media have the obligation to check the information\nfrom their own sources and from occasional collaborators,\ncomparing it with the data furnished by the competent\nauthorities, before transmitting news or points of view\nwhich can generate panic.\n[byline: Alina Grigore]\n******\n[2]\nDate: Fri, 14 Oct 2005\nFrom: Mary Marshall <tropical.forestry@btinternet.com>\nSource: BBC News, 14 Oct 2005 [edited]\n<http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/health/4341894.stm>\n\n9 people are under medical observation in Turkey after\nreports of 40 pigeons in their neighbourhood died in\nmysterious circumstances. All 9 are from Manisa, which is\nclose to the village where the fatal H5N1 strain of bird flu\nwas identified this week. The 9 are being monitored as 'a\nprecaution', officials said.\nThe news comes as EU veterinary officers begin an emergency\nmeeting to discuss measures to contain bird flu.\nThe H5N1 strain of avian flu has killed more than 60 people\nin South East Asia since 2003. Those who have been in the\npresence of dead or dying birds are most likely to become\ninfected, and the chances of human-to-human transmission are\nstill seen as very slim.\nIn Turkey, around 8600 birds were culled this week in and\naround the village of Kiziksa, in the neighbouring province\nto Manisa.\nThe Anatolia news agency reported samples from the dead\npigeons have been sent for testing in Izmir, western Turkey.\nThere have been several other reports of unexplained bird\ndeaths in the country, but except for those in Kiziksa, none\nhas been confirmed as bird flu.\nOsman Ozturk, deputy head of the Manisa health department,\nsaid: 'There is no sign of illness in the 9 people.' He said\nthey were put under medical observation simply as a\nprecaution while their house was being disinfected.\nScientists fear that the bird flu virus could mutate into a\nhuman pandemic strain if people suffering normal human flu\nare also infected with the H5N1 type.\nEuropean Union health commissioner Markos Kyprianou\nconfirmed on Thursday that the virus found in the Turkish\nvillage of Kiziksa was the deadly strain, adding: 'There is\na direct relationship with viruses found in Russia,\nMongolia, and China.' He went on: 'It is a highly pathogenic\nand aggressive virus and we in the European Union have to\ndeal with that.'\nThe EU veterinary officers meeting in Brussels will look at\nmeasures to try to reduce the chance of contact between wild\nbirds and poultry in high-risk areas, which could include\nrequiring some poultry to be kept inside.\nA separate EU meeting of bird flu experts is expected to\nissue advice on the potential risk for humans who come into\ncontact with migratory birds.\nEU foreign ministers are also to hold emergency talks on the\nbird flu threat on Tuesday [18 Oct 2005] when they meet in\nLuxembourg for WTO negotiations.\nTurkish authorities have urged calm, amid reports of people\nflocking to pharmacies to buy Tamiflu (oseltamivir), the\nantiviral believed to be most effective against bird flu.\nHealth minister Recep Akdag said the situation was 'under\ncontrol', adding that Ankara was prepared for any possible\nflu pandemic. Pharmacies in Romania have also reported a big\nsurge in demand for vaccines against common flu.\nThe EU moved to ban all bird and poultry products from\nRomania on Thursday after tests on 3 ducks which died last\nweek in the Danube delta confirmed the presence of the H5\nstrain of bird flu. Tests for the H5N1 strain are expected\nto be completed on the ducks on Friday. The EU has also\nbanned the import of live birds and feathers from Turkey\nuntil April 2006.\nThe H5N1 strain remained largely in South-East Asia until\nthis summer, when Russia and Kazakhstan both reported\noutbreaks. Scientists fear it may be carried by migrating\nbirds to Europe and Africa but say it is hard to prove a\ndirect link with bird migration\n******\n[3]\nDate: Fri, 14 Oct 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: BBC News, 14 Oct 2005 [edited]\n<http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/health/4341496.stm>\n\nPeople should not panic after the discovery of a deadly form\nof avian flu among birds in Turkey, the UK government has\nsaid. The Department of Health stressed its advice on who\nshould be vaccinated against flu was unchanged. It said\nvulnerable groups, such as the elderly and some children, to\nhave the seasonal flu jab as normal. EU veterinary officers\nare holding an emergency meeting in Brussels to discuss\nmeasures to contain bird flu.\nPeople in the UK with weak immune systems, such as children\nwith asthma or diabetes, have long been advised to have an\nannual jab to protect them against flu. 'I don't think, at\nthis stage, the public should feel they are under a\ndifferent threat than before,' said Dr David Salisbury, head\nof immunisation at the Department of Health.\nSince the H5N1 strain of bird flu, which has killed 60\npeople in South East Asia, was confirmed in birds in Turkey\non Thu, 13 Oct 2005, concern has risen about the UK's plans\nto contain any outbreak here.\nNews of the outbreak in north west Turkey came after avian\nflu was also confirmed in ducks in Romania. The EU said\nthose cases were assumed to be the same strain. Samples of\nthe dead birds were sent from Turkey and Romania to the UK\nfor laboratory analysis.\nDavid Salisbury, head of immunisation at the Department of\nHealth, told BBC News that people in identified groups,\nincluding the elderly, children with conditions such as\ndiabetes or asthma, and others who had weakened immune\nsystems should get the seasonal flu vaccination as normal.\nBut he added: 'The currently available vaccine is for people\nvulnerable to flu, but will not protect them against an\nemerging pandemic strain.'\nThe government orders around 14 million doses of flu vaccine\nfor the annual vaccination campaign again seasonal\ninfluenza. But Dr Salisbury said experts were planning for\nthe eventuality of bird flu mutating to spread between\nhumans. 'The risk is very real, we're very aware of what's\nhappening in South East Asia and are monitoring very\ncarefully the spread of disease amongst birds. We're\nwatching very carefully for cases in humans, and the\npresence of bird disease in Europe of course raises\neverybody's anxieties.'\nDr Salisbury said the UK public should not feel the dangers\nfrom bird flu had increased, following the emergence of bird\nflu in Turkey. 'I don't think, at this stage, the public\nshould feel they are under a different threat than before.'\nBut he said the developments in Turkey would be considered\nin UK preparations. He said developing a vaccine would take\n3-5 months, and could only be undertaken once the strain of\nany virus causing a pandemic was identified.\nThis time delay was the reason the UK was stockpiling\nantiviral drugs to treat symptoms if they emerged, Dr\nSalisbury said. The government has ordered 14.6 million\ndoses of the antiviral drug Tamiflu. This would be enough\nfor 25 per cent of the population -- the proportion the\nWorld Health Organization predicts would be affected in a\npandemic. 'Normal' flu affects 5-10 per cent of the\npopulation.\nThe UK government said plans were also in place to contain\nthe spread of avian flu among wild and domestic birds. But\nthe National Farmers' Union has expressed concern that\npublic fears over the virus could damage chicken and poultry\nsales -- even though the virus cannot be passed on through\neating chicken.\nMeanwhile EU specialists are meeting to discuss new measures\nto stop bird flu spreading in Europe after the outbreaks in\nTurkey. The European Commission has already banned the\nimport of live birds, poultry and feathers from Romania.\nEU veterinary officers are also holding emergency meetings\nto explore measures to reduce the chance of contact between\npoultry and wild birds in high risk areas.\n******\n[4]\nDate: Fri, 14 Oct 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Surfbirds news, 14 Oct 2005 [edited]\n<http://www.surfbirds.com/sbirdsnews/archives/2005/10/avian_influenza.html>\n\nOver the last few weeks, many birdwatchers will have become\naware of considerable media interest in the subject of avian\ninfluenza or 'bird flu', following outbreaks in central Asia\nand the Black Sea region of the highly pathogenic type of\nthe H5N1 virus strain which developed within poultry.\nRepresentatives of BTO (British Trust for Ornithology), WWT\n(Wildfowl and Wetlands Trust), RSPB (Royal Society for the\nProtection of Birds), and JNCC (The Joint Nature\nConservation Committee = UK Government's wildlife adviser)\nhave been involved in discussions with the relevant\ngovernment agencies, principally to advise on the latest\nknowledge of the origins of birds wintering in the UK,\nmigration routes and timing, and bird distributions within\nthe UK. Such information is derived in large part from the\nhard work of volunteers working on schemes such as the BTO\nRinging Scheme and the BTO/WWT/RSPB/JNCC Wetland Bird Survey\n(WeBS). We have also remained in close contact with\ninternational colleagues.\nThe overall assessment is that the chance of this strain of\nthe virus being carried to the UK by a migrating bird is\ncurrently low (and perhaps much less than the chance of\ntransmission via illegally imported poultry). In addition,\neven if the highly pathogenic form of H5N1 avian influenza\ndid make it to the UK, it is important to note that there\nare no known cases of transmission from wild birds to\nhumans. In South East Asia, the virus has spread\n(infrequently) to humans as a result of people coming into\nclose contact with infected poultry within the context of\nthe confined proximities of poultry farms. Thus, the risk to\nhuman health from wild birds carrying avian influenza would\ncurrently appear to be very low.\nNevertheless, it is clearly sensible to keep the situation\nunder review. A number of organisations are working together\nto deliver a national surveillance programme for wild birds\non behalf of Defra; for further details see\n<http://www.defra.gov.uk/animalh/diseases/notifiable/disease/ai/index.htm>.\nThis will include enhanced monitoring for sick or dead\nbirds, coupled with a programme of taking faecal samples\nfrom a) apparently healthy live birds, and b) birds shot as\npart of legal wildfowling activities. As part of this\nprocess, we would ask birdwatchers in the field to keep an\neye out for any suspicious cases of large-scale mortality or\nsickness among wild birds.\nWaterbirds are potentially among the most vulnerable wild\nbirds. Obviously, all birdwatchers encounter dead birds\noccasionally, almost all due to perfectly natural causes, so\nuse your common sense. However, if you should come across an\nincident that seems out of the ordinary, this should be\nreported via the Defra Helpline on 08459 335577. Calls would\nthen be referred to more local laboratories. Specialists at\nthe labs would then make an assessment on what further\naction, if any, should be taken.\nAlthough there have been no proven cases of humans catching\nthe disease from wild birds, the virus is spread through\nnasal secretions and faeces, so please do not touch sick\nbirds or carcasses in the event of a suspicious die-off.\nNote that separate guidelines have been provided to ringers\nand these will be made available to anyone else who\nregularly handles wild birds. In general, however, to guard\nagainst a wide variety of illness including avian influenza\nit is always prudent to exercise basic hygiene (such as\nwashing hands with soap, especially before eating) when\ncoming into close contact with wild animals.\nAt a time when there is a lot of misinformation circulating\non this issue, it is essential to keep matters in\nperspective and to sift fact from fiction. We reiterate\nthat, to the best of our current knowledge, we consider the\nchance of wild birds bringing highly pathogenic H5N1 to the\nUK to be low and the potential for onward transmission from\nwild birds to people to be very low. Obviously, however, we\nare continuing to monitor the situation and if there are any\nfurther developments we will communicate these widely, in\nthe first instance via organisational websites.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[The advice to birdwatchers provided in the common statement\nof the 4 British ornithology-related organisations, includes\ninformation and instructions which are currently useful for\nbirdwatchers anywhere. They are applicable in the many other\ncountries -- particularly in Europe and the Middle East --\nwhich have recently intensified the surveillance in wild and\nmigrating birds. This has become particularly important in\nview of the following new OIE press release. - Mod.AS]\n******\n[5]\nDate: Fri, 14 Oct 2005\nFrom: Maria Zampaglione, Communication Department, OIE\n<m.zampaglione@oie.int>\nSource: OIE press release, 14 Oct 2005 [edited]\n\nAt the request of the Russian authorities the World\nOrganisation for Animal Health sent a team of worldwide\nrenowned experts in avian influenza and ornithology to\nSiberia in order to assess the avian influenza situation in\nthe region (see OIE press release of 4 Oct 2005].\nThe complete Mission Report of this scientific mission will\nbe available online in the Highlights of the OIE website\nthis afternoon(<http://www.oie.int>).\nOne of the main conclusions of the report is that in certain\nconditions migratory birds could carry the Asian H5N1\ninfluenza virus to other parts of the world. The migratory\nroutes of these potentially infected wild birds are mainly\ndirected to the Caspian Sea, the Middle East, and Africa. A\nnumber of these birds could rest during the migration or\nmigrate to western Europe.\nFacing the current and potential evolution of the Avian\ninfluenza spread, the OIE confirms its position about the\npriority of eliminating the virus at the animal source,\nemphasizing the importance of the early detection and rapid\nresponse mechanisms carried out by Veterinary Services in\ncountries at risk.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[The Mission's report (29 pages) has become available in the\nmeantime; see\n<http://oie.int/downld/Missions/2005/ReportRussia2005Final2.pdf>.\n- Mod.AS]", "summary": "On 13 Oct\n2005, several hours after a Romanian newswire saying that\nthe samples were found negative by EU experts, the EU\nCommission officially announced that 'its experts had\ndetected the H5 virus strain in 2 samples taken in a\nsuspected backyard farm in the Danube delta, while further\ntests were necessary to ascertain if the virus in question\nis the H5N1 strain'. (Wildfowl and Wetlands Trust), RSPB (Royal Society for the\nProtection of Birds), and JNCC (The Joint Nature\nConservation Committee = UK Government's wildlife adviser)\nhave been involved in discussions with the relevant\ngovernment agencies, principally to advise on the latest\nknowledge of the origins of birds wintering in the UK,\nmigration routes and timing, and bird distributions within\nthe UK. Health minister Eugen Nicolaescu said that aside from the\nprotection offered by the ministry, 'citizens need to know 3\nbasic things: firstly, to wash their hands with water and\nsoap, secondly, to only purchase poultry and egg from\nauthorised sources, namely veterinary-certified stores, and\nthirdly, to keep away from dead birds or birds that had come\nin contact with dead birds'. Facing the current and potential evolution of the Avian\ninfluenza spread, the OIE confirms its position about the\npriority of eliminating the virus at the animal source,\nemphasizing the importance of the early detection and rapid\nresponse mechanisms carried out by Veterinary Services in\ncountries at risk.\n CNA recalls\nthat mass media have the obligation to check the information\nfrom their own sources and from occasional collaborators,\ncomparing it with the data furnished by the competent\nauthorities, before transmitting news or points of view\nwhich can generate panic.\n Source: Surfbirds news, 14 Oct 2005 [edited]\n<http://www.surfbirds.com/sbirdsnews/archives/2005/10/avian_influenza.html>\n\nOver the last few weeks, many birdwatchers will have become\naware of considerable media interest in the subject of avian\ninfluenza or 'bird flu', following outbreaks in central Asia\nand the Black Sea region of the highly pathogenic type of\nthe H5N1 virus strain which developed within poultry. Answering a request for medicines by Romania's Health\nMinister, Eugen Nicolaescu, the representatives of the World\nHealth Organisation (WHO) agreed to supply, at no charge,\n1000 of the 5000 doses of antiviral medicines the government\nneeds for the preventive treatment of the population that\ncame into contact with the identified focus of avian flu. \nDavid Salisbury, head of immunisation at the Department of\nHealth, told BBC News that people in identified groups,\nincluding the elderly, children with conditions such as\ndiabetes or asthma, and others who had weakened immune\nsystems should get the seasonal flu vaccination as normal. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n We reiterate\nthat, to the best of our current knowledge, we consider the\nchance of wild birds bringing highly pathogenic H5N1 to the\nUK to be low and the potential for onward transmission from\nwild birds to people to be very low. Given that the virus emerged in a small locality, where\nlocals do not buy birds from outside their community,\nchances of the disease spreading are smaller compared with\nwhat would be in a similar case in western Europe,' says\nDanish expert Jorgen Westergaard. [The advice to birdwatchers provided in the common statement\nof the 4 British ornithology-related organisations, includes\ninformation and instructions which are currently useful for\nbirdwatchers anywhere. He said developing a vaccine would take\n3-5 months, and could only be undertaken once the strain of\nany virus causing a pandemic was identified.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2006-04-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2003-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-30 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2005-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Constanta County", "country": "Romania"}, {"location": "Luxembourg", "country": "Luxembourg"}, {"location": "Brussels", "country": "Belgium"}, {"location": "the Tulcea County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Manisa", "country": "Turkey"}, {"location": "Kiziksa", "country": "Turkey"}, {"location": "Kazakhstan", "country": "Kazakhstan"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ankara", "country": "Turkey"}, {"location": "Tulcea \n County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ceamurlia", "country": "Romania"}, {"location": "Turkey", "country": "Turkey"}, {"location": "Tulcea County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tulcea", "country": "Romania"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Romania", "country": "Romania"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1179", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza - Asia (13): Russia (Siberia, Urals), H5N1", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1179", "date": "2005-08-30 23:50:00", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA - ASIA (13): RUSSIA (SIBERIA, URALS), H5N1\n**********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nDrug Resistance Updates\n<http://intl.elsevierhealth.com/journals/drup>\n\n[1]\nDate: Tue, 30 Aug 2005\nFrom: Christian Griot <christian.griot@ivi.admin.ch>\nSource: Itar Tass, 30 Aug 2005 [edited]\n<http://www.tass.ru/eng/level2.html?NewsID=2362151&PageNum=0>\n\nBird flu has been confirmed in 46 Russian settlements and suspected in another\n80, the Rosselkhoznadzor Federal Service for Veterinary and Phytosanitary\nInspection reported as of 29 Aug 2005.\nVeterinary services lifted quarantine from 3 settlements.\nThe Novosibirsk region reported 2 new settlements where bird flu infection is\nsuspected and a new suspected settlement in the Omsk region.\nIn the Tyumen region, quarantine was lifted from 2 settlements in 2 districts.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[2]\nDate: Tue, 30 Aug 2005\nFrom: Nati Elkin <nati@poultrymed.com>\nSource: RIA Novosti, 30 Aug 2005 [edited]\n<http://en.rian.ru/russia/20050830/41252682.html>\n\nBird flu has hit another district in the Tyumen region [in Russia's official\nreports to the OIE, the spelling is Tiumen] in the Urals, the region's chief\nveterinarian Sergei Derkach said. 57 infected birds were slaughtered in the\nvillage of Sladkovo, Derkach said, adding that measures were being taken to\nstop the spread of the disease.\nThe first cases of death were reported in the region on 26 Jul 2005.\nQuarantine was imposed on 1 Aug 2005 when lab tests conducted in Novosibirsk,\na large Siberian city, confirmed bird flu. About 30 500 infected birds have\nbeen slaughtered in the region so far.\nBird flu was earlier reported in 7 settlements in the region's 3 districts.\nRegional authorities have allocated 6.2 million rubles (about USD 218 000) to\ncurb the spread of the virus.\n[Byline: Alexander Perestoronin]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Sladkovo (Latitude: 55:31:39N, Longitude: 70:20:09E) is situated in\nTyumensky, one of the 22 districts within Tyumen Oblast. The previous 3 AI-\naffected districts in Tyumen are Berdyuzh, Armizonskoye, and Kazanskoye (as\nnotified in Russia's follow-up report No.2 to the OIE, ProMED archive\n20050822.2475). A map can be accessed at\n<http://www.oie.int/cartes/RUS050826.jpg>.\nTyumen Oblast is a regional subdivision within the Urals -- one of Russia's 7\nfederal districts. Novosibirsk and Omsk oblasts are situated within the more\neasterly Siberian Federal District. - Mod.AS]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Source: RIA Novosti, 30 Aug 2005 [edited]\n<http://en.rian.ru/russia/20050830/41252682.html>\n\nBird flu has hit another district in the Tyumen region [in Russia's official\nreports to the OIE, the spelling is Tiumen] in the Urals, the region's chief\nveterinarian Sergei Derkach said. [Byline: Alexander Perestoronin]\n--\nProMED-mail\n< Sponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nDrug Resistance Updates\n<http://intl.elsevierhealth.com/journals/drup>\n\n[1]\n 57 infected birds were slaughtered in the\nvillage of Sladkovo, Derkach said, adding that measures were being taken to\nstop the spread of the disease. ASIA (13): RUSSIA (SIBERIA, URALS), H5N1\n**********************************************************\n promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n The Novosibirsk region reported 2 new settlements where bird flu infection is\nsuspected and a new suspected settlement in the Omsk region.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2005-08-29 00:00:00", "2005-08-01 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Sladkovo", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Novosibirsk", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "URALS", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1156", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza - Asia (04): EU update, H5N1", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1156", "date": "2005-08-18 23:50:00", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA - ASIA (04): EU UPDATE, H5N1\n****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nTravel Medicine and Infectious Disease\n<http://www.travelmedicine.elsevier.com>\n[1]\nDate: Thu, 18 Aug 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Ria Novosti, 17 Aug 2005 [edited]\n<http://en.rian.ru/russia/20050817/41175461.html>\n\nBird flu spreads from Western Siberia to South Urals\n--------------------------------------------------\nAbout 113 000 birds have died as a result of bird flu spreading in Russia,\nthe Agriculture Ministry said Wednesday [17 Aug 2005].\nThe ministry's press release cites specific figures in 6 regions of Western\nSiberia and South Urals hit by the disease.\n'According to the Federal Service for Veterinary and Phytosanitary\nSupervision, some 11 100 birds have died in the region's 13 districts,' the\npress release said.\nLab tests confirmed the disease in 6 populated areas of the Altai\nterritory, and the disease is suspected to have spread to another 12\npopulated areas in the region.\nThe veterinary service said the bird flu hit 6 areas in the Tyumen region,\nkilling 18 100 birds.\nIn the Omsk region, the disease was discovered in 6 populated areas, where\nsome 6000 birds have been killed. Over 5000 birds were killed in the Kurgan\nregion, with the disease confirmed in 6 settlements and suspected in 12\nothers. In the Chelyabinsk region, 2 populated areas have been hit by the\nbird flu and nearly 500 birds killed.\nThe veterinary service said bird flu had been confirmed in 15 settlements\nin the Novosibirsk region, with another 25 suspected. 'Some 70 000 birds\nhave been killed in 10 areas,' the press release said.\nThe veterinary service said bird flu had been confirmed in Russia's 35\npopulated areas, with another 69 suspected.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[2]\nDate: Thu, 18 Aug 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Eurosurveillance weekly report, Vol 10 (8), 18 Aug 2005 [edited]\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ew/2005/050818.asp#1>\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza reported to be spreading into western Russia\n--------------------------------------------------\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) seems to have spread westward in\nRussian bird populations. Authorities are reporting new outbreaks of\ninfections in birds at 15 poultry farms around the city of Chelyabinsk,\nimmediately east of the Ural mountains [1]. Preliminary results of\npolymerase chain reaction testing have indicated that this is type A/H5N1,\nwhich has also recently caused outbreaks in birds in South-East and Central\nAsia, and Siberia [2].\nThese preliminary results have yet to be confirmed by an international\nreference laboratory. Russian authorities are reported to be monitoring the\nhuman situation by daily home visits in the affected villages.\nAn avian influenza outbreak caused by another HPAI virus type, A/H7N7,\noccurred in 2003 in the Netherlands, with 89 PCR-confirmed human cases in\npeople who had close contact with infected poultry or with poultry workers\n[3,4,5]. The A/H7N7 virus is considerably less pathogenic for humans than\nA/H5N1. Because of the threat of spread of the A/H5N1 virus by wild birds\non their east-west migrating routes to the Netherlands [6], on 16 August,\nthe Dutch Ministry of Agriculture, Nature and Food Quality advised\ncommercial poultry farmers to keep poultry indoors at least until the\nbeginning of 2006 [7]. This measure is designed to prevent contact between\nfarmed birds and migratory birds which could be carrying A/H5N1.\nAlthough EU Member States are strengthening their preparedness for a\npotential human influenza pandemic, preparedness for outbreaks on poultry\nfarms also needs to be improved. Plans should include measures to protect\nindividuals involved in the direct management of any HPAI outbreaks and\nminimise the risk for viral reassortment in humans and other animals [8],\ndrawing on the experiences of controlling the Asian outbreaks by the Food\nand Agriculture Organization\n<http://www.fao.int>),\nOrganisation Mondiale de la Sante Animale (OIE,\n<http://www.oie.int>)\nand the World Health Organization\n(<http://www.who.int>) [9,10].\nEffective preparedness and timely control of such outbreaks relies on a\nclose collaboration between public health and veterinary sectors. Some\nEuropean countries have or are developing integrated plans for the event of\nA/H5N1 occurring in EU poultry flocks.\nReferences:\nRussian Federal Agency for Surveillance in the Field of Consumer Rights and\nHuman Welfare, 16 Aug 2005 (in Russian)\n(<http://www.gsen.ru/hotline/index.html#16082005>\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza reported in Russian bird populations.\nEurosurveillance 2005; 10 (8): 11/8/2005.\n(<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ew/2005/050811.asp#2>)\nFouchier RAM, Schneeberger PM, Rozendaal FW, Broekman JM, Kemink SAG,\nMunster V, et al. Avian influenza A virus (H7N7) associated with human\nconjunctivitis and a fatal case of acute respiratory distress syndrome;\nProc Natl Acad Sci 2004; 101(5); 1356-1361.\nKoopmans M, Wilbrink B, Conyn M, Natrop G, van der Nat H, Vennema H, et al.\nTransmission of H7N7 avian influenza A virus to human beings during a large\noutbreak in commercial poultry farms in the Netherlands. Lancet 2004;\n363(9409):587-93.\nAvian Flu Epidemic 2003: Public health consequences. 2004, RIVM rapport\n630940004,\n(<http://www.rivm.nl/bibliotheek/rapporten/630940004.html>)\nMunster VJ, Wallensten A, Baas C, Rimmelzwaan GF, Schutten M, Olsen B, et\nal.
