Asia (12): Viet Nam, civets, H5N1", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1172", "date": "2005-08-26 23:50:00", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA - ASIA (12): VIET NAM, CIVETS, H5N1\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nInternational Journal of Antimicrobial Agents\n<http://intl.elsevierhealth.com/journals/ijaa>\n\nDate: Fri 26 Aug 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Associated Press via Globe and Mail, Toronto, 26 Aug 2005 [edited]\n<http://www.theglobeandmail.com/servlet/story/RTGAM.20050826.wbirdflu0826/BNStory/International/>\n\nBird flu spreads to new species\n-----------------------------------\nBird flu has killed 3 rare civets born in captivity at a national park in\nViet Nam, marking the 1st time the virus has been reported in the species,\nofficials said on Friday [26 Aug 2005].\nThe Owston civets died in late June 2005 at the Cuc Phuong National Park,\nabout 120 km south of Hanoi. Samples sent to a lab in Hong Kong came back\npositive for the H5N1 virus, said Scott Roberton, technical adviser for the\ncivet conservation program at the park.\nHe said other animals at the park have been tested -- including chickens,\nrats and other birds -- but none have tested positive for the virus.\n'It's another good example of how dangerous this thing is,' Mr. Roberton\nsaid. 'No animals are ill, no people are ill. We're still trying to figure\nout where the source was. The civets were not fed any type of poultry, and\n20 other civets of the same species in adjacent cages did not become sick',\nhe said. 'The World Health Organization and Viet Nam health officials are\nexpected to test staff and animal keepers to determine [whether] anyone\ncaring for the civets has been infected with bird flu,' he said.\nAnton Rychener, head of the UN Food and Agriculture Organization and the\nWorld Organization for Animal Health in Hanoi, confirmed the results.\nCat-like civets are captured in the wild and served as a delicacy at\nrestaurants in Viet Nam and China.\nScientists suspect that SARS, or Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome, which\nkilled nearly 800 people worldwide in 2003, was passed to humans from civet\ncats and other mongoose-like animals sold in live food markets in southern\nChina.\nPeter Horby, an epidemiologist for the WHO in Hanoi, said the development\nwould not make people more susceptible to bird flu, because humans have\nless contact with civets than [with] poultry. 'The interesting thing is\nthat it's a new species,' he said. 'It continues to surprise.'\nBird flu had previously been found in other mammals, such as cats and tigers.\nThe virus has killed 61 people region-wide, with the bulk of those deaths\nin Viet Nam. Health experts have repeatedly warned that the world is due\nfor an influenza pandemic that could kill millions and cripple economies.\nThey fear the bird flu virus will mutate and become easily transmitted from\nperson to person. So far, most human cases have been traced back to contact\nwith poultry.\nOwston civets are globally threatened and found in southern China, Viet Nam\nand Laos.\n[Similar items have been sent by Christian Griot, A-Lan Banks, Mary\nMarshall and Joe Dudley, who are cordially acknowledged].\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Owston's Banded Palm Civet (_ Chrotogale owstoni_) belongs to the family\n_Viverridae_, subfamily _Hemigalinae_, genus _Chrotogale_. The genotyping\nof the causal agent recorded in the civets, and its comparison to previous\nisolates of H5N1 strains from mammals, are expected with interest.\nStudies of H5N1 infection of pigs (mammals of particular significance in\nrelation to the epidemiology of avian influenza in respect to human health)\nusing viruses isolated in Viet Nam and Thailand have recently been\npublished (Young Ki Choi, Tien Dzung Nguyen et al. Journal of Virology,\nAugust 2005, p. 10821-10825 Vol. 79, No. 16). We are grateful to Christian\nGriot for bringing this paper to our attention. - Mod.AS]\n[This is an interesting report; but perhaps not so surprising. Other\nmembers of the order Carnivora are know to be susceptible to avian\ninfluenza viruses.\nFamily Felidae - both domestic cats (H7N7) and zoo tigers and leopards\n(H5N1) have suffered infection and the H5N1 virus was transmitted among zoo\ntigers.\nFamily Mustelidae - the ferrets, badgers, skunks, etc. Ferrets are highly\nsusceptible to influenza viruses. The first human influenza virus was\nisolated by Wilson Smith and Stuart-Harris by inoculation of patient\nmaterial into ferrets in the 1930's. Ferrets are still the animals of\nchoice for production of diagnostic antisera (e.g. see the WHO statement\n'Evolution of H5N1 Avian Influenza Viruses in Asia' by The World Health\nOrganization Global Influenza Program Surveillance Network at\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/eid/vol11no10/05-0644.htm>). - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Ferrets are still the animals of\nchoice for production of diagnostic antisera (e.g. see the WHO statement\n'Evolution of H5N1 Avian Influenza Viruses in Asia' by The World Health\nOrganization Global Influenza Program Surveillance Network at\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/eid/vol11no10/05-0644.htm>). \nBird flu has killed 3 rare civets born in captivity at a national park in\nViet Nam, marking the 1st time the virus has been reported in the species,\nofficials said on Friday [26 Aug 2005]. Scientists suspect that SARS, or Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome, which\nkilled nearly 800 people worldwide in 2003, was passed to humans from civet\ncats and other mongoose-like animals sold in live food markets in southern\n Sponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nInternational Journal of Antimicrobial Agents\n<http://intl.elsevierhealth.com/journals/ijaa>\n\nDate: Fri 26 Aug 2005\n \nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n The World Health Organization and Viet Nam health officials are\nexpected to test staff and animal keepers to determine [whether] anyone\ncaring for the civets has been infected with bird flu,' he said. Peter Horby, an epidemiologist for the WHO in Hanoi, said the development\nwould not make people more susceptible to bird flu, because humans have\nless contact with civets than [with] poultry. ' The civets were not fed any type of poultry, and\n20 other civets of the same species in adjacent cages did not become sick',\nhe said. ' Source: Associated Press via Globe and Mail, Toronto, 26 Aug 2005 [edited]\n<http://www.theglobeandmail.com/servlet/story/RTGAM.20050826.wbirdflu0826/BNStory/International/>\n\nBird flu spreads to new species\n Samples sent to a lab in Hong Kong came back\npositive for the H5N1 virus, said Scott Roberton, technical adviser for the\ncivet conservation program at the park. Family Felidae - both domestic cats (H7N7) and zoo tigers and leopards\n(H5N1) have suffered infection and the H5N1 virus was transmitted among zoo\ntigers. The genotyping\nof the causal agent recorded in the civets, and its comparison to previous\nisolates of H5N1 strains from mammals, are expected with interest. The first human influenza virus was\nisolated by Wilson Smith and Stuart-Harris by inoculation of patient\nmaterial into ferrets in the 1930's. AVIAN INFLUENZA - ASIA (12): VIET NAM, CIVETS, H5N1\n***********************************************\n Other\nmembers of the order Carnivora are know to be susceptible to avian\ninfluenza viruses. Owston civets are globally threatened and found in southern China, Viet Nam\nand Laos.\n \nusing viruses isolated in Viet Nam and Thailand have recently been\npublished (Young Ki Choi, Tien Dzung Nguyen et al. He said other animals at the park have been tested -- including chickens,\nrats and other birds -- but none have tested positive for the virus.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "sars"], "syndromes": ["acute respiratory syndrome"], "event_date": ["2021-03-26 00:00:00", "2005-08-25 00:00:00", "2003-03-25 00:00:00", "2005-03-25 00:00:00", "1930-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Thailand", "country": "Thailand"}, {"location": "Viet Nam", "country": "Vietnam"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "Hong Kong"}, {"location": "Toronto", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Hanoi", "country": "Vietnam"}, {"location": "Laos", "country": "Laos"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1171", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza - Asia (12): Russia (Siberia), H5N1", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1171", "date": "2005-08-26 23:50:00", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA - ASIA (12): RUSSIA (SIBERIA), H5N1\n****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nInternational Journal of Antimicrobial Agents\n<http://intl.elsevierhealth.com/journals/ijaa>\nDate: Fri, 26 Aug 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: EpiNorth, Official Russian press release 26 Aug 2005 [edited]\n<http://www.epinorth.org>\n\nThe sanitary-epidemiological situation in the Russian Federation 25 Aug\n2005 (Updated: 26 Aug 2005)\n---------------------------------------------------\nCases of avian influenza in humans who have been in contact with dead birds\nhave not been recorded.\nChanges in the territory covered by the epizootic have not been noted.\nOver the past 24 hours, the mass die-off of birds has ended in Omsk,\nNovosibirsk, Tyumen and Kurgan oblasts.\nIn connection with the absence of threat of infection to humans, the\nmedical observation has ended in 13 settlements.\nIn Altay Kray, a mass die-off of domestic birds has been registered for the\n1st time in the village of Khabary in the district of Khabary. A series of\nsanitary anti-epidemic measures has been implemented.\nIn Chelyabinsk oblast, deaths of some domestic [birds?] has been recorded\nagain in 2 villages.\nIn the settlements where mass die-off of birds has been registered, a\nseries of measures continues to be implemented.\nOn 25 Aug 2005, the Federal Agency for Surveillance in the Field of\nConsumer Rights and Human Welfare held a teleconference with the leaders of\nthe Territorial directorates and the Federal State Health Enterprises\nCentres for Hygiene and Epidemiology on the status of the implementation of\nthe series of preventive and antiepidemic measures in the regions suffering\nfrom the epizootic, plans for preparation for a possible influenza\npandemic, and implementation of measures for prophylaxis of influenza\nbefore the 2005-2006 season.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Russia's official follow-up report to the OIE, dated 20 Aug 2005,\nspecified 6 affected areas: Altai Territory (5 affected districts), Tiumen\nRegion (3), Omsk Region (3), Kurgan Region (6), Chelyabinsk Region\n(2) and Novosibirsk Region (4 affected districts). According to later\n(media) reports, the republics of Kalmykia and Altai were added, when a\nsingle duck shot by a huntger was reportedly found infected with a 'H5'\ninfluenza virus, without further detail. The Altai territory ('Krai') and\nAltai republic are 2 different, though neighbouring, entities. The republic\nis situated southeast of the krai (see map at\n<http://www.oie.int/cartes/RUS050729.jpg>).\nThe EU-sponsored map 'Outbreaks of avian influenza (A/H5N1) in animals and\nman reported from Asia since December 2003' was updated on 24 Aug 2005 and\ncan be seen at\n<http://www.europa.eu.int/comm/health/ph_threats/com/Influenza/ai_recent_en.htm>.\n- Mod.AS]", "summary": "On 25 Aug 2005, the Federal Agency for Surveillance in the Field of\nConsumer Rights and Human Welfare held a teleconference with the leaders of\nthe Territorial directorates and the Federal State Health Enterprises\nCentres for Hygiene and Epidemiology on the status of the implementation of\nthe series of preventive and antiepidemic measures in the regions suffering\nfrom the epizootic, plans for preparation for a possible influenza\npandemic, and implementation of measures for prophylaxis of influenza\nbefore the 2005-2006 season.\n A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Source: EpiNorth, Official Russian press release 26 Aug 2005 [edited]\n<http://www.epinorth.org>\n\nThe sanitary-epidemiological situation in the Russian Federation 25 Aug\n2005 (Updated: 26 Aug 2005)\n [Russia's official follow-up report to the OIE, dated 20 Aug 2005,\nspecified 6 affected areas: Altai Territory (5 affected districts), Tiumen\nRegion (3), Omsk Region (3), Kurgan Region (6), Chelyabinsk Region\n(2) and Novosibirsk Region (4 affected districts). The EU-sponsored map 'Outbreaks of avian influenza (A/H5N1) in animals and\nman reported from Asia since December 2003' was updated on 24 Aug 2005 and\ncan be seen at\n<http://www.europa.eu.int/comm/health/ph_threats/com/Influenza/ai_recent_en.htm>. According to later\n(media) reports, the republics of Kalmykia and Altai were added, when a\nsingle duck shot by a huntger was reportedly found infected with a 'H5'\ninfluenza virus, without further detail. Sponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nInternational Journal of Antimicrobial Agents\n<http://intl.elsevierhealth.com/journals/ijaa>\n In connection with the absence of threat of infection to humans, the\nmedical observation has ended in 13 settlements.\n AVIAN INFLUENZA - ASIA (12): RUSSIA (SIBERIA), H5N1\n****************************************************\n The republic\nis situated southeast of the krai (see map at\n<http://www.oie.int/cartes/RUS050729.jpg>).", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2005-03-25 00:00:00", "2003-12-25 00:00:00", "2005-08-20 00:00:00", "2005-08-24 00:00:00", "2005-08-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Altai", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Khabary", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Kalmykia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "the Russian Federation", "country": "Uruguay"}, {"location": "Kurgan Region", "country": "Azerbaijan"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1151", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza - Asia: Russia (Siberia), H5N1", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1151", "date": "2005-08-16 23:50:00", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA - ASIA: RUSSIA (SIBERIA), H5N1\n********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nTravel Medicine and Infectious Disease\n<http://www.travelmedicine.elsevier.com>\n[As the H5N1 avian influenza virus has spread thoughout Asia, our posts on\nnon-humans have spread to different threads for different geographical\nareas and different avian species. In order to simplify the threads we are\nstarting a new unifying thread, 'Avian influenza - Asia', which will\nencompass much of what before had been in an ever increasing number of\nthreads. - Mod.DK]\n[1]\nDate: Tue, 16 Aug 2005\nFrom: Mary Marshall <tropical.forestry@btinternet.com>\nSource: Reuters alertnews, 16 Aug 2005 [edited]\n<http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/L16296660.htm>\n\nRussia says dangerous bird flu outbreak spreads\n-----------------------------------------------\nRussia said on Tuesday [16 Aug 2005] an outbreak of bird flu in Chelyabinsk\nwas dangerous to humans, as teams of sanitary workers destroyed birds\n[domestic? wild? - see comment] in Siberia in an attempt to prevent the\nwestward spread of the deadly virus.\nThe H5N1 strain of bird flu is behind the outbreak in Chelyabinsk, a city\nin the Ural mountains, the Emergencies Ministry said in a statement.\nIt said no cases among humans have been confirmed in Russia.\n'Measures are being taken to prevent the spreading of the infection among\ndomestic birds and to exclude the possibility of the infection moving to\nhumans,' the statement added. Russia is battling to contain a bird flu\noutbreak, which top health officials say has killed more than 11 000 birds\ncountrywide and could spread westwards to Europe, the Middle East and Africa.\nThe outbreak was discovered in mid-July 2005 in Novosibirsk and has spread\nthrough Tyumen, Omsk, Kurgan, Altai and now Chelyabinsk, which is about\n1000 km (600 miles) from Novosibirsk.\nSenior agricultural officials believe the flu was brought by migrating\nbirds from Asia, where more than 50 people have died from the deadly H5N1\nstrain since 2003.\nOfficials fear that the virus could spread to Europe and Africa as tens of\nmillions of birds continue their migration to warmer climates from next\nmonth ahead of Russia's harsh winter.\nChelyabinsk lies in the Ural mountains, the geographic divide between Asia\nand Europe. Russia's top state epidemiologist, Gennady Onishchenko, said\nmigratory birds move on to warmer areas in southern Russia, Africa and\nEurope in the autumn after nesting in Siberia.\nBut the diversity of Siberia's bird species makes plotting the flight paths\nof the birds difficult, specialists in Moscow said.\n'There are about 800 different species of birds in Russia and so there are\nmany different migration flows which criss-cross Russian territory,' said\nDr. Pavel Tomkovich, a senior ornithologist at Moscow's Zoological Museum.\nHe said water fowl will leave to winter in warmer climates, flying through\nRussia's southern regions, northern Kazakhstan, the Caspian and Black seas\ntowards the Mediterranean and north Africa. That would/could take infected\nbirds through Russia's agricultural heartland in the south.\nHealth officials were meeting in Moscow on Tuesday to discuss the\nsituation, the state's consumer watchdog said.\nIn parts of Chelyabinsk, barriers were placed on roads and local officials\nimposed a ban on the sale of all poultry products, the Itar-Tass news\nagency reported. Farmers are being compensated for birds which were being\ndestroyed, the agency said.\nBird flu comes in different stains, such as H5 and H7, which have 9\ndifferent subtypes. The H5N1 subtype is highly pathogenic and can be passed\nfrom birds to humans, though there have been no cases of human-to-human\ntransmission.\n[Byline: Guy Faulconbridge; additional reporting by Maria Kiselyova]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[2]\nDate: Tue, 16 Aug 2005\nFrom: Mary Marshall <tropical.forestry@btinternet.com>\nSource: CIDRAP News, 15 Aug 2005 [edited]\n<http://www.cidrap.umn.edu/cidrap/content/influenza/avianflu/news/aug1505avian.html>\n\nAvian flu spreads westward in Russia\n-------------------------------------\nAvian influenza has cropped up in chickens near Russia's Ural Mountains,\npossibly signaling a continued westward march of the deadly H5N1 virus,\nnews services in Russia reported today.\nThe Chelyabinsk region along the southern end of the Urals is the 6th area\nin Russia to have been hit by avian flu outbreaks recently, according to\nAgence France-Presse (AFP) and Reuters. The Urals separate Siberia from\nEuropean Russia.\nA regional official said 60 chickens in the village of Oktyabrskoye died\nover the weekend, according to an online report by Mosnews.com. The report\nsaid testing had detected an H5N1 virus in the dead birds. However, the AFP\nand Reuters reports said it was not yet known if the virus was H5N1.\nOther parts of southwestern Siberia that have reported recent outbreaks of\navian flu include Novosibirsk, Altai, Omsk, Tyumen, and Kurgan, all to the\neast of Chelyabinsk, according to AFP. But the H5N1 strain has been\nidentified only in the Novosibirsk, Altai, and Omsk outbreaks, the report said.\nThe Siberian outbreaks have killed 10 896 wild and domestic birds,\naccording to an RIA Novosti news agency report quoted by AFP. Hundreds of\nthousands of birds have been culled since the 1st in the series of Russian\noutbreaks was reported in Novosibirsk on 21 Jul 2005, according to\nMosnews.com. No human cases have been reported.\nRussia's top government epidemiologist, Gennady Onischenko, warned that\nmigrating birds could spread avian flu to Russia's major agricultural\nregion and on to the Middle East and Mediterranean Sea this fall.\n'An analysis of bird migration routes has shown that the contagious A\n(H5N1) virus may spread from western Siberia to the Caspian and Black Sea\nareas this fall,' said Onischenko, as quoted by an RIA Novosti report\ntoday. 'Some birds nesting in the affected regions (the Novosibirsk and\nAltai territory) migrate to the above-mentioned areas for winter or stop\nthere on their way to Africa or Europe.'\nHe added that bird migration routes run through Azerbaijan, Iran, Iraq,\nGeorgia, Ukraine, and Mediterranean countries, raising a risk of outbreaks\nthere as well, according to the story. Onischenko made the statements in a\nletter to regional directors of the Federal Service for the Oversight of\nConsumer Protection and Welfare.\nRussia's Agriculture Ministry said all sick and infected birds in\nChelyabinsk were being destroyed, and Russian media reported that roads\nleading to the affected village were cordoned off in an effort to contain\nthe outbreak, according to Reuters.\nA Russian agricultural official said the Chelyabinsk outbreak is near a\nlake that borders the Kurgan region and Kazakhstan, where other avian flu\noutbreaks have been reported recently, according to the Mosnews.com report.\nMeanwhile, a Russian journalist named Maria Pashkova, who was hospitalized\nafter visiting an area affected by avian flu, has been tested for the\nillness, according to an RIA Novosti report today. Results of the test are\nexpected later this week.\nMosnews.com reported that Pashkova had already recovered from her illness.\n4 other Russians were hospitalized with suspected avian flu recently, but\nall 4 tested negative, the RIA Novosti story said.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[In the absence of an official OIE update since 5 Aug 2005, it is not clear\nwhat measures are currently being undertaken by the Russian authorities to\ncontrol the disease within the 5 regions (oblasts) situated west of the 1st\naffected region, Novosibirsk, and to prevent its further spread. It would\nalso help to know if virological/serological surveillance in wildfowl is\nbeing undertaken. - Mod.AS]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n [Byline: Guy Faulconbridge; additional reporting by Maria Kiselyova]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n A Russian agricultural official said the Chelyabinsk outbreak is near a\nlake that borders the Kurgan region and Kazakhstan, where other avian flu\noutbreaks have been reported recently, according to the Mosnews.com report.\n Russia's Agriculture Ministry said all sick and infected birds in\nChelyabinsk were being destroyed, and Russian media reported that roads\nleading to the affected village were cordoned off in an effort to contain\nthe outbreak, according to Reuters. An analysis of bird migration routes has shown that the contagious A\n(H5N1) virus may spread from western Siberia to the Caspian and Black Sea\nareas this fall,' said Onischenko, as quoted by an RIA Novosti report\ntoday. ' \nRussia's top government epidemiologist, Gennady Onischenko, warned that\nmigrating birds could spread avian flu to Russia's major agricultural\nregion and on to the Middle East and Mediterranean Sea this fall. Hundreds of\nthousands of birds have been culled since the 1st in the series of Russian\noutbreaks was reported in Novosibirsk on 21 Jul 2005, according to\nMosnews.com. [In the absence of an official OIE update since 5 Aug 2005, it is not clear\nwhat measures are currently being undertaken by the Russian authorities to\ncontrol the disease within the 5 regions (oblasts) situated west of the 1st\naffected region, Novosibirsk, and to prevent its further spread. \nAvian influenza has cropped up in chickens near Russia's Ural Mountains,\npossibly signaling a continued westward march of the deadly H5N1 virus,\nnews services in Russia reported today. The H5N1 subtype is highly pathogenic and can be passed\nfrom birds to humans, though there have been no cases of human-to-human\ntransmission.\n In order to simplify the threads we are\nstarting a new unifying thread, 'Avian influenza - Asia', which will\nencompass much of what before had been in an ever increasing number of\nthreads. \nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n Sponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nTravel Medicine and Infectious Disease\n<http://www.travelmedicine.elsevier.com>\n Russia said on Tuesday [16 Aug 2005] an outbreak of bird flu in Chelyabinsk\nwas dangerous to humans, as teams of sanitary workers destroyed birds\n [As the H5N1 avian influenza virus has spread thoughout Asia, our posts on\nnon-humans have spread to different threads for different geographical\nareas and different avian species. Officials fear that the virus could spread to Europe and Africa as tens of\nmillions of birds continue their migration to warmer climates from next\nmonth ahead of Russia's harsh winter. Meanwhile, a Russian journalist named Maria Pashkova, who was hospitalized\nafter visiting an area affected by avian flu, has been tested for the\nillness, according to an RIA Novosti report today. Senior agricultural officials believe the flu was brought by migrating\nbirds from Asia, where more than 50 people have died from the deadly H5N1\nstrain since 2003. \n4 other Russians were hospitalized with suspected avian flu recently, but\nall 4 tested negative, the RIA Novosti story said. The Chelyabinsk region along the southern end of the Urals is the 6th area\nin Russia to have been hit by avian flu outbreaks recently, according to\nAgence France-Presse (AFP) and Reuters. Russia's top state epidemiologist, Gennady Onishchenko, said\nmigratory birds move on to warmer areas in southern Russia, Africa and\nEurope in the autumn after nesting in Siberia. Other parts of southwestern Siberia that have reported recent outbreaks of\navian flu include Novosibirsk, Altai, Omsk, Tyumen, and Kurgan, all to the\neast of Chelyabinsk, according to AFP. Source: Reuters alertnews, 16 Aug 2005 [edited]\n<http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/L16296660.htm>\n\nRussia says dangerous bird flu outbreak spreads\n Source: CIDRAP News, 15 Aug 2005 [edited]\n<http://www.cidrap.umn.edu/cidrap/content/influenza/avianflu/news/aug1505avian.html>\n\nAvian flu spreads westward in Russia\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2003-03-25 00:00:00", "2005-08-16 00:00:00", "2005-07-21 00:00:00", "2021-03-30 00:00:00", "2005-08-05 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Ukraine", "country": "Ukraine"}, {"location": "Chelyabinsk", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Iraq", "country": "Iraq"}, {"location": "Iran", "country": "Iran"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Georgia", "country": "Georgia"}, {"location": "Altai", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Novosibirsk", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Kazakhstan", "country": "Kazakhstan"}, {"location": "Azerbaijan", "country": "Azerbaijan"}, {"location": "Moscow", "country": "Russia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1160", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza - Asia (06): Mongolia, migratory birds, H5N1", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1160", "date": "2005-08-19 23:50:00", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA - ASIA (06): MONGOLIA, MIGRATORY BIRDS, H5N1\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nTravel Medicine and Infectious Disease\n<http://www.travelmedicine.elsevier.com>\n\n[1]\nDate: Fri, 19 Aug 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource:Wildlife Conservation Society Release, 18 Aug 2005, via Mongabay com\n[edited]\n<http://news.mongabay.com/2005/0818-wcs_flu.html>http://news.mongabay.com/2005/0818-wcs_flu.html\n\nAvian flu, H5N1, identified in wild Mongolian birds\n----------------------------------------------\nThe United States Department of Agriculture (USDA) has positively\nidentified the pathogenic form of avian flu -- H5N1 -- in samples taken\nfrom birds last week in Mongolia by field veterinarians from the Wildlife\nConservation Society (WCS). It is the 1st instance of this viral strain\noccurring in wild migratory birds with no apparent contact to domestic\npoultry or waterfowl.\nPresent in Mongolia for a health survey of wild bird populations in the\nsouth and north of the country, WCS field vets Drs. William Karesh and\nMartin Gilbert responded to initial reports of the most recent avian\ninfluenza outbreak in Kovsgol Province near the Russian border from the\nMongolian Ministry of Food and Agriculture, which conducted preliminary\ntesting of birds that died at Erkhel Lake. Their finding coincided with\nconfirmations of cases of avian influenza in Russia and Kazakhstan. Karesh\nand Gilbert immediately traveled to the site with a team of Mongolian\nvirologists, veterinarians, and public health officials. Approximately 100\ndead birds were found at the site.\nThe team -- including personnel from WCS, the Mongolian National Academy of\nSciences, the Mongolian Institute of Veterinary Medicine, the State Central\nVeterinary Laboratory, Ministry of Food and Agriculture Veterinary\nDepartment, and the Ministry of Health Mongolian Center of Communicable\nDiseases with Natural Foci -- collected samples from hundreds of wild\nbirds, both live and dead including, ruddy shelduck, herring gull,\nblack-headed gull, bar-headed goose, whooper swan, and Eurasian wigeon that\nare all at risk for contracting the virus.\nRecent reports of influenza outbreaks in wild birds in China and Russia\nhave failed to put die-offs in perspective with the numbers of unaffected\nbirds, thus there was no way to assess the impact. The WCS team at Erkhel\nLake in Mongolia collected this information for the 1st time. Overall, over\n6500 apparently healthy birds of 55 species were observed on the lake. The\npercentage of sick or dead birds was miniscule according to Gilbert\nfollowing the survey, suggesting that either the virus had little effect on\nthe birds or that very few were actually infected by the bug. Early results\nsuggest that it may be the latter.\nSupported by the U.N.'s Food and Agriculture Organization (F.A.O.), the\nteam has sent the samples (774 in total) to the USDA's Poultry Research\nLaboratory in Athens, Georgia, for further testing to determine whether\nthis virus is the H5N1 strain that has killed over 50 people in Southeast\nAsia and more than 5000 wild birds in western China. As of today,\npreliminary tests from one dead whooper swan collected in Mongolia have\nshown the presence of the H5N1 strain of Avian Influenza using RT-PCR,\nwhile results from 30 live whooper swans living at the same site and also a\nnearby lake were negative for the virus. Samples collected from other live\nbirds at the 2 sites, including 60 ruddy shelducks, 24 bar-headed geese,\nand 25 black-headed gulls, were found to be negative for the virus.\nWhereas prior outbreaks in wild birds have happened either in close\nproximity to infected domestic poultry and waterfowl, or in regions where\nsuch contact could not be excluded, Mongolia's paucity of domestic poultry\nsuggests a new vector of avian flu. Finding the H5N1 strain during this\nexpedition suggests that while the highly pathogenic avian influenza can be\ncarried across long distances, the waterfowl species typically identified\nin recent outbreaks appear to be victims rather than effective carriers of\nthe disease.\nThe multidisciplinary, collaborative response to this latest outbreak\nreflects the WCS One World-One Health approach to making informed,\nmultidisciplinary decisions on global health crises that intersect human,\nwildlife, and livestock health. WCS experts are warning that to contain\nthis potential epidemic, prevention activities must include better\nmanagement practices in farms, especially those that are small and\nopen-air, where domestic poultry and waterfowl are allowed to intermingle\nwith wild birds. Officials would also need to monitor wildlife markets,\nwhere wild and domesticated species are kept in close proximity, and risk\nexposure to a wide range of pathogens.\nWildlife and health experts, including the F.A.O., maintain that\nindiscriminate culling of wild migratory bird populations would be\nineffective in preventing the spread of avian flu. 'Focusing our limited\nresources on the hubs and activities where humans, livestock, and wildlife\ncome into close contact,' says Dr. William Karesh, Director of WCS's Field\nVeterinary Program, who lead the WCS team in Mongolia, is 'the best hope\nfor successfully preventing the spread of avian flu and protecting both\npeople and animals.'\n******\n[2]\nDate: Fri, 19 Aug 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail\nSource: OIE Disease Information Disease Information 19 Aug 2005 Vol. 18 -\nNo. 33 [edited]\n<http://www.oie.int/eng/info/hebdo/AIS_57.HTM#Sec6 >\n\nAvian influenza in Mongolia in migratory birds (follow-up report No. 1) See\nalso: 12 Aug 2005\nInformation received on 18 Aug 2005 from Dr Ravdan Sanjaatogtokh, Director,\nState Veterinary Services, Ministry of Food and Agriculture, Ulaanbaatar:\nEnd of previous report period: 10 Aug 2005 (see Disease Information, 18\n[32], 253, dated 12 Aug 2005).\nEnd of this report period: 18 Aug 2005.\nSuspicious samples were sent on 15 Aug 2005 to the OIE Reference Laboratory\nfor avian influenza at Hokkaido University, Japan. The following test\nresults were received on 17 Aug 2005:\nSample reference / Bird species / Location / Influenza A virus subtype\nNo. 1 / bar-headed goose (_Anser indicus_) / Erhel lake, Huvsgel province/ H5\n[There is no sample No. 2]\nNo. 3 / whooper swan (_Cygnus cygnus_) / Erhel lake, Huvsgel province / H5\nNo. 4 / whooper swan (_Cygnus cygnus_) / Erhel lake, Huvsgel province / H5\nAnalysis of samples is still in progress.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Mongolia's emergency notification to the OIE on the observations in\nmigratory birds (see 20050813.2367) reported that the causal agent was\n'avian influenza virus type A' and that subtyping was in progress. In\ntoday's (19 Aug 2005) Mongolia's follow-up report to the OIE, the temporary\nresults of the virological investigation in 3 samples,from migratory birds\nfound dead at Erhel lake are reportedly H5. The report states that\n'Analysis of samples is still in progress'. The said results were received\non 17 Aug 2005 from the OIE Reference Laboratory for avian influenza at\nHokkaido University, Japan, to which they had been sent on 15 Aug 2005. See\nthe follow-up report at <http://www.oie.int/eng/info/hebdo/AIS_57.HTM#Sec6>.\nThe final results from the OIE reference laboratory in Japan, as well as\nthe genotyping of the identified virus strains from both investigating\nlaboratories, are anticipated with interest. - Mod. AS].\n[Given the reports above, there is a high probability this virus will turn\nout to be H5N1. This only underscores the fact that H5N1 is circulating in\nboth wild birds and domestic poultry over large areas of Central\nAsia. Moreover, the typing of the Russian H5N1 virus indicates that the\nvirus has a relatively close genetic relationship to the strain circulating\nin Southeast Asia. One potential interpretation of the mounting evidence\non the distribution of H5N1 in space and over species is that it has\nexpanded its geographic range by developing a heretofore unrecognized level\nof intensity in its relationship with migratory birds, which unfortunately\nincludes host mortality.\nCooperation of all parties involved, as seen in Mongolia, is critical in\nunderstanding the implications of the new geographic range of the\ndisease. Results of genetic typing of all isolates in all species is\ncritical and will hopefully aid in the interpretation of the molecular\nepidemiology of this newly emerged disease. - Mod.PC]", "summary": "The team -- including personnel from WCS, the Mongolian National Academy of\nSciences, the Mongolian Institute of Veterinary Medicine, the State Central\nVeterinary Laboratory, Ministry of Food and Agriculture Veterinary\nDepartment, and the Ministry of Health Mongolian Center of Communicable\nDiseases with Natural Foci -- collected samples from hundreds of wild\nbirds, both live and dead including, ruddy shelduck, herring gull,\nblack-headed gull, bar-headed goose, whooper swan, and Eurasian wigeon that\nare all at risk for contracting the virus. Field\nVeterinary Program, who lead the WCS team in Mongolia, is 'the best hope\nfor successfully preventing the spread of avian flu and protecting both\npeople and animals.'\n******\n A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n As of today,\npreliminary tests from one dead whooper swan collected in Mongolia have\nshown the presence of the H5N1 strain of Avian Influenza using RT-PCR,\nwhile results from 30 live whooper swans living at the same site and also a\nnearby lake were negative for the virus. Supported by the U.N.'s Food and Agriculture Organization (F.A.O.), the\nteam has sent the samples (774 in total) to the USDA's Poultry Research\nLaboratory in Athens, Georgia, for further testing to determine whether\nthis virus is the H5N1 strain that has killed over 50 people in Southeast\nAsia and more than 5000 wild birds in western China. WCS experts are warning that to contain\nthis potential epidemic, prevention activities must include better\nmanagement practices in farms, especially those that are small and\nopen-air, where domestic poultry and waterfowl are allowed to intermingle\nwith wild birds. William Karesh and\nMartin Gilbert responded to initial reports of the most recent avian\ninfluenza outbreak in Kovsgol Province near the Russian border from the\nMongolian Ministry of Food and Agriculture, which conducted preliminary\ntesting of birds that died at Erkhel Lake. Finding the H5N1 strain during this\nexpedition suggests that while the highly pathogenic avian influenza can be\ncarried across long distances, the waterfowl species typically identified\nin recent outbreaks appear to be victims rather than effective carriers of\nthe disease. One potential interpretation of the mounting evidence\non the distribution of H5N1 in space and over species is that it has\nexpanded its geographic range by developing a heretofore unrecognized level\nof intensity in its relationship with migratory birds, which unfortunately\nincludes host mortality. Whereas prior outbreaks in wild birds have happened either in close\nproximity to infected domestic poultry and waterfowl, or in regions where\nsuch contact could not be excluded, Mongolia's paucity of domestic poultry\nsuggests a new vector of avian flu. The\npercentage of sick or dead birds was miniscule according to Gilbert\nfollowing the survey, suggesting that either the virus had little effect on\nthe birds or that very few were actually infected by the bug. has positively\nidentified the pathogenic form of avian flu -- H5N1 -- in samples taken\nfrom birds last week in Mongolia by field veterinarians from the Wildlife\nConservation Society (WCS). The following test\nresults were received on 17 Aug 2005:\nSample reference / Bird species / Location / Influenza A virus subtype\n The multidisciplinary, collaborative response to this latest outbreak\nreflects the WCS One World-One Health approach to making informed,\nmultidisciplinary decisions on global health crises that intersect human,\nwildlife, and livestock health. Sponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nTravel Medicine and Infectious Disease\n<http://www.travelmedicine.elsevier.com>\n\n[1]\n \nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n Samples collected from other live\nbirds at the 2 sites, including 60 ruddy shelducks, 24 bar-headed geese,\nand 25 black-headed gulls, were found to be negative for the virus. Recent reports of influenza outbreaks in wild birds in China and Russia\nhave failed to put die-offs in perspective with the numbers of unaffected\nbirds, thus there was no way to assess the impact. Mongolia's follow-up report to the OIE, the temporary\nresults of the virological investigation in 3 samples,from migratory birds\nfound dead at Erhel lake are reportedly H5. [Mongolia's emergency notification to the OIE on the observations in\nmigratory birds (see 20050813.2367) reported that the causal agent was\n'avian influenza virus type A' and that subtyping was in progress. The said results were received\non 17 Aug 2005 from the OIE Reference Laboratory for avian influenza at\nHokkaido University, Japan, to which they had been sent on 15 Aug 2005. It is the 1st instance of this viral strain\noccurring in wild migratory birds with no apparent contact to domestic\npoultry or waterfowl. Wildlife and health experts, including the F.A.O., maintain that\nindiscriminate culling of wild migratory bird populations would be\nineffective in preventing the spread of avian flu. ' [edited]\n<http://news.mongabay.com/2005/0818-wcs_flu.html>http://news.mongabay.com/2005/0818-wcs_flu.html\n\nAvian flu, H5N1, identified in wild Mongolian birds\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2005-08-18 00:00:00", "2005-08-19 00:00:00", "2005-08-10 00:00:00", "2005-08-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2005-08-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "the United States Department of Agriculture", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Georgia", "country": "Georgia"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "Japan"}, {"location": "Huvsgel", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Athens", "country": "Greece"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Kazakhstan", "country": "Kazakhstan"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Mongolia", "country": "Mongolia"}, {"location": "Kovsgol Province", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1145", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza - Russia (Siberia)(13): H5N1, OIE", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1145", "date": "2005-08-13 23:50:00", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA - RUSSIA (SIBERIA)(13): H5N1, OIE\n*************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nInfectious Disease products\n<http://www.intl.elsevierhealth.com/infectiousdiseases/>\nDate: 13 Aug 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: OIE [edited]\n<http://www.oie.int/eng/info/hebdo/a_current.htm#Sec6>\n\nHighly Pathogenic Avian Influenza In Russia - Additional information\n--------------------------------------------------------------------\n[The following is a translation of additional information received by the OIE\non 5 Aug 2005 from Dr Evgueny A. Nepoklonov, Head of the Main Veterinary\nDepartment, Ministry of Agriculture and Food, Moscow, concerning 'The\nstructure of the haemagglutinin and neuraminidase genes of influenza virus\nisolates from Novosibirsk region'. This information supplements the OIE\nDisease Information Update, 5 Aug 2005, Vol. 18 - No. 31\n<http://www.oie.int/eng/info/hebdo/a_current.htm>, posted on ProMED-mail\nas 'Avian influenza - Russia (Siberia)(10): H5N1, OIE20050808.2315' - Mod.CP]\nElectrophoregrams of amplification products using PCR primers recommended by\nWHO indicated that the type A virus found in the samples of material is\nrelated to subtype H5N1. For confirmation of the PCR results, amplified cDNA\nfragments of 2 loci from the haemagglutinin gene and of a fragment of the\nneuraminidase gene were sequenced. The results of the sequencing confirmed\nthat the type A virus found in the samples of material is related to subtype\nH5N1.\nIn order to obtain additional information about the virulence of the isolates\n(by determination of the structure of the haemagglutinin cleavage site), the\nappropriate region of the genome was amplified and PCR fragments were\nsequenced. This showed that the [inferred amino acid sequence] in this region\nis PQGERRRKKR/GL, which is analogous to the sequence of the highly virulent\nvirus (HPAI) found in 3 species of migratory water birds during the epidemic\nin May/June on Qinghai Lake (People's Republic of China) (ref. 1).\nThe nucleotide sequences of the PCR fragments of 2 other regions of the\nhaemagglutinin and neuraminidase sub-units showed highest similarity with the\nnucleotide sequences of isolates from infected mountain geese and gulls at the\ntime of that epidemic.\n[The report is illustrated by sequence data of the cleavage site for an\nisolate from a turkey from the village of Suzdalka, Dovolnoye district,\nNovosibirsk region (Information provided by Vector, the State Scientific\nCentre for Virology and Biotechnology)]\nAccording to the sequence data, the cleavage site structure is practically\nidentical to that of the highly pathogenic strain of subtype H5N1 isolated in\nHong Kong in 1997.\nPhylogenetic analysis of the preliminary data on the neuraminidase structure\nshows that it is practically identical to that of the isolate from bar-headed\ngeese (_Anser indicus_) from the Qinghai Lake region (People's Republic of\nChina).\nReference:\n----------\n(1) J. Liu, H. Xiao, F. Lei. et al. Highly Pathogenic H5N1 Influenza Virus\nInfection in Migratory Birds. <http://www.sciencexpress.org>\n6 July 2005 / Page 1/ 10.1126/science.1115273\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[These sequence data reported to the OIE confirm unequivocally that the virus\nrecovered from wild aquatic birds in Siberia is a highly pathogenic avian\ninfluenza A (H5N1) virus, closely related to the strain responsible for the\ncurrent disease outbreaks throughout East Asia. These data are compatible with\nthe theory that HPAI virus is being carried northwards by migrating waterfowl.\nThe Russian scientist reported that the inferred amino acid sequence at the\ncleavage site is similar to that of the H5N1 virus isolated in Hong Kong in\n1997. If this sequence differs significantly from that of the current East\nAsian viruses, it might indicate that the virus reached Siberia by a different\nroute. This will be clarified as sequence data for this and other regions of\nthe genome accumulate. - Mod.CP]\n[Elsevier reference:\nJ. Hess, J. Pare 2005. Viruses of waterfowl. Seminars in Avian & Exotic Pet\nMedicine 13(4):176-183. <http://dx.doi.org/10.1053/j.saep.2004.04.002>]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n [The following is a translation of additional information received by the OIE\non 5 Aug 2005 from Dr Evgueny A. According to expert examination by\nthe regional branch of the Republican veterinary laboratory, antibodies\nagainst bird flu have been detected in the tested samples.\n\nQuarantine measures have been applied in Talapker village; entry and\ndeparture are strictly limited, and 678 birds have been eliminated.\n\nAccording to the Kazakhstan Emergency Ministry, 5 sanitary veterinarians\nand 2 anti-epidemic brigades are involved in the elimination of poultry.\n\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Wed 17 Aug 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: RIA Novosti, 16 Aug 2005 [edited]\n<http://en.rian.ru/business/20050816/41165367.html>\n\n\nBird flu outbreak in Kazakhstan\n-----------------------------------\nOver 100 domestic birds have died of bird flu in a village in northern\nKazakhstan, Kazakh chief veterinarian Asylbek Kozhmuratov said on Tuesday\n[16 Aug 2005].\n\nBird flu outbreaks had previously been discovered in 5 regions of northern\nand central Kazakhstan.\n\nKozhmuratov said the Kazakh Agriculture Ministry wanted to ban the fall\nhunt for wild birds, as they could potentially be infected, and to conduct\nbird vaccinations.\n\nDr. Nikola T. Belev, the president of the International Epizootic Bureau's\nRegional Commission for Europe, said that, if bird flu 'spread to Europe\nwhere there were many birds, the disaster would be equal to 2 tsunamis.'\n\nOver 9000 birds have been slaughtered in Kazakhstan to prevent the disease\nfrom spreading further.\n\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The official notifications of Kazakhstan to the OIE (last update: 9 Aug\n2005) have, so far, mentioned one affected province (oblast): Pavlodar, in\nnortheastern Kazakhstan, bordering the Russian province Novosibirsk. The\ndisease affected geese. Yesil is situated distantly west of Pavlodar. Data\non the species involved in the additional outbreaks are not available.\n\nThe Republic of Kazakhstan, in central Asia, borders on Siberian Russia in\nthe north, China in the east, Kyrgyzstan, Uzbekistan, and Turkmenistan in\nthe south, and the Caspian Sea and European Russia in the west. It is the\n9th largest country in the world: about 1 050 000 square miles (2 719 500\nsq km), almost 4 times the size of Texas, with a population (as of 1995) of\nabout 17.4 million. Kazakhstan is administratively divided into 14\nprovinces (oblasts) and 3 cities. - Mod.AS]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nSponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nTravel Medicine and Infectious Disease\n<http://www.travelmedicine.elsevier.com>\n\n[1]\n \nPoultry mortality was registered in the Yesil region, Talapker village, of\nNorth Kazakhstan oblast (province) on 12-16 Aug 2005, Kazinform has learned\nfrom the Kazakhstan Emergency Ministry. Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nInfectious Disease products\n<http://www.intl.elsevierhealth.com/infectiousdiseases/>\nDate: 12 Aug 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: OIE Disease Information 12 Aug 2005 Vol. 18 - No. 32 [edited]\n<http://www.oie.int/eng/info/hebdo/a_current.htm#Sec4>\n\nHighly Pathogenic Avian Influenza In Kazakhstan\nFollow-up report No. 1\nSee also: 5 Aug 2005\nTranslation of information received on 9 Aug 2005 from Dr Marat Mynzhanov,\nDirector, Veterinary Surveillance Department, Ministry of Agriculture, Astana:\nEnd of previous report period: 2 Aug 2005 (see Disease Information, 18 [31],\n231, dated 5 Aug 2005).\nEnd of this report period: 9 Aug 2005.\nPrecise identification of agent: influenza virus type A, subtype H5N1, highly\npathogenic.\nDate of first confirmation of the event: 29 Jul 2005.\nDate of start of the event: 22 Jul 2005.\nAdditional tests were carried out on pathological material and sera taken from\nwildfowl and poultry from the infected farm.\nLaboratories where diagnosis was made:\nPavlodar region branch of the Kazakhstan National Veterinary Laboratory\nSpecies examined: avi (geese)\nDiagnostic tests used\n- virus isolation test on different cell cultures;\n- virus isolation test on embryonated chicken eggs;\n- inoculation of pathological material into birds of different species;\n- haemagglutination inhibition test;\n- neuraminidase activity inhibition test;\n- post-mortem examination of poultry which died following inoculation of\npathological material;\n- electron microscopy examination of material after several passages;\n- real-time PCR(1), with the participation of international experts;\nScientific Research Institute for Agriculture\nSpecies examined: avi (geese)\nDiagnostic tests used\n- virus isolation test on different cell cultures;\n- virus isolation test on embryonated chicken eggs;\n- inoculation of pathological material into birds of different species;\n- haemagglutination inhibition test;\n- neuraminidase activity inhibition test;\n- post-mortem examination of poultry which died following inoculation of\npathological material;\n- electron microscopy examination of material after several passages;\n- real-time PCR(1), with the participation of international experts;\n- standard PCR.\nDate: 8 Aug 2005\nResults: positive for highly pathogenic avian influenza type A, Subtype H5N1\nControl measures undertaken:\n- control of wildlife reservoirs;\n- stamping out;\n- quarantine;\n- movement control inside the country;\n- screening;\n- zoning;\n- disinfection of infected premises/establishment.\n(1) PCR: polymerase chain reaction\n[A highly sensitive & specific assay for viral nucleic acid. The real-time\nversion, used here, produces results in a couple of hours. - Mod.JW]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[This report is based on samples taken from farmed, not wild geese*. However,\nboth this report and previous report indicate concern about wild birds as a\nsource of the virus. Given recent reports on migratory bird infection with\nH5N1 in the surrounding countries, it would not be surprising to find H5N1\nspilling over into a farm setting as this epidemiological investigation\nunfolds. - Mod.PC]\n*[Note that although the report mentions 'Additional tests were carried out on\npathological material and sera taken from wildfowl and poultry from the\ninfected farm', it says 'Species examined: avi (geese)'. It is not clear\nwhether this means that tests on other species were negative, or merely that\nthe results are not yet available. - Mod.JW]", "summary": "Diagnostic tests used\n- virus isolation test on different cell cultures;\n- virus isolation test on embryonated chicken eggs;\n- inoculation of pathological material into birds of different species;\n- haemagglutination inhibition test;\n- neuraminidase activity inhibition test;\n- post-mortem examination of poultry which died following inoculation of\npathological material;\n- electron microscopy examination of material after several passages;\n- real-time PCR(1), with the participation of international experts;\nScientific Research Institute for Agriculture\nSpecies examined: avi (geese)\n Diagnostic tests used\n- virus isolation test on different cell cultures;\n- virus isolation test on embryonated chicken eggs;\n- inoculation of pathological material into birds of different species;\n- haemagglutination inhibition test;\n- neuraminidase activity inhibition test;\n- post-mortem examination of poultry which died following inoculation of\npathological material;\n- electron microscopy examination of material after several passages;\n- real-time PCR(1), with the participation of international experts;\n- standard PCR. Additional tests were carried out on pathological material and sera taken from\nwildfowl and poultry from the infected farm.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2005-08-02 00:00:00", "2005-08-09 00:00:00", "2005-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Astana", "country": "Kazakhstan"}, {"location": "Kazakhstan", "country": "Kazakhstan"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1149", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza - Russia (Siberia)(14): H5N1", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1149", "date": "2005-08-15 23:50:00", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA - RUSSIA (SIBERIA) (14): H5N1\n*********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nTravel Medicine and Infectious Disease\n<http://www.travelmedicine.elsevier.com>\n[1]\nDate: Mon 15 Aug 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Reuters alertnet, 15 Aug 2005 [edited]\n<http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/L15292005.htm>\n\nRussia reports bird flu in 6th region\n-----------------------------------------\nA bird flu outbreak in Russia appeared to be spreading westward on Monday\n[15 Aug 2005], after officials confirmed the virus had broken out in a 6th\nregion since the epidemic struck the country in mid-July 2005.\nIt was unclear whether the virus found in the Urals region of Chelyabinsk\nwas the deadly H5N1 strain that has killed more than 50 people in Asia\nsince 2003. It has been confirmed in a number of Siberian regions and\nneighboring Kazakhstan.\nInterfax news agency quoted Andrei Gasilov, vice-governor of Chelyabinsk,\nas saying the virus had killed 60 birds in the village of Oktyabrskoye on\nthe Kazakh border since Saturday [13 Aug 2005].\nOther Russian regions hit by the flu include Novosibirsk, Tyumen, Omsk,\nKurgan and Altai.\nChelyabinsk, which borders Kurgan on the east side of the Ural mountains\ndividing Europe and Asia, is the westernmost region to have been struck so\nfar. The Emergencies Ministry in Moscow, contacted by Reuters, could not\nconfirm the Chelyabinsk outbreak.\nAlthough no humans have yet been affected, there are fears the disease\ncould spread to humans on the Eurasian landmass, possibly unleashing a\nglobal influenza pandemic.\nInterfax quoted Gasilov as saying domestic birds were being culled in the\nvillage to prevent the virus, which has killed more than 10 000 birds\ncountrywide, from spreading further.\nOfficials said wild birds, increasingly active in August as they prepare to\nmigrate to warmer regions in Europe, Asia and America, were to blame.\n'Results of epizootic checks have shown that they (migrant birds) are the\nmain source of infection,' Ria-Novosti news agency quoted an official with\nthe Novosibirsk state consumer rights watchdog as saying.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[2]\nDate: Mon 15 Aug 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Reuters, 15 Aug 2005 [edited]\n<http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/L15292005.htm>\n\nRussian bird flu outbreak advances towards Europe\n-----------------------------------------------\nRussia cordoned off roads and slaughtered hundreds of birds on Monday [15\nAug 2005] to contain the advance of a bird flu epidemic towards Western Europe.\nThe outbreak, previously confined to 5 remote areas of Siberia, has now\nstruck a major industrial region -- Chelyabinsk -- in the Ural mountains,\nwhich separate Asia from Europe. 'All ill and infected birds are being\nslaughtered there,' the Agriculture Ministry said in a statement.\nIt was unclear whether the virus found in Chelyabinsk was the deadly H5N1\nstrain that has killed more than 50 people in Asia since 2003 and has hit\nRussia's Siberia as well as neighboring Kazakhstan and Mongolia since\nmid-July 2005.\nCarried by flocks of wild birds migrating from Siberia to warmer regions,\nthe virus has been steadily moving westward through the regions of\nNovosibirsk, Tyumen, Omsk, Kurgan and Altai.\nChelyabinsk, separated from European Russia by the Ural mountains, and\ntechnically still in Siberia, is the westernmost region to have been struck\nso far. It lies about 1000 km (600 miles) from the region where the 1st flu\noutbreak was reported.\nAlthough no humans have yet been affected, there are fears the disease\ncould spread to humans on the Eurasian landmass, possibly unleashing a\nglobal influenza pandemic.\nMedia reported that roads leading to the infected village of Oktyabrskoye\nin Chelyabinsk had been cordoned off to prevent the virus from spreading\nfurther.\nIn other affected regions, police boosted road checks, and 400 domestic\nbirds were culled in Chelyabinsk alone to block the virus that has killed\nmore than 10 000 birds countrywide.\nThere was no word on Monday [15 Aug 2005] on the situation in Kazakhstan\nand Mongolia, where bird flu has also been registered along their sprawling\nborders with Russian Siberia.\n[Byline: Maria Golovnina]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[3]\nDate: Mon 15 Aug 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: RIA Novosti, 15 Aug 2005 [edited]\n<http://en.rian.ru/russia/20050815/41155526.html>\n\n2 large regions in Western Siberia hit hardest by bird flu\n-----------------------------------------------\n2 major regions in Western Siberia are conducting measures to localize bird\nflu, a regional official said on Monday [15 Aug 2005].\nMore than 18 000 head of poultry have been slaughtered in the Tyumen\nregion, where bird flu was identified in 6 populated areas, an official\nfrom the local Emergency Situations Ministry said. He added that other\nmeasures were being taken to prevent the disease from spreading, such as\nquarantining affected farms and stopping unauthorized personnel from\nentering them.\nA local official in the Altai territory said 10 regions had been hit by the\nvirus. However, he added that no new cases had been registered in 9 of the\n14 affected villages. The official said migrating birds were thought to\nhave spread the infection, and so the source would disappear when they left\nwhen cold weather arrived in fall. He said measures to eliminate the\ndisease and prevent it from spreading were continuing in the territory.\nNo cases of people falling ill with the virus have been registered.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Russia's last follow-up report to the OIE on the HPAI outbreak there was\nsent on 5 Aug 2005, notifying of cases in 3 villages in Novosibirsk. A new\nupdate is due to assess the accuracy of the media news on the alleged\nspread of the virus westwards into 5 additional regions (oblasts). - Mod.AS]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n It was unclear whether the virus found in Chelyabinsk was the deadly H5N1\nstrain that has killed more than 50 people in Asia since 2003 and has hit\nRussia's Siberia as well as neighboring Kazakhstan and Mongolia since\nmid-July 2005. He added that other\nmeasures were being taken to prevent the disease from spreading, such as\nquarantining affected farms and stopping unauthorized personnel from\nentering them. \nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n [Byline: Maria Golovnina]\n--\nProMED-mail\n< Sponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nTravel Medicine and Infectious Disease\n<http://www.travelmedicine.elsevier.com>\n -----------------------------------------------\n2 major regions in Western Siberia are conducting measures to localize bird\nflu, a regional official said on Monday [15 Aug 2005]. In other affected regions, police boosted road checks, and 400 domestic\nbirds were culled in Chelyabinsk alone to block the virus that has killed\nmore than 10 000 birds countrywide. Source: RIA Novosti, 15 Aug 2005 [edited]\n<http://en.rian.ru/russia/20050815/41155526.html>\n\n2 large regions in Western Siberia hit hardest by bird flu\n Interfax quoted Gasilov as saying domestic birds were being culled in the\nvillage to prevent the virus, which has killed more than 10 000 birds\ncountrywide, from spreading further. Source: Reuters alertnet, 15 Aug 2005 [edited]\n<http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/L15292005.htm>\n\nRussia reports bird flu in 6th region\n Interfax news agency quoted Andrei Gasilov, vice-governor of Chelyabinsk,\nas saying the virus had killed 60 birds in the village of Oktyabrskoye on\nthe Kazakh border since Saturday [13 Aug 2005]. Source: Reuters, 15 Aug 2005 [edited]\n<http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/L15292005.htm>\n\nRussian bird flu outbreak advances towards Europe\n More than 18 000 head of poultry have been slaughtered in the Tyumen\nregion, where bird flu was identified in 6 populated areas, an official\nfrom the local Emergency Situations Ministry said. Carried by flocks of wild birds migrating from Siberia to warmer regions,\nthe virus has been steadily moving westward through the regions of\nNovosibirsk, Tyumen, Omsk, Kurgan and Altai. There was no word on Monday [15 Aug 2005] on the situation in Kazakhstan\nand Mongolia, where bird flu has also been registered along their sprawling\nborders with Russian Siberia. The outbreak, previously confined to 5 remote areas of Siberia, has now\nstruck a major industrial region -- Chelyabinsk -- in the Ural mountains,\nwhich separate Asia from Europe. ' Results of epizootic checks have shown that they (migrant birds) are the\nmain source of infection,' Ria-Novosti news agency quoted an official with\nthe Novosibirsk state consumer rights watchdog as saying. A new\nupdate is due to assess the accuracy of the media news on the alleged\nspread of the virus westwards into 5 additional regions (oblasts). The official said migrating birds were thought to\nhave spread the infection, and so the source would disappear when they left\nwhen cold weather arrived in fall. It was unclear whether the virus found in the Urals region of Chelyabinsk\nwas the deadly H5N1 strain that has killed more than 50 people in Asia\nsince 2003. Although no humans have yet been affected, there are fears the disease\ncould spread to humans on the Eurasian landmass, possibly unleashing a\nglobal influenza pandemic. Although no humans have yet been affected, there are fears the disease\ncould spread to humans on the Eurasian landmass, possibly unleashing a\nglobal influenza pandemic. Media reported that roads leading to the infected village of Oktyabrskoye\nin Chelyabinsk had been cordoned off to prevent the virus from spreading\nfurther. Chelyabinsk, which borders Kurgan on the east side of the Ural mountains\ndividing Europe and Asia, is the westernmost region to have been struck so\nfar.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2005-08-15 00:00:00", "2021-08-25 00:00:00", "2005-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-27 00:00:00", "2005-08-05 00:00:00", "2003-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-29 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "America", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kazakhstan", "country": "Kazakhstan"}, {"location": "Altai", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Chelyabinsk", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Moscow", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Novosibirsk", "country": "Russia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2208431", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza - Russia (Siberia)(11): H5N1", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2208431", "date": "2005-08-11 23:50:00", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA - RUSSIA (SIBERIA)(11): H5N1\n********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nInfectious Disease products\n<http://www.intl.elsevierhealth.com/infectiousdiseases/>\nDate: Thu, 11 Aug 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Eurosurveillance Vol 10 (8), 11 Aug 2005 [edited]\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ew/2005/050811.asp#2>\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza reported in Russian bird populations\n---------------------------------------------------\nThe highly pathogenic avian influenza virus type A(H5N1), which\ncontinues to infect humans in Vietnam and Indonesia, has been\nreported to have infected bird populations in Russia, according to\nthe World Organisation for Animal Health (OIE, <http://www.oie.int>\n[1].\nThe disease has been reported in 13 villages in the Novosibirsk\nregion in Siberia, and was first detected on 18 Jul 2005. The virus\nis believed to have been transmitted to domestic poultry from wild\nwaterfowl after contact at open reservoirs.\nA total of 18 513 domestic birds have been slaughtered in the 3\naffected districts. There are controls on the movement of poultry,\nand many other bird populations in the region are being screened.\nAffected farms are being disinfected.\nIn Europe, there has been concern that the highly pathogenic A(H5N1)\nvirus could be carried in by birds migrating from Russia [2].\nAvian influenza in wild birds has also recently been reported in\nMongolia and in domestic poultry in Kazakhstan -- type A and type\nA(H5), respectively, further subtyping pending [3,4]. The H5N1 virus\nwas also detected in Xinjiang province in China in June [5]. This\nprovince borders on Mongolia and Kazakhstan.\nVietnam continues to report cases of human avian influenza. 3 more\nhuman cases of H5N1 infection were confirmed on 5 Aug 2005, bringing\nthe total since mid-December 2004 to 63 cases, of which 20 have been\nfatal [6]. One fatal and one probable human case of H5N1 infection\nwere reported in Indonesia at the end of July, where H5N1 has\naffected domestic poultry since March 2005, and recently, pigs [7].\nBetween February and May 2005, 4 fatal human cases of H5N1 infection\nwere also reported in Cambodia [8].\nThe European Union responded to the reports of circulating A(H5N1)\nvirus in Russia and Kazakhstan on 8 Aug 2005 by asking member states\nto ban the import of feathers and live birds from these countries\nwith immediate effect. The European Commission Standing Committee on\nthe Food Chain will review this ban in September [9].\nReferences:\nOIE. Highly pathogenic avian influenza in Russia -- follow-up report\nno.1. 5 Aug 2005.\n(<http://www.oie.int/eng/info/hebdo/a_current.htm#Sec7>)\nEurosurveillance. Scientists' report outlines European priorities in\ntackling infectious diseases. Eurosurveillance 2005; 10(6): 16 Jun\n2005 (<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ew/2005/050616.asp#1>)\nOIE. Follow up report\nnumber 1. 20 Jun 2005\n(<http://www.oie.int/eng/info/hebdo/AIS_65.HTM#Sec1>)\nWHO CSR. Avian influenza - situation in Vietnam - update 27. Disease\noutbreak news, 5 Aug 2005.\n(<http://www.oie.int/eng/info/hebdo/AIS_65.HTM#Sec1>)\nWHO CSR. Kazakhstan (Pavlodar)(02): H5N1", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1139", "date": "2005-08-10 23:50:00", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, GEESE - KAZAKHSTAN (PAVLODAR) (02): H5N1\n*********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nInfectious Disease products\n<http://www.intl.elsevierhealth.com/infectiousdiseases/>\nDate: Wed 10 Aug 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Reuters, 10 Aug 2005 [abridged and edited]\n<http://today.reuters.com/news/newsArticle.aspx?type=topNews&storyID=2005-08-\n10T122234Z_01_N10478282_RTRIDST_0_NEWS-BIRDFLU-RUSSIA-DC.XML>\n\nRussian bird flu advances, Kazakhs say virus deadly\n---------------------------------------------------\nIn Kazakhstan, which shares a long border with Siberia, the\nAgriculture Ministry confirmed that the virus found in birds was the\ndeadly H5N1 strain.\nThe ministry, which reported an outbreak of avian flu on 4 Aug 2005,\nsaid a quarantine was in place in the affected area near the\nGolubovka village in northern Kazakhstan's Pavlodar region.\nKazakhstan, roughly the size of Western Europe, with a population of\njust 15 million people, sought to play down fears of a growing\nproblem.\n'The epizootic situation in (Kazakhstan's) poultry farms is safe,'\nthe agriculture ministry said. 'As of 9 Aug 2005, there have been no\nreports of new outbreaks of the disease among poultry or wildfowl in\nthe republic.'\nIt added that officials were testing wildfowl in the many lakes and\nreservoirs near the village of Golubovka. A quarantine was also in\nplace in the village of Vinogradovka, where bird flu was earlier\nreported and where 345 poultry had been culled, it said.\n[Byline: Raushan Nurshayeva and Maria Golovnina]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n*****\n[The Kazakh veterinary services notified the OIE on 2 Aug 2005 about\nan outbreak of avian influenza type A, subtype H5, in a goose farm in\nthe village of Golubovka, Irtysh district, Pavlodar region. The\ncurrent news about the further identification of the virus strain as\nH5N1 is expected to be officially confirmed. - Mod.AS]\n[Thanks also to Kirk Greenway for a similar report from RIA Novosti. - Mod.JW]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Source: Reuters, 10 Aug 2005 [abridged and edited]\n<http://today.reuters.com/news/newsArticle.aspx?type=topNews&storyID=2005-08-\n10T122234Z_01_N10478282_RTRIDST_0_NEWS-BIRDFLU-RUSSIA-DC.XML>\n\nRussian bird flu advances, Kazakhs say virus deadly\n [Byline: Raushan Nurshayeva and Maria Golovnina]\n--\nProMED-mail\n< Sponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nInfectious Disease products\n<http://www.intl.elsevierhealth.com/infectiousdiseases/>\n The ministry, which reported an outbreak of avian flu on 4 Aug 2005,\nsaid a quarantine was in place in the affected area near the\nGolubovka village in northern Kazakhstan's Pavlodar region. [The Kazakh veterinary services notified the OIE on 2 Aug 2005 about\nan outbreak of avian influenza type A, subtype H5, in a goose farm in\nthe village of Golubovka, Irtysh district, Pavlodar region. A quarantine was also in\nplace in the village of Vinogradovka, where bird flu was earlier\nreported and where 345 poultry had been culled, it said. In Kazakhstan, which shares a long border with Siberia, the\nAgriculture Ministry confirmed that the virus found in birds was the\ndeadly H5N1 strain. As of 9 Aug 2005, there have been no\nreports of new outbreaks of the disease among poultry or wildfowl in\nthe republic.'", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2005-08-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2005-08-04 00:00:00", "2005-08-10 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Vinogradovka", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Golubovka", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Kazakhstan", "country": "Kazakhstan"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1192", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza - Asia (14): Russia (Siberia, Urals), H5N1", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1192", "date": "2005-09-08 23:50:00", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA - ASIA (14): RUSSIA (SIBERIA, URALS), H5N1\n**********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nJournal of Clinical Virology\n<http://intl.elsevierhealth.com/journals/jocv>\nDate: Thu, 8 Sep 2005\nFrom: Christian Griot <christian.griot@ivi.admin.ch>\nSource: Ria Novosti, 7 Sep 2005 [edited]\nBird flu was confirmed Wed 7 Sep 2005 in 47 Russian settlements, the\nAgriculture Ministry reported.\nAccording to data cited by the Federal Service for Veterinary and\nPhytosanitary Oversight in a ministry press release, another 80 settlements\nare suspected of having bird flu. The quarantine has been lifted from 9\nearlier registered populated areas and 4 lakes in the Omsk region. The\nservice said the bad epizootic situation in the Altai territory [kray], the\nTyumen, Kurgan, Chelyabinsk and Novosibirsk regions [oblasts] has not\nchanged in the last 2 days.\nThere are plans to lift the quarantine from 6 settlements in the Kurgan\nregion within a week.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Omsk oblast, Novosibirsk oblast, and Altai kray are situated within\nRussia's Siberian Federal District; Tyumen, Kurgan and Chelyabinsk oblasts\nare situated within the Urals Federal District. See maps\n<http://www.iiasa.ac.at/Research/LUC/GIS/img/adm_rus.jpg>\n<http://www.grida.no/graphics/CEE/russia/russieoblast.jpg>.\nFor our readers' convenience, the following is a description of Russia's\nadministrative divisions.\nAll of the federal subjects of Russia ('The Russian Federation') are\ngrouped into 7 federal districts (Russian federalnyye okruga, singular\nfederalny okrug), each administered by a governor appointed by the\npresident of the federation.\nThe federal districts are: Central Federal District, Southern Federal\nDistrict, Northwestern Federal District, Far Eastern Federal District,\nSiberian Federal District, Urals Federal District, and Privolzhsky (Volga)\nFederal District.\n1.Central Federal District ( Tsentralny federalny okrug). Administrative\ncenter: Moscow.\nIncludes: Belgorod Oblast, Bryansk Oblast, Ivanovo Oblast, Kaluga Oblast,\nKostroma Oblast, Kursk Oblast, Lipetsk Oblast, Moscow (federal city),\nMoscow Oblast, Oryol Oblast, Ryazan Oblast, Smolensk Oblast, Tambov Oblast,\nTver Oblast, Tula Oblast, Vladimir Oblast, Voronezh Oblast, Yaroslavl Oblast.\n2. Southern Federal District (Yuzhny federalny okrug). Administrative\ncenter: Rostov-na-Donu.\nIncludes: Adygeya Republic, Astrakhan Oblast, Chechnya Republic, Dagestan\nRepublic, Ingushetia Republic, Kabardino-Balkaria Republic, Kalmykia\nRepublic, Karachay-Cherkessia Republic, Krasnodar Krai, North\nOssetia-Alania Republic, Stavropol Krai, Rostov Oblast, Volgograd Oblast.\n3. Northwestern Federal District (Severo-Zapadny federalny okrug).\nAdministrative center: St. Petersburg.\nIncludes: Arkhangelsk Oblast, Nenetsia Autonomous District, Kaliningrad\nOblast, Leningrad Oblast, Karelia Republic, Komi Republic, Murmansk Oblast,\nNovgorod Oblast, Pskov Oblast, St. Petersburg (federal city), Vologda Oblast.\n4. Far Eastern Federal District (Dalnevostochny federalny okrug).\nAdministrative center: Khabarovsk.\nIncludes: Amur Oblast, Jewish Autonomous Oblast, Kamchatka Oblast, Koryakia\nAutonomous District, Khabarovsk Krai, Magadan Oblast, Chukotka Autonomous\nDistrict, Primorsky Krai, Sakha (Yakutia) Republic, Sakhalin Oblast.\n5. Siberian Federal District (Sibirsky federalny okrug).
