Urals Federal District (Uralsky federalny okrug). Administrative center:\nYekaterinburg.\nIncludes: Kurgan Oblast, Sverdlovsk Oblast, Tyumen Oblast, Khantia-Mansia\nAutonomous District, Yamalia Autonomous District, Chelyabinsk Oblast.\n7. Privolzhsky (Volga) Federal District (Privolzhsky federalny okrug).\nAdministrative center: Nizhny Novgorod.\nIncludes: Bashkortostan Republic, Chuvashia Republic, Kirov Oblast, Mari El\nRepublic, Mordovia Republic, Nizhny Novgorod Oblast, Orenburg Oblast, Penza\nOblast, Perm Oblast, Permyakia Autonomous District, Samara Oblast, Saratov\nOblast, Tatarstan Republic, Udmurtia Republic, Ulyanovsk Oblast.\n- Mod.AS]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Includes: Altai Republic, Altai Krai, Buryatia Republic, Chita Oblast, Aga\nBuryatia Autonomous District, Irkutsk Oblast, Ust-Orda Buryatia Autonomous\nDistrict, Khakassia Republic, Kemerovo Oblast, Krasnoyarsk Krai, Taymyria\nAutonomous District, Evenkia Autonomous District, Novosibirsk Oblast, Omsk\n All of the federal subjects of Russia ('The Russian Federation') are\ngrouped into 7 federal districts (Russian federalnyye okruga, singular\nfederalny okrug), each administered by a governor appointed by the\npresident of the federation. Includes: Belgorod Oblast, Bryansk Oblast, Ivanovo Oblast, Kaluga Oblast,\nKostroma Oblast, Kursk Oblast, Lipetsk Oblast, Moscow (federal city),\nMoscow Oblast, Oryol Oblast, Ryazan Oblast, Smolensk Oblast, Tambov Oblast,\nTver Oblast, Tula Oblast, Vladimir Oblast, Voronezh Oblast, Yaroslavl Oblast. The federal districts are: Central Federal District, Southern Federal\nDistrict, Northwestern Federal District, Far Eastern Federal District,\nSiberian Federal District, Urals Federal District, and Privolzhsky (Volga)\n The\nservice said the bad epizootic situation in the Altai territory [kray], the\nTyumen, Kurgan, Chelyabinsk and Novosibirsk regions [oblasts] has not\nchanged in the last 2 days. \nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n Sponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nJournal of Clinical Virology\n<http://intl.elsevierhealth.com/journals/jocv>\n [Omsk oblast, Novosibirsk oblast, and Altai kray are situated within\nRussia's Siberian Federal District; Tyumen, Kurgan and Chelyabinsk oblasts\nare situated within the Urals Federal District. "2005-08-08 23:50:00", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA - RUSSIA (SIBERIA)(10): H5N1, OIE\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nInfectious Disease products\n<http://www.intl.elsevierhealth.com/infectiousdiseases/>\nDate: 8 Aug 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: OIE Disease Information, 5 Aug 2005, Vol. 18 - No. 31 [edited]\n<http://www.oie.int/eng/info/hebdo/a_current.htm>\n\nHighly Pathogenic Avian Influenza in Russia\n-----------------------------------------------\nFollow-up report No. 1\nSee also: 29 Jul 2005\nInformation received on 5 Aug 2005 from Dr. Evgueny A. Nepoklonov,\nHead of the Main Veterinary Department, Ministry of Agriculture and\nFood, Moscow:\nEnd of previous report period: 24 Jul 2005 (see Disease Information,\n18 [30], 218, dated 29 Jul 2005).\nEnd of this report period: 5 Aug 2005.\nPrecise identification of agent: influenza virus type A, subtype\nH5N1. An isolate from the village of Suzdalka has been subjected to\nan in-depth examination. The preliminary results of sequencing show\nthat the isolate can be considered highly pathogenic.\nDate of 1st confirmation of the event: 23 Jul 2005.\nDate of start of the event: 18 Jul 2005.\nNature of diagnosis: clinical, post-mortem and laboratory.\nDetails of outbreaks:\n1st administrative division (region): Novosibirsk (Novosibirskaya oblast)\nLower administrative division (district): Kupino\nType of epidemiological unit: village\nName of the location: ...\nSpecies: avi\nDate of start of the outbreak: 18 Jul 2005\nNumber of animals in the outbreaks:\nsusceptible / cases / deaths / destroyed / slaughtered\n... / ... / ... / ... / ...\n1st administrative division (region): Novosibirsk (Novosibirskaya oblast)\nLower administrative division (district): Dovolnoye\nType of epidemiological unit: village\nName of the location: ...\nSpecies: avi\nDate of start of the outbreak: 22 Jul 2005\nNumber of animals in the outbreaks:\nsusceptible / cases / deaths / destroyed / slaughtered\n... / ... / ... / ... / ...\n1st administrative division (region): Novosibirsk (Novosibirskaya oblast)\nLower administrative division (district): Chistoozernoye\nType of epidemiological unit: village\nName of the location: ...\nSpecies: avi\nDate of start of the outbreak: 22 Jul 2005\nNumber of animals in the outbreaks:\nsusceptible / cases / deaths / destroyed / slaughtered\n... / ... / ... / ... / ...\nDescription of affected populations: chickens, turkeys, ducks and\ngeese in backyard holdings.\nThe disease has been reported in a total of 13 villages:\nIn 5 villages, birds have shown clinical signs of the disease, and\ndeaths have been reported; birds have tested positive to antibodies\nto H5, and the virus has been isolated.\nIn 4 villages, no deaths have been reported, but birds have tested\npositive for antibodies to H5, and the virus has been isolated.\nIn the remaining 4 villages, no deaths have been reported, nor has\nthe virus been detected in any of the birds. However, birds have\ntested positive to antibodies to H5.\nDiagnosis:\nLaboratories where diagnosis was made: Federal Centre for Animal\nHealth (ARRIAH)\nNumber of animals examined: 70\nDiagnostic tests used: ELISA(1) for antigen detection\nDates: 23 Jul - 5 Aug 2005\nResults: positive\nLaboratories where diagnosis was made: All-Russia State Research\nInstitute for Control, Standardization and Certification of\nVeterinary Preparations\nNumber of animals examined: 5\nDiagnostic tests used: PCR(2) (M-protein gene)\nDates: 23 Jul - 5 Aug 2005\nResults: positive\nLaboratories where diagnosis was made: Association for Scientific\nProduction NPO Vektori\nNumber of animals examined: 62\nDiagnostic tests used: hemagglutination test\nDates: 23 Jul - 5 Aug 2005\nResults: positive\nLaboratories where diagnosis was made: Novosibirsk inter-regional\nveterinary laboratory, Federal Governmental University\nNumber of animals examined: 5324\nDiagnostic tests used: ELISA(1) for antibody detection\nDates: 28 Jul 2005\nResults: positive\nSource of outbreaks or origin of infection: the epidemiological\nanalysis has shown that the disease started in poultry in contact\nwith wild waterfowl at open water reservoirs. Waterfowl are\nconsidered the primary source of the virus. In addition, there are\nreports of the disease in wild birds. Infection of domestic birds in\nall the affected localities, some of which are up to 600 km apart,\noccurred simultaneously. In all cases, the source of infection was\nwild waterfowl in lakes frequented by domestic birds.\nControl measures undertaken:\n- Stamping out: stamping out of birds suspected of being infected has\nbegun. In all 3 affected districts, a total of 18 513 domestic birds\nof 5 species have been destroyed.\n- Quarantine.\n- Movement control inside the country.\n- Screening: all localities in Novosibirsk region are being screened\nfor circulation of the virus and presence of seropositive birds.\n- Zoning.\n- Disinfection of infected premises/establishments.\nVaccination prohibited: yes.\nOther details/comments:\n- No signs of the disease have appeared in commercial poultry farms\nin the region. Monitoring of all 14 commercial poultry farms did not\nreveal any circulation of the virus or seropositive birds.\n- In localities where the infection has resulted in deaths of birds,\nmortality since the beginning of the epizootic has not exceeded 3.3\npercent.\n- The application of control measures has sharply reduced mortality.\nThere are no longer any deaths accompanied by characteristic clinical\nsigns among domestic birds, and total daily mortality in the\ndifferent localities is only some thousandths of the total flock.\n(1) ELISA: enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay\n(2) PCR: polymerase chain reaction\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[This confirms recent reports that the virus in Russia is an H5N1,\nnot an H5N2 as previously reported in the media. This sequence of\nevents confirms the importance of being cautious concerning\nconclusions about the types of viruses involved in any outbreak,\nparticularly prior to having definitive laboratory results. - Mod.PC]", "summary": "Results: positive\nLaboratories where diagnosis was made: All-Russia State Research\nInstitute for Control, Standardization and Certification of\nVeterinary Preparations\nNumber of animals examined: 5\nDiagnostic tests used: PCR(2) (M-protein gene)\n Results: positive\nLaboratories where diagnosis was made: Novosibirsk inter-regional\nveterinary laboratory, Federal Governmental University\nNumber of animals examined: 5324\nDiagnostic tests used: ELISA(1) for antibody detection\n \n(1) ELISA: enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay\n(2) PCR: polymerase chain reaction\n--\nProMED-mail\n< A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Number of animals in the outbreaks:\nsusceptible / cases / deaths / destroyed / slaughtered\n... / ... / ... / ... / ...\n Number of animals in the outbreaks:\nsusceptible / cases / deaths / destroyed / slaughtered\n... / ... / ... / ... / ...\n Lower administrative division (district): Dovolnoye\nType of epidemiological unit: village\nName of the location: ...\n Lower administrative division (district): Chistoozernoye\nType of epidemiological unit: village\nName of the location: ...\n Information received on 5 Aug 2005 from Dr. Evgueny A. Diagnosis:\nLaboratories where diagnosis was made: Federal Centre for Animal\nHealth (ARRIAH)\n Number of animals in the outbreaks:\nsusceptible / cases / deaths / destroyed / slaughtered\n... / ... / ... / ... / ... In 5 villages, birds have shown clinical signs of the disease, and\ndeaths have been reported; birds have tested positive to antibodies\nto H5, and the virus has been isolated. There are no longer any deaths accompanied by characteristic clinical\nsigns among domestic birds, and total daily mortality in the\ndifferent localities is only some thousandths of the total flock. In localities where the infection has resulted in deaths of birds,\nmortality since the beginning of the epizootic has not exceeded 3.3\npercent. \n- Screening: all localities in Novosibirsk region are being screened\nfor circulation of the virus and presence of seropositive birds. Other details/comments:\n- No signs of the disease have appeared in commercial poultry farms\nin the region. Number of animals examined: 70\nDiagnostic tests used: ELISA(1) for antigen detection\n Number of animals examined: 62\nDiagnostic tests used: hemagglutination test\n Results: positive\nLaboratories where diagnosis was made: Association for Scientific\n 18 - No. 31 [edited]\n<http://www.oie.int/eng/info/hebdo/a_current.htm>\n\nHighly Pathogenic Avian Influenza in Russia\n The preliminary results of sequencing show\nthat the isolate can be considered highly pathogenic.\n Sponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nInfectious Disease products\n \nFollow-up report No. 1\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2005-08-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Suzdalka", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Moscow", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1121", "headline": "PRO/AH> Avian influenza - Russia (Siberia)(07): H5N1 susp.", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1121", "date": "2005-08-01 23:50:00", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA - RUSSIA (SIBERIA) (07): H5N1 SUSPECTED\n*******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nTransactions of the Royal Society of Tropical Medicine and Hygiene\n<http://tinyurl.com/eyno6>\nDate: Sat 30 Jul 2005\nFrom: Jody Lanard <jody@psandman.com>\n\nPast history of H5N1 in Russia? (FAO bulletin 26?)\n-----------------------------------------------\nRegarding the H5N1 identified in Novosibirsk in July 2005, ProMED\nposting 20050730.2216, 30 Jul 2005, cites CIDRAP News as follows: 'If\nthe report is accurate, the outbreak marks the 1st known appearance\nof the H5N1 virus in Russia.'\nHowever, according to the FAO bulletin Update on the Avian Influenza\nsituation (FAO AIDE NEWS, issue 26, 20 Dec 2004, see link and excerpt\nbelow), H5N1 was identified in migrating birds there 'during the past\n4 years.'\nI don't know whether this was subsequently disproved, or whether\nthere is another reason for the statements that July 2005's H5N1\nfinding is the 1st in Russia, but I thought I would call the apparent\ndiscrepancy to your attention for clarification. Please remember, I\nam a psychiatrist, not a vet, and this stuff is hard for me to sort\nout.\nHere is the FAO citation:\n<http://www.fao.org/ag/againfo/subjects/documents/ai/AVIbull026.pdf>\n'Russia: In the last issue of FAO AIDE news (No. 25) we published\ninformation that may have misinterpreted the original scientific\ndata. We have subsequently learned that on several occasions H5N1\navian influenza viruses have been isolated from migrating birds in\nthe Novosibirsk region of Russia during the past 4 years. In 2003, an\nH5 avian influenza virus was isolated and sequenced by the Laboratory\nto Investigate and Monitor Emerging Zoonotic Diseases (Novosibirsk,\nRussia) from a wild mallard duck on Lake Chany in the south of\nWestern Siberia. The A/mallard/Chany/9/03 avian influenza virus was\nrelated, but not identical, to H5N1 avian influenza viruses currently\ncirculating in domestic poultry in Asia. The virus's hemagglutinin\nsequence showed 90-95 percent similarity to the current Asian H5N1,\nwhich is in turn similar to Eurasian H5 avian influenza viruses\nA/duck/Potsdam/1402-6/86 (H5N2) and A/turkey/England/50-92/91 (H5N1).\nThese data emphasize the need for continuing surveillance of\nmigratory birds for avian influenza viruses. Studies of these viruses\nwill increase the understanding of the ecology of avian influenza\nviruses, including the transfer of these viruses between migratory\nbirds and domestic poultry. However, the A/mallard/Chany/9/03 avian\ninfluenza virus is not the same virus as the Asian H5N1, and is not\nevidence of infection and spread of the current Asian H5N1 avian\ninfluenza virus by migratory birds to areas outside infected Asian\ncountries/regions. (19 Nov 2005, source: Dr. Swayne, Southeast\nPoultry Research Laboratory, USDA/ARS).'\n--\nJody Lanard, M.D.\nThe Peter Sandman Risk Communication Website\n<http://www.psandman.com>\n<jody@psandman.com>\n[We are grateful to Dr. Lanard for her attentive observation. It\nmight be assumed that CIDRAP actually meant the 1st known H5N1\n'outbreak' rather than 'appearance' (of the virus) in Russia.\nDr. Lanard's query has been forwarded to Dr. David Swayne, the author\nof the FAO citation. Dr. Swayne (Laboratory Director, Southeast\nPoultry Research Laboratory USDA/ARS, <dswayne@seprl.usda.gov>) has\nkindly forwarded to us the following clarification:\n'All AI viruses are type A influenza viruses in the virus family of\n_Orthomyxoviridae_, but are subdivided into subtypes based on\nhemagglutinin (H) and neuraminidase (N) proteins using serological\ntests. There are 16 H and 9 N subtypes thus potential for 144\ndifferent H and N combinations. In addition, all AI viruses fall into\none of 2 pathotypes: low (LPAI) and high (HPAI) pathogenicity.\nThe virus reported last spring from Novosibirsk is an H5 subtype,\nbut, based on sequencing, was related but not identical to the H5N1\nHPAI viruses in SE Asia. They are like 3rd cousins, only related to\neach other by 90-95 percent. In addition, the SE Asia H5N1 are HPAI\nviruses, but the prior Novosibirsk virus is LPAI virus. The subtype\nof the N has not been reported, so it could be any of the N1-9.\nThe current virus from Novosibirsk has been reported only over the\nInternet as H5N1 and has not been verified as H5N1 by the OIE/FAO or\nWHO reference laboratory. We must [suspend] judgment until verified.'\nWe are very grateful to Dr. Swayne for his response. Final, official\ndata on the current Russian isolate are anticipated.\nFurther reading:\nK. Okazaki, A. Takada et al (2000):\nPrecursor genes of future pandemic influenza viruses are perpetuated\nin ducks nesting in Siberia. Arch Virol. 145(5):885-93. (...'the\ngenes of the isolates in Siberia are closely related to those of H5N1\ninfluenza virus strains isolated from chickens and humans in Hong\nKong in 1997 as well as to those of isolates from domestic birds in\nsouthern China.') - Mod.AS]", "summary": "Dr. Swayne (Laboratory Director, Southeast\nPoultry Research Laboratory USDA/ARS, <dswayne@seprl.usda.gov>) has\nkindly forwarded to us the following clarification:\n'All AI viruses are type A influenza viruses in the virus family of\n_Orthomyxoviridae_, but are subdivided into subtypes based on\nhemagglutinin (H) and neuraminidase (N) proteins using serological\ntests. However, the A/mallard/Chany/9/03 avian\ninfluenza virus is not the same virus as the Asian H5N1, and is not\nevidence of infection and spread of the current Asian H5N1 avian\ninfluenza virus by migratory birds to areas outside infected Asian\ncountries/regions. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n (...'the\ngenes of the isolates in Siberia are closely related to those of H5N1\ninfluenza virus strains isolated from chickens and humans in Hong\nKong in 1997 as well as to those of isolates from domestic birds in\nsouthern China.') - Mod. In 2003, an\nH5 avian influenza virus was isolated and sequenced by the Laboratory\nto Investigate and Monitor Emerging Zoonotic Diseases (Novosibirsk,\nRussia) from a wild mallard duck on Lake Chany in the south of\nWestern Siberia. Studies of these viruses\nwill increase the understanding of the ecology of avian influenza\nviruses, including the transfer of these viruses between migratory\nbirds and domestic poultry. The virus's hemagglutinin\nsequence showed 90-95 percent similarity to the current Asian H5N1,\nwhich is in turn similar to Eurasian H5 avian influenza viruses\n However, according to the FAO bulletin Update on the Avian Influenza\nsituation (FAO AIDE NEWS, issue 26, 20 Dec 2004, see link and excerpt\nbelow), H5N1 was identified in migrating birds there 'during the past\n4 years.' Regarding the H5N1 identified in Novosibirsk in July 2005, ProMED\nposting 20050730.2216, 30 Jul 2005, cites CIDRAP News as follows: 'If\nthe report is accurate, the outbreak marks the 1st known appearance\nof the H5N1 virus in Russia.' Further reading:\nK. Okazaki, A. Takada et al (2000):\nPrecursor genes of future pandemic influenza viruses are perpetuated\nin ducks nesting in Siberia. I don't know whether this was subsequently disproved, or whether\nthere is another reason for the statements that July 2005's H5N1\nfinding is the 1st in Russia, but I thought I would call the apparent\ndiscrepancy to your attention for clarification. The Peter Sandman Risk Communication Website\n<http://www.psandman.com>\n<jody@psandman.com>\n Sponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nTransactions of the Royal Society of Tropical Medicine and Hygiene\n<http://tinyurl.com/eyno6>\n The A/mallard/Chany/9/03 avian influenza virus was\nrelated, but not identical, to H5N1 avian influenza viruses currently\ncirculating in domestic poultry in Asia. We have subsequently learned that on several occasions H5N1\navian influenza viruses have been isolated from migrating birds in\nthe Novosibirsk region of Russia during the past 4 years. The virus reported last spring from Novosibirsk is an H5 subtype,\nbut, based on sequencing, was related but not identical to the H5N1\nHPAI viruses in SE Asia.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2003-03-25 00:00:00", "2004-12-25 00:00:00", "2005-07-25 00:00:00", "1997-03-25 00:00:00", "2005-11-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Novosibirsk", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Hong \n Kong", "country": "Thailand"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1123", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza - Russia (Siberia)(08): H5N1 susp.", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1123", "date": "2005-08-01 23:50:00", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA - RUSSIA (SIBERIA) (08): H5N1 SUSPECTED\n*******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nTransactions of the Royal Society of Tropical Medicine and Hygiene\n<http://tinyurl.com/eyno6>\n\n*****\n[1]\nDate: Mon 1 Aug 2005\nFrom: Dave Halvorson <halvo002@umn.edu>\n\nRe: Avian influenza - Russia (Siberia)(07): H5N1 suspected\n-----------------------------------------------\nThis discussion is important because H5N1 has been isolated many\ntimes and [in] many places. In my lab, we isolated H5N1 from ducks in\n1981 and 1985 and experimentally infected ducks with a duck isolate\nof H5N1. None of these H5N1s were in any way related to the current\nSE Asia outbreak.\nWith the current lack of understanding in the media and general\npublic, the detection (and subsequent 'reporting') of a generic H5N1\nvirus or antibody could have devastating consequences related to\npanic and politics.\n--\nDavid A. Halvorson, DVM\nDiplomate, ACPV\nExtension Veterinarian - Avian Health\nCollege of Veterinary Medicine\nUniversity of Minnesota\nSaint Paul, Minnesota 55108\n<halvo002@umn.edu>\n******\n[2]\nDate: Tue 2 Aug 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: The Moscow Times, 2 Aug 2005 [edited]\n<http://www.themoscowtimes.com/stories/2005/08/02/013.html>\n\nRegion Moves to Contain Bird Flu\n-------------------------------------\nNovosibirsk Governor Viktor Tolokonsky met with local officials on\nMonday [1 Aug 2005] to discuss measures for containing an outbreak of\nthe avian flu strain that can infect humans.\nThe outbreak began in the Novosibirsk region in early July 2005,\nkilling thousands of domestic fowl. The country's veterinary service\nlast week [final week July 2005] identified the virus as the H5N1\nstrain, which can fatally infect humans. No human cases have been\nreported in Russia.\nTolokonsky said Monday [1 Aug 2005] that the local administration had\nearmarked 9 million rubles (USD 315 000) to conduct quarantine\nmeasures in 18 towns and villages intended to stem the outbreak of\nthe avian flu.\n'The quarantine entails killing all poultry in the regions where the\noutbreak was recorded,' Tolokonsky said, Itar-Tass reported.\nThe veterinary service said the avian flu outbreak had been recorded\nin 13 settlements of the Novosibirsk region and one village in the\nAltai region. 'Necessary measures are being taken to contain the\ninfection's source,' it said in a statement.\nThe Emergency Situations Ministry said the outbreak already had\nkilled 2382 domestic fowl, including 127 since Sunday [31 Jul 2005]\nmorning.\nNew outbreaks had been registered in the Omsk region, where 450 fowl\nhad been killed, and the Altai region, where 300 died, but the strain\nthere had not been determined yet, the ministry said.\nChannel One television reported that workers of poultry farms were\nordered to wear protective clothes and undergo disinfection\nprocedures.\nValery Mikheyev, the chief sanitary doctor for the Novosibirsk\nregion, said that medical experts conduct regular checks on residents\nof the affected villages.\nThe veterinary service said that the virus apparently had been\nbrought by birds migrating from Southeast Asia. The virus has swept\nthrough poultry populations in large areas of Asia since 2003,\nkilling tens of millions of birds and at least 60 people, most of\nthem in Viet Nam and Thailand.\nAlmost all the human fatalities had contracted the virus from\npoultry. But experts worry it could mutate into a more deadly virus\nthat could spread from person to person.\n[Byline: Vladimir Isachenkov]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[There is an increasing flow of newswires pertaining to the\nidentification of the causal virus strain in Siberia as H5N1, but, so\nfar, this has not been officially confirmed or notified. - Mod.AS]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n \nDavid A. Halvorson, DVM\nDiplomate, ACPV\nExtension Veterinarian - Avian Health\nCollege of Veterinary Medicine\n Tolokonsky said Monday [1 Aug 2005] that the local administration had\nearmarked 9 million rubles (USD 315 000) to conduct quarantine\nmeasures in 18 towns and villages intended to stem the outbreak of\nthe avian flu. With the current lack of understanding in the media and general\npublic, the detection (and subsequent 'reporting') of a generic H5N1\nvirus or antibody could have devastating consequences related to\npanic and politics. The virus has swept\nthrough poultry populations in large areas of Asia since 2003,\nkilling tens of millions of birds and at least 60 people, most of\nthem in Viet Nam and Thailand. Channel One television reported that workers of poultry farms were\nordered to wear protective clothes and undergo disinfection\nprocedures.\n [Byline: Vladimir Isachenkov]\n--\nProMED-mail\n< Saint Paul, Minnesota 55108\n<halvo002@umn.edu>\n******\n The veterinary service said the avian flu outbreak had been recorded\nin 13 settlements of the Novosibirsk region and one village in the\nAltai region. ' The country's veterinary service\nlast week [final week July 2005] identified the virus as the H5N1\nstrain, which can fatally infect humans. New outbreaks had been registered in the Omsk region, where 450 fowl\nhad been killed, and the Altai region, where 300 died, but the strain\nthere had not been determined yet, the ministry said. The Emergency Situations Ministry said the outbreak already had\nkilled 2382 domestic fowl, including 127 since Sunday [31 Jul 2005]\nmorning. Source: The Moscow Times, 2 Aug 2005 [edited]\n<http://www.themoscowtimes.com/stories/2005/08/02/013.html>\n\nRegion Moves to Contain Bird Flu\n Valery Mikheyev, the chief sanitary doctor for the Novosibirsk\nregion, said that medical experts conduct regular checks on residents\nof the affected villages. [There is an increasing flow of newswires pertaining to the\nidentification of the causal virus strain in Siberia as H5N1, but, so\nfar, this has not been officially confirmed or notified. But experts worry it could mutate into a more deadly virus\nthat could spread from person to person.\n", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1981-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2005-08-02 00:00:00", "1985-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-29 00:00:00", "2003-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-28 00:00:00", "2005-08-01 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Thailand", "country": "Thailand"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "necessary", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Viet Nam", "country": "Vietnam"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1136", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza - Russia (Siberia)(11): H5N1", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1136", "date": "2005-08-09 23:50:00", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA - RUSSIA (SIBERIA) (11): H5N1\n*********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nSponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nInfectious Disease products\n<http://www.intl.elsevierhealth.com/infectiousdiseases/>\n\n[1]\nDate: Mon, 8 Aug 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: EU Health and Consumer e-News, 8 Aug 2005 [edited]\n<http://europa.eu.int/comm/dgs/health_consumer/dyna/enews/index.cfm>\n\n\nAvian Influenza in Russia and Kazakhstan: Import of Feathers and Live\nBirds Banned\n---------------------------------------------------\nThe Commission has asked Member States to implement a ban on all\nimports of feathers and live birds from Russia and Kazakhstan with\nimmediate effect, due to confirmed outbreaks of Avian Influenza (AI)\nin these countries.\n\nRussia and Kazakhstan have been added to the list of 9 Asian\ncountries (Thailand, Cambodia, Indonesia, Laos, China, Vietnam, North\nKorea, Pakistan and Malaysia) not allowed to export birds, their meat\nor products to the EU because of AI. No ban is necessary for eggs,\npoultry meat or meat products on this occasion, as there is no trade\nbetween Russia and Kazakhstan and the EU in these products. The\nStanding Committee on the Food Chain will review the decision when it\nmeets in September 2005.\n\nFor more information on Avian Influenza, see:\n<http://europa.eu.int/comm/food/animal/diseases/controlmeasures/avian/index_en.htm>\n\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Tue, 9 Aug 2005\nFrom: Mary Marshall <tropical.forestry@btinternet.com>\nSource: Reuters alertnews, 8 Aug 2005 [dited]\n<http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/L08679894.htm>\n\n\nRussian bird flu may be spreading, humans unaffected\n-----------------------------------------------------\nA bird flu outbreak in Russia's Siberian regions may be spreading,\nbut no humans have been infected so far, officials and Russian media\nsaid on Monday.\n\nThe highly potent H5N1 strain, confirmed in the Siberian region of\nNovosibirsk, has swept parts of Asia and killed more than 50 people\nsince 2003. Outbreaks in Russia and later in neighbouring Kazakhstan\nhave been reported since mid-July 2005.\n\nIn a sign the outbreak had yet to be contained, news agencies\nreported the virus may have spread to 2 more districts of the Kurgan\nregion in western Siberia where bird flu was confirmed in wildfowl\nlast week.\n\n'Dead bird samples from these areas have been taken away for\n[testing],' Interfax news agency quoted a regional agriculture\nofficial as saying.\n\nBut Russia's consumer rights watchdog said the situation was under\ncontrol. 'As of 7 Aug 2005, the epidemic situation...remains\nstable...There have been no infections and no one was suspected of\nhaving been infected,' the watchdog, part of the Health Ministry,\nsaid in a statement.\n\nSome health officials fear the virus that has swept through Asia\ncould mutate into a lethal strain that could rival or exceed the\nSpanish flu pandemic that killed up to 40 million people across the\nglobe at the end of World War One.\n\nItar-Tass news agency quoted Novosibirsk officials as saying mass\ndeaths among farm birds largely stopped on Monday [8 Aug 2005] in the\nworst-affected, quarantined areas of the Novosibirsk region.\n\nMass poultry deaths in Novosibirsk have been registered since 10 Jul\n2005, according to media reports. The number of Russian regions hit\nby the avian flu rose to 5 last week.\n\nRussia's growing bird flu crisis could drive up imports of poultry.\nRussia annually consumes more than 2 million tonnes of poultry meat\nand imports more than half its needs from the United States, Brazil\nand other countries.\n\nThe European Union has decided to ban imports of chickens and other\nproducts from Russia and Kazakhstan, although in practice the EU does\nnot buy poultry from the 2 ex-Soviet countries.\n\nKazakhstan\n---------\nIn Central Asia's Kazakhstan, the deaths of 364 hens in the village\nof Krasny Yar, initially assumed to having been caused by bird flu,\nturned out to be due to a regular bird disease, Interfax quoted\nregional veterinary officials as saying.\n\nBut there was no word on the situation in other, more widely affected\nKazakh regions, including Pavlodar, where bird flu had been\nregistered officially.\n\nThe Russian Emergencies Ministry said in a note issued on Monday [8\nAug 2005] that a total of 5573 domestic and wild birds had been\naffected in the Novosibirsk, Omsk and Tyumen regions.\n\nRussia has culled tens of thousands of domestic birds in past days to\nprevent the virus spreading. In Tyumen region alone, more than 12 000\nchickens, ducks and geese had been killed, Tass said.\n\nTass quoted Tyumen officials as saying the virus had been confirmed\nin another small village called Vorobyovo, but it was unclear how\nmany birds were affected there. Tass said checks were being carried\nout in a number of nearby settlements.\n\nInterfax news agency reported from Altai, another affected Siberian\nregion, that state inspectors joined forces with local hunters to\nlocate, check and, if necessary, shoot down infected birds,\nespecially in areas near big farms.\n\n[Byline: Maria Golovnina]\n\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3]\nDate: Tue, 9 Aug 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Itar-Tass, 8 Aug 2005 [edited]\n<http://www.itar-tass.com/eng/level2.html?NewsID=2300180&PageNum=0>\n\n\nBan on Russian poultry import won't harm producers: ministry\n--------------------------------------------------\nThe ban on the import of poultry and poultry farming products from\nRussia imposed by a number of countries will cause no negative\neffects on domestic producers, for the sole reason the export of\nthese items from Russia is very insignificant, Agriculture Ministry\nhas told Prime-Tass.\n\nThe EU countries banned the import of poultry and related products\nfrom Russia and Kazakhstan in the wake of the bird flu epidemic,\nalthough they are not their importers. Azerbaijan, Ukraine,\nKyrgyzstan, Tajikistan and Hong Kong did so, too.\n\nCases of avian influenza have been registered in the Novosibirsk,\nOmsk, Tomsk, and Tyumen Regions and the Altai Territory [of Russia].\nThe disease has not affected any humans so far.\n\nBird flu has been identified in the Pavlodar Region of Kazakhstan.\n\nThe Emergency Situations Ministry last week warned that the bird flu\nmay travel from Siberia to European Russia during the autumn\nmigration.\n\nIt is believed that the disease was brought to Siberia from China.\n\nThe Russian union of poultry producers has asked the government to\ntake urgent measures to prevent the spread of the virus.\n\nThe Russian poultry farming industry has been [growing steadily] for\nthe past few years, as domestic demand has soared and import quotas\nrestricted import.\n\nAccording to the Poultry Producers Union's forecasts, this year's\nproduction was to grow by 17 percent on the year to 1.4 million\ntonnes.\n\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Russia officially notified the OIE on 5 Aug 2005 that the avian\ninfluenza virus type A from Novosibirsk (Southwest Siberia),\ninitially (24 Jul 2005) reported as H5, has been finally confirmed as\nH5N1. The notification includes some statements which require\nclarifications:\n\n1. The affected species are reportedly chickens, turkeys, ducks and\ngeese. However, birds of 5 species have been destroyed. What was the\n5th species involved?\n\n2. 'In localities where the infection has resulted in deaths of\nbirds, mortality since the beginning of the epizootic has not\nexceeded 3.3 percent'. Such low death rates, if applicable to\nchickens, put in question the pathogenicity of the Russian AI strain\nand its similarity to SE Asian strains. Clarification will help.\n\n3. Reportedly, 'the application of control measures has sharply\nreduced mortality'. It is not clear what control measures have\nreduced mortality of AI-affected flocks.\n- Mod.AS]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nSponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nInfectious Disease products\n<http://www.intl.elsevierhealth.com/infectiousdiseases/>\n\n[1]\n The ban on the import of poultry and poultry farming products from\nRussia imposed by a number of countries will cause no negative\neffects on domestic producers, for the sole reason the export of\nthese items from Russia is very insignificant, Agriculture Ministry\nhas told Prime-Tass. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Russia officially notified the OIE on 5 Aug 2005 that the avian\ninfluenza virus type A from Novosibirsk (Southwest Siberia),\ninitially (24 Jul 2005) reported as H5, has been finally confirmed as\nH5N1. \n\nIn a sign the outbreak had yet to be contained, news agencies\nreported the virus may have spread to 2 more districts of the Kurgan\nregion in western Siberia where bird flu was confirmed in wildfowl\nlast week. \n\nInterfax news agency reported from Altai, another affected Siberian\nregion, that state inspectors joined forces with local hunters to\nlocate, check and, if necessary, shoot down infected birds,\nespecially in areas near big farms. \n\nSome health officials fear the virus that has swept through Asia\ncould mutate into a lethal strain that could rival or exceed the\nSpanish flu pandemic that killed up to 40 million people across the\nglobe at the end of World War One. \n\nRussia and Kazakhstan have been added to the list of 9 Asian\ncountries (Thailand, Cambodia, Indonesia, Laos, China, Vietnam, North\nKorea, Pakistan and Malaysia) not allowed to export birds, their meat\nor products to the EU because of AI. Russia (Siberia)(06): H5N1 susp.", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1118", "date": "2005-07-30 23:50:00", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA - RUSSIA (SIBERIA)(06): H5N1 SUSPECTED\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nPrinciples and Practice of Infectious Diseases Online, 6th edition\n<http://tinyurl.com/7sfzw>\nDate: Sat, 30 Jul 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: CIDRAP News, 29 Jul 2005 [edited]\n<http://www.cidrap.umn.edu/cidrap/content/influenza/avianflu/news/july2905avian.html>\n\nRussian birds have H5N1\n-----------------------\nNews services said today the avian influenza outbreak reported last week in\nRussia involves the dangerous H5N1 strain.\nA statement from Russia's Agriculture Ministry identified the flu outbreak\nin poultry in the Novosibirsk region of Siberia as H5N1, according to the\nAssociated Press (AP).\n'That raises the need for undertaking quarantine measures of the widest\nscope,' the AP quoted the ministry as saying.\nIf the report is accurate, the outbreak marks the 1st known appearance of\nthe H5N1 virus in Russia. The virus has been active in Southeast and East\nAsia since late 2003, causing more than 100 human cases with more than 50\ndeaths in Vietnam, Thailand, Cambodia, and Indonesia.\nThe outbreak in southwestern Siberia was 1st reported last week. Late last\nweek, an official at a Russian disease research center identified the virus\nas H5N2, which is less virulent than H5N1 and has infected humans. But in a\n24 Jul 2005 report to the World Organization for Animal Health, Dr. Evgueny\nA. Nepoklonov of the Ministry of Agriculture Moscow said the virus had been\nidentified only as an H5.\nEarlier reports said the disease had killed hundreds of geese, ducks,\nturkeys, and chickens in 9 villages. No human cases have been reported.\nNews of the Siberian outbreak comes about 2 months after the first reports\nof an outbreak among migratory birds at the Qinghai Lake wildlife refuge in\nnorthern China. World Health Organization (WHO) officials who visited the\nsite in June 2005 estimated that about 5000 birds had died. They worried\nthat birds leaving the refuge later this summer would spread the disease to\ndistant places.\n2 reports published in scientific journals earlier in July 2005 seconded\nthat concern. A group of Chinese researchers writing in Science called\nQinghai Lake 'a breeding center for migrant birds that congregate from\nSoutheast Asia, Siberia, Australia, and New Zealand.' They said the\noutbreak posed a risk that H5N1 could become a global threat.\nIn addition to the Qinghai Lake outbreak, 2 poultry outbreaks were reported\nin June in China's northwestern province of Xinjiang, to the west of the\nwildlife refuge.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[The above CIDRAP item provides useful complementary background. The\nidentification of H5N1, still to be officially confirmed and duly notified,\nhas also been reported on 30 Jul 2005 by the Russian newspaper Kommersant\n(see <http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/L30334331.htm>). - Mod.AS]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n But in a\n24 Jul 2005 report to the World Organization for Animal Health, Dr. Evgueny\nA. Nepoklonov of the Ministry of Agriculture Moscow said the virus had been\nidentified only as an H5. The\nidentification of H5N1, still to be officially confirmed and duly notified,\nhas also been reported on 30 Jul 2005 by the Russian newspaper Kommersant\n \nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n Sponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nPrinciples and Practice of Infectious Diseases Online, 6th edition\n<http://tinyurl.com/7sfzw>\n News of the Siberian outbreak comes about 2 months after the first reports\nof an outbreak among migratory birds at the Qinghai Lake wildlife refuge in\nnorthern China. In addition to the Qinghai Lake outbreak, 2 poultry outbreaks were reported\nin June in China's northwestern province of Xinjiang, to the west of the\nwildlife refuge. -----------------------\nNews services said today the avian influenza outbreak reported last week in\n Late last\nweek, an official at a Russian disease research center identified the virus\nas H5N2, which is less virulent than H5N1 and has infected humans. They worried\nthat birds leaving the refuge later this summer would spread the disease to\ndistant places. \n2 reports published in scientific journals earlier in July 2005 seconded\nthat concern. A statement from Russia's Agriculture Ministry identified the flu outbreak\nin poultry in the Novosibirsk region of Siberia as H5N1, according to the\nAssociated Press (AP).", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2005-07-25 00:00:00", "2005-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-06-25 00:00:00", "2005-06-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Thailand", "country": "Thailand"}, {"location": "Vietnam", "country": "Vietnam"}, {"location": "Cambodia", "country": "Cambodia"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "New Zealand", "country": "New Zealand"}, {"location": "Xinjiang", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Siberia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Indonesia", "country": "Indonesia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1116", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza - Russia (Siberia)(05): H5N1 susp.", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1116", "date": "2005-07-29 23:50:00", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA - RUSSIA (SIBERIA)(05): H5N1 SUSPECTED\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nPrinciples and Practice of Infectious Diseases Online, 6th edition\n<http://tinyurl.com/7sfzw>\n[1]\nDate: Fri, 29 Jul 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource:The Associated Press, 29 Jul 2005 [edited]\n<http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2005/07/29/AR2005072900734.html>\n\nDangerous Bird Flu Strain Found in Russia\n-----------------------------------------\nInvestigators have determined that a strain of bird flu virus infecting\nfowl in Russia is the type that can infect humans, the Agriculture Ministry\nsaid Friday [29 Jul 2005].\nThe virus caused the deaths of hundreds of birds in a section of Siberia\nthis month, but no human infections have been reported.\nIn a brief statement, the ministry identified the virus as avian flu type A\nH5 N1.\n'That raises the need for undertaking quarantine measures of the widest\nscope,' the statement said. Ministry officials could not immediately be\nreached for elaboration.\nStrains of bird flu have been hitting flocks throughout Asia and some fatal\nhuman cases have been reported there.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[According to the current AP media item, the agent is Influenza virus type\nA, serotype H5N1. This contradicts earlier media-derived information (see\n20050723.2127), according to which the agent was H5N2. An early official\nnotification on the determined neuraminidase (N) type is urgently required.\n- Mod.AS]\n******\n[2]\nDate: 29 Jul 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: OIE Disease Information 29 July 2005 Vol. 18 - No. 30\n<http://www.oie.int/eng/info/hebdo/AIS_60.HTM#Sec4>\n\nAvian influenza in Russia\n------------------------\nImmediate notification report\nTranslation of information received on 24 July 2005 from Dr Evgueny A.\nNepoklonov, Head of the Main Veterinary Department, Ministry of Agriculture\nand Food, Moscow:\nReport date: 24 July 2005 (see also Disease Information, 18 [29], 212,\ndated 22 Jul 2005).\nPrecise identification of agent: influenza virus type A. The haemagglutinin\nsubtype has been preliminarily identified (from pathological material) as\nH5. After confirmation by virus isolation a separate notification will be\nsent. Tests are being performed to determine the neuraminidase type.\nDate of first confirmation of the event: 23 Jul 2005.\nDate of start of the event: 18 Jul 2005.\nNature of diagnosis: clinical, post-mortem and laboratory.\nDetails of outbreak:\nFirst administrative division: Novosibirsk region (Novosibirskaya oblast)\nLower administrative division: Kupino\nType of epidemiological unit: village\nName of the location: ...\nDate of start of the outbreak: 18 Jul 2005\nSpecies: avi\nNumber of animals in the outbreak\nsusceptible / cases / deaths / destroyed / slaughtered\n... / ... / ... / ... / ...\nFirst administrative division: Novosibirsk region (Novosibirskaya oblast)\nLower administrative division: Dovolnoye\nType of epidemiological unit: village\nName of the location: ...\nDate of start of the outbreak: 22 Jul 2005\nSpecies: avi\nNumber of animals in the outbreak\nsusceptible / cases / deaths / destroyed / slaughtered\n... / ... / ... / ... / ...\nFirst administrative division: Novosibirsk region (Novosibirskaya oblast)\nLower administrative division: Chistoozernoye\nType of epidemiological unit: village\nName of the location: ...\nDate of start of the outbreak: 22 Jul 2005\nSpecies: avi\nNumber of animals in the outbreak\nsusceptible / cases / deaths / destroyed / slaughtered\n... / ... / ... / ... / ...\nDescription of affected populations: chickens, turkeys, ducks and geese in\nbackyard holdings in 9 villages.\nDiagnosis:\nLaboratory where diagnosis was made: Federal Centre for Animal Health (ARRIAH)\nDiagnostic tests used / Date / Results\n- ELISA(1) (for antigen detection)/ 23 Jul 2005 / positive\n- PCR(2) (M-protein gene) / .../ [no result yet - Mod. PC]\n- haemagglutination test / ... / [no result yet - Mod. PC]\nSource of outbreaks or origin of infection: an epidemiological analysis has\nshown that the disease started in a flock in contact with wild waterfowl at\nopen water reservoirs. This is proposed as the primary source of the virus.\nIn addition, there are reports of the disease in wild birds.\nControl measures undertaken:\n- stamping out;\n- quarantine;\n- movement control inside the country;\n- screening;\n- zoning;\n- disinfection of infected premises/establishments.\nVaccination prohibited: yes.\nOther details/comments:\n- Considering the low mortality rate (1-2.6 percent, depending on the\nlocality), the virus titres are very high in some samples of pathological\nmaterial.\n- No signs of the disease have appeared in commercial poultry farms in the\nregion.\n- The reasons for the disease's lack of species specificity are still\nunclear. Bacteriological and toxicological tests of samples of water and\nsoil from around the water and feeding points in the affected areas are\ncontinuing.\n- Newcastle disease virus was not found in samples from the affected areas.\n(1) ELISA: enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay\n(2) PCR: polymerase chain reaction\nNote by the OIE Animal Health Information Department: Changes in the\nobligations of OIE Member Countries to notify avian influenza ('notifiable\navian influenza'), which were adopted during the 73rd OIE General Session\nin May 2005, will come into effect on 1 Jan 2006. The OIE Animal Health\nInformation Department is publishing the above report, based on the\nofficial notification received from the Delegate of Russia, because of the\nimportance of monitoring the disease situation in Asia.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Although this report does not contain critical neuraminidase (N) type\ninformation, we are including it because its URL provides a few more\ndetails -- a map of the outbreak area, test results and date etc. See\nprevious OIE posting on this outbreak. - Mod.PC]", "summary": "Control measures undertaken:\n- stamping out;\n- quarantine;\n- movement control inside the country;\n- screening;\n- zoning;\n- disinfection of infected premises/establishments. AVIAN INFLUENZA - RUSSIA (SIBERIA)(05): H5N1 SUSPECTED\n**************************************************\n --\nProMED-mail\n< --\nProMED-mail\n< Diagnosis:\nLaboratory where diagnosis was made: Federal Centre for Animal Health (ARRIAH)\n AS]\n******\n (for antigen detection)/ 23 Jul 2005 / positive\n- PCR(2) (M-protein gene) / .../", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2006-01-01 00:00:00", "2005-03-25 00:00:00", "2005-07-24 00:00:00", "2005-05-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 00:00:00", "2005-07-29 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Moscow", "country": "Russia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1124", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza - Russia (Siberia)(09): H5N1 susp.", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1124", "date": "2005-08-02 23:50:00", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA - RUSSIA (SIBERIA) (09): H5N1 suspected\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nTransactions of the Royal Society of Tropical Medicine and Hygiene\n<http://tinyurl.com/eyno6>\n[1]\nDate: Tue 2 Aug 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: AFP via Gulftimes, Qatar, 2 Aug 2005 [edited]\n<http://www.gulftimes.com/site/topics/article.asp?cu_no=2&item_no=46932&version=1&template_id=39&parent_id=21>\n\nMass poultry slaughter in Siberian villages\n-----------------------------------------------\nHealth authorities in neighboring provinces of Russia and Kazakhstan\nset about slaughtering poultry yesterday [1 Aug 2005] amid signs that\nthe deadly bird flu virus was steadily spreading westwards from\nChina, officials said. The chief sanitary doctor of the Siberian\nprovince of Novosibirsk said that slaughtering of poultry would begin\ntoday in 13 villages where avian flu had been detected, the H5N1\nsub-type that can be transmitted to humans.\n'The destruction will begin on 2 Aug 2005. Measures are being worked\nout to compensate the birds' owners,' Valery Mikheyev was quoted by\nItar-Tass news agency as saying. He played down the danger to people\nliving in the villages where the virus had been found.\n'The state of health of the inhabitants of these areas gives no cause\nfor alarm,' Mikheyev said. 'Up to 6000 people are being checked per\nday,' he said.\nIn the neighboring Kazakh province of Pavlodar, meanwhile, officials\nsaid they had slaughtered 2350 geese and 250 ducks, after some 600\npoultry at a farm died from bird flu starting on 20 Jul 2005, the\nKazakh Sanitary and Epidemiological Agency said [see commentary].\nTests were under way to determine whether the cases in Kazakhstan\nwere of the H5N1 type.\nSo far, cases of H5N1 around the world have mainly been transmitted\nbetween animals. But it has killed more than 60 people in Southeast\nAsia since 2003, including in Viet Nam, Thailand, Cambodia and\nIndonesia. The arrival of the virus in Russia was greeted with alarm\nin some communities, amid expectations that bird flu could spread to\nmore densely populated western Russia.\nThe Kommersant newspaper reported that one poultry company in the\nwestern Siberian province of Orenburg was preparing to shoot down\nmigratory birds flying over its territory. 'The most dangerous thing\nis that from Kazakhstan the route of migratory birds goes through the\nEuropean part of Russia where the poultry industry is concentrated,'\nKommersant quoted the company's director, Nikolai Khaustov, as\nsaying. 'We have already distributed cartridges to volunteers who\nwill fire at all birds flying towards our factory. The situation is\nalarming,' Khaustov said.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[2]\nDate: Tue 2 Aug 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Itar-Tass News agency, 2 Aug 2005 [edited]\n<http://www.tass.ru/eng/level2.html?NewsID=2281149&PageNum=0>\n\n65 000 domestic birds to be destroyed in Novosibirsk region over flu\n-----------------------------------------------\nAbout 65 000 domestic birds will be destroyed in 13 settlements of\nRussia's Novosibirsk region, where quarantine was introduced over\nbird flu, the deputy governor of the region told a press conference\non Tuesday [2 Aug 2005].\nAlthough the number of fowl killed by bird flu has declined over the\npast few days, a decision was reached to destroy all household\npoultry and pay compensation to the population, Viktor Gergert said.\nAlmost 9 million rubles [USD 315 000] have been earmarked for that\nfrom the regional budget.\nSo far, no cases of humans being infected with bird flu have been\nregistered in the Novosibirsk region, sources from the regional\nheadquarters set up to tackle the problem have said.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[3]\nDate: Tue 2 Aug 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Kazinform - Kazach Information Agency, 2 Aug 2005 [edited]\n<http://www.inform.kz/txt/showarticle.php?lang=eng&id=133382>\n\nBird flu rages on the border of Kazakhstan and Russia\n-----------------------------------------------\nThe Berdyuzhskii district in Tyumen oblast, bordering on Kazakhstan,\nis under quarantine due to a 'flu bird' outbreak, our correspondent\nreports.\nOfficial authorities are not commenting. According to unofficial\ndata, the veterinary administration of the Tyumen oblast government\nhas begun large scale inspection of all poultry plants.\n[Byline: Kalil Kabdulvakhitov]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[4]\nDate: Tue 2 Aug 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: ABC - Australia, 2 Aug 2005 [abridged, edited]\n<http://www.abc.net.au/worldtoday/content/2005/s1428173.htm>\n\nIllegal bird trade may be contributing to spread of bird flu\n-----------------------------------------------\nThe rapid spread of the deadly Asian bird flu virus is sparking\nconcerns about the effectiveness of the international containment\nprotocol.\nThe highly contagious strain of avian flu has now turned up in\npoultry stocks in Siberia and Kazakhstan, and some health authorities\nsay it's only a matter of time before the disease hits European Union\ncountries.\nRussian doctors have been quick to blame migratory birds flying in\nfrom infected regions of China. But bird experts say an illegal trade\nin poultry cannot be ruled out as the source of the latest outbreak.\nIn a bid to halt the spread of bird flu, all domestic birds in a\nwestern Siberian region will be slaughtered today [2 Aug 2005].\nThat's thousands of geese, chickens and ducks from more than a dozen\nvillages.\nJust over the border in Kazakhstan, the cull has been underway for\ndays, and a bird transport ban has been imposed on the affected areas.\nThe virus was 1st detected 2 weeks ago in the area, and the World\nHealth Organization has still yet to confirm that it is the highly\ncontagious strain of the virus, H5N1.\n[Byline: Karen Barlow & Eleanor Hall]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[In their notification on HPAI to the OIE, 24 Jul 2005, the Russian\nauthorities indicated as follows: 'The hemagglutinin subtype has been\npreliminarily identified (from pathological material) as H5. After\nconfirmation by virus isolation, a separate notification will be\nsent. Tests are being performed to determine the neuraminidase type.'\nRather puzzling: so far there is still no official information about\nthe N (neuraminidase) serotyping of the H5 virus strain involved in\noutbreaks in Russia, H5N1 remaining 'suspected.' And, in spite of\nrepeated newswires about a human case and about outbreaks in poultry,\nthere has been no official response at all from neighboring\nKazakhstan.\nThere are rumors about the northwestward spread of the disease in\nSiberia from Novosibirsk to the oblasts (regions, administrative and\nterritorial divisions) Omsk and Tyumen (Tioumen); further information\nand an official update are urgently needed.\nA useful map, provided by OIE's Animal Health Information Department,\ncan be accessed at\n<http://www.oie.int/cartes/RUS050729.jpg>.\n- Mod.AS]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n [Byline: Kalil Kabdulvakhitov]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n \nAbout 65 000 domestic birds will be destroyed in 13 settlements of\nRussia's Novosibirsk region, where quarantine was introduced over\nbird flu, the deputy governor of the region told a press conference\non Tuesday [2 Aug 2005]. The most dangerous thing\nis that from Kazakhstan the route of migratory birds goes through the\nEuropean part of Russia where the poultry industry is concentrated,'\nKommersant quoted the company's director, Nikolai Khaustov, as\nsaying. ' Health authorities in neighboring provinces of Russia and Kazakhstan\nset about slaughtering poultry yesterday [1 Aug 2005] amid signs that\nthe deadly bird flu virus was steadily spreading westwards from\nChina, officials said. The chief sanitary doctor of the Siberian\nprovince of Novosibirsk said that slaughtering of poultry would begin\ntoday in 13 villages where avian flu had been detected, the H5N1\nsub-type that can be transmitted to humans. The highly contagious strain of avian flu has now turned up in\npoultry stocks in Siberia and Kazakhstan, and some health authorities\nsay it's only a matter of time before the disease hits European Union\ncountries. The virus was 1st detected 2 weeks ago in the area, and the World\nHealth Organization has still yet to confirm that it is the highly\ncontagious strain of the virus, H5N1.\n And, in spite of\nrepeated newswires about a human case and about outbreaks in poultry,\nthere has been no official response at all from neighboring\nKazakhstan.
