Source: Webindia123, India, 11 May 2005 [edited]\n<http://www.newindpress.com/Newsitems.asp?ID=IE320050510121915&Title=Features>\n\nBird flu strain found in 3 Chennai poultry workers\n The government has ordered director of medical education P Vijayalakshmi to\ninvestigate the reported bird flu strain found among Tamil Nadu poultry\nworkers. All 3 who show positivity have never travelled overseas, nor is any poultry\nimported into India from East Asia regions where epidemics have occurred --\nso a native exposure to the virus is the only alternative, she says. Dr Jackie Katz of the CDC's Influenza Branch confirmed to this website\nnewspaper that the 3 people tested positive for antibody to a highly\npathogenic H5N1 virus. Researchers found the H5N1 signs in samples collected in 2002, which was\nconfirmed by the world's foremost infectious diseases laboratory, the\nCenters for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), Atlanta late in 2004. The avian influenza virus has been in the headlines since its outbreak in\nEast Asia in 2004, and the World Health Organisation (WHO) has issued a\nglobal alert about this highly contagious bug. Poultry is a major\nstate industry for the area, and migratory birds arrive every year on Tamil\nNadu's coast in Vedanthangal, north of Chennai. But virus isolation and sequencing has not been attempted in India, as\nthere is a lack of such a secure bio-safety facility, said Dr A C Mishra,\ndirector of the National Institute of Virology, Pune. But Habayeb says there is no reason to panic, as India has adequate\nmechanisms for control of disease outbreaks, citing the effective handling\nof the SARS incident.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "sars"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2002-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2005-05-12 00:00:00", "1997-03-25 00:00:00", "2005-05-11 00:00:00", "2001-03-25 00:00:00", "2004-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Vedanthangal", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kattangalathur", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Atlanta", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "Hong Kong"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1084", "headline": "PRO/AH> Avian influenza - Eastern Asia (71): H5N1, duck meat, 2003", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1084", "date": "2005-07-14 23:50:00", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA - EASTERN ASIA (71): H5N1, DUCK MEAT, 2003\n**********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSponsored in part by Elsevier, organizer of\nThe 1st International Conference for the Journal of Travel Medicine and\nInfectious Disease\n<http://tinyurl.com/8vv5p>\nDate: Thu 14 Jul 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Virology, 17 Jun 2005 [edited]\n<http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?\ncmd=Retrieve&db=pubmed&dopt=Abstract&list_uids=15964604&query_hl=12>\n\nJapan: Characterization of an H5N1 Influenza virus in imported Duck Meat\n------------------------------------------------------------------------\nThe following is the abstract of a paper authored by M. Mase and 7 others at\nthe Department of Infectious Diseases, National Institute of Animal Health, 3-1-\n5 Kannondai, Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305-0856, Japan, entitled 'Isolation of a\ngenotypically unique H5N1 influenza virus from duck meat imported into Japan\nfrom China', published ahead of print in Virology 17 Jun 2005.\n'An influenza A (H5N1) virus was isolated from duck meat processed for human\nconsumption, imported to Japan from Shandong Province, China in 2003. This\nvirus was antigenically different from other H5 viruses, including the Hong\nKong H5N1 viruses isolated from humans in 1997 and 2003. Sequence analysis\nrevealed that 6 genes (PB1, PA, HA, NA, M, and NS) of this virus showed greater\nthan 97 percent nucleotide identity with their counterparts from recent H5N1\nviruses, but that the remaining 2 genes (PB2 and NP) were derived from other\nunknown viruses. This duck meat isolate was highly pathogenic to chickens upon\nintravenous or intranasal inoculation, replicated well in the lungs of mice and\nspread to the brain, but was not as pathogenic in mice as H5N1 human isolates\n(with a dose lethal to 50 percent of mice (MLD(50)) = 5 x 10(6) 50 percent egg\ninfectious doses [EID(50)]). However, viruses isolated from the brain of mice\npreviously infected with the virus were substantially more pathogenic (MLD(50)\n= approximately 10(2) EID(50)) and possessed some amino acid substitutions\nrelative to the original virus. These results show that poultry products\ncontaminated with influenza viruses of high pathogenic potential to mammals are\na threat to public health even in countries where the virus is not enzootic and\nrepresent a possible source of influenza outbreaks in poultry.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Significant features of this report are: (1) The apparent survival of an avian\ninfluenza virus in processed duck meat destined for export; (2) the antigenic\ndistinctiveness of this virus from other H5N1 viruses known to be in\ncirculation between 1997 and 2003, notwithstanding the greater than 97 percent\nnucleotide identity of the HA and NA genome subunits; (3) the characterization\nof this virus as a reassortant with 2 genome subunits from one or more unknown\ninfluenza virus.\nBiological characterization of the virus in mice suggested that it was less\npathogenic than human isolates of H5N1 viruses but that it had potential to be\ncome more virulent, although extrapolation from mouse to man seems a dubious\nprocedure at this stage of knowledge. Perhaps the most intriguing feature of\nthis report is the unresolved identity of the influenza virus (or viruses)\ncontributing the PB2 and NP genome subunits, which one must assume was/were\ncirculating in some host somewhere in China at that time or before. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "[Significant features of this report are: (1) The apparent survival of an avian\ninfluenza virus in processed duck meat destined for export; (2) the antigenic\ndistinctiveness of this virus from other H5N1 viruses known to be in\ncirculation between 1997 and 2003, notwithstanding the greater than 97 percent\nnucleotide identity of the HA and NA genome subunits; (3) the characterization\nof this virus as a reassortant with 2 genome subunits from one or more unknown\ninfluenza virus. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n These results show that poultry products\ncontaminated with influenza viruses of high pathogenic potential to mammals are\na threat to public health even in countries where the virus is not enzootic and\nrepresent a possible source of influenza outbreaks in poultry.\n Sequence analysis\nrevealed that 6 genes (PB1, PA, HA, NA, M, and NS) of this virus showed greater\nthan 97 percent nucleotide identity with their counterparts from recent H5N1\nviruses, but that the remaining 2 genes (PB2 and NP) were derived from other\nunknown viruses. The following is the abstract of a paper authored by M. Mase and 7 others at\nthe Department of Infectious Diseases, National Institute of Animal Health, 3-1-\n5 Kannondai, Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305-0856, Japan, entitled 'Isolation of a\ngenotypically unique H5N1 influenza virus from duck meat imported into Japan\nfrom China', published ahead of print in Virology 17 Jun 2005. However, viruses isolated from the brain of mice\npreviously infected with the virus were substantially more pathogenic (MLD(50)\n= approximately 10(2) EID(50)) and possessed some amino acid substitutions\nrelative to the original virus. Biological characterization of the virus in mice suggested that it was less\npathogenic than human isolates of H5N1 viruses but that it had potential to be\ncome more virulent, although extrapolation from mouse to man seems a dubious\nprocedure at this stage of knowledge. This duck meat isolate was highly pathogenic to chickens upon\nintravenous or intranasal inoculation, replicated well in the lungs of mice and\nspread to the brain, but was not as pathogenic in mice as H5N1 human isolates\n The 1st International Conference for the Journal of Travel Medicine and\nInfectious Disease\n<http://tinyurl.com/8vv5p>\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1997-03-25 00:00:00", "1971-03-25 00:00:00", "2003-03-25 00:00:00", "2005-06-17 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Tsukuba", "country": "Japan"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Shandong Province", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Hong", "country": "Thailand"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "Japan"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "790", "headline": "PRO/AH> Avian influenza A/H5N1, migratory birds - Russia (Siberia)(02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=790", "date": "2004-11-30 23:50:00", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA A/H5N1, MIGRATORY BIRDS - RUSSIA (SIBERIA) (02)\n****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Tue 30 nov 2004\nFrom: David Swayne <dswayne@seprl.usda.gov>\n[The following statement has been received from David E. Swayne, Laboratory\nDirector, Southeast Poultry Research Laboratory, Agricultural Research\nService, U.S. Department of Agriculture, Athens, Georgia, USA; David L.\nSuarez, Veterinary Medical Officer, Southeast Poultry Research Laboratory,\nAgricultural Research Service, U.S. Department of Agriculture, Athens,\nGeorgia, USA; and Alexander Shestopalov, Director, Laboratory to\nInvestigate and Monitor Emerging Zoonotic Diseases, 'Vector' State Virology\nand Biotechnology Institute, Novosibirsk, Russia. ProMED-mail welcomes the\nopportunity to post this information. - Mod.CP]\n\nMisinterpretation of Data on Isolation of Avian Influenza A (H5N1) Virus\nfrom Migratory Birds in Siberia\n---------------------------------------------------\nA recent report in the media indicated that an avian influenza A (H5N1)\nvirus had been isolated from migrating birds in the Novosibirsk region of\nRussia. The report is a misinterpretation of the scientific data.\nIn a joint avian influenza project in wild birds between laboratories at\nthe 'Vector' State Virology and Biotechnology Institute (Novosibirsk,\nRussia), the Ivanovski Institute of Virology (Moscow, Russia) and the U.S.\nDepartment of Agriculture (Athens, Georgia), several avian influenza\nviruses including H5-type influenza viruses have been isolated from\nmigratory birds in Russia over the past 4 years. In 2003, an H5 avian\ninfluenza A virus was isolated by the Laboratory for Investigation and\nSurveillance of Emerging Zoonotic Diseases (Novosibirsk, Russia) from a\nwild mallard duck on lake Chany in the south of Western Siberia and\nsequenced to determine relatedness to other H5-type avian influenza A\nviruses in Asian poultry. The A/mallard/Chany/9/03 avian influenza A virus\nwas related to, but was not identical to current avian influenza A (H5N1)\nviruses circulating in domestic poultry in Asia.\nThe A/mallard/Chany/9/03 avian influenza virus has hemagglutinin sequence\nsimilarity in the 90-95 percent range to the current Asian influenza A\n(H5N1) virus, which is similar to sequences of other Eurasian H5-type avian\ninfluenza viruses, including A/duck/Potsdam/1402-6/86 (H5N2) and\nA/turkey/England/50-92/91 (H5N1).\nThese data emphasize the need for continuing surveillance of migratory\nbirds for avian influenza viruses, and studies of such viruses will\nincrease our understanding of the ecology of avian influenza viruses,\nespecially in transfer of such viruses between migratory birds and domestic\npoultry. However, the A/mallard/Chany/9/03 avian influenza virus is not the\nsame virus as the Asian H5N1, and is not evidence of infection and\nspreading of the current Asian H5N1 avian influenza virus by migratory\nbirds outside of the 7 infected Asian countries/regions.\n--\nDavid E. Swayne, DVM, PhD\nLaboratory Director\nSoutheast Poultry Research Laboratory\nUSDA/ARS\n934 College Station Road\nAthens, Georgia\n<dswayne@seprl.usda.gov>", "summary": "In a joint avian influenza project in wild birds between laboratories at\nthe 'Vector' State Virology and Biotechnology Institute (Novosibirsk,\nRussia), the Ivanovski Institute of Virology (Moscow, Russia) and the U.S.\nDepartment of Agriculture (Athens, Georgia), several avian influenza\nviruses including H5-type influenza viruses have been isolated from\nmigratory birds in Russia over the past 4 years. In 2003, an H5 avian\ninfluenza A virus was isolated by the Laboratory for Investigation and\nSurveillance of Emerging Zoonotic Diseases (Novosibirsk, Russia) from a\nwild mallard duck on lake Chany in the south of Western Siberia and\nsequenced to determine relatedness to other H5-type avian influenza A\nviruses in Asian poultry. These data emphasize the need for continuing surveillance of migratory\nbirds for avian influenza viruses, and studies of such viruses will\nincrease our understanding of the ecology of avian influenza viruses,\nespecially in transfer of such viruses between migratory birds and domestic\npoultry. The A/mallard/Chany/9/03 avian influenza virus has hemagglutinin sequence\nsimilarity in the 90-95 percent range to the current Asian influenza A\n(H5N1) virus, which is similar to sequences of other Eurasian H5-type avian\ninfluenza viruses, including A/duck/Potsdam/1402-6/86 (H5N2) and\nA/turkey/England/50-92/91 (H5N1). However, the A/mallard/Chany/9/03 avian influenza virus is not the\nsame virus as the Asian H5N1, and is not evidence of infection and\nspreading of the current Asian H5N1 avian influenza virus by migratory\nbirds outside of the 7 infected Asian countries/regions.\n A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n --\nDavid E. Swayne, DVM, PhD\nLaboratory Director\nSoutheast Poultry Research Laboratory\nUSDA/ARS\n934 Suarez, Veterinary Medical Officer, Southeast Poultry Research Laboratory,\nAgricultural Research Service, U.S. Department of Agriculture, Athens,\nGeorgia, USA; and Alexander Shestopalov, Director, Laboratory to\nInvestigate and Monitor Emerging Zoonotic Diseases, 'Vector' State Virology\nand Biotechnology Institute, Novosibirsk, Russia. A recent report in the media indicated that an avian influenza A (H5N1)\nvirus had been isolated from migrating birds in the Novosibirsk region of\nRussia. CP]\n\nMisinterpretation of Data on Isolation of Avian Influenza A (H5N1) Virus\nfrom Migratory Birds in Siberia\n The A/mallard/Chany/9/03 avian influenza A virus\nwas related to, but was not identical to current avian influenza Director, Southeast Poultry Research Laboratory, Agricultural Research\nService, U.S. Department of Agriculture, Athens, Georgia, USA; David L.\n College Station Road\nAthens, Georgia\n<dswayne@seprl.usda.gov> AVIAN INFLUENZA A/H5N1, MIGRATORY BIRDS - RUSSIA (SIBERIA) (02)\n A (H5N1)\nviruses circulating in domestic poultry in Asia. ProMED-mail welcomes the\nopportunity to post this information. The report is a misinterpretation of the scientific data.\n Date: Tue 30 nov 2004\n [The following statement has been received from David E. Swayne, Laboratory\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "influenza a/h5n1"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2003-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Georgia", "country": "Georgia"}, {"location": "Moscow", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Novosibirsk", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Athens", "country": "Greece"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "775", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza A/H5N1, domestic ducks - Asia", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=775", "date": "2004-10-29 23:50:00", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA A/H5N1, DOMESTIC DUCKS - ASIA\n*********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Fri 29 Oct 2004\nFrom: Marianne Hopp <mjhopp12@yahoo.com>\nSource: WHO - CSR (Communicable Disease Surveillance & Response)\nOutbreak News, 29 Oct 2004 [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2004_10_29/en/>\n\nAvian influenza - situation in Asia: altered role of domestic ducks\n-------------------------------------------------------------------\nCountries experiencing outbreaks of H5N1 in poultry need to be aware\nthat domestic ducks may have acquired an important role in the\ntransmission of highly pathogenic H5N1 to other poultry and,\npossibly, to humans as well.\nA new laboratory study [see commentary] of domestic ducks infected\nwith several 2004 H5N1 viruses shows that, when compared with\ninfections caused by viruses from 2003, domestic ducks are shedding\nmore virus for longer periods. The majority are doing so without\nshowing symptoms of illness.\nFindings from this study also show that, compared to highly\npathogenic avian influenza [HPAI] viruses from previous outbreaks, the\nrecent H5N1 viruses survive several days longer in the environment.\nThe study found that the quantities of virus excreted by\nhealthy-looking ducks approach those excreted by diseased -- and\nvisibly very ill -- chickens. This suggests that domestic ducks might\nnow be acting as a 'silent' reservoir for the H5N1 virus, which is\nhighly pathogenic for chickens.\nTo date, no evidence has linked human H5N1 cases to exposure to\nasymptomatic domestic ducks. However, the laboratory findings come at\na time when some human cases could not be traced to contact with\ndiseased or dead poultry.\nIn terms of preventing further human cases, it is of public health\nconcern that ducks may be infected and shed virus for long periods,\nyet issue no 'warning signal' in the form of visible signs and\nsymptoms that alert people to take precautions. The concern is\ngreatest in rural areas of affected countries, where free-ranging\nducks and chickens often mingle, frequently sharing the same water\nsupplies.\nThe new findings expand on recent evidence, based on characterization\nof H5N1 viruses from southern China, that domestic ducks have played\na central role in generating and maintaining H5N1, in its highly\npathogenic form, in parts of Asia. [Li KS, Wang J, Smith GJD et al.\nGenesis of a highly pathogenic and potentially pandemic H5N1\ninfluenza virus in eastern Asia. Nature; 430 (8 July 2004): 209-13].\nFindings pointing to an altered role for domestic ducks join other\nrecent evidence that the H5N1 virus circulating in parts of Asia has\nincreased its pathogenicity in chickens and mice (a laboratory model\nfor mammals), and has expanded its host range to include mammals,\nsuch as felines, not previously considered susceptible to infection.\n[In view of the said findings, the following] public health\nrecommendations for affected countries [should be applied]:\n- Investigation of human cases should now include possible exposure\nto apparently healthy domestic ducks, as well as to diseased or dead\npoultry, as a risk factor for infection.\n- Advice for people living in an affected area should be revised to\ninclude precautions for apparently healthy ducks similar to those for\nvisibly ill poultry.\n- Ducks should not be kept as pets or allowed to enter households.\n- Water supplies for human use should not be drawn from open ponds\nused by domestic ducks and should be stored in ways that prevent\ncontact with ducks.\n- Once prepared and properly cooked, duck meat and eggs do not pose a\nrisk to human health.\n- Significant exposure can occur during home slaughtering and\npreparation prior to cooking, and these risks need to be addressed.\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2004_10_29/en/>\n<http://www.who.int/foodsafety/micro/avian2/en/>\nWHO, FAO, and OIE recognize that the altered role of domestic ducks\nin the transmission cycle of H5N1 should be addressed, as it may\ncomplicate efforts to control the disease in poultry and to prevent\nfurther human cases.\nResearch on the prevalence of asymptomatic infection in ducks in Asia\nis urgently needed. Such information will allow a focused approach to\nthe prevention of human cases arising from exposure to apparently\nhealthy domestic ducks.\nThe wider implications of the role played by domestic ducks are being\njointly considered by FAO and OIE in formulating a long-term strategy\nfor bringing the current outbreaks in poultry under control. With the\nH5N1 virus now endemic in parts of Asia, significant changes in\nfarming practices may be needed to control the disease, especially in\nrural areas, and thus reduce opportunities for community-wide\nexposure.\nIn animals, surveillance remains the key to prevention and control,\nand this activity needs to be adequately supported.\nFAO and OIE have recently issued comprehensive guidelines for\nresponding to the outbreaks of H5N1 in poultry in Asia.\n[See 20040927.2672 and\n<http://www.oie.int/eng/AVIAN_INFLUENZA/FAO%20recommendations%20on%20HPAI.pdf>].\nThe 2 agencies are conducting research on the epidemiology of H5N1\ninfection in ducks and on the use of vaccination to control infection.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[According to the CSR notification, the laboratory studies mentioned\nwere completed last week [3rd week of October 2004] by researchers at\nthe WHO collaborating center for animal influenza viruses at St. Jude\nChildren's Research Hospital in Memphis, Tennessee, USA. The main\nfindings are being made public by the WHO, in advance of publication,\nbecause of their significance for human health.\n<http://www.who.int/csr/disease/avian_influenza/labstudy_2004_10_29/en/>\nThe findings, and the subsequent WHO recommendations, might have\nimpact upon the internationally prescribed measures to control HPAI.\nIf (apparently) 'healthy' ducks are present in the vicinity of\naffected poultry farms, the stamping out of the latter might not be\nsufficient to eradicate the outbreak. This new situation might\nprescribe a need to reassess existing provisions, as laid out in\nchapter 2.7.12 of OIE's terrestrial animal health code\n<http://oie.int/eng/normes/mcode/en_chapitre_2.7.12.htm>\nIt might also explain the recurrence of the disease in countries like\nThailand, where stamping-out policy without vaccination has been\napplied. - Mod.AS]", "summary": "Findings pointing to an altered role for domestic ducks join other\nrecent evidence that the H5N1 virus circulating in parts of Asia has\nincreased its pathogenicity in chickens and mice (a laboratory model\nfor mammals), and has expanded its host range to include mammals,\nsuch as felines, not previously considered susceptible to infection.\n With the\nH5N1 virus now endemic in parts of Asia, significant changes in\nfarming practices may be needed to control the disease, especially in\nrural areas, and thus reduce opportunities for community-wide\nexposure.\n A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n [In view of the said findings, the following] public health\nrecommendations for affected countries [should be applied]:\n- Investigation of human cases should now include possible exposure\nto apparently healthy domestic ducks, as well as to diseased or dead\npoultry, as a risk factor for infection. Countries experiencing outbreaks of H5N1 in poultry need to be aware\nthat domestic ducks may have acquired an important role in the\ntransmission of highly pathogenic H5N1 to other poultry and,\npossibly, to humans as well.\n This new situation might\nprescribe a need to reassess existing provisions, as laid out in\nchapter 2.7.12 of OIE's terrestrial animal health code\n<http://oie.int/eng/normes/mcode/en_chapitre_2.7.12.htm>\n A new laboratory study [see commentary] of domestic ducks infected\nwith several 2004 H5N1 viruses shows that, when compared with\ninfections caused by viruses from 2003, domestic ducks are shedding\nmore virus for longer periods. WHO, FAO, and OIE recognize that the altered role of domestic ducks\nin the transmission cycle of H5N1 should be addressed, as it may\ncomplicate efforts to control the disease in poultry and to prevent\nfurther human cases. The new findings expand on recent evidence, based on characterization\nof H5N1 viruses from southern China, that domestic ducks have played\na central role in generating and maintaining H5N1, in its highly\npathogenic form, in parts of Asia. \n- Water supplies for human use should not be drawn from open ponds\nused by domestic ducks and should be stored in ways that prevent\ncontact with ducks. In terms of preventing further human cases, it is of public health\nconcern that ducks may be infected and shed virus for long periods,\nyet issue no 'warning signal' in the form of visible signs and\nsymptoms that alert people to take precautions. The concern is\ngreatest in rural areas of affected countries, where free-ranging\nducks and chickens often mingle, frequently sharing the same water\nsupplies. However, the laboratory findings come at\na time when some human cases could not be traced to contact with\ndiseased or dead poultry.\n \nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n \n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2004_10_29/en/>\n<http://www.who.int/foodsafety/micro/avian2/en/>\n The wider implications of the role played by domestic ducks are being\njointly considered by FAO and OIE in formulating a long-term strategy\nfor bringing the current outbreaks in poultry under control. Such information will allow a focused approach to\nthe prevention of human cases arising from exposure to apparently\nhealthy domestic ducks. Outbreak News, 29 Oct 2004 [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2004_10_29/en/>\n\nAvian influenza - situation in Asia: altered role of domestic ducks\n------------------------------------------------------------------- The study found that the quantities of virus excreted by\nhealthy-looking ducks approach those excreted by diseased -- and\nvisibly very ill -- chickens.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "influenza a/h5n1"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2003-03-25 00:00:00", "2004-10-25 00:00:00", "2004-07-08 00:00:00", "2004-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tennessee", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Thailand", "country": "Thailand"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Memphis", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "721", "headline": "PRO/AH> Avian influenza, porcine, H5N1 - China (06): OIE", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=721", "date": "2004-09-05 23:50:00", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, PORCINE, H5N1 - CHINA (06): OIE\n******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: September 1, 2004\nFrom: Alfonso Rodriguez, M.D.<ajrm_msds@yahoo.es>\nSource: OIE Press Releases [edited]\n<http://www.oie.int/eng/press/en_040901.htm>\n\nAvian influenza virus in pigs - An update\nFollowing OIE's press release of 22 Aug 2004, the Veterinary Authorities of\nthe People's Republic of China have at the request of the OIE, provided\nadditional details concerning the isolation of H5N1 strain of influenza\nvirus in pigs.\nThey have confirmed that one H5N1 strain was isolated in 2002 from\nmaterials collected from pigs in the Fujian province in 2001. Subsequently,\n1936 samples were collected in 2003 from pigs in 14 provinces including\nFujian and again one H5N1 strain was isolated from that province. These 2\nisolates have been subjected to detailed analysis and have been shown to be\nhighly homologous to the duck-derived H5N1 virus isolated recently in birds\nin China.\nAccording to the Chinese authorities, no variation in the virus has been\nobserved. More recently, as part of their ongoing epidemiological\nsurveillance programme, 1.1 million samples including 4447 from pigs have\nbeen collected and analysed between April and August 2004 from 10 provinces\nincluding Fujian, and no infection from H5N1 has been detected in pigs.\nThe above findings do not at this stage indicate any major evolution\nregarding H5N1 infection in pigs.\nHowever, the OIE wishes to insist on the necessity for Member Countries\naffected by avian influenza to increase their epidemiological surveillance\nto better understand the implications of the existence of H5N1 virus in pigs.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[We hope that OIE's call for greater emphasis on swine influenza is\naccepted by all members, not just in the letter of the regulation but also\nin its spirit. FAO has also highlighted this need by emphasizing the need\nfor sub-regional surveillance networks (see 20040827.2401 below).\nCalls by OIE, FAO and WHO for a greater focus on the status of H5N1 in\nswine are entirely appropriate but should be accompanied by a reminder that\ntransparency of results and particularly publication of data is crucial\nwhen a significant new finding affecting the epidemiology of the influenza\nvirus comes forth. The salient feature of transparent reporting systems is\nnot only that everyone in the world knows what is going on, but they know\nit in a timely fashion. Clearly in this case timeliness was an issue, as\nmany of these isolations occurred a few years ago [see the comments of\nMod.CP in 20040822.2330 below].\nThe H5N1 virus appears to have evolved in China. We must study its\nevolution and epidemiology wherever and whenever the disease occurs.\nChinese scientists will be the leaders in this effort, but the results must\nbe open to scientists everywhere. Publications like the one Chen and\nWebster submitted to the National Academy of Science in the USA are very\nhelpful in this regard, as they are immediately accessible to a wide\nspectrum of scientists all over the world. Clearly, scientists from outside\nChina should pay better attention to Chinese journals such as the Chinese\nJournal of Preventive Veterinary Medicine (see 20040822.2330) as well --\neven if they have to get help with articles published in Chinese.\nSince the SARS epidemic, China has made significant strides in\ntransparency, as evidenced by a surveillance program testing 1.1 million\nsamples since April and the publications cited above. The problem in this\ncase -- as in many other situations with a potentially explosive disease in\na reservoir host -- is that findings of the H5N1 virus in pigs does not\nmean that there is a clinical epidemic in pigs, in production facilities or\non small farms, which is a point with which Chinese agricultural\nauthorities are obviously concerned.\nUntil the data from these virus isolations -- and, more importantly, future\nsurveillance information on H5N1 in swine now being gathered -- are\nincorporated into regular and detailed surveillance reports, questions will\nlinger. This situation is too important to both human and animal health\nauthorities worldwide for any unnecessary unanswered questions. For\nexample, Dr. Marty Zaluski of the North Carolina Department of Agriculture\nwanted to know the significance of the results given; we didn't know\nwhether the swabs were from nasal or tissue swabs. Mod.AS had a similar\nquery in 20040823.2345. Transparency means providing the salient details --\nand with this virus, the more we know, the better prepared we can be. - Mod.PC]", "summary": "The problem in this\ncase -- as in many other situations with a potentially explosive disease in\na reservoir host -- is that findings of the H5N1 virus in pigs does not\nmean that there is a clinical epidemic in pigs, in production facilities or\non small farms, which is a point with which Chinese agricultural\nauthorities are obviously concerned. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Calls by OIE, FAO and WHO for a greater focus on the status of H5N1 in\nswine are entirely appropriate but should be accompanied by a reminder that\ntransparency of results and particularly publication of data is crucial\nwhen a significant new finding affecting the epidemiology of the influenza\nvirus comes forth. These 2\nisolates have been subjected to detailed analysis and have been shown to be\nhighly homologous to the duck-derived H5N1 virus isolated recently in birds\nin China.\n More recently, as part of their ongoing epidemiological\nsurveillance programme, 1.1 million samples including 4447 from pigs have\nbeen collected and analysed between April and August 2004 from 10 provinces\nincluding Fujian, and no infection from H5N1 has been detected in pigs. Until the data from these virus isolations -- and, more importantly, future\nsurveillance information on H5N1 in swine now being gathered -- are\nincorporated into regular and detailed surveillance reports, questions will\nlinger. Following OIE's press release of 22 Aug 2004, the Veterinary Authorities of\nthe People's Republic of China have at the request of the OIE, provided\nadditional details concerning the isolation of H5N1 strain of influenza\nvirus in pigs. From: Alfonso Rodriguez, M.D.<ajrm_msds@yahoo.es>\nSource: OIE Press Releases [edited]\n<http://www.oie.int/eng/press/en_040901.htm>\n\nAvian influenza virus in pigs - An update\n For\nexample, Dr. Marty Zaluski of the North Carolina Department of Agriculture\nwanted to know the significance of the results given; we didn't know\nwhether the swabs were from nasal or tissue swabs. China should pay better attention to Chinese journals such as the Chinese\nJournal of Preventive Veterinary Medicine (see 20040822.2330) as well --\neven if they have to get help with articles published in Chinese.\n \nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n However, the OIE wishes to insist on the necessity for Member Countries\naffected by avian influenza to increase their epidemiological surveillance\nto better understand the implications of the existence of H5N1 virus in pigs. Subsequently,\n1936 samples were collected in 2003 from pigs in 14 provinces including\nFujian and again one H5N1 strain was isolated from that province.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "sars"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2001-03-25 00:00:00", "4447-03-25 00:00:00", "1936-03-25 00:00:00", "2002-03-25 00:00:00", "2004-09-01 00:00:00", "2021-04-25 00:00:00", "2003-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Fujian", "country": "China"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "773", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza A/H5N1, migratory birds - Russia (Siberia)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=773", "date": "2004-10-28 23:50:00", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA A/H5N1, MIGRATORY BIRDS - RUSSIA (SIBERIA)\n********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Wed 27 Oct 2004\nFrom: Natalia Pchenitchnaia <fogel@jeo.ru>\nSource: Agency Mednovosti.ru, 25 Oct 2004\n[in Russian, translated by NP,edited]\n<http://pda.mednovosti.ru>\n\nAvian influenza discovered in Novosibirskaya region (Russia)\n-----------------------------------------------\nAccording to the Interfax news agency, avian influenza type H5N1 has\nbeen discovered in migratory birds in the Novosibirskaya region. As\nsuggested by Alexander Shestopalov, the head of the zoonoses\nlaboratory in the State Scientific Center for Virology and\nBiotechnology 'Vector,' preliminary data indicate that the virus was\nbrought from south-east Asia by migratory birds, such as ducks\nand geese, which annually winter there.\nThe analysis of tests of samples obtained from the birds in the\nspring and the autumn months is proceeding, with final results\nexpected in December 2004. Shestopalov stated that the H5N1 virus was\nidentified in birds sampled last year [2003].\nThe birds, which probably are carriers of the influenza virus, live\ngenerally in the lowland zone of Barabinsko-Kulundinskoj (Novosibirsk\narea), which is known as a crossroads for migrating birds. 'It is a\nrather sparsely populated area with many lakes; therefore, direct\ncontact of the carrier birds with people is unlikely,' Shestopalov\nnoted.\nScientists have warned of possible mutations, and genetic\nreassortment, of avian and human influenza viruses. They have warned\nthat conditions for such a scenario might prevail [also] on Russian\nterritory.\n\n--\nNatalia Pchenitchnaia, MD, MPH\nAssistant Professor\nDepartment of Infectious Diseases\nRostov State Medical University\nRostov-on-Don, Russia\n<fogel@jeo.ru>\n[Waterfowl are known to play a significant role in the spread of influenza A\nviruses. Migratory birds were blamed for the outbreaks of bird flu in Asian\ncountries during the current and previous HPAI outbreaks. First hand details\nof the Russian observations, and, specifically, the genetic make-up of\nisolates, will be useful, as will details of similar investigations in other\ncountries to which waterfowl seasonally return from south-east Asia. -\nMod.AS].", "summary": "As\nsuggested by Alexander Shestopalov, the head of the zoonoses\nlaboratory in the State Scientific Center for Virology and\nBiotechnology 'Vector,' preliminary data indicate that the virus was\nbrought from south-east Asia by migratory birds, such as ducks\nand geese, which annually winter there. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n \n\n--\nNatalia Pchenitchnaia, MD, MPH\nAssistant Professor\nDepartment of Infectious Diseases\n First hand details\nof the Russian observations, and, specifically, the genetic make-up of\nisolates, will be useful, as will details of similar investigations in other\ncountries to which waterfowl seasonally return from south-east Asia. It is a\nrather sparsely populated area with many lakes; therefore, direct\ncontact of the carrier birds with people is unlikely,' Shestopalov\nnoted. Rostov State Medical University\nRostov-on-Don, Russia\n<fogel@jeo.ru>\n The birds, which probably are carriers of the influenza virus, live\ngenerally in the lowland zone of Barabinsko-Kulundinskoj (Novosibirsk\narea), which is known as a crossroads for migrating birds. ' The analysis of tests of samples obtained from the birds in the\nspring and the autumn months is proceeding, with final results\nexpected in December 2004.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "influenza a/h5n1"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2004-12-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Novosibirskaya", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "647", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza H5N1, mammals: pathogenicity", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=647", "date": "2004-07-01 23:50:00", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA H5N1, MAMMALS: PATHOGENICITY\n*********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 30 Jun 2004\nFrom: Pablo Nart <p.nart@ntlworld.com>\nSource: Nature, 29 Jun 2004 [edited]\n<http://www.nature.com/nsu/040628/040628-13.html>\n\nAvian flu grows more virulent\n-----------------------------\nThe bird flu virus is mutating and becoming more dangerous to mammals, say\nresearchers. The discovery reinforces fears that a human pandemic of the\ndisease could yet occur. Avian flu hit the headlines in 1997 when a strain\ncalled H5N1 jumped from chickens to people, killing 6 people in Hong Kong.\nWithin 3 days, the country's entire chicken population was slaughtered and\nthe outbreak was controlled.\nSince then new strains of virus have emerged, killing a further 14 people.\nAs yet, no strain has been able to jump routinely from person to person.\nBut if a more virulent strain evolves, the fear is that it could trigger\nwidespread outbreaks, potentially affecting millions of people.\nNow, genetic and animal studies show that the virus is becoming more\nmenacing to mammals. Immediate action is needed to stem the virus's\ntransmission, says Hualan Chen from Harbin Veterinary Research Institute,\nChina, who was involved in the research.\nChen and colleagues studied 21 H5N1 flu virus samples taken from apparently\nhealthy ducks, which act as a natural reservoir for the disease, in\nsouthern China between 1999 and 2002. The researchers inoculated groups of\nchickens, mice and ducks with virus samples taken from different years and\nwaited to see which animals became ill. Their results are presented this\nweek in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences. [not yet on\nwebsite <http://www.pnas.org/> that I can find. - Mod.SH].\nAs expected, ducks were immune to the virus's effects and the chickens fell\nsick. However, the mice also became ill, losing weight and the use of their\nlimbs. Crucially, the severity of their illness was linked with the year\nfrom which the virus sample was taken. Viruses isolated in 2001 and 2002\nmade the animals more ill than those isolated earlier on. The findings hint\nthat some time around 2001, the virus became adept at infecting mammals.\nGenetic analysis of the same samples reveals that the virus's DNA changed\nover that time, suggesting that accumulated mutations may have contributed\nto the increased virulence.\nResearchers are concerned that a virus that has acquired the ability to\ninfect mice could also infect humans. 'The disease could resurge [sic] at\nany time,' warns virologist Marion Koopmans from the National Institute of\nPublic Health and the Environment in Bilthoven, the Netherlands. The\nfindings highlight the need for improved surveillance to ensure that any\nfuture outbreaks are curtailed, she says. Although domestic poultry are\neasily culled, wild animals are more difficult to contain. 'It is\nimpossible to eradicate the natural reservoir,' says Koopmans, 'so we need\nto learn to live with it.'\nBirds may not be the only villains in this story, however. Chen believes\nthat pigs may also play a part. In Asia, chickens and pigs are often kept\nin close proximity, so the virus may have shuffled back and forth between\nthe 2 species, picking up mutations and becoming better at infecting\nmammalian hosts. Humans may then have caught the disease from swine.\n[byline: Helen R Pilcher]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[It is difficult to evaluate these experiments. There is no doubt a\npotential reservoir of genetic variation in wild water fowl that could\nabruptly -- by genetic interaction (reassortment of genome subunits of\navian and mammalian viruses during co-infection of a common host), or\ngradually by progressive mutation -- generate a new human pandemic strain\nexpressing novel antigens to which the human population has no prior\nimmunity. That this has not happened in recent years indicates that the\nevolution of a pandemic virus is a complex and relatively infrequent\nphenomenon.\nThe experiments of Chen and colleagues show that a temporal series of\nisolates of H5N1 virus from ducks exhibited increasing virulence when\ninoculated into mice. Why this phenomenon is temporally related is unclear.\nThese observations conflict with the results of previous phylogenetic\nanalysis, which indicated that avian influenza viruses from wild fowl have\nnot evolved much over the past 60 years in contrast to mammalian viruses,\nand as a consequence it has been concluded that influenza viruses in wild\nbirds appear to be in 'evolutionary stasis'. Furthermore, these experiments\nwith mice may not have direct relevance to the evolution of human pathogens\ntransmitted by the respiratory route. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "There is no doubt a\npotential reservoir of genetic variation in wild water fowl that could\nabruptly -- by genetic interaction (reassortment of genome subunits of\navian and mammalian viruses during co-infection of a common host), or\ngradually by progressive mutation -- generate a new human pandemic strain\nexpressing novel antigens to which the human population has no prior\nimmunity. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n These observations conflict with the results of previous phylogenetic\nanalysis, which indicated that avian influenza viruses from wild fowl have\nnot evolved much over the past 60 years in contrast to mammalian viruses,\nand as a consequence it has been concluded that influenza viruses in wild\nbirds appear to be in 'evolutionary stasis'. In Asia, chickens and pigs are often kept\nin close proximity, so the virus may have shuffled back and forth between\nthe 2 species, picking up mutations and becoming better at infecting\nmammalian hosts. [byline: Helen R Pilcher]\n--\nProMED-mail\n< The researchers inoculated groups of\nchickens, mice and ducks with virus samples taken from different years and\nwaited to see which animals became ill. Chen and colleagues studied 21 H5N1 flu virus samples taken from apparently\nhealthy ducks, which act as a natural reservoir for the disease, in\nsouthern China between 1999 and 2002. The experiments of Chen and colleagues show that a temporal series of\nisolates of H5N1 virus from ducks exhibited increasing virulence when\ninoculated into mice. Genetic analysis of the same samples reveals that the virus's DNA changed\nover that time, suggesting that accumulated mutations may have contributed\nto the increased virulence. That this has not happened in recent years indicates that the\nevolution of a pandemic virus is a complex and relatively infrequent\nphenomenon. Immediate action is needed to stem the virus's\ntransmission, says Hualan Chen from Harbin Veterinary Research Institute,\nChina, who was involved in the research. Furthermore, these experiments\nwith mice may not have direct relevance to the evolution of human pathogens\ntransmitted by the respiratory route. Source: Nature, 29 Jun 2004 [edited]\n<http://www.nature.com/nsu/040628/040628-13.html>\n\nAvian flu grows more virulent\n The\nfindings highlight the need for improved surveillance to ensure that any\nfuture outbreaks are curtailed, she says. It is\nimpossible to eradicate the natural reservoir,' says Koopmans, 'so we need\nto learn to live with it.' The disease could resurge [sic] at\nany time,' warns virologist Marion Koopmans from the National Institute of\nPublic Health and the Environment in Bilthoven, the Netherlands. AVIAN INFLUENZA H5N1, MAMMALS: PATHOGENICITY\n*********************************************\n Avian flu hit the headlines in 1997 when a strain\ncalled H5N1 jumped from chickens to people, killing 6 people in Hong Kong.", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1997-03-25 00:00:00", "2004-06-29 00:00:00", "2001-03-25 00:00:00", "2002-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Netherlands", "country": "Netherlands"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "Hong Kong"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "592", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza A (H5N1) virus, human vaccine (06)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=592", "date": "2004-04-10 23:50:00", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA A (H5N1) VIRUS, HUMAN VACCINE (06)\n*********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 9 April 2004\nFrom: Jim Robertson PhD, John Wood PhD <jrobertson@nibsc.ac.uk>\n\n[This thread has been temporarily reconnected to enable Dr Jim Robertson\nand Dr John Wood to make the following statement relating to the\nProMED-mail post 'Avian influenza A (H5N1) virus, human vaccine (05)\n20040403.0917', which contained an article from the Atlanta\nJournal-Constitution under the heading: 'NIBSC Wins Race to Genetically\nEngineer H5N1 Vaccine Strain.' - Mod.CP]\nWe would like to point out that the only race in developing an H5N1 avian\ninfluenza vaccine strain was against time and nature and not against our\ncolleagues in the USA at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention\n(CDC) and St Jude Children's Research Hospital. The 3 labs concerned have\nworked together, exchanging information and reagents that have accrued in\nthe process of developing the vaccine strain. As occurs with the annual\ndevelopment of vaccine reference strains, the development of a pandemic\nstrain should not be left to a single laboratory, as the success in\ndeveloping a strain that is suitable is subject to many factors, some of\nthem unknown. There is still no guarantee that the virus developed by NIBSC\nwill be an effective vaccine strain, and the strains developed elsewhere\nwill also be evaluated. Since the avian influenza in east Asia presented an\nextremely serious public health issue, speed was of the essence, and so it\nwas for this reason, and this reason alone, that the various labs involved\nhave worked non-stop on this matter. We are pleased to have been\nsuccessful, but find it objectionable and disreputable that some have cast\nthe project as a race against our WHO colleagues.\n--\nJim Robertson, PhD\nJohn Wood, PhD\nDivision of Virology\nNational Institute for Biological Standards and Control (NIBSC)\nSouth Mimms\nPotters Bar\nHertfordshire UK\n<jrobertson@nibsc.ac.uk>\n[This thread now resumes its severed status. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n As occurs with the annual\ndevelopment of vaccine reference strains, the development of a pandemic\nstrain should not be left to a single laboratory, as the success in\ndeveloping a strain that is suitable is subject to many factors, some of\nthem unknown. South Mimms\nPotters Bar\nHertfordshire UK\n<jrobertson@nibsc.ac.uk>\n Jim Robertson, PhD\nJohn Wood, PhD\nDivision of Virology\nNational Institute for Biological Standards and Control (NIBSC)\n We would like to point out that the only race in developing an H5N1 avian\ninfluenza vaccine strain was against time and nature and not against our\ncolleagues in the USA at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention\n Since the avian influenza in east Asia presented an\nextremely serious public health issue, speed was of the essence, and so it\nwas for this reason, and this reason alone, that the various labs involved\nhave worked non-stop on this matter.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2004-04-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "719", "headline": "PRO/AH> Avian influenza, cats: H5N1 susceptibility", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=719", "date": "2004-09-03 23:50:00", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, CATS: H5N1 SUSCEPTIBILITY\n******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Fri, 3 Sep 2004\nFrom: Mary Marshall <tropical.forestry@btinternet.com>\nSource: National Geographic News, 2 Sep 2004 [edited]\n<http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2004/09/0902_040902_birdflu.html#main>\n\nCats Can Catch and Spread Bird Flu, Study Says\n--------------------------------------------------\n'That cats could so easily be infected and could transmit the infection to\nother cats means that in areas where poultry are infected with H5N1 virus,\ncats could act as vectors,' said Thijs Kuiken, a veterinary pathologist in\nthe department of virology at the Erasmus Medical Center in Rotterdam, Holland.\n'Cats could transmit the virus from one poultry farm to another, or could\ntransmit the virus to people,' said Kuiken, an author of the study\ndescribed in tomorrow's issue of the journal Science.\nThe avian influenza A virus was responsible for massive poultry slaughters\nin 8 Asian countries in 2003 and 2004. 37 cases of direct bird-to-human\ntransmission, 26 of them fatal, were officially reported. Anecdotal reports\nof fatal infections in cats also emerged during the outbreak.\nKuiken and his colleagues investigated whether the virus could make cats\nsick when the pathogen was introduced into their airways or when the cats\nate infected chickens.\nThe researchers introduced the H5N1 virus into the airways of 3 cats. 3\nother cats were fed an infected chick. Finally, 2 cats were exposed to the\nvirus by being placed in the same cage as the 1st 3 cats.\nThe cats soon showed signs of disease: raised body temperature, decreased\nactivity, and labored breathing. All developed severe lung disease. One cat\ndied after 6 days of infection.\n'Were we surprised? Yes!' Kuiken said. 'Although we had expected to see\nsome pathologic change in the lungs -- because of the anecdotal reports of\ncats dying from H5N1 virus infection in Thailand -- we didn't expect them\nto be so severe and present in all animals.'\n'Often an infectious agent that causes mortality in the field has a much\nless severe effect when the infection is performed in the laboratory,'\nKuiken added. 'With H5N1 virus, the experimental infection also resulted in\nsevere lesions.'\nPreviously there were no reports of disease in cats from infection with an\ninfluenza A virus. Kuiken says the evidence of transmission from cat to cat\nis a particularly important finding.\n'With all of the human cases of H5N1 virus infection, the virus was\ntransmitted from bird to human (bird to mammal), not from human to human\n(mammal to mammal),' Kuiken said. 'Our study shows that H5N1 virus\ntransmission from cat to cat (mammal to mammal) is possible.'\nThe ability of the virus to infect cats suggests that cats could enable the\npathogen to adapt to mammals. If the virus could replicate more easily in\ncats, it also might replicate more easily in humans, increasing the risk of\na human influenza pandemic.\n'That this H5N1 virus caused pneumonia and death in cats suggests that the\nvirus has increased its ability to cause disease in this species -- not\nthat the species is less resistant,' Kuiken said.\nSome scientists downplay the threat of the new findings.\n'To be a significant new threat, the infection would have to keep the cat\nwell enough to travel and spread and yet sick enough to maintain high doses\nof virus so that transmission is achieved,' said Ian Jones, a professor at\nthe School of Animal and Microbial Sciences at the University of Reading in\nEngland.\n'This experimental situation shows this can occur. But it is a long way\nfrom the natural situation where a sick animal may hide away or die,' he\nadded. 'So the real increase in risk may actually be quite small.'\nMichael Lai, a professor of molecular microbiology and immunology at the\nUniversity of Southern California in Los Angeles, says the report should\nnot scare people.\n'It's true that the more animals the virus can infect, the more likely the\nvirus can spread to humans,' Lai said. 'However, the possibilities that a\ncat serves as an additional reservoir for avian flu and that it may allow\nhuman and avian flu viruses to recombine are quite remote.'\nIf the transmission occurred easily, Lai said, we should have seen\nwidespread flu infection in cats in the avian flu epidemic areas in the\npast few years. This did not happen.\nThe study authors also tested the effect of another type of influenza\nvirus, H3N2, which most commonly causes flu in humans. Cats exposed in the\nsame way to this virus did not develop disease.\n[Byline: Stefan Lovgren]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[The text of the paper 'Avian H5N1 Influenza in Cats' by Thijs Kuiken, Guus\nRimmelzwaan, Debby van Riel, Geert van Amerongen, Marianne Baars, Ron\nFouchier and Albert Osterhaus, is available at\n<http://www.sciencemag.org/cgi/rapidpdf/1102287v1.pdf>.\nThey conclude: 'The implications of the findings are first that, during\nH5N1 virus outbreaks, domestic cats are at risk of disease or death from\nH5N1 virus infection, either due to feeding on infected poultry or wild\nbirds, or due to contact with infected cats. Second, the role of cats in\nthe spread of H5N1 virus between poultry farms, and from poultry to humans,\nneeds to be re-assessed. Third, cats may form an opportunity for this avian\nvirus to adapt to mammals, thereby increasing the risk of a human influenza\npandemic'.\nThe paper provides convincing experimental confirmation for the Thai\nobservations in Felidae and the findings of the Faculty of Veterinary\nSciences at Thailand's Kasetsart University, reported in the postings\nbelow. - Mod.AS]", "summary": "--------------------------------------------------\n'That cats could so easily be infected and could transmit the infection to\nother cats means that in areas where poultry are infected with H5N1 virus,\ncats could act as vectors,' said Thijs Kuiken, a veterinary pathologist in\nthe department of virology at the Erasmus Medical Center in Rotterdam, Holland. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n They conclude: 'The implications of the findings are first that, during\nH5N1 virus outbreaks, domestic cats are at risk of disease or death from\nH5N1 virus infection, either due to feeding on infected poultry or wild\nbirds, or due to contact with infected cats. Although we had expected to see\nsome pathologic change in the lungs -- because of the anecdotal reports of\ncats dying from H5N1 virus infection in Thailand -- we didn't expect them\nto be so severe and present in all animals.' The paper provides convincing experimental confirmation for the Thai\nobservations in Felidae and the findings of the Faculty of Veterinary\nSciences at Thailand's Kasetsart University, reported in the postings\nbelow. - Mod. With all of the human cases of H5N1 virus infection, the virus was\ntransmitted from bird to human (bird to mammal), not from human to human\n That this H5N1 virus caused pneumonia and death in cats suggests that the\nvirus has increased its ability to cause disease in this species -- not\nthat the species is less resistant,' Kuiken said. Cats could transmit the virus from one poultry farm to another, or could\ntransmit the virus to people,' said Kuiken, an author of the study\ndescribed in tomorrow's issue of the journal Science. [Byline: Stefan Lovgren]\n--\nProMED-mail\n< Kuiken and his colleagues investigated whether the virus could make cats\nsick when the pathogen was introduced into their airways or when the cats\nate infected chickens. If the virus could replicate more easily in\ncats, it also might replicate more easily in humans, increasing the risk of\na human influenza pandemic. Third, cats may form an opportunity for this avian\nvirus to adapt to mammals, thereby increasing the risk of a human influenza\npandemic'. If the transmission occurred easily, Lai said, we should have seen\nwidespread flu infection in cats in the avian flu epidemic areas in the\npast few years. Second, the role of cats in\nthe spread of H5N1 virus between poultry farms, and from poultry to humans,\nneeds to be re-assessed. Cats exposed in the\nsame way to this virus did not develop disease.\n Source: National Geographic News, 2 Sep 2004 [edited]\n<http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2004/09/0902_040902_birdflu.html#main>\n\nCats Can Catch and Spread Bird Flu, Study Says\n However, the possibilities that a\ncat serves as an additional reservoir for avian flu and that it may allow\nhuman and avian flu viruses to recombine are quite remote.' AVIAN INFLUENZA, CATS: H5N1 SUSCEPTIBILITY\n******************************************\n Often an infectious agent that causes mortality in the field has a much\nless severe effect when the infection is performed in the laboratory,'\nKuiken added. ' But it is a long way\nfrom the natural situation where a sick animal may hide away or die,' he\nadded. ' Michael Lai, a professor of molecular microbiology and immunology at the\nUniversity of Southern California in Los Angeles, says the report should\nnot scare people.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2004-03-25 00:00:00", "2004-09-02 00:00:00", "2003-03-25 00:00:00", "2004-09-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Thailand", "country": "Thailand"}, {"location": "Los Angeles", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Felidae", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Rotterdam", "country": "Netherlands"}, {"location": "Holland", "country": "Netherlands"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "656", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza - East Asia: genesis of H5N1 epidemic virus", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=656", "date": "2004-07-08 23:50:00", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA - EAST ASIA: GENESIS OF H5N1 EPIDEMIC VIRUS\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n******\n[1]\nDate: Thu 8 Jul 2004\nFrom: Marianne Hopp <mjhopp12@yahoo.com>\nSource: World Health Organization (WHO), CSR, Disease Outbreaks News, Thu 8\nJul 2004 [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2004_07_08/en/>\n\nCurrent evaluation of risks to humans from avian influenza A (H5N1) virus\nfollowing recent reports\n-----------------------------------------------\nIn the last 2 weeks, avian influenza appears to have re-emerged in poultry\nin several countries in Asia. These outbreaks could either be new outbreaks\nof Highly Pathogenic Avian Influenza A(H5N1) virus, or, a continuation of\nthe outbreaks 1st reported earlier in 2004. These events, in addition to 2\nnew research reports -- about the virus becoming increasingly pathogenic\nand becoming more widespread in birds in the region -- fuel the World\nHealth Organization's concern about the threat the virus poses to human health.\nWHO has been concerned about this virus, influenza A(H5N1) virus, because\nof its threat to humans, both in farm settings in Asia, and, its greater,\npotentially global risk. Several countries in Asia have witnessed this\nvirus crossing the species barrier -- moving from infected chickens or\nducks directly into humans -- in 3 documented outbreaks since 1997. These\ndirect human infections have produced severe, and sometimes fatal,\noutcomes. Moreover, the virus has the potential to acquire the ability to\nspread easily from human to human, and, thus, trigger a global influenza\npandemic.\nNow, 2 research reports have added to our understanding of this virus. 1st,\nmembers of China's Ministry of Agriculture, and colleagues, reported, in a\npaper published last week [1st week of July 2004] in the Proceedings of the\nNational Academy of Sciences, that the virus appears to be widespread in\ndomestic ducks in southern China. Further, the scientists found that the\nvirus is causing increasingly severe disease. However, these trials were\ndone in mice and may not have a direct implication for humans.\nDuring the 2nd week of July 2004, the journal Nature published a report\n[see following report - Mod.CP] which indicates domestic and wild birds in\nthe region may have contributed to the increasing spread of the virus, and,\nsuggests that the virus is gaining a stronger foothold in the region. These\nobservations suggest that control of the virus may be even more difficult\nthan thought in the spring of 2004.\nEffective risk management tools exist to control outbreaks of influenza\nA(H5N1) virus infection, when they are detected in poultry operations.\nChina, for example, was quick to employ these tools during the 1st week of\nJuly 2004, when an outbreak was discovered in Anhui province. These\nrisk-management measures include the culling of infected and exposed birds,\nstringent biosecurity measures, and vaccination. While this approach can\nstill take months, or, even years to contain the virus completely, these\nmethods have been effective in the past.\nHowever, tools to assess the risk to human health are less well developed.\nWhile recent reports indicate the virus has been present consistently in\nthe environment for the last several years, it has still not acquired the\nability to infect humans easily. Why? Is there something about this virus\nwhich resists this development? Given the recent reports, WHO urges, and\noffers assistance, that such risk-assessment activities -- including\nsurveillance in animals and humans, and strain analysis -- be undertaken as\nsoon as possible.\nMore knowledge of the virus could be acquired if WHO had full access to all\nvirus isolates, and clinical specimens, from recent outbreaks. All H5N1\nviruses are not the same, and how they differ could provide important\ninsights. For example, the work reported in Nature suggests that the\nIndonesian avian influenza virus, while belonging to the genotype of\nviruses seen in Viet Nam and Thailand, is also distinct. What, if any,\nimpact does this difference have? With this information, public health\nplanners would know that they are confronting the same virus in all of the\nrecent outbreaks in Asia. This is another set of the many questions that\nneed to be answered imperatively.\nPandemic preparedness activities started by WHO in the wake of the\noutbreaks reported earlier in 2004 continue. Less than two weeks ago [end\nof June 2004], WHO hosted a meeting in Kuala Lumpur with experts from 13\ncountries and areas of the Asia-Pacific region. Among other activities, the\nmeeting participants were provided with a WHO preparedness self-assessment\ntool. WHO is collaborating with scientists, and the pharmaceutical\ncommunity, on a global surveillance system to monitor changes in the\nvirus's susceptibility to known antivirals. Finally, pandemic vaccine\ndevelopment continues. 2 vaccine manufacturers, both based in the United\nStates, have produced a supply of trial vaccine which will be tested for\nsafety and efficacy in humans.\nIn summary, recent developments suggest that:\n* the virus is more widespread than previously thought and found in wild\nbirds, and, therefore, it may be more difficult to eliminate.\n* virus isolates and specimens from all recent outbreaks need to be shared\nwith the WHO laboratory network to monitor the circulating viruses and to\nassess the adequacy of the current pandemic vaccine strain.\n* as control measures are strengthened, national governments are encouraged\nto provide human influenza vaccinations to culling workers.\n* all people, especially culling workers, exposed to infected birds need to\nbe provided with antivirals.\n* human trials of experimental influenza pandemic vaccines should be\naccelerated.\n* while early identification of avian influenza cases in humans is\ndifficult, stepped up surveillance for the early detection of the disease\nin humans is essential.\nThe risk of emergence of a new human pandemic virus will remain as long as\nthe avian influenza virus exists in the environment. WHO's concern, and\nactivities, continue at a high level following recent reports. Because the\nH5N1 threat is unlikely to be resolved in the short term, WHO is working\nwith other international agencies, including the Food and Agricultural\nOrganization (FAO), and World Organization for Animal Health (OIE), to\nmonitor events.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[2]\nDate: Thu 8 Jul 2004\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Nature 430, 209 - 213, Thu 8 July 2004 [edited]\n\nGenesis of the H5N1 virus associated with human illness in East Asia\n-----------------------------------------------\n[The following is the reference for the Nature paper referred to in the\npreceding WHO statement, and the accompanying abstract. - Mod.CP]\nTitle: Genesis of a highly pathogenic and potentially pandemic H5N1\ninfluenza virus in eastern Asia\nAuthors: K.S. Li and 21 others from the Joint Influenza Research Centre\n(SUMC & HKU), Shantou University Medical College, Shantou, Guangdong\n515031, China; Department of Microbiology, The University of Hong Kong,\nQueen Mary Hospital, Hong Kong SAR, China; Fakultas Kedokteran Hewan,\nUniversitas Airlangga, Surabaya 60115, Indonesia; Department of\nMicrobiology, Sriraj Hospital, Bangkok 10700, Thailand; Department of\nLivestock Development, National Institute of Animal Health, Bangkok 10900,\nThailand; Department of Virology, National Institute of Veterinary\nResearch, Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development, Hanoi, Viet Nam;\nVirology Department, National Institute of Hygiene and Epidemiology, Hanoi,\nViet Nam and the Virology Division, Department of Infectious Diseases, St\nJude Children's Research Hospital, Memphis, Tennessee 38105, USA.\nAbstract: 'A highly pathogenic avian influenza virus, H5N1, caused disease\noutbreaks in poultry in China and 7 other east Asian countries between late\n2003 and early 2004; the same virus was fatal to humans in Thailand and\nViet Nam. Here, we demonstrate a series of genetic reassortment events\ntraceable to the precursor of the H5N1 viruses that caused the initial\nhuman outbreak in Hong Kong in 1997, and, subsequent avian outbreaks in\n2001 and 2002. These events gave rise to a dominant H5N1 genotype (Z) in\nchickens and ducks that was responsible for the regional outbreak in 2003 -\n2004. Our findings indicate that domestic ducks in southern China had a\ncentral role in the generation and maintenance of this virus, and, also,\nthat wild birds may have contributed to the increasingly wide spread of the\nvirus in Asia. Our results suggest that H5N1 viruses with pandemic\npotential have become endemic in the region and are not easily eradicable.\nThese developments pose a threat to public and veterinary health in the\nregion, and, potentially, the world, and suggest that long-term control\nmeasures are required.'\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>", "summary": "Title: Genesis of a highly pathogenic and potentially pandemic H5N1\ninfluenza virus in eastern Asia\nAuthors: K.S. Li and 21 others from the Joint Influenza Research Centre\n(SUMC & HKU), Shantou University Medical College, Shantou, Guangdong\n515031, China; Department of Microbiology, The University of Hong Kong,\nQueen Mary Hospital, Hong Kong SAR, China; Fakultas Kedokteran Hewan,\nUniversitas Airlangga, Surabaya 60115, Indonesia; Department of\nMicrobiology, Sriraj Hospital, Bangkok 10700, Thailand; Department of\nLivestock Development, National Institute of Animal Health, Bangkok 10900,\nThailand; Department of Virology, National Institute of Veterinary\nResearch, Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development, Hanoi, Viet Nam;\nVirology Department, National Institute of Hygiene and Epidemiology, Hanoi,\nViet Nam and the Virology Division, Department of Infectious Diseases, St\nJude Children's Research Hospital, Memphis, Tennessee 38105, USA. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n******\n Because the\nH5N1 threat is unlikely to be resolved in the short term, WHO is working\nwith other international agencies, including the Food and Agricultural\nOrganization (FAO), and World Organization for Animal Health (OIE), to\nmonitor events. These events, in addition to 2\nnew research reports -- about the virus becoming increasingly pathogenic\nand becoming more widespread in birds in the region -- fuel the World\nHealth Organization's concern about the threat the virus poses to human health. Abstract: 'A highly pathogenic avian influenza virus, H5N1, caused disease\noutbreaks in poultry in China and 7 other east Asian countries between late\n2003 and early 2004; the same virus was fatal to humans in Thailand and\nViet Nam. \nWHO has been concerned about this virus, influenza A(H5N1) virus, because\nof its threat to humans, both in farm settings in Asia, and, its greater,\npotentially global risk. Our findings indicate that domestic ducks in southern China had a\ncentral role in the generation and maintenance of this virus, and, also,\nthat wild birds may have contributed to the increasingly wide spread of the\nvirus in Asia. * virus isolates and specimens from all recent outbreaks need to be shared\nwith the WHO laboratory network to monitor the circulating viruses and to\nassess the adequacy of the current pandemic vaccine strain.\n Given the recent reports, WHO urges, and\noffers assistance, that such risk-assessment activities -- including\nsurveillance in animals and humans, and strain analysis -- be undertaken as\nsoon as possible. Here, we demonstrate a series of genetic reassortment events\ntraceable to the precursor of the H5N1 viruses that caused the initial\nhuman outbreak in Hong Kong in 1997, and, subsequent avian outbreaks in\n2001 and 2002. These outbreaks could either be new outbreaks\nof Highly Pathogenic Avian Influenza A(H5N1) virus, or, a continuation of\nthe outbreaks 1st reported earlier in 2004. CP] which indicates domestic and wild birds in\nthe region may have contributed to the increasing spread of the virus, and,\nsuggests that the virus is gaining a stronger foothold in the region. Several countries in Asia have witnessed this\nvirus crossing the species barrier -- moving from infected chickens or\nducks directly into humans -- in 3 documented outbreaks since 1997. Moreover, the virus has the potential to acquire the ability to\nspread easily from human to human, and, thus, trigger a global influenza\npandemic. While recent reports indicate the virus has been present consistently in\nthe environment for the last several years, it has still not acquired the\nability to infect humans easily. For example, the work reported in Nature suggests that the\nIndonesian avian influenza virus, while belonging to the genotype of\nviruses seen in Viet Nam and Thailand, is also distinct. "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=581", "date": "2004-04-03 23:50:00", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA A (H5N1) VIRUS, HUMAN VACCINE (05)\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Sat 3 Apr 2004\nFrom: Pablo Nart <p.nart@ntlworld.com>\nSource: The Atlanta Journal-Constitution, Sat 3 Apr 2004 [edited]\n<http://www.ajc.com/news/content/news/0404/03birdflu.html>\n\nNIBSC Wins Race to Genetically Engineer H5N1 Vaccine Strain\n--------------------------------------------------\nA British government laboratory has genetically engineered a safe version\nof the avian influenza A (H5N1) virus to use as the basis of a vaccine,\nbeating out the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and St. Jude\nChildren's Research Hospital in Memphis, who were pursuing the same goal.\nThe achievement by the National Institute for Biological Standards and\nControls (NIBSC) in London will be announced next week by the World Health\nOrganization. WHO is overseeing the research, which aims to create a\nvaccine against avian influenza A (H5N1) virus as insurance in case the\ndisease begins to spread rapidly among people.\nAvian influenza A (H5N1) virus has flared across Asia since November 2003,\nkilling 24 humans, most of them children, and triggering the slaughter of\nmore than 100 million poultry in 10 countries in an attempt to control the\ndisease. 3 labs -\u00ad the London lab, the CDC, and St. Jude -\u00ad have been\nworking in labs that have high levels of biosecurity protection, attempting\nto alter the highly infectious virus into a vaccine seed stock that could\nsafely be used in a pharmaceutical manufacturing plant.\nAt the CDC, however, spokesman David Daigle confirmed that the CDC effort\nhad not yet reached the goal, and that the agency has been told that the\nLondon lab did. The St. Jude group could not be reached. All 3 labs were\ntrying to create a new virus using a process called reverse genetics. The\n1st step was to insert 2 genetic components [the H5 and N1 encoding\nsubunits] from the H5N1 avian flu virus into a benign flu virus commonly\nused in laboratories. All 3 labs passed that milestone in February 2004.\nThe 2nd step was to grow the new virus in pure cell lines that would be\nacceptable to regulatory authorities, including the U.S. Food and Drug\nAdministration. That was to be followed by safety-testing the reproduced\nvirus on chickens and ferrets to prove that its virulent qualities were\nremoved, the final hurdle before the new viral strain could be released to\nmanufacturers.\nThompson indicated that the new strain will be given to manufacturers next\nweek when the official announcement is made. 3 manufacturers have agreed to\nmake sample batches of flu vaccine from the virus and to put the new\nvaccine through clinical trials, he said.\n[Byline: M.A.J. McKenna]\n--\nPablo Nart\n<p.nart@ntlworld.com>\n[ProMED-mail does not normally record progress in vaccine development and\nproduction. Since the initial goal of genetically engineering a vaccine\nproduction strain has been achieved by one of the 3 competing laboratories,\nthis thread is now cut. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n [Byline: M.A.J. That was to be followed by safety-testing the reproduced\nvirus on chickens and ferrets to prove that its virulent qualities were\nremoved, the final hurdle before the new viral strain could be released to\nmanufacturers.
