[Presumably\nthis refers to production of an H5N1 type influenza virus by reverse\ngenetics endowed with low egg lethality and consequently suitable for use\nas a seed stock in vaccine production. - Mod.CP]\nThe WHO will give the prototype virus next week to 3 drug makers who have\nexpressed interest in producing small sample vaccine batches and carrying\nout clinical trials, WHO spokesman Dick Thompson said. The clinical trials\nare expected to take several months, but large-scale vaccine production\nwould only begin if a deadly pandemic broke out, he added. Since avian\ninfluenza erupted in Asia, the WHO has been racing to develop a vaccine to\nprotect humans against the H5N1 type avian influenza virus. Avian influenza\nhas killed 26 [23 confirmed by WHO] people in Viet Nam and Thailand and\ndecimated poultry stocks across Asia.\n'One laboratory has produced the prototype virus. We have sent a note to\nvaccine manufacturers that the virus would be ready next week,' Thompson\ntold Reuters. In January, WHO asked 3 high-security collaborating centers\nto produce a prototype. The spokesman declined to say which had succeeded,\nbut he added that a formal announcement was expected next week.\nThe 3 are: the Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta, Georgia, St. Jude\nHospital in Memphis, Tennessee, and Britain's National Institute for\nBiological Standards and Control. Initially 11 drug manufacturers had\ncontacted the WHO about producing the vaccine, but only 3 have confirmed\nthey want to proceed, according to Thompson. 'Avian influenza seems to have\nfaded as a concern among manufacturers. They are unwilling to spend a lot\nof money to make up the clinical batch,' he said.\nClinical trials will be conducted in the United States, under the\nsponsorship of the U.S. National Institutes of Health, according to the WHO\nspokesman. This meant that drug makers required a U.S. license, he added.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Guessing the identity of the successful laboratory would make a good\nsubject for a sweepstake. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n A high-security laboratory has created a prototype avian influenza virus,\nthe first step toward making a human vaccine [against the potentially\ndeadly avian influenza virus currently widespread in East Asia], a World\nHealth Organisation (WHO) spokesman said on Thu 1 Apr 2004. AVIAN INFLUENZA A (H5N1) VIRUS, HUMAN VACCINE (04)\n**************************************************\n We have sent a note to\nvaccine manufacturers that the virus would be ready next week,' Thompson\ntold Reuters.", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2004-04-01 00:00:00", "2021-01-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Thailand", "country": "Thailand"}, {"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Britain", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Tennessee", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Memphis", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Viet Nam", "country": "Vietnam"}, {"location": "Georgia", "country": "Georgia"}, {"location": "Atlanta", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "218", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Influenza, H5N1 human case - China (Hong Kong) (05)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=218", "date": "2003-02-28 23:50:00", "main_text": "INFLUENZA, H5N1 HUMAN CASE - CHINA (HONG KONG) (05)\n*************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 27 Feb 2003\nFrom: George Robertson <RobertG3@wyeth.com>\nSource: The Scientist online, Thu 27 Feb 2003 [abbreviated and edited by\nMod.CP]\n\nGenetic Characterization of the 2003 Human Isolate of H5N1 Influenza Virus\n--------------------------------------------------\nThe new avian influenza virus that has killed at least one person in South\nChina is genetically different from the avian influenza virus strain that\ninfected 18 people in Hong Kong and killed 6 of them in 1997. Like the 1997\nvirus, the new strain does not appear to contain sequences from human flu\nviruses that would speed its spread from person to person, lessening fears\nthat a lethal pandemic flu may be imminent.\nMalik Peiris, a microbiologist at the University of Hong Kong who is\nstudying the new virus, told 'The Scientist' that the avian influenza virus\nstrain from the 9-year-old boy is completely sequenced. The 6 internal\ngenes of the virus, as well as the neuraminidase gene, are derived from a\ndifferent genetic lineage from that of the 1997 virus. Only the\nhaemagglutinin derives from the same lineage as 1997. 'In addition, we also\ncan establish that the virus has not acquired any human influenza internal\ngenes,' said Pieris.\nAlthough similar, this year's hemagglutinin gene 'has undergone change, so\nthat the 1997 and 2003 viruses, while related, can be distinguished\nserologically. In addition to being antigenically different the 2003 virus\nappears to be more pathogenic for ducks than its predecessor,' Ian Gust\ntold The Scientist. 'The factors which control infectivity seem to lie on\ngenes other than those coding for the H5 and N1 surface proteins.' Gust, at\nthe University of Melbourne in Australia, is collaborating with the WHO\ninfluenza research team.\nPeiris says he is reassured by the fact that the bird virus has not\nreassorted with a human influenza virus, which probably hampers its ability\nto infect people. 'However, it is not possible to say with certainty that\nthis virus will not transmit human to human, purely from genetic data. The\nepidemiological data is important. The key will be to enhance surveillance\nin humans to ascertain whether there are further human cases. So far, there\nare none.'\nAlthough the Hong Kong death occurred less than 2 weeks ago, researchers\nwere able to move quickly with genetic studies because they set up an early\nwarning system after the 1997 outbreak and had already been studying the\nrecent infections in Hong Kong birds. 'The precursors of these viruses are\nall over Asia. It's not as though this thing came out of left field again.\nWe've been waiting to see when it would happen,' said Robert Webster, of\nSt. Jude Children's Research Hospital in Memphis, Tennessee.\n[Byline: Tabitha M Powledge]\n--\nGeorge A. Robertson, PhD\nDirector of Quality Control Operations\nWYETH VACCINES\nMarietta, PA 17547-0304\n<RobertG3@wyeth.com>\n[This thread is now cut. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 27 Feb 2003\n Like the 1997\nvirus, the new strain does not appear to contain sequences from human flu\nviruses that would speed its spread from person to person, lessening fears\nthat a lethal pandemic flu may be imminent. \nMalik Peiris, a microbiologist at the University of Hong Kong who is\nstudying the new virus, told 'The Scientist' that the avian influenza virus\nstrain from the 9-year-old boy is completely sequenced. Although the Hong Kong death occurred less than 2 weeks ago, researchers\nwere able to move quickly with genetic studies because they set up an early\nwarning system after the 1997 outbreak and had already been studying the\nrecent infections in Hong Kong birds. ' George A. Robertson, PhD\nDirector of Quality Control Operations\nWYETH VACCINES\n The 6 internal\ngenes of the virus, as well as the neuraminidase gene, are derived from a\ndifferent genetic lineage from that of the 1997 virus. Peiris says he is reassured by the fact that the bird virus has not\nreassorted with a human influenza virus, which probably hampers its ability\nto infect people. ' In addition, we also\ncan establish that the virus has not acquired any human influenza internal\ngenes,' said Pieris. ' Although similar, this year's hemagglutinin gene 'has undergone change, so\nthat the 1997 and 2003 viruses, while related, can be distinguished\nserologically. Gust, at\nthe University of Melbourne in Australia, is collaborating with the WHO\ninfluenza research team. Marietta, PA 17547-0304\n<RobertG3@wyeth.com>\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2003-02-27 00:00:00", "1997-03-25 00:00:00", "2003-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Memphis", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "Hong Kong"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "Tennessee", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "HONG KONG", "country": "Hong Kong"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "507", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza H5N1, mammals - East Asia", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=507", "date": "2004-02-21 23:50:00", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA H5N1, MAMMALS - EAST ASIA\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 21 Feb 2004\nFrom: ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Associated Press [edited]\n\n3 pet cats have died of bird flu and a white tiger has been infected by the\nvirus at a zoo in Thailand, an official said Friday, raising concerns about\nthe spread of the avian disease among mammals.\nIt was unclear whether the virus could spread from felines to humans, but\nthe veterinarian who announced the latest confirmed infections advised\npeople to avoid contact with pet cats in areas with poultry, which are at\nhigh risk of catching the disease.\n'At this moment we know that felines can get infected for sure,' Dr.\nTeeraphon Sirinaruemit, a veterinarian at Kasetsart University, told a news\nconference. 'It is best for owners not to have direct contact with cats if\nthere are chickens in the neighborhood.'\nSo far, cases in people have been traced largely to direct contact with\nbirds sickened by the H5N1 virus that has decimated poultry stocks through\nwide swaths of Asia. It has jumped to humans in Thailand and Vietnam,\nkilling 22. The pet cats are the first domesticated mammals known to have\ncontracted the disease in the current outbreak.\nWorld Health Organization viral expert Dr. Prasert Thongcharoen said this\ndevelopment is 'very dangerous because pets are very close to humans.\nBecause this disease is new to the world, nobody knows how far it can go,'\nthe WHO expert said Thursday, after reports of the cats' possible\ninfections surfaced.\nTeeraphon said Friday that the carcasses of the 3 pet cats who died were\ntested, along with [samples from] a white tiger at the Khao Khiew zoo in\nChonburi province near Bangkok. All were found to have the H5N1 virus.\nHe said the white tiger has since recovered and is in good health. The Khao\nKhiew zoo is the same one where a clouded leopard died of the bird flu [in\nJanuary 2004], the first mammal apart from humans to die in this year's\noutbreak. Teeraphon said lab tests on 3 house cats and the tiger\nhas 'confirmed 100 percent identical genetic code to the bird flu virus found\nin chickens.'\nHealth experts are concerned about the bird flu sickening other animals, in\npart because that could prompt mutations in the virus that in turn makes it\neasier to pass among people. That concern holds especially for pigs because\nof their genetic similarities to humans [see comment below].\nTeeraphon said the 3 cats were among 15 owned by a Thai woman in Nakhon\nPathom province outside Bangkok. One of them ate a chicken carcass on a\nfarm where there was a bird flu outbreak, he said. The cat disappeared and\nthe remaining 14 became weak, started vomiting, and coughed blood before\ndying. 3 were sent for necropsy on 11 Feb 2004, which confirmed they had\nthe virus, he said. It was not clear what happened to the remaining 11, but\nTeeraphon suggested that they had been buried by the owner. The owner is\nhealthy but is being monitored because one of the cats used to sleep in her\nbed, he said.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Dr.Zhiru Guo of the Laboratory of Animal Virology, Veterinary Institute,\nChangchun University of Agriculture & Animal Sciences, China, comments that\nthe situation should be carefully watched, since after 1st passage through a\nmammal, transmission to another mammalian species, including humans, may be\neasier. - Mod.JW]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n [Dr.Zhiru Guo of the Laboratory of Animal Virology, Veterinary Institute,\nChangchun University of Agriculture & Animal Sciences, China, comments that\nthe situation should be carefully watched, since after 1st passage through a\nmammal, transmission to another mammalian species, including humans, may be\neasier. It was unclear whether the virus could spread from felines to humans, but\nthe veterinarian who announced the latest confirmed infections advised\npeople to avoid contact with pet cats in areas with poultry, which are at\nhigh risk of catching the disease. The Khao\nKhiew zoo is the same one where a clouded leopard died of the bird flu [in\nJanuary 2004], the first mammal apart from humans to die in this year's\noutbreak. Source: Associated Press [edited]\n\n3 pet cats have died of bird flu and a white tiger has been infected by the\nvirus at a zoo in Thailand, an official said Friday, raising concerns about\nthe spread of the avian disease among mammals. \nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n Teeraphon said lab tests on 3 house cats and the tiger\nhas 'confirmed 100 percent identical genetic code to the bird flu virus found\nin chickens.' Teeraphon said Friday that the carcasses of the 3 pet cats who died were\ntested, along with [samples from] a white tiger at the Khao Khiew zoo in\nChonburi province near Bangkok. Because this disease is new to the world, nobody knows how far it can go,'\nthe WHO expert said Thursday, after reports of the cats' possible\ninfections surfaced. Health experts are concerned about the bird flu sickening other animals, in\npart because that could prompt mutations in the virus that in turn makes it\neasier to pass among people. So far, cases in people have been traced largely to direct contact with\nbirds sickened by the H5N1 virus that has decimated poultry stocks through\nwide swaths of Asia. Zhukov, Head of the Laboratory for Prediction of\nViral Virulence for Humans, Institute of Aerobiology, SRC Virology &\nBiotechnology 'Vector', Koltsovo, Novosibirsk rg., 630559, Russia]\nBecause of the extraordinary situation created by the outbreak of\nhighly pathogenic avian influenza in East Asia, I am making the\nfollowing request for assistance. As Head of the Laboratory for\nPrediction of Virus Virulence for Humans at the State Research Center\nof Virology and Biotechnology 'Vector', Russia, and within the\nframework of an investigation funded by DARPA [USA's Defense Advanced\nResearch Projects Agency, the central research and development\norganization for the Department of Defense], we have developed a\nmethod of prediction of human susceptibility to influenza using data\nobtained from in vitro experiments with primary cells from humans.\nResults have been presented at several international conferences\n(Slovakia, 2000; Atlanta, 2002; Munich, 2003), and publications are\nin preparation.\nI am [seeking a collaborating laboratory] which has and can\nofficially supply our Center with live avian influenza A (H5N1)\nvirus, isolated both from chickens and humans [during the current\noutbreak], to [enable us to] estimate the probability of virus\ntransmission from human to human.\n--\nDr. Vladimir A. Zhukov, Ph.D.\nHead of Laboratory for Prediction of Viral Virulence for Humans,\nInstitute of Aerobiology,\nSRC Virology & Biotechnology 'Vector'\nKoltsovo, Novosibirsk rg.,\n630559, Russia.\n<vzhukov@vector.nsc.ru>\n[ProMED-mail is relaying this message as a public service and has no\ndirect association with Dr. Zhukov's Department. His 9-year-old son was also infected but recovered. They were the\nfirst cases of avian influenza passing to humans since an outbreak in the\nterritory killed 6 people in 1997, triggering worldwide alarm.\n'Results of the laboratory tests ... show that the virus genes were purely\navian in origin,' a spokesman for the Department of Health said in a\nstatement. In the absence of human [influenza virus] genes in the avian\nvirus, the risk of human-to-human transmission will be low.' Earlier on\nMonday, government officials told legislators that the absence of human\n[influenza virus genes] meant it was unlikely there would be an epidemic. A\nleading microbiologist in Hong Kong has said the virus could only cause a\npandemic if it got mixed up with human flu strains [i.e., if the avian\nvirus had acquired human influenza virus genes, facilitating\nperson-to-person transmission of the reassortant virus. - Mod.CP]\nOn Fri 21 Feb 2003, a government official said it had detected no unusual\nincrease in flu activity or any other H5-type virus over the past few\nweeks. It said it was still investigating the source of the recent\ninfection and conducting further laboratory tests on the victims' relatives\nto determine whether they had also contracted the virus.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[This is the second recorded occurrence of apparent direct transmission of\nan avian influenza virus to human hosts, unmodified by reassortment of\nviral genes or by adaptation to an intermediate mammalian host.\nFortunately, this H5N1 avian influenza virus, although able to cause severe\ndisease in the initial human host, probably because there is no\npre-existing immunity to H5-type virus, has no ability to spread from\nperson to person. There are many other avian influenza viruses, however, in\nwild and domestic bird populations in relatively close proximity to man,\nespecially in the Far East, and it may only be a matter of time before an\navian virus able to spread from person to person makes its appearance.\nNonetheless, since generally avian influenza viruses multiply in the gut\nand are spread through water, the probability of such an event should\nremain low. Perhaps the most important matter to be resolved at this\njuncture is the manner in which the original infections occurred. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A\nleading microbiologist in Hong Kong has said the virus could only cause a\npandemic if it got mixed up with human flu strains [i.e., if the avian\nvirus had acquired human influenza virus genes, facilitating\nperson-to-person transmission of the reassortant virus. There are many other avian influenza viruses, however, in\nwild and domestic bird populations in relatively close proximity to man,\nespecially in the Far East, and it may only be a matter of time before an\navian virus able to spread from person to person makes its appearance.\n A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 24 Feb 2003\n Fortunately, this H5N1 avian influenza virus, although able to cause severe\ndisease in the initial human host, probably because there is no\npre-existing immunity to H5-type virus, has no ability to spread from\nperson to person. [This is the second recorded occurrence of apparent direct transmission of\nan avian influenza virus to human hosts, unmodified by reassortment of\nviral genes or by adaptation to an intermediate mammalian host.\n A 33-year-old Hong Kong man died last Monday [17 Feb 2003] of pneumonia and\ndoctors confirmed he had contracted an H5N1-type avian influenza virus\nafter visiting relatives who keep chickens in China's southern Fujian\nprovince. (see previous report:\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2003_02_20/en/>)\n\nTo date the current outbreak of influenza A(H5N1) in Hong Kong S.A.R. has\nbeen limited to 2 cases, one of whom has died. Both cases were members of\nthe same family who returned to their home in Hong Kong S.A.R. on 8 Feb\n2003 after travelling to Fujian province, China. The mother and children\nwere in mainland China for 14 days; the father for 9 days.\nThe father of the family (a 33-year-old man) developed respiratory symptoms\non 7 Feb 2003 whilst in Fujian Province, China. He was admitted to hospital\nin Hong Kong S.A.R. on 11 Feb 2003 with pneumonia but died on 17 Feb 2003.\nInfluenza A virus (H5N1) was isolated from post-mortem specimens on 20 Feb\n2003. The man's 9-year-old son also became unwell whilst in Fujian\nprovince. He was admitted to hospital in Hong Kong S.A.R on 12 Feb 2003\nwith pneumonia. Influenza A virus (H5N1) was isolated from 2 nasopharyngeal\naspirates taken from the boy on 19 Feb 2003. The boy is in a stable\ncondition. Additional family members have also had respiratory symptoms.\nThe boy's 8-year-old sister died on 4 Feb 2003 whilst the family was in\nFujian Province, China. The cause of her death is under investigation. The\nmother has now recovered from what was thought to have been a parainfluenza\nvirus infection.\nAn outbreak of atypical pneumonia occurred between November 2002 and\nFebruary 2003 in Guandong province, China. Health authorities in China\ninvestigated the outbreak and identified _Chlamydia pneumoniae_ as the\ncausative agent. The Ministry of Health in Beijing has informed WHO that\nthe outbreak in Guandong is over and that there is no evidence of a link\nbetween the outbreak in Guandong and the H5N1 cases in Hong Kong SAR.\nThe Department of Health in Hong Kong S.A.R has intensified its\nsurveillance for influenza among patients with influenza-like symptoms or\natypical pneumonia. No unusual increase in influenza activity has been\ndetected over the past few weeks. WHO is continuing to work closely with\nhealth authorities in Beijing, China and Hong Kong S.A.R. Reagents for\nlaboratory diagnosis of influenza A(H5N1) virus have been made available to\nthe Ministry of Health in Beijing, the National Influenza Centres, and\nother members of the WHO Global Influenza Surveillance Network.\n--\nMarianne Hopp\n<mjhopp12@yahoo.com>", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 27 Feb 2003\n WHO is continuing to work closely with\nhealth authorities in Beijing, China and Hong Kong S.A.R. Reagents for\nlaboratory diagnosis of influenza A(H5N1) virus have been made available to\nthe Ministry of Health in Beijing, the National Influenza Centres, and\nother members of the WHO Global Influenza Surveillance Network. Both cases were members of\nthe same family who returned to their home in Hong Kong S.A.R. on 8 Feb\n2003 after travelling to Fujian province, China. As of Thu 27 Feb 2003, no further cases of human influenza A(H5N1) have\nbeen reported in Hong Kong S.A.R. (see previous report:\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2003_02_20/en/>) The Department of Health in Hong Kong S.A.R has intensified its\nsurveillance for influenza among patients with influenza-like symptoms or\natypical pneumonia. The Ministry of Health in Beijing has informed WHO that\nthe outbreak in Guandong is over and that there is no evidence of a link\nbetween the outbreak in Guandong and the H5N1 cases in Hong Kong SAR. Health authorities in China\ninvestigated the outbreak and identified _Chlamydia pneumoniae_ as the\ncausative agent. The\nmother has now recovered from what was thought to have been a parainfluenza\nvirus infection. INFLUENZA, H5N1 HUMAN CASE - CHINA (HONG KONG) (04)\n***********************************************\n \nMarianne Hopp\n<mjhopp12@yahoo.com> The father of the family (a 33-year-old man) developed respiratory symptoms\non 7 Feb 2003 whilst in Fujian Province, China.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2003-02-12 00:00:00", "2003-02-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-27 00:00:00", "2003-02-17 00:00:00", "2003-02-04 00:00:00", "2003-02-27 00:00:00", "2003-02-08 00:00:00", "2003-02-07 00:00:00", "2003-02-19 00:00:00", "2003-02-20 00:00:00", "2003-02-11 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Fujian Province", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Guandong province", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Hong Kong S.A.R.", "country": "Hong Kong"}, {"location": "HONG KONG", "country": "Hong Kong"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Fujian", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Guandong", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Beijing", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Fujian province", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "Hong Kong"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "166", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, H5N1 - China (Hong Kong) (07)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=166", "date": "2001-07-10 23:50:00", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, H5N1 - CHINA (HONG KONG) (07)\n**********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org> AVIAN INFLUENZA, H5N1 - CHINA (HONG KONG) (07)\n **\n", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": [], "event_date": [], "locations": [{"location": "HONG KONG", "country": "Hong Kong"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "213", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Influenza, H5N1 human case - China (Hong Kong) (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=213", "date": "2003-02-20 23:50:00", "main_text": "INFLUENZA, H5N1 HUMAN CASE - CHINA (HONG KONG) (02)\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1]\nDate: 20 Feb 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: WHO / Communicable Disease Surveillance & Response (CSR) [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2003_02_20/en/>\n\nInfluenza A(H5N1) in Hong Kong Special Administrative Region of China - Update\n---------------------------\nAs of 20 February the Department of Health in Hong Kong SAR confirmed that\na 33-year-old man, who died in hospital in Hong Kong on 17 Feb 2003, had\nbeen infected with a strain of the influenza A(H5N1) virus. ( see previous\nreport ). A nasopharyngeal aspirate taken from the man tested positive for\ninfluenza A(H5N1) in the Hong Kong SAR Government Virus Unit.\nThe 33-year-old man is the second confirmed case of influenza A(H5N1) virus\nrelated to this outbreak in Hong Kong SAR. The man is known to have been\nthe father of the 9-year-old boy reported as having tested positive for\ninfluenza A(H5N1) yesterday. Both cases had travelled to Fujian Province\n(China) in January 2003, and 2 other members of the family who accompanied\nthe cases to Fujian in January have also been unwell. The mother of the\nfamily has now made a full recovery; the other affected member of the\nfamily (an 8-year-old girl) died on 4 Feb 2003 in Fujian Province. The\nhealth authorities in Hong Kong SAR are continuing laboratory and\nepidemiological investigations to determine the source of infection of this\noutbreak. Further laboratory tests, including gene sequencing, are being\nconducted. The Department of Health in Hong Kong has reported that no\nunusual increase in influenza activity has been detected over the past few\nweeks.\nThe World Health Organization is in close contact with the health\nauthorities in Beijing, China and in Hong Kong, SAR. The WHO Global\nInfluenza Surveillance Network has been alerted, and additional reagents\nfor laboratory diagnosis are being made available to National Influenza\nCentres and other Members of the Global Influenza Surveillance Network.\n******\n[2]\nDate: 20 Feb 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: AP Online 20 Feb 2003 10:28 EST [edited]\n\nBird Flu Death Confirmed in Hong Kong\n----------------------------------------\nA Hong Kong man who died earlier this week had contracted bird flu, health\nofficials confirmed Thursday, in a case that disturbingly echoes a 1997\noutbreak in which the disease first crossed over into humans and killed 6\npeople.\nWhen bird flu hit Hong Kong's populace more than 5 years ago, officials\nkilled all the territory's 1.4 million chickens in an attempt to wipe out\nthe virus.\nHealth Department spokeswoman Eva Wong said the man, whom she did not\nidentify, had been infected with the H5N1 bird flu virus. The hospital that\ntreated him said he died of severe pneumonia.\nThe man's 9-year-old son remained hospitalized Thursday with the same\nstrain of the bird flu. It is a different strain of the disease than the\none that infected humans in 1997.\nThe man's family visited relatives in southeastern China's Fujian province\nin late January 2003. One of his daughters, an 8-year-old, contracted\npneumonia and died 28 Jan 2003 in a Fujian hospital. Officials were\ninvestigating what caused her death.\nThe man, his son, wife, father and another daughter were hospitalized in\nHong Kong after their return. The wife and father were released Thursday,\nbut the other daughter, 10, remains in the hospital.\nWong said officials believed the disease did not originate in Hong Kong,\nbut declined to say whether the family might have caught it in mainland China.\nMainland health authorities so far found that none of the family's\nrelatives or medical staff caring for them in Fujian had shown similar\nsymptoms.\nThe latest case coincided with reports that 12 chickens were found dead at\nmarket stalls in a Hong Kong suburb Wednesday -- one of numerous outbreaks\nof bird flu in recent months. It was, however, unclear whether the birds\nwere infected with the same strain as the boy and his father, whose home is\nin a different area.\nThe cases have prompted speculation that the bird flu might have originated\nin mainland China. Hong Kong returned almost 10 000 chickens to the\nmainland in 2001 and 2002 after tests indicated they might have been\nexposed to the virus. A mainland Chinese official recently insisted the flu\nwas endemic to Hong Kong.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[This newswire confirms a second case of human illness (and first death)\nassociated with an H5N1 infection. In this article there is the additional\nsuggestion that the geographic area of transmission of this infection may\nhave been Fujian, as the entire family had been in Fujian in the immediate\nperiod preceding onset of illness. While it may be too late to obtain\nspecimens from the family member who died while in Fujian, results of\nspecific avian influenza testing from the area in Fujian where the family\nstayed will be of interest and may possibly shed further light on this. To\ndate there has been confirmation of H5N1 activity among poultry in Hong\nKong but not elsewhere in mainland China. Perhaps this current cluster of\nhuman H5N1 infections with associated mortality will lead to more\nwidespread avian testing/monitoring in mainland provinces. We await\nfurther information on this outbreak as it becomes available. - Mod.MPP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n A Hong Kong man who died earlier this week had contracted bird flu, health\nofficials confirmed Thursday, in a case that disturbingly echoes a 1997\noutbreak in which the disease first crossed over into humans and killed 6\npeople. While it may be too late to obtain\nspecimens from the family member who died while in Fujian, results of\nspecific avian influenza testing from the area in Fujian where the family\nstayed will be of interest and may possibly shed further light on this. \nMainland health authorities so far found that none of the family's\nrelatives or medical staff caring for them in Fujian had shown similar\nsymptoms. The WHO Global\nInfluenza Surveillance Network has been alerted, and additional reagents\nfor laboratory diagnosis are being made available to National Influenza\nCentres and other Members of the Global Influenza Surveillance Network. In this article there is the additional\nsuggestion that the geographic area of transmission of this infection may\nhave been Fujian, as the entire family had been in Fujian in the immediate\nperiod preceding onset of illness. The\nhealth authorities in Hong Kong SAR are continuing laboratory and\nepidemiological investigations to determine the source of infection of this\noutbreak. \nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n As of 20 February the Department of Health in Hong Kong SAR confirmed that\na 33-year-old man, who died in hospital in Hong Kong on 17 Feb 2003, had\nbeen infected with a strain of the influenza The mother of the\nfamily has now made a full recovery; the other affected member of the\nfamily (an 8-year-old girl) died on 4 Feb 2003 in Fujian Province. The man is known to have been\nthe father of the 9-year-old boy reported as having tested positive for\ninfluenza A(H5N1) yesterday. When bird flu hit Hong Kong's populace more than 5 years ago, officials\nkilled all the territory's 1.4 million chickens in an attempt to wipe out\nthe virus. The latest case coincided with reports that 12 chickens were found dead at\nmarket stalls in a Hong Kong suburb Wednesday -- one of numerous outbreaks\nof bird flu in recent months. Hong Kong returned almost 10 000 chickens to the\nmainland in 2001 and 2002 after tests indicated they might have been\nexposed to the virus. It was, however, unclear whether the birds\nwere infected with the same strain as the boy and his father, whose home is\nin a different area. Perhaps this current cluster of\nhuman H5N1 infections with associated mortality will lead to more\nwidespread avian testing/monitoring in mainland provinces. The Department of Health in Hong Kong has reported that no\nunusual increase in influenza activity has been detected over the past few\nweeks. Source: WHO / Communicable Disease Surveillance & Response (CSR) [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2003_02_20/en/>\n\nInfluenza A(H5N1) in Hong Kong Special Administrative Region of China - Update\n INFLUENZA, H5N1 HUMAN CASE - CHINA (HONG KONG) (02)\n***************************************\n To\ndate there has been confirmation of H5N1 activity among poultry in Hong\nKong but not elsewhere in mainland China. The 33-year-old man is the second confirmed case of influenza A(H5N1) virus\nrelated to this outbreak in Hong Kong SAR.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1997-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-01-25 00:00:00", "2003-01-28 00:00:00", "2021-02-20 00:00:00", "2003-02-20 10:28:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2003-02-17 00:00:00", "2003-02-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2001-03-25 00:00:00", "2003-02-20 00:00:00", "2002-03-25 00:00:00", "2003-01-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Hong Kong Special Administrative Region of China - Update", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Beijing", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "Hong Kong"}, {"location": "the Hong Kong SAR Government Virus Unit", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Hong Kong 's", "country": "Hong Kong"}, {"location": "Hong \n Kong", "country": "Thailand"}, {"location": "HONG KONG", "country": "Hong Kong"}, {"location": "fujian", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Fujian province", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Fujian", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Fujian Province", "country": "China"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "194", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, H5N1/97-like viruses - China (Hong Kong)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=194", "date": "2002-06-22 23:50:00", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, H5N1/97-LIKE VIRUSES - CHINA (HONG KONG)\n*****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Tue 18 Jun 2002\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Reuters Health eLine, Tue 18 Jun 2002 [edited]\n<http://www.reutershealth.com/frame2/eline.html>\n\nResearch Provides Clues to 1997 'Bird Flu' Outbreak\n---------------------------------------------------\nNEW YORK: Recent outbreaks of [avian influenza] 'bird flu' in Hong Kong did\nnot spread to people as [the outbreak] in 1997 did, but studying these\noutbreaks help scientists understand how viruses jump from birds to humans.\nDuring the 1997 outbreak, 6 people died after being infected with a strain\nof influenza virus that previously had infected only birds. To control the\nspread of the virus, more than 1.5 million chickens and other poultry were\nslaughtered in the Hong Kong area. Since the 1997 outbreak, Hong Kong has\ntaken several steps to reduce the risk of another outbreak. Geese and ducks\nare now slaughtered at a central facility to keep viruses from spreading to\nchicken and other poultry. The 1997 virus is thought to have originated in\ngeese and other birds that live in water and to have crossed over to\nland-living birds.\nAlthough the virus that caused the 1997 outbreak has not reappeared in the\nregion, several viruses believed to be precursors of the species-jumping\nvirus have been detected, according to a report in the June 25th issue of\nthe Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences [ref: Proceedings of\nthe National Academy of Sciences 2002;99:8950-8955; online 19 Jun 2002\n<http://www.pnas.org/cgi/content/abstract/132268999v1>]. In fact, between\nFeb and May 2001, several of these viruses moved from geese and ducks to\nchicken and other land poultry, leading to an outbreak of disease in Hong\nKong markets.\nThe viruses found in 2001 'were not the same as those found causing disease\nin man in 1997,' according to J.S.M. Peiris, one of the researchers\ninvolved in the study. The 1997 virus was unique in that it was an avian,\nor bird, virus that directly infected and caused serious illness in people,\nPeiris said. Even though there were no documented cases of human infection\nwith the bird viruses detected recently, Peiris and colleagues found signs\nthat the viruses had changed in certain ways to make it possible to move\nfrom geese and ducks to chicken and other poultry. These changes could have\nalso occurred in the early development of the 1997 virus, according to the\nresearchers. The 2001 viruses were able to infect mice and spread to the\nbrain, which [avian influenza] viruses normally are not capable of\ndoing. These unusual qualities of the virus do not prove that they could\ninfect humans, but they do raise concerns, the authors report.\nUnlike in 1997, in 2001, and during a more recent case in 2002,\nsurveillance of poultry markets provided an early warning, so the outbreak\nwas kept under control. But the researchers note, 'Measures in Hong Kong\nare not likely to reduce the possibility of such a virus arising in the\nwider region of East Asia including southern China that has been recognized\nas an influenza epicenter.'\n[Byline: Merritt McKinney]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[The PNAS paper referred to above is entitled: 'Emergence of multiple\ngenotypes of H5N1 avian influenza viruses in Hong Kong SAR,' and is\nauthored by Y. Guan , J. S. M. Peiris , A. S. Lipatov, T. M. Ellis, K. C.\nDyrting, S. Krauss, L. J. Zhang, R. G. Webster, and K. F. Shortridge. The\nabstract of the paper states that: Although A/Hong Kong/156/97\n(H5N1/97)-like viruses associated with the 'bird flu' incident in Hong Kong\nSAR have not been detected since the slaughter of poultry in 1997, its\nputative precursors continue to persist in the region. One of these,\nGoose/Guangdong/1/96 (H5N1 Gs/Gd)-like viruses, reassorted with other avian\nviruses to generate multiple genotypes of H5N1 viruses that crossed to\nchickens and other terrestrial poultry from its reservoir in geese. Whereas\nnone of these recent reassortants had acquired the gene constellation of\nH5N1/97, these events provide insight into how such a virus may have been\ngenerated. The recent H5N1 reassortants readily infect and kill chicken and\nquail after experimental infection, and some were associated with\nsignificant mortality of chickens within the poultry retail markets in Hong\nKong. Some genotypes are lethal for mice after intra-nasal inoculation and\nspread to the brain. On this occasion, the early detection of H5N1 viruses\nin the retail, live poultry markets led to preemptive intervention before\nthe occurrence of human disease, but these newly emerging, highly\npathogenic H5N1 viruses provide cause for pandemic concern.\nThis study confirms the inference that H5N1-type influenza viruses with\nnovel combinations of other genes are being continuously generated by\nreassortment from the pool of influenza viruses present in wild and\ndomesticated birds in the South China area and that the poultry markets of\nthe Hong Kong SAR provide a convenient focus for surveillance of new\nstrains of H5N1 (and other antigenic types) with potential for spread in\nnon-avian hosts. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "This study confirms the inference that H5N1-type influenza viruses with\nnovel combinations of other genes are being continuously generated by\nreassortment from the pool of influenza viruses present in wild and\ndomesticated birds in the South China area and that the poultry markets of\nthe Hong Kong SAR provide a convenient focus for surveillance of new\nstrains of H5N1 (and other antigenic types) with potential for spread in\nnon-avian hosts. Although the virus that caused the 1997 outbreak has not reappeared in the\nregion, several viruses believed to be precursors of the species-jumping\nvirus have been detected, according to a report in the June 25th issue of\nthe Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences [ref: Proceedings of\nthe National Academy of Sciences 2002;99:8950-8955; online 19 Jun 2002\n<http://www.pnas.org/cgi/content/abstract/132268999v1>]. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n The\nabstract of the paper states that: Although A/Hong Kong/156/97\n(H5N1/97)-like viruses associated with the 'bird flu' incident in Hong Kong\nSAR have not been detected since the slaughter of poultry in 1997, its\nputative precursors continue to persist in the region. But the researchers note, 'Measures in Hong Kong\nare not likely to reduce the possibility of such a virus arising in the\nwider region of East Asia including southern China that has been recognized\nas an influenza epicenter.'\n One of these,\nGoose/Guangdong/1/96 (H5N1 Gs/Gd)-like viruses, reassorted with other avian\nviruses to generate multiple genotypes of H5N1 viruses that crossed to\nchickens and other terrestrial poultry from its reservoir in geese. Recent outbreaks of [avian influenza] 'bird flu' in Hong Kong did\nnot spread to people as [the outbreak] in 1997 did, but studying these\noutbreaks help scientists understand how viruses jump from birds to humans.\n Even though there were no documented cases of human infection\nwith the bird viruses detected recently, Peiris and colleagues found signs\nthat the viruses had changed in certain ways to make it possible to move\nfrom geese and ducks to chicken and other poultry. On this occasion, the early detection of H5N1 viruses\nin the retail, live poultry markets led to preemptive intervention before\nthe occurrence of human disease, but these newly emerging, highly\npathogenic H5N1 viruses provide cause for pandemic concern. In fact, between\nFeb and May 2001, several of these viruses moved from geese and ducks to\nchicken and other land poultry, leading to an outbreak of disease in Hong\nKong markets. The recent H5N1 reassortants readily infect and kill chicken and\nquail after experimental infection, and some were associated with\nsignificant mortality of chickens within the poultry retail markets in Hong\nKong. [The PNAS paper referred to above is entitled: 'Emergence of multiple\ngenotypes of H5N1 avian influenza viruses in Hong Kong SAR,' and is\nauthored by Y. Guan , J. S. M. Peiris , A. S. Lipatov, T. M. Ellis, K. C.\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-06-25 00:00:00", "2001-05-25 00:00:00", "2002-06-19 00:00:00", "2002-06-18 00:00:00", "1997-03-25 00:00:00", "2001-03-25 00:00:00", "2002-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Hong \n Kong", "country": "Thailand"}, {"location": "HONG KONG", "country": "Hong Kong"}, {"location": "NEW YORK", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "Hong Kong"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "the Hong Kong SAR", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hong Kong SAR", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "212", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Influenza, H5N1 human case - China (Hong Kong)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=212", "date": "2003-02-19 23:50:00", "main_text": "INFLUENZA, H5N1 HUMAN CASE - CHINA (HONG KONG)\n**********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n\n[1]\nDate: 19 Feb 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: NY Times / AP 19 Feb 2003 9:59 AM\n<http://www.nytimes.com/aponline/international/AP-Hong-Kong-Bird-Flu.html>\n\nHong Kong Boy, 9, Contracts Bird Flu\n--------------------------------\nHONG KONG (AP) -- A 9-year-old boy contracted bird flu after visiting\nsouthern China last month and his sister and father have died of\nunspecified illnesses, officials said Wednesday, raising fears of a\nrecurrence of the deadly disease that first hit humans and killed six\npeople in 1997.\n\nIncidents of bird flu set off alarms in Hong Kong because of the deadly\noutbreak six years ago. Officials then killed all 1.4 million chickens in\nthe territory to try to wipe out the virus.\n\nThe boy suffering from bird flu and his family visited relatives in China's\nFujian province late last month.\n\nThe boy's 8-year-old sister developed pneumonia and died in a Fujian\nhospital on Jan. 28. Their 33-year-old father fell sick with pneumonia Feb.\n7 and returned to Hong Kong for treatment before dying in Princess Margaret\nHospital on Monday. The exact cause of both deaths was still being\ninvestigated, officials said.\n\nThe Health Department said the boy tested positive for the H5N1 strain of\nthe avian flu, or bird flu. It is a different strain of the disease than\nthe one that infected humans in 1997.\n\nThe boy was admitted to a hospital Feb. 12, three days after the start of a\nfever. He was in stable condition Wednesday, officials said.\n\nThe boy's 30-year-old mother, his sister and grandfather were also in\nPrincess Margaret Hospital. The mother had an influenza virus infection but\nhas since recovered. The hospital said all three were in good condition and\nit was not immediately clear why the three were in the hospital.\n\n``The Department of Health has stepped up its surveillance system further\nby testing all severe pneumonia cases for H5. So far, we have no other\npositive results,'' Dr. Tse Lai-yin said in a statement.\n\nThe department is closely liaising with mainland authorities to monitor the\nsituation and has reported the case to the World Health Organization, said\nDiana Kam, a health department spokeswoman.\n\nMedical experts said the government needs to learn if the H5N1 virus\noriginated in Hong Kong or on the mainland.\n\n``We have to see whether the boy's family has also contracted the bird\nflu,'' lawmaker Dr. Lo Wing-lok, who represents the medical sector, told\nreporters. ``Is this an independent case or an outbreak?''\n\nMeanwhile, Hong Kong agricultural officials reported new cases of bird flu\nat four poultry stalls in suburban Tai Po market where 12 chickens were\nfound dead Wednesday morning.\n\nAfter samples from the dead chickens tested positive for the H5 strain of\navian flu, the poultry stall owners slaughtered all the birds in the\nstalls, authorities said.\n\nEarlier this month, Hong Kong sent back almost 10,000 chickens from\nmainland China after tests indicated they may have been exposed to bird flu.\n\n******\n\n[2]\nDate: 19 Feb 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: WHO/ WER\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2003_2_19/en/>\n\nInfluenza A(H5N1) in Hong Kong Special Administrative Region of China\n---------------------\nAs of 19 February results from two laboratories have confirmed the presence\nof an avian influenza virus in a child in Hong Kong SAR. Tests conducted in\ntwo samples from this single patient have identified the virus as the\nstrain of influenza A(H5N1). A similar virus caused an outbreak in Hong\nKong SAR in 1997, with 18 cases detected and six deaths.\n\nIn the current outbreak, a 9-year-old boy who travelled to Fujian Province\n(China) in January with his mother and his two sisters became ill on\nFebruary 9 and was admitted to a Hong Kong hospital on February 12. He has\nrecovered and is in a stable condition. Other members of his family\npresented with a similar illness. The child's sister and father have died.\nThe boy's mother was ill but has recovered.\n\nIt is not yet known whether the other family members were also infected\nwith influenza A(H5N1). A medical and epidemiological investigation is\nongoing in Hong Kong to determine the cause of those illnesses. Results\nshould be available in the next few days. Investigations are ongoing to\ndetermine the source of the infection.\n\nThe World Health Organization is collaborating closely with health\nauthorities in Hong Kong SAR and China in investigating the outbreak. The\nWHO Global Influenza Surveillance network has been alerted.\n\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[As these articles mention, there was an outbreak of H5N1 influenza in Hong\nKong in 1997/1998 (see ProMED-mail postings below covering this\noutbreak). In this current instance there is the suggestion that the\nlocation of infection may have been in Fujian Province (China) if the\nfather also had H5N1 influenza. These articles also suggest that the\ncurrent strain of H5N1 is different from the strain involved in the 1997\noutbreak.\n\nOn a provocative note, checking the geography it is noteworthy that\nGuangdon Province is adjacent to Hong Kong and Fujian Province is the next\nnortherly province on mainland China. A rather curious coincidence to have\na major respiratory outbreak in a nearby province (see ProMED-mail postings\non Pnuemonia - China (Guangdong) listed below). As a reminder there were\napproximately 350 cases of pneumonia with 5 deaths reported in Guangdong\nprovince. Checking population statistics, Guangdong province has a\npopulation of 70,510,000 with a population density of 1,027 per square mile\n-- a respiratory syndrome outbreak with approximately 350 cases in this\nenvironment would be classified as a small outbreak.\n\nMore information on this outbreak as it becomes available would be\nappreciated. - Mod. MPP]", "summary": "Boy, 9, Contracts Bird Flu\n--------------------------------\nHONG KONG (AP) -- A 9-year-old boy contracted bird flu after visiting\nsouthern China last month and his sister and father have died of\nunspecified illnesses, officials said Wednesday, raising fears of a\nrecurrence of the deadly disease that first hit humans and killed six\npeople in 1997. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n\n Checking population statistics, Guangdong province has a\npopulation of 70,510,000 with a population density of 1,027 per square mile\n-- a respiratory syndrome outbreak with approximately 350 cases in this\nenvironment would be classified as a small outbreak. \n\nMeanwhile, Hong Kong agricultural officials reported new cases of bird flu\nat four poultry stalls in suburban Tai Po market where 12 chickens were\nfound dead Wednesday morning. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[As these articles mention, there was an outbreak of H5N1 influenza in Hong\nKong in 1997/1998 (see ProMED-mail postings below covering this\noutbreak). \n\n``We have to see whether the boy's family has also contracted the bird\nflu,'' lawmaker Dr. Lo Wing-lok, who represents the medical sector, told\nreporters. LaBudde <ral@lcfltd.com>\nA detailed story of the influenza A type H5N1 outbreak in Hong Kong,\npresented by returning experts to the USFDA (Food and Drug Administration)\nis available on the JAMA website\n<http://www.ama-assn.org/public/journals/jama/jamahome.htm> in the issue of\nMar. 4 /98, JAMA 279: 643-644.\nNote that in the following quote:\n>>>>>>>\n'One of the striking things about these cases is the age-related\nmortality,' Fukuda said. 'If you just eyeball them, you can see that they\nare concentrated among young adults.' Of 7 patients 18 years of age and\nolder (up to 60 years), 6 died. Of 11 patients younger than 18 years, 2\ndied. 'An 88% mortality among the older age group. This was very striking\nto us,' he said.\n>>>>>>>>>\nDr Fukuda is referring to CFR (case fatality rate), not mortality as a\nresult of infection. Serology has shown that a number of people in Hong\nKong have developed antibodies to the virus without having been sick.\n--\nJack Woodall\nDirector, ProMED-mail\nRio de Janeiro (en route to Atlanta for the ICEID Conference)\n......................................jw/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Calisher <calisher@usa.healthnet.org>\nSource: The Lancet 351:467-471, 1998\nOrigin: The H5N1 study group of The Hospital Authority of Hong Kong, The\nChinese University of Hong Kong and The University of Hong Kong.\n\nA paper entitled 'Clinical features and rapid viral diagnosis of human\ndisease associated with avian influenza A H5N1 virus' appeared in The\nLancet. It documents data on the first 12 cases of H5N1 influenza in Hong\nKong. The key findings are these:\nPatients ranged from 1-60 years of age. Clinical presentation was that of\nan influenza-like illness. Five patients had clinical or radiological\nevidence of pneumonia at the time of presentation to hospital and two\nothers developed pneumonic changes after hospitalisation. Bacteria commonly\nassociated with community-acquired pneumonia such as _Streptococcus\npneumoniae_, _Haemophilus influenzae_ and _Staph. aureus_ were not isolated\nfrom the respiratory tract or blood cultures in any of the patients. All 7\npatients older than 13 years had severe disease (4 deaths) whereas children\n5 years or younger had relatively less severe disease with the exception of\none who died with Reye's syndrome associated with intake of aspirin.\nGastrointestinal manifestations, elevated liver enzymes, renal failure\nunrelated to rhabdomyolysis and pancytopenia were unusually prominent in\nthese patients. Factors associated with severe disease (i.e., those\nrequiring intensive care or ventilator support) included older age, delay\nin hospitalisation, lower respiratory tract involvement and a low total\nperipheral white blood cell count or lymphopenia at admission.\nThe results of type and subtype specific rapid diagnostic tests for\ndetection of influenza A in nasopharyngeal or endotracheal aspirates were\ncompared. An H5-specific reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction\nassay was the most sensitive test for rapid diagnosis. A commercially\navailable enzyme immunoassay (Directigen Flu A; Becton Dickinson) was more\nsensitive than direct immunofluorescence for rapid viral diagnosis of H5N1\ninfected patients. Later in December 1997, when influenza A H3N2 and H1N1\nbegan to co-circulate in the human population, rapid exclusion of H5N1\ninfluenza in those specimens positive for influenza A by type specific\n(reactive with the influenza A nucleoprotein, i.e., reacts with all human\ninfluenza A) rapid tests became important. A diagnosis of H5N1 influenza\ncould be reliably excluded in those specimens that were strongly reactive\nby immunofluorescence (i.e., >10 fluorescent positive cells / spot) with\nthe influenza A type specific reagent but negative with the H5 subtype\nspecific monoclonal antibody pool.\n--\nProMED-mail\ne-mail: promed@usa.healthnet.org\n......................................chc/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. ISID\nand its associated service providers shall not be held\nresponsible for errors or omissions or held liable for any\ndamages incurred as a result of use or reliance upon posted\nor archived material.\n************************************************************\nVisit ProMED-mail's web site at <http://www.promedmail.org>.\nSend all items for posting to: promed@promedmail.org\n(NOT to an individual moderator). If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "summary": "\nProMED-mail\ne-mail: promed@usa.healthnet.org\n......................................chc/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. A diagnosis of H5N1 influenza\ncould be reliably excluded in those specimens that were strongly reactive\nby immunofluorescence (i.e., >10 fluorescent positive cells / spot) with\nthe influenza A type specific reagent but negative with the H5 subtype\nspecific monoclonal antibody pool.\n ISID\nand its associated service providers shall not be held\nresponsible for errors or omissions or held liable for any\ndamages incurred as a result of use or reliance upon posted\nor archived material.\n All 7\npatients older than 13 years had severe disease (4 deaths) whereas children\n5 years or younger had relatively less severe disease with the exception of\none who died with Reye's syndrome associated with intake of aspirin. Factors associated with severe disease (i.e., those\nrequiring intensive care or ventilator support) included older age, delay\nin hospitalisation, lower respiratory tract involvement and a low total\nperipheral white blood cell count or lymphopenia at admission. A commercially\navailable enzyme immunoassay (Directigen Flu A; Becton Dickinson) was more\nsensitive than direct immunofluorescence for rapid viral diagnosis of H5N1\ninfected patients. Bacteria commonly\nassociated with community-acquired pneumonia such as _Streptococcus\npneumoniae_, _Haemophilus influenzae_ and _Staph. aureus_ were not isolated\nfrom the respiratory tract or blood cultures in any of the patients. Later in December 1997, when influenza A H3N2 and H1N1\nbegan to co-circulate in the human population, rapid exclusion of H5N1\ninfluenza in those specimens positive for influenza \n\nA paper entitled 'Clinical features and rapid viral diagnosis of human\ndisease associated with avian influenza A H5N1 virus' appeared in The\nLancet. The results of type and subtype specific rapid diagnostic tests for\ndetection of influenza A in nasopharyngeal or endotracheal aspirates were\ncompared. Five patients had clinical or radiological\nevidence of pneumonia at the time of presentation to hospital and two\nothers developed pneumonic changes after hospitalisation. Gastrointestinal manifestations, elevated liver enzymes, renal failure\nunrelated to rhabdomyolysis and pancytopenia were unusually prominent in\nthese patients.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "influenza a/h5n1"], "syndromes": ["influenza-like illness"], "event_date": ["1998-02-13 00:00:00", "1997-12-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Hong \n Kong", "country": "Thailand"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "98", "headline": "PRO> Influenza H5N1, human -
